\lx adchau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 3
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he hunts, is hunting'

    \se adcháonk
    \va audcháonk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \ge `hunting, what is taken by hunting'
    \so Prov.12.27

    \se adchaen
    \va audchaen
    \nt +
    \ps N.agent / agent noun in |-ënunü-|.
    \ge `a hunter'
    \so Gen.10.9
    (|Adchâënin, -nuog.| `A fowler, fowlers'    C.5/156.)

    \se adchanau
    \ps With an.obj. / TA
    \ge `he hunts (him, live game)'
    \so Mic.7.2
    pl. |-anáog|√
    infin. |achanat| `to hunt'    C.

    \nt MN: Kah nishnoh wosketomp ..., adchonont touohkomukque puppinashimwoh,...
    \ng suppositive |Kah nishnoh wosketomp ..., adchonont touohkomukque puppinashimwoh,...| `And whatsoever man there be ..., which hunteth and catcheth any beast ...'    Lev.17.13√

\dv |ahchu| `he strives after, is diligent or active to secure'

[Narragansett [xnt] |Auchaûi.| `Hee is gone to hunt or fowle.', |Ntauchâumen.| `I goe afowling or hunting.'; |Auchaûtuck.| `Let us hunt.', |Nowetauchaûmen.| `I will hunt with you.'    R.W.88,164; 164.
Cree |ach|, `he is active, diligent'.]

\lx adchuwompag
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 3
\ge `"in the morning watch", just before light'
\so Ex.14.24; Judg.16.2

    \nt MN: utchuwompan
    \ng Suppositive of |utchuwompan| (`it dawns, light comes'), q.v.
    \ps adv
    \xv no pajeh utchuwompanit
    \xe until the day dawn
    \so 2 Pet.1.19
    \ng 3->_adv_ participle to AI verb


\lx adhosu
\va adhôsu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 3
    \nt +
\ps AI(+O)
\ge `to lay (os) an ambush for sth, to lie in ambush'
\so Josh.8.2,9,13
    \xv ..., kah nag moncheog adhosinneat,...
    \xe ...: and they went to lie in ambush,...
    \so Josh.8.9

    \xv ..., kah adhositcheg; wutcheksue otanat:...
    \xe ..., and their liers in wait on the west of the city,...
    \so Josh.8.13

    \xv .... adhôsish onkou∞táni.
    \xe ...: lay thee an ambush for the city behind it.
    \so Josh.8.2

    \se adhosu
    \va adhôsu
    \nt !
    \ps NA,agent noun, to stem of headword
    \ge `lier in wait, ambush [metonymically for the group]'
    \so Josh.8.14,19,21
    \xv Kâh adhosuog teanuk neepóog wutch wutayeuongan∞out,...
    \xe And the ambush arose quickly out of their place,...
    \so Josh.8.19

    \se adhosuwaheau
    \ps TA, causative, to stem of headword
    \ge `to set sb to lie in ambush'
    \so Josh.8.12
    \xv ..., kah wutadhosuwaheuh nashaue Bethel kah Ai wutcheksuiyeu otanat.
    \xe ..., and [he] set them to lie in ambush between Bethel and Ai, on the west side of the city.
    \so Josh.8.12

    \se adham
    \ps TI1a, derivational relationship to headword uncertain
    \ge `to lie in wait against sth'
    \so Josh.8.4

    \xv ... kusseh adham∞k otan, onkouotanat:...
    \xe ..., Behold, ye shall lie in wait against the city, even behind the city:...
    \so Josh.8.4

\nt Remark: Any relationship to the initial |adta..| `hide'?


\lx adt
\va át
\ve changed form
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 3
\ps prep.
\ge `in, at, to'
\so El.Gr.22
    (sometimes written |ahhut|) { changed reduplicated form }:
    \xv adt yaút naiyag
    \xe upon the four corners
    \so Ex.38.2
    \xv [ayeuonk] adt sepaginit hashab
    \xe [a place] for spreading nets upon
    \so Ezek.26.14
    (|ahhut sepagenit|    Ezek.47.10)
\nt As a prefix, |adt| (sometimes |at|, |ut|, or |'t|) is apparently related to |ohtau|, `he has'; |ohteau| ("se habet"), `it is'; |ohtáe|, `belonging to, or possessing (a qualiy, attribute, etc.)'.
    So, in the Cree, according to Howse (Gr. 21), |oo| prefixed, or, before a vowel, |oot|, "shows that the subject possesses the noun--he has, i.e., owns, or possesses (it)," as "|assám|, `a snowshoe'; |oot-assám-u|, `he has snowshoes'."

    \se |ahhut|, |ahut|
    \nt +
    \ps P, changed reduplicated form of |ut|; also to the initial |(ad)tan-|, unchanged as |(ut)tan-|
    \ge `in, at, to', often with a sense typical of reduplication, such as habitual or repeated activity
    \nt Remark: |ahhut| is common in (descriptive) names of garments, instruments, and tools.
    \xv ..., kah pish wunnushoh uttoh ahut nushit chikohtae mag∞onk anaquabit Jehovah,...
    \xe ..., and kill it in the place where hey kill the burnt offering before the Lord:...
    \so Lev.4.24
    \xv muppuhkukqut ahhohtag
    \xe mitre'    Lev.8.9; Lev.8.13: `bonnet

[Vineyard Rec. |ta|, |tah|, v.i. 157a.]


\lx adtah
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
    \nt +
\ps NI, ?deverbal, perhaps to initial of |adhahtou| TI `to conceal, hide sth'
\ge `apron, breeches, skirt'
\so Deut.22.30,27.20; Ezek.44.18; C.24/171; see also s.v. |Au~tah|
    \xv ..., asuh matta poskinnum∞unneat ∞shoh wuttadtuh.
    \xe ..., nor [shall he] discover his father's skirt.
    \so Deut.22.30
    \xv ..., kah hashabpue adtahwhunash ut wusségan∞óut:...
    \xe ..., and shall haue linnnen breeches vpon their loynes:...
    \so Ezek.44.18
    \xv Askoskque attoh.
    \xe Green apron
    \so C.24/171


\lx adtahshe
\va adt-tahshe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
\ps adv.
\ge `as often as, as many as'
\so Rev.3.19
    \nt Remark: Changed form of the relative root |tahsh-|
    \nt +
    |att∞che|    Rev.11.6
    |ahhut tahshe|    2 K.4.8 { changed reduplicated form |
    |utt∞che|    1 Cor.11.25,26
\cf tohsu
\cf utt∞che

[Narragansett [xnt] |ayátche| `as often as'
Cree |it-tússu-uk| `they are so many'; |hè it-túsechick| `as many as they are'
Delaware [del] |endchi| `so much as, as many'; |endchen| `so often as'    Zeisb.]


\lx adtahtou
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
\ps v.t. / TI2
\twn |adtashau| TA
\ge `he hides (it)', +`to conceal sth'
\so Mt.25.18
    \xv Kuttinn∞wáonk nutadtahtauun ut nuttahut,...
    \xe Thy word have I hid in my heart,...
    \so Ps.119.11; (M): |Nuttattohtauunnap|√; Jer.13.5

    \xv ..., Toh kittinnompasimun nushogkut kematun, kah adtahtauog ∞sqheonk?
    \xe ..., What profit is it if we slay our brother and conceal his blood?
    \so Gen.37.26
    \ng 12->0

    imper. 2d pers. |adtahtaush| `hide it'    Jer.13.4

    \se !|adtahtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to hide sth from sb'
    \so Gen.18.17; Deut.30.11; Ps.88.14,143.7(M)
    \xv ..., Sun woh nutádtahtauon Abraham ne kodnéhheog,
    \xe ..., Shall I hide from Abraham the thing which I do;
    \so Gen.18.17 { 1->3+0 objective }; (E0&1) |nutáhtuttáuon|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta nutadtahtó∞mun wutch nussontimómunônut, nutteagunnonut mahtsháit,...
    \xe ..., We will not hide it from my lord, how that our money is spent;...
    \so Gen.47.18
    \ng 1p->(?3+)0 negative indicative absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche yeu ann∞team∞onk ann∞nun yeu kesukok, matta kutattahtonteaun, asuh matta nôohtano.
    \xe For this commandment which I command thee this day, it is not hidden from thee, neither is it far off.
    \so Deut.30.11
    \ng X->2+0 objective

    \xv ...? tohwaj adtahtiean kuskesuk?
    \xe ...? why hidest thou thy face from me?
    \so Ps.88.14(M)
    \ng 2->1+0

    \xv ...missohhamah yeuyeu toh asean ahque attuhtah.
    \xe ...; and tell me now what thou hast done; hide it not from me.
    \so Josh.7.19
    \ng 2->1+0
    \xv ...: adtahtiehkon kuskesuk,...
    \xe ...: hide not thy face from me,...
    \so Ps.143.7(M) { 2->1+0 }; (E): |ahque ahtohtah|

This is a caus. inan. form, from a primary not found in Eliot.
\cf auttah
\cf adtau
\cf adtashau

\et For a suggestion, see under |adtashau| below.


\lx adtahwhunuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
    \nt +
\ps TA+O, dative to creative verb
\ge `to make sb an apron', "to make sth into an apron for sb"
\so Gen.3.7
    \xv ..., kah nish wutadt(a)hwhunuhkonnaoash wutch wuhhogkaoh.
    \xe ..., and [they] made themselves aprons.'    Gen.3.7  {  3p->3
    \so +0p-pro objective  }


\nt Remark: The following forms with initial |adtan-| are changed forms of initials that appear as |tan-| in unchanged forms. These are to be found at T.157b under ||t||.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4


\lx adtannegen
\va -nekin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
\ps v.t. (inan. subj.) / II (?)
\ge `it brings forth, bears, produces' (as the earth when cultivated, plants, a cultivated tree, fruit, etc.)
\cf tannegen
The prefix |adt| marks appropriation, a growing, or bringing forth, to or for an owner. { See entry on the initial |adtan-|, T+.157b. }


\lx adtannekitteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
\nt Remark: See also entry under |(ad)tann-| at T+.157b.
\ps v.i. / AI+O
\ge `he plants (lays the foundation of) his house'

    \nt MN: adtannikitteadt qussukquanit
    \ng suppositive |adtannikitteadt qussukquanit| `when he built (founded) his house on a rock'    Mt.7.24
    \xv adtanikteadt naguntu
    \xe which built his house upon the sand
    \so Mt.7.26

    \se adtanehteau
    \va uttan-
    \ps With inan. subj. / II
    \ge `the house is planted, or founded'    Mt.7.25  {The form attested, loc.cit., is |uttannehteausu|; perhaps the entry is miscited or misidentified.}
\cf wekitteau


\lx adtashau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\twn |adtahtou| TI2
\ge `he hides (himself, or another)'
\so Jer.23.24; Lk.1.24
    \xv ..., kah wutch kuskesukqut pish nutattashit,...
    \xe ...; and from thy face shall I be hid,...
    \so Gen.4.14
    \ng X->1 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv wuttáttashuh
    \xe she hid them'    Josh.2.4  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv ...: qut Jesus adtushóp wohhoguh, kah suhhamup wutch templeut,...
    \xe ...: but Jesus hid himself, and went out of the temple,...'    Jn.8.59(M.)  { 3->3
    \so preterite objective }
    \nt +

    \xv Adtasheh wutch kéme ukken∞nittuongan∞wout matcheet∞wog:...
    \xe Hide me from the secret counsel of the wicked;...
    \so Ps.64.2; (M): |Adtasheh|
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \nt +
\cf adtahtou

[Cree |káht-ow| `he hides it'; |káht-tayoo| `he hides him'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nekañda8añ|, |nekañ8ta8añ| `je le lui cache'; |nekañd8n| `je cache cela'.]

\et B. 15, 90/446, A.163, H.310 *a?le∙wa `he places him' (i.e. **ap-l-), *l confirmed by Del. ahléew `put s.o. down', O'M.19a; the initial would then perhaps be *at- (as in H.385, Mass. |adtauau| `buy'). Note also |nompashau| `restore'.


\lx adtôau
\va adtauau
\va attóau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
\ps v.t. / AI(+O), long-vowel stem
\ge `he acquires possession of, makes his own; (used by Eliot for) he buys'
\nt G&B. 608 |attaanat| `to buy, rent it'
    \xv ... Potiphar ..., Wut-Egyptian, wutadtauónuh ...
    \xe ... Potiphar, ..., an Egyptian, bought him ...'    Gen.39.1 { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah nag n∞waog ohkeit Kanaan nutadtaómun mameéchimug.
    \xe ...? And they said, From the land of Canaan to buy food.
    \so Gen.42.7
    \nt +
    \xv Webe wutohkeeu sephausuenúog matta wutadtaónash,...
    \xe Only the land of the priests bought he not;...
    \so Gen.47.22
    \ng 3->0p, negative objective; source of plural unclear

    \xv ..., kah n nòh adtoaup nashpe kutteauguash,...
    \xe ..., and he that is bought with thy money,...
    \so Gen.17.13
    \ng ?2->_3_, preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv ... wame adtoadche wutche teauguash...
    \xe ... all that were bought with his money,...'    Gen.17.23  { 3->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah adtoohpoh wutche teauguash penuwohteuh...
    \xe ..., and bought with money of the stranger,...'    Gen.17.27  { 3->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \nt +
    \nt MN: noh adtôadt, ... noh maguk
    \ng suppositive |noh adtôadt, ... noh maguk| `he who buys, ... he who sells'    Is.24.2

    \xv ..., adtóush ut anaquabhettit yeu wadohkitcheg, kah anaquabhettit Elderse nummissiineumog,...
    \xe ..., Buy it before the inhabitants, and before the elders of my people. ...
    \so Ruth 4.4
    \ng 2->0 imperative
    \nt +
    imperat. |adtôash| `buy thou (it)'    Jer.32.7,8
    \xv adtôagk
    \xe buy ye
    \so Is.55.1

    \xv anoadtu rubisash
    \xe she is of price above [is worth more than] rubies
    \so Prov.31.10
    \ng initial |ánue|

    \xv adt mishóadtik
    \xe of great price
    \so 1 Pet.3.4

    \se adtôáonk
    \ps vbl. n.
    \ge `purchasing, acquiring'
    \so Jer.32.8

    \se adtôáe
    \ps adj. and adv.
    \ge `of or relating to purchase'
    \so Jer.32.11,12,16

    \se !|adtôamau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O (in some sense)
    \ge `to buy, purchase sth of sb' (i.e. "from"); additionally `to buy sb' (Gen.47.23)
    \nt G&B. 608 |(nutt)attaamonah|
    \so Gen.47.19,23; Deut.2.6, Ruth 4.5
    \xv ... Kusseh, kutadtaâmunumw∞ yeu kesukok, kah kutohkeimw∞, wutch Pharaoh,
    \xe ..., Behold, I have bought you this day and your land for Pharaoh:...
    \so Gen.47.23
    \ng 1->2p absolute
    \xv Nag pish kutadôamôog meechum wutche teaguash, onk woh kummeetsimw∞,...
    \xe Ye shall buy meat of them for money, that ye may eat;...
    \so Deut.2.6
    \xv ..., ne kesukok adtoâan wutóhteuk Naomi wutch wunnutcheganit, kah wonk mos kutadtôamon Ruth um-Moabit,...
    \xe ..., What day thou buyest the field of the hand of Naomi, thou must buy it also of Ruth the Moabitess,...
    \so Ruth 4.5

    \xv Ne ohteuk âdtaomop Abraham wunnaumonuh Heth, na Abraham posekìnon,...
    \xe The field which Abraham purchased of the sons of Heth: there was Abraham buried,...'    Gen.25.10  { 3->3
    \so +_0_ preterite participle }

    \xv ...? attóominnean kah nutohkeán, wutch petukqunneg,...
    \xe ...? buy {us} and our land for bread,...
    \so Gen.47.19
    \ng 2->1p imperative

    \nt See B.1962, 16.21, 334, on this as an example of a secondary derivative via TA |-m| with phonological irregularity; M.L.30 |ata∙wamεw| TA `he borrows, gets credit, buys from him'; Rasles 2/378a |keta`tañmer| `j'achette de toi', and example below. It is not a normal TA+O verb, apparently being derived by transitivizing an AI+O verb stem (which is transitive via the relational initial).

    \se |adtôanshau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, representative final
    \ge `to buy sb sth'
    \so Gen.44.25,46.2

    \xv ..., kah attóanshinnean na wutch,...
    \xe ..., and buy for us from thence;...
    \so Gen.46.2
    \ng 2p->1p(+0?) imperative

\cf óadtuhkau
\ge he pays (him)

[Narragansett [xnt] |Kuttattaúamish aûke| `I would buy land of you.'    R.W.157/r.165.
Western Abenaki [abe] |netatañ8é| `J'achette, je traitte'; |netatañmañ| `-- de lui'; |ata8é8añgan| `achat, traittement'    R.2/378a.√
Cree |A`t-àwáyoo| [|áhd-ahwá|, Chip.] `he exchanges, barters'    Howse 157,100√.
Chip. |Atâwenan, (nind)| `I sell him, (her,it) some {an.} obj., I dispose of him, (her, it)'    Bar.2.54b,1.224a.√
    Algonquian [alg] |ATAWE| `traiter, faire la traite, commercer' (most glosses: `vendre'); |ATAM| `vends-le lui'    Cq.65ab;64b-65a.]
    \nt +

\et B., item 194, 106/463, A.185, H.385: *ata∙we∙wa AI `he trades, sells', H.384 *ata∙wame∙wa (M,O)

\lx adtonkqs
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 4
\ps as n.
\ge `a kinsman, or kinswoman'
    pl. |-sog|
    \xv kadtonkqs
    \xe thy cousin
    \so Lk.1.36√
    \xv ..., onk us wôhwohtam∞onk, nutonkqs.
    \xe ...; and call understanding thy kinswoman.
    \so Pro.7.4√
    \xv Newutche nuttonkqsog, weekontàm∞k,...
    \xe Wherefore, sirs, be of good cheer:...
    \so Acts 27.25
    \nt +
    \xv wadtunkqusoh
    \xe her cousins
    \so Lk.1.58√
    \xv wodtonkqsin
    \xe a cousin
    \so C.12/162√
\nt One who is akin to or in some sense belongs to another.
\cf adtôau
\cf ohtunk
\cf togquos
\ge a twin
\so ()

[Narragansett [xnt] |Natòncks| `My cousin.'; |Kattònks| `Your cousin.'; |Watóncks| `A cousin.'; |Wattonksíttuock| `They are cousins.'    R.W.29.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |Nnadañg8s,| pl. |-8ssak| `mon cousin, dicit vir v. mulier, seu le fils des parens de ma mère.'; |Nnadañg8sesesk8^é.| `ma cousine, dicit vir, la fille du parent de ma mère.' [|n'dañg∞ses| (dimin.) and |squa| fem.)]; |Nadañg8| `dit-on à la femme de son frère',... `mon gendre, dit le père au mari de sa fille', etc.    R.376/498b,378/499a.√
Cree |áhkoo-mayoo| `he is related to him'
Chip. |nindangoshe| `my mother's brother's daughter, or my father's sister's daughter' (dicit mulier).]
\et Compare A.39,374, H.712-713, *eΘa∙nkwime∙wa TA `related', and |wuttinnunkumôin|, 212b. The status of the variation in the initial vowel is unclear to me; could the |a-| derive from the common(?) use of changed conjunct forms of the derived possessive verb?


\lx adtuhteau
\va adtehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
    \nt +
\nt Remark: incorporating Trumbull's entry; c.f. T.315a, s.v. "ripe".
\ps II
\ge `to be ripe'

    \xv ..., kah yeuyeu ahquompiyeup negonne adtuhtag wenominneash.
    \xe .... Now the time was the time of the first ripe grapes.
    \so Num.13.20√

[Algonquian [alg] |ATIS,o| `être mûr (en parlant des fruits), être teint (en parlant des étoffes', |Atiten minan| `les bluets sont mûrs'    Cq.69a.
Cree |Utitä'o| or |utitä'wun| `It is ripe, it is dyed, it is tanned'    Frs.497a.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |atete8i, atete8ara| `fruits murs'    M.82/83a.
Delaware [del] |@`tíhte∙w| II `it is ripe'; |atíhteew| II, |atúsuw| AI `be ripe'    G.1982.26, no.69; O'M.43b.
Nask. |atiihtaaw| II `it is ripe (fruit or berries)', |atiihtaapiyuw| AI `the berries (anim) change colour'    McK&J.1.28b.
Sh. |hatte| `it is ripe'    D.-V.429.]

\et B.1925.153; G.1982; A.191, H.391,393 *atehsowa AI, *atehte∙wi II `dyed, colored'


\lx adtumehtam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
    \nt +?
\ps TI1a, directive final
\twn |adtumehtauau|
\ge `to resist sth'
\so Acts 6.10
    \xv Kah matta wuttapenum∞unneau nuhhén attumehtamunat ∞waantamóonk, kah Nashauanitt∞h aninnumunkqutche ket∞hkon.
    \xe And they were not able to resist the wisdom and the spirit by which he spake.
    \so Acts 6.10


\lx adtumehtauau

    \nt +
\ps TA, |-ht-aw-| stem
\twn |adtumehtam|
\ge `to turn back upon sb, resist sb'

    \xv ..., adtumehtauaog n∞swehtohukquehetticheh.
    \xe ... [they] turned back upon the pursuers.

    \xv ..., howan woskehukquean, ahque adtumehtau,...
    \xe ..., That ye resist not evil:...'    Mt.5.39 { |tô ponerô| as `the wicked person
    \so ; Annotations takes it in the sense of AV, as an abstract noun. }

\lx aetai
\va aeetaue
\va aeetawe
\va éhtái
\va aéhtaeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
\ps adv. / (initial |aehtaw-|), PreN, PreV(?)
\ge `at both sides', +`on either side'
\nt G&B.597
\so Ezek.47.7,12; Ex.25.19
    \xv ..., kah upponamunau aéhtaueu wuttugkeóont,...
    \xe ..., and laid it upon both their shoulders,...
    \so Gen.9.23 (i.e. "on the shoulders of both of them"?)
    \nt +
    \xv Ut nashauwe nashaummaogkodtut, kah aeetae seep ne pomantamóe mehtug,...
    \xe In the midst of the street of it, and on either side of the river, was there the tree of life,...
    \so Rev.22.2√
    \xv éhtái-kenag
    \xe sharp on both sides, "two-edged"
    \so Prov.5.4

[Western Abenaki [abe] |Éida8i8i| v. |épemai8i| `au bout, aux 2 bouts de q^q^ ch.'    R.P12/552b.
Algonquian [alg] |EITA| `de chaque côté, des deux côtés'    Cq.98b.
Cree +|AYITAW| (ad.) `des deux côtés, des deux bords'; |aye'tow| `At both ends'    Lac.D.328b-329a; Frs.67a.
EOjib. |eye∙yi∙tuwaye?i∙| `at both sides, at both ends', |eye∙yi∙tuwinikk| `on both arms'    B.1957.240b.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |Eita8agame| `des deux costés de la riviere', |Eita8i8ntchi| `des deux costés'    Grv.149/113a.
M.-P. |ehetuwiw| P `on both sides'    LeS.17a.
Menominee [mez] |e∙toh|: red. |a∙ye∙toh| `at both ends or sides'; |e∙tawa∙hkamek| `at both sides of the place', |i∙tawi∙hkanaw|, |a∙yi∙tawi∙hkanaw| `at both sides of the road'     M.L.63, B.1962, 17.14;17.50,77.
Nask. |aaituw| `both sides, ends', |aaituuyuw| `both sides of the body'    McK&J.4b-5a.
WAbn. |aidawi-| `on both sides'    D.1.XXVII.]

\et. H.150 *a∙yi∙tawiΘkanaw- XP `at both sides of the road'.

\lx agwappehtauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
    \nt +
\ps TA, stem in |-ht-aw-|
\twn |agwappehtam|
\ge `to submit (o.s.) unto sb, to be subject to sb'
\dv agw- + -appehtau-, de-stem form of |appehtauau| (v.i.); calque
\so Mt.8.9, Heb.2.5, Eph.5.21,22,24
    \xv ..., netagwapetau ketass∞t,...
    \xe ..., I will set a king over me,...
    \so Deut.17.14
    \xv Newutche nen wosketomp agwu nanaânuwaog, kah ayeuteaog nutagwappehtunk,...
    \xe For I am a man under authority, having soldiers under me:...
    \so Mt.8.9
    \xv Kah wame teanteaquasinish sohkog, neit pish Wunnaumonain agwapehtauau neh agwe ponamungqutche wame, onk woh God wameyeu∞ ut wame.
    \xe And when all things shall be subdued unto him, then shall the Son also himself be subject unto him that put allthings under him, that God may be all in all.
    \so 1 Cor.15.28

    \xv Noh matta agwappehtauôógkut pasukhower,...
    \xe To whom we gave place by subjection, no, not for an hour;..
    \so Gal.2.5
    \xv Newutche, neyane moeuwehkomonk agwapehtauont Christoh, ne ummittamwussinneunk unnehheahettich nehenwonche wasukkoouh nishnoh ut.
    \xe Therefore as the church is subject unto Christ, so let the wives be to their own husbands in every thing.
    \so Eph.5.24
    \xv Newutche yeu neyane nôadtit, wunnetupanatamwe mittamwossissog, ..., wunn∞whosuog, agwapehtauahettit nehenwonche wessukoouh
    \xe For after this manner in the old time the holy women also, ..., adorned themselves, being in subjection unto their own husbands:
    \so 1 Pet.3.5

    \xv N∞swehtok nag nanawunukqueógig, kah agwapehtok,...
    \xe Obey them that have the rule over you, and submit yourselves:...
    \so Heb.13.17
    \xv Agwapehtoadtegk ut qushaonganit God
    \xe Submitting yourselves one to another in the fear of God.
    \so Eph.5.21
    \ng reciprocal (AI); series of 2.p. imperatives
    \xv Ummittamwussinneunk agwapehtok nehenwonche kahsukowoog, neyane ut Lordut
    \xe Wives, submit yourselves unto your own husbands, as unto the Lord.
    \so Eph.5.22

    \se agwappehtam
    \dv TI1a
    \twn |agwappehtauau|
    \ge `to be subject to sth'
    \so Jas.5.17
    \xv Elias agwapehtamup n∞chumwesuongash neyane kenawun,...
    \xe Elias was a man subject to like passions as we are,...
    \so Jas.5.17


\lx agwappu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
    \nt +
\ps AI+O (P+AI)
\ge `to be under, to be in bondage under', i.e. "under, subject to the power of"
\so Gal.4.2,3,5.18
    \xv Qut agwappu kuhk∞tomwehteaenuut, kah nanánuwaénuut, noh pajeh utt∞cheyeu∞k ∞shoh unn∞wunit.
    \xe But is under tutors and governors until the time appointed of the father.
    \so Gal.4.2
    \xv Neyane nenawun, mogkiésúeog, nutagwappemunónup muttaohkéeu waj kutchehteomukish.
    \xe Even so we, when we were children, were in bondage under the elements of the world:
    \so Gal.4.3
    \xv Qut nashpe sagkompaganitteaog nashauanit, matta kutagwappúmw∞ naumatuonk
    \xe But if ye be led of the Spirit, ye are not under the law.
    \so Gal.5.18

    \se agwappehheau
    \ps TA(+O?), causative
    \ge `to put in subjection to sb' i.e. "to make subject to sb"
    \so Heb.2.5
    \nt Not quite certain; 1st ed. has |agwappehteaou|, which is a TA verb (see separate entry), and the calqued locative in Heb.2.5 disturbs the syntax; gender of |muttaohke| inanimate?
    \xv Newutche wutangelsumut matta agwappehheaou muttaohke ne paóm∞ug, papaume ne án∞wáog.
    \xe For unto the angels hath he not put in subjection the world to come, whereof we speak.
    \so Heb.2.5

\lx ahchewesu

\ps AI+O

    \xv ..., kah yeuyeu matta woh wuttamheóog ne ahchewesehettit.
    \xe ...: and now nothing will be restrained from them, which they have imagined to do.

    \ng 3p->_0_ participle

    \ps NI

\lx ahchewanumau

\ps TA
\twn |ahchewontam|
\ge `to covet sb, to desire sb'
\so Ex.20.17, Ps.73.25
    \xv ...? kah matta howan nutahchewonamoh yeu ut muttaohket webe ken
    \xe ...? and there is none upon earth that I desire besides thee.
    \so Ps.73.25; (M): |nutahchuanumoh|

    \xv Ahchewontogkon week ketatteamung, ahchewanumúhkon ummittamwussoh ketatteamung, asuh wosketompae wuttinnúmoh, asuh mittamwussisse wuttinnúmoh, asuh wutoxinumoh, asuh wutassimoh, asuh ne teaguas ohtunk ketatteamung.
    \xe Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's house, thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife, nor his manservant, nor his maidservant, nor his ox, nor his ass, nor any ting that is thy neighbour's.
    \so Ex.20.17√


\lx ahchewontam

    \xv ahcheuantam
    \xe he is earnest-minded

    \nt MN: ahchewontog
    \ng suppositive |ahchewontog| `he who is covetous'
    changed, pl. |Kah Pharisesog wonk iahchewontogig yeush wame wunn∞tamunaoash, kah wuttôôntuhkonouh.| `And the Pharisees also, who were covetous, heard all these things: and they derided him.'    Lk.16.14

    imper. 2d pl. |ahchewontam∞k| `covet ye' (the best gifts)    1 Cor.12.31
    imperat. of prohibition, |Ahchewontukon keetatteamung ummittamwussoh, asuh ahchewontukon ketattamung wek, wutohteuk, asuh wosketompae wuttinneum, asuh mittatwossisse wuttinneum, wutoxumoh, asuh wutassumoh, asuh ne teaguas ahtunk ketatteamung| `Neither shalt thou desire thy neighbour's wife, neither shalt thou covet thy neighbour's house, his field, or his manservant, or his maidservant, his ox, or his ass, or any thing that is thy neighbour's.'    Deut.5.21√ { E1&2: gender error? cf. Ex.20.17 }

    \se -tamónk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \ge `coveting, covetousness'
    \so Hab.2.9
    (|ahhahchuwonk|    Man.Pom.86)

    Cotton has (p.70) |nutahchuueehteom| (?) `I procure'; (p.53) |nuttahchuehteo| `I get' (?).


\lx ahchippog
\va -pog
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
    \nt +
\ps ?NI (cf. |wunnepog|, T.202b-203a)
\dv |as(h)k-| `green' + |-i-| + |-pog(u)| NI `leaf'
\ge `green herb'

    \xv ..., onatuh ahchippog, wame kittinnumauunash.
    \xe ...; even as the green herb have I given you all things.

\lx ahchu
\va ahcheu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
\ps v.i. / PreV, adverb
\ge `he is diligent, makes effort, exerts himself' (cf. |adchah| `he hunts')
    Used by Eliot only as an adverb, in the sense of `diligently, earnestly, exceedingly, very much', etc.:
    \xv ..., kah wame missinninnuog ahque ahchue na áhettich, newutche nag ogguhsuog.
    \xe ...; and make not all the people to labour thither; for they [the hostile Ai] are but few.
    \so Josh.7.3
    \nt +
    \xv ahchu anakausuog
    \xe they "had a mind to work" (worked "with a will")
    \so Neh.4.6;
    |ahchue taphekon| (prohib.) `labor not to comfort me'    Is.22.4
    \xv ahche mishe kutonkquatunk
    \xe thy exceeding great reward
    \so Gen.15.1
    \xv Kah wonk m∞cheke iánussuog missinninnúog ∞weechauôuh, kah floksog, kah heardsog, ahche missi ahtóonk.
    \xe And a mixed multitude went up also with them; and flocks, and herds, even very much cattle.
    \so Ex.12.38
    \nt +
    \xv ahchúe pannupwushau S--
    \xe he must needs go through S--
    \so Mass.Ps.
    \xv Kah ahchúe pannupwushau Samaria.
    \xe And he must needs go through Samaria.
    \so Jn.4.4
    \nt +
    This verb may be regarded as, in some sort, an intensive of |ussu|, |usseu|, which expresses animate action, he moves, he does (Lat. agit), while |adchau| denotes action for a purpose or directed toward an end.

[Cree "|ache-oo| (ch = tch) or |age-oo| (g=dg), `he moves' (quasi, Lat. agere)"    Howse, 156.
Chip. |aunj-eh|.
Western Abenaki [abe] |ahañtai| `de plus en plus'; |-- negañmih8si| `surpasse-toi de plus en plus'.
Delaware [del] |ahchwé| (when prefixed) `very'; |achowat| `hard, painful'    Hkw.; Zeisb.]

\lx ahk∞teau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
    \nt +
\ps II
\ge `to hang'
\so Ex.35.17
\nt Remark: An independent form has not yet been found; for the spelling suggested, cf. <ohteau>, G. 1981, 40, p.80, and the etymology that Hewson's (H. 190) listing suggests. The vowel of the conjunct form is unexpected under this analysis (cf. <ohtag>)? See also |ogk∞chin|.

    \se ahha(h)k∞teau
    \ps II, reduplicated
    \ge `to hang'
    \so Ex.35.17

    \xv ...; kah ahhahk∞tik onkwhonk, wutche squoantâme chippinneutunk.
    \xe ..., and the hanging for the door of the court,
    \so Ex.35.17

    \se ak∞chit-
    \ps TI(2?); no parallel form found elsewhere yet.
    \ge `to hang sth up'
    \so Ps.137.2
    \xv Nutak∞chittomun nut-harpsumunnonash anumussukuppehtu, ut noeu.
    \xe We hanged our harps upon the willows, in the midst thereof.
    \so Ps.137.2; (M): |Nuttogkoochittomunonup|

\et H.180-191, e.g. *akote∙wi II `hang'


\lx -âhkon
\va -uhkon
\va -ogkon
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 5
\ge the characteristic (suffix) of the imperative of prohibition, 2d sing. Its force is equivalent to that of |ahque| prefixed:
    \xv ontahâhkon
    \xe do not remove it
    \so Prov.23.10;
    \xv kumm∞t-úhkon
    \xe do not steal, steal not
    \so Ex.20.15.


\lx ahkuhk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\cf ohkuk


\lx ahp-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
    \nt +
\nt Remark: often spelt |app-|, |ohp-|
\ps initial, transitive relational
\ge `on', precise sense, especially with respect to |woskeche|, to be established. (The latter appeas to be used of vertical relationships, and perhaps |ahp-| emphasizes contact, rather like English "on".)
\so various entries that follow, largely under |app-|.

\et *axp- (*asp-) e.g. H.506ff.


\lx ahpappin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\cf appappn


\lx ahpéh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\cf appéh


\lx ahp∞teau
\va upp∞teau
\va ohp∞teau
\va uhp∞ht-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it withers' i.e. `becomes dry, dries up'
\so +Gen.41.23; Ps.90.6,129.6; Is.15.6,19.6,7,40.7,8; Lam.4.8; Jer.12.4; Ezek.19.12; Amos 1.2,4.7; Joel 1.17; 1 Pet.2.4; Jude 12
    \xv uhp∞htaash
    \xe withered
    \so Gen.41.23
    \nt +
    \xv Maskeht ahp∞teau, uppeshau penusheau,..
    \xe The grass withereth, the flower fadeth:...
    \so Is.40.7,8
    \nt +
    \xv Nompoáe n∞n∞han, kah neekin: wunnonk∞uk tummehthamun, kah uhp∞teau,
    \xe In the morning it flourisheth, and groweth up; in the evening it is cut down, and withereth.
    \so Ps.90.6; (M) |uppoopohteau|
    \nt +

    \xv Ogqunneungqussehettich moskehtuut woskechekomukqut: ne ahpohtag asq waummékininnokup,
    \xe Let them be as the grass upon the housetops, which withereth afore it groweth up:
    \so Ps.129.6  { _0_ participle }; (M) |napoohtag|
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche quenau n[e]pauz nashpe waapit kossopittag, ohp∞teau mosket, kah ne uppeshau mahtsheau,...
    \xe For the sun is no sooner risen with a burning heat, but it withereth the grass, and the flower thereof falleth,...
    \so Jas.1.11
    \ng transitive?
    \nt +

    \se |uhp∞pohteau|
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: placed here despite unclear relationship to the headword.
    \ps II
    \ge `to wither away'
    \so Mt.13.6 (cf. Ps.90.6(M) above)
    \xv ...: ooneepog wonk matta pish uppoopohtanoo,...
    \xe ...; his leaf also shall not wither,...
    \so Ps.1.3(M); (E) |n∞kshaun∞h|
    \xv Qut nepauz pashpishont, kunkohteadteash kah newutche matchaog wadchabukinoash uhp∞pohtaash.
    \xe And when the sun was up, they were scorched; and because they had no root, they withered away.
    \so Mt.13.6

    \se !|upp∞pasu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \ge `to wither'
    \so Ps.37.2
    \xv ..., kah pish upp∞passuog onatuh oshkoshqut.
    \xe ..., and [they shall wither as the green herb.
    \so Ps.37.2 { of evil-doers, |matchesecheg| }; (M) |uppoopassuog|

\dv |appwau|, |ohteau|, `it is dried by heat, parched'
\cf nunâpi
\cf nunassenát
\cf nunnobohteateou
\cf muss∞pohteau
\nt { portion transferred to , T.72a
\cf nupp∞pasu
\so cf. also  }
\cf apwóu

\et Relationship to H.2483-2485, 2487 *pa∙?s-, *pa∙?t- `dry' (C,M,O)?


\lx ahpukquasin
\va ohpukquasin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
    \nt +
\ps AI+O
\dv [|ahp-| `on' + |ukqu-| `head' + |-á-| AI] (bahuvrihi) + |-sin| AI `to lie' (for close parallel, c.f. H.801)
\ge `to lie with one's head on sth'
\so Gen.28.11,28.18
    \xv ..., kah nemunum na ohtagish qussukqunash, kah wutohpukquasinúnash,...
    \xe ...; and he took of the stones of that place, and put them for his pillows,...
    \so Gen.28.11 (corrected from (E1))
    \ng 3->0p objective

    \xv ..., kah nemunum qussuk ne ápukquasukup,...
    \xe ..., and [he] took the stone that he had put for his pillows,...
    \so Gen.28.18

    \se ahpuhqussum∞un
    \ps NI, deverbal noun, to middle reflexive of TA stem
    \ge `bed's head'
    \so Gen.47.31
    \xv ..., kah Israel nauaeu ut wutappuhquassum∞unit.
    \xe .... And Israel bowed himself upon the bed's head.
    \so Gen.47.31

[Western Abenaki [abe] |p8`k8^ésím8n, nar| `Coussin de tête'    R.142/422b.
Algonquian [alg] |Apikwêcimon| `Coussin'    Lem.D.148b.
Cree |Uspiskwä'simon|, or |Uspiskwä'simonwin| `A pillow, a bolster;...'    Frs.492b.
Fox |apehkwe∙⌠inwa| `he lies with head upon smth', |apehkwe∙⌠imo∙ni| `pillow, thing used to lay the head on'    Fx.L.26-27.
WAbn. |apkwasimon| NA `pillow'    D.1.41.]

\et H.513 *axpexkwe∙⌠imoni NI `pillow' [*axp- + *-exkw- + *-e∙-] + *-h⌠in/?h⌠im+wi + *wa.


\lx ahquantam
\va ahquoantam
\va ahquontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\ps v.t. / TI1a, mental final
\twn |ahquanumau| TA
\ge `he forgives (it), pardons'
\so 2 Chr.7.14;
    [|ahque-antam|, `refrains from thinking of']

    imperat. 2d sing. |ahquoantash|, `forgive thou (it)'    1 Sam.25.25;

    \se ahquontamauau
    \ps With an. 2d obj., / TA+O, |-aw-| stem
    \ge `he forgives (it) to (him)'
    \xv ..., kah pish monaneteae ahquontamauóneau ...
    \xe ..., and it shall be forgiven them;...
    \so Num.15.25
    \ng X->3p+0-obj
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta kutahquontamunkou kuppanneusseongan∞oash,...
    \xe ...; he will not forgive your transgressions ...
    \so Josh.24.19
    \ng 3->2p+0
    \nt +
    \xv ..., tohhen nagwutteaeu neemat matchenehukqueh, m∞che mos nutahquontamau? ...
    \xe ..., how oft shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? ...
    \so Mt.18.21

    \xv Kah ahquoantamaiinnean nummatcheseongash, neane matchenehukqueagig nutahquontamóunnonog.
    \xe And forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors.
    \so Mt.6.12
    \ng 2->1p+0
    \nt +

    \se ahquoantausu
    \ps act.intrans., / AI
    \nt Remark: Alternative form of middle reflexive to TA verbs in -ánum-, with -si final added to TI -ántam- (as a TI-based version of what B. 1962, 15.95, p.293 indicates)?? Or is the example from Ps.86.5 of an |-us| preterite ("unreal" in a dispositional predication)?
    \nt +
    \ge `he exercises forgiveness, pardons, forgives'.
    \xv ...nish noh howan wunnoguhkouheuh wetatteámunguh, pish kutahquoantaúsim∞,...
    \xe ...Every creditor that lendeth aught unto his neighbour shall release it;...
    \so Deut.15.2
    \ng apparently 2p form, despite AV
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche ken Jehovah k∞netum, kah teanuk kutahquoantus:...
    \xe For thou, Lord, art good, and ready to forgive:...
    \so Ps.86.5; (M): |kukkakunne ohquontos|
    \nt +

    \se --ausúonk
    \ps Vbl.n.,
    \ge `the exercise of forgiveness'
    \so Ps.130.4
    \se --tamóonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a forgiving, forgiveness'(e.g. of sins, Col.1.14).
\cf mehquantam


\lx ahquanumau
\va ohquanumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\ps v.t. an. / TA, mental final
\twn |ahquoantam| TI1a
\ge `he forsakes, abandons (keeps away from, |ahque|) him'
    \xv ..., kah nag pish nutaquanumóog, kah nag pish nuttunkhumauóog nuskesuk,...
    \xe ..., and I will forsake them, and I will hide my face from them,...
    \so Deut.31.17
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche Demas nutahquanumuk, womontogkup yeu muttaok, kah aui Thessalonica,...
    \xe For Demas hath forsaken me, having loved this present world, and is departed unto Thessalonica;...
    \so 2 Tim.4.10
    \ng Note absentative.
    \nt +
    pl. |-máog| `they forsake (him)'    Judg.2.13

    \nt MN: -móg
    \ng suppositive |-móg| `if ye forsake'    Josh.24.20.
    \xv tohwutch ohquanumean?
    \xe why hast thou forsaken me?
    \so Mt.27.46
    \nt +
\cf úhquanumau
\ge he abhors, forsakes or abandons with abhorrence
\so (intens. )


\lx ahqu-
\va ohqu-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge `to cease, leave'
\so preceding and following entries
    \xv ..., kah ahquegheau.
    \xe ...; and [she] left bearing.
    \so Gen.29.35; to final |-e(e)kheau|, T+.82b.
    \xv Leah nag wutahquegheaonk,...
    \xe When Leah saw that she had left bearing,...
    \so Gen.30.9
    \xv ..., kah ut ohquodtinneohteau peississitteaut,...
    \xe ..., and [he] left at the youngest:...
    \so Gen.44.12
    \ng i.e. "finished (doing what he was doing)"


\lx ahqu-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge termination of eventuality--state or process
\so following entries


\lx ahque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\ps v.i. / AI; usually PreV
\ge `he leaves off, desists, refrains'
    \xv Kah ahque keket∞hkauont, kah GOD ashpeit wutch Abrahamut.
    \xe And he left off talking with him, and God went up from Abraham.
    \so Gen.17.22√
    \xv ..., neit keneechan∞oog pish ahque wabesuáheáog Jehovah.
    \xe ...: so shall your children make our children cease from fearing the Lord.
    \so Josh.22.25
    \nt +
    \xv ..., noh matta ahque womonunk pamontamunitcheh, kah napinitcheh,...
    \xe ..., who hath not left off his kindness to the living and to the dead. ...
    \so Ruth 2.20√

\nt More commonly used as a negative-imperative or prohibitive particle-answering to Greek me:; Fr. ne pas:
    \xv ahque wabesish
    \xe "fear not", do not fear
    \so Gen.15.1
    \xv -- natwontam∞k
    \xe take ye not thought, leave off thinking
    \so Mt.10.19
    \xv -- hettash
    \xe do not call (it)
    \so Acts 10.15
    \xv -- tapenuk
    \xe when she could not longer
    \so , etc. (when she left off being able)    Ex.2.3.

\nt Sometimes it receives the regular verbal inflections:
    \xv ahqueh
    \xe have thou patience with me, refrain thou to me
    \so Mt.18.29
    [= |ahkumeh| Mt.18.26, a more questionable form]
    |ahqhuk| [|ahque-∞k|] `refrain ye'    Prov.17.14
\cf uhquáe
\cf uhque

[Narragansett [xnt] |Aquíe| `Leave off or doe not.'; |Aquie assókish| `Be not foolish.'    R.W.39;41.√
Quiripi [qyp] |matta eakquino| `it ceaseth not'    Pier.15.40.
Cree "|Eg'à| (= |ithkà|), subordin. neg. NOT: used with {Subj.} and {Imperat.}"; "|àk-|, or |awk'-|, and |âkoo-|, privative and intensive" prefixes.    Howse 171;172√.
Western Abenaki [abe] |É`k8i| `cessatio'em sign'at'; |nedé`k8ippi| `Je cesse, v.g. de manger'; |é`k8^ihaia| `Demeure en repos, dit-on à celui qui se fâche, badine, &c.'    R.12P/552b;95/406a;438/521a.
    Lp.A. |ak8i| negative imperative    D., passim.
    \nt +
WAbn. |akwi| PT negative imperative particle; `stop, cease'    D.1.21.]


\lx ahquedne
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\ps as n. / NI
\ge `an island'
    \xv kishke ahquednet
    \xe near an island
    \so Acts 27.16
    pl. |-nash| (|ogquidnash|    Is.40.15)

[Howse (Cree Gr. 152) gives a "verb expressive of a state of rest": "|a'koosu|, he sits (a bird, in a tree); |a'koo-moo|, he suspends, sits (e. g., a duck in the water); |a'koo-tin|, inan. subj. it suspends, is situate, e.g., an island in the water."
Mi'kmaq [mic] |agwi@tk| `it is in the water'; |Epägwi@t| `it lies in the water' (name of Prince Edward island)    Dawson's Acadian Geology, app., p. 673.]

\et G.1981, 5, 58: PEA *akwïnt@n "[agent noun `floater', in most languages `canoe']"


\lx ahquéhteau
\va quehteau
\va ahqueteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\ps v.t. (caus.) / TI2, governing subordinative
\ge `he refrains from (it), leaves it off'
    \xv ..., onk wutahqueteauunneau ayimun keitotan.
    \xe ...: and they left off to build the city.
    \so Gen.11.8
    \ng 3p->S objective/subordinative
    \nt +

    imper. 2d. pl. |AHquetea∞k ussenat kukkitteamonteanitteaongash anaquabhettit wosketompaog,| `Take heed that ye do not your alms before men,...', i.e. "refrain from doing"    Mt.6.1√

\dv With the characteristic of forcible or disastrous action, |ahqshau| `he is compelled to refrain, unwillingly refrains', or the like    Is.33.8

[Narragansett [xnt] |aquétuck| `let us cease' (fighting); but the verb is imperat. 2d pl.]

\ge `it ceases to bear, or produce, becomes barren'
\so Ps.107.34
\dv |ahque|, with the formative of verbs of inan. growth, |-ekin|.

\so Cant.2.11
\dv |ahque|, privative, with |-'non|, the formative of verbs of raining (falling water). +(See further s.v. |sokanon|.)
    \xv Newutche kusseh, popon mahtsheau, ahqunnon kah pomsheau.
    \xe For, lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone;
    \so Cant.2.11

\lx ahquoantam

\cf ahquantam


\lx ahquompi
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 6
\ps v. imp.; as n. / II, NI
    \dv initial: relative root |ahkw-| `so far, so long', of time; the derived inanimate noun is much better attested, in unambiguously possessive and locative forms, perhaps due to calquing.
    \nt +
\ge `a time, a season'
\so Ezek.16.8; Dan.7.12; 8.17
    \xv Kah ahquompi pas∞tshám∞ Israel m∞che wunnupp∞onk,...
    \xe And the time drew nigh that Israel must die:...
    \so Gen.47.29
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah yeuyeu ahquompiyeup negonne adtuhtag wenominneash.
    \xe ... Now the time was the time of the first ripe grapes.
    \so Num.13.20
    \nt +

    suppos. and indef. |ahquompak| `when it is the time, at the time when'
    \xv ahquompak
    \xe at that time
    \so Gen.21.22
    \ng 0->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ne aquompak
    \xe at that time
    \so Josh.11.10
    In his Grammar (p.21), Eliot classes "|ahquompak|, when", with "adverbs of time". With verb subst. |ahquompiyeu∞|, `time is, there is a time', Eccles.3.2, et seq.
    (|oggosohquompi| `a little time'; |kesu@kkâttae ahquompi| `daytime'    C.)

    [Algonquian [alg] |AKO| `depuis que, tant que, (avant un verbe au subjonctif)'    Cq.32b-33a.]
    \nt +

\et H.481-500 *axkw- (*askw-) `so far, so long'; this relative root is best attested in spatial senses, but there are also uses in linear ordering (cf. Hewson's gloss "next") and time, as in the Algonquin example. A possible direct connection, elucidating the |-omp-|, would be Fox |ahkwa∙pye∙yawi| `it extends so far (life)', Fx.L.25, presumably with the "string" final as in *-a∙pye∙k, H. p.242; further, also with reference to the passage of time, Cree |Iskwa'puyew| or |Iskwa'puyin| II `It ends, it passes away, it passes by.', Frs.260a. For forms without the velar, cf. Men. -(a∙)py- `string', B.1962, 14.302-303, 260.


\lx ahquoppu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 7
    \nt +
\ps AI, i-stem
\ge `not to be' (i.e. "cease to exist")
\so Gen.42.36, Ps.59.12(M)
\dv |ahqu-| + |ap-|
    \xv ..., Joseph ayóhquobéup, kah Simeon ahquoppu,...
    \xe ...: Joseph is not, and Simeon is not,...
    \so Gen.42.36
    \ng reduplicated preterite
    \xv ..., mahtuppan, onk woh ohquapuog:...
    \xe ..., consume them, that they may not be:...
    \so Ps.59.12(M)

\lx ahtuhsau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 7
    \nt +
\nt Remark: status uncertain; H.324: *a?ta∙?sowa AI `deposit' would match.
\ps AI+O(?)
\ge `to commit sth (to sb)'
\so 1 Pet.4.19; Ps.31.5(M)

    \xv ..., nag ahtuhs∞wahettich nanawéheónat ukketeahogkôunóuh ut wunneseonganit,...
    \xe ..., let them ... commit the keeping of their souls to him in well doing,...
    \so 1 Pet.4.19


\lx ahtuhshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 7
    \nt +
\ps AI+O, transitive initial stem, final unclear
\ge `to charge sb (with sb/sth)[OED s.v., 13a], commend, commit sb (to sb/sth)', also reflexively
\so Gen.40.4; 2 Chron.12.10,34.16; Job.5.8; Jer.39.14,40.7,41.10; 1 Pet.2.23
    \xv Nompe nish ketass∞t Rehoboam ayim brasse ogqunnegash: kah wutahtahshonash en wunnutcheganit, negonneyeuit ut wadchanonganit,...
    \xe Instead of which king Rehoboam made shields of brass, and committed them to the hands of the chief of the guard,...
    \so 2 Chron.12.10
    \ng 3->0p-pro objective
    \xv Woh nunnattinneah GOD, kah nutahtush GOD nuttinniyeuonk.
    \xe I would seek unto God, and unto God would I commit my cause:
    \so Job.5.8
    \xv Nag ann∞team∞og, kah neemunaog Jeremiahoh ..., kah wutáhtashonuh ut Gedaliah ...
    \xe Even they sent, and took Jeremiah ..., and committed him unto Gedaliah ...'    Jer.39.14  { 3p->3
    \so -pro objective }
    \xv Qut Jesus matta wuttahtuhshôwôopah wohhoguh, newutche wahheop wame wosketompoh,
    \xe But Jesus did not commit himself unto them, because he knew all men,
    \so Jn.2.24(M)
    \ng dative final?
    \xv ..., wutahtushonáoh Goduh, n nah wanamptauáhettiche.
    \xe ..., they commended them to the Lord, on whom they believed.'    Acts 14.23  { 3p->3
    \so -pro }
    \xv ..., ne woskheáhettit, mat quogwohtoôou, qut ahtuhshau wuhhog neh sampwe wussittumunutcheh.
    \xe ...; when he suffered, he threatened not; but committed himself to him that judgeth righteously:
    \so 1 Pet.2.23

    \xv ..., Wame ne ahtúhshop kittinneumog wutusseneau.
    \xe ..., All that was committed to thy servants, they do it.
    \so 2 Chron.34.16
    \ng X->3+_0_ preterite participle

    \xv Ahtush kutanakausuongash LORD,...
    \xe Commit thy works unto the LORD,...
    \so Prov.16.3
    \xv Ahtuhsh kummay Jehovah,...
    \xe Commit thy way unto the LORD;...
    \so Ps.37.5, cf. (M) |Ahtahsoowash kummay Jehovahut:...|


\lx ahtuhshin-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 7
    \nt +
\ps [isolates various, perhaps manual final]
\se `to commit ...
    \xv Ut kenutcheganit kutahtóhshinun nunnashauonk:...
    \xe Into thine hand I commit my spirit:...
    \so Ps.31.5 { (E1&2) erroneous |ku-| for |nu-| }; (M) |nuttohtosoowam|

    \xv Ne wanegik ahtúhshinúmukup, wadchansh,
    \xe That good thing which was committed unto thee, keep ...
    \so 2 Tim.1.14
    \ng X->2+_0_ preterite participle, theme 4, hence to a TA stem, syncopated?


\lx ahtuk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 7
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a deer'
\so El.Gr.9
    pl. |ahtuhquog|    El.Gr.9
    |adtunkquog|    1 K.4.23
    (|attük|    C.4/156; |ottucke|    Wood).
    This name is used by Eliot for `roe', `roe-buck', and in one place for `hart', as well as for `deer', generic. Elsewhere he has |nukkonahtuk| (old deer) for `hart' (Deut. 12, 15); and more often, |aiyomp| or eiyomp (Ps. 42, 1; Cant. 2, 17), also transl. `roe' (Prov. 5, 19; 6, 5; Cant. 8, 14). Of the several names applied by Eliot to deer-kind: |ahtuk|, in New England, appears to have been the common name of the fallow deer, Cervus virginianus.

    \se !|ahtuhqusseet|
    \nt +
    \ps ?NI
    \ge `hind's foot'
    \so Ps.18.33
    \xv ahtûhqusseetit
    \xe like hindes feet
    \so Ps.18.33; (M) |adtuhqusseetit|
    \ng locative; apparently the term for the male used?

    Narragansett [xnt] |attuck| and |nóonatch|
    Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |noughitch|, |nögh-ich| `deer'; |waughtúggachy| `deer i.e., wet-nose'; |cunggachie mauky"ase|, `a great deer' (Abn. |mañr8s| `cerf'; `maurouse' of Josselyn); |mausshakeet maukkyhazse| `the biggest deer' (moose?)    Stiles MS.
    Etchemin [etc] |adook|
    Delaware [del] |achtúch|
    Western Abenaki [abe] |n∞rké| `chevreuil'
    Old Alg. |awaskesh|    Lah.
    Chip. |wawáshkeshi|, |wawwawshesh| `red deer'; |atík| `reindeer', Cervus sylvestris.
[See what Schoolcraft (Ind.Tribes, III, 520) says of the tradition that at the first deers were the hunters of men, and his statement that the mythic "|Adik| was a famous hunter of the North", etc. Look for the possible relation of Mass. |adchau|, `he hunts', |ahchu|, `he strives after', etc., and |ahtuk| (|attuck|), `deer'.]
    |aiyomp|, |ayimp|, |eiyomp|, `hart', `roe', is Abn. |aïañbe|, the mate of deer or deerkind, a buck.
    Narragansett [xnt] |kuttíomp| [|kehteiyomp|] `a great buck'; and so, |paucottâuwaw|, |-taúwat|, `a buck'
    Delaware [del] |ayapeü|    Zeisb.
    East. Chip. |ayarbey awaskesh| `male deer'    Long.

    |eiyompáemese| pl. |-sog| `young hart'    Cant.8.14
    `young roes'    Cant.4.5; dimin. of |eiyomp|.
    |qunnegk| pl. |-gquàog|, |-quôog| `hind'    Gen.49.21; Cant.2.7; `a doe, the female deer'
    Narragansett [xnt] |aunàn|, |qunnèke| (the former term corresponding to Abn.  |hè`rar|, female of deer-kind); |qunnequáwëse| `a young doe'.

\lx amaequanum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \xv ..., yeu kesukok nutamáequánum, ukkekómuwaonk Egypt wutch kuhhogkaóut,...

\lx amáeu
\va amáei
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 8
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he departs, goes away, withdraws himself'
\so Job 27.21; Gal.2.12
\nt without reference to the mode or to the act of going, but simply to the separation or removal of one person or thing from another.
    \xv Nusse peyont, pish nusse amaeu ∞wásukiimuk mittumwussit: neìt ummittumwussoh pish nashpe amai.
    \xe If he came in by himself, he shall go out by himself: if he were married, then his wife shall go out with him.
    \so Ex.21.3
    \nt +

    \nt MN: amait
    \ng suppositive |amait| , |amaiit| `when he went away'
    \xv Onk n nih keteahogkou aumait (newutche nupp∞) kah wuttissowenuh Benoni,...
    \xe And it came to pass as her soul was in departing, (for she died) that she called his name Benoni:...
    \so Gen.35.18
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d pers. sing. |amaish| `depart, go away'
    \xv Qut noh pann∞wohtog amayit, amayitch,...
    \xe But if the unbelieving depart, let him depart. ...
    \so 1 Cor.7.15
    \nt +

    \se |amaemo|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to go (away)'
    \so Deut.32.36
    \xv ... nag menutchegan amaemo,...
    \xe ... when he seeth that their power is gone,...
    \so Deut.32.36

    \se amáeuau
    \ps with an.obj. / TA
    \ge `he goes away from him'
    |amaeuoh|, |amayeoh| `he went away from him'    Judg.6.21 (?)

    more commonly
    \se amaehtauau
    \ps with an.obj. / TA
    \ge `he departs or goes away from (him)'
    \so 1 Sam.16.14

    imperat. 2d + 1st sing. |amaéihtah| `depart thou from me'    Lk.5.8

    suppos. part. |amehtauont| `when he departs, when departing, from (him)'    Jer.17.5

    \se !|amaeheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to draw sb away'
    \so Deut.30.17

    \xv ..., kah matta n∞tam∞an, qut amaehenumuk,...
    \xe ..., so that thou wilt not hear, but shalt be drawn away,...
    \so Deut.30.17
    \ng X->2

\lx amisque
\va amis
\ve =
\lg Mahican [mjy]
\so Trumbull 8
\ge `a beaver'
\so Edw.
\nt Cf. |tummunk|, a name which was applied properly only to the living adult animal. (Abn. |tema`k8^é|, `castor vivant'.)
    |Amisk|, a generic name for beaver-kind, has been retained in the principal Algonquian dialects:
Western Abenaki [abe] |pep8nemesk8|, |nipenemesk8| `winter beaver, summer beaver'; |kemésk8| `great beaver', or `beaver skin'; |atsimesk8| (or |nañbémesk8|), `male', |n8sémesk8| (or |skémesk8|) `female beaver'
Cree |umísk|
Chip. |amík|
Shawnee [sjw] |amèxhwah|
Miami |mahkwaw|
Del. (Minsi) |amochk|    Zeisb.

\lx anakausu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 8
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he works, he labors'
\so Prov.31.13
    \xv ..., N∞sh yeu uppaudanakausin, kah nutanakaus
    \xe ..., My Father worketh hitherto, and I work.
    \so Jn.5.17
    \xv Nemehkuh nupp∞onk anakausu ut nuhhogkanónut, qut pomantamóonk ut kuhhogkauóont.
    \xe So then death worketh in us, but life in you.
    \so 2 Cor.4.12
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nutanakausimun, anakauseog nashpe nehenwónche nutcheganunnónash,...
    \xe And [we] labour, working with our own hands:...
    \so 1 Cor.4.12
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche nenawun n∞weetanakausumómun GOD,...
    \xe For we are labourers together with God:...
    \so 1 Cor.3.9
    \nt +
    \xv Epaphras, ... k∞wonkomukou nagwutteae kutanakausuwanshikou ut uppeantamunat,...
    \xe Epaphras,..., saluteth you, always labouring fervently for you in prayers,...
    \so Col.4.12
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh anakausit
    \ng suppositive |noh anakausit| `he who works'    Eccl.3.9
    \xv Newutche neg neanussitcheg pann∞wáe Apostlesog, as∞kekodteamoe anakausitcheg,...
    \xe For such are false apostles, deceitful workers,...
    \so 2 Cor.11.13
    \nt +
    \xv Newaj nen wonk anakause, manuhkeusseon neyane wutanakausuonk, noh mahshanakausit ut nuhhokat.
    \xe Whereunto I also labour, striving according to his working, which worketh in me mightily.
    \so Col.1.29
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche wetomunog, yeu kuttinne ann∞nunan, matta howan anakausegk, meetsehkitch.
    \xe For even when we were with you, this we commanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat.
    \so 2 Thess.3.10
    \nt +

    \xv Noh kúm∞tug ahque wonk komm∞tich, qut aynwoh anakausitch, anakausuwohtauutch nashpe wunnutcheash ut ne wanegik,...
    \xe Let him that stole steal no more: but rather let him labour, working with his hands the thing which is good,...
    \so Eph.4.28
    \nt +
    \xv Eyeu nuttann∞nóunonog neyaniitcheg kah n∞wehquetumauóunónog ..., wunohteae anakaushettich kah mechhettich nehenwonche uppetukqunnungan∞.
    \xe Now them that are such we command and exhort, that with quietness they work, and eat their own bread.
    \so 2 Thess.3.12
    \nt +

    \se !|anakausum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to work'
    \so Eph.1.19

    \xv ..., neyane anakausum∞uk mohsag ummenuhkesuonk.
    \xe ..., according to the working of his mighty power,
    \so Eph,1.19

    \se anakausuen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a worker'
    \so Is.40.19
    pl. |-enuog|,    Is.44.11

    \se anakausuonk
    \va anakausuong(an
    \nt +
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI, deverbal noun
    \ge `laboring; work, labor'; +also, by calque, in product sense for the implicit object of result, as OED s.v. "work", sb., senses 9 and 10: "The product of the operation or labour of a person or other agent", "A thing made; ..."
    \so Eccl.3.10,11
    pl. |anakausuongash| `works'    Mt.8.22
    \nt +
    \xv ...kah nish noh goatse weshagkane anakausuonk,...
    \xe ..., and all work of goats' hair,...
    \so Num.31.20
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |anakáusu| `a laborer', pl. (suppos.) |-sichik|.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nedarokké| `je travaille'; |nedarokkéh8'si| `je travaille pour moi'; +|aro`keddin| `On travaille'    R.486/539b.
Chip. |anoki|    Bar.; |annokee|    Sch.
    Algonquian [alg] |ANOKI| `travailler', w. note: "s'emploie plus souvent dans le sens de {faire la chasse}..."    Cq.52b-53a.
    \nt +
WAbn. |aloka| AI `work'    D.1.33,2.454.
Lp.A. |ketalkans a sane@'tax| `travaille tu le dimanche'; |nitalkansita8an| `je travaille pour lui'    D.108 (etc.).
Mi'kmaq [mic] |e@lookwä'| `To Work'; |elukwet| AI `work',     R.284a; DeB.13a.
M.-P. |luhke| AI `he works; he does (something)'    LeS.39a.]

\et H.437-447; 446 *aΘoxkye∙wa AI `work'; stem here extended with the common AI final *-(e)si.


\lx anamakéesuck
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 8
\ge `this day, today' [= |yeu kesukod|    El.]
    \xv anamanâukock
    \xe tonight

\lx anántam
\va unántam
\va an-
\va un-
\ve spurious form from changed forms of
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 8
    \nt Remark: Entry is split between this lemma and one at T.170b under |unnantam-| and T.171b under |unnanum-|.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / TI1a-O, mental final
\ge `he thinks, purposes, wills; is minded'; +`would (not) have, would (not) that'
\so Lk.12.17; Acts 19.21
    \xv WOnk nematog, mat nuttenantam∞ woh kuttass∞kinneáont,...
    \xe Moreover, brethren, I would not that ye should be ignorant,...
    \so 1 Cor.10.1
    \nt +

    |ne anantamup| (pret.) `that which I thought'    Is.14.24
    \nt MN: ne anontog
    \ng suppositive |ne anontog| `what he may think, or will; "according to his will"'    Dan.4.35
    (|unantog| `if he permit'    Heb.6.3)

    \se ananumau
    \va unnanumau
    \nt +
    \va unnánumau
    \va innanumau
    \nt !
    \ps With an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he wills to (him), he permits (him)'; +(Paul) `would (not) have'; `to give sb leave (to do sth), to suffer sb (to do sth)'
    \xv ..., newutche matta kittinnanumunoh mussin.
    \xe ...: therefore suffered I thee not to touch her.
    \so Gen.20.6
    \ng 1->2 negative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche Jehovah sekeneam nuttenanumukqunat k∞weechaununnaóut.
    \xe ...: for the Lord refuseth to give me leave to go with you.
    \so Num.22.13
    \ng proleptic object with t-subordinative, 1->2p
    \nt +
    \xv Neit Joshua wuttinànumuh missinninnuh monchek, nishnoh wosketomp ut wutohtoonganit.
    \xe So Joshua let the people depart, every man unto his inheritance.
    \so Josh.24.28
    \ng AV infinitive => direct speech, imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ONK papaume wadchukish Nashauanitt∞ut, nematog, matta kuttinánumun∞mw∞ kutass∞kinneáont.
    \xe Now concerning spiritual gifts, brethren, I would not have you ignorant.
    \so 1 Cor.12.1
    \nt +

    \nt MN: ..., LORD unnanumit.
    \ng suppositive |..., LORD unnanumit.| `if the Lord permit.'    1 Cor.16.7√

    \se anantam∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `thought, purpose, opinion, will'

    \se ananumaonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `permission, will or thought' (in relation to an an. obj.)
    \so Job 12.5
    rmk See under |unnanumau|, T+.171b.
    \nt +

    \se anantamwe
    \va anantam∞e
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `willingly'
    \so Judg.5.2

\nt This is the intens. or augment. form of the primary verb |antam| `he is mind-ed, has in mind' (with an an. obj. |anumau|), which is not, perhaps, found separately in Eliot, but is the base of all verbs of mental action and of emotion. Maillard (Micmac Gr. 91) distinguishes this class of verbs as "personnels mentaux: ces verbes designent [sic] les différentes modifications de l'esprit, de la pensée, ou de l'âme."


[Narragansett [xnt] |nteántam| or |ntunnántam| `I think'; |nteatámmowonck| `my thought or opinion'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nederérdam| `je pense'.
Chip. |inendam| `he thinks'; |kashkendam| `he is sad', etc.    Bar.; |nindenáindum| `I think'    J.
Cree |itéthetum| `he thinks (it)'; |itéthe-mayoo| `he so thinks (him)'; |méthoéthetum| `he well thinks, approves, etc.'
Delaware [del] |elendam| `indicates a disposition of the mind'; |niw-elendam| `I am sad'    Zeisb.]


\lx anaquabit
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 9
\ps as a prep. / "AI+O" in some sense, conjunct tantum
    \dv initial |un-aqu-| (assuming change and relative root) + |appe-| AI `to be, sit'; despite the temptation, I see no way of connecting |-aqu-| with the incorporated noun root |-ehqu-| "eye, face".
    \nt +
\ge `before, in the presence of (him)', +`before sb's face, in the sight of sb'
\so Ex.8.20; 9.13; Lk.21.36
\nt This is a verb in the suppositive (its regular indicat. pres. would be |anaquappu|), and varies in number and person with its subject, which is the object of the preposition by which we must translate the verb:

    \xv ... kuttinnum miskom kitteamonteanitteaonk ut anaquabean...
    \xe ..., thy servant hath found grace in thy sight,...
    \so Gen.19.19
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    |nunneepoh anaquabean| (2d sing.) `I stand before thee'    Ex.17.6
    | -- anaquabit| (3d sing.) ` -- before him'
    \xv ... ussenat wutusseongan∞, ut mukkinneaekomukqut, anaquabit Aaron kah anâquabenit wunnaumonuh,...
    \xe ...to do their service in the tabernacle of the congregation before Aaron, and before his sons:...
    \so Num.8.22
    \ng agreement in obviation
    \nt +
    | -- anaquabeóg| (2d pl.) ` -- before you'
    | -- anaquabhettit| (3d pl.) ` -- before them'    Deut.9.2
    \xv Noh woh sohhog ut anaquabhettit, kah woh petutteau ut anaquabenit:...
    \xe Which may go out before them, and which may go in before them,...
    \so Num.27.17
    \ng switch of obviation
    \nt +
    |neepau anaquabeh| (1st sing.) `he stands before me'    Ps.139.5

    In some dialects this prepositive verb is further varied with the position or attitude of its subject -- before him when sitting, when standing, when lying down, etc. (see Baraga, Otchipwe Gr., 469 [+1878: 338, no. 4 "{Before}", with distinct initial in a similar conjunct construction]); but if such distinction was made in the Massachusetts language it escaped Eliot's observation.

\dv |anaquappu| is formed of |appu| (`he remains, he is') and |onkoue| (`beyond, in advance of') or some nearly related word.

    \se anaquohtag
    \ps With inan. subj. / II
    \ge `before it'
    \dv (suppos. of |anaquohteau|)
    \so Ex.19.2; Judg.20.28
    \xv ... wutohteakonit Machpelah, ne anaquohtag Mamre,...
    \xe ... in the field of Machpelah, which is before Mamre,...
    \so Gen.49.30
    \nt +

    \xv Nuppomsham anaquohtagwek.
    \xe I walked before his house,
    \so C.111/235

\cf arquabi
\so Quir.     Pier


\lx anaquesuonk
\va ónoq-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 9
\ps vbl. n.
\ge `a joining, a joint'
\so Eph.4.16
    pl. |-ongash|    Cant.7.1


\lx anaquoshau
\va anaquaushau
\va anaquashau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 9
    \nt +
\ps AI+O, transitive initial, conjunct tantum
\ge `to be before sb, to be before sb's face' (motion of the participants implied: "to go along in front of")
\so Gen.24.7,32.17; Ex.13.22,14.19,23.28,29; Josh.3.14; Lk.9.52

    \xv ..., noh pish an∞nau wutangelumoh ut anaquaushaan,...
    \xe ...; he shall send his angel before thee,...
    \so Gen.24.7
    \ng 2->3
    \xv ..., howan ken, kah tunohkutom? kah howane wuttaiheuh anaquoshaan?
    \xe ..., Whose art thou? and whither goest thou? and whose are these before thee?
    \so Gen.32.17
    \ng 2->3
    \xv .., neyanáhkuhquomaushahettit, nutanakausuongan anaquashai:...
    \xe ... according as the cattle that goeth before me...
    \so Gen.33.14
    \ng 1->3
    \xv ...; kah neepattaquonkane matohqs, onchekompau wutch anaquoshanit, kah neepau uppusquanout.
    \xe ...; and the pillar of the cloud went from before their face, and stood behind them.'    Ex.14.19  { 3
    \so ->3 }
    \xv Kah ann∞nau ann∞naéneuh en anaquoshadt,...
    \xe And sent messengers before his face:...
    \so Lk.9.52
    \ng 3->0


\lx anaqushau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 9
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he trades, traffics'
    \xv ..., kah pish anaqushaumw∞ ut ohkit.
    \xe ..., and ye shall traffic in the land.

    \ng 2p indicative, shared prefix

\lx angel
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 9
    \nt +
\nt Remark: |angels| quite rare, as plural only; in (E0) in column headings; |-angelum-|, as opposed to |-angelsum-|, largely restricted to a small number of books (currently Gen., Num., Mt., Acts, Rev.), though even here not used exclusively.
\ps TA
\ge `angel'
\so common
    \xv nutangelsum
    \xe mine Angel
    \so Ex.23.23
    \xv ... wutangelumoh GOD,
    \xe ... the angel of the Lord...
    \so Acts 5.19
    \xv ... Angels anumungqueog,...
    \xe ... by the disposition of angels,...
    \so Acts 7.53
    \xv ... nashpe angels...
    \xe by angels
    \so Gal.3.19


\lx anit
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 9
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it exceeds, goes beyond, is more than' { This is misplaced, the two roots being quite distinct. }
\ge `it rots, corrupts'; `to be corrupt, rotten, to stink'
\dv |ánue|, `more, beyond', with the formative of verbs of growth: `it goes beyond, exceeds (the good or normal)'.
    \xv Kah ohke anit ut anaquabit GOD:...
    \xe The earth also was corrupt before God,...
    \so Gen.6.11; sim. Gen.6.12
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ∞wadchanumunneau en mohtompog ne ánont Moses, kah matta anetun∞, kah matta ∞hquán∞.
    \xe And they laid it up till the morning, as Moses bade: and it did not stink, neither was there any worm therein.
    \so Ex.16.24
    \ng 0 negative indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh ayim∞k anit mehtugq kah ummechummeuonk anit,...
    \xe ...; or else make the tree corrupt, and his fruit corrupt:...
    \so Mt.12.33
    \nt +
    \xv wuskannem anit ut agwe puhquohkit
    \xe the seed is rotten under the clods
    \so Joel 1.17
    \xv ...: kah nag wuttusseneau tummuhhouónat anittue chetuhquab: qut nenawun mat anitn∞h.
    \xe ... Now they do it to obtain a corruptible crown; but we an incorruptible.
    \so 1 Cor.9.25
    \ng apparently not conjunct
    \nt +

    suppos.inan. |ne aneuk| `a corrupt thing'    Mal.1.14
    `rottenness'    Prov.12.4
    \xv Newutche yeu woh aneuk mos hogqueheau mat woh ánittin∞g,...
    \xe For this corruptible must put on incorruption,...
    \so 1 Cor.15.53; similarly 1 Cor.15.54
    \nt +
    \xv Wonk neekeóg mat wutch ahhanneuk wuskannem, qut wutch mat aannitn∞g nashpe wuttinn∞wáonk GOD, ne pamontam∞m∞uk, kah machemohtag.
    \xe Being born again, not of corruptible seed, but of incorruptible, by the word of God, which liveth and abideth for ever.
    \so 1 Pet.1.23
    \ng Form unclear (both editions)--odd variety of change, or of reduplication (in durative sense)? Sim.: 1 Pet.3.4 |aanittin∞g|
    \nt +

    \se aninnu
    \va anunn∞
    \ps with an.subj. / AI
    \ge `he rots' (`stinketh'    Jn.11.39)
    \xv Newutche n∞wahteoh mahche nuppon, aninnowe pish kutáninnumw∞,...
    \xe For I know that after my death ye will utterly corrupt yourselves,...
    \so Deut.31.29
    \ng cognate preverb
    \nt +
    pl. |aninwog| `they are corrupt'    Ps.14.1; Is.50.2


    suppos.an. |noh anit| `he who is rotten or is corrupt; corrupted or putrefied flesh or an. being' (sometimes used by Eliot for |aneuk|, after an inan. substantive, as Prov.10.7)  { syncopated? }

    \se ann∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `decay, rottenness'
    \so Prov.14.30

    \se annun∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `rottenness (of flesh, or an. obj.), putrefaction'
    \so Lev. 22.25; Job 17.14

    suppos.pass. (inan. subj.) |anunnumuk| `when it is rotted, rottenness'    Hos.5.12

\nt The primary signification, it will be observed, is `to exceed, to pass beyond'; hence |noh anit|, `he who exceeds or goes beyond (the natural, the common or the normal)' designates any an. being of supernatural, uncommon, or abnormal qualities or powers; and with the indef. prefix instead of the demonstrative, |m'anit| (`somebody on something that exceeds'), became the name of supernatural being or agency, which is usually translated `God'.

[Delaware [del] |alett| `rotten'; |alúl| AI `rot, be rotten' Zeisb.;O'M.28b.]

[NOTE--It was the intention of the compiler to rewrite the foregoing definition.]

    [Lp.A |alet| `pourri'    D.23.]
    \nt +

\et H.430 *aΘetwi II `it stinks, is rotten, decayed'; S., no 172, p.374, with II reflexes in Massachusett.

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 10
\ps II
\ge `it is a help or support'
\dv |-uhk| marking continuance or permanence
\ps as n. `a support, "a stay"'    1 K.10.19.

\lx anittue
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 10
\ps adj.
\ge `corrupted'
\so Ps.35.5; Prov.25.26
    pl. |-tash|
    \xv ...: kah nag wuttusseneau tummuhhouónat anittue chetuhquab: qut nenawun mat anitn∞h.
    \xe .... Now they do it to obtain a corruptible crown; but we an incorruptible.
    \so 1 Cor.9.25
    \nt +
\cf ánin

\lx annóosu
\va ann∞osu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 10
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he hopes, trusts, is hopeful'
\so 1 Cor.13.7
    (|noh annoâsu|    C.)
    \xv nutannóus
    \xe I hope
    \so 2 Cor.1.13

    \nt MN: annóosit
    \ng suppositive |annóosit| `when, or if, he hopes'

    \se !|annoossoowahhau| (M)
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to make sb hope'
    \so Ps.22.9(M)
    \xv ...; kuttannoossoowahhip, nonontamon wussogkodtunkash noohkas.
    \xe ...; thou didst make me hope, when I was upon my mothers breasts.
    \so Ps.22.9(M)
    \ng 2->1 preterite indicative

    \se annóosuonk
    \va annóous-
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI
    \ge `hoping; hope, expectation of good'
    \so Rom.8.24; Ps.62.5
    \xv ... kutayimaiup ánoósuonk, n∞nont ut wussogkodtunganit nokas.
    \xe ...; thou didst make me hope, when I was upon my mothers breasts.
    \so Ps.22.9


\lx ann∞
\va unnau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 10
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `he says to, tells (him)'
\cf unnau
\cf n∞ónat
    Pret. |an∞op|, |an∞wop| `he said to him, he told him'

    \xv ne ánun
    \xe what is commanded (said)
    \so Ex.34.11
    \nt MN: noh anont
    \ng Suppositive |noh anont| `he who tells or says to, "commands", or directs'
    |toh anont| `what he commands (may command), "his commandment"    Prov.8.29

    \se annúmau
    \va annumau
    \nt +
    \ps With inan.obj. / TA+O
    \ge `he gives (command) to, commands (it) to (him)'
\nt In the verse last cited three forms of the primary verb occur in the suppositive: |anúmmaont| `when he gave (his decree) to'; |toh anont| `his commandment', i.e. `his commanding, word-giving'; |án∞wodt| `"when he appoints", commands (it)'.
    Eliot's use of the several forms and derivatives of this verb does not enable us to distinguish them accurately. The primary signification of the root is, perhaps, `to send (cf. |ann∞tam|, |ann∞nau|); to commission, to direct, to tell'.


[Cf. Abn. |neda`rañ| `j'ai coutume de lui dire'; |ar8s| `flèche' [i.e. a missile].
Delaware [del] |allumsi| `go along'; |alluns| `arrow, bullet'; |allummahen| `to throw'; |ptukaluns| `[round missile], bullet'    Zeisb.]


\lx ann∞nau
\va -N-
\ve ; cf. etymology
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
    \nt Remark: There is occasional evidence of what is perhaps confusion of this stem with that of |unn∞wau|.
    \nt +
\ps v.t.an. / TA(+O), applicative final
\twn |ann∞tam|
\nt G&B.604
\ge `he commands, directs (him)'; +`to appoint sb, bid sb'
    |..., newutche ne nuttin ann∞nuttean.| ...: for so I am commanded.'    Lev.8.35  { X->1 indicative }
    \nt +
    \xv nutann∞n
    \xe I command or tell (them)
    \so 1 K.17.4
    \xv Kah kutann∞numun neemattinnonog ... woh kutamohkauonanout nishnoh ∞wemattin noh nanwiyeue pamushadt,...
    \xe Now we command you, brethren, ..., that ye withdraw yourselves from every brother that walketh disorderly,...
    \so 2 Thess.3.6
    \ng 1p->2p indicative, syncopated
    \nt +

    \xv ..., GOD ne anunn∞nomp.
    \xe ..., as God had commanded him.'    Gen.21.4  { changed |un-| + 3->3
    \so +_adv_ preterite conjunct }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nosweetash kuttinninn∞wonk neyan unn∞nun
    \xe ..., obey my voice, according to that which I command thee.
    \so Gen.27.8
    \ng 1->2+_0_ participle, initial syllable aberrant?
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nummahche ussen neyan ann∞sean,...
    \xe ...; I have done according as thou badest me:...
    \so Gen.27.19
    \ng 2->1+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Ne Jehovah anan∞nont Mosesoh, ne Aaron wuttin wadchanumun ut anaquohtag wauwaonk, wutche wadchanumunat.
    \xe As the Lord commanded Moses, so Aaron laid it up before the Testimony, to be kept.'    Ex.16.34 { relative root initial/preverb with change, 3->3
    \so +_adv_ conjunct }
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah nag sephausuog anaquabit Jehovah penowe n∞teau, ne matta ánunn∞nunk.
    \xe ..., and [they] offered strange fire before the Lord, which he commanded them not.'    Lev.10.1  { 3->3
    \so +_?0_ negative participle }
    \nt +
    \nt MN: ne ann∞nog
    \ng suppositive |ne ann∞nog| `that which I command you'    Deut.4.2
    \ps 0
    \xv ..., kah wuttinn∞waongash, nish ann∞nonish yeu kesukok,...
    \xe ..., and his commandments, which I command thee this day,...
    \so Deut.4.40
    \ng 1->2+_0p_; presumably syncopated |-un-ôn-|
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche pish kenanauwehteau wuttinn∞waongash kah kuhk∞waongash, kah wussittum∞ongash, nish an∞nonch yeu kesukod, nish ussenat.
    \xe Thou shalt therefore keep the commandments, and the statutes, and the judgments, which I command thee this day, to do them.
    \so Deut.7.11
    \ng thus E1&2; clearly for |an∞noneh|, i.e. 1->2+_0p_, with variant 0p participial suffix (G&B 549); presumably syncopated |-un-ôn-|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nag teanuk qushkeog wutch mayut, ne ann∞nog,...
    \xe ...; they are quickly turned aside out of the way which I commanded them;...
    \so Deut.9.12
    \ng 1->3+_0_
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish kuttit ussen wame ne ánann∞nun.
    \xe ..., and there thou shalt do all that I command thee.
    \so Deut.12.14
    \ng 1->2+_0_
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Wame ne anunn∞seog nutussenan, kah uttoh an moncheaheaog, nutónan.
    \xe ...All that thou commandest us we will do, and whithersoever thou sendest us, we will go.
    \so Josh.1.16
    \ng 2->1p+_0_
    \nt +
    \xv ... woh naneeswe kutussenaóash, kah pish wonk kutussenaóash nish an∞nunógísh.
    \xe ..., that ye both do and will do the things which we command you.
    \so 2 Thess.3.4
    \ng 1p->2p+_0_
    \nt +

    \xv Pharaoh ussitch, kah ann∞nonch piahquttumunutche ne ohkit,...
    \xe Let Pharaoh do this, and let him appoint officers over the land,...'    Gen.41.34  { 3->3
    \so imperative }
    \nt +

\ge `he hires, employs (him)'
    \xv ..., newutche wunnamuhkut mahche kutann∞sh ken wutche nunnaumon ummandraksumoh,...
    \xe ...; for surely I have hired thee with my son's mandrakes. ...
    \so Gen.30.16
    \ng 1->2; (E0&E1): |kutann∞nsh|
    \nt +
    \xv nutann∞nuk
    \xe he hires me
    \so Judg.18.4

    \nt MN: noh ann∞nont
    \ng suppositive |noh ann∞nont| `he who hires'    Mt.20.1
    suppos. pass. |ann∞nit| `when he is hired'    Neh.6.13

\ge `he sends (him)'
\so Ex.24.5
    \xv ..., kah Jehovah nuttann∞nukqun nuppaguatauunanonut.
    \xe ...: and the LORD hath sent us to destroy it.
    \so Gen.19.13
    \ng 3->1p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ann∞nau Judahhoh negonáe onk nagum, en Josephut,...
    \xe And he sent Judah before him unto Joseph,...'    Gen.45.28  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv Kusseh, nuttann∞n noh ann∞nog anaquabean,...
    \xe Behold, I send my messenger before thy face,...
    \so Mk.1.2
    \ng 1->3 indicative; 1->_3_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Nemehkuh yeuyeu matta kenaau kuttann∞s∞mw∞ yeu pajeh, qut GOD,...
    \xe So now it was not you that sent me hither, but God:...
    \so Gen.45.8
    \ng 2p->1 negative
    \nt +

    \xv ... Wut∞shin noh an∞sit,...
    \xe ... the Father which sent me,...
    \so Jn.12.49
    \ng _3_->1 participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh matta an∞nit, aneuukkénaumóou neh an∞nukqutcheh.
    \xe ...; neither he that is sent greater than he that sent him.
    \so Jn.13.16
    \nt +

    \xv Ann∞n∞k pasuk keenaau,...
    \xe Send one of you,...
    \so Gen.42.16
    \ng 2p->3 imperative
    \nt +
    imperat. 2d + 1st pers. { |ann∞neh| `send me' } `send thou to me'    Is.6.8  { 2->1 imperative }
    \xv N∞sh Abraham, monanumeh, kah ann∞s Lazarus,...
    \xe Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus,...
    \so Lk.16.24
    \ng 2->3 imperative
    \nt +

    \se ann∞[n]áen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `one who serves for hire' { to gloss 2 }
    \so Ex.12.45
    \ge `one sent, a messenger' { to gloss 3 }; +`apostle'
    \so Prov.17.11
    \xv ..., kusseh, nutann∞n nutann∞naeninneum anaquabean,...
    \xe ..., Behold, I send my messenger before thy face,...
    \so Mt.11.10
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wutann∞naéneumoh quashkehettit, wuttinnoneau wame ne asehettit,...
    \xe And the apostles, when they were returned, told him all that they had done.
    \so Lk.9.10
    \nt +

    \se an∞nnuwaen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a commander' { to gloss 1 }
    \so Is.55.4

[Narragansett [xnt] |anóce| (= |ann∞'s|) `hire him'; |kutann∞nsh| `hire you'.]

\et H.453-454 (& 437-447?) *aΘwiΘe∙wa TA `order'
