\lx ann∞tam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
\ps v.t.inan. / TI1a
\twn |ann∞nau|
\ge `he sends (it)'
\so Lam.1.13
    \xv Ne aséhettit wuttinann∞teamunneau Eldersut nashpe wunnutcheganit Barnabas kah Saul.
    \xe Which also they did, and sent it to the elders by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.
    \so Acts 11.30
    \nt +

    imper. 2d pl. |-tam∞k|, |-team∞k| `send you'    2 Sam.17.16

    \se -team∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a sending, a command'
    \so 2 Jn.4


\lx ann∞team∞
\va ann∞hteam∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv |an∞N-| + indefinite (animate) object final |-t^yá-|, G&B item 14, 580: "A longer form |-t^eámwi-| is used with verbs that involve speaking.", this verb being cited. (The state of affairs in Menominee appears to be different: see B.1962, 15.18-35, esp. 15.24.)
\ge `to command, send', sometimes with the relative root |unn-| as initial(-like), indicating the content of the command (so that the verb acts as if it is a transitive taking a object denoting that content).
    \xv ..., neit nutan∞team, kah pish kenemskont na wutche,...
    \xe ...: then I will send, and fetch thee from thence:...
    \so Gen.27.45
    \ng 1 indicative
    \xv Neit sephausuaen pish ann∞team∞, kutchissittauunat ne ápit enninneáonk,...
    \xe Then the priest shall command that they wash the thing wherein the plague is,...
    \so Lev.13.54
    \ng 3 indicative
    |Newajeh Adonibezek Jerusaleme ketass∞t, ann∞teamo en Hohamut Hebrone ketass∞t,..., n∞wau.| (E1&2) `Wherefore Adonizedec king of Jerusalem sent unto Hoham king of Hebron, ..., saying,'    Josh.10.3  { 3 indicative }

    \xv Kah monchit kah wadtinneumuhkauont onkatogeh manitt∞h,..., ne matta anann∞hteam∞.
    \xe And hath gone and served other gods,..., which I have not commanded;
    \so Deut.17.3
    \ng |an-|, changed relative root |uN-|, presumably for the propositional antecedent
    \xv Kah wuttinouh Jesus nean ann∞teamwit, kah wuttenanumóuh né nushash.
    \xe And they said unto them even as Jesus had commanded: and they let them go.
    \so Mk.11.6
    \xv Kah wuttinneumun n∞wau, LORD, mahche n nih, neyan ann∞teamwean, kah asq mohchi.
    \xe And the servant said, Lord, it is done as thou hast commanded, and yet there is room.
    \so Lk.14.22

    \xv Ann∞teamsh en Joppa, wehkom Simon ussowesu Peter,...
    \xe Send therefore to Joppa, and call hither Simon, whose surname is Peter;...
    \so Acts 10.32

\nt Puzzle: What is the following form: |..., newutche ne unan∞hteamuneah.| `..., : for so I am commanded.' Lev.10.13 (1&2)?? (C.f. the straightforward version of the same text at Lev.8.35: |..., newutche ne nuttin ann∞nuttean.|, X->1+0). It is hard to see how an indefinite object form could be a direct translation of a form with a first person logical object, so perhaps it represents "so it is commanded", or the like.


\lx annúmau
\va annumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `he gives word to, commands (him)'

    \xv anakausuonk ne anúmauont
    \xe the task which he (suppos.) giveth (to them) to do
    \so Eccles.3.10
    \xv anúmaont
    \xe when he gives (to the sea) his decree
    \so Prov.8.29
\cf ann∞
\cf aninnum
\ge `he helps, assists (him)'
    \xv wutannúmaoh
    \xe he helped them
    \so Acts 18.27
    \xv kutannumunkqun
    \xe he helps us
    \so 1 Sam.7.12
\nt Research needed: It must be suspected that this is merely a syncopated form of |aninnummauau| (q.v.), cited in a specialized sense. More investigation required.


\lx annún
\va annin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
\ps v.t. / AI+O + locative?
\ge `he lays hold of, puts hands on, seizes'

    \se annu
    \va annunau
    \nt !
    \ps with an.obj. / TA

\nt In either form the verb signifies `to take hold of an an. object'; in the inan. form, `to seize (him) by a part, a limb, the dress, etc.' (inan. obj.):
    \xv wutannuh wunnutcheganit
    \xe he took her by the hand
    \so Mk.1.31; +Gen.39.12
    \xv Kah wunnutcheganit wutannunoh nunksquau, & wuttinuh. ...
    \xe And he took the damsel by the hand, and said unto her,...
    \so Mk.5.41
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kuttanneh nuttinohkóunit.
    \xe ...: thou hast holden me by my right hand.
    \so Ps.73.23√; (M): |kuttaninnip|
    \xv wuttannuh wusseetut
    \xe she caught him by the feet
    \so 2 K.4.27√


    \nt MN: noh anúmwoh annunont wehtauogut
    \ng suppositive |noh anúmwoh annunont wehtauogut| `he who a dog takes by his ears'    Prov.26.17
    \ng 3'->3, theme 1?
    \xv ..., kah ummittamwussoh pasuk pas∞tshau pohquohwhunont wessukeh wutch wunnutcheganit noh togkomont, kah summagunuk wunnutcheg kah aninnont ukkosuonganit.
    \xe ..., and the wife of the one draweth near for to deliver her husband out of the hand of him that smiteth him, and putteth forth her hand, and taketh him by the secrets:
    \so Deut.25.11
    \nt +
    \xv Kah neemunau peissesoh, kah upponuh nag wunnashaúmuóut: kah ánunont wúhpitténit, wuttinuh,
    \xe And he took a child, and set him in the midst of them: and when he had taken him in his arms, he said unto them,
    \so Mk.9.36
    \nt +

    imperat. |anin wussukqunat| `take (him) by the tail'    Ex.4.4

\lx anógqs
\va anogqs
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
\ps n.an. / NA
\ge `a star'
\so El.Gr.9; 1 Cor.15.41; Job 22.12
    |Anogqs|, {A Star}. |Anogqsog|.    El.Gr.9/256
    \nt +
    pl. |anogqsog|
    |mishánogkus| [|mishe anogqs| `great star'] `the morning or day star'    2 Pet.1.19
    \xv Kah pish nuttinnunnumau mishanogqussoh.
    \xe And I will give him the morning star.
    \so Rev.2.28
    \nt +

\nt For |anógqussu| `he appears, shows himself'. In distinction from the sun, which rises or comes forth (|paspishau|) and sets (goes away, |wayau|), the stars appear in their places when the absence of the sun and moon makes them visible.

[Narragansett [xnt] |anóckqus|, pl. |anócksuck|; |mishánnock| `morning star'.
Chip. |anáng|    Bar.; (St Mary's) |an-óong|.
Delaware [del] |aránck|    (Camp.); |alank|    (Zeisb.).
Modern Abn. |al-akws|    K.A.]

\et A.201, H.412 *aΘa∙nkwa NA `star'; see G.1965, no.5, 211ab for a discussion of the quantity of the second vowel.


\lx anohke

    (|aunohke|    C.)

\lx aninnohsu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Forms are included here that must be assumed to have undergone syncope of the second syllable. This stem does not occur in the Mayhew corpus, the equivalent usually being |unashket-|.
\ps AI
\ge `to minister, serve'
\so Num.8.25,26,18.2
    \xv ..., kah matta pish wonk aninnohse. / Qut noh pish áninnohsu kenugke wemadut,...
    \xe ..., and shall serve no more: / But shall minister with their brethren ...
    \so Num.8.25-26
    \xv ...: qut ken, kah kenaumonog weeche ken, pish aninnohsuog anaquohtag wauwaé kommuk.
    \xe ...: but thou and thy sons with thee {shall minister} before the tabernacle of witness.
    \so Num.18.2

    \se aninnohsue
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of service'
    \so Num.4.26
    \xv ...kah wame aninnohsue auwahteaongash,...
    \xe ..., and all the instruments of their service,...
    \so Num.4.26

    \se aninnohsuonk
    \va -suongan-
    \va annohsuonk
    \ps deverbal noun
    \ge `office'
    \so Gen.41.13; Lev.7.35; Num.3.3,4,10; Deut.10.6; Acts 24.27
    \xv ..., neg namwohtomuk wunnutchegan∞óut, sephausue aninnohsuonk ussenat.
    \xe ..., whom he consecrated to minister in the priest's office.
    \so Num.3.3

    \se aninnohsuongane
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of ministry'
    \so Num.4.12; 1 Tim.3.1
    \xv Kah nag pish neemunnumwog wame aninnohsuongane auwohteaongash, nish nashpe aninnumwontamwuhettit ut Sanctuarieut,...
    \xe And they shall take all the instruments of ministry, wherewith they minister in the sanctuary,...
    \so Num.4.12

    \se anninohsuen(in
    \va anohsuen-
    \ps NA, agent noun
    \ge `help, officer'
    \so Gen.2.18,20,37.36,40.2,7; Ex.5.10,15.19; Deut.1.15; Josh.1.10; Mt.5.25; Lk.12.58; Jn.7.32,45,46,18.3,12,18,22,19.6; Acts 19.35
    \xv ..., Matta wunnegenninno wosketomp wunnonsiin, nutayimau aninnohsuénuh nagum ut anaquabit,
    \xe ..., It {is} not good that the man should be alone: I will make him an help meet for him.
    \so Gen.2.18
    \xv ... en Potipharut, wutanohsuéneumoh Pharaoh,...
    \xe ... unto Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh's,...
    \so Gen.37.36
    \xv ..., kah aninnohsuenuog ut kenugke kutchippan∞ongan∞óut.
    \xe ..., and officers among your tribes.
    \so Deut.1.15
    \xv ..., kah wussittumwaenin kuttiss∞unuk aninohsuenuut:...
    \xe ..., and the judge deliver thee to the officer,...
    \so Mt.5.25
    \xv Kah aninnohsuénin quóhtinont missinninnuh,...
    \xe And when the town clerk had appeased the people,...
    \so Acts 19.35

    \se aninnohsuenu
    \ps AI, predicate nominal
    \ge `to be a help, in an office'
    \so Ex.28.1,3,4,29.44,30.30; Deut.33.7
    \xv ..., onk woh n∞wawussúmuk sephám∞wae aninnohsuenûunneat ...
    \xe ..., that he may minister unto me in the priest's office,...
    \so Ex.28.1

    \xv ...: kah ken aninnohsueneush wutch wunnanakontantamhuenumoh.
    \xe ...; and be thou a help to him from his enemies.
    \so Deut.33.7


\lx anóme
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 11
    \ps PreN, ?PreV, to initial |anôm-|, |enôm-|
    \nt +
\ge `(it is) within, it is inside of'
\so Neh.6.10; Ps.122.2
    \xv en anóme
    \xe in the innermost parts of
    \so Prov.26.22
    = |en an∞mut|    Prov.18.8

    suppos. (or locat.?) |anomut| `when it is within or inside'

    \ps `adv. of place'
    \ge `within
    \so El.Gr.21
    |Anomut|, {Within}.    El.Gr.21/268
    (|Poquatchimi@yeu unnommi@yeu.| `Without, within'    C.?31/176; also 109/234.)

    \xv ennom∞tani
    \xe within the city
    \so Gen.18.26
    \nt +
    \xv wuttinnomhog
    \xe the inwards, entrails' (`within his body
    \so )    Lev.1.9

\nt In other dialects the primary meaning of |anóme| is `below', `under'.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |arañmek| `dessous'; |arañma`k8^émek| `sous l'arbre'    R.176/432b.
Chip. |anámaii| or |anám'| `under, underneath, below'    Bar.460 (|pindjaii|, |pindj'| `in, within, inside of').
Delaware [del] |allami|, |-iyey| `therein, in there'    Zeisb.Gr.175.]

\et G.1965, no.6, 211b-212a; A.198; H.399-400 *aΘa∙m(-)


\lx an∞hom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 12
\ps v.t. / AI?
\ge `he sings (a song)'

    \nt MN: -homont
    \ng suppositive |-homont| `when he sings, he singing'    Prov.25.20

    imperat. 2d pl. |an∞hom∞k ... an∞homáonk| `sing ye a song'    Ps.149.1

    \se -homau
    \ps With an.2d obj. / TA+O
    \ge `he sings to (him)'

\cf két∞homom
\dv |an∞| (|ann∞|) `he tells', and |∞m| `he goes on telling, he narrates'.
\et Is there a "strong" form of *eΘ- `thus, thither, that way' i.e. *aΘ- (c.f. H.417ff) which is combined here with the final |-hom-| `sing' (c.f. B.1962, 16.143, p.357, |-ah| `by tool' etc., as TI-O verb "for moving through wind or water, and for entuning or singing")? Levelling from changed forms? The final is also present in |két∞homom|.


\lx an∞hque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 12
\ps a defective or unipersonal verb used as an adverb or auxiliary,
\ge does not admit of exact translation. It signifies, primarily, `to correspond with, to be like in form, degree, extent, duration,' etc.
(cf. |ne-ane| `to be like in kind, of the same kind'.)
\ps As an adv.
\ge it is variously translated `as much as', `as far as', `as large as', `in like manner', etc.
    \ps changed form of |unn∞hque|, relative root, quantity (length, space and time, size)
    \nt +
    \xv ne anoohque ... ne noohque
    \xe as much as, ... so much
    \so Rev.18.7
    \xv noh ne anoohque ussit
    \xe he who so does (`hath so done this deed
    \so 1 Cor.5.3)
    \xv ..: nesahteagk ne an∞hque kishkag wetu nesnehchage ishquanogkod,...
    \xe ..: the length whereof was according to the breadth of the house, twenty cubits,...
    \so 2 Chr.3.8√

    suppos. inan. |ne anukkenuk|, |pasuk ne anukkenuk| `"of one size", one in extent'    1 K.6.25
\cf nogque

[Narragansett [xnt] |tou anúckquaque| `how big?'; |yò anúckquaque| `so far'; dim. |yò anuckquaquêse| `so little way (hence)'; |tounúckquaque| `how far?'
Western Abenaki [abe] |éna8i8i| `avec ressemblance d'une chose à une autre'.]


\lx an∞tau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 12
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), |-ô-| stem
\ge `he revengeth himself, takes revenge'
\so Nah.1.2; +Josh.20.3; C.28/174,72/206
    \xv GOD m∞summuaen, kah Jehovah ann∞tau: Jehovah ann∞tau, kah chenauausu, Jehovah ann∞tauau ayeuhqutcheh,...
    \xe God is jealous, and the LORD revengeth; the LORD revengeth, and is furious; the LORD will take vengeance on his adversaries,...
    \so Nah.1.2
    \nt +
    \xv Kah quoshwehtamwae ann∞tônat wame mat n∞swehtamôonk, ken∞swetam∞ongan∞ mahche nnag.
    \xe And having in a readiness to revenge all disobedience, when your obedience is fulfilled.
    \so 2 Cor.10.6
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah nish pish k∞tushp∞h∞aonganinneaoash wutch noh ann∞tont musqueheonk.
    \xe ...: and they shall be your refuge from the avenger of blood.
    \so Josh.20.3
    \ng _3_->0 participle
    \nt +

    \se an∞tauau
    \ps with an. obj. / TA(+O??), |-aw-| stem
    \nt Remark: This appears to be a simple TA verb, built to the initial(?) |ann∞t-| rather than to a TI stem, hence of a type apparently not recognized by Bloomfield; alternatively, a directive final, which implies an initial |an∞-|, separating this from the AI type, and without any sign of the |-h-| that this implies. Perhaps not (dative) |-aw-| but a long vowel? cf. stem of !|ann∞tauwanshau|.
    \nt +
    \ge `he takes revenge on (him)', +`to render vengeance to sb, take vengeance on sb'
    \so Nah.1.2; +Gen.4.15; Rom.12.19; 2 Thess.1.8
    \xv ..., nutann∞tau ayeuuhkausitcheg, kah nutunkquatau nag sekeneunkqueaneg.
    \xe ...; I will render vengeance to mine enemies, and will reward them that hate me.
    \so Deut.32.41
    \xv Kussinnáut n∞teau, wutann∞tauônat nah mat wahéonegeh Goduh,...
    \xe In flaming fire taking vengeance on them that know not God,...
    \so 2 Thess.1.8
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Toh utt∞che, woi LORD, ..., matta k∞sittum∞, kah kutann∞tóh n∞squeheonganun, neg wodohkitcheg ohkeit?
    \xe ..., How long, O Lord, ..., dost thou not judge and avenge our blood on them that dwell on the earth?
    \so Rev.6.10
    \ng apparently TA+O; spelling? see also Lev.19.18.
    \nt +

    \xv An∞tau Midianitsog wutan∞taong[a]n∞ wunnaumonuh Israel,...
    \xe Avenge the children of Israel of the Midianites:...
    \so Num.31.2
    \ng Hebrew with cognate object
    \nt +

    \se an∞táonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `revenge'
    \so 2 Cor.7.11, +Num.31.2,3
    \xv ..., Ann∞tâonk nuttaihe, & neen nutann∞tau, n∞wau LORD.
    \xe ..., Vengeance is mine; I will repay, saith the Lord.
    \so Rom.12.19
    \nt +

    \se !|ann∞taittue|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \dv ?to |an∞tauau|, with ?reciprocal final equivalent to passive
    \ge `vengeance of'
    \so Jude 7
    \xv ..., onkapunnahettit ann∞táittue micheme n∞teau.
    \xe ..., suffering the vengeance of eternal fire.
    \so Jude 7


\lx Ntannôtam.
\va Kuttannótous.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 12
    \nt +
Western Abenaki [abe] |nedar8da| `Je me venge', |ar8dañ| 3., |nedar8'da8añ| `de lui', |nedar8da8é8añ| `p'r lui', |nedared8añdamen| `Je me venge de cela'    R.496/540b-541a.

\lx ánue
\va anue
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 12
\ps adv.; the sign of the comparative degree; / PreV, initial
    \nt Remark: There are occasional indications that like |wech(e)-| it may condition the use of the consociative final |-m-|, e.g. ?Deut.17.20, Num.24.7, Josh.24.31, 1 Sam.9.2, 1 Cor.1.25, ?2 Cor.7.13, 1 Tim.5.8

    \xe (it is) better
    \so Mt.18.8, 9

    \xv ... GOD, noh ánue ménuhkesutog yeush unninneáongash ...
    \xe ... God, which hath power over these plagues:...
    \so Rev.16.9
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nisahtepomantamwéhetiit Eldersog neg anue pomantam∞moncheg Joshuahoh,...
    \xe ..., and all the days of the elders that overlived Joshua,...'    Josh.24.31  { _3p_->3
    \so participle to TA with consociative final }
    \nt +

[Quiripi [qyp] |arwe|, |arche|, |artche|    Pier.; |arche mêsï| `the greatest'    p.40; |arche| `chiefly'    p.40; in compos. |arwe|, |arwenúguot| `more noble; |arwenúngesee| `more excellent'    p.10; |arwe-kíttamanchâsko| `most merciful'    p.41.

    \nt +

\lx ánuunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 13
    \nt +
\ps TA
\twn |ánuunum|
\dv |ánu-| `more' + |-un-| `by hand'
\ge `to have power over sb', converse of `to be subject to sb'
\so Rev.13.7
    \xv ...: kah menuhkesuonk aninnumauop wutánuunónat wame auwadtuongash, kah unnont∞waongash kah wutohtimoneash.
    \xe ...: and power was given him over all kindreds, and tongues, and nations.
    \so Rev.13.7
    \xv ...: neg ne aniitcheg nahohtoeu nupp∞onk matta nah wutánuunuh ...
    \xe ...: on such the second death hath no power,...
    \so Rev.20.6
\nt Follow up needed: Lk.10.17, 10.20 `be subject to sb' puzzling: converse/conjunct for no obvious reason? (deriv. of |agwe-|, the calque |agwap-|, normally used?)

\lx anwohsimau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps TA, causative to final |-sin-|, `lay'

    \xe ..., when the Lord thy God hath given thee rest from all thine enemies round about,...

    \xv Newutche Jesus noh anwohsiumóus, neit matta woh missohwhon ompetak, onkatog kesukódtut.
    \xe For if Jesus had given them rest, then would he not afterward have spoken of another day.
    \so Heb.4.8

    [|Nuttannu@wossumweh nuhhog.| `I rest myself'    C. (bad)] { T's comment in parentheses (to C.49?/189) presumably because C.'s gloss is in fact `I ease myself' [OED, s.v. 1c "to relieve the bowels"], and the verb is transitive. }


\lx anwôhsin
\va anwohsin
\va anwosin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps v.i. / AI, final |-(h)sin-| `lie'

\so Ex.20.11; 31.17
    \xv Kah GOD onantam nesausuk audtashikquinukok kah ∞t∞wóntamun: newutch neit anwohsin wutch wame wutanakausuonganit, ne GOD kesteunkup kah ayikup.
    \xe And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because that in it he had rested from all his work which God created and made.

    \xv anwosin

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nedaré8éssin, 3. aré8éssin.| `Je me repose, aiant travaillé, v. sine labore'    R.438/521a.
    Cree |A`thoo-ásti-n| `it pause-blow is, it is (become) calm, still.'; |Uywa'stin| `Calm (as sea, etc.)'; |aywâstin| II `the wind ceases; it is calm'; |alwe∙piw| (Moose) `he takes a rest'    Howse 151; Frs.34b; Alb.E.11b; G.1980.98. { Confusion here? |-a∙stin| used of wind, PA *-a∙?Θen, Howse ex. an intruder? }

    \nt ?

\lx appappin
\va ahp-
\va ahpappu
\ve r.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 13
\ps v.i. / headword is deverbal noun to the AI+O verb (P+AI)
\ge `he sits upon (it)';
    \xv wutahpappin
    \xe she sits on it
    \so Lev.15.20
    \ng conjunct form to be expected

    \nt MN: ne appapit
    \ng suppositive |ne appapit| `that whereon he sits'    Lev.15.22,23,26
    \xv ..., ohke passôagkem∞ ne apappéhettit.
    \xe ..., that the ground clave asunder that was under them:
    \so Num.16.31
    \ng i.e. "that they were on"
    \nt +

    \se !|appapuwen|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `saddle'
    \nt Remark: "sadle" is used at Lev.15.9.
    \so Gen.22.3, by abstraction, and etymology

    \se |appappuwunneheau|, |ahp-|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \nt Remark: Despite the ornative sense, this does not fit the closest form of final that Bloomfield lists, the mechanical final, |-hw-, -h-|, which "[a]s a secondary suffix ... is added to nouns" (1962,16.143, p.357). Since the verb here is of TA type, the orthography would normally record the |-w-|, typically in spelling such as |-hwhau|. It looks like a causative, which makes little sense morphologically or semantically.
    \ge `to saddle sb'
    \so Num.22.21; Judg.19.10; 2 Sam.17.23,19.26; 2 K.4.24
    \xv Kah Balaam omohkeu nompoaeu, appappuwunnéheau wutassumoh,...
    \xe And Balaam rose up in the morning, and saddled his ass,...
    \so Num.22.21
    \xv ..., nutahpappuunneh nutassum, onk woh naiyeumuk,...
    \xe ..., I will saddle me an ass, that I may ride thereon,...
    \so 2 Sam.19.26

    \se |appapuwenehteau|, |-ehk-|
    \nt +
    \ps AI+O(?), ?creative final
    \dv The final appears to be in |-ehk-|, which is consonant with the derivation from a noun stem and the ornative sense, but creative verbs normally are intransitive and "mean to make or to gather such-and-such" (B.1962, 15.13, p.276). The direct object will have to be interpreted as the recipient of the saddle.
    \ge `to saddle sb'
    \so Gen.22.3
    \xv Onk Abraham nompoaeu omohkeu, kah appapuwenehteau wutassimoh,...
    \xe And Abraham rose up early in the morning, and saddled his ass,...'    Gen.22.3  { 3->3
    \so absolute }

    \se !|appapuwenehkauau|, |appapuan-|, |-uun-|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final, derived from |appapuwenehk-| AI+O
    \dv This final is probably not the normal collocation |-hk-aw-|, which yields a simple TA verb and does not apply to noun stems. The dative final normally applies to TI stems, but Cuoq explicitly permits it with the creative verbs: Cq.1891, 256-257, 93-94, and examples in Cq. s.v. |MIDJIM|, and others.
    \ge `to saddle sb sb'
    \so 1 K.13.13,23,27

    \xv Kah unnau wunnaumonuh, appapuanuhkah asse, neit wutapappuunuhkauoh assoh ...
    \xe And he said unto his sons, Saddle me the ass. So they saddled him the ass:...'    1 K.13.13  { 2->1+3 imperative (number error, correct in v.27 |appappuunuhkiegk|); 3->3'+3
    \so objective }

\dv Augm. of |appin|.

[Chip. |ahpahbewin| `a saddle'    Sum.
    Algonquian [alg] |Apapiwin| `selle, chaise rembourrée, tapis, coussin, natte', |Apapiwinikazo| `il est sellé, (le cheval) on l'a sellé'    Cq.55b.
    \nt +
Cree |Uspu'piwin| `A saddle, a cushion'    Frs.159b,492b.
Fx. |ahpapi∙ni| `chair, seat'    Fx.L.26.
Muns. |áhp@p∙n| `chair'    G.1982, (103), 28.]

\et G.1982, 4.5, 28; H.507ff. *axp- `on'; 508: *axpapiwa AI `to sit on', 509 *axpapiweni `seat'


\lx appéh
\va ahpéh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 13
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a trap, a snare'
\so Is.8.14; 24.17; Job 18.10
    pl. |-hanog|, |-heonog|    2 Sam.22.6; Job 22.10
    \xv Wadchaneh wutch appéhannit na ponamaihétticheh,...
    \xe Keep me from the snare which they have laid for me,...
    \so Ps.141.9; (M): |ahpehhonut|
    \nt +

    \se ?!|appehhannu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, predicate nominal to |appeh(han)|
    \ge `to be a snare'
    \so Josh.23.13
    \xv ..., qut nag pish appehhannu∞og kah puttahham∞onganu∞og en kuhhogkaout,...
    \xe ...; but they shall be snares and traps unto you,...

    (|n'uppaih| `I wait for him'    Ps.130.5)

[Narragansett [xnt] |apè|; pl. |apèhana| `traps'; |wuskapéhana| `new traps'.

\lx appéhtauau
\va appehtauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 13
    \nt +
\ps TA, directive final, |-ht-aw-| stem; used as de-stemmed final.
\ge `to sit about sb; to be in, be upon, dwell in sb'; commonly inverse, and bearing a converse sense: `to have, be possessed with' (esp. of demons & spirits?); usage does not seem to be quite firm.
\so Gen.41.38, Lk.2.25,40, 7.8,33, Jn.3.36, 5.26,38
    \xv ..., Moncheahennean en pigsut, onk woh nutappehteaóonnonog.
    \xe ..., Send us into the swine, that we may enter into them.
    \so Mk.5.12
    \xv Sunnummatta k∞namptamw∞ neen nutappéhtau Wut∞shimau, & Wut∞shimau nutappéhtunk? ...: qut nashpe Wut∞shimau noh appéhtiit, noh usseu anakausuongash.
    \xe Believest thou not that I am in the Father, and the Father in me? ...: but the Father that dwelleth in me, he doeth the works.
    \so Lk.14.10; Mayhew: |nuttappehtau|, |nuttappehteunk|, |apehtiit|
    \xv Ne kesukok mos k∞wahteaumw∞, nutappéhtauáonk N∞sh, kah kutapéhtaiimw∞, kah kutappéhtauunumw∞.
    \xe At that day ye shall know that I am in my Father, and ye in me, and I in you.
    \so Jn.14.20 ((E1) also, except accent; recte Mayhew 1709: |nuttappehtau N∞sh|; and Eliot Jn.14.10,11)

    \xv ..., nesuog mattannit apehtauoncheh nogskououh sohhamwehettit wutch weenohket,...
    \xe ..., there met him two possessed with devils, coming out of the tombs,...'    Mt.8.28  { 3->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \xv Kah na mo wosketomp ut Synagogut appehtunk nishkeneungqueu nashauanitto, kah mishont∞wau.
    \xe And there was in their synagogue a man with an unclean spirit; and he cried out,
    \so Mk.1.23
    \xv Kah wéìnuhquaeu neh wéinappehtunkqutcheh, kah n∞wau, Nôk nokas kah neematog.
    \xe And he looked round about on them which sat about him, and said, Behold my mother and my brethren!'    Mk.3.34 (with added preverb; see |waéenu| `round about
    \so )
    \xv ..., Nussontimom, kuppaudtoush nunnaumon, noh ápetunkqut mokâket∞g nashauanit.
    \xe ..., Master, I have brought unto thee my son, which hath a dumb spirit;
    \so Mk.9.17
    \xv ..., Yeush kutt∞wongash matta wutohtaóunash appehtunkqut mattannitt∞h,...
    \xe ... These are not the words of him that hath a devil. ...
    \so Jn.10.21
    \xv Newutche nishkeneunkqussitcheg mattanitt∞wog ..., wussohwheetongk∞woh áppetunkquehettiche,...
    \xe For unclean spirits,..., came out of many that were possessed with them:...'    Acts 8.7  { _3
    \so _->3p }
    \xv ..., pauwauog, kutche weéhquetumwog ∞weesuonk Lord Jesus napenahettit nah apetunkqunutche matanitt∞,...
    \xe ..., exorcists, took upon them to call over them which had evil spirits the name of the Lord Jesus,...'    Acts 19.13; see also Mt.8.16  { apparently _3
    \so _->3(p), with |-un-| and lacking |-het-|, cf. Acts 8.7 }

\et H.288 *api∙?tawe∙wa TA `sit near' (gloss of O. form: `dwell in s.o.') i.e. *api- `sit, (be)' + H. p.247 *-i∙?t(aw) `close to'. See B.1962, 16.133, p.355, on directive final: |ape∙qtawεw|, |ape∙qtam| `he sits in relation to him, it, near him, it; he dwells in it'.


\lx appesettukqussin
\va -tukqussun
\va -tukqsin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 13
    \nt Remark: Two adjacent apparently identical entries combined.
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \nt +
\ge `he kneels'; (v.i.) `rest on their knees; to kneel on his knees'
\so 1 K.8.54; 2 Chr.6.13, etc.; +Gen.41.43; Lk.22.41; Acts 20.36,21.5
    \xv ..., wutch wutappesittukqussunn∞waheonat ukkuttukquoh,...
    \xe ... from kneeling on his knees...
    \so 1 K.8.54
    \ng t-subordinative, TA causative stem
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ne quesekompauin, appesetukqussin ut ukkuttukqut ...
    \xe ...: and upon it he stood, and kneeled down upon his knees ...
    \so 2 Chr.6.13
    \ng 3
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wutomahkauoh, utt∞che qussuk woh paudtuhteamuk, kah uppesittukqsun, kah peantam.
    \xe And he was withdrawn from them about a stone's cast, and kneeled down, and prayed.
    \so Lk.22.41
    \xv ..., kah nutappesittukqussunnumun kishketùg, kah nuppeantamúmun.
    \xe ...: and we kneeled down on the shore, and prayed.
    \so Acts 21.5
    \nt +

    \xv ..., appesittukqussinuttuh ut anaquabit Jehovah ...
    \xe ..., let us kneel before the Lord our Maker.
    \so Ps.95.6; (M) |appesittukqussunuttuh|
    imperat. 2d pl. |appesetukqussun∞k| `Bow the knee'    Gen.41.43√

    \se +heuh
    \ps caus. / TA, to a distinct, unidentifed stem
    \ge `he made them kneel'
    \so Gen.24.11
    \xv Kah ukkamelsumoh uppesitúkqussumheuh ut poquadchu-∞tanit,...
    \xe And he made his camels to kneel down without the city ...'    Gen.24.11(E0,E1&2)  { uncorrected printer
    \so s error for |-sun-| ? }
    \nt +

    \se !|appesetukqussinowehtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, directive final
    \ge `to kneel (down) to sb'
    \so Mt.17.14; Mk.1.40,10.17
    \xv ..., uppeyauonuh wosketomp wutapesittukqussinnowéhtauòh,...
    \xe ..., there came to him a certain man, kneeling down to him,...'    Mt.17.14  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv Kah peyaónuk wutchek∞uh, wunnanompasumukquoh, kah wutappesittukqussunn∞wehtunkquoh,...
    \xe And there came a leper to him, beseeching him, and kneeling down to him,...'    Mk.1.40  { 3
    \so ->3 objective}

\lx áppu
\va appu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 13
\ps v.i. / AI
\twn |ohteau|, II
\ge  `he sits', +`to abide, be (somewhere)'
    \xv nutap
    \xe I sit
    \so Ezek.28.2
    \ng 1 indicative
    pl. |appuog| `they sit'    Ps.119.3  { 3p indicative }
    (|matta apéi| `he is not at home'    Prov.7.19)
    \xv Paguodche matta wutappeineau napannatahsuog sampwesecheg,...
    \xe Peraduenture there shall lacke fiue of the fiftie righteous:...
    \so Gen.18.28
    \ng 3p negative subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut nutapimun poquadchik wompanu.
    \xe ..., we will abide in the street all night.
    \so Gen.19.2
    \ng 1p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Sun yeu wuttapinneau onkatoganeg? ...
    \xe ..., Hast thou here any besides? ...
    \so Gen.19.12
    \ng 3p subordinative
    \nt +

    \nt MN: ken ápean
    \ng suppositive |ken ápean| `thou that sittest'    Jer.22.2
    \xv ..., aphettit ohteakonit,...
    \xe ..., when they were in the field,...
    \so Gen.4.8
    \ng (E0) "th[e]y sitting"; 3p conjunct
    \nt +

    imperat. |apsh|
    \xv ..., Yeu appek weeche asse,...
    \xe ..., Abide ye here with the ass,...
    \so Gen.22.5
    \ng 2p imperative
    pl. |apek|, |apegk|    Gen.22.5; 1 Sam.19.2; Mt.10.11

\ge  `he rests, remains, abides' (Gk. ménei)    Ps.10.8; 1 Jn.3.14

    \nt MN: noh apit
    \ng suppositive |noh apit| `he that abideth, who remains' (Gk. ho mén∞n)    2 Jn.9

\ge `he is, he continues to be, lives, in a state where rest or inactivity is implied'
    \xv Toh kutapin
    \xe Where {art} thou?
    \so Gen.3.9
    \ng 2 subordinative
    \xv na kutappin
    \xe thou art there
    \so Ps.139.8
    \xv Neit nag wuttinóuh, Uttoh wutapen K∞sh? ...
    \xe Then said they unto him, Where is thy Father? ...
    \so Jn.8.19
    \nt +
    \xv matta pish nutáppu
    \xe I shall not be
    \so Job 7.21

    \nt MN: ne apit
    \ng suppositive |ne apit| `where he was'    Ex.20.21
    pl. part. |Kah namohsog neg apitcheg sepuut, pish nupp∞og,...| `And the fish that is in the river shall die,...`    Ex.7.18, 21 { _3p_ participle }
    \xv ... weechaiyeuthettiche nag ápitcheg onkatog kuht∞nogqut,...
    \xe ...their partners, which were in the other ship,....
    \so Lk.5.7
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \xv ... wame neg noh apitcheg otanash ...
    \xe ... all the inhabitants of the cities,...
    \so Gen.19.25
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +
    |apinitcheh|    Gen.50.4  { _3'_ participle }
    \nt +

    imperat. |na apsh| `be there' (`remain there')    Ex.24.12; cf. 1 Sam.19.3

    \se |ôappu|, *|oiapu| (M)
    \nt +
    \ps AI, reduplicated
    \ge `to abide, continue, tarry (in a place)'
    \so Jn.7.9, 10.40(M.)
    \xv ...: noh pohponoowadt, matta pish oiapu anuhquapeh.
    \xe ...: he that telleth lies, shall not tarry in my sight.
    \so Ps.101.7(M)
    |Yeush kutt∞wongash ànont, ash ôappu Galile.| (also thus 1st.ed.) `When he had said these words unto them, he abode still in Galilee.' (in context: "stayed (on) there for a while")    Jn.7.9
    \xv Kah wonk monch∞p onkoue Jordan, uttuh John adt negone kutchissummuohp; kah na wuttôapinneah.
    \xe And went away again beyond Jordan, into the place where John at first baptized; and there he abode.
    \so Jn.10.40(M.)
    \ng obviative subject? (absentative??)
    \xv ..., kah na wuttoiapinneap weche ukkodnehtuhtaenumoh.
    \xe ..., and [he] there continued with his disciples.
    \so Jn.11.54(M.)
    \xv ..., onk howan wanomuhtiit, woh matta oiapeh pohkunnahtu.
    \xe ..., that whosoever believeth on me, should not abide in darkness.
    \so Jn.12.46(M.)

    \nt These would be plausible reflexes of a reduplication of the kind attested elsewhere (so B. 106, p. 122/480; B.1962, 21.20, p.428) as *a∙y-: e.g. (B.1962, ib.) Men. |ape∙w| `he sits', |a∙yapew| `he keeps sitting, remains seated').

    \se !|appewonau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative in |-ôN-|?
    \ge `to abide with sb'
    \so Num.22.8
    \xv ...: kah Moabbe sontimôog appewonaog Balaamoh.
    \xe ...: and the princes of Moab abode with Balaam.
    \so Num.22.8

\nt With |áppu| (`he is at rest, or inactive') cf. |ayeu| (`he is in place, posited'), |ahteau| (`he has himself, or is in possession'; habet, se
habet; see |ahtauunnát|), |ussu| (`he acts, is doing', agit), and |unnnin|, |wut-unniin| (`he is such as, or of the sort of'): the verbs by which Eliot translates, with sufficient accuracy, the substantive verb of existence.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Yo áppitch ewò| `Let him sit there.'; |Mat apeù| `He is not at home'    R.W.34.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |ned'ápi| `je suis assis'; 3d sing. |ap8|.
Cree, |áppu| (1) `he sits'; (2) `he remains'.
Delaware [del] |w'dappin|, |achpin| `he is there in a particular place'; suppos. |epit|    Zeisb.; |achpu| `he is at home'    Zeisb.]

\lx apwóu

"as used by Eliot":
\ps v.t.inan. / AI+O
\ge `he bakes or cooks (bread or other inan. obj.)
    \xv apwóog petukqununk
    \xe they bake bread
    \so (in an oven)    Lev.26.26
    \xv apwau petukqunneg
    \xe he baketh (a cake of) bread
    \so Is.44.15; 2 Sam.13.8
    \xv Kah pish kenemunum pasquag n∞khik kah pish kutappon, nabo neenash petukqunnegash ...
    \xe And thou shalt take fine flour, and bake twelve cakes thereof:...
    \so Lev.24.5√
    \ng 2->0 subordinative

    \xv petukqunungash apwouont
    \xe {his} Baker
    \so Gen.40.1
    \ng _3_->0 participle
    \nt +

\cf app∞su

\nt [Rasles gives for the Abnaki several verbs expressing the mode of preparing animal and vegetal food, all of which, doubtless, had correspondences in the Massachusetts dialect, though these are not to be found in Eliot: e.g. |ned'abipesi| [= |net'apepesin|?] `je fais cuire dans la cendre'; |nebagas`t8n| `je fais cuire' (v.g. de la viande); |nebagassemañk penak| `je fais cuire des poires de terre'; |ned'abamég8^é| `je fais cuire sur les charbons'; |nepesak8^abamég8^é| `-- à la broche'; |nepesa`kg8^abañn| `je grille' (v.g. un auguille, viande); |nedabé8añn| `je grille de la viande, sans broche'; |n8"é8ébap8'`k8^é| `je rôtis, me servant d'une corde'; |ed'ap8'sin|, |nepessag8^a bañn|, etc., `je rôtis avec une broche', etc.; |ned'abañn| `je rôtis' (v.g. un lièvre); `je le fais rôtir', etc.

[Cf. Del. |achpoan| `bread'    Zeisb.]

\et H.301 *apwe∙wa AI `roast', G.1965, no.2, 210b.

\lx ash
\va as
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 15
\ps adv.
\ge `of continuance, still'
\so El.Gr.21
\ps conj.
\ge `while'
\so Mk.5.35; Lk.22.47
    \ge "before, ere"
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: Note the occurrence of (a) a negative verb (regular with the sense "before"--perhaps as "while not (yet)"?) and (b) a reduplicated verb, in an extended durative function, perhaps comparable to the frequent use of a negated reduplicated verb to render "never". The conjunctional uses often show a conjunct verb, and also, strikingly, one that is in the preterite (|-p-|) form.
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut Abraham ash neepau anaquabit Jehovah.
    \xe ...: but Abraham stood yet before the LORD.
    \so Gen.18.22
    \nt +
    \xv Yeush kutt∞wongash ànont, ash ôappu Galile.
    \xe When he had said these words unto them, he abode still in Galilee.
    \so Jn.7.9; (M): |âs ôapeup Galile.|
    \nt +

    \xv ..., onkwoh nukketeahogkou k∞nanumuk ash nanupp∞omp.
    \xe ...; that my soul may bless thee before I die.'    Gen.27.4  { cf. |asquam nonnupooohp| `before I die
    \so , Ntv.Wr. 48.18, p.167, analyzed as 1 subjunctive to a conjunct preterite negative, G&B.566. }
    \nt +
    (|Kah ash pam∞adt kusseh mataánukeg ...| `And while he yet spake, behold a multitude,...'    Lk.22.47√ { initial |pam-| with durative sense? })
    \xv ash pamontam
    \xe while I live
    \so Ps.63.4√; (M): |aspamantam|
    (|as pamontam|    Ps.146.2)
    \xv as yeu apeh
    \xe "while I have any being", while I remain here
    \so Ps.146.2
    \xv Ash aáhtauògkup wequai, wunnamptam∞k ut wequaiyeúut,...
    \xe While ye have the light, believe in the light,...
    \so Jn.12.36; (M): |As aohtauogq wequai|
    \ng reduplicated preterite
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah omohku ash nanóuttùhhetteg,...
    \xe ...: and she rose up before one could know another. ...
    \so Ruth 3.14
    \ng 3p reciprocal, reduplicated negative
    \nt +
    \xv ...; onk woh matta naum∞ nupp∞onk, ash nanauônkup uk-Christumoh GOD.
    \xe ..., that he should not see death, before he had seen the Lord's Christ.'    Lk.2.26  { 3->3
    \so reduplicated negative preterite }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah neit ne kesukokok kenuhkukkonkomw∞, ash waáhteau∞ogkup.
    \xe ..., and so that day come upon you unawares.
    \so Lk.21.34 { 0->2p reduplicated negative preterite }
    \nt +
    \xv Nussontimom, peyaush nunnaumon ash nanupp∞kup.
    \xe Sir, come down ere my child die.
    \so Jn.4.49; (M): |nanupp∞kup|
    \ng reduplicated negative preterite
    \nt +

\cf asq

[Narragansett [xnt] |as pumméwi| `he is not gone by', i.e., `he is yet going'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |echk| `lorsque, pendant que'.
Chip. |ka mashí|, |mashí nánge| `not yet'; |bwa mashi| `before'.
Delaware [del] |es| `yet'    Zeisb.]

\lx ashim
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 15
\ps n.
\ge `a fountain'
\so Cant.4.12
\nt (but elsewhere |tohkekom|). The nearest correspondence with this word found in any dialect of the Algonquian is Abn. |asiem nebi|, `il puise de l'eau'; |äsihi nebi|, `vas quérir, puise, de l'eau, soit du ruisseau, soit à la cabane'; |neda`sihibé|, `je puise de l'eau, fonti vel fluvio.'  Perhaps related to |assam-au| `he gives nourishment to, he provides' (?).

\lx ashqushau
\va asqushau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 15
    \nt +
\ps AI
\ge `to remain'
\so Ex.26.12(?); Josh.21.20

    suppos. part. |ashqshont| `he who remains'
    \xv Kah wutteateashiyeuonk wunnaumonuh Kohath, Levitsog, neg asqushoncheh wunnaumonuh Kohath,...
    \xe And the families of the children of Kohath, the Levites which remained of the children of Kohath,...
    \so Josh.21.20
    \ng The disagreement in obviation between demonstrative link and participle is unclear--regardless of what precisely is taken as the antecedent. Does it relate to the obviative (appositional partitive?) that follows?
    \nt +
    pl. |..., onk woh kenaau wutohtoongan∞ askqshôncheg penuwohteáog,...|`..., that ye might be a possession unto the residue of the heathen,...'    Ezek.36.3,4√

\lx aske
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 16
\ge `(it is) raw, not cooked or prepared for food'
    (|askin|    C.)
    |askeyaus| [|aske-weyaus|] `raw flesh'    1 Sam.2.15
\nt The primary signification is, `not yet' (see |asq|); `not yet mature, green' (whence |muskeht| `grass', etc. ); `not yet fitted to be eaten, raw'.

[Narragansett [xnt] |askùn| `it is raw'.

\et H.351-, S. item 165, 371: *a⌠k- `fresh, green, raw'

\lx ask∞tasq
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 16
\ps n. / NI
    pl. |ask∞tasquash|    Num.11.5
    \nt where it is put for `cucumbers'
    \xv monask∞tasquash
    \xe melons
    \so Num.11.5
    (|m∞nosketa@muk| `cucumbers', `or a raw thing', and |ohhosketa@muk| `watermelon'    C.)
\dv |-usq|, n. generic for `that which is eaten raw or green', with |askeht|, `green' (in color); `green-colored fruit which may be eaten raw or unripe'.
    "In Summer, when their corne is spent, Isquoutersquashes is their best bread, a fruite like a young Pumpion."    Wood's N.E. Prospect, b.2, ch.6 (1865: 76.1-2).√
    "{Squashes}, but more truly |Squontersquashes|, a kind of Mellon, or rather Gourd, ..."    Josselyn Rar.57
    \nt +
\cf asq


[Narragansett [xnt] |Askútasquash| "their Vine aples, which the {English} from them call {Squashes} about the bignesse of Apples of severall colours"    R.W.103/r.101.√

\lx askuhwhau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 16
    \nt +
\ps TA
\twn |askuhhum|
\ge `to watch sb'
\so Ps.37.32, Mt.27.54
    \xv Matchetou askuhwau wunnomwausseaénu, kah ukkodtinneánuh,
    \xe The wicked watcheth the righteous, and seeketh to slay him.
    \so Ps.37.32; (M): |ashkuhwhau|


\lx askuhwheteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 16
\ps v.i./ AI
    \dv indefinite object form to TA |askuhwhau| (cf. t-subordinative form below).
    \nt +
\ge `he keeps watch, watches'; +`to lie in wait'
\so 1 Sam.4.13
    \xv nutaskuhwheteam
    \xe I watch
    \xv Nutaskwéteam,...
    \xe I watch,...
    \so Ps.102.7√; (M): |Nuttashkwheteam|
    \xv ..., kah an∞nau nanauwehteauwunutche squoant askuhwhekonat.
    \xe ..., and commanded the porter to watch.
    \so Mk.13.34
    \nt +

    \xv ..., wutanohsuéneumoh Pharaoh, kah mugquomp askuhwheteadt.
    \xe ..., an officer of Pharaoh's and captain of the guard.
    \so Gen.37.36.
    \nt +

    imper. 2d pl. |-teagk| `watch ye'    Mk.13.35,37
    \xv ..., Jehovah askuhwheteaj nashauwe nen kah ken, chachaubuhteáog.
    \xe ..., The LORD watch between me and thee, when we are absent one from another.
    \so Gen.31.49
    \nt +

    \se -teae
    \va -teaeu
    \nt +
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `of watching' (with |komuk| `a watch tower'); +`of the guard'
    \so Is.21.5
    \xv ..., askuhwekontam∞k askuhweteae komukqut,...
    \xe ..., watch in the watchtower,...
    \so Is.21.5
    \xv wekit askuhwheteaeu mugquomp
    \xe the house of the captain of the guard
    \so Gen.40.3
    \nt +

    \se -teaonk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \ge `watching, a watch'

    \se -teaen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a watchman'
    \so Ps.90.4; Judg.7.19


\lx askuhwhonau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 16
    \nt +
\ps TA, |-ôN-|, applicative stem
\twn |askuhwhontam|
\ge `to look for sb' (i.e. roughly "to be on the lookout for"; as OED s.v. look 15a), `to wait for sb'
\so Mt.24.50
    \xv Matchetowog nutaskwhonuk nunnushhukqunnaôut,...
    \xe The wicked have waited for me to destroy me:...
    \so Ps.119.95; (M): |nuttashkuhwhonukuppaneg|

    \xv Neh wadtinneumit pish peyau kesukodae matta askuhwhonunk, kah ut hower ne matta wahteau∞k.
    \xe The lord of that servant shall come in a day when he looketh not for him, and in an hour that he is not aware of,
    \so Mt.24.50


\lx askuhwhontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 16
    \nt +
\ps TI1a, |-ont-| applicative stem
\twn |askuhwhonau|
\ge `to watch sth'
\so Acts 9.24, 2 Tim.4.5
    \xv Qut Saul wahteón askuhwháonk, kah askuhwhontamwog squontamash kesukodaeu, kah nukkonáeu nushónat.
    \xe But their laying await was known of Saul. And they watched the gates day and night to kill him.
    \so Acts 9.24

    \xv Qut ken askuhwhontash nishnoh teaguas,...
    \xe But watch thou in all things,...
    \so 2 Tim.4.5


\lx askuhwhosu
\va askuhwhôsu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 16
    \nt +
\ps AI, middle reflexive to TA applicative
\ge `to watch'; also for `the guard, the ward'
\so Gen.39.1, Ps.130.6, Acts 12.10
    \xv ... Potiphar wutaninnohsuaeneumoh Pharoh, ummugquomp ut askuhwhôsinneat, Wut-Egyptian,...
    \xe ... Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, captain of the guard, an Egyptian,...
    \so Gen.39.1
    \xv ..., kah wunnamheuh kouéog, kah unnau Peteroh, Sun woh mo k∞weche askuhwhosuom∞mw∞ pasuk hower.
    \xe ..., and findeth them asleep, and saith unto Peter, What, could ye not watch with me one hour?
    \so Mt.26.40

    \xv ..., kusseh nawhutche askuhwhositcheg peyaog ∞tanat,...
    \xe ..., behold, some of the watch came into the city, ...
    \so Mt.28.11

    \se askuhwhosuonk
    \ps N, nom.act.
    \ge `watch'
    \so Ps.141.3, Mt.27.66
    \xv Ponsh askuhwhosuonk, woi Jehovah anaquohtag nutt∞n:...
    \xe Set a watch, O Lord, before my mouth:...
    \so Ps.141.3; (M): |ashkuhwhosuonk|

    \se askuhwosue
    \ps PreN
    \ge `(of the) guard'
    \so Acts 28.16
    |..., noqut pasuk∞wit aninnumauau missinon askuhwhosue mugquompuh.|... `..., the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard:...'    Acts 28.16

\lx as∞kekodteâm∞

    \ng suppositive |noh as∞kekudteamwit| `he who deceives'    Job 12.16
    (|nutass∞kekodteam| `I cheat'    C.)

    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `deceiving, deceit, craft'

    \se -am∞en

    \ge `a deceiver, one who is crafty'

    \xe They did work wilily,...
    \so Josh.9.4
    \xv Kah wuttamontam∞ongash yeu ut muttaohket, kah as∞kekodteamoe weenauweetuongash,...
    \xe And the cares of this world, and the deceitfulness of riches,...

    \xe For false Christs and false prophets shall arise,...

    \xv ..., asuh mat as∞kekomwe nutauwohteamun wuttinn∞wáonk GOD,...
    \xe ..., nor handling the word of God deceitfully,...
    \so 2 Cor.4.2

\lx asq
\va ashq
\va asquam
\va as
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 17
    \ps PreV, Adv, Conj; sometimes takes conjunct clause; verb often in negative form.
    \nt +
\ge `not yet, before that'; +`while ... yet'
\nt G&B.606
\so Jer.1.5; 1 Sam.3.7; Lk.22.34
    \xv ..., newutche ummatcheseongan∞ Amoritog asquam numwohtano.
    \xe ...: for the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet full.
    \so Gen.15.16
    \ng PreV, negative indicative verb
    \nt +
    \xv Qut asquam kaéhetteg wosketompaog...
    \xe But before they lay down, the men of the city,...
    \so Gen.19.4
    \ng negative conjunct verb
    \nt +
    \xv ... (asq pomantog) ...
    \xe ... (while he yet lived) ...
    \so Gen.25.6; (E0&E1) |as|;
    \ng verb not negative, conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ... n∞waog, k∞sh n∞wop asquam napok n∞wau.
    \xe ..., saying, Thy father did command before he died, saying,
    \so Gen.50.16
    \ng verb probably negative
    \nt +
    \xv Peore matcheseunk, sun peasin wutche kenawun ne asquam wutch pahkeseog pajeh yeu kesukok,...
    \xe Is the iniquity of Peor too little for us, from which we are not cleansed until this day,...
    \so Josh.22.17
    \nt +
    \xv Asquam nukkodtantam∞h howan wutteauquash, silver asuh gold, asuh wutogk∞onganash.
    \xe I have coveted no man's silver, or gold, or apparel.
    \so Acts 20.33
    \nt +

\nt Opposed to |ánue| `further, more than'. It is the base of |aske|, *|askun| `it is raw or not prepared for food': |ashkoshki| `green'; |wuske| `young, new'. In composition it serves as the n. generic for whatever is eaten or otherwise used when green or immature; not yet ripe; pl. |asquash|, whence our `squash.'
\cf ask∞tasq

[Narragansett [xnt] |asquam| `not yet'; |as pumméwi| `he is not gone by'; |askùn| `it is raw'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |éskitamek 8a`sa8é| `melon d'eau, qu'on ne fait pas cuire'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |echk| `lorsque, pendant que'; |echk8menahh| `auparavant'.
Cree |numma éskwa| `not yet'.
Delaware [del] |esquo|, |esquota| `not yet'    Zeisb.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |esc8a| `not yet'.]

\so Trumbull 17


\lx asqueyeu∞
\va ashqueyeu∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 17
    \nt +
\ps II
\ge `to remain', i.e. "to be left as a remainder, as the rest of sth"
\so Ps.17.14(M), Ps.76.10

    \xv ...: ne asqueiyeu∞g musquanittuonk ne k∞tammehtean.
    \xe ...: the remainder of wrath shalt thou restrain.
    \so Ps.76.10; (M): |asqueyeuuk|

\et Presumably to (the initial portion of) H. 360 *a⌠kwawi- `after'.


\lx assa[au
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 17
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `to turn back'
    \xv matta nutassa∞p
    \xe I did not turn back
    \so Is.50.5

    \xv ...: qut howan assayit, nukketeahogkou matta wuttapeneauoh.
    \xe ...: but if any man draw back, my soul shall have no pleasure in him.
    \so Heb.10.38
    \nt +
\cf assóúshau

[Chip. |nind ajéta| `I draw (move) backwards'    Bar.]
\et B.93/448, 22 *a⌠yee `back', exs. 85,86; A.180-182; H.365-381


\lx assamau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 17
\ps v.t.an. / TA, often with additional "direct" object (Bloomfield's "substantive attribution", B.1962, ch.22)
\ge `he feeds (him), gives (him) to eat'
\so Ps.136.25
    \xv Kah wonk neekheau weematoh Abel, kah Abel assamau sheepsoh,...
    \xe And she again bare his brother Abel. And Abel was a keeper of sheep,...'    Gen.4.2  { 3->3
    \so absolute; with adoption of the Hebrew reading }
    \nt +
    \xv Neit Jakob assamau Esau petukqunneg kah sóbâheg tuttupuhquamash ...
    \xe Then Jacob gave Esau bread and pottage of lentils;...
    \so Gen.25.34
    \nt +
    \xv ...: yeu nehhean, wonk pish nukqushkem, nutassam, kah nanauehheóog kuffloksumog.
    \xe ...: if thou wilt do this thing for me, I will again feed and keep thy flock.
    \so Gen.30.31
    \nt +
    \xv Kah na kittit assamunun,...
    \xe And there will I nourish thee,...
    \so Gen.45.11
    \ng 1->2 subordinative
    \nt +

    \xv ..., yeuoh noh Anah maskauont mulesoh ut touohkomukqut, assamont wutassumoh ∞shoh Zibeon.
    \xe ...: this was that Anah that found the mules in the wilderness, as he fed the asses of Zibeon his father.'    Gen.36.24  { _3_->3
    \so conjunct }
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d pl. |assam∞k| `feed ye' (the flock)    Zech. 11.4
    2d+1st sing. |assameh| `give me to eat'

    \se |assamâonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, verbal noun
    \ge `mess' [cf. OED s.v., 1a "A serving of food; a course of dishes; a prepared dish ..."]
    \so Gen.43.34
    \xv ..., qut Benjamin assamâonk napanna tahshit tahshinnú∞ neadtahshinnu∞∞g nagog,...
    \xe ...: but Benjamin's mess was five times so much as any of theirs. ...
    \so Gen.43.34

    \se |assammuaen|
    \nt +
    \ps NA, agent noun, probably to indefinite object form of stem
    \ge `herdman'
    \so Gen.13.7
    \xv wutassammuáenumoh wunnetasumoh Abram
    \xe the herdmen of Abram's cattle
    \so Gen.13.7
    \ng 3 possessor obviative; (E0) gloss: "the feeders of his cattle"

    \se sohkomau
    \ps TA
    \ge `he goes on feeding, habitually feeds or provides food for (him)'

    |nussohkomon| (suppos. `when) I feed (the flock)'    Zech.11.7

    imperat. 2d sing. |sohkomm∞s nutshepsemesog| `feed my lambs'    Jn.21.15
\dv |assamau|, with characteristic (|ohk|) of continued action.

[Narragansett [xnt] |assámme| `give me to eat'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |neda`samañ| `Je lui donne à manger'; |neda`sar| `Je donne à manger'.    R.328,330/480b,482a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |eshem8ey| `je donne à manger'.
Cree |ássamayoo| `he gives him food'; |ássamíssoo| `he gives himself food, serves himself'.
    Delaware [del] |xámeew| TA(+O) `feed (s.t. to) s.o.'    O'M.373a.
    \nt +
Miami |ah⌠am-| TA `feed him'    B&C.17a.
Shawnee [sjw] |ha?⌠-|, |(-)h⌠-| (plus |-a-|, |-it-|) `FEEDING, EATING.' |ha?⌠acike| `he does the feeding', |nit⌠ama| `I feed him'    D.-V.436.
WAbn. |samô| TA `feed him'    D.1.444.]

\et H.159: *ah⌠ame∙wa (TA) `feed'; cf. G.1982, fn.90, 32.

\lx assepinum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 17
\ps v.t. / TI1b, manual final |-un-|
\ge `he ties (it) together, binds up'
    \xv ..., nutahhassepenomun shevesash ut ohteakonit,...
    \xe ..., we were binding sheaves in the field,...
    \so Gen.37.7
    \nt +

    imper. 2d pl. |assepin∞k| `bind ye' (the tares, in bundles)    Mt.13.30
= |wushpunnum|, q.v.

    [Algonquian [alg] |ANZ-| `ensemble, par bandes, en groupes, les uns avec les autres', |Anzibij| `lie-les ensemble', |Anzabite| `gerbe'    Cq.54ab.
    \nt +

    EAbn. |nek8tasibis8ar-engliscarnar| `Sheaves of wheat, sprays of flowers'    A.279.
    \nt ?
Fox |asipapito∙wa| `he ties them in a bunch'    Fx.L.287a.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |{r} ansaki, ansahaki| `ensemble', "|ansa, anse, ans8| au commencement d'un mot signifient signie, amas, collection, ensemble, union pour'", |nig8t8, ninch8 ansipira8e|`un, deux paquets, une, deux gerbes &c.'    M.31-32/60ab.]

\et Cf. H.275 *ansahpiΘe∙wa TA `to bind', with a complex final *-ahpiΘ (cf. B.1962, 16.93, 347), as in most of the cognates above; present example: prefinal |-*p-| `tie' with *-en- final.


\lx assishquttauaog

\nt according to Eliot, in Job 38.31; Ames 5, 8; but R. Williams gives |shwishcuttowwáuug| as the name of `the golden metewand', i.e. the three stars in the belt of Orion, and this is more probably correct, the name signifying `three fires', or a long wigwam in which there are three fires; |Shwíshcuttow|    R.W.32,80.√

    \ng 3 indicative

    \ng 3p conjunct


\lx assompamukquodt
\va asamp-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 17
\ps n. / NI, II
\dv (suppos. `where he hides')
\ge `a hiding-place, a place of concealment'
    \xv ..., kah apsh assompamukquodtut,...
    \xe ..., and abide in a secret place,...
    \so 1 Sam.19.2√
    \xv NOh wadohket wuttasompamukquadtoomut anue Quanuhquappit,...
    \xe HE that dwelleth in the secret place of the most high,...
    \so Ps.91.1(M)
    \ng 3 possessor locative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ut assampamukquodtut,...
    \xe ...in secret places...
    \so Jer.23.24√
    `in a den'    Heb.11.38

    \se assumpamukque
    \ps Adj. and adv.

    \se --ayeuonk

    \se !|assompamukquodtuhteau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI+O, ?creative verb
    \ge "to make sb/sth (as) a secret place"
    \so Ps.18.11
    \xv Pohkenai ootahsompamukquatuhkonap:...
    \xe He made darkness his secret place:...
    \so Ps.18.11(M)
    \ng 3->0 preterite ?objective/?subordinative (why |oo-|?
    \nt This analysis takes the verb to act as a transitive, with a (preceding) direct object.

\lx asuhkauau
\va asúkkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 17
\ps v.t.an. / TA, stem in |-aw-|
\ge `he goes after (him), pursues, follows'; +`to be, come after sb'
\so Deut.1.36; Acts 16.17
    \xv monaog wutasukauóuh
    \xe a great multitude followed him
    \so Mt.20.29
    \nt +
    pl. |-kauáog|
    \xv ..., newutche matta mamusse nutasukunk∞og.
    \xe ...; because they have not wholly followed me:
    \so Num.32.11
    \nt +
    \xv Pasuk nutásukonk ánue missuken onk neen;...
    \xe There cometh one mightier than I after me,...
    \so Mk.1.7
    \nt +

    \nt MN: ... noh woh asukiit.
    \ng suppositive |... noh woh asukiit.| `... the man that shall be after me.'    Eccl.2.18√
    \xv kah wame néh asukaoncheg neetasu
    \xe and all that followed the droves'    Gen.32.19  { _3p_->3
    \so }
    \nt +

    imperat. pl. |asuhkiek| `follow me'    1 Cor.4.16

    \se asuhkom
    \va asukom
    \nt !
    \ps inan.subj. { Error for "inan. obj." } / TI1a
    \ge `he goes after (it)'
    \so Rom.8.1; 1 Cor.14.1; 1 Thess.5.15; 2 Tim.2.22; Heb.12.14; 2 Pet.2.15; Jude 7
    pl. |asuhkomwog|    Jer.2.8
    \xv Newutche kenaau nematog kutasukomumw∞ ummoeuwehkomongash; GOD ...
    \xe For ye, brethren, became followers of the churches of God ...
    \so 1 Thess.2.14
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche matta nutasukomômun as∞kekodteamoe nanwonchemowongash,...
    \xe For we have not followed cunningly devised fables,...
    \so 2 Pet.1.16
    \nt +

    \xv Kah missegen matta pish wahteoôun ut ohkit newutche mahshagquodt ne asuhkog:...
    \xe And the plenty shall not be known in the land by reason of that famine following;...
    \so Gen.41.31; (E0&E1) |asukog|
    \nt +
    \xv Naumatue wunnomwayeuonk onk woh pakodche nnih ut kuhhogkanónut, matta asuhkom∞og weyaus, qut asuhkauogkut Nashauanit.
    \xe That the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.
    \so Rom.8.4
    \ng _1p_->0 (negative), _1p_->3 participles
    \nt +

    \xv Womonog ahque asuhkash ne machuk, qut ne wanegik,...
    \xe Beloved, follow not that which is evil, but that which is good. ...
    \so 3 Jn.11
    \nt +

    \se !|asuhkom∞m∞|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a with inan.subj.
    \ge `(for it) to follow it'
    \so 1 Pet.1.11

    \xv ..., negonne wauwámuk wutchequnehtam∞ongash Christ, kah sohsum∞onk asukom∞m∞ug.
    \xe ..., when it testified beforehand the sufferings of Christ, and the glory that should follow.
    \so 1 Pet.1.11

\et Any relationship to A.192,194, H.394,395 (from M.1935) *atem- TA, *atent- TI `overtake', with assibilation of an initial at- before *-ehk- `by body, foot'? (What is the initial of *ata∙we∙wa AI `trade'? *ato∙t- `on'?)


\lx asuhkaue

\so Trumbull 17

    \nt Remark: misplaced lemma, with changed vowel taken as primary.

\lx attumunnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 18
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he receives (it); takes, as his own, from another'; lit. `takes in his hand' (|-nnum|)
\so Gen.26.12
    \xv Kohkukquéan wadchuut, nutattumunumunat hassune tableash,...
    \xe When I was gone up into the mount to receive the tables of stone,...
    \so Deut.9.9
    \nt +
    \xv pish kutattumunumunneau
    \xe ye shall receive [it]
    \so Mt.21.22
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh attumunnuk
    \ng suppositive |noh attumunnuk| `he who receiveth'    Prov.29.4
    pass. inan. |ne attumunnumuk| `that which is received'    2 K.5.26.

    \se |attumunau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \ge `to get, receive sb'
    \xv ..., Nutattumun wosketomp wutch Jehovahut.
    \xe ..., I have gotten a man from the Lord.
    \so Gen.4.1
    \ng 1->3 absolute; (E0) "I have received"
    \xv Kah nag attumunáog wosketómpuh wutche ummeetsuongan∞,...
    \xe And the men took of their victuals,...
    \so Josh.9.14
    \ng "Or, they receiued the men by reason of their victuals." AV marginale
    \xv ... howan ponamauog nunnutchegash woh attumunáu Nashauanitto.
    \xe ..., that on whomsoever I lay hands, he may receive the Holy Ghost.
    \so Acts 8.19
    \xv ..., newutche pish nutattumunuk.
    \xe ...; for he shall receive me.
    \so Ps.49.15; (M): |nuttatumunuk|

    \xv Jason átumúnonche,...
    \xe Whom Jason hath received:...
    \so Acts 17.7

    \xv Noh wonk an∞nog, newutche attumin, noh wutch nehenwonche nunnogkussit.
    \xe Whom I have sent again: thou therefore receive him, that is, mine own bowels:
    \so Philem.12

    \se attumunnumauau
    \ps With an. 2d obj. / TA+O
    \ge `he receives (it) from (him)'

[Cree |oótinum| `he takes it'.]


\lx au
\va âu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 18
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem, with alternation |ô-|/|-á-| (an "umlauting stem", Goddard)
\ge `he goes thither' (to or toward a person or place); +`to journey, go on one's way; to go unto, up (to)'
\nt opposed to |w∞m|, |∞m| `he goes thence' (from a person or place)
\nt G&B.514-515, 549-552, 569, 678, s.v. |o|; G.1981, 37, 73
\so Gen.26.1; 33.17; Ex.4.18
    \xv Onk pish kutom k∞shut...
    \xe And thou shalt go to thy fathers...
    \so Gen.15.15
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... tunoh k∞m, kah tunoh kuttom,...
    \xe ..., whence camest thou? and whither wilt thou go? ...
    \so Gen.16.8
    \ng 2 indicative, distal centrifugal + 2 indicative, distal centripetal
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche uttoh woh nuttin ón n∞shut, kah wusken matta weechógk∞un.
    \xe For how shall I go up to my father, and the lad be not with me?
    \so Gen.44.34
    \ng 1 subordinative
    \nt +
    (|Newutche nasuki matta appéi, noadtit aui.| `For the goodman is not at home, he is gone a long journey:'    Prov.7.19√) { 3 absentative }
    pl. |auog| Hos.7.11
    (`they journeyed' i.e. `went on their way'    Gen.35.5)
    \xv Ann∞non yeu kesukok womononat Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m, ônat ummayut,...
    \xe In that I command thee this day to love the Lord thy God, to walk in his ways,...
    \so Deut.30.16
    \nt +
    \xv Ayeuweh nuttónat kuttinn∞waongane may:...
    \xe Make me to go in the path of thy commandments:...
    \so Ps.119.35
    \ng 1 t-subordinative
    \xv ..., yeuwutch onk yeáên ongkouwe pish nutom Gentils.
    \xe ...: from henceforth I will go unto the Gentiles.
    \so Acts 18.6
    \nt +
    \xv ... matta woh auou Jerusalem.
    \xe ..., that he should not go up to Jerusalem.
    \so Acts 21.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., pokshadtauopanneg wuttahh∞oash wunnaumonuh Israel, matta woh wuttonaóut ohke ...
    \xe ..., they discouraged the heart of the children of Israel, that they should not go into the land ...
    \so Num.32.9
    \nt +
    \xv Paáhettit Mysia, qutchehteaog ón Bythynia,...
    \xe After they were come to Mysia, they assayed to go into Bithynia:...
    \so Acts 16.7
    \ng This example is presumably a subordinative with X-subject (as object clause) to this verb. Acts 16.10 has |ôn| in the same context.
    \nt +
    \xv ... nanompasumóuh matta oón Jerusalem.
    \xe ..., [we] besought him not to go up to Jerusalem.
    \so Acts 21.12
    \nt +

    \nt MN: uttoh ayôi
    \ng suppositive |uttoh ayôi| `whither I (may) go'    Jn.14.4
    (|aôi|    Mass.Ps.)
    \xv may ne áyoi
    \xe the way in which I go
    \so Job 23.10
    (but |aôôn| `as I go, as I went to'    Acts 26.12
    \xv ôôn uttoh woh áoi
    \xe going whither I may go
    \so 2 Sam.15.20
    \xv aúon
    \xe if I go to
    \so Ps.139.8)
    \xv ... en mayut ne aóyomp
    \xe ..., in the way which I went.
    \so Gen.35.3
    \ng reduplicated?
    \nt +
    |..., onk neit aûan ohkekontu:...| "and then return to the gr[.]und", `..., till thou return unto the ground;...'    Gen.3.19(E0)
    \xv toh áyóan
    \xe where thou goest
    \xv ne ayôan
    \xe in thy way, as thou goest
    \so Ex.23.20
    suppos. 3d sing. and part. |ayont| (|aiont|, |aónt|, +|aont|) `when he goes, he going'    Jer.41.6; Jn.12.35; +Gen.42.38; Acts 9.3  { 3 conjunct }
    2d pl. |aôóg| `whither ye go'    Deut.4.5; 11.8; +|ayoóg| Gen.45.24
    3d pl. |ne áahettit| `as they went', `when they were going'    Lk.10.38
    \xv Onk neáahettit, peyaantamwog nippe,...
    \xe And as they went on their way, they came unto a certain water:...
    \so Acts 8.36
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |aush|    Mt.9.6)
    1st pl. |ontuh| (|otuh|, |aonotuh|    Mass.Ps.) `let us go to'
    2d pl. |ongq| `go ye'    Mt.21.2; Josh.2.16;
    |ong|    Acts 23.10; |onkq|    Num.14.25
    \nt +
    \xv ..., uhkon onkatoganit ohteuhkonit mukkupashquonat, asuh ahque yeu wutch monchish,...
    \xe ...? Go not to glean in another field, neither go from hence,...
    \so Ruth 2.8
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish kuppummeneutunkanúhkau missinninnúog, waénu: n∞wash, Nukqussek onk ôhteógk wadchuut,...
    \xe And thou shalt set bounds unto the people round about, saying, Take heed to yourselves, that ye go not up into the mount,...
    \so Ex.19.12
    \ng 2.pl.prohib.
    \nt +

    \se !|aong(an)|, !|auong(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, deverbal
    \ge `going(s), journey(s), way'
    \so Gen.29.1,45.21; Ps.68.24
    \xv NEit Jakob au wutaonganit,...
    \xe THEN Jacob went on his journey,...
    \so Gen.29.1
    \xv Naumwog kutauonganash, woi GOD, wutauonganash num Manitt∞m,...
    \xe They have seen thy goings, O God, even the goings of my God,...
    \so Ps.68.24; (M) |kuttaonkash|, |wu-|

    \se auom∞
    \va aum∞
    \nt +
    \ps with inan. subj. / derived II
    \ge `to go (thither), to turn (hither and thither)'
    \nt +
    \xv ... togkodteg, ne nishnoh aum∞,...
    \xe ... sword which turned every way,...
    \so Gen.3.24
    \ng 0 indicative

    \xv ..., qut matta k∞wahteo∞ uttuh wam∞uk, kah uttoh aom∞uk:...
    \xe ..., but canst not tell whence it [the wind] cometh, and whither it goeth:...
    \so Mass.Ps. Jn.3.8√

\nt From the root of this verb is formed, by prefixing |m'| (preteritive?), |m'ai|, |may|, `a path'; i.e. `where there has been going' (Old Engl. gang).

    |au| or |w∞m| was used when going to or from a place which was spoken of without reference to the locality of the speaker; |peyau| (`he comes') and |monchu| (`he goes') to or from the place of the speaker, or in which the speaker assumes to be; |amáeu|, `he absents himself, takes himself away', without reference to the act of going.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Yò cuttâunan.| `Goe that way.'; |Yò aûnta,| `Let us goe that way.'    R.W.69√
Chip. |nind-ezhah| `I go' (Jn.11.11); pret. |ke ezháh| `he went to' (2.12); suppos. |azháhyon| `whither I go' (8.14;14.4); |azhahwahnan| `whither thou goest' (14.5).
Western Abenaki [abe] |nemañ neda| `je vas là'; |nemañtsi| `je vas, je m'en vas'.
Delaware [del] |eu| or |waeu| `he goes (thither, to a place)'; suppos. |aane| `if I go'; |ate| `if he goes'; part. |eyat| `going'; imperat. |aak| `go ye'.
    Fx. |á-, ä-| [i.e. |a∙-, e∙-|] `go'; |ihe∙wa| `he goes', |neta| ]    Mch.St.621a; Fx.L.45.
    \nt +
Shawnee [sjw] |hee-| (in alternation with |-haa-|, |(-)taa-| `GOING', |heewa, yeehaaci| `he went, where he went'    D-V.456-457.]

\lx aumaûi
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 18
\ge `he is fishing, "is gone to fish"'
    \xv Aumau~og.
    \xe They are fi[i]shing.
    \so R.W.106/r.114
    \xv Ntaûmen.
    \xe I am fishing.

    suppos. pl. |aumachick| (|omácheg|    El.) `they who fish, fishermen'

    \se ómaen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `fishermen'
    \so El.
    pl. |-enuog|


\nt This verb signifies to fish with hook and line. It is not used by Eliot except in the participial |ómacheg|, and the derived n. agent. (Cf. |n∞tamógquam| `I goe a fishing.') Its base is |ôm|: (|aum|) `a fishhook' (Mt.17.27), primarily a verb signifying `he takes fish,' or simply `he takes' (cf. |amàunum|, `he takes, with his hand' etc.), which in the suppos. has |âmaik| (|âmmâg|, |ômmâg|), `when he takes,' and pass. `what is taken'; pl. |âmâgquog|, |ômmagquog|. This suppos. or participial serves in composition as a noun generic for `fish taken by the hook', and (in the singular) for a place of taking fish, `fishing place'; and it was used by Eliot, in a wider sense, for all fish, as |kehtahhanâmaquog| `sea-fishes', Num.11.22; |mogkommâquog| `great fishes', Jn.21.11; |howamagqut| (objective) `to any fish', Deut.4.18.
\cf namohs

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nedañmé| `je pêche à l'hameçon'; |añmé| `il pêche, etc.'; |añmañgan| `on pêche là, il y a pêche'.
Delaware [del] |a-man| `fishhook'    Zeisb.]

\lx áunag
\va ônag
\va unnag
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 19
\ps II
\dv suppos. of |unne|, q.v.
\ge `if it be so, when it is so'
    |ne aunag|, |neaunak| `that which is (i.e. when it is) so or thus'
    pl. |nish aunagish|, |-kish|
\ps used substantively
\ge  `event, occurrence, action; what is to be, or may be, so, or in such manner'
    \xv wanne ne aunag papaume ayeuwuttuonk
    \xe all the things concerning the war
    \so 2 Sam.11.18
    \xv uttoh aunak
    \xe how the matter may fall
    \so Ruth 3.18
    \xv pasuk ne woh aunag
    \xe one thing is needful, must be so
    \so Lk.10.42
    |Pharisesog n∞tamwog missinninnúog weogquttumwog neôuagish pâpaume nagum,...| (sic; 1st ed.: |neônagish|) `The Pharisees heard that the people murmured such things concerning him;...'    Lk.7.32
    \nt +
    \xv ne áunak
    \xe the color of it
    \so , i.e. its appearance, likeness    Num.11.7; Ezek.1.16
    Negat. |...: matta ânan∞gk ...| `If it were not so,...'    Jn.14.2; (M): |unnan∞kus|
    = |matta unan∞g|    Judg.9.15

    (|neânag| `such'    C.)
\ps As prep.
\ge `according to, after the manner of'

\cf neane

\lx auwam
\va auwom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 20
    \nt +
\ps NA, also medial
\ge `cousin, kin', perhaps including `wife' (Ntv.Wr.58:8,10)
\so Gen.24.38,40,41
\nt G&B. 608, s.v. (nutt)auwam; NtvWr. 204, to document 58
    \xv nutta(u)wom pety
    \xe my cousin Betty
    \so Ntv.Wr.58:8,10
    \nt Remark: Goddard and Bragdon note (Ntv.Wr.204) that "Joseph and Betty Josnin are referred to as husband and wife in contemporary English records", and state that "the translation `my cousin' used here is intended in the general sense this word had in Colonial New England, which could even include one's wife." Unfortunately, they give no reference for this latter claim, and I have not been able to confirm it from OED, Schmidt's Shakespeare Lexicon, the Century Dictionary, EDD, or DARE. (DARE notes a euphemistic use, applied to an unmarried couple. It is perhaps a legal usage, by sideslip via the extended sense of "next of kin" to include those entitled to inherit rather than simply "blood relatives" c.f. Black, s.v., without indication of antiquity.)
    \xv Qut woh kuttôm n∞sh weekit, kah nuttinauwomóuhtu,...
    \xe But thou shalt go unto my father's house, and to my kindred,...
    \so Gen.24.38
    \ng second locative; relative root initial
    \xv ..., kah pish keneemun ummitamwussoh nunnaumon wutch nutauwamôtu,...
    \xe ...; and thou shalt take a wife for my son of my kindred,...
    \so Gen.24.40
    \ng second locative

    \se auwamau
    \ps TA
    \ge "to have sb as friend, kin" [cf. OED "friend", 3.]
    \so Mk.3.21; Lk.14.12,21.16
    \nt G&B.608 s.v. |auwamochek|
    \nt Remark: Compare TA |unnunkumau| `to have sb as kin', also like a verb of possession, but without the prefix, and with a TA final in ending in |m|. Note that |nutta(u)wom| could formally be a 1->3 independent absolute form of this verb.

    \xv auwamatcheg
    \xe thy kinsmen
    \so Lk.14.12
    \ng 2->_3_ participle
    \xv auwamógig
    \xe [your] kinsfolk
    \so Lk.21.16
    \ng 2p->_3_ participle

    \se !|auwadtuong(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, to !|auwadti-| AI, reciprocal stem
    \ge `family, kindred'
    \so Gen.12.3
    \xv ..., kah ut kuhhogkat wame wuttauwadtuongash ohket pish wunnanumóog.
    \xe ...: and in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed.
    \so Gen.12.3
    \ng 3 possessor plural
    \xv ...: kah menuhkesuonk aninnumauop wutánuunónat wame auwadtuongash, kah unnont∞waongash kah wutohtimoneash.
    \xe ...: and power was given him over all kindreds, and tongues, and nations.
    \so Rev.13.7

\cf paswauwamau
\nt +

[Algonquian [alg] |∙AWEMA| `frère, soeur. Ce mot se dit de frére à soeur, et de soeur à frère', "Le sens du mot |AWEMA| devient plus général, si on lui adjoint une préformante:" |Nind inawema| `je lui suis parent', |Nind inawendimin| `nous sommes parents'    Cq.72b.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |Nitawema| `il est mon parent', |Nitawentimina| `nous sommes parents, allies'    Grv.36/62.
Menominee [mez] |ena∙wε∙mε∙w| TA `he is related to him', |ena∙wε∙htowak| AI `they are related to each other'    M.L.55.
Miami |aweem-| TA `be related to him, allied with him'    B&C.28a.]

\et *awe∙m- TA `to be related to sb'

\ps v.t. inan. / AI+O
\ge `he makes use of, uses (it); +`to work sth'
\nt G&B. 609 |auwohk-|
    \xv ..., kah ∞wowunnumpâsumun, uppemunneotonussumun, wutauwohkon ut ∞nôiyeuut,...
    \xe ..., and cut it into wires, to work it in the blue,...
    \so Ex.39.3
    \ng 3->0 subordinative
    \nt +
    pl. |-téaog muttinohkou| `they use the right hand'    1 Chr.12.2
    \xv -- yeu siogk∞waonk
    \xe they use this proverb
    \so Ezek.18.2
    \xv Auwohkönat.
    \xe To use, to be used
    \so C.83/214.
    \nt +
    (|Nuttauohteam| `I use'; |nutt auwohteam| `I wear'    C.84/215)

    \nt MN: noh auwohteadt
    \ng suppositive |noh auwohteadt| `he who uses, the user'    Deut.18.10

    \xv Kah eyeu auwohteatuh yeu kuhk∞tumwehteaonk.
    \xe And now let us make some use of this text.
    \so C.253.
    \ng 1p->0 imperative
    \nt +

    \se auwohteaonk
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI
    \ge `making use of, using'; +`vessel; instrument, weapon'
    pl. |(-)auwohteaongash| `weapons'    Gen.27.3; 1 Sam.21.8
    \xv Wame wutauwohteauongash pummu wuttauwáekomuk, wutch waússumuwáonk wame ukkinnunkwhonganash, kah wame ukkinnunkwhonganash chippinnutunk wompuhshág.
    \xe All the vessels of the tabernacle in all the service thereof, and all the pins thereof, and all the pins of the court, shall be of brass.
    \so Ex.27.19
    \nt +
    {The Instrument where   by  he wrought.}
        |Auwohteaonk  ne    nashpe wutussen.|    Log.Prim.20/34

(Cf. |ayeuhteau|.)

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |neda8ékkañn, 3. 8d.| `Je me sers de cela', |a8é'kké| `sers-t'en'    R.463/528b.
    \nt +
M.-P. |`t-uwehkahal| TA, |`t-uwehkan| TI `he uses him, it'; |'t@weehkan| TI `er benutzt es'    LeS.102b; Sz.225.

\lx auwuttam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 20
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\ge `to think sth', in the sense of "intend"; in explanatory tag: `that is: "__"'
\nt Remark: Not clear how if at all it is differentiated from the form with relative root initial |(un)nauwuttam|, q.v.
\so Gen.50.20; Rom.7.18
    \xv Kah kenaau kutauwuttamûmwop wutche ne machuk, GOD wuttinnauwuttamun wanegik,...
    \xe But as for you, ye thought evil against me; but God meant it unto good,...
    \so Gen.50.20
    \ng ?2p->0 preterite absolute; see N&Q.
    \xv Newutche n∞wahteoh matta wanegeninn∞g nutappéhtunk (nuttauwuttam neyausut) ...
    \xe For I know that in me (that is, in my flesh,) dwelleth no good thing:...'    Rom.7.18 { i.e. "I mean: in my flesh"; incidentally, doesn
    \so t the text perhaps mean "I know that something that is not good dwells in me", not exactly what the writer intended? }

\lx ayeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 20
\ps v.i. / AI, i-stem
\ge  `he is here, or there; he is in a place, is located', +`to linger'
\ge  `he dwells'
    \xv ..., newutche ayeu mukoshquttaut Mamre,...
    \xe ,,,, for he dwelt in the plain of Mamre ...
    \so Gen.14.13
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Noh ayeu, kah appu qussukquanit,...
    \xe She dwelleth and abideth on the rock,...
    \so Job 39.28√
    |nuttai|, |nuttaih| `I dwell (in or at)'    Ps.23.6; Ezek.43.9
    \xv kuttai
    \xe thou dwellest
    pl. |ayeuog| `they dwell'    Dan.4.12; Is.30.19
    \xv Qut nutáyimun wètuomut,...
    \xe But we have dwelt in tents,...
    \so Jer.35.10
    \ng 1p indicative
    \nt +
    negat. |..., newutche nag matta ayeu∞og.| `..., because they {were} not.'    Jer.31.15√
    pret. |nuttaiup| `I was (there)'    Acts 11.5
    [indef. |Nanashwétog kesukquash, na mo nuttaiin:...| `I {was} there:...'    Prov.8.27√  { 1 subordinative }
    \xv ... toh kuttaiin?
    \xe where dwellest thou?
    \so Jn.1.38]
    \ng 2 subordinative

    suppos. 1st pers. |uttoh áyee| (|áei|) `where I may dwell'    Is.49.20; Ezek.43.7
    2d pers. |áyean|
    \xv Kah padjeh n naiyit,...
    \xe And while he lingered,...
    \so Gen.19.16(E1)
    \ng 3->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    3d pers. |noh âyit| `he who dwells'    Is.8.18
    \xv ne ayig
    \xe where he dwells
    \so Job 15.28
    \xv ... mishe kah uhqunneunkque touohkomuk, ne aihetit n∞tae ask∞kog, kah skorpionsog, kah kóhnkan,...
    \xe ...that great and terrible wilderness, wherein were fiery serpents, and scorpions, and drought,...
    \so Deut.8.15
    \nt +
    \xv ONK n nih Apollos áit Corinth, Paul paúmuhkog kussuhkôiyeúwe otanash, peyau Ephesus,...
    \xe And it came to pass, that, while Apollos was at Corinth, Paul having passed through the upper coasts came to Ephesus:...
    \so Acts 19.1
    \nt +
    pl. (particip. ) |neg ayegig|, |neg na ayitcheg| `the inhabitants, they who dwell there'    Ezek.38.11; Mic.7.13

    imperat. |ayish| `dwell thou'

    \se ayeuonk
    \va -ong(an
    \nt +
    \ps Vbl.n. / deverbal NI
    \ge `a place'
    \nt G&B.609
    \so Gen.18.24; Deut.12.21;
    \ge `dwelling place', +`dwelling'
    \so Num.24.21

[Muh; (suppos.) |oieet| `he "who lives or dwells in a place"    Edw.
Chip. |ahyáh| `he is (in a place)'    Jn.6.9; 8.35, 40; |tah ahyáh| `he shall be (there)'    Jn.12.26; (|ahneende aindahyun| `where
dwellest thou?'    1.38); suppos. |áhyáyon| `while I am (here)'    9.5; |ahy-ód| `(where) he is'    7.11.
Cree |net ían| `I am being or existent'; |i-ów|, |i-àoo| `he is,' etc.; inan. |i-ów| `it is', etc.; suppos. |i-ï-án|, or |í-a-yán| `if I am', etc.; |i-át|, `if he is', etc. (|i-á-thit| `if he is', in relation to another). Howse (136, 198) regards this as "the verb substantive in its absolute form,"
and Schoolcraft (II, 436-441) gives the whole conjugation of the corresponding Chip. verb, "|i-e-au|, to be," as a substantive verb.]

\et H.539, S., no. 105, pp.348-350: *ayi∙wa AI `he exists, is there, he abides, remains, stays', *ayi∙wi II `it exists, is there, it remains'


\lx ayeuau

    \nt +

\ge `to be against sb, to be sb's adversary'
\so Gen.42.36; Neh.50.8; Is.50.8,63.18

    \xe ...: all these things are against me.

    \xe ...: who is mine adversary? let him come near to me.

    \ng 3->1 indicative

\lx ayeuhteau
\va ayeuwehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 21
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he makes war, engages in war, fights'

    imperat. |ayeuhteáuash| `make war, do battle, fight'    Prov.20.18

    \se ayeuhteaonk
    \va ayeuwuttuonk
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI
    \ge `war, a battle'
    pl. |-ongash|    Job 10.17

    \se ayeuteaen
    \va -in
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `one who fights or makes war'
    \so Josh.17.1; 1 Sam.16.18

    \se !|ayeuwohteau|, !|ayeuteau|, !|ayeuhteau|, !|ayeuwehteau|
    \nt +
    \ps NA, agent noun
    \ge `army, host, men of war'
    \so Gen.21.22,32,26.26,32.2; Mt.22.7; Lk.23.11
    \xv ..., kah Phikol missugkenomp ut wutayeuwohteamut.
    \xe ..., and Phichol the chief captain of his army.
    \so Gen.26.26(E1)
    \xv Kah Herod kah weeche wutayeuhteomuh matta tohhentupanumouh ...
    \xe And Herod with his men of war set him at nought, ...
    \so Lk.23.11

    \se |ayeuwutteanshau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, |-nuhsh-| representative/benefactive
    \ge `to fight for sb'
    \so Josh.10.42
    \xv ...newutche Jehovah um-Manitt∞moh Israel ayeuwutteaunshoh Israeloh.
    \xe ..., because the Lord God of Israel fought for Israel.
    \so Josh.10.42

\nt Sanskrit yudh (pret. áyutsi), pugnare
\so cum acc., impugnare
\so âyudha, arma

[Narr. (imperat. 2d pl.) |Jûhetteke| `fight'; (1st pl.) |Jûhettíttea| `let us fight'.    R.W.175/r.183.√
Muh. (suppos.) |oioteet| `the man who fights'    Edw.12.√

Cree |Ootéete-{náyoo}| `{he} assaults, attacks {him}.'    Howse 91.
    Lp.A. |aiauten| `La guerre', |8lsanten ak8i 8ank ai8teten| `faisons la paix ne soyons plus en guerre'    D.78,98
    \nt +
Unquachog [unq] |ayutówac| `war (the)', |aiyeutiionk| `war in Massachusetts'    Jeff.1791.17a.
WAbn. |aodi| AI `fight, make war', |aodowôgan| NI `war, a fight'    D.1.40.]
