\lx Kehtanit
\va Keihtannit
\va keht-anit
\ve `the chief or greatest manit'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 32
\ge for `the Lord God'
\so Gen.24.3, 7
    With the verb subst. |kehtanit∞|, |keihtannitto| `he is (or it is) the greatest manitto';
    and with the locative suffix, |kehtanito-ut| `the place of the great manito, or where he is':
    hence, probably, |Kautántowwit| `the great Southwest God' (R.W.), or rather his home in the Southwest.

[Delaware [del] |getannitowit|    Zeisb.Gr.37.]

\lx kehtoh
\va keihtoh
\va kehtoh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 32
\ps n. / NI

    \nt +
\so Gen.1.10; Ps.78.13; Hag.2.6
    with indef. affix, |kehtohhan|, |kehtahhan| `any sea'  { source? }

    \so Num.11.22; (E1): |ketahhannâmâquog|

\dv For |kehteau| `it is very great, vast'; = |'k-ahteau| `it is going on, or is indefinitely extended'.

\lx kémeu
\va keme
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 33
\nt Follow up needed: Reorganize
\ps II
\ge `(it is) secret, private'
\ps as adv. / PreV
\ge `in secret', +'within oneself, secretly'
\so Mt.6.4,6; +Lk.14.25
    \xv Newutche Sarah kemeu hahanu,...
    \xe Therefore Sarah laughed within herself,...
    \so Gen.18.12; (E0) "secretly"
    \ng PreV
    \nt +
    \xv Kah David wahteou Saul keme kodwoskehuau,...
    \xe And David knew that Saul secretly practised mischief against him;...
    \so 1 Sam.23.9
    \ng PreV

    \xv Newutche monteag kemein, ne woh mat wahteauwahuwomuk:...
    \xe For nothing is secret, that shall not be made manifest;...
    \so Lk.8.17
    \ng 0 negative indicative
    \nt +

    pl. |Keme∞gish wutchayeum∞ash Jehovah num-Manitt∞mun,...| `The secret things belong unto the LORD our God:...'    Deut.29.29√  { _0p_ participle }

    (|Kemeyoüê.| `Privately', |Kemeyëue.| `Secretly'    C.106/229-230.)
    \xv ..., kah kishpinnau wuskesuk∞∞ash ut kémeayeuut
    \xe ...; and bind their faces in secret.
    \so Job 40.13√

    \se kemeyeu∞
    \nt Remark: Is this distinct from the headword as II verb?
    \nt +
    \ps With verb subst. / denominal II
    \xv Onk woh kukkitteamonteanitteaongash kemeyeu∞ash,...
    \xe That thine alms may be in secret:...
    \so Mt.6.4
    \ng 0p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah yeu wussuttumooonk pish kemeyeu asuh pish pohquaëyeu,...
    \xe And this judgment shall be either private or publick,...
    \so C.257
    \nt +

    \nt MN: kemeyeu∞uk
    \ng suppositive |kemeyeu∞uk| or |-yeuuk| `when it is secret'
    \xv ... kah ahque wahshadtoush kemeyeu∞uk en onkatuk.
    \xe ...; and discover not a secret to another:
    \so Prov.25.9
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah matta kemeyeuuk k∞taméhik,...
    \xe ..., and no secret troubleth thee,...
    \so Dan.4.9
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt +

    \ps as n.
    \ge `a secret'
    \so [participial examples, v.s.] Ps.44.21(M)
    \xv ...? newutche wahteau ukkemeyeumash muttah.
    \xe ...? for he knoweth the secrets of the heart.
    \so Ps.44.21(M)
    \ng 0 possessive 0p
    \nt +

    \se !|kemeyeuonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `secret'
    \so Ps.24.14(M)
    \xv Jehovah ukkemeyeuonk oowechiyeumukqunnau neh quoshukqutche:...
    \xe The secret of the Lord is with them that fear him;...
    \so Ps.25.14(M); (E) |ukkemeseong|

\cf komm∞to

[Western Abenaki [abe] |Kimi8i| `en cachette'    R.P.20/556.
Delaware [del] |Kimi| `secretly'; |kíimii| `secretly'    Zeisb., B&A.53; O'M.83b.
    Algonquian [alg] |KIM-| `en cachette, à la dérobée'    Cq.164b-165a.
    \nt +
Cree x |KIM| (rac.) `en secret, en cachette', |KIMWEW| `il parle en secret, tout bas'; |kîm-| `deviously, furtively, secretly, sneakily'    Lac.D.394a-395b; Alb.E.53b-54b.
Ill. {R} |Kimi| `en cachette, en secret. on change q^que fois la derniere syllabe'    Grv.202/139b-140a.
Lp.A. |Kimi| `en cachette'    D.36.
M.-P. |kikimi| PreV `secretly, stealthily, silently'; |kikimi-| `heimlich'    LeS.25b; Sz.89.
Menominee [mez] |ke∙m| PreV `secretly, by stealth',     M.L.89-90.
Miami |kiim-| `secretly, quietly'    B&C.56b-57a.

Shawnee [sjw] |kiim-| `UNOBSERVED'    D.-V.305.
WAbn. |gim-| `secretly, stealthily'; |gôgimi| `very secretly'     D.1.xl,200-201;220.]

\lx kenai

    \xe a sharp stone

    (|keniyeue| `sharply'    C.)

    \nt MN: kenag
    \ng suppositive |kenag| `when it is sharp, that which is sharp'    Is.5.28; Rev.14.14

\lx ken∞nau
\va ken∞N-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
\ps v.t. an. / TA, applicative final
\twn |ken∞tam|
\ge `he speaks (with authority, or as a superior to an inferior) to (him), he counsels, advises, instructs'; +`to speak unto, with sb, to talk with sb; to speak of sb; to pronounce sb sth' (where "sth" is a predicate, in a proleptic object construction)...
\so Ex.33.9; Deut.5.24; 2 Sam.17.15
    |..., woús nutapshom ken∞non Jehovah,...| "..., I haue taken vpon me to speake vnto the LORD,..."  { X->3 subordinative }
    \nt +
    \xv ... nutt∞n kukkinn∞nukumw∞.
    \xe ... that {it is} my mouth that speaketh unto you.
    \so Gen.45.12
    \ng 0->2p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv KAh Jehovah ken∞nau Mosesoh, n∞wau, Ken∞s wunnaumonuh Israel, n∞wash,
    \xe And the Lord spake unto Moses, saying, Speak unto the children of Israel, saying,'    Lev.4.1(-2)  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv ..: neit pish sephausuen ukken∞nuh pahkesu,...
    \xe ...; then the priest shall pronounce him clean:...'    Lev.13.34  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nuppeyok pasuk nesausuk adtahsuutcheg angelsog, ..., kah nukken∞nuk, n∞wau, na win,...
    \xe And there came unto me one of the seven angels ..., and talked with me, saying, Come hither,...
    \so Rev.21.9
    \ng 3->1
    \nt +
    recip. |kah ken∞nittuog| `and they consulted'    Mt.26.4
    \nt +
    \xv Kah neán womussét, wuttinninnumoh nogkuskunkup, kah wuttinne kunn∞nowôopah, Kunnamon pomontam.
    \xe And as he was now going down, his servants met him, and told him, saying, Thy son liveth.
    \so Jn.4.51(M)
    \ng (E2): |..., kah wuttinuh, n∞waog,...|; 3p->3 preterite
    \nt +

    \xv ..., ∞nohteau k∞sh∞ kutchise noh kón∞nog? ...
    \xe ..., Is your father well, the old man of whom ye spake? ...
    \so Gen.43.27  { 2p->_3_ participle }; (E0&E1) |kôn∞nog|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., on[ ] noh kan∞ssop, kah noh chadchekeimip,...
    \xe ..., and which spake unto me, and that sware unto me,...
    \so Gen.24.7  { _3_->1 preterite participle, with mutation }; (E0) |kân∞sop|
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Moses shwosuk tahshinchagu kodtumwohkomup, kah Aaron shwosug tahshinchage kah nishwudt kodtumwáe kôn∞náhettit Pharohhoh.
    \xe And Moses was fourscore years old, and Aaron fourscore and three years old, when they spake unto Pharaoh.
    \so Ex.7.7
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jehovah n∞tamup wadtauatonkqussue kukkutt∞wongash ken∞seog,...
    \xe And the Lord heard the voice of your words, when ye spake unto me;...
    \so Deut.5.28
    \ng 2p->1
    \nt +
    \xv Jesus wuttinuh, Nen kón∞nun nen nagum.
    \xe Jesus saith unto her, I that speak unto thee am he.
    \so Jn.4.26
    \ng presumably changed conjunct; 1st ed.: |kôn∞nun|; Mayhew: |kan∞n-nun|
    \nt +
    \xv N∞wahteáunnan GOD kôn∞nont Mosesoh,...
    \xe We know that God spake unto Moses:...
    \so Jn.9.29
    \nt +
    \xv Matta peyâos, kah ken∞nogkus matta woh ohtau∞og matcheseonk:...
    \xe If I had not come and spoken unto them, they had not had sin:...
    \so Jn.15.22
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nutompamuhquaip naumunat ne wadtauatonkqussuonk kon∞sit,...
    \xe And I turned to see the voice that spake with me. ...
    \so Rev.1.12
    \ng 3->1

    imperat. 2d sing. |ken∞s|
    \xv ..., Yeu wamach, ahque wonk ken∞neh yeu papaume.
    \xe ..., Let it suffice thee; speak no more unto me of this matter.
    \so Deut.3.26
    \ng 2->1
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nussontimom, ken∞s nemat, woh nutchippunumunk ahtóonk.
    \xe ..., Master, speak to my brother, that he divide the inheritance with me.
    \so Lk.12.13
    \nt +
    pl. |ken∞n∞k|
    \xv Kah unnáog Mosesoh ken∞sinan, kah hó ken∞tauunnumun kah ahque GOD ken∞nukqutteuh, ishkont nupmun.
    \xe And they said unto Moses, Speak thou with us, and we will hear: but let not God speak with us, lest we die.
    \so Ex.20.19
    \ng 2->1p; 3->1p
    \nt +

    \se ken∞nuáonk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    pass. |ken∞nittuonk|
    \ge `counsel, advice'
    \so Prov. 20.18

    \se ken∞nuaen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a counselor'
    pl. |-énuog|    Job 3.14

    \se ken∞s∞waenin
    \so Is.9.6

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |neker8'rañ, 3. ak.| `[Je parle] à lui'    R.378/499b.
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |GANOJ| `parle-lui, adresse-lui la parole', |Ni ganona| `je lui parle'    Cq.107b.
Cree |KITOTEW| `il lui parle, il lui adresse la parole,...'    Lac.D.417b.

WAbn. |gelo-| `speak, talk', |gelola| `speak to someone'    D.1.XXXIX,192.]

\et Ho., no.68, 260b *keΘo-, *kaΘo∙- `talk', H.944 *kaΘawiΘe∙wa TA `talk', W., no.278, 142-143


\lx ken∞tam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps TI1a

\so Lev.14.48, Lk.9.54
    \xv ..., neit pish sephausuen ken∞tam wetu pohki, newutche enninneáonk neetskehteauun.
    \xe ...: then the priest shall pronounce the house clean, because the plague is healed.
    \so Lev.14.48
    |..., Lord, kuttenanatamun, woh nukken∞tamunán n∞tau n∞kem∞ut wutch kesukqut... `..., Lord, wilt thou that we command fire to come down from heaven,...'    Lk.9.54

\lx kenugkayeu

\lx kenugke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
    \ps Prep/PreN, often governing locative, occasionally governed by |ut|.
    \nt +
\ge `among'
\so Gen.17.10; Lev.11.2
    \xv ..., , ut kenugke mahtugquekontu tanóhketeaonganit.
    \xe ... amongst the trees of the garden.
    \so Gen.3.8
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kenugke wosketompaog weekit Abraham,...
    \xe ..., among the men of Abraham's house,...
    \so Gen.17.23
    \nt +
    |kunnuke|    Mass.Ps.

    (Vbl.n. |kenugkiyeuonk| `a mixture'    C.)

The primary signification is `mixed' or `intermingled':
    \xv kánukke muttaanukeg
    \xe a mixed multitude
    \so Num.11.4
    = |kenukshae mattaanukeg|    Neh.13.3
\cf kenukshau

    [Algonquian [alg] |KINIKA-| `pêle-mêle'    Cq.168a.
    \nt +
Cree |Kítheekow| `among'; |keyikow| `among, mixed with, even'; |kiyikawi| `something mixed with something else, mixed together'    Howse 34; Frs.7b,277b; Alb.E.59a.
Ill. {R} |Kireca, Kireki, Kirica| `in cpoone pesle mesle, confusion, meslange'    Gr.217/146b-147a.]

\et H.994-995 *kelek- `mix'

\lx kenún
\va kinún
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
    \nt Remark: There appears to be no evidence for this form.
    \nt +
\ps v.t.

    \se kenau
    \va kinou
    \nt !
    \va keninau
    \nt !
    \va kenunnau
    \ps with an. obj. / TA, with manual final
    \ge `he bears or carries'
\nt This appears to be the earlier form (corresponding to |annûn|, q.v.), from which |kenunnum|, |-nau|, are derived. To it must be referred |ukkinóuh| `they bore him', Mk.2.3, unless this is misprinted for |ukkenunnóuh|, as in Lev.10.5;√
    \xv Onk Esau quogque wunnogskâuoh, kah ukkinuh,...
    \xe And Esau ran to meet him, and embraced him,...
    \so Gen.33.4; also Gen.48.10
    \ng assuming a sense "hold firmly by/with the hands"
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nag pas∞tshaog, kah ukkenunnóuh wuthogk∞unn∞ôut poquadchit tuppuksinn∞onganit,...
    \xe So they went near, and carried them in their coats out of the camp;...
    \so Lev.10.5√
    \nt +
cf. |..., kah pish ukkeninuh ut upp∞chenanóut,...| `..., and [he shall] carry them in his bosom,...'    Is.40.11√
    \xv ..., uppaudtauóuh pasuk∞ nanunkqussu, yauog ukkinóuh.
    \xe ..., bringing one sick of the palsy, which was borne of four.
    \so Mk.2.3
    \nt +
    (|Nukkünum (nukkünun) wosketomp.| `I carry a man'    C.41/184)

    \se |kenadtam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, oral final (to extended initial?)
    \ge "to bring sth in the mouth"
    \so Gen.8.11
    \xv ..., kah kusseh kenadtam wunnépogque Olive, ne pashkodtog:...
    \xe ..., and, lo, in her mouth was an olive leaf pluckd off:...
    \so Gen.8.11: (E0): "loe - she brought - a leaf"


\cf kóunum

[Narragansett [xnt] |Ku[]níish.|    `I will carry you.'    R.W.73.
    Algonquian [alg] |KINA-| `retenu, arrêté, empêché'    Cq.165b-166a.
    \nt +
Cree |KIT| (rac.) `empêcher, retenir'; |kitinew| `S/he detains her/him;...'    Lac.413ab; Alb.E.52a.
Delaware [del] |Gelen'nin| `to take hold; (or, to hold in the hand. A.)'; |ku@l-| `to hold firmly,...', with broad range of extended senses.    B&A.39; O'M.104b-108a.
Ill. {R} |Kira| `dans le composé marque de deffense, empescheement 8g'; |Nikirina| `je le prend, arreste, saisy, home ou beste'    Gr.215/146a; 218/147a.
M.-P. |'kolonal| TA `he holds onto him'; |'k@lnal| `er hält ihn'    LeS.29a; Sz.79.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |ke@lnu@m|, |ke@lnu@k| `To hold'; |keln'k| `hold' [NB]    R.132b; DeB.25b.
WAbn. |gal-, gel-| `to hold', e.g. |gelnem| TI `to hold (as in hand)'    D.I.174,178,190-192.]

\et G.1981, 10 *keΘenamwa `he carries it', to a root *keΘ- `held firmly', 10, 29 *keΘene∙wa TA, with ref. to Gen.33.4; repeated G.1982, fn.61, p.28; no evidence presented. H.1142-1143 *keΘahamaw- `forbid' no doubt belongs here (cf. Cuoq's gloss), and perhaps also H.1140 *keΘa∙pame∙wa `to look at'.

\lx kenunnau
\va kin-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\twn |kenunnum|
\ge `he carries (an an. obj.) in his hand or arms'
    With pronom. affixes, |ukkinunóh| `she bears them'    Deut.32.11

    \nt MN: kónunnont
    \ng suppositive |kónunnont| `when he carries (him), when carrying'
    \xv ahtompeh
    \xe a bow
    \so Amos 2.5
    \xv mukkiesoh
    \xe a child
    \so Num.11.12
    \xv ... (kah nag kononcheg chépekompáog) ...
    \xe : and they that bare him stood still.
    \so Lk.7.14
    \nt +

\cf kenún


\lx kenunnum
\va kununnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\twn |kenunnau|
\ge `he carries or bears (it) by hand' [and therefore improperly used in Is.53.4, 11]
\so Mk.14.13
    \xv Kah Moses kenunnum wuskonash Joseph,...
    \xe And Moses took the bones of Joseph with him:...
    \so Ex.13.19
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Miriam ..., nemunum timbrel ut wunnutcheganit, kah wame mittamwussissog sohhamwog wutasukauóuh kenunumohettit timbrelsoh, kah paumukahettit.
    \xe And Miriam ..., took a timbrel in her hand; and all the women went out after her with timbrels and with dances.
    \so Ex.15.20
    \nt +
    \xv kunnunumup
    \xe he bare it
    \so Mass.Ps. Jn.12.6
    \xv ..., kah neh ukquenahtauóuh pummetunkapunneg, onk woh ukkinnumunat nahôhtoeu Jesus ut.
    \xe and on him they laid the cross, that he might bear it after Jesus.
    \so Lk.23.26
    \nt +

    \xv Ahque teag kenunnum∞k wutch kuppomushaongan∞,...
    \xe Take nothing for your journey,...
    \so Lk.9.3
    \nt +
\cf kenún
\cf kóunum


\lx kenup-

    \nt +
\ps initial

    [Algonquian [alg] |KINIP-| `vite, à la hâte'    Cq.168b.
    \nt +

\lx kenuppe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
\ps PreV
\ge `swiftly, in haste'
\so Dan.3.24; Is.5.26
    \xv ..., kah petutteaôg otan, kah wussohkomuneau, kah kenuppe chikohsumog otan.
    \xe ...: and they entered into the city, and took it, and hasted and set the city on fire.
    \so Josh.8.19
    \nt +

    |-peyeu|
    \ps as adj /

    \se -peyeu∞
    \ps with verb subst. / denominal II
    \ge `there is haste, it "requires haste"'
    \so 1 Sam.21.8
    \xv ..., newutch ketass∞t wuttinniyeuonk kenuppeyeu∞,
    \xe ..., because the king's business required haste.
    \so 1 Sam.21.8
    \nt +


\lx kenuppu

    \xe I made haste,...

    |Kunnipish wutche nuttanumonteaonk,... `Make haste to help me,...'    Ps.(M).38.22  { 2 imperative }

[Algonquian [alg] |Kinipi| `{être en hâte}, se hâter, se dépêcher', |Kenipidjik| `ceux qui se hâtent'    Cq.168b.
Cree |KIYIPIW| `il agit promptement, avec agilité'    Lac.D.420a.
Lp.A. |nipi nanch kilipil| `va chercher de leau vite', |natam8k8e@ kilipik8e@| `alles vite chercher'; |kilipis mantsis mat manakepia| `depeche toy tu n'auras pas le temps', |kilipiten matchiten mat mana-/kepaimena| `depechons nous'       D.1;47.]

\lx kenuppétu
\va kenuppetu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
\ps v.i. / AI, initial + |-etu| `to grow', T+.26b
\ge `he grows fast', +AV `to grow', with no indication of speed in any source.
\so Gen.21.8,20
    \xv Onk mukkies kenuppétu, kah ∞cheninnop:...
    \xe And the child grew, and was weaned:...
    \so Gen.21.8
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    pl. |mukitchogqussog kenuppétuog| "the boys grew"    Gen.25.27  { 3p indicative }

\dv |kenuppe|, with the formative of verbs of an. growth

    [Algonquian [alg] |Kinipik,i| `croître vite, à vue d'oeil'    Cq.168b.]
    \nt +

\et H.998 *kelipikiwa AI `to grow fast'


\lx kenuppeusseu
\va kenupesu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Probably simply a collocation. The forms of the second type have been entered here pending clarification of its status, the problem perhaps being comparable to that found with |matchesu|. (I have as yet been unable to find any present indicative examples with 1s/2s subject or others that would confirm the analysis.)
\ps AI
\ge `to haste, make haste'
\so Gen.24.18,20,46; Josh.8.14; 1 K.20.41; 2 K.9.13; Ps.119.60
    \xv Kah n∞wau, Wuttattash nussontimom kah kenupesen, kah n∞kìnum upp∞thonchu ut wunnutcheganit...
    \xe And she said, Drink, my lord: and she hasted, and let down her pitcher upon her hand,...
    \so Gen.24.18
    \ng X subordinative
    \xv Kah ukkénuppeússen, sokunum upp∞thansh ut neetasuok ∞tattamwaech∞wout,...
    \xe And she hasted, and emptied her pitcher into the trough,...
    \so Gen.24.20
    \ng 3 subordinative
    \xv Kah ukkenuppesen. & wunn∞kinumun upp∞thonchúm wutch wuhh[o]gkat,...
    \xe And she made haste, and let down her pitcher from her shoulder,...
    \so Gen.24.46
    \ng 3 subordinative
    \xv Nukkinnuppeusséip
    \xe I made haste,...
    \so Ps.119.60
    \ng 1 preterite indicative


\lx kenupshau
\va kenupishau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 34
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he makes haste, he goes quickly, +to haste, hasten'; `to flee, run'
\so Eccl.1.5; 1 Sam.17.45
    \xv Kah Abraham kenupshau en wetuomut en Sarahut,...
    \xe And Abraham hastened into the tent unto Sarah,...
    \so Gen.18.6; (E0): "hasted into the house"
    \xv ...: wuttinn∞waonk kenupshau.
    \xe ...: his word runneth very swiftly.
    \so Ps.147.15; (M): |kunnupwushom∞| (II)
    \nt +

    \xv ..., matta kenupshaas, kah peyoas kenogskiinneat...
    \xe ..., except thou hadst hasted and come to meet me,...
    \so 1 Sam.25.34
    \ng 2 negative preterite subjunctive
    \nt +
    \nt MN: kanupshont
    \ng suppositive |kanupshont| , |kenupshont|    Job 9.26; Prov.7.23
    \xv ...; onatuh wompsik∞k noh kanupshont in wunnehtoonganit.
    \xe ...: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.
    \so Job.9.26
    \ng _3_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onatuh psukseesuk kanupishont en oppéhanit,...
    \xe ...; as a bird hasteth to the snare,...
    \so Prov.7.23
    \ng 3 changed conjunct
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kenupsaush en Laban neemattut ut Haran.
    \xe ..., flee thou to Laban my brother to Haran;'    Gen.27.43 (all texts)  { 2 imperative; printer
    \so s error? }
    \nt +
    \xv Kenupshagk kuhkuhquegk en n∞shut,...
    \xe Haste ye, and go up to my father,...
    \so Gen.45.9
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    imperat. |kenupshaush| `go thou quickly, make haste'    1 Sam.20.35; 23.27  { 2 imperative }

    \se !|kenupshaum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to haste'
    \so Job. 31.5; Ps.147.15(M) (v.s.)

    \xv ..., asuh nusseet kenupshaum∞∞k en as∞kekodteam∞onganit;
    \xe ..., or if my foot hath hasted to deceit;
    \so Job 31.5
    \ng 0 conjunct

    \se kenupsháe
    \ps Adj. and adv. / PreN, PreV
    \ge `swift-going', +`apace, swift(ly)'
    \xv ... kenuppe wussem∞og;...
    \xe did flee apace:
    \so Ps.68.12
    \nt +
    \xv Nish pamshóm∞ash onatuh kenupshae kuht∞nogquash;...
    \xe They are passed away as the swift ships:...
    \so Job 9.26√
    \xv ..., nag pish kenuppe kenupsháe peyaog.
    \xe ..., they shall come with speed swiftly:
    \so Is.5.26√
    (|..., kónupisháe pt∞éhit,...| `..., being caused to fly swiftly,...'    Dan.9.21√)

    \se kogkenupshau
    \ps Augm. and intens. / AI
    \ge `he goes swiftly'

    \nt MN: kakenupshont
    \ng suppositive |kakenupshont| `(when) going swiftly, "swift of foot"'    Amos 2.15
    \xv neg kakenupshonitcheg
    \xe they who are swift
    \so Amos 2.14; Jer.46.6

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nekérbar8kké.| `Je me dépêche à faire cela'    R.170/431a.]

\lx kepuhkoNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
    \nt +
\ps TA; applicative to AI |kepuhteau|
\ge `to cast, throw sb down'
\so Ps.36.12,140.11; Lk.9.42
    \xv ...: newutch GOD ummenuhkesuonganu∞ wutanóhsineat, kah ukkepuhkausuonat.
    \xe ...: for God hath power to help, and to cast down.
    \so 2 Chron.25.8
    \ng indefinite object, with mutation
    \xv .... kepuhkonog, kah matta pish tapenum∞og neepauun.
    \xe ...: they are cast down, and shall not be able to rise.
    \so Ps.36.12; (M): |kepuhkonoog|
    \ng X->3p objective
    \xv Kah noh na wag, mattannit ukkepuhkonuh kah wunnenekukkauoh:...
    \xe And as he was yet a coming, the devil threw him down, and tare him....
    \so Lk.9.42

    \se kepuhkonittuong(an
    \ps NI, to theme 2a stem, hence "passive"
    \ge `overthrow'
    \so Gen.19.29
    \xv ... kah sohh∞wunau Lotuh wutch nôeu kepuhkonittuonganit, ne kepuhteadt otanash ne wadohkit Lot.
    \xe ..., and sent Lot out of the midst of the overthrow, when he overthrew the cities in the which Lot dwelt.
    \so Gen.19.29
    \ng locative
    \nt +


\lx kepuhquohham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
    \nt +
\ps TI1a(-O)
\ge `to sink down'
\so Acts 20.9
    \xv ..., kepuhquohhm kah penushau wutch wohqut weetuómut, kah neemunáhettit nupp∞oh.
    \xe ..., he sunk down with sleep, and fell down from the third loft, and was taken up dead.
    \so [kataenekhtheìs apò toû húpnou; ductus somno]    Acts 20.9 (1st ed.: |kepuhquohham|)


\lx kepuhteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Note that the palatalization is absent in n-paradigm forms (G.1974, 326a; G.1981, 77; G&B.528)
\ps AI+O
\dv |kep-| `down' + |-ôhk-| `drop, throw' + |-á-|; see |unnohkonau| for cognates.
\ge `to overthrow sb or sth' (lit.)
\so Gen.19.21,29; 1 K.19.10; Mk.11.15; Ps.140.4,11
    \xv ..., kah matta woh nukkepuhteam yeu otan,...
    \xe ..., that I will not overthrow this city,...
    \so Gen.19.21; (E1,E0) |nukkepuhteaú|, erroneous.
    \xv Kah ukkepuhkonash yeush keitotanash ...
    \xe And he overthrew those cities,...
    \so Gen.19.25
    \ng 3->0p objective; replaces |ukkepuhonash| (typographical error) of (E0&1)
    \xv ..., kepuhteaog kut Altarumoh,...
    \xe ..., [they have] thrown down thine altars,...
    \so 1 K.19.10
    \xv ... wosketompaut neg ahchewontogig kepuhkon nutauonganash.
    \xe ..., who have purposed to overthrow my goings.
    \so Ps.140.4; (M) |kepuhteahpaneg|
    \ng X subordinative; _3p_ preterite participle
    \xv ...: woskehuwâonk pish ayeuau woskehuaenuh ukképôhkónat.
    \xe ...: evil shall hunt the violent man to overthrow him.
    \so Ps.140.11; (M): |ukkepuhkonukqunnat|
    \ng with applicative
    \xv ..., kah kepuhteau wuttableum∞ash ôs∞wompacheg teauguash,...
    \xe ..., and [he] overthrew the tables of the moneychangers,...
    \so Mk.11.15

    \xv ..., ne kepuhteadt otanash ne wadohkit Lot.
    \xe ..., when he overthrew the cities in the which Lot dwelt.
    \so Gen.19.29
    \ng 3->0 conjunct
    \xv OOsittumwaenum∞uh kepuhteámuk ut qussukquantehtu, pish n∞tamwog nuttinn∞waongash,...
    \xe When their judges are overthrown in stony places, they shall hear my words,...
    \so Ps.141.6; (M): |kepuhteamuk|

    \xv Kah kepuhteagk wutaltarum∞uh,...
    \xe And ye shall overthrow their altars,...
    \so Deut.12.3

\lx kesauwameonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
    \nt +
\ps NI
\ge `army, host; armour'
\so Num., passim, 2 Cor.6.7, Rev.19.19
    \xv Wutch neesnechage kodtumwohkomunat kah paameu, nishnoh pasuk nashpe sohhog kesauwameonk, ut Israelut, pish kummaiyae wehkomôog nashpe kesauwameongash, ken kah Aaron,
    \xe 1.3: From twenty years old and upward, all that are able to go forth to war in Israel: thou and Aaron shall number them by their armies.
    \so Num.1.3
    \xv Kah ukkesauwameumoh, kah yeug nag agkemutcheg yauunchage muttannonganog kussuog, kah napanna tahshe pasuk∞∞og,
    \xe And his host, and those that were numbered of them, were forty thousand and five hundred.
    \so Num.2.19
    \xv Nashpe wunnomwáe wuttinnowaonk, nashpe ummenuhkesuonk GOD, nashpe sampweussuwae kesauwaméonk, en muttinnohkóunit, kah en menadcheeanit.
    \xe By the worde of trueth, by the power of God, by the armour of righteousnesse, on the right hand, and on the left,
    \so 2 Cor.6.7
\nt Remark: c.f. |kesauwaméog| `harnessed' 3.p. Ex.13.18, and possessive forms |-kesauwameum-| `host' Num., passim.


\lx kesi-
\va kes-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
    \ps initial
    \nt +
\ge in comp. words has the force of `fully', `completely', or sometimes simply augment., `very much.'
    \xv ..., kah chapogquómukish tannegen kesadtéhtaash.
    \xe ...; and the clusters thereof brought forth ripe grapes:
    \so Gen.40.10
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wusken na wutappén kenogkenéganit, ussowesu Eutychus, kosukkoúit,...
    \xe And there sat in a window a certain young man named Eutychus, being fallen into a deep sleep:...
    \so Acts 20.9
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh mat wunnaumonuh Israel kussompatam∞og wuskesuk Moses...
    \xe ..., so that the children of Israel could not stedfastly behold the face of Moses...
    \so 2 Cor.3.7
    \nt +
    \xv Onk woh manittoe wosketomp pannupheau, pannuppe kesauwame en nishnoh wunanakausuonk.
    \xe That the man of God may be perfect, throughly furnished unto all good works.
    \so 2 Tim.3.17
    \nt +

[Western Abenaki [abe] |kesi|, `très'; +|Kisi| `cela est fait', |kisi mañts8"a| `il est parti'; |kisi nitsíg8ét.| `Il est meur' [melon], |kisi nitsig8^ét.| `Le blé est meur'    R.20/555a;20/556a;338/485b,340/487a.
Delaware [del] |gischi|, |kischi|, `done, ready',    Zeisb.
    Algonquian [alg] |KIJ-| `racine qui exprime l'idée de {perfection}, d'ouvrage bien fini, parfaitement achevé'    Cq.157a.
    \nt +
WAbn. |giz-| `can, be able to; complete, completed action, already, make, do'    D.1.xl.]

\et B. 101, 120/478 (and elsewhere): *kii⌠- `finish, done'; Ho.1957, no. 88, 262b-263a: *ki∙⌠- `completed'; W.1975, no.66, 91-92; A. 2096; H. 1209-.

\lx kesittu

\lx kesohkôontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
    \nt +
\ps TI1a(-O)
\ge `to be guilty'
\so Lev.4.13,(27),5.4,17,6.4, Mt.27.24
    \xv ...: tokônogque matta ∞wahteau∞un, qut onch kesohkôontam kah pish naiyeutam ummatcheseonk.
    \xe ...; though he wist it not, yet is he gulty, and shall bear his iniquity.
    \so Lev.5.17
    \xv ..., matta nukkesohkoantam∞ ∞sqheonk yeuoh sampweseaen, nanawompattam∞k, kenaau.
    \xe ..., I am innocent of the blood of this just person: see ye to it.
    \so Mt.27.24

    \xv ...: & wahteunk kah kesohkôontog yeush pasuk∞kish:
    \xe ...; when he knoweth of it, then he shall be guilty in one of these.
    \so Lev.5.4
\nt Remark: Same initial at Lev.4.22, Num.5.6, Mt.26.66, Mk.14.64; distinction unclear. There is a form in |-óadtam| found at Num.5.6,35.31, Ps.51.14(M) (|-otam-|, perhaps a spelling variant, if the final is in fact |-ôtam-| (TI |-t-| preceded by earlier |a∙|? i.e. an applicative?) rather than the commoner |-an(a)tam-| `by thought'.

    \nt +

\lx kesteau
\va kesitteau
\va kesehtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
\ps v.i. / TI2, causative
\twn |kezheau| TA
\ge `it is finished, completed, made complete'; +`to create, finish, make sth'
    \xv ...: ne ne Pillerse anakausuonk kesteáuun.
    \xe ...: so was the work of the pillars finished.
    \so 1 K.7.22
    \ng X->0 subordinative
\nt Remark: sometimes used as v.t. inan. / TI
    \xv Nashpe wuttinn∞waonk GOD kesteauunash kesukquash;...
    \xe By the word of the Lord were the heavens made:...
    \so Ps.33.6; (M) |kesehtauunapash|
    \xv .., newutch LORD kesteauun wuske ne teag ut ohkeit:...
    \xe ...? for the Lord hath created a new thing in the earth, ...
    \so Jer.31.22
    \ng 3->0 objective?
    \xv ..., kah kesteaunat wutanakausuonk.
    \xe ..., and to finish his work.
    \so Jn.4.34
    \ng X->0 t-subordinative
    (|Ahquehtöuu@nat, kestouunat.| `To leave off, to finish'    C.63/199
    |Nuttiyam, nukkeesteo, -up.|`I make, or did'    C.65/201.)
    \nt +
    \xv Keshitoüunate.
    \xe To create
    \so [diaeresis original]    C.45/187.  { t-subordinative; for |kesiht-|? }
    \nt +

    \xv ... wutch wame wutanakausuonganit ne kesteunk
    \xe ... from all his work which he had made.
    \so Gen.2.2
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., noh kasehtunkup kesuk kah ohke.
    \xe ..., , which made heaven and earth.
    \so Ps.115.15(M)
    \ng _3_->0(p) preterite participle
    \nt MN: ... noh kezteunk weekqshinne ohke,...
    \ng suppositive |... noh kezteunk weekqshinne ohke,...| `..., the Creator of the ends of the earth,...'    Is.40.28√
    \ps 3

    \ps With an.obj. |kezheau| q.v.

    \se |kesteauau|
    \nt +?
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to make sb sth'
    \so Gen.8.20
    \xv Kah Noah kesteauau Altaroh ut Jehovah,...
    \xe And Noah builded an altar unto the LORD;...'    Gen.8.20  { 3->(3')+3
    \so absolute, with locative phrase as indirect object }

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nekisi`t8n| `J'achève quelq^ chose'.    R.6/379ab.
Cree |Kéese-t-{ow}| `{he} finishes {it}'    Howse 105√.

\lx kesuk
\va kesuk
\va -
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 35
\ps n. / NI
\nt G&B.631
\ge `the visible heavens, the sky'
\so Gen.1.1
\ge `a day'
    \xv Kah ukkesuk∞ash Adam,...
    \xe And the days of Adam
    \so Gen.5.4
    \ng 3 possessive plural
    \nt +
    \xv pasuk kesuk
    \xe in one day
    \so Gen.27.45; 1 Sam.2.34
    \xv quinni kesuk
    \xe all the day long
    \so Ps.25.5; 71.15
    pl. |-kquash|
    \xv monatash kesukquash
    \xe many days
    \so Is.24.22
    \nt (but more commonly used, |m∞chetikquinogok|;
    \cf quinne

    \nt Remark: Conjunct forms moved to entry |kesukod|
    \nt +

    \se kesukquáe
    \ps Adj. and adv.; +final
    \ge `of heaven'
    \so Ps.78.23,24
    \ge `of the day'
    \so Jer.31.35
    \xv kesukque wequai
    \xe a light by day
    \nt Remark: There are a few instances of the use of this (complex) as a final to a numerical initial in the sense "(for) n days". See |nequttakesukquae|, and the following for indications of the usage.
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nutattumunukqun, kah nukkoueáhukqun nishshukesukquae, womonittuwáe.
    \xe ...; who received us, and lodged us three days courteously.
    \so Acts 28.7, Jn.2.20(M); variant form in |-eu| at Mt.12.40
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Sontimom, yeu ahquompak anunn∞ newutch yaue-kesukquae nupp∞.
    \xe ..., Lord, by this time he stinketh: for he hath been dead four days.
    \so Jn.11.39
    \nt +

\nt |kesuk| by its form appears to be the suppositive or participial of a verb |ke@su|, or with inan. subj. |ke@sin| (|kussin|) `it warms or is warm'. Though this verb is not formed separately in the indicative, it may be traced in the prefix |kus-|, |kussa-| (q.v.), in the passive form |kussittau| `he is heated, made warm' (as n. `heat of the sun'), and in the verb-adj. an. |kes∞su| (|kes∞sinneat| `to be warm' C.). Hence in other dìalects the name of the sun as the source of heat:
    Western Abenaki [abe] |kiz8s| (comp. |nekis88's| `je suis chaudement')
    old Alg. |kijis| (= |kezhis|)
    Chip. |gë'zis|, |kësis| (cf. |gë'zhik| `sky'; |gë'zhikod| `day')
    Menominee [mez] |kay-shoh| (cf. |kay-shaïck| `sky')
    Mahican [mjy] |keesogh|    Edw.
    Delaware [del] |gischuch|, etc.
The same radical, probably, is found in |kesanohteau| (|kesann∞"ta| C.) `it is ripened'; |kesteau| (Cree |kéesëtow|) `he perfects, completes', and with an. obj. |kezheau| (Cree |kéesehayoo| `he finishes') `he makes, "creates", gives life to'; |kesukin| `it grows to maturity, is full grown, is ripe'; and with an. suhj. |kesittu| -- in all which there is an apparent reference to the sun as the source of vital warmth and of mature development of animal and vegetal life. Sansk. kâs and kâs' (lucere, splendere); kus' (splendere).

[Narragansett [xnt] |Kéesuck.| `The Heavens.'    R.W.79; (|keesk|    Stiles); |Kéesqush keesuckquâi| `By day.'    R.W.67.
Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |kéezuk|    Stiles.
Western Abenaki [abe] |kiz8k8| `jour; le ciel, l'air'.
Chip. |gë'zhik|, |gézick| `sky'.
Menominee [mez] |kayshaick| `sky'.
Shawnee [sjw] |keè-sa-kèe| `day'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |kishk8k| `aujourd'hui'.
Delaware [del] |gischuch| `sun'; |gíschgu| `day'; +|kíishooxkw| NA `sun'    Zeisb.; O'M.86b.]

\et B. items 56, 58, 17, 91/447; Ho. item 91, 263a: *ki∙⌠ek- `day, sky'; A.934-937; H.1217-1218


\lx kesukod
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
\ps as n. / II, NI
\ge `daytime, the day', as a measure of time (i.e. `while day is')
\nt G&B.631 (1) II `it is (a) day', (2) NI `day'.
\so Gen.1.5,14,16;
\ge opposed to |nukon|, `the night season'
\so Gen.1.5
    \xv Kah ut k∞wekontamwe kesukodtum∞wout,...
    \xe Also in the day of your gladness,...
    \so Num.10.10
    \ng 2p possessive locative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kusseh kenupp∞e kesukodtumash paswohtaash,...
    \xe ..., thy days approach that thou must die:...
    \so Deut.31.14
    \ng 2 possessive 0p
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche wutunkqanumoe kesukodtum∞ paswohteau,...
    \xe ...: for the day of their calamity is at hand,...
    \so Deut.32.35
    \ng 3p possessive 0
    \nt +
    pl. |kesukodtash|    Dan.8.14,27.
    \xv Newutche ummishe musquanittamwe kesukodtum peyaum∞,...
    \xe For the great day of his wrath is come;...
    \so Rev.6.17
    \ng 3 possessive 0
    \nt +

    \nt MN: kesukok
    \ng suppositive |kesukok| `when it is day, on a day'
    \ps adv
    \xv yeu pajeh kesukok
    \xe unto this day
    \so Gen.19.38
    \nt +
    \xv ne kesukok
    \xe on that day
    \so Gen.21.8
    \xv yeu kesukok
    \xe on (or within) this day, today
    \so Ps.95.7; Ex.2.18
    pl. |kesukokish|
    \xv ásekesukokish
    \xe every day, daily
    \so Is.51.13; Ps.145.2
    \ng 0p->_adv_ iterative, perhaps as "every time that it is (a) day"; G&B.554

    \se |kesukodtu∞|
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: On the |-u-|, note the etymology.
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to be for a day'
    \so Gen.1.14

    \xv ..., kah kesukodtu∞wuhhettich,...
    \xe ..., and [let them be] for days,..
    \so Gen.1.14
    \ng 0p imperative

    \se kesukodáe
    \va -dáeu
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `in the daytime, by day'
    \so Ex.13.21; Job 5.14
    \xv kesukodtáeu kah nukkonáeu
    \xe by day and by night
    \so Ps.1.2
    (|kesukodáe kah nukhonae|    Josh.1.8)
    |kesukkâttae|    C.

\et H.1216-1217 *ki∙⌠ekatwi NI, II `day'


\lx kesukodtumash
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
    \nt Remark: probably a ghost form, containing a possessive theme; but cf. Ex.4.10, Mk.13.17 (which latter could be interpreted as "his/her", cf. Lk.1.5)
    \nt +
\ps n. pl. / NI
\ge `days', in the sense of years [|kodtum∞ash|] or as measuring long periods of time
\so Deut.11.21 ; Job 14.1 [+possessive |-m-|]
    |..., matta n∞nónt∞waénu∞, asuh matta wutch negonne kesukodtumash, asuh nadteuh konn∞nadt kittinneum,...| "..., I am not +eloquent, neither heretofore, nor +since thou hast spoken vnto thy seruant:...", "+{Heb. a man of words.}/+{Heb. since yesterday/nor since the third day.}"    Ex.4.10(E1&2)

    \xe How many are the days of thy servant? ...
    \so Ps.119.84√; (M) |Tahtashunash ukkesukodtumash|;
    \ng possessive |-m-|
    \xv ..., kah nag n∞saitcheg yeush ut kesukodtumash.

    \so Mk.13.17(E1&2)

    \nt +

\lx keteáhogkóu

\lx keteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `he is alive, he lives, or is quick, quick'; implying the possession of vital energy or of animation; comp. |pomantam|
\ge `he is in good health, he is recovered from sickness'
\so 2 K.20.7; Is.39.1
    \xv nag pish keteaog
    \xe they shall recover
    \so Mk.16.18
    |Asq kongketeau?| (augm.) `Is he well?' |Asq keteau| `he is well'    Gen.29.6√ { "perfect durative" reduplication with |asq| }
    \xv sun woh nukketeam
    \xe shall I recover?
    \so 2 K.8.8,9

    \xv Ukkomm∞towonk naméhteae naméhteadt ut wunnutcheganit, asuh ox, asuh asse, asuh sheep, ketead, pish neesit piskeu ôadtéhteau.
    \xe If the theft be certainly found in his hand alive, whether it be ox, or ass, or sheep; he shall restore double.
    \so Ex.22.4
    \nt +

    \se !|keteaum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to live, be quick'
    \so Gen.9.4; Lev.13.24

    \xv ..., kah keteaum∞ug ne chôgohtag, ne wompéchohkag,...
    \xe ..., and the quick flesh that burneth have a white bright spot,...
    \so Lev.13.24
    \ng _0_ participle

    \se keteáe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `of life, in life'
    \xv ..., wame weyaus neg keteae nahnohshoncheg.
    \xe ... of all flesh wherein is the breath of life.
    \so Gen.7.15
    \xv -- matug
    \xe tree of life
    \so Prov.13.12
    \xv -- tohkekom
    \xe fountain of life
    \so Prov.13.14
    `quick'    Num.16.30

    \se keteaonk
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI
    \ge `living or being alive; the life principle or vital force; "the soul" (i.e. the life)'
    \so Job 12.10
    \xv ..., newutche nupponumun nukketeaonk, onk woh wonk nunneemunumun,
    \xe ..., because I lay down my life, that I might take it again.
    \so Jn.10.17; (M) |nussepshittauun|
    \ng 1->0 ?objective (second mention)
    \nt +
    \xv ukketeaonk weyaus wusqueheonganit
    \xe the life of the flesh [is] in the blood
    \so Lev.17.11
\cf kitonckquêi

[Narragansett [xnt] |Pitch nkéeteem?| `Shall I recover?'; |Nickeétem.| `I am recovered.', |Kitummáyi nick/êekon.| `I am just now recovered.'; |Konkeeteâug|    `They are well.'    R.W.186/r.194;191/r.199;3.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |kíghé| `il se redonne la vie'.    R.440/522a,498/542a.√
    Algonquian [alg] |KIKE| `guérir, être guéri' (with footnote on "exterior" nature of malady)    Cq.162a.
    \nt +
Cree |Ke'käo| `Healed, {part.} (from open sores)'; |kîkîw| `Her/his sore is healed'    Frs.94b,271b; Alb.E.53b.
Delaware [del] |Kiken| `to mend in health, to grow better'; |kíikeew| AI `be cured, healed'    B&A.53; O'M.83a.

Miami |kiikii-| AI `be alive, have life'    B&C.55b.
WAbn. |gigaô| TAd `cure him'    D.1.199,2.96.]

\et G. refers to PA *ki∙ke∙- `heal, recover' in a suggestion reported by Day (1975: 361b, to fn.596; see also G.1981, 39, 76, with |keteau| < PA *ki∙ke∙wa) on the forms Lp.A |kiken|, |kikike| (unglossed example); the examples given in this entry, which can be multiplied, would add support for this reconstruction, which is not to be found in A., H. or Ho.1957.


\lx ket∞hkontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\ge `to proclaim sth, to utter sth' (by speech)
\so Ex.33.19; Josh.2.14,20; Heb.5.11
    \xv ..., kah nukket∞hkontam ∞wesuonk Jehovah ut anaquabean? ...
    \xe ..., and I will proclaim the name of the Lord before thee;...'    Ex.33.19 { reduplicated at 34.5,6, for AV `proclaim
    \so }
    \xv Noh papaume monatash an∞wáog, kah siogkodtash ket∞hkontamunat, newutche kenaau kukkogkopsomw∞.
    \xe Of whom we have many things to say, and hard to be uttered, seeing ye are dull of hearing.
    \so Heb.5.11

    \xv Kah ket∞hkontaman yeu n∞tamanatam∞onganun,...
    \xe And if thou utter this our business,...
    \so Josh.2.20


\lx ket∞homom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
\ps v.i. / TI1a
\ge `he sings, recites in song'
    \xv nukket∞homom
    \xe I sing
    \so Ps.57.7

    \se ket∞homauau
    \ps with an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he sings to (him) or tells by song'
    pl. |-amauáog| `they sing to (him)'    1 Chr.16.33
    \xv Wame muttaok pish k∞wowussumuk, kah pish kukket∞homungquog, pish unn∞homoog k∞wesuonganit.
    \xe All the earth shall worship thee, and shall sing unto thee: they shall sing to thy name.
    \so Ps.66.4; (M): |kukketoohomunk|, |unoohhomaog|
    \nt +

    \nt MN: kodt∞hamont
    \ng suppositive |kodt∞hamont|
    pl. |-oncheg|    Eccl.2.8

    \se ket∞homáe
    \va -hamwáe
    \ps Adv. and adj.
    \ge `of singing, of song'
    \so 2 Sam.19.35; Neh.7.67

    \se ket∞homáonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a singing, song'
    |wame ket∞homáe ukket∞homaongash David| (pl.) `all the psalms (singing songs) of David' [title of the psalms in meter]

    \se ket∞homwáen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a singer'
    \so 1 Chr.6.33

\cf kutt∞
\ge he speaks
\cf ket∞kau
\ge he goes on speaking, he talks
\cf an∞hom

[Western Abenaki [abe] |ki8ahad8| `il chante'.]


\lx ket∞kau
\va ket∞hkau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
\ps v.t.an. / AI(+O), long-vowel stem, with |ô| alternant (cf. |keket∞hkau|, T.31b)
    \dv AI corporal stem (as B.1962, 15.227, 313?)
    \nt +
\ge `he tells (him), he goes on speaking to (him)', +`to speak'
\so 2 Sam.20.18
    \xv KUhk∞tam∞k kenaau kesukquok, kah nukket∞hkam,...
    \xe GIVE ear, O ye heavens, and I will speak;...
    \so Deut.32.1
    \nt +
    \xv Angel ketookau Zachariasoh
    \xe An angel addresses Zacharias
    \so Lk.1.17,Hd(2)
    \nt +
    \xv K∞waantamwe ket∞hkam
    \xe {Thou speakest wisely}
    \so E.Gr.23/270
    \nt +
    \xv Kah n∞tamohettit ket∞hkau Hebrwe anóntowáonk,...
    \xe (And when they heard that he spake in the Hebrew tongue to them,...)
    \so Acts 22.2
    \nt +

    \xv Newutche howan kenugke wame weyaus, n∞togkus ∞wadtuatonkqussuonk pomantamwae GOD, kôdt∞hkont wutch nôeu n∞taut ...
    \xe For who is there of all flesh, that hath heard the voice of the living God speaking out of the midst of the fire,...
    \so Deut.5.26
    \nt +
    \xv ...: onk woh kussampotont ket∞hkôan,...
    \xe ..., that thou mightest be justified when thou speakest,...
    \so Ps.51.4  { 2 conjunct }; (M) |ketookoan|
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche ne wuttinn∞waonk, nashpe ket∞hkahettit angelsog, menuhkohtagis,...
    \xe For if the word spoken by angels was steadfast,...
    \so Heb.2.2
    \ng 3p->_0_ participle; |nashpe| erroneous
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kittinneum k∞wehquetumaush ket∞hkaj kutt∞wonk ut wuhtauogkut nussontimom,...
    \xe ..., let thy servant, I pray thee, speak a word in my lord's ears,...
    \so Gen.44.18
    \ng 3->0 imperative
    \xv ... ket∞hkunk k∞wehquetumonumw∞ ut wuhtauogut Pharaoh,...
    \xe ..., speak, I pray you, in the ears of Pharaoh,...
    \so Gen.50.4
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    imperat. 2d sing. |ket∞kash|    1 Sam.3.10  { 2 imperative }
    \xv ..., ahque wabesish, ket∞hkash, ahque ahk∞ash.
    \xe ..., Be not afraid, but speak, and hold notthy peace:
    \so Acts 18.9
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +

    suppos. pass. |ahquompi ne adt keket∞komuk| (freq.) `a time for speaking' [when it is to be spoken]    Eccl.3.7  { X conjunct, to reduplicated stem }

\dv |kutt∞|, `he speaks', with |'k| progressive

[Narragansett [xnt] |kekutto kâunta| `let us speak (talk) together'; |kuttókash| `speak'.]


\lx keket∞kontam
\va ketokontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\ge `to speak (of) sth'
\so Lk.5.21; Jn. 3.31,11.13; Heb.2.3,9.19
    \xv Qut Jesus keket∞kontam wunnupp∞onk: qut nag unnantamwog keket∞kontam wutanwôhsine kouéonk.
    \xe Howbeit Jesus spake of his death: but they thought that he had spoken of taking of rest in sleep.
    \so Jn.11.13

    \xv ..., Howan yeuoh keket∞kontog blasphemaongash?...
    \xe ..., Who is this which speaketh blasphemies?...
    \so Lk.5.21
    \xv Newutche Moses kôdt∞kontog nish noh an∞team∞onk ut wame missinninnúut, neyanussit naumatuonk, neemunum wusqueheunkan∞ kalfsog kah goatsog,...
    \xe For when Moses had spoken every precept to all the people according to the law, he took the blood of calves and of goats,...
    \so Heb.9.19


\lx kezheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 36
\ps v.t.an. / TA, causative
\twn |kesteau| TI2
\ge `he perfects, completes, finishes (him), "creates"'; +`to create, make sb'
\so Gen.1.27; 5.1
    \xv Kah kezheau GOD matikkenunutcheh P∞tâopoh,...
    \xe And God created great whales,...'    Gen.1.21  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    |nukkezeh|, |nukkezheeh| `I create him'  { source? }
    pret. |nukkezheomp|    Is.54.16
    \xv Kezhittinneat.
    \xe To be created
    \so C.45/187.
    \nt +

    \xv ... neg wame puppinashimwog ohkekonit, neh Jehovah Manit keshaumpoh,...
    \xe ... any beast of the field which the Lord God had made. ...'    Gen.3.1  { 3->_3
    \so _ preterite participle }
    \nt +
    \nt MN: ..., ne kesukok GOD kezheunt mìssinninnúh ...
    \ng suppositive |..., ne kesukok GOD kezheunt mìssinninnúh ...| `.... In the day that God reated man,...'    Gen.5.1
    \ps adv
    \xv ..., Pish nuppaguanóog missinninnuog, neg kezheagkuppanneg, wutch woskeche ohket:...
    \xe ..., I will destroy man whom I have created from the face of the earth;...
    \so Gen.6.7  { 1->_3p_ preterite participle }; cf. Gen.7.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., keme kezhimuk: kah wanehimuk ut agwe ohket.
    \xe ...: when I was made in secret, and curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth.
    \so Ps.139.15
    \ng X->1 conjunct
    \nt +

    With inan. obj. |kesteau| (q.v.)

[Cree |kéesehayoo| `he finishes him'; |kéechehayoo| `he begins him'. (See in Howse, Cree Gr., pp. 19, 20, and 84, verbs of `making' in |-káyoo|, |-katáyoo|, and |-kásoo|.)
Western Abenaki [abe] |nekisi`t8n| `j'achève quelque chose'; (with an. ohj.) |nekisihañ|.
Delaware [del] |kischiton| `he makes, prepares (something)'; |kischi| `ready, done'; |kischitoon| `to make something ready'; |kischiecheu| `it is ready, done, finished'    Zeisb.]

\et Ho.1957, no. 88, 262b *ki∙⌠ihe∙wa TA `he completes, finishes, gets done with, him'; A.947, H.1228


\lx kinohtauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37
    \nt +
\ps TA(+O?), perhaps with directive final |-ht-aw-| (or with dative final to TI stem?)
\ge `to give sb a pledge (of sth)'
\so Gen.38.17,18;
    \xv ... Sun woh kukkinohtah noh pajeh negonshuwáan?
    \xe ..., Wilt thou give me a pledge, till thou send it?
    \so Gen.38.17
    \ng 2->1+0
    \xv ... Teaguas kukkinohtaush? ...
    \xe ..., What pledge shall I give thee? ...
    \so Gen.38.18
    \ng 1->2+0

    \se kenohtouáonk
    \ps NI, deverbal noun
    \ge `pledge'
    \so Gen.38.20
    \xv ..., woh attumunum kenohtouáonk wutch mittamwos wuñutcheganit,...
    \xe ..., to receive his pledge from the woman's hand:...
    \so Gen.38.20

    \se kenohtohsuonk
    \va -ong(an
    \ps NI, deverbal noun; identity of verb stem not yet certain
    \ge `pledge'
    \so Ex.22.26; Deut.24.6,10,11,12,13; 1 Sam.17.18
    \xv Nemunuhkitch kenohtohsuonk anomut ohtag togkuhwhonganompsk asuh woskeche togkuhwhonganompsk, newutche nemunum kenohtohsue keteahogkounoh.
    \xe No man shall take the nether or the upper millstone to pledge: for he taketh a man's life to pledge.
    \so Deut.24.6
    \xv ..., kah attumunush ukkinohtôsuongan∞.
    \xe ..., and take their pledge.
    \so 1 Sam.17.18

    \se kenohtohsue
    \ps PreN
    \ge `to pledge' (i.e. "(sb's X) as a pledge", "a pledge (consisting) of sb's X")
    \so Deut.24.6,17
    \xv ..., kenotohsue neemunnum∞kon wuthogk∞onk sekoousq.
    \xe ...; nor take a widow's raiment to pledge.
    \so Deut.24.17
[Western Abenaki [abe] |negheret8n| `Je donne cela pour gages', |negheretá8añ|, v. |8añn| `à lui'    R.266/461a.]

    \se kenuhtohsuan(uh)shau
    \ps TA+O, representative final to stem in |-hs-| seen in preceding nouns?
    \ge ?`to pledge sb for sb'
    \so Gen.43.9
    \xv Nukkinuhtúhsuansh nuhhogkuh, ut nunnutcheganit pish kuttit natauwompam,...
    \xe I will be surety for him; of my hand shalt thou require him:...'    Gen.43.9  { 1->3+3
    \so representative (reflexive direct object)? [why no obviative inflection?] }

\lx kinukkinum
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 37
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he mixes or mingles (one thing with another)'
\so C.

    \nt MN: kinukkinuk
    \ng suppositive |kinukkinuk| `when he mixes it'

    \ps and substantively
    \ge `a mixture', the |kinnikinnic| and |killikinnic| of western tribes, tobacco mixed with the bark of the red osier (Cornus sericea) or leaves of bearberry (Arctostaphylos uva-ursi).

\lx kishke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37
    \ps initial, PreV, PreN (with locative)
    \nt +
\ge `(it is) by the side of, near to, by'
\nt G&B.631 |keskee| `next to, near, beside'
    \xv ..., kah noh kishke neepau ut kishkunk...
    \xe ...; and he stood by them under the tree:...
    \so Gen.18.8
    \ng PreV
    \nt +
    \xv kishke mayut
    \xe by the wayside
    \so Gen.38.14,21
    \xv kishketuk
    \xe by the river's side, the bank, brink of the river
    \so Num.24.6; Ezek.47.6,7
    \xv kishkepeyau
    \xe he came near to
    \so , etc.    Dan.8.17

[Western Abenaki [abe] |kikatsi8i| `contre quelque chose, joignant quelque chose, le long du bord de la rivière'; |ketsi8i| `tout proche'.
Delaware [del] |giechgi|; +|kíixkii| PC `near'    O'M.88a.
Chip. |tchigau| or |tchig|.
Cree |chéeke| `close by, near, nigh, by'.
    Miami |kihci-| II `it is close, near (in distance)'    B&C.53b.
    \nt +
Shawnee [sjw] |ki?ky-| `CLOSE BY'    D.-V.296.]

\et G.1981, 31, 69, 39, 78 *kyi∙Θk- `beside, near to', (no evidence given), with palatalized form Mass. |kehch-|.


\lx kishki
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37
\ps II
\ge `(it is) broad, great from side to side'
\nt G&B.635-636 II `it is wide'
    \xv keitotan missi kah kishki
    \xe the city ( was) large and great
    \so Neh.7.7

    \nt MN: ne kishkag
    \ng suppositive |ne kishkag| (|koshkag|, |koskag|) `the breadth of it, its breadth or width from side to side'    Job 37.10; Ex.26.2,8
    \ps adv
    (= |ne an∞hquekishkag|    Ex.25.10; +also Log.Pr.20/33 as `so broad') { relative preverb |unn∞hque| `so far', T.91b, with changed vowel }

    \xv mishekishkáe
    \xe broad, wide
    \so (absolutely, or as opposed to narrow)    Is.33.21; Mt.23.5

    \se !|unnukishki|
    \nt +
    \ps II, with relative initial/preverb |un-|
    \ps "to be so broad, of such breadth"
    \so Gen.13.18; Log.Pr.

    \xv Omkish paspwushaush ohket nesahteag kah ne anukskag:...
    \xe Arise, walk through the land in the length of it and in the breadth of it;...
    \so Gen.13.18
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle, syncopated

[Western Abenaki [abe] |8sañmikeskég8 keskis8, sse| `Il ë trop large, trop ample (dont il ë habillé ', |keské| `Large, cela l'est'    R.311/475a.
    M.-P. |kskotqe| II `it is wide (of a brook)'; |k@skeeyo| II `es ist weit'; |kskeyu| AI,II `s/he, it is wide, broad'    LeS.34b; Sz.82; F&L.
    \nt +
WAbn. |kaska| II `it is wide' (often |kska|)    D.1.251.]


\lx kishkunk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37
\ps n. / locative expression (PP-like)
\dv |kishk-| `by, near' + |-unk(w)-| `tree, wood'
    \xv ut kishkunk
    \xe under the tree
    \so Gen.18.4,8
\cf mehtug

\et B.95, 117-118/475 *-a∙xkw- `wood, tree', G.65, no. 13, 213ab; this noun stem acts as the object of the prepositional initial (compare, for example, E. "downriver", "overboard", "upstairs", and the obsolete prefix "a-", "adrift", "afire", "afoot")

    \xe ... God ..., who hath withheld from thee the fruit of the womb?

\lx kishpinum
\va kusp-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37

\ge `he ties (it) firmly, binds close, makes fast'
\dv |kuppi| (`close, fast'), with the formative (|-num|, with an. obj. |-nau|) of verbs denoting action of the hand

    imperat. 2d sing. |kispinush|, |kusp-|    Prov.6.21  { erroneous forms! read: |Kishpus|, |kishpus| }

    \se kishpinau

    \xe they tied them

    \so conjunct }
    \nt +


    (Vbl. n. |kishpinóonk| `binding'    C.)

    [Menominee [mez] |kεhpe∙nε∙w| `he ties him'    M.L.76.
    \nt +

\et initial(?): *keΘ- `?' (e.g. "deter, prevent movement"?) Ho.1957, no.65, p.259b, G.1982, 5.102, p.37; final: H. p.249, B.1962 15.61, 286-287: *-piso `be tied' [B. item 15, 5, 87/442, 55, 104/461 *-piso AI `move without obstruction, glide', identified B.1962, 15.61 -- H. has *-peso.]


\lx kishpissu
\va -ussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37
\ps v.i. / AI+O
\ge `he ties or fastens, makes fast'; pass. `he is tied, made fast'

    pl. |-suog| `they are tied'    2 K.7.10
    \xv Kah kishpis kenutcheganit, wutch kukkinneasuonk,...
    \xe And thou shalt bind them for a sign upon thine hand,...

    \ng aphaeresis of |ku-|; form not objective: perhaps in fact imperative, with assimilation of |-(u)sh| to final continuant?
    \nt +
    \xv sunnummatta woh ompinneau wutche kishpissinneat Sabáth dayeu?
    \xe And ought not [she] ... be loosed from this bond on the sabbath day?
    \so Lk.13.16
    \nt +

    \ge `bond'

\lx kitonckquêi
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 37
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he is dead'

    suppos. 2d sing. |kitonckquèan| `when thou diest' [`shalt die']
    3d pl. |-quéhettit| `when they die'

    pret. (intens.) |kakitonckquêban| `they are dead and gone'
    \xv paúsawut kitonckquêwa
    \xe he can not live long' [`he is near dying
    \so ]    R.W.
\dv Apparently from |keteáonk| (vbl.n. from |keteau| q.v.), `the life', with the formative of verbs of going; |keteaonkqáeu| `life goes'. In the Abnaki, a verb adj., from the same base, |ké`tañ8s8|, signified both a dead person and a specter or the apparition of the dead (answering to |chepy|, q.v.); "un qui est mort, si on parle de lui, dicitur |ke`tañ8s8"a|; un mort qui reviens après sa mort, |ké'tañ8s8|," Rasles.

\cf kutchissumau


\lx kittumonkutauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37
    \nt +
\ps TA, aural final
\ge `(for sb-a) to be entreated of sb-b', i.e. "for sb-b to succeed in a plea to sb-a"
\so Gen.25.21
    \xv .., onk Jehovah ukkittumonkutáuoh, kah Rebekah neh ummittumwussoh wompequauoh.
    \xe ...: and the LORD was entreated of him, and Rebekah his wife conceived.
    \so Gen.25.21

\et H.1125 *ketema∙kehtawe∙wa `to hear sb with pity', with final *-eht-aw- `to hear', for which see B.1962, 16.137, p.356.


\lx kitteamonteanumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 37
\ps v.t.an. / TA, mental final
\ge `he pities, is kind to, shows mercy to (him)'

    \xv ... Jehovah kodtumonteanumont,...
    \xe ..., the LORD being merciful unto him:...'    Gen.19.16  { 3->3
    \so changed conjunct }
    \nt +
    \nt MN: Noh kodtumonteanumont matchekuoh,...
    \ng suppositive |Noh kodtumonteanumont matchekuoh,...| `He that hath pity upon the poor,...'    Prov.19.17
    \ps 3
    \xv Kah Ruth um-Moabit unnau Naomìoh, onti ohteuhkonit, kah mukkuppasquadti asuhkaue noh kodtumonteanumit. ...
    \xe And Ruth the Moabitess said unto Naomi, Let me now go to the field, and glean ears of corn after him in whose sight I shall find grace. ...
    \so Ruth 2.2
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |-monch| Zech.7.9
    pl. |-megk| Job 19.21

    \se kitteamonteanittuonk
    \ps Vbl. n. pass. / deverbal noun to theme 2a
    \ge `compassion, mercy'
    \so Num.11.15
    \ge `grace' Gen.34.11
    \nt +

    \se nukkitteamonteanitteam
    \ps v.i. / AI, indefinite object final
    \ge `I pity'

    \xv kittumongkeneankquat
    \xe (when he is) miserable, pitiable

    \xv kuttumung
    \xe sadly
    \so C.

\cf kutamungineaeau
\cf kuttumungee

[Western Abenaki [abe] |neketemañghérmañ..., 3. aket.| `J'ai c'passion de lui.'    R.123/416a.]

\et *ketema∙k- `pity' etc. A.826-833; H.1122-1131; Ho. item 63, 259b: *ketem- `in a bad way, ruined, miserable' (*kete∙m- would match here better?) + *-e∙lem TA, *-e∙lent- TI.

\lx kiyunk

\lx ko
\va koh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 38
\ps may be regarded as the present imperfect or continuing present tense of an irregular and defective verb of existence.
\ge It signifies not merely `he (or it) is', but connotes prior existence, `he continues to be'; |k|, in this as in derivate verbs, denoting continuance or progression. Past existence was expressed by |mo| (q.v.), which we may call the preterite absolute of the same verb, signifying `it was and is not', and therefore not properly employed in speaking of that which continues to be. Eliot has in some instances combined |ko| and |mo|, and |ko| and |pish|, to express the past (aorist) and future tenses of the verb `to be':
    \xv noh koh mo, no koh, noh paont
    \xe who was, and is, and is to come
    \so Rev.4.8
    so |ken nukoh [= |noh koh|] mô, ken nukoh, ken paóan| [and |ken nukoh pish|]    Rev.11.17; 16.5
    |nenukoh| [for |nen noh koh|] `I am' i.e. `I who continue to be'
    and |neen nukoh| `I am'    Mk.13.6 { for "ego sum", against (e.g. AV, Geneva) "I am {Christ}" }
    |mónkô [for |mo ne koh| ?] nnih| `it was so'    Gen.1.7, 9, 11, etc.
    \xv kah uttoh kó wutapin
    \xe and where is he?
    \so Job.14.10, where |kó| serves as an auxiliary to |wutapin|
    \xv Neit toh kó pish nussimun? ...
    \xe What shall we say then? ...
    \so Rom.7.7
    \nt +

|kobhamuk|, |koppô-|, suppos. pass. (inan.) of |kuppi| `stopped, closed'

\va -aong
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps vbl.n.
\ge `an inclosure or shut-up place, a "haven"'
\so Acts 27.8; Gen.49.13
    \xv ketahhanne kobpaonganit
    \xe at the haven of the sea
    \so Gen.49.13
    \nt +

\va kuppi

\cf koppômuk

    \xv kukt∞nog kobpoksheau

\lx kod
\va kodt-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 38
    \ps initial, PreV, desiderative
    \nt +
\ge with a verb, signifies intention, purpose, wish, desire, and sometimes gives to the suppositive present the force of the paulo-post-future, as
    \xv uttoh GOD kod usseit
    \xe What God is about to do
    \so Gen.41.28
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \xv kodayimóg
    \xe intending to build
    \so Lk.14.28√
    \ng 2p->0 conjunct
    \xv kod nuhhug Syria
    \xe as he was about to sail into Syria
    \so Acts 20.3√
    \ng 3 conjunct
    \nt Remark: In all three examples the conjunct form is independently required.
    \nt +
    with the indicative:
    \xv nukodwaantam
    \xe I will be wise
    \so Eccl.7.23

    \nt MN: kodôan
    \ng suppositive |kodôan| `(when) "thou seekest to go"'    1 K.11.22

[Narragansett [xnt] |katoû enéechaw| `she is falling into travail' i.e. is about to be delivered.
Western Abenaki [abe] |kadá8i| inan. subj. |kéda8i| "nota futuri, vel potius ad exprimendum je veux, afin que, sur le point de"    Rasles.
Delaware [del] |n'gatta| `I will' (from |gattamen| `to want, will, desire'); |gotta| `he willeth'    Zeisb.Gr.162.
    In the Chip. and Cree |ka@| (before a vowel, |kad|) or |a@| has apparently lost its desiderative force and become a prefix or auxiliary of the simple future indicative. See Baraga, 88; Howse, 199.]

\et Ho.57, no.21, 253b-254a, G.1981, 2, 57, 44, 97: *katawi, *katw- `be about to, intend to'

    \nt +

\ge ?`end, head, top of (sth)'
\so various lemmata that follow

[Algonquian [alg] |KATCI-| `par un bout, sur le bord d'un objet'    Cq.149ab.]


\lx kodchuki
\va kodchuhkoi
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 38
\ps II ? / NI
\ge `(it is) a piece, or a part of (it)'; +`morsel, parcel of (land)'
\so Judg.9.53; Dan.5.5, 24
    \nt G&B. 488, stem in |ïyü|; 633: |kotchukkoi| NI `piece'
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: The examples that follow show inanimate nouns. The noun is presumably derived from an II verb (cf. B.1962, 14.96: 242), but that is not yet definitively attested in this material (Ps.147.17(M)?).
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nunneemskom kodchuhkoi petukqunneg,...
    \xe And I will fetch a morsel of bread;...
    \so Gen.18.5
    \nt +
    \xv Kah adtóau kodchúhki ohteuk,...
    \xe And he bought a parcel of a field,...
    \so Gen.33.19
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah Benjaminoh aninnumauau nishwudt pasuk∞e kodchuhkí silver, kah napanna tahshit ôhosue hogk∞ongash.
    \xe ...; but to Benjamin he gave three hundred pieces of silver, and five changes of raiment.
    \so Gen.45.22
    \nt +
    \xv ..., negonne wuttugquoh nuttaphum kodchuhkoi ohke,...
    \xe .... The first said unto him, I have bought a piece of ground,...
    \so Lk.14.18
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche nummiskom ne kodchuhkoi wanteauomp.
    \xe ...; for I have found the piece which I had lost.
    \so Lk.15.9
    \nt +
    \xv Matta woh howan upponum∞h wuske kodchuhkoi m∞nak nukkonhogk∞nut,...
    \xe No man putteth a piece of new cloth unto an old garment,...
    \so Mt.9.16; Lk.5.36
    (|Askin neane kodchúkhi weyaus.| `Raw as a piece of meat'    C.28/174)√

\ge `a morsel' (of food)
\so Prov.23.8
    \xv ..., kah quogkinsh kukkodchuhki∞m ut vinegerut...
    \xe ..., and dip thy morsel in the vinegar. ...
    \so Ruth 2.14
    \nt +

    \xv Suhwhuhteau ukkuppadtinumoh onatuh kodchuhkakish puttukqunneg:...
    \xe He casteth forth his ice like morsels:...'    Ps.147.17(M);(E): |kodchuhke petukqunneganit| { Mayhew
    \so s form presumably a conjunct verb }
    \nt +

    |kodchukishk| (|kodchukiwisq|) `a potsherd'    Job 2.8

    \se |kodchuhkesu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \ge `piece'
    \so Lk.24.42
    \xv Kah wuttinnumauouh kodchuhkesu ahabwosit namos, kah honny comb.
    \xe And they gave him a piece of a broiled fish, and of an honeycomb.
    \so Lk.24.42

\lx kodneheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 38
    \nt +
\ps TA+O
\dv |kod-| `desire, intend' + |(un)neh-| TA+O `to do sth to sb'
\ge `to be about, to list, to think to do sth (to sb)'
\so Gen.18.17,41.25; Deut.19.19; Mt.9.13

    \xv ..., Sun woh nutádtahtauon Abraham ne kodnéhheog,
    \xe ..., Shall I hide from Abraham that thing which I do;'    Gen.18.17  { 1->(3
    \so )+_0_ participle; (E0, gloss) "I about to do" }
    \xv Neit pish kittinheau, ne kodneheont wematoh,...
    \xe Then shall ye do unto him, as he had thought to have done unto his brother:...
    \so Deut.19.19
    \xv ..., kah ummahche unnehheouh uttoh kadnehheahettit neansukwhosik nashpe nagum.
    \xe ..., and they have done unto him whatsoever they listed,...
    \so Mk.9.13


\lx kodtantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 38
\ps v.t. / TI1a, mental final
\ge `he desires, longs for, wishes (it)'
\dv |kod|, with the formative of verbs of mental state or disposition
    \xv nukkodtantam
    \xe I desire (it)
    \so Job 33.32

    \xv ..., kodtantog neh pogketinnonat.
    \xe ..., when he was determined to let him go.
    \so Acts 3.13
    \ng 3->0 conjunct
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |ahque kodtantash| `do not desire'    Prov.23.3

    \se kodtantam∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `desire, will'
    \so Prov.18.1; Rom.7.18

    \se kodtanumau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, mental final
    \ge `he desires or longs for (him)', +`to desire sb, for sb's desire to be unto sb, to have a desire unto sb, for sb's soul to cleave unto sb'
    \xv Kah ukketeahogkóunoh kodtanumau Dinah ...
    \xe And his soul clave unto Dinah ...
    \so Gen.34.3
    \nt +

    \nt MN: kodtánumadt
    \ng suppositive |kodtánumadt| `if thou hast a desire unto her'    Deut.21.11

    \se !|kodtantamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to require sth of sb'
    \so Deut.10.12

    \xv ..., teag Jehovah kum Manitt∞m kodtantamungquean, qut webe qushonat Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m,...
    \xe ..., what doth the Lord thy God require of thee, but to fear the Lord thy God,...
    \so Deut.10.12

[Narragansett [xnt] |ncattaûntum| or |ncattiteam| `I long for it'.

\lx kodtantupau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 38
    \nt +
\nt Remark: incorporating Trumbull's lemma |kodtántupont|, |kodtontupont|; currently only attested in conjunct forms
\ps ?AI+O
\dv |kodt-| `top' + |-ontup-| `head' (extended medial) + |-á-| AI to N-final stem
\ge `(?to be) the crown of the (?sb's) head, pate'; the verb apparently denotes a relation between a person and the top of that person's head, with an initial portion composed of two dependent nouns.
\so Gen.49.26; Deut.28.35,33.16,20; Job 2.7; Ps.7.16(M)

    \xv ..., wutch k∞woskeche kusseetut, nô pajeh kodtantudpoan.
    \xe ..., from the sole of thy foot unto the top of thy head.
    \so Deut.28.35; (E1): |kodtantuppoan|
    \ng 2->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah sokshadtoh muhpit nashpe kodtontupont.
    \xe ..., and teareth the arm with the crown of the head.
    \so Deut.33.20
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wutch agwe wussetut, pajeh kodtontupont.
    \xe ... from the sole of his foot unto his crown.
    \so Job.2.7
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wutcheke usseonk pish pogkishin nehenwonche kodtantupont.
    \xe ..., and his violent dealing shall come down upon his own pate.
    \so Ps.7.16(M); (E) |uppuhkukqut|
    \nt +

[Western Abenaki [abe] |8sskitañ'tebi| `[au-dessus] de la tête'; |8skitsi8i| `déhors, au-dessus de'; |Kétté| `in antecessum, avant, auparavant'    R.176/433a;P.46/565a;P.20/555b.
    Algonquian [alg] |katci-| `par un bout, sur le bord d'un objet'; |katci-| `BOUT, Par un--(en saisissant, touchant etc.)'    Cq.149a; Lem.97b-98a.
    \nt ?+
    Mi'kmaq [mic] |u@ktoogwäju@n| `Forehead'    R.115a.
    \nt ?
Ojibwe [oji] |Katigwan| `forehead, brow'; |ngatig| `my forehead'    Bar.182b; Rhodes 1985.480b.]


\lx kodtauwompasu

    \xv ..., kodtauompasupanneg...

    \ps 3
    \xv ..., kah sohwôhteau wame adtòànutcheh, kah kodtaompausitcheh ut templeut,...
    \xe ..., and cast out all them that sold and bought in the temple,...'    Mt.21.12  { _3
    \so _ participle }

    \xe ..., four hundred shekels of silver, current {money} with the merchant.
    \so Gen.23.16
    \ng plural
    \nt +
    \xv Qut kodtauompasuen matta pish qushkinnum∞ ne kodtauompasit,...
    \xe For the seller shall not return to that which is sold,...
    \so Ezek.7.13√

\lx kodtinnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 38
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he draws or pulls (one thing out of another)'; +`to take sth off (from somewhere)'
    \xv Onk Pharaoh kodtinum uppethennutchab wutch wunnutcheganit,...
    \xe And Pharaoh took off his ring from his hand,...
    \so Gen.41.42
    \nt +
    \xv nukkodtannum nuttogkodteg
    \xe I draw (out) my sword
    \so Ex.15.9
    \xv ..., neit kodtinnum ummokis.
    \xe ... So he drew off his shoe.
    \so Ruth 4.8√
    \xv Howan kenaau kutassum∞, asuh kutoxinum∞ petshunt pahsohtheganit, sun woh mat teanuk kukkodtn∞ Saboth dayeu?
    \xe Which of you shall have an ass or an ox fallen into a pit, and will not straightway pull him out on the sabbath day?
    \so Lk.14.5; E1: also |kukkodtn∞|
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh ummokis kodtinuk
    \ng suppositive |noh ummokis kodtinuk| `he who draws off his shoe, "that hath his shoe loosed"'    Deut.25.10

    imperat. 2d sing. |kodtinash|, |-tunush|

    \se kodtinnau
    \va kodnau
    \va kodtunau
    \nt !
    \ps with an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he pulls (him) out'; +`to pluck sb (out of sth)'
    \xv ..., kah nag matta awakompanauóog, asuh pish howan ukkodtunuh wutch nunnutcheganit.
    \xe ...; and they shall never perish, neither shall any man pluck them out of my hand.
    \so Jn.10.28; Mayhew: |ukkodtunuh|
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d pl. |kôdn∞k wutch n∞tauut| `pull him out of the fire'    Jude 23
    with pron. affix |kodinneh| `pull thou me out'    Ps.31.4

\dv |kodt-|, with formative of action performed by the hand.
\cf kodsheau
\ge it falls out of

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nekétenemen| `je tire (manu), v.g. une épine du doigt'; |kéthígan| `tire-bourre'.
    Algonquian [alg] |KIT-|, |KITCI-| `dégainer, quitter, ôter (de), tirer de'    Cq.172b,175b-176ab.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |ktúneew| `pull s.t. animate off, take s.t. animate off, take s.t. animate out (using the hands)', sim. |ktúnum| TI    O'M.101a-104b.
Shawnee [sjw] |kit-| `DIG UP, TAKE OUT'    D.-V.291-292.]

\et Surely not to be separated from A.814-816,834,...; H.1115,1121,1133,...; Ho. no. 61, p. 259a: *ket- `out of enclosure or entanglement'? While *ka∙nt- `push, shove', Ho. no. 32, pp. 254b-255a, H.846-856, esp. 855, may be better formally, it is perversely centrifugal in its sense. If this latter had reflexes in Massachusett, could there have been a blend?

\lx kodtúm∞
\va kodtum∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 39
    \ps II
    \nt +
\ge `(it is) a year'
\nt G&B.634
\so Lev.25.5; Deut.14.22; Lk.2.41
    pl. |-m∞ash|

    \nt MN: kôdtumuk
    \ng suppositive |kôdtumuk| , |-m∞k|    2 K.19.29; Lk.13.7
    \xv ..., kah wutassamuh petukqunneg wutche wame netasu, ne kodtum∞k.
    \xe ...; and he fed them with bread for all their cattle for that year.
    \so Gen.47.17
    \ng 0 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah upeyaunóuh wonk nahohtoeu kodtum∞k,...
    \xe ..., they came unto him the second year,...
    \so Gen.47.18
    \ng 0 conjunct
    \nt +

    \se |kodtum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `a year'
    \so Gen.47.18
    \xv Kah ne kodtum∞ mahtshunk:...
    \xe And when that year was ended,...
    \so Gen.47.18

    \se kodtumwáe
    \va kodtum∞e
    \nt +
    \ps Adj. and adv. / PreN, PreV
    \ge `of a year, yearly'
    \nt G&B.634
    \so Lev.16.34; 25.53
    \xv Nabo neese kodtumwae wuttinneúmohkauaog Chedorlaomer,...
    \xe Twelve years they served Chedorlaomer,...
    \so Gen.14.4
    \nt +
    |Neit na mo mashagquodt pomontog David nishwe kodtumwae kogkodtumwae,...| (freq.) `Then there was a famine in the days of David three years [i.e. three times yearly], year after year;...'    2 Sam.21.1√  { simple and reduplicated }

\nt For |quthum∞| `it measures or is a measure'; suppos. |quadhumuk| (?).
\cf quttuhham

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nquittecautúmmo.| `1 Yeere.'; |Tashecautúmmo?| `How many yeeres?'; Chashecautúmmo cuttáppemus?| `How many yeeres since you were borne?', etc.    R.W.66-67.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |nek8tsigaden;| `Année, 1', |nissigaden;| `2', etc. "one year, two years"    R.24/384b.
Delaware [del] |kattææn| `year'; |Gachtin| `year'; +|katúm| AI `be so many years of age' (with number preverb), |katún| II `be a year'    Camp.; Zeisb., B&A.36; O'M.76b.
Shawnee [sjw] |kut'o|.
    LpA. |ninzi katem8| `il a deux ans'    D.73.
    \nt +
Mahican [mjy] |ngutte kahtenà| `1 Jahr', |nóno káteek| `heuer'    Schm.153.
M.-P. |nisikotone| AI `he is two years old', |'qocikoton| II `it is one year'; |kw@ciik@t@ne| AI `er ist ein Jahr alt', |kw@ciik@t@n, kw@ciik@t@k| II `es ist ein Jahr'    LeS.53b,80b; Sz.98.
WAbn. |ligaden| II `it is a year', |gassigadema| AI `he is so many years old'    D.1.271,182.]


\lx kodtumwohkom
\va kodtumwohkom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 39
\ps v.i. / TI1-O
\dv |kodtúm∞|, with the formative of verbs of progress (|-hkom|) `he goes from year to year';
\ge (with a numeral or indefinite quantitative) `he is -- years old'; +note the use of a PreV form of the number expression.
    \nt G&B.635
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Abram shwósuk tahshinchag kodtumwohkomup kah nequtta,...
    \xe And Abram was fourscore and six years old,...
    \so Gen.16.16
    \ng 3 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Ishmael wunnaumonuh nabo nishwe kodtumwohkomwoh...
    \xe And Ishmael his son was thirteen years old,...'    Gen.17.25  { 3
    \so indicative }
    \xv Onk Joseph nishwinchage kodtumwohkom ne nepauut anaquabit Pharáoh ...
    \xe And Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh ...
    \so Gen.41.46
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Neyaunehchage kodtumwohkomup ...
    \xe Forty years old was I ...
    \so Josh.14.7
    \ng 1 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah teanuk nunksquau omohkeu, kah pómushau, newutche naboneese kodtumwohkom:...
    \xe And straightway the damsel arose and walked: for she was of the age of twelve years. ...
    \so Mk.5.42√
    \ng 3 indicative
    \xv Noh kuttea@she kodtum wöhkom.
    \xe How many years old are you?
    \so C.119/240√
    \ng 2 indicative

    \xv Onk Adam nequt pasuk∞we kah nishwinchag kodtumwohkog, wunnaumonáeu ...
    \xe And Adam lived a hundred and thirty years, and begat a son ...
    \so Gen.5.4 (E1&2); (E0): |kodtumwohkon| "And - Adam - when one - hundred - & - thirty - years old - ..."
    \ng 3->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ... neemunnumwansheh kowushinem nashwekodtum wohkog, & squoshimwe goat nashwe kodtumwohkog, kah ram nashwe kodtumwohkog,...
    \xe ..., Take me an heifer of three years old, and a she goat of three years old, and a ram of three years old,...
    \so Gen.15.9
    \ng 3->_adv_ participle

\lx kogkéau
\va kogkéwau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 39
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he is mad, insane, beside himself'
\so 1 Sam.21.14; Jn.10.20
    \xv Onk wuttinóuh, Kukkogkm, qut ummunnuhkeu unn∞won, Nnih,...
    \xe And they said unto her, Thou art mad. But she constantly affirmed that is was even so. ...
    \so Acts 13.15
    \nt +
    (|kakewau|    Mass. Ps.)
    |kukkogkéi| (pres. actual) `thou art beside thyself'
    |matta nukkogkeoh| (negat.) `I am not mad'    Acts 26.24, 25

    \nt MN: noh kogkeait
    \ng suppositive |noh kogkeait| `he who is mad'
    pl. |-eácheg|    Mt.4.24

    \se kagkeámuk
    \ps suppos. pass. inan, as n.
    \ge `madness, being mad'
    \so 1 Sam.21.13

    \se kogkeáonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `madness'
    \xv Kah nag numwáehtunkquog kogkeáonk,...
    \xe And they were filled with madness;...
    \so Lk.6.11
    \nt +

    \se kogkeaen
    \va -aenin
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a madman'

    \se kogke
    \va kogkee
    \ps Adv.
    \ge `madly, of madness'

    \se kogkeésu
    \ps Vb.adj.
    \ge `he does madly, he is actively mad, "lunatic"'
    \so Mt.17.15

\et possibly *ka∙ki∙w-e∙-wa, heavy reduplication to Ho., no.94, 264a-265a *ki∙w- `around, (re)turning', with senses "act crazily, be dizzy, drunk, silly".

\lx kogkohkham

    \nt +
\ps TI1a, causative
\ge `to describe sth', as OED s.v. 6: "To mark off or distribute into parts; to map or parcel out."
\nt Remark: Compare following lemma |kogkóhsum|.
\so Josh.18.6,9,10
    \xv Kah wosketompaog moncheog, káh pannupwushaog ohke, kah koggohkhamwog ut otanahtu, nesausuk chippe ut b∞kut,...
    \xe And the men went and passed through the land, and described it by cities into seven parts in a book,...
    \so Josh.18.9

    \xv Newajeh pish kogkohkhamóg ohke nesausuk tahshe chippeu, kah paudtiegk;...
    \xe Ye shall therefore describe the land {into} seven parts, and bring {the description} hither to me,...
    \so Josh.18.6

    \xv ..., kah Joshuah ummeechumuhkonuh neh nonche koggohkhamunutcheh ohke, n∞wau, monchek, kah pannupwushagk ohke, & koggohkham∞k,...
    \xe ...and Joshua charged them that went to describe the land, saying, Go and walk through the land, and describe it,...
    \so Josh.18.8

\et Relationship to e.g. Alg., Cq.138ab, |KAK-|, (freq. |KAKAK-|) `à plusieurs côtés, polygone'; Cree, Frs.181b, 297a |kuku`k-| etc. `square' (perhaps the shape a more basic sense than Ho.1957, no.3, 251-252 *kaHk- `sharp')?

\lx kogkôunum
\va kogkóunum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 40
\nt Remark: Listing of reduplicated forms under |kóunum|, T.41a, transferred here.
\ps v.t. freq. / TI1b, manual final, reduplication to |kóunum|, T.41a
\ge `he withholds (it)'; +`to hold sth', e.g. a doctrine; `to take hold on sth'
\so Prov.31.19
    \xv ..., kah wunnutcheg kogkôunum Esau wogquoan ...
    \xe ..., and his hand took hold on Esau's heel;...
    \so Gen.25.26
    \ng 0->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche naut nawutche kogkôunumwog ukkuhk∞tomuhteaonk Balaam,...
    \xe ..., because thou hast there them that hold the doctrine of Balaam,...
    \so Rev.2.14
    \ng !3p->0 absolute
    \nt +

    \xv Neyane wonk neg nawhutche kogkóunukeg ukkuhk∞tomuhteaongan∞ Nicolaitansog, ne sekeneam.
    \xe So hast thou also them that hold the doctrine of the Nicolaitanes, which thing I hate.
    \so Rev.2.15
    \ng _3p_->0 participle
    \nt +

    \se |kogkóunau|, !|kogkôunau|
    \ps with an. obj. / TA, manual final
    \ge `to lay hold of, (up)on, hold sb'
    \so Gen.19.16; Ps.139.10; Rev.20.2
    \xv ..., wosketompaog ukkogkanôuh wunnutcheg,...
    \xe ..., the men laid hold vpon his hand,...'    Gen.19.16  { 3p->3
    \so +0 objective }
    \nt +
    \xv GOD wutomohkinuh wonk, òmpenitwuttammepunnaonganash nupp∞onk, newutche nupp∞onk woh mo ukkogkôunoh.
    \xe Whom God hath raised up, having loosed the pains of death: because it was not possible that he should be holden of it.
    \so Acts 2.24
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kogkoûnau dragonoh, noh nukkonne ask∞k, noh mattannit ...
    \xe And he laid hold on the dragon, that old serpent, which is the Devil,...
    \so Rev.20.2

    \se kogkôunumauau
    \ps with an. 2d obj. / TA+O, |-aw-| stem
    \ge `he withholds (it) from (him)'
    \xv kukkogkôunumau
    \xe thou withholdest (it) from him
    \so Job 22.7

\dv |kóunum|.

\lx komm∞to
\va kumm∞to
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 40
\ps v.i, and t. inan. / AI(+O)
\ge `he steals'
\nt G&B.635
\so Gen.31.19; Mt.6.20
    \xv ...: newutche Jakob matta wahteaúou Rachel ukkumm∞tinuh.
    \xe .... For Jacob knew not that Rachel had stolen them.'    Gen.31.32  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche ut toh woh nuttin kumm∞tnan wutch kussontimom weekit silver asuh gold?
    \xe ...: how then should we steal out of thy lord's house silver or gold?
    \so Gen.44.8
    \ng 1p->0 subordinative
    pl. |kumm∞towog|    Mt.6.19
    (|Nukkumm∞t| `I steal'    C.77/210)

    suppos. pass. inan. |ne komm∞tomuk| `that which is stolen'    Gen.31.39
    \xv Kah noh komm∞tuk wosketompuh, onk magu, asuh namehteauut wunnutcheganit, pish nushau.
    \xe And he that stealeth a man, and selleth him, or if he be found in his hand, he shall surely be put to death.'    Ex.21.16  { 3->_3
    \so _; to C-final stem }; also Ex.22.1, Deut.24.7
    \nt +

    imperat. of prohib. 2d pl. |komm∞tuhkon| `do not steal'    Ex.20.15; Mk.10.19

    \se komm∞towonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `stealing, theft'
    \so Ex.22.3; Hos.4.2

    \se komm∞towaen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a thief'
\dv |kémeu| `secretly, by stealth'.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Cukkúmmote wèpe.| `You steale'; |Kamóotakick.| (suppos. pl.) `Thieves'    R.W.171/r.179; 128/r.136√
Chip. |kemoodeshkeh| `he is a thief'; suppos. |chegemoodid| `he who steals'    Jn.10.1,10.
Western Abenaki [abe] |kem8tené| `il dérobe'.
Delaware [del] |kimochwen| `to steal away privately'    Zeisb.]

\et H. 1001,1004, S. no. 205, p.390: *kemo∙twe∙wa TA, *kemo∙twiwa AI+O `to steal'


\lx -kompau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 40
    \nt +
\ps final, AI
\ge `to stand'
\nt Remark: No example of use as initial in current corpus. Cuoq (146b) only lists a final |-KAPAW,I| `être debout, tenir debout', and dictionaries of various other languages (e.g. Cree, Delaware, Fox) clearly attest non-initial uses without obvious initial occurrences. Day gives |gôbo| AI `he stands', D.1.217, but I have found no example of use as an initial in Rasles. There was an exchange between Michelson and Gerard (1911-1912) on this point, although Michelson had stated clearly "It should be noted that Baraga does not specify that {nin gabaw} can not be used initially. Since the correspondents in the related languages cannot occur as initial stems, I doubt if this can in Ojibwa." (Michelson 1911: 339).

    \cf amakompau
    \cf chequnikompau
    \cf kehchekompauwehtauau
    \cf nauwakompau
    \cf onchekompau
    \cf quenikkompau
    \cf quesikkompau
    \cf quinnuppekompau
    \cf quttukkuhquakompau
    \cf menuhkekompau
    \cf menuhtekompau
    \cf noekompau
    \cf nó-
    \cf nôu-
    \cf quoshagkompau
    \cf weechekompaumau
    \cf weinnekompau

    \se -kompattau
    \nt Remark: This appears to parallel the relationship seen in |neepau|/|neepatt(e)au|, T.81ab.
    \ps final, II
    \ge `to stand'

    \cf menuhtikompattau
    \cf waenekompattau

    \xv woskeche komuk
    \xe the top of the house
    \so Is.22.1

    \xe in the watch tower

    \so Lk.12.24
    (|maayea-kömuk| `meeting-house'    C.)
    `At length, we came to { |Mattapuyst| }, and went to the { |Sachimo Comaco| } (for so they call the { Sachims } place, though they call an ordinarie house { |Witeo| })...'    Winslow 1624,27.25-27
