\lx koshkomme
\va -eu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 41
    \nt +
\ps PreN, PreV
\ge `accidentally, before the time, out of due time, uncertain'
\nt Remark: Usage in Gen.41.44 diverges.
\so Gen.41.44; Num.14.4; Deut.20.19(Hd); Mt.8.29; 1 Cor.15.8; Log.Pr.21/34
    \xv ..., Nen Pharaoh, matta pish howan koshkomme tahshinum∞ wunnutcheg asuh wusseet ut wame ohkit Egypt.
    \xe ..., I am Pharaoh, and without thee shall no man lift up his hand or foot in all the land of Egypt.
    \so Gen.41.44
    |koshkome nushehteaonk| Cf. "The expiation of an vncertaine murder", Dut.21, summary to v.1, also E2, except spelling.    Deut.20.19(Hd) (E1: Deut.21.4(Hd))) { Deut.21.1: "IF {one} bee found slaine in the lande,..., {and} it bee not knowen who hath slaine him:" }
    \xv ...? sun kuppeyam kutawakompunnasunnanonut koshkommeu.
    \xe ...? art thou come hither to torment us before the time.
    \so Mt.8.29
    {Sometimes  accidentally  doth it.}
    |M∞mansh     koshkome      wutussen.|
    {D[e]ut} 4.42. {D[e]ut} 19.5.    Log.Pr.21/34. { The two references are to accounts of accidental death; |koshkomme| is not used in either passage. }

\lx kouéu
\va kouweu
\va koueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 41
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `he sleeps'; +`to lie (down), to lodge' (cf. OED lodge v. 7: "To remain or dwell temporarily in a place; {esp.} to pass the night, sleep. Now {rare}"); `to dream'; euphemistically: `to be asleep' "to be dead"
\so Gen.2.21; Mt.8.24; 9.24
    \xv Qut God peyaonau Abimilechuh ut kouénat...
    \xe But God came to Abimelech in a dream by night,...
    \so Gen.20.3
    \ng X t-subordinative; also Gen.20.6
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah na kouéneau ash papaumwusháhettegkup.
    \xe ..., and [they] lodged there before they passed over.
    \so Josh.3.1
    \nt +
    (definit. pres. |kouéi| `he is asleep, he now sleeps'    1 K.18.27)
    \xv nukkouem
    \xe I sleep
    \so Cant.5.2
    \xv Newutche nag kaécheg kouéog ut nukonit,...
    \xe For they that sleep sleep in the night;...
    \so 1 Thess.5.7
    \nt +

    \xv Qut asquam kaéhetteg wosketompaog...
    \xe But before they lay downe,...
    \so Gen.19.4
    \ng 3p->_adv_ negative changed conjunct
    \nt +
    suppos. 2d sing. |kaéan| `thou that sleepest'    Ruth 1.16, Eph.5.14√
    3d sing. |noh kait|, |kawit| `he who sleeps'
    \xv ..., kuhkinneasish uttoh kait,...
    \xe ...thou shalt mark the place where he shall lie,...
    \so Ruth 3.4
    \nt +
    pl. |papaume nag káwécheg| `concerning them which are asleep' (i.e. dead)    1 Thess.4.13
    \xv Qut kaéhettit wosketompaog
    \xe But while men slept,...
    \so Mt.13.25
    \nt +

    \se kouéonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `sleeping, sleep'
    \so Prov.24.33
    \xv mishekoueonk
    \xe a deep sleep
    \so Gen.15.12

    \se kouéuen
    \va -énin
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a sleeper'
    \so Jonah 1.6

[Narr. (pres. defin.) |cowwêwi| `he is asleep'; |cowwêwock| `they sleep'; |yò cowish| `lodge here'; (suppos.) |câwit| `while he slept'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |neka8i| `je dors'; 3. |ka8.|    R.186/436b.
Delaware [del] |gauwiu|, participle pres. (suppos.) |gewi| `sleeping', |gauwin| `to sleep'; |n'gáuwi| (|n'gówe| Cass) `I sleep'; |kawíiw| AI `sleep'    Zeisb.; Hekw.; O'M.76b-77b.
    Algonquian [alg] |KAW-| `à bas', |Kawicim,o| `être couché'    Cq.150ab.
    \nt +
Cree x|KAW| (rac.) `faire succomber, jeter par terre, abattre', |KAWISSIMOW| `il se couche, il se met au lit.'    Lac.D.377a-378a.
Lp.A |mat nika8i| `je nedors pas'; |etenh kika8i| `dors tu'; |ka8i8| `il dort'; |ka8i8ok| `ils dorment'; |nika8i8ank| `mon sommeil'    D.56;7;53.
    WAbn. |nekawí| `I sleep'; |gaó| `he sleeps'    W.133;D.1964.388b.]
    \nt +

\lx kowashinneog
\va kowashinog
\va c-
\va k∞-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 41
    \nt +
\ps NA, plurale tantum, though G&B.615 gives the singular form |Couish|.
\dv |kow-| `cow' + something that looks suspiciously similar to |-ashim(w)-|, `beast', q.v, T+.14b.
\ge `cattle, kine'
\nt Remark: Eliot appears not to observe any consistency in the translations of the AV terms in this semantic domain or in the spellings. The entry gives only a rough guide.
\so Gen.32.15,41.2-4,18-20; Num.31.28,30,33,38,44; Deut.28.4,18,51
    \xv ...: yauunchágkodtoh kowashinoh, kah piukqussuog nomqoshimwog. ...
    \xe ..., forty kine and ten bulls,...
    \so Gen.32.15
    \xv Kah mamátchissitcheg, kah ianauwussitcheg k∞washinog mahchep∞og nesausuk adtahs∞unutcheh, kah waanogqunutcheh kowashinneah,...
    \xe And the ill-favoured and lean-fleshed kine did eat up the seven well-favoured and fat kine. ...
    \so Gen.41.4
    \xv ..., kah ummeechummuongan∞ kenetasumog; wunnetuongan∞ kukkowashinumog,...
    \xe ..., and the fruit of thy cattle, the increase of thy kine,...
    \so Deut.28.4

    \se kowashinne
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of a bullock' [! -- though cf. OED s.v. sb. +2 "Applied loosely to a bull, or bovine beast generally. {Obs.} exc. {dial.}"; EDD "Horned cattle of either sex"; does not list Essex or Herts.]
    \so Deut.15.19,33.17
    \xv Wussohsumôonk ogqueneunkquodtich ukkowashinne mohtomegheonche,...
    \xe His glory is like the firstling of his bullock,...
    \so Deut.33.17

    \se kowashinem
    \va kowashenem
    \va kowashinemes-
    \ps NA, final |-ashim(w)| (+ diminutive)
    \ge `(young) bullock, calf, heifer'
    \so Gen.15.9; Lev.4.3,4,7,8,10,12,14,15,20,21,8.2; Lk.15.23
    \xv ... neemunnumwansheh kowushinem nashwekodtum wohkog,...
    \xe ..., Take me an heifer of three years old,...
    \so Gen.15.9
    \xv Kah pish pas∞au kowashinemesoh,...: kah pish ponam wunnutcheg, uppuhkukqut kowashinem, kah nushau kowashinnemesoh,...
    \xe And he shall bring the bullock ...; and shall lay his hand upon the bullock's head, and kill the bullock ...
    \so Lev.4.4
    \xv Neyane amaunumuk wutch kowashenemesut,...
    \xe As it was taken off from the bullock ...
    \so Lev.4.10
    \xv Kah pas∞k wanogqut kowashenem,...
    \xe And bring hither the fatted calf,...
    \so Lk.15.23; cf. Lk.15.27 |... & k∞sh nushau wanogqunutche Calfeoh,...|

    \se kowashinnemese
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of the bullock'
    \so Lev.4.5
    \xv ..., pish neemunum wutch kowashinnemese wusqueheunk:...
    \xe ... [he] shall take of the bullock's blood,...
    \so Lev.4.5

\lx k∞tnau
\va k∞tnehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
\ps v.t. / TI2
\ge `he makes an addition to (it), increases (it) by adding'
(cf. |k∞chteau|)
    \xv ..., kah matta ukk∞tnauóun,...
    \xe ... and he added no more. ...
    \so Deut.5.22√
    \xv ukk∞tnehteauun
    \xe he addeth to it
    \so Gal.3.15

    \xv ahque k∞tnish
    \xe thou shalt not [do not] add to it
    \so Deut.12.32
    imperat. 2d pl. |k∞tnehteau∞k| `add ye to (it)'    1 Pet.1.5
    \xv ..., anantogig k∞tnehteauunach wutonkapunaonk ut kenepissuonganit.
    \xe ..., supposing to add affliction to my bonds:'    Phil.1.16 { if treated as o.r. for o.o.: `supposing: "let them add ..."
    \so ; no X form cited by G&B. 572 }
    \nt +


\lx k∞tnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
    \nt +
\ps TI1b
\ge `to add sth'
\so Lev.6.5,27.13,15,19,27,31; Mt.25.3, Log.Pr.43/56,44,51/63
    \xv ..., kah pish k∞tnum napannna adtahshe chippag. ...
    \xe ..., and shall add the fifth part more thereto,...
    \so Lev.6.5
    \xv Onk nag as∞kutcheg neemunnumwog ∞wequanantegan∞ash, qut matta k∞tnum∞og pumme.
    \xe They that were foolish took their lamps, and took no oil with them:
    \so Mt.25.3
    \ng i.e. "did not add oil"

            {Predicate.}
    |2. Ne K∞tnumuk.|    Log.Pr.43/56 { i.e. "what is added" }


\lx k∞wa
\va k∞
\va k∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a pine tree, "fir"'
\nt G&B.633: |koowa| `pine tree'.
\so Hos.14.8
    \xv Na wuttit wadjisheahkoneau psuksesog: kah stork ∞wetu k∞waoh.
    \xe Where the birds make their nests: as for the stork, the fir-trees are her house.
    \so Ps.104.17
    \nt +
    pl. |k∞waog|
\dv the same root as |kóus|, the tree, like the English pine (pin tree), taking its name from its pointed leaves, épines, or its general shape.

[Narragansett [xnt] |kówaw| `a pine tree'; dimin. |kowawésuck| (pl.) `young pines'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |k8"é| `pin'; |kañ8is| `épine'    Rasles; modern. Abn. |ko-wa| `pine tree'    K.A.
Delaware [del] |cu-we|    Zeisb.]


\lx k∞wutche

\so Trumbull 42
    \nt +
\ps P
\ge `among, amongst' (and other prepositions in related senses)
\nt Remark: Semantic relationship to |kenugke| unclear.
\so Gen.20.16,23.6,18,34.30,40.20, Mt.11.11,27.56, Mk.13.10, Acts 20.30,32,24.5
    \xv ... kusseh yeuoh kuttungquequohhou k∞wutche neg weetomukqueaneg, kah wamu {onkatogeg}:...
    \xe ...: behold, he {is} to thee a covering of the eyes, unto all that are with thee, and with all {other}:...
    \so Gen.20.16
    \ng for "unto"
    \xv N∞taiinnean nussontimom ken manittoe Sontim k∞wutche neenawun,...
    \xe Hear us, my lord: thou art a mighty prince amongst us:...
    \so Gen.23.6
    \xv Kah wunaunchem∞kaonk mos negonne n∞tamwahuwon k∞wutche wame wutohtimoneat.
    \xe And the gospel must first be published among all nations.
    \so Mk.13.10

\lx kuhkenauun-

    \nt +
\ps transitive, manual final
\ge "to fashion, form sb"
\so currently only known in derived forms

    \ps II, patient final
    \ge "to be formed, have a form" (stative)
    \so Gen.1.2
    \xv Kah Ohke mômatta kuhkenauauneunkquttinn∞ kah monteagunninno,...
    \xe And the earth was without form, and void,...
    \so { 0 negative indicative }


\lx kuhkenauwéhhéau
\va kuhkenauweheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
\ps v.caus. an. / TA causative
\ge `he shapes, fashions, gives form to (an an. obj.)', +`to form sb, work sb curiously'
\so Job 26.13
\dv (augm. of |kenaiheau|, T.33a)
    \xv Kenutchegash nukkezhikup, kah waeenumoae nukkuhkenauwehhikqunapash,...
    \xe Thine hands have made me and fashioned me together round about;...
    \so Job 10.8
    \ng 0p->1 preterite objective
    \xv ...; wunnutcheg, kuhkenauwéheau pepemsque ask∞koh.
    \xe ...; his hand hath formed the crooked serpent.'    Job.26.13  { 0->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    pass. |kuhkenaihetteau| `he is formed'
    pret. |Kusseh nukkuhkenaihetteap ut matcheetupanatamwonganit:..| `Behold, I was shapen in iniquity;...'    Ps.51.5; (M) |nukkehkenawehhitteap|  { X->1 preterite indicative }
    \xv ..., noh kuhkénauéheop chansompsoh,...
    \xe ..., he formed grasshoppers...'    Amos 7.1  {  3->3
    \so preterite absolute }
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah k∞wánhuk GOD, noh kahkenahikqueop.
    \xe ..., and hast forgotten God that formed thee.
    \so Deut.32.18
    \ng _3_->2 preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wunnuhteae kahkenawehhimuk ut ohkee appesunut.
    \xe ..., and [I was] curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth.
    \so Ps.139.15(M)
    \ng X->1 changed conjunct
    \nt +
    \nt MN: kahkenauwéheont
    \ng suppositive |kahkenauwéheont| `he forming (when he forms)'    Is.44.0


    \se kuhkenauwehteau
    \ps With inan. obj. / TI2
    \ge `he shapes or fashions (it)'
    pret. |Nukkuhkenauwehteop wequai kah nukkezteop pohkenni:...| `I form the light, and create darkness:...'    Is.45.7  { 1->0 preterite absolute }

    \xv ... noh kahkenauwehteunkup noadt.
    \xe ... him that fashioned it long ago.
    \so Is.22.11
    \ng _3_->0 preterite participle
    \nt +

    \se kuhkénauwe
    \ps Adv.
    \ge `shapely, in order, orderly'
    \so Lk.1.1,3

\cf kenauwameonk


\lx kuhkham
\va kuhham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
\ps v.t. / TI1a, causative

    \xv ukkuhkhamun
    \xe he marks it out' (|nashpe pemunneat| `by a line
    \so Is.44.13)

    \xv kuhheganehtu
    \xe within the lines, "gates"
    \so Deut.15.7

    `line'    Is.28.10

\lx kuhkinneam
\va kehkinneam
\va kehkeneam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
\ps v.t / TI1a
\twn |kuhkinneau|, TA
\ge `he observes, takes note of, marks (mentally or by observation)'; +`to behold, look on, see sth'
\so Lev.13.33
    \xv SAbbath mahche paumushaum∞uk, ..., Mary Magdalen kah onkatuk Mary peyaog kuhkinneamunat weenohke.
    \xe In the end of the sabbath, ..., came Mary Magdalene and the other Mary to see the sepulchre.
    \so Mt.28.1
    \nt +
    \xv NE week negonne kesukok peyau Mary Magdalene nompoaeu, ash papesukok, en weenohkeet, kah kuhkinneam qussuk amaunumunat wutche weenohkeet.
    \xe The first day of the week cometh Mary Magdalene early, when it was yet dark, unto the sepulchre, and seeth the stone taken away from the sepulchre.
    \so Jn.20.1; [Mayhew: |naumup|]
    \nt +
    \xv Kah numm∞cheke móh, newutche wanne howan namehheóon tapenum woshwunnumunat kah wutogketamunat ne b∞k, asuh ukkehkenaumunat.
    \xe And I wept much, because no man was found worthy to open and to read the book, neither to look thereon.
    \so Rev.5.4
    \nt +

    (|nukkeehkeneam| `I view'    C.).

    \nt MN: kóhkinnuk
    \ng suppositive |kóhkinnuk|
    3d pl. |...: yeu ne wunnókonum Jehovah, ne woh kóhkinnumohettit wunnaumonuh Israel pannuppu uppometuongan∞ont.| `...: this is that night of the Lord to be observed of all the children of Israel in their generations.'    Ex.12.42√

    \xv ..., tahshinum∞k kuskesuk∞∞ash kah kuhkinneam∞k ohteuhkonash, Newutche pagodche wompiyeuash en kepenumunat.
    \xe ..., Lift up your eyes, and look on the fields; for they are white already to harvest.
    \so Jn.4.35; Mayhew: |kehkinneam∞k|
    \nt +
    \xv Kuhkinneash yeuwutche ∞neet∞wonk kah wutonkquenehuwáonk GOD,...
    \xe Behold therefore the goodness and severity of God:...
    \so Rom.11.22
    \nt +

\et  G.1981, 41, 85, 42, 89; H.1144-1168: *kexk- `known, observed, marked' + final *-in- (related to the final in |n-| TI, |naw-| TA, meaning `to see'?).


\lx kuhkinneasu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
\ps v.i. / AI(+O)
\ge `he makes a mark, distinguishes by mark or observation'; +`to observe sth' (e.g. a feast, statutes)
\so Job 33.11
    \xv Onk wematoh ishkauónuk, qut ∞shoh kukkinneasu wuttinn∞waonk.
    \xe And his brethren envied him; but his father observed the saying.
    \so Gen.37.11
    \nt +
    \xv Pish kukkehkeneas Tabernakle mishadtupp∞onk nesausuk tahshequinne, mahche mohmounuman k∞weatchiminneash kah k∞wineum.
    \xe Thou shalt observe the feast of tabernacles seven days, after that thou hast gathered in thy corn and thy wine:
    \so Deut.16.13
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |..., kuhkinneasish uttoh kait,...| `... thou shalt mark the place where he shall lie,...'    Ruth 3.4√
    \xv Newutche n∞tam∞k woi Israel, kah kuhkinneasek ussenat,...
    \xe Hear therefore, O Israel, and observe to do it;...
    \so Deut.6.3
    \nt +

    \se kuhkinneasuonk
    \va -ong(an
    \nt +
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI
    \ge `a mark, sign, token'
    \so Rev.13.16; 14.9; Is.20.3
    pl. |-ongash|    Gal.6.17; Ps.135.9
    \xv ..., mahche unnupp∞num ukkéhkinneasuonk, God wunnumuhkitteyeu∞.
    \xe ..., [he] hath set to his seal, that God is true.
    \so Jn.3.33(M)
    \ng 3 possessor

    \se !|kuhkinneausonganu|, |kuhkinneasuonganu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to be for a sign, token'
    \so Gen.1.14,9.13

    \xv ...kah kukkineasuonganuhhettich,...
    \xe ..., and let them be for signs,...
    \so Gen.1.14
    \ng 0p imperative


\lx kuhkinneasuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
    \nt +

\ge `to seal sb' [i.e. "to put a sign on"?]
\so ?Mt.27.66; Jn.6.27(E&M)
    \xv ..., ukkehkinneahsukonau qussuk, kah ponamwog askuhwhósuonk,
    \xe ..., ukkehkinneahsukonau qussuk, kah ponamwog askuhwhósuonk,

    \xv ...: newutche Mannit Wutt∞shumau noh ukkehkinneasuhkouopah.
    \xe ...: for him hath God the Father sealed.'    Jn.6.27(M)  { 3->3

    \so preterite changed conjunct }


\lx kuhkinneau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 42
    \nt +
\ps TA
\twn |kuhkinneam|, TI1a
\ge `to behold, look on, see sb'
\so Mt.22.11; Mk.3.5; Jn.19.26,27; Acts 23.1
\nt Perhaps two stems, one with |-aw-| extension (probably |-naw-| `see'); see under etymology of |kuhkinneam|.
    \xv Kah ketass∞t paont ukkehkenaùonat missinninnuh, na wunnauun wosketompuh matta wussentamwae wunashaiyoou.
    \xe And when the king came in to see the guests, he saw there a man which had not on a wedding garment:'    Mt.22.11 { 3->3
    \so t-subordinative }
    \xv ONk Paul wutahchuwe kuhkinneau kan∞nuttinutche, n∞wau,...
    \xe And Paul, earnestly beholding the council, said,...
    \so Acts 23.1

    \xv Kah weéne musquanetamwu kuhkinneauont, neuantog pogkenumoonk ut wuttahh∞wout, unnau wosketompuh, Summagunush kenutcheg,...
    \xe And when he had looked round about on them with anger, being grieved for the hardness of their hearts, he saith unto the man, Stretch forth thine hand. ...
    \so Mk.3.5
    \ng Or |-aw-| stem?

    \xv ..., unnau ohkasoh, Mittamwossis kuhkinneau Kenaumon.  Neit unnau ukkodnetuhtauaénumoh, Kuhkinneau kokas.
    \xe ..., he saith unto his mother, Woman, behold thy son!  Then saith he to the disciple, Behold thy mother!
    \so { |-aw-| stem? }     Jn.19.26-27

    \se kuhkinneanungqussu
    \ps AI, verb of undergoing
    \ge `to be known' (i.e. "observable, knowable through seeing")
    \so Gen.41.21
    \xv Onk mahchipwóhettit, matta kuhkenaneungqusseog, nah umm∞wh∞óguh,...
    \xe And when they had eaten them up, it could not be known that they had eaten them,...
    \so Gen.41.21

\nt cf. Tooker on the interpretation of the name Cheekanoe, Cockenoe, etc., 1896, 21-22

\lx kuhk∞wau

\lx kuhkinnegan

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\lx kuhkuhhunk

\lx kuhkuhqueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 43
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `he goes upward, ascends'
\so Ex.24.15, 18; Judg.13.20
    \xv ... wutch wunnehtoonganit nunnaumon kukkuhkukquem,...
    \xe ... from the prey, my son, thou art gone up:...
    \so Gen.49.9
    \nt +

    \xv Kah matta howan kuhkuhquet en kesukqut, qut noh n∞kit wutch kesukqut,...
    \xe And no man hath ascended up to heaven, but he that came down from heaven,...
    \so Jn.3.13(E1&2)
    \ng presumably 3 (negative?) conjunct, as "there is none that ..."
    \nt +
    \nt MN: howan kohkuhqueit
    \ng suppositive |howan kohkuhqueit| `who shall ascend?' etc.    Rom.10.6

    \xv Kenupshagk kuhkuhquegk en n∞shut,...
    \xe Haste ye, and go up to my father,...
    \so Gen.45.9
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Kuhkuhquish kah posekin k∞sh,...
    \xe ..., Go up, and bury thy father,...
    \so Gen.50.6
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kuhkuhquehettekitch wame missinninnuog, qut papaume, neese muttannonganog kussuog asuh papaume nishwe muttannonganog kussuog wosketompaog kuhkuhquehettich, kah togkodtamwehettich Ai,...
    \xe ..., Let not all the people go up; but let about two or three thousand men go up and smite Ai;...
    \so Josh.7.3
    \ng 3p prohibitive, 3p imperative

    \se kuhkuhque
    \ps Adv.
    \ge `above, higher'
    \so Josh.15.19

    suppos. inan. |kohkuhquag| (`that which goes above') `a summit, a heap'. { e.g. Josh.3.13; to a verb !|kuhkuhqui| II? }
    [|onatuh kottonkquag| `as an heap'    Mass.Ps.33.7√]

    \se |kukuhqueiyeu|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `upper'
    \so Josh.16.5
    \xv ...wutohtoongane sussippoiyeum∞, wutchépoaeu, ne Ataroth addar, wehque kuhkuhqueiyeu Beth-horon.
    \xe ...: even the border of their inheritance on the east side was Atarothaddar, unto Bethhoron the upper;
    \so Josh.16.5

    \se |kuhkuhqsheau|, |kukhkuksheau|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \dv |kuhkuhqu-| + |-uhshô| `go, walk'
    \ge `to go up (to somwhere)', verb of motion for spatial configuration
    \so Josh.15.6,7,8
    \xv ...: kah sussippoi kuhkuhqsheau en koduhkoag wadchuut,...
    \xe ...: and the border went up to the top of the mountain ...
    \so Josh.15.8

    \se kuhkuhqshin
    \ps With inan. subj. / II
    \dv |kuhkuhqu-| + |-uhshun| `become, fall'
    \nt +
    \ge `it goes up'
    \so Ezek.41.7

    \xv ..., ne anaquohtag en kuhkukqshik Adumim, ne sowaniyeueiyeu sepuut,...
    \xe ..., that is before the going up to Adummim, which is on the south side of the river:...
    \so Josh.15.7

    \se |kuhkuhquehtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, |-ht-aw-| stem
    \ge `to go up (un)to sb', i.e. "to climb, go higher to"
    \so Deut.10.1; Josh.15.15
    \xv Kah na wutch kuhkuhquehtáuáu en nah wadohkinitcheh Debir,...
    \xe And he went up thence to the inhabitants of Debir:...
    \so Josh.15.15

    \xv ... kah kuhkuhquehtah en wadchuut, kah ayish mehtugque Ark,
    \xe ..., and come up unto me into the mount, and make thee an ark of wood.
    \so Deut.10.1
    \nt +

    \se !|kuhkukqueanishau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, |-nuhsh-| final, representative/benefactive
    \ge `to go up for sb'
    \so Deut.30.12

    \xv ...howan pish kohkuhqueanishhikqueog ne kesukquehtu,...
    \xe ..., Who shall go up for us to heaven,...?
    \so Deut.30.12
    \ng sp. with additional |h| E1&2: no obvious role

\cf qunnukque
\cf qunnunkque

B.1962, 16.102, 348-349 |-poN-|, |-poto∙| `snatch, pull, handle roughly', "No connective is used with the roots |εN-|, |oN-|, |pi∙t-|;..."; H. p. 248. (His no. 93 belongs with *-piΘ "tie".)

\lx kukkehtau
\va kukkeihtau
\va kuhkeihtauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 43
\ps v.t. an. / TA, aural final |-(u)ht-aw-|
\ge `he gives attention to, hearkens to, observes (him)'; +`to give ear unto sb'
\dv |kuhkham| he marks (?).
    \nt Remark: There seem to be stems with and without |-aw-|, though the former predominate; insufficient data to sort it out at present.
    \nt +
\so +Gen.4.23,49.2; Ps.77.1
    \xv Kah Moses ken∞nau wunnaumonuh Israel, qut mat kuhkeitauwóowog Mosesoh,...
    \xe And Moses spake so unto the children of Israel: but they hearkened not unto Moses...
    \so Ex.6.9
    \ng |-aw-| stem
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Kusseh, wunnaumonuh Israel matta nukkeihketunk∞og, kah uttôh woh nuttin Pharaoh kuhkeihtunkqunan? kah neen matta quoshqusausin∞ nussissitt∞nash.
    \xe ..., Behold, the children of Israel have not hearkened unto me; how then shall Pharaoh hear me, who am of uncircumcised lips?
    \so Ex.6.12
    \ng |-aw-| stem; 3p->1; subordinative 3->1p??
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah Jehovah nukkeihtunkup wonk na ut ahquompak, kah Jehovah matta kuppaguanuk∞p.
    \xe ...; and the Lord hearkened unto me at that time also, and the Lord would not destroy thee.
    \so Deut.10.10
    \ng |-aw-| stem, 3->1 preterite
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Tohhen sampoi anaquabìt GOD, kukkuhkuttonteaneau m∞cheke neit GOD, wussittum∞k kenaau.
    \xe ..., Whether it be right in the sight of God to hearken unto you more than unto God, judge ye.
    \so Acts 4.19
    \ng |-aw-| stem, TA+O X->2p form?
    \nt +
    \xv Onk Peter chuhchunkquttáhhog squont nunksq kohketauont, ussowesu Rhoda.
    \xe And as Peter knocked at the door of the gate, a damsel came to hearken, named Rhoda.
    \so Acts 12.13
    \ng |-aw-| stem
    \nt +

    \xv Kah matta kukkeihtaéog kukquoshqussosinneaout; neit neemunnomun nuttaunun, kah nummonchemun
    \xe But if ye will not hearken unto us, to be circumcised; then will we take our daughter, and we will be gone.
    \so Gen.34.17
    \ng negative }; |matta kukkehtiéóg|    Lev.26.14 { 2p->1(p), |-aw-| stem
    \nt +
    \xv Neane kukkehtauogkup Moses ut nish noh teag, ne kittinne kuhkehtauununan:...
    \xe According as we hearkened unto Moses in all things, so will we hearken unto thee:...
    \so Josh.1.17
    \ng |-aw-| stem; 1p->3+_"0"_; 1p->2+"0"
    \nt +

    Imperat. 2d sing. |kukkeitash|    Ps.45.10
    [|ahchusutash|    Mass. Ps.]
    (2d+1st sing.) |kukkehtah| `hearken to me'    Num.23.18
    \xv Moiék kah n∞tam∞k kenaau wunnaumonuh Jakob, kah kukkeitók Israel k∞sh∞.
    \xe Gather yourselves together, and hear, ye sons of Jacob; and hearken unto Israel your father.
    \so Gen.49.2
    \ng not of |-aw-|-stem shape?
    \nt +
    2d pl. |noh kukkeitok| `to whom, hearken ye'    Deut.18.15

    \se !|kuhkeitam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, aural final |-(u)htam|
    \ge `to hearken unto sth'
    \so Gen.3.17,4.23
    \xv Kah Adamwoh unnau, newutche kukkéiketam ∞wadtauatonkqussuonk kummittumwussis, kah kummeech mahtug ...
    \xe And unto Adam he said, Because thou hast hearkened unto the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree,...
    \so Gen.3.17
    \ng 2->0 absolute

    \xv ..., N∞tam∞k nuttinn∞waonk, kenaau ummittamwossoh Lamech, kukkeitam∞k nukkeket∞kaonk,...
    \xe ..., Hear my voice; ye wives of Lamech, hearken unto my speech:...'    Gen.4.23; (E0): |kukkéitam∞k| `harken ye

[Narragansett [xnt] |kíhkita| `hearken thou to me'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nekiktam| `Je suis attentif, seu, j'écoute', imper. |ki`ta|, `ils' |ki`tam8k8|; |kek8ittañmi.| `Je t'écoute, je t'obéis'    R.38/389a;200/440a.]

\et *kexk- `know' + *-eht-aw- TA, *-eht(-am) TI `hear', H. p.245, B.1962, 16.137, 356.

\lx kuppohham
\va kuppuhham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 44
\ps v.t. / TI1a, mechanical final
\ge `he stops, stays, closes (it)'; +`to close sth up, shut sth (up)'
\so 2 Chr.32.30, +Gen.20.18
    pl. 2 K.3.25; Heb.11.33
    \xv Newutche God kuppohham wame wuttóontómuk∞m∞uh ut weekit Abìmelech,...
    \xe For the Lord had fast closed up all the wombs of the house of Abimelech,...
    \so Gen.20.18
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah pish kuppohham wetu nesausuk tahshikquinne.
    \xe ..., and [he shall] shut up the house seven days:
    \so Lev.14.38
    \xv ..., kuppuhhamwog wutt∞n∞woash qunnón∞og.
    \xe ..., [they] stopped the mouths of lions,
    \so Heb.11.33
    \xv ... . noh woshwunuk matta howan ukkupham∞un, kah [n]oh kóphog, kah matta howan ∞wohswunum∞un.
    \xe ..., he that openeth, and no man shutteth; and shutteth, and no man openeth;
    \so Rev.3.7
    \nt +

    \nt MN: kobhog
    \ng suppositive |kobhog| `when he stops (it)'
    \xv noh kobhog
    \xe he who stops (it)
    \so Job 38.37
    pl. |neg kobhogeg|    2 Chr.32.4
    pass. (inan. subj.) |Onk nnih, papaume kobhamuk squontamash,...| `And it came to pass about the time of shutting of the gate,...'    Josh.2.5; Titus 1.11√ { X->0 }

    \se kuppohhau
    \va kuppuhhou
    \nt !
    \va kuppuhwhau
    \nt !
    \ps with an. obj. / TA, mechanical final
    \ge `he stops (him)'; +`to conclude sb' (OED s.v. 1), `to shut sb in, up'
    \so Gen.7.16; Ex.14.3; Lev.13.4,11,21,26,31,33; Rom.11.32; Rev.20.3
    \xv ...: kah Jehovah ukkuppuhwhoh.
    \xe ...: and the LORD shut him in.'    Gen.7.16  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv ...: matta pish ukkuppohwhoh, newutche noh nishkeneunkqussu.
    \xe ..., and [he] shall not shut him up: for he is unclean.
    \so Lev.13.11
    \xv Newutche GOD ummoáe kuppáhwhôh ut pann∞wohtamunat,...
    \xe For God hath concluded them all in unbelief,...
    \so Rom.11.32

    \se !|kuppohhamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, mechanical final + dative final
    \ge `to shut up sth from sb'
    \so 1 Jn.3.17

    \xv Qut howan ahtunk yeu muttaohkée maumachiash, kah nauont wematoh quenauhikquoh, kah kuppohhamauont kitteamonteannitteáe wunnogkus,...
    \xe But whoso hath this world's good, and seeth his brother have need, and shutteth up his bowels of compassion from him,...
    \so 1 Jn.3.17

    \se kuppohham∞onk
    \va -mówonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a stopping (place), a "haven"'
    \so Acts 27.12
\dv |kuppi| + |∞m| (|ohham|) `he goes'.

    [|nuk-kupham| `I shut'    C.]

[Narragansett [xnt] |kuphómmin| `to shut the door'; |kúphash| `shut the door'    R.W.

\lx kuppohosu

\va kuppohhôsu
\va kuppôhosu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 44
\ps v.adj./ AI, derivational passive
\ge `he is stopped, stayed, shut in'; +`to be shut up'
\so 1 Sam.23.7; Rom.3.19
    \xv ..., nukkuphás, kah matta woh nussohhom∞h.
    \xe ...: I am shut up, and I cannot come forth.
    \so Ps.88.8; (M): |nukkuphos|
    \nt +
    \xv Qut ash papeyunkup wunnamptam∞onk, nanauwehhetteamun agwe ut naumatuonganit, kuppuhôsin wutch wunnamptam∞onk, ne woh ompetak wahteauwáhuwomuk.
    \xe But before faith came, we were kept under the law, shut up unto the faith which should afterwards be revealed.
    \so Gal.3.23
    \ng X-subject subordinative

\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he stops or closes'

    \se |kuppohhosu|, !|kuppuhhasu|, |kuppuhhausu|

    \ps II, derivational passive
    \ge `to stanch, be shut, stopped'
    \so Gen.8.2, Mt.25.10; Acts 21.30, Rom.3.19, Rev.21.25, Rules C.L.II.1
    \xv ... kah (k)enogeneganash kesukqui∞k kuppuhhásuash,...
    \xe ..., and the windows of heaven were stopped,...
    \so Gen.8.2
    \ng 0p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv kah squont kuppohhôsu
    \xe and the door was shut.
    \so [state]    Mt.25.10
    \xv Peyau uppisquani, kah missunnum wussiéu wuthogk∞, kah teanuk qussinausuonk kuppuhhausu.
    \xe Came behind him, and touched the border of his garment: and immediately her issue of blood stanched.
    \so Lk.8.44

    \xv ..., ∞weyaus sohwutchuog, asuh kuppohhósik ∞weyaus wutch wussohwutchuwannenat: ne wunnishkeneunkqussuonk.
    \xe ...: whether his flesh run with his issue, or his flesh be stopped from his issue, it is his uncleanness.
    \so Lev.15.3

\cf kogkopsau
\ge (he is) deaf

\lx kupputt∞n
\va kuppi-wutt∞n
\ve =  `closed mouth'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 44
\ps v.i. / AI, bahuvrihi
\ge `he is dumb, speechless'
    \nt Remark: This appears to lack the usual AI final |-á-|; possibly an illusion due to the two examples cited by Trumbull.
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah wame matcheseonganog pish kupputt∞naéog.
    \xe ...; and all iniquity shall stop her mouth.
    \so Ps.107.42
    \ng i.e. "all wicked people will shut up" }; (M): |...; kah wame matcheusseonk pish kupputtoonaemoo.| { more literal
    \nt +
    \xv pish kukkupputt∞n
    \xe thou shalt be dumb
    \so Lk.1.20
    pret. |kupputt∞nup| `he was speechless'    Lk.1.22

    \se !|kupputt∞nahpinau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \ge `to muzzle sb'
    \dv |kupputt∞n-| + |-a(h)pin-| TA `to bind'
    \so Deut.25.4

    \xv Kupputt∞napunuhkon ox, tattashkukog weatchiminneash.
    \xe Thou shalt not muzzle the ox when he treadeth out the corn.
    \so Deut.25.4


\lx kuppshagkinau
\va kuppish-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 44
    \nt +
\ps TA, manual final
\dv initial |kup-| `closed'; intermediate element |-(h)shak-| probably to *-hΘak-`board, plank', Ho.57.258, H., p.245, B.1962, 14.321,17.47,18.86, v.i.).
\ge `to put sb in prison'
\so Gen.39.20,40.3,41.10,42.16; Mk.1.14; Jn.3.24; Acts 4.3,5.18,5.25,8.3;
    \xv ... kah ukkupshagkinukquoh, ne adt ketass∞t kupshakkinausitcheg wewépapinit, kah na wutappin kuppishagkinau.
    \xe ..., [he] and put him into the prison, a place where the king's prisoners were bound: and he was there in the prison.
    \so Gen.39.20
    \ng status of third instance unclear--undergoer noun?
    \xv ..., kah kenaau pish kupshagkinitteaumw∞,...

    \ng indefinite object; _3p_ participle

    \xv ..., neg kobshagkinausitcheg ut kuppishagkinittuonganit.

\lx kutche
\va k∞che
\va k'∞che
\va k'wutche
\va kitche
\va -∞-
\ve The forms in  are almost certainly spurious, v.i.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 45
    \ps PreV
    \nt +
\ge signifies, primarily, `it proceeds or makes progress from'; hence, `it begins, has its origin or source'
\nt but while |n∞che| is used with reference to a beginning or starting point, present or past, |k∞che| or |kutche| connotes progression or the going on from a beginning or origin in the past to the present or future, or the relation of a cause to its effect in the present or future. Eliot does not appear to have made this distinction in all cases; e.g. |kitchu| `he began' (to curse etc.), Mt.26.74;
but |n∞che| in the corresponding verse, Mk.14.71.
    \xv ..., kah ne wutche kutche wosketompaog wehquetumwog ∞wesuonk Jehovah.
    \xe ...: then began men to call upon the name of the LORD', i.e. `therefrom went on
    \so Gen.4.26√; (E0): "that - from - began - men - to call upon - his name"
    \xv ..., kutche ogketash nesausuk tahshe weeksash wutch negonne kesukok ne adt kepenuman,
    \xe ...: begin to number the seven weeks from such time as thou beginnest to put the sickle to the corn....
    \so Deut.16.9
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ahque kutche n∞wagk ut kuhhogkaóut,...
    \xe ..., and begin not to say within yourselves,...
    \so Lk.3.8
    \nt +
    (|Kuttche| `Begun'; |k∞che| `more'    C.88/218;26/173)
    \xv Nenkitche, nukkittcheu@ssem, -un.
    \xe I begin, we begin
    \so C.38/181
    \nt +

    \xv na ... k∞ch
    \xe from thence
    \so (will [he] gather thee )    Deut.30.4
    \ng misanalyzed: |ku-| + |wutch|
    \xv yeu k∞che omohkinunun
    \xe for this cause I raised thee up
    \so Ex.9.16
    \ng misanalyzed: |ku-| + |wutche|
    \xv k∞chekekónán, k∞chemamonchanan, k∞chu wutóhkináan, k∞chekinnean
    \xe in him [from him] we live, we move, we have our being ... we are his offspring
    \so Acts 17.28
    \ng misanalyzed: |ku-| + |wut(che)-| as initial
\cf k'
\ge |
\cf kachém∞
\cf kahchem∞uk
\so (suppos. )
\cf kehche
\cf keht-

[Narr. { source identified incorrectly, v.s. }
Western Abenaki [abe] |kétté| `in antecessum, avant, auparavant'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |kich| et |kigi| [= |kitche|] `servent à former des tems
antérieurs; |kich| répond aussi à notre oui, ou déjà, pour le temps passé'    Maill.
Cree |kéeche-tow| `he begins it'; |kútche| (conj. causal) `that, to the end that'.
Chip. |kíja| `in advance, beforehand'; |kitchi| [`after', in time]    Bar.]

    \xe ... shall they heap to themselves teachers, having itching ears;

\lx kutchishin
\ve also used in
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 45
\ps v.i. (inan. subj.) / II
\ge `it begins'
\so Man.Pom. 88; +?Ex.26.9, Num.16.46,47, Jn.6.64, Rom.16.25, 2 Tim.1.9
\nt opposed to |wohkukquoshin| `it ends'
    \xv ..., newutche kussopiteae musquantam∞onk sohham∞m∞ wutch anaquabit Jehovah, ut énninneaonk kutchishin.
    \xe ...: for there is wrath gone out from the LORD; the plague is begun.
    \so Num.16.46
    \xv Qushauonk Jehovah neit kutchishin waantam∞onk:...
    \xe The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom:...
    \so Ps.111.10; (M): |Qushaonkanit Jehovah ut kutchishin waantamooonk:...|
    \nt +
    \xv Ne kutt∞wonk (nussin) k∞wahteauunneau, uttiyeu án∞wamuk pannuppu wame Judea; onk wutch kutchishin ut Galile,...
    \xe That word, I say, ye know, which was published throughout all Judaea, and began from Galilee,...
    \so Acts 10.37
    \nt +

    \xv ..., yeush waj kutchishik onkapunnaongash.
    \xe ...: these are the beginnings of sorrows.'    Mk.13.8 { Compare Mt.24.8: |Wame yeush wutch kutchissin uhquanum∞ongash.| `All these are the beginning of sorrows.
    \so (without number agreement) }
    \nt +
    \xv ...; newutche k∞waomausip, asquam kodshinunn∞k muttaok.
    \xe ...: for thou lovedst me before the foundation of the world.
    \so Jn.17.24; (M): |katshinunn∞k|
    \ng negative conjunct II

    \nt Remark: The mode of existence of the forms in |-sin| and |-shin| is puzzling. The final is no doubt the same as appears in, say, |pogkussin| AI, |pogkishin| II `to fall' with the expected distribution of the gender twins. With the current II verb, there seems to be a preference for the |-sin| form, without regard to the gender. Indeed, it is not certain whether there are any AI examples at present, and inanimate nouns certainly appear as subjects of this form--for a further brief comment, see under |kutchissin|.
    \nt +

    [Cree +|kitchi| (ad. et rac.) `au commencement', |kitchisin, wok| (a.a.) `il commence', |kitchittin, wa| (a.in.) `ça commence'; |Kiche`tawin| M.C. `A beginning'    Lac.D.415b;Frs.279a.]
    \nt +

\et The initial is *kec-/*ket- H.978-979,1115,1121,1133- `away, forth, out'; the final *-h⌠in AI, *-hΘen II `to fall, lie', B.76, 111/468; A. 414,422-423; H. p. 246; with some combined sense like "to start to move away/out"


\lx kutchisqua
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 45
\cf kehchisqua


\lx kutchissik
\va kádshik
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 45
\dv suppos. of |kutchissin| or |-ishin|
\ge `when it begins'
\ps as n.
\ge `the beginning (of that which continues to be or to act)'
    \xv weske kutchissik
    \xe in the (very, or new) beginning
    \so Gen.1.1
    \xv wutche kutchissik onk yean wehqshik
    \xe from the beginning to the end
    \so Eccl.3.11
    \xv kádshik muttaok
    \xe the beginning of the world
    \so Is.64.4
\cf kehchissu
    \nt Remark: There seems to be no reason to treat these as nouns. They should appear under the conjunct forms of the two verbs.
    \nt +


\lx kutchissin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 45
    \nt +
\ps II (AI expected?)
\ge `to begin'; participle used in translating "beginning"
\so Gen.1.1,10.10,49.3; Mt.24.8, Acts 10.37, 1 Pet.4.17
    \xv Newutche ne aquompak peyaum∞ wussittumóonk mos ut kutchissin weekit GOD, kah negonne kutchisik ut kuhhogkanonut, uttiyeu pish ∞wohkukquoiyeum∞ nag matta noswetam∞gig ∞naunchem∞kaonk GOD?
    \xe For the time is come that judgment must begin at the house of God: and if it first begin at us, what shall the end be of them that obey not the gospel of God?
    \so 1 Pet.4.17
    \xv Wame yeush wutch kutchissin uhquanum∞ongash.
    \xe All these are the beginning of sorrows.
    \so Mt.24.8
    \ng without number agreement
    \xv Wanne wut∞she, wanne wutokase, wanne ontseu, matta kutchissinno kesukodtash asuh wohkukóe pomantamóonk:...
    \xe Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days, nor end of life;...
    \so Heb.7.3
    \ng negative II in |-un-|, without number agreement

    \xv WEske kutchissik ayum GOD Kesuk & Ohke.
    \xe IN the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.
    \so Gen.1.1
    \ng 0->_adv_ conjunct
    \xv Onk newaje kutchissik wuttahs∞tamóonk Babel,...
    \xe And the beginning of his kingdom was Babel,...
    \so Gen.10.10; (E0): "And - from hence - the beginning - of his Kingdom"
    \ng 0->_adv_ (changed) conjunct
    \xv Kuttinn∞waonk wunnamuhkuteyeu∞ wutch weske kutchissik:...
    \xe Thy word is true from the beginning:...
    \so Ps.119.160; (M): |Kuttinnoowaonk wunnomwaonkanuoo
    \ng waj} kutchissik:...|  { Both versions with |-ss-|
    \xv ..., nummishamunash kemeu wadchanumikish, na wutch weske kutchissik muttaok.
    \xe ...; I will utter things which have been kept secret from the foundation of the world.
    \so Mt.13.35
    \xv Newutche neit pish missi wuttaméhpunáonk, matta hônan∞g nô waj kutchissik muttaok, onk yeu pajeh; kah pish matta wonk unnano.
    \xe For then shall be great tribulation, such as was not since the beginning of the world to this time, no, nor ever shall be.
    \so Mt.24.21

\nt Although there are occasional instances in which one might be able to argue about the gender of the subject or about the precise interpretation, the evidence indicates that the majority of examples must be taken as containing an inanimate intransitive verb. Is it possible that there has been some dissimilatory influence from the palatoalveolar of the initial?

\nt Cotton (38/181) has an AI stem of the shape |kitcheusse-|, which appears to be vowel-final (with a long vowel). This must be initial |kutchë-| + |-ussë-| AI `do'.


\lx kutchissumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 45
\ps v.t. an. and refl. / TA, final uncertain
\ge `he washes himself or another'; +`he baptizes (him)'
\so 2 Sam.12.20; Jn.9.7
\nt Follow up needed: There appear to be AI (i.e. TI-O?) and TA uses; separate study required. Part of the difficulty lies in the elusiveness of the "middle reflexive" final |-wi-| (G&B item 11, 580). For clear examples, see Jn.9.7(M), C.83/215.
    \xv ..., kah nukkutchessum,...
    \xe ... [and I] washed,...
    \so Jn.9.11; (M): |nukkutsimup|
    \xv ..., Nukkutsummuwam nashpe nippe,...
    \xe ..., I baptise with water,...
    \so Jn.1.26; (M): |nukkutsummuám|
    \ng AI, TA with indefinite object final: G&B item 12, p.580
    \nt +
    \xv Neen wunnamuhkut kukkutsumunumw∞ nippe,..., noh pish kukkutsumukou nashpe wunnetupanatamwe Nashauanit, kah n∞tau.
    \xe I indeed baptize you with water;...: he shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost and with fire:
    \so Lk.3.16
    \nt +
    \xv kukkutsumunneau
    \xe ye shall be baptized
    \so Mt.20.23; on these, compare Mt.3.11, and Goddard 1981, 3, p.57.
    \ng AI, subordinative?
    \nt +
    (|Nukkitisum, -omp| `I wash, {or} did'    C.83/215.)
    pl. |-maog wuthashabp∞oh| (an.) `they wash their nets'    Lk.5.2

    \nt MN: kutchessumog nuhhog nippe
    \ng suppositive |kutchessumog nuhhog nippe| `if I wash myself with water'    Job 9.30
    \xv Onk wame missinninnuog kodchishsumut, onk nnih Jesus wonk kodchishsumut, kah paantog, kesuk wôshwemo.
    \xe Now when all the people were baptized, it came to pass, that Jesus also being baptized, and praying, the heaven was opened,
    \so Lk.3.21
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ponum ahhut kutchessumumuk, nashauwe mukkinneáekommukqut kah Altar, kah ne wussókanumun nippe, kutchessumwinneat.
    \xe And he set the laver between the tent of the congregation and the altar, and put water there, to wash withal.
    \so Ex.40.30,... i.e. "what one washes o.s. in"
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |-mush| `wash thyself'    2 K.5.10 { AI/TI }
    \xv ...Monchish kutchissimwish ut Siloame nuppisseit (uttuh ânauwuttamuk, An∞nop) Newutche monch∞p, kah kutchissimup,...
    \xe ..., Go, wash in the pool of Siloam (which is by interpretation, Sent) He went his way therefore, and washed,...
    \so Jn.9.7,11(M)
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche kutchessum kuhhog,...
    \xe Wash thyself therefore,...
    \so Ruth 3.3
    \ng TA
    \nt +

    \se kutchissumóonk
    \va kitsummuwaonk
    \nt !
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `washing one's self or another; +baptism'
    \so Eph.5.26; Tit.3.5
    \xv Ukkitsummuwaonk John, ∞m∞∞us kesukqut, asuh wosketompauhtu?
    \xe The baptism of John, was it from heaven, or of men?
    \so Lk.20.4
    \nt +


    \se |kutchessumwaen(in)|
    \nt +
    \ps vbl.n.
    \ge `baptist'
    \xv Kah unnau wuttinneumoh, yeuoh John kutchessummuwaénin,...
    \xe And said unto his servants, This is John the Baptist;...
    \so Mt.14.2
    \xv ..., k∞wutche nag nekitcheg ut mitammwossissut, matta waápeh aneuukken∞mont John kutchessumuwaeneuh,...
    \xe ..., Among them that are born of women there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist:
    \so Mt.11.11

    \se kutchissittau
    \va kitshittau
    \ps With inan. obj. / TI2
    \ge `he washes (it)'
    \so Gen.49.11; 1 K.22.38
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnumauh nippe, kutchessitóog wusseetoash,...
    \xe ..., and [he] gave them water, and they washed their feet;...
    \so Gen.43.24
    \ng 3p->0(p) absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., uttoh adt seauhteamuk, pish kukkitshittaun ...
    \xe ..., thou shalt wash that whereon it was sprinkled ...
    \so Lev.6.27√
    \ng 2->0 objective
    \xv Nukkutshitto nunnutchegash ein pahketeahónat:...
    \xe I will wash mine hands in innocency:...
    \so Ps.26.6
    \ng 1->0(p) absolute; (M) also
    \nt +

    \xv Kah hogk∞onk ..., ne pish kodshittauon, kah enninneáonk amaéhtog, neit pish kutchissittauun nahohtóeu, kah pish pohki.
    \xe And the garment, ..., which thou shalt wash, if the plague be departed from them, then it shall be washed the second time, and shall be clean.
    \so Lev.13.58
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |kutchissittaush|    2 Sam.11.8
    \xv ..., kah kutchessittau∞k kusseett∞woash ...
    \xe ..., and wash your feet,...
    \so Gen.18.4; Gen.19.2
    \ng 2p->0(p) imperative; Gen.19.2(E0) |kutchssittau∞k|
    \nt +

    \se kutchissittóonk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \so Neh.4.23

    \se !|kutchessisseetauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, |-aw-| stem, incorporated object; bare initial, lacking final in |m|?
    \ge `to wash sb's feet' (i.e. "to foot-wash sb", with derived transitivity via relational noun)

    \xv ..., kutchessisseetauont wunneetupanatamwoh,...
    \xe ..., if she have washed the saints' feet,...'    1 Tim.5.10  { 3->3
    \so conjunct }

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nekesíg8â, 3. kes.| `Je me lave le visage'; |nekesíretsa, 3. kes.| `Les mains'; |nekeseséghenañ.| `Je lave v.g. une chemise'    R.313/475b.
Delaware [del] |kschiechsu| v. adj. `clean'; |kschiechem| `wash him'; |kschiechtool| `wash it'    Zeisb.
    Lp.A |kekettcheman| `tu le laveras'; |niketseten nisit| `je lave me pieds', |niketseten nahga| `je lave mon corps'    D.50av,100;66.]
    \nt +

\et On the finals, compare B.1962, 16.35, p. 336: Men. TA |-qNEm|, TI |-qNEto∙|, with prefinal |-qN-| `wet', as in: |kese∙qnemεw|, |kese∙qnetaw| `he washes him, it'? (Goddard 1981, 26, pp.65-66 relevant here on the inexact correspondence?) The only similar forms that I have seen so far are those given by Mathevet. It is hard to believe that there is no connection with the initial |kuss-| attested in |kussenitchau| (v.s.), which exhibits the expected reflex of PA *kes(i∙)- `wash', as H.1078-1086, particularly in view of the presence of the unusual |m|/|tau| finals; but it is harder still to give a plausible account, on my present grasp of the historical phonology. One possibility, for which I have found no evidence, is that the |s| of *kes(i∙)- is a reflex of the early assibilation that yields the *t/*s alternation, with later by-forms in |c| by the usual palatalization in these eastern languages. A possibly more plausible route is via the various distant effects, some dissimilatory, that affect these coronals (though usually in "expressive" contexts?). The |-h⌠-| to be expected from the complex final would have to be both conditioning environment, somehow taking *s to *c by assimilation and hardening--an analogical model would be far preferable here?--, and target, being dissimilated to *s, in different phases. (Example: Goddard IJAL 1982, 21, fn.15: "M |ace∙skew| (/c/ irregular for /s/"?) I had originally taken the |-ts-| forms to be the result of syncope and reduction of the |-cs-| cluster to |-ts-|; but Cotton gives some forms with |-kitis-| (C.83/215), and this appears to be confirmed by Jn.13.10(M) |Noh katussumut| `He that is washed' ((E): |Noh kódchissumwit|). [Goddard had also suggested the |cs| > |ts| change, G.1981, 3, 57-58, unfortunately without any comment on the |c| itself].


\lx kutchittóushau
\va kitchittóushau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 46
    \nt +
\ps AI (& II?)
\ge `to go forward, go on (to), pass on (to)'
\so Ex.14.15; Josh.6.8
    \xv ...? ken∞s wunnaumonuh Israel, onk woh kutchittóusháog.
    \xe ...? speak unto the children of Israel, that they go forward:
    \so Ex.14.15
    \xv Kah kussussippóiyeum∞ pish quttukqshau wutch sowaniyeu,..., kah pish nano kutchituhshau weehque Hazar-addar, kah nano kutchituhshau wehque Azmon.
    \xe And your border shall turn from the south to the ascent of Akrabbim,..., and shall go on to Hazaraddar, and pass on to Azmon:
    \so Num.34.4
    \ng Instance of II use of |-á-|, or "personification"--the whole verse illustrates the use of a transfer from walking to a spatial configuration. Calque?

    \xv ..., kah wuttámiyeu as∞hkauwushaum∞ Ark, kóchittóusháhettit, kah pohpequohtauwéhettit nashpe mônopuhpequash.
    \xe ..., and the rearward came after the ark, {the priests} going on, and blowing with the trumpets.
    \so Josh.6.9

    \xv ..., kutchittóushagk, kah weénuhkom∞k otan, kah noh kenauwamit, kitchittóushaj anaquohtag wut-Arkum LORD.
    \xe ..., Pass on, and compass the city, and let him that is armed pass on before the ark of the Lord.
    \so Josh.6.7

\et A. 672-674, H.978-979, Ho. 1957, no. 61, 259a: *ket- `out of enclosure or entanglement', with an extended stem *keci?t-; + *-wohΘ-e∙- `walk'

\lx kutt∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 46
\ps v.i. / AI(+O)
\ge `he speaks, utters speech'
\so 1 K.8.12; Job 3.2
    \xv kutt∞ kah n∞wau
    \xe he spake and said
    \xv ..., nag wunne kutt∞og, kodt∞koncheg.
    \xe ..., They have well spoken that which they have spoken.
    \so Deut.18.17
    \nt +

    Freq. [|kekutt∞|]

    suppos. pl. |kákutt∞g|, |kákett∞g|
    negat. |mat kákutt∞g|, |mo-kákutt∞g| `when they speak not, the speechless, the dumb'    Ex. 4.11; Ps.38.13

    \se ket∞kau
    \dv With |k'| progressive
    \ge `he goes on speaking, he talks'

    \se keket∞kau
    \ps freq. progressive
    \cf ket∞kau

    \se kutt∞wonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `speech, utterance' (`the Word'    Jn.1.1)
    pl. |-ongash|
    \xv kukkutt∞wongash
    \xe thy words, thy speech
    \so Job 4.4; Is.29.4
    \xv ket∞hkaj kutt∞wonk
    \xe let him speak a word
    \so Gen.44.18
    (|kutt∞onk|    C.)
    \cf kehket∞hkáonk
    \ge continued speech, talk, narration

    \se |kakut∞e| (1st ed.: |káket∞e| ?) { status of |-∞-| here? }
    \nt +
    \ps A
    \ge "capable of speech"?
    \so 2 Pet.2.16
    \xv mat kakut∞e asse
    \xe the dumb ass
    \so 2 Pet.2.16


|hett∞wonk| (see |hennau|), |unnont∞waonk|, `language, mutual speech'.

(Sansk. gad (dicere, loqui) and kath (loqui); repet. gudgudu (lallans,    balbutiens.)

\lx mag∞
\va magou
\va mág∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 47
\ps v.t. / AI+O, consonant-final stem
    \nt Remark: On transitivity of the cognate verb in Menominee, see B.1962, 22.75, p.450.
    \nt +
\ge `he offers or presents (it), he gives (it)'
\nt G&B.638
\so Esth.2.18; Ps.147.16
    (|mâkun-|    Mass.Ps.)
    \xv nummag
    \xe I present (it)
    \xv ummagun
    \xe he offers it
    \xv ... paudtoou ummeechummuonk ohke ummagunat en Jehovahut.
    \xe ... brought of the fruit of the ground an offering unto the Lord.
    \so Gen.4.3
    \ng 3->0 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kusseh nag nummagununk wame piukque chippagish ut Israel, wutche ahtoonk,...
    \xe I have given [them] all the tenth in Israel for an inheritance,...
    \so Num.18.21
    \ng 1->3p+0(p) objective (G&B.528)
    \nt +

    \xv Naphtali, ..., noh maguk wunanuk∞waongash.
    \xe Naphtali ...: he giveth goodly words.
    \so Gen.49.21
    \ng _3_->0(p) participle
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |magish|
    2d pl. |mag∞k|

\ge `he gives in exchange, he sells'
    pl. |mag∞og| `they sell'    Ex.21.35

    \xv ... Nen Joseph kematou noh mag∞ógkup en Egypt.
    \xe ..., I am Joseph your brother, whom ye sold into Egypt.
    \so Gen.45.4
    \ng 2p->_3_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \nt MN: noh maguk
    \ng suppositive |noh maguk| `he who sells, the seller'    Is.24.2

    \se mahmag∞
    \ps freq.
    pret. |mahmagup| `he sold often, "was a seller of"'    Acts 16.14

[Narragansett [xnt] |Máuks máugoke| `Give this.' [i.e. 2+2p]; |Tashin mesh commaûg?| `How much have you given?'; |Cummaugakéamish| I will give you land.'    R.W.44; 156/r.164; 158/166.
Western Abenaki [abe] |neméghen, 3, am.| `Je donne cela'    R.186/436a.
Cree |máygu| `he gives'; |mämáygu| `he gives with iteration'; |máygaysku| `he gives very often, habitually'; x|MEKIW, ok| `il donne', |MEKIWIN| `don, présent'; |mêki-| AI `give (it/him) out as present; give (it/him) away, release (it/him); give (her) in marriage'    Howse 46,70-71; +Lac.D.450b; sim. Alb.E.81b; W&A.88.
Chip. |mégewain| `he gives it'; |mégewa| `He g[ives]. or give away'; |Migiwe, (nin)| `I give, I contribute, I make a present, I grant, I allow'; |mi:kwe:| AI `give things away'    J. {cited by Howse}; +Bar.234b; W.244a; P&G.75.
Delaware [del] |më ken| `he gives away, parts with (it)'; |méek| AI `give s.t. away'    Zeisb.Gr.144; +O'M.167a.
    Algonquian [alg] |MIKIWE| `donner', |Ka nita mikiwesi| `{il n'aime pas à donner}, il n'est pas donateur'    Cq.221ab.
    \nt +
Miami-Illinois [mia] |nimiki| `je donne.' |miki8a| 3a.    M.289/180b.
Menominee [mez] |me∙kow| `he gives something to someone, to people; he makes a gift or payment', |nemi∙kim|    M.L.130; also B.1962, 15.25, 279.
Miami |mikiani| `I give (away, indef.)'; |miikii-| AI `give'.    D.-V.360; B&C.79b.
WAbn. |maga| AI `give away'    D.1.285.]

\et G.1981, 100, fn.17 *mye∙k-, without evidence.

\lx mahch-
\va mahs-
\va maht-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 47
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge various; to do with decay, ending, exhaustion, loss; see entries that follow.

[+Abn. |Metsitsi| `finalem't', |Métsi8i|, v. |métsi8itsi| `trop tard'    R.P.24/558a.
Algonquian [alg] |METC|, qqf. |MET-|, qqf. |MESI| `usé, qui ne peut plus servir'    Cq.214a.
Cree {x} |MEST| (rac.) `dépenser, détruire entièrement', {x} |METT| `{même racine que} |mest|, etc. {peut-être qu'elle dit un peu plus.}    Lac.D.452b-453b.
Delaware [del] |mehc-|, |mehs-|, |meht-| `finish, miss, wear out, ...'    O'M.167b-169b.
Ill. {R} |Meta, metchi| `dans le composé achevement de qq. chose'; {R} |Métchi| `autrefois, depuis long temps, il y a long temps'    Grv.274/174a; 276/175a, (exs. passim 274-280).
M.-P. |meehci-| (|meeht-|) PreV `beenden, aufhören, stehen bleiben'    Sz.117-118.

Shawnee [sjw] |me?t-| `COMPLETELY, PERFECTIVE, FINISHING, WEARING OUT'    D.-V.355.
WAbn. |mat-| `finish', |maz-| `remove, clear'    D.1.xlix-l.]

\et *me∙?c- `exhaust, consume, exterminate; all (gone)': Michelson 1935, 161; A. 1187-1188; B. 25, 93/449 [*meeq\ci `to exhaustion']; H.1690-1694, 1684-1688; Goddard 1981, 21-22; with allomorphs *me∙?s- (e.g. in *-hk-) and *me∙?t-.


\lx mahche
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 47
\ps Prt, PreV
\dv (nearly related to if not identical with |mahtsheau| `it passes away, is gone')
\ge `after, in time'
\so Lk.6.1
    \xv mahche quinnuppekompauean
    \xe after thou art (mayest be) converted
    \so Lk.22.32

\ge it serves as the auxiliary of the perfect and past perfect tenses, and, combining with the verb, receives the pronom. prefix:
    \xv ummahche ussen
    \xe he hath done it
    \so Is.44.23

    \xv ne mahche
    \xe that which hath been
    \so Eccl.3.15
    \xv mahche wunnamunuh
    \xe (he) had blessed them
    \so Gen.24.1

\nt Cotton, strangely enough, associates this word with "ahtöuu@nat, to have, to be had," and gives "nummahche, I have or had; kum-mahche, thou hast, thou hadst," etc.
\cf amáeü
\ge he departs
\cf màw
\so Narr.

[Narragansett [xnt] |mauch| or |mésh|: |Tashin mesh com-maûg| `How much have you given?'; +|Cuttaunchemókous.| `I will tell you newes.', |Cummautaunchemókous.| `I have done my newes.' (i.e. |-maut-|)    R.W.156/r.164;54.√
Cree |ghee| (auxil.) `have'.
Chip. |ke| or |ge|    J.; |ki-| (suppos. |ka-|) sign of the perfect and pluperfect    Bar.; |mashî| `yet' [i.e. `until now']; |ka mashî| `not yet'.
Delaware [del] |ma-tschi| `already'    Zeisb.Voc.]

\lx mahchep∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 47
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), i-stem
\ge `he has eaten, has done eating'
\ge `he makes an end of eating, eats (it) up'
\so Ex.13.32
    \xv Kah mamátchissitcheg, kah ianauwussitcheg k∞washinog mahchep∞og nesausuk adtahs∞unutcheh, kah waanogqunutcheh kowashinneah,...
    \xe And the ill-favoured and lean-fleshed kine did eat up the seven well-favoured and fat kine. ...'    Gen.41.4  { 3p->3
    \so }
    \nt +
    infinit. |-punneat|  Lk.17.9

    \xv Onk n nih mahchipwehettit weatchiminneash ...
    \xe And it came to pass, when they had eaten up the corn ...
    \so Gen.43.2
    \ng 3p conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nunnemunumup b∞kemes wutch wunnutcheganit angel, kah nummahchipwunneáh, kah mo ut nutt∞nut ogk∞wekon honyut, kah quenau mahchipweon, nunnogkus wesogkon.
    \xe And I took the little book out of the angel's hand, and ate it up; and it was in my mouth sweet as honey: and as soon as I had eaten it, my belly was bitter.
    \so Rev.10.10
    \ng 1->0 "absentative" indicative; 1->0 conjunct
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |mahchipwush| `eat it up'  Rev.10.9  { 2->0 }
    (|nummahchip| `I devour'   C.)

    \se mahchipwau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he devours (him)', i.e. eats him up, makes an end of him
    \so Ezek.19.6
    \xv ..., kah wutohkeim∞ kummátwom∞óog pish kummahchepukquneau.
    \xe ..., and the land of your enemies shall eat you up.
    \so Lev.26.38
    \ng 0->2p
    \nt +

\dv |mahche| and |-upp∞|, formative of verbs of eating.

[Narragansett [xnt] |maúchepwut| `when he hath eaten'; |mauchepweéan| `after I (shall) have eaten'.]

\et |-p∞| is the middle reflexive corresponding to TA |-pw-|, as M. |-pi| (AI), B.1962, 15.110, p.295.

\lx mahshagquodt
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 48
\ps n. / II, NI (see added sublemma)
\ge `(a time or season of) famine'; +"for there to be a famine"
\so Gen.12.10; 26.1; +Ruth 1.1, Lk.4.25
    \nt Remark: The morphology and the conjunct forms give the clearest evidence in favor of the existence of the verb. As usual, the categorization of particular examples often remains uncertain.
    \nt +
\dv |mahtsheau|.
    \xv Kah na mahshagquodt ut ohket,..., newutche mahshagquod wussaume ne ut ohkeit.
    \xe And there was a famine in the land,...: for the famine was grievous in the land.
    \so Gen.12.10
    \ng 0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv KAH n nih kesukodtash wussittumwaenúog nánawunnumwahettit, na mo mahshagquodt ohkeit,...
    \xe Now it came to pass in the days when the judges ruled, that there was a famine in the land,...
    \so Ruth 1.1
    \ng ?0 indicative; verb status slightly doubtful owing to presence of |mo|, syntax not understood

    \xv ..., asq mashagquodtinn∞g,...
    \xe ..., before the years of famine came:...
    \so Gen.41.50
    \ng 0 negative conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Kah mahshagquok ohkit Egypt, missinninnuog mauunnitteauog Pharaohoh wutch petukqunneg,...
    \xe And when all the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread:...
    \so Gen.41.55
    \nt +
    \xv ... pomantog Elias, kesuk kobhausik nishwe kodtumwae, kah nequtta tahsuog nepauzsaog, mahshe mahshagquohk pannuppe wame wutohtimóneat.
    \xe ... in the days of Elias, when the heaven was shut up three years and six months, when great famine was throughout all the land.
    \so Lk.4.25
    \ng (changed) conjunct

    \se |mahshagquodt|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `famine'
    \so Gen.41.30,54; Ps.33.4(M)
    \xv Onk na pish wuttit waâpin nesausuk tahshit kodtumwae mahshagquodt nahohtôeu, ..., kah mahshagquodt pish matchehteau ohke.
    \xe And there shall arise after them seven years of famine; ...; and the famine shall consume the land.
    \so Gen.41.30
    \xv Pohquohwunonat ukketeahogkonoouh wutch nuppooonkanit, kah nag pomantamwahonat mohshogquodut.
    \xe To deliver their soul from death, and to keep them alive in famine.
    \so Ps.33.19(M)
    \ng locative; (E): |wutch mohshogqunnonat.|, t-subordinative

    \se mahshogque
    \ps Adv. / PreN
    \se `of famine'
    \nt +
    \so Ps.37.19
    \xv Matta pish akodchuog ut matcheetinat kah mashogque kesukodtut pish wamep∞og.
    \xe They shall not be ashamed in the evil time: and in the days of famine they shall be satisfied.
    \so Ps.37.19; (M): |mashogque|
    \nt +

    \se |mahshagqu-|
    \nt +
    \ps initial
    \nt Follow up needed: 
    \xv ...: newutche mahshagquinneun ut ohkeit Kanaan.
    \xe ...: for the famine was in the land of Canaan.
    \so Gen.42.5
    \xv ..., newutché mahshagquottuhkequn ohkeit Kanaan,...
    \xe ...; for the famine is sore in the land of Canaan:...
    \so Gen.47.4


\lx mahshétahshik
\va mishetashin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 48


\lx mahtântam
\va mohtantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 48
\ps v.i. / TI1a (TI-O), ??mental final (see remark)
\ge `he is old', implying decrepitude, senility, and decay.
\cf kehchissu
\dv |maht-| (|mahche|) and |-antam|, the formative of verbs of mental activity, `he is past-minded or failing-minded'
    \nt Remark: The evidence of possible cognates in Maliseet-Passamaquoddy suggests that the |-an-| may represent the nasal vowel, and therefore does not contain the sequence |n|+|t|. The vowel |o| of the first syllable will need explaining away if this is to be associated with |mahche-|, but the forms of Abenaki and Maliseet-Passamaquoddy are in its favour. The contrast in spelling of the two verbs in Gen.18.10 is striking.
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Abraham kah Sarah mohtantam∞∞og, kah sepepomantamwog,...
    \xe Now Abraham and Sarah were old, and well stricken in age:...
    \so Gen.18.10
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv N∞skenneu∞p, yeuyeu nummahtauntam,...
    \xe I have been young and now am old:...
    \so Ps.37.25√

    \nt MN: mahtauntog
    \ng suppositive |mahtauntog| `when she is old'    Prov.23.22
    \xv ..., mahtauntog kah sepe pomantog, ...
    \xe ..., being old and full of days:...
    \so Gen.35.29
    \nt +
    `full of days'    Jer.6.11
    `stooping for age'    2 Chr.36.17

    \se mahtantamóonk
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI
    \ge `(infirm) old age'
    \xv Kah wuskesukquash Israel tuhkequnash newutche mahtauntamóonk,...
    \xe Now the eyes of Israel were dim for age,...
    \so Gen.48.10(E1)
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |Mattaûntum| `Very old nnd decrepit.'    R.W.27√.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nemétsíné|, `Je suis mort', 3. |mét.|    R.344/489a.
    \nt +
M.-P. |meehtaat@m| `er ist gestorben (z.B. er ist an Alterschwäche [sic] gestorben)'; |mehtatom| `he dies of old age' |mehtatomi naksq| `old maid'; |mehtatom|, pl. |mehtatomuhtuwok| AI `s/he dies of old age'    Sz.118; LeS.42b; F&L.
WAbn. |macina| AI `he dies'    D.1.281-282.]


\lx mahtohqs
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 48
\cf matokqs


\lx maht∞
\va maht∞au
\va maht∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 48
    \nt Remark: Trumbull's lemma probably non-existent.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he ceases, is done, makes an end (of speaking)', with t-subordinative or conjunct verb
    \so Gen.49.33; Mt.11.1; Lk.11.1
    \nt +
    [|Nummahteaim, -ep.| (?) `I cease, {or} did,'    C.42/184.]

    \nt MN: asq maht∞og
    \ng suppositive |asq maht∞og| `before he had done speaking'    Gen.24.15
    \ng 3 negative conjunct
    \xv Kah asq maht∞aon ut nuttahhut,...
    \xe And before I had done speaking in my heart,...
    \so Gen.24.45√
    \ng 1 (negative) subjunctive
    \xv ... maht∞wadt Jesus ken∞nont ukkodnetuhtaéneumoh nabo nees∞unutcheh,...
    \xe ..., when Jesus had made an end of commanding his twelve disciples,...
    \so Mt.11.1
    \nt +

\et *me∙?t- `exhaust, consume, exterminate; all (gone)': Michelson 1935, 161; A. 1191-1192; H.1690-1694, 1684-1688; Goddard 1981, 21-22; *-ow-e∙- `speak, voice', H. p.248.


\lx mahtshán∞
\va mohtshán∞

\so Trumbull 48

[Delaware [del] |schauwutteü| `it is faded'    Zeisb.Gr.164.]


\lx mahtsheau
\va mahtshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 48
\ps v.i. (inan. subj.) / II(+O)
    \dv |máht-| `complete, exhausted' + ?|-uhsh-ô-| II `fly'
    \nt +
\ge `it passes away, fails, perishes, comes to an end' (as the grass or a flower)
\ge `to waste, spend sth'
\nt G&B.517: "Stem in |-ô|"; 639
\so James 1.10,11; C.118, 21/238
    \xv Kah nippe mahtshau wishquadt:...
    \xe And the water was spent in the bottle,...
    \so Gen.21.15
    \ng 0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Onk teaguash mahtshaash wutch ohkit Egypt ...
    \xe And when money failed in the land of Egypt ...
    \so Gen.47.15
    \ng 0p indicative
    \nt +
    (man's life)    Job 14.10
    (his strength) `decays'    Neh.4.10
    \xv ..., kah na ut mohtsheau ummaumachiash mogkemág∞e pomantog.
    \xe ..., and there wasted his substance with riotous living.
    \so Lk.15.13
    \nt +
    \xv ... qut osso@okqua tohneit nawekontam∞onkannüuk ut ne teagwe matchet∞e usseonganit, ne teanuk mohtshau ...
    \xe ...but on the contrary, if there be any pleasure in a wicked action it is quickly gone,...
    \so C.118/238
    \nt +

    \nt MN: ne mahtshunk
    \ng suppositive |ne mahtshunk| `that which is past'    Eccl.3.15
    \xv nippe mahtshunk
    \xe when the water fails
    \so Job 14.11
    \xv Kah mahtshunk wame, neit waábe mishe mahshagquodt ne ohkeit,...
    \xe And when he had spent all, there arose a mighty famine in that land;...
    \so Lk.15.14
    \ng 0 conjunct
    \nt +

    \se |mahtshau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \ge `to fade away, perish'
    \so 2 Cor.4.16; Jas.1.11

    \xv ..., kah ne uppeshau mahtsheau, kah neyan∞wunnegik mahtsheau, neyane pish wenaueetuen mahtshunt ut ummayut.
    \xe ..., and the flower thereof falleth, andthe grace of the fashion of it perisheth: so also shall the rich man fade away in his ways.
    \so Jas.1.11
    \ng 3->_adv- conjunct (participle)

    \se mahtsháe
    \ps Adv. and adj.
    \so Jn.6.27

    \se |mahtshadtau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2
    \ge `to abolish, devour, spend, waste sth; pass (time)'
    \so Gen.31.15; ; Ps.90.9
    |...? newutche mag∞ nuhogkanonash | kah máhtshadtau wame nutteágwunnónut.| `...? for he hath sold us, and hath quite devoured also our money.'    Gen.31.15  { 3->0 }
    \xv Kah n∞wekontamwe mahtshadtoh, kah nussauwunnum wutche kenaau,...
    \xe And I will very gladly spend and be spent for you;...
    \so 2 Cor.12.15
    \ng 1(->0) indicative
    \xv Mâhtshottouu@nat.
    \xe To waste
    \so C.84/215
    \xv Mahtshattouu@nat.
    \xe Wasting, wasted
    \so C.98/224

    \xv Mahtshadtunk ut weyausut penuanittuonk,...
    \xe Having abolished in his flesh the enmity,...
    \so Eph.2.15
    \ng 3->0 conjunct

    \xv ..., mahtshadtau∞k kutahquompiyeum∞ yeu adt áneapeóg, ut wabesuonganit
    \xe ..., pass the time of your sojourning here in fear:
    \so 1 Pet.1.17
    \ng 2p->0 imperative

    \se !|mahtshadtauau|
    \nt ?+
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to waste sb's sth'
    \so Lk.16.1
    \xv ..., kah wutushpunanon ummahtshadtauuh ummaumachiash.
    \xe ..., and the same was accused unto him that he had wasted his goods.'    Lk.16.1  { 3->3
    \so -pro+0 }

\nt Follow up needed: |Kah nutayim kut∞tanaoash mahtshadt,...| `And I will make your cities waste,...'    Lev.26.31  { calque; II in |-t-| ? }
    \xv Noh mohtahkonnau wohhoguh.
    \xe He wastes himself
    \so C.84/215
    \ng corporal AI+applicative, B.1962, 15.227, 313?

    \xe ...; and she shall be utterly burned with fire:...
    \so Rev.18.8
    \ng X->3 conjunct, following |Newajeh|

    \ps AI, middle reflexive
    \ge `to be consumed'
    \so Gen.19.15; Jas.4.3;
    \xv ..., ishkont kummahtus, kenugke otan ut ummatcheseonganit.
    \xe ...; lest thou be consumed in the iniquity of the city.

    \ng 2 indicative
    \xv ..., newutche kuppanne wehquetumumw∞, onk woh kummahtussimw∞, ut kummatchekodtantam∞ongan∞wóut
    \xe ..., because ye ask amiss, that ye may consume {it} upon your lusts.
    \so Jas.4.3
    \ng 2p indicative; interpretation? no ref. to fire in NT

    \xe at, in the last day

    \xe yet a little while

\lx manit
\va manitto
\va manit
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 49
\ps NA
\ge (usually translated) `God'; but Eliot more often transferred the names `God' and `Jehovah' to the Indian text. He has, however,
    \xv Manit wame masugkenuk
    \xe God Almighty
    \so Ex.6.3
and in the 7th v.
    \xv neen Jehovah kum-Manitt∞mw∞
    \xe I am the Lord your God' (lit. `I the Lord am your God
    \so )
and
    \xv neen kum-Manitt∞mw∞
    \xe I will be to you a God' (lit. `I am your God
    \so )    ibid.
    pl. |manitt∞og|    1 K.20.23; 2 K.18.33
    with |keht-|, |Keihtannit| `the Lord God'    Gen. 24.7
    i.e. `the great manit'.
\dv |aneu| or |an-u| `he exceeds, is beyond, superior to,
or more than (|ánue|) another person or thing'

    \nt MN: anit
    \ng suppositive |anit| `when he is superior to or more than', etc.
    (cf. |ánin|; suppos. |aweuk| `that which exceeds', hence `that which rots or becomes corrupt')
    with the indeterminate and impersonal prefix, |m'anit| `he who (or that which) exceeds or passes beond the common or normal, the preternatural or extraordinary'.

    Possessive form, |nummanitt∞m| `my god'
    \xv kummanitt∞mw∞
    \xe your gods
    \so , etc.,
the suffix |∞m| denoting that "the person doth challenge an interest in the thing" El.Gr.12.

    \se manitto
    \ps [This] is the verb subst. form, / AI, predicative final
    \ge `he or it is manit'
    \nt Remark: They "cry out |Manittóo|, that is, it is a God," "at the apprehension of any Excellency in Men, Women, Birds, Beasts, Fish, &c. ..." etc.    R.W.118/r.126.√
    \xv nen Manitto
    \xe I am God
    \so Is.43.12

    \se |manittoe|, |manitt∞e|,...
    \nt +
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `divine, godly, of God'
    \so Gen.23.6; Deut.7.25; Rom.3.2; 2 Cor.7.10; 1 Tim.1.4; 2 Tim.3.12,17; 2 Pet.1.3,...

    \se !|ummanitt∞mu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), verb of possession
    \ge `to have (sb as) a god'
    \so Deut.5.7
    \xv ..., neit Jehovah pish n∞-Manitt∞mun
    \xe ...; then shall the LORD be my God:
    \so Gen.28.21
    \ng 1->3 objective

    \xv Um-Manitt∞mehkon onkatogig Manitt∞og ut anaquabeh.
    \xe Thou shalt have none other gods before me.
    \so Deut.5.7
    \ng 2->3 prohibitive

[Narragansett [xnt] |manìt|; pl. |manittówock|.
Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |mundtu|    Stiles.
Chip. |món-é-do|, |mune-do|; |Kitchi Manito| `Great Spirit, Lord God'    (Bar.);
|kesha-munedoo|    J.
Delaware [del] |manétto| `god, spirit, angel'    Camp.; |manitto|, |get-annitto|    Zeisb.
Mahican [mjy] |mannito| `a spirit or spectre'    Edw.]

\et H.1566 *maneto∙wa `spirit'

\lx man∞ham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 50
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\ge `he ransoms or redeems (it) by payment, he buys (it)'
    \xv ..., man∞hamman, man∞sh, qut matta man∞ham∞an, usseh, onk woh n∞wateoun: newutche wanne howan onkatuk woh man∞ham∞un webe ken, kah nen nahohtóeu, kah n∞wau numman∞hamun.
    \xe .... If thou wilt redeem it, redeem it: but if thou wilt not redeem it, then tell me, that I may know: for there is none to redeem it beside thee; and I am after thee. And he said, I will redeem it.
    \so Ruth 4.4
    \nt +

    \nt MN: Kah man∞homwe man∞huk ohteuk, noh wanetupanatamwahtunk,...
    \ng suppositive |Kah man∞homwe man∞huk ohteuk, noh wanetupanatamwahtunk,...| `And if he that sanctified the field will in any wise redeem it,...'    Lev.27.19√
    \ng with cognate preverb in "minimizing" sense; note the matching of the gender in the preverb, by comparison with Lev.27.13, (v.i.)
    \xv kodman∞huk week
    \xe if [he] will redeem his house
    \so Lev.27.15√

    \se man∞whau
    \va manow-
    \nt +
    \va manouw-
    \ps with an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he ransoms (him)'; +`to redeem sb'
    \so Lev.25.49
    \xv Kah noh wóshwunuk wutóontomuk asse, pish kummán∞h wutch sheepsemésoh: kah matta manowóadt, neit pish kuppohkukquan: nish noh ummehtamégen kenaumonog pish kummán∞h:...
    \xe But the firstling of an ass thou shalt redeem with a lamb: and if thou redeem him not, then shalt thou break his neck. All the first born of thy sons thou shalt redeem. ...
    \so Ex.34.20
    \nt +
    \xv ..., yeug mán∞whóog wutch kenugke wosketompahtu,...
    \xe .... These were redeemed from among men,...
    \so Rev.14.4
    \nt +

    \nt MN: Kah man∞whae man∞whont,...
    \ng suppositive |Kah man∞whae man∞whont,...| `But if he will at all redeem it,...'    Lev.27.13√
    \ng with cognate preverb construction, in this verse somewhat equivocal, but parallel to Lev.27.19 (v.s.)
    \xv ... kah matta howan wunnetuhtaouun ket∞hamáonk, qut webe yeug nequt pasuk∞∞og kah yauunchagkussuog kah yauut muttannonganogkussuog, neg man∞whutcheg wutch ohkeit.
    \xe ...: and no man could learn that song but the hundred and forty and four thousand, which were redeemed from the earth.
    \so Rev.14.3
    \nt +

    \xv ...; neit pish wuttenanumuh manouwhunach ...
    \xe .., then shall he let her be redeemed:...
    \so Ex.21.8
    \ng proleptic object, with o.r.
    \nt +

    \se man∞wháonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a ransom'
    \so Ex.21.30; Mt.20.28
\cf wunn∞ham
\cf wunn∞whau
\cf wunn∞wau
\ge he values, fixes the valuation of (with an. obj. |wunn∞whau|), and |wunn∞wau|
\nt `he values, fixes the valuation of (with an. obj. ), and  `he makes a treaty or covenant with'

[Narragansett [xnt] |kum-manóhamin| `have you bought it?'; |kum-manóhamóush| `I will buy of you'.

\lx man∞nau

\ps n. / NI

    \xe on my cheek

    \xe thy cheeks
    \so Cant.1.10
    (|konónut| `on thy cheek'    Lk.6.29
    = |konn∞naut|    Mt.5.29)
    \xv wann∞nau
    \xe his cheek
    \so Lam.3.30
    (|wonnünou|    C.)
\dv Perhaps from |n∞mau| `it sucks'; perhaps from |an∞nau| `it speaks'.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |man8é| `joue'; |nan8é| `ma joue'; (3d p.) |8an8é|.]

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    "{Obs.} In steed of shelves, they have severall baske[t]s, wherein they put all their houshold-stuffe: they have some great bags or sacks made of {Hempe}, which will hold five or sixe bushells."    R.W.36-37√.
    "|Notassen| or bags, which they plait from hemp which grows wild." Megapolensis.
\dv |n∞tin| `he lifts or takes up (a burden)'.

\nt but `nettles' is transferred in Job 30.7, Hos.9.6, and Zeph.2.9. Comparing (Narr.) |Masaûnock.| `Flaxe.', R.W.164/r.172, the name may probably be assigned to Urtica canadensis, the Canada nettle or "Albany hemp", the fibrous stalk of which was used by the Indians for baskets, mats, and nets.√
