\lx matchaog
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\ps adv. of denying
\ge `no'; +`nay, nothing', negative existentials
    \nt Remark: On the usage of "nay", the following portion of the OED entry may still (only in part?--cf. Gen.18.15) be relevant to AV (given its relationship to, for instance, Coverdale's and Tyndale's work dating from the 1530s), though, of course, there may well be no corresponding distinction in Massachusett: OED, s.v. "nay" adv. 1. a. "A word used to express negation, dissent, denial, or refusal, in answer to some statement, question, command, etc. Now arch. or dial. ... In older usage {nay} (like {yea}) was usually employed when the preceding statement, etc., had no negative word in it; when a negative was expressed, the usual answer was {no} (or {yes}). This distinction is clearly stated by Sir T. More in his {Confutation of Tindale} Wks. (1557) 448/1."
    \nt +
\so El.Gr.21
    "{Denying}. |Matta|, |Matchaog|, {No}. {Also} |Mo| {sometimes signifieth} Not."    E.Gr.21/268
    \nt +
    \xv Neit Sarah quen∞wau, n∞wau, Matta nutáhanu, newutche wabesu; Onk n∞wau, Matchaog, qut kutahánup.
    \xe Then Sarah denied, saying, I laughed not; for she was afraid. And he said, Nay; but thou didst laugh.
    \so Gen.18.15
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pahsahtheg matchaog ohtano, wanne nippeno.
    \xe ...: and the pit was empty, there was no water in it.
    \so Gen.37.24
    \nt +
    \xv Kah qushkeu en wematut, kah n∞wau, Peisses matchaog,...
    \xe And he returned unto his brethren, and said, The child is not;...
    \so Gen.37.30
    \nt +
    \xv Matchaog, monchek kenaau wosketompaog,...
    \xe Not so: go now ye that are men,...
    \so Ex.10.11
    \ng context complex
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matchaog ohto∞g, neit pish magun wutche komm∞towonk.
    \xe ...: if he have nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft.
    \so Ex.22.3
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Rachel maiémon uppeissesimoh, kah matta hahk∞waou, newutche nag matchaog.
    \xe ..., Rachel weeping for her children, and would not be comforted, because they are not.
    \so Mt.2.18
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah paaontog, matchaog namehteau webe wunnepaguash,...
    \xe ...: and when he came to it, he found nothing but leaves;...
    \so Mk.11.13
    \nt +
    \xv Kuttinnonnumw∞, matchaog,...
    \xe I tell you, Nay:..."
    \so Lk.13.3,5
    \ng following positive polar question
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah peyau kah natinneham mechumúonk nah ut, kah matchaog namehteaou.
    \xe ...; and he came and sought fruit thereon, and found none.
    \so Lk.13.6
    \nt +
    \xv Sun wuttabuttantamauoh neh wuttinneumunneuh, newutche wutussen neyane ann∞nont? matchaog!
    \xe Doth he thank that servant because he did the things that were commanded him? I trow not.
    \so Lk.17.9
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nuttattogkomukqunnónog monaog nagumun, matta n∞sumugk∞unnónog, nuttin Romansumun, onk nukkupshagkinnukqunnónog, onk yeuyeu nukkéme sohwhunnukqunnónog? matchaog wunnamuhkut, qut peyahettich nehenwonche, kah sohh∞wunukqutteuh.
    \xe ..., They have beaten us openly uncondemned, being Romans, and have cast us into prison; and now do they thrust us out privily? nay verily; but let them come themselves and fetch us out.
    \so Acts 16.37
    \nt +
    \xv ohtoou matchaog
    \xe he has nothing
    \so Prov.13.7
    = |ohtoou mo teag|    Prov.13.4
\cf matta


\lx matche
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\ps PreN, PreV
\ge `(it is) bad'
\ps as adj. and adv.
\ge `bad, badly'
    \xv matche meenan
    \xe a naughty tongue
    \so Prov.17.4
    \xv matche an∞naenin
    \xe a wicked messenger
    \so Prov.13.17

    \se |matchit|, |machit|
    \nt +
    \ps II; some instances of NI (comparable to "agent nouns") included
    \twn ?|matchesu| (2), AI (compare meanings)
    \ge `to be evil'
    \nt G&B.643
    \so Gen.6.5,47.9; Jn.3.19,7.7; Eph.5.16
    \xv Kah nag wonk onkquatausitcheg matchet wutche wunnegen nutayeuuhkonukquog,...
    \xe They also that render evil for good, are mine adversaries:...
    \so Ps.38.20; (M) |machuhk wutche wanekuk|
    \xv ..., newutche wutusseongan∞oash matchitash.
    \xe ..., because their deeds were evil.
    \so Jn.3.19; (M) |matchitash|
    \xv ..., qut woh k∞wadchanóog wutch matchitut.
    \xe ..., but that thou shouldest keep them from the evil.
    \so Jn.17.15; (M) |wutch ne machuhk|

    \nt MN: Howan onkquatôsit machuk wutch wanegik, machuk matta pish amaémun∞ wutch wekit.
    \ng suppositive |Howan onkquatôsit machuk wutch wanegik, machuk matta pish amaémun∞ wutch wekit.| (as n.) `Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.'    Prov.17.13√
    \ps 0
    \xv Na machuk oteau, ne naum ut agwe nepáuzsaut,...
    \xe There is an evil which I have seen under the sun,...
    \so Eccl.6.1√
    \xv ..., Nishnoh howan negonáe ponum wanegik wine, kah nahen tápsippámhettit, neit machuk;...
    \xe ..., Every man at the beginning doth set forth good wine, and when men have well drunk, then that which is worse:...
    \so Jn.2.10; (M) |machuhk|

    \se matchet
    \ps adv. of quality / probably II verb, as above
    \so El.Gr.18
    \dv Intens. of |matta|

(Cf. Engl. not, nought, naughty.)


[Narragansett [xnt] |Matchit| `Naught, or evill.'    R.W.36√.
Western Abenaki [abe] |matsigheni8| `Cela est mal, cela n'est pas bien'.    R.324/479a.
Delaware [del] |medhik| (inan.) `bad, evil'; |machtit| `bad (it is)'    Zeisb.
    Lp.A. |matchit| `mechant', |machet| `c'est laid, mauvais', |ak8i machek l8mankan| `ne chante rien de mauvais', |kemache se8ans| `chante tu mal'    D.23,79,54,84...]
    \nt +


\lx matcheheau
\va matchheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative
\ge `to defile, destroy, spoil sb' [OED "spoil" v.1, 2. "To strip (persons) of goods or possessions by violence or force; to plunder, rob, despoil. Also {fig.} Now {rare} or {arch.}".]
\so Gen.34.2,5,13,27,49.27; Ex.3.22,12.36,34.13; Mt.5.17,9.17,15.11,18,20
    \xv ..., nauont, wunnemunoh, wunnasinuh, kah ummatcheuh.
    \xe ..., he took her, and lay with her, and defiled her.'    Gen.34.2  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv ..., kah pish kummatcheheaóog wut-Egyptianeog.
    \xe ...; and ye shall spoil the Egyptians.
    \so Ex.3.22
    \ng 2p->3p indicative
    \xv Qut pish kummatchheaumw∞ wut-Altarsum∞uh,...
    \xe But ye shall destroy their altars,...'    Ex.34.13  { 2p->3
    \so indicative }

    \se matchehteau
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to consume, curse, destroy, hurt sth, to make sth worse, set sth at nought, spoil sth'
    \so Gen.41.30; Ex.21.26; Mt.9.16,12.29; Mk.15.29; Acts 19.27; Rev.6.6
    \xv ..., , kah mahshagquodt pish matchehteau ohke.
    \xe ...; and the famine shall consume the land;
    \so Gen.41.30
    \xv Nemehkuh matta wepe yeu kutanakausuonganun pish matchehtaun, qut wonk weeku masukkenug manit Diana pish matta tahéntupanumóu, kah ummissugken∞wonk pish matchehtaun,...
    \xe So that not only this our craft is in danger to be set at nought; but also that the temple of the great goddess Diana should be despised, and her magnificence should be destroyed,...
    \so Acts 19.27
    \ng X->0

    \xv Kah wosketomp togkodtog wuskesuk wuttinnúmoh wosketompuh, asuh wuskesuk wuttinnúmoh mittamwussissoh kah matchehteauont,...
    \xe And if a man smite the eye of a servant or the eye of his maid, that it perish; ...
    \so Ex.21.26
    \ng 3->0

    \xv ..., kah ahque matchehteash pumme kah wine.
    \xe ...; and see thou hurt not the oil and the wine.
    \so Rev.6.6
    \ng 2->0 imperative


\lx matchéku
\va macheku
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\nt Remark: See also |matchetu|, T+.51b.
\ps v.i. / AI, i-stem
\twn No instance of expected II verb in |-kin| found yet. (Cf. other languages.)
\ge `he is poor' (lit. `he grows badly or becomes poor'    Prov.10.4)
\so Deut.15.4; 2 Sam.12.1
    \xv Qut nummatchek kah nukquenauhuk,...
    \xe But I am poor and needy,...
    \so Ps.40.17; (M) |nummatchek|
    \nt +
    \xv Matcheku noh segenamwe anakausit,...
    \xe He becometh poor that dealeth with a slack hand:...
    \so Prov.10.4
    \nt +
    pl. |-uog|    Prov.10.15; Mt.26.11
    \xv ..., tunkonogque ∞wenaiékinneah, onk matchekeup wutche kenaau, onk kenaau nashpe ummatchekuonk woh k∞chenaeekinneau.
    \xe ..., though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, that ye through his poverty might be rich.
    \so 2 Cor.8.9
    \nt +
    (|Matcheku@e| `Poor, poverty'    C.27/174.
    \xv Nummatchek.
    \xe I am poor
    \xv Noh matchek∞
    \xe He is poor
    \so C.69/204
    \xv Matchekko@oe
    \xe Poorly
    \so C.106/229.)

    \xv Kah wosketomp matchekit, matta pish kenashpe sepsinóh ukkinnohtohsuonk.
    \xe And if the man be poor, thou shalt not sleep with his pledge:
    \so Deut.24.12
    \nt +
    \xv ..., weenaékinitcheh kah matchekinitcheh,...
    \xe ..., rich and poor,...'    Rev.13.16  { _3
    \so _ participle }
    \nt +

    \se matchekuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `poverty'
    \so Prov.13.18

    \se matchékuen
    \ps N.agent.
    \ge `a poor man'
    \so Ex.23.3

[Narragansett [xnt] |Machêtu.| `A poore man.', |Nummácheke.| `I am a poore man.'    R.W.160/r.168,161/r.169.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nematsíghi.| `Je suis laid', matsigheni8 `Cela est mal, cela n'est pas bien'    R.308/474a; R.325/479a.
    \nt +
M.-P. |mociku| AI `he is bad (bad at what he does, evil, etc.), |mocikon| II `it is spoiled, no good'; |m@ciiko|, |m@ciiken| `er, es ist schlecht'    LeS.45b; Sz.121.
Menominee [mez] |mace∙kew| AI, |mace∙ken| II `he, it grows poorly, is in bad shape, goes bad, gets or is in a bad situation'    M.L.106.
WAbn. |mácikó| `he is bad', |mácikén| `it is bad'; |majigid| AI pt `bad animate one, he is bad', |majigek| II pt `bad thing, that which is bad' (no independent form cited)    W.79; D.1.287.]


\lx matchemungqueheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
    \nt +
\ps TA causative
\ge `to make sb stink'
\so Gen.34.30; Ex.5.21
    \xv ..., newutche kummatchemungwuhhimun ut wuskesukqut Pharoh,...
    \xe ...; because ye have made our savour to be abhorred in the eyes of Pharaoh,...
    \so Ex.5.21
    \ng 2p->1 indicative; verb in source texts means "stink", cf. e.g. Tyndale "ye haue made the sauour of vs stincke in the sighte of Pharao", Luther "habt stincken gemacht"


\lx matchemungquot
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\ps n. / II
\twn |matchemunkqussu|
\ge `a bad smell'
\so Ps.38.5; Ex.7.18
For |matchemungquohteau| `it smells badly'; from |matche|, with formative of verbs of smelling
    (|machümonquat| `a stink'    C.14/163.

[Narragansett [xnt] |machemóqut| `it stinks'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |matsimañg8^at| `cela sent mauvais'.
Delaware [del] |machtschimaquot|    Zeisb.]


\lx matchemunkqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\ps v. adj. an. / AI
\twn |matchemungquot|
\ge `he smells badly' { i.e. `smells bad' }; +`to stink'
    \xv ... Lord, tuhkés matchummunkquiss∞ai: newutche mahche nupp∞ yoqunne.
    \xe ... , Lord, by this time he stinketh: for he hath been dead four dayes.
    \so Jn.11.39(M.)
    \ng ?3 absentative indicative
    \nt +
    |Nummatchimunkqus,| |-sup.| `I stink, or did'    C.77/210
    \xv Nummatchimunkqussi@mun.
    \xe We stink, or did
    \xv Matchimunkqussinneat.
    \xe To stink

    \se -qusuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `making a bad smell'
    \so Joel 2.20

[Narragansett [xnt] |machemóqussu| `a vile or stinking person'    R.W.
Western Abenaki [abe] |matsimañg8s8| `il sent mauvais'.]

\et cf. B.1962, 15.143, p.300: |-mya∙kose| AI, |-mya∙kwat| II "consists of prefinal |-mya∙| `smell' with AI |-Ekose|, II |-Ekwat|".

\lx matchenau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `he curses (him)'; +`to speak evil of'
    \xv ..., Ahque quhtin∞k, newutche matta howan monchanatam∞onk usséit n∞wesuonganit, woh nunnukkumme matchenuk∞h.
    \xe ..., Forbid him not: for there is no man which shall do a miracle in my name, that can lightly speak evil of me.
    \so Mk.9.39
    \ng 3->1; what is |-∞h|?
    \nt ?+
    \xv Ne nashpe wananumogkut GOD noh Wut∞shimau, kah ne nashpe nummatchenómun wosketompaog,...
    \xe Therewith bless we God, even the Father; and therewith curse we men,...
    \so Jas.3.9
    \ng subordinative, to what?
    \nt ?+

    \xv Ahque matchenittegk, neematog noh matchenont weematuh, kah wasumont wematuh, matchetam naumatuonk,...
    \xe Speak not evil one of another, brethren. He that speaketh evil of his brother, and judgeth his brother, speaketh evil of the law, and judgeth the law:...'    Jas.4.11  { 2p imperative to reciprocal; _3_->3
    \so participle }
    \nt +

    \se |matchetam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a
    \ge `to speak evil of sth'
    \so Jas.4.11 (v.s.)
    \nt Given the pairing, the TA probably has the |-N-| final.

    \se mamatchenau
    \ps intens. / AI

    \nt MN: noh mamatchenont
    \ng suppositive |noh mamatchenont| `he who curses, when he curses'    Ex.21.17

\cf matcheu
\cf mattánumau


\lx matcheneheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv |matche-| + |(u)nneheau| TA
\ge `to commit a trespass against sb, deal ill with sb, do evil to sb, injure, offend sb, to sin, trespass against sb, do sb (no, some) wrong, ...'
\nt G&B.638, s.v. |madchenehhikquean|; T.172b.
\so frequent
    \xv ..., yeuyeu kumm∞cheke matchenehennumun onk nagoh,...
    \xe ...: Now will we deal worse with thee, than with them....
    \so Gen.19.9
    \ng 1p->2 indicative
    \xv ..., Neetomp matta kummatchenehenn∞, sunnummatta k∞n∞wòmunonus nequtompskot.
    \xe ..., Friend, I do thee no wrong: didst not thou agree with me for a penny?
    \so Mt.20.13
    \ng 1->2 negative indicative

    \xv ..., tohwutch ne in matchenéheóg, kittinnomw∞ wosketomp n∞wemattimun?
    \xe ..., Wherefore dealt ye so ill with me, as to tell the man whether ye had a brother?
    \so Gen.43.6
    \ng 2p->1 conjunct
    \xv Kah wuttinnaiin howan matchenéhheont pasuk yeug papéississitcheg,...
    \xe And whosoever shall offend one of these little ones that believe in me,...'    Mt.9.42  { 3->3
    \so conjunct }
    \xv ... kemat matchenehukquean, aushkom ...
    \xe ...: If thy brother trespass against thee, rebuke him;...
    \so Lk.17.3
    \ng 3->2 conjunct

    \se matchenehuk∞ong(an
    \ps deverbal noun to theme 2
    \ge `trespass'
    \so Gen.50.17
    \xv ..., ahquantamau yeuyeu kummatchenehuk∞wongan∞ kematog,...
    \xe ..., Forgive,..., the trespass of thy brethren,...
    \so Gen.50.17
    \ng 2p possessive


\lx matchesu
\va matcheusseu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\ps v.adj.an. / AI, long-vowel stem
    \dv |matche| + |usse-| `to do, make'
    \nt +
\ge `he is an evil doer, he does evil, is (actively) bad'
    \xv ..., neit woh kummatchesem.
    \xe ..., and it would be sin in thee.
    \so Deut.23.21
    \nt +
    \xv Qut kutchithontaman quoshauwâonk matta pish kummatcheseu.
    \xe But if thou shalt forbear to vow, it shall be no sin in thee.
    \so Deut.23.22
    \nt +
    \xv 4. Adam teanuk matchesu kah awakompanau. {Gen. 3.}
    \xe 4. Adam quickly sinned, and was punished. {Gen. 3.}
    \so Chr.Cov.Conf., 4
    \nt +
    \xv ... newutche pish kummatchesemw∞ ut wuskesukqut Jehovah,...
    \xe ...; because ye will do evil in the sight of the LORD,...
    \so Deut.31.29
    \nt +
    \xv Nag wonk matta matcheseog:...
    \xe They also do no iniquity:...
    \so Ps.119.3; (M) |Nag wonk wanne matcheusseog:|
    \nt +

    \xv Wunneechanean, ..., kah sepe ayéan ut ohkit, kah anisheóg, ..., kah matcheseóg ut anaquabit Jehovah ...
    \xe When thou shalt beget children,..., and ye shall have remained long in the land, and shall corrupt yourselves,..., and shall do evil in the sight of the LORD ...
    \so Deut.4.25
    \ng 2p
    \nt +
    \xv Kah tohneit wosketomp matcheseit tamh∞adt nupp∞nk,...
    \xe And if a man have committed a sin worthy of death,...
    \so Deut.21.22
    \ng 3
    \nt +
    \xv ..., tohwutch nen matcheussumuk wutch ne wajeh taubuttantam?
    \xe ..., why am I evil spoken of for that which I give thanks?
    \so 1 Cor.10.30
    \ng X->3; perhaps as "make me (out to be) evil"?
    \nt +
    |{Cor.} 6.9. Matcheussecheg matta auog kesukqut.| for AV "[Know ye not that] the unrighteous shall not inherit the kingdom of God?"    Log.Pr.68/80 { _3p_ participle; loosely for (E2) |matta sampwesegig, mat pish ahtau∞og ukkehtass∞tamóonk GOD?| }
    \nt +

    \xv ..., matcheussehtuh onk woh wunnegenin∞g,...
    \xe ...,) Let us do evil that good may come? ...
    \so Rom.3.8
    \ng 12 imperative
    \nt +

    \se matcheseonk
    \va matcheseong(an
    \nt +
    \ps Vbl.n. / deverbal noun
    \ge `wickedness, evil doing'; +`evil, iniquity, sin'
    \so Prov.14.17; 10.16; +Gen.15.16,18.20,50.17
    \xv ..., kah newutche ummatcheseonganooash ahche uhqunneunkquodtash.
    \xe ..., and because their sin is very grievous:
    \so Gen.18.20
    \ng 3p possessor plural
    \nt +
    \xv Nutunkquatunkquog matcheseonk wutch wunneseonk,...
    \xe They rewarded me evil for good,...
    \so Ps.35.12; (M) |machuhk wutch wanegik|, sim. 38.20(M)
    \nt +

    \se matcheseaen
    \ps N.agent.
    \ge `an evil doer'
    \so Prov.13.6, 21
    pl. |-aénuog|    Prov.14.19

[Cree |Mútchissu| `he is wicked'    Hws.143.√
Delaware [del] |mattauchsuwi| `sinful'    Zeisb.Gr.104; |machtissu| `he is bad'    Zeisb.Voc.21.]


\lx matchesu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
    \nt +
\ps AI
\twn ?|matchit|, II (s.v. |matche|); see B. 75, 110/467, B.1962, 15.200, 309 for the coupling; the meanings are distinct, being centred here on appearance-derived properties rather than on evaluation of behaviour?
\ge `to be ill-favoured'
\so Gen.41.4,19,20,27; Lev.27.12; Deut.17.1; ?Acts 25.5
    \xv ... nesausuk tahsuog onkatogig kowashinog ... n∞chumwesuog, ahche mamatchissuog kah iónauussuog ...
    \xe ... seven other kine ..., poor and very ill-favoured and lean-fleshed, ...
    \so Gen.41.19
    \ng (E2) only; reduplicated
    \xv ...neane matta nanauóogig wame ohkit Egipt ummatchissinneaout.
    \xe ..., such as I never saw in Egypt for badness.
    \so Gen.41.19
    \ng 3p t-subordinative

    \xv Kah sephausuen pish ∞n∞whôh, uttoh unne wunnegit asuh matchessinit,...
    \xe And the priest shall value it, whether it be good or bad:...
    \so Lev.27.12
    \xv SEphausuhkon en Jehovah kum-Manitt∞mut howae óxen, asuh sheep, n∞chumwesit, asuh machesit,...
    \xe Thou shalt not sacrifice unto the Lord thy God any bullock, or sheep, wherein is blemish, or any evil-favouredness:...
    \so Deut.17.1

[Cree |Muchi'sew| `He is bad in appearance, he is bad'; |Mútchissu| `he is wicked'; |mi'chïsou|, |mi'chïn| `Il, cela est laid, sale'    Frs.339a; Hws.143; V.229b.
(Del. |Machtissu| `bad, ugly'    B&A.70.)

(Mah. |machtessò| `bös'    Schm.35.)

\lx matchetou
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 51
\ps v.i. / AI
    \nt Remark: The form of the stem is puzzling. 2 singular indicative forms in |-m| point to a long-vowel final; conjunct forms in |-k| point to a consonant-final stem, but the consistent |-u-| vowel there raises doubts, and it could perhaps be a spelling of the nasal vowel. Does a w-final stem (cf. |mau|) solve this? a stem in |-aw-| or |-ôw-|? The impression given by the Massachusett examples is not of a simple stative verb but of a verb denoting a disposition or tendency to act in certain ways. See also under etymology.
    \nt +
\ge `he is bad [inherently or by nature, |matche-ohtau|], +`to be evil, wicked; to be abject, ungodly'
\so Prov.13.5, 22; +Ps.34.21; Mt.13.19,38; 1 Jn.2.13,3.12; Rev.2.2 (pl.)
    \xv Qut wosketompaog Sodom matchetowog,...
    \xe But the men of Sodom were wicked,...
    \so Gen.13.12
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nen kah nummissinninnúmog nummatchetumun.
    \xe ..., an I and my people are wicked.
    \so Ex.9.27
    \ng 1p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Sun tapeneunkquot unnonat ketass∞t kummatchetum,...
    \xe Is is fit to say to a king, Thou art wicked? ...
    \so Job.34.18
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    pl. |-t∞wog|    Prov.14.19

    \xv ..., neit peyau matchetuk,...
    \xe ..., then cometh the wicked one,...
    \so Mt.13.19
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah matta nag kummukk∞naôog matchetukeg,...
    \xe ..., and how thou canst not bear them which are evil:...
    \so Rev.2.2

    \se !|matchetou|
    \nt +
    \ps NA, agent noun
    \ge `the wicked' [singular?]
    \so common
    \xv ..., Sun kuppagwun sampwesecheg weeche matchet∞wog?
    \xe ..., Wilt thou also destroy the righteous with the wicked?
    \so Gen.18.23
    \ng plural
    \xv Matcheseonk pish nushau matchet∞oh:...
    \xe Evil shall slay the wicked:...
    \so Ps.34.21; (M) |noh matchetuk|
    \ng obviative
    \xv ..., naumon ∞naiyeuonk matchetowog.
    \xe ..., when I saw the prosperity of the wicked.
    \so Ps.73.3; (M) |matchetukig|
    \ng plural

    \se matchetóonk, -towonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `badness [of heart or purpose (inactive)]'; +`evil'
    \so Prov.8.7; Eccl.3.16
    \xv Newutche woh mo tapogkeetamounash matchetowonganash n∞weinuhkongqunash ...
    \xe For innumerable evils have compassed me about,...
    \so Ps.40.12; (M) |machuhkish|


[Cree |mathátissu| `he is bad'.]

\et Is there a relationship to e.g. Alg. |-TO| `faire', -|TWA|, |Matcitwa| `{mal faire}, mal agir', Cq.404b-405a,408ab,209a; Cree |Ttwaw| `façon, habitude, allure, etc.'... |{matchi}ttwaw| `il a une mauvaise habitude'..., Lac.Gr.86, No.51; or Men. |-qta∙| "freely added to roots, forming AI verbs which denote ways of moving and of doing work", B.1962, 15.168, p.304, and |mace∙qtaw| `he does, acts, works poorly, performs his work or action badly', B.1975.106?


\lx matchetu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 52
    \nt +
\nt Remark: variant of |matcheku| (q.v.), preserving the expected palatalization (G.1981, 40, 84); no fully established differentiation of sense seems to obtain; more study required. The relationship to |matchetou| is not fully clear me, though the spelling seem to be fairly systematically differentiated. Nominal uses are included here in this preliminary entry.
\ge `to be wicked; to be poor' (of appearance, health, wealth)
\ps AI
\so Gen.41.19(E0&E1); Ruth 3.10; Lk.18.22;
    \xv ..., n∞chumwesuog, ahche matchittuog kah iônauússuog neane matta nanauoogig ...
    \xe ..., poor and very ill-favoured and lean-fleshed, such as I never saw ...
    \so Gen.41.19(E1)
    \ng of cattle
    \xv ..., ishkont kummatcheet, ken, kah kek, kah wame ne adtahshekean:
    \xe ...; lest thou, and thy household, and all that thou hast, come to poverty.
    \so Gen.45.11
    \ng 2 indicative
    \xv ...: magish wame kutahtauonk chachaubenumau matchetuog,...
    \xe ...: sell all that thou hast, and distribute unto the poor,...
    \so Lk.18.22
    \xv ... wenauetüog matcheteaog ...
    \xe ..., rich and poor,...
    \so C.255.

    \xv ... nesausuk tahsuoh onkatogane matche nashauonguh, m∞cheke matchetinitcheh onk nagum,...
    \xe ... seven other spirits more wicked than himself,...'    Mt.12.45  { _3
    \so _ participle; probably to |matchetou|? }

\lx matchteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \nt +

\so Gen.8.21,26.29, Ruth 4.6, Mk.3.27,14.58, 1 Cor.9.18, Heb.7.18

    \so +0 TA+O, |-aw-| stem }

\lx matokqs
\va mahtohqs
\va -mahtokqus-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 52
\ps n. / II
\ge `a cloud'
\so [common]
    \xv Nuppon nutahtomp matokqsut,...
    \xe I do set my bow in the cloud,...
    \so Gen.9.13
    \ng locative
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche ummahtokqussum Jehovah ohtau woskeche pummuwuttauwáekommukqut kesukodâeu,...
    \xe For the cloud of the Lord was upon the tabernacle by day,...
    \so Ex.40.38
    \ng 3 possessive
    \nt +

    \se !|matokqsehteau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI+O, creative final
    \ge `to bring (of cloud)', "to gather, make cloud"; calqued on the Hebrew text
    \so Gen.9.14

    \xv ..., matokqséhteaon mattokqs yeu ohket,...
    \xe ..., when I bring a cloud over the earth,...
    \so Gen.9.14
    \ng 1->0 subjunctive

[NOTE.--This definition was not completed.]

    [Narragansett [xnt] |Mattâuqus.| `A cloud.'    R.W.83.
    \nt +
    Mahicanni |machtáhq| `a cloud'    Heckewelder 1885, from Levine & Bonnvillain 1980.55]
    \nt ?


\lx matta
\va mat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 52
\ps adv.
\ge `no, not'
    compounded with |teag| (`thing, res'):
    |matta teag|, |matteag|: |matchaog| `nothing, rien'    Lk.22.35; Prov.13.7, +Mk.6.8
\dv Apparently a contraction of |mohteau| (|mo| privative and |ohteau|) `it is not'; cf. |mo|, |monteag|. In some dialects the particle undergoes further contraction, as in Del. |tá| `a lazy no' (Hkw.), as in the French `point' for `ne point'. In composition, |mat|, as a prefix, has a privative and sometimes a direct negaive force, sometimes is the equivalent of |matche| `bad'.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Macháug| `No, or not'; |Wuchè machaùg|    `About nothing.'; |Nétop machàge.| `Friend, not so.'    R.W.36;42;124/r.132.
Narragansett [xnt] |mattuks| `no'    Stiles.
Western Abenaki [abe] |mañda| `non'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |m8| `point'; |m8k8èch| `rien, ne pas'; |ma8en| `personnes'.
Cree |númma@| `no, not'; |nummánta| (strong neg.) `no'; |númmanisse| (soft neg.) `no'.
Delaware [del] |makhta|, |tah|    Zeisb.; |mátta| `no'; |tá|, a lazy no; |tagú| `no, not'; |atta, ta| `no, no'    Hkw.
Powhatan [pim] |mattagh|    Smith.]

\so R.W.76
    \xv mattâsu nóteshem
    \xe I came from hard by
    \so ibid.28

\va mattamag

    pl. |+wog|    Eccl.7.4, 5

    \se mattamogque
    \va -magwe
    \ps Adv. and adj.
    \ge `foolish(ly)
    \so Prov.17.25


    \se mattamagqueussu, -magwesu
    \ps Vb. adj.
    \ge `he does foolishly, is foolish (actively)'

    \se mattamag∞onk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \ge `folly' (abstractly)
    \so Prov.15.14; 1 Cor.3.19

    \se mattamagweseonk
    \va -queusseonk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \ge `foolish doing, folly acted'
    \so Prov.14.17, 18; 1 Cor.1.18.


\lx mattanau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 52
    \nt +
\ps TA, ?applicative (cf. Del. cognate)
\ge `to overtake sb'
\so Gen.31.23,25,44.4,6; Deut.28.2; Josh.2.5
    \xv Neit Laban mattanau Jakoboh,
    \xe Then Laban overtook Jacob.
    \so Gen.31.25
    \xv kah umma[t]tanóuh wadchuut Gilead.
    \xe and they overtook him in the munt Gilead.
    \so Gen.31.23
    \xv Onk ummattanoh,...
    \xe And he overtook them,...
    \so Gen.44.6
    \xv Qut kenaau nematog matta kutapúm∞ póhkenahtu, ne kesukok woh kummattanukqunnaóut onatuh komm∞towaen.
    \xe But ye, brethren, are ot in darkness, that that day should overtake you as a thief.
    \so 1 Thess.5.4

    \xv ..., kah mattanadt us, ...
    \xe and when thou dost overtake them, say unto them,...
    \so Gen.44.4
    \ng 2->3(p) conjunct
    \xv NEematog, howan mattanukquit matcheseonk, ..., noh sampshan∞k nashpe manunnissue nashauonk,...
    \xe Brethren, if a man be overtaken in a fault, ..., restore such an one in the spirit of meekness;...
    \so Gal.6.1
    \ng X->3 conjunct

[Delaware [del] |Mattalan| `to come up with somebody.'; |matáleew| `catch up to s.o., overtake s.o., catch up to s.o.'s level'    B&A.75; O'M.160b-161a.]

\lx matteagunninn∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
    \nt +
\nt Remark: See also |monteagunninno|, T+.64b.
\ps II, negative predicative to |mat+teag| (including the II negative suffix)
\ge `to fail, pass (away)'
\so Lk.16.17,21.33; ?Acts 21.24
    \xv Kah anue nikkummat kesuk kah ohke matteagunnunn∞ onk nukqut chohkishik naumatuonk woh matteagunninn∞.
    \xe And it is easier for heaven and earth to pass, than one tittle of the law to fail.
    \so Lk.16.17
    \ng 0 negative indicative (2x)
    \xv Kesuk, kah ohke pish matteagunninn∞,...
    \xe Heaven and earth shall pass away;...
    \so Lk.21.33
    \ng 0 negative indicative
    \xv ..., yeush n∞tamogish papaume ken, matteagunóash,...
    \xe ... that those things. whereof they were informed concerning thee, are nothing;...
    \so Acts 21.24
    \ng 0p negative indicative, with syncope(?)

    \se matteagqunnehteau
    \ps TI2, causative (identity of base stem? lacking negative suffix or syncopated?)
    \ge `to make sth void'
    \so Ps.119.126(M)
    \xv ..., newutche nag mateaqunnehteoook kuttinnomatuonk.
    \xe ...: for they have made void thy law.
    \so Ps.119.126(M)
    \ng 3p->0 absolute

\lx matwau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
\ps AI
\ge `(he is) an enemy'
\so Ex.15.9; Is.59.19
    pl. |matwaog|

    \xv Quequenauanumwehettich, kah mohtuppaehettich matwahettit wutch nukketeahogkôunoh:...
    \xe Let them be confounded and consumed, that are adversaries to my soul:...
    \so Ps.71.13; (M): |matwaitcheg|
    \ng sole unequivocal evidence for the verb at present
    \nt +

    \se |matwau|
    \nt +
    \ps NA
    \dv agent noun to headword, per B.1962, 14.96, p.242
    \ge `enemy, foe, soldier'
    \so Gen.49.8;
    \xv ..., kah k∞skannemunneog pish ohtóog ∞squontam∞ ummatwom∞oh,
    \xe ...; and thy seed shall possess the gate of his enemies;
    \so Gen.22.17
    \ng 3p possessor obviative
    \xv kummatwomog
    \xe thine enemies
    \so Deut.20.1
    \xv kummatwom∞oog
    \xe your enemies
    \so Deut.30.3
    \xv ummatwomoh
    \xe his enemies
    \so Num.32.21
    \xv ummatwom∞uh
    \xe their enemies
    \so Josh.7.8
    \xv Kah matwaog wutuss∞wunóuh ut hall, ussowetamun Pretorium, kah wehkumaog moae wame matwaoh.
    \xe And the soldiers led him away into the hall, called Pretorium; and they call together the whole band.
    \so Mk.15.16
    \xv Kâh nutaiyeu kummatwómog kuahpannehtuonk.
    \xe Until I make thy foes thy footstool.
    \so Acts 2.35
    \xv Maumachish noh matwaú woh paguanit ne nupp∞onk.
    \xe The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death.
    \so 1 Cor.15.26

    \se !|ummatwam(e)u|
    \nt +
    \ps AI+O, verb of possession
    \ge `to be sb's enemy', i.e. "to have sb as enemy"
    \dv |wu-| 3 + |matwa-| `enemy' + |-m-| possessive theme + |-i-| AI
    \so Num.35.23, Ps.7.4(M),69.4(M)

    \xv ..., kah togkomont kah nuppinit, kah matta neh matwomegk, asuh mat kodnehik∞k.
    \xe ..., and cast it upon him, that he die, and was not his enemy, neither sought his harm:'    Num.35.23 { negative conjunct, 3->3
    \so ; aphesis of prefix }
    \xv ... (nux, nuppohquohwhunop noh tohnooche wamatwomeomp)
    \xe ... (yea I have delivered him that without cause is my enemy)
    \so Ps.7.4(M)
    \ng preterite participle, 1->_3_
    \xv ...: nag kod-nushukqueoneg tohnooche wamatwomweoneg, menuhkesuog:...
    \xe ...: they that would destroy me, being mine enemies wrongfully, are mighty:...
    \so Ps.69.4(M)
    \ng participle, 1->_3_

\lx mau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
    \nt Remark: C-final? -- see etymology and conjunct forms, though the 3p forms perhaps do not fit, reflecting the PA *-i-. See also examples from Cotton.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he cries, weeps'; +`to mourn'
\so 2 Sam.13.19
    \xv ..., kah natinneham toh woh adt mo∞g, kah petutteau negohkouit, kah ne wuttitmauun.
    \xe ...; and he sought where to weep; and he entered into his chamber, and wept there.
    \so Gen.43.30
    \ng 3->_adv_ participle; 3 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ne wuttit mauwunneau mishe mauonk,...
    \xe ...; and there they mourned with a great and very sore lamentation:...
    \so Gen.50.10
    \ng 3p subordinative; cognate object
    \nt +
    pl. |mauog|    2 Sam.13.36

    \nt +
    \xv Nen nummome.
    \xe I weep, {or} did
    \so C.84/215
    \nt +

    \nt MN: N noh sohhog kah mauug
    \ng suppositive |N noh sohhog kah mauug| `He that goeth forth and weepeth,...'    Ps.126.6;√ (M) |mog|
    \xv Qut Mary poquadche neepau weenohkeet, mau, kah maug nauwóseu,..
    \xe But Mary stood without at the sepulchre weeping: and as she wept, she stooped down,...
    \so Jn.20.11
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Mittamwossis, toh wutch mauan?...
    \xe ..., Woman, why weepest thou?...
    \so Jn.20.13; (M) |mauan|
    \nt +
    suppos. pl. (particip.) |neg maugig| `they who weep'    1 Cor.7.30
    suppos. pass. |maumuk| `when there is weeping'    Eccl.3.4
    (|neg mogig| `they that mourn'    Mt.5.4√)
    \xv ..., pish nôogkompóog, wutche quihtam∞onk wutawakompanáonk mauéhettit kah maémohettit.
    \xe ..., shall stand afar off for the fear of her torment, weeping and wailing,
    \so Rev.18.15
    \nt +

    \se mauemau
    \ps freq.
    \ge `(he mourns)'
    \xv ...: wussekousquom∞oh matta mauem∞oh.
    \xe ...: and their widows made no lamentation.'    Ps.68.74; (M) |mauemoopaneg|  { 3
    \so negative indicative; 3p negative preterite (obviative subject) }
    \nt +

    \se mauwe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \so Num.25.6
    (|maue|    2 Sam.3.16)

    \se mauonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `weeping'

    \se |mauaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to make sb to howl'
    \so Is.52.5
    \xv ...? nag nanawunoncheg, mauáheuh,...
    \xe ...? they that rule over them make them to howl,...'    Is.52.5  { 3p->3
    \so objective }

\lx mauemau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
\ps v.t.an. / TA, oral final |-m-|
\ge `he mourns for (him)'; +`to bewail sb, weep for, ?upon sb; to make a mourning for sb'
\so Gen.37.34
\dv (freq. of |mau|)
    \xv Onk Jákob nehnekshadtau wuthogk∞unash, kah mattónag ponam uppusquanit, kah mauemau wunnaumonuh m∞chetikqunne.
    \xe And Jacob rent his clothes, and put sackcloth upon his loins, and mourned for his son many days.'    Gen.37.34  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah n∞wau, newutche nuttom weenohkit wutche nunnaumon, mauwon: yeu wuttin mauemukqun ∞shoh.
    \xe ...; and he said, For I will go down into the grave unto my son mourning. Thus his father wept for him.'    Gen.37.35  { 3
    \so ->3 subordinative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah mauemau ∞shoh nesausuk tahshikquìnne.
    \xe ...: and he made a mourning for his father seven days.'    Gen.50.10  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    pl. |-maog| `they mourn'    Num.20.29
    \xv ..., pish ummauémoh kah wunneuantam∞onouh, naumohettit pukkittau wutchikausuonk.
    \xe ..., [they] shall bewail her, and lament for her, when they shall see the smoke of her burning,
    \so Rev.18.9
    \nt +

    \xv ... kah mittamwossissog neg wonk mogeg, kah mouemoncheg.
    \xe ... and of women, which also bewailed and lamented him.'    Lk.23.27  { _3p_->3
    \so participle }
    \nt +

    imperat. prohib. |mauemuhkon| `mourn thou not'    Ezek.24.17  { 2 prohibitive }
    \xv Qut Jesus ompamuhquait nô en n∞wau, wuttauninneunk wutch Jerusalem, ahque mauemegq, qut mauem∞k kuhhogkaóog kah kenechan∞oog.
    \xe But Jesus turning unto them said, Daughters of Jerusalem, weep not for me, but weep for yourselves, and for your children.
    \so Lk.23.28
    \ng 2p->1 imperative; 2p->3 imperative
    \nt +

    \se |mauwetam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, oral final
    \ge `to weep over sth'
    \so Lk.19.30(Hd), Lk.19.41
    |mauwetam Jerusalem| "he wept over Jerusalem"    Lk.19.30(Hd)
    \xv Kah pas∞tshadt, moninneam keihtotan, kah ummauwetamun.
    \xe And when he was come near, he beheld the city, and wept over it.
    \so Lk.19.41


    \se mauem∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `mourning'
    \so Zech.12.11

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nema8imañ| `Je le pleure'    R.400/508a.
    Algonquian [alg] |Mawim| `pleure-le'    Cq.211a.
    \nt +
M.-P. |muwimal| TA `s/he grieves, mourns, weeps for h/'    F&L.
Miami |nimawima| `I cried for him' (misclassified)    D.-V.372.]

\et H.1642 *mawime∙wa TA, 1647 *mawintamwa TI `bewail'


\lx maumachi
\va maumachai
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
\ps NI
\ge `"household stuff", property', +`furniture, goods, stuff'
\nt G&B.650: |monmachaiyeuash| 'household goods'
\so Gen.31.37
\nt plurale tantum?
    \xv Onk wame neemunnumwog maumachiyeuash ut Sodom,...
    \xe And they took all the goods of Sodom ...
    \so Gen.14.11
    \nt +
    \xv ...; newutche matta wohkukquoshininn∞ ne monak, kah sohsumoonk wutch wame wunnegane maumachiash.
    \xe ...: for there is none end of the store and glory out of all the pleasant furniture.
    \so Nah.2.9√
    \xv Howan ahtuhshont wetatteamunguh, teauguash, asuh maumachiash, woh wadchanumungqut;...
    \xe If a man shall deliver unto his neighbour money or stuff to keep,...
    \so Ex.22.7√
    |Momachiukkömuk|, and |momachiash.|    `A shop, and goods'    C.11/161
    \nt +

The primary meaning is perhaps `things taken.'
\cf maumunni
\ge it is taken
\so (as spoil, 1 Sam.4.17,19)

[Narragansett [xnt] |Maumachíuash| `Goods.'; |Nummaumachíuwash.| `My goods.'; |Aúquiegs| `Housholdstuffe.'    R.W.36;121/r.129;36.]

\lx mauunneau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
    \nt +?
\ps AI+O, long vowel stem
\ge `to gather sth'
\so Lev.25.3,5,11, Mt.7.16
\nt Remark: This belongs with |mauunnum|, |móunum| TI, and !?|mauunnau| TA, and presumably with the forms in |maue-|/|miáe| in intransitive/middle senses, e.g. of groups of people gathering. However, it is used with inanimate objects, and therefore cannot be a spelling of the TA verb. The identity of |-unn-| is not clear to me; most probably it is a de-stem form of |-min-| `berry, grain, fruit', so that this is a transitive verb with incorporated ("medial") object. This would also account for the form of the AI final, and the contexts in which I have found it so far. Siebert's *mawinsowa `he gathers berries, fruit, grain, nuts' (1975: 364, item 147; H.1646) would then perhaps contain this same complex.
    \xv ..., kah nequtta tahshe kodtummo, pish k∞nteoh k∞weenominneóhteuk, kah pish kumauunneam ne na adtannegik.
    \xe ..., and six years thou shalt prune thy vineyard, and gather in the fruit thereof;
    \so Lev.25.3
    \xv ..., kah matta k∞nteôe weenóminneash, mátta pish kummauunneaunash,...
    \xe ..., neither [shalt thou] gather the grapes of thy vine undressed:...
    \so Lev.25.5
    \xv ..., sun mauunneauog wenominneash ut asinekóussehtu asuh figsash ut kogkóunogkohquohh∞wêhtu.
    \xe ... . Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles?
    \so Mt.7.16

    \xv Kah kuppogham∞ongan∞ weehqshin nó pajeh weenominneash mauinneaumuk, kah wenominneash mauinneamuk pish wehqshin ohteuhkonat,...
    \xe And your threshing shall reach unto the vintage, and the vintage shall reach unto the sowing time:...
    \so Lev.26.5

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nummoúwinneem.| `I goe to gather.'; |Mowinne-aûog.| `He or they gather.'    R.W.99/r.97.]


\lx mauunitteauau
\va mauunniteauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv |mau-| `cry, weep' + |-un-| ? + |-htaw-| directive; role of |-un-| unclear (cf. B.1962, 16.140, p.356 on "prefinal |-ε∙nw|", perhaps meaning "with pity"?).
\ge `to cry unto sb'
\so Gen.4.10,41.55, Ex.5.15,8.12,14.10,17.4,22.23, Ps.61.2, Mt.15.22, Lk.18.7

    \xv ...? ∞wadtauatonkqussuonk keemat ∞sqheonk nummauunnitteunk wutch ohkekontu
    \xe ...? the voice of thy brother's blood crieth unto me from the ground.
    \so Gen.4.10
    \ng 0->1 indicative
    \xv Kah Moses mauunitteauau Jehovah n∞wau,...
    \xe And Moses cried unto the LORD, saying, ...'    Ex.17.4  { 3->3
    \so absolute }

    \xv Kah Jehovah unnáu Mosesoh, tohwutch, mauunnitteúean? ...
    \xe And the LORD said unto Moses, Wherefore criest thou unto me? ...
    \so Ex.14.15
    \xv M∞hm∞hsqheáe m∞hm∞sqhead wunnamuhkut, mauk, mauunnitteungqueon, n∞tamoe, nunn∞tam ummauonk.
    \xe If thou afflict them in any wise, and they cry at all unto me, I will surely hear their cry;
    \so Ex.22.23


\lx mauunnitteauáonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
    \ps NI, verbal noun
    \ge `cry'
    \so Gen.18.20
    |..., Newutche missi ummauunnitteauáonk Sodom, kah Gomorrah,...| `..., Because the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is great,...    Gen.18.20  { 3 possessor }


\lx mauunnitteaunshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 53
    \nt +
\ps TA
\nt Remark: The morphological analysis is unclear, and the semantic variety of the objects is puzzling. The final looks like the representative final, but without its meaning, and what precedes it can hardly be the directive final.
\ge `to mourn unto sb; to weep for sb; to weep with sb'
\so Gen.23.2; Mt.11.17, Rom.12.15
    \xv ..., kah Abraham ummauunnitteaunshuh & ummamuttamwanshuh.
    \xe ... and Abraham came to mourn for Sarah, and to weep for her.'    Gen.23.2  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv kummauunnitteaunshìnumun
    \xe we have mourned unto you
    \so Mt.11.17
    \ng 1p->2p indicative

    \xv ,,,, kah mauunnitteaunsh∞k neg maugig.
    \xe ..., and weep with them that weep.
    \so Rom.12.15
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative

\lx meechu
\va meech
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
\ps v.t. inan. / TI3
\twn |m∞whau|, |móhwhou| TA
\nt G&B.644; B.1962, 7.34-38; 16.155
\ge `he eats' (that which is inanimate, primarily vegetal food; but sometimes |weyaus| `flesh' is the object of the verb; cf. |moowhau| `he eats what is alive')
    \xv nummeech
    \xe I eat
    \xv ... woh meechwog nishnoh oshquashqui moskeht,...
    \xe ... I have given every green herb for meat;...
    \so Gen.1.30
    \ng 3p->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah unnau mittamwossissoh, Nux, wussinneas GOD, matta woh kummeech∞h nish noh pasuk mahtug tanohketeaonganit.
    \xe ... . And he said unto the woman, Yea, hath God said, Ye shall not eat of every tree of the garden?
    \so Gen.3.1
    \ng 2p->0 negative indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Neit mittamwossis nag ne in wunnegen mahtug meechinat, ... neemunum ummeechummuonk, kah ummeechin: kah wonk wuttinnumaun wasukeh weeche, onk ummeechinnin.
    \xe And when the woman saw that the tree was good for food, ..., she took of the fruit thereof, and did eat, and gave also unto her husband with her; and he did eat.'    Gen.3.6 { |ummeechinnin|: analysis? 3
    \so subject in n-paradigm?? }
    \nt +
    \xv ummeechin
    \xe he eats it
    \so Gen.3.22; Is.7.22
    \xv ..., woh nummeechumun mahtugque ummeechummuongash tanohketeaonganit.
    \xe ..., We may eat of the fruit of the trees of the garden:
    \so Gen.3.2
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh meechik
    \ng suppositive |noh meechik| , |meechuk| `he who eats (it)'    Jn.6.58, 51
    \xv Webe yeu meechhettit wuskenuog,...
    \xe Save only that which the young men have eaten,...
    \so Gen.14.24
    \ng 3p->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah aninnumungquean petukqunnunk ne woh meechu, kah hogk∞onk agwee.
    \xe ..., and [if he] will give me bread to eat, and raiment to put on,
    \so Gen.28.20
    \ng 1->0 (cf. G&B 550)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Uttiyeu penuwohteaog ahappehettit, uttoh woh adt meech paumukauadtuonk ...
    \xe ..., Where is the guest chamber, where I shall eat the passover ...?
    \so Mk.14.14
    \ng 1->0 (cf. G&B.559)
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah meechuóus matcheseongane sephausuonk yeu kesukok; woh wunnegenus ut anaquabit Jehovah?
    \xe ...: and if I had eaten the sin offering today, should it have been accepted in the sight of the Lord?
    \so Lev.10.19
    \ng 1->0 preterite subjunctive
    \nt +

    \xv Meech∞hkan ne teag nishkeneunkquok.
    \xe Thou shalt not eat any abominable thing.
    \so Deut.14.3; Deut.15.23: |meechuhkon|
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Boaz wuttinuh meetsehettit yeu peyâush, kah meech petukqunnunk,...
    \xe And Boaz said unto her, At mealtime come thou hither, and eat of the bread,...
    \so Ruth 2.14
    \ng also Deut.12.23 (c.f. G&B.572)
    \nt +

    \se meechum∞
    \va meechummu
    \ps pass.inan. / AI, II, predicative to |meechum|
    \ge `it is eaten', +`to fruit'
    \so Gen.1.11,9.1(E0&1)
    \nt +

    \xv ... metchummué mehtugquash meechummu∞k meechummuonk nishnoh pasuk neane wuttinnussuonk,...
    \xe ... the fruit tree yielding fruit after his kind,...
    \so Gen.1.11
    \ng _0_ participle

    whence
    \se meechum
    \ps NI
    \nt +
    \ge `victuals', +`food' (E0)
    \so Gen.14.11

    \se |meechumue|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `fruit(s)'
    \so Gen.1.11(E1); Lev.25.16
    \xv meechummue mahtugquash
    \xe the fruit tree
    \so Gen.1.11

    \se meechummuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `fruit, vegetal food'
    \so Gen.3.3; Amos 8.2
\cf meetsu
\cf m∞hwau
\nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |Keen méitch.| `pray eate.'; |Téaquacumméich| `What will you eat?'    R.W.14;11.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nemitsi| `[Je mange] cela'; |nemitsesi| `Je mange' (v.i.); |nem8hañ| `Je mange poisson, poire de terre, pommes, homines in g're,...' (an.obj.).    R.328/480a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |migichi| `je mange'.

\lx meechumehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
    \nt +
\ps ?AI+O
\ge `to charge sb (that...)'
\nt Remark: The relationship of the final, which appears to be the creative final |-uhk-| + |-á-|, to that of the following entry is unclear as yet, since the stem would be expected to have a sense "to gather, make food". The sentential object of English is perhaps an instance of substantive attribution.
    \xv Neit meechumehteau ukkodnetuhtaeneumoh, woh matta wuttinnôunneau howaneh, yeuoh Jesus, noh Chrîst.
    \xe Then charged he his disciples that they should tell no man that he was Jesus the Christ.'    Mt.16.20  { 3->3
    \so +0 absolute }

    \xv Qut meechumehteash Joshau, kah kuss∞m kah menuhkeh:...
    \xe But charge Joshua, and encourage him, and strengthen him:...
    \so Deut.3.18
    \ng 2->3 imperative

    \se meechuméhteaonk
    \ps NI, deverbal noun
    \ge `charge'
    \so Gen.26.5
    \xv ... kah nanahteaop nummeechuméhteaonk,...
    \xe ..., and [he] kept my charge,...
    \so Gen.26.5


\lx meechumuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
    \nt +
\ps TA, dative final to (denominal) creative verb.
\ge `to buy sb (a little) food'
\so Gen.43.2,4
    \xv ... hon nummonchemun, kah kummeechumuhkauunumun,
    \xe ..., we will go down and buy thee food:
    \so Gen.43.4
    \ng 1p->2

    \xv ..., wonk monchek, kah meechumémesuhkoiinnean.
    \xe ..., Go again, buy us a little food.
    \so Gen.43.2
    \ng 2p->12 imperative, built to diminutive stem


\lx meechumuhkoNau
\va -ehk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
    \nt +
\ps TA, final |-uhk-| + applicative |-ôN-|
\ge `to charge sb that...' i.e. "to command, enjoin, order sb to do sth" (comminari, mandare, praecipere); `to give sb charge' (|papaume| `concerning, over sb')
\so Gen.26.11,28.1,49.29; Ruth 2.9; Ps.91.11(M), Mt.17.9; Mk.1.43; C.42/184
    \xv Newutche pish mechumuhkonau wut-Angelsumoh papaume ken, woh kunnanawehhikqunaout ut wame kummayash.
    \xe For he shall give his angels charge over thee, to keep thee in all thy ways.
    \so Ps.91.11(M); (E): |ahtuhshau|
    \xv Kah ummeechumuhkonuh matta ∞wahshonounneau.
    \xe And charged them that they should not make him known:
    \so Mt.12.16
    \xv ..., pish wuttinnumauh wutangelsumoh ummeechumuhkonat papaume ken,...
    \xe ... He shall give his angels charge concerning thee:...
    \so Mt.4.6

    \xv Yeu nuttinne n∞swetamunan ∞wadtauatonkqussuonk Jonadab ..., wame neáne meechumuhkonukquéog,...
    \xe Thus have we obeyed the voice of Jonadab ... in all that he hath charged us,...
    \so Jer.35.8
    \ng 3->1p+_adv_ conjunct
    \xv Kah ummeechumuhkonuh onk woh mo howane wuttinnóunneau, kah wonk m∞cheke meechumuhkonont nano m∞cheke wonk wunn∞tamwáhuóneau.
    \xe And he charged them that they should tell no man: but the more he charged them, so much the more a great deal they published it;'    Mk.7.36  { 3->3' objective; 3->3
    \so +_adv_ conjunct }
    \xv Nummeechumuhkonomun.
    \xe We charge
    \so C.42/184
    \xv Kummechumahkonish.
    \xe I charge thee
    \so C.42/184

    \xv Yeush mehquoantamwahuash, nag meechumúhkus ut anaquabit LORD, matta m∞hm∞squtteinnaôut papaume kutt∞wongash,...
    \xe Of these things put them in remembrance, charging them before the Lord that they strive not about words ...
    \so 2 Tim.2.14

    \se meechumuhkonáonk
    \ps NI, verbal noun
    \ge `charge'
    \so Num.3.8,25,31,38,8.26,18.3,4
    \xv Kah nag pish nanawehteauog kummeechumuhkausuwâonk, kah meechumuhkonáonk wame tabernakle:...
    \xe And they shall keep thy charge, and the charge of all the tabernacle:...
    \so Num.18.4

    Note also:
    \xv Nummechimmuhkontüe.
    \xe I charge (a gun)
    \so C.42/184
    \xv Mechumuhkönat.
    \xe To charge, or order
    \so C.42/184

\et One possible external connection is with Alg. |MIDJIDJIM| `donne-lui commission de dire', Cq.217a, |Midjidjim| `Commissioner', Lem.D.127b, etc.; Men. |mece∙cemεw| `he commissions him, sends him on an errand', M.L.287, B.1962,449--but that probably amounts to explaining the obscure through the equally obscure. Another, probably better, possibility is to take the initial at face value and assume a transfer of sense from a TA form with an ornative sense parallel to (Woods) Cree "Méchim, {food}; méchime{kátum}, {he food}-makes {it}, i.e. {he baits it} ({a trap})" (Howse 1844: 20, no.7). (The usage noted by Cotton, in the purely physical sense of "load" is also pertinent here, and it is the semantic origin of the present usage in English, seen even more clearly in another Romance borrowing, "cargo".) This would establish, via the creative final |-uhk-|, the connection with the AI form seen in the earlier lemma |meechumehteau|. The semantic link, which could well depend on some highly culture-specific metonymy, would still have to be established. (The phonology is probably no bar to this, since the |hk| form is found essentially in contexts in which the |sk| form is dissimilated with respect to coronal consonants in the initial.)


\lx meepit
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
\cf mepit


\lx Meesk
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 54
\ps n.
\ge `elbow'
\so C.6/157
    \xv Nisquan
    \xe the elbow
    \so Wood (1634-1639)
    \nt +
    \xv Meesk, menutcheg
    \xe Elbow, hand
    \so C.6/157
    "Eliot |weesk|"    S., no 76, 337, G.1981, 31
    \nt +

    \nt Remark: "Elbow" does not appear in AV, if the e-text that I use is reliable; S. probably derived this form from Cotton's entry.
    \nt +
\cf ishquanogkod

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nesk8ân| `mon coude'; 3d pl. |8sk8anar|.√
Delaware [del] |wi squon|, `(his) elbow'    Zeisb.
    WAbn. |-keskwan| "(reshaped)", |nkeskwán| `my elbow', |wkéskwaná| `his elbow'    W., no.95, 98.]
    \nt +

\et A.1561,2201; H.2346,3848; B. 10, 89/444; S. no. 76, p.337; G.1981, 31: (S) *-ye⌠kwana NA `elbow'.


\lx meesunk
\va meis-
\va meyaus-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
\ps n. coll.
\ge `the hair' (of the head)
\so Is.50.6; Ezek.39.17
    \xv ummeesunk
    \xe her hair
    \so Jn.12.3
    \xv pasuk meyausunk
    \xe one hair
    \so Mt.5.36
    \xv Kah ummeesunkan∞ ogquenunkquodt ummeesunkan∞óut mittamwussissog,...
    \xe And they had hair as the hair of women,...
    \so Rev.9.8
    \nt +
(Cf. |weshágan| `hair on the body or limbs, the hair of animals, and |qunônuhquoau| `he has long hair'.)
\nt This word has the form of a noun collective, and is perhaps from |m∞su|, `he cuts close or shaves off', primarily `he smooths', signifying that which is cut off, in distinction from the long or scalp lock, |qunonukquóonk|.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nem8sañ| `je le tonds'; |nem8'si| `je me tonds, je me rase les cheveux'; |mas8k8^añn| `chevelure d'ennemis'; |nemassek8^é| `je lève la chevelure'.
Menominee [mez] |maish| `head'; |may-nay-nunn| `hair'    Sch.II.470.
Delaware [del] |mi lach| `hair'; |miech hee ken| [cf. |weshagan|    El.] `hair or wool'    Zeisb.]


\lx meetsu
\va metsu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he eats, he takes food'; +negative (often |matme(e)ts-|) `to fast'
\so 1 K.19.6
\dv Active intrans. form (or verb adj. an.) of |meech-u|, as if |meech-esu|.
    \xv ... onk meetsuog.
    \xe ...: and they did eat.
    \so Gen.18.8
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta nummetsuh, onk mahche eyon nuttinsháonk,...
    \xe ..., I will not eat, until I have told mine errand. ...
    \so Gen.24.33
    \ng 1 negative indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Quagwoshwetash toh woh adt meetsee, kah puttukquobpissish, kah nanauéhhe, nô pajeh nummahchepunneat, kah ompetak woh kummets kah k∞tattam.
    \xe ..., Make ready wherewith I may sup, and gird thyself, and serve me, till I have eaten and drunken; and afterward thou shalt eat and drink?
    \so Lk.17.8
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Paul wunnanompasumoh n neh wamu metsin, n∞wau, Yeu yaunchadtikquinukod matta kummeetseinneau.
    \xe ..., Paul besought them all to take meat, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting, having taken nothing.
    \so Acts 27.33
    \ng 2p subordinative
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh meetsit
    \ng suppositive |noh meetsit| `he who eats, "the eater"'    Is.55.10
    \xv Noh meetsit, ahque mishonónumonch neh mat meetsinegeh. kah noh mat meetseg, ahque wussumonch neh meetsinutcheh: newutche GOD wutattumunúh.
    \xe Let not him that eateth despise him that eateth not; and let not him which eateth not judge him that eateth: for God hath received him.
    \so Rom.14.3
    \nt +
    \xv ... tohwutch mat metséog nenawun kah Pharisesog nohnompu, qut kukkodnetuhtaêneumog matta matmeetseog.
    \xe ..., Why do we and the Pharisees fast oft, but thy disciples fast not?
    \so Mt.9.14
    \nt +

    Imperat. |meetsish| `eat thou'
    pl. |meetsek|

    \se meetsuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `food' (`meat'    Mt.6.25)
    \xv metissuonk
    \xe meat'    Ps.111.5(M) (c.f. T.
    \so s proposal about derivation above)
    \nt +
\cf meechu
\cf m∞whau
\so (v.t.an.)

    \se |meetsuonganu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to be for food'
    \so Gen.6.21
    \xv ..., kah pish meetsuonganú∞ wutche ken kah naghog.
    \xe ...; and it shall be for food for thee, and for them.
    \so Gen.6.21

[Narragansett [xnt] |ascúmetesímmis| (= |asq kúmmetesímmis|) `have you not yet eaten?'; |kommetesímmin| `your eating' (infinit. 2d sing.).
Western Abenaki [abe] |nemitsesi| `je mange'    R.328/480a.√
Mi'kmaq [mic] |migichi| `je mange'.
Cree |méchesoo| `he eats'; |méchesóosu| `he eats a little'.
Chip. |wësin| `he eats'.
Menominee [mez] |mee-tee-shin|.
Delaware [del] |mitsu|; +|míitsuw| AI `eat'    Zeisb.; O'M.170b.
M.-P. |mitsu| AI `he eats'; |mitso| `er isst'    LeS.45a; Sz.132.
WAbn. |mici| AI `eat'    D.1.315.]

\et S. no.74, pp.334-335: PA *mi∙cyehswiwa `he eats' "but PEA /*mi∙tahswiwa/ (AI) `he eats'", the basis for the latter not being explained. The final of the PA form is presumably the ancestor of the reflexive suffix referred to by B.1962, 15.34, 103, pp. 280, 293-294. T.'s suggestion is phonologically akin to what is seen in Mass. |kutchessum-|/|kutsum-| perhaps, and the examples from Abenaki (Rasles) and Cree might confirm the possibility of such a form; but wasn't there probably a PA allomorph *mi∙t- (cf. Mayhew's and Williams's forms, and Siebert's, based on (?) an interpretation of Virginian Algonquian |Meihtussur| `Eate w^th me', and a Penobscot form.)?

\lx méhchéeu
\va méhchéyeu
\va mehchu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
\ps v.i. / AI

\so Gen.25.21; 11.30; Lk.1.7

    \nt +
    \xv Qut Sarai mehchéeu wanne wunneechaneu.
    \xe But Sarai was barren; she had no child.

    \xe The fruitlesse figge tree
    \so Lk.13, column heading, K2rb; tr. from AV summary

    \xv Numwameechume sohhamup, kah Jehovah wonk nuppás∞k mehchu,...
    \xe I went out full, and the LORD hath brought me home again empty:...

    \nt +

    (|mehchiyéue| `barren'; |mohchiyéue| `empty'    C.)

    \se !|mehchewushau|
    \nt +

    \ng 1 indicative

    \ps TA, causative

    \so Gen.16.2
    \xv ..., Kusseh yeu yeu GOD numméhchehúk,...
    \xe ..., Behold now, the LORD hath restrained me from bearing:...
    \so Gen.16.2  { 3->1 indicative

\lx mehquantam
\va mehquoantam
\va mehquontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 54
\ps v.t. / TI1a, mental final
\ge `he remembers (it)'
    \xv ... nummehquontam nummatcheseongash yeu kesukok.
    \xe ...,I do remember my faults this day:
    \so Gen.41.9√
    \ng 1->0p absolute

    \nt MN: mehquontog
    \ng suppositive |mehquontog| `when he remembers'    2 Cor.7.15

    imperat. 2d sing. |mehquantash|    Ex.20.8; Deut.5.15

    \se mehquantam∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `remembrance (of inan. obj.), a memorial'
    \so Eccl.1.11; Neh.2.20
    (|wunnegen mehquontamu@onk| `a good memory'    C., should be |wunne mehquontam∞onk|)

    \se !|mehquantamwahau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, causative
    \ge "to make sb remember sth"
    \so following entry

    \se !|mehquantamwahh∞wau|, |-huwau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI, indefinite object final
    \ge `to make sth to be remembered'
    \so Ps.45.17(M),111.14(E&M)
    \xv Pish Nummehquantamwahhoowam Koowesooonk ut nishnoh pometuonkanut:...
    \xe I will make thy name to be remembred in all generations:...
    \so Ps.45.17
    \ng 1->X+0 absolute
    \xv Ummonchanatamwu anakausuongash mehquontamwáhuwau:...
    \xe He hath made his wonderfull works to be remembred:...
    \so Ps.111.14; (M) |Mehquantamwahhuwop|
    \ng 3->X+0(p) (preterite) absolute

    \se mehquânumau
    \va mehquanumau
    \nt +
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, mental final
    \ge `he remembers (him)'
    \so Gen.19.29
    with affixes, |kummehquanumoush| `I remember thee'    Jer.2.2√  { 1->2 indicative }
    \xv ..., matta ahque kummehquanumoush ut nuppeantamunat nukonnaeu kah kesukodaeu.
    \xe ..., that without ceasing I have remembrance of thee in my prayers night and day;
    \so 2 Tim.1.3
    \nt +

    imperat. |nummehquânumeh| `remember thou me'
    \xv Mehquanum kittinninneumog Abraham Isaak kah Jakob,...
    \xe Remember thy servants, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob;...
    \so Deut.9.27
    \nt +

    \se mehquânumâonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `memory, remembrance (of an.obj.)'
    \so Job 18.17; Prov.10.7

\xv ..., howan noh mehqunohkouut,...
\xe ..., with whom it is found ...
\so Gen.44.10,16
\ng X->_3_+0 participle, to ?|mehqunohkauau|

\dv |ahquantam| [|ahque-antam|] `he refrains from thinking of', with negat. prefix; |mo-ahquantam| `he does not refrain', etc.


[Narragansett [xnt] |Cummequâwname| `Do you remember me?' {Trumbull "corrects" the gloss to 2.sg. `dost thou' in his tr.; but Williams never uses the (apparently already obsolete for Williams, a Londoner [DNB]) familiar form in his glosses.}    R.W.41.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |nemi`k8'mañ.| `Je l'avertis, le fais souvenir'; |nemi`ka8itéhañdamen. 3. amik.| `J'ai inventé cela, je suis le p'r, &c.'; nemi`k8^itéhañ'damen| `J'ai la mémoire de cela, je m'en souviens'; id. `Je me souviens de cela.', nob. |[nemi`k8^ité]hañmañ.| / v. |nemi`k8^éremañ.|    R.40/390a; 298/470b; 338/485b; 469/531b.]
    Delaware [del] |Migomi| `put me in mind.', |Miguntin| `to remind each other.'; |mihkóomeew `to remind s.o., bring something to s.o.'s mind', |mihkóhptam| TI, |mihkoptámweew| TA `to recognize the taste of s.t./s.o.', ?|mihkwchéenum| `feel for s.t., feel s.t. (using the hands).'    B&A.84; O'M.172ab.
    \nt +
Lp.A |ni mik8elima| `je me ressouviens de luy'; |memik8alimaten| `Ressouvenons nous de luy'    D.2,103;34.
M.-P. |mihquitahamal| TA `s/he recalls h/, thinks of h/ (all of a sudden), remembers h/'; |mihkuluwemal| TA `s/he reminds h/ to be heedful, helps h/ remember, prompts h/; s/he counsels h/, gives h/ advice.'; ?|mihqaphal| TA `s/he comes to h/ tracks, comes across h/ tracks.'; ?|mihqapomal| `s/he catches sight of h/, notices h/.'    F&L.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Migwedäädu@m,...| `To remember'; ?|ikustaq| TA `overhear, ear by happenstance', ?|mikuwa:l'k| TA `find satisfactory', |mikwit-e:l'mk| `remember, call to mind'    R.216b; DeB.47a.
WAbn. |mikolawama| TA `he reminds someone'; |mikokaham| TI `discover something in the ground, uncover something new by digging'    D.1.317.]

\et Only Eastern? Apparently something like *miHkw- (vowel length?) `?' (one expects a meaning like "remember" to be seconday, and some of the other items listed above may well reflect a more original sense), with (?near-)conflation with *meΘkaw- in various languages, especially where the clusters merge, but with some signs of retention of the contrast *-kaw- versus *-kw-. Some connection with senses like "accident" and "find" is also noticeable. (Del. |msháaleew| `think about, remember s.o.', O'M.178b, presumably to *me⌠- `hit [cf. intendo arcum, animum in?], touch', etc.])

\lx mehtug

\va mehtug

\lx menadchu

    (|Menätche menitcheg.| `The left hand'    C.6/157)

    \xe Left handed

    \va menadcheaniyeu

    \ps of inan.obj. / II
    \ge `(it is) on the left'
    \so Zech.4.3,11; +Gen.14.15
    \xv Kah neesinash oliveuhtugquash kishohteau, pasuk wutohteau enninnohkôunneiyeu aht∞chag, kah onkatog menadchéinniyeu.
    \xe And two olive trees by it, one upon the right side of the bowl, and the other upon the left side thereof.
    \so Zech.4.3
    \nt +

    \se ?!|menadteasheau|
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: The additional |-uht-| in (E0), and in the conjunct forms of (E1) and (E2) may be by contamination from the form |nuttinohteash-|. See commentary on Genesis 13.9.
    \ps AI
    \ge `to take the left hand, go to the left (hand)'
    \so Gen.13.9
    \xv ..., menadtuhteashaan nen nuttinohteasheam, asuh eninnuhteashean nen nummenadteasheam.
    \xe ...: if {thou wilt take} the left hand, then I will go to the right; or if {thou depart} to the right hand, then I will go to the left.
    \so Gen.13.9; (E0&E1): |menadtuhteashean| "if thou doest [l]eft [hand] it"; (E0): |nummenadtuhteasheam| "I will left [h]and it"; (E1): |nummead-/teasheam|

[Narragansett [xnt] |Yo nmúnnatch.| `The left hand.' (of the path or way).R.W.69.√
    Alg. (with distant metathesis and different vowel; Cree, Fox similarly) |NAMANDJI| `être gaucher', |∙Namandji nindj| `main gauche', |Namandining| `à gauche'; |nämandji; nämândi| `Gauche'     Cq.253ab; Lem.D.
    \nt ??+
    Cree |NAMATCHIW| `il est gaucher'; |Numù`chëw.| `Left-handed'    Lac.D.477a; Frs.109b.
    \nt ?
Delaware [del] |Menantschiwon,| `left hand'; |mu@lánjiiw|, |mu@nánjiiw| `be left-handed'    B&A.81; O'M.181a,511a.
    Fox |nemaci∙wa| `he has a left side'    Fx.L.125.
    \nt ?
Miami-Illinois [mia] |Manantchi8a manantchita| `gaucher', |Nimanantchi8ni| ,`mon bras gauche'    Grv.241/157b.
Mahican [mjy] |nm'natschéwe| `link', |Menatschéu.| `Er ist [link].'    Sch.90.
    Menominee [mez] |nema∙hcyan| "poss loc only", |nenε∙mahcyaneh| `to or at my left'    M.L.157.
    \nt ?
Miami |manandjondji| `left (side)'    D.-V.370.]


\lx menadtam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 55
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\ge `he vomits (it) up', +`to spue sth out'
\so Lev.18.25; Jonah 2.10
    \xv ..., kah ohke menadtam neh noh wodohkinutcheh.
    \xe ..., and the land itself vomiteth out her inhabitants.
    \so Lev.18.25
    \ng TI verb despite the object
    \nt +

    \xv Onk ne ohke matta woh kummenadtam∞ônuk∞, nishkhetteaóg, neyane munnadtog wutohtimoin, ne negonáe onk kenaau.
    \xe That the land spue not you out also, when ye defile it, as it spued out the nations that were before you.
    \so Lev.18.28
    \ng analysis of independent form not clear; applicative TA final?
    \nt +

    \se menadtam∞onk
    \va menatam∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `vomiting'
    \so Jer.48.26
    \xv ..., anum wonk quinnuppu en ummenatam∞onganit,...
    \xe ..., The dog is turned to his own vomit again;...
    \so 2 Pet.2.22
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |n'munnádtommin| `I vomit'    R.W.
Delaware [del] |melandam| `he vomits'    Zeisb.]
\et Other languages (F., M.) have reduplicated forms, and H. reconstructs such for PA: 1491 *ma∙me∙mele∙wa, 1683 *me∙melatamwa

\lx meninnunk
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 55
\ps n.
\ge `milk'
\so In the title of the Indian translation by Grindal Rawson of Cotton's "Milk for Babes." In the quotation from 1 Peter 2.2, onthe title-page, the adv. and adj. |meninnunnúe| (`of milk, milky') is substituted for Eliot's |sogkodtungane|.
    Participial or suppos. inan. from |n∞nau| `he sucks', with |m'| prefixed, `that which he sucks'
[cf. |sogkodtunk|; or is it `what is given' (|menin-|)?].
\cf n∞nontamunát
\cf n∞nunát

\lx menuhke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 55
    \nt +
\ps PreV
\ge `diligently, earnestly, greatly, straitly,...'
\so Gen.19.3;... common

    \xe And he pressed upon them greatly,...

\lx menuhkeheau
\va menuhkheau
\va menehk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 55
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative
\twn |menuhkehteau| TI2
\ge `to confirm, establish, relieve, stablish, strengthen, support, sustain sb; make sb strong'
\so Gen.27.37,48.2; Lev.25.35; Deut.3.28,28.9,29.13,32.6; Ps.105.24; Lk.22.43; Rom.16.25; 1 Cor.1.8; 2 Cor.1.21,22; Phil.4.13; Col.2.7; 1 Thess.3.2; 2 Thess.3.3; 2 Tim.4.17; 2 Pet.1.12
    \xv ..., kah Israel menuhkheau wuhhogkuh,...
    \xe ...: and Israel strengthened himself,...'    Gen.48.2  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv Kah kemat nano matchekit, ... neit pish kummenuhkeh,...
    \xe If thy brother be waxen poor,...; then thou shalt relieve him:...
    \so Lev.25.35
    \ng 2->3 objective
    \xv ...? sunnummatta kukkezhuk, kah kummenuhkehik∞h?
    \xe ..., hath he [the LORD] not made thee, and established thee?
    \so Deut.32.6
    \ng 3->2 negative
    \xv Kah nutann∞nomp Timotheus ..., kummenuhkehikqunnaout, kah kuttaphikqunnaout papaume k∞namptam∞ongan∞ont.
    \xe And sent Timotheus,..., to establish you, and to comfort you concerning your faith:
    \so 1 Thess.3.2
    \ng 3->2p

    \xv ...: wosketomp wunnaumonuh wutch nehenwonche, ken manuhkeheadt.
    \xe ..., upon the son of man, whom thou madest strong for thy self.
    \so Ps.80.17; (M) |manehkehheohp|
    \ng 2->_3_ (preterite) participle
    \xv Noh wonk pish mánuhkehukqueog adt wohkukquoshik,...
    \xe Who shall also confirm you unto the end,...
    \so 1 Cor.1.8
    \ng _3_->2p participle
    \xv Yeuyeu noh manuhkehikqueog, weche kenaau, ut Christut, kah sasequnukqueogkup noh GOD. / Noh wonk kuhkinneasue menuhkehikqueog,...
    \xe Now he which stablisheth us with you in Christ, and hath anointed us, is God; /Who hath also sealed us,...
    \so 2 Cor.1.21-22
    \ng _3_->1p participle
    \xv Wadchabeteuhkoniteáóg, kah wekikônitteaóg ut wuhhogkat, kah manuhkehetteaóg ut wunnamptam∞onganit, neyane kuhk∞tomonteaóg,...
    \xe Rooted and built up in him, and stablished in the faith, as ye have been taught,...
    \so Col.2.7
    \ng X->2p conjunct

    \xv Qut meechumehteash Joshau, kah kuss∞m kah menuhkeh:...
    \xe But charge Joshua, and encourage him, and strengthen him:...
    \so Deut.3.28
    \ng 2->3 imperative

\lx menuhkéteou
\va menuhkehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 56
\ps v. caus. inan. / TI2 causative
\twn |menuhkeheau| TA
\ge `he makes (it) hard or strong'; +`to confirm, establish (covenant), harden (the heart) sth, to make sth sure, to labour'`
    \nt G&B.645
    \nt +
    \so Gen.9.17; Ex.4.21,7.3,10.1,14.4,...; Lev.26.9; Deut.27.26; Mt.26.66; 2 Cor.5.9; Heb.6.17,10.9
    \nt +
    pl. |-teoog|    Jer.5.3
    \xv Kah nummenuhketeoh n∞n∞waonk nashau nen kah ken,...
    \xe And I will establish my covenant between me and thee,...
    \so Gen.17.7
    \ng 1->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jehovah menuhketeau wuttah Pharoh,...
    \xe And the LORD hardened the heart of Pharaoh ...
    \so Ex.14.8
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Neit moncheog ummenuhkehtaunneau weenohkee, ukkehkinneahsukonau qussuk, kah ponamwog askuhwhósuonk,
    \xe So they went and made the sepulchre sure, sealing the stone, and setting a watch.
    \so Mt.27.66
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche nummenuhkehteamun, wetomogkut, asuh matta wetomogkut, onk woh kuttapeneunkqun.
    \xe Wherefore we labour, that whether present or absent, we may be accepted of him.
    \so 2 Cor.5.9
    \nt +
    (|Numme@nehkeehteo, -up| `I fasten, {or} did'    C.51/191√)

    \xv ...Yeu kuhkinneasuonk wutche wunn∞waonk ne manukkehteaun nashauwe ut neen, kah wame weyaus ohket.
    \xe ..., This is the token of the covenant, which I have established between me and all flesh that is upon the earth.
    \so Gen.9.17
    \ng 1->_0_ participle, formally subjunctive
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ut sanctuariut, woi Lord, ne kenutchegash manuhkéhteungkup.
    \xe ..., in the sanctuary, O LORD, which thy hands have established.
    \so Ex.15.17
    \ng 0p->_0_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv Matanumunaj noh matta menuhkehteunk yeush naumatuongane kutt∞wongash ussenat,...
    \xe Cursed be he that confirmeth not all the words of this law to do them:...
    \so Deut.27.26
    \ng 3->0(p) negative participle
    \nt +
    \xv ...kah wudtuk ne mânuhkehteâan wutch nehenwonche ken.
    \xe ..., and the branch that thou madest strong for thy self.
    \so Ps.80.15; (M) |manehkehtauohp|
    \ng 2->_0_ (preterite) participle
    \nt +

    \se |menuhketeausu|
    \nt +
    \ps II, derivational passive
    \ge `to be confirmed, made strong'
    \nt G&B.581, 646
    \so Gen.49.24; Ntv.Wr.134.27
    \xv ..., kah wuhpittenash wunnutcheganit menuhketeausupash,...
    \xe ..., and the arms of his hands were made strong ...
    \so Gen.49.24(E2)
    \ng 0p preterite indicative


\lx menuhkehteauau
\va menuhketeauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 56
    \nt +
\ps TA+O, dative final to causative
\ge `to establish sth with sb; to confirm sth in sb'
\nt G&B.646
\so Gen.6.18,9.9,?17.19,17.21; Heb.2.3; 1 Cor.1.6
    \xv Qut ken kummenuhketeoush n∞n∞waonk;...
    \xe But with thee will I establish my covenant;...
    \so Gen.6.18  { 1->2+0 }; (E1): |kummenuhkehteoush|
    \xv Qut n∞n∞waonk nummenuhkehteauon Isaak,...
    \xe But my covenant will I establish with Isaac,...
    \so Gen.17.21
    \ng 1->3+0 objective/subordinative
    \xv Neyane wauwéunáonk Christ kummenuhkehteanteaneauóut.
    \xe Even as the Testimony of Christ was confirmed in you.
    \so 1 Cor.1.6
    \ng t-subordinative, X->2p+0


\lx menuhkeu
\va menuhke
\va menuhki
\va menuhkoi
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 56
    \nt Remark: Entry subdivided to distinguish Prev from V.
    \nt +
\ps II
\ge `(it is) strong, firm, hard'; +`to be fierce'
\so Ex.6.1; 1 K.19.11; Ezek.3.9
    \xv ... ummusquantam∞ongan∞, newutche menuhkiyeup,...
    \xe ... their anger, for it was fierce;...
    \so Gen.49.7
    \ng 0 preterite indicative
    \nt +

    \nt MN: manuhkehik
    \ng suppositive |manuhkehik| `when it is hardened'    Job 38.38√
    \ng X->0 changed conjunct to causative

    \se |menuhke|, |menuhkeu|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge Great variety of equivalents, frequently as intensifier in combination with verb
    "{Menuhke} or {Menuhku} `Strongly'"    El.Gr.21/267
    \xv Kah m∞cheke ummenuhke nanompassumuh nahog,...
    \xe And he pressed upon them greatly,...
    \so Gen.19.3

    \se menuhkesu
    \ps with an. subj. (v. adj. an.) / AI
    \ge `he is strong'
    \so Is.40.26

    \se |menuhkesum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, derived from AI stem
    \ge `to revive'
    \so Gen.45.27
    \xv ..., kah wunnashauonk ∞sh∞oh Jakoboh munuhkesum∞.
    \xe ..., the spirit of Jacob their father revived.
    \so Gen.45.27

    \se |menuhkesue|
    \nt +
    \ps adj., adv. / PreN, PreV
    \ge `powerful'
    \so Mt.26.64
    \xv apit menuhkesue wuttinohkonit
    \xe sitting on the right hand of power
    \so Mt.26.64

    \se menuhkesuen
    \ps N.agent.
    \ge `a strong man'
    pl. `mighty men of valor'    2 Chr.32.21

    \se menuhkesuonk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \ge `strength, might'

    \se !|ummenuhkesuonganu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, possessive verb
    \ge `to have power'
    \so Josh.8,20; Lk.12.5
    \xv ..., kah wanne menuhkesuonganeog yeu wutusp∞hoanaout asuh yeu nogque:...
    \xe ..., and they had no power to flee this way or that way:...
    \so Josh.8.20
    \ng 3p negative indicative
    \xv ..., ummenuhkesuonganu wuttinuhkonat en chepiohkomuk,...
    \xe ... [he] hath power to cast into hell;...
    \so Lk.12.5
    \ng 3 indicative

[Narragansett [xnt] |minikêsu| `strong'; |minioquêsu| [dimin. `little strong'] `weak'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nemerkasani| `je me sers de force, j'emploie la force'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |menakèi| `je suis pressé' (adv. |menaké|); |melkei| `je suis dur' (adv. |melki|).]

\lx menuhkohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 56
    \nt +
\ps II
\dv |menuhk-| + |ohteau|
\ge `to stand, stand still in strength, stand sure, be steadfast'
\so Num.30.4,5.7,11,12; Josh.11.13; Lk.11.18; 2 Tim.2.19; Heb.2.2
    |Qút ∞shoh mat tapeneamuneg ne kesukok n∞tog, matta pasuk ukquoshauaongash, asuh ukkeneepissuongash, nish nashpe keneepinoncheh ukketeahogkôunoh, pish memenuhkohtan∞ash:...| (E1&2) `But if her father disallow her in the day that he heareth, not any of her vows, or of her bonds wherewith she hath bound her soul, shall stand;...'    Num.30.5 { reduplicated negative }
    \xv Kah mattannit chippehtôadtit, uttoh woh en menuhkohteau wutass∞tam∞onk? ...
    \xe If Satan also be divided against himself, how shall his kingdom stand? ...
    \so Lk.11.18
    \xv Qut ukquenohtag∞m GOD menuhkohteau, ahtunk yeu menuhketeae kuhkinneasuonk, LORD waheau wuttaiheoh,...
    \xe Nevertheless the foundation of God standeth sure, having this seal, The Lord knoweth them that are his. ...
    \so 2 Tim.2.19

    \xv Qut yeush keitotanash nish manuhkohtagish, Israel matta wutchikohsum∞unaoash, qut webe Hazor,...
    \xe But as for the cities that stood still in their strength, Israel burned none of them, save Hazor only;...
    \so Josh.11.13
    \xv Newutche ne wuttinn∞waonk, nashpe ket∞hkahettit angelsog, menuhkohtagis,...
    \xe For if the word spoken by angels was steadfast,...
    \so Heb.2.2

    \se menuhkohtáe
    \ps PreV
    \ge `steadfastness of'
    \so Col.2.5
    \xv ..., wekontamwe naumon k∞niyeuongan∞, kah menuhkohtáe k∞namptam∞ongan∞ ut Christ.
    \xe ..., joying and beholding your order, and the steadfastness of your faith in Christ.
    \so Col.2.5

    \se menuhkohtau
    \ps TI2, causative to initial? (relationship to |mehuhkehteau|?)
    \ge `to settle sth'
    \so Lk.21.14

    \xv Menuhkohtau∞k newutche kuttahh∞wout, matta negonne natwontam∞unat, toh áne namp∞hamuk
    \xe Settle it therefore in your hearts, not to meditate before what ye shall answer:
    \so Lk.21.14

\lx menukque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 56

    \nt +

EOj. |ma∙muwi| particle and preverb `all, all together, among them all'    B.1957.246a.

M.-P. |mawi| |(maw-)| PV `together; in a group'    LeS.42a.

\et H.1502-1511 *ma∙wac/t- `all, assemble(d), collect(ed), gather(ed)', reduplicated H.1489-1490 *ma∙maw-; H. gives only examples of the unreduplicated form that also have post-initial *-ac/*-at (and in some languages instances with *s?).

\lx mianau
\va móunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 57
\ps v.t.an. / TA, manual final
\twn |mianum|, TI1b
\ge `he assembles, gathers (them) together'
\so 2 Sam.12.29

    imperat. 2d sing. |mian|, |miyan|, |móin| `gather thou (them) together'    2 Sam.12.28; Esth.4.16; Num.21.16

    \se mohmóunau
    \ps Augm. and freq. / TA, reduplicated
    \ge `to gather people (together)'
    \so Mk.13.27; +Jn.11.52; Rev.16.14
    \xv Kah Laban mohmounau wame ne apitcheg,...
    \xe And Laban gathered together all the men of the place,...
    \so Gen.29.22
    \ng 3->3(p)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish qushkeu, kah kummohmounuk wutch kenugke wame missinninnutu, uttoh an Jehovah kum-Mânitt∞m seohukqueop.
    \xe ..., and will return and gather thee from all the nations, whither the Lord thy God hath scattered thee.
    \so Deut.30.3
    \ng 3->2
    \nt +
    \xv ...: muhmôunnau suhwhuhteamukkuppaneg wutch Israelut.
    \xe ...: he gathereth together the out-casts of Israel.
    \so Ps.147.2(M)

    \xv Wadchanean woi Jehovah num-Manitt∞mun, kah mômounninnean wutch kenugke penuwohteaut,...
    \xe Save us, O Lord our God, and gather us from among the heathen,...
    \so Ps.106.47; (M): |muhmonunninnean|

    \se miannum
    \va miyanum
    \nt !
    \ps With inan. obj. / TI1b, manual final
    \twn |mianau|, TA
    \nt Remark: identical to |mounum|, TI1b, T.65ab
    \ge `he gathers (it or inan. things)'; +`to lay sth together'
    {First       orderly       to lay tog[]th[]r  Notions}
    |1. Negonne kohkonumukish miyanumunat        wahittum∞ash|    Log.Pr.64/74-75  { X->0p t-subordinative }

    \nt MN: Noh tummehtahhog, asuh kuppuhhósit, asuh mayanuk,...
    \ng suppositive |Noh tummehtahhog, asuh kuppuhhósit, asuh mayanuk,...| `If he cut off, and shut up, or gather together,...'    Job 11.10
    \ng 3 conjunct

\cf móunum
\nt This verb has the formative of action by the hand, and perhaps Eliot was wrong in using it in the sense of calling together or causing to assemble.
In the same sense Rasles (as Abn. below) employs the caus. an. form.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nemaë'ghimañk arenañbak.| `J'assemble les hommes'    R.34/388a.]√


\lx Míchachunck
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 57
\ps N
\ge `the soule'
\nt R. Williams (122/r.130) says this word "is of affinity, with a word signifying a looking glasse, or cleere resemblance, so that it hath its name from a cleere sight or discerning."
    Pierson's Catechism in the Quinnipiac dialect has |mittachonkq| `soul'. The word has no discoverable affinity with either of the two names (|Kaukakíneamuck| and |Pebenochichauquânick|?) which Williams gives (p. 157/r.165) to `looking glass'. Elsewhere (p. 127/r.135) Williams writes pl. |Michichónckquock| {`soules'}.

[Chip. |wabmotchitchagwan|    Bar.46.
Delaware [del] |me tschi tschank| `soul, spirit'    Zeisb.]

\lx min
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 57
\ps n. gen. / N-final
\ge `a fruit'; restricted in its application to the smaller fruits, such as corn, berries, nuts
    pl. |minneash|
\nt Not used by Eliot except in compound names. It appears to be formed by prefixing the indef. particle |m'| to |-in|, the formative of verbs of growing, `that which is grown', or which results from growth. See |weatchimin| (`corn'), |wenominneash| (`grapes'), |keneumunneash| (`first ripe fruits'), |wómpiminneash| (`chestnuts, "white nuts"'), etc. Eliot has always the inan. plural. In some other dialects names compounded with |min| (or |minis|) have occasionally the an. form.
\nt See B.1962, 14.252, 255-256, 18.73, 392 for a collection of examples.

[Chip. |meen|; pl. inan. |meen-un| `berries'    Sch.II.368; but |mandá-min|, pl.an. |-minag| `corn'; |miskwi-min|, pl. |-minag|, `raspberries', etc.
Cree |ménis| `a berry'.
Delaware [del] |mihn| `huckleberry'    Zeisb.]

\va mihsh-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 58
    \nt +
\nt Remark: There are two almost identical forms, |mi(h)sh-| and |mis-|, deriving from proto-allomorphs of the same root. Whether any semantic distinction exists has not been established.
\ps initial
\ge `large'
\so Entries that follow.

\et H.1844-1849 *me?Θ- `large', beside H.1826-1831 *me?⌠- `large' in palatalizing environment

\lx mishadtupp∞

    \xe ... he made them a feast,...'    Gen.19.3  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    \xe And he made them a feast,...
