\lx misham
\va mus-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 58
    \nt +
\ps TI1a, probably mechanical final
\nt A syncopated form of |missohham|, q.v.
\ge `to interpret sth, make mention of sth, utter sth'
\so Gen.35.11,40.8,42.29,49.1; Ps.48.13, Ps.71.16(M),78.2(M); Mt.13.35; Mk.11.33; Jn.4.25; Rev.1.1
\nt Follow up needed: Preliminary entry; number of stems uncertain.
    \xv ..., kah matta howan nauwuttam∞onk ummisham∞un,...
    \xe ..., and there is no interpreter of it,...
    \so Gen.40.8
    \ng 3->0 negative objective
    \xv ...: pish nummisham kussampweusseonk,...
    \xe ...: I will make mention of thy righteousness,...
    \so Ps.71.16(M)
    \xv ...: nummushom nupwoaonkash nanekoneyeuukuppash:
    \xe ...: I will utter dark sayings of old:
    \so Ps.78.2(M)
    \xv ..., nuttinnukquómun unnukquom∞onk, kah matta howan nauwuttam∞onk ummisham∞un,...
    \xe ..., We have dreamed a dream, and there is no interpreter of it. ...
    \so Gen.40.8

    \xv ... yeush keitotanash, nish mashamukupash nashpe ne ahéttamuk.
    \xe ..., these cities which are here mentioned by name,
    \so Josh.21.9

    \se mishamauau
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to tell sb sth, of sth, to name sth (to sb?)'
    \so Gen.3.11,22.2,9,23.16,32.29,40.9,42.29,49.1
    \xv ..., Howan kummishamungqun kupposkissuonk?...
    \xe ..., Who told thee that thou wast naked?...
    \so Gen.3.11; (E0): "who - tould thee - thy nakedness"
    \ng 3->2+0 objective/subordinative
    \xv Onk piahquttumwe sokanuk wuttattamoónk ummishamaon wuttinnugquomuonk Josephoh,...
    \xe And the chief butler told his dream to Joseph,...
    \so Gen.40.9
    \ng E0, E1&2; objective, despite "absolute" (inanimate) secondary object
    \xv ..., kah ummìshamâuonuh wasenumoncheh, neh adt anakausitcheh,...
    \xe ... And she shewed her mother in law with whom she had wrought,...
    \so Ruth 2.19
    \ng objective, with obviative, because secondary object animate and "definite"

    \xv ... ut pasuk wadchuut uttiyeu mashamauun.
    \xe ... upon one of the mountains which I will tell thee of.
    \so Gen.22.2
    \ng 2->1+_0_ participle
    \xv ... kah Abraham quttuhhamauau Ephronuh silver ne mashamungqut, n∞tamohettit wunnaumonuh Heth,...
    \xe ...; and Abraham weighed to Ephron the silver, which he had named in the audience of the sons of Heth,...'    Gen.23.16  { 3
    \so ->3+_0_ participle; (Ephron had named the price, obviation status maintained.) }
    \nt ?

    \xv ..., missohhamah k∞wehquetumoush k∞wésuonk,...
    \xe ..., Tell me, I pray thee, thy name,...
    \so Gen.32.29(E0&E1)
    \ng 2->1+0 imperative
    \xv ...? missohhamaiek nash k∞wehquetumánumw∞:
    \xe ..., tell me them, I pray you.
    \so Gen.40.8
    \ng 2p->1+0p

    \et To *me⌠- (vowel uncertain) `bare, clear, plain, public, uncover', e.g. Alg. |MICIC| Cq.215b216a; Ojib. Bar.236-237 |Miji-|; Cree Frs.333b-334b |Mo(o)s-|; Miami D.-V.364 |mä⌠i⌠-|; Del. B&A.87 |Moschiwi|; Micm. R.30a |Moose-|; M.-P. |messuwi|, etc. (as "make publich, reveal")
    \nt ?+

\lx mishanantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 58
\ps v.t. / TI1a, mental final
\ge `he despises, contemns, thinks meanly of (it)'
    \xv ..., kah ukketeahogkoun∞oh mishanántamwog, newutche may,
    \xe ...: and the soul of the people was much discouraged because of the way.
    \so Num.21.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nawhutche mishantamunash kah nawhutche mishanontamunash
    \xe ...; and some to honor, and some to dishonor
    \so 2 Tim.2.20
    \nt +

    \se mishanánumau
    \ps with an.obj. / TA
    \ge `he despiseth (him); +to dishonour sb'
    \so Prov. 14.2,31; +Gen.16.4,5
    \xv ..., kah nag ∞wompequauonk nummishananumit nehenwonche wuskesukqut,...
    \xe ...; and when she saw that she had conceived, I was despised in her eyes:...
    \so Gen.16.5
    \ng X->1 absolute
    \nt +

    \xv ..., qut nukquehtiánum N∞sh, kah kenaau kummishanánumumw∞.
    \xe ...; but I honour my Father, and ye do dishonour me.
    \so Jn.8.49
    \nt +

    \se mishananumáonk
    \ps Vbl. n. act.
    \ge `dishonoring'

    \se mishananittuonk
    \ps Vbl. n. pass.
    \ge `being dishonored, contempt, disgrace (passive)'    Ezra 4.14; Ps.35.26; Prov.18.3

    (|meshanantamwe| `meanly'    C.)

[Western Abenaki [abe] |mí`k8"é| `écureuil'; |prénik8|, |mesánik8| `ces 2 ont un beau poil'; |anik8"sess| (dimin.) `suisse' [`chipmunk'].    R.22/383a√.

\lx mishánogqus
\va mishe-anogqs

\lx mishantam
\va missantam
\va missontam
\va mussontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 58
    \nt Remark: Two distinct stems, derived from distinct allomorphs of the initial, are conflated in this entry; whether any semantic distinctions correlated with them is unclear, as also whether all instances really belong here. The answer may in part depend on theological questions about attitudes such as pride, and how Eliot dealt with them. The initial here can probably be taken either as adverbial (quantity or "size" of thought, as Trumbull takes it, so including Cotton's "aim at", indicating intensity) or as predicative (attributed to the object of thought, as in "be for, mind, respect"). Trumbull's gloss "intent upon" is not found in AV. (Cf. also |mishanantam|, |mishanumau| supra.)
    \nt +
\ps v.i. and t. inan. / TI1a, mental final
\twn |missanumau|, TA
\ge `he thinks much, meditates, is intent upon (it)'; +`to mind, to muse on sth, to respect sth, to be for sth, be ...-minded'; `to despise sth', (C): `to aim at sth'
\so Jer.49.30; Dan.6.3; +Ps.119.117(M), Ps.120.7(M); Rom.3.19,8.5,6,9.11,12.16; Phil.2.2,3.16,8.2
    \xv Nummussontam wunnohteaonk: qut kodtoowonish nag mussontamog aiyeuwuttuonk.
    \xe I am for peace: but when I speak, they are for war.
    \so Ps.120.7(M)
    \nt +
    \xv Nummehquontam n∞adt kesukkodtash, nunnatwontam wame kutanakauasuongash, nummissantam kenutchegane anakausuongash.
    \xe I remember the dayes of old, I meditate on all thy works: I muse on the work of thine hands.
    \so Ps.143.5; (M): |nummosantam|
    \nt +
    \xv Nummissantamun.
    \xe I aim at', |Missântamunat.| `To aim at
    \so C.37/181
    \nt +

    \xv ..., asuh ahque mishanatam∞k wutche nag,...
    \xe ..., nor be afraid of them:...
    \so Deut.31.6
    \ng 2p(->0) imperative; intr.!
    \xv Tatupanatam∞uttegk, ahque missontam∞k môgagish,...
    \xe Be of the same mind one toward another. Mind not high things,...
    \so Rom.12.16
    \ng 2p->0p imperative

    \se |missantamóonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, nom.act.
    \ge `much thinking, meditation' +`meditation; mind; purpose, endeavours (C)'
    \so Gen.6.5(E0); Ps.119.97(M); Rom.8.7,9.11; C.30/176
    \xv Newutche weyausue missantamóonk, ne wútayeuuhkonukqun GOD,...
    \xe Because the carnal mind is enmity against God:...
    \so Rom.8.7
    \xv ..., ummissantamúonk God, neyaunak uppepenamóonk woh menehtikompohteau,...
    \xe ..., that the purpose of God according to election might stand,...
    \so Rom.9.11
    \xv Tahn∞che, missontam∞ongash.
    \xe Vain endeavours
    \so C.30/176

    \se |missantam∞e|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `imagination of; profane'
    \so Gen.6.5; 2 Tim.2.16
    \xv nishnoh missantam∞e wuttenantamoonk ut wuttahut
    \xe every imagination of the thoughts of his heart
    \so Gen.6.5
    \xv mamishanatamoe kah tahn∞che kogkehteum∞ongash
    \xe profane and vain babblings
    \so 2 Tim.2.16
    \ng reduplicated

    \se !|missanumau|, !|mishanumau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, mental final
    \twn |missantam|, TI
    \ge "to be [sb] minded", i.e. "to have one's thought intent on, to be focussed on"?; `to esteem, magnify, praise sb'
    \so Gen.16.4,5,49.9; Lk.1.46
    \xv Judah, ken kematog pish kummishanummukquog:...
    \xe Judah, thou {art he} whom thy brethren shall praise:...
    \so Gen.49.9
    \ng 3p->2 indicative
    \xv ..., nukketeahogkou mishánumau LORD.
    \xe ..., My soul doth magnify the Lord.'    Lk.1.46  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv Newutche missantamunat weyaus, ne nupp∞onk, qut missánumónat Nashauanit, ne pomantamóonk kah wunohteaonk.
    \xe For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.
    \so Rom.8.6
    \ng X->3 t-subordinative

    \xv ..., nishnoh onkatogeh mishanumáhettich onk nagumau.
    \xe ... let each esteem other better than themselves.'    Phil.2.3  { 3p->3
    \so imperative }
    \xv Kah womausue mishanum∞k, wutche wutanakausuongan∞,...
    \xe And to esteem them very highly in love for their work's sake. ...
    \so 1 Thess.5.13
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative

    [Lp.A. |ak8i missantam8kan Kaga| `ne sois pas orgueilleux'    D.90.]
    \nt +


\lx mishant∞wau
\va mishont∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 58
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he shouts, cries out with a loud voice', +`to cry, lift up one's voice; to make an X noise'
\so Jer.25.30
    (|Mishontooönat| `To roar'    C.72/206)  { X t-subordinative }

    \xv ..., Teagwe woh mishont∞wai,...
    \xe ..., What shall I cry?...
    \so Is.40.6
    \ng 1->_0_/_adv_ conjunct

    \xv ...mishont∞wahteogk, ..., nopajeh kesukodtut, unninnóg mishont∞wagk, neit pish kummishont∞wamw∞.
    \xe ..., Ye shall not shout, ..., until the day I bid you shout; then shall ye shout.
    \so Josh.6.10
    \ng 2p prohibitive; 2p imperative; 2p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ...  weekontamwe mishont∞wak en um Manitt∞moh Jakob.
    \xe ...: make a joyfull noise unto the God of Jacob.
    \so Ps.81.1
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    imperat. 2nd sing. |Mishont∞wash| `Cry', `Lift up thy voice'    Is.40.6,9√  { 2 imperative

    \se mishant∞wáe
    \ps Adv. and adj.
    \ge `with loud voice, loudly'
    \so Ps.150.5; Prov.27.14

    \se mishant∞waonk
    \va -ont∞waonk
    \va mishont∞waong(an
    \nt +
    \ps Vbl.n. / NI
    \ge `a shout, a loud noise', +`cry'
    \xv .... newutche ummishont∞waongan∞ nano missi ...
    \xe ... the cry of them is waxen great...
    \so Gen.19.13
    \ng 3p possessor
    \nt +
    \xv Manittou spéi nashpe mishont∞waonk:...
    \xe God is gone up with a shout,...
    \so Ps.47.5
    \ng (M) |muhshontoowaonk|
    \nt +

    \se ?!|mishontowohtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, directive final
    \ge `to make a noise unto sb'
    \so Ps.100.1

    \xv WEEkontamwae mishontowohtoh Jehovah...
    \xe MAke a joyful noise unto the Lord,...
    \so Ps.100.1
    \ng 2p->3 imperative ((E1) correctly |mishantowohtok|)

\dv |mishe| and |-ont∞wau| (`he utters').
\cf mishont∞ahpuhsu

[Narragansett [xnt] |mishaúntowash| `speak out'.]

\lx mishéheau

\so 1 K.1.15
    \xv .... kummishhesh, & kummittahesh ...

    \so Gen.48.4
    \ng 1->2 indicative

    \xv nummisheh
    \xe I exalt (him)

    \xv ..., neyane attumunumiéog ne woh paumushaog, kah woh k∞sekitteaheamw∞ GOD, ne woh netatupe nano kummishhitteamw∞.
    \xe ..., that as ye have received of us how ye ought to walk and to please God, so ye would abound more and more.
    \so 1 Thess.4.1

    \nt MN: noh misheheunt

    suppos. pass. (part.) |mishehit| `made great, exalted'    2 Cor.12.7  { X->3 conjunct }

    \xv Kah LORD nano mishéhhik∞k kah muttaanhik∞k en womonittinneat, kàh wame wosketompaog, neyanhenog kenaau.
    \xe And the Lord make you to increase and abound in love one toward another, and toward all men, even as we do toward you:
    \so 1 Thess.3.12
    \ng 3->2p imperative
    \nt +

    \se mishéhteau

    \so Hos.12.1
    \xv ..., onk nummishteoh wutohtim.
    \xe ..., and I will make him a great nation.
    \so Gen.17.20
    \ng i.e. "into", with predicative "object"; ??1->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ... kummishteauun kummonaneteaonk...
    \xe ... thou hast magnified thy mercy,...
    \so Gen.19.19
    \ng 2->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv nummishteoh
    \xe I magnify (it)
    \so Rom.11.13

    \nt MN: noh mashteunk
    \ng suppositive |noh mashteunk| Prov.28.8

    \se !|mishehteauau|, !|mishteauau|

    \ng 1->2+0 absolute


\lx mishehtashin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 59
\ps v.i. / |mishe-| + ? +|-ahshun| "wind blows" (G&B.517, 704 |sauwashun|, 747 |wutchewashin|)
\ge `it storms, there is a tempest'

    \nt MN: Kah taiatje peyaúm∞ mishont∞wom∞ wutch kesukqut, onatuh mahshétahshik,...
    \ng suppositive |Kah taiatje peyaúm∞ mishont∞wom∞ wutch kesukqut, onatuh mahshétahshik,...| `And suddenly there came a sound from heaven as of a rushing mighty wind,...'    Acts 2.2
    \ng 0 changed conjunct

    \se mishehtash
    \ps as n.
    \ge `a tempest, a gale of wind'
    \so Job 27.20; Is.29.6
    \xv ..., mishehtash ukkomm∞tinoh nukkonáe.
    \xe ..., a tempest stealeth him away in the night.
    \so Job.27.20
    \nt +
    \xv waaban mishshehtash
    \xe there arose a tempestuous wind
    \so Acts 27.14
    \xv wutch mishe tahshinit
    \xe from the storm
    \so Is.25.4


\nt [The separation of words in the last example implies that Eliot understood |mishehtashin| to be formed of |mishe| and |tahshin|, i.e. `a great uplifting.' It seems rather to be from |mishehteau|, with the formative of verbs denoting action of the wind, |-shin|, `the wind increases greatly.']
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 59

[Narragansett [xnt] |mishitâshin| `there is a storm'.]

\et  H., p.242 *-a∙?Θen II "blown by wind", M. |-ε∙qne∙n| Nask. -aastin "of wind" (vowel length?)

    \xv Mishquammauquock.
    \xe Red fish, Salmon.
    \so R.W.105/r.113
    \nt +
    (= |mishqui-âmaug|)

\lx mishummeechumu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 59
    \nt +
\ps AI, II, i-stem (|mishe| `great' + |meechum| `food, fruit'), predicative verb in the sense "containing, full of"
\ge `to be fruitful, to bear, bring forth much fruit'
\so Gen.9.1(E0&E1),7(E0&E1),17.20,26.22; Ex.1.7; Ps.67.6(E&M); Jn.15.5,8,16; Acts 14.17; 2 Cor.9.12; cf. also Gen.47.28, with PreV |mishe|
    \xv ..., kah pish kummishummeechumimun yeu ohkit.
    \xe ..., and we shall be fruitful in the land.
    \so Gen.26.22
    \xv Neit pish ohke mishummechummu;...
    \xe Then shall the earth yield her increase;...
    \so Ps.67.6
    \ng II; (M) marks it as such: |mishummechumoomoo|

    \xv Yeu nashpe N∞sh sohsumwaheau, mishummeechuméog,...
    \xe Herein is my Father glorified, that ye bear much fruit,...
    \so Jn.15.8; (M): |mishimmechumeogq|

        be ye fruitfull     multiply       fill ye   earth.
        \xv ... mishummeechumegk, & muttaan∞gk, &  numwapegk ohke.
        \xe ..., Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.
        \so Gen.9.1(E0)
        \ng 2p imperative

        \se mishummeechummu
        \ps PreN
        \ge `fruitful'
        \so Gen.49.22
        \xv Joseph mishummeechummu wuttuk,...
        \xe Joseph is a fruitful bough,...
        \so Gen.49.22

        \se mishummeechumeheau
        \ps TA, causative
        \ge `to cause sb to be fruitful, to make sb fruitful'
        \so Gen.17.20,41.52; Lev.26.9
        \xv Kah nahohtôeu wuttissowenuh Ephraim, newutche GOD nummishummeechummehuk, ut nutúhquónamuneat.
        \xe And the name of the second called he Ephraim: for God hath caused me to be fruitful in the land of my affliction.
        \so Gen.41.52
        \ng 3->1 indicative


\lx mishuntugk∞∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 59
    \nt Remark: (E1): |mishuntugquou|, with a (retained) typographical error, for |-uhtugq-|?
    \nt +
\ps II?, ?bahuvrihi (though lacking inalienably possessed noun?--like "bahuvrihi", or simply a verb of being?)
\ge `it is much wooded, a forest', +`it is a wood' ("much-treed")
    \xv ..., newutche ne mishuntugk∞∞...,
    \xe ...; for it is a wood,...
    \so Josh.17.18√


\lx miskauau
\va mussuhkauau
\ve 2 stems
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 59
\ps v.t. an. / TA, |-aw-|, perhaps corporal final |-hk-aw-| for second form
\twn |miskom|, |mishkom|
\ge `it happens to or befalls (him), it is found by or comes by chance to (him)'; + `(he) finds (him)'
    \xv mahchukish ... pish ummiskauóuh
    \xe evils shall befall them
    \so Deut.31.17

    \xv ..., yeuoh noh Anah maskauont mulesoh ut touohkomukqut,...
    \xe ...: this was that Anah that found the mules in the wilderness,...'    Gen.36.24  { _3_->3
    \so participle }
    \nt +
    \nt MN: ..., ishkont pagquodcheh woh woskehtowonk mussuhkunk
    \ng suppositive |..., ishkont pagquodcheh woh woskehtowonk mussuhkunk| `..., Lest peradventure mischief befall him.'    Gen.42.4
    \ng 0->3 absolute, |-hkaw-|
    \xv Kah matta muskouáhetteg, qushkéog wonk en Jerusalem,...
    \xe And when they found him not, they turned back again to Jerusalem,
    \so [i.e. having searched]    Lk.2.45
    \nt +

\et B. 10, no.28, 89/444, *nemeΘkawaawa `I find him', H.1910-1920, B.1962, 16.121, p.352; H.1914 *meΘkawe∙wa TA `find'; but also H.1877-1879 *me⌠-ehk-aw `catch/touch'? i.e. two distinct initials here, conflated by Trumbull?


\lx miskom
\va mishkom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 59
\ps v.t. inan. / TI1a
\twn |miskauau|
\ge `he happens upon, finds (it)', +also fig., as AV "find favour, mercy"
    \xv ..., onk sauanumwog ummi[s]komunáout squoant.
    \xe ...,: so that they wearied themselves to find the door.
    \so Gen.19.11
    \ng 3p->0 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ... kuttinnum miskom kitteamonteanitteaonk ut anaquabean...
    \xe ..., thy servant hath found grace in thy sight,...
    \so Gen.19.9
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv woh kummishkom
    \xe thou shalt find (it)
    \so Mt.17.27
    \xv noh natinnohhog ummiskomin:...
    \xe and he that seeketh findeth;...
    \so Mt.7.8
    \nt +

    \xv ..., teaguash nish maskomagkupash wussadt man∞tadt, nuppaudtunánonash wonk,...
    \xe ..., the money, which we found in our sacks' mouths, we brought again unto thee ...
    \so Gen.44.8
    \ng 1p->_0p_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \nt MN: maskog
    \ng suppositive |maskog| `when he finds (it)'    Ps.119.162; Mt.13.44

[Western Abenaki [abe] |memëskamen| `je trouve ce que j'avois perdu' (with an. obj. |nemeska8añ|); |nedaskamesi| `j'ai fais une bonne trouve'    Rasles.

\lx missín

    \ps PreN

    \xe And when Abram heard that his brother was taken captive,...

    \ng absentative, direct speech
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Howan matcheusset, mussuno∞ ut matcheusseonkanit.
    \xe ..., Whosoever committeth sin is the servant of sin.
    \so Jn.8.34(M.)
    \nt +

    \xv ..., nashpe ∞sqheonkan∞ neg nashitcheg, kah neg mohsinaitcheg,...
    \xe ...; and that with the blood of the slain and of the captives,...
    \so Deut.32.42
    \nt +

    \se missinnó∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `captivity'

\lx missinnin
\va missinnin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 60
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a man' homo, i.e. any captive or tributary, in which classes were included all men other than those of the speaker's nation or race (viri).
\dv (from |missin|, with indef. affix)
\nt G&B.648
\cf wosketomp
\cf omp
    Pl. |missinninnúog| `people', hoi polloì    Ex.24.2, 3; Deut.4.33; Num.22.5
    \xv missinnin kah puppinashim
    \xe man and beast
    \so Gen.6.7
    \xv howae missinnin ken
    \xe of what people are you?'    Jonah 1.8; lit. `what kind of slave are you?
    (|missinnin| or |missinninnuog| `a people'; |wunnissue missinnin| `a pretty fellow'    C.)

    \se !|missinninnueu|, |-u∞|, |-eu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, predicative final
    \ge `to be, become a people'
    \so Gen.48.19; Deut.32.21
    \xv Kenaau negonáeu, mattá kummissinninnu∞mw∞, qut yeuyeu ummissinninneumoh GOD,...
    \xe Which in time past were not a people, but are now the people of God:...
    \so 1 Pet.2.10
    \ng 2p indicative

    \xv ..., kah nen nag numm∞m∞sqheóog en m∞sitteamuneat nashpe yeug matta masinninnuégig,...
    \xe ...: and I will move them to jealousy with those which are not a people;...
    \so Deut.32.21

[Narr. "First, {generall}, belonging to all {Natives}, as {|Nínnuock|}, {|Ninnimißinnûwock|}, {|Eniskeetompaüwog|}, which signifies {Men}, {Folke}, or {People}."    R.W.A3v.]

\et non-initial portion to H.619 *elenyiwa `man'.


\lx missinohkau
\va missinohteau
\ve for !?
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 60
    \nt Remark: Entry reorganized, split across two lemmas; somewhat uncertain.
    \nt +
\ps v.t. an. / TA (AI+O?)
\ge `to carry, take sb captive'
\so Num.31.9; Ps.68.18,106.46; ?Rev.13.10
    \xv Kah wunnaumonuh Israel missinohteaog Midiane mittamwussissoh kah peissesumôuh,...
    \xe And the children of Israel took all the women of Midian captives, and their little ones,...
    \so Num.31.9
    \nt +
    \xv Kuttuspeup en ongkouwu, kummissinohteam missinnohkonunk,...
    \xe Thou hast ascended on high, thou hast led captivity captive,...
    \so Ps.68.18; (M): |kummussinohteap|
    \nt +

    \xv Kah wutayimauoh ukkitteamonteanummonaout nag wame masinohteacheg.
    \xe He made them also to be pitied of all those that carried them captives.
    \so Ps.106.46; (M): |masunnohkonukquehhitteuhp|
    \xv Noh masinóhteadt, noh pish au missináinneat ...
    \xe He that leadeth into captivity shall go into captivity:...
    \so Rev.13.10
    \nt +

    \se !|missinohkonau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \ge `to carry sb captive'
    \so Gen.34.29, 2 K.15.29, (See also T.232a.)
    \xv ..., kah nah ummissinnohkonuh ut Assyria.
    \xe ..., and [he] carried them captive to Assyria.
    \so 2 K.15.29
    \xv neit wutch Davidut onk yean ummissinohkonauh ut Babylon, nabo yauwudt pometuongash,...
    \xe and from David until the carrying away into Babylon are fourteen generations;
    \so Mt.1.17
    \xv ..., Neenawun Abraham wunneechanoh, kah matta howan nummamissunóhkonuk∞mun:...
    \xe ..., We be Abraham's seed, and were never in bondage to any man:...
    \so Jn.8.33; Mayhew: |nummamussunóhkonukk∞mun|

\et c.f. H.1880-1881 *me⌠enamwa TI, *me⌠ene∙wa TA `to catch' + *-ehk- `by body'+ -*Θ-?? (surfeit of transitivity!)

\lx missugken[∞
\va missuken
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 60
\ps v.i. / AI, C-final stem (variably or two similar stems?)
\ge `he is great, powerful, mighty'; +`to be an elder'
\nt G&B 515,652 (with 3 conjunct forms in |-t|)
\so 1 Chr.16.25
    |nummissugken|    Acts 8.9
    \nt +
    |kummissugken|    Gen.26.16
    \nt +
    \xv ánue missuken onk neen
    \xe one mightier than I
    \so Mk.1.7√
    \xv Noh pish missugkenu∞,....
    \xe He shall be great, ...
    \so Lk.1.32
    \nt +
    |missugkenwoh|    Gen.48.19  { 3' indicative }
    \nt +
    |missugkenwog|    Rev.18.23
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta ánue missugken∞ quoshodtumwaen onk noh John, kutchessummuaenin,...
    \xe ..., there is not a greater prophet than John the Baptist:...
    \so Lk.7.28
    \ng 3 negative indicative
    \nt +

    \nt MN: masugkenuk
    \ng suppositive |masugkenuk| Lk.22.26
    \ps 3
    \xv ...neg masugkenuppanneg,...
    \xe ..., the same {became} mighty men ...
    \so Gen.6.4
    \ng _3p_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv MANIT WAME MASUGKENUK
    \xe God Almighty
    \so Ex.6.3
    \xv masugkenutche
    \xe eldest'    Gen.24.2  { _3
    \so _ participle }

    \xv ..., kah missugkensh ken ut Ephrata, kah waeenomukqusish ut Bethlehem.
    \xe ...: and do thou worthily in Ephratah, and be famous in Bethlehem:
    \so Ruth 4.11
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +

    \se missugken∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `greatness' (in power, importance, etc., relatively)
    \so Esth.10.1

    (|Missegkinneat| `to abound'; |Missekinneat| `to increase'    C.35/179;57/195)√

\dv |missi|, with apparently the formative of verbs of physical or inanimate growth (|-kin|); but, if so, this verb could not properly have an animate subject.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nemeseghir| `Je suis grand', 3 |meseghir|, suppos. |méseghirek|; but |mesák8s8| nob., v. |meség8| `Gros'    R.275/463b; 276/464b.

\lx mittamwus
\va mittamwussis
\va mittamwossis
\va mittumwussis
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 61
    \nt Remark: Presumably |-is| is a diminutive suffix, which is also seen in the denominal verb. The two forms are perhaps treated as free variants, the diminutive form lacking any detectable affective nuance.
    \nt +
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a woman', mulier
\nt G&B.653, s.v. |muttumus| `woman'
\so Deut.21.1; 28.56; Gen.2.22; 3.2
\nt (cf. |squá| femina)
\ge `a wife', uxor
\so Gen.12.14; Deut.22.14; 1 Cor.7.16
    \xv ...; kah wuttinnúmu mittumwussissoh wut-Egiptianuh ussowesu Hagar.

    \so Gen.16.1

    \nt +

    \so Gen.17.15(E0)
    \ng 2 possessor obviative

    \xv Peyaonuk mittamwossisoh ohtou alabastare box, mishoadtue pummee,...
    \xe There came unto him a woman having an alabaster box of very precious ointment,...
    \so Mt.26.7
    \ng obviative
    \nt +
    \xv Nesuog mittamwussissog pish togguhwhosuog togguhwhonganit,...
    \xe Two women shall be grinding at the mill;...
    \so Mt.24.41
    \nt +
    \xv numm-
    \xe my wife
    \xv kumm-
    \xe thy wife
    \xv ummittamwussoh
    \xe his wife, the wife of (him)
    \so Gen.12.12; 19.26
\cf wusso
\ge (she) is his wife

\lx mittamwussu
\va mittamwussissu
\va ∞mittumwussissinneat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 61
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), i-stem, verb of possession
\ge `she is a wife {(to him)'; `he has, takes a wife/(her) as wife'}, +`to take a wife, sb to wife; to become sb's wife'
\nt G&B.682; item 9, 579; see also T.169b, s.v. |ummittamwussenat|.
    \nt Remark: Like Trumbull, I have not distinguished the diminutive and non-diminutive forms. Note that the forms given by Trumbull superficially do not fit the description of verbs of possession given by G&B. (no.9, 579), partly because, not having a third person verb prefix (in the "absolute" forms), the pure nominal form of the possessive alone appears, often aphetized, and partly because in his conjunct example the possessive prefix is lost, again by aphesis, as G&B.484. (Where change is applied to the prefix, it is of course retained.) The entry is misplaced, treated as if the aphetic form were the norm, and should appear under |ummittamwussenat| and |ummittamwussu|, T.169b. I have given a large number of supplementary examples to provide a good survey of the patterns seen in possessive verbs, and the variety of AV locutions translated in this way.
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish ummittamwussu penompoh.
    \xe And he shall take a wife in her virginity.
    \so Lev.21.13
    \nt +
    \xv kah negonne ummittamwussu,...
    \xe and the first took a wife
    \so Mk.12.20
    \nt +
    |ummittamwussu|, |-wussissu| `he takes to wife'    2 Chr.21.6; Gen.25.1
    \xv ...? ne n∞che woh nukkod ummittamwussin,...
    \xe ...? so I might have taken her to me to wife:...
    \so Gen.12.18-19
    \ng 1->3-obj; there is an error in verse division (1&2).
    \nt +
    \xv ... onk n∞mittamwussissin.
    \xe ...; and she became my wife.
    \so Gen.20.12
    \ng 1->3 objective (subordinative?)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Matta pish k∞mittumwussissu wuttóninneunk wutch Kanaan.
    \xe ..., Thou shalt not take a wife of the daughters of Canaan;
    \so Gen.28.6
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut matta neit ∞mittumwussisséinoh.
    \xe ..., and she was not given unto him to wife.
    \so Gen.38.14
    \nt +
    \xv ...: qut penompoh kenugke ummissinninneumut, pish ∞mittamwussissinneuh.
    \xe ...: but he shall take a virgin of his own people to wife.
    \so Lev.21.14
    \ng Note the objective form induced by the preverbal (indefinite) nominal.
    \nt +

    \nt MN: mittamwussit onkatog
    \ng suppositive |mittamwussit onkatog| `if she be the wife of another'    Jer.3.1
    \ng 1&2
    \xv ...: Jakob ummittumwussit wuttaunoh Heth,...
    \xe ...: if Jacob take a wife of the daughters of Heth,...
    \so Gen.27.46
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh wonk ummittumwussean onkátogig onk yeug nuttônog,...
    \xe ..., or if thou shalt take other wives beside my daughters,...
    \so Gen.31.50
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Esau yauunchage kodtumwohkom wamittumwussissit Judith wuttaunoh Beeri Wuthittite, kah Bashamath wuttaunoh Elon Wuthittite.
    \xe And Esau was forty years old when he took to wife Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, and Bashemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite:
    \so Gen.26.34 (Gen.25.20: |wom-|)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh nahohtoeu wesukaiin nuppuk, noh wamittamwussisseup.
    \xe ...; or if the latter husband die, which took her to be his wife;
    \so Deut.24.3
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah kussontimom wunnaumonuh ummittumwossisitch,...
    \xe ..., and let her be thy master's son's wife,...'    Gen.24.51  { 3->3
    \so }
    \nt +
    \xv kah na ut ummittumwussish wuttonoh Laban kokas wematoh.
    \xe and take thee a wife from thence of the daughters of Labn thy mother's brother.
    \so Gen.28.2
    \ng 2->3
    \nt +
    \xv ..., k∞wehquetumoush aninnumau ummittumwussitch.
    \xe ...: I pray you give her him to wife.'    Gen.34.8 { 3->3
    \so ; typical shift to direct speech form, as if "give her him--let him have her to wife" }

\lx m'n∞t
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 61
\cf man∞t


\lx mo
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 61
\ps adv.
\ge `{Also} Mo {sometimes signifieth} Not.'
\nt G&B.648
\so El.Gr.21
    \xv mo teag
    \xe nothing
    \so Is.40.17
    = |monteag|    Is.41.17
    = |matteag|    Lk.22.35
\cf matta

\nt Negation appears to be the primary signification of this particle, or rather of its base, |m'| (q.v.).  With the formative of the verb substantive (|m-∞|, |mo|) it came to have the force of an affirmation of past being (fuit) by denial of present, and thus supplied the preterit of the defective verb of existence; |ko| `it was and continues to be'; |mo| `it was and is not'; |pish| `it will be'. (The limited or definite present, `is now', was marked by the affix |-∞| for verbs of being, |-ni| or |-i| for verbs of an. or inan. action. For the former class, see El.Gr.16.)  Eliot sometimes combined |mo| with |ko| to form an aorist (|koh mô|, |mónkô|. See |ko|). For the force of |m'| as a prefix, indeterminate and impersonal, see |m'|:
    \xv na mo ayeuwuttuonk
    \xe there was a battle
    \so 2 Sam.2.17
    \xv mô wequai
    \xe there was light
    \so Gen.1.3
    \xv ken mo wuttinneumin
    \xe thou wast a servant
    \so Deut.5.17
    \xv neg mo neematog
    \xe these (who are dead) were my brothers
    \so Judg.8.19
    \xv mo ayeuau
    \xe he was made
    \so , etc.,    1 Cor.15.45.
|-mo| or |-m∞|, the characteristic of active intransitive verbs when their subject is inanimate, is nearly related to the impersonal prefix |m'| -- for example,
    \xv n∞keu
    \xe he descends' |n∞ke-m∞| `it descends or is let down
    \xv ∞m
    \xe he goes'; |∞m∞| `it goes
    \so .

[Mi'kmaq [mic] |m8| `point'; |ma8en| (de |m8| et |8en| `quelqu'un'), `personne'.]


\lx moáe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 61
\cf miáe


\lx Moamitteau~g
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 61
\ge "{A little sort of fish}, halfe as big as Sprats, plentifull in Winter."
\so R.W.108/r.116√
\nt Perhaps the smelt (Osmerus eperlanus), hut the name may he applied to any species which `goes in shoals' or `a great many together.' It has been corrupted to "mummychaug" and "mummachog", by which name several species of small fish are popularly known, especially the ornamented minnow (Hydrargyra ornata, LeSueur).
\dv |mohmoeau|; pass. and mutual form, |mohmoitteauog| `they go gathered together or in great numbers'.

\lx mohtometu
\va mohtommetu
\va mehtametu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 62
    \nt +
\nt Remark: stem |mohtomeg-|, with palatalization. Since the majority of forms are conjunct, the first vowel is uncertain, although there are probably enough non-conjunct forms to suggest the correctness of this spelling, and the etymological connections imply the nasal vowel. The connection with |mohtompan| also seems plausible. However, there are at least two instances, in a nominal form, of |méhtam-| in the current corpus (Gen.10.15, all editions; Ex.34.20, both editions).
\dv |mohtam-| `earliest, first' + |-ek-i-| `to become, grow'
\ps AI
\ge "to be born first", as conjunct translating `(to be) the first born, elder'
\so frequent
    \xv ...; matta woh ayeuau wunnaumonuh noh womonit ummohtommeginneat negonne wunnaumonat noh sekenauit, noh mohtommegit.
    \xe ..., that he may not make the son of the beloved first born before the son of the hated, which is indeed the first born:
    \so Deut.21.16
    \ng 3 t-subordinative

    \xv ..., kusseh Milcah nagum wonk neechauau keematoh Nahor, / Huz mohtommeginitcheh kah Buz weematoh. ...
    \xe ..., Behold, Milcah, she hath also borne children unto thy brother Nahor; / Huz his first born, and Buz his brother,...'    Gen.22.20-21  { _3
    \so _ participle }
    \xv Kah Laban nesitàunioh, ∞wesuonk mohtomegit Leah, kah ∞wesuonk nahohtôeu Rachél.
    \xe And Laban had two daughters: the name of the elder was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.
    \so Gen.29.16
    \ng _3_ participle

    \se |mohtomegin|
    \nt ?
    \ps NA, verbal abstract?
    \ge `first born'
    \so Ex.13.2,15
    \xv Pahke chippunnumah nishnoh ummohtomegin ...
    \xe Sanctify unto me all the first born,...
    \so Ex.13.2
    \xv ..., kah nishnoh mohtommegin nunnaumon nuppohquohwhun.
    \xe ..., but all the first born of my children I redeem
    \so Ex.13.15
    \ng appositional

    \se mohtomeg(e)heau
    \ps TA, causative to |mohtomeg-|
    \ge usually conjunct in rendering `eldest' or `first born'
    \so Gen.27.1,19,32,42,35.23,36.15,38.6,7,49.3; Ex.4.22,23,11.5
    \xv Noh pish nummohtomekeh,...
    \xe Also I will make him my first-born,...
    \so Ps.89.27(M)
    \ng as 1->3 objective }; (E): |nummohtommegitteaeh| { analysis? cf. Gen.44.12

    \xv ..., kah weekomau Esauoh mohtomegheoncheh,...
    \xe ..., he called Esau his eldest son,...'    Gen.27.1 { 3->_3
    \so _ }
    \xv ..., Israel nunnaumon, mohtammegheog. / ..., kusseh pish nunnush kenaumon mohommegheadt,
    \xe ..., Israel is my son, even my first born: ..., behold, I will slay thy son, even thy first born.
    \so Ex.4.22-23
    \ng 1->_3_, 2->_3_ participles

[Algonquian [alg] |MADJI-, voy. MAT-|; |MADJIKIWIS| `fils aîné, frère aîné'; |MAT-| `... L'idée générale de ce mot est de {passer du repos au mouvement, de l'inaction à l'action, de se mettre en mouvement pour faire une action, une chose}'; |Matipo| `il commence à neiger'    Cq.195b-196a;196a;208a-209a.
Ill. {R} |mattami| `le premier. premierement, pp^alement: it. au fond', Gr.256/164b.
Ojibwe [oji] |maad-|/|maaj-| `start', Rh.210-215.
Shawnee [sjw] |maaci, maat-| `MOVING, CHANGING POSITION', D.-V.353.
WAbn. |môj-| `begin, start', D.1.328-330 (as in Mass. |monchu|).]

\et Initial *ma∙c-/ma∙t- `move', B. 101, 120/478, H.1466-1476, 1499-1500

\lx mónáe
\va m∞náe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 63
    \nt Remark: probably |môn(á)-|
    \nt +
\ps PreV?
\ge `there is much, there is abundance']

    \se monáu
    \ps II
    \ge `to be many'
    pl. |nano m∞naash| `they are increased'    Jer.5.6
    \xv monaash
    \xe they are many
    \so Jer.5.6

    \nt MN: mónak
    \ng suppositive |mónak| `when there is abundance, when it abounds'    Ps.72.7; 1 Pet.3
    \ng or to |monát| II
    \xv yeu monak
    \xe this great store
    \so 2 Chr.31.10

    \se monaog
    \va m∞na-
    \nt +
    \ps with an. subj. / AI, plurale tantum
    \twn |monát|, II
    \ge `(they are) many persons', +`to bring forth abundantly; to multiply'
    \so El.Gr.8; Ex.1.9; Dan.12.4; Mt.7.14
    \xv newutche monaog
    \xe for multitude
    \so Gen.16.10
    \ng perhaps 3p
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh matta kuppepenunkou, newutche kumm∞cheke monamw∞ onk neg howáe missinninnuog ...
    \xe ..., nor [did he] choose you, because ye were more in number than any people;...
    \so Deut.6.7
    \nt +
    \xv Nuttehhenit Legion, newutche numm∞namun
    \xe My name is Legion: for we are many.
    \so Mk.5.9
    \nt +

    suppos. pl. |monacheg|    Is.60.5; 2 Cor.4.15
    \xv ... uttiyeug m∞nacheg nippekontu,...
    \xe ..., which the waters brought forth abundantly,...
    \so Gen.1.21; E0: "which swarm in waters"
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +
    suppos. 3d pl. |Monahettit, nummatchenéhìkquog,...| `As they were increased, so they sinned against me,...'    Hos.4.7√  { 3p conjunct }

    \xv ..., M∞nahettich nippekontu pomantamwae pomomutcheg,...
    \xe ..., Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life,...
    \so Gen.1.20; E0: "sarm[.]ut let"
    \ng 3p imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Mishenetuonitteg, monagk, kah muttaan∞gk ohket,...
    \xe .., Be fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth,...
    \so Gen.1.28
    \ng 2p imperative

    \se monaonk
    \ps Vbl. n.
    \ge `abundance'
    \so Deut.33.19

[Narragansett [xnt] |Maunetash| `Great store', |Maunâuog, Wussaumemaunâuog.| `They are too full of people.'    R.W.60.√
    Algonquian [alg] |MANE| (ä long) `être nombreux', |Ni manemin, ki manem, manek| `{nous sommes, vous êtes, ils sont nombreux}', |Manet| `{elle est en grande quantité} (cette chose), il y a beaucoup de cela.'    Cq.204ab.
    \nt +
Fx. |ma∙ne| `much, many', |ma∙ne∙wa|, |ma∙ne∙twi| `he, it is numerous'    Fx.L.94.
K. |maane| `many, much, a lot', |maanea|, |maaneetwi| `be much, be many, be a lot'    V.58.
Menominee [mez] |ma∙nε∙w| AI, |ma∙nε∙t| II `he, it is numerous, in plenty; there is much of him, it; there are many of them'    B.975.115.
    Miami |malami| `too', |malamiwälinwiani| `I am too fat'; |maalami| adv. `too much'    D.-V.367; B&C.67a.
    \nt ?
Shawnee [sjw] |maale|, |mamaale-| `MANY, VARIOUS, PLENTIFUL', |maaleetwi| `it's plentiful', |nimaaleepe| `we are plentiful', |mamaalekaate(le)?Θi| `centipede'    D.-V.365.]

\et cf. G.1981, 32, p.69 *ma∙Θe∙twi II `there is a lot', without comparative evidence; also *ma∙Θe∙wa AI (so also ?**ma∙Θe∙wi II). H. has *ma∙le∙twi, H.1477-1479, but without Cree evidence; Ar. wóno:Θ- `there are many', Slz.136, looks close and may settle the matter.


\lx mônak

[Narr. máunetash, `"great store", abundance'.]

\et H.1479 *ma∙le∙twi II `numerous'. (Goddard cites *ma∙Θe∙twi in passing, G.1981, 32, 69, but unfortunately gives no supporting evidence. I have not managed to find any plausible cognate in Cree, and, to the extent that I can grasp the description, Goddard's history of Arapaho and Atsina implies *l, if the forms in |wón-| `many' (Slz.136) belong here.)

\lx moncheaheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 64
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative to |monchu|
\ge `to bring sb, to send sb away; to let sb go' (i.e. away, free)
\so frequent
    \xv ... onk woh kummoncheáhenup weeche wekontamóonk,...
    \xe ..., that I might have sent thee away with mirth,...
    \so Gen.31.27
    \ng 1->2 preterite
    \xv ..., kah pish moncheaheau nomposhimwe goats en touohkommukqut.
    \xe ...: and he shall let go the goat in the wilderness.'    Lev.16.22 { the (e)scape goat; 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., qut anakausuenúog wuttattagkomóuh, kah ummehche moncheahéouh.
    \xe ...: but the husbandmen beat him, and sent him away empty.'    Lk.20.10  { 3p->3
    \so objective }

    \xv Weeche moncheaheog nemattin hon nummonchemun,...
    \xe If thou wilt send our brother with us, we will go down ...
    \so Gen.43.4
    \ng 2->1p+3 conjunct, additional object via |weeche|
    \xv ...: kah mahche ne nag, noh pish kummoncheahukou na wutch moncheahukquéog, sohwhokonittue kussohwhohkónukou na wutch moáe.
    \xe ...; afterwards he will let you go hence: when he shall let you go, he shall surely thrust you out hence altogether.
    \so Ex.11.1
    \ng 3->2p indicative; 3->2p conjunct

    \xv ..., moncheahegq onk woh nuttom nussontimomut.
    \xe ...; send me away that I may go to my master.
    \so Gen.24.56
    \xv ... Moncheaheh k∞wehquetumoush kah qushkeaheh en neematut, en Egypt kah nukkehkinneam toh wuttin ash pomantamunneau, kah Jethro unnau Mosesoh, wunohteae monchish.
    \xe ..., Let me go, I pray thee, and return unto my brethren which are in Egypt, and see whether they be yet alive. And Jethro said to Moses, Go in peace.
    \so Ex.4.18

\et H.1466: *ma∙cihe∙wa TA `move'


\lx monchu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 64
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem (G&B.514-516)
\ge `he goes, se movet' (denoting merely the act of going, without reference to its end or aim); hence, `he departs, goes away, removes', +`to go one's way, pass on, away'
\so Mt.25.18; Gen.24.10
    \xv ..., kah moncheog.
    \xe ..., and went their way.
    \so Gen.14.11
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... pish kummonchemw∞ kuttâongan∞wóut,...
    \xe ... [ye shall] go on your ways.
    \so Gen.19.2
    \ng 2p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv nummonchem
    \xe I go
    \so Mt.21.30; Lk.15.18
    pret. |nummonchip| `I went'    Jer.13.5

    \nt MN: noh monchit
    \ng suppositive |noh monchit| `he who goes'    Jer.22.10

    imperat. |monchish| `go thy way'    Gen.12.18  { 2 imperative }√
    pl. |monchek| `go'

    freq. |mamonchu|, q.v.
Related to |amáeu|, `he departs' (?).

\nt Cf. Sansk. mañch (ire, se movere); manth, math (commovere, agitare); Lat. motus, mittere.

[Narragansett [xnt] |mauchéi| (pres.defin. = |mon-chu-i|) `he is gone'; |maúchish| `be going' (imperat.); |num-mauchèmin| `I go'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nemañtsi| `je vais'; |nemañ neda| `je vais là'    R.494/540a.√
Cree |áchee-oo| `he moves'.
Chip. |aunjéh|    Howse 194; |ma'ja| `he goes'    Sch.II,469.
Delaware [del] |matschiü| `he is gone'; suppos. |matschit|    Zeisb.]

\et H.1476 *ma∙cyi∙wa `move', to *ma∙t-


\lx móneau
\va monneau
\va monunneau
\va monneauau
\va moneauau
\va moninneauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 64
    \nt Remark: More than one stem, or one stem |môn-u-naw-| with syncopation, where |-naw-| is a non-initial meaning `see'. (See B.1962, 16.127, p.354, 19.29,31, p.420 on the finals TA |-naw|, TI |-n| `see'.)
    \nt +
\ps v.t. an.
\ge `he looks (intently) at, observes (him)'; +`to behold sb, cast one's eyes upon, look on, upon sb, for sb to be seen (of sb)'
    \xv Kah ahtomp pish appu matokqsut, onk pish nummonneau onk woh nummehquoantam machemohtag n∞n∞waonk,...
    \xe And the bow shall be in the cloud and I will look upon it, that I may remember the everlasting covenant ...
    \so Gen.9.16; (E0): |nummôn-/neau| "I look on it"
    \ng 1->3 objective
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wussontimomuh ummittamwussoh ummoninneáuoh Josephuh,...
    \xe ..., his master's wife cast her eyes upon Joseph;...'    Gen.39.7  { 3->
    \so objective (second mention?) }
    \nt +
    \xv Qut mukkée nano sepakem∞uk ut wadtuhquabit, mahche nag sephausuaen, wutche uppahkesuonk, neit pish moneauau nahohtôeu nashpe sephausuaenin.
    \xe But if the scab spread much abroad in the skin, after that he hath been seen of the priest for his cleansing, he shall be seen of the priest again:
    \so Lev.13.7; (E1): |móneauâu|
    \nt +
    \xv ummonunneauoh
    \xe he looked on them
    \so 2 K.2.24
    \xv Neit kodnetuhtaénuog monneauttuog, chanánittamwog howan neánit.
    \xe Then the disciples looked one on another, doubting of whom he spake.
    \so Jn.13.22
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nag kuhkuhk∞unóog en kesukqut nashpe mahtokqs, kah ummatwom∞uh moninneunkquog.
    \xe .... And they ascended up to heaven in a cloud; and their enemies beheld them.
    \so Rev.11.12
    \nt +

    \nt MN: moneauont
    \ng suppositive |moneauont| Mt.5.28
    \xv ...: moneaihettit nunnukkukquosháog.
    \xe ...: when they looked upon me, they shaked their heads.
    \so Ps.109.25; (M): |monuneihittit|
    \nt +

    imperat. (affix: 2sg.+1sg.) |monneah| `look thou on me'    Ps.119.132
    pl. |monneiek|, |monunneiek| `look ye'    Job 6.28


    \se móninneam
    \va mónunneaum
    \va moneneam
    \nt +
    \va m∞neam
    \va moneaum
    \va moneam
    \nt Remark: Some of the additional examples are taken to be syncopated forms.
    \nt +
    \ps With inan. obj. / TI1a
    \ge `he looks at (it)'; +`to behold sth; to look (up)on sth'
    \so Ps.104.32; Ezek.21.21; Ex.14.24
    \xv ..., kah wunnegen nohen moneaumunneat,...
    \xe ..., and that it was pleasant to the eyes,...
    \so Gen.3.6
    \ng X->0 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Neit Lot spadtawompu, kah moneam wame mukoshqut Jordan,...
    \xe And Lot lifted up his eyes, and beheld all the plain of Jordan,...
    \so Gen.13.10; (E0): "looked on"
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah unnohquaeu nogqueu Sodom kah Gomorra, kah nogqueu wame ne ohket mukoshquttaut kah ummoneneamun,...
    \xe And he looked toward Sodom and Gomorrah, and toward all the land of the plain, and beheld,...
    \so Gen.19.28
    \ng 3->0 subordinative
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh moninneog
    \ng suppositive |noh moninneog| `he who looks' etc.    Num.21.8

    \xv Naish woi Manit nutogqunneganun: kah monunneash wuskesuk sasequnukquean.
    \xe Behold, O God, our shield, and look upon the face of thine anointed.
    \so Ps.84.9; (M): |moninneash|
    \nt +
\cf kuhkinneam

    \xv ..., wuttinn∞waonk Jehovah peyaónuk Abram ut monomansinneat,...

    \so Gen.15.1
    \ng X t-subordinative
    \xv Neit kukkinn∞nomp wunneetupanatamweyeuit, ut monamansinneat,...
    \xe Then thou spakest in vision to thy holy one,...
    \so Ps.89.19; (M) |ut unnammanissuonkanit|
    \xv ...: onk wuttinuh, Manit ut monamansinneat, Ananias,...
    \xe ...; and to him said the Lord in a vision, Ananias. ...
    \so Acts 9.10
    \xv Kah yeu nutussinnauoneau horsesog, ut monomansinneat, kah neg noh quenapitcheg,...

    \so Rev.9.17

\lx monteag

\cf matta


\lx monteagunninno
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 65
    \nt +
\nt Remark: cf. |matteagunninno|, T+.52b; |teagunninno|, T+.160b.
\dv initial identical to |mô| negative particle + |teag| NI "thing" + |-un-| II final + negative |-in-|
\ps II, (negative) predicative/existential
\ge `to be void, to pass away', i.e. "to be(come) nothing"
\so Gen.1.2; Ps.33.10; Mk.13.31 (cf. Lk.21.33)
    \xv ...: wuttinanatam∞onganoash missinninnuog wutayimunash monteagwunninn∞ut.
    \xe ...: he maketh the devices of the people of none effect.
    \so Ps.33.10
    \ng 0p (negative) t-subordinative
    |Kesuk kah ohke pish monteagunninno, qut nukkutt∞ongash matta pish monteagunninn∞ash.| `Heaven and earth shall pass away: but my words shall not pass away.    Mk.13.31  { 0 (negative) indicative; 0p (negative) indicative }

    \se monteagqunnehteau
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to make sth of none effect'
    \so Num.30.8,12
    \xv ..., neit pish monteagqunnehteaou ukquoshauaonk ...
    \xe ..., then he shall make her vow...of none effect;...
    \so Num.30.8
    \ng 3->0 absolute


\lx montogkukquam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 65
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\dv |mon(t)-| `together' + |-ak-| `on' + |-(u)kwô-m-| `to sew'+TI
\so Gen.3.7

    \se montogkukquamauau
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to sew sth together for sb'
    \so Gen.3.7
    \xv ...: kah montogkukquomoog figse wunnepogquosh,...
    \xe ...; and they sewed fig leaves together,...'    Gen.2.7  { 3p->3
    \so +0p absolute; (E0&1) have |wuhhogkáuh| "for themeselves", om. in (E2). }

[?Parallel uses of the initial:
Cree |mâwasakokwâtam| TI `S/he sews them all altogether, i.e. patches for a quilt'    Alb.E.79b.
WAbn. |môwna| TI `bring sth together in a bunch'    D.1.336.]

\lx mos
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 65
\ge "a word signifying futurity", corresponding to the auxiliary `must' or `shall' before a verb in the indicative

    \xv mos nunnnup
    \xe I must die
    \so Deut.4.22
    \xv m∞che mos nutahquontamau
    \xe how often shall I forgive him?
    \so Mt.18.21
    \xv ne mos nnih
    \xe it must needs be so
    \so Mk.13.7

\lx moskeht
\va maskeht
\va moskeht
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 65
\ps n. / NI
\ge `grass', +`herb'
    \nt G&B.642.
    \nt +
\so El.Gr.10; Gen.1.11; Is.40.7,8
    pl. |-ehtuash|    Dan.4.25,32,33
    `pasture'    1 Chr.4.39,40

    \xv moskehtuash
    \xe hay

    \se -oskeht(u
    \ps NI, derived final
    |woskoshkehtuash| (= |wuske-oskehtuash|) `tender grass'    Prov.27.25

    \se mishashkehtuai
    \ps II (?), denominal
    \xv mishashkehtuai ne ohke
    \xe there was much grass in that place
    \so Jn.6.10

    (|Oskosk, mosketu@ash.| `Grass, hay'; +|nummosketiimash.| `my grass'    C.10/160; 33/178.)

    \se moskehtu∞
    \ps Vbl.subst. / AI,II denominal predicative
    \ge `he is grass'
    \so Is.40.6
    \xv ..., newutche matta moskehtuun∞ wutche neetasuog ...
    \xe ...; for thy servants have no pasture for their flocks;...
    \so Gen.47.4
    \ng 0 negative indicative, existential
    \nt +

    \se moskehtuemes
    \ps Dim.
    \so El.Gr.12
\dv |askehteau| `it is (lit, it makes, caus. inan.) green', with the indeterm. prefix, `that which is green'.
\cf aske

\lx mosogquehtauau

    \xv Qut kenaau kummosogquehtauômw∞ Jehovah kum-Manitt∞mw∞, kenáau kuppomantamumw∞,...
    \xe But ye that did cleave unto the Lord your God are alive ...
    \so Deut.4.4
    \xv ...: kah Orphah chipwutt∞napwau wasenumoncheh, qut Ruth umm∞sogquehtauoh.
    \xe ...: and Orpah kissed her mother in law; but Ruth clave unto her.
    \so Ruth 1.14

    \xv ... nush∞k nish noh kittinneum∞óog neg mósogquehtauoncheg Baal Peoroh,
    \xe ..., Slay ye every one his men that were joined unto Baalpeor.
    \so Num.25.5

    \xv Qush Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m nagum noswetau, mosogquehtau, kah chadchekeyeuash nashpe ∞wesuonk.
    \xe Thou shalt fear the Lord thy God; him shalt thou serve, and to him shalt thou cleave, and swear by his name.
    \so Deut.10.20
    \xv ..., kah wuttinneumuk∞k kah mósogquehtok.
    \xe ..., and ye shall serve him, and cleave unto him.
    \so Deut.13.4

\lx móunum

\ge `he gathers together (inan. obj.)'
    \xv ..., k∞wahunup kussiogkus, kukkepenum uttoh adt matta ahketeauup, kah kummounum ne matta seaonteaop.
    \xe ..., I knew thee that thou art an hard man, reaping where thou hast not sown, and gathering where thou hast not strawed:

    \xe And Joseph gathered corn as the sand of the sea,...

    \nt +

    \xe And let them gather all the food of those good years that come,...
    \so Gen.41.35
    \ng 3p->0 imperative
    \nt +

    \se móunumóonk
    \va mouunnum∞onk

    \so 1 K.9.21; Mt.17.25

    With an. obj. |mianaü|, q.v.

\lx m∞che
\va móhche
\va m∞hche
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 66
    \ps ?PreV; note that there is no example in the current corpus of a subject prefix prefixed to this form, suggesting a position more like that of e.g. |matta| `not'.
    \nt +
\ge as an auxiliary of the future tense, expresses obligation or necessity (=|mos| |∞tche|); +commonly co-occurring with |mos| and usually preceding it; typical AV locutions: `be bound to, behoove to, must (needs), necessary, ought to'
    \ge `altogether' (i.e. "completely, fully") (cf. |m∞cheke|)
    \nt +
    \so Num.30.14; 1 Pet.1.7
    \nt +
    \xv Qut nish m∞hche kummeechinash anaquabit Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m,...
    \xe But thou must eat them before the Lord thy God ...
    \so Deut.12.18
    \nt +
    \xv M∞che ken pannupwusham Ar,...
    \xe Thou art to pass over through Ar,...
    \so , etc.    Deut.2.18
    \ng absence of subject prefix an error? also E1.
    (cf. |n∞che mos| `it must needs be'    Mt.18.7 { |n-| also E1. })
    \xv ..., tohhen nagwutteaeu neemat matchenehukqueh, m∞che mos nutahquontamau? ...
    \xe ..., how oft shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? ...
    \so Mt.18.21
    \xv ..., Yeu wussukwhosu, kah yeu m∞hche mos Christ wutchequnnehtamun,...
    \xe ..., Thus it is written, and thus it behooved Christ to suffer,...
    \so Lk.24.46
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche m∞hche nuttinnántam,...
    \xe For I am persuaded that ...
    \so Rom.8.38
    \nt +
    \xv Newajeh móhche ogwehtamóg,...
    \xe Wherefore ye must needs be subject,...
    \so Rom.13.5
    \nt +
    \xv M∞hche nagwutteae nuttabuttantamauómun GOD wutche kenaau ...
    \xe We are bound to thank God always for you, ...
    \so 2 Thess.1.3√
    \xv Newutche m∞hche mos onk nagwutteomukish nish wadcheeiyeuugish kesukqut, woh pahketeauunash nashpe yeush,...
    \xe It was therefore necessary that the pattern of things in the heavens should be purified with these;...
    \so Heb.9.23
    \nt +

    \xv Qut wessukeh m∞hche matta ken∞nuk∞gk asekesukokish:...
    \xe But if her husband altogether hold his peace at her from day to day;...
    \so Num.30.14
    \nt +
    \xv Onk ukqutchehteónk k∞namptam∞onk, ne m∞hche ánue wunnegik onk ne mahtshae golde qutchehteóonk,...
    \xe That the trial of your faith, being much more precious than of gold that perisheth,...
    \so 1 Pet.1.7; E1: |m∞che|
    \nt +
\cf mos
\cf ∞che

[Quiripi [qyp] |môuche| `there must be'    Pier.
    LpA. |m8chi| `tout a fait'    D.16, etc.]
    \nt +


\lx m∞cheke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 66
    \ps Adv, often as PreV; correlate |onk| introducing ground of comparison
    \nt +
\ge "a word signifying more, much," used to express degrees of comparison
\so El.Gr.15
    "|M∞cheke| {Much.}"    El.Gr.15/261
    \nt +
    \xv anue m∞cheke
    \xe much more
    \so Rom.5.9
    `more exceedingly' Gal.1.14
    \xv nano m∞cheke
    \xe more and more
    \so Mk.15.14
    \xv m∞cheke m∞cheke
    \xe exceedingly, very much
    \so Gen.17.2,6,20
    \xv m∞cheke onk
    \xe more than
    \so Mt.10.37
    (|m∞chekeyeuuk| `excessively'    C.)


\lx m∞chekeheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 66
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative final
\ge `to multiply sb'
\so Gen.22.17; Deut.30.5
    \xv ..., kah pish kutanue m∞chekehik onk nag k∞shik.
    \xe ..., and multiply thee above thy fathers.
    \so Deut.30.5
    \ng 3->2 indicative

    \xv ..., Kah m∞chekehuwaon numm∞chekeh k∞skannemeneog,...
    \xe ..., and in multiplying I will multiply thy seed...
    \so Gen.22.17
    \ng 1 subjunctive to indefinite object derivative; 1->3(p) absolute

\lx m∞m∞squeuttam

\ge `he murmurs, mutters, grumbles'
\nt Perhaps not rightly used in Jn.6.61
    cf. |ummomoskkéetauóuh| `he gnasheth upon him with his teeth'    Ps.37.12, and
    \xv nummaumusketunkquog
    \xe they gnash upon me
    \so etc.    Ps.35.16

\lx m∞s
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 67
\ps n. / NA
\nt The name of the moose (Cervus alces, L.) is used by Eliot in the pl.; |m∞sôog| for `fallow deer', 1 K.4.23;
    "moos, a beast bigger than a stag," etc., Smith's
Descr. of N.E. (1616).
    "Which the salvages call a mose", Morton's N.E. Canaan.
    "The beast called a moose", Wood's N.E. Prospect.
    The plural indicates |m∞s∞|, or |m∞su|, as the original form of the singular, a name given to the animal from his habit of stripping the lower branches and bark from trees when feeding; |m∞s-u| `he trims' or `cuts smooth', `he shaves.'
    \cf m∞sum

[Narragansett [xnt] |moòs|; pl. |-sóog|.
Western Abenaki [abe]|m8s|; pl. |-sak|.
Chip. |mons|    (Bar.); |möz|, |mooze|    (Sch.II,464).
Cree |mongsöa|.
Menominee [mez] |monsh|.]

\lx msíckquatash

\so Trumbull 68
\ps n.pl. / NI

\lx mukkinnum
\va magk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 69
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he collects or gathers' (inan. objects) { "collect" not AV }
    \xv Onk mukkinnum wame meechum nesausuk tahshit kodtumwae,...
    \xe And he gathered up all the food of the seven years,...
    \so Gen.41.48
    \nt +
    infinit. |-umunat herbsash| `to gather herbs'    2 K.4.39

    \nt MN: Kah noh magunuk uppukquem heifer...
    \ng suppositive |Kah noh magunuk uppukquem heifer...| `And he that gathereth the ashes of the heifer...'    Num.19.10√
    \ps 3
    \xv ..., kah wame neadtáhshekhettit nish magkunnumohettiche,...
    \xe ..., and all their substance that they had gathered,...
    \so Gen.12.4
    \ng 3p->_0_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv ...k∞wehquetumoush mukkuppasquadti, kah mukkinnumutti asuhkáue kepenumwenuog,...
    \xe ..., I pray you, let me glean and gather after the reapers...
    \so Ruth 2.7
    \ng 1 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv mukkinum∞k
    \xe gather ye
    \so (the tares)    Mt.13.30
    \xv mukkinitch
    \xe let him gather
    \so (the manna)    Ex.16.16

    \se !|mukkinau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \ge `to gather sb' (as in "to one's fathers"); `to take sb' (by force?)
    \so Gen.25.8,34.28,49.29; Deut.30.4
    \xv Mukkináog wutshepsum∞uh, kah wutoxinum∞uh,...
    \xe They took their sheep, and their oxen,...
    \so Gen.34.28-29
    \xv ... kah mukinau en ummissinninnúmehtu.
    \xe ...; and [he] was gathered to his fathers.
    \so Gen.25.8
    \ng X->3
    \xv ..., na pish k∞ch mukkinnukqun Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m, kah ne pish k∞tinukqun.
    \xe ..., from thence will the Lord thy God gather thee, and from thence will he fetch thee:
    \so Deut.30.4
    \ng 3->2

    \se |mukkinneu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, middle reflexive, long-vowel stem
    \ge `to gather os (pl.); to be gathered (unto sb)' (as euphemistic synonym for "to die"; `to get os(?)'
    \nt Remark: On the formation, to the TA/TI final |-un-| `by hand', see B.1962, 15.121, 297, 16.56, 340.
    \so Gen.34.30,35.29,49.33; Lev.26.25; Num.11.30,31.2
    \xv ..., pish nag mukineog ayeuuhkóne nen kah pish nushukquog,...
    \xe ..., they shall gather themselves together against me, and slay me;...
    \so Gen.34.30
    \ng (E0&E1) |mukkinnéog|
    \xv Onk Isaak nashomont ukkteahogkounuh, kah nupp∞,: kah mukkinneu ummissinninnúmut,...
    \xe And Isaac gave up the ghost, and died, and was gathered unto his people,...
    \so Gen.35.29
    \xv ..., ne mahche nnag neit pish kummukkinnem en kummissinninnutu,
    \xe ...: afterward shalt thou be gathered unto thy people.
    \so Num.31.2

\cf móunum

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nemeghenassi| `Je trie', |nemegheneman, nob. nemeghenañ.| `Je le trie'    R.488/538a.
    Delaware [del] |makúneew| TA `pick s.o. up (using the hands); pick s.t. animate (off trees)    O'M.154b-155a.
    \nt +
M.-P. |mokonal| TA `he picks him out'; |m@k@nal| TA `er wählt ihn aus', |m@k@n@m@n| TI `er wählt es aus'    LeS.46a; Sz.122.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Me@gu@nu@m| `To pick'; |meknk| TA `gather; collect; pick up; choose', |mekn'm| TI `gather; collect; pick up; choose'; |megnêmn| `you select something out of many'    R.195b; DeB.43b; MCS.248a.]

\lx mukk∞kin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 69
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he bares himself, unclothes'

    imperat. 2d pl. |mukk∞kek|, |-eg| `be bare, "strip yourselves"'    Is.32.11

    \se mukk∞kinau
    \ps with an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he strips, makes (him) bare'; +`to oppress sb, spoil sb'
    \xv Wame neg paumshacheg mayit ummukk∞kinnóuh:...
    \xe All that pass by the way spoil him:...
    \so Ps.89.41; (M): |ummukkookunouh|
    \nt +
    \xv Mattá woh howan petutteáu menuhkoshketomp weekit, kah ummukk∞kinuh, qut negonne wehweepáppinont menuhkoshketompuh, kah neit woh matchteauoh week.
    \xe No man can enter into a strong man's house, and spoil his goods, except he will first bind the strong man; and then he will spoil his house.
    \so Mk.3.27
    \nt +
    \xv Onk kutjishonumómw∞ matcheku, sunnummatta weenaueetuenuog kummukk∞kinuk∞óog, kah kuss∞wun∞wóog anaquohtag wussittumoe appuongash?
    \xe But ye have despised the poor. Do not rich men oppress you, and draw you before the judgment seats?
    \so Jas.2.6
    \nt +

    \nt MN: magg∞kinont
    \ng suppositive |magg∞kinont|
    pl. |-oncheg| `spoilers'    Jer.51.48

    \xv ..., unnau wutayeuteomuh, na ong, mukk∞kinnuagk, pas∞k wohkónn∞sinit.
    \xe ..., commanded the soldiers to go down, and to take him by force from among them, and to bring him into the castle.
    \so Acts 23.10
    \ng N.B. Typical use of o.r. for o.o. of the English. Same stem?
    \nt +
    imperat. prohib. |ahque mukk∞kin matcheku| `do not [strip] rob the poor'    Prov.22.22

    \se mukk∞kinnuwaen
    \ps N.agent.
    \ge `a plunderer, a robber'
    pl. -énuog| `extortioners'    Is.16.4

    (suppos. |mukkookinnuwaenuit| `if he rob', i.e. `if he be a robber'    Ind. Laws, xvi).

    \se |mukk∞kinum|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1b
    \ge `to spoil sth' i.e. "to despoil sth"
    \so Gen.34.27,29
    \xv Wunnaumonuh Jakob quenittamwog ne nohtômuk, kah mukk∞kinnumwog otan, newutche nag matcheheaog ummissesuoh.
    \xe The sons of Jacob came upon the slain, and spoiled the city, because they had defiled their sister.
    \so Gen.34.27
    \xv Nummukk∞kinnum∞wontam onkatogish moeuwekomongash, nemunnumon onkquatunkash nag wutche, kutannummaununnaóont.
    \xe I robbed other churches, taking wages of them, to do you service.
    \so 2 Cor.11.8
    \ng Two inanimate objects, one tacit, denoting the spoil, as in "to despoil sth of sth"? See entry |-wontam|.

    \se !|mukk∞kinuk∞onk|, |-ong(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, to theme 2
    \ge "being robbed"
    \so Ntv.Wr.151.1-3; G&B.584,651
    \xv yeunuh [[wutche]] wussukquohwonog wutche nummukk∞kinuk∞onganun Englishmananog yeu ahquombi 1747
    \xe This [[is about]] writing is about our being robbed by the English at this time, 1747.
    \so Ntv.Wr.151.1-3

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nemeg8gnañ| `je le pille'.    R.397/507a.√]


\lx !mukk∞nau|
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 69
    \nt +
\ps TA
\twn |mukk∞nam|
\ge `to leave, let sb alone, to bear, endure, suffer sb'
\so Mt.15.14, 17.17, 23.23; Mk.1.24; Lk.9.41; Rev.2.2, 2.20
    \xv ..., Woi mat wunnamptamoe kah mamuttanumwe pometeonk, toh utt∞che woh k∞wetomunnumw∞, toh utt∞che woh kummukk∞nanumw∞, noh paudtiegk.
    \xe ..., O faithless and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you? how long shall I suffer you? bring him hither to me.
    \so Mt.17.17
    \xv N∞wahteoh kutanakausuongash, kah kummenuhkesuonk, kah kummanunnissuonk, kah matta nag kummukk∞naôog matchetukeg,...
    \xe I know thy works, and thy labour, and thy patience, and how thou canst not bear them which are evil:...
    \so Rev.2.2

    \xv Yeuunne mukk∞nôukut, wame wosketompaog woh ∞namptauóuh,...
    \xe If we let him thus alone, all men will believe on him;...
    \so Jn.11.48; Mayhew: |mukk∞nauogut|

    \xv Nag mukk∞nok, nag pogkenukig sagkompanaog pogkenumwoh:...
    \xe Let them alone: they be blind leaders of the blind. ...
    \so Mt.15.14

    \se mukk∞nam
    \ps TI1a
    \twn |mukk∞nau|
    \ge `to take wrong, to suffer sth'
    \xv Newutche yeuyeu wunnamuhkut matúhsuáonk ken[u]gke kenaau, newutche kuppetukonittumw∞, tohwutch ane mo mukk∞namoóg, tohwutch ane mó mukk∞namoóg kutass∞kekoninitteaneau?
    \xe Now therefore there is utterly a fault among you, because ye go to law one with another. Why do ye not rather take wrong? why do ye not rather suffer yourselves to be defrauded?
    \so 1 Cor.6.7

\lx mukquoshim
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    |mummugquoshum|    Gen.49.27  { reduplicated, presumably intensive }
\nt For |mukquoshim| the Mass.Ps. (John 10.12) has |natt∞hqus|.
\dv |m∞hwhau| `he eats live flesh', with (|-oshim|) the generic determinative of the names of beasts.

[Narragansett [xnt] |muckquashím|, pl. |-mwock|; |moattôqus| `a black wolf'; |natóqus| `a wolf'; |natóquashunck| `a wolf-skin coat'.
Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |mucks|    Stiles.
Chip. |mah ing gun|, |më ën' gun|, |maw e kan| (|maheengun|    J.)    Sch.II,464.
Menominee [mez] |manh-wawe|.
Shawnee [sjw] |m'wài wah|.
Mex. |mayaquen| [qu = k].
Otomi |muhu|.]

\et The final is clearly to PA *-a?Θemwa `dog' (cf. G.1981, 28, 67), and Goddard suggests an initial related to Narr. |muckquétu| `swift', but without citing any other evidence for this stem. This would account directly for the reduplication.

\lx munnawhatteaûg
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 70
\ps NA
\ge `"a fish somewhat like a herring,"
\so R.W.
\nt Probably Alosa menhaden, Mitch., the `bony fish', `hard head', or `munhaden' of the fishermen; called also in the northern parts of New England, |pauhagen|. Both names have reference to the use of this and other species of herring as fertilizers; |munnóhquohteau| `he manures or enriches the earth', and Abn. "|pakkikañn| `on engraisse la terre'," whence "|p8kañgané| `petit poisson'."

\lx munnóh
\va munnoh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 70
\ps n. / NI
\ge `an island', +`isle'
\nt G&B.652
\so Acts 28.1; Rev.6.14
    \xv Nashpe nag chadchaubenaog ummunhanôm∞wóash Gentiles ut wutohtuwóut,...
    \xe By these were the isles of the gentiles divided in their lands;...
    \so Gen.10.5
    \ng 3p possessor 0p
    \nt +
    with the locative affix, |munnóhhannit| (|menoh-|, |munnáh-|) `to, at, or on the island'    Acts 13.6; 27.26; 28.7,9,11
    pl. |-óhhanash|    Ps.97.1; Is.41.5

    \se munnóhhanne
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `of an island'

\lx muskouantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 71
\ps v.i. / TI1a (TI-O), mental final
\ge `he is boastful'
\so Ps.34.2
\ge `he rejoices, exults, is very glad'
\so Ps.14.7
    \xv Kah nameheont, upponuh wuttugkit, muskauantam.
    \xe And when he hath found it, he layeth it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
    \so Lk.15.5 (for |wekontam| of (E1))
    \nt +

    imperat. |-antash| `rejoice thou'    Joel 2.21
    3d pers. |-antaj| `let him rejoice'    Ps.48.11

    \se !|muskouantam∞onk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, nom.act.
    \ge `joy'
    \xv ..., onk ayimouôog weematt∞uh missi mskoúanatamm∞onk.
    \xe ...: and they caused great joy unto all the brethren.
    \so Acts 15.3
\cf muskôau

    \se !|muskouanatamheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to make sb glad'
    \so Ps.45.8

    \xv ..., uttoh waj muskouanatamhinumuk.
    \xe ..., whereby they have made thee glad.
    \so Ps.45.8
    \ng X->2+_adv_ preterite conjunct

    \se !|muskouantam∞woNau|, |-anatam-|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative
    \ge `to rejoice in, over sb'
    \so Ps.9.2,Ps.30.1(M),Ps.33.21,66.6,...,149.2
    \xv N∞weekontam kah kummuskouanatam∞wonsh nuttinn∞homom...
    \xe I will be glad and rejoyce in thee:...
    \so Ps.9.2; (M) |kummuskouanatamoowonsh|
    \ng 1->2 indicative
    \xv ..., kah matta kuttiyeuomp nummatwomog nummushkauantammooonukqunnaout.
    \xe ..., and hast not made my foes to rejoyce over me.
    \so Ps.30.1(M)
    \ng 3p->1 t-subordinative
    \xv Newutche nuttahhun weekontam∞onoh,...
    \xe For our heart shall rejoyce in him:...'    Ps.33.21  { ?3->3
    \so objective }

    \xv Ahque nummatwomog muskauanatam∞woushettich pann∞waeu,...
    \xe Let not them that are mine enemies wrongfully, rejoyce over me:...
    \so Ps.35.19; (M) |muskauantammoooshettitch|
    \ng 3p->1 imperative; Ps.35.24
    \xv Weekontam∞unok Jehovah...
    \xe Rejoyce in the Lord,...
    \so Ps.97.12; (M)|Wekontamooonoohk|
    \ng 2p->3 imperative

    \se !|muskouantam∞wontam|, |-anatam-|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative
    \ge `to rejoice at, in sth'
    \so Ps.13.5,35.26
    \xv ..., nuttah pish muskouanatam∞wontam k∞wadchan∞waonk.
    \xe ..., my heart shall rejoyce in thy salvation.
    \so Ps.13.5; (M) |muskouantamoowontam|
    \ng 0->0 absolute

    \xv ...mashkouwantamoowontogig noowoskhetteaonk:...
    \xe ...them..., that rejoyce at mine hurt:...
    \so Ps.35.26(M)
    \ng _3p_->0 participle

\lx musquéheonk
\va msq-
\va -ongan
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 71
\ps vbl. n.
\ge `blood'
\nt G&B.685, s.v. |∞squeheonk| `his blood'; with remark to T.71, 206: "w. the incorrect implication that the forms in wus- can mean `his blood'".
\so Deut.12.16,23; Acts 17.26; 28.8
\dv [from causat. |musquéhhéau| `it makes him red, it reddens']
    \xv n∞sqh-
    \xe my blood
    \xv k∞sqh-
    \xe thy blood
    |wusq-| or |∞sq-| `his blood' { |wusq-|, e.g. Acts 20.28, 1 Jn.5.6, Rev.20.28; |wsq-|, e.g. Lk.22.44, Acts 22.20, Eph.6.12, Rev.16.6 }

    \se musqueheongane
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `bloody'
\cf neepuck

[Narragansett [xnt] |Mishquè, néepuck.| `The blood.'; |Msqui, neépuck.| `Blood'; |Mishquínash.| `The vaines.'; |Misquineash.| `The vaines.'    R.W.51;190/r.198;51;190/r.198.
Chip. |mis'kwë| `blood'; |us kwai aub| `(his) vein'.
Shawnee [sjw] |misk wèe| `blood'; |m'shks mah| `vein'; +|m?⌠kw-| `RED, BLOOD', |m?⌠kwi| `blood', |nim?⌠komi| `my blod'    D.-V.363-364.
Menominee [mez] |mainh kee| `blood'; +|mεhki∙h| `blood'    M.L.117.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nemesig8^aghesi| `Je suis tout couvert de sang', |mesigh8^aghes8| 3.    R.457/526b.
Delaware [del] |mhuk| `blood'    Zeisb.Gr.104.
    Algonquian [alg] |MISKWI| `sang'    Cq.231b-232a.
    \nt +
Cree |mi`'ko| NI `The blood'    Frs.324a.
Mun. |móhkw| NI `blood'    G.1982, (117), 29.]

\et S.1975, no. 28, 317 *meçkwi `blood', H.1723. The Massachusett forms seem to have been reanalyzed in part as containing the indefinite possessor prefix, cf. |wusqueheonk|.

\lx mussinum
\va mis-
\va mussunnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 72
\ps v.t. / TI1b, manual final
\ge `he touches (it)' [`he smooth-handles it'; from |m∞si|, with the formative of verbs denoting action performed by the hand]
    \xv ..., asuh woh mat kummissunnum∞unneau ishkont kenupm∞.
    \xe ..., neither shall ye touch it, lest ye die.
    \so Gen.3.3
    \ng 2p->0 negative objective
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh masunuk
    \ng suppositive |noh masunuk| he who touches it'    Lev.15.7,12; Amos 9.5

    freq. |mohmussunnum| `he touches (it) often, he handles (it)'

    \se mussunnum∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `touching, touch'
    (|missinum∞onk|    C.)

    \se mussunau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he touches (him)'
    \so Gen.20.6
    \xv ..., neyane mat kummussúnunnómunnónup,...
    \xe ..., as we have not touched thee,...
    \so Gen.26.29
    \ng 1p->2(p) negative
    \nt +
    \xv ...: sunnummatta numméchumuhkonoh wuskenuog matta kummussunukk∞unaóont? ...
    \xe ...: have I not charged the young men that they shall not touch thee? ...
    \so Ruth 2.9
    \ng 3p->2
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jesus summagunum wunnutcheg kah ummussinoh...
    \xe And Jesus put forth his hand, and touched him,...
    \so Mt.8.3
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh masunont
    \ng suppositive |noh masunont| `he who touches him'    Lev.15.11,19

    \se mississin
    \dv |mus-| + |-u-hsin| AI `to lie' ("to lie in contact with")
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: entry split, for gender twins
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O)
    \ge `to reach (to sth)'
    \xv missussin sussipponkomuk
    \xe it reached to the wall of the house
    \so 2 Chr.3.11,12
    \ng of wings, probably animate

    \se |missishin|, |mussehshin|
    \nt +
    \dv |mus-| + |-u-hshin| II `to lie'
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to reach (unto sth), rest (upon sth), to run aground'
    \so Gen.8.4; Acts 27.41
    \xv Kah Ark mussehshin nesausuk audtahsuit nepauz,...
    \xe And the Ark rested in the seventh month,...
    \so Gen.8.4
    \ng 0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ne sohkukquok missishin kesukqut,...
    \xe ..., and the height thereof reached unto heaven,...
    \so Dan.4.11
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv ..., neit missishin kuht∞nog,...
    \xe ..., they ran the ship aground;...
    \so Acts 27.41

    [Delaware [del] |Mischenummen| `to receive, to get.', |Mischenahan| `to touch somebody, to handle some one.'; |mshíixiin| AI, |mshíixun| II `touch, make contact, be in contact with the ground, be in contact with the floor', |mshúneew| TA, |mshúnum| TI1b `to receive sb, sth'    B&A.85; O'M.179b.
    \nt +

\lx muttaan
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 73
    \nt +
\nt Remark: See also |muttáan∞og| below; but the verb is apparently not a plurale tantum.
\ps AI, consonant-final stem
\ge `to multiply'
    \xv ..., na matta woh wóogketam∞mog newutche muttaanwog.
    \xe ..., which cannot be numbered for multitude.
    \so Gen.32.12
    \xv ...onk kuppomantam, kah woh kummuttaan,...
    \xe ..., that thou mayest live and multiply:...
    \so Deut.30.16

    \xv ... kah kuttinnummoush madtauánukeg missinninnuog,...
    \xe ..., and I will make of thee a multitude of people;...
    \so Gen.48.4
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \xv Kah mattaanukeg wonk moyeu peyaog ...
    \xe And the multitude cometh together again,...
    \so Mk.3.20
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \xv ..., matta weechayeumunk muttaanutcheh.
    \xe ... in the absence of the multitude.'    Lk.22.6  { _3
    \so _ participle }

    \xv ..., Mshéneetuónittegk, kah muttaan∞k,..., kah puppinshasog muttaanhettich ohket.
    \xe ..., Be fruitful, and multiply,..., and let fowl multiply in the earth.
    \so Gen.1.22; Gen.1.28 |muttaan∞gk|
    \ng 2p imperative
    \xv ..., mishammechumish, kah muttáansh wutohtimôin, kah m∞naash wutohtimóneash pish wutchiyeum∞ash kuhhogkat,...
    \xe ...: be fruitful and multiply; a nation and a company of nations shall be of thee,...
    \so Gen.35.11
    \ng 2 imperative
    \xv Reuben pomantaj, kah ahque nupitch kah ummissinninneumoh muttaanitch.
    \xe Let Reuben live, and not die; and let {not} his men be few.'    Deut.33.6  { 3(
    \so ) imperative }

\nt Remark: In the following, at least the palatalization and the vowel length would require explanation.
[Algonquian [alg] |MITC-| `grand, gros'    Cq.233b.
Cree |Mè'chä't| `Many, a good quantity, a large number'    Frs.316a.
EOj. |mecca∙, mecca∙mekat| `it is large'    B.1958.246b.
Menominee [mez] |mε∙c| PreN `big, large' sg. only    M.L.119.
Miami |mehch(aa)-| initial `big, large'    B&C.74a.]


\lx muttaanheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 73
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative final, to |muttaan| AI
\ge `to make sb to multiply, to multiply sb' i.e. "cause there to be many"
\so Gen.16.10,17.2,6,20; Lev.26.9; Deut.1.10,7.13,13.17,17.16,17 (TA+O),28.63; Ps.107.38; 1 Thess.3.12; Heb.6.14
    \xv ... kah nummuttaáneh m∞cheke m∞cheke,...
    \xe ..., and [I] will multiply him exceedingly:...
    \so Gen.17.20
    \ng 1->3 objective
    \xv Kah k∞skanemuneog nummattaanhéaog onatuh anogqsog kesukqut,...
    \xe And I will make thy seed to multiply as the stars of heaven,...
    \so Gen.26.4; (E0, E1): |-mutta-|
    \ng 1->3p objective
    \xv ..., onk woh muttaanheau horsesoh,...
    \xe ..., to the end that he should multiply horses:...'    Deut.17.16  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., wunnamuhkut wunánumunon k∞nanumush, kah muttaonhennon kummuttaánhesh.
    \xe ..., Surely blessing I will bless thee, and multiplying I will multiply thee.
    \so Heb.6.14
    \ng cognate conjunct, 1->2

    \xv ... Muttaanhennon nummuttaaneh k∞skannemunog m∞cheke,...
    \xe ..., I will multiply thy seede exceedingly,...
    \so Gen.16.10
    \ng 1->2 subjunctive; 1->3(p) absolute

    \xv Asuh muttaanheunkutch mittamwussinneuh,...
    \xe Neither shall he multiply wives to himself,...
    \so Deut.17.17
    \ng imperative; TA+O with dative final?
    \xv Kah LORD nano mishéhhik∞k kah muttaanhik∞k en womonittinneat,...
    \xe And the Lord make you to increase and abound in love one toward another,...
    \so 1 Thess.3.12
    \ng 3->2p imperative

\lx muttánnunk
\va muttannong
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 73
    \nt Remark: Some of the forms clearly include finals of various probably classificatory kinds.
    \nt +
\ps n. coll.; an. or inan. / NA, NI, depending on the final
\dv |muttáeu|
\ge `a very great number, a multitude, a thousand'
    \xv Nequt muttannunk, nequt muttannunk wutch wame wutchippan∞ongan∞wóut Israel, pish kummoncheahéoog en ayeuwuttinneat.
    \xe Of every tribe a thousand, throughout all the tribes of Israel, shall ye send to the war.
    \so Num.31.4√
    \xv Kah sequetaham∞ongash,..., mo nequtta tahshe pasuk∞e muttannunkanogkussuog & nesausuk tahshinchage muttannunganog kussuog, kah napanna tahshe muttannunganog kussuog sheepsog.
    \xe And the booty,..., was six hundred thousand and seventy thousand and five thousand sheep,
    \so Num.31.32
    \ng The animate final is commonly spelt as a separate word, both styles appearing in this example.
    \nt +
    pl.inan. |-ogkodtash|    1 Chr.22.14
    \xv Kah wame sephausue gold, ...: mo nabo nequtta pasuk∞e muttannonganogkodtash shekelsash, kah nesausuk tahshe pasuk∞∞ash, kah napanna tahshinchagkodtash,...
    \xe And all the gold of the offering ..., was sixteen thousand seven hundred and fifty shekels....
    \so Num.31.52
    \nt +

    \se muttanongane
    \ps Adj. and adv. / PreN
    \ge `of thousands'
    \nt +
    \xv ... nashpe muttanongane mugquompaog, kah nequt pasuk∞e mugquompaog:...
    \xe ..., of the captains of thousands, and of the captains of hundreds,...
    \so Num.31.52
    pl. an. |muttannonganogkussuog, nequt muttanong[ane] muttanonganogkussuog| `a thousand thousand (persons)'    1 Chr.21.5
(See |-ogkodt-|.)

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nquittemittànnug| `1000'    R.W.24√.
Western Abenaki [abe] |mtára| `ten'; |neg8d amk8a`ki| `one thousand'.
    WAbn. |medala| `ten (for abstract items and in counting)'    D.I.307.]
    \nt +

\et A.1258-1260, H.1890-1896, *meta∙- `ten', in some form extended in *-l- or *-Θ-, perhaps followed by a numerative for hundreds resembling the form, something like *-a∙hk(w)-, seen in other languages (B.1962, 17.67, p.378; Voorhis IJAL 43 (1977), 47a, V.1988, 145; Fx.L. 105; Baraga 137b: "Hundred, ningotwâk", Valentine 2001, 876: "final /-(w)aak/ `hundred'"; Ho.1948, 213b: suffix √|wak| `hundreds'). Some languages have a variant form of the extension of the initial, as e.g. Fx. |meta∙swa∙hkwe| `ten hundred', Fx.L.105.

\lx na

    \xe therefrom, thence, hence

\lx nabo
\va nab
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 73
\ps a particle:
\nt G&B.659 |napa| `and', P (with numbers).
    Then from 10 to 20 they {adde} afore the Numeral ({nab} or {nabo}) and then it is not needful to {adde the following additional}, though sometimes theydo it.
    As for Example:
    11  {Nabo nequt}.
    12  {Nabo neese}.
    13  {Nabo nish}.
    14  {Nabo yau}.
    15  {Nabo napanna}.
    16  {Nabo nequtta}.
    17  {Nabo nesausuk}.
    18  {Nabo shwosuk}.
    19  {Nabo paskoogun}."    El.Gr.14/260-261
    (|nobo nés| `twelve'    Mass.Ps.)

    Examples, including inflected and PreN/PreV forms:
    \nt +
    \xv nabonees∞∞woh sontimoh
    \xe Twelve princes
    \so Gen.17.20
    \ng obviative
    \xv Kah Ishmael wunnaumonuh nabo nishwe kodtumwohkomwoh...
    \xe And Ishmael his son was thirteen years old,...
    \so Gen.17.25
    \ng preverb
    \xv nabo nequttuoh wunnaumonuh
    \xe his eleven sons
    \so Gen.32.22
    \ng obviative
    \xv ...: kah neemun nabo nesuog wosketompaog kenaau,...
    \xe ...; and I took twelve men of you,...
    \so Deut.1.23
    \ng plural
    \xv nabo nesausuk audtahshikquinohhog nepauz
    \xe the seventeenth day of the month
    \so Gen.7.11
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle, with the "additional"

\cf napanna
\cf nabinotawan
\ge he repeats his words
\so and Chip
\cf nabaan
\ge he fastens it (or puts it) to the end of something,
\so Bar
\dv [From |neepau| (?).]

[Narragansett [xnt] |Piuck nabna quìt| `11.'; |Piucknab nèese| `12,'...    R.W.22√
Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |piug-naubutnuquút| `eleven'    Stiles.
Western Abenaki [abe] |neg8dañnkáo| `eleven'; |nisañnkáo| `twelve'    R.358/493a.√
Chip. |Midâsswi ashî bêjig| `eleven'; |Midâsswi ashî nij| `twelve'    Bar.307√
Cree |Métàtat-péy-ak-oo-sàu@p| `Eleven.', |Métàtat-néeshoo-sà-up| `Twelve.' `eleven', etc.    Howse 308-309.√]

\lx nadtauwompadtam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 74
    \ps With inan. obj. / TI1a
    \ge `he looks for (it)'; +`to require sth'  (cf. OED, s.v. II. 5.a. "To ask for (some thing or person) authoritatively or imperatively, or as a right; to demand, claim, insist on having.")
    \xv ..., kenatauwompatamun ut nunnutcheganit, komm∞tomuk kesukodáeu, asuh komm∞tomuk nukonâeu.
    \xe ...; of my hand thou didst require it, whether stolen by day, or stolen by night.
    \so Gen.31.39
    \ng 2->0-pro objective
    \nt +

    suppos. 2d pl. |nadtauwompadtamóg wequai| `while ye look for the light'    Jer.13.16

    \se nadtauwompamau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he looks for or at (him)'; +`to require sb', as TI verb
    \xv ..., ut nunnutcheganit pish kuttit natauwompam,...
    \xe ...; of my hand shalt thou require him:...
    \so Gen.43.9
    \ng 2->3 objective; cf. Vlg. "de manu mea require illum"

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nederañbadámen|; (with an. obj.) |-bámañ| `je le regarde'.]

\et H.2174-2176 *natawa∙pame∙wa, TA *natawa∙pantamwa TI `to look for sb/sth', *na∙tawa∙piwa AI; the usage in Massachusett suggests the presence of the oral final.
