\lx naéhtau
\ve Does this exist?
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 74
\ps v.t. / TA?
\ge `he appears, shows himself to (him)'
\dv [causat. inan. from |náum| `he sees' (?)]

    \se naeihtauau
    \ps TA, |-htaw-|-stem, directive final (?--cf. B.1962, 16.133, 355: there, stated to be essentially only to AI stems)
    \ge `to appear (un)to sb, show oneself (un)to sb' [dynamic sense]
    \nt Research needed: None of the examples that Trumbull gives appear unequivocally to belong to his headword. I have put them all under this sublemma for now, subject to the force of further evidence, and have expanded or modified the examples where Trumbull (or Hale) appears to have abbreviated too drastically.
    \xv Kah Jehovah wunnaéihtauoh, kah n∞wau, ahque w∞msish en Egypt,...
    \xe And the Lord appeared unto him, and said, Go not down into Egypt;...
    \so Gen.26.2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche na GOD wuttit naéihtaonah ...
    \xe ...; because there God appeared unto him,...'    Gen.35.7  { 3->3
    \so ? (anomalous subordinative form? applicative?) }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., GOD wame manuhkesit. nunaeihteunk ut Luz ...
    \xe ..., God Almighty appeared to me at Luz ...
    \so Gen.48.3
    \ng 3->1 absolute
    \nt +
    with affixes: |...: newutche yeu kesukok kenaeihtunk∞ Jehovah.| `..., for to day the LORD will appeare vnto you.'    Lev.9.4√  { 3->2p absolute }
    \xv Kah kusseh naeihtauau Moses kah Elias keket∞kauon.
    \xe And behold, there appeared vnto them Moses, and Elias, talking with him.'    Mt.17.3  { ?3->3
    \so absolute [!] }
    \nt +
    |Kah Elijah monchu naehtauonat Ahab,...| (infin.) `And Elijah went to shew himself unto Ahab. ...'    1 K.18.2  { X->3 t-subordinative }

    pret. |..., uttoh adt Jehovah naehtaomp Davidoh ∞shoh,...| `..., where the Lord appeared unto David his father,...'    2 Chr.3.1  { 3->3'+_adv_ preterite participle }
    \xv ... uttiyeuwoh naeitauwop.
    \xe ..., who appeared unto him.'    Gen.12.7  { _3_->3
    \so preterite participle }
    \xv ... en Godut, noh naeihtunkquean: wasémwean wutch wuskesukqut Esau kemat.
    \xe ... unto God, that appeared unto thee when thou fleddest from the face of Esau thy brother.
    \so Gen.35.1
    \ng _3_->2
    \nt +
    ?|..., onatuh enninneaónk naeihtait ut wetuómut.| `..., It seemeth to me there is as it were a plague in the house:'    Lev.14.35 { Analysis assumed: |enninneaónk|: NA; |naeihtait|: 3->1 conjunct (why?); still uncertain }
    \nt +

\cf nahtinau
\ge he shows (it) to
\cf nahtussu


\lx naen
\va na en
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 74
    \nt +
\ps Pro+P "to there", spatial, temporal, and also animate
\ge `(un)to him, them',...; till, until'
\so Gen.19.6,
    \xv Onk na en Shemut..., wuttit {mukkiog} neekinneau.
    \xe Unto Shem also,..., even to him were children born.
    \so Gen.10.21
    \xv ... Lot naen sohham...
    \xe ... Lot went out...unto them,...
    \so Gen.19.6
    \xv Neit Pilate sohham na en,...
    \xe Pilate then went out unto them,...
    \so Jn.18.29
    \xv ..., an∞téam∞wog naen,...
    \xe ..., [they] sent unto him,...
    \so Acts 19.31
    \xv ..., kah wutch Gentilsehtu yeuyeu kutann∞nush naen.
    \xe ..., and from the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thee.
    \so Acts 26.17

    \xv ..., onk na en nompóeu.
    \xe ... until the morning.
    \so Ex.12.22
    \xv ..., onk na en uppeyonóont ohkit na wadohtimuk:...
    \xe ..., until they came to a land inhabited:...
    \so Ex.16.35
    \xv Naen kummatwomog nutayeuwonaóont kukquenánnéhtuonk,...
    \xe Till I make thine enemies thy footstools.
    \so Lk.20.43

\lx nagum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps pron. 3d sing. an. / { emphatic or "strong", as in coordinations, in some sense, often contrastive, as in elliptical converses }
\ge `he, +she; himself/herself'
\nt G&B.507, with plural |nagumau|: "These pronouns are used for emphasis with verb and nouns and in verbless predications. The[y] also appear as objects of prepositions,..."
\so El.Gr.7
    = |noh|, q.v.)
    pl. |nagoh| (= |nahoh|) `they'
    \xv ..., kah wetu hassunnekit nagum kah neswe wuttaunoh.
    \xe ..., and he dwelt in a cave, he and his two daughters.

\lx nahanushau

\va nohnushau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv ?|nahan-| "well" + |-uhshá-| AI `to go'
\ge "to go, travel well", used in imperative `depart, fare ... wel'
\so Lk.9.61; Acts 5.40,17.9,18.21,23.22; 2 Cor.13.11

    \xv ...: qut negonne moncheaheh, unnonat nag nekìt apitcheg, nohnushagk.
    \xe ...; but let me first go bid them farewell, which are at home at my house.
    \so Lk.9.61
    \ng 2p imperative; o.r. for o.o. of source texts
    \xv Neit kehchimumugquomp wuskennuh unnanumau nohnushash,...
    \xe So the chief captain then let the young man depart,...
    \so Acts 23.22
    \ng 2 imperative; o.r. for o.o of source texts
    |Nehunüshshash,| or |wunnïish.| `Fare you well.'    C.102/227  { 2 imperative }

[Algonquian [alg] |NA-| `bien, comme il faut'    Cq.243b.
Cree {x} |NAH| (rac.) `être habile à, etc., être apte à, etc., bien.'    Lac.D.472a.
Fx. |nah-| `accustomed, good, proper, well'    Fx.L.112-113.
Miami |nah-| `correct, proper, well'    B&C.85ab.]

\lx nahnashau

    (|nen nunnâssham| `I breathe'    C.)

    pl. (part.) |...qut uppapaquane paguánuh wame neh nanashonitcheh,...| `..., but utterly destroyed all that breathed,...'    Josh.10.40√ { _3'_  participle }

    \se ?!|nahnahshontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative
    \ge `to breathe sth out'

    \xv ..., kah neg nashontogig woskehuwaonk.
    \xe ..., and such as breathe out cruelty.
    \so Ps.27.12
    \ng _3p_->0 participle } (M): |nohnohshontog|  { _3_->0 participle
    \nt +

\et (of !|nahshau|) B., no 46, 15, 90/446, G.1981, 25, 65, *le∙hle∙wa AI `to breathe' (G.1982, 4.1, 26 on possibility of *le∙hΘe∙wa), A.1152, H.1427


\lx nahog
\va nahhog
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps personal pronoun, 3p animate
    \nt Remark: The examples suggest that this may act as a plural emphatic, including the use as object of prepositions (cf. G&B.507). The form |nah(h)og| is used by Eliot, probably at least partly in this fashion, in contexts where an obviative would be expected, e.g. Gen.1.22,14.15(2x),19.3,23.8,37.6,41.19.
    \nt +
\ge `they, them'
\so C.33/178,107b/231; Gen.1.27(E0), ...
    \xv Kah ukken∞nuh nahog. n∞wau,...
    \xe And he communed with them, saying,...
    \so Gen.23.8
    \ng obviative, no discernible emphasis
    \nt +
    |... wuttinnussuonganit God wuttinne kezheuh nahoh,/ wosketomp & mittamwossis ukkezheuh nahog.| "in the image of - [God] - he made - him/ man -   [&] - woman - he made - them" `..., in the Image of God created he him; male and female created hee them.'    Gen.1.27(E0) { retained in (E1&2) }
    \xv Ut nahog, ut yeug.
    \xe To them, to those
    \so C.10b/213√
    \xv Nag, nahog, {or} nagumau.
    \xe They, them
    \so C.33/178
    \nt +
    \xv Nagumau, nag, nahog.
    \xe They, them
    \so C.107b/213
    \nt +
    \xv Wutch nahog.
    \xe Of them, {or} those
    \so C.107b/213

    \se nahoh
    \va náhoh
    \nt +
    \ps personal pronoun, demonstrative, obviative
    \nt +
    \so Gen.1.27,13.6,18.8,19.18,...
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Lot wuttinuh nahoh, Woi ahque n naj nussontimom.
    \xe And Lot said unto them, Oh, not so, my Lord:
    \so Gen.19.18

\cf noh


\lx nahohtôeu
\va ne hohtôeu
\ve =  `the next in order'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps adv. / PreN, PreV
\ge `secondly', +`after; other; the second time'; the order can be spatial or temporal.
    \nt G&B.654,672
    \nt +
\so El.Gr.21
    \xv Nahohtôeu
    \xe Second
    \so El.Gr.21/268 (adverbs "Of order")
    \xv ..., kah k∞skannemunneog nahohtóeu ken.
    \xe ..., and with your seed after you.
    \so Gen.9.9
    \nt +
    \xv ... weekomau Abrahamoh wutch kesukqut nahohtôeu.
    \xe ... called unto Abraham out of heaven the second time.
    \so Gen.22.15
    \nt +
    \xv Nahohtôeu ompásik, Emeraud. Saphyr, kah Diamond.
    \xe And the second row shall be an emerald, a sapphire, and a diamond.
    \so Ex.28.1√
    \xv Kah ne nahohtóe yóaeu∞k pummuwuttauwáekommuk ...
    \xe And for the other side of the tabernacle,...
    \so Ex.36.25
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nag aninnumauónat, kah ∞skannemunnuoh nahohtóeu.
    \xe ..., to give unto them and to their seed after them.
    \so Deut.1.8√
    \ng temporal
    \xv ..., onk woh ukkinnumunat nahôhtoeu Jesus ut.
    \xe ..., that he might bear it after Jesus.
    \so Lk.23.26√
    \ng spatial
\cf hohtôeu

\lx nahtinau
\va noht-
\va -N-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps v.t. inan. and an. / TA+O, applicative final
\ge `he shows (it/him) to (him); he makes (it/him) appear to (him)'; +`to make sth known to sb'
\so Esth.48 (infin.)
    \xv Woi LORD Jehovah, ken∞che nahtin kummissugken∞onk kuttinneum, kah kumménuhkinnutcheg:...
    \xe O Lord God, thou hast begun to shew thy servant thy greatness, and thy mighty hand:...
    \so Deut.3.24
    \ng 2->3+0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah kenahtinush wosketomp noh natinneahwhadt,...
    \xe and I will show thee the man whom thou seekest.'    Judg.4.22 { T. tr. `you
    \so .};
    \xv ..., woh wunnohtinnóneau wunnechán∞oh.
    \xe ...: that they should make them known to their children.'    Ps.78.5  { 3p->3
    \so +0p objective }; (M) |wunnahtunnoneau|
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kenahtinugk∞ mashekishkag waabe quoshwéetósu,...
    \xe And he shall shew you a large upper room furnished:
    \so Lk.22.12
    \ng 3->2p+0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah kinahtinush n∞namptamóonk nashpe nutanakausuongash,...
    \xe ..., and I will show thee my faith by my works.
    \so Jas.2.18
    \ng 1->2+0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., teague kuhkinneas[u]onk kinnahtissimun, newaj yeush usséan.
    \xe ..., What sign shewest thou unto us, seeing that thou doest these things?
    \so Jn.2.18
    \ng 2->1p+0 indicative
    \nt +

    \xv howan nahtínukqueog
    \xe who will show (it) to us?
    \so Ps.4.6
    \nt MN: nohtinont
    \ng suppositive |nohtinont| Judg.1.25
    \xv ..., nuppinshom waussumónat ut anaquohtag wusseetash angel, noh yeush naihtusitchish.
    \xe ..., I fell down to worship before the feet of the angel which shewed me these things.
    \so Rev.22.8
    \nt +

    \xv ...: nahtusseh k∞namptamóonk wanne anakausuonganunn∞ut, kah kinahtinush n∞namptamóonk nashpe nutanakausuongash,
    \xe ...: shew me thy faith without thy works, and I will shew thee my faith by my works.
    \so Jas.2.18
    \ng 2->1+0 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv Phillip wuttinuh, LORD, nahtussinnean Wut∞shimau, kah n∞wamanittamumun.
    \xe Philip saith unto him, Lord, shew us the Father, and it sufficeth us.
    \so Jn.14.8,9; Mayhew: |nahtissinnean|
    \ng 2->1p imperative
    \nt +
\cf naéhtau
\cf namehéau


\lx nahtussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps v.t. / AI(+O) ?
\ge `he shows, makes apparent' (|-ussu| `performs the act of showing')

    imperat. |nahtus| `show thou (it)'    Ezek.43.10
    with affix, |nahtusseh kummayash| `show me thy ways'    Ps.25.4
    (|nahtuhseh keek| `show me your house'    C.)
\nt Research needed: Spurious entry; no doubt belongs in previous lemma: these are palatalizing/mutation environments.


\lx nahtwunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge `to take sb'

    \xv ... ishkont wo[.]ketuonk nunnahtwunuk kah woh nunnup.
    \xe ..., lest some evil take me, and I die.

\lx nahwhunk
\va nawhonk
\va nawhónk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
    \nt +
\ps Prev? (II conjunct?)
\ge `certainly, must, necessary, needful, ought to; peradventure' i.e. strong or weak (deontic, epistemic, and other domains) modal. Currently, the weak sense is only attested once.
\so Gen.30.16,50.15; Acts 13.46,14.22,15.5,24,18.21,19.21,26.9,27.26 (strange distribution!)
    \xv ..., Nawhónk kuppetukah nen, newutche wunnamuhkut mahche kutann∞sh ken wutche nunnaumon ummandraksumoh,...
    \xe ..., Thou must come in unto me; for surely I have hired thee with my son's mandrakes. ...
    \so Gen.30.16
    \xv ...Joseph paguodche kussekeneunkqun, kah nahwhunk kutonkquatunkqun, wame ne machuk ne neanheogkutup.
    \xe ..., Joseph will peradventure hate us, and will certainly requite us all the evil which we did unto him.
    \so Gen.50.15
    \xv ..., nawhonk negonne kuttinnuhteáneau wuttinn∞waonk God,...
    \xe ..., It was necessary that the word of God should first have been spoken to you:...
    \so Acts 13.46
    \xv ... Nawhonk quoskquswoog, kah wuttann∞nouh ussen wuttinn∞waonk Moses.
    \xe ..., That it was needful to circumcise them, and to command them to keep the law of Moses.
    \so Acts 15.5
    \xv ..., nawhonk nunnánaitauun yeu mshadtupp∞onk ut Jerusalem ...
    \xe ..., I must by all means keep this feast that cometh in Jerusalem:...
    \so Acts 18.21
    \xv Nuttenantamup ut nuttahut, nawhonk n∞woshetteóh monatash, ayeuúhkone ∞wesuonk Jesus wutch NeZareth.
    \xe I verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
    \so Acts 26.9
    \xv Qut nawhonk kukkuhpémun ut menohhannet.
    \xe Howbeit we must be cast upon a certain island.
    \so Acts 27.26


\lx nái
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it makes a point or angle, it is angled or angular'
    \xv yaue nái
    \xe it is four-angled, square
    \so Ezek.45.2
    \xv ut yaue naee
    \xe on the four corners
    \so ibid.

    \nt MN: naiag
    \ng suppositive |naiag| , |naiyag| `when it makes an angle';
    as n. `a corner, an angle'
    \xv yaue naiyag wetu
    \xe the four corners of the house' (lit. `where the house four-corners
    \so )    Job 1.19
    = |yauwe náyag|    Ex.27.2
    and |yaue nahnayag| (freq. `all the corners')    Acts 11.5
\cf nashin

\lx namehéau
\va namhéau
\va nameheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps v.t. an. / TA, causative final
\ge `he finds (him), discovers (him)' [`makes him visible']; +`to befall, come upon sb'
\dv causat. an. form from |nau| `he sees him'; cf. |nahtinau|, |naéhtau|
    \nt G&B.655, s.v. |nammeh/at|, |namehto|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut na matta nameheon anninohsuaenin,...
    \xe ... but ... there was not found an help ...
    \so Gen.2.20
    \ng X->3 negative subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Paguodche woh naut kenameh yauonchagodto[g],...
    \xe ..., Peradventure there shall be forty found there:...
    \so Gen.18.29
    \ng 2->3(p) absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wosketomp wunnamheuh,...
    \xe And a certain man found him,...'    Gen.37.15  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., sunnummatta yeush machukish kenamhuk∞unánonash, newutche kum-Manitt∞mun matta k∞wetomuk∞un.
    \xe ..., Are not these evils come upon us, because our God is not among us?
    \so Deut.31.17
    \ng 0p->12
    \nt +
    |nenamheh|, |nenamehheh| `I find him' {distinct stem?}
    (|-nammeh|    Hos.9.10)
    \xv kenamheh
    \xe thou findest me
    \xv kenamhesh
    \xe I find thee
    \so 1 K.21.20
    negat. |nen matta namheóh| `I did not find him'    2 Cor.2.13

    \nt MN: namehéont
    \ng suppositive |namehéont| `when he finds, he finding'    Prov.18.22
    \xv ..., Naméheog napanna tahshinchagodtog sampweusseáenuog ut Sodom,...
    \xe ..., If I find in Sodom fifty righteous,...
    \so Gen.18.26
    \ng 1->3 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish nnih, monakish machukish, kah nanakontanum∞ongah nanameheahettit,...
    \xe And it shall come to pass, when many evils and troubles are befallen them,...
    \so Deut.31.21
    \ng 3p->0p[!] conjunct -- compare use of theme 2 in Deut.31.17 above; reduplication misprinted, confirmed from E1.
    \nt +

    \se namehteau
    \va nampt(e)au
    \nt +
    \ps with inan. obj. / TI2
    \ge `he finds (it)'
    \so Prov.18.22; 17.20
    \xv Qut wuskuhwhunnan mat namehteóou toh woh ohtag wusseet,...
    \xe But the dove found no rest for the sole of her foot,...
    \so Gen.8.9
    \ng 3->0 negative absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah na wunnampteauunneau tohkékonaûe wutahamonk.
    \xe ..., and [they] found there a well of springing water.
    \so Gen.26.19
    \ng 3p->0 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh nunnamteoh kitteamonteanittúonk anaquabean.
    \xe ..., that I may find grace in thy sight.
    \so Gen.32.5
    \ng 1->0 absolute? inflection in |-oh|
    \nt +
    \xv Kah naum matugque figs noadtut wunnépogk∞∞, peyau, onk woh wunnampteauun teaguas na ut, kah paaontog, matchaog namehteau webe wunnepaguash,...
    \xe And seeing a fig tree afar off having leaves, he came, if haply he might find any thing thereon: and when he came to it, he found nothing but leaves;...
    \so Mk.11.13
    \ng 3->0 subordinative?, 3->0 negative absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wame teanteaquassinish nish weekogkish, kah wanegugish kutamaehtunkqunash, kah nash pish matta wonk kenamptauouunash.
    \xe ..., and all things which were dainty and goodly are departed from thee, and thou shalt find them no more at all.
    \so Rev.18.14
    \ng 2->0p negative objective
    \nt +
    (|Nunnâmeehteo, -ooup.| `I find, or did'    C.52/191)

    \xv ..., namehteaúon kitteamonteanittuonk ut anaquabean,...
    \xe ..., If now I haue found fauour in thy sight,...
    \so Gen.18.3
    \ng 1->0 subjunctive
    \nt +
    \xv Kittinneumog uttoh adt namehteauan nuppitch,...
    \xe With whomsoever of thy servants it is found, both let him die,...
    \so Gen.44.9
    \ng 2->0+_3_ participle
    \nt +
    \nt MN: namehteunk
    \ng suppositive |namehteunk| Lk.15.9

    \se |namehteauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem
    \ge `to find sth for, in sb'
    \so Deut.24.1; Lk.23.4; Jn.18.27(Hd),18.28,19.4; Acts 7.46; Rev.3.2
    \xv ..., newutche wunnamteauoh nishkeneunkquok:...
    \xe ..., because he hath found some uncleanness in her:...
    \so Deut.24.1
    \xv ..., matta nunnamtea∞h ummatcheseonk yeuoh wosketomp.
    \xe ..., I find no fault in this man.
    \so Lk.23.4
    |Pilat mat namteauau matcheseonk| "Pilate finds no fault in him"    Jn.18.27(Hd)
    \xv ..., kodtantam namehtaun wek Ummanitt∞moh Jakob.
    \xe ..., and desired to find a tabernacle for the God of Jacob.
    \so Acts.7.46

    \se |namehikqussu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, existential passive ("verb of undergoing")
    \twn |nameheoquodt|
    \ge `to be found' i.e. "be findable, exist"
    \so Rev.18.22
    \xv ..., kah matta howáe anakausuenúog, uttoh wuttinanaukausuonk, pish wonk namehikqussu ut kuhhogkat,...
    \xe ...; and no craftsman, of whatsoever craft he be, shall be found any more in thee;...
    \so Rev.18.22

    \se !|nameheoquodt|
    \nt +
    \ps II, dispositional/existential passive ("verb of undergoing")
    \twn |namehikqussu|
    \ge `to be found' i.e. "be findable, exist"
    \so Rev.18.21
    \xv ..., Yeu ne pish chekée n∞kuhkon mishe keihtotan Babylon, kah matta pish wonk nameheoquodtinno.
    \xe ..., Thus with violence shall that great city Babylon be thrown down, and shall be found no more at all.
    \so Rev.18.21
    \nt +

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nenami`tt8n|, nob. |nenamihañ, 3. 8n.| `Je découvre, je vois'; |nenamih8^é.| `Je vois'    R.158/427b;504/543b.
    Narragansett [xnt] |Machâge cunna miteôuwin?| `Doe you find nothing.', |Ntauhaunanamiteoûwin| `I cannot find.'    R.W.37.]
    \nt +


\lx namohkaeihheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps v.t. / TA+O(?); direct object appears to be optional
\ge `he lends to (him)'
\dv [causat. form of |namohkau|]
    \xv En pen∞wohteaut woh kutauwohteae namakouhuwam, qut en kematut matta pish kutauwohteae namakouhuau,...
    \xe Unto a stranger thou mayest lend upon usury; but unto thy brother thou shalt not lend upon usury:...
    \so Deut.23.20
    \ng varied inflection? (1&2), or is there an indefinite (inanimate?) object in a normal AI verb?; |en| + locative  for indirect object
    \nt +
    \xv namohkaaihhuau
    \xe lendeth
    \so Ps.112.5; (M): |namohkouwehhuwau|
    |-kohheau|    Prov.19.17

    \xv Namohkoúheadt teauguash nummissinninnumog, neg machekitcheg, ahque unneh neane namôhkahuwaenuut,...
    \xe If thou lend money to any of my people that is poor by thee, thou shalt not be to him as an usurer,...
    \so Ex.22.25
    \nt +
    \xv Kah namohkáeiheog nagoh, woh ôadtuhkonkqueogig, ne toh hen wunnegen? ...
    \xe And if ye lend to them of whom ye hope to receive, what thank have ye? ...
    \so Lk.6.34
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d pl. |Qut womon∞k kummatwóm∞ôog, kah wunnesek kah namohkaeihuágk, matta natauwompattám∞unat ne teag wonk:...| `But love ye your enemies, and do good, and lend, hoping for nothing again;...'    Lk.6.35√
    |..., netomp namakouhe shwinash petukqunegash.| (?) `..., Friend, lend me three loaves.'    Lk.11.5√
\cf nogkohkáeihhuunát

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nenemeka8ihañ| `je lui prête'; imperat. |nemaka8ihi| or |nemeka8i|.    R.414/514a.√]


\lx namohkau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\lx namohs
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 75
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a fish'
\so El.Gr.9, Mt.17.27; Ex.7.18,21
    (|nâmâs|    C.)
    pl. |-sog|
    \xv ... onatuh namohsut ...
    \xe ... as fishes ...
    \so Gen.48.16
    \ng locative
    \nt +

    dimin. |namohsémes|
    pl. |-mesog|    Mt.15.34

\nt [The first letter does not belong to the root, but represents the determinative particle. It is not found in compound words (see |-âmag|). The base is the same as in |aum|; trans. |aum-au| `he fishes'. In the Old Algonkin and in some modern dialects the determinative prefix is given to the sturgeon as the fish par excellence. The final |s| represents the an. adj. form |-esu|, or what is equivalent to it, |ôâas|, `animal, animate being'.]

[Narragansett [xnt] |nammaùus|, pl. |-suck|.
Western Abenaki [abe] |namés|, pl. |-sak|.
Old Alg. |kicons| (|namain| `sturgeon').
Chip. |kë'gö| (|nam ai'|, |naughmay| `sturgeon').
Menominee [mez] |nahmaish| (|nahmawe| `sturgeon').
Delaware [del] |na mees|, pl. |-sak|.
Powhatan [pim] |noughmass|    J. Smith.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |nemesh|    Maillard.
    Algonquian [alg] |NAME,...wak| `esturgeon'    Cq.254a.
    \nt +
EOj. |neme∙| `sturgeon'    B.1957.251b.
Lp.A |namens. pl. namensak| `poisson'    M.2.]

\et B. 59, item 176; S. 1975, item 84, p. 340: *name∙?sa `fish'

    \xe And when Peter saw it, he answered unto the people, Ye men of Israel, why marvel ye at this? ...'    Act.3.12  { 3->3

\lx nan
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 76
\ps particle
\ge denoting likeness or identity, `the same as', or `such as'
    \xv noh nan
    \xe the same person
    \so Heb.13.8; Ps.102.27
    \xv ne nan
    \xe the same thing
    \so Dan.5.5; Jn.4.53
    (|nenan|, |nnih|, |nont nee| `the same'    C.)
    \xv ne nan qussuk
    \xe that same stone
    \so Mt.21.42
    pl. inan. |nanoash| `such (things)'    James 3.10

    \se nano
    \ps II, 3 negative form of |nnih|, |unni| (with admixture of positive forms)
    \ge `to be so, such; to be so done'
    \nt G&B.720, s.v. |unnai|, with list of refs. to T. & C.
    with verb subst. |ne nano| `it is the same, it is so'
    \xv noh nano (nnoh)
    \xe he is the same or such
    \xv ..., Woh mô nana ut nutohkin, negonne magun peississit nukasquam mohtomegit.
    \xe It must not be so done in our country, to give the younger before the first born.
    \so Gen.29.26; (E0&E1) |nano|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Mtta ne nano, LORD;...
    \xe ..., Not so, Lord;...
    \so Acts 10.14√
    \xv ..., yeush matta woh nanoash.
    \xe ..., these things ought not so to be.
    \so Jas.3.10√

    \nt MN: ne nag
    \ng suppositive |ne nag| `if it be so'    Dan.3.17
    \ng positive
    \xv matta nan∞g
    \xe if it be not so
    \so Dan.3.18

    imperat. 3d sing. |ne naj| `let it be so, "even so"'    Mt.11.26; Lk.11.2; Rev.22.20  { positive }
    |ne nach|    Mt.15.28
    \nt +
    \xv ahque ne naj
    \xe not so
    \so Acts 11.8
\cf áunag
\cf neane
\cf nnih
\nt [All these have the same base, and it is impossible to distinguish always the forms of each under Eliot's varying notation.]

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nni, eíu.| `It is true.' / |Mat enâno|, {or}, |mat eâno.| `It is not true.'    R.W.57√.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |arâi| `cela arrive, hoc accidit'    R.34/387b.]

\lx nanashwu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 76
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `he prepares, makes ready'
    \xv ...? newutche nuppákodche nanashwem, matta webe wewheppapunnuttéin, qut nuppun ut Jerusalem ...
    \xe ...? for I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die at Jerusalem ...
    \so Acts 21.13
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk yeuyeu nanashwéog, pahtóog kukquoshomaongan∞.
    \xe ...: and now are they ready, looking for a promise from thee.
    \so Acts 23.21
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |-wish| `prepare thyself, be ready'    Jer.46.14
    \xv Kah nanashwish nompoáe. ...
    \xe And be ready in the morning,...
    \so Ex.34.2
    \nt +

    \se nanashweau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he prepares or makes (him) ready'

    \se nanashwetam
    \ps with nan. obj. / TI1a
    \ge `he makes (it) ready', +`to prepare sth'
    \xv ..., newutche ne GOD ummenuhke nanashwetamun, kah GOD teanuk pish wutussen.
    \xe ...; it is because the thing is established by God, and God will shortly bring it to pass.
    \so Gen.41.32
    \nt +
    \xv ..., pish nanashwetamwog ne petakodtahettit,...
    \xe ..., that one the sixth day they shall prepare that which they bring in;...
    \so Ex.16.5
    \nt +

    \nt MN: nanashwetòg
    \ng suppositive |nanashwetòg| `when he prepares (it)'    Prov.8.27

    \xv ..., Nanashwehtam∞k ummay LORD, ayim∞k ummayash sampwíyeuut.
    \xe ..., Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.
    \so Lk.3.4
    \nt +

    \se -wetamau
    \va -wetamauau
    \ps with inan. obj. and an. ending / TA+O
    \ge `(he) prepares (it) for (him)'
    \xv ..., kah pish nunnanashweetamau ∞weetuonk,...
    \xe ..., and I will prepare him a habitation;...
    \so Ex.15.2√

\lx nánauwánumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 76
    \nt +
\ps TA, mental final
\ge `to take care of sb; to reign over sb'
    \xv ..., kah uppas∞uh ut ordnary, kah wunnánauanumoh.
    \xe ..., and brought him to an inn, and took care of him.
    \so Lk.10.34

    \xv Nanauwánum, kah uttoh áne mahtshatauan, wonk peyóon, kuttóadtuhkoush.
    \xe Take care of him; and whatsoever thou spendest more, when I come again, I will repay thee.
    \so Lk.10.35

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nenéna8érdámen, 3. 8nén, nob. nenéna8érman| `Je le conserve'    R.127/417b; see also A.135, s.v.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |ninena8iha| `je le garde, veille a sa conserva[ti]on' |ninena8it8 ign.|, |nena8it8ca min8tene| `garde, santinelle, deffenseur du vill'    Gr.333/201b.
WAbn. |nanawalema| `take care of someone', |nanawaldam| `keep, preserve something'    D.I.351,II.61.
\cf Nana8anban ...
\cf Ninana8nen
\cf nana8anbamen
\ge prens garde que ...', |Ninana8nen|
\nt Lp.A.  `prens garde que ...',  `je le garde'     [unglossed]    D.44,91]

\et The Abenaki correspondences and the Illinois forms point to PEA *ne∙naw-; other secure correspondences not yet found.


\lx nanaweheau
\va nanauweheau
\va nanaiheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 76
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative final
\twn |nanauwehteau|
\ge `to keep sb' (including preserve in a state); `to serve sb'
\so Gen.6.19,20,30.29,31,40.4,46.34; Deut.4.9; Lk.4.10; Rom.2.25; Gal.3.23,6.13
    \xv ..., kah toh nuttin nánauweheonap kenetasumog,
    \xe ..., and how thy cattle was with me.
    \so Gen.30.29
    \ng 1->3 preterite
    \xv Kah askuhwheteaeu mugquomp wutahtushonuh Josephuh, kah wunnannaheuh,...
    \xe And the captain of the guard charged Joseph with them, and he served them:...
    \so Gen.40.4
    \ng 3->3-pro objective; syncopated
    \xv ..., meechumuhkonau wutangelsumoh kenanauwehukqunnaout.
    \xe ..., He shall give his angels charge over thee, to keep thee.
    \so Lk.4.10
    \ng 3p->2 t-subordinative
    \xv Qut ash papeyunkup wunnamptam∞onk, nanauwehhetteamun agwe ut naumatuonganit,...
    \xe For before faith came, we were kept under the law,...
    \so Gal.3.23
    \ng X->1p
    \xv Newutche nag quoshqusausitcheg matta nanauwehheo∞og naumatuonguh,...
    \xe For neither they themselves who are circumcised keep the law;...'    Gal.6.13 { 3p->3
    \so negative indicative; object animate! }

    \xv ... kittinneumóg noh nanânauwéheoncheg neetahsu ...
    \xe ..., Thy servants' trade hath been about cattle ...'    Gen.46.34  { _3p_->3
    \so participle to reduplicated stem }
    \xv Newutche quôshqusausuonk, wunnamuhkut wunnenehuómm∞, nanauwehheadt naumatuonk ...
    \xe For circumcision verily profiteth, if thou keep the law:...
    \so Rom.2.25
    \ng object animate!

    \xv Webe nunnukqusish kuhhog, kah kukketeahogkou menuhke nanaweh,...
    \xe Only take heed to thyself, and keep thy soul diligently,...
    \so Deut.4.9
    \ng 2->3
    \xv ...: pahke nanauweh kuhhog.
    \xe ...; keep thyself pure.
    \so 1 Tim.5.22
    \ng 2->3

\nt Remark: What is the analysis of the form in |weeche nanaweheunt naumatuongash, nashpe wutanwoh∞un∞oash| `by the direction of the lawgiver', Num.21.18(E1&2)--confusion because object can be treated as animate, as Rom.2.25, Gal.6.13?


\lx nanauwehteau
\va nanaeihteau
\va naneaiteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 76
    \nt +
\ps TI2
\twn |nanaweheau|
\ge `to keep sth, to see to sth' ["keep" in a range of senses]
\so Gen.2.15,17.9,10,18.19,39.23; Deut.4.6; Mt.14.6,27.4; Mk.9.10; Lk.11.21; 1 Cor.7.37
    \xv Onk Jehovah Manit neemunau Adam kah upponuh tanohketeaonganit Eden, ∞nteauunat, kah wunnanauwehteauunat.
    \xe And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden to dress it and to keep it.
    \so Gen.2.15
    \ng 3->0 t-subordinative
    \xv Kah nanaunuk kupishagkinittuonk matta teag nanaihteóou ut agwu wunnutcheganit,...
    \xe The keeper of the prison looked not to any thing that was under his hand;...
    \so Gen.39.23
    \xv Kah ne wunnanauwéhteauunneau ne n∞waonk ut wuhhogkaóut: nat∞tommôadtéhettit, toh nauwuttamun omohkéonk wutch nuppunat.
    \xe And they kept that saying with themselves, questioning one with another what the rising from the dead should mean.
    \so Mk.9.10

    \xv Yeu n∞n∞wáonk uttoh pish nanawehteauog ut nashauwe nen kah ken & k∞skannemunog nahohtôeu ken,...
    \xe This is my covenant, which ye shall keep between me and you, and thy seed after thee:...
    \so Gen.17.19
    \ng 2p->_0_ participle
    \xv Qut Herod toh utt∞che neekis nanaeihteomuk, Herodias wuttaunoh pomugkôoh ut nah anaquabenit,...
    \xe But when Herod's birthday was kept, the daughter of Herodias danced before them,...
    \so Mt.14.6
    \xv Menuhkasketomp tapauwamit, nanauwehteunk wek, wunohteaum∞ash ummaumachiash.
    \xe When a strong man armed keepeth his palace, his goods are in peace:
    \so Lk.11.21
    \xv ...: nanauwéhteauwéhettit nuttinn∞waonk, neit woh nanauwehteauog kuttinn∞waongan∞oash.
    \xe ...: if they have kept my saying, they will keep yours also.
    \so Jn.15.20; (M) |Nanawehteauwehhittis|; |nanawehteoog|

    \xv Newutche nish nanaeiteog, kah ussek,...
    \xe Keep therefore and do them [viz. statues and judgments];...
    \so Deut.4.6
    \xv N∞wau, Nummatchesem, newutche n∞nass∞m matta kesontam∞ ∞sqheonk, Kah n∞waog Toh neentinukkongqunan? ken nanaeitaash.
    \xe Saying, I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood. And they said, What is that to us? see thou to that.
    \so Mt.27.4
    \xv Womauséóg, woh kenanauwehteaómw∞ nutann∞hteamowongash.
    \xe If ye love me, keep my commandments.
    \so Jn.14.15; (M) |nanawehteo∞k|


\lx nanawunnum
\va -aánum
\va -aunum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 76
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\twn |nanawunnau| TA
\ge `[primarily to keep safely,] he rules over, governs (it)'; `to be ruler over sth'
\so Dan.4.17; 5.21
    \xv Kah uppònuh GOD wussepakehtam∞onganit kesukquash, woh wequasumwog ohke. Onk woh wunnananumunneau kesukod kah nuhkon,...
    \xe And God set them in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth, And to rule over the day and over the night,...
    \so Gen.1.17-18
    \ng 3p->0 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Kenanaunum
    \xe Thou rulest (it)
    \so Ps.89.9; (M) |Kunnanawunum|
    \ng 2->0 absolute
    \xv ..., noh wussontimomoh ayiunkqut wunnanauunumunat week,...
    \xe ..., whom his lord hath made ruler over his household,...
    \so Mt.24.45
    \ng t-subordinative, 3->0

    \xv Kah nanaunuk kupishagkinittuonk matta teag nanaihteóou ut agwu wunnutcheganit,...
    \xe The keeper of the prison looked not to any thing that was under his hand;...
    \so Gen.39.23; 39.21: |nanawunuk|
    \nt +

    \xv Kah ∞nohteaonk GOD, nanauwunitch ut kuttahh∞wout:...
    \xe And let the peace of God rule in your hearts,...
    \so Col.3.15
    \nt +

    \se |nanaum∞m∞|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1b, inanimate subject
    \ge `to rule sth'
    \so Gen.1.16 (2x)
    \xv ..., wequananteg mohs[a]g nananum∞m∞ kesukod,...
    \xe ...; the greater light to rule the day,...
    \so Gen.1.16
    \ng 0->0 absolute

    \se nanawunnau
    \va -áunnau
    \va nanauunau
    \nt !
    \va nahnánau
    \nt !
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, manual final
    \twn |nanauwunnum|, TI1b
    \ge `he rules over or governs (him)'; `to have dominion over, reign over sb'
    \so Ps.59.13; Rom.7.1; +Gen.36.31,45.8,47.3; Lev.26.17; Num.10.15; Deut.15.6,17.15; Ps.47.8,146.10; Mt.24.45; Lk.16.3,19.14; Rev.19.15
    \xv .... kah pish kukkodtanum kasuk, kah pish kenanauwunuk
    \xe ...; and thy desire shall be to thy husband, and he shall rule over thee.
    \so Gen.3.16
    \ng 3->2
    \xv ... kah nag sekenunkqueógig pish kenanauunuk∞óog,
    \xe ...: they that hate you shall reign over you;...
    \so Lev.26.17
    \ng 3p->2p
    \nt +
    \xv ...kah pish kenanawunnum monaash wutohtimóneash, qut nag matta pish kenanauunuk∞og.
    \xe ...; and thou shalt reign over many nations, but they shall not reign over thee.
    \so Deut.16.6
    \ng 2->0; 3p->2 negative
    \nt +
    \xv Jehovah pish nanauunnuau micheme,...
    \xe The Lord shall reign for ever,...
    \so Ps.146.10; (M): |nanawinnuwau|
    \ng 3 indefinite object

    \nt MN: nanawunont
    \ng suppositive |nanawunont| , |nanaánont| `he who rules'
    \xv Kah yeug ketass∞tàmwog nananuwacheg ut ohkit Edom, asquam nananuáwahettegkup tahs∞tamwog ut Israel.
    \xe And these are the kings that reigned in the land of Edom, before there reigned any king over the children of Israel.
    \so Gen.36.31
    \ng _3p_ participle, indefinite object; 3p reduplicated negative conjunct, indefinite object(?)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., néwutche nish noh nahnanouwunont shepsoh, noh ohqánumau ut Egyptianut.
    \xe ...; for every shepherd is an abomination unto the Egyptians.'    Gen.46.34  { _3_->3
    \so participle, reduplicated (occupation) }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kittinneumog nahnánoncheg shipsoh nenawun, kah n∞shunônog.
    \xe Thy servants are shepherds, both we, and also our fathers.'    Gen.47.3  { _3p_->3
    \so participle, reduplicated, with syncope? }
    \nt +
    pl. |-oncheg| `they who bear rule, rulers'    Ex.18.21; Is.52.5
    \xv Wonkom∞k wame neg nanauunukqueóogig,...
    \xe Salute all them that have the rule over you,...
    \so Heb.13.24
    \ng _3_->2p participle
    \nt +
    (|Nananuacheeg| `the Magistrates'    title-page of Indian Laws√)    Hatchets 1  { _3p_ participle, indefinite object }

    \xv ..., kah nanawunonch namohsog kehtohhannet ...
    \xe ...: and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea,...
    \so Gen.1.26
    \ng 3->3p(!) imperative
    \nt +

    \se |nanaunumwaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, causative
    \ge `to make sb a ruler over sb'
    \so Gen.41.43,47.6; Ex.18.21
    \xv ... & nananumwaheau wame ohke [E]gypt
    \xe ...: and he made him ruler over all the land of Egypt.
    \so Gen.41.43

    \xv ..., neit nanaunumwáh neetahsu neg wadchanogeg.
    \xe ..., then make them rulers over my cattle.'    Gen.47.6  { 2->3
    \so +3 imperative, "make them rule the cattle that I have"; (E0&E1) read |nanaununwáh|. }

    \se nanuwunnuaén
    \va nananuwaén
    \va nananuaén
    \ps N. agent
    \ge `a ruler'
    \so Num.13.2; Ex.22.28; Jer.51.46
    \ge `a nobleman'
    \so Jn.4.46
    = |mushóshketomp|    Mass.Ps.

    (|nanauonnuónat| `to rule or govern'; |nânâwanumeeh| `keep thou me'    C.).

[Narragansett [xnt] |neen nanowwúnneinun| `I oversee, I look to or keep'; |naunóuwheant| (and |nanouwétea|) `a keeper or nurse, an overseer and orderer (of their worship)'    R.W.52,112.]

\lx nanó
\va nano
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 77
\ps used as an adverb of comparison / PreV
\ge `(it increases) more and more, increasingly', +`to be waxen'
    \xv nano missi
    \xe it increases (becomes more and more great)
    \so Job 10.16
    \xv nano m∞natash
    \xe they (inan.) increase in number, are more, many
    \so Ezra 9.6
    \xv Kah Jesus nano waantam, kah monchaétu:...
    \xe And Jesus increased in wisdom and stature, ...
    \so Lk.2.52
    \xv ... ummishont∞waongan∞ nano missi...
    \xe ... the cry of them is waxen great...
    \so Gen.19.13
    \nt +

    (|nânô| `moreover'    C.)
    \xv nanomwonkquaeu nano nunkquaash
    \xe heaps upon heaps
    \so Judg.15.16.

\lx nanompananumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 77
    \nt +
\ps TA, mental final
\ge ?
\so -

    \se nanompananumóonk
    \ps NI, deverbal noun
    \ge `anguish'
    \so Gen.42.21
    \xv .... naumog wunnanompananumóonk ukketeahogkounoh ...
    \xe ..., in that we saw the anguish of his soul, ...
    \so Gen.42.21


\lx nanompanwau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 77
    \nt +
\ps AI(+O?), long-vowel
\ge `to intreat'
\so C.57/195
\nt G&B.656, s.v. |(nun)nanabannomun|.
    \xv Nunnashaonk uppen∞antamun nummittamwos, tôkonogque nanompanwonah wutche nehenwonche nunnogkussée neechanog.
    \xe My breath is strange to my wife, though I entreated for the children's sake of mine own body.'    Job 19.17  { 1->3
    \so objective? }
    \nt ?+
    \xv Nunnânompa@nwam, -wap.
    \xe I intreat, or did
    \xv Nunnannompanwamun, -nonup.
    \xe We intreat, or did
    \xv Nunnâmpanwonat.
    \xe To intreat

    \se nanompanwonshau
    \ps TA, representative final
    \ge `to entreat for sb'
    \so Ex.8.9,28; 1 Sam.2.25
    \xv ... qut wesketomp matcheneheont Jehovah, howan woh wunnanompanwonshuh? ...
    \xe ...: but if a man sin against the LORD, who shall entreat for him? ...'    1 Sam.2.25  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    \xv ... uttoh adt nanompanwonshin kah wutch kittinnúmog, kah wutch kummissinninnúmog, onk woh nuttummehtâhwhóog tinnogkuhteaog ...
    \xe ...: when shall I entreat for thee, and for thy servants, and for thy people, to destroy the frogs ...
    \so Ex.8.9
    \ng 1->2 (changed) conjunct

    \xv ...: nanompanwánshek:
    \xe ...: entreat for me.
    \so Ex.8.28
    \ng 2p->1 imperative


\lx nanompassumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 77
\ps TA (TA+O?), oral final, ?to AI stem
\ge `he supplicates of, entreats (him)'; +`to beseech, press upon, urge sb' { "supplicate" very rare, |wehquetum-| being the usual rendering }
\so Gen.42.21; Ruth 1.16
\nt G&B.656, s.v. |(kun)nanabassummunnumun|.
    \xv ...kah ummenuhke nanompassumoh, kah wunnemunumun.
    \xe .... And he urged him, and he took it.
    \so Gen.33.11
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Woi GOD kenanompassumsh noh neetskeh yeuyeu.
    \xe ..., Heal her now, O God, I beseech thee.
    \so Num.12.13
    \ng 1->2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut onch mat nunnamp∞hamauoh, qut woh nunnanompassum n∞sittumwaen.
    \xe Whom, ..., yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.
    \so Job 9.15
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nunnanumpassum Wut∞shimau, kah kittinnumunkou onkatoge Taphuaenúh,...
    \xe And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you another Comforter,...
    \so Jn.14.16√; (M) |nunnanompassum|
    \xv wunn∞che nanopasumóuh
    \xe they began to entreat him
    \so Mk.5.17; (E1) |nanompasumóuh|
    \ng correctly
    \xv ..., kenanampassumukqun, n∞wau, wussumukquean nuppabuhtanumukqunat en LORD ut, peyunk nekit onk na appek,...
    \xe ..., she besought us, saying, If ye have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come into my house, and abide there. ...
    \so Act 16.15
    \ng 3->1p
    (|Kenânompassumush.| `I pray, or intreat you'    C.69/204) { 1->2 }
    (|Kenânompassu@wunümw∞.| `I intreat you'    C.57/195) { G&B.656 emends |-w-| to |-m-|; 1->2p }

    \xv ... nanompassumunog,...
    \xe ..., when he besought us,...
    \so Gen.42.21
    \ng 1(p)->2(p) conjunct [!]
    \nt +

    \xv ..., nanompassum∞k Jehovah, onk woh nutamaunumunk tinnogkuhteasu,...
    \xe ..., Entreat the LORD, that he may take away the frogs from me,...
    \so Ex.8.8
    \ng 2p->3 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ahque nanompassumeh kenukkonununat,...
    \xe ..., Entreat me not to leave thee,...
    \so Ruth 1.16
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \nt +

    \se !|nanompassittum|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1b, oral final
    \ge `to entreat sth'
    \so Ps.119.58(M); Prov.19.6
    \xv Nunnanompassuttumup kuskesuk nashpe mamusse nuttah:...
    \xe I intreated thy favour with my whole heart:...
    \so Ps.119.58(M); (E) |Nanómpassum|
    \xv Monaog nanompassittumwog ukkitteamonteanitteaonk sontim:...
    \xe Many will entreat the favour of the prince:...
    \so Prov.19.6

    \xv ..., yeuyeu nanompsitch wuskesuk Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m, kah peantamwansheh,...
    \xe ..., Entreat now the face of the LORD thy God, and pray for me,...
    \so 1 K.13.6; (E1) |nanompasitch|
    \ng |-tch-| for syncopated |-tush|

    \se !|nanompasittumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to entreat to sb for sb'
    \so Gen.23.8

    \xv ..., n∞tiegk, kah nanompasittumaiegk Ephron wunnaumonuh Zohar.
    \xe ..., hear me, and entreat for me to Ephron the son of Zohar.
    \so Gen.23.8
    \ng 2p->1+3 imperative, as if "entreat E. for me"

    Other stems:
    \nt +
    \xv Nannompassittinneat.
    \xe To be intreated
    \so C.57/195

\cf nanumpassumau

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 77

\lx nanwe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 77
\ps adv. and adj.
\ge `common [from |nan| `the same, such as'], general, usual, normal'; hence `native or indigenous', as opposed to |penôwe| `strange, foreign, of another kind'
    \xv nanwe missinninnuog
    \xe common people
    \so Mk.12.37
    \xv -- petukquneg
    \xe common bread
    \xv Nanwe wut-Epistleum IUDE.
    \xe THE GENERALL Epistle of Iude.
    \so √
    `Any body' |Nanwe, howan, auwon.|    C.20/167
    \nt +
    `Any man, any wood' |Nanwe wosketomp, nanwe mishash.|    C.20/167
    \nt +
    `Common people' |Nanwe missinninnüog.|    C.21/168
    \nt +
    `Fit for any thing' |u@nauwöhkon, nanweteag,|    C.22/169
    \nt +
    `General' |Nanwe mamusseyeue.|    C.23/170
    \nt +
    `Thankfull for any thing' |Tabattântam∞e, wutche nanwe, teag.|    C.30/176
    \nt +
    `Any man, any wood' |Nanwi woske, nanwe wuttuhgunash.|    C.107d/232
    \nt +
    `Neither, either' |Mattane, nanwe.|    C.110/234 { under "Conjunctions" }
    \nt +
    `Humour no man for his wealth; do nothing sinfully to please any.' |Wauwehkeögish matta wosketomp wuthe wuttahennetimuk teagua; ussëkon matcheseäe, wussikke@teahönat nanwee.|    C.115/237
    \nt +
    `I wish such an one would come and set down on my land, I would be kind to him as long as I have any thing.' |Nâpehnont neahhenissit peyont kah appit nuttohkëit. Woh nooneunneh tô sâhke ahtou nanwe teag.|    C.120/240
    \nt +

\cf nnih
\cf nnìn

[Delaware [del] |lenni| `original (?), common'; |lenni m'bi| `pure water'; |len-achpoan| `common bread'; |lenachsinnall| `common stones'    Hkw.; |lenee| `common', "applied to such objects of nature or of art as are of common occurrence"; |lenee aughkweeyun| "common cloth, such as the
Indians ordinarily use,"    Cass in N.A. Review, No. 50, p. 68.
Western Abenaki [abe] |areni|; |areni 8damañ| `du petun [tabac] commun du pays'; |nedarenañd8"é| `je parle Abnaqui'; |arenañpe| [= Del. |len-âpé|], homo (|séénañpé| vir).
Mic. |ln8| `man'.
The Iroquois equivalent is |on8é| e.g. "onk8é on8é, sauvage, homme vrai."]

\lx nanwiyeu
\va nanwayeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he wanders about (has no specified place), strays'; +`to spread abroad; to be disorderly, lawless, unruly; to be scattered abroad'
    \so Gen.10.10; Ex.5.12; Ps.109.10; Mt.9.36; Acts 5.36,37,8.1,4,11.19; 1 Thes.5.14; 1 Tim.1.9; Heb.11.37,38
    \nt +
    pl. |-yeuog| `they wander' ("through all the mountains"    Ezek.34.6)
    \xv ..., kah wame weechaiyeumohpoh, nanwayeuwog, onk en tuppayeog
    \xe ...; and all, as many as obeyed him, were scattered, and brought to nought.
    \so Acts 5.36
    \nt +

    \xv ..., qut woh mohmóunneau pasuk∞uneat wunuaumonuh [sic] GOD neh nanwyinutcheh.
    \xe ..., but that also he should gather together in one the children of God that were scattered abroad.
    \so Jn.11.52; (M): |naswayeuehpaneg|
    \ng for |nan-|?
    \nt +
    \xv Yowutche nag nanwaècheg, nanonáog, kah kuhk∞tomuhteáog.
    \xe Therefore they that were scattered abroad went everywhere preaching the word.
    \so Acts 8.4
    \ng |nanonáog| with same initial?
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kenanompassumunumun neemattinnónog samwutteaháhuk neg nanwiitcheg:...
    \xe Now we exhort you, brethren, warn them that are unruly,...
    \so 1 Thess.5.14
    \nt +

    \xv Wunneechan∞oh nagwutteaeu nanwaihettich kah wenshaunitch,...
    \xe Let his children be continually vagabonds, and beg:...
    \so Ps.109.10; (M): |nanwaihittitch|; |wenshaunitch| correct in (M): |wenshahhitich|
    \nt +

    \se !|nanwiheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ps `to scatter sb (abroad)'
    \so Gen.11.9,49.7
    \xv ..., nag nutchippunôog ut Jakobut, káh nunnanwiheáog ut Israelut.
    \xe ...: I will divide them in Jakob, and scatter them in Israel.
    \so Gen.49.7
    \ng 1->3p objective

    \se |nanwiyeue|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `wandering; disorderly'
    \xv nanwiyeue wusken qushkeu
    \xe the wandering youth returns
    \so Lk.15.18, headline (reading of 1st ed.)
    \xv ... woh kutamohkauonanout nishnoh ∞wemattin noh nanwiyeue pamushadt,..
    \xe ..., that ye withdraw yourselves from every brother that walketh disorderly,...
    \so 2 Thess.3.6

    \se !|nanwiweseu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \ge `to be disorderly'
    \so 2 Thess.3.11
    \xv Newutche n∞tamumun náwutche kenugke kenaau nanwiweseog matta anakauseog, qut n∞numimauog.
    \xe For we hear that there are some which walk among you disorderly, working not at all, but are busybodies.
    \so 2 Thess.3.11

    \se nanwusshau
    \va nanwushau
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \ge `he wanders', i.e. `is lost'
    \so C.; +Gen.20.13,21.14; Ps.55.7(M),59.15(M),107.4,119.176(M)
    \dv With |sh| of involuntary action or mischance; +more probably |-uhsh-á/ô-| `to go, walk'.
    \xv ... GOD ayimungquean nanwúshon wutch weekit n∞sh,...
    \xe ..., when God caused me to wander from my father's house,...
    \so Gen.20.13
    \ng proleptic object, with X subordinative; c.f. derived causative used by Mayhew, Ps.107.40

    \se !|nanwushaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to cause sb to wander'
    \so Ps.107.40(M)
    |Sookunumauau sontimuh meshananittuonk, kah wunnanwushshahheuh ut touohkomukqut, uttuh mo adt maynook.| `He poureth contempt upon princes: and causeth them to wander in the wilderness, where there is no way.    Ps.107.40(M)

    \nt Remark: Whether there is a relationship to |nanwe| remains to be investigated. There is an initial of the form |nasw-| that appears to be synonymous with |nanw-|, and replaces it in Gen.10.15(E2) as compared with the earlier versions.
    \nt +

    [??Fx. |nano∙⌠kwe| `at random'    Fx.L.116.]
    \nt +

\lx nashaue
\va nashaueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
\ps prep. / PreN
    \nt Remark: The translation commonly has |nashaue| before both members of the conjoined object of AV, calquing on the Hebrew text (and LXX); see e.g. Gen.13.3 infr.
    \nt +
\ge `between'; +usually spatial, rarely temporal
\so Dan.8.5; Mic.7.14
    `in the middle'    Jer.39.3;
    \xv ..., ne ohkeit weske wadt∞tap nashauwe Bethel, kah nashauwe Hai.
    \xe ..., unto the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Bethel and Hai;
    \so Gen.13.3
    \nt +
    \xv nashaue mayash
    \xe between the passages
    \so 1 Sam.14.4√
    \xv nanashaue nenawun kah ken
    \xe between us and you
    \so Lk.16.26√
    \ng mistranslation!
    \xv nanohkontap nashaue neeninash
    \xe I am in a strait betwixt two
    \so Phil.1.23
    \xv ne penowomái nashawe ummittamwussin kah penomp
    \xe there is a difference between a wife and a virgin
    \so 1 Cor.7.34
    \xv nashaue ken kah nagum
    \xe between thee and him
    \so Mt.18.15
    \xv Neit nanashaûe mishadtupp∞onk, Jesus kuhkúhqueu en Templeut,...
    \xe Now about the midst of the feast Jesus went up into the temple,...
    \so Jn.7.14; (M) |papaume nanashaue|
    \ng temporal
    \nt +

\cf nishwe
\cf nashwe
\cf nashwe
\cf nashaue
\cf neese
\ge in the middle', and |nishwe| or |nashwe|
\ge . To the latter (|nashwe|) |nashaue| is nearly related, as are both these to |neese| `two
\nt `in the middle', and  or  `third'. To the latter ()  is nearly related, as are both these to  `two'

\lx nashpe
\va nashpeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
\ps prep. / PreN, initial (see entry below)
\ge `by means of, by, with (an inan. agent, instrument, etc.)'
\nt G&B.660
\so Ps.78.26; 1 Chr.12.33-37; Eccl.2.1

    \se !|nashpeu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), prepositional object, long-vowel final
    \ge `for sth to be with sb, bearing sth, to have sb/sth with one, to carry, take (sb/sth with one), to travel with sb'
    \so Gen.46.5; Ps.126.6(M); Mt.15.30; Mk.6.8; 2 Cor.8.19; Rev.22.12
    \xv ..., kah wunnaumonuh Jsarel nashpeog Jakoboh ∞sh∞oh, kah ummukkieseum∞oh, kah ummìttamwuss∞oh, tatuppequanumukkâhtu, Pharaoh ne negonshhuapash wunnayeumukqunat.
    \xe ...: and the sons of Israel carried Jacob their father, and their little ones, and their wives, in the wagons which Pharaoh had sent to carry him.
    \so Gen.46.5
    \xv Kah monaog monacheg uppeyauunóuh, nashpeog yeuh, quanukquesunutcheh, pogkenumunutcheh, mo kaket∞gig, wosketahhósitcheg, kah monaog onkatoganeg,...
    \xe And great multitudes came unto him, having with them those that were lame, blind, dumb, maimed, and many others,...
    \so Mt.15.30
    \xv Kah nah wuttinann∞nuh matcháog wunnashpenaôont ut uppomushaonganóut, qut webe anwohhou;...
    \xe And commanded them that they should take nothing for their journey, save a staff only;...
    \so Mk.6.8
    \xv Kah kusseh, teanuk nuppeam, kah nutonkquatunk nunnashpem nuttinnumauónat nish noh wosketomp, ne pish áunag wutanákausuonk.
    \xe And, behold, I come quickly; and my reward is with me, to give every man according as his work shall be.
    \so Rev.22.12

    \xv ... mechum, ne woh adtashinashpehettit,...
    \xe ... food, as much as they can carry,...
    \so Gen.44.1
    \ng 3p->0^_adv_ participle, with relative root preverb
    \xv Noh suhhog kah mog, nashpet mushshoatue wuskanem,...
    \xe He that goeth forth and weepeth, bearing precious seed,...
    \so Ps.126.6(M)

[Quiripi [qyp] |spe|    Pier.
Delaware [del] |nachpi|; |naxp-| initial `with, in addition,...',    Zeisb.; O'M.189a-190a.]

\et G.1981, 19, 64: *naΘpi `with'; no cognates given.


\lx nashpe-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge `by, with, ...'
\so local entries
\nt Remark: Other possible cases:
    \xv kenashpekompau wunnamptamóonk
    \xe thou standest by faith
    \so Rom.11.20
    \ng indistinguishable from preverb
    \nt ?
    \xv yeush wunnashpwussukwhósinash
    \xe these things were written of him
    \so Jn.12.16
    \ng failure to lose initial {w-} suggests that this is a mere "loose compound" of some sort?


\lx nashpeki-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
    \nt +
\ps AI
\ge `to grow in/by sth'
\dv |nashpe| initial + |-ki-| AI `to grow'
\so 1 Pet.2.2, 2 Pet.3.18
    \xv Onatuh mishketuog kodtantam∞k pahke sogkodtungane wuttinnowáonk, onk woh kenashpekinneau.
    \xe As newborn babes, desire the sincere milk of the word, tht ye may grow thereby:
    \so 1 Pet.2.2

    \xv Qut nashpekegk kitteamonteanittuonk,...
    \xe But grow in grace,...
    \so 2 Pet.3.18

    \se nashpekeheau
    \va nashpekiaheau
    \nt !
    \ps TA, causative to lemma
    \ge "to make sb grow by sth"
    \so Log.Pr.67/79
    \nt Remark: Perhaps two forms reflect alternative derivations from the AI and II stems (with the overt inanimate subject in the minor premise attracting the form of the stem into the inanimate??)
    |{Oggus.} 1. Ne nashpekhikqueog woh nukkodtantamumun.
    Qut wuttinn∞waonk kenashpekinahikqun.
    Newaj woh nukodtantamumun.| "{Syllogism} 1: We should desire that by which we are made to grow. But the word makes us grow. Therefore we should desire it."    Log.Pr.67/79

[Abn. s.v. croître, naître? e.g. |nenespíghin| `Je crois avec cela'    R.150/425b.
Delaware [del] |naxpíikuw| `grow up with s.o.'    O'M.189b.]


\lx nashpishau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
    \nt +
\ps AI+O?
\ge `to catch sb/sth away'
\dv Presumably the initial |nashpe-| + |-uhsh-á-| of "smooth movement", flight
\so Mt.13.19, Acts 8.39
    \xv ..., neit peyau matchetuk, kah wunnashpshan ne ohketeaumukup ut wuttahhut, ...
    \xe ..., then cometh the wicked one, and catcheth away that which was sown in his heart. ...
    \so Mt.13.19
    \xv Onk wamohettit nippekontu, Nashauanit nashpishau Phillipoh, eunuch matta wonk wunnauoh, onk monchu muskouántam.
    \xe And when they were come up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip, that the eunuch saw him no more: and he went on his way rejoicing.
    \so Acts 8.39

[Delaware [del] |naxpíhleew| AI+O `to grab s.t., seize and take s.t. along'    O'M.189b.]


\lx nashqunánum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge (with |n∞tau|) `he kindles' (a fire)
\so Lam.4.11
    \xv nunnashqunánum n∞teau
    \xe I kindle a fire
    \so Jer.21.14; 43.12; 49.27

    \nt MN: ..., noh nashqunnánug n∞tau,...
    \ng suppositive |..., noh nashqunnánug n∞tau,...| `... he that kindled the fire...'    Ex.22.6√


\lx nashquneau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 78
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it burns'; +to be kindled'
    \xv n∞tau nashquneau
    \xe a fire burns, "is kindled"
    \so Deut.32.22; Jer.15.14
    \xv Kah Balak ummusquantam∞onk nashqunnau ayeuuhkone Balaam,...
    \xe And Balak's anger was kindled against Balaam,...
    \so Num.24.10
    \nt +

    \se nashqunáe
    \va nashqunáeu
    \nt +
    \ps Adv. & Adj. / PreN, PreV
    \ge `burning'
    \xv nashqunáe n∞tau
    \xe burning fire
    \so Dan.7.9
    \xv -- mohkossaash
    \xe burning coals
    \so Ps.140.10
    \xv -- missechuog
    \xe red-hot iron
    \so Indian Laws, I

\et perhaps with II final *-eΘ-e∙- `blaze, burn', G.1980.144 [11th Alg.Conf.]; cf also: ?Alg. |-AKONE| `feu, flamme', Cq.33b; ?Del. |naxkw-| `on fire', O'M.188b-189a.


\lx nashqussum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 79
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he lights (a lamp, candle, torch, etc.), he sets it on fire'
    (`kindles a fire'    Jer.17.27)
    pret. |-umup lampsash| `he lighted the lamps'    Ex.8.3 { erroneous ref. }
    \xv Asuh howae mittamwossis, piogqunneohtunk silver wannehteunk pasuk, matta nasqussum∞ wequananteg, kah chekham∞ wetu,...
    \xe Either what woman having ten pieces of silver, if she lose one piece, doth not light a candle, and sweep the house,...
    \so Lk.15.8
    \nt +

    \nt MN: nashqussuk wequananteg
    \ng suppositive |nashqussuk wequananteg| `when he lights a candle'    Lk.8.16


\lx nashqutteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 79
\ps v.i. / TI2-O ?
\ge `it burns, it is burning'
    \xv n∞n∞náe nashqutteau
    \xe it burns with a flame, "a flame burneth"
    \so Joel 2.3

    \nt MN: ne nashquttag
    \ng suppositive |ne nashquttag| `that which burns, fire'
    \xv onatuh wuttuhq en nashquttag
    \xe as wood to fire
    \so Prov.26.21
\nt Of all these forms the base is the name of fire which Williams writes |sqútta|, but which is not used separately as a substantive by Eliot. Of the three names for fire which appear to have been most frequently used, |n∞tau| or |n∞teau| was apparently restricted to fire kindled for domestic use or for the service of man; |chikoht| (Narr. |chíckot|), from |cheke| `fierce, violent', to fire as a power or in action; and |nashqutta| (|sqútta|, R.W.) as nearly equivalent to our characterization of "the devouring element," or fire as an enemy.
\cf nashquttin

[Narragansett [xnt] |sqútta| `fire'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |sk8'ta^i| `feu'; |sk8ta8"io| `il y en a'.    Rasles 248/455a.]√

\so Is.28.2; 29.6

    \nt MN: nashquit
    \ng suppositive |nashquit| Job 27.21
    (|nashquittin| `a northerly storm or a tempest'    C.)

    \nt Remark: The relationship of this item, if any, to |nanw-|, which has a similar sense, is unclear. Any proto-language palatalizing environment has been obliterated.
    \nt +


\lx natauwaheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 79
    \nt +
\ps TA
\twn |natauwahtou|
\ge `to visit sb' (in the typical AV uses)
\ge `to spy' (intransitive, but not formally distinct?)
\so Gen.21.1,50.24,25; Ex.3.16; Ps.17.3; Mt.25.36; Lk.1.78; Acts 7.23, ...
\so Gen.42.9,11,14,16,30,31,34; Josh.2.1
    \xv ONK Jehovah nátauwáhheau Sarahoh ne án∞wop,...
    \xe AND the LORD visited Sarah as he had said,...
    \so Gen.21.1
    \ng (E0&1) |nátawóhhau|
    \xv ..., sohham natauwóhhau wuttaunneunk ne ohkeit.
    \xe ..., [she] went out to see the daughters of the land.
    \so Gen.34.1
    \xv ..., kenaau kenatauaheámw∞ ...
    \xe ..., Ye are spies;...
    \so Gen.42.9
    \xv Kah Joseph unnau wematoh, nunnup, kah GOD natauwahuadt kenatauwáhukou, kah kummoncheahukou yeu wutch ohkit,...
    \xe And Joseph said unto his brethren, I die: and God will surely visit you, and bring you out of this land ...
    \so Gen.50.24
    \ng on |natauwahuadt|, v.i.; in "cognate preverb" construction; see also Ex.3.16,13.19 with the familiar type of preverb.
    \xv ...,  natauwáhuwae kenátauwáhennúmwop, kah ne ánhenóg ut Egypt.
    \xe ..., I have surely visited you, and seen that which is done to you in Egypt:
    \so Ex.3.16
    \xv Kah Joshua wunnnaumonuh Nun, ann∞nau neesuoh wosketompoh wutch Shittim, keme natauwohheônat,...
    \xe And Joshua the son of Nun sent out of Shittim two men to spy secretly,...
    \so Josh.2.1
    \xv ..., newutche n∞tam ut ohkit Moab, Jehovah natauwaheau ummissinninneumoh, wuttinnumauoh petukqunnunk.
    \xe ...: for she had heard in the country of Moab how that the Lord had visited his people in giving them bread.
    \so Ruth 1.6
    \xv Mó nupposkis, kah kuthogqussimwop, mô nummahchinam kah kenatauwahimw∞,... ..., nummahchinop kah nukkupshagkinosip & matta kenatah∞mwop.
    \xe Naked, and ye clothed me: I was sick, and ye visited me:......: sick, and in prison, and ye visited me not.
    \so Mt.25.36+43

    \xv ..., kah n∞tamohettit Jehovah nadtauwaheont wunnaumonuh Israel, kah kahkinneog ∞tammehpunnaongan∞oash, neit nauwanumwog uppuhkuk∞∞ash, kah nauwaeog.
    \xe ...: and when they heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel, and that he had looked upon their affliction, then they bowed their heads and worshipped.
    \so Ex.4.31
    \xv Howan wosketomp woh mehquanumadt? kah wosketomp wunnaumonuh woh nadtauheadt?
    \xe What is man that thou art mindful of him? and the son of man that thou visitest him?
    \so Ps.8.4; (M): |nadtauheadt|

    \xv Mequanumeh woi Jehovah, nashpe kukkitteamonteanumaonk kummissinninnumog: woi nattouwahhe nashpe k∞wadchanuwaonk.
    \xe Remember me, O Lord, with the favour that thou bearest unto thy people: O visit me with thy salvation!
    \so Ps.106.4; (M): |nattauwahhe|

    \se natauwahuau
    \ps AI, indefinite object final
    \ge `to visit'
    \so Gen.50.24,25

    \xv ... GOD natauwahuadt pish kenatauwahukou,...
    \xe ..., God will surely visit you,...
    \so Gen.50.25
    \ng 3 conjunct

\et A member of the large family of derivatives of the initial *nat(a)w- `seek, try', as H.2174-2206; the final to |wah-| `know'. These perhaps yield the apparently divergent senses fairly naturally.

    \nt +

\twn |natauwaheau|
\ge `to visit sth' (in the typical AV uses)
\ge `to view sth, spy out sth'
\so Ex.20.5,32.24,34.7, Lev.18.25, Ps.65.9,80.14,89.32

    \xe And the land is defiled: therefore I do visit the iniquity thereof upon it, and the land itself vomiteth out her inhabitants.

\lx natinneahkoNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 79
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative
\ge `to search sb', i.e. "to carry out a search of sb"
\so Ps.139.1,23
    \xv WOi Jehovah, kenátinneakósip kah k∞wáheh.
    \xe O LORD, thou hast searched me, and known me.
    \so Ps.19.1  { 2->1, preterite }; (M) |kunnatinneahkosip|

    \xv Natinnekóseh, woi num-Manitt∞m, kah wahteaush nuttah:...
    \xe Search me, O God, and know my heart:...
    \so Ps.139.23  { 2->1 }; (M) |Natinneahkoseh|

    \se !|natinneahkontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative
    \ge `to search (out) sth'
    \so Gen.31.34,37; Deut.1.24,13,14l Josh.2.2,3; Jn.5.39; Acts 17.11; Rom.8.27; 1 Cor.2.10
    \xv ...: kah Laban natinneukontam wame wek, qut matta wunnámheuh.
    \xe .... And Laban searched all the tent, but found them not.
    \so Gen.31.34
    \xv ..., newutche nag peyaog natinneakontamunat wame ohke.
    \xe ...: for they be come to search out all the country.
    \so Josh.2.3

    \xv Kah noh natinneakontog metahhash,...
    \xe And he that searcheth the hearts ...
    \so Rom.8.27

    \xv Natinnekóntam∞k wussukwhonganash ...
    \xe Search the scriptures;...
    \so Jn.5.39; (M) |Natinneahkontam∞k|

    \se -adtinnekontam
    \ps de-stem derivative
    \so Ps.145.3(E&M)
    \xv ...: kah ummissugken∞wonk, mat woh {howan} uppogkodadttinnekóntam∞un.
    \xe ...: and his greatness is unsearchable.
    \so Ps.145.3(E1&2)
    \ng 3->0 negative objective

\lx nat∞tomau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 79
\ps v.t. an. / TA, oral final { Does this exist?--cognates suggest it does. }
\ge `he questions (him), asks (him) a question

    \xv ..., noh tápukken, nat∞tumók,...
    \xe ...; he is of age, ask him,...
    \so Jn.9.21 (M) |nat∞tumohk|
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt ?+

    \se nat∞tamauau
    \va nat∞tomauau
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to ask sb (sth), to require sth of sb'
    \so Mt.16.13; +Gen.40.7,43.7
    \xv ..., na nat∞tomungqunnonog ket∞homaonk,...
    \xe ... there [they] required of us a song;...
    \so Ps.137.3; (M): |nohnattuttumonkqunnanonup|
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wunnat∞tomauau ∞shoh,...
    \xe And he asked his father, ...
    \so Mk.9.21
    \nt +
    |-mauoh|    Mt.22.35

    \xv Kah kenaumon nat∞tomungquean, ompetak, an∞wadt, Toh nauwuttam∞∞ wauwaongash,...?
    \xe And when thy son asketh thee in time to come, saying, What mean the testimonies,...?
    \so Deut.6.20
    \nt +

    \se nat∞tomuhkau
    \va -uhk-á-
    \ps with the characteristic (|-hk|) of continued action; / AI, indefinite final (G&B. no. 14, 580).
    \ge `he makes inquiries, goes on asking questions (of him)', +`to ask after, make inquiry for sth; enquire'
    \so common
    \nt +
    infinit. |..., nat∞tomuhkonat papaume Judah kah Jerusalem,...| `..., to inquire concerning Judah and Jerusalem,...'    Ezra 7.14√  { X t-subordinative }
    \xv ... nag wosketompáog ..., nát∞tamuhteápanneg wek Symon,
    \xe ..., the men...had made inquiry for Simon's house,...
    \so Acts 10.17
    \ng 3p preterite indicative
    \nt +

    \xv ..., Tohwutch nat∞tomuhteaan n∞wesuonk?...
    \xe ..., Wherefore is it that thou dost ask after my name?...
    \so Gen.32.29
    \ng 2->0+_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Nat∞tomohteadt nuskehteáonk ...
    \xe When he maketh inquisition for blood,...
    \so Ps.9.12
    \ng 3->_adv_ conjunct (subjunctive); (E1) |nushehteaonk|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onatuh woh pahke nat∞tomuhteaog ne teag papaume yeuoh,...
    \xe ..., as though ye would inquire something more perfectly concerning him:...
    \so Acts 23.15
    \ng 2p->0 conjunct
    \nt +

    \xv ..., nat∞tomuhteagk howan tapenuk,...
    \xe ..., enquire who in it is worthy,...
    \so Mt.10.11
    \ng 2p imperative

    \se !|nat∞tomuhteaong(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, deverbal
    \ge `question'
    \so common
    \xv ..., Neen wonk kenat∞tomauonumw∞ pasuk nat∞tomuhteaonk,...
    \xe ..., I will also ask of you one question,...
    \so Mk.11.29

    \se nat∞tomuhteaonganu
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge "to be a question"
    \so 1 Cor.10.25

    \xv Nish noh teag magun adt kodtauwompasimuk, meetsek, matta nat∞tomuhteaonganìnn∞g newutche metahhannit.
    \xe Whatsoever is sold in the shambles, that eat, asking no question for conscience sake:
    \so 1 Cor.10.25
    \ng 0 negative conjunct (existential sense)

    \se |nat∞tomoNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative final
    \ge `to examine sb'
    \so 1 Cor.9.3

    \xv Nunnamp∞hamauwaonk neg nat∞tomasitcheg yeu.
    \xe Mine answer to them that do examine me is this:
    \so 1 Cor.9.3
    \ng _3p_->1 participle

[Narragansett [xnt] |Kunnatotemì?| `Doe you aske me?'; |Nnatotemúckaun.| `I will aske the way.'; |Nétop Kunnatótemous.| `Friend, I will aske you a Question.'    R.W.68; 123/r.131.√

    \nt +

\lx natt∞hqus
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 79
\ps NA
\ge `a wolf'
\so Jn.10.12
    (|natt∞qussuog| `wolves'    C.)
    \xv Ontoquos
    \xe a Wolfe
    \so Wood

\lx náum
\va naum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 79
\ps v.i./ TI3
\ge `he sees'
\so Job 28.24; Mt.12.22
\ps t.inan. / TI3
\ge `he sees (it)'
\nt G&B.524-525, etc.; 661
\so Job 34.21
    \xv nunnaum
    \xe I see
    \so Jer.1.11; Jn.9.25
    \xv ... pish naumun.
    \xe ... it shall be seen.
    \so Gen.21.14
    \ng X->0 objective
    \nt +

    \nt MN: nag
    \ng suppositive |nag| `when he sees (it)'    Gen.42.1; 3.6
    \ng 3->0 conjunct
    \xv ... wame ne ohke nauma(n) ...
    \xe ... all the land which thou seest,...
    \so Gen.13.15
    \ng 2->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., naumon kuskesuk,...
    \xe ..., since I have seen thy face,...
    \so Gen.46.30
    \ng 1->0 subjunctive
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ishkont k∞wanantam n nish, kuskesukquash nagkupash:...
    \xe ..., lest thou forget the things which thine eyes have seen,...
    \so Deut.4.9
    \ng 0p->_0p_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    |naik|    Mt.21.19

    imperat. 2d sing. |naish|, |naush|, |násh|
    pl. |naum∞k| `see, behold'
    \xv ..., Ahque naumutti wunnupp∞onk wusken,...
    \xe ..., , Let me not see the death of the child. ...
    \so Gen.21.16
    \ng 1->0 imperative
    \nt +

    \se náum∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `sight'
    \so Deut.28.67; Lk.4.18

    \se !|naum∞m∞|
    \nt +
    \ps TI(-O), inanimate subject
    \dv final |-m8u-|, G&B. no.16, 580-581
    \ps `to see (sth)'
    \so Gen.45.12
    \xv ..., kuskesuk∞∞ash naum∞m∞ash,...
    \xe ..., your eyes see,..., that ...
    \so Gen.45.12
    \ng 0p->0 indicative

    \se nâau
    \va nauau
\ps With an. obj. / TA
    \ge `he sees (him)', +`to behold sb'
    \so Gen.42.7; Jn.1.29
    \xv ..., Egiptianog wunnauôuh mittumwussis nikkôme wuneetu.
    \xe ..., the Egyptians beheld the woman, that she was very fair.'    Gen.12.14  { 3p->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    with affixes, |kenáeh| `thou seest me'    Gen.16.13 { 2->1 indicative }
    \xv ..., newutche kenaush sampweusseaen ut anaquabeh, yeu pometuonkanit.
    \xe ...; for thee have I seen righteous before me in this generation.
    \so Gen.7.1
    \ng 1->2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nunnonche nau ash na nupp∞omp.
    \xe ...: I will go and see him before I die.
    \so Gen.45.28
    \ng 1->3 objective
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ken Jehovah mamuskesukque kenait,...
    \xe ..., that thou Lord art seen face to face,...
    \so Num.14.14
    \ng X->2
    \nt +
    \xv Kah asse nunnogq, quinuppu ut anaquabeh nishwudt nompe:...
    \xe And the ass saw me, and turned from me these three times:...
    \so Num.22.33
    \ng 3->1
    \nt +
    \xv ..., mahshe kodtantamóg kenainneananonut, neyane nenawun wonk kenáunnunnanónut.
    \xe ..., [ye] desiring greatly to see us, as we also to see you:
    \so 1 Thess.3.6
    \ng 2p->1p (with extra |-na-|, on th model of the latter?); 1p->2p
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh na wutch nauon uhquae missinninnúh.
    \xe ..., that thence he might see the utmost part of the people.
    \so Num.22.41
    \ng X->3, subordinative
    \nt +

    \nt MN: nauont
    \ng suppositive |nauont| `when he sees (him)'    2 K.4.25
    \xv noh naiit
    \xe he who seeth me
    \so Jn.12.45; 14.9
    \xv ..., Sun nunnatinneah noh nógqueh?
    \xe ..., Have I also here looked after him that seeth me?'    Gen.16.13  { _3
    \so _->1 participle }
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche pish n nih Egyptiansog nogquean, n∞waog yeuh ummittumwussoh ...
    \xe Therefore it shall come to pass, when the Egyptians shall see thee, that they shall say, This is his wife:...
    \so Gen.12.12
    \ng 3->2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., noh matta howan mahche nauongeh, asuh woh nauoncheh,...
    \xe ...; whom no man hath seen, nor can see:...
    \so 1 Tim.6.16
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche chequnehtam neyane nauut, noh matta woh nauôut.
    \xe ...: for he endured, as seeing him who is invisible.
    \so Heb.11.27
    \ng i.e. X-subj. not replaced by |-(u)k| in negative (even though the verb is clearly negative in form? (c.f. G&B 561)
    \nt +
    \xv ...: [ne]wutche wut-Egyptianseog neg nauógeg yeu kesukok, matta pish wonk kenauoog micheme.
    \xe ...: for the Egyptians whom ye have seen today, ye shall see them again no more for ever.
    \so Ex.14.13
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d pl. |nôk|    Is.42.1
    |n∞wau, peyaush, natitteuh.| "Come, let vs see one another in the face."    2 Chr.25.17  { 12 imperative to reciprocal }
    \nt +

    \se !|naumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem
    \ge "to see sb's sth", with |-aw-| as "dative of possession" (often with body part terms, even though this may well not have been idiomatic?); `to see sth with sb'
    \so Lev.13.14,20.17; Deut.16.4
    \nt Remark: Speculative entry at present
    \xv Kah na matta pish seane petukqunneg kenaumonteoh, ut wame kutohtimóin,...
    \xe And there shall be no leavened bread seen with thee in all thy coast seven days;...
    \so Deut.16.4
    \ng X->2+0

    \xv Qut ne kesukok, keteteáe weyaus naumauut, noh pish nishkeneunkqussu.
    \xe But when raw flesh appeareth in him, he shall be unclean.
    \so Lev.13.14
    \ng X->3+0 TA conjunct
    \xv Kah wosketomp noh nemunont weetahtu, wuttaunoh ∞shoh, asuh ohkasoh wuttaunoh, kah naumoatéhettit ukkóussuongan∞ ne matche teag,...
    \xe And if a man shall take his sister, his father's daughter, or his mother's daughter, and see her nakedness, and she see his nakedness; it is a wicked thing;...
    \so Lev.20.17; (1): |naumóatéhettit|
    \ng reciprocal for the converse forms of AV; the reciprocal binds the primary (indirect) object position, as if "see [(to) each other] [their nakedness]", the |-o-| following the stem representing |-aw-|.

    \se !|naumwaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, causative
    \ge `to shew sb sth, cause sb to see sth'
    \so Gen.48.11; Deut.34.4
    \xv ..., kenaumwahunun nashpe kuskesukquash ...
    \xe ...: I have caused thee to see it with thine eyes,...
    \so Deut.34.4
    \ng 1->2+0-obj

\cf nogque
\cf wompu

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nenamih8^é| `Je vois'    R.504/543b.
Delaware [del] |ne men| `to see'; +M. |né∙m| `he sees it'    Zeisb.; G.1982.41.
    F. |ne∙we∙wa| `he sees him'    Fx.L.121.
    \nt +
K. |neemwa| `he saw it'    V.1974.63.
Mahican [mjy] |Nahk'ma onámen.| `Er siehet'    Schm.121.
Menominee [mez] |nenε∙men| `I see it', |nε∙mwah| `he sees it'    M.L.154,B.1962, 8.30, 160.
M.-I. |nineme| `je le voy ign.'; |neemwa| `he sees it'    M.332/200b; C.276.
Shawnee [sjw] |nineeme| `I see it', |honeewaali| `he sees him'    D.-V.385.]

\et S.1975, no. 178, 377-378 (with aberrnt reconstruction, but noting the reshaping as TI2 type in northerly eastern languages); G.1982.41: *ne∙mwa, with cognates, fn.138; H.2225 *ne∙we∙wa TA.

\lx nauwanum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 80
\ps v.t. / TI1b, manual final
\ge `he bends or bows down (his person, head, face, etc.)'
\so Ex.34.8
    \xv ..., kah nauwanum wuskesuk en ohkekontu.
    \xe ..., and he bowed himself with his face to the earth.
    \so Gen.48.12
    \nt +
    pl. |-umwog|    Ex.4.31; Lk.24.5
    \xv ..., kah nauánum uppuhkuk, kah nauánum wuhhog ut wuskesukqut.
    \xe ...: and he bowed down his head, and fell flat on his face.
    \so Num.22.31
    \ng Eliot follows "Hebr." in the second conjunct: "Bowed himselfe."
    \nt +

    pret. |Nauwanumómp Judah,...| `When I have bent Judah for me,...'    Zech.9.13
    \nt Research needed: Trumbull's gives a misleading translation. I am not sure what the form is. It looks like a TA conjunct preterite form, and from the AV text one expects a TA+O verb. One might also expect (?) a subjunctive here, but that has a 1 preterite in |-k-us| according to Eliot's description (Gr.40-41/288); and also some reflex of the AV reflexive--so perhaps a |-wi-| middle reflexive to a dative form is lurking here.

    \se |nauwanau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, manual final
    \ge `to bow sb'
    \so Gen.49.15
    \xv ..., kah nauwánau uhpequanuh quahquenahtómuk,...
    \xe ...; and bowed his shoulder to bear,...'    Gen.49.15  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
