\lx náyeumau
\va nai∞mau
\va nayeumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 80
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\twn |nayeutam|, TI1a
\ge `he bears or carries' (on his back or shoulders) an an. obj.; +`to ride sb' (theme 2)
    \xv ..., kah naum tatappequanumukquaash, nish Joseph negonshhuacheh, wunnayeumukqunnat,...
    \xe ...: and when he saw the wagons which Joseph had sent to carry him,...
    \so Gen.45.27
    \ng 0->3 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    infin. 3d sing. |Ne ∞néhikqun wosketomp wunáyeumonat yokoh waskénuit.| (an.) `It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.'    Lam.3.27√

    \xv ..., kah noh naomut ónt∞nshau.
    \xe ..., so that his rider shall fall backward.
    \so Gen.49.17
    \ng X->_3_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Nukket∞hamau Jehovah. newutche sohsumóe mishéheau wuhhogkuh, horses kah neh na∞muhpuh wuttinnuhkónuh kehtahhannet.
    \xe ..., I will sing unto the LORD, for he hath triumphed gloriously: the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea.'    Ex.15.1  { 3'->_3
    \so _ preterite participle, as "the one that it carried?; also Ex.15.21, present participle }
    \xv ..., sunnummatta nen kutassum, nayeumukquean, na wutch adt wadcháneap yeu pajeh yeu kesukok,...
    \xe ..., Am not I thine ass, upon which thou hast ridden ever since I was wont to do so unto this day? ...
    \so Num.22.30
    \ng _3_->2 participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., tapenuman ken wutch kuhhogkâyeu, quenashonaôont naiyeumutcheg.
    \xe ..., if thou be able on thy part to set riders upon them [the horses]
    \so 2 K.18.23
    \ng X->_3p_ participle; Jer.51.21: |na∞mutcheg| (G&B.557)
    \nt +!
    \xv ..., webe noh pumpinashim na∞mukqueh.
    \xe ..., save the beast that I rode upon.
    \so Neh.2.12
    \ng _3_->1 participle
    \nt +
    \xv ... tapenuman wutch k∞weech∞humukqunnaóut neh na∞mahetticheh.
    \xe ..., if thou be able on thy part to set riders upon them.'    Is.36.8 { 3p->_3
    \so _ participle (E1 also), i.e. "those that they carry"?; cf. 2 K.18.23 }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., mos kenàmheomw∞ assemes kishpissu, n noh asquam na∞munk wosketompuh:
    \xe ... ye shall find a colt tied, whereon yet never man sat:...'    Lk.19.30  { _3_->3
    \so negative participle, as "carry" }
    \nt +
    \xv ...? kuttinun wussiogkodt∞m mittamwossis, kah puppinashim noh naiyeumont,...
    \xe ...? I will tell thee the mystery of the woman, and of the beast that carrieth her,...'    Rev.17.7  { _3_->3
    \so }
    \nt +

    \se !|na∞mitteau|
    \nt ?+
    \ps AI?, indefinite object(?)
    \nt Remark: Identification of the category uncertain.
    \ge `to ride' [!]
    \so 2 K.9.25; Ps.45.4(M) (v.i.); Is.30.16
    \xv ...: kah naiyeumutteamun kakenupshoncheg,...
    \xe ...: and, We will ride upon the swift;...
    \so Is.30.16
    \ng 1p->3p

    \xv ..., ken kah nen asuhkaue na∞mitteaog ∞shoh Ahab,...
    \xe ..., when I and thou rode together after Ahab his father,...
    \so 2 K.9.25
    \ng 12 conjunct


\lx nayeumuk
\va nai∞muk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 80
\ps AI(+O), C final stem (|-kqu-|); see etymology and N&Q on Gen.41.43. Many of the examples here are equivocal, and are placed here merely on the basis of the occurrence of "ride" in the AV text.
\nt which has the form of the suppos. pass. participle, `when he is carried or borne (on the shoulders of another)', is used by Eliot for the indicative v.t. `he rides upon'
    \ge `to ride upon sb, in sth; to carry sb'
    \nt +
    \xv kah nayeumuk assoh
    \xe and [she] rode upon an ass'    1 Sam.25.42√  { 3->3
    \so , equivocal }
    \xv ...: assesog wutche ketass∞t neh wekit neh wunnaiyeumukqunaóont,...
    \xe ..., the asses be for the king's household to ride on:...'    2 Sam.16.2  { 3p->3
    \so t-subordinative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nutahpappuunneh nutassum, onk woh naiyeumuk,...
    \xe ..., I wil saddle me an ass, that I may ride thereon,...
    \so 2 Sam.19.26
    \ng aphaeresis of 1 prefix; form otherwise puzzling--if it has a pronominal third person argument
    \nt +
    \xv Nayeumuk Cherub, kah pt∞eu
    \xe And he rode upon a cherub, and did fly'    2 Sam.22.11√  { 3->3
    \so , unmarked, equivocal }
    (= |nayeumugk|    Ps.18.10)√; (M) |nayeumukup|
    \xv Neit Jehu nayeumuk chariot,...
    \xe So Jehu rode in a chariot,...
    \so 2 K.9.16
    \ng 3->0
    \nt +
    pl. |..., kah nai∞mukquog kamelsoh,...| `and they rode upon the camels,...'    Gen.24.61√  { 3p->3', equivocal }
    \xv ..., kusseh, LORD naiyeumuk kenupshae matokqs,...
    \xe ..., behold, the LORD rideth upon a swift cloud,...
    \so Is.19.1
    \ng 3->0
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta nunnayeumuk∞mun horsesog,...
    \xe ...; we will not ride upon horses:...
    \so Hos.14.3
    \ng 1p->3p negative absolute (hardly 3p->1p to |nayeumau|, where n-paradigm expected!)
    \nt +

    \xv Ken∞nok, kenaau na∞mukqueógish wompi ássesog,...
    \xe Speak, ye that ride upon white asses,...
    \so Judg.5.10
    \ng _2p_->3(p) participle, equivocal
    \nt +
    suppos. part. pl. |neg na∞mukqutcheg| `they who ride upon (asses)'    Judg.10.4
    \xv ..., webe yaue pasuk∞∞og wuskenuóg neg na∞mukqutcheg Camelsoh,...
    \xe ..., ave four hundred young men which rode upon camels,...'    1 Sam.30.17  { _3p_->3
    \so participle, equivocal }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah horse ne ketass∞t na∞mukqutcheh,...
    \xe ..., and the horse that the king rideth upon,...'    Esth.6.8  { 3->_3
    \so _ participle, equivocal }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., horsmanog nayeumukqutche horsesoh.
    \xe ..., horsemen riding upon horses.'    Ezek.23.6√ { _3p_->3
    \so participle, equivocal }
    sing. |noh na∞mukqut horsesoh| `he that rideth the horse'    Amos 2.15√  { _3_->3' participle, equivocal; G&B.557-558 as 3'->_3_, perhaps because |-quit| expected to i-stem? }

    \xv Kah k∞wohquánum∞wonganit, wunnaiyeue nâiyeumukqush,...
    \xe And in thy majesty ride prosperously,...
    \so Ps.45.4  { 2 imperative }; (M) |naiyeumitteash|

    (hence |nahnaíyeumooadt| `a horse or a creature that carries'    C.)

    \se !|nayeumwaheau|, !|naiyeumwaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O), causative
    \nt Remark: Note that the causal target is the rider rather than the carrier/the ridden despite the absence of |-kqu-|.
    \ge `to cause sb to ride (upon sb), to make sb ride (in sth)'
    \so 1 K.1.33,38,44; 2 K.10.16
    \xv ..., nayeumwaheaog Solomonoh, ut ummeulumoh ketass∞t David,...
    \xe ..., and [they] caused Solomon to ride upon king David's mule,...'    1 K.1.38  { 3p->3
    \so +locative, absolute }
    \xv ...: neit wunnaiyeumheuh ut wut-chariottumut.
    \xe .... So they made him ride in his chariot.'    2 K.10.16  { 3(p?)->3
    \so +locative, objective }
    \xv Kuttahshineh en wabanit: na kenaiyeumwahin, kah kummohtupanum nuhhog.
    \xe Thou liftest me up to the wind; thou causest me to ride upon it, and dissolvest my substance.
    \so Job 30.22
    \ng 2->1+0-pro, objective

    \xv ..., kah Solomon nunnaumon nayeumheuk nehenwonche nummulumut,...
    \xe ..., and cause [ye] Solomon my son to ride upon mine own mule,...
    \so 1 K.1.33
    \ng 2p->3+locative, imperative

    \se !|nayeumukquhheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O), causative
    \ge `to cause, make sb to ride (in, upon sth)'
    \so Gen.41.43; Is.58.14; Hos.10.11
    \xv Kah wunnayeumukquhheuh nahohtôeu tatuppequanumuk ne ohtunk ...
    \xe And he made him to ride in the second chariot which he had;...'    Gen.41.43  { 3->3
    \so +0+locative }
    \xv ..., kah kenayeúmukquéhesh ut qunuhqui ayeuonganehtu ut ohkeit,...
    \xe ...; and I will cause thee to ride upon the high places of the earth,...
    \so Is.58.14
    \ng 1->2+locative
    \xv ...: nunnayeumukqueh Ephraim:...
    \xe ...: I will make Ephraim to ride;...
    \so Hos.10.11
    \ng 1->3

[Narragansett [xnt] |Kunníish.| `I will carry you.' (on my back); |Naynayoûmewot.| `A Horse'; |Wunnia, naynayoûmewot.| `He rides on Horse-back.'    R.W.73; 72,106/r.104; 72.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |nenah8'mañ| `Je le (nob.) porte sur mes épaules', 3. |8nah8mañr|; |ahass8| `cheval', |nenah8meghé v. nenah8m8k8 ahass8| `j'y vais'; |n8"ih8mañ| v. |nenanh8mañ| `Je charge qq'un, seu, je le porte v.g. l'enfant'.    R.408/512a; 111/412b/ 100/408a.√
Delaware [del] |nech na yun gees| `a horse'; |na pu mau| `he is carried'; |na yu muk| `he carries me'; |na yun dam| `he carries a load'; +|nayóomeew| `carry s.o. on one's back'    Zeisb.; O'M.190b.
    Cree |Nuyo'mäo| TA `She carries him on her back, (i.e. a child in a moss-bag)', |Nuyù'chikäo| AI `He packs freight, he carries a pack on his back', |Nuyù'tum| TI `He bears it, he carries it, he endures it, he suffers it, he undergoes it.'    Frs.380b; also Alb.E.106a(?-107a).
    \nt +
Fx. |no∙mekowa|, |no∙mekwiwa| `he rides on horseback'    Fx.L.59,131.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |Ninaïa| `je le porte sur mes epaules.', |ninaïah8i| `je part chargé, mon paquet sur le dos'    Grv.309-310/190a.
Menominee [mez] |naya∙hε∙w| TA `he takes or carries him on his back', |nayo∙mε∙w| TA, |nayo∙htam| TI `he carries him, it on his back'    M.L.146.
Mun. |nehnayó∙nk@s| `horse'    G.1990.464, w. fn.38.
Shawnee [sjw] |nay-|, |naw-| `carrying on back', |ninaya, ninawe| `I packed him, it (on my back)', |ninayeko| `I am packed by it, I ride'    D.-V.388.]

\et final *-o∙m- `on the back' (e.g. H., p.248), and H.2222 *nayo∙me∙wa `carry s.o. on one's back'; compare B.1962, 15.153, p.302 (also 16.53, p.339): "|-o∙mEki|, with TA |-o∙m| `carry on the back', is used of riding on the back of an animal: |nay∙omekow| `he rides horseback'."


\lx nayeutam
\va nayeuwuttam
\va naiyeutam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 80
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\twn |nayeumau|, TA
\ge `he bears or carries (it) on his person', +`to be laden with sth'
    |..., piukqussuoh Asses, naiyeutamwog wanegik ut Egypt, kah piukqussuog squoshimwog | assesog, naiyeutamwog weatchiminneash,...| `...; ten asses laden with the good things of Egypt, and ten she asses laden with corn ...'    Gen.45.23  { 3p->0 indicative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nunnayeutamumun ummatcheseongan∞oash.
    \xe ...; and we have borne their iniquities.
    \so Lam.5.7
    (`on his breastplate'    Ex.28.29)
    \xv pish nayeutam ∞weanun
    \xe he shall bear his own burden
    \so Gal.6.5
    \xv Nagum nehenwonche, nayeuwuttam kummatcheseonganunonash ut nehenwonche wuhhogkat, ut mehtugqut,...
    \xe Who his own self bare our sins in his own body on the tree,...
    \so 1 Pet.2.24
    \nt +

    suppos. part. pl. |nayeutogig| `they who bear' [`are "laden with"']    Is.1.4
    \xv Nean kuhquttuk Aaron, kah wunnaumonuh, ne pish nnih wame wuttannohsuongan∞ Gershonitse wunnaumonuh, wame ne na∞tamwehettit, kah wame wuttannosuongan∞,...
    \xe At the appointment of Aaron and his sons shall be all the service of the sons of the Gershonites, in all their burdens, and in all their service:...
    \so Num.4.27
    \ng 3p->_0_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah monchek, naiyeutam∞k weatchiminneash wutche mahshagquodt kekuwóut
    \xe ...: go ye, carry corn for the famine of your houses:
    \so Gen.42.19
    \ng 2p->0 imperative
    \nt +

\dv [From |nauwaeu|, |nauwaehtam| `he bends or stoops to it' (?).]

[Narragansett [xnt] |niâutash| `take it on your back'; |niáutamwock| `they are loden', i.e. `carry burdens'.]

\et Cf. B.1962, 16.53, p.339: |-o∙m|, TI |-o∙ht| `carry on the back'; H. p.248


\lx nayin
\va nain
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 80
    \nt +
\ps particle
\ge `unto him', them'
\nt G&B.655 `to that', as |na| + |en|.
\so Gen.37.13; Acts 9.38
    \xv ...? peyaush kah kuttann∞nsh nayin,...
    \xe ...? come, and I will send thee unto them. ...
    \so Gen.37.13


\lx ne
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 80
\ps demonstrative and directive particle or pron. inan.; +proximal and distal (primarily the latter); adverbial in local, temporal and manner senses. On the temporal sense, cf. |neit|.
\ge `this, that'
\so El.Gr.7
    "Demonstratives ... of things ... |Yeu| {This}. |Ne| {This}."    El.Gr.7/254
    pl. |nish| `these, those'
    \xv ne teag
    \xe this thing
    \xv ne adt
    \xe thereat, at that place
    \so Ezek.6.13
    \xv ..., ne quanupishunk wame ohkeet Havilah,...
    \xe ...: that {is} it which compasseth the whole land of Havilah,...
    \so Gen.2.11
    \ng (E0) gl. "this"
    \nt +

    \xv ...: kah ne upponun wosketompuh neh kahkenaiheaumpoh.
    \xe ...; and there he put the man whom he had formed.
    \so Gen.2.8
    \ng (E0) gl. "th[e]re"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ne wuttit nuppun.
    \xe ...: and he died.
    \so Gen.5.5
    \ng (E0) gl. |ne wuttit|: "then"
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ne wutussen Noah ne wame GOD anann∞nomp, ne wutussen.
    \xe Thus did Noah; according to all that God commanded him, so did he.
    \so Gen.6.22
    \ng (E0) gl.: 1st and 3rd tokens: "so"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nishnoh puppinshas neanussit,...
    \xe ..., and every fowle after his kind,...
    \so Gen.7.14; sim.8.19
    \ng (E0) gl. "aft[.]r"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne mahche usseon
    \xe ..., as I have done.
    \so Gen.8.21
    \ng (E0) gl. "as"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ne wutohkinneau.
    \xe ..., and they dwelt there.
    \so Gen.11.2
    \ng (E0) gl. "there"
    \nt +
    \xv Ne adt ayikup Altar,...
    \xe Unto the place of the altar,...
    \so Gen.13.4
    \ng (E0) gl. "To there"
    \nt +


\lx neane
\va neyane
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 80
    \ps PreN, PreV (manner predicative; adverbial) (to an initial |nean-|)
    \nt +
\ge [|ne unne| `like this, of this kind, such as this'], `so, such, in the same manner as, as',    El.Gr.22; Lk.22.27,29; Mk.4.26
\nt G&B.662-663
    |Neane|, {As}.    El.Gr.22/268
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Onk neyane pish k∞skannémunog.
    \xe ..., So shall thy seed be.
    \so Gen.15.5
    \ng predicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah Sarah wutahquenaiin neyane mittamwussissog.
    \xe ...: {and} it ceased to be with Sarah after the manner of women.
    \so Gen.18.11
    \ng (E0) gloss: "as with"
    \nt +

    \se !|neyanesu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \ge `such as'
    \so Acts 23.3; Hatchets XX

    \xv ..., ne kutappen k∞sumeh neánesit naumatuonk, onk kutusseh tagkomunaj ayeuukkone neanesit naumatuonk?
    \xe ...: for sittest thou to judge me after the law, and commandest me to be smitten contrary to the law?
    \so Acts 23.3
    \ng 3->_pred_ participle (|naumatuonk| here animate), i.e. "as the law is"

    \se !|neaunai|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge "to be such"

    \nt MN: neâunak
    \ng suppositive |neâunak| , |-ag| (`when it is so, or such as'), `according to, in accordance with, like'
    \ps pred
    \xv ..., ununkquodtok neaunak wutanakausuonk:...
    \xe ...: recompense her according to her work;...
    \so Jer.50.29
    \ng 0->_pred_ participle
    \xv ..., kah n naj neaunak unnaumatuonk.
    \xe ...; and let it be done according to the law.
    \so Ezra 10.3√
    \ng 0->_pred_ participle, i.e. "as the law is"

    (|Neânag sohsum∞"onk.|    `Such glory'
    \xv Neana@gish chadchaboaongash.
    \xe Such differences
    \xv Neane, ne nêane@sitcheg wosketomp.
    \xe Such, as such men
    \so C.29/175.)

    \se |neaneyeu∞|, |neyaneyeu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, II, ?predicative
    \ge `to be as sth, of the form of sth, to agree to sth [i.e. matches, is like],...'
    \so Gen.18.25; Ex.39.5; Deut.6.24; Mk.4.30,14.70; Lk.22.26; Phil.2.7; 2 Tim.1.13; 2 Pet.3.8
    \xv ...: kah sampwesecheg neyaneyeuunát matcheet∞ut,...
    \xe ..., and that the righteous should be as the wicked,...
    \so Gen.18.25
    \ng AI, X t-subordinative
    \xv ..., pasuk kesukod, neyaneyeu∞ ut Lordut, nequt mattannongane kodtum∞,...
    \xe ..., that one day is with the Lord as a thousand years,...
    \so 2 Pet.3.8
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv ..., kah nemunum en wuhhogkat neyaneyeuuneat wuttinneumuneat,...
    \xe ..., took upon him the form of a servant,...
    \so Phil.2.7  { AI, 3 t-subordinative

    \xv Menuhkinish neyaneyeuukish sampwont∞wonat ne n∞tamauweop,...
    \xe Hold fast the form of sound words, which thou hast heard of me,...
    \so 2 Tim.1.13
    \ng _0p_ iterative participle

    \xv ... neyaneyeuitch peississinitcheh,...
    \xe ..., let him be as the younger;...
    \so Lk.22.26
    \ng 3 imperative

\ps as n. / 0->_adv_ (manner) participle
\ge  `the appearance of a thing, its likeness'
    \xv ne áunak onatuh ne áunak
    \xe the color thereof as the color of
    \so Num.11.7
    \xv neáunag yeu muttaok
    \xe the fashion of this world
    \so 1 Cor.7.31
    \xv neaunak menutcheg
    \xe in the form of a hand
    \so Ezek.10.8
\cf áunag
\cf na
\cf nan
\cf nnih
\cf nô
\cf noh
\cf unne

\lx neechan
\va neechaneu
\ve i.e. ?!?
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 81
\ps v.i. / AI, predicative to |neechan| NA
\ge `he or she issues from or is given birth' { Does this exist? } +`to be a child'
\ps as n. / NA
\ge `issue or offspring (without regard to sex or age)'

    \nt MN: neechânit
    \ng suppositive |neechânit| `when he or she is a child'    Rom.9.8
    \ng 3 conjunct
    pl.part. |neg neechânutcheg| `they who are children or issue'    ibid.  { _3p_ participle }

    \se neechan
    \ps NA, deverbal to |neechau|
    \nt +
    \ge `child, issue, whelp'
    \nt G&B.663
    pl. |neechanog| `they are children' (i.e. issue)
    \xv ... qunnonou wunneechanoh,...
    \xe ..., a lion's whelp,...
    \so Gen.49.9
    \nt +
    \xv keneechanog
    \xe thy children
    \so Rom.9.7
    `thy issue'    Gen.48.6
    \xv wunneechanoh
    \xe the issue of (him)
    \so Rom.9.26,27

    \se !|wunneechaneu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, possessive verb
    \ge "to have a child", `for a child to be born unto sb'
    \so Gen.15.2(E0&1),17.17,30.3
    \xv ..., michemwusháan matta wunneechaneunat,...
    \xe ..., seeing I go childless?...
    \so Gen.15.2(E1)
    \ng X negative t-subordinative
    \xv ..., Sun woh n∞neechan, nequt pasuk∞we kodtumwohkomon,...
    \xe ..., Shall a child be born unto him that...
    \so Gen.17.17
    \ng 1 indicative; lit. "shall I have a child"

    \se wunneechâneunk
    \ps N.collect.
    \ge `his issue', collectively
    \so Rom.9.8

    \se |neechanishau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O), representative final to ?
    \ge `to bear sb a child'
    \so Gen.21.2,22.22
    \xv ..., kah neechanîshau Abrahamoh wunnaumonuh,...
    \xe ..., , and [she] bare Abraham a son in his old age,...'    Gen.21.2  { 3->3'+3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ...: yeuoh shwosuk tahsuoh Milkah wunnechanshonuh Nahoroh weematah Abraham.
    \xe ...: these eight Milcah did bear to Nahor, Abraham's brother.'    Gen.22.22  { 3->3'+3
    \so objective }

\cf ontseu

[Western Abenaki [abe] |n8nitzañni, 3. 8nitzañn8; n8nitzañnin, 3. 8nitzañnar.| `J'ai un enfant'; |kenitzañnak|; |kenitzañnak| `tes enfans'.    R.213/444a.

    Algonquian [alg] |∙NIDJANIS| `enfant, terme de relation. S'applique également aux petits des animaux'    Cq.271a.]
    \nt +

\et A.1602-1604, H.2359 *ni∙cya∙na NA `child'; deverbal to |neechau| (as B.1962, 14.44, 233).


\lx neechau
\va néchau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 81
\ps v.i. and t.an. / AI(+O), long-vowel stem
\ge `she gives birth to a child, is delivered, is in labor'; +`to bear (a child), bring forth (sb); to breed; to have labour, travail'
\so Is.66.7; Gen.3.16,4.17,22,35.16
    \xv ..., onk woh neechâog m∞cheke ut ohkekontu.
    \xe ..., that they may breed abundantly in the earth,...
    \so Gen.8.17
    \ng 3p indicative
    \xv ... Sun wunnamuhkut nunneecham mohtantamon?
    \xe Shall I of a surety bear a child, which am old?
    \so Gen.18.13√
    \ng 1 indicative
    \xv ..., kah Rachel nechau, kah siogke nechau.
    \xe ...: and Rachel travailed, and she had hard labour.
    \so Gen.35.16
    \ng 3 indicative
    \xv ... pish k∞wompequau ut kutoontomukqut, kah pish keneecham kenaumon, kah pish kuttissowen Jesus,
    \xe ..., thou shalt conceive in thy womb, and bring forth a son, and shalt call his name Jesus.
    \so Lk.1.31
    \ng 2->3 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Neit Elizabeth ahquompak na ut woh neechadt, kah neechau wunnaumonuh.
    \xe Now Elizabeth's full time came that she should be delivered; and she brought forth a son.'    Lk.1.57  { 3->_adv_ conjunct; 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    pret. |neechop| `she was delivered, she gave birth to (a child)'    Heb.11.11

    \nt MN: Onk n nih nechadt, sohwunum wunnutcheg,...
    \ng suppositive |Onk n nih nechadt, sohwunum wunnutcheg,...| `And it came to pass, when she travailed, that the one put out his hand:...'    Gen.38.28√
    \xv ... wunnaumonuh Hagar neechajeh,...
    \xe ... his son['s name], which Hagar bare,...
    \so Gen.16.15
    \ng 3->_3_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh ummukkiyeum∞uh neh neechahetticheh?
    \xe ..., or unto their children which they have borne?'    Gen.31.43  { 3p->_3
    \so _ }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah neechad nunksquaésoh, neit pish nishkeneunkqussu neesu weeksae,...
    \xe But if she bear a maid child, then she shall be unclean two weeks,...'    Lev.12.5  { 3->3
    \so }
    \nt +

    \se |neechauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, dative final
    \ge `to bear sb unto sb'
    \so Gen.22.20,25.12,36.12; Mt.7.11
    \xv ..., kusseh Milcah nagum wonk neechauau keematoh Nahor,
    \xe ..., Behold, Milcah, she hath also born children unto thy brother Nahor;'    Gen.22.20  { 3->3'+3
    \so absolute }

    \xv ... wunnaumonuh Abraham, noh Hagar wut-Egyptian, ummaidumoh Sarah neechauompuh Abrahamoh.
    \xe ..., Abraham's son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah's handmaid, bare unto Abraham:'    Gen.25.12  { 3->_3
    \so _ preterite participle }

\lx neekin
\va nekin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 81
\ps v.i. / II (see remark added)
\twn |netu| AI
\ge `he or she is born'; +`to grow'
\nt [Regularly the formative |-kin| denotes the growth of inanimate being, as does |-etu| that of animate: |netu| `he grows'; |nekin| `it grows'; but from Eliot's use of these two forms it appears that |nekin| had the force of an an. passive, `he is born, he is grown'; |netu| an. intrans., which we may nearly translate by `he has birth', `he grows.'  See both forms in the same verse, Jn.3.4]:
    \nt Remark: The first example in Jn.3.4 is 3 subordinative to |neetu| (lacking palatalization), T.82ab, |-n| being that of the n-paradigm. (Example given under |neetu|.) The conjunct examples below from Jn.1.13,3.,6 are simple conjunct forms to the AI verb |neetu|. The other forms here are to the II verb |nekin|
    \nt +
    |wutch nekinneát| (infin.)  `from birth'    Hos.9.11
    \xv nekin
    \xe (a tree) grows, is grown
    \so Ezek.17.6; Dan.4.33
    (of the hair)    Judg.16.12

    \nt MN: nekik
    \ng suppositive |nekik| , |negik| `when it grows or is grown'    Dan.4.33
    (|nekuk|    Mt.13.32)
    \xv ...; kah nishnoh mosket ut ohteakonit asq nekinninn∞g:
    \xe ..., and every herb of the field before it grew:...
    \so Gen.2.5
    \ng 0 negative conjunct
    \nt +
    pl. an. |-kig|: |nékeekig|    Rom.9.11
    pl. inan. |-kish|: |nekukish|    2 K.19.29
    (pass. form) |nekit| `when he is born'    Jn.3.5,6
    pl. |neg nékitcheg|    Jn.1.13
\cf adtannegen
\cf sonkin
\cf tannegen
\so etc

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nig8| `un enfant est né, il est sorti'; |tzanig8| (cf. |tannegen|, El.) `il cesse de croître'; +|nenighihé| `J'accouche', dicitur etiam de [animalibus]; |kadá8i neghihé| `Elle est prête d'accoucher'    R.352/491a;4/378b.]

    \xe ..., [he] was warned from God by an holy angel to send for thee into his house,...
    \so Acts 10.22

    \xv Ann∞n∞k pasuk keenaau, kah neemskauonch kemat∞oh,...
    \xe Send one of you, and let him fetch your brother,...'    Gen.42.16  { 3->3
    \so imperative }


\lx neemoun
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 81
    \nt +
\ps NI
\ge `provision'; note the implication of a journey in the cognates.
\so Gen.45.23; Josh.9.12
    \xv ..., kah piukqussuog squoshimwog assesog, naiyeutamwog weatchiminneash, kah petukqunnegânash, kah wunnemauunash ∞shoh.
    \xe ..., and ten she asses laden with corn and bread and meat for his father by the way.
    \so Gen.45.23
    \xv Yeu nuppetukqunnonganun nukkissapittae nemannumunnanonup wutch neékinonut wutch nunneemounun,...
    \xe This our bread we took hot for our provision out of our houses ...
    \so Josh.9.12

    \se neemoune
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of provision'
    \so Josh.9.5
    \xv ..., kah wame neemóune petukqunegash, nunóhtaash kah ogquonkshaash.
    \xe ...; and all the bread of their provision was dry and mouldy.
    \so Josh.9.5

    \se !|nemounuhteau|
    \nt ?
    \ps AI(+O), creative final
    \ge `to comfort sb'
    \so Gen.18.5(E0&1)
    \xv ... kodchuhkoi petukqunneg, neemóunúhkun kuttahh∞wóog,...
    \xe a morsel of bread to comfort your hearts
    \so Gen.18.5(E0), gloss
    \ng X->3(p) subordinative

    \se !|nemounuhkauau|
    \nt ?
    \ps TA
    \dv |nemoun| + |-uhk-au-|; on which, see T+.168a.
    \ge `to give sb provision'
    \so Gen.18.5,45.21
    \xv .., kah wunnemounúhkauoh wutche wuttaongan∞.
    \xe ..., and [he] gave them provision for the way.'    Gen.45.21  { 3->3
    \so indicative }

    \xv ..., kah neemóunúhkok kuttahh∞wóog,...
    \xe ... comfort ye your hearts,...
    \so Gen.18.5(E2)
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative

[Western Abenaki [abe] |neníma|, 3. |nímañ| `Je prens des vivres p'r le voiage'    R.502/543a.
Cree |nimâwin| `approvisionnement de vivres, provisions pour le voyage'; |Nëma'win| NI `Travelling provisions.'; |nîmâ-| AI `take provisions; take a packed lunch'    Lac.D.497a; Frs.357a; W&A.124.

\lx neen

    but |nanashaue kenawun| `between us' (all of us, inclus, pl.)    Judg.11.10
\nt The pronoun in the singular has the form of the noun agent, with |n'| directive or demonstrative as the base.

\lx neepau
\va neepoh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 82
    \nt Remark: Some conjunct forms point to a C-final stem in |w|; see the etymology, occasional conjunct forms, and Cotton's forms.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI
\twn |neepatt(e)au| ?
\ge `he stands, holds himselferect'
\ge as implying a change of posture `he rises, erects himself', +`to rise up'

    \xe ...; and he stood by them ...

    \nt +
    \xv Kah wosketompaog nepoog newutch...
    \xe And the men rose up from thence,...

    \nt +
    pl. |-póog|    Ex.32.6
    (|Nunnep∞, -up.| `I stand, or did'

    \xv Kah Abraham t∞keu nompoaeu en na neepokup ut anaquabit Jehovah
    \xe And Abraham gat up early in the morning to the place where he stood before the LORD:
    \so Gen.19.27

    \xv ... ut anaquabenit wame noh neepanitcheh,...
    \xe ... before all them that stood by him;...
    \so Gen.45.1
    \ng _3_ participle

    \xe ..., Up, get ye out of this place:...
    \so Gen.19.14
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    pl. |-p∞k|, |-pôk| `stand ye'    1 Sam.12.16; Nah.2.8

\lx neeshauog
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 82
    \nt +
\ps AI, plurale tantum, |nees-| `two' + |-uhsh-á-| `to go'
\ge `for (both of) two to go (together)'
\so Gen.22.6
    \xv ..., kah neeshauog.
    \xe ..., and they went both of them together
    \so Gen.22.6
    \ng 3p indicative
    \xv Neit nag neeshauog...
    \xe So they two went...
    \so Ruth 1.19


\lx neeshaúog
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 82
\ps NA
\ge `eels'
\so R.W.
    \xv Neeshau~og
    \xe Eeles.
    \so R.W.105/r.113.
    |neeshuongok|    Stiles.

[|Neese-auog| `they go by twos or in pairs, they couple'; cf. Abn. |niss8"8ak| `ils sont mariés'. See |nequittéconnaúog|.]
The name of `neshaw eel' is yet retained by the fishermen of Marthas Vineyard and perhaps elsewhere in Massachusetts for the silver eel (Muræna argentea, Le Sueur).
I am inclined to believe that it originally belonged to the lampreys (Petromyzon americanus, Le Sueur), which may appropriately be called `pairers' or `couplers' in distinction from the `single going' eel.

[Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |neesh|, pl. |neeshuaugx|    Stiles.
    Lp.A |nisse pl. 8ak| `anguille'    M.2,103.]
    \nt +


\lx neesinwog
\va neesissin
\va neesin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 82
    \dv |nees-| `two' + |-sin| AI `to fall, lie' (consonant-final)
    \nt +
\ps v.i. (pl.) / AI
\ge `they lie two together, they couple'
\ps v.t. / AI+O
\ge `they lie with, have carnal connection with', +`to come together, lie by, with sb' { Trumbull's own evidence indicates that the plural is not required. }
\so 1 Sam.1.22
    sing. |..., onk mohtomegit petutteau, onk neesin ∞shoh,...| `...: and the first born went in, and lay with her father;...'    Gen.19.33; 35.22  { X->3(') subordinative }
    \xv ..., kah peississit nepau kah wunnesinuh,...
    \xe ...o, and the younger arose, and lay with him:...'    Gen.19.35  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nushok nish noh mittumwossis noh wahheont wosketompuh, neesissinunat wosketomp.
    \xe ..., and kill every woman that hath known man by lying with him.'    Num.31.17 { AV: "Hebr.": `by lying with {a male}
    \so }; Num.31.35: |ut neesinat|
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh neesuk
    \ng suppositive |noh neesuk| `he who, etc.'    Lev.20.13;
    \xv ... pish kuppapaquanne paguanomw∞ nishnoh wosketomp, kah nishnoh mittamwossis noh neesuk wosketompuh.
    \xe ..., Ye shall utterly destroy every male, and every woman that hath lain by man.'    Judg.21.11  { _3_->3
    \so participle }
    \xv ..., nagum okasoh Maryhoh kah Josehp quoshodhettit (asquam naneesinhettékup) ...
    \xe ...: When as his mother Mary was espoused to Joseph, before they came together,...
    \so Mt.1.18
    \ng 3p reduplicated negative preterite conjunct
    \nt +

    imperat. 1st pl. |..., kah n∞wau, neesintuh.| `..., and she said, Lie with me.'    Gen.39.7,12  { 12 imperative }
    \xv ..., kah petutteash kah neesish onk woh k∞wadchanumauómun ∞skanemeneuh k∞shun.
    \xe ...; and go thou in, and lie with him, that we may preserve seed of our father.
    \so Gen.19.34
    \ng 2->3 imperative
    \nt +

\dv |neese| `two', with the formative (|-sin|) of verbs of lying down.

    \se neesinn∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `coupling, lying with another'
    \so Num.31.18

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nen8sinbena|, |nis8sin8da|, |nis8sin8k| `nous couchons 2 ensemble' (de 2 viris non malè audit, de viro et foeminâ, malè).    R.134/419b-420a.√
    Miami-Illinois [mia] |Ninch8ichin8ki| `ils sont couchés deux ensemble'    Grv.345/207b.
    \nt +
Menominee [mez] |ni∙sihsenok| AI `they lie as two'    M.L.162.
Shawnee [sjw] |ninii⌠o?⌠inepe| `we lie together'    D.-V.380.
WAbn. |nizesin| AI `two sleep together'    D.1.369.]


\lx neesneechag
\va nesnechag
\va neesneehchag-
\va nesneehchag-
\va neesin-

\ps num.
\ge `twenty'

    Adj.pl. an. |Neesneechag| |kodtog|    El.Gr.14/261
    inan. |Neesneechag| |kodtash|

    \xv nequt pasuk∞∞og nab neesinnehchag
    \xe a hundred and twenty

    \nt +

\dv |neese| and |nutcheg| (`hand'; see |menutcheg|), `the second time of employing the hand in counting, twice [the number of fingers on each] hand'.


\lx nees∞hkauau

\lx neeswe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 82
    \ps num., quantifier; PreN, PreV; also initial
    \nt +
\ge `both, the two'
\so Mt.15.14; Lk.6.39
    \xv Onk neeswe poskussuog wosketomp kah ummittamwossoh,...
    \xe And they were both naked, the man and his wife,...
    \so Gen.2.25
    \nt +

    \se |naneeswe|, |na neswe|, |na neeswe|; also |naneese|, |na neese|
    \nt +
    \ps pronominal and conjunctional uses, like the gloss
    \ge `both, each (of two)'
    \nt G&B.657
    \so Gen.40.5; Lgc.Pr.36/48,53/64-65; C.20/168,22/169,99/225
    |NANEESWE NUKKOE TESTAMENT KAH WONK WUSKU TESTAMENT. "Conteyning the Old Testament, AND THE NEW:"|    Eliot 1685, title page
    \xv Onk nag nukquomwog unnukquomuonk neswe, na neswe unnugquomwog ne nohkog, na neswe neyanunnauwuttam∞m∞ug unnukquom∞onk,...
    \xe And they dreamed a dream both of them, each man his dream in one night, each man according to the interpretation of his dream,...
    \so Gen.40.5
    \xv Na neese wunnohteáe nusseepsin kah nukkouem,...
    \xe I will both lay me down in peace, and sleep:...
    \so Ps.4.8; (M): |Naneese|
    `in     both       Propositions.'
    |ut na neeswe pakodtitumooonganit.|    Log.Pr.53/65.

\cf neese


\lx neeswekheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 82
    \nt +

    \xe ...: and God healed Abimelech,...'    Gen(E1).20.17; (E2) with dittography |neetskeheheau|  { 3->3
    \so absolute }

    \xv pish na nuppeam kah nunnetskeh.

    \xe I heal thee

    imperat. |neetskeh kuhhog| `heal thyself'    Lk.4.23

\lx neetu
\va neek-
\va nek-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 82
\ps v.i. / AI, i-stem
\twn |nekin| II
    \nt Remark: The final |-k| is palatalized in the citation form (G&B. 514). This verb may initially look like an aphetized form of |un-|+|-ek-i-|, but note the Algonquin form, and the Abenaki forms that settle the matter. (No example found with change on the verb as yet.)
    \nt +
\ge `he (or it) grows', as a plant or animal
\so Job 8.11; Ps.92.12
    pl. |-uog|    Jer.12.2
\ge `he is born'
    \nt G&B.669
    \nt +
\so Prov.17.17; Job 5.7; Is.9.6
    \xv ..., onk wunnaumonuh neetuoh mahche tomogkog.
    \xe ...; and unto them were sons born after the flood.'    Gen.10.1  { 3
    \so indicative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wuttit {mukkiog} neekinneau.
    \xe ..., even to him were {children} born.
    \so Gen.10.21
    \ng 3p objective/subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Uttoh woh wuttin wosketomp neekin wonk kutchisuut? sun woh nahohtôe petutteau wunnogkussit ohkasoh kah woh neetu?
    \xe ..., How can a man be born when he is old? can he enter the second time into his mothers womb, and be born?
    \so Jn.3.4; (M): |nekin|, |netu|
    \ng |wu-...neekin| 3s subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Ahque monchantash ne ánun, mos wonk keneetimun wutch waábe.
    \xe Marvel not that I said unto thee, Ye must be born again.
    \so Jn.3.7 { final phrase, marginale: "Or, from aboue."; incorrect person (with theological consequences?): 12 for 2p }; (M): |kunnompe netimw∞.|
    \xv ... Ken kuppannuppenéet ut matcheseonganit, kah kukkuhk∞tomaiimun?...
    \xe ...Thou wast altogether born in sins, and dost thou teach us?...
    \so Jn.9.34(1&2) { uncertain; taken as: |-pannuppe neet|, where the final consonant is levelled from 3s. The possibility is confirmed by G.1981, 39, p.77, w. fn 11, p.100; 40, pp.83-84. }; (M): |Kuppannupe taneteup|
    \nt +

    \xv ..., na ohke ut neeteup,...
    \xe ... in the land of his nativity,...
    \so Gen.11.28
    \ng 3->_adv_ preterite (unchanged) conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ... wuttinnumoh, at nekinitche nehenwonche weekit,...
    \xe his...{servants}, born in his own house,...'    Gen.14.14  { _3
    \so _ participle }; Gen.17.23: |neekinutche|
    \nt +
    \xv ...kah uttoh ane nukkonadt k∞sh kah kokas, kah ohke ne adt neekean,...
    \xe ...and how thou hast left thy father and thy mother, and the land of thy nativity,...
    \so Ruth 2.11
    \ng 2->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Onk n nih nashikquinukok Pharoh adt nekis,...
    \xe And it came to pass the third day, which was Pharaoh's birthday,...
    \so Gen.40.20(E0,1&2)
    \ng apparently subjunctive preterite, in unusual function if G&B.566 is accurate.
    \nt +
    \xv Ne kesukod nupp∞m∞utch, neadt nekeáus, kah nukkon, neadt n∞womukus, mukkutchouks wompequain.
    \xe Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night in which it was said, There is a man child conceived.
    \so Job.3.3
    \nt +

    \se !|neeteum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to be born'
    \so Jn.3.6(M)

    \xv Ne nateum∞uk wutch weyausut, weyausum∞:...
    \xe That which is born of the flesh, is flesh:...
    \so Jn.3.6(M)  { _0_ participle }; (E) |neekit|

    \se !|-ekheau|, |-eekheau|, |-ekehheau| { forms somewhat uncertain }
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: The exact sense and the syntax of these verbs remain uncertain, mainly because the impregnator is often mentioned and the woman is not (though see Gen.29.35 and perhaps the Narragansett examples). For the simple de-stem form |-ek-i-|, see |-etu|, T+.26b.
    \ps ?TA, ?causative final, de-stem form to |nekheau| TA, T+.83b.; for transitive examples, see in particular those translating AV "travail". The Narragansett examples give further instances of quantity-denoting initials.
    \nt G&B.727: "|wachekehheakkuk| `(those) whom I begot on (her)', lit. `whom I caused to be born from (her)' TA"
    \ge `to be in travel, travail' i.e. "to be in labor", as "to cause to be born"? (status of Gen.10.25?)
    \so Gen.10.25,41.50; Gal.4.19; Is.66.7,8; Jer.4.31,6.24; Jn.16.21(M.)
    \xv Onk neesweekheau Eber, pasuk ussowesu Peleg,...
    \xe And unto Eber were born two sons: the name of one was Peleg;...
    \so Gen.10.25; (E0): "two sonns had"
    \xv Onk Joseph neeswekheau wunnaumonuh,...
    \xe And unto Joseph were born two sons,...'    Gen.41.50  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., newajeh ussowenont Judah, kah ahquegheau.
    \xe ...: therefore she called his name Judah; and left bearing.
    \so Gen.29.35
    \xv ..., kah m∞chekegheont, n∞chumwesu.
    \xe ...; and she that hath many children is waxed feeble.
    \so 1 Sam.2.5
    \xv ...? sun woh ohke neechahtauun pasuk kesukod, asuh woh wutohtimoin pasukqut neekin: newutche queenau Zion kodtauweekheont neechau wunneechanoh.
    \xe ...? Shall the earth be made to bring forth in one day? or shall a nation be born at once? for as soon as Zion travailed, she brought forth her children.
    \so Is.66.8
    \xv Muttumwussis kodtouekehheont uhquanum∞, newutche wuthour∞m peyom∞:...
    \xe A woman, when she is in travel, hath sorrow, because her hour is come:...
    \so Jn.16.21(M)
    \xv Nummukkiésumog neg kodnekheogeg wonk, noh pajeh Christ kakeneunungqussit en kuhhogkaóut.
    \xe My little children, of whom I travail in birth again until Christ be formed in you,
    \so Gal.4.19
    \ng Paul writing! preverb |kod| -- not a de-stem form

    \se |kodtauegehhae|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `in travel' i.e. "in labor"
    \so Ps.48.6(M.)
    \xv Wapissooonk na wuttut tohqunukqunaop, kah uhquomomooonk, onatuh kodtauegehhae muttumwussis.
    \xe Fear took hold upon them there, and pain, as of a woman in travel.
    \so Ps.48.6(M.)

cf. |neekin|.
\nt This word is not easily translatable; it signifies `he comes into life, has birth', but it also (with an an. subj.) connotes the coming into the family or tribal relation, domestic life and growth.
\cf wétu

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nig8| `un enfant est né, il est sorti'; |tzanig8| (cf. |tannegen|, El.) `il cesse de croître'; +|nenighihé| `J'accouche', dicitur etiam de [animalibus]; |kadá8i neghihé| `Elle est prête d'accoucher'    R.352/491a;4/378b.
    Algonquian [alg] |NIK,I| `naître'; |Nikih| `{fais-le naître}, donne-lui le jour.'    Cq.272b.]
    \nt +
Cree |NIKIHIKUMAW, ok| `parent, père, ou mère'; |ne ne'kehikowuk| `My parents'; |nini∙kihikwak| `my parents'    Lac.D.496a; Frs.135b,(357a); G.1990.473, (115).
Delaware [del] |kiishíikuw| AI `be born'    O'M.86a.
EOj. |-ni∙ki| AI `be born'    B.1958, 12.69,82.
Fox |ni∙kiwa| `he is born'    Fx.L.129.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |Niki8a, nikita| `solitarie nunquam dr Educaon, agrandiss dune chose qui croist'    Grv.343/206b.
Narragansett [xnt] |Muchickéhea.| `Fruifull.', |Cutchashekeâmis?| `How many children have you had?', |Nquittékea.| `I have hadone.', |Neesékea.| `Two, &c.'    R.W.140/r.148.
Ojibwe [oji] |Nigia, (nin)| `I give him birth, I bring him forth'    Bar.287b.

\et G.1981, 40, 83: PA *ni∙kiwa, without gloss or cognates; G.1990, (115), 473 *ni∙ki-h- TA `cause to be born', H.2245 *nehta∙wikihe∙wa TA `produce' (Cree: of mother)


\lx neetuoNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative (cf. B.1962, 16.71, 343)
\nt Remark: There is no direct evidence for |-ôN-| at present.
\ge `to be born of sb', as a use of a verb meaning "to bear sb"
\so Gen.1.22,9.1,7; Job.14.1,15.14,25.4; Lk.1.35; Jn.3.6(M)

    \xv WOsketomp noh neetuonont mittamwussissoh, ogguhsinsash ukkesukodtumash,...
    \xe Man that is born of a woman is of few days,...'    Job.14.1  { _3_->3
    \so participle }

\lx negonne
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
\ps `adv. of order'
\ge `first', +`at the first'
\so El.Gr.21.
\nt Like |nequtta| (`one'), of which it is the ordinal, |negonne| appears to be nearly related to |nukkône| (Abn. |negañnié) `old, ancient', and so `first in order of time'.
    \xv Negonnu
    \xe {First}
    \so E.Gr.21/268
    \xv Kah nishnoh ohketemuk ut ohteakonit negonne asquam ahken∞g;...
    \xe And every plant of the field before it was in the earth,...
    \so Gen.2.5
    \ng apparently merely corroborative?
    \nt +

    \se |negonáe (onk)|, |negonne (onk)|
    \nt +
    \ps relational, followed by noun phrase, most commonly a personal pronoun; |onk| as in comparative construction
    \ge `before', spatial (usually with movement, "ahead of, in front of") or temporal; relationship to |anaquab-|, |anaquosh-| unclear.
    \so Gen.45.5,7,46.28; Lev18.28,30; Lk.21.12; Jn.5.7,8.58; Gal.1.17; Rom.16.7
    \xv Kah GOD nutann∞nuk negonáe onk kenaau, woh k∞wadchanumaúununáont wunneechan∞onk ut ohket,...
    \xe And God sent me before you to preserve you a posterity in the earth,...
    \so Gen.45.7

\cf nukkomauonát
\cf nukkône
\cf pasuk

[Narragansett [xnt] |Necáwni mèich teàqua.| `First eat something'    R.W.12.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |Nikkañni8i| `devant, par avance', |nenikkañn8ssé| `je marche devant.'    R.P31/559b.
Delaware [del] |nigani| `at the first'    Zeisb.
    Lp.A |nikanni| `Devant', |nigani. niganiou| `je vai devant'    D.59/215,22/131.]
    \nt +

\et G.1965, no.38, 216b; H.2365-2372, *ni∙ka∙n- `ahead, at the head, in front'


\lx negonohtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
    \nt +
\dv |negon-| `first' + |oht-| II `to be'; perhaps also |oht-| TI2 `to have'
\ps II, currently only attested in conjunct forms?
\ge `to be before, first, lower, past, uppermost,...'
\so Gen.2.11,6.16; Mt.23.6; Mk.12.28-30; Gal.1.13; Phil.3.16; Heb.5.12,6.1
    \xv Negonohtag hettamun Pison,...
    \xe The name of the first is Pison:...

\lx negonshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
\ps v.i. / AI
    \dv |negon-| + ambulatory final |-uhsh-| + |-á-|
    \nt +
\ge `he goes first, he is in advance'
\ps v.t. / AI+O, via transitivity of initial
\ge `he goes before (them)'
\nt The characteristic |-sh| denotes going swiftly, as in 2 Sam.18.27.
    \xv Pomushaituh, kah monchetuh, kah negonsham.
    \xe Let us take our journey, and let us go, and I will go before thee.
    \so Gen.33.12
    \ng with apheresis of |nu-|
    \nt +

    \nt MN: ..., nuttenantam noh negonshont ogquomâshau Ahimaaz ...
    \ng suppositive |..., nuttenantam noh negonshont ogquomâshau Ahimaaz ...| `..., Methinketh the running of the foremost is like the running of Ahimaaz,...'    2 Sam.18.27√
    \ng fugitive final?
    \xv Kah unnau negonshanutcheh,...
    \xe And he commanded the foremost,...'    Gen.32.17  { 3
    \so participle }
    \nt +

    \se negonshaen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `a leader'
    \so Acts 24.5

    \se !|negonuhshaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA causative
    \ge `to put sb foremost (in a journey, procession), set sb before sb; to send sb before sb'
    \so Gen.33.2,48.20
    \nt G&B.665, s.v. |(won)nekehchehoo/won|?
    \xv Kah wunnegonashoh wuttinneumoh mittumwussissoh kah wunnechan∞oh,...
    \xe And he put the handmaids and their children foremost,...'    Gen.33.2  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., kah negonohshau Ephraimoh onk Manassesoh
    \xe ...: and he set Ephraim before Manasseh.'    Gen.48.20  { 3->3
    \so , assuming "simplified" spelling }
    \xv Kah nunnegonshan Angel;...
    \xe And I will send an Angel before thee;...
    \so Ex.33.2
    \ng (E1&2); not 1->2!; 1->3 subordinative?
    \nt ?

    \se |negonshhuau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, indefinite oject to TA
    \ge `to send'
    \so Gen.45.23,27,46.5
    \xv Kah en ∞shut yeu wuttinne negonshhuon, piukqussuoh Asses,...
    \xe And to his father he sent after this manner; ten asses ...
    \so Gen.45.23
    \ng 1 subordinative
    \xv Nunnékónchüam, -ap.
    \xe I send, or did,
    \so C.74/208

    \xv ...tatappequanumukquaash, nish Joseph negonshhuacheh, wunnayeumukqunnat,...
    \xe ..., which Joseph had sent to carry him,...
    \so Gen.45.27
    \ng 3->_0p_ participle
    \xv ..., tatuppequanumukkâhtu, Pharaoh ne negonshhuapash wunnayeumukqunat.
    \xe ..., in the wagons which Pharaoh had sent to carry him'    Gen.46.5  { 3
    \so ->_0p_ preterite participle }

    [Narragansett [xnt] |Nnegónshem.| `I will goe before.', |Negónshesh.| `Goe before.'; |Awanick negonshachick?| `Who are these before us?'    R.W.70;72.]
    \nt +

\et H.2372 *ni∙ka∙nwohΘe∙wa AI `to walk ahead, at the head'


\lx negonshauau
\va negonshhauau
\va negonohshauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
    \nt +
\nt Remark: tentative lemma; presumably an extended form of !|negonuhshaheau| TA; the causative final |-h-| following |-sh-| is not always written; some of the forms contain the indefinite object final in |-uw-á-|, as a place-holder for the person sent (with something); the object sent is perhaps expressed by substantive attribution. Furthermore, it is unclear whether the dative final can be suffixed to an TA stem, or, if it cannot be, what would otherwise give rise to |-auau| structure. (See also the more complex and perhaps incompatible example s.v. |negont∞au|, 2 Chron.2.3.)
\ps TA (TA+O? -- via transitive initial)
\ge `to send sb sth'
    \xv ... pish negonsh∞wam goatsemes wutch floksut:...
    \xe ..., I will send thee a kid from the flock. ...
    \so Gen.38.17
    \ng indefinite object; AI, not 1->2!
    \xv Onk Judah negonshauáu goatsemesoh ut wunnutcheganit wutompuh wutadullamite,...
    \xe And Judah sent the kid by the hand of his friend the Adullamite,...
    \so Gen.38.20
    \xv ..., kah kusseh, noh anogqs, uttoh nauáhetteupuh wutchepwoeiyeu, negonshauoh noh en,...
    \xe ...; and, lo, the star, which they was in the east, went before them,...'    Mt.2.9  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv Newutche ut Thessalonica, kenaau kenegonshhuwamwop pasukqut kah wonk en nukquenauwahikqunat.
    \xe For even in Thessalonica ye sent once and again unto my necessity.
    \so Phil.4.16
    \ng indefinite object, 2p preterite

    \xv Pasoo asuh nekonchhuash saup nompoäe.
    \xe Do you come, or else send him tomorrow early.
    \so C.119/240


\lx negont∞au
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
\ps v.t. / TA
\ge `he sends a message to (him), i.e. `sends word before or in advance of coming'
\so 2 Chr.2.3
    \xv Kah Solomon negont∞au en Hiram Tyre ketass∞t n∞wau . neanheop David n∞sh, kah kenegonchhuontamauop Cedaroh, ∞wesu[h]konat, wutayinneat, (ne unnehe.)
    \xe And Solomon sent to Huram the king of Tyre, saying, As thou didst deal with David my father, and didst send him cedars to build him an house to dwell therein, {even so deal with me}.
    \so 2 Chron.2.3
    \nt +
    (|nunnékónchuam| `I send'    C.)
    \xv ...ne nauman wussukwhush ut wussukwhonganit, kah negonchhuash en nesausuk audtahshinnu∞gish moeuwehkomongash nish ut Asia,...
    \xe ...What thou seest, write in a book, and send it unto the seven churches which are in Asia;...
    \so Rev.1.11
    \ng word not fully legible, but clearly belongs with the example from Cotton (though not under this headword)
    \nt +

    [Algonquian [alg] |NIINA| `de notre nation', |Niinawe| `parler la langue de notre nation'    Cq.271ab.
    \nt +
Cree |nehiyâwiw, ok| `il est Cris', |nehiyâwew, ok| `il parle Cris'; |nehiyâwiw| `S/he is Cree', |nehiyawew| `S/he speaks an aboriginal language, i.e. Cree'; |nêhiyaw-| `Cree; Indian'    Lac.D.492b; Alb.E.110ab; W&A.114-116.

    Shawnee [sjw] |nahalwaa-,...n?halwaa-| (plus |-t-|) `RELATED AS KIN, EARNED, POSSESSED (in reference to home)', |ninahalwa?to|, |ninahalwaha| `I possess it, him'    D.-V.382.]

\lx nehnekikom
\va -ekugkom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
\ps v.t. / TI1a (b?), reduplicated
\ge `he tears or rends (it)'
\so Josh.8.7
    \xv ... nenekkuhkomwog wuthogk∞unash.
    \xe ..., [they] rent their clothes:
    \so Num.14.6
    \nt +
    \xv wunnehnekikomun
    \xe he tears it in pieces
    \so (of a wild beast)    Mic.5.8
    \xv nen nehnekugkom
    \xe I rend (it)
    \so Hos.13.8


    \se nehnekukkau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, reduplicated, |-hk-aw-| stem
    \ge `he tears or rends (him)', as a wild beast his prey
    with affixes |wunnehnékukkauoh| `he tears him'    Lk.9.42

    \nt MN: noh nehnekukauont
    \ng suppositive |noh nehnekukauont| `he who tears (when tearing)'    1 K.13.26
    \xv Noh woh nehnégikáuut, matta kuppaudtauun∞un,...
    \xe That which was torn {of beasts} I brought not unto thee;...
    \so Gen.31.39
    \ng X->3
    \nt +

\dv Intens, from a primary |nekaeu|, with the characteristic (|-uhk|) of continued action. From the same primary are formed |nekussósu| `he cuts or gashes'; |nehneksaeu| `it rends or tears'; |nehnekinum| `he tears (it) by hand, etc.' See the following.

    [?Cree |yikittowisiw| `il se divise en fourche, il est fourchu'; |Tháthicke-pu@thu| `it rends, as cloth.'    Lac.D.662a; Howse 146.
    \nt +
Ill. {R} |Riki, rica| in compos v.ulgo `rupture, destruction de qq^ chose', |Rikica8i| `dechiré, rompu'    M.509/291b.
Menominee [mez] |ne∙kanεn| AI, |ne∙kanεt| II `he, it goes out of shape with decay', |ne∙keskaw| AI, II `he, it rots away; he has a skin eruption'    M.L.159.
Ojibwe [oji] |Nanânigama, (nin)| `I tear some {an.} obj. with the teeth'; |Nigoshkân, (nin)| `I tear it to pieces'    Bar.272b;288a.
Shawnee |liiky-| `dismantled'    D.-V.347.]

\et H.1449 *li∙kahamwa `divide' (C,F)

\lx nehtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
    \nt +
\ps TI2, causative to |nup-|
\twn |nuhshau| TA
\ge `to kill, slay sth, to mortify sth, to sacrifice sth; to perish'
\so Gen.20.4,41.36, Lev.6.25,27.29, Col.3.5, Rev.6.8
    \xv ..., ayeuonganit ne adt nushit chikohtae sephausuonk, matcheseongane sephausuonk pish ut nehtauun, ut anaquabit Jehovah,...
    \xe ...: In the place where the burnt offering is killed shall the sin offering be killed before the Lord:...
    \so Lev.6.25
    \ng X->0
    \xv Matta kenehtó∞ paumukóadtuonk, woh toh ut kuttinnóme kuhheganit,...
    \xe Thou mayest not sacrifice the passover within any of thy gates,...
    \so Deut.16.5

    \xv Wunnaumonuh Jakob quenittamwog ne nohtômuk,...
    \xe The sons of Jacob came upon the slain,...
    \so Gen.34.27
    \ng X->_0_

    \xv Newutche nehtau∞k kuppompuhchaiyeum∞ash nish muttaohket ohtagish,...
    \xe Mortify therefore your members which are upon the earth;...
    \so Col.3.5

    \se nehtauau
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem
    \ge `to kill sb/sth for sb'
    \so Lk.15.30
    \nt Remark: Lk.15.30 illustrates the general point that the direct object of a double object verb derived by means of |-aw-| is not restricted to the gender requirements of the source TI verb.
    \xv ..., kenehtau wanogqunutche kalfoh.
    \xe ..., thou hast killed for him the fatted calf.
    \so Lk.15.30

\et H.2308 *ne?ta∙wa TI `to kill sth' (i.e. *nepta∙wa).

\lx nehtô-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 83
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge `cunning, skilful'
\so entries following, s.v. |nehtônum|, |nóhtoe|, !|nohtompeantam|, !|nohtompuhpequau|, (these latter two usually as participles); cognates

    [Remark: There are in some languages two sets of initials of somewhat similar shape occupying similar semantic fields: more analysis required; those in |-aw| probably are distinct (though such are apparent in root extensions in H.2231-2236).
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |NITA|, (|nita-|}) `se met devant un verbe pour signifier qu'on a coutume de faire l'action qu'exprime ce verbe, qu'on sait la faire, qu'on est capable de la faire. Cette particule sert quelquefois à rendre notre terminaison française ...{eur}, {euse}', |NITAWIH, NITAWITON| `sois capable de le faire'    Cq.283b-284a.
Cree +|NITTA| (rac) `propre à, etc, apte à, etc., habile à, etc.', |nittâwihew, ttaw| `il en est capable, il le peut'; |Ne`ta| {partic.} `Prefixed to verbs to express expertness, readiness, ability, etc.'    Lac.D.504ab; Frs.360b-361a.
Delaware [del] |nihtaa-| PV `skilfully, know how to (do something)', |nihtáhtoow| TI2 `know how to do s.t.'    O'M.202b-203a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |nataw-| `know how to', |netaw-|; |nadà-wi-| `a productive prefix denoting capability, expertise or skill', |nedà-wi|; ?perhaps also: Micmac |nuja-|, |nuji-|, |nut-| [various agent nouns in "-er"|    DeB.53ab, 55b-56a; MCS.274a, 281a-282b; DeB.58b-60b.
M.-P. |'tawi| (|`taw-|), |-nihtawi-| PV `know how; be good at'; ?perhaps also: ?|nuci| (|nuc-|, |nut-|) PreV `do something on a regular basis or as an occupation'; |noci-| (|not-|) `einen Beruf (Anstellung, Arbeit) haben'    LeS.92b; LeS.56a-57b; Sz.150-151,153-154.
WAbn. |ntôw-| `capable, competent, expert, able to do something well', |ntôwto| AI `be capable, able to do something well'; ?perhaps also: WAbn. |nod...-igad|, |noj...igad| `one who does ... as a trade of profession', |noji-|    D.1.lvii, 390-391; D.1.lvi; exs.371-375.]

\et H.2242-2247 *neht-? (+H.2231-2236, as |-s| alternants)

\lx nekheau

\nt Remark: See also |-ekheau|, s.v. |neetu|
\ps TA, causative to AI |nek(i)-|
\twn |nekehteau| TI2
\ge `to bear, beget sb' (i.e. a child)
\so Gen.4.1,2,20,6.4,15.3,48.6; Ezra 10.3; Lk.11.27
    \xv ..., kah wompequôou, kah neekheau Kainoh,...

    \so absolute }

    \xv ..., & kusseh noh neekkit ut neekit, noh wamahtunk nutahtauonk.
    \xe ...: and, lo, one born in my house is mine heir.
    \so Gen.15.3
    \ng X->_3_ participle; (E2) has |neek-/kit|, for (E0&E1): |neekhit| "borne"
    \xv Kah keneechanog neekheadcheg nahohtóeu onk nagoh. neg pish kuttaiheog ...
    \xe And thy issue, which thou begettest after them, shall be thine,...
    \so Gen.48.6
    \ng 2->_3p_ participle
    \xv ..., Wunnanumau ôontomuk noh nekhikqueas, kah sogkodtunkash nish n∞n∞washash.
    \xe ..., Blessed is the womb that bare thee, and the paps which thou hast sucked.
    \so Lk.11.27
    \ng _3_->2 subjunctive (as participle) preterite


\lx nekitteauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 84
    \nt +
\ps TA(+O)
\dv |-ht-aw-|, directive stem to AI(+O) stem, with infection; the identity of the initial, the lack of any trace of the |ht| spelling, and the argument structure are puzzling.
\ge `to bear sb (un)to sb, to be born unto sb' (i.e. "[a child] to [a father]")
\so Gen.16.1,21.3,5,9,24.24,47,25.2,26,30.19,34.1,35.26,36.4,5,14,38.5,46.18,20,25,27; Deut.21.15;Ruth 4.12; 1 Chron.3.1,3.4,3.5; Job 1.2; Jer.20.15
    \xv QUt Sarai Abram ummittamwussoh matta wunneekitteunk∞oh;...
    \xe Now Sarai Abrams wife bare him no children:...'    Gen.16.1  { 3
    \so ->3 negative objective, no direct object expressed }
    \xv Kah wunnekitteunkquoh Zimram,...
    \xe And she bare him Zimran,...'    Gen.25.2  { ?3'->3+3
    \so objective }
    \xv Kah wonk Leah wompoquau, kah nekitteauau Jakoboh nequtta tahshu wunnaumonuh.
    \xe And Leah conceived again, and bare Jacob the sixth son.'    Gen.30.19  { 3->3'+3
    \so indicative, with expected obviative }
    \xv Kah Adah nekitteauau Esauoh, Eliphaz, kah Bashemath nekheau Revel.
    \xe And Adah bare to Esau Eliphaz; and Bashemath bare Reuel;'    Gen.36.4  { 3->3'+3(
    \so ) indicative, second object unmarked }
    \xv ..., Mukkutchouks keneeketeont,...
    \xe ..., A man child is born unto thee;...
    \so Jer.20.15
    \ng 3->2 indicative?; here "thee" denotes the father.

    \xv Onk Abraham wuttussowenuh wunnaumonuh neh neekitteawutche, Sarah neekitteauwonche, Isaak:
    \xe And Abraham called the name of his son that was born unto him, whom Sarah bare to him, Isaac.'    Gen.21.3  { X->3+_3'_; 3->3'+_3
    \so _ }
    \xv ...: kah appu Chezip nekitteauut.
    \xe ...: and he was at Chezib, when she bare him.'    Gen.38.5  { ?X->3'+3
    \so }
    \xv ...Phares (neh Tamar nekitteaompuh Judahoh)...
    \xe ... Pharez, whom Tamar bare unto Judah,...'    Ruth 4.12  { 3->3'+_3
    \so _ preterite }
    \xv Kah yeuh wunnaumonuh D(a)vid, yeuh neekitteawómukuppaneh ut Hebron:..
    \xe Now these were the sons of David, which were born unto him in Hebron;...'    1 Chron.3.1  { X->3+_3
    \so _ preterite participle }

    \se -ekitteauau
    \ps TA, de-stem form
    \ge `to bear sb --'
    \so Gen.44.27
    \xv ..., K∞wahteauunneau nummittumwos neesweekitteunk;
    \xe ..., Ye know that my wife bare me two sons.
    \so Gen.44.27
    \ng 3->2 indicative

\lx nemehkuh

    \ng manner adverbial, anaphoric

    \so Gen.21.32

    \xe so
    \so (accordingly)    Gen.37.14√

\lx nemunnum
\va nemunum
\va neemunum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 84
\ps v.t. / TI1b, manual final
\ge `he takes (it) in or with his hand'
\so Ex.24.6; Is.40.15; Mt.14.19
    \xv Onk wame neemunnumwog maumachiyeuash ut Sodom,...
    \xe And they took all the goods of Sodom...
    \so Gen.14.11
    \ng 3p->0p absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah mátta woh neemunnúmo ne teaguas ne ahtoan,...
    \xe ..., and that I will not take any thing that is thine,...
    \so Gen.14.23
    \ng 1->0 negative absolute
    \nt +
    pl. |-umwog| `they take (it)'    Josh.4.8

    \xv Onk ne muhpeteog Jehovah Manit neemunuk wutch wosketompaut,...
    \xe And the rib, which the Lord God had taken from man,...
    \so Gen.2.22
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |nemunush|
    pl. |-num∞k|
    \xv Kah neemunush ken wame ne woh meechumuk,...
    \xe And take thou unto thee of all food that is eaten,...
    \so Gen.6.20
    \ng 2->0 imperative
    \nt +

    \se nemunau
    \ps with an.obj. / TA, manual final
    \ge `he takes (him)' { e.g. `leads, conducts' }
    \so Josh.2.4
    \xv Onk Jehovah Manit neemunau Adam kah upponuh tanohketeaonganit Eden,...
    \xe And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden...'    Gen.2.15  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +

    \xv ...: ken noh namunneohp wutch noohkas unnogkusset:...
    \xe ...: thou art he that took me out of my mothers bowels:...
    \so Ps.71.6(M)
    \ng _3_->1 preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv Kah howan quoshomont ummittamwussoh, kah asq nemununk? ...
    \xe And what man is there that hath betrothed a wife, and hath not taken her? ...'    Deut.20.7  { _3_->3
    \so negative conjunct }
    \nt +

    \xv Kah neemun∞k k∞sh∞, kah kek∞óash,...
    \xe And take your father and your households,...
    \so Gen.45.18
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nemun Joshua wunnaumonuh Nun, ... kah ponumau kenutcheg.
    \xe ..., Take thee Joshua the son of Nun, ..., and lay thine hand upon him;
    \so Num.27.18
    \ng 2->3 imperative
    \nt +

    \se !|nemunumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final (of disadvantage)
    \ge `to take sth from, of sb'
    \so Gen.2.21,14.23,30.37,31.31,44.29; Num.16.15; Lk.11.22,19.8; 3 Jn.7
    \xv ...; wunnemunumauoh wame wuttinnauwameonk,...
    \xe ..., he taketh from him all his armour,...'    Lk.11.22  { 3->3
    \so -pro+0 }
    \xv Newutche, wutche ∞wesuonk sohhámwog, wanne teag wunnemunumóunnaóut wutch gentilsut.
    \xe Because that for his name's sake they went forth, taking nothing of the Gentiles.'    3 Jn.7  { 3p->(3
    \so )+0, negative t-subordinative }

    \xv ..., kah nemunumauog howan ne teaguas náshpe pann∞wáe spunnonnaonk, nunnompenumau yauut tahsheu.
    \xe ...; and if I have taken any thing from any man by false accusation, I restore him fourfold.
    \so Lk.19.8
    \ng 1->3+0

    \xv Ahque neemunumau wutchiyeuonk,...
    \xe Take thou no usury of him,...
    \so Lev.25.36
    \ng 2->3+0 imperative
    \nt +

    \se !|nemunumwanshau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-nuhsh-| representative/benefactive final
    \ge `to bring sth unto sb, take sb sth'
    \so Gen.15.9; Ex.25.2,3; Lev.14.4,15.14; Num.3.41,17.2; Deut.30.12

    \xv ... howan pish kohkuhqueanishhikqueog ne kesukquehtu, kah nemunumwanshhikqueog ...
    \xe ..., Who shall go up for us to heaven, and bring it unto us,...
    \so Deut.30.12
    \ng _3_->1p+0 participle; sp. with additional |h| in E1&2: no obvious role (justification?), and absent ib.30.13

    \xv ... neemunnumwansheh kowushinem nashwekodtum wohkog,...
    \xe ..., Take me an heifer of three years old,...
    \so Gen.15.9
    \ng 2->1+0 imperative

    \cf maumunni
    \ge it is taken away
    \xv tohqunnum
    \xe he catches or takes hold of it
    \so , etc.
The formative, |-unnum| (an.obj. |-unau|), denotes, generally, action performed by the hand; more exactly, physical action performed directly upon the object without the intervention of an instrument or agent.

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |nenimadámen|, nob. |nenimamañ| `Je prens qq ch. avec la bouche'    R.66/398a.
    \nt +
Ill. {R} |Ninima| `je le porte ala main, entre mes bras', |Ninime| ign. |Ninima8a| `je luy porte je porte ce qui est a luy'    Gr.343-344/206b.
Miami |niim-| TA/TI `carry sb/sth aloft in hand'    B&C.91b.]

\et H. (2378), 2382-2384 *ni∙m- `hold (up), raise'; also H.2376-2377 `food for journey', as in e.g. |NIM| (rac.) `porter avec soi, avoir des provisions de bouche, il est approvisionné de vivres', Lac.D.497a?

\lx nequittéconnaúog
\lg Narragansett [xnt]

    \xv nequttika

\lx nequt
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 84
    \nt Remark: This root does not appear to be attested in Mayhew's texts, though there are examples in the native writings (see G&B.667-668, Word index).
    \nt +
\ps num. / PreN, PreV
\ge `one'
\so El.Gr.14 (see Pickering's Notes, xliv-xlvi)
    |nequtta tahshe| (1+5) `six'    Job 5.19
    \xv nequtta tahshinchag
    \xe sixty
    \so 2 Sam.2.31
\nt Cotton makes this distinction between |nequt| and |pasuk| (q.v.)
    "|nequt|, a thing that is past: |pasuk|, a thing in being," which, though not absolutely correct, is perhaps etymologically well founded.
|Nequt| appears to be nearly related to |negonne| `first in order', and to |nukkone| (another form of the same word), `old', or `left behind'; perhaps also to |nekin| `it is born or begins to be'. The primary meaning is that which begins a series: one, as a beginning of numeration, while |pasuk| signifes one by itself, a unit.

    \se !|nequttu∞|
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: The predicative verb is largely attested only in complex numerals, |pasuk| providing more straightforward instances of such usage. The role of the indicative verbs in apparently attributive use is uncertain.
    \ps AI, predicative, i-stem
    \ge "to be one"
    \so Gen.32.22,37.9; Josh.15.51(II); Mt.28.16; Mk.16.14; Lk.24.33
    \xv ..., kah nabo nequttuoh wunnaumonuh. ...
    \xe ..., and his eleven sons,...
    \so Gen.32.22
    \xv Neit nabo nequttuog kodnetuhtaenuog auog Galile,...
    \xe Then the eleven disciples went away into Galilee,...
    \so Mt.28.16
    \xv ...kah mo weetogkemau nabo nequttu∞og Apostlesog.
    \xe ...; and he was numbered with the eleven apostles.
    \so Acts 1.26

    \xv ..., kah nameheáog nabo nequttuunutcheh moiéog,...
    \xe ..., and found the eleven gathered together,...'    Lk.24.33  { _3
    \so _ participle }

    \se nequttu∞
    \ps II
    \ge "to be one"
    \so Josh.15.51
    \xv ..., nabo nequttu∞ash keitotanash nashpe wutotanamesu∞ash.
    \xe ...; eleven cities with their villages.
    \so Josh.15.51

[Narragansett [xnt] |nquít|.
Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |nuquút|    Stiles.
Western Abenaki [abe] |pézek8| `one'; |nek8dañs| `six'; |neg8da`teg8^é| `one hundred', etc.; |nek8tsi8i| `sans mélange d'aucune chose, ... uniquem't...sans mélange'; +|nañnek8tsi8i| `parfois'    R.358/493ab;P.22/557b;P.6/549b.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |nek8t| `un, une fois'.]

\et H.2258 *nekwetwi `one'

\lx nequt∞hkauau
\va -∞kauau
\va okauau
\ve part of entry transferred from  `he', T.104b
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 85
    \nt +
\ps AI, bahuvrihi (dvigu)
\ge `to have one wife'
    \xv nequt ∞kauau
    \xe ..., the husband of one wife,...
    \so 1 Tim.3.2  [unius uxoris (virum); miâs gunaikòs ándra]
    \ng agent noun derivative?

    \xv Howan mat mataunchemóunónt, nequt∞hkauont, wunnechanoh pabuhtanumukqussinit,...
    \xe If any be blameless, the husband of one wife, having faithful children ...
    \so Tit.1.6
    \ng _3_ participle

    \xv Deakonsog nequt∞kauwáhettich,...
    \xe Let the deacons be the husbands of one wife,...
    \so 1 Tim.3.12
    \ng 3p imperative

\nt Presumably some term for wife or spouse is lurking as a medial noun |-∞(h)kau-| (+ the usual decompound AI final |-á-|) in this form. See T+.112a. No directly applicable plausible shapes are to be found in Hockett 1964 or Speck 1918. No doubt the forms |okas| `mother' and |okummes| `aunt, grandmother' do not constitute accidental resemblances.
    On the question of the precise meaning of the medial, the following lemma and Rasles's gloss provide some preliminary data.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nis8`ka8é|, 1a. |nenis8'`ka8a| `Homme qui a 2 femmes . femme q. a 2 maris'    R.286/467a.]

\ps AI, bahuvrihi (dvigu)

    \so 1 Tim.5.9

\lx nesáusuk
\va nesausuk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 85
\ps num. / cardinal numeral
\ge `seven'
\so Mk.8.5
\nt El.Gr.14/260
\nt usually with |tahshe| or |adtahshe|; +the distribution of the attributive forms with and without agreement remains unclear.
    \xv Nesausuk tahshe.
    \xe 7
    \so El.Gr.14/260
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah nesausuk tahsuog sephausuenuog, nesausuk tahshinash ramse askonne monopuhpequash kenunnumóhettich ut anaquohtag wut Arkum Jehovah.
    \xe ..., and let seven priests bear seven trumpets of rams' horns before the ark of the Lord.
    \so Josh.6.6
    \nt +
    \xv nesáusuk tahshe
    \xe seven
    \so Ezek.45.23
    an. pl. |-tahsuog|    Ezek.45.23

    \se |nesausuk tahsuog|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, numeral verb, plurale tantum
    \ge `to be seven' (in number)
    \so Gen.46.24
    \xv ..., wame keteahogkôunog nesausuk tahsuog.
    \xe ...: all the souls were seven.
    \so Gen.46.24

    \xv John en nesausuk tahshinash moeuwehkomongásh ut Asia, ..., kah wutch nesausuk audtahs∞itcheg nashauanitt∞og, neg apitcheg anaquohtag wutappuonk.
    \xe JOHN to the seven churches wich are in Asia: ...; and from the seven spirits which are before his throne;
    \so Rev.1.4
    \ng _3p_ participle

[Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |nezzáugnsk|    Stiles.
Narragansett [xnt] |énada|.
Western Abenaki [abe] |tañba8añs|.
Cree |néeshwâssík| or |téypuckoop|.

\lx netassu
\va netasu
\va neetasu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 85
    \nt Remark: The final vowel generally present in uninflected forms in (E) and (M), but absent in C.
    \nt +
\ps v.adj. (as n.) / NA
    \nt G&B.669

\ge `a domestic animal', +`cattle'

    \xe the firstlings of his flock
    \so Gen.4.4

    (|Nompashim netas, usquashimwe netas.| `A bull, cow'    C.4/156)

    \so Gen.4.20; Num.32.4

    \xe ..., and thy servants have cattle:

\dv |neetu| and (the base of) |assamau| `he feeds him': `house-fed animals'.

\lx nishkeneunkque
\va -ungque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 86
\ps PreN, II
\ge `(it is) unclean, filthy'
\so Lev.5.2; 1 Tim.3.3,8

    \nt MN: -unkquok
    \ng suppositive |-unkquok| `when it is unclean'    Lev.5.2
    \ng to |nishkeneungquodt| below
    \xv ne --
    \xe that which is unclean, filthy, "abominable"
    \so Jer.44.4; Lev.7.21

    \se nishkeneunkqussu
    \ps With an. subj. v. adj. an. / AI
    \ge `he is unclean, (one who is) unclean', etc.
    \so Lev.11.5; 12.2; Job 15.16

    \nt MN: -ussìt
    \ng suppositive |-ussìt| Lev.5.3

    \se -ussuonk
    \ps Vbl.n. (an.)
    \ge `uncleaness'
    \so Lev.5.3; Col.3.5

    \se |nishkeneunkquodt|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to be unclean'
    \so Lev.11.32,35,15.4; Rom.14.14, Jas.1.27, 1 Pet.1.4
    \xv Nishnoh appin uttoh kait, noh sohwutchuwanneit, pish nishkeneunkquodt,..
    \xe Every bed, whereon he lieth that hath the issue, is unclean:...
    \so Lev.15.4

    \xv ..., matta teaguas nishkeneunkquodtinn∞ nusseu qut noh wadt∞wontog teaguas nishkeneunkquok, nishkeneunkquodtinn∞ wuhhogkat.
    \xe ..., that there is nothing unclean of itself: but to him that esteemeth any thing to be unclean, to him it is unclean.
    \so Rom.14.14
    \ng second negative independent form in (unfortunate) error? printer?
    \xv Pahke peantamóonk kah matta nishkeneunkquodtinn∞g ut anaquabit GOD, kah wut∞shimau, yeu,...
    \xe Pure religion and undefiled before God and the Father is this,...
    \so Jas.1.27

    \se nishkeneunkquodtau
    \ps With inan. subj. / II
    \ge `it is unclean or filthy'

    \se -odtáe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \so Zech.3.3,4

[Delaware [del] |nis ksu| `nasty'; +|Niskeu| (etc.) `nasty, dirty'; |níiskew| II, |níisksuw| AI `be dirty'    Zeisb.; B&A.98; O'M.197a-199b.
    Lp.A. |Niskit8n8| `il parle mal des ons et des autres'    D.51.

\lx nishwe
\va nish
\va shwe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 86
\ps num. / PreN, PreV, ?and counting form
\ge `three'
    \nt G&B.660,670
    \nt +
\so El.Gr.14; Ex.21.11
    |nishweu|    1 Cor.13.13
    pl.an. |nishuog|
    \xv ... kah kusseh, nishuoh wosketompuh weechekompaumuk,...
    \xe ..., and, lo, three men stood by him:...
    \so Gen.18.2
    \ng obviative
    \nt +
    inan. |nishwinash|, |shwinash|    1 Chr.21.10
More exactly
    \xv nish
    \xe three
    \so ;
    |nishwe|, adj. (inan.) `the third'    Rev.6.5; 2 K.19.29; (an.) Dan.5.7; Rev.4.7;
    \xv shwe peksú∞ nanohkinausik n∞khik
    \xe three measures of fine meal
    \so Gen.18.6
    \ng ?PreV to deverbal noun
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah adtahtunk nìsheu peksogut n∞khik,...
    \xe ... and hid in three measures of meal,...
    \so Lk.13.21
    \nt +
    and adv. `thirdly'    2 Cor.12.28
    \xv ut nashwe kodtum∞∞uk
    \xe the third year
    \so Deut.26.12√
    \ng changed PreV
    |nishwu| "adv. of order" `thirdly'    El.Gr.21

    \xv nishwudt n∞mpe
    \xe three times, at the third time
    \so Ex.23.14,17; Ezek.21.14.
    \ng locative

    \se !|nishu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, predicative
    \ge "to be three"; _3_ participle: `third'

    suppos. (an.) |nash∞it| `when he is third, he who is third'    Rev.16.4  { _3_ participle }
    \xv Kah nashuudt angel pepequau,...
    \xe And the third angel sounded,...
    \so Rev.8.10
    \ng _3_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nashuudt neyane wonk.
    \xe ...; and the third [brother] likewise.
    \so Mk.12.21
    \ng _3_ participle
    \nt +
    = |nash∞ut|    Rev.14.9
    = |nasheu∞ut|    Mt.22.26

    \se !|nishwinnu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge "to be three"; _0_ participle: `third'
    \so Gen.2.14,6.16,38.24; Jn.21.14; Rev.11.14,21.19

    \xv ..., negonohtag óhquann∞nog, nahohtoohtag, kah nashwunnu∞ug pish kutayim.
    \xe ...; with lower, second, and third stories shalt thou make it.
    \so Gen.6.16
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt Remark: |nashwinneahettit nepauzsaog| "about three months after", Gen.38.24: apparently animate _3p_ participle, to this stem; correct?

\cf nashaue
\ge between

\et A.1503, H.2319 *ne?Θwi `three', H.2323 *ne?Θwiwa AI `to be three'; on the II stem in |-n-|, cf. Del. |nxúnool| II `be three of them, be three in number' (O'M.207b), Miami |nihsenwi| num. `three times' (B&C.90a), |nΘene| `three times' (D.-V.381); also B.1962, 15.193, 307?

\lx nnih
\va unni
\va unnai
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 86
\ps v.i. / II, aphetic form, sometimes spelt |n nih| etc.
\ge `it is so, it is like or the same as' (with an. subj. |neanussu|, q.v.); +`to come to pass (that)'
\nt G.1981, 10, p.59 etc.; G&B.720, s.v. |unnai|, with listing of entries in T; see also esp. s.v. |unni|, T.170b.
    \xv neanussit wosketomp, nnih ummenukesu∞nk
    \xe as is a man so is his strength
    \so Judg.8.21
    \xv mónkó nnih
    \xe it was so
    \so Gen.1.7
    \xv Onk nôadt nnih∞p ...
    \xe And in process of time it came to pass, that ...
    \so Gen.4.3
    \ng 0 preterite; (E0&1) |n nih∞p|
    \nt +
    \xv nnih
    \xe it came to pass
    \so Gen.6.1; 38.1; Mt.7.28
    \xv Kah Laban n∞wau kusseh, nukkodtantam niyóuut ne an∞wáan.
    \xe And Laban said, Behold, I would it might be according to thy word.
    \so Gen.30.34; (E0) |niyeuut|
    \ng t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv nè yeuyeu nnih
    \xe that now is (so)
    \so Eccl.3.15
    \xv uttoh woh yeush en nnih
    \xe how can these things be (so)?
    \so Jn.3.9
    \xv ne mos nnih
    \xe it must needs be so
    \so Mk.13.7
    pret. |nniyeup| `it was so'    Eccl.3.15
    pl. |yeush nniyeupash| `these things were so'    Is.66.2

    \nt MN: nnag
    \ng suppositive |nnag|
    \xv nnih mahche yeu nnag
    \xe it came to pass after this' i.e. `it was so after this was so
    \so 2 Sam.13.1
\cf neane
\cf unne

[Delaware [del] |Leu| `true'; `it is so'; +|léew| II `be, happen'    Zeisb.Gr.173; Zeisb.Voc.9;+O'M.134a.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |arâi|, |arâighesa|, |arâigheban| `cela arrive, hoc accidit'    R.34/387b.
    \nt +

\lx nnih
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 87
    \nt Remark: identical to |nnih| above.
    \nt +
\ps II
\ge `(it) was so'
\so Gen.1.7
    `it came to pass'    Gn.6.1; 38.1; Mt.7.28
    `is'    Eccl.3.15
    = |unne| q.v.
\nt Apparently a verb substantive from |nan| or |neane|, literally `it (was) so', or `it (is) so':
    \xv n∞wáog nennih
    \xe they said these things were so
    \so Acts 24.9
    \xv uttoh woh yeush en nnih
    \xe how can these things be (so)?
    \so Jn.3.9
    \xv nnih mahche yeu nnag
    \xe it came to pass after this' (`it was so after this was so
    \so )    2 Sam.13.
    \xv ne mahche ánagkup, ne yeuyeu nnih
    \xe that which hath been is now
    \so Eccl.3.15
    \xv ne pish ának mahche nniyeup
    \xe that which is to be hath already been
    \so Eccl.3.15
    \xv yeush nniyeupash
    \xe these things have been
    \so Is.66.2
    \xv nniyeup
    \xe it came to pass' (`was so
    \so )    Neh.4.12
    \xv ne mos nnih
    \xe it must needs be so
    \so Mk.13.7
    \xv woh nniyeuash
    \xe (all things) are possible' (`may be so
    \so )    Mk.10.27
    (|nenih| `that is'    C.181
    |ne ennih| or |nemehkuh ne| (conj.) `so that'    C.234)
\cf áunag

[Narragansett [xnt] |Eîu| { or } |Nnîu?| `Is it so?'    R.W.5; |Nni, eíu.| `it is true'    ibid.57.√]

[This second definition of |nnih| appears in the unrevised portion of the manuscript between the term |nishk| and ||p||, and, although it repeats to some extent the references contained in the first (revised) definition, it is here inserted in full. The first definition of |nnih| occurs in the revised manuscript, where it follows the term *|nickómmo|.]


\lx nnìn
\va ninn-
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 87
\ps NA
\ge `man', +`male'
\so R.W.
    pl. |nnínnuog|,
    |...; but two sorts of {names} they had, and have amongst {themselves}. / First, {generall}, belonging to all {Natives}, as {|Nínnuock|}, {|Ninnimißinnûwock|}, {|Eniskeetompaüwog|}, which signifies {Men}, {Folke}, or {People}.| `'    R.W.A3v
    \nt +
    |Nnìn-nnínnuog, {&} |keétomp-aûog|    `Man_men'    R.W.27
    \nt +
    |Wuttàke wuchè wuckeesittin pausuck Enìn|, {or}, |Eneskéetomp.|    `Last of all he made one Man'    R.W.125/r.133
    \nt +
    \xv ..., God ukkezheuh nahoh ninnuoh kah squa.
    \xe ... God made them male and female.
    \so Mk.10.6
    \nt +

\nt [R.W.] who also writes |enin| `man', and pl. |nínnuock|, a "general name belonging to all natives". Related to |ne|, |neen| (`I'), |nanwe|, and |unne| (of the kind or species), the radical meaning of |nnin| or |nnìnnu| is, `he is like myself', or `of the same kind'. This word could properly have no place in Eliot's translation. It is, however, once or twice introduced, as in Mk.10, 6: |ninnuoh (accusat.) kah squa| `male and female', i.e. `man and woman'. The Indians restricted its application to men of their own race or like themselves. (See |nanwe|.)


[Quiripi [qyp] |ren|, pl. |rènawawk|.
Western Abenaki [abe] |arenañbé| `homme'; |nedarenañd8"e@| `Je parle Abnaqui'.    R.286/467a;379/499b.√
Chip. |inini|    Bar.; |enínnee|    J.
Cree |Ethínu|, `(homo) a man, an Indian'    Howse 18.√
Shawnee [sjw] |èe len eè| `man'; |len àh wai| `an Indian'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |ln8i| homo.
Delaware [del] |lenno| `man'; |lenâpé| [= Abn. |arenañbé] `a Delaware', vir; |lenni| `a man'    Zeisb. (see |nanwe|); |lin ni le na pe| `Indians of the same nation'    Zeisb.S.B.70.
    Lp.A |ilin8| `un homme fait'    D.16.]

\lx nôeu
\va nóe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 87
\ps adj.; / +initial, PreN, often following |en|, |ut|, often governs locative, PreV; often with implicit anaphoric object as "in the midst of it, them".
\ge `in the middle, the midst'; +normally spatial, with occasional temporal usage.
\so Ex.15.8; Judg.16.29
    \xv en nóeu
    \xe in the midst
    \so Prov.23.34; Mt.10.16
    = |ut nôeu|    Ps.78.28
    \xv ... kah wutchadchabenuh ut nôeu,...
    \xe ... and divided them in the midst,...
    \so Gen.15.10
    \ng i.e. "cut them down, through the middle"
    \nt +
    \xv nóeukommuk
    \xe in the midst of the hall
    \so (i.e. inclosed place)    Lk.22.55
    \xv ut nôeu adtanohketeamuk
    \xe in the midst of the garden
    \so Gen.2.9
    \xv ... kah sohh∞wunau Lotuh wutch nôeu kepuhkonittuonganit,...
    \xe ..., and sent Lot out of the midst of the overthrow ...
    \so Gen.19.29
    \nt +
    \xv wutch nôeu asinnekóusséhtu
    \xe from the midst of the bush
    \so Ex.3.2
    \xv ..., ahque amauneh nóeu ut nukkesukkodtumut,...
    \xe ..., take me not away in the midst of my days:...
    \so Ps.102.24; (M) |ut noeu nukkesukkodtumut|
    \ng temporal
    \nt +
    \xv wushou nôeu Samaria kah Galile
    \xe went through the midst of Samaria and Galilee
    \so Lk.17.11
    \xv ..., kah nôe ponáhettit,
    \xe ...; and when they had set her in the midst,
    \so Jn.8.3
    \nt +
\cf nashaue
