\lx nogkohkáeihhuunát
\va nogkohkouheau
\va nogguhkouheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 88
\ps v.t. / TA, apparently causative (permissive?) to |nogkohkou| `to borrow'
\ge `to lend']
    \so Deut.15.2,6,8,24.11,28.12,44
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nish noh howan wunnoguhkouheuh wetatteámunguh, pish kutahquoantaúsim∞,...
    \xe ...: Every creditor that lendeth aught unto his neighbour shall release it;...'    Deut.15.2  { 3->3
    \so +0 }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish kenogkohkouwe(h) monaog wutohtimóneunk, qut matta pish kenogkohkó∞h ...
    \xe ...: and thou shalt lend unto many nations, but thou shalt not borrow;...
    \so Deut.15.6√
    \ng 2->3; original quotation defective, untraced
    \xv Noh pish kenogguhkouhik, kah matta pish kenogguhkouheuh,...
    \xe He shall lend to thee, and thu shalt not lend to him:...
    \so Deut.28.44
    \nt +
    \xv Micheme monaneteau, kah nogkohkaeihhuun:...
    \xe He is ever merciful, and lendeth;...
    \so Ps.37.26
    \ng indefinite object; (M) |nogkohkauwehhuwau|
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah wosketomp noh nogohkouheadt, noh pish kussohh∞wuttunk ukkenohtohsuonk.
    \xe ..., and the man to whom thou dost lend shall bring out the pledge abroad to thee.
    \so Deut.24.11
    \ng 2->_3_
    \nt +
    \xv noh nogohkouheoncheh
    \xe that which is lent to
    \so 1 Sam.2.20

    \se nogohkoônit
    \va -kouhuadt
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `he who lends, a lender'
    \so Is.24.2; Prov.22.7
\cf namohkaeikheau


\lx nogkohkouunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 88
\ps v.t. / AI
\ge `to borrow']
    \xv Matcheetou nogohkou qut matta wonk wunnompenumo∞un:...
    \xe The wicked borroweth, and payeth not again:...
    \so Ps.37.21√; (M) |nogohkou|
    \xv matta pish kenogkohkó∞h
    \xe thou shalt not borrow
    \so Deut.15.6
    \xv ..., kah pish kenogguhkoue monaog wutohtimoneash, kah matta pish kenógohkóou.
    \xe ...: and thou shalt lend unto many nations, and thou shalt not borrow.
    \so Deut.28.12
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Tauwanne nussontimom, newutche nogkohkauunah:
    \xe ..., Alas, master! for it [the axe] was borrowed.
    \so 2 K.6.5√
    \ng X->0 objective (absentative?)

    \se !|nogkuhkauonau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative
    \ge `to borrow of sb'
    \so Mt.5.42

    \xv Howan wehquttumunkquean, aninnumau, noh nogkuhkaónukquean, ahque qushketau.
    \xe Give to him that asketh thee, and from him that would borrow of thee turn not thou away.
    \so Mt.5.42
    \ng _3_->2; AV solecism

    \se nogkohkouaenin
    \ps n. agent.
    \ge `a borrower'
    \so Is.24.2
    = |nogkuhkauwaenin|    Prov.22.7

    \se |nogkuhkouonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `hire'
    \so Gen.30.18
    \xv ..., GOD nuttinnumunk nunnoguhkouonk, newutche nuttinnumau nummaidumoh nasuk:...
    \xe ..., God hath given me my hire, because I have given my maiden to my husband:...
    \so Gen.30.18

\cf namohkau

\lx nogkushkauónat
\va nogkusk-
\va nogkishk-
\va nogskauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 88
\ps v.t.an. / TA, corporal final
\ge `to meet (anyone)', +`to |nogkuskauwau|
\ps v.t.an. / TA, corporal final
\ge `to meet (anyone)', +`to meet with sb'
\so Jer.51.31; Mt.25.1
    \xv Onk ketass∞t Sodom sohham wunnogskauoh,...
    \xe And the king of Sodom went out to meet him,...'    Gen.14.17  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah wonk kusseh, peyau kenogskunkq, kah nogquean, weekontam ut wuttahhut.
    \xe .... And also, behold, he cometh forth to meet thee: and when he seeth thee, he will be glad in his heart.
    \so Ex.4.14
    \ng 3->2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Onk na kuttit nogkushkauunun,...
    \xe And there will I meet with thee,...
    \so Ex.25.22
    \ng 1->2 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ken∞gskunkqunat
    \xe to meet thee
    \so 2 K.5.26
    \xv wunogskauónat
    \xe to meet him
    \so 2 K.5.21; 2 Sam.19.24
    \xv wunnogskauoh
    \xe he met him
    \so 1 K.18.7
    \xv ONk Jakob aáyomp, kah wutangelsumoh GOD wunnogskauôoh,...
    \xe And Jacob went on his way, and the angels of God met him.'    Gen.32.1  { 3p->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +

    \xv Nogkushkouadt manunneungquean wutoximoh, asuh wutassiumoh quonsénit, quehchúunadt pish kukquehchuuttauonuh,
    \xe If thou meet thine enemy's ox or his ass going astray, thou shalt surely bring it back to him again.
    \so Ex.23.4
    \ng 2->3
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish k∞wadchanumunash ut mukkinneaekommukqut, anaquohtag wauwaonk uttoh adt nogkushkauun.
    \xe And thou shalt lay them up in the tabernacle of congregation before the testimony, where I will meet with you.
    \so Num.17.4
    \ng changed 1->2+_0_; "2" for "2p"
    \nt +
    \xv Uttoh ane nogkushkunkqueop ut mayut,...
    \xe How he met thee by the way,...
    \so Deut.25.18
    \ng changed 3->2 preterite
    \nt +

    \xv ... monchish nogkushkau Moses, in touhkomukqut:...
    \xe ..., Go into the wilderness to meet Moses. ...
    \so Ex.4.27
    \ng 2->3
    \nt +
    \xv ..., neemunk wutch kuppomushaóngan∞, kah monchek nogkushkok,...
    \xe ..., Take victuals with you for the journey, and go to meet them,...
    \so Josh.9.11
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Kusseh wussentamwaen paont, sohham∞k nogkushk∞k.
    \xe ..., Behold, the bridegroom cometh; go ye out to meet him.
    \so Mt.25.6
    \nt +

    \se !|nogkushkauatteum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, reciprocal
    \dv AI reciprocal => II
    \ge `to meet together' (of lines, paths, roads)
    \xv ...: kah nogkushkoatteum∞ash ut Asher, nanummiyeu, kah Ishachar wutchepwoiyeu.
    \xe ...; and they met together in Asher on the north, and in Issachar on the east.
    \so Josh.17.10

    \xv ..., ne ayeuonganit adt neesinash nogkishkauadtum∞uk mayash,...
    \xe ..., in a place where two ways met;...
    \so Mk.11.4
    \ng changed 0

    (|wunne nogkishkôadtuonk| `well met' (as a salutation)    C.225)

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nokus káuatees| `Meet him', |Nockuskauatítea| `Let us meet', |Neenmeshnóckukaw.| `I did meet.', |Mesh Kunnockqus| `Did you meet?', "{Obs.} They are joyfull in meeting of any in travell, and will strike fire either with stones or sticks, to take Tobacco, and discourse a little together."    R.W.73-74√.
Cree |Núgge-{skowáyoo}| `{he} meets {him}'; +|nakiskawew| `S/he meets her/him'    Howse 85; Alb.E.99a,360a.
Chip. [|Náhgeshk{oodáhdewug}| (anim.) `{they} meet {each other}.'; +|Nagishkâge, (nin)| `I meet'    Howse 85√; Bar.267a.
    Algonquian [alg] |NAKA-| `opposition, retardement, obstacle, contrariété, empêchement,
    \nt +
soutien, rencontre'    Cq.250b.
    Delaware [del] |ngíiskaweew| `to meet sb'    O'M.530b.]
    \nt +

\et H.2134 *nake⌠kawe∙wa TA `meet'


\lx nogque
\va nogqueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 88
    \nt Remark: aphetized form of |unnogque|, with the distal initial |un-|.
    \nt +
\ps (prep.) / PreN, PreV, perhaps governing locative of nouns other than place names
\ge `toward'
\nt G&B.722, s.v. |unnogque| `towards'
\so Cant.7.4
    |Yeu nogque|, {This way-ward}. |Ne nogque|, {That way-ward}.    El.Gr.21/268, no.11
    \nt +
    \xv Kah neh wadohkehettit wutch Meshua, nogqueu Shephar,...
    \xe And their dwelling was from Mesha, as thou goest unto Shephar,...
    \so Gen.10.30
    \ng (E0), gl.: "toward"
    \nt +
    \xv Onk chipwúnau wuhhogkuh nogwe en nahog,...
    \xe And he divided himself against them,...
    \so Gen.14.15(E0)
    \ng (E1&2) emend |ayeuuhkonónat|; apparently lacking the contrary element
    \nt +
    \xv Kah unnohquaeu nogqueu Sodom kah Gomorra, kah nogqueu wame ne ohket mukoshquttaut ...
    \xe And he looked toward Sodome and Gomorrah, & toward all the land of the plain,...
    \so Gen.19.28
    \ng (E0), gl.: "toward"
    \nt +
    \xv yeu nogque
    \xe hither
    \so 2 K.2.8
    \cf yôái
    \xv en nogque
    \xe toward' (`the east
    \so Zech.14.4)

    \xv En, nenogque.
    \xe To, towards, or that way
    \so C.111/235
    \nt +

\dv |nauonát| `to see' (?): { The |l| of cognate forms disposes of that hypothesis; these belong under |nauau| TA. }
    \xv nôk
    \xe behold ye
    \xv muskesuk nogqueon
    \xe when the eye saw me
    \so Job 29.11
    \xv -- neh nogqut
    \xe the eye which saw him
    \so Job 20.9
    \xv noh nógqueh
    \xe who seeth me' [`whom I am in the presence of
    \so ]    Gen.16.13
    \xv -- nógquean
    \xe when he seeth thee
    \so Ex.4.14
    \xv -- nogqueon
    \xe when it sees me
    \so Job 29.11
    \xv howan kenogkumun
    \xe who seeth us
    \so Is.29.15
    \xv matta kenógk∞un
    \xe he sees us not
    \so Ezek.8.12
    (| -- wunnaum∞un| Ezek.9.9)
    \xv matta nogk∞
    \xe it does not behold him
    \so Job 20.9
Hence, "to the sight of." It can hardly be the contracted form of |ne ogquè|.
\cf ne
\cf
\cf nuhquainat

[Delaware [del] |loquel| `see thou'; pl. |loqueek| `see ye'    Zeisb.Gr.174.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |arag8^i8i| `de ce côté-là, de l'autre côté' R.P.8/550a.
    \nt +
M.-P. |oloqi| PV `in that direction; over that way'; |@l@kwiw| P `dort drüben, in jene Richtung'    LeS.60b-61a; Sz.58.
WAbn. |lagw-|, as |lagwiwi| adv. `a way, direction, region, vicinity'    D.1.264-265.]

\lx nogquissinneat
\va nogqussu
\ve + Eliot
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 88
\ps v.i. / AI, to |nau-| `to see'; see B.1962, 15.141, 299-300, "verb of undergoing".
\twn |nogquod|, II
\ge `to appear'; +`to be manifest, visible'
\so C.180
    \xv ..., newutche ut matokqsut, nen pish nunnogqus, ut ne petwohtag monaneteáe appuonganit.
    \xe ...: for I will appear in the cloud upon the mercy seat.
    \so Lev.16.2
    \ng 1 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ...: GOD nógqusseup ut weyausut,...
    \xe ...: God was manifest in the flesh,...
    \so 1 Tim.3.16
    \ng 3 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    `I appear, we appear,' |Nunnogquis, -su@mun.|    C.36/180√
    Q. `Do all the Indians come to meeting?' |Sunwame Indiansog peyâg ut môêonga@nit.| A. `No, some stay away.' |Mat, nôwhitche mat nogquissog.|    C.101/226  { 3p negative indicative }
    \nt +

    \xv Christ noh kuppomantam∞onganun nógqussit, neit pish kenaau wonk k∞weeche nògqussinneau ut sohsum∞onganit.
    \xe When Christ, who is our life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with him in glory.
    \so Col.3.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., en ketass∞t michemapit, matta woh nap∞k, matta woh nogqusseg, noh webe waantamwe GOD,...
    \xe ... unto the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God,...
    \so 1 Tim.2.17
    \nt +

\lx nóhtoe
\va nehtôe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
\ps PreV
\ge `skilful, skilled'; +`cunning; to skill (of sth, to do sth), to handle (in specific fashion)'
\so 2 Chr.2.7
    \xv ..., wanne howan kenugke neenawun, woh nunnehtôe wunnagetohhohseumun, neane Sidoninasog.
    \xe ... that there is not among us any that can skill to hew timber like unto the Sidonians.
    \so 1 K.5.6√
    \xv ... wosketomp, nôhtoe anakausuontog gold,...
    \xe ... a man cunning to work in gold,...
    \so 2 Chron.2.7√
    \xv ..., kah noh nóhtoe kohkókáusit, weeche núhtoe anuhkausitcheg neg weeomutcheg ut Judah,...
    \xe ..., and that can skill to grave with the cunning men that are with me in Judah ...
    \so 2 Chr.2.7√
    \xv nehtóe
    \xe can skill to
    \so 2 Chr.2.8√
    |nehtuhto| (?)    2 Chr.2.14
    \xv ..., wame nah nahtôe wunne puhpegquacheg.
    \xe ..., all that could skill of instruments of music.
    \so 2 Chr.34.12
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wame nohtóe chemacheg,...
    \xe And all that handle the oar,...
    \so Ezek.27.29
    \nt +
    \xv Nup-pahk-nuh-tô-pe-pe-nau-wut-chut-chuh-quô-ka-neh-cha-nehcha-e-nin-nu-mun-nônok
    \xe Our well skilled Looking Glass makers
    \so Mayhew 1722.16

\lx nohtónukqus
\va nohtonugqus
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
\ps n. / NA, dependent
\ge `a brother' (?), +`sb[woman]'s brother' (??cross-sibling)
    \xv nunnohtonugqus
    \xe my brother
    \so Gen.20.13
    \ng attributed to Sarah
    \xv wunohtónugqusoh
    \xe her brother'    Gen.24.53,55 { Rebekah
    \so s brother }
    \xv ..., kah nohtonukqussog kah neetahtuog,...
    \xe ..., and my brethren, and my sisters,...
    \so Josh.2.13
    \ng Rahab speaking; apheresis of prefix, also E1
    \nt +
    \xv nohtónukqus
    \xe my brother'    Jn.11.21√ { Martha
    \so s brother, Lazarus }
    \xv Kenohtónukqus
    \xe thy brother'    Jn.11.23√ { Martha
    \so s brother }
    |noh wunnohtónukqusoh| (constr.) `whose brother'    Jn.11.2√ { Mary's brother, Lazarus }

    \se |wunohtónukqussu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, verb of possession
    \ge `to have a brother' (of a female)
    \so Gen.24.29
    \xv Kah Rebekah wunohtónukqussu, kah ussowenau Laban,...
    \xe And Rebekah had a brother, and his name was Laban:...
    \so Gen.24.29

\nt [Employed only by females or to express the relation of a brother to a sister. See |weetuksquoh|. In the translation of John's gospel printed with the Massachusetts Psalter (1709 ), |wetahtu| is substituted for |wunnohtónukqussoh| of Eliot.]
\cf weemat
\cf weetomp

    \nt Remark: I find nothing very similar in Speck 1918 or Hockett 1964, though there are some tantalizing looking forms in |-gwu/es(-)| in Speck's listings for cousins in Penobscot, (St. Francis) Abenaki, and Maliseet-Passamaquoddy (ib., 157). The nasals preceding those presumably represent vowel nasalization rather than nasal segments.
    \nt +


\lx nohtonumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `to handle (?), to carry in the hand(?), to use habitually, to be skilled in the use of'
    \xv nehtônumwog togkodtegash
    \xe they handle swords
    \so Ezek.38.4
    \xv noh nohtonuk
    \xe sickle, he who handleth the sickle
    \so Jer.50.16
    \xv neg nohtonukeg
    \xe they who handle
    \so (shield, spear, etc.)    1 Chr.12.8; 2 Chr.25.5
\cf nóhtoe


\lx nomp-
\hm 1
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge `again; instead of, replacing (cf. "re-")
\so entries following; etymology

[Cree +|tâp| (rac.) `être à la place, comme si, etc., pareillement.'; |Tap-| `again, back, re-, etc.', |Ta'piskoch| adv., adj. `As, alike, as well as, equally, the same, like, both, for instance'    Lac.D.606b; Frs.465a-466b.
Ill. {R} |rapa| `a la place d'un autre, qque fois pour une chose qu on fait entrer dans une autre'    M.493/283ab.
Menominee [mez] |na∙p| `back, in return; for his part; in his poor way; poor fellow'    M.L.147.
    M.-I. |naapi| `also, likewise'    C.43.
    \nt +
Shawnee [sjw] |laap-| `THE SAME REPEATED', |nilaapilawi| `I do so over and over', |nilaapΘeto| `I replace it'    D.-V.345.]

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge `(wear) about the neck'
\so entries following; etymology

    \xv ..., kah wuthogk∞unúhkouh hogk∞ánash, kah golde pemunneat wunnompuhqunuh.
    \xe ..., and arrayed him in vestures of fine linen, and put a gold chain about his neck;
    \so Gen.41.42

    [?Abn. |nenañpet8n|, 3. |nañ.| `Je l'enfile en collier', |nenañpeañbié|, 3. |nañpeañbié| `J'enfile'    R.215/444b.

\lx nompagunum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
    \nt +
\ps TI1b
\ge `to give account of sth'
\ps Mt.12.36
    \xv ..., Wosketompaog pish wutch nìshnoh pasuk tahn∞chekutt∞wonk nag n∞wáhettit, wunnompagunumwog ut wussittumwáe kesukodut.
    \xe ..., That every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.
    \so Mt.12.36
    \ng word order; absolute

    \se nompagunumauau
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to give account to sb, reckon with sb; to require sth of sb'
    \so Lev.25.50; Deut.18.19,23.21; 1 Pet.4.5
    \xv Pish ∞nompagunnumauoh noh tapwhont,...
    \xe And he shall reckon with him that bought him ...
    \so Lev.25.50
    \xv ..., howan matta kohkuttam∞g nukkutt∞wongash, nish pish án∞wáche ut n∞wesuonganit, n∞nompagunûmauon.
    \xe ... whosoever will not hearken unto my words which he shall speak in my name, I will require it of him.
    \so Deut.18.19
    \xv Quosh∞waan quoshauwaonk en Jehovah kum-Manitt∞mut, matta pish kupputt∞óh óadtuhkonat, newutche Jehovah kum Manitt∞m pish menuhke k∞nompagunumunkqun,...
    \xe When thou shalt vow a vow unto the LORD thy God, thou shalt not slack to pay it: for the LORD thy God will surely require it of thee;...
    \so Deut.23.21
    \ng 3->2
    \xv Nag pish wunnompagunumauaog nah teanuk wasittumunutche pomantamunutche kah napunutche.
    \xe Who shall give account to him that is ready to judge the quick and the dead.
    \so 1 Pet.4.5

\lx nompashau

\lx nompe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
\ps adv. / PreV, P(?), Adv
\ge `again; instead of'
\so Gen.26.18
    `instead of'    Gen.4.25; Judg.15.2; Num.8.16
    \xv Kah sephausuaen noh sasequnit noh nompe wutch wunnaumonuh, noh pish wuttinteauun,...
    \xe And the priest of his sons that is anointed in his stead shall offer it:...
    \so Lev.6.22
    \nt +
    \xv Neemun Levitsog nompe nishnoh mohtomegit kenugke wunnaumonat Israel, kah wunnetaseum∞oh Levitsog, nompe wunnetasum∞oh,...
    \xe Take the Levites instead of all the first born among the children of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites instead of their cattle;...
    \so Num.3.45
    \nt +
    (= |wutch nompe|    Num.8.18)
    `repeatedly', expressing with a numeral the number of repetitions or `times':
    \xv nishwudt nompe
    \xe three times' (`to the third time
    \so )    Num.22.28, 32
    \xv nesausuk tahshit nompe
    \xe seven times
    \so Lev.8.11; 14.7
    \xv m∞chekut nompe
    \xe oftentimes
    \so Lk.8.29
    \xv ...: mamechumuk ne ohteakonit waéenu nishnoh otan, ne wunnompe wadchanumun
    \xe ...: the food of the field, which was round about every city, laid he up in the same.
    \so Gen.41.48
    \nt +

    \se |nompu|, |nompeu|
    \nt +
    \ps PreV, Adv(?) (in |nompu ut|)
    \ge `in sb's/sth's stead'
    \so Gen.21.13,36.33-34,36-39; Ex.29.30
    \nt Remark: Gen.36.35 has |nompe| in the same use.
    \xv ... nompu ut wunnaumonuh.
    \xe ..., in the stead of his son.
    \so Gen.22.13
    \xv Kah Bela nupp∞, kah Jobab wunnaumonuh Zera ut Bozza wunnompu nananuwomukquoh.
    \xe And Bela died, and Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his stead.
    \so Gen.36.33
    \xv Nesausuk tahshikqunne, noh sephámwaénúut nompeu wunnaumonuh, pish wutogqunneash:...
    \xe And that son that is priest in his stead shall put them on seven days,...
    \so Ex.29.30
    \ng translation? participial phrase preceding antecedent: "the [ being priest in his stead ] son"?

    \se nonompu
    \va nohnompit
    \ps freq. / reduplicated

    \xv noh nompeyit ne teag
    \xe he who repeateth a matter
    \so Prov.17.9
    \xv sun nen nunnompin God
    \xe Am I in God's stead?
    \so Gen.30.2
    \ng to |nompenau|
\cf namp∞ham

[Delaware [del] |lappi| `again'    Zeisb.Gr.171; `once more'    ibid. 175.
Western Abenaki [abe] |ni arihiáné, netse nañbi kederih8ren| `Je te ferai co'e tu me feras'; |nedagatsi, m^da kég8^i nañbi még88a.| `Je suis honteux de n'avoir rien a lui  rendre'; |nañbi| `réciproquement'    R.242/452b (c.f. s.v. COMME); 289/467b;432/518b.√]


\lx nompenau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
    \nt +
\ps TA, manual final
\ge `to be in sb's stead, in the place of sb; to succeed sb; to be the heir of sb'
\so Gen.30.2,50.19; Deut.2.21,22
    \xv ..., Ahque webesek newutche sun nen nunnompin GOD?
    \xe ..., Fear not: for am I in the place of God?
    \so Gen.50.19
    \xv Neanheomp wunneechanoh Esau, ..., paguanont Horimsoh wutch anaquabhettit, kah nah wunnompinóuh, kah nag wunnompohteamóuh yeu pajeh yeu kesukok.
    \xe As he did to the children of Esau, ..., when he destroyed the Horims from before them; and they succeeded them, and dwelt in their stead even unto this day:
    \so Deut.2.22
    \xv ..., kah kenompenoog, kah wutohkean wutohtuóut.
    \xe ..., and thou succeedest them, and dwellest in their land;
    \so Deut.12.29

    \xv ..., yeuoh nompenont, hah, nushontuh, onk ne ahtóonk woh k∞taiheinnean.
    \xe This is the heir: come, let us kill him, that the inheritance may be ours.
    \so Lk.20.14; Mk.12.7; Gal.4.1

    \se |nompenauau|
    \nt ?+
    \ps TA(+O), dative final
    \ge `to be heir (?to sb) with sb'
    \so Gen.21.10
    \xv ..., newutche wunnaumonuh yeuoh missinóe mittumwussis, matta pish nompanunk∞ weeche nunnaumonuh,...
    \xe ... the son of this bondwoman shall not be heir with my son,...'    Gen.21.10  { 3
    \so ->3 negative absolute }

    \nt Sense `heir', as specialization of "the one that replaces, succeeds sb"? Mt.21.38 has |nompenuk|, to |nompenum|, perhaps as `the one that takes it again', or some other use of |nomp-| that implies replacement or stepping into the shoes (of the owner). Similarly, perhaps, Gal.3.29. Gal.4.30 has a stem |nompinauou| (E1: |-auau|), apparently in |-aw-|, which I believe to be simply one spelling of the (probably absolute) 3 TA negative (compare e.g. Ex.34.7(?); Deut.22.30; Josh.20.5; Lk.8.51; Jn.5.22,23; 1 Cor.14.2; and similar effects in relevant long-vowel AI verbs such as |au|, |pomushau|, and |peyau|, as Mt.24.48; Lk.1.45; Jn.7.1,8.12,10.10; Acts 21.4)
Parallel senses can be found in other languages, as in the following:

[Chip. |Nâbishkawa, (nin)| `I take his place, his employment, his power, I am instead of him, I succeed him'    B.248a,263a; also Cq.245b.
Cree |tâp| (rac.) `être à la place, comme si, etc., pareillement'    Lac.D.606b.
Delaware [del] |laapáhleew| `to replace sb'    O'M.127a.
K. |naapeenemo-| `adopt him'    V.77.
Menominee [mez] |na∙paqnεw| TA `he puts him back; he replaces him in the way of restoration or by an equivalent'    M.L.147.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Napoonäookw'| `To succeed him in office, etc.'    R.258a.]

\et **Θa∙p-en-e∙wa


\lx nompennumunát
\va nompenum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 89
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `to restore, to render back'
    \xv ...: pish nompenum ne chekée nemunuk,...
    \xe ... he shall restore that which he took violently away,...
    \so Lev.6.4
    \nt +

    \xv Nompenuman pish kenompe aninnumauon ukkinnohtosuonk wayont,...
    \xe In any case thou shalt deliver him the pledge again when the sun goeth down,...
    \so Deut.24.13
    \ng cognate conjunct, to preverb in synonymous combination with verb
    \nt +
    \xv Kah noh pish nompenuk kukketeaonk,...
    \xe And he shall be unto thee a restorer of thy life,...
    \so Ruth 4.15
    \nt +

    \xv nompennush
    \xe restore thou (it)
    \so Judg.11.13

    \se !|nompenumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `restore sb sth' i.e. "sth to sb"

    \xv ..., kah nemunumauog howan ne teaguas náshpe pann∞wáe spunnonnaonk, nunnompenumau yauut tahsheu.
    \xe ...; and if I have taken any thing from any man by false accusation, I restore him fourfold.
    \so Lk.19.8

\lx nonche
\va naunche
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \ps PreV
    \nt +

    \nt +
    \so Ruth 2.12, Chr.12.17, Jn.1.39,46

    \xe thou art come to trust

    \xe if ye be come to betray me

    \xe ..., he departed thence to teach and to preach in their cities.
    \so Mt.11.1
    \nt +
    \xv ...nuttaphum kodchuhkoi ohke, kah m∞chu nonche naumun,...
    \xe ..., I have bought a piece of ground, and I must needs go and see it:...

    \nt +

\lx nonsiyeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 90
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Transferred from entry |nussu|.
\ps AI
\ge `to be alone, desolate, destitute'
\so Gen.2.18; Lev.13.46; Ps.25.16,68.6; Mk.6.47; Gal.4.27; Heb.11.37
    \xv wosketomp wunnonsiin
    \xe that the man should be alone
    \so Gen.2.18
    \nt +
{ emended; 3 subordinative }
    \xv ... nonsiyeuog, wuttamepunáog onkapunáog.
    \xe ...; being destitute, afflicted, tormented;
    \so Heb.11.37
    \ng 3p indicative
        (|Nunnânsiup.| `I was alone'    C.20/167  { 1 preterite indicative }

        \xv ..., newutche noh nonsiit m∞cheke nechenau onk noh wassukkiit.
        \xe ...: for the desolate hath many more children than she which hath a husband.
        \so Gal.4.27
        \ng _3_ participle

        \se nonsiyeum∞
        \ps II, derived
        \ge `to be desolate'
        \so Ps.143.4(E)
        \xv ...: nuttah nuttinnomiyeumut nonsiyeum∞.
        \xe ...: my heart within me is desolate.
        \so Ps.143.4(E)

        \se nonsiyeue
        \ps PreV
        \ge `all alone'
        \so C.20/167,107d/232
        |Nomsiyeuë, wukse|) `All alone'       C.20/167
        \xv Nonsiyeu
        \xe All alone
        \so C.107d/232

\nt Remark: Some material transferred from |nussu|. It is not clear whether there is a relationship between the two forms (reduplication?). Note the contrast, (E) vs. (M), at Ps.143.4.


\lx nont
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 90
\nt used by Cotton sometimes for the verb `to be', often, apparently, as an expletive (see |nont| below):
    \xv nen nont
    \xe I be
    \xv ken nont
    \xe thou art
    \xv nohne
    \xe he is
    \xv nenih
    \xe that is
    \so C.181
    \xv kenauun yeu
    \xe we are
    \xv kenauna
    \xe ye are
    \xv nâg na
    \xe they are
    \so ibid.
    \xv nagum nont
    \xe he was
    \xv nenauun nee
    \xe we were
    \xv kenau ne
    \xe ye were
    \xv nâg ne
    \xe they were
    \so ibid.
    \xv napeh nont ne u@nnioog
    \xe O that we were (such)
    \so ibid.
    \xv nont kuppeyômp
    \xe thou didst come
    \so C.185
    \xv nont wame nunnuppümun
    \xe we must all die
    \so C.188
    \xv nont noowonteap
    \xe I did dig
    \so ibid.
    \xv mukkitchogqu@issog nont puhpu@og
    \xe boys will play
    \so C.204
    \xv nont paswee nupp∞an
    \xe thou must shortly die
    \so C.237
    \xv nont woh samp∞au
    \xe he must confess (his sins)
    \so C.252
    \xv newag kisnont kussampooantamunanonate
    \xe we must therefore acknowledge
    \so C.Math.Notit.Ind.55
    so, in title to Ind.Laws:
    \xv nish nashpe nananuacheeg kusnunt sasamatahamwog
    \xe by which the magistrates are to [i.e. must] punish
    \so , etc.
    \xv nont woh samp∞au
    \xe he must confess
    \so C.252


\lx nont

\so Trumbull 90
\ps Adv
\ge `only'

    \xe (who can...) but God only?

    \xv pasuk nont God
    \xe there is but one God
    \so Ind.Primer 19,31
    \xv pish nagum nont k∞waussum
    \xe him only shalt thou serve
    \so Mt.4.10

\lx noasu
\va nôasu
\va nôussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 90
    \nt +
\ps AI
\twn |nôadt|, II
\ge `to be far off, a good way off'
\so Gen.21.16,44.4
    \xv Kah monchu, kah nummatappu uppiu[h]sukukauoh, noasu,...
    \xe And she went, and sat her down over against him a good way off,...
    \so Gen.21.16

    \xv ..., kah matta nôussúhhetteg ...
    \xe ..., and [when they were] not yet far off,...
    \so Gen.44.4
    \ng 3p negative conjunct


\lx nô∞sukomunneat
\va nâ∞-
\va nauus-
\va na∞sukom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 90
\ps v.i. / TI1a, corporal final { entry split, to distinguish TA twin }
\ge `to be at a distance, to be far from'
\so Lam.3.17; +Gen.18.25, Ex.23.7, Num.9.10, Lk.7.6, Jn.21.8
    \xv ..., kena∞sukom mukk∞kinnittuonk,...
    \xe ...: thou shalt be far from oppression;...
    \so Is.54.14
    \ng 2->0 absolute
    \xv Ken mattá kenô∞sukam∞ ukketss∞tam∞onk God,...
    \xe Thou art not far from the kingdom of God. ...
    \so Mk.12.34
    \ng 2->0 negative absolute

    \xv ..., neit ash nó∞sukom∞k wetu, noqutpasuk∞it ann∞nau wetompuh,...
    \xe .... And when he was now not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to him,...
    \so Lk.7.6
    \ng 3->0 negative conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut ásh no∞sukog, ∞shóh nogq, kah kitteamonteanumukquoh,...
    \xe ..., But when he was yet a great way off, his father saw him, and had compassion,...
    \so Lk.15.20
    \ng 3->0 conjunct
    \nt +

    \xv Na∞sukash ne ussen, nushon sampweussecheg weeche matchet∞woh:...
    \xe That be far from thee to do after this manner, to slay the righteous with the wicked;...
    \so Gen.18.25
    \ng 2->0 imperative
    \nt +

    \se !|no∞suhkauau|, !|na∞sukauau|, !|na∞suhkauau|, !|nô∞s-|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, corporal final
    \ge `to be afar off, far from sb', `God forbid ...'
    \so Deut.12.21, Mt.15.8,16.22, Mk.7.6
    \xv na∞sukonqueog
    \xe (it) is far from us
    \so Is.59.9
    \xv ..., Yeug missinninnuog nukquhtianumukquog ut wussisset∞n∞wout, qut wuttahh∞oash nunnô∞suhkonqunash.
    \xe ..., This people honoreth me with their lips, but their heart is far from me.
    \so Mk.7.6; Mt.15.8: |wuttah∞woash nunna∞sukongqunash|
    \xv ..., tôkonongq[u]e matta kená∞sukkongk∞un nish noh pasuk kenaun.
    \xe ..., though he be not far from every one of us.
    \so Acts 17.27
    \ng 3->12

    \xv Ayeuonk ne Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m pepenog, na ponamunat ∞wesuonk, na∞sukongquean, neit ...
    \xe If the place which the Lord thy God hath chosen to put his name there be too far from thee, then ...
    \so Deut.12.21
    |ayeuonk wussaume na∞sukoman| (and |na∞sukongquean|) `if the place be too far from thee'    Deut.12.21; 14.24

    \xv ..., Nô∞sukkongquttei, yeu woh nuttussen,...
    \xe ..., God forbid that I should do so:...
    \so Gen.44.17
    \ng 0->1 imperative
    \xv nô∞sukók
    \xe get ye far from (him)
    \so Ezek.11.15
    \ng 2p->3 imperative
    \xv ..., Nó∞sukongqush Lord, matta pish kittinhetteáun.
    \xe ..., Be it far from thee, Lord: this shall not be unto thee.
    \so Mt.16.22
    \ng 0->2 imperative

\cf n∞hqueu
\cf anúckquaque


[Delaware [del] |na schachki| adv. (?) `so far'    Zeisb.Gr.174.]

\lx nosweetauónat
\va n∞swet-
\va nosweht-
\va n∞swehtauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 91
\ps v.adj.an. / TA, directive final
\ge `to serve', +`to obey sb'
\so Deut.10.12
    `to obey'    Prov.30.17; 2 Cor.10.5
    \xv ...: Kah Abram wun∞swetauoh ne an∞wadt Sarai.
    \xe ...: and Abram hearkened to the voice of Sarai.'    Gen.16.2  { 3->3
    \so +0 indicative }
    \nt +
    |Noh nosweetauont ∞shoh wekontamwaheau.
    \nt +
    Qut waantamwe wunnaumoniin nosweetau ∞shoh.| "One that obeys his father makes him glad. But a wise son makes a glad father."    Log.Pr.71/84, to Prov.10.1
    \xv n∞swetauonaóut
    \xe to serve them
    \so Deut.4.19
    \ng X->3p t-subordinative

    \xv ..., kah wonk Nashauanit, nnoh anumauont GOD neh n∞swehtunkqutcheh.
    \xe ...; and so is also the Holy Ghost, whom God hath given to them that obey him.
    \so Acts 5.32
    \nt +

    { some distinct stems here, some to the following sublemma }
    \xv n∞swëtah nen
    \xe yield yourself to me
    \so C.216
    \xv noswehtôk
    \xe obey ye (them, an.)
    \so Eph.6.1
    \xv nooswetamu@nate
    \xe to obey'; |ken n∞swëtah| `obey thou me'; |n∞swehtaw manit| `obey God
    \so C.202

    \se noswehtamunát
    \ps with inan. obj. / TI1a
    \ge `to obey the words of, commands of', etc.
    \so 1 Sam.8.19
    \xv ..., newutche kenosweetam nuttin∞waonk.
    \xe ...; because thou hast obeyed my voice.
    \so Gen.22.18
    \ng 2->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah woh matta kenoswehtamomw∞ nehenwonche kuttahh∞woash kah nehenwonche kuskesuk∞∞ash, nish neahen nanwun∞dsquaóg.
    \xe ...; and that ye seek not after your own heart and your own eyes, after which ye use to go awhoring:
    \so Num.15.39
    \nt +

    \xv nosweetash
    \xe obey thou
    \so Gen.27.8
    \xv n∞swetam∞k
    \xe obey ye
    \so Deut.13.4

\lx n∞che
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 91
\ps adv. / PreV
\ge `thenceforth, therefrom, from that time'; `to begin to'
\dv for |na ∞ch|
\nt Often used interchangeably with |k∞che|, |kutche|; but while both are inceptives, |n∞che| seems to appropriately mark the time and |kutche| the occasion of beginning of action, as |wutche| does the cause of action.
[NOTE. -- On further examination I do not find this distinction well founded. See |∞ch|.]
    \xv ONk n nih wosketompaog n∞che monahettìt ut woskeche ohkit,...
    \xe And it came to pass, when men began to multiply on the face of the earth,...
    \so Gen.6.1
    \nt +
    \xv yeu kesukok n∞che kummishsesh
    \xe this day will I begin to magnify thee
    \so Josh.3.7
    \xv n∞che wekitteau
    \xe he began to build
    \xv neg nagig n∞che wutt∞ntohkonôuh
    \xe they began to mock him
    \so Lk.14.30,29;
    \xv yeu n∞che ussenaóut
    \xe this they began to do

    [|matta n∞che peyoh| `I am not come'    Mt.9.13
    \xv n∞chi Jehovah
    \xe I am the Lord's' (i.e. `I proceed from the Lord
    \so )    Is.44.5
    in which places |n∞che| is perhaps used for |nen ∞ch|.]

\cf tahn∞che
\cf kutche

[Delaware [del] |nutschi| `at the beginning'    Zeisb.Gr.177.]


\ps !|n∞chitteam|
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 91
    \nt +?
\ps TI1a, general TI final
\ge `to require sth (at the hand of sb)'
\so Gen.9.5
    \xv Kah wunnamuhkut ∞squeheunk kuppomantam∞ongan∞ pish n∞chitteamon: pish n∞chitteamon ut níshnoh puppinnashim kah nishnoh wosketomp,...
    \xe And surely your blood of your lives will I require: at the hand of every beast will I require it, and at the hand of man;...
    \so Gen.9.5
    \ng 1->0 objective (2x)

\nt Remark: The same verse concludes with the following:
    \xv ..., kah nishno[h] howan weematoh pish n∞chumon ukketeaonk wosketomp.
    \xe ...; at the hand of every man's brother will I require the life of the man.
    \so Gen.9.5
    This looks like the twin TA form, i.e. 1->3 objective, but the object is inanimate (as witness the lack of the obviative suffix).

\lx n∞heau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 91
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge `to grieve sb, make sb heavy, sorry, to offend sb'
\so Gen.49.23; Prov.10.1; Mt.18.6; 2 Cor.2.22,7.8,7.9; Eph.4.30; Log.Pr.71-72/84-85
\nt Remark: The initial presumably identical by some means to that of |neúantam|, T.85a, here with TA causative final |-h-| and "infection".
    \xv Mattammag∞e wunnaumoniin n∞heau ohkasoh.
    \xe ... a foolish son is the heaviness of his mother.
    \so Log.Pr.71/84 (from Prov.10.1; AV text as translation)
    \xv Newutch tunkônogque ken∞hennaóont nashpe wussukwhonk,..., newutche n∞wahteoh nenan wussukwhonk ken∞hikquneau,...
    \xe For though I made you sorry with a letter,...: for I perceive that the same epistle hath made you sorry,...
    \so 2 Cor.7.8

    \xv Qut howan n∞heont pasuk∞ yeuh mukkiemesoh wanamptiinitcheh,...
    \xe But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me,...
    \so Mt.18.6
    \xv Newutche n∞hennog, howan neit noh wekontamwahit, kah noh neuanatamheóg.
    \xe For if I make you sorry, who is he then that maketh me glad, but the same which is made sorry by me?
    \so 2 Cor.2.2

    \xv Kah ahque n∞heuk wunnetupanatamwe wunnashauanitt∞muh GOD,...
    \xe And grieve not the holy Spirit of God,...
    \so Eph.4.30

    \xe Limber cloth

\lx n∞hkik
\va n∞khik
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 91
    rmk This lemma appears to be in error for |n∞khik(an)| (cf. derivatives and the Narr. and WAbn. forms); I find no example of |n∞hkik| in the current corpus. None the forms that Trumbull cites are of this form. The cognates appear to imply a form |n∞hkhig(an)|?
    \nt +
\dv `that which is softened or made soft'
\nt It is used by Eliot for
    \xv n∞khik
    \xe meal
    \so (1 Chr.12.40)√,
    \xv n∞khik
    \xe flour
    \so (Lev.2.4,5,7; 24.5)√,
    and |n∞khik| `ground corn' (2 Sam.17.19)√

    \se |n∞khikann∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to yield meal'
    \so Hos.8.7
    \xv ..., sontipposhunk matta pish n∞khikann∞: {nookhikanneug}, pen∞wohteaog pish ummisseashqunneau.
    \xe ...: the bud shall yield no meal: if so be it yield, the strangers shall swallow it up.
    \so Hos.8.7
    \ng 0 negative indicative; 0 conjunct

    \se n∞khikanehteau
    \ps AI, creative final
    \ge `to grind meal'
    \so Is.47.2

    \xv n∞khikanehteush
    \xe grind thou meal
    \so Is.47.2
    \ng 2 imperative

    "..., the best of their victuals for their journey is {Nocake}, (as they call it) which is nothing but {Indian} corne parched in the hot ashes; the ashes being sifted from it, it is afterward beat to powder, ...", Wood 1634, Part.2, Chap.6., 58.

[MARGINAL NOTE. -- "From a word which means `to sift', sifted. cf. sieve. From |n∞keu|?"]

\lx n∞kinat
\va n∞keu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 92
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `to descend, to go down', +`to come down'
    \xv n∞keu
    \xe he descended
    \so Ex.34.5
    (from heaven)    Mt.28.2
    `she went down'    Gen.24.16
    \xv n∞k∞p
    \xe he descended
    \so (pret.)    Eph.4.9
    \xv n∞ch n∞kem kesukqut
    \xe I came down from heaven
    \so Jn.6.38

    \xv noh n∞kit
    \xe he who descends, or descended
    \so Ps.133.3; Eph.4.10

    \xv n∞kitch
    \xe let him descend or come down
    \so Mk.15.82

    \xv n∞n∞keog
    \xe they shall descend
    \so Jn.1.51
    \ng reduplicated, 3p indicative

    \se |n∞kéontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative |-t-|
    \ge `to descend upon sth'
    \so Ex.19.18,19
    \xv Onk wadchu Sinai wame pukutauau newutche Jehovah wunn∞keontamun ut n∞taut,...
    \xe And mount Sinai was altogether on a smoke, because the Lord descended upon it in fire:...
    \so Ex.19.18
    \nt Compare B. 1962, 16.69, on applicatives: "AI stems in |-ε∙| take TA |-N|, TI |-t| with replacement of |-ε∙| by |-a∙|:"; here, not a replacement (|-wont-| ?).

    \se n∞kémo
    \va -m∞
    \ps II to |n∞keu|?
    \ge `it was let down'
    \so Acts 10.11; 11.5; Rev.21.10

\lx n∞numunát
\va n∞nanum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 93
    \nt Remark: The initial |n∞n(a?)-|, with a privative sense, is seen at its simplest in |n∞ne| (v.s.), this yielding narrower glosses such as `fail, lack, want', hence `cannot, be unable'. The transitive verbs no doubt have the manual final |-un-|. I have found no first person form with the prefix visible adjacent to the verb stem. (The only second person forms found are conjunct.) The analyses are therefore tentative. The entry summarizes an examination of essentially all AV occurrences of "cannot" and "could not" (including 2nd person subject forms and inverted forms with a pronominal subject). Separate entries have been set up for examples from Cotton's Vocabulary owing to uncertainty about the interpretation of the spellings and the transitivity.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / TI1b
\ge `to be unable' { normally governing (t-)subordinative verb; occasionally with pleonastic (inflectional) negation. }; +`to bear, endure sth'
    \nt G&B.673 (nun)noonequttam TI-O `I am unable', with different final.
    \nt +
    \so Judg.6.27,14.14; 2 K.3.26; 1 Chr.21.30; 2 Chron.7.2; Neh.13.24; Job.37.19,23; Is.7.1; Dan.5.8; Jonah 1.13; Mt.17.16; Mk.2.4; Lk.1.7,14.6,20,16.3,26,...
    \nt +
    \xv Kah n∞waog, n∞nanumumun, yean wame pas∞wônaònt floksog môeu,...
    \xe And they said, We cannot, until all the flocks be gathered together,...
    \so Gen.29.8
    \ng 1p->0 absolute, with apheresis and ellipsis of verb phrase
    \nt +
    \xv NEit Joseph n∞nanum∞ kèhchithón ut anaquabenit wame noh neepanitcheh,...
    \xe Then Joseph could not refrain himself before all them that stood by him;...
    \so Gen.45.1
    \ng 1 negative absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche Jehovah n∞num uppás∞ónat yeuh missinninnuh, en ohkeit ...
    \xe Because the Lord was not able to bring this people into the land ...
    \so Num.14.16√
    \ng 3->0 indicative absolute, syncopated
    = |n∞nunum|    Deut.9.28
    \xv Kah n∞nanum∞ namp∞hamauónat Abneroh pasuk kutt∞onk,...
    \xe And he could not answer Abner a word again,...
    \so 2 Sam.3.11
    \ng 3 negative absolute; also Gen.45.3; 2 Chron.13.7,30.3
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah n∞nanumumun neepauuneat poquadchit,...
    \xe ..., and we are not able to stand without,...
    \so Ezra 10.13√
    \ng 1p->0 absolute, apheresis
    \xv ...? kusseh, wehtauogk∞ matta quoshqussausin∞, kah n∞nanumóog kuhkeitamun:...
    \xe ...? Behold, their ear is uncircumcised, and they cannot hearken:...
    \so Jer.6.10
    \ng 3p->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., n∞nanum omohken kittinnumauunat.
    \xe ...; I cannot rise and give thee.
    \so Lk.11.7√; Lk.16.3
    \ng 1->0 absolute, apheresis
    \xv KAh nen nematog, n∞nanum kukken∞nunnaôont neyane wunnashauanitt∞mitcheg,...
    \xe AND I, brethren, could not speak unto you as unto spiritual,...
    \so 1 Cor.3.1
    \ng 1(->0) absolute, apheresis
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche wunn∞numuneau ne ánunn∞nit,...
    \xe (For they could not endure that which was commanded,...)
    \so Heb.12.20
    \ng 3p->0 objective
    \nt +

    \xv ....(newutche neese pasuk∞∞og appuog wuttat, neg sauunukeg newaj n∞nánumwehettit qushkogkonat sepues Bezor.)
    \xe ...: for two hundred abode behind, which were so faint that they could not go over the book Besor.
    \so 1 Sam.30.10; similarly 1 K.8.11
    \ng 3p(->0) conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Newaj sephausuenuog n∞numhettit neepauun wowussummuónat,...
    \xe So that the priests could not stand to minister ...
    \so 2 Chron.5.14
    \ng 3p(->0) conjunct; double syncope
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kuht∞nogqut padchuwábog, kah n∞numum∞m∞ug nohhen pomushaut, nunnomshómun,
    \xe And when the ship was caught, and could not bear up into the wind, we let her drive.
    \so Acts 27.15
    \ng 0(->0) conjunct, pleonastic negation?; (E1) also, assuming reading |n∞nunum∞m∞ug|
    \nt +
    \xv ...; momattohquo@ttup newaj n∞nnünnum ussënat ne koduseyeu ut ...
    \xe ; weather has bin so bad I could not do what I had to do here. ...
    \so C.108/233
    \ng 1(->0) conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Assuhkom∞"kon teag uttïyeu nooninüman papänee sampwee nehtinneat usseonk.
    \xe Follow nothing of which thou canst not well justify the doing.
    \so C.113/236
    \ng 2(->0) participle
    \nt +

    \se !|n∞nunau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \nt Remark: There appears to be a TA verb, but its sense and syntax remain obscure; perhaps: "to fail in affecting x (by hand), with respect to V-ing x", or "to fail in causing (by hand) x to V", with the typical proleptic object.
    \ge `could not', with t-subordinative; `could not bear sb'
    \so Josh.15.63
    \xv ..., kah ne ohke uttoh adt penuwohteahettit wunn∞nunnoh néwutche wunnetasum∞uh.
    \xe ...; and the land wherein they were strangers could not bear them because of their cattle.'    Gen.36.7  { 0->3
    \so ?? syntax obscure }
    \xv Papaume Jebusitsog, wadohkitcheg Jerusalem, wunnaumonuh Judah wunn∞nunòuh áma∞hkauònat,...
    \xe As for the Jebusites the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the children of Judah could not drive them out:...
    \so Josh.15.63
    \xv Cedarsash ut wuttittanohketeamut GOD wunn∞nuh adtashonat:...
    \xe The cedars in the garden of God could not hide him:...'    Ezek.31.8  { 3->3
    \so syncopated (or II without subject agreement? what then is |-uh|?); (E1) may have |-un|? }

    \se ?!|n∞nau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI?/II?
    \ge `to be wanting, defective'
    \so C.83/214
    (|N∞nat| `To be wanting, or defective'    C.83/214)

    \xv Qut sephausuénuog wussaum-ogguhsuog, newaj n∞náhettit wunnushonaoont wame chikohtáe mag∞ongash:...
    \xe But the priests were too few, so that they could not flay all the burnt offerings:...
    \so 2 Chron.29.34
    \ng 3p->0p; hardly a syncopated TA instance

    \se !|n∞ninnuwau| (C)
    \nt +
    \ps AI, long-vowel stem? (indefinite object to TA stem?)
    \ge `to falter, fail'
    \so C.51/191,108/233,113/236
    \xv N∞ni@nnúwönat.
    \xe To falter, or fail
    \so C.51/191
    \xv Nunn∞che nooninnuwam ut noowatamooonganit.
    \xe I begin to falter, or fail in my understanding
    \so C.51/191

    \se !|nooninnuwöm∞| (C)
    \nt +
    \ps II, to AI verb
    \ps `to fail'
    \so C.91/220
    \xv Nooninnuwömoo.
    \xe Failing
    \so C.91/220

    \xv ûnheau áma∞hkauónat
    \xe he could not drive them out
    \so Judg.1.19
    \ng misplaced; see lemma |oneheau|, T+.107b.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Noónshem|/|Nonânum| `I cannot.'; |Nóonshem Pawtuck/quámmin.|    `I cannot reach.'; |Nonânum.|/|Nòonshem.| `I cannot.' / |Tawhitch nonanum/êan?| `Why can you not?'; |Nóonshem metesím/min.| `I cannot eate.'    R.W.6;40;155/r.163;186/r.194.√
Delaware [del] |nol hand| `lazy'    Zeisb.
    Algonquian [alg] |NON-| `étroit, trop juste, trop petit, à l'étroit'    Cq.286ab.
    \nt +??
Cree |No`tä'pu'yew| AI `He is deficient, he lacks, he is in want, (of it).', II `It is deficient, falls short, it fails.', |No`tä'sew| `He is inefficient, he is a poor workman, he is worthless, his strength falls short, he is awkward.'    Frs.368b-369a.
Ill. {R} |N8ra, n8re, n8ri.| `marque qq chose de court, d'imparfait. ...', |Nin8rabama| `je ne le voy pas tout entier.'    Gr.357/213b.
Lp.A. |ni n8lnem| `je n'en puis plus, soit de fatigue ou d'age', |n8n8lilanlalkansin| `je nepeux pas travailler'    D.71,89.
Men. initial |no∙n-| `fail to', as |no∙nahcekε∙w| `he fails to finish the food', |no∙nenεw| TA |no∙nenam| TI `he fails to reach him, it with his hand', etc.    M.L.165.]

\et No other close correspondence found; H.2426 *no∙nta `too soon', and H.2432-2434 *no∙nte∙ (with AI final appended) `lack, want' perhaps have extended forms of a semantically plausible source, though they do not match the Cree, Loup A, and Illinois forms. Note also Men. |no∙s-|, as |no∙sehsen| AI |no∙sehnεn| II `he, it gives out, falls short, is deficient; he runs short of something (as, of money)', |no∙se∙w| AI `he runs short, has not enough', ibid., and forms in |nu∙s-|, ib.166, perhaps indicating mutation and matching the Illinois forms (which certainly seem to belong with the Algonquin, to judge from the examples that Gravier gives).


\lx n∞nunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 93
\ps v.t.
\ge `to suck'
    (|nunn∞nunát| `I to suck'    Job 3.12, with prefix of 1st pers.;)
    \xv nunn∞n
    \xe I suck
    \so C. 211
    \xv pish ken∞n
    \xe thou shalt suck
    \so (the milk)    Is.60.16
    \xv pish n∞nwog
    \xe they shall suck
    \so Deut.33.19

    \xv neg n∞nontogig
    \xe they who suck (the breasts)
    \so Joel 2.16
    (|n∞nunutche| `a sucking child'    Is.49.15, = |nonânese|    R.W.45)
\cf n∞nontamunát


\lx n∞sau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 93
    \nt +
\ps AI(+O)
\nt Remark: On the |s|, see G.1980, 149.
\ge `to give sb suck, become nurse unto, nurse sb'
    \xv Howan woh ánont Abrahamoh, Sarah woh n∞soou mukkiesoh?
    \xe Who would have said unto Abraham, that Sarah should have given children suck?'    Gen.21.7  { 3->3
    \so indicative; (E0&1) |n∞sóou| }
    \xv ..., kah mittumwussis neemunau mukkiésoh, kah wunn∞sáneuh.
    \xe ... . And the woman took the child, and nursed it.
    \so Ex.2.9
    \xv Kah Naomi neemunáu mukgiesoh kah uponuh upp∞chenauóinat, & wunn∞sáinoh.
    \xe And Naomi took the child, and laid it in her bosom, and became nurse unto it.
    \so Ruth 4.16

    \xv Qut missi wutonkapunaonk noh wompequait kah n∞sait yeush ut kesukodtash,...
    \xe But woe unto them that are with child, and to them that give suck, in those days!
    \so Lk.21.23
    \xv Kah missi wutonkapunnaongan∞ pôussutcheg, & n∞sautcheg yeush ut kesukodtash
    \xe And woe unto them that are with child, and to them that give suck in those days!
    \so Mt.24.19; sim. Mk.13.17

\et Compare:
    Narragansett [xnt] |Noosâwwaw.| `A Nurse'    R.W.142/r.150
    WAbn. |noni-|, |noz-| `give suck to'    D.LVI


\lx n∞santamauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 93
    \nt +
\ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem
\ge `to nurse sb for sb'
\so Ex.2.7,2.9
    \xv ... Woh nummonchem, k∞wehquetumwánshish mittumwussis n∞cháchuus, Wuthebrew mittumwussis, onk woh ken∞sontamunk mukkiésoh.
    \xe ..., Shall I go and call to thee a nurse of the Hebrew women, that she may nurse the child for thee?
    \so Ex.2.7

    \xv ..., Neemun yeuoh mukkies n∞sontamah,...
    \xe ..., Take this child away, and nurse it for me,...
    \so Ex.2.9
    \ng On contraction, see G&B 570.


\lx n∞ónat
\va n∞wonat
\va n∞wau
\va unn∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 93
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), indefinite object final
\ge `to say' (with reference to the thing said); +`to speak (of sb/sth), to speak (to sb); to command (so, thus)'
\nt G&B.722 |unnoowau|; T+.173b.
\so Lk.14.7
\nt It is used by Eliot as synonymous with the irregular verb |ussinát|, `to say', but the latter appears to have been used when attention was to be called to the speaker or the person spoken to.
    Cf.
    \xv ann∞
    \xe he says to
    \xv ken∞nau
    \xe he speaks with authority
    \xv kutt∞
    \xe he speaks, utters speech
    \xv kat∞kau
    \xe he goes on speaking
    \xv kehket∞kau
    \xe he goes on talking
    \xv uttinónat
    \xe to say to
    (cf. Num.24.13)
    \xv n∞wau
    \xe he said
    \so Gen.27.35; 1 K.8.15
    \xv n∞wop
    \xe he said
    \so 1 K.8.12; 2 Sam.13.28
    (|an∞wop| `he said to'    2 Sam.13.35
    \xv unnau
    \xe he said to, or saith to
    \so ibid.)
    \xv n∞waog
    \xe they say or said
    \so Is.41.7
    (|unn∞wónat| `to say'    C.207)

    \xv n∞adt
    \xe if he say
    \so Gen.24.14
    \xv ..., Pharaoh ne an∞wop.
    \xe ..., as Pharaoh had commanded.
    \so Gen.47.11
    \ng 3(->_manner_) } changed preterite conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv n∞wau ... Jehovah toh ánukque, ne nussin
    \xe he said ... "What the Lord saith [may say] to me, that will I speak"
    \so 1 K.22.14
    \ng 2nd verb: 3->1 participle to |unnau|/|wuttinuh|
    \xv n∞waan
    \xe if thou sayest
    \so Prov.24.12
    \xv ..., kah kusseh wuttinonkumôin ne Boaz an∞wopoh, pomushau,...
    \xe ...: and, behold, the kinsman of whom Boaz spake came by;...
    \so Ruth 4.1; c.f. Heb.2.5,11.18
    \nt +
    \xv ...: n noh-∞wutch neh Jehovah an∞wacheh wunnaumonuh nussontimom.
    \xe ...: let the same be the woman whom the LORD hath appointed out for my master's son.
    \so Gen.24.4; (E0&E1) |an∞wóhpah|

    \xv n∞wash
    \xe say thou
    \so Prov.20.22; Lk.7.7; +Gen.12.13
    \xv n∞wagk
    \xe say ye
    \so Lev.11.2
    (|unnók| `speak ye to'    ibid.)
    \xv ahque kutchan∞wagk
    \xe do not begin to say
    \so Lk.3.8

    \nt This belongs with |unn∞wónat| (|unn∞wau|), of which it is presumably an aphetic (and commoner) variant.
    \nt +

[Quiripi [qyp] |ruwan| `to speak'    Pier.52.
Delaware [del] |lu-e-u| `he says'    Zeisb.Voc.9, 20; |lu-eep| `he said' (pret.); |lua| `say on, tell'.]

\lx n∞tamunát
\va n∞tam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 94
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\ge `to hear'
\so Ezek.12.2
    \xv nunn∞"tam
    \xe I hear
    \so 1 Sam.2.23 (C.194)
    \xv n∞tam
    \xe he hears or heard
    \so 1 Sam.2.22
    \xv n∞tamunap
    \xe he heard
    \so Ps.78.21
    \xv n∞tamwog
    \xe they hear or heard
    \so Mt.11.5
    \xv n∞toadtinneat
    \xe to be heard
    \so C.194

    \xv ... n∞tamon k∞wadtauatonkqussuonk ut tanohketeaonganit,...
    \xe ... I heard thy voice in the garden,...
    \so Gen.3.10
    \ng 1->0 (changed) subjunctive
    \nt +
    \xv Onk n∞tog Abram missinnówi kemáttì,...
    \xe And when Abram heard that his brother was taken captive,...
    \so Gen.14.14
    \ng 3->0 conjunct, with o.r.; (E0) gl.: "hearing"
    \nt +
    \xv mehtauogwash n∞tam∞m∞ut
    \xe ears to hear with
    \so Deut.20.4
    \xv Kah enninnumuk kah n∞tamas,...
    \xe And it be told thee, and thou hast heard of it,...
    \so Deut.17.4
    \nt +

    imperat. |n∞tash| `hear thou'    Deut.33.7
    \xv n∞tam∞k
    \xe hear ye
    \so Is.42.18; Deut.6.4; +Gen.4.23,49.2
    \ng 2p->0 imperative

    \se n∞tónat
    \ps with an. obj. / TA, dative final
    \ge `to hear a person'; +`to hearken unto sb'
    \xv Kah papaume Ishmael ken∞taush,...
    \xe And as for Ishmael, I have heard thee:...
    \so Gen.17.20
    \ng 1->2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nanompassumunog, & matta ken∞tauòunònup:...
    \xe ..., when he besought us, and we would not hear;...
    \so Gen.42.21
    \ng 12->3 negative preterite
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah matta ken∞tiyeumop,...
    \xe ...; and ye would not hear? ...
    \so Gen.42.22
    \ng 2p->1 negative preterite
    \nt +
    \xv Kah panneauóg wutche nen, kah matta unnantam∞og ken∞tiinneaóut,...
    \xe And if ye walk contrary unto me, and will not hearken unto me;...
    \so Lev.26.21
    \ng 2p->1 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ken∞tah
    \xe thou hearest me
    \so Ps.17.6
    \ng 2->1; see G.1981, 37, 73-74 on the contraction: |-aw-| stem + theme 3.
    \xv Newutche Jehovah n∞tauau matchekuoh,...
    \xe For the LORD heareth the poor,...
    \so Ps.69.33; (M): |nootauau|
    \nt +
    \xv Kah woshwunuk nishwe seale, nunn∞tau nishwe puppinashim n∞wau, Peyaush kah naish,...
    \xe And when he had opened the third seal, I heard the third beast say, Come and see. ...
    \so Rev.6.5
    \ng 1->3 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah onkatuk nunn∞tou wutch altar[u]t, n∞wau,...
    \xe And I heard another out of the altar say,...
    \so Rev.16.7
    \nt +

    \xv Kah yeush wutch asquam n∞tiéóg,...
    \xe And if ye will not yet for all this hearken unto me,...
    \so Lev.26.18
    \ng 2p->1 conjunct
    \nt +
    |Mehtauog n∞tiit, neit n∞nanumuk,...| (subj.) `When the ear heard me, then it blessed me;...'    Job 29.11√  { 0->1 conjunct }
    \xv Kah wame nág n∞tauoncheg, monchanatamwog ∞wohtam∞ongan∞ôut, kah wunnamp∞ham∞ongan∞óash.
    \xe And all that heard him were astonished at his understanding and answers.'    Lk.2.47  { _3p_->3
    \so participle }
    \nt +
    \xv noh n∞tauusk
    \xe he that heareth you'    Lk.10.16  { _3_->2 participle; analysis? archaism, PA *-eΘk 3->2, not given by G&B? Note that the following conjunct verb is |jishánumukquean|, i.e. _3_->2, also 2 singular translating `you
    \so }
    \xv Kah n∞tauáhettit Sontimoh moncheog,...
    \xe When they had heard the king, they departed;...'    Mt.2.9  { 3p->3
    \so conjunct }
    \nt +
    \xv ... Qut Jesus nawôsikômpau, kah wuttinwhunitch wussukham∞∞ ohke, onatuh mo n∞tauonk.
    \xe ... But Jesus stooped down, and with his finger wrote on the ground, as though he heard them not.'    Jn.8.6  { 3->3
    \so negative conjunct }
    \nt +

    \xv N∞taiinnean
    \xe Hear us,...
    \so Gen.23.6
    \ng 2->1p imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., n∞tiegk, kah nanompasittumaiegk Ephron ...
    \xe ..., hear me, and entreat for me to Ephron,...
    \so Gen.23.8
    \ng 2p->1 imperative
    \nt +
    (|n∞tah| `hear thou me'    1 K.18.37
    |ken n∞tah|    C.194)
    \xv n∞tiegk kenaau Levitsog
    \xe Hear me, ye Levites
    \so 2 Chr.29.5√
    \ng 2p->1 imperative
    `hearken ye'    2 Chr.18.27
    (|ken∞tamümw∞| `ye hear'    C.194

    \se !|n∞tamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O (|-aw-|)
    \ge `to hear sth of sb'
    \so 2 Tim.2.2

    \xv ..., qut howan yeuoh n∞tamauog yeush? ...
    \xe ...: but who is this, of whom I hear such things? ...
    \so Lk.9.9 [Vlg. "quis autem est iste de quo audio ego talia"]
    \ng 1->_3_+0(p) participle
    \xv Kah nish n∞tamauwéanish ut kenugke monaog wauwacheg, ne nan ahtush paubuhtanumweinnuog, neg woh tapenukeg kuhk∞tomauun onkatogig wonk.
    \xe And the things that thou hast heard of me among many witnesses, the same commit thou to faithful men, who shall be able to teach others also.
    \so 2 Tim.2.2 [Vlg. "et quae audisti a me per multos testes..."]
    \ng 2->1+_0p_ participle

    \se |n∞tamwaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, causative
    \ge `to make sb to hear sth'
    \so Ps.51.8,66.8(M)

    \xv N∞tamwaheh weekontam∞onk kah muskouanatam∞onk,...
    \xe Make me to hear joy and gladness:...
    \so Ps.51.8; (M) |Nootamwahhe|
    \ng 2->1+0 imperative

    \se !|n∞tunkqussu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, existential passive ("verb of undergoing")
    \twn |n∞tunkquodt|
    \ge `to be heard' i.e. "to exist as someone that can be heard"
    \so Rev.18.22,23
    \xv Kah ∞wadtauatonkqussuongan∞ harpersenuog, musiciansog, kah puhpequaenuog, kah monopuhpequaenuog, matta pish wonk n∞tunkqusseog ut kuhhogkat,...
    \xe And the voice of harpers, and musicians, and of pipers, and trumpeters, shall be heard no more at all in thee;...
    \so Rev.18.22
    \ng gender by attraction? or voice (sound produced by instruments?) animate, like some musical instruments?

    \se !|n∞tunkquodt|
    \nt +
    \ps II, existential passive ("verb of undergoing"); also II+O (Josh.24.27) in personification as transitive?
    \twn |n∞tunkqussu|
    \ge `to be heard'
    \so Rev.18.22
    \xv Kah unnehtam∞onk n∞tunkquodt Pharaoh wekit,...
    \xe And the fame thereof was heard in Pharaoh's house,...
    \so Gen.45.16
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnont∞wáonk qussukquáne tog∞whonganompisk matta pish n∞tunkquodtinn∞ ut kuhhogkat.
    \xe ...; and the sound of a millstone shall be heard no more at all in thee;
    \so Rev.18.22
    |..., kusseh, yeu qussuk pish k∞wauwáonukqunnan, newutche n∞tunkquot wame wuttinn∞waongash Lord, nish ánukqueógkupash:...| (E1&2) `..., Behold, this stone shall be a witness unto us; for it hath heard all the words of the Lord which he spake unto us:...'    Josh.24.27 { Why not TI marked for II subject? }
    \et c.f. B.1962, 15.137, p.299, apparently from the TA stem.

\et B.214,215, 108/465; H.2430-2431: *no∙ntawe∙wa, *no∙ntamwa `to hear sb/sth'.


\lx n∞tattinehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 94
    \nt +
\ps AI(+O)?
\dv |n∞t-| `begin' + |-at-| prefinal + |-un-| manual final + indefinite object
\ge `to begin at sb'
\so Gen.44.12
    \xv ... & n∞tattinehteau ut mohtommegitteaut, kah ut ohquodtinneohteau peississitteaut,...
    \xe ... and [he] began at the eldest, and left at the youngest:...
    \so Gen.44.12

[Delaware [del] |Nutschi| `at the first, at the beginning'; |noot-|, as in |nootalóhkeew| AI `start working', |nóotu@weew| `start to make noise'    B&A.102; O'M.203a-204a, 204b-205a.]


\lx n∞tau
\va n∞teau
\va noohtau
\va noohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 94
    \nt Remark: Note Goddard's comment (1981.99, fn.5): "An unhistorical /h/ also appears in n8htau [sic] `fire' (Ps. 11:6), n8tau (Ps. 11:6, metrical version); noohtau, noohteau (MV in Mayhew 1709, Ps. 11:6, 18:8); cf. Mun ló∙te∙w `it burns'. Perhaps this has been contaminated by chikohteau 'it burns', chíkkoht `fire' (C 86)." All but four of the tokens of the initial in this text have the |h|.
    \nt +
\ps n. / NI
\ge `fire'
\so Ps.105.39; Prov.30.16; Gen.22.6
    \xv ..., kah neemunum n∞teau wunnutcheganit,...
    \xe ...; and he took the fire in his hand,...
    \so Gen.22.6
    \nt +

\cf chikkinásuog

[Quiripi [qyp] |arra ront'| 'as the fire', |yout| `fire'    Pier.22√.

    Lp.A |l8te|, etc. `Le feu'    D.2,3,...
    \nt +

\lx nuhkodneheau

    \xe ..., Ye know that the princes of the Gentiles exercise dominion over them, and they that are great exercise authority upon them.

\lx nuhkuhkáuónat
\va nuhkuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 94
\ps v.t.an.obj. / TA, corporal final
\twn |nuhkuhkom| TI1a
\ge `to come upon, to overwhelm', +`to fall upon sb, take hold upon sb; to be upon sb [as guilt, responsibility]'
\so Ex.14.26; +Gen.43.18; Deut.19.10
    \xv {Mishe} wabesuonk kah siaskshaonk, pish wunnuhkukauuh,...
    \xe Fear and dread shall fall upon them;...
    \so Ex.15.16
    \nt +
    \xv ...: noh matchenau ∞shoh asuh ohkasoh, ∞sqheonk pish nuhkuhhonk.
    \xe ...: he hath cursed his father or his mother; his blood shall be upon him.'    Lev.20.9; (1): |nuhkuhkonk| { treated as 3
    \so ->3 }
    \nt +
    \xv pish nuhkuhkauau sontimoh
    \xe he shall come upon princes
    \so Is.41.25
    \xv ..., kah uhquehpunnatahhaonk nunnuhkuhkonk.
    \xe ..., and horrour hath overwhelmed me.'    Ps.55.5(M); (E), ib. |nunnuhkukkongquog| `are come upon me'; Ps.119.54(M) `Horror hath taken hold upon me
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kusseh, wutangelumoh LORD wunohkuhkauoh,...
    \xe And, behold, the angel of the Lord came upon him,...
    \so Acts 12.7
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche matta askuhwheteaan, pish kenúhkekoush onatuh komm∞towaen, kah matta pish k∞wahteo uttiyeu hour nóhkekauun.
    \xe ... . If therefore thou shalt not watch, I will come on thee as a thief, and thou shalt not know what hour I will come upon thee.
    \so Rev.3.3
    \ng 1->2
    \nt +

    \xv ... machuk nuhkuhkongqut n∞sh.
    \xe ..., the evil that shall come on my father.
    \so Gen.44.34
    \ng 0->3 participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne nohkukongque asekesukokish, wunnanáwontam∞ongan∞ wame moeuwehkomonganog
    \xe ..., that which cometh upon me daily, the care of all the churches.
    \so 2 Cor.11.28
    \ng 0->1 participle
    \nt +

\et *lexkehkawe∙w, initial as S., no. 237, 402, H.1448 *lehkepye∙wi II `it is flooded, under water'. Cf. |nehtippaeu|, T.83a.


\lx nuhkuhkomunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 94
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\twn |nuhkuhkauau| TA
\ge `to cover over, to envelop, to overwhelm', +`to cover sth, prevail upon sth' (perhaps principally of water)
    \xv Neit nippe nohkuhkom ohke ...
    \xe And the waters prevailed upon the earth ....
    \so Gen.7.24
    \ng 0->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nippe qushkem∞, kah nuhkuhkom tatuppequanumukquaash, kah neg nai∞mutcheg, kah wame wutchipwushaonk Pharoh, neg asuhkauóncheg en kehtahhannet:...
    \xe And the waters returned, and covered the chariots, and the horsemen, and all the host of Pharaoh that came into the sea after them;...
    \so Ex.14.28; 40.34
    |wunnohkukómun|, |wunnúhkukkomun| `it covered it'    Ex.24.15,16
\dv |n∞kinat|.

\lx nuhquainat
\va unuhquainat
\va unnuhquáeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 94
\ps v.i. / AI, probably bahuvrihi
\ge `to look, to direct the eye', without reference to an object
\nt cf. |nadtauwómpu| `he looks for a purpose, he looks in order to see something which is or is not within sight'
    \xv ...onk nuhquaéog Sodom,...
    \xe ..., and looked toward Sodome:...
    \so Gen.18.16
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ahaôsukqueu unuhquáeu, kah matta howane nauau:...
    \xe And he looked this way and that way, and when he saw that there was no man,...
    \so Ex.2.12
    \nt +
    \xv nuttinuhquain nogque
    \xe I look toward (it)
    \so Jonh 2.4
(cf. |nogque|)
    \xv nuhquaéog
    \xe they looked or faced
    \so (to the north, etc.)    1 K.7.25


    \xv ..., toh wutch nuhquaéóg kesukquieu? ...
    \xe ..., why stand ye gazing up into heaven? ...
    \so Acts 1.11√
    \xv Qut howan unnuhquáit pahke chippe naumatuonganit,...
    \xe But whoso looketh into the perfect law of liberty,...
    \so Jas.1.25
    \nt +

    V.t. |noh nógqueh| `he who sees me'    Gen.16.13 { here in error; conjunct theme 2 inverse (3->1) to |naau| (TA). }

\nt The compounds are numerous, as:
    \xv ompamuhquaenát
    \xe to look back or behind
    |sohh∞quainat| (|sonk∞hq-|) `to look out from, to look forth'
    |ushpuhquáinat| (|asp-|, |ishp-|, |sp-|) `to look upward', etc.
\dv (|naumunat|) |naum| `to see'; |-uhquáe| `to that side; in that direction' (?).
\cf nô
\cf nôadt
\cf pânikquâ
\cf wompu
    (Cf. |kuhkinassinneat| `to take a view'    C.214.)

    [Lp.A. |netelek8a8i espemikik| `je regarde, j'ai les yeux tournés du cotté du ciel', |mat nitelek8a8i8an| `je n'y ai pas regardé', |elek8a8is| `regarde de ce cotte la', etc.    D.21,65.]
    \nt +

\et *eΘ+ final *-i∙nkw-e∙ `face, eye' + AI, H. p.247; cf. H.725 *eΘa∙piwa `to look thither, thus'

\lx nukkodtumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 95
\ps v.t. / TI1b (TI1a)
\twn |nukkonónat|, TA
\ge `to leave behind, to abandon, to forsake' (inan. obj.)
\so Prov.13.14; 16.17; Dan.9.5
    \xv Qut neteag k∞chumush, newutche kenukkodtam negonne k∞womantamóonk.
    \xe Nevertheless I have somewhat against thee, because thou hast left thy first love.
    \so Rev.2.4 (1&2)
    \nt +
    \xv nunnukodtum
    \xe I leave
    \so C.199
    \xv nukodtumu@nat
    \xe to leave
    \so C.199
    \xv {Prov.} 22.6. Nehtuhpeh peisses ut mayut ne woh ayont: kah kehchisuit matta pish wunnukkodtumooun.
    \xe Train up a Child in the way which he should go & when he is old he will not depart from it.
    \so I.P. A2v (= p.4; 1720: p.4, tr.: ib.5)
    \nt +

    \xv Neg nakodtukeg sampoi may, kah nanwiyeuwog,...
    \xe Which have forsaken the right way, and are gone astray,...
    \so 2 Pet.2.15
    \nt +
    \xv ne teag nogkodtümuk
    \xe a thing left
    \so C.172

    \se nukkonónat
    \ps With an. obj. / TA

    \se !|nukkodtumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O (|-aw-| stem)
    \ge `to leave sth with sb'
    \so Gen.39.15; Jn.14.27
    \xv Wunohteaonk kenukkodtumaunumw∞, n∞nohteaonk kuttinnumauunumw∞,...
    \xe Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you:...
    \so Jn.14.27; Mayhew |Wunnohteaonk kunnukkodtumouunumw∞, n∞nohteaonk kuttununumauunumw∞:...|

    \xv ..., Yeuyeu nukkodtumauunutti nawhutche wechógqueaneg,...
    \xe ..., Let me now leave with thee some of the folk that are with me. ...
    \so Gen.33.15
    \ng 1->2+3

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nickáttash| {singular.} `Leave, or depart.', |Nickáttammoke,| {plur.}, |Nickattamútta.| `Let us depart.'; |Mat Kunníckansh| `I will not leave you.', |Aquie Kunnickatshash.| `Doe not leave me.', |Tavvhítch nickatshiêan?| `Why doe you forsake me?'     R.W.44;74.
Cree |núgga-tum| `he fetcheth him'    Howse 42.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nenegatemen, 8ios, 8ig8"am, &c.| `J'abandonne, je laisse, cela, v.g. viande, cabane, robbe, &c.|', |nenegárañ| v. |nenegatsiharañ| `Je l'abandonne, je le quitte'    R.1/377a.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |Ngattummen| `to leave behind, to bequeath' |{nga'ttammen}|, Z., (to abandon, {not} to bequeath. A.); |ngáleew| TA `leave s.o. behind', |ngátum| TI `leave s.t. behind'    B&A.95; O'M.193a.
Menominee [mez] |neka∙nε∙w, neka∙tam| `he leaves, abandons him, it'    M.L.155.
~M.-P. |nokolal| TA `he leaves him', |nokotomon| TI `he leaves it'; |n@k@lal| TA `er verlässt ihn', |n@k@t@m@n| TI `er verlässt es'    LeS.54b-55a; Sz.144.
Miami |näkala| `I leave him', |näkatamani| `I leave it'; |nakal-| TA `abandon him, leave him behind'    D.-V.378; B&C.86a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Nakalu@k, No@ktu@m| `Abandon, Leave'; |naqalk| TA `to leave behind'    R.1a,156a (variant sp.); DeB.52a.
Nask. |nikitaaw| TA `she/he leaves him/her, it (anim) behind', |nikitim| TI `she/he leaves it behind'    McK&J.1.201b-202a.
Shawnee [sjw] |naka-| `DESERTION, MOVEMENT AWAY', |ninakala| `I left him home' and `I departed from him', |naka⌠iwe| `she separated from her husband', |ninakata| `I went away from it'    D.-V.378.]
WAbn. |ngalômeg| TA `one leaves someone', |ngadôzig| TI `one leaves something'; |wnekalô'| `he abandons him', |wnekátemén| `he abandons it'    D.1.363; W.76.]

\et *naka- with applicative final `to leave sb/sth', A.1371, H.2118-26(-2135?), H.2126 *nakaΘe∙wa TA `away'; the vowel correspondences are somewhat unsettled; t-extension common, cf. B.1962, 16.65, 342: |neka∙nε∙w|, |neka∙tam| `he leaves him, it', with |-aN|, |-at| finals; basic sense of the initial `depart' (intransitive)? Status of sense "stop" uncertain.

\lx nukkône

    (`original', `old'    C.173)

    \xe ancient river
    \so Judg.5.21

    \xe old lion
    \so Is.30.6

    \xe the old ways
    \so Job 22.15

    \xe the ancient mountain

    \xe these are ancient things

    \xe that which waxeth old

[Western Abenaki [abe] |negañnié| `c'est une vieille coutume'; |negañni arenañbak| `les anciens'; |nikkañni8i| `devant, par avance'; |nenikkañn8ssé| `je marche devant'    Rasles 558,559.

\lx nukkonean∞
\va nukkonniin∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 95
    \nt +
\ps II
\ge `to wax old'
\so Deut.8.4,29.5
    \xv ..., kuthogk∞un∞ash matta nano nukkoneain∞ash ut kuhhogkaóut, kah kummokus matta nukkonniinn∞ ut kusseetut.
    \xe ...: your clothes are not waxen old upon you, and thy shoe is not waxen old upon thy foot.
    \so Deut.29.5


\lx nukkonónat
\va -N-
\ve ; cf. examples and etymol. note.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 95
\ps v.t.an. / TA, applicative
\twn |nukkodtumunát|, TI1a
\ge `to leave, to go away from, to abandon, to forsake'
\so Deut.12.19
    pass. |noh nussu nukkonau| `he alone is left'    Gen.44.20, +Gen.42.38 |nukkonnou|  { X->3 }
    \xv ..., Wusken matta woh nukkonaou ∞shoh, newutche nukkonnont ∞shoh, woh nupp∞oh.
    \xe ..., The lad cannot leave his father: for if he should leave his father, {his father} would die.'    Gen.44.22  { 3->3' negative absolute; 3->3
    \so conjunct }
    \nt +
    \xv pish nukkonau
    \xe he shall leave (them)
    \so Mk.10.7; Eph.5.31
    \xv Kah penuanatúonk missi, onk nukkónittúog,...
    \xe And the contention was so sharp between them, that they departed asunder one from the other:...
    \so Acts 15.39√ (see |nukkodtumunát|)
    \ng reciprocal
    \xv ... Matta kenukkonnunn∞ asuh kutahquanumunn∞.
    \xe ..., I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee.'    Heb.13.5; Deut.15.16: |Matta kenukonunn∞| `I will not go away from thee
    \so { 1->2 negative }
    \nt +
    \xv Matta kuttit nukkonn∞mw∞ tauwyésuinneat, pish kuppeyaounumw∞.
    \xe I will not leave you comfortless: I will come to you.
    \so Jn.14.18
    \ng 1->2p negative, syncopated
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk mos kutchadchapiyeumw∞, nishnoh pasuk nehenwonche wutayeuonganit, kah pish kenukkossumw∞,...
    \xe ..., that ye shall be scattered, every man to his own, and shall leave me alone:...
    \so Jn.16.32; Mayhew |kunnukkossumw∞|
    \ng 2p->1
    \nt +
    (|nukkonittinneat| `to be left'    C.199)

    \xv nukkonóg
    \xe if ye turn away
    \so Num.32.15
    \xv toh wutch nukkônóg
    \xe why have ye left (him)
    \so Ex.2.20
    \xv ONK n nih, nagonnógkut nagoh kah wanághomôog, paóúsukkuhkomog Choos,...
    \xe And it came to pass, that after we were gotten from them, and had launched, we came with a straight course unto Coos,...
    \so Acts 21.1
    \ng 1p->3(p)
    \nt +
    |nukkonont| (part.) `leaving'    Gen.2.24  { 3->3' (changed) conjunct }
    `"departing from", abandoning'    Jer.3.20
    \xv Newajeh yeu nukkonun ut Creetut, woh k∞nohtáuunat nish asq ananógish,...
    \xe For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting,...
    \so Tit.1.5
    \ng 1->2 subjunctive
    \nt +

    \xv ..., nukkonn∞k pasuk kemattou,...
    \xe ...; leave one of your brothers here with me,...
    \so Gen.42.33
    \ng 2p->3
    |... ahque nukkôsseh:...| (an. suffix) `...; leave me not,...'    Ps.27.9; (M): |ahque nukkosseh|  { 2->1 }
    \xv ..., k∞wehquetumoush, ahque nukkossinnan,...
    \xe ..., Leave us not, I pray thee;...
    \so Num.10.31
    \ng 2->1p
    \nt +

[The Narragansett form appears to have been (|nukkodtshónat|) |nickatshónat| for the v.an., though the first of the following examples may be traced to |nukkonónat|: |mat kunníckansh| `I will not leave you'; |ahquie kunnickkatshash| `do not leave me'; |tawhítch nickatshiêan| `why do you forsake me?'    R.W.75. (This form has the characteristic |sh| of disastrous or undesirable action.)]

\et See under twin |nukkodtum-| TI.

    \xe to be in a full (good old) age

    (see |-quinne| and |kodtumwohkom|)

\lx nukon
\va nuhkon
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 95
\ps n. / II
\ge `night', `to be night'
\so Gen.1.5,16: +Gen.1.18; Jn.9.4; Rom.13.12; Rev.21.25,22.5
    \xv ... newutche matta pish na ut nuhkonunn∞.
    \xe ...: for there shall be no night there...
    \so Rev.21.25
    \ng 0 negative indicative; predicative?
    \nt +
    \xv Kah na matta pish nukon∞h,...
    \xe And there shall be no night there;...
    \so Rev.22.5
    \ng 0 negative indicative, syncopated; predicative?
    \nt +

    \xv yeu nohkog
    \xe this night
    \so Gen.19.5
    \ng 0->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kenaeu wonk yeu appek yeu nuhkog,...
    \xe ..., tarry ye also here this night,...
    \so Num.22.19
    \ng 0->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +

    \se |nukon|, |nuhkon|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `night'
    pl. |nukonash|, |nuhkonash|    Job 7.3
    \xv Nukkon, -ash
    \xe Night, nights
    \so C.15/164.

\dv |n∞kinat| `to descend, to go down'; or from |nukkonónat| `to leave, to go away from (?) the sun, gone down or having left' (?).
\cf nohkog

    [Menominee [mez] |nεhka∙n| II `it is evening'    M.L.150.
    \nt +
    Mont. |Richkanapin i8| `sei8rner, rester encore t8t Le I8r', |Riskanapi8 pl. 8ek| `il, ils demeurent t8t Le I8r'; |ni riskanapin| `je demeure encore ce soir.'    Fbvr.324; Slv.140.
    \nt ?
Shawnee [sjw] |l?kanwi| `it is moderating this evening'    D.-V.348.]

\et H.1445-1447 *lexkan- `evening' (slight evidence)

\lx nukquttegheon
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps NA
    \dv |nequt-| `one' + |-ek(e)he-| `to bear (a child)' + ?|-n| verbal abstract? (cf. mut.mut. Alg. |Pejikonjan| `enfant unique, l'unique enfant de sa mère', Cq.332b?)
    \nt +
\ge `an only child, son or daughter'
    \so Judg.11.34; Jer.6.26; Amos 8.10; Zech.12.10; Lk.7.12,8.42,9.38; Jn.1.14,18,3.16,18; Heb.11.17; 1 Jn.4.9
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah neh mo wunnequttegheonuh,...
    \xe ...: and she was his only child;...
    \so Judg.11.34
    \ng 3 possessor obviative
    \nt +
    \xv ...: noh wunnukquttegheónuh ohkasoh,...
    \xe ...; she is the only one of her mother,...
    \so Cant.6.9√
    \xv ...: ogquohpâusish mauwemat kenukquttegheon,...
    \xe ...: make thee mourning, as for an only son,...
    \so Jer.6.26
    \ng 2 possessor proximate
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche noh nunnukquttegheun.
    \xe ...; for he is mine only child.
    \so Lk.9.38√

    \se |nukquetegheae|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `only (child)'
    \so Gen.22.2,16
    \xv ..., Neemun yeuyeu kenaumon kenukquetegheáe Isaak noh womonadt ...
    \xe ..., Take now thy son, thine only son Isaac, whom thou lovest,...
    \so Gen.22.2


\lx nummatappinneat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps v.i. / AI, |nummat-| + |-appu|
\ge `to seat one's self, to sit down'
    \xv nummatappu
    \xe he sat down
    \so Ruth 4.1; Lk.14.28
    \xv nummatappuog
    \xe they sat down
    \so Ruth 4.2; Lk.22.55
    \xv Kah monchu, kah nummatappu uppiuksukukauoh,...
    \xe And she went, and sat her down over against him a good way off,...
    \so Gen.21.16
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nummatappuog meechwog petukqunneg;...
    \xe And they sat down to eat bread:...
    \so Gen.37.25
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +

    \xv kah namatapit
    \xe and when he was set
    \so Mt.5.1
    \nt +

    \xv nummatapsh
    \xe sit down
    \so Is.52.2
    \xv omohkish, k∞wehquetumoush, nummatapsh, kah meetch n∞weyaus ...
    \xe arise, I pray thee, sit and eat of my venison,
    \so Gen.27.19
    \nt +

    (|nummattâpu@nat| `to sit'; |nunnummâttap| `I sit'; |appu| `he sits'    C.209)
\cf appin
cf. Abnaki (Rasles, `asseoir', p. 388).

    [Del.(M) |l@`mátàp@w| `he sits'    G.1982, (225), 40.
    \nt +
Fx. |nematapiwa| `he sits upright'    Fx.L. 125, G.1990b,456.]

\et G.1982, 5.11.3, fn.131, p.40: *Θemat- `erect', "a root derived from a TI stem".
