\lx numwá-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge `full (of sth)'
\so following lemmas
\et No obvious proto-form in standard listings


\lx numwabehtauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
    \nt +
\ps TA, |-eht-aw-| stem
\nt Remark: Like |appehtauau| typically in inverse form
\ge `for sb to be full of sth, filled with sth'
\so Deut.34.9; Ps.69.20(M); Acts 4.31,5.17,6.5,8,7.55,9.17,11.24,13.9,45; Rom.15.14; Col.1.9
    \xv Kah Joshua wunnaumonuh Nun, numwabehtunk nashauanitt∞e waantamóonk,...
    \xe And Joshua the son of Nun was full of the spirit of wisdom;...
    \so Deut.34.9
    \ng 0->3
    \xv Ushpunatuonk poohqunumup nuttah; kah nunnumwapehtunk tohkequnnooonk:
    \xe Reproach hath broken my heart, and I am full of heaviness:...
    \so Ps.69.20 {  0->1 }; (E): |nuhhogkat numwohteau onkquanum∞onk|
    \xv Qut Jewsog nauáhettit monánutcheh, numwabetunkquog iskauanittuonk,...
    \xe But when the Jews saw the multitudes, they were filled with envy,...
    \so Acts 13.45
    \ng 0->3p


\lx numwabeu
\va numwapeu
\va numwappu
\ve ! not currently found
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
    \nt +
\ps AI(+O?)
\dv |numwá-| `full of' initial + |api-| `to be at' (AI)
\twn |numwohteau| II
\ge `to be full of sb, be filled with sb', `to fill sth' [in the sense: contained/container]; sometimes with a locative adjunct denoting the container; syntax obscure, though with clear indications that the subject is animate (cf. |numwohteau|).
\so Ps.127.5; Jn.2.7,21.11; Acts 5.3
    \xv Kah wunnaumonuh Israel mishummeechumúog, kah nanomonáog kah muttaánwog, kah nano puhkénonkqussuog, muttáeu, kah ohke wunnumwápeneau.
    \xe And the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly, and multiplied, and waxed exceeding mighty; and the land was filled with them.
    \so Ex.1.7
    \ng n-paradigm due to plural pronominal subject, as "they filled the land"?
    \xv ...kah wutegiptiansog weekuóut pish nanumwápuog iánussitcheh, kah wame ohkeit ne aphettit.
    \xe ...: and the houses of the Egyptians shall be full of swarms of flies, and also the ground whereon they are.
    \so Ex.8.21
    \ng reduplicated
    \xv Neit wuttinneumoh sohhamwoh mayikontu, kah mounaog namheahettiche, matchetowog kah wunnet∞wog, kah numwapuog missinninnuog wussentam∞wonganit.
    \xe So those servants went out into the highways, and gathered together all as many as they found, both bad and good: and the wedding was furnished with guests.
    \so Mt.22.10
    \xv ..., Sohhash en mayuhkontu, kah pummeneutunkanéhtu, kah chekée petukas, onk woh neek numwápin
    \xe ..., Go out into the highways and hedges, and compel them to come in, that my house may be filled.
    \so Lk.14.23
    \ng X->0 subordinative, |neek| as object?
    \xv ... & kuhpinau hashabpoh, wunnumwapinneau mogkommâquog,...
    \xe ..., and drew the net to land full of great fishes,...
    \so Jn.21.11; (M): |wunnumwapinneaop|
    \ng plural agreeing with |mogkommâquog|? n-paradigm due to pronominal object? -- container treated as object, contained as subject "fish filled it"?
    \xv ..., nag woh wutanwôsinunnaóut ogguhsese, nô pajeh weeche wuttinneumunneuh wonk, kah wemat∞uh, nag nushonaóut neyane nag, woh wunnumwápinneaóut.
    \xe ..., that they should rest yet for a little season, until their fellow servants also and their brethren, that should be killed as they were, should be fulfilled.
    \so Rev.6.11

    \xv OOnaiyeu woskeetomp noh uppetanwonit nomwapenit,...
    \xe Happy is the man that hath his quiver full of them [children/arrows]:...
    \so Ps.127.5; (M): |Wunniyeu wosketomp noh uppetanwon namwapinit:...|
    \ng locative vs. non-locative container
    \xv ..., Annanias tohwutch mattanit numwabit kuttahhut, pann∞waheun wunneetupanatamwe Nashauanit,...
    \xe ..., why hath Satan filled thine heart to lie to the Holy Ghost,...
    \so Acts.5.3
    \ng taken to be conjunct; is Satan the substance contained or a causal agent?

    \xv ..., Mshéneetuónittegk, kah muttaan∞k, kah numwapegk nippe ut kehtohhannit,...
    \xe ..., Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas,...
    \so Gen.1.22
    \ng 2p->0 imperative
    \xv ..., Numwâpag ahkuhquog nippe. Kah wunnumwapágunóuh.
    \xe ..., Fill the water pots with water. And they filled them up to the brim.
    \so Jn.2.7; (M): |Numwápag|
    \ng |-ag| unexpected in putative i-stem


\lx numwábpanumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `to fill (one thing with another)'
    \xv numwapogkunnumwog wunnonkash
    \xe they filled the troughs (with water)
    \so Ex.2.16
    \ng different stem
    \xv numwôquom upp∞thonch∞mut
    \xe she filled her pitcher
    \so Gen.24.16
    \ng different stem
    \xv ...: wonk sookunnon numwapanumoomoo nippisseash
    \xe ...: the rain also filleth the pools.
    \so Ps.84.6(M) { NI subject }; (E1&2): |...: kah sokanon numwohbagwutteau nuppissepagwos.|

    \xv numwában kutaskon pummee
    \xe fill thy horn with oil
    \so 1 Sam.16.1
    \ng different stem
    \xv numwabpanum∞k
    \xe fill ye (barrels with water)
    \so 1 K.18.33


\lx numwáe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps adj. / PreN(?), PreV, (optionally?) transitive
    \nt Remark: syntax quite varied, occasionally verb-like (see e.g. Judg.6.38, Ps.75.8,104.16, Lk.4.28). The example from Cotton indicates that this is an animate form, with an accompanying inanimate form |numwohta(e?)|; however, other examples do not indicate resistance to inanimate "subjects" (denoting containers).
    \nt +
\ge `full of, filled with'
\so Num.22.18; 24.13; Judg.6.38
    \xv ..., tohneit Balak aninnumaiit weekit numwae silvr kah gold,...
    \xe ..., If Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold,...
    \so Num.22.18
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah senuppânum neechippog wutch fleecut, numwae wunnonkanit nippe.
    \xe ..., and [he] wringed the dew out of the fleece, a bowl full of water.
    \so Judg.6.38
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche wunnitchegannut Jehovah ahteau wuttattamwaetch, kah ne wine mishqui, numwae kunnittippannosu, onk ne na ootsookunumun:...
    \xe For in the hand of the Lord, {there is} a cup, and the wine is red: it is full of mixture, and he poureth out of the same:...
    \so Ps.75.8(M); (E): |numwaeu kenittepáunausu|
    \nt +
    \xv Ummuhtugkumash Jehovah, numwae wussippeyeuooash:...
    \xe The trees of the Lord are full of sap:...
    \so Ps.104.16(M); (E) |numwohteau|
    \ng the contained not mentioned
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wame neg apitcheg Synagogut; yeush n∞tamwehettit, numwae musquanatamwog.
    \xe And all they in the synagogue, when they heard these things, were filled with wrath,
    \so Lk.4.28
    \nt +
    \xv ...; onk woh n∞wekontam∞onk numwae pakodchehtôsu ut wohhogaout.
    \xe ...; that they might have my joy fulfilled in themselves.
    \so Jn.17.13(M); (E): |..., n∞weekontamóonk woh ahtoog numwohteau wuhhogkaont.|
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche ut wuhhogkat, appehtunk wame numwae wuhhogkae manittóowonk.
    \xe For in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily.
    \so Col.2.9
    \nt +
    |Wosketomp numwae ishkauussu@onk. `A man full of envy'
    \nt +
    \xv Numwae, pâshanne.
    \xe Fully
    \so C.104/228

    \se |numwohta|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `full of'
    \so Gen.21.14
    \xv wisquadt n[u]mwohta nippe
    \xe a bottle of water
    \so Gen.21.14
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wame otanat numwohta wogkouéonk,...
    \xe And the whole city was filled with confusion:...
    \so Acts 19.29
    \nt +
    \xv Wetu numwohta momatchiash,
    \xe A house full of goods
    \so C.23/170


\lx numwamechimehkónat
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps AI ? (TI2 ?)
\ge `to fill [to make full with food (?)]
\so C.191
    \xv nu@nnumwamechimëhteam
    \xe I fill' [`I am filled, I become full of food
    \so (?)]    C.191


\lx numwameechum
\va numwameechumeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps AI(+O), i-stem
\ge `I am full {?}, he is full' (of food)
    \nt Remark: Although this may in effect contain an incorporated object denoting the item contained, an external (object) noun phrase may still be present, and denote a wider class of contained items than just food.
    \nt +
\so Prov.30.9; +Deut.33.23; Rom.1.29,11.12; 1 Cor.4.8; Phil.1.11,4.18
    \xv Kah papaume Naphthali, n∞wau Naphthali tapantam nashpe wómoausue tapeneaum∞onk, kah numwameechumeu nashpe ∞nanitteaonk Jehovah, ohtaush kehtoh kah sowaniyeu.
    \xe And of Naphtali he said, O Naphtali, satisfied with favour, and full with the blessing of the Lord: possess thou the west and the south.
    \so Deut.33.23
    \ng third person subject; contained as instrumental
    \nt +
    \xv Ishkont numwameechum, kah kutch(e)ketoush,...
    \xe Lest I be full, and deny thee,...
    \so Prov.30.9
    \ng in context: "of food"; apheresis of prefix

    \xv Numwameechumméhettit wame panneusseongash, nanwun∞dsquauáonk, matcheseonk, ahchewontamóonk, ishskauánittuonk, numwohtoog ishkauánittuok, shehteaonk, penuanittuonk, as∞kekodteam∞wonk, matanittúonk, kehkemwae matcheìtcheg.
    \xe Being filled with all unrighteousness, fornication, wickedness, covetousness, maliciousness; full of envy, murder, debate, deceit, malignity; whisperers,
    \so Rom.1.29
    \xv Nâmwameechuméog nashpe ummechummuongash sampweusseonk,...
    \xe [Ye] Being filled with the fruits of righteousness,...
    \so Phil.1.11


\lx numwameechumehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
    \nt +
\ps TI2, causative to |numwameechume-|
\ge `to fill sth (with sth)'
\so Deut.6.11; Lk.5.7; Jn.6.13
    \xv Kah wowhôtionumauwaog weechaiyeuthettiche nag ápitcheg onkatog kuht∞nogqut, woh peyaog kah wutannumunk∞oh, kah peyaog, kah numwameechumehteaog neeswe kuht∞nogwash, onk kod quttauwéog
    \xe And they beckoned unto their partners, which were in the other ship, that they should come and help them. And they came, and filled both the ships, so that they began to sink.
    \so Lk.5.7
    \ng in context, animate subject denotes the contained
    \xv Yeuwutche mohmóunumúneau kah numwameechumehteáog nabo neesinash man∞tash, wutche ussquéhteungash napanna tahshinash barlie petukqunegash,...
    \xe Therefore they gathered them together, and filled twelve baskets with the fragments of the five barley loaves,...
    \so Jn.6.13; (M): |numwamechumehteouppaneg|

    \xv Kah wetuomash numwohteau wunne maumachiash, nish matta numwameechumehteapash,...
    \xe And houses full of all good things, which thou filledst not,...
    \so Deut.6.11


\lx numwápagod
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps N? (II verb?)
\ge `(a place) full of water'
\so 2 K.3.17

    \nt Remark: For the etymology, see |numwapagunum|, and B.1962, 18.186, p.414 on the medial |-εpi∙k| `water, liquid': "Before II |-at|: |ε∙hkopikah|; derived noun |wa∙naskopi∙kat|."
    \nt +


\lx numwapagunum
\va numwohpagunum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
    \nt +
\ps TI1b, manual final
\dv |numwá-| `fill' + |-(?u)pág-| `liquid, water' + |-un-| manual final
\ge `to fill sth' (with liquid)
\so Josh.9.13

    |Kah yeush wine wisquash nish nowapagunumagkupash, wuskehiash,...| (E1&2) `And these bottles of wine, which we filled, were new;...'    Josh.9.13  { 1p->_0p_ preterite participle }

    \se !|numwapagunau|, !|numwohpagunau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, manual final
    \ge `to fill sb' (with liquid)
    \so Gen.21.19; Jn.2.7
    \xv ..., kah numwôhpagunau wishquau nippe,...
    \xe ..., and [she] filled the bottle with water,...'    Gen.21.19  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    |..., Numwâpag ahkuhquog nippe. Kah wunnumwapágunóuh.| (also E1) `..., Fill the water pots with water. And they filled them up to the brim.'    Jn.2.7; (M): |..., Numwápag nippe-ohkuhquoh nippe. Kah wunnumwâponowoopah en wussaut.|  { 3p->3' (preterite) objective }

\et For the medial classifying noun, *-epye∙(k) `water, liquid', see B.93, no. 359, 94,97; B.1962, 17.69, 379, 18.186, 414, on |-εpi∙k|, with Hockett's remark; Warne 1975, entries "black", "cold", "red" (liquids), "within", "white" (e.g. |mkwíbagá| `it is red liquid', p.134); Valentine 2001, 9.11.1.2, ex. 455 |bkwebiigmi| `be dirty water', H.3977 on "Winnebago".


\lx numwáp[pinneat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps v.i. / AI+O ?
\ge `to fill up, to make full' (of an. obj.)
    \xv nag pish numwápuog
    \xe they shall fill
    \so (thy houses, i.e. thy houses shall be full of them)    Ex.10.6


\lx numwohtauunat
\va numwohtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps v.t. and i. / TI2, causative
\ge `to fill up, to make full, to be full' (inan. subj.)
    \nt Remark: The intransitive and stative forms belong in the lemma |numwohteau|, and have been transferred there.
    \nt +
    \xv ...: Israel pish peshauau, kah wunéht∞nuhquamú∞, kah pish numwohtou woskeche muttaohkit nashpe meechummuonk.
    \xe ...: Israel shall blossom and bud, and fill the face of the world with fruit.
    \so Is.27.6√
    \xv ...: wóhshinush m∞cheke kutt∞n kah pish numwôhtaun.
    \xe ...: open thy mouth wide, and I will fill it.
    \so Ps.81.10; (M): |nunnumwohtouun|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., pish numwohteo {aiyeuonkash} nuppooe mohhogash:...
    \xe ..., he shall fill the places with the dead bodies:...
    \so Ps.110.6(M)
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah nag numwohto∞paneg anashkodt∞onus seanuppog,...
    \xe ...: and they filled a spunge with vinegar,...
    \so Jn.19.29(M); (E): |wunnumwohtineau spungut vineger|
    \nt +
    \xv Kah angel nemunum censer, kah wunnumwohtauun n∞tau ut altarut,...
    \xe And the angel took the censer, and filled it with fire of the altar,...
    \so Rev.8.5√

    \xv Nish nashpe tisashquaenin matta nomwohto∞g wunnutcheg:...
    \xe Wherewith the mower filleth not his hand:...
    \so Ps.129.7; (M): |namwohtoook|
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah numwohtoush kenutcheganit n∞tae mokossaash wutch nanashaue cherubimsut,...
    \xe ..., and fill thine hand with coals of fire from between the cherubim,...
    \so Ezek.10.2
    \xv numwohtaj
    \xe let (it) be filled
    \so C.191
    \ng different stem, |numwohtam| ?


\lx numwohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
    \nt +
\ps II(+O)
\dv |numw-| `full' + |ohtá-| II `to be there'
\twn |numwabeu|, |numwapeu|, AI (cf. |appu| vs. |ohteau|)
\ge `to be filled (with sth), full (of sth)' (making the assumption that the subject denotes the container cf. Ps.74.20(M))
\so Gen.6.11,13,14.10,15.16,21.4,29.21,...; Ps., passim; Mt., passim; Mk.4.37,15.36; Lk.9.17,11.34,36; ...
    \xv ..., newutche ummatcheseongan∞ Amoritog asquam numwohtano.
    \xe ...: for the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet full.
    \so Gen.15.16
    \ng 0 negative indicative
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnohkóunn∞ numwohteau matcheseonkquatunkash.
    \xe ...: and their right hand is full of bribes.
    \so Ps.26.10; (M): |wuttinnohkounnoo namwohtosik nashpe magkooonk.|
    \ng derivational passive to TI2
    \xv ...: newutche pohkunae aiyeuonkash ut ohkeit numwohtaash uhquanumwehhuae wuttohkeonkash.
    \xe ...: for the dark places of the earth are full of the habitations of cruelty.
    \so Ps.74.20(M); (E): |... pogkenâoash ut ohkeit, wunnumwohteau wutohtu∞ash mukk∞kinneaenuog,|
    \ng i.e. no agreement, perhaps a subordinative form
    \xv ...: kah qussuk noh togkomont nunnukontunk, mishadch∞∞, kah numwohteau mamusse ohkeit.
    \xe ...: and the stone that smote the image became a  great mountain, and filled the whole earth
    \so Dan.2.35
    \xv ..., kah tukk∞og pogkussinwog kuht∞nogqut, neit yeuyeu numwohteau.
    \xe ..., and the waves beat into the ship, so that it was now full.
    \so Mk.4.37
    \xv ...: kah wetu numwohtóp ne asummunkquohkup sussequeonk.
    \xe ...: and the house was filled with the odour of the ointment.
    \so Jn.12.3(M); (E1&2): |wetuómut numwóhhan|
    \ng error?
    \xv ..., óhquanumóonk numwohteau kutahh∞woash
    \xe ..., sorrow hath filled your heart.
    \so Jn.16.6; (M): |kuttahh∞ numwohteau n∞wantam∞onk.|
    \ng word order!

    \xv Newutche wame kuhhog numwohtag wequai, matta chippano pohkenai, wame numwohteau wequai,...
    \xe If thy whole body therefore be full of light, having no part dark, the whole shall be full of light,...
    \so Lk.11.36

    \xv Nuttoon numwohtaj koowaenomitteaonk, kah nashpe kukquehtianumitteaonk quinne kesuk.
    \xe Let my mouth be filled with thy praise, and with thy honour all the day.
    \so Ps.71.8(M)
    \ng contained as object in first conjunct, as instrumental in second }; (E): |Nutt∞nut numwohtaj k∞waweenomutteaonk, kah kukquehtianumitteaonk qunnikesuk.| { container as locative, contained as subject?


\lx numwonkquau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
\ps n. / II
\ge +`to be an heap'
    \nt Remark: Attestation and sublemma transferred from |nomunkquág|.
    \nt +
\nt G&B.676
    \xv ...: & pish numwonkquau micheme, matta pish wonk ayimm∞un,
    \xe ...: and it [the city] shall be an heap for ever; it shall not be built again.
    \so Deut.13.16√

    \xv Yeush nomunquagish wauwon nashauwe ut ken kah neen yeu kesukok,...
    \xe This heap is a witness between me and thee this day.
    \so Gen.31.48
    \ng _0p_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv onatuh nomwonkquag
    \xe as an heap
    \so Ps.78.13
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt +

    \se numwonkquau
    \ps NI
    \ge `a heap'
    \xv Kah ∞waapenumauouh mishe numwonkquáu qussukqunash yeu pajeh yeu kesukok,...
    \xe And they raised over him a great heap of stones unto this day....
    \so Josh.7.26√

    \se nummunkquáe
    \ps A, Adv
    \ge `heaped'
    \so Cant.7.2
    \xv nanomwonkquaeu nono nunkquash
    \xe heaps upon heaps
    \so Judg.15.16
\dv |nanomwonkquaeu|.
\cf nomunkquág


\lx numwonkquttauunát
\va numwongquatau
\va nomunquadtau
\va numwonkquodtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 96
    \nt Remark: This does not exhibit systematically the palatalization that one would expect in a denominal creative verb, though some examples may be of that type.
    \nt +
\ps v.t. / TI2 causative
\ge `to heap up'; +`to cast sth, to set sth up, to heap sth up, to make (sth into) a heap, sth to stand'
\so Eccl.2.26
    \xv numwonkquottou
    \xe he heapeth up [riches]
    \so Ps.39.6(E&M)√
    \xv Kah Jakob unnau weematoh, Mukkinnum∞k qussukquanash kah nemunnumwog qussukquanash kah wunnumwonkquodtauunáoash, & meetsuog ne ut ne nomunkquag.
    \xe And Jacob said unto his brethren, Gather stones; and they took stones, and made an heap: and they did eat there upon the heap.
    \so Gen.31.46
    \ng 3p->0p objective
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Joshua numwongquatau nabo neenash qussukquanash, ut noeu Jordan,...
    \xe And Joshua set up twelve stones in the midst of Jordan,...
    \so Josh.4.9
    \xv ...: wunnumwónkquáhteauun nippe onatuh nomwonkquag.
    \xe ...: and he made the waters to stand as an heap.
    \so Ps.78.13
    \ng 3->0 ?subordinative; or creative final?
    \nt +

    \xv Onk Laban unnau Jakoboh, Naush yeu nomungquag, kah naush yeu neepatuhquonk ne yeu nomunkquodtau ut nashauwe neen kah ken,
    \xe And Laban said to Jacob, Behold this heap, and behold this pillar, which I have cast betwixt me and thee;
    \so Gen.31.51  { 1->_0_ participle }; (E0) |naumòunkquttau|, E1 with |-ó-|
    \nt +

    \se nanómongquodtauunat
    \ps freq.
    \ge `to heap up abundantly or to make great heaps'
    \so Ps.39.6; Job 27.16
\cf nomunkquág

    \xe I will dry up
    \so (the waters)    Is.42.15; 44.27
    \xv nunnáhsum sepuash
    \xe he drieth up the rivers
    \so Hag.1.4

\ge he maketh it (the sea) dry
\so Hag.1.4
\cf nunobpe
\cf nunnobohteateou

    (|nunkon|)    Matt.11.30

    \so Ps.62.9

\lx nunk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\lx -nunkqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 97

\nt Remark: often in the form |-neunkqu-| owing to infection

\so Gen.39.6,40.6,40.7,41.21; ...

    \se -nunkquodt
    \ps II
    \so Lev.11.32; Mt.3.15; Rev.9.19; ...

\et See B.1962, 15.141, 300-301; *na:- (*naw-) `see' + *kwes-/*-kwatw middle.

    pl. |nunksquaog|    Ps.148.12
    \xv wunnunksquomoh
    \xe her maidens

    \ng 3 possessor obviative
    dim. |nunksquaes|, |nunksquaemes|    El.Gr.12

    \se nunksqua-

    \ge `to be a girl, young woman'

    \so Ezek.23.3

    \nt +
    \xv MAtta pish kutayimômw∞ nunneukontunkanog, asuh matta pish keneepattauômw∞ ne teague unnunneukontunk, ne teague nunneukontunkone qussuk ut kuttohtuóut,...
    \xe Ye shall make you no idols nor graven image, neither rear you up a standing image, neither shall ye set up any image of stone in your land,...

    \nt +

    \xe ..., and idolaters,...

\lx nunnobohteáou

    \xe on dry ground

    = |nabohteaóuut|, |nabohteaôúut| `(up)on (the) dry gound'    Ex.14.16,22√
    (|nunnapohteaiyeuut| `in dry places'    Mass.Ps., Ps.105.41)

    \xe from the dust of the earth

\lx nunnukkuhquohtauau

\lx nunnukkunumunát

    \so Heb.12.26

    pass. |nunnukkeem∞| `it was shaken'    Ex.19.18√  { distinct stem }
    (|Neit ohke nukkeemo,...| `Then the earth shook ...'    Ps.18.7√; (M) |nunnukshumoop|)

\lx nunnukkushonát
\va nannukshonát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 97
\ps v.i. / AI, II long-vowel stem
\ge `to tremble, to shake'
    \xv nunnunnukkushom
    \xe I quake
    \so (for fear)    Heb.12.21
    \xv nunnukkushomp
    \xe I trembled
    \so Hab.3.16
    \xv nunnuksheau
    \xe it trembled
    \so 2 Sam.22.8
    \xv nunnukshaog
    \xe they trembled
    \so Ex.19.16; 1 Sam.14.15
    \xv nunnukshau mishenuksháonk m∞cheke
    \xe he trembled very exceedingly
    \so Gen.27.33
    (|Nunnukki@shshom.| `I shake, or tremble'    C.74/208
    \xv Nunnukkisshônat
    \xe to tremble, or tingle
    \so C.213
    \xv N∞weyaus nunnukisshau
    \xe My flesh trembleth
    \so C.82/214)√

    |nunnukkushont|, |-qushont| (part.) `trembling'    Mk.5.33; Acts 9.6
    |matta woh nanukkushonog| (?) `which cannot be moved' (?)    Heb.12.28  { _0_ negative participle to II }

    \se !|nunnukkukquashau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, |-uhkquá-| `eye, head' + |-uhshá-|
    \ge `to shake the head'
    \so following derivative

    \se |nunnukkukquashaong(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps II, deverbal noun
    \ge `a shaking of the head'
    \so Ps.44.14(M)
    \xv ..., nunnukukquashaonk kunnukke missininuog.
    \xe ...: a shaking of the head among the people.
    \so Ps.44.14(M)

[Delaware [del] |nun gach tschi| `I shake for cold'    Zeisb.Voc.25.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nenanekpañï| `Je tremble de crainte'    R.145/424a.]

\lx nunnukqussenát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 97
\ps v.i. / AI(+O)
\ge `to take heed, to act cautiously'; +the sense is not clear, as can be seen by comparing Deut.12.13 and Deut.12.19, one with a negated t-subordinative, the other with a positive one.
    (|nunnukqussinneat| `to beware'    C.182)
    (|nen nunnükqus| `I beware'    C.182
    \xv matta nunnukqussu
    \xe he took no heed
    \so 2 K.10.31

    \xv Uttoh woh wuttin wusken pahketeauun ummay nashpe nunnukqussit kukkutt∞onk.
    \xe Wherewith shall a young man cleanse his way? by taking heed thereto according to thy word.
    \so Ps.119.9; (M): |nashpe wunnunukquissuontamooonk|; +Log.Pr.75/89

    \xv nunnukqussish (kuhhog)
    \xe take heed to thyself
    \so Ex.34.12; Deut.4.9; 12.30
    \xv Kah Pharoh wuttinuh amaeihtah, nunnukqsush, ahque wonk naush nuskeuk, ne wutche nekesukok nauman nuskesuk, pish kenup.
    \xe And Pharaoh said unto him, Get thee from me, take heed to thyself, see my face no more; for in that day thou seest my face thou shalt die.
    \so Ex.10.28√
    \xv Nunnukqusish kuhhog matta mag∞unat kutchikohtae mag∞ongash nishnoh ayeuonganit ne nauman.
    \xe Take heed to thyself that thou offer not thy burnt offerings in every place that thou seest:
    \so Deut.12.13
    \nt +
    \xv Nunnukqsish kuhhog nukkonnonat Levite nesohke pomantaman ut ohkeit.
    \xe Take heed to thyself that thou forsake not the Levite as long as thou livest upon the earth.
    \so Deut.12.19
    \ng as if "beware, refrain from leaving ..." (E1&2)
    \nt +
    \xv nunnukqussek
    \xe take ye heed (to yourselves)
    \so Deut.11.16; 27.9; Jer.9.4; Mt.16.6
    \xv nunnukqussitch
    \xe let him take heed
    \so 1 Cor.10.12
    \xv nunnukqussuontash kehtah
    \xe beware of the sea
    \so C.232)


\lx nunnukqussuón∞k
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 97
= |wabesuón∞k|    Phil.3.2; +Mk.12.38
    \xv Ken wonk noh nunnukqussúos,...
    \xe Of whom be thou ware also;...
    \so 2 Tim.4.15
    \nt +
\nt Follow up needed: Suggests an |-oN-| (applicative) derivative?


\lx nunnukqussuontamunat
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 97

    \xv nunnukqussuontash keitah
    \xe beware of the sea

    \ng 2->0 imperative

\lx -nutch
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 98
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Content moved here from entry |menutcheg|, T.55b.
\ps dependent NI; (NA at Gen.5.29)
\ge `hand', +'hand-breadth'
\nt G&B.677-678
\so Ex.4.4,7.5; Deut.19.21; Amos 5.19; Mk.9.43; Jn.20.25; Acts 21.1,19.33; Eph.4.28; I.P.9, line 2
    |Nunnutcheg| {my hand}    El.Gr.11/257
    |Wunnutcheg| {his hand}    ib.
    |Kenutchegash|, or |kenutcheganash|, {thy hands}.    ib.
    \nt +
\nt often in contracted form, |menutch|, |nunnutch|, |wunnutch|, etc.
    |Menutcheg|, {A Hand}. |Menutchegash.|    El.Gr.10/256
    \xv ...kenutch...wunnutch...
    \xe ...thine hand...his hand...
    \so Ex.4.4(E2)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Kusseh kittinnum kenutcheganit appu,...
    \xe ..., Behold, thy maid is in thy hand;...
    \so Gen.16.6
    \ng 2 possessor locative
    \nt +
    \xv wunnutchét
    \xe on his hand
    \so Acts 28.3
    \nt +
    \xv wunnutchegan∞ash
    \xe their hand
    \so Gen.19.16
    \ng 3p possessor plural; (E1) |-oash|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kuttogquehteoh nukkesukkodumash munnitcheg...
    \xe ..., thou hast made my days as an hand-breadth,
    \so Ps.39.5(M)

    \se puttukqunitch
    \ge `the fist'
    \so Ex.21.18

    \se anomanutcheg
    \ge `the inside of the hand, the palm, the hollow'
    \so Lev.14.15, 26.
    \dv (|anóme| `within')
    \xv ... nashpe wuttahunan∞nitcheg ...
    \xe ...with the palm of his hand,...
    \so Jn.18.22(M.)
    \nt +
\cf muttinnohkóu
\cf menadchu
    (|menitcheg|    C.
    \xv nunnitchek
    \xe my hand
    \so E.M.).

\lx nuppoh
\va nuppohwhun
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 98
\ps n. / NA (NI) (cf. C, Narr.); there are some signs that this can be treated as dependent stem and perhaps some confusion.
\ge `a wing'
\nt (not found except in the constructive or objective |nuppoh|, |nuppohwhunoh|, with prefix of 3d person)
    \so Ex.37.9; Lev.1.17; Deut.32.11; Ps.61.4,63.7,68.13,91.4,104.3; Lk.13.34; Rev.4.8,9.9,12.14
    \nt +

    \xv Wunnüppoh,-whunash.
    \xe A wing, wings
    \so C.4/156.
    \nt +

    \se |nuppohwhune|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of...wings'
    \so ?Gen.1.21; Deut.4.17; Ps.(M).61.4,63.7
    \xv ..., kah nishnoh ∞nuppohwhunin puppinshaash,...
    \xe ..., and every winged fowl...
    \so Gen.1.21
    \ng all texts; with (doubled?) 3 prefix; not clear what other analysis fits, despite additional final |-n|
    \nt ?
    \xv ..., agqueneunkquok howae wunnuppauhwhunne puppinshaas,...
    \xe ..., the likeness of any winged fowl...
    \so Deut.4.17
    \ng with 3 prefix
    \xv ...: pish nupbahtantam ut kunnuppohwune onkanuhtaut.
    \xe ...: I will trust in the covert of thy wings.
    \so Ps.61.4(M)

    \se nuppohwunau
    \ps AI, denominal
    \nt Remark: Unusual type, possessive in sense, but not in form (though note Eccl.10.20), the final |-ô/á-| resembling that of a bahuvrihi. (The nominal stem is clearly complex, so the bahuvrihi formation could be archaic?)
    \nt +
    \ge `winged, having wings'
    \so Is.6.2; +?Gen.1.21; Ps.55.6
    \xv ..., nish noh pasuk nequtta tahshe nuppohwhunau,...
    \xe ...: each one had six wings;...
    \so Is.6.2
    \ng 3 indicative

    \xv ..., kah noh wânuppohwhunit pish wussin uttoh ánagk.
    \xe ..., and that which hath wings shall tell the matter.
    \so Eccl.10.20
    \ng _3_ participle

    \xv ..., woi onunuppohwhunonti wuskuhwhunonáut,...
    \xe ..., O that I had wings like a dove;...
    \so Ps.55.6
    \ng 1 imperative; relative root } (M) |ununnuppohwhunontuh|  { 12 imperative, reason unknown
    \nt +

    \se yauinnapúhwhunau
    \ps AI, bahuvrihi (dvigu)
    \nt Remark: For two further bahuvrihi occurrences, see Ezek.17.3.
    \nt +
    \ge `having four wings'
    \so Ezek.1.6
\cf wunnuppoh
\cf wunnuppohwhun
[Allied to |nuppunat| and |nepaus| (?).]

    [LpA. \8lip'8ig8na| `S8n aile'    D.35.
    \nt +
Narragansett [xnt] |Wunnùp,-pash] `Wing, Wings:'; |Wunnúppaníck ánawhone| `Wing-shot:'    R.W.91.]

\lx nuppunát
\va nupp∞
\va nup
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 98
\ps v.i. / AI, C-final stem
\ge `to die'
\nt G&B.676: |nup∞| AI `he died'; note the absentative forms.
\so Eccl.3.2; 1 Cor.9.15
\nt The literal or primitive meaning of this verb is perhaps `to go away', or, rather, `to sleep'. It is probably allied to |nuppoh|, `a wing or wings'. The Indian languages abound in euphemisms for expressing death, "so terrible is the King of Terrors to all natural men." "They abhor to mention the dead by name, .. and amongst States, the naming of their dead Sachims" is one ground of war, R.W.161.
    |nupp∞|, |nup| `he dieth' or `died'    Job 14.10; 21.23; Is.59.5; Gen.23.2; Ezek.24.18
    \xv Newutche wunnamptamog Jesus nup, kah omohku wonk,...
    \xe For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again,...
    \so 1 Thess.4.14
    \nt +
    \xv nen nunnup
    \xe I died...
    \so Gen.30.1,48.21; Rom.7.9
    \xv pish kenup
    \xe thou shalt die
    \so Gen.2.17
    \xv pish nup
    \xe he shall die
    \so Ezek.18.4,20
    \xv nuppun
    \xe he dieth
    \so Eccl.3.19
    \xv nupup
    \xe [he] died
    \so Gen.11.28
    \ng 3 preterite
    \nt +
    (|pish nunnüp| `I shall die'
    \xv nont wame nenuppümun
    \xe we must all die
    \so C.188)
    (|nuppünnat| `to dy'    C.114/237√)

    |nuppuk|, |nupuk| `when he dies or is dead, he may die'    Eccl.3.19; Rom.7.2; 2 Sam.3.33  { 3 conjunct }
    \xv noh neit nupuk
    \xe who died there
    \so 2 Sam.10.18
    \xv Kah nag an∞naog en Josephut n∞waog, k∞sh n∞wop asquam napok n∞wau.
    \xe And they sent a messenger unto Joseph, saying, Thy father did command before he died, saying,
    \so Gen.50.16
    \ng 3 negative changed conjunct
    \nt +
    |napukeg|, |nupukeg| pl. `the dead'    Eccl.4.2
    = |napunutchig|    Num.16.48 { obv. }
    \xv Ken sun kutánue missugken onk n∞shun Abraham, nnont napuki? & quoshodtumwaénuog nápukog, howan tatuppéheadt kuhhog?
    \xe Art thou greater than our father Abraham, which is dead? and the prophets are dead: whom makest thou thyself?
    \so Jn.8.53
    \ng |-og| for |-eg|? -- conjunct, despite the English
    \nt +

    \xv ..., yeuyeu nuppitti,...
    \xe ..., now let me die,...
    \so Gen.46.30
    \ng 1 imperative
    \nt +
    |Noh blasphemont nupitch|    Lev.24.14(Hd) (1&2) "Let him die who blasphemes" { 3 imperative }
    \nt +

    \se !|nupp∞|
    \nt +
    \ps NA, deverbal agent noun
    \ge `(sb's) dead'
    \so Gen.23.3,6
    \xv Kah Abraham neepau wutche anaquabit wunnup∞moh...
    \xe And Abraham stood up from before his dead,...
    \so Gen.23.3
    \ng 3 possessor obviative; referring to Sarah

    \se |nupp∞m∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, regular derivative
    \ge `to die'
    \so Gen.7.21
    \xv Kah wame weyaus nupp∞m∞,...
    \xe And all flesh died ...
    \so Gen.7.21
    \ng 0 indicative

[Algonquian [alg] |nipai-|; +|NIP,o| `mourir'    Cq.279b.
Chip. |niba| `he sleeps'    (Bar.); |nibó| `he dies'. (The Chip. prefix |ni| (Bar.) denotes a `going away', change (?) of place or posture; cf. |nepau| `to rise up'.)
Narr.: Roger Williams usually employs the verb |kitonckquêi[nat]| (q.v.) `to die', and has |nipwì|, |màw| [|nupp∞|, |amáeu| (?)] `he is gone'; |níppitch ewó| `let him die' [a sentence: `let him be put to death']; |niphéttitch| `let them die'    R.W.122; |michemesháwi| `he is gone forever'    R.W.160; |yo ápapan| `he that was here'; |mauchaúhom| `the dead man'; pl. |mauchaúhomwock|, = |chèpeck|; |chepassôtam| `the dead sachem'; |chepasquâw| `a dead woman'; |sachimaûpan| `he that was prince [sachem] here'    R.W.161.
Cree |níppu| `he is dead'; |nippów| `he sleeps'    Howse 31.
Delaware [del] |mboiwi| `mortal'; |mboagan| `death'    Zeisb.Gr.104.]


\lx nupweshanónat

    \xv nupweshanómun
    \xe we persuade

    \nt +

    \xe I perswade, or did
    \so C.68/203)

    \nt +

\lx nupwou

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 99
    \nt +
\nt Remark: This may well be identical to |nupw∞au|.

\so Gen.41.33,39
    \xv ..., matta howan wuttinnupwóun kah waantam∞un netatuppe ken.
    \xe ..., there is none so discreet and wise as thou art:
    \so Gen.41.39
    \ng 3 negative subordinative

    \xv ... Pharaoh natinnewhonch wosketompuh waantamunnutcheh, kah nópwónutcheh,...
    \xe ... let Pharaoh look out a man discreet and wise,...'    Gen.41.33  { _3

    \xe Take you wise men, and understanding, and known among your tribes,...

    \nt +
    \xv ...: newutche ∞waantam∞ongan∞ waantàmwog pish wutahquahtauun, kah ∞wohwohtam∞ongan∞ wunnupwom∞oh pish adtahauóneau.
    \xe ...: for the wisdom of their wise men shall perish, and the understanding of their prudent men shall be hid.
    \so Is.29.14
    \nt +

    \xe the wise and prudent

    \nt +

    \xe ..., I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and will bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent.
    \so 1 Cor.1.19
    \ng ref. to Is.29.14; cf. Vlg. "sapientiam sapientium, ... prudentiam prudentium", Gk. similarly
    \nt +

\lx nupwoáonk

    \xe mysteries

    \nt +
    (|nupwôwaonk|    C.163)
\nt Research needed: Curious apparent homonymy, presumably related to (and linked via?) the initial of |nupweshanau| `to persuade sb':
    \xv nupwôaonganit
    \xe prudence
    \so (loc.)    Eph.1.8
    \nt +
    \xv Waantam, wunnupwowae kenos∞wäonk.
    \xe Crafty or cunning counsels
    \so C.21/168
    \nt +

    \xv Ut mamutt∞nut pish nukkinn∞n, ut monomansinneat, kah matta ut nupwóaonganehtu,...
    \xe With him will I speak mouth to mouth, even apparently, and not in dark speeches;...
    \so Num.12.8
    \ng second locative
    \nt +

\cf napw∞acheg
\cf siogk∞waonk

    \xe you commit murder

\lx nushónat
\va nushau
\va nuhshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 99
\ps v.act.an. / TA, (applicative) causative to |nup-|
\twn |nehtau|, TI2
\ge `to kill', +`to slay sb'
\so Deut.9.28; Esth.3.13; Acts 9.24
    pass. |nushittinneat| `to be killed'    Esth.7.4
\nt but |nushau|, |nushaog| (3d pers. sing. and pl.), are used indifferently for the active or passive voice, `he or they slew or were slain'
\cf nushúhkônat
    \xv Na∞sukash ne ussen, nushon sampweussecheg weeche matchet∞woh:...
    \xe That be far from thee, to do after this manner, to slay the righteous with the wicked,...
    \so Gen.18.25
    \ng X->3(p) subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv nunnush
    \xe I slew him
    \so 1 Sam.17.35; 2 Sam.1.16
    \xv ..., chadchekeemeh nashpe GOD, matta kenushéinat, asuh kuppôninneat nussontimom wunnutcheganit,...
    \xe ..., Swear unto me by God, that thou wilt neither kill me, nor deliver me into the hands of my master,...
    \so 1 Sam.30.15
    \ng 2->1 negative t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv wuttit nushon
    \xe he murders (them)
    \so Ps.10.8
    `he slew'    Judg.15.15
    \xv pish nunnush
    \xe I shall slay
    \so Gen.27.41
    |nushau|, |nusheau| `he slew'    1 Sam.17.36; Ex.2.12; 2 Chr.25.3
    `he was slain'    Dan.5.30
    \xv wunshóuh
    \xe (it) slew them
    \so Dan.3.22; +(E1) |wunnushóuh|
    \ng analysis? 0->3(p), with "pseudo-absentative" inflection?
    = |nah wunnushoh|    Lk.13.4
    \xv pish nushau
    \xe he shall be put to death
    \so Ex.21.12,15,16, etc.
    \xv mos nushau
    \xe [he] must be killed
    \so Rev.13.10√
    \xv nushaog
    \xe they slew
    \so Gen.49.6; Judg.3.29
    \xv pish nushoog
    \xe they shall be slain
    \so Ezek.26.6
    \xv ... nag pish nushoog nashpe togkodteg,...
    \xe ... [they] shall be slain by the sword;...
    \so { X->3p indicative }; Ezek.26.6; Ezek.32.21 { nushôog }; Ezek.32.23,24,25; Is.22.2 { nushóog }
    pass. |pish nunnushit| `I shall be slain'    Prov.22.13  { X->1 indicative }
    \xv ...: matta quinuppegis wutch nuhhogkat, wunnamuhkut wonk ken woh kenushish,...
    \xe ...: unless she had turned from me, surely now also I had slain thee,...
    \so Num.22.33
    \ng 1->2, with |-ish| for |-ush| (1&2)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche tamussumon uhquae kummonak, kah matta kenushinno, wahteaush kah naush,...
    \xe ...: for in that I cut off the skirt of thy robe, and killed thee not, know and see, that ...
    \so 1 Sam.24.11
    \ng 1->2 negative subordinative
    \nt +
    (|Nishehkönat, nunishonat.| `To kill'    C.58/196)

    |nushont|, |nashont| (part.) `slaying'    Gen.4.15; Ex.21.14
    \xv ... Abel, Kain nohshompoh.
    \xe ... Abel, whom Cain slew.'    Gen.4.24  { 3->_3
    \so _ preterite participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., napehnont tokkodteg ohtag nunnutcheganit, newaj yeuyeu woh nushin.
    \xe ...: I would there were a sword in mine hand, for now would I kill thee.
    \so Num.22.29  { 1->2 (changed) subjunctive }; also 1 Sam.19.17
    \nt +
    \xv ∞sqheonk nashit
    \xe the blood of the slain
    \so Num.23.24
    \ng X->_3_ participle
    \xv noh nashomuk
    \xe who was slain
    \so Judg.20.4
    \ng X->_3_ participle
    \xv ..., weeche nag nashitcheg nashpe togkodteg,...
    \xe ... in the midst of them that are slain by the sword:...
    \so Ezek.32.20
    \ng X->_3p_ participle

    \xv nush
    \xe kill thou
    \so Judg.8.20; Acts 10.13
    \xv nush∞k
    \xe kill ye
    \so Lk.15.23
    \xv Kah yeu néhean, nusheh k∞wehquetumoush nusheh,...
    \xe And if thou deal thus with me, kill me, I pray thee, out of hand,...
    \so Num.11.15
    \ng 2->1
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |niss| `kill him'; pl. |nìssoke|    R.W.122.]

\et G.1981, 26, 65: *ne?le∙wa (i.e. **neple∙wa), (contra H.2314 *ne?Θe∙wa on the basis of the Munsee development; no relevant Cree reflex)

\lx nussau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 99
    \nt +
\ps AI, stem in unstable |-ô-|?
\ge `to cast one's young' i.e. "to miscarry"
\nt Remark: I take the form not to be a euphemistic sense of |nussu|. The shape of the final is not the same but still uncertain.
\so Gen.31.38; Ex.21.22,23.26
    \xv ...: squoshimusse shepsog kah goatsog matta nussáuoúog:...
    \xe ...; thy ewes and thy she goats have not cast their young,...
    \so Gen.31.38
    \xv Matta pish nussóun, asuh mehcheyein ut kutohkit:...
    \xe There shall nothing cast their young, nor be barren, in thy land:...
    \so Ex.23.26

    \xv Wosketompaog mekónetehettit, & togkomont wopequaúoh mittamwussissoh, kah nussont, qut wanne nushittuonganninn∞ wunnamuhkut pish sasamatahwhau,...
    \xe If men strive, and hurt a woman with child, so that her fruit depart from her, and yet no mischief follow: he shall be surely punished,...
    \so Ex.21.22

    \se nussauonk
    \ps NI, action noun
    \ge `untimely birth'
    \so Ps.58.8(M)
    \xv ...: onatuh wun-nussauonk muttumwossus,...
    \xe ...: like the untimely birth of a woman,...
    \so Ps.58.8(M)

\lx nuttiniin

\so Trumbull 100
\ps anaphoric predicate, 1st. pers. subj.

    |nen nuttinniin nen nuttinniin| for `I am that I am'    Ex.3.14
    |newutche ne nuttiniin| (|ne nuttunniin|    Mass. Ps.) `for so I am'    Jn.13.13

    \xe but it is not so with me
    \so Job 9.35
    \xv yeu mo nuttinaiin
    \xe thus I was
    \so Gen.31.40
    \xv yeu nuttinaiin
    \xe thus I have been (and am)
    \so Gen.31.41
    \xv woh nuttinni onatuh ne matta ániyeu
    \xe I should have been as though I had not been
    \so Job 10.19
    (|nen nuttinne-aiin nen nuttinne-aiin| `I am such as such as I am', or `I myself remain or continue to be such as I myself remain' [|nuttinne-aiin| = `I am such as (I)']
    \xv nuttinni
    \xe I am become
    [|nuttinni]yumun| `we are become'
    \xv unniinat
    \xe to become
    \so C.181)

\lx nux
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 100
\ps adv.
\ge `yea, yes, verily'; +`even' [in AV particularizing sense]
\so El.Gr.21
    \xv Nux
    \xe Yea
    \so E.Gr.1666.21; 1822.268
    \nt +
    "...: yea there is one word that has no other Letter but such a vowel ô unless it should be thought needful to have two of y^m for the drawing out of sound a Litle longer. In English ye word is `yea' or `yes'; but there being an other Indian word of y^e same signification viz |nux| as it is comonly writen, but should rather be |nukkies| in two sillables, the former is scarse ever vsed in writeing."    Mayhew 1722.14
    \xv ... kah nagum nux nagum nehenwonche n∞wop yeuoh nohtonugqus:...
    \xe ..., and she, even she herself said, He is my brother:...
    \so Gen.20.5
    \nt +

    verb subst. |nuxyeu∞utch| `let it be yea'    James 5.12 (cf. Gr.16/262)

    \xv nuk
    \xe yes
    \so Stiles (Narr.)
\cf ô

[Mi'kmaq [mic] |è| `oui'; |lok| (= |nok|), `bien'    Maill.29.
Western Abenaki [abe] |`ga| `signif. affirmitatem': |niga| `oui, c'est cela'    Rasles 553;
\xv nikki
\xe c'est cela même
\so R.555.
Chip. |a nange ka| `yes, certainly'; |e nange| `O yes'    Bar.476.
Delaware [del] |ekee| `ay!'    Zeisb.
Illin. "Rad. {naga}, {nagata}, vox feminis propria, `assurément, vraiment'; {nissi naga} `oui vraiment, je le dis'."    Grav.MS.]

\lx ô
\va ôô
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 100
\ps Adv
\ge `yea, yes'
    "but there being another Indian word of the same signification, viz., |nux|, ... the former is scarce ever used in writing." -- Exp. Mayhew.
    (|ôu| `well, it is well'    C.227.)


\lx ôâas
\va óaus
\va howaas
\va ôaas
\va oaas
\va owaas
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 100
    \nt Remark: In the current corpus, |howaas| is only attested at Lev.1.42,43,44,46, translating AV "whatsoever" and other generalizing forms; there is no sign of a noun in the ancient texts, and it therefore is out of place here. It is possible that the form is specific to generalizing use. The plural forms are striking, not paralleled in noun stems in G&B.'s material, as far as I can establish, and normally an indication of a conjunct verb.
    \nt +
\ps n. / NA
\ge `an animal, a living creature'
\so Gen.2.19; 7.4; Lev.11.47; +Gen.1.21,24,6.19
    (|Quinnukquesukekeshkhoowae äöas.| [|oâas|] `A lame creature'    C.25/171)
    pl. |nishkeneunkque owáasineg| `doleful creatures'    Is.13.21√
    |oásineg|    Ezek.1.14
    |-oaásineg|    Ezek.1.19
    (|Mat pahkesu@e oâasineg.| `Imperfect creatures.'    C.25/171
    \xv Pomantam∞@e, oowaasineg.
    \xe Living creatures
    \so C.4/156)
    \xv Nishnoh óaus wunnahnahshonat
    \xe every thing that hath breath
    \so Ps.150.6√
    \xv nishnoh oaas pámontog
    \xe every thing that liveth
    \so Ezek. 47.9
    \xv nishnoh oaas pish pomantam
    \xe every thing shall live
    \so Ezek. 47.9
    \xv oaas momonchin
    \xe creeping thing
    \so Lev.11.20,21
    \xv wuske oâas
    \xe a new creature
    \so Gal.6.15

\lx oadtehteaonk
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 100
\ps n.
\ge `payment'
\so C.203


\lx óadtehteauunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 100
\ps v.t. / TI2 ?
\ge `to pay, as a debt, a vow, etc.; to make payment of'
    \xv óadtehteaou
    \xe he pays (tribute)
    \so Mt.17.24
    |∞adtehteau|    Jonah 1.3
    \xv pish kutôadtehteam
    \xe thou shalt pay (money)
    \so 1 K.20.39

    \xv óadtehteash
    \xe pay thou (thy vow)
    \so Eccl.5.4

    \se |oadtehteaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, causative
    \ge `to amerce sb in sth' (hapax in AV) i.e. "to cause sb to make payment of sth"
    \so Deut.22.19
    \xv Kah pish wutoadtehteaheóuh nequt pasuk∞unuain silver,...
    \xe And they shall amerce him in an hundred shekels of silver,...
    \so Deut.22.19
    \ng See BWB 18: "It ["amerce"] is not the right word, however, in the one passage where it occurs in KJ ... ASV and RSV translate "they shall fine him a hundred shekels of silver."


\lx óadtuhkónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 100
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `to pay to'
\so Deut.23.21; Esth.4.7
    \xv kutoadtuhkoush
    \xe I will pay thee
    \so Num.20.19
    \xv nen nutóadtuhkauoog
    \xe (in that case) I will pay [them]
    \so Esth.3.9

    |óadtuhkou|, |-kau| `pay thou to (him or them)'    2 K.4.7; Ps.50.14
    \xv óadtuhkah
    \xe pay thou me
    \so Mt.18.28
    (|oadtuhkah eyeu| `pay me now'    C.203)
\cf adtóau

\lx ogguhse
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 101
\ps adj. / PreN
\ge `little' [small in quantity or amount]
\nt G&B.679; note forms in |nagk-| in (M), G&B.654.
\so Prov.24.33
    \xv anue ogguhse
    \xe much less
    \so Prov.17.7
    (|ogkosse|, adv. `little'    C.233).

    \se !|ogguhsu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, NA
    \ge `few'
    \so Mt.20.16,22.14
    \xv ..., , newutche monaog pish wehkomoog, qut ogguhsuog pepenauutcheg.
    \xe ...: for many be called, but few chosen.
    \so Mt.20.16, 22.14

    \se !|ogguhsin|
    \nt +
    \ps (II?), NI, with uses as PreN and PreV?
    \ge `few, little, a few things'
    \so Lev.25.52; Mt.8.26,25.21,23; 2 Cor.8.15; Rev.2.20
    \xv Kah ushqushunk ogguhsinash kodtumm∞ash,...
    \xe And if there remain but few years ...
    \so Lev.25.52
    \xv ..., woi kenaau ogguhsin k∞namptam∞onkan∞,...
    \xe ..., O ye of little faith? ...
    \so Mt.8.26
    \xv ..., kuppaubuhtanumukqus ut ogguhsinash,...
    \xe ...: thou hast been faithful over a few things,...
    \so Mt.25.21, 25.23
    \xv Qut ogguhsenash k∞chimush,...
    \xe Notwithstanding I have a few things against thee,...
    \so Rev.2.20

    \xv ..., kah noh ogguhsinuk wanne quenauwáhik∞
    \xe ...; and hee that had {gathered} little, had no lacke.
    \so 2 Cor.8.15
    \ng _0_ participle??

    \se ogguhsemese
    \ps PreN
    \ge `a little'
    \nt G&B.679
    Dim. |ogguhsemese nippe| `a little water'    Gen.24.17√
    \xv iogguhsemese
    \xe by little and little
    \so Deut.7.22
    \ng reduplicated

    \se |ogguhsese|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN, adverb
    \ge `a few, a little while, for a little season, for a time, a short time, a while'; most of temporal duration, but not exclusively
    \so Mk.14.35; Jn.14.19; 1 Cor.7.5; 2 Cor.11.1; 1 Thess.2.17; Philmn.15; Heb.2.7; 1 Pet.1.6,5.10; Rev.6.11
    \xv Kah ongkoue au ogguhsese,...
    \xe And he went forward a little,...
    \so Mk.14.35
    \xv NUkkodtantam kummukk∞náununeánonut ogguhsese ut nutas∞tuonganit ...
    \xe Would to God that ye could bear with me a little in my folly:...
    \so 2 Cor.11.1
    \xv Ogguhsese kuttiuhquonkqueh onk neg angelsog,...
    \xe Thou hast made him a little lower than the angels,...
    \so Heb.2.7
    \xv ..., nag woh wutanwôsinunnaóut ogguhsese,...
    \xe ..., that they should rest yet for a little season,...
    \so Rev.6.11

    = |Oôgguhséseu| `By little and little'    Ex.23.30 { reduplicated }

    \se !|ogguhsesu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, NA, as PreN?
    \ge `a few'
    \so Mt.15.34,20.16,22.14
    \xv ..., Nesausuk, kah ogguhsesuog namohemesog.
    \xe ..., Seven, and a few little fishes.
    \so Mt.15.34

    \se !|ogguhsesin|
    \nt +
    \ps II, NI?
    \ge `few'
    \so Gen.47.9
    \xv ... ogguhsesinash kah matchitash kesukodte kodtum∞ash nuppomántamoonk,...
    \xe ...: few and evil have the days of the years of my life been,...
    \so Gen.47.9
    \ng 0p indicative

    [Algonquian [alg] |AGAC-| `petit, étroit, mince, fin'; |AGAS-| `petit, en petit nombre'    Cq.15b;16a-17a.
    \nt +
Chip. |Agâshi, (nind).| `I am small, little', |Agâss| `in composition signifies {small, fine, narrow}' etc.    Bar.7a-8b.
Fx. |aka∙wi-| PreV `["a little ways"(?)] "barely"'    Fx.L.22 (B.'s gloss, with editor's tentative interpretation).
K. |akaasiihi-| AI `be a little, be few', |akaasw-| `a little, a few'    V.12.]

\et *aka∙- + -(hs/h⌠)- `little, small' (diminutive form to *ak- `count'?); |-uh-| spelling of nasal vowel.

\lx ogkemónat
\va agkemónat
\va ogkemau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 101
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\twn |ogketam| TI1a
\ge `to number or count' (an. obj.), +`to take the sum of, tell sb'
\nt G&B.678
    \xv Ne anann∞nont Jehovah Mosesoh, ne wuttinnu neh ogkemon ut Sinâi touohkomukqut.
    \xe As the Lord commanded Moses, so he numbered them in the wilderness of Sinai.
    \so Num.1.19
    \ng subord.
    \nt +
    \xv Neaunag wuttinnowâonk Jehovah, ne wuttinogkemon nashpe wunnutcheganit Moses,...: kah nag ogkemóog nashpe nagum,...
    \xe According to the commandment of the Lord they were nmbered by the hand of Moses,...: thus were they numbered of him,...
    \so Num.4.49
    \ng subord., indic.; X subj.
    \nt +

    \xv agkemehetteupoh
    \xe when they numbered (them)
    \so Num.26.64√
    \xv nag agkemutcheg
    \xe they that were numbered
    \so Num.26.57

    \xv Yeuyeu natauwompish kesukquieu, kah ogkem anogqsog, woh wamogkemat:...
    \xe Look now toward heaven, and tell the stars, if thou be able to number them:...
    \so Gen.15.5
    \nt +
    \xv ogkem
    \xe Take the sum of (them)
    \so Num.26.2 { erroneous tr., addressed to two hearers; as also e.g. Num.4.2; correct at e.g. Num.3.15,40,4.22 }√
    \xv ogkém∞k
    \xe Take ye the sum of (them)
    \so Num.1.2√

[Cree |U'cke-{mayoo}| `{he} counts {him}.'    Howse 43√.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nedaghidamen| `Je le conte', nob. |nedoghímañ|.    R.128/418a.
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |∙AKIM| `compte-les, énumère-les'    Cq.31b.
Delaware [del] |akíimeew| `count s.t. animate', |akíindam| `count s.t., read s.t.'    O'M.22b-23a.
Menominee [mez] |ake∙mε∙w| TA, |ake∙htam| TI `he counts him, it (usually them)'    M.L.14.
Miami |-akintam| TI `count it, keep time (as in a cloc)'    B&C.19a
M.-P. |okitomakon| NI `counter; counting stick', |'t-okitomuwan| TA+O `he reads it to him'    LeS.58a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |ekimk| TA `recite; read; count (off)', |ekitm| TI id.    DeB.9.
Shawnee [sjw] |hak-| `COUNTING', |nitakimaaki|, |nitakitaana| `I count them [the people, the things]'    D.-V.432.
WAbn. |agida| TI `count, read', |agizi| AI `count, read'    D.1.13.]

\et A.95-97; H.173-179; B.73, 109/466, 82, 112/470: *akime∙wa TA, *akintamwa TI `to count'

\lx ogketamùnát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 101
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\twn |ogkemau| TA
\ge `to number, to count, to take the sum of'
    \xv nashpe ogketamunát
    \xe by count, "according to certain number"
    \so Deut.25.2 (inan. obj.)
    \xv ogktam
    \xe he counts
    \so Job 31.4
    \xv ogketam
    \xe he has numbered
    \so Dan.5.26

    \xv ogketaj ne adtahsik
    \xe let him count the number of
    \so Rev.13.18


\ge `to read'
\so C.206
    \xv ..., pish kutogketam yeu naumatuonk anaquabhettit wame Israel, ut wehtauog∞óut.
    \xe ..., thou shalt ead this law before all Israel in their hearing.
    \so Deut.31.11
    \nt +
    \xv ogketam
    \xe he read
    \so Josh.8.34
    \xv ogketamup matta
    \xe he read not
    \so Josh.8.35
    \ng ??

    \xv noh ogketog
    \xe he who reads
    \so Mt.24.15
    \xv ..., kah wuttinuh, K∞wautam[u]n ne agketamunh?
    \xe ..., and said, Understandest thou what thou readest?
    \so Acts 8.30 [1st.ed.: |agkeetamanh|]
    \nt +

    \xv ogketash
    \xe read thou
    \so Jer.36.6

    \se !|ogketamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-|-stem
    \ge `to reckon sth unto sb'
    \so Lev.27.18,23
    \xv .... neit sephausuen pish wutogketamauoh teaguash, neyaunag kodtum∞ash nish ashqshunkish, nô pajeh Jubilee k∞dtum∞ut:...
    \xe ..., then the priest shall reckon unto him the money according to the years that remain, even unto the year of the jubile,...
    \so Lev.27.18

[Narragansett [xnt] |akétash|, pl. |akettamòke| `count or reckon (it), "tell my money"'; |akésuog| `they are telling of rushes'; |natkèsimin| `I am telling or counting'; "for their play [gaming with rushes] is a kind of arithmetic"; |ntaquìe akésamen| `I will leave play' [I cease counting]    R.W.136,145,146.

\lx ogqu-

\lx ogk∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 101
    \nt +
\ps AI (+locative of comparison)
\ge `to speak like, after the manner of'
\dv |ak(w)-| (+locative ?) `like, similar' + |-∞w-| `speak, by voice' + |-á-| AI
\so 1 Cor.13.11, Gal.3.15, Rev.13.11
    \xv ...: qut ut wuskesukqut wasennumukqutcheh neyane ogk∞wau mamúskeyimuk.
    \xe .... But he seemed as one that mocked unto his sons-in-law.'    Gen.19.14  { 3->3
    \so indicative }
    \xv Neematog, nutogk∞wam wosketomput,...
    \xe Brethren, I speak after the manner of men;...
    \so Gal.3.15
    \xv Mogkiesúeon, nutogk∞wop mukkiesut, nutogque wahteauop mukkiesu[t], nutogque unnantamup mukkiesut,...
    \xe When I was a child, I spake as a child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child:...
    \so 1 Cor.13.11

\lx ogquanumunát
\va ogquantam
\ve r. ? cf. Mt.11.16, below
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 101
\ps v.t. / TI1a, mental final
\ge `to liken or compare one thing with another'
    \xv uttoh woh nutogquontamun
    \xe to what shall I liken (it)
    \so Mt.11.16

    \se |ogquantamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem
    \ge `to impute, reckon sth to sb'
    \so Lev.17.4, Num.18.27
    \xv ..., ∞sqheonk pish ogquontamauau noh wosketomp, noh seahham wusqueheonk,...
    \xe ...; blood shall be imputed unto that man; he hath shed blood;...
    \so Lev.17.4
    \xv Kah kuttashinnumwe mag∞onk pish kutogquontamonteaneau, onatoh weatchiminut ne ahhut tantuppoghamuk,...
    \xe And this your heave offering shall be reckoned unto you, as though it were the corn of the threshing floor,...
    \so Num.18.27
    \ng X->2p+0

    \se ogquanumónat
    \ps an. / TA, mental final
    \ge `to liken one person to another', +`to count sb (for) sb, sth to sb for sth'
    \xv ..., kah wutogquanumoh sampweusseaeneuunneat.
    \xe ..., ; and he counted it to him for righteousness. '    Gen.15.6  { 3->3
    \so +0 objective }
    \nt +
    \xv Sunnummatta nutogquanumuk∞un penuwohteáut? ...
    \xe Are we not counted of him strangers? ...
    \so Gen.31.15
    \ng 3->1p negative
    \nt +

    \xv Neit Howan ogquanumóg Godut?...
    \xe To whom then will ye liken God?...
    \so Is.40.18
    \ng 2p->3+loc conjunct

    \xv Ahque ogquánum kittinneum wuttaunut Belial,...
    \xe Count not thine handmaid for a daughter of Belial:...
    \so 1 Sam.1.16
    \ng 2->3 imperative

    \se ogqueneunkquodt
    \va -quot
    \va ogqunneunkquodt
    \nt +
    \ps inan. / II (+locative)
    \twn |ogqunneunkqussu|
    \ge `it is like (it may be likened to)'
    \nt G&B.679
    \nt +
    \so Mt.13.31; 20.1; 22.2
    \xv ..., kah newutche wananeyeuash ogqunneunkquodtash ask∞kut, kah uppuhkukk∞m∞ash ...
    \xe ...: for their tails were like unto serpents, and had heads,...
    \so Rev.9.19
    \nt +

    \xv ..., Teague otan yeu agqueneunkquok, mishe otan ...
    \xe ..., What city is like unto this great city!
    \so Rev.18.18
    \nt +
\nt The verb substantives from |ogque| and |ogquenneunk| and their derivatives are variously formed and with no uniformity of application: {i.e. further stems}
    \xv pish nutogqunneunkqueh
    \xe I will liken him to
    \so Mt.7.24
    \ng TA causative
    \xv kuttogqunneauau
    \xe do ye make it like (him), "compare it unto" (him)
    \so Is.40.18

    \se |ogqueneunkheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA (+locative)
    \ge `to make sb as/like unto sb/sth, to transform sb into sth'
    \so Deut.10.22, 2 Cor.11.14, Heb.2.17
    \xv ... kah yeuyeu Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m kutogqueneunkhuk anogqsut wutch mutaanukeg.
    \xe ...; and now the Lord thy God hath made thee as the stars of heaven for multitude.
    \so Deut.10.22
    \xv Newutche woh ogqueneunkheau wematuh nishnoh ut,...
    \xe Wherefore in all things it behoved him to be made like unto his brethren,...
    \so Heb.2.17
    \ng predicate complement not locative
    \xv ..., newutche mattanit nagum ogqueneunkheau wuhhogkuh wequaé Angelsut.
    \xe ...; for Satan himself is transformed into an angel of light.
    \so 2 Cor.11.14

[Delaware [del] |k'delgiqui| `so as thou, thou art like'; |w'delgiqui| `so as he, he is like'    Zeisb.Gr.172,173.]


\lx ogquè
\va agque
\va wuttogque
\va ogque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 102
\ps PreV, initial; governs nominal object in locative
\ge `like to, in the same manner as'; +`as though'
\so Is.40.22, 24.31, +1 Cor.13.11
    \xv ne ogquè
    \xe like it
    \so Deut.4.32
    \xv Kah pas∞sukomwog otanemes ne oiyahettit, kah ogque usseu anea pomushaumuk.
    \xe And they drew nigh unto the village, whither they went: and he made as though he would have gone further.
    \so Lk.24.28
    \ng analysis of verb?
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Howan unnanumehkitch mattammog qut usseóg, anch ogque attumunegk mattammagwut,...
    \xe ..., Let no man think me a fool; if otherwise, yet as a fool receive me,...
    \so 2 Cor.11.16
    \nt +
    \xv Kah k∞wananatamumw∞ wehquetumóonk ne agque unnukqueogig mukkiesut,...
    \xe And ye have forgotten the exhortation which speaketh unto you as unto children,...
    \so Heb.12.5
    \ng changed form
    \nt +
    \xv Noh adt ogque peyâóg pomantamwáe qussukquanit,...
    \xe To whom coming, as unto a living stone,...
    \so 1 Pet.2.4
    \nt +
\cf agqueneunkquok
\cf nogque
\cf ogk∞wau

[Delaware [del] |linaquot|, |elinaquot| `so, so as'    Zeisb.Gr.172.]


\lx ogqueheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 102
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative/factitive to initial
\nt Remark: Government of the locative only seen in Phil.3.21 of current examples.
\ge `to make sb (as, like (un)to sb/sth, in the likeness of sb/sth), to conform sb (to sth), to fashion sb (like unto sb/sth)'
\ps Gen.32.12; Ps.83.11(M); Rom.12.2; Phil.2.7,3.21; 1 Pet.1.14
    \xv ..., kh k∞skannemuneog nutogqueh kehtahanne naguntu,...
    \xe ..., and [I will] make thy seed as the sand of the sea,...
    \so Gen.32.12
    \xv ..., kah ogqueheau neanussit wosketomp.
    \xe ..., and [he] was made in the likeness of men:
    \so Phil.2.7

    \xv Okqueh wuttohtoskouwomoouh en Oreb,...
    \xe Make their nobles like Oreb,...'    Ps.83.11(M)  { 2->3
    \so imperative }
    \xv Kah ahque ogqueheuk kuhhogkaóog yeu muttaohkit,...
    \xe And be not conformed to this world:...
    \so Rom.12.2
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative

    \se ogquehteau
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to make sth like sth' (+locative)
    \so Ps.18.33
    \xv Nusseetash ogquéhteau ahtûhqusseetit,...
    \xe He maketh my feet like hindes feet,...
    \so Ps.18.33; (M) |ogquehteau|
    \ng 3->0(p) absolute

    \se ogquehteausu
    \ps II, s-passive to TI gender twin
    \ge `to be made (like to sth)'
    \so Rom.1.23
    \xv ..., en unneukontonkanit ogquehteausu anunnuk wosketomp,...
    \xe ... into an image made like to corruptible man,...
    \so Rom.1.23


\lx ogqueneunk
\va agqueneunk
\ve entry quite probably spurious, as also the derivation suggested; no example in NT, Gen., Ex.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 102
\ps n.
\ge `likeness, similitude'
\so Deut.4.16,17,18
    \xv agqueneunkquok
    \xe that which is like to
    \so { changed conjunct of the ollowing verb }
    = |ogqueneunkquodt|    Mt.13.31; 22.2
\dv The 2d pers. subj. pres. of the verb used for the concrete noun.


\lx ogqueneunkqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 102
\ps adj. an. / AI, governs locative
\twn |ogqueneunkquodt|
\ge `(he) is likened or made like to', +`become as sth'
\so Mt.7.26; 13.24
    \xv ..., newajeh missinninnuog wuttahh∞oash mohtuppaem∞uk, kah ogqueneunkqussuog nippeit.
    \xe ...: wherefore the hearts of the people melted, and became as water.
    \so Josh.7.5

\lx ogqunnau
\va ogquonau
\va h-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 102
    \nt +
\ps TA(+O), manual final (formally TA, with an additional argument via the transitive initial |ogqu-|)
\twn |ogqunnum|
\ge `to put sth [clothing] on sb, to clothe sb with sth'
\so Gen.3.21,,27.15; Ex.28.41,29.8,40.13; Num.27.20; Mt.6.30,27.28; Mk.15.17
    \xv Onk Jehovah Manit wutayimauoh hahk∞nìe hogk∞unash Adam kah ummittamwus, kah wutogquonnoh nahog.
    \xe Unto Adam also and to his wife did the LORD God make coats of skin, and clothed them.'    Gen.3.21  { 3->3
    \so }
    \xv Kah Rebekah nemunum ∞néogk∞onk ..., kah wutogquonon Jakoboh ...
    \xe And Rebekah took goodly raiment ..., and put them upon Jacob ...'    Gen.27.15  { 3->3
    \so +0-pro }
    \xv Kah upposkinóuh, kah wuthogquonóuh msquonagk.
    \xe And they stripped him, and put on him a scarlet robe.'    Mt.27.28  { 3p->3
    \so +0 }

    \xv Yowutche God yeu hogquonont moskehtuoh touohkomukqut, ...: sunnummatta m∞cheke pish kutogqunukkou,...
    \xe Wherefore, if God so clothe the grass of the field,..., shall he not much more clothe you,...'    Mt.6.30  { 3->3
    \so +"0" (adv.); 3->2p indicative (negative) }

\et H.220 *akwene∙wa TA `to put on'

    (|Nuttogqueneunkqs sauwunumuk.| `I seem to be weary'    C.74/208)√

    \xv Ogqunneungqussehettitch wossodteamunit tooantog waban:...

\lx ogquodchuau

\lx ogquodtum

\lx ohkas

\lx ohke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 103
\ps n. / NI
\nt G&B.679-680; see also ib. 502 on palatalization.
\ge `the earth, land'
\so Gen.1.10; Ps.78.69
    \xv ut ohkeit
    \xe on the earth
    \so Lev.11.2
    (|ohké| `ground'  C.160)
\ge `a country, region'
\so 2 K.3.20
    |ut wutohtuwóut|, |wutohtuout| `in their lands', `in their nations'    Gen.10.5  { 3p possessor locative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnetahwhouh wame wutohtuwoont Amalekitsog,...
    \xe ..., and smote all the country of the Amalekites,...
    \so Gen.14.7
    \ng 3p possessor locative
    \nt +
    \xv en wutohtuout Philistanog
    \xe unto the land of the Philistines
    \so Gen.21.32
    \ng 3p possessor locative
    \nt +
    \xv ut ohkeit
    \xe in the land
    \so 1 K.8.37
    \xv nutohket
    \xe to my country
    \so Gen.24.4
    \xv kutók
    \xe thy land
    \so Ex.34.24
    pl. |ohkeash| `countries'  Gen.26.3,4
    \xv ohkekontu
    \xe upon the ground
    \so Gen.19.25
    \ng second locative
    \nt +

    \xv weenohke
    \xe the grave
    \so Prov.30.16

    \se !|ohkeu|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to be the land'
    \so Gen.13.9
    \xv Sun mo wame ohkeno anaquabean?...
    \xe Is not the whole land before thee?...
    \so Gen.13.9
    \ng 0 negative indicative

\dv the same radical as |ókas| (`mother'), |∞she| (`father'), |wóóu| (`an egg'), etc.; `that which produces' or `brings forth'. Like |ókas| (q.v.), the form is passive. Cf. Greek, géa, gé; Egyp. kaui (fem.); ka, a bull; kua, the phallus (?).

[Narragansett [xnt] |aûke| and |sanaukamuck| `earth or land'; |níttauke|, |nissawnâwkamuck| `my land'; |wuskâukamuck| `new ground'    R.W.89.
Delaware [del] |hacki|    Zeisb.Voc.8.]

\et A.228, H.502 *axkyi `land'.

\lx ohkehteaunát
\va ahkehteaunat
\va ohkehteau
\ve r.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 103
    \nt Remark: Contents of entry |ohteuhkonat|, T.104a, transferred to here; on the phonology see G.1981, 39, 77.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), long-vowel stem
    \dv |ohke-| + creative final |-uhk-á-|, with palatalization(s). See G.1981, 39, 77.
    \nt +
\ge `to plant, to sow or plant a field'
    \nt G&B.680
    \nt +
\so Mt.13.3; Lev.26.5; Eccl.3.2; Is.28.24,61.11; +Ps.107.37; Jer.31.5
    \xv ohkehteau tanohketeaonk
    \xe [he] planted a garden
    \so Gen.2.8, sim. 9.19√
    \xv ..., kussohwohteam penuwot, kah kutohkekon.
    \xe ...: thou hast cast out the heathen and planted it [a vine]
    \so Ps.80.8
    \ng 2->0 objective/subordinative }; (M) |kuttohkehkonap|  { 2->0 preterite objective/subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Onk woh ohkehteaog ohteuhkónash, kah woh ohkehteáog weenominneohtekonash ...
    \xe And sow the fields, and plant vineyards,...
    \so Ps.107.37  { 3p->0p indicative }; (M) |ohteuhkonehteaog|, |wenominneahteuhkonehteoog|
    \nt +
    \xv pish weenominneohketeauauog
    \xe they shall plant vineyards
    \so Is.65.21
    \ng with preverb(?)
    (= |pish ohkehteaog weenominneohtekonash|  Zeph.1.13√)
    \xv pish kutohketeam
    \xe thou shalt sow
    \so Mic.6.15
    \xv ..., Kusseh ohkehteaénin sohham ohteuhkonat.
    \xe ..., Behold, a sower went forth to sow;
    \so Mt.13.3
    \nt +
    (|Ohkeehkönat.| `To sow or plant'
    \xv Nuttohkeehteam.
    \xe I sow or plant
    \xv Ahquompi kuttohketeam kuttanni.
    \xe When do you sow your ry
    \so C.76/209
    \xv Ohkehkönat.
    \xe Sowing, sown
    \so C.96/223.)
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kummeetsimw∞ wutch weenominneohtekonash, kah olive chippinneutunkash nish matta ohketeauogkupash.
    \xe ...; of the vineyards and oliveyards which ye planted not do ye eat.
    \so Josh.24.13
    \ng 2p->_0p_ negative preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv ne ahketeaop
    \xe that which thou sowest
    \so 1 Cor.15.36,37
    pass. |...: ahquompiyeum∞ ohkehteaunat, kah utt∞cheyeu∞ adt amaunumuk ne ahketeamukup.| `...; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted.'  Eccl.3.2√  { X t-subordinative; X->_0_ preterite participle }
    |ahketead(t)| subj. `when he sowed'  Mt.13.4
    \xv noh ahketeadt
    \xe he that sows
    \so Mt.13.37
    \xv Sun ku@ttohtou ahâhkehte mu@kik nâut? Nux
    \xe P. Have you any plants in it? Yes.
    \so C.102/226
    \ng X->_3p_ participle, reduplicated, with incorrect word division
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wenominneohteuhk ne kuttunuhkou ahkehteomooukup,...
    \xe And the vineyard which thy right hand hath planted,...
    \so Ps.80.15(M)
    \ng 0->_0_ preterite participle to II+O erivative }; (E) |adohketeâan kuttinnohkóunit| { 2->_0_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv Ohkehteuhkon ne teague, mehtugque kuppohkomuk, kushke wut-Altarumoh Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m,...
    \xe Thou shalt not plant thee a grove of any trees near unto the altar of the Lord thy God,...
    \so Deut.16.21
    \ng 2->0 prohibitive
    \nt +

    \se !|ohteuhkauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O (AI+O+O), dative final
    \ge `to sow sb unto sb'
    \so Hos.2.23
    \xv Kah noh nutohteuhkauónuh nuhhog ut ohkeit,...
    \xe And I will sow her unto me in the earth;...'    Hos.2.23  { 1->3+3
    \so objective (w.r.t. DO) }

    \se ?!|ohkehkonau|, ?!|ohteuhkonau|, ?!|ohkehteaunau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, ?applicative (no mutated forms yet noted); on the type, see Howse 1844, no.7, 20; B.1962, 16.69
    \ge `to plant sb'
    \so 2 Sam.7.10; 1 Chron.17.9; Ps.44.2(M); ?Is.40.24; Jer.2.21,11.17,12.2,42.10; Amos 9.15
    \xv ..., kah kuttahkehkonopaneg;...
    \xe ..., and plantedst them [the heathen]
    \so Ps.44.2(M)
    \ng 2->3p objective preterite
    \xv Nux nag pish matta ohkéhteaununk, nux matta pish seahwhoog,...
    \xe Yea, they shall not be planted; yea, they shall not be swn;...
    \so Is.40.24
    \ng X->3p negative objective
    \nt ?
    \xv Qut onch kutohtekônunup wunnégenne weenomwussippog,...
    \xe Yet I had planted thee a noble vine,...
    \so Jer.2.21
    \ng viz. "in the form of a noble vine"; 1->2 preterite indicative
    \xv Nag kutohtukónunk,...
    \xe Thou hast planted them,...
    \so Jer.12.2
    \ng 2->3p objective
    \xv ..., kah kutohteuhkonunumw∞,...
    \xe ...; and I will plant you,...
    \so Jer.42.10
    \ng 1->2p indicative

    \xv Newutche Jehovah áyeuteaunit, noh ahteuhkonukquean,...
    \xe For the LORD of hosts, that planted thee,...
    \so Jer.11.17
    \ng _3_->2 participle

    \se !|ohkehkontam|, |ohteuhkontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative
    \ge `to plant sth' (of place receiving the plant/seed, or of the plant)
    \so Gen.47.23; ?Deut.28.39; Is.5.2; Jer.29.5
    \xv ..., kusseh, yeush wuskannemuneash wutche kenaau, kah pish kutohteuhkontàmumw∞ ohke.
    \xe ...: lo, here is seed for you, and ye shall sow the land.
    \so Gen.47.23
    \ng 2p->0
    \xv ..., kah wutohtekontamuneash pepenamwe weenomwussippogwash,...
    \xe ...,  and planted it with the choicest vine,...
    \so Is.5.2
    \ng 3->(0+?)0p objective

    \xv ..., kah ohteuhkontam∞k tanohketeaongash, kah meech∞k ne noh adtanegik.
    \xe ...; and plant gardens, and eat the fruit of them;
    \so Jer.29.5
    \ng 2p->0(p) imperative; cf. Jer.29.28, repetition: |ohkehteagk|

\cf ohteuhkonat

[Narragansett [xnt] |Aukeeteaûmen.| `To plant Corne.'; |Aukeeteaûmitch.| `Planting time.' (`let him plant'); |Aukeeteáhettit.| `When they set Corne.'; |Nummautaukeeteaûmen.| `I have done planting.'  R.W.100/r.98.√
    Western Abenaki [abe] |neda`kki`ké.| `je seme'    460/528a; 59/394b sim.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |hagíheu| `he is planting'; |Hakíhen| `to plant, to farm', |Hakihet| `planter, farmer'; |ahkíiheew| AI(+O) `plant (s.t.)'    Z.144; B&A.47; O'M.18b.
M.-P. |kihke| AI `he plants'    LeS.25b.
Mahican [mjy] |a@hhkëhämu@k.| `... zu pflanzen.'    M.110.
Mun. |ahkí∙he∙w| `he plants'    G.1981.77.
WAbn. |(a)kika| AI `sow, plant, literally make or work land'    D.1.19,254.]

\et G.1981, 77 *axkihke∙wa `he plants'

\lx ohpannehtuonk
\va -ong
\va ahpann-

\ge `footstool'

    \xv Kesuk nutapappuonk, sanohkomuk nutohpannehtuonk,...

    \xe ..., Stand thou there, or sit here under my footstool:
    \so Jas.2.3

    \se ohpannehtuonganuhkauau

    \ge `to make sb sb's footstool'
    \so Ps.110.1(M)
    \xv ..., napajeh kummatwomog kuttahpanehtuonkanuhkouununat.

    \ng 1->2+3(p) t-subordinative

\lx ohtáeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ge `he croucheth'

    \so Ps.10.10; (M) |Ohtaeu|
    \nt +


\lx ohtauunát
\va ahtauunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 104
\ps v.t. / TI2
\ge `to possess, to have (in possession)'; +`to inherit sth'
\so Gen.23.9; Judg.18.9; Neh.9.15; Amos 2.10
    \nt Remark: Trumbull does not give |ohteau| II `to be there' a distinct entry, and a new lemma, |ohteau|, has been inserted below to remedy this omission. (Refs.: B. 73, 109/466; B.1962, 15.70, 289; G.1981, 37, p.73, 40, p.80, bt.; G&B.681-682).
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh kittinnumaunun ne ohke, woh kutahtaunat.
    \xe ..., to give thee this land, to inherit it.
    \so Gen.15.7
    \ng 2->0 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ahtóog naut,...
    \xe ..., and they had possessions therein,...
    \so Gen.47.28
    \ng 3p absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ohtauunnát ohke
    \xe to inherit the land
    \so Ex.23.30
    \xv Matta peyâos, kah ken∞nogkus matta woh ohtau∞og matcheseonk: qut yeuyeu matta ahtauóog onkhum∞onk matcheseonk.
    \xe If I had not come and spoken unto them, they had not had sin: but now they have no cloak for their sin.
    \so Jn.15.22
    \nt +
    \xv nutahtomun ... wetu
    \xe we have ... a house
    \so 2 Cor.5.1
    \xv noh wadchanont wunnaumoniineuh, ohtau pomantamóonk
    \xe he that hath the Son hath life
    \so 1 Jn.5.12
    \xv noh ... matta ohtoou pomantamóonk
    \xe he hath not life
    \so 1 Jn.5.12
    (|Ahtöuu@nat.| `To have, to be had'    C.55/194√
    \xv Ahteauu@nat.
    \xe To spare ({or} preserve,)
    \so C.76/210√
    \xv ohto
    \xe he hath (it)
    \so Mass.Ps.)

    \xv ..., kah nishnoh teag ahtôan yeuut otanit,...
    \xe ..., and whatsoever thou hast in the city,...
    \so Gen.19.12
    \ng 2->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ne teaguas ohtunk ketatteamung.
    \xe any thing that is thy neighbor's.
    \so Ex.20.17
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \xv Kah yeu ohke, ne ohtauogkup na ahquompak,...
    \xe And this land, which we possessed at that time,...
    \so Deut.3.12
    \ng 1p->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv noh ohtunk
    \xe the owner
    \so (suppos.)    Prov.1.19
    \ng _3_ participle
    \xv neg ohtunkeg ohke
    \xe who were possessors of lands
    \so Acts 4.34
    \ng _3p_->0 participle
    \xv howan ohtunk
    \xe who hath?
    \so Prov.23.29; Ex.24.14
    \ng _3_ participle

    \xv ..., kah k∞skannemuneog ahtauhettich ∞squoantam∞ash neg sekeneauóncheg.
    \xe ..., and let thy seed possess the gate of those that hate them.
    \so Gen.24.60
    \ng 3p->0(p) imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nunn∞che mag Sihon kah wutohke ut anaquabean, n∞che ohtaush, onk woh kutohtau wutohke.
    \xe ..., I have begun to give Sihon and his land before thee: begin to possess, that thou mayest inherit his land.
    \so Deut.2.31
    \ng 2(->0) imperative; 2->0 absolute indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ...: Peyonk wunanumukqueogish n∞sh, ahtau∞k ketass∞tamóonk ...
    \xe ..., Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom ...
    \so Mt.25.34
    \ng 2p->0 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jesus namp∞ham wuttinuh, Ahtau∞k wunnamptam∞onk Godut.
    \xe And Jesus answering saith unto them, Have faith in God.
    \so Mk.11.22
    \ng 2p->0 imperative
    \nt +

\nt It is this verb in the intransitive form (|ohteau|) which Eliot has most frequently employed to supply the want of the verb of existence (see Du Ponceau's notes to Eliot's Grammar, xxi–xxix, and Pickering's Supplem. Observ., xxx–xliv). Thus,
    |ayeuonk ... ohteau wuttat Kirjath-jearim| `the place is behind Kirjath-jearim    Judg.18.12
    \xv ohteau
    \xe it is, it was
    \so Ex.40.38; Mt.6.30
    \xv pish ohteau
    \xe it shall be
    \so Gen.17.13; Mt.6.21
    \xv ohtag
    \xe (that) which is
    \so Mt.5.14
    |pish ohtaash| (inan. pl.) `they shall be'    Deut.6.6
    \xv ohtop
    \xe it was
    \so Jn.1.1
    \xv kutahtauun
    \xe thine is
    \so Mt.6.13
    \xv ahtoou ahtoonk
    \xe he "hath any inheritance"
    \so Eph.5.5
    \xv ahtoog
    \xe they had
    \so (brick, etc.)    Gen.11.3
    \xv nupp∞onk ohteau ohkuhqut
    \xe there is death in the pot
    \so 2 K.4.40
    |na ohtu|, |nah ohta| `there are (there is?)'    C.Math. Not.Ind. 52

    (|nutahtou|, |nutohtô| {not found in C.}, |nuttohtô| `I have, {or} had; I possess (it) {no occurrence of "possess" in C.}'
    \xv kutahtoup
    \xe thou hadst
    \xv noh ahtou
    \xe He hath
    \xv nuttahtomun
    \xe We have, we had
    \xv kuttahtomwoo
    \xe Ye have, ye had
    \xv nag ahtoog
    \xe They have, {or} had
    \so C.55/193-194√)

[Delaware [del] |olhatton| or |wulatton| `he has or possesses'    Zeisb.Gr.158; |hattaü| `he has, it has, it is there'    ibid.162; |hatteu|    Zeisb.Voc.18.]

\et B. 73, no. 240, 109/466, A.171, H.326, G.1981, *a?ta∙wa (i.e. **apta∙wa, causative) `to place, have sth'


\lx ohtauwaheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 104
    \nt +
\ps TA+O, TA causative to |ohtau| TI2
\ps `to cause sb to inherit sth'
\so Deut.31.7
    \xv ..., kah ken pish k∞tohtauwáheoneau.
    \xe ...; and thou shalt cause them to inherit it.
    \so Deut.31.7


\lx ohteak
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 104
\cf ohteuk


\lx ohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 104
    \nt +
\ps II
\twn |appu| AI
\ge `to be, remain (there)'
\nt G.1981, 37, p.73, 40, p.80, bt. (on phonology and spellings); G&B.681-682. This item is subsumed by Trumbull under |ohtauunát| TI2 `to possess sth', T.103b-104a. See that entry for brief examples of the indicative forms. Additional examples follow.
    \xv ...: kenutcheg ohteau ut wussittuppukan∞ónt kummatwomog:...
    \xe ...: thy hand {shall be} in the neck of thine enemies;...
    \so Gen.49.9
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv micheme ohtáash wadch(ua)sh
    \xe the everlasting hills
    \so Gen.49.26
    \ng 0p indicative
    \xv Asuh neese kesukquae, asuh pasuk nepàuz, asuh nequt kodtumwáe, matokqs sepohtag Tabernâkleut woskeche ohtaut wunnaumonuh Israel tuppuksinwog,...
    \xe Or whether it were two days, or a month, or a year, that the cloud tarried upon the tabernacle, remaining thereon, the children of Israel abode in their tents,...
    \so Num.9.22
    \ng t-subordinative for the predicative adjunct participle
    \xv Sunnummatta nish ohtan∞ash ogkomut Jordan, nogque adt wayont,...
    \xe Are they not on the other side Jordan, by the way where the sun goeth down,...
    \so Deut.11.30
    \ng 0p negative indicative
    \xv Asuh matta ongkoue ketahhannit ahtano,...
    \xe Neither is it beyond the sea,...
    \so Deut.30.13
    \ng 0 negative indicative

    \xv ..., nematog, kah n∞sh wek neh ohtagup ohkeit Kanaan, nuppeyaônukqun.
    \xe ..., My brethren, and my father's house, which were in the land of Canaan, are come unto me;
    \so Gen.46.31
    \ng _0_ preterite participle

\et A.174, H.331, B. no.57, 17, 91/447, 73, 109/466: *a?te∙wi II `there' i.e. **apte∙wi (as B.1962, 15.70, 289).


\lx -ohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 104
\cf -ohtáe


\lx ohteóonk
\va ahtóonk
\va ahtauonk
\va ohtoonk
\va ohtuonk
\va ohtôonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 104
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a possession'; +`inheritance, property'
\nt G&B.682 |(nutt)ohtoonk| 'my property'
    \xv wutohtuonk
    \xe a possession
    \so Gen.47.11; (E0) |wutahtuonk|
    \ng 3 possessive
    \xv wutch ahtóonk
    \xe for a possession
    \so Lev.14.34
    \xv machemohtag ohtóonk
    \xe an everlasting possession
    \so Gen.17.8

    \se !|ohtoonganu∞|, |ahtoonganu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, II, predicative
    \ge `to be an inheritance, a possession'
    \so Num.24.18; Judg.21.17; Ezek.36.3
    \xv Kah Edom pish ahtóo[n]ganu∞, kah Seir pis[h] ahtóonganu∞ wutche ummatwómuh,...
    \xe And Edom shall bee a possession, Seir also shall be a possession for his enemies,...
    \so Num.24.18
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv ..., Na mos ohtoonganeu∞ wutch neg pohquohhugeg wutch Benjamin,...
    \xe ..., There must be an inheritance for them that be escaped of Benjamin,...
    \so Judg.21.17
    \ng 0 indicative, existential
    \xv ..., onk woh kenaau wutohtoongan∞ askqshôncheg penuwohteáog,...
    \xe ... , that ye might be a possession unto the residue of the heathen,...
    \so Ezek.36.3
    \ng 2p indicative

    \se !|wutohtoonganu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), verb of possession
    \ge `to have an inheritance'
    \so Gen.23.18; Deut.18.1
    \xv ..., kah wame wutchippan∞onk Levi matt pish chippiyeumeu, asuh wutohtaonganu kenugke Israelut,...
    \xe ..., {and} all the tribe of Leui, shall haue no part nor inheritance with Israel:...
    \so Deut.18.1
    \ng 3 negative indicative

    \nt +

\lx ohteuk
\va ohteak
\va ohteuk
\va ohteuhk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 104
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a field'
    \nt G&B.601,712
    \nt +
\so Mt.13.38,44
\nt land which is cultivated or inclosed, or to which the idea of ownership or individual possession attaches (from |ohtauunát| or |ohtáe|, and |ohke|);
    pl. |ohteuhkónash|    Ps.107.37; Jn.4.35
    (|ahteukko@nash|    C.160)
    \xv wutohteuk Ephron
    \xe the field of Ephron
    \so Gen.23.17
    \ng 3 possessor
    \nt +
    |..., kah wame matugquash ne ohteakonit,...| `..., and all the trees that were in the field,...|  { locative }
    \xv ut wutohteakonit
    \xe in his field
    \so Mt.13.31
    \xv ut ohteakonit
    \xe in the field
    \so Ex.23.29
    \xv ut woskeche ohteakonit
    \xe in the open field
    \so Num.19.16; Lev.14.53
    (|ahte@uk| `soil, a field'    C.160)
\cf okke

    \se !|ohteuhkonehteau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), creative final
    \ge `to make a field, sow the fields'
    \so Ps.107.37(M); C.76/209; Ntv.Wr.23.2
    \xv Kah woh ohteuhkonehteaog, kah wenominneahteuhkonehteoog,...
    \xe And sow the fields, and plant vineyards,...
    \so Ps.107.37(M)
    \ng 3p indicative
    \xv Ohkehkonittinneat.
    \xe To be planted
    \so C.76/209
    \ng X->0 t-subordinative

    \xv ... waque ahtuhkanehteapah ...
    \xe ... as far as she formerly made her field ...
    \so Ntv.Wr.23.2
    \ng 3->_adv_ preterite participle; see G&B.601.

    [Ab. |kí`kañn| `champ', |neda`kikañn| `mon champ'    R.96/406b.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |Hagihácan.| `Field'; |Hakihakan| `field, plantation'; |ahkiiháakan| NI `field'    Z.74; B&A.47; O'M.18b.

\lx ókas

    \xe the mother of Jesus

    \xe the mother

    \nt +
\dv the radical |óu|, |∞|, with a termination marking the nomen patientis, as |∞she|, |∞ch| does the nomen agentis. Perhaps the same word (with animate termination), as |ohke| `earth'.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Okásu, {&} Wítchwhaw| `A mother.'; |Nókace, nítchwhaw| `My mother.'    R.W.28.√]
