\lx omp
\va -omp-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 105
\ps n. / final
\ge `man'
\nt This word is nowhere found by itself, and perhaps was already obsolete when Eliot's acquaintance with the language was commenced; but its recurrence in compound words suffices to fix it as the dialectic name appropriated, in accordance with Indian usage, to the favored race, whose men were all viri, while those of other tribes or nations were contemptuously regarded as even less than homines -- |missinnuog|, or captives. (See |missín|; |missinnin|.) From this root come, apparently:
    |nompaas| (|ne-omp-ôáas| `the man animal') `a male'
    |wosketomp| (|woskehuae-omp| `hurtful or bloody man') `a warrior, or "brave", one who bears arms' (see note below)
    |mugquomp| (|mogke-omp| `great man') `a captain'
    |nunkomp| (|nunkon-omp| `light man'?) `a young man, not grown up'
    |penomp| (|penowe-omp|? `a stranger to man, nescia viri?) `a virgin'
    |omskauónat| (for |omp-|) `to conquer, to put to flight'
    and, perhaps, |ompehteáonk| (|omp-ohtáe| `that which belongs to man or to the conqueror') `tribute'.
[NOTE. -- Regarding |wosketomp| the compiler notes: "This is wrong, but I can not fix the true meaning of |wosket-|." This is followed by a note in pencil: "Perhaps NOT wrong. 1883."]


\lx omp-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 105
    \nt +
\ps initial, P, (PreV?)
\ge `back; against; up'
\so Various of the following entries; an extended form in |ompam-|

[Algonquian [alg] |ABOT-| `à rebours, à l'envers'    Cq.9b.
Cree |+âb| (rac.) `revenir sur, etc., se retourner'; |âp| (rac.) `détacher, détortiller, aller en arrière, retourner sur, etc.'    Lac.280b;295b.
Delaware [del] |aap-| `back, backward, (re)turn (home), upside down, inside out, ...'    O'M., 8a ff.]
Fx. |a∙pi-| (prev) `go and perform act & then return'    Fx.L.42.
Miami |apwäi| (adverb) `back', |apwäpitwani| `I bring it back'; |aapwe| `back', |aapwaalaapi-| AI `look back'    D.-V.428; B&C.9a-10b.
Menominee [mez] |a∙p-| `back; inside out; return; ...'    M.L.36-38.
M.-P. |api| (|ap-|) `having gone to do X and returned; be back from doing X'; |ap-| (|api-|) PV `gehen, um etwas zu tun und zurückkommen'    LeS.9b; Sz.36.
Micm. (NOTE: {Back}, in composition, is made by |@p| and |@b@je|, as prefixes.)"    R.27b.
Mont. |ab8| `Retour'    Fbvr.3.
Shawnee [sjw] |haap-| `REGAINING LIFE', |haap-| `RETURNING (from activity far from home)', |haap-| (plus |-ii-|) `UNDOING'    D.-V.426.
WAbn. |ôba-| `in back, behind'    D.1.LIX.]

\lx ompamuhquaenát

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \so absolute }

\lx -ompamukqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 106
    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv de-stem final |-ompam| `see' + |-ukqus-| AI dispositional/passive + |-i-|; structurally parallel to |-nunkqussu| (cf. B.1962, 15.137-142, 299-300).
\ge "to appear __, be __ in appearance, have a __ look", with visual predicates, usually of color.
    \xv Rachel wunnetu, kah wunnompamukqussu
    \xe Rachel was beautiful and well-favored
    \so Gen.29.17
    \xv moompamukqussitcheg neetasuog
    \xe brown cattle (among the sheep)
    \so Gen.30.32
    \xv mushquompamukqussit
    \xe reddish
    \so Lev.13.49,14.37
    \xv pohkenompamukqussit
    \xe somewhat dark
    \so Lev.13.55
    \xv ashkoshquompamukqussit
    \xe greenish
    \so Lev.14.37
    |Nusqueompamukqussue| [erroneous (E1&2), for |musque-|] `of fierce countenance'    Deut.28.50

    \se -ompamukquodt
    \ps II
    \se "to appear __, be __ in appearance, have a __ look"
    \xv wompi mishquompamukquodt
    \xe white, and somewhat reddish
    \so Lev.13.19,24
    \xv pohkenompamukquodt
    \xe somewhat dark
    \so Lev.13.21,26
    \xv pohkenompamukquok
    \xe [but] if it be ... somewhat dark
    \so Lev.13.28
    \xv waenotuonk wunnompamukquat
    \xe praise is comely
    \so Ps.147.1(M); (E) |tapeneunkquot|

    \xv nishnoh mahtug ne wanompamukquok
    \xe every tree that is pleasant to the sight
    \so Gen.2.9
    \ng _0_ participle

\lx ompehteáe

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps adj.
\ge `of tribute'
    \xv -teaguash

\lx ompohchu
\va omponchu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 106
    \nt +
\ps AI (+locative PP), i-stem
\ge `to return (again), turn again', "to go back"
\dv |omp-| `back' + |(m)onch-| `to go' (de-stemmed)?
\so Gen.43.10; Mt.10.13; Gal.1.17,4.9
    \xv ..., wunnamuhkut woh nunneesit omôhchemun.
    \xe ..., surely now we had returned this second time.
    \so Gen.43.10; error for (E0&E1) |ompôhchemun|
    \xv ..., qut nuttomp Arabia, kah nutomponchep en Damaskus.
    \xe ...; but I went into Arabia, and returned again unto Damascus.
    \so Gal.1.17

    \xv Qut yeuyeu mahche wahheóg GOD asuh ayn GOD wahukqueóg, tohwaj omponchéog wonk en n∞chumwesue kah wensháe waj kutchehteómukish,...
    \xe But now, after that ye have known God, or rather are known of God, how turn ye again to the weak and beggarly elements,...
    \so Gal.4.9

    \se omponchem∞
    \ps II (+locative PP)
    \ge `to return'

    \xv ..., qut matta tapenum∞mun∞g, k∞nohteaongan∞ omponchem∞utch ut kuhhogkaout.
    \xe ...: but if it be not worthy, let your peace return to you.
    \so Mt.10.13

[Delaware [del] |aapáachiiw| AI `return home'    O'M.8a.

    Mi'kmaq [mic] |@bajaase|; |Abajipkesin| `To return', {v.int.}; |apaja:sit| AI `come back, return'    R.219a; DeB.4a.]
    \nt ?

\lx ompsk
\va ompsq
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 106
\ps in compound words / final ?
\ge `a stone or rock'
\nt equivalent in some cases to |qussuk|, in others to |hassun|.
    See:
    |kenompsq| (`a sharp stone', under |kénai|)
    |wanashquompskqut| (`the top of a rock')
    |togwonkanompsk| (`a millstone', under |togguhwonk|)
    |kussohkoi-ompsk| (`a high pointed rock'), etc.
Not used in Eliot's Bible except in compound words; but |missitche ompsqut| (obj.) `a great stone', is in Samp.Quinnup., p.156. The primary meaning seems to be an upright (|ompaé|) rock or stone (|p'sk|). Eliot has:
    |pasipskodtut| [|pahsu-p'sk|] `in a cleft of the rock'    Ex.33.22
    \xv agwe passompskodéhtu
    \xe under the [cleft upright] rocks
    \so Is.57.5
    \xv woskeche piskuttu
    \xe (from) "the top of the rocks"
    \so Num.23.9
    \xv ut att∞che pishkodtut
    \xe on a crag of the rock
    \so Job 39.21
    |kenugke pumipskquehtu| (of river courses) `among the rocks'    Job 28.10
    \xv kussampskóiyeuut
    \xe on (high) rocks' (or `on a high rocky place
    \so )    Jer.4.29
    \xv chippipskut
    \xe "upon a rock" under water
    \so Acts 27.29
    \xv mamossompsquehtu
    \xe in "gravel"
    \so (?)    Is.48.19
    \xv wutch woskechepiskquttu
    \xe from the top of the rocks
    \so Num.23.9
    (sing. |woskechepiskq| `on the top of a rock'    Ezek.24.7)


\lx ompskot
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 107
\ps n. / NI
    \xv nequtompskot
    \xe a penny
    \so Mt.20.9; Mk.12.15; Rev.6.6
    (|ompskod| `a penny'    C.203
    \xv ompskotash
    \xe pence
    \so Ind.Laws, II, p.3)

    \se omskinausu
    \ps II
    \ge `to be ... span(s) long' {?}
    \xv nequt omskinausu ne sahteag
    \xe a span shall be the length of it
    \so Ex.28.16
    \cf nequtompskinaushettit
    \ge of a span long
    \so (pl.)

[Narragansett [xnt] |nequittómpscat| `1 penny' (that is, `a penny's worth of |wámpan|'; probably a measure of length); |neesaúmscat| `2 pence'; |yowómscat| `4 pence'; |quttatashaúmscat| `6 pence' ( = |quttauatu|, |quáttuatu|; |neen| = 2 |quáttuatues|, = 12 pence, or a shilling); |piúckquat| (10 |quáttuatues|), 60 pence, = |quttatashincheck aumscat|, = |nquittómpeg|, or |nquitnishcau@su|, 1 fathom of their stringed money; |neesaumpaúgatuck|, 2 fathoms = 10 shillings, etc.; |neesaumsqussayi|, 2 spans of |wámpan|; |yowompscussáyi|, 4 spans, etc.,    R.W.128,135.]

\et Related to S.'s *a∙⌠k- `downward, below' (1975, item 328, pp.402-403)? Not probable, given Mayhew's forms. To |am-| (vowel?) `away' + |-sk-| `by foot, body'? Vowel here looks like |-ô-|, but that of |am-| usually spelt with simple |a|? Relationship to |áma∞hkauau| T.7b?

\lx onch-
\va ont-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 107
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge `change'
\so entries that follow, comparative

[Algonquian [alg] |AND-| `de nouveau, de rechef, à nouveau, encore, autrement, différemment', |Andap,i| `changer de place', |Andakasine| `changer de souliers', |Andabij| `lie-le de nouveau ou d'une manière nouvelle'; |ANDJ-| `de rechef, à nouveau', |Andjih| `change-le, refais-le', |Andjike| `changer de logis', |Andjik,o| `être en état de grossesse, être enceinte, (changement subi dans le physique, {andj}, {ik}, {o})'    Cq.42ab;44a.
Cree x |âtt| (rac.) `mettre dans une autre position, changer de place, refaire de nouveau'    Lac.D.315a.
Ill. {r} |anta, antchi, anti| `dans la compoon, transpoon, ailleurs, changement', |nitantac8i| `je change d'habit', |antchic8a| `elle est enceinte, grosse', |nitantchiki| `je refais ma cabanne'    M.33-34/61a-62a.]

\et c.f. G., item 22, 214b: *a∙nt- `move, change, afresh, anew', preverb *a∙nci, with examples below under |onch-| and |ont-|; A.34-36, 40-43; H.51-59, 63-66

\lx oneheau
\va ônheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 108
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative
\nt Remark: Syntax and meaning not clear--some instances perhaps with proleptic object shared with following subordinative; meaning perhaps "a vain attempt to cause".
\ge `could not', usually with subordinative or with ellipsis of the following verb phrase.
\so Josh.17.12; Judg.1.19; Mk.6.19,9.18; Lk.9.40
    \xv Qut wunnaumonuh Manasseh wuttônheouh sohh∞kauónat neh wadohkinitcheh otanahtu,...
    \xe Yet the children of Manasseh could not drive out the inhabitants of those cities;...
    \so Josh.17.12
    \xv ... qut ûnheau áma∞hkauónat wadohkinitcheh ∞nouhkoiyeuut,...
    \xe ...; but [he] could not drive out the inhabitants of the valley,...
    \so Judg.1.19
    \xv ...: kah nanompasumomp kukkodnetuhtaénumog, wussohwôhkonnaóut, kah wuttónheóuh.
    \xe ...: and I spake to thy disciples that they should cast him out; and they could not.
    \so Mk.9.18

    \se onehteau
    \va onteau
    \nt !
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `could not', syntax of the TA verb
    \so Ex.8.18; Num.9.6; Judg.3.22; Lk.19.3
    \xv Kah pauwaog ne ukqutchehteauunneau náshpeu uppauwaouongan∞, pas∞onat yeuhkquog, qut wutonehteauunneau ...
    \xe And the magicians did so with the enchantments to bring forth lice, but they could not:...
    \so Ex.8.18
    \xv Kah nátinnéham wunnauónat Jesusoh howan noh, kah wutónteauun newutche tahsuhkôadtuonk,...
    \xe And he sought to see Jesus who he was; and could not for the press,...
    \so Lk.19.3

    \xv ..., newaj onteunk amaunumun togkodtedteam wutch wunnógkussit,...
    \xe ..., so that he could not draw the dagger out of his belly;...
    \so Judg.3.22

    \se !|ôhôneau|
    \nt ?
    \ps AI (reduplicated)
    \ge `could not; ?hardly'
    \so Ex.9.11; Lk.9.39
    \xv Kah pauwaog ôhhôneau neepóog ut anaquabit Moses,...
    \xe And the magicians could not stand before Moses...
    \so Ex.9.11
    \xv ... kah wunnehnekinuh, onk péhtáuut∞nauh, kah pápukkehtahwhont, wuttôhôneu kod matta nukkonuh.
    \xe ...; and it teareth him that he foameth again, and bruising him, hardly departeth from him.
    \so Lk.9.39

\et perhaps to H.69-73 *a∙nw(e∙)- `fail, fault; refuse', which would lose the *w? (See Cuoq's entries |ANO-| `inutilement; en défaut, en faute, avec déplaisir, dégoût' and `ne...plus, sans rien faire', Cq.51b-52a, for some stems.)

\lx ongquomónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 108
\cf onkquommomm∞onk


\lx onk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 108
\ps conj.
\ge a particle which nearly answers to the Greek dè:, and is commonly used in the continuation of a recital or for connecting parts of a proposition or members of a sentence less closely and directly than by |kah|. It is sometimes put for `and', Gen.20.12,13; Mt.18.5; elsewhere for `so', `so that', Ps.78.20,29 {, and frequently for the comparative conjunction "than" (AV "then") }.
    \nt G&B.683
    \nt +
    \xv Touwisshäe, wonkanet, onk, {or} wonk
    \xe Abroad, again
    \so C.109/233

    \xv anue onk wame
    \xe more than all
    \so 1 Chr.16.20
    \xv anue missuken onk neen
    \xe he is more great than I
    \so {"mightier than I"}    Mk.1.7
    \xv missi onk
    \xe greater than
    \so Mk.4.32
    (|Onkatuk onkne, tokanögque.| `Besides, although'    C.110/234)
\nt [Was it originally the same as |wonk|?]
    \nt Research needed: Additional uses:
    \nt +
    a. Note the common use of |onk woh| in final clauses, where the verb appears to be in the subordinative, and similar constructions, e.g.:
    \xv ...; onk woh nuttittanahtôadtin wutche kenaau,...
    \xe ..., that I may cast lots for you here ...
    \so Josh.18.6
    \xv toh woh nuttinne wunnesen, onk woh nutahtaun micheme pomantamóonk?
    \xe what good thing shall I do, that I may have eternal life?
    \so Mt.19.16
    Here, to judge in a preliminary way from co-ordinated forms (e.g. Jn.3.16, 15.16), |onk| is the principal operator, and |woh| acts as a mood-sign governed by it.
    There are many examples of this type in C.

    b. Sentence-initially, |onk| may correspond to AV "now".

    c. |onk| for "for" in "mapping" structures, where an item in one series is associated with another item in a series:
    \xv Chìshquetahhamôonk onk chishquetahhamóonk, muskesuk onk muskesuk, meepìt onk meepit, neyane wosketahwhont wosketompuh, ne pish unnéheon wonk.
    \xe Breach for breach, eye for eye, tooth for tooth: as he hath caused a blemish in a man, so shall it be done to him again.
    \so Lev.24.20

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 108
\ps adv.
\ge `a little farther
\so Acts 27.28
\dv (dimin. of |ongkoue|)

[Narragansett [xnt] |awwassése|    R.W.55.]

    \so }

[H. proposes forms with *-Θp-, which would however yield Mass. |-sp-|] + *-en- `by hand' (?--spelling |-an-|, |-ôn-| etc.)

\lx onkatog
\va onkatuk
\va onkatog
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 108
    rmk Spellings in |-k| restricted to word-final instances? The animate plural in which the latent syllable appears normally appears to be in |-eg| (rarely |-ig|), whereas the inanimate shows both |-ash| and |-ish|.
    \nt +
\ps adj. / PreN, pronominal
\ge `another', +`the other'
    \nt G&B.684
    \nt +
\so Deut.28.30
    \xv pasuk ... onkatog
    \xe one ... the other
    \so Deut.21.15
    \xv ketass∞t ayeuhkonont wonkatogeh ketass∞toh
    \xe a king going to war against another king'    Lk.14.31 (here |-onkatog| has the prefix of 3d pers., `his other
    \so (?), and objective affix)
    pl. |onkatogig|
    (|únkatak|    Pier.14)

    \se |onkatogke|, |onkatoge|
    \nt +?
    \nt Remark: apparently a rare and still slightly doubtful form, most examples of the spelling probably being obviatives lacking the final |h|.
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `another'
    \so Gen.4.25; ?Ex.21.10
    \xv ..., newutche GOD nuttinnumunk onkatogke wuskannem ...
    \xe ...: For God, said she, hath appointed me another seed ...
    \so Gen.4.25
    \ng assuming |wuskannem| is NI here
    \xv Onkatoge ummittumwusseheunt,...
    \xe If he take him another wife,...
    \so Ex.21.10
    \ng PreV?

\dv |onk| or |wonk|.

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |ketak|, |ketaghik|, ig. |kedaghir| `les autres'    R.44/391a.

\lx onkauoht
\va onkauohteau
\va onkauwoht
\va onkouoht
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 108
\ps n. / NI, II?
\ge `a shadow'
\so Gen.19.8; 2 K.20.9; Is.32.2
    \xv ... newutche yeu waj peyaog ut agwe onkouohtáut neekit.
    \xe ...: for therefore came they under the shadow of my roof.
    \so Gen.19.8
    \ng locative
    \nt +
    \xv Wadchuash onkohtopash,...
    \xe The hills were covered with the shadow of it,...
    \so Ps.80.10; (M): |Ne nashpe wadchuash onkauuhtopash,...|
    \nt +
    \xv wutonk∞ohtom nupp∞onk
    \xe [the] shadow of death
    \so Mt.4.16
    \nt +

    \nt Remark: Note that the etymological root appears to denote a 2-place relation, "beyond, behind", and the entity on which the shadow is thrown appears to be treated as the subject of the verb in the example from Ps.80.10. The Eliot version is then perhaps something like "the hills are in its shadow" ("behind it"); the Mayhew version is less clear.
    \nt +

\et G.1965, item 8, 212a, A.16, H.24: *a∙kawa∙?te∙wi II `there is a shadow'.

\lx onkquatauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 109
    \nt +
\nt Remark: replacing and incorporating entry |onkquotteónat|, below T.108b-109a.
\ps v.t.an. / TA+O, dative final to TI2 causative?
\ge `to recompense (a person)'; +`to requite sb sth, to reward sb'
\nt G&B.684
\so Gen.47.22, Rev.11.18
    \xv ..., naneeswe onkquottauau mattammagwoh, kah onkquottauau panneusseaenuh.
    \xe ... [he] both rewardeth the fool, and rewardeth transgressors.
    \so Prov.26.10√
    \xv neh pish wutonkquatauoh
    \xe he will recompense her
    \so Jer.51.6
    \xv ..., kuppapasku onkquatonsh.
    \xe ... I will render double unto thee;
    \so Zech.9.12; (E1) |onkquatoush|√
    \ng 1->2(+0)
    \xv ..., Joseph paguodche kussekeneunkqun, kah nahwhunk kutonkquatunkqun, wame ne machuk ne neanheogkutup.
    \xe ..., Joseph will peradventure hate us, and will certainly requite us all the evil which we did unto him.
    \so Gen.50.15
    \ng 3->12+0 objective
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish onkquatauau ann∞t∞adtuonk ayeuuhkonnukqutcheh,...
    \xe ... and [he] will render vengeance to his adversaries,...'    Deut.32.43  { 3->3
    \so +0 absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish k∞nanumít, newutche nag matta woh kutonquatunk∞og, newutche pish kutonkquatont, omohkehettit sampwesecheg.
    \xe And thou shalt be blessed; for they cannot recompense thee: for thou shalt be recompensed at the resurrection of the just.
    \so Lk.14.14
    \ng 3p->2 negative; X->2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Ann∞taonk wutchiyeum∞ nuhhogkat, ne nutonkquatau n∞wau LORD,...
    \xe ..., Vengeance belongeth unto me, I will recompense, saith the Lord. ...
    \so Heb.10.30
    \nt +

    \xv Qut noh onkquatauut, kah matta noh nanawunont shepsoh,...
    \xe But he that is an hireling, and not the shepherd,...
    \so Jn.10.12  { X->_3_ participle }; (M) |noh onkquattauaeninnuit|
    \nt +

    \xv ..., papen∞eneheuhkon missinninnuog, asuh onkquatòntteohkon,...
    \xe ...; thou shalt not respect persons, neither take a gift:...
    \so Deut.16.19
    \ng X->2(+0) prohibitive
    \xv Unonkquatók neyan onkquatunkqueóg,...
    \xe Reward her even as she rewarded you,...
    \so Rev.18.6 { 2p->3+_adv_ imperative; 3->2p+_adv_ participle; relative root initial supports the comparison of equality. }√

\ge `to hire, to pay wages'
    \xv kutonkquatoush
    \xe I will give thee hire
    \so 1 K.5.6

    \xv ... missohhámah toh an unkquatauun?
    \xe ... tell me, what shall thy wages be?
    \so Gen.29.15
    \ng 1->2+_0_, changed
    \nt +
    \xv Noh onkquatauut wussemo, newutche noh onkquttauou, kah matta tohhentupánumaú∞ shepsoh.
    \xe The hireling fleeth, because he is an hireling, and careth not for the sheep.
    \so Jn.10.13
    \ng X->_3_
    \nt +

    \se |onquatauonk|, |-ong(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, deverbal, transitive
    \ge `hire, portion'
    \so Gen.47.22
    \xv ..., kah meechwog onkquatauaongan∞ Pharaoh anumauont,...
    \xe ..., and did eat their portion which Pharaoh gave them:...
    \so Gen.47.22
    \ng with indefinite object final?

    \se onkquatoe
    \ps PreV., Adv
    \xv ..., yeu, kah yeu Micah onkquatóe nuttinhikqun,...
    \xe ..., Thus and thus dealeth Micah with me,...' (`pays me such wages
    \so )    Judg.18.4√
\cf ann∞nau

[Narragansett [xnt] |Kuttaúnckquittaunch.| `I will pay you.'; |Kummuchickónckquatous.| `I will pay you well.'; |Tocketaonckquittíinnea.| `What wil you give me?'; |Kutteaûg Comméinsh.| `I will give you your Money.'    R.W.69;154/r.162.]

\lx onkquequohhou
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 109
\ps (v.i.) / AI, ?middle reflexive in |-(w)i-| (G&B, no. 11, 580) to a TA causative with the mechanical causative final in |-ahw-| to a bahuvrihi composed of |onkqu-| `to cover' and |-equ-| `eye, face', "to be face-covered", hence "to cause os to be face-covered".
\ge `he covered his face' (with it)
\so Is.6.2; Ex.34.33
    \xv Kah Moses mahche ken∞nuh, kah ongquequóhhou.
    \xe And till Moses had done speaking with them, he put a veil on his face.
    \so Ex.34.33
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nashpe nees∞oh onkquequohhou,...
    \xe ..., with two he covered his face,...
    \so Is.6.2
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +

\et *a∙kw- `cover' (G.1965, no. 8, 212a) + *-i∙nkw- `face, eye' (H.247; B.1962, 18.155, p.407; Cq.127a) + *-ahw- TA mechanical causative (B.1962, 16.143, p.357)

\lx ontahtauunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 110
\ps v.i. / AI, bahuvrihi ?
    \nt Remark: Most of this material probably belongs under TI2 |ontataúunat| below, and an II verb with a final corresponding to |ohteau| `to be' (PA *a?te∙wi) must be recognized; clear AI examples with evidence of palatalization probably belong here; however, at least one other possibility exists that may be hard to distinguish from it: H.68 *a∙ntwike∙wa (bahuvrihi) `to move camp/tent' (e.g. Gen.13.18,26.22).
    \nt Follow up needed: .
    \nt +
\ge `to be moved, to be in a state of motion or to be made to move from one place to another, passively'
\so Jer.24.9;
    \xv Neit Abram ontatteau weetu, kah paont na wuttaiin pagontimmusasqut Mamre ut Hebron,...
    \xe Then Abram removed his tent, and came and dwelt in the plain of Mamre, which is in Hebron,...
    \so Gen.13.18
    \nt +
    *|matta ontahtáun∞ut| (pass. neg.) `not to be moved'    1 Chr.16.30
    \xv pish ontohteau
    \xe it shall be removed
    \so Ezek.7.19
    \xv sun woh qussuk ontahtauun
    \xe shall the rock be removed?
    \so Job 18.4
    \xv pish ontahtauun
    \xe it shall be removed from its place
    \so Is.22.25
    \xv quenohtag ontohteau
    \xe the foundation moved [was moved]
    \so 2 Sam.22.8
    \xv mat pish ohtohtano
    \xe it shall not be moved
    \so Ps.96.10

\nt sometimes transitive, `to move or impart motion to':
    |wutontataúunat| with prefix of 3d pers. `to remove it'    Gen.48.17
[*NOTE. -- "Wrong. This is a different verb. See ontataúunat."]

[Cree (1) |a't-astáyoo| (inan.) `he is, or is lying, in another place'; (2) |a't-atháyoo| (an.), `he ali-ates, puts, him in another place, removes him';  (3) |a't-ootáyoo| `he goes elsewhere, "removes"'    Howse 157.
Chip. (1) |aund'-ahtá|, (2) |ood'aund'-assáun|, (3) |aund'-oota|    ibid.]

\et H.66 *a∙ntaxkye∙wa AI `to change one's abode, country' (bahuvrihi)


\lx ontahteau
\va ontohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 110
    \nt +
\ps II
\dv |ont-| `move' + |-ohteau| II
\ge `to be moved, move, remove'
\so Ps.18.7,46.2,68.8,82.5,93.1,96.10,99.1,104.5; Mt.17.20
    \xv ...: onk agwu ohtagish wadchuash ontahtaash, kah nukkem∞ash ...
    \xe ...; the foundations also of the hills moved and were shaken,...
    \so Ps.18.7; (M): |ontohtopash|
    \xv ...: kah muttaok meneh keteauun, onk woh matta ontohtano.
    \xe ...: the world also is stablished, that it cannot be moved.
    \so Ps.93.1
    \xv ..., pish kuttittamunneau yeu wadchu, monchish yeu wutch, yaaush, kah woh ontohteau,...
    \xe ..., ye shall say unto this mountain, Remove hence to yonder place; and it shall remove:...
    \so Mt.17.20

    \xv Newajeh matta wabeseog tokonogque ôntohtag ohke, kah tokonogque wadchuash ôntahtag en nóeu ketahhannit.
    \xe Therefore will we not fear, though the earth be removed, and though the mountains be carried into the midst of the sea;
    \so Ps.46.2

    \xv ...: appu {noeu} cherubimsut, ohke ontahtaj.
    \xe ...: he sitteth between the Cherubims, let the earth be moved.
    \so Ps.99.1(M)

    \xe ... with fire unquenchable.
    \so Lk.3.17√

\lx -ont∞w-á-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 110
    \nt +
\ps final, AI
\ge "to speak a language" (more generally: "to make noise, sound with the voice, to make a sound"?)
\nt Remark: The name of the language is given either as an initial or adverbially, cross-referenced in the initial. See also |unnont∞wau|, |-onk|, T+.173a.
\so T.58a, s.v. |mishont∞wau|; Mk.7.35, 16.17; Acts 10.46,19.6
    \xv Newutche wunn∞tauóuh íánant∞waoh, kah mishsheheaog GOD. ...
    \xe For they heard them speake with tongues, and magnify God. ...'    Acts 10.46  { 3
    \so indicative; initial |eiyáne|, T.25b }
    \xv ...; n∞wau, woh kittinnont∞wam Greeke;
    \xe ...? Who said, Canst thou speak Greek?
    \so Acts 21.37
    \ng 2 indicative; initial |unn-|, cataphoric to |Greeke|
    \xv ... noh ∞wesuonk Hebrewont∞waonganit Abaddon, qut Greekont∞waonganit ussowesu Apollyon.
    \xe ..., whose name in the Hebrew tongue is Abaddon, but in the Greek tongue hath his name Apollyon.
    \so Rev.9.11
    \ng lcoative, deverbal noun

[Narragansett [xnt] |Awanagusàntowosh| `Speake English.', |Eenàntowash| `Speake Indian.', |Nippenowàntawem| `I am of another language', |Penowantowawhettûock| `They are of a divers language.'    R.W.8-9.]

    \nt +

\lx ôs∞wunnumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 111
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `to change'
\so Dan.7.25; Jer.2.36
    \xv ... kah ôs∞wunum nutonkquatunkash piogqut nompe,...
    \xe ..., and [he has] changed my wages ten times; ...
    \so Gen.31.7; sim. Gen.31.41
    \nt +
    \xv ós∞wunum wutogk∞unash
    \xe he changed his raiment
    \so Gen.41.14√
    \xv ..., Yeuoh Jesus ut Nazareth, yeu pish uppaguatoun ayeuonk, onk pish ós∞wunnum uhshuáonganash, Moses anumunkqueagupash.
    \xe ..., that this Jesus of Nazareth shall destroy this place, and shall change the customs which Moses delivered us.
    \so Acts 6.14
    \nt +
    |{Pahke wahteauunat uttiyeu Oggusanuk∞wae wuttinniyeuonk auwokonat, kah wonk os∞wunumunat wuttinniyeuonk.}| "Clearly to make known how to use a syllogistic form and also how to change it."    Log.Pr.65/77, heading
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah ôs∞wunum∞k kutogk∞un∞ash.
    \xe ..., and change your garments.
    \so Gen.35.2
    \nt +

    \se ôs∞wunau
    \ps TA
    \ge `to change [some animate]'
    \xv matta wutós∞wunoh
    \xe he does not change it
    \so Lev.27.10
    \ng TA, of a beast

    \xv ós∞wunont
    \xe if he change
    \so Lev.27.10

    \se ôs∞wem∞
    \ps II
    \ge `it changes, it is changed'
    \so Lam.4.1

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |és8"a`tté.| `On les change de place, cela est mis à la place de l'autre'; |añsitâï8i| v. |és8ï8i| `En échange', |añsitaï8i io miri| `Donne moi cela en échange'    R.96/406;196/438b(,P.14/553b).
    \nt +
Miami-Illinois [mia] |nitacha8assa| `je le mets a la place de'...    Gr.1/47b-48a.
K. |aasó-| `over to the other side,...; in exchange, exchange', |aasoeskam-| TI `change it (of clothing)'    V.7.
Lp.A |ans8anman8at8ak| `ils changent une chose pour un autre', |ans8anman8ateten| `changeons'    D.97.
Miami |a⌠awatwani| `I change (exchange for) it'; |aa⌠it-| `in turn'     D.-V.435; B&C.10b.
Ojibwe [oji] |a:$itto:$kon| TA `to change s.o's clothing'    P&G.9.
Shawnee [sjw] |haa⌠oo-| `CROSSING, CHANGING ONE POSITION OR THING FOR ANOTHER', |nitaa⌠oona| `I exchanged him, traded him for another'    D.-V.435.]

\et H.114-124,126-128(?) *a∙⌠(aw)- `(a)cross, in turn, opposite'; note also Ojibwa forms pointing to PA *a∙ns- (|a∙nsekkank| `he changes it (a garment)', B.1957, 233a; |aanzikan| TI `change s.t. with foot or body (e.g. clothes)', N&N.18b; |aanzkang| TI `change s.t. (of clothes)', Rh.12b) and also to PA *a∙nt- (|aunjekoonuhya| `He ch[anges]. his clothes', W.186b; cf. also Cree |à'tuwäo| `He changes his coat (as an animal)', Frs.38a?), where the forms in *-s- could merely be assibilated forms of the latter--note the presence of a grand assibilator, the corporal final. The fairly clear presence of *w indicates that the first source is to be preferred for Massachusett. Rasles's entries indicate the semantic closeness of similar sounding initials, which may have led to a certain amount of cross-talk, especially in languages where the nasal is lost and the shibilant of *a∙⌠- merges with the sibilant.

\lx -∞-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 111
\ps suffix
\ge an inseparable negative particle, interposed between the radical and the last syllable, or the suffix, of affirmative verbs, to constitute the negative form:
    \xv ∞wadchanumun
    \xe he keeps it
    \xv ∞wadchanum∞un
    \xe he does not keep it
    or, as more commonly found,
    |matta ∞wadchanum∞un| (with a double negative)
    The negative |∞| enters into the composition of several words other than verbs of negation, as |wanne| (q.v.), |∞-anne| `none'.
\cf howan
\ge someone
\cf unneu
\so etc


\lx ∞ch
\va ∞tch
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 112
\ps adv.
\ge `out of, forth from, thence'
    \xv na ∞tch sohhamun
    \xe there went forth from
    \so Num.11.31
    \xv na ∞ch sohhamun
    \xe he went out from thence
    \so 1 K.12.25
    \xv na ∞ch qushken
    \xe thence he returned
    \so 2 K.2.25
    \xv ∞tcheun
    \xe he made from (it)
    \so Gen.2.22
\nt This is one of the most important radicals of the language, denoting origin, source, causation: cf. |na ∞tch| (|n∞che|) `therefrom';* |k∞ch|, |k∞che|, |kutche|, which denote origin and progress, though often used by Eliot for |n∞che|; whence |kutche| or |kéhche| `chief'; |kehchis| `old'; |kutchissik| `the beginning' (of action, etc.), and the perhaps identical |wutche| as a preposition (`from, out of, for'). |∞sh| `a father', and |∞kas|, |ókas| `a mother', and perhaps |ohke| `the earth', have apparently the same origin; hence, too, |∞chetuonganog| `parents', etc.; also |wutch|, |wutche|: |mo teag wutch| `without cause', 1 Sam.19.5 = |mat teag wutch|, Lam.3.52 = |wanne monteag wutch|, Ps.35.7, = |wutch monteag|, ibid.;
|nenan wutche|, for the same cause, Phil.2.18.
\cf wutche
[*NOTE. -- After "|na ∞tch (n∞che)|, therefrom", in the manuscript, occurs the following:
"|mô ∞tche| (|m∞che| and, with a slightly altered form and meaning, |mahche|), `thence-after' (the sign of the pluperfect tense)." In the margin this is marked "omit", and a footnote explains that "|m∞che|, for |môs ∞tche|, with reference to a future, implies obligation or necessity. See |m∞che|."]

[Cree and Chip. See Howse, Cree Gr., pp. 166, 289, 291.]


\lx ∞chaus
\va ∞chaas
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 112
\ps n.
\ge `a fly'
\so Eccl.10.1; Is.7.18
\cf m∞súhq

[Delaware [del] |u tsche|    Zeisb.Voc.12; pl. |ütschëwak|    ibid. 31.]


\lx ∞cheinnat
\va ∞chininnat
\va ∞chininónat
\va ∞chininnau
\ve + for , ?!
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 112
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `to be weaned'
\so Gen.21.8; +1 Sam.1.22; Ps.131.2
    \xv Onk mukkies kenuppétu, kah ∞cheninnop:...
    \xe And the child grew, and was weaned:...
    \so Gen.21.8
    \xv ..., matta nukkuhkuk∞h nô pajeh mukkies wutt∞chininónat,...
    \xe ..., {I will not go up} until the child be weaned,...
    \so 1 Sam.1.22
    \ng 3 t-subordinative
    \xv ... onatuh ∞chininnat mukkies wutch okasit: nukketeahogkou onatuh ∞chininneat mukkies.
    \xe ... as a child that is weaned of his mother: my soul is even as a weaned child.
    \so Ps.131.2
    \ng ?X t-subordinative
    \nt +

    \se !|∞chininnaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to wean sb'
    \so 1 Sam.23.24; 1 K.11.20; Ps.(M).131.2; Is.28.9; Hos.1.8
    \xv ..., ne apsh nô pajeh kut∞chininnaheonat,..., kah wun∞nuh nô pajeh wut∞chininnáhéonat.
    \xe ..., tarry until thou have weaned him;..., and [she] gave her son suck until she weaned him.
    \so 1 Sam.1.23

    \xv ... Genubath wunnaumonuh, neh Taphne ∞chinináheoncheh ut Pharaoh wekit,...
    \xe ... Ge-nubath his son, whom Tahpenes weaned in Pharaoh's house,...
    \so 1 K.11.20

    \se |∞chininnáe|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `weaned'
    \so Is.11.8; Ps.(M).131.2
    \xv Kah n∞n∞e mukkies pish tannuppompu ∞wonogqut asp, kah ∞chininnáe mukkies pish pethennum wunnutcheg sesegq ∞wonogqut.
    \xe And the sucking child shall play on the hole of the asp, and the weaned child shall put his hand on the cockatrice den.
    \so Is.11.8

    \dv ?Perhaps a restructured form of |wutch| `from' + ?|-inin-| `breast, nipple' + |-á-| AI, by reanalysis of a form with |wu-| prefixed as the stem. The noun medial would be a reflex of the form posited as *meΘeni NI `somebody's nipple' (Mch.1935.136b; A.1274; [unable to find Warne's examples, 1975, no.47, p.87, from Voegelin 1941 (perhaps Shawn. |(-)lenya| `nipple, |(-)lenye `milk', D.-V.365?) or Rasles]); perhaps also present in |meninnunk|, Narr. |Munnúnnug|, Abn. |merenák8s| `milk', and Narr. |Wunnunògan| `A Breast.', R.W. 142/r.150, R.54/393b, 308/474b, though the final remains obscure. [?Cf. B.1962, 14.77, 239: |-a∙kan|? but there to an AI root.]
    \nt +

\lx ∞munát
\va wámunat
\va ∞m
\ve 2nd form spurious, based on changed conjunct forms
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 112
\nt Remark: This entry still needs attention.
\ps v.i. / AI (AI+O, with object of source; goal with locative in -|ut|?)
\ge `to go or come from', +centrifugal ("hence, thence"), `to go forth, journey from, out of somwhere' often with |wutch|
\nt cf. |au| v.i. `he goes thither'; |peyau| `he comes hither' {centripetal}.
    |∞mun|, |∞m|, |w∞m| `he goes or comes, went or came'    2 Chr.1.13; Job 37.9; Prov.14.16; Dan.8.5
    \xv nutonsem kah n∞m Godut
    \xe I proceeded forth and came from God
    \so Jn.8.42
    \xv noh n∞mun
    \xe I am from him
    \so Jn.7.29
    \xv na ∞mun
    \xe he went thence
    \so 2 K.2.25; Gen.20.1; 35.21
    \xv ∞mwog
    \xe they journeyed` (`went
    \so )    Gen.35.16
    (`went from'    Num.33.5,13,17, etc.)
    |tunoh k∞m|, |toh k∞mun| `whence comest thou?'    Gen.16.8; Job 1.7
    \xv tohnoh k∞mw∞
    \xe whence come ye?
    \so Gen.42.7
    \xv pish ∞mwog wutch wuhhogkat
    \xe "they shall be of her", i.e. proceed from her
    \so Gen.17.16
    \xv Kah wosketomp n∞wau, yeu ∞muneau, newutche nunn∞taóog n∞waog ontuh Dothan: kah Joseph wunn∞sukauoh wematoh, kah wunnamheuh ut Dothan.
    \xe And the man said, They are departed hence; for I heard them say, Let us go to Dothan. And Joseph went after his brethren, and found them in Dothan.
    \so Gen.37.17
    \nt +
    \xv ∞mup aongkouohkomuk
    \xe (she) came from the uttermost parts
    \so , etc.    Mt.12.42
    (|tohhunn∞ k∞m kekit| `when did you come from home?'    C.185)

    \xv ...: wutche yeug waguppanneg wutche Arkut,...
    \xe ...; from all that go out of the ark,...
    \so Gen.9.10,18
    \ng _3p_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv ... wámohettit wutchepwoáau,...
    \xe ..., as they journeyed from the east,...
    \so Gen.11.2
    \ng 3p changed conjunct
    \xv Kah nesahteag ahquompi wutch wamog Kadesh Barnea, ... , shwinchage kah shwosuk tahshe kodtumwae,...
    \xe And the space in which we came from Kadeshbarnea, ..., was thirty and eight years;...
    \so Deut.2.14
    \ng 1p->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Levit ∞k wohtohut k∞squontamehtu ut wame Israelut,...
    \xe And if a Levite come from any of thy gates out of all Israel,...'    Deut.18.6 { apparently an archaism, |wum+k|; cf. G.1979, 6.34, 182, Munsee |w@nk| 3s cjt. to |w@m| `come from
    \so }
    \nt +
    \xv Asq yeu wám∞omp, kah matta wonk qushkeon,...
    \xe Before I go {whence} I shall not return,...
    \so Job 10.21
    \ng 1->_adv_ negative preterite participle
    |howan yeuoh wag Edom| (suppos.) `who is this that cometh from Edom?    Is.63.1  { _3_ participle }
    \xv ..., ∞k ohteakonit,...
    \xe ..., when he comes from the field,...
    \so Lk.17.7
    \ng 3->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    (|noh wág Godut| `(who art) come from God'    Mass.Ps., Jn.3.2)
    \xv ..., newutche n∞wahteoh uttóh wómomp, kah uttôh ayôi: qut matta kenaau k∞waóunnau uttôh womuhp, kah uttôh ayói.
    \xe ...: for I know whence I came, and whither I go; but ye cannot tell whence I come, and whither I go.
    \so Jn.8.14
    \ng 1->_adv_ preterite participle; variant spellings?
    |...: newutche n∞wahteo uttuh wamuhp, kah uttuh aoi: qut matta k∞wahteomw∞ uttuh wam, kah uttuh aoi.|    Jn.8.14(M.) { Note null 1 ending. }
    \nt +
    \xv waik Judea
    \xe when he came out of Judea
    \so Jn.4.54√
    \ng hapax?
    \xv Onk wamohettit nippekontu, Nashauanit nashpishau Phillipoh,...
    \xe And when they were come up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip,...
    \so Acts 8.39
    \nt +
    \xv en mayut ne wâman
    \xe in the way by which thou camest' (`mayest come' i.e. `mayest come from
    \so )    Is.37.29; +|ut mayut ne waman|    Acts 9.17
    \xv ..., wâmon Macedonia,...
    \xe ..., when I departed from Macedonia,...
    \so Phil.4.15
    \ng 1 changed subjunctive
    \nt +
    \xv ... Yeug na wagig mishe wuttammepunnaonganit,...
    \xe ..., These are they which came out of great tribulation,...
    \so Rev.7.14
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv ahque ∞m∞gk
    \xe depart not from
    \so Acts 1.4

    \se ∞m∞∞
    \ps with inan. nom. / II
    \ge `to come, proceed from'
    \nt +
    \nt G&B. |wummoo| 742
    \xv ...: yeu ∞m∞∞ Jehovah ut,...
    \xe ..., The thing proceedeth from the LORD:...
    \so Gen.24.50
    \xv ∞m∞∞ nannummiyeu
    \xe it cometh (is come) out of the north
    \so Jer.46.20
    \xv um∞∞
    \xe (there) proceeds out of (inan.)
    \so Mk.7.21
    \xv ∞m∞∞
    \xe there came out of (the cloud a voice)
    \so Lk.9.35

    \xv ..., qut nashpe nish noh kutt∞onk ne wom∞uk wutch Jehovah wutt∞nut wosketomp wutch pomantamun.
    \xe ..., but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of the Lord doth man live.
    \so Deut.8.3
    \ng _0_ participle; note the contrast with the corresponding (changed) AI form |wag|
    \nt +
    (|uttuh wam∞uk| `whence it cometh'    Mass. Ps., Jn.3.8)
    |wów∞uk| (for |wóm∞uk|? {1st ed.: |wó-m∞uk|}) kesukqut| `(it) may come from heaven'    2 Pet.1.18

\nt The Mass. Ps. substitutes |ômau| (|aummau|) for Eliot's |au| `he went to', where obj. is inan.

    \se !|∞mheau|, !|∞meheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to send sb away'
    \so Gen.43.14
    \xv ..., onk woh na ∞mheuh onkatuk kematou, kah Benjamin:...
    \xe ..., htat he may send away your other brother and Benjamin. ...'    Gen.43.14  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    Derivatives:
    |pomohhamunat| (|pummoh| `the sea') `to go by water'
    \xv sohhamunat
    \xe to go forth
    |wámunat|, |wómunat| (|wom∞enat|?) { spurious citation forms, based on changed conjunct? (No such form is cited, and none is likely to be citable.) }
\cf wadchinat

    \xv Kah ummuttaakinne tuppuksinn∞onk wunnaumonuh Dan moncheog, wuttat waágig kenugke wame tuppuksinn∞wongash pannuppe ukkenauwameongan∞:...
    \xe And the standard of the camp of the children of Dan set forward, which was the rearward of all the camps throughout their hosts:...
    \so Num.10.25
    \xv Qut monaog negonshacheg pish wuttat ∞mwog, kah wuttat wagig pish negonshauog.
    \xe But many that are first shall be last; and the last shall be first.
    \so Mt.19.30; c.f. Mt.20.16

    ((|nuttóm nummissinninneumut| `I go to my people'    Num.24.14

    \xe I shall go to him
    \so 2 Sam.12.23
    \xv kutómun
    \xe we are going
    \so Num.10.29))
    \xv ongk
    \xe go ye to
    \so , from |ônat|, |auónat|    Mt.21.2; Josh.2.16 (more commonly |monchek|)

\lx ∞nói
\va ∞nóe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 113
\ps adj.
\ge `blue'
\so Esth.1.6
    |∞nôagk|, |∞nôag| `blue (cloth)'    Ex.38.18,23; 2 Chr.2.7
    = |∞nóónag|
    pl. |∞nóiyeuash|    Esth.1.6
\nt [Roger Williams gives Narr. |peshaúi| `blue' (p.154), but that is apparently identical with |uppéshau| `a flower'.  Possibly the Indian who taught him the word, having misunderstood his question, gave him the name of the object to which his attention was called instead of its color.
Cotton gives |peshai| `blue' (168); |uppëshou| `a flower' (160); |peshânno@quat| `blue color' (168). Cf. Arab. zahr, a flower; az'rek, blue.]


\lx ∞nou
\va ∞nói
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 113
\ps adj. / medial or final form of |m∞nôi|
\ge `deep'
\nt Except in compound words, it has always the definitive prefix, |m'∞nói|, probably to distinguish it from |∞nói| `blue' (the color of deep water); and for the same reason the |m'| is retained in such compounds as |m∞nompag| `deep waters'.
\cf m∞nôi

\lx ∞she

\so Trumbull 113

\nt G&B.685, s.v. |(n)∞sh|

    \xv n∞sh
    \xe my father
    \so Gen.22.7; Lk.15.21
    \xv n∞shun
    \xe our father
    \so Lk.3.8; 11.2
    \xv k∞shun
    \xe our (incl.) father
    \so Gen.19.31

    \xv k∞sh
    \xe thy father

    \xe ... from my forefathers ...

    \ng 1 possessor plural
    |k∞sheu| (|k∞sh∞|) `your father'    Gen.31.6,7; 43.7  { 2p possessor }
    |∞shoh| (constr.) `the father of, his father'    Prov.17.21; (obj.) Gen.19.33; 28.7  { 3 possessor obviative }
    \xv ..., onk woh au Isaakanit ∞shut ohkit Kanaan.

    \nt +

    \xe ..., and was laid unto his fathers,...
    \so Acts 13.36
    \ng 3 possessor locative
    \nt +
    \xv ∞sh∞woh Edomitsog
    \xe the father of the Edomites
    \so Gen.36.9
    \ng 3p possessor obviative
    \nt +
    \xv ∞shuouh
    \xe their father
    \so Gen.50.15
    \ng 3p possessor, obviative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne Jehovah chadchekeomomp k∞sh∞oguh,...
    \xe ..., which the Lord sware unto your fathers ...
    \so Deut.11.9 { 2p possessive, absentative obviative; see G&B. 494-495,504 }; also Deut.11.21,13.17,...
    \nt +

    \xv ken pish wut∞shin
    \xe thou shalt be a father
    \so (of many nations)    Gen.17.4
    \ng indefinite possessor, G&B.491,500

    \se wut∞shimau
    \ps TA verb of possession; NA "undergoer" noun (B. 82, 113/471; B.1962, 2.50, 44; 14.99, 242; 15.9, 275-276; 16.37, 337; see also G&B.500, for an apparently distinct analysis)
    \ge "to have sb as father"; "one that one has as a father"
    \xv wut∞shimau
    \xe [he who is (?)] a father
    \so Ps.103.13; Prov.4.1; Is.9.6; 1 Thess.2.11
    \xv Yeuyeu weemattin pish wunnass∞máu weematoh, en nuppunat, kah wut∞shimau wunnaumonuh:...
    \xe Now the brother shall betray the brother to death, and the father the son;...
    \so Mk.13.12


    \se wut∞sheu
    \nt Remark: The forms are variable, owing to the somewhat equivocal relationship to the noun stem |-∞sh-| and its forms. Cf. Gen.44.19,20
    \ps AI(+O), verb of possession (B. 58,68, 105/461, 108/465; B.1962, 15.9-10, 275-276)
    \ge "to have (sb as) a father", hence `to be sb's father'
    \nt G&B., no.9, 579
    \xv ... K∞t∞shimwou? asuh k∞wemattimw∞?...
    \xe ..., Have ye a father, or a brother?
    \so Gen.44.19
    \ng 2p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... N∞wut∞shimun kutchise,...
    \xe ..., We have a father, an old man,...
    \so Gen.44.20
    \ng 1p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ...? sunnummatta k∞t∞shéin, noh taphukquean?...
    \xe ...? is not he thy father that hath bought thee?...
    \so Deut.32.6
    \ng 2->3 negative objective
    \xv Wanne wut∞she, wanne wutokase, wanne ontseu,...
    \xe Without father, without mother, without descent,...
    \so Heb.7.3
    \ng presumably 3 negative absolute

    \xv ..., GOD wut∞sheóg,...
    \xe ..., If God were your Father,...
    \so Jn.8.42
    \ng 2p->3 conjunct
    \xv ..., natauwahónat mat wadt∞sh∞gig, kah sekoussquaog, onkapúnnáhettit,...
    \xe ..., To visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction,...
    \so Jas.1.27
    \ng _3p_ negative participle

\cf óteshem
\cf ∞tshoh
\cf wadchinat

[Narragansett [xnt] |Osh| `A Father.'; |Nosh| `My father.', |Còsh| `Your father.'; |Cuttòso| `Have you a father?'    R.W.28√.
Delaware [del] |nooch| `my father'; |gooch| (|kooch|) `thy father'; |ochwall| `his father'    Zeisb.Voc.]

\et B. 32, 96/452, with remarks on form; G.1981, 25, 65, 37, 74; H.2414; W., no.110, 102: *nohΘa, *o∙hΘali

\lx ox
\va oxen
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 114
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Forms quite variable, the English singular or plural being used as basis for inflection and derivation, even within single books.
\ps NA
\ge `ox'
\so Deut.14.4,5,26,18.3,22,22.1,4,25.4,28.31,...
    \xv Kah Abimelech neemunau sheepsoh, kah oxinoh...

\lx p'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 114
\cf pâ-


\lx pâ
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 114
\ps a particle which, prefixed to a verb in the indicative, gives it the sense of the 1st pers. imperative
    \xv n∞waantam
    \xe I am wise
    \xv pâ-n∞waantam
    \xe let me be wise
    \so El.Gr.25

[Cree |pa@|, indecl. particle, prefixed to the root of the verb, has the force of `should' or `would' conditional: |ne pa@ nipan| `I should or would sleep'.]


\lx pa
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 114
\ge applied to extension in time, an indefinite going-on. It has the force of `yet' in such phrases as `while he was yet speaking'.
    Indic. |ash pásnekesukok| `while it was yet day'    2 Sam.3.35

    \xv paamu
    \xe "upward" in age or time': `from twenty years old [|kah paamu|] and up-ward', i.e. `passing
    \so Num.26.2,4
    = |paáme|    2 Chr.31.16,17
    \nt MN: ash pamwadt
    \ng Suppositive |ash pamwadt| `while he yet spoke'    Job 1.16,17; Mt.14.43
    Pass. (inan. subject) |pamém∞| `it is passed'    Ps.18.12
    Imperat. 3d pers. would be, regularly formed, |paj| or |pajeh| (q.v.) [or |pamejeh| (?)] `let it go on or continue (until)'.
\cf (suppos.
\ge he lives
\so pômantumpamôntog|)
\cf pomushau
\ge he walks
\cf pâmsheau
\ge it is past
\so etc
(Cf. also Sansk. pamb, ire, se movere.)

[Western Abenaki [abe] |pemi| (= |amptsi| and |añptsi|), in compos. `pendant, vel encore'; `il est à' (with verb in infinitive)    Rasles.
Delaware [del] |pem mi| `yet, to this time'    Zeisb.]


\lx pa-
\va pe-
\va pu-
\va p'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 114
\ge prefixed to words which signify motion, denotes indirection in the act or agent. Th verbs of motion it signifies `all about', `in one direction or another', or without direction.
    \cf pa-nne
    \ge out of the way',
    \so astray', and
    \xv pu-mmoh
    \xe the sea
    \xv pa-m∞s∞
    \xe he swims
    \xv pa-mompagin
    \xe it creeps
    \xv pamítchuan
    \xe (water) runs
    \so , etc.

[For the Cree, Howse (84) has |pímmitáchemoo| `he moves himself horizontally, crawls', and perhaps this may be the primary signification.]

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 114
\ps adv.
\ge `past, upward' (in age or time)
\so Num.26.2,4
\cf pâme

    i.e. `that which blows away'

\lx pabahch-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 115
    \nt +
\ps initial ?
\dv palatalized form of initial |pabaht-| `trust'?
\ge ?
\so Ps.118.5;119.45

    \xv pabuhchaieyeuonganit
    \xe in a large place
    \so Ps.118.5; (M): |pabahchaiyeuonkanit|

    \se pabahchieyeue
    \ps PreV
    \xv Kah pish pabahchiyeue nuppumusham:...
    \xe And I will walk at liberty:...
    \so Ps.119.45; (E): |-nanouwe|


\lx pabahtanum
\va pa-bát-an-um
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 115
\ps v.t. / TI1b (TI-O)
\ge `he trusts'
    \nt Remark: It is doubtful whether this headword exists as such; any example of this shape probably belongs under the following sublemma, as a TA |-ánum-| derivative.
    \nt +

    \se pabahtanumau
    \ps TA, mental final
    \twn |pabahtantam|
    \ge `he trusts in (him), has confidence in', +`to commit sb, make sb one's trust'
    \xv Kah nanawunuk kuppishagkinnittuonk pabuhtanumau Josephuh ut wunnutcheganit wame neh kobshagkinutcheh,...
    \xe And the keeper of the prison committed to Joseph's hand all the prisoners ...
    \so Gen.39.22
    \ng "entrusted"
    \nt +
    \xv Pabuhtanumau Goduh,...
    \xe He trusted in God;...
    \so Mt.27.43
    \nt +
    \xv ..., gentilsog nah woh uppabahtanumóuh.
    \xe ...; in him shall the Gentiles trust.
    \so Rom.15.12
    \nt +

    \xv ..., wadchan kittinneum n noh pabahtanumugquean.
    \xe ..., save thy servant that trusteth in thee.
    \so Ps.86.2; (M): |pabahtanumukquean|
    \xv Noh pabohtanumit ne peasik, nóh pabohtanumau wonk, ut ne mohsag,...
    \xe He that is faithful in that which is least is faithful also in much:...
    \so Lk.16.10
    \ng X subject bound? or middle reflexive? object?
    \nt +

    \se pabahtantam
    \ps inan. / TI1a
    \twn |pabahtanumau|
    \ge `he trusts (it), depends on (it)'

    \se pabahtanumwe
    \va -wáe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `faithfully'

    (|pâpahtantämwe|    C.)

    \se !|pabahtanumukquodt|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to be fithful' (i.e. "(so constituted as) to be trusted"?), `to be upright'
    \dv "verb of undergoing" (i.e. "passive" dispositional), as B.1962, 15.133, 299, to TA stem |pabahtanum-|. (This type is attested elsewhere.)
    \so s.119.86,137(M),138; Rev.22.6
    \xv Wame kuttinn∞waongash paubuhtanumukquodtash:...
    \xe All thy commandments are faithful:...
    \so Ps.119.86; (M): |pabahtanumukquatash|

\nt Follow up needed: examples of Lk.16.11,12; no sign of cognates.

\ge `thunder'
\dv [From a verb which signifies `to hear', `to be heard' (?). Pierson's Catechism (Quiripi) has |padak| `he heareth'. Cf. Cree |péytow-ayoo| `he hears him'; |péytum| `he hears it'. But see the next following verb.]
[NOTE. -- The bracketed part of this definition is marked "omit" in the manuscript.]

[Western Abenaki [abe] |pédañghiag8| `le foudre, tonnerre'.
Quiripi [qyp] |páddahquáhhum|    Pier.
Delaware [del] |peelhacquon| `it thunders'    Hkw., which Cass corrects to |paathoc'quon| `it begins to thunder' (from |paö| `to come', and |hoc'quon| `thunder'). [Is either correct?] Zeisb. has |ped hac quon| `it thunders'; |pen da quot| `it is heard'    Voc.26.
    Lp.A |petek8ahan. `tonnere'    M.antef.v.,100.]
    \nt +

\lx pagúanau
\va paguaN-
\va pagwunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 115
\ps v.t.an. / TA, applicative
\ge `he destroys (him)'; +`to cut sb off, to slay sb'
    \xv ..., kah matta pish wonk wame weyaus paguanoon nashpe nippe togmogkon,...
    \xe ...; neither shall all flesh be cut off any more by the waters of a flood;...
    \so Gen.9.11
    \ng ?X->3 negative absolute, or subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv pish nag mukineog ayeuuhkóne nen kah pish nushukquog, kah pish nen nuppaguanit, kah neek
    \xe ..., they shall gather themselves together against me, and slay me; and I shall be destroyed, I and my house.
    \so Gen.34.30
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nah uppaguanun nashpe mishe paguanóonk nô pajeh paguananonaóont,
    \xe ..., and [he] shall destroy them with a mighty destruction, until they be destroyed.'    Deut.7.23 { calqued cognate object, 3->3
    \so subordinative; X->3p t-subordinative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Ahqhinnean, toh kittinhennumun, ken Jesus ut Nazareth? kuppeam kuppaguasunnanónut? ...
    \xe ..., Let us alone; what have we to do with thee, thou Jesus of Nazareth? art thou come to destroy us? ...
    \so Lk.4.34
    \ng 2->1p t-subordinative
    \nt +

    \xv ..., pagwas neesuog nunnáumonuk,...
    \xe ..., Slay my two sons,...
    \so Gen.42.37
    \ng 2->3(p) imperative
    \nt +
    \xv Paguas naghog, woi God,...
    \xe Destroy thou them, O God,...
    \so Ps.5.10(M)
    \nt +

    \se paguatau
    \va pagwodtau
    \va pagwatau
    \nt !
    \va paguadtau
    \nt !
    \ps inan. / TI2
    \ge `he destroys (it)'
    \xv ..., sun kuppáguadtoh wame keihtotan ukquenassinneaóut napanna tahsuog?...
    \xe ...: wilt thou destroy all the city for lack of five?...
    \so Gen.18.28
    \ng 2->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Qut yeu pish kuttinheoneau, pish kuppaguatau wut-Altarsum∞uh,...
    \xe But thus shall ye deal with them; ye shall destroy their altars,...
    \so Deut.7.5
    \ng ?2->0 absolute; odd example: |Altar| seems to be of variable geder; 2s for 2p of source
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche nuppaguatauunnean yeu aiyeuonk. ...
    \xe For we will destroy this place,...
    \so Gen.19.13
    \ng 1p->0 objective
    \nt +

    \xv ..., asquam Jehovah paguatao∞k Sodom kah Gomorrah:...
    \xe ..., before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah,...
    \so Gen.13.10
    \ng 3->0 negative conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Onk nnih GOD paguatunk otanash mukoshquttaut. ...
    \xe And it came to pass, when God destroyed the cities of the plain,...
    \so Gen.19.29
    \ng 3->0 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Neane wutohtimóneash nish Jehovah paguatunkish ut anaquabeôg, neit pish kutushpunóneau,...
    \xe As the nations which the Lord destroyeth before your face, so shall ye perish;...
    \so Deut.8.20
    \ng 3->_0p_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv Papaquanne paguatok wame ayeuongash ...
    \xe Ye shall utterly destroy all the places,...
    \so Deut.12.2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Paguatau∞k yeu Temple, kah nishikquinnogkok nutómuhkinumun.
    \xe ..., Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.
    \so Jn.2.19

    \se paguateau
    \va pagwohteau
    \ps v.i. / AI, indefinite object final
    \ge `he is destroying, or is a destroyer'
    pl. |paguatoog| `they destroy, are destroyers'
    \nt (This was the name given to the Muhhekans of eastern Connecticut by neighboring tribes: |Pequattôog| `Pequots', "destroyers".)

    \se paguanuonk
    \va -uong(an
    \nt +
    \ps Verbal / NI
    \ge `destroying, destruction'
    \so Prov.15.11; 18.7; Is.59.7
    \xv ..., uttoh in paguanuongash wutayimun ut ohkeit.
    \xe ..., what desolations he hath made in the earth.
    \so Ps.46.8
    \nt +
    `pestilence'    Ps.91.6
\dv |pohq-| (|pogk-|) `to break, to divide'.
\cf pohqui

[Narragansett [xnt] |Paúquana.| `There is a slaughter.', |Pequttôog paúquanan.| `The Pequts are slaine.'    R.W.180/r.188.
Cree |púckwahtayoo| `he hates (him)'.]


\lx paguodche
\va pagwodche
\va paguodcheh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 115
\ps adv./ There is some tendency for it to co-occur with |woh|.
\ge `it may be, perhaps', +`peradventure'
\nt G&B.690 |paquachee| `perhaps'
\so El.Gr.22; Gen18.24,28-32
    "Of Doubting. |Pagwodche|, {It may be}. |Toh|, {It may be}."    El.Gr.22/268
    (|Ammiat, pogquâtche.| `Perhaps'    C.109/234.)

[Algonquian [alg] |pak8ash| `probablement'; +|PAKWAC| `apparemment, probablement'    Cq.324b.
    Cree |pakwanaw| etc. NI `Guesswork' etc.    Alb.E.147a.
    \nt +
Menominee [mez] |pakuanaw| `at a guess, at random, on the off chance; not knowing; off alone', |pakuano∙sew| `he is uninformed'    M.L.192-193.]

\lx pahchau
\va pauchau
\va póhchau
\va puhcháu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 115
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he turns aside, deviates'
    \xv ..., nupóhcham yeuyeu, nukkodnaumun yeu mishe unnaumanissuonk,...
    \xe ..., I will now turn aside, and see this great sight,...
    \so Ex.3.3
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jehovah nauont puhcháoh ukkodnaúmunnin,...
    \xe And when the Lord saw that he turned aside to see,...
    \so Ex.3.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah asse pahchau wutch mayut, kah au ohteuhkonit,...
    \xe ...: and the ass turned aside out of the way, and went into the field:...
    \so Num.22.23√

    \xv Qut nag pohchacheg en wonke ummayeuout,...
    \xe As for such as turn aside unto their crooked ways,...
    \so Ps.125.5(M); (E): |áoncheg|
    \nt +

[Delaware [del] |pachgechen| `where the road strikes off'; |pachgeen| `to turn out of the road'; +|páxkeew| AI `turn (off the road)'    Zeisb./+B&A.104-105; O'M.229a.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nepeskéssé, 3. pes.| `Je vais hors du chemin', |nepeské`ra, 3. peské`ré| `Je le perds'    R.106/441a.
WAbn. |beska-| `aside, to one side, branching off'    D.1.xxxiii,103-105.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |pakki[, paki]| `tantost egarement, manquer le chemin, ne le pas suivre, rompre, casser, enflure, douceur, repos, paix', |nipacki| `je ne suis pas le chemin, suis un sentier au pres du chemin, prend[s] un detour, m'egare'    M.418/246ab.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |peska:sit| AI `to leave or go off the trail or road'    DeB.67a.
Nask. |pischaaw| AI `she/he turns off the path to go by another route'    McK.&J.1.289a.]

\et H.2561 *paΘke∙wa AI `separate'; see G.1981, 39, 78 on the special Massachusett development of *sk to |hch| under palatalization, citing this form.


\lx pahheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 115
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `he waits for (him)'
    \xv nuppaih
    \xe I wait for (him)
    \so Ps.130.5

    \nt MN: noh pâhhit
    \ng suppositive |noh pâhhit| `he who waits'

    \xv Kah unnau nananuanutcheh, Yeu ut pahhinnean, onk wonk ná pajeh qushkeog,...
    \xe And he said unto the elders, Tarry ye here for us, until we come again unto you:...
    \so Ex.24.14
    \nt +

    \se pahtau
    \va pahto
    \ps v.t.inan. / TI2
    \ge `he waits for (it)', +`to stay'

    \se pahtussu
    \ps V.i.an. / AI, i-stem
    \ge `he is waiting', +`to be in expectation, to be ready, to linger, tarry'
    \so Gen.43.10; Ps.130.5; Lk.3.15; Acts 22.16; 1 Pet.3.20
    \nt +
    \xv Nuppaih Jehovah nukketeahogkou pahtussu:...
    \xe I wait for the Lord, my soul doth wait:...
    \so Ps130.5; (M) |pahtissu|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., pasukqut sepechequnehtog GOD, pahtussu ut ukkesukodtumash Noah,..
    \xe ..., when once the long-suffering of God waited in the days of Noah,...
    \so 1 Pet.3.20
    \nt +
    (|Pahts∞og.| `They wait, (vid. Stay,)'; |Nuppahtis, -up| `I stay, {or} did.', |Nuppahtsi@mun, -nônup.| `We stay {or} did'    C.83/214;77/210
    \xv Pahtsü wunnenchhuo@nat.
    \xe Ready to do good
    \so C.28/174.)
    \xv Nukquâshwap, nuppahtis moncheenat.
    \xe I am ready ({or} wait) to go
    \so C.71/206
    \nt +

    \nt MN: Wunninumunach noh pahtsit,...
    \ng suppositive |Wunninumunach noh pahtsit,...| `Blessed is he that waiteth,...'    Dan.12.12√
    \xv Kah kusseh tohwutch pahtusséan;...
    \xe And now why tarriest thou? ...
    \so Acts 22.16
    \ng 2 conjunct
    \nt +

    \xv Pahti@sish wutch nen.
    \xe Stay for me
    \so C.77/210
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +

    \se |pahtissuwonau| (M)
    \nt +
    \ps TA, |-ôN-| applicative
    \twn |pahtissowontam|
    \ge `to wait for, (up)on sb'
    \so Ps.33.2,37.7,9,34,59.9,62.1(M)
    \xv Nukketeahogkonun pahtissoowanau Jehovah:...
    \xe Our soul waiteth for the Lord:...
    \so Ps.33.20(M)
    \xv {Waj} ummenuhkesuonk pish kuppahtissuonish:...
    \xe Because of his strength will I wait upon thee:...
    \so Ps.59.9(M)
    \xv Nuppahti@ssuönat.
    \xe To wait for
    \so C.83/214

    \xv ...: qut pahtissoowonnoncheg Jehovah, pish wutahtauuneau ohke.
    \xe ; but those that wait upon the Lord, they shall inherit the earth.
    \so Ps.37.9

    \xv Anwohsinooous Jehovah, menuhke pahtissoowos:...
    \xe Rest in the Lord, and wait patiently for him:...
    \so Ps.37.7(M)

    \se |pahtissowontam| (M)
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, |-ôt-| applicative
    \twn |pahtissuwonau|
    \nt Remark: |-ont-| here represents the nasal vowel, as G&B 581, item 20.
    \ge `to wait for sth'
    \so Ps.39.7,52.9(M)
    \xv Kah yeuyeu Jehovah, teaguas nuppahtissoowontom?...
    \xe And now, Lord, what wait I for?...
    \so Ps.52.9(M)

    \se pahtsúonk
    \ps Verbal noun
    \ge `waiting, "forbearance"'
    \so Rom.2.4

\dv |pâ|.
\cf pâme

[Delaware [del] |pee soop| `he waited' (pret.)    Zeisb.
    Algonquian [alg] |PIH| `attendre, être en attente, dans l'expectative'    Cq.335b.]
    \nt +

\et H.2853-5: *pye∙he∙wa TA, *pye∙hta∙wa TI `wait for'

\lx pahkheau
\va pahkehheau

    \nt +

    \xe ..., and be clean,...
    \so Gen.35.2
    \ng 2p
    \nt +

    Adj.an. `clean, pure'

\lx pajeh
\va padjeh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 116
\ps adv. / PreV, PreN, conj.
\ge `until'; +`(un)to, while'; occasionally spatial
\nt G&B.688, s.v. |pache| `up to, as far as, until', P
    \xv yeu pajeh
    \xe until now
    \xv nó pajeh
    \xe until
    (|nâpaj|    C.)

    \xv Kah padjeh n naiyit ...
    \xe And while he lingered, ...
    \so Gen.19.16(E0&1)
    \ng 3 conjunct verb; (E2) corrupt
    \nt +
    \xv ...: yeuoh ∞sh∞oh wunneechanoh Ammon yeu pajeh kesukok.
    \xe ...: the same is the father of the children of Ammon, unto this day.
    \so Gen.19.38
    \nt +

    \nt Remark: |nô pajeh|, |nó pajeh| commonly governs a clause with either a t-subordinative or a conjunct verb. An independent verb seems quite rare.
    \nt +
\cf pâme

[Delaware [del] |petschi|; +`until, unto; until here, so far; (up to here. A.);    |peechi-| `here, to here, towards the speaker'    Zeisb.; B&A.114; O'M.232.]

    \xe ...And when ye had girded on every man his weapons of war, ye were ready to go up into the hill.

    \nt +

    \xe ...; and thou shalt quite take away their murmurings from me,...

\lx pa@kodchimau
\ve Well attested in NT.
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 116
\ps v.t.an. / TA, oral final
\ge `he condemns (him)', primarily, `disposes of, makes an end of'
    \xv Pogkodchummuönat.
    \xe To condemn', `To convince
    \so C.45/186.
    \ng On the first sense given, cf. the English doublet "convict", and the "convergence" seen in "conviction"; presumably "conclusive talk" in either case.

    \xv noh pakodchimit
    \xe he who condemns


\lx pakodchteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 116
\ps v.i. / TI2; a syncopated form of the sublemma (cf. Jn.5.36);
\nt Follow up needed: to be consolidated
\ge (inan.subj.) `it finishes, completes, or comes to an end';
    \ge  `to end, finish sth'
    \nt +
    \so Gen.2.2
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nesausuk audtashikqu[i]nukok pakodjteau GOD wutanakausuonk ne ayik,...
    \xe And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made;...'
    \so Gen.2.2
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    intensive |..., pakojteauunat panneusseonk,...| `..., to finish the transgression,...'    Dan.9.24√  { X->0 t-subordinative }; (M) |pakodchehtouunat|
    \xv ...: newutche anakausuonkash Wut∞shimau aninnumaiitcheh pakodjteauunat,...
    \xe ..., for the works which the Father hath given me to finish,...
    \so Jn.5.36√
    \ng X->0 t-subordinative
    pass. part. |..., kah asquam pakojteauun.| `..., and yet it is not finished.'    Ezra 5.16  { X->0 negative subordinative }

    \se pogkodchehteau
    \ps TI2
    \ge `he akes complete, finishes'
    \nt The causative form ... is of more frequent occurrence.
    \xv ..., nuppogkodchehteoh nuppummayeuonk,...
    \xe ..., I have finished my course,...
    \so 2 Tim.4.7
    \ng 1->0 absolute

[Del |pakantschiechton| `he fulfills, completes (it)'    Zeisb.]

\lx pakodtittum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 116
    \nt +
\ps TI1b
\ge `to condemn sth'
\so Mt.12.41,42
    \xv Missinninnuog Nineve, pish ómohkeog ∞sittum∞onganit ayeuuhkonittue yeu pometuonk, kah pish uppakodtuttimunneau,...
    \xe The men of Nineveh shall rise in judgment with this generation, and shall condemn it:...

    \ge `sentence (of sth)'

    \xv ..., kah nag pish kukkuhk∞tomungquog pakodttittumwu wussittum∞onk.
    \xe ...; and they shall shew thee the sentence of judgment:'    Deut.17.9 { with printer
    \so s error }


\lx pakodtittum∞onk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 116
    \nt +
\ps NI
\ge `proposition'
\so Log.Pr., passim
    {Second part teacheth us bindingly to compose Notions, to make every kinde of Proposition.}
    |Nahohtoeu chippai kukkuhk∞tomunkqun moappissue moehteauunat wahittum∞ukish, ayimunat nishnoh eiyane pakodtittum∞onk.|    Log.Pr.8/22
\dv By process/product metonymy, the verbal noun to !|pakodtittum| TI1b "to cause sth to be complete" (attested sense: `to condemn sth'), hence: "what is caused to be complete, completed"? (Quite speculative at present, in the absence of a supply of verbs in |-ittum|.) See Miner Hist.Linguistica 1 (1974), 176 for the basic connection.)

\lx pâme
\va paáme
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 116
\ps may he regarded as a defective verb used separately as an auxiliary or in composition with other verbs to denote progress, continuance, or duration of action. It is related to, if not formed from, the indefinitive particle.
    |páme|, |paámu|, is the suppos., |pummeu| the indic. form.
\cf pômantam

[MARGINAL NOTE. -- "Rewrite this. cf. |pomantam|; |pomohhom|; |pomushau|. |ash pummeu|, 2 K.14.4, see |ash|."]

\et To the prolific family *pem- `along, "continuing"', e.g. much of H.2588-2645

\lx pamítchuan
\va -utchuwan
\va -∞wan
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 116
\ps v.i.impers. / II
\ge `it flows or runs' (as water, irrespective of direction or force)
\ps As n.
\ge `running water'
\so Prov.5.15

    (|onatuh nippeit pamuttchuwohk| `as waters which run,'    Mass.Ps.,Ps.58,7)

    Imperat. 3d pers. |pomitchuwadj| `let (the waters) be dispersed abroad'    Prov.5.16

\nt To review: From |pâme| (q.v.) and |wutcheu| `it proceeds from'. More immediately, from |pomushau| `he walks, moves', with the introduction of the hard |ch|, denoting involuntary or inanimate activity.

[Cree |pimmíchewun| `it flows', as water    Howse 49.]
\et H.2617 *pemiciwanwi II `flow'

[Delaware [del] |palliwi| `elsewhere, otherwise'; |palliaeu| `he goes away, goes wrong'    Zeisb.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nebareniñ|, |nebarenemen| `Je le manque, je ne puis l'attraper, je ne puis le prendre'    R.330/482b.
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |PAN-| `échappé de ...'    Cq.327a.
Cree +|PAT| (rac.) `manquer, se tromper, manquer son coup'; |Pu'ttuhum| `He misses it, he misses the mark, he misses the trail'...    Lac.D.543b-544b; Frs.443ab.
Fx. |pAn-| `lose, miss; fail to hear; miss stepping upon'; |panahwe∙wa, panahamwa| `he misses hitting him, it by tool'...    Mch.St.648a; Fx.L.137.
K. |pan-| `miss, fail to contact'...    V.100.
Menominee [mez] |panε∙nε∙w, panε∙nam| `he lets him, it slip or drop from his hand',...    M.L.193.
Miami |pal-| `miss, fail to contact'    B&C.102ab.
Shawnee [sjw] |pal-| `FAILURE THROUGH DELAY'    D.-V. 90.
WAbn. |bal-| `wrong, erroneous'    D.1.xxxii, 71-73.]

\et H.2549-2555 *paΘ- `lose, miss, ruin'

    \ge `wrong-going, "perverseness"'

\lx pann∞wau

    \se pann∞wae
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `falsely, deceitfully'

    \se pann∞waonk
    \ps N. verbal
    \ge `wrong saying, a lie'
    \so Ps.7.14; Rev.21.27

    \se pann∞waenin
    \ps agent.vb.
    \ge `a liar'
\dv |panne| and |n∞wau| `he speaks'.

\lx pannu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 117
\cf panne

    \se |pannuppeyeu∞|
    \nt +
\ps AI
\twn |pannuppeyeu∞|, II
\ge `to be perfect, without blemish'
\so Lev., passim, Mt.19.21, Jas.1.4
    \xv Kah tohneit pas∞ont lamboh wutche wussephausuonk, wutche matcheseae sephausuonk, pish pas∞au squoshimwoh pannuppeyeu∞oh.
    \xe And if he bring a lamb for a sin offering, he shall bring it a female without blemish.
    \so Lev.4.32
    \xv Qut mánunnaiyeuonk uppannupanakausuonk óhtauitch, onk woh kuppannuppeyeumw∞, kah kummississimw∞, wanne teag quenauhikk∞un.
    \xe But let patience have her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing.
    \so Jas.1.4

    \xv ..., uttoh unne nomposhimwoh asuh squoshimwoh, pish mag∞ pannuppeyeuunutcheh, ut anáquabit Jehovah.
    \xe ...; whether it be a male or female, he shall offer it without blemish before the Lord.
    \so Lev.3.1
    \xv ..., Kodtantaman pannuppeyeu∞un, monchish, kah magish ne adtahshadchassuwaan, kah aninnumau matchekuog,...
    \xe ..., If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor,...
    \so Mt.19.21

    \se pannuppeyeu∞
    \ps II
    \twn |pannuppeyeu∞|, AI
    \ge `to be perfect'
    \so Rev.3.2, Heb.9.11
    \xv ...: newutche matta namteauohkutanakausuongash pannuppeyeu∞ash ut anaquabit GOD.
    \xe ...: for I have not found thy works perfect before God.
    \so Rev.3.2

    \xv ...: nashpe ánue mohsag kah pannuppeyeuuk pummuwuttauwáekommuk mat waj kesteómuk menutcheganit,...
    \xe ..., by a greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands,...
    \so Heb.9.11

\lx papaume

\et Wolfart 1973 (6.221: 66a) lists the Cree cognate |papäm-| `about' as a reduplicated derivative of the initial |pim-| `along'. with a gloss `about'. On the form of the reduplication, compare B.1962, 21.22, 429: to Men. |pεm-|, |papa∙m-|.

\lx paponaumsû
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 118
\ps n. / NA
\ge "a winter fish, which comes up in the brooks and rivulets; some call them frost fish," etc.,
\so R.W.105
    pl. +|og|
\nt The `tom-cod' or `frost-fish' of the markets (Gadus [Morrhua] tomcodus,
Mitch.). Tacaud, the specific name given by Cuvier, may be from |tohkoí| (Narr. |tahkì|) `when it is cold', `cold-weather fish', or Narr. |taquáttin| `frost, it is frozen', `frost-fish', but certainly does not signify `plenty fish' in any Algonquian dilect.
\dv |poponáe| and |aumsû|, dimin.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |ap8nañmes8ak| `petits [poissons] de la mer'.]

\lx pask∞gun tahshe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 118
\ps num. / PreN, PreV
\ge `nine'
    pl. an. |pask∞gun tahsúog|
    inan. | -- tahshinash| (or |tohsúash|)    El.Gr.14
    (|pasuk∞gun|    Lk.17.17)

    \se nabo pask∞gun
    \ge `nineteen'
    \nt (as an adj. varied by |tahshé| (or |tohsú|) in pl.an. and inan.    2 K.25.8)
    \so El.Gr.14/261
    \xv Nabo paskoogun.
    \xe 19
    \nt +

    \se pask∞gun tahshinchag
    \ps Number
    \nt +
    \ge [`nine hundred' { erroneous! }] `ninety'
    \so El.Gr.15/261
    \xv Paskoogun tahshinchag kodtog, kodtash.
    \xe 90
    \so El.Gr.15/261
    \nt +

    \se |pask∞gun tahshinchage|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \xv Kah Abraham pask∞gun tahshinchage kodtumwohkom kah pask∞gun,...
    \xe And Abraham {was} ninety years old and nine,...
    \so Gen.17.24
    \nt +

    \se |pasuk∞gun tahshe pasuk∞w-|
    \nt +
    \ps Number
    \ge `nine hundred'
    \so Gen.5.5,...; Judg.4.3
    \xv Kah wame kesukodtash uppomantamoonk Adam, pasuk∞gun tahshit pasuk∞we kodtumwae, kah nabo shwinchag,...
    \xe And all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred and thirty years:...
    \so Gen.5.5
    \ng ?attributive
    \xv ...: newutche ohto pasak∞gun tahshe pasuk∞∞ash moushogque chariotsash:...
    \xe ...: for he had nine hundred chariots of iron:...
    \so Judg.4.3
    \ng attributive, 0p

\ps Adv.
\ge `near by'
\so Gen.19.20; Mt.24.33
    \xv ..., kah na wutch pahs∞∞ Ephrath, kah Rachel nechau,...
    \xe ...; and there was but a little way to come to Ephrath: and Rachel travailed,...
    \so Gen.35.16
    \ng (E0) |pas∞|
    \nt +

[Chip. |bésho| `near by'    Bar.
Western Abenaki [abe] |péss8t| `c'est proche'.
Delaware [del] |peschot|    Zeisb.
    Algonquian [alg] |PECO-| `court, (se dit du temps et de l'espace)', |PECOTC| `près'    Cq.331b-332a.]
    \nt +


\lx pas∞au
\va pasau
\va pás∞au
\va pas∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 119
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `he brings (him) to', +`to bring, carry sb (forth, into, out of, (un)to)'
\nt G&B.691 |passou| TA
    \xv Onk uppas∞woh poquadchik...
    \xe And he brought him forth abroad,...'    Gen.15.5  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ...? tohwutch yeu unnéhheog, kuppás∞umun wutch Egypt,
    \xe ...? wherefore hast thou dealt thus with us, to carry us forth out of Egypt?
    \so Ex.14.11
    \ng 2->1p
    \nt +
    \xv Sun peásin yeu kuppas∞innean wutch ohkeit, ne tomogkok sogkodtunk kah hony,...
    \xe Is it a small thing that thou hast brought us up out of a land that floweth with milk and honey,...
    \so Num.16.13
    \ng 2->1p; TA+O pattern of G&B 531--why? c.f. ib., 16.14 |matta kuppas∞∞mun| (1&2)
    \nt +
    \xv Neit wussantimomoh pish pas∞uk wussittumwáenúut, kah pish uppas∞oh ut squoantamut,...
    \xe Then his master shall bring him unto the judges; he shall also bring him to the door,...'    Ex.21.6 { 3'->3 absolute, with subsequent characteristic switch of obviation to 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish kuppas∞che pás∞ wunnaumonuh, kâh kutogquánóog hogk∞ongash.
    \xe And thou shalt bring his sons, and clothe them with coats:
    \so Ex.40.14
    \nt +
    \xv uppas∞uh
    \xe he brings him
    \so Lk.10.34
    \xv Onk kukkuttinaog missinninneuh,..., kah wunuhkukauouh, kah wutohqunóuh, onk uppas∞óuh ken∞nuttuonganit.
    \xe And they stirred up the people,..., and came upon him, and caught him, and brought him to the council.'    Acts 6.12  { 3p->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +

    \xv Pas∞wudt, an∞team∞ wohshimunutche wuhhog ...
    \xe When she was brought forth, she sent to her father-in-law,...
    \so Gen.38.25
    \ng X->3
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Peyôóg ohkeit ne pas∞unog.
    \xe ..., When ye come into the land whither I bring you,
    \so Num.15.18
    \ng 1->2p
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d pl. |pas∞k| `bring ye hither'    Lk.14.21

\nt This is the primary (and perhaps the only) signification of the verb: "near them", `bring them near'.
\dv |pâs∞| `near'.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nepés8añ| `Je l'apporte'    R.28/385b.
    Cree |Pä'sewäo| TA `he brings him'; |pesowew|, id.    Frs.411a; Alb.E.160a.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |péeshùweew| TA `bring s.o., bring s.t. animate'    O'M.234b.

\et G.1982, 5.1.1, 30 *pye∙⌠iwe∙wa, with fn.73; also G.1979, 4.23, 69.

\lx pás∞sukau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 119
\ps v.i. / AI
    \nt Remark: If this exists, cf. B.1962, 15.227, 313 |pi∙sεhkaw| AI `he, it moves hither', to the corporal final
    \nt +
\ge `he goes or comes near, he approaches'

    \se !|pas∞suhkom|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1, corporal final
    \ge `to come nigh, near (un)to sth'
    \ps Ex.16.9; Lev.21.17,18,21.23,24,28; Deut.2.19,20.10,25.1; Josh.3.4,8.5,9.8; Acts 10.9,22.6
    \xv ...; noh matta pish pas∞sukom∞ sephausineat uppetukqunnunk um-Manitt∞moh.
    \xe ..., let him not approach to offer the bread of his God.
    \so Lev.21.17
    \ng 3(->0) negative absolute (despite AV imperative)

    \nt MN: noh pas∞sukog
    \ng suppositive |noh pas∞sukog| `he who comes near'    Num.1.51; Lk.7.12
    \ng 3->0 participle
    \xv ... moncheon, pas∞sukomon Damascus, puhshaquodt,...
    \xe ..., as I made my journey, and was come nigh unto Damascus about noon,...
    \so Acts 22.6
    \ng 1 subjunctive
    \nt +

    \xv ..., pas∞sukom∞k anaquabit Jehovah,...
    \xe ..., Come near before the LORD:...
    \so Ex.16.9
    \ng 2p(->0) imperative

    \se |pas∞sukauau|, !|pas∞suhkauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, corporal final
    \ge `to come, go near unto sb, to keep fast by sb'
    \so Gen.18.23,20.4,27.27,33.3,37.18,44.18,45.4; Deut.30.14; Ruth 2.23
    \nt Remark: cf. |paswuhkauau| -- probably related through variant forms of the initial, here the initial |pas∞t-|, assibilated by the corporal final |-uhk-|, as B.1962, 16.122, p.352: "preceding |t| is replaced by |s|", and 19.25, p.419.
    \xv Kah Jakob pas∞sukauau Isaakoh ∞shoh, kah ukquttinoh, kah n∞wau, unnont∞waonk wuttinnont∞waonk Jakob, qut menutchegash wunnutchegash Esau.
    \xe And Jacob went near unto Isaac his father; and he felt him, and said, The voice is Jacob's voice, but the hands are the hands of Esau.'    Gen.27.22  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., onk pish kuppas∞sukah,...
    \xe ..., and thou shalt be near unto me,...
    \so Gen.45.10
    \ng 2->1 indicative
    \xv Qut wuttinn∞waonk kuppas∞sukongqun,...
    \xe But the word is very nigh unto thee,...
    \so Deut.30.14
    \ng 0->2 objective (G&B.520)

    \xv Qut Abimelech asquam pas∞sukauonk ...
    \xe But Abimelech had not come near her:...'    Gen.20.4  { 3->3
    \so negative conjunct; Geneva "not yet" }
    \xv ..., onk nenaan, asquam pas∞sukunk∞og nunnushôun.
    \xe ...: and we, or ever he come near, are ready to kill him.
    \so Acts 23.15
    \ng 3->1p negative conjunct

    imperat. |pas∞sukiitch| `let him come near to me'    Is.50.8  { 3->1 imperative }
    \xv Kah Joseph unnau wematoh, pas∞sukiegk k∞wehquetumonumw∞, kah uppas∞sukauóuh kah n∞wau Nen Joseph kematou noh mag∞ógkup en Egypt.
    \xe And Joseph said unto his brethren, Come near to me, I pray you. And they came near. And he said, I am Joseph your brother, whom ye sold into Egypt.'    Gen.45.4  { 2p->1 imperative; 3p->3
    \so objective }

\lx pas∞tshau
\va pas∞che-au
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 119
\ps v.i. / AI, |pas∞t-| + |-uhshau|
\ge `he goes or comes near, approaches'
\so 2 Sam.18.25
    \xv ..., onk pas∞tshaog kod pohquanumwog squoant.
    \xe ..., , and [they] came near to break the door.
    \so Gen.19.9
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh pa∞tshadt
    \ng suppositive |noh pa∞tshadt| `he who comes near'    Num.3.10,38

    \se |pas∞tsham∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to draw nigh'
    \so Gen.47.29
    \xv Kah ahquompi pas∞tshám∞ Israel m∞che wunnupp∞onk,...
    \xe And the time drew nigh that Israel must die:...
    \so Gen.47.29

\nt |pas∞tshau| expresses merely the fact of approach or proximity; |pás∞sukau|, the action of going or coming, continuing to approach.

\lx pas∞waheau

    \nt +
\ps TA, causative
\ge `to bring sb forth'
\nt Remark: The form is suspect, apparently built to a TA stem, and, as a double transitive, does not seem to have the meaning required, viz "cause sb to binrg sb" or the like; at present I can find no other instance as a translation of "bring forth".
\so Gen.1.24

    \xv ..., Pas∞waheonch ohke pomantamwaeu oáos,...

\lx paspishau
\va pashpishau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 119
\ps v.i. / AI, |pas(h)p-| + |-ushsh-á-|
\ge `it breaks through, it bursts forth, blossoms', (after |nepauz|, `the sun') `rises', +also without overt subject
\so Eccl.1.5
    \xv Nepauz paspishop ut ohkeit, Lot petutteadt Zoar.
    \xe The sun was risen upon the earth when Lot entered into Zoar.

    \ng 3 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah qushkodteadt Peniel pashpishau,...
    \xe And as he passed over Penuel the sun rose upon him,...
    \so Gen.32.31
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +

    suppos.part. |paspishont| `(when rising,) sunrise'  Eccl.1.5; Num.21.11; Ps.50.1  { 3 conjunct }
    \xv Qut nepauz pashpishont, ...
    \xe And when the sun was up, ...

    and of the rising of the `day-star'    2 Pet.1.19

    \ge `sun rising'

    \se papashpishau

    pl. |-aog|  2 Sam.2.29
\dv Freq. or intens. of |péshaui| `it blossoms, bursts forth'

[Narragansett [xnt] |Páspisha.| `It is Sunne-rise.'    R.W.62.]√

\et G.1981, 18, 64: PA *pacpi?le∙wa `he (sun) rises', G.1974, 106a: *pacp-`through (something difficult or resistant)', with comparative evidence.

\lx passehtham
\va -tahham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 119
    \nt +
\ps TI1a, mechanical final
\ge `to cleave sth'
\so Judg.15.19; Ps.78.15,141.7; Is.48.21
    \xv ..., pasehtham wonk qussuk, kah nippe sohwhutchuan.
    \xe ...: he clave the rock also, and the waters gushed out.
    \so Is.48.21

    \xv ..., onatuh howan tamuhtahog kah passehtahhog mehtukquash woskeche ohkeut.
    \xe ..., as when one cutteth and cleaveth wood upon the earth.
    \so Ps.141.7(M)

    \se papassehtham
    \va -tahham
    \nt Remark: See also |pahpassehteau|, T.115b.
    \ps TI1a, reduplicated
    \ge `to cleave sth'
    \so Gen.22.3; 1 Sam.6.14; Eccles.10.9
    \xv ..., kah papassetaham wuttuhqunash wutche chikohsue sephausuonk,...
    \xe ..., and [he] clave the wood for the burnt offering,...
    \so Gen.22.3
    \ng 3->0 absolute

    \xv ..., kah noh papassehthog wuttuhqunash pish nunnukquodtut appu.
    \xe ...; and he that cleaveth wood shall be endangered thereby.
    \so Eccles.10.9

    \se pahsehtahwhau
    \ps TA, mechanical final |-hw-|
    \ge `to cleave sb'
    \so Job 16.13
    \xv Uppepemeuwaeneumoh n∞weenuhkunk, pahsehtahwhau nutt∞unissoh:...
    \xe His archers compass me round about, he cleaveth my reins asunder,...
    \so Job.16.13

\et The situation appears to be complicated, with extensions and different vowels. Hewson has a set *pi∙w-, roughly "pieces", H.2984-2794, and what looks like an extended form *pi∙?s-, roughly "in pieces", of sizes from small to large. (Size may be relevant, if the following belong here: Alg. |PISA-, PISI-| `être en menus morceaux', |PIW-| `menu; de peu de valeur', Cq.346a, 350b-351a.) The Eastern languages tend to show similar consonantism with a lower vowel. Investigation needed.

FENDRE, initial: |pes-|; Del., O'M. 602ab: s.v. `split', initial |pas-|, e.g. |pasúsheew| TA `cut s.t. animate in two,' etc.; Ojib., Bar.351a-352a: |Pâss-|, |Pass-|, P&G.119: |pa:ss-| `split, break, crack'; K., Vrh.98 |paaΘ-| `split'. Vowel?
