\lx pasuk
\va pásuk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 119
\ps num. / PreN; also as NA `one'
\ge `one'
\nt G&B.691
\so Ex.12.46; Judg.9.2; Eccl.4.8,10
\nt In his Grammar, Eliot gives as the numeral adnoun `one', |nequt|, only.
    \xv Onk pasuk peyau pohquohhogkup,...
    \xe And there came one that had escaped,...
    \so Gen.14.13
    \ng Vlg.: "et ecce unus qui evaserat..."
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nishnoh pasuk wosketomp kenugke kenaau pish quoshqusausu.
    \xe ... every man child among you shall be circumcised.
    \so Gen.17.10
    \nt +

    \se pasuk∞∞
    \nt Remark: slightly revised entry
    \nt +
    \ps AI, numeral verb, with some examples included of nominal (attributive) type
    \ge `sb is one'; homophonous with form meaning "one hundred".
    \nt G&B.691
    \xv ..., Kusseh missinninnúog pasuk∞∞og, kah wame pasuk unnontt∞waonk:...
    \xe ..., Behold, the people is one, and they have all one language;...
    \so Gen.11.6
    \nt +
    pl. |..., kah yeug nishuog pasuk∞∞og.| (AI) `...: and these three are one.'    1 Jn.5.7√

    \se |pasukquinnu|, |pasukquinne|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `one'
    \so Gen.41.22; Deut.28.7,25

    \se |pasukquinnu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps ?AI, numeral verb (This must remain doubtful, given the prenominal position of the examples.)
    \twn |pasukquinnu∞|, II, v.i.
    \ge `to be one'
    \xv ..., kah nag pìsh pasukqunnu∞ weyaus∞
    \xe ...; and they shall be one flesh.
    \so Gen.2.24
    \ng number and syntax unclear
    \xv ..., kah na pish pasukqunnú∞ shepseh chippinnútunk, kah pasuk∞∞ nanawunont shepsoh,
    \xe ...; and there shall be one fold, and one shepherd.
    \so Jn.10.16; (M) |passuk|...|passuk|
    \nt +
    \xv Onk monacheg wanamptogig pasukqunu∞ wuttahhou kah pasuk∞∞ keteahogkou, onk matta pasuk n∞waou ne teaguas ne ohtonk, yeu nutahtauonk,...
    \xe And the multitude of them that believed were of one heart and of one soul: neither said any of them that aught of the things that he possessed was his own;...
    \so Acts 4.32
    \ng PreN?
    \nt +

    \se |pasukquinnu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II; also NI derivative, Eph.4.13?
    \twn |pasuk∞∞|, AI, v.s.
    \ge `to be one'
    \so Gen.41.25; Jn.10.16; Acts 4.2; 1 Cor.12.19
    \xv ...: wuttinnugquom∞onk Pharaoh pasukquinnú∞,...
    \xe ..., The dream of Pharaoh is one:...
    \so Gen.41.25
    \xv Upputtugquiyeúm∞ash, kah ne adtáhshontugquinogok pish pasukquinnú∞ash,...
    \xe Their knops and their branches shall be of the same:...
    \so Deut.25.36
    \ng 0p
    \xv Noh pajeh wame kuppeyonanónut ut pasukquinnu∞ut wunnamptam∞onk,...
    \xe Till we all come in the unity of the faith,...
    \so Eph.4.13
    \ng locative, perhaps as multiplicative "onefold"
    \xv ..., nashpe wabesuonk kah nunnukshaonk, pasukqunnu∞ut kuttahh∞woash,...
    \xe ..., with fear and trembling, in singleness of your heart,...
    \so Eph.6.5

    \xv Kah wame pasukquinneú∞∞k pompuhchai, uttiyeuwoh muhhog.
    \xe But if they were all one member, where were the body?
    \so 1 Cor.12.19
    \ng _0_ participle

    \se |pasukquehheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA causative
    \ge `to be joined to sb', i.e. "to be one with sb"
    \so Eph.5.31
    \xv Newutche yeu, wosketomp pish nukkonau ∞shoh kah okasoh, kah pish pasukquehheau ummittamwussoh, kah nag neeswe pish pasuk weyaus.
    \xe For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and shall be joined unto his wife, and they two shall be one flesh.
    \so Eph.5.31

    \se pasuk∞onk
    \ps Verbal
    \ge `being one, unity, oneness'

    \se -pasuk∞og
    \ge with |nequt| prefixed, `one hundred'
    inan. |-k∞ash|
    \so El.Gr.15

    \se |pasuk∞we|, |pasuk∞e|
    \nt +
    \ps ?PreN, PreV
    \ge `hundred (times)'
    \xv Kah Noah nequtta tahshit pasuk∞we kodtumwohkom,...
    \xe And Noah was six hundred years old...
    \so Gen.7.6
    \ng PreV
    \xv Tokonogque matcheseaenin nequt pasuk∞e matcheseit,...
    \xe Though a sinner do evil an hundred times,...
    \so Eccl.8.12
    \ng PreV

\nt See Pickering's note on |nequt| and |pasuk| in the reprint of Eliot's Grammar (2 Mass.Hist.Coll.IX), p. xlv. Cotton made this distinction: "nequt, a thing that is past; pasuk, a thing in being."
This Heckewelder considered a mistake, yet it was not without some foundation. |pasuk| denotes unity and completeness, one by itself, and without reference to a series; |nequtta| (its ordinal is |negonne| `first') appears to have the same base as |nukkonne| `old, discarded, left behind' [cf. |nukkonau| `he leaves (him) behind'], and so `first in order of time'; but if this distinction was not already obsolete in the time of Eliot and Williams it does not appear to have been observed by either.

[Mah. "páschuk is the true Mahicanni word for one"    Hkw.
Narragansett [xnt] |pâwsuck|    R.W. (who gives also |nquít| `one').
Western Abenaki [abe] |pézek8|, inan. |pézek8n| `one' (but |nequt| or its equivalent is found in |nek8dañs| [= |nequtta tashe|] `six'; |neg8dañnkáo| `eleven'; |neg8da`teg8^é| `one hundred', etc.)    Rasles.
Chip. |ba-shick| and |nin-god-juáh| (or |ning o dwa|)    Sch.II,211,213,216. "Before substantives signifying measure of time or other things, ... instead of |bejig| [|bashick|], we say |ningó|."    Bar.Gr.433. |pázhig| `one'; |pázhegoo| `he is one'    Jones.
Cree |péyak|, |péyakoo| `he is one or alone'; |péyakootow| (inan.) `he uniteth'    Howse.]

\et G.1974, 113a, G.1981, 57: *pe∙⌠ekwi `one'; Rh&C.183.


\lx pasukqueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Eliot has forms of |neepau| where Mayhew uses this verb.
\ps AI
\ge `to arise'
\so Mk.10.1; Jn.11.31,13.4,14.31(M)
    \xv KAh pasukqueu na wutch, kah peyau ohkeit Judea ogkomáe Jordan:...
    \xe And he arose from thence, and cometh into the coasts of Judea by the farther side of Jordan:...
    \so Mk.10.1
    \xv ..., ne nawahhittit Mary kunnuppe passukque, kah suhham,...
    \xe ..., when they saw Mary that she rose up hastily, and went out,...
    \so Jn.11.31(M)

    \xv ... Passukqueg, yeu wutch monchetuh.
    \xe ...: Arise, let us go hence.
    \so Jn.14.31(M)
    \ng 2p imperative

[Algonquian [alg] |PASIKWI| `se lever de son siège', w. fn.1 "Ce verbe se dit du mouvement par lequel on passe de la posture d'assis à celle debout. Se lever du lit, se lever quand on est couché, s'exprime par un mot tout différent, le verbe WANICKA. ...'    Cq.330ab
Cree |Pusi'koo| `He arises (from sitting), he stands up'; x |PASIKOW| `il se lève, étant assis'    Frs.440a; Lac.D.537b.
Fx. |pasekwi∙wa| `he arises'    Fx.L.138.
Ill. ε |Nipassig8i| `je me leve, me mets debout'    Gr.441/257b.
Lp.A |passik8is| `Leve toy'    D.14,62,114.
Mun. |pàs@'kwi∙w| `he gets up (from sitting)'    G.1982.40.
Shawnee [sjw] |paΘekw-| `ARISE',|paΘekwi| `he gets up'    D.-V.89.]

\et S. no.14, p.312 *pasekwi∙wa AI `to arise, get up from one's seat', H.2542


\lx pasukquhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
    \nt +
\ps TA, corporal final
\ge `to rouse sb up'

    \xe ...; who shall rouse him up?'    Gen.49.9  { 3->3
    \so objective }


\lx pasukquinnu
\va pasukqunnu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
    \nt +
\nt Remark: This may well be identical--fairly certainly homophonous--to the forms with the final |-quinne/u| used for day counts, T+.139a; cf. also the numeral verb |pasukquinnu∞| s.v. |pasuk|--so the locative sense could simply be contextual, deriving from the spatial expression that is modified.
\ps PreV (adv.), PreV
\ge `one place'
\so Gen.1.10; Eccl.3.20,6.6; Acts 2.1; 1 Cor.11.20,14.23
    \xv ... moém∞idj nippe ut agwu kesukquash pasukqunnu,...
    \xe ..., Let the waters be gathered together in one place,...
    \so Gen.1.10
    \xv Wame auog pasukquinnu,...
    \xe All go unto one place;...
    \so Eccl.3.20
    \xv ..., nag wame moappuog pasukqunnu∞ wuttohhou.
    \xe ..., they were all with one accord in one place.
    \so Acts 2.1
    \ng (E1) |wutta[hh]ou|, cf. Gen, AV "accord(e)"; PreN, representing the first "one"?
    \xv Newutche moeu peyôog ut pasukquinnu ayeuonganit,...
    \xe When ye come together therefore into one place,...
    \so 1 Cor.11.20
    \ng PreN

[WAbn. |bazegwenook| 0 conj. `in one place, on the same spot'    D.1.83.]


\lx pasukqut

\ge `once'

\lx paswauwamau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge `to be near of kin unto sb'
\so Lev.25.25, Ruth 2.20
    \xv ..., wosketomp kuppaswauwômukqun, pasuk noh nahohtoe kuttinnunkumoun.
    \xe ..., The man is near of kin unto us, one of our next kinsmen.
    \so Ruth 2.20

    \xv ..., noh paswauwamont,, pish peyau, kah pish man∞hom,...
    \xe ..., and if any of his kin come to redeem it,...
    \so Lev.25.25

\nt Remark: There is another form, slightly more frequent, !|pas∞tauwomau|, apparently with the longer form of the initial in |-t|. See e.g Lev.18.6,12,13, 20.19, 21.2, Ruth 3.9.

\et There are related forms pointing to a root |(-)ôwam-| (PA *a∙we∙m ?), found in clear initial position in e.g. Gen.24.40,41 |nutawamôtu| `my kindred', Lk.14.12 |auwamatcheg| `thy kinsmen', Lk.21.16 |auwamógig| `kinsfolk'. See also |auwam|, T+.19b. In other languages, compare B.1962, 16.13, 332-333, M.L.53: |ena∙wε∙mε∙w TA `he is related to him'; B. Fox lexicon, ed. G.,52,60: |inawe∙me∙wa| `he is related to him so'; Cq.72b: |∙AWEMA| `frère, soeur. Ce mot se dit de rère à soeur, et de soeur à frère;'... "Le sens du mot AWEMA devient plus général, si on lui adjoint une préformante: |Nind inawema|, `je lui suis parent;". The occurrence of this root and then the root |-unk(w)-| in the same verse (Ruth 2.20) as an apparent strengthening suggests either that there is not much difference between the meanings, or that at least one of the terms was not being used strictly. See also the reference to Goddard and Bragdon's discussion under the lemma |auwam|.


\lx paswauwátúog
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
\ps v.i. (pl.) / AI
    \dv Probably reciprocal to the preceding TA verb, with loss of |-m-| before reciprocal suffix (G&B item 15, p. 580).
    \nt +
\ge `they are near of kin'
    `they are her near kinswomen'    Lev.18.17 { probably reciprocal }
\dv |pâs∞| and |weetauoog|, `they are related', lit. `they live together'

\dv |pâs∞| and |ohteau| `se habet'.

\lx paudtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
\ps v.t. / TI2
\ge `he brings (it)'
\so 1 K.8.32; Esth.3.9
    (|patou| `he brings'    C.)
    `he cometh with'    2 Sam.18.27

    \nt MN: paudtunk
    \ng suppositive |paudtunk| `when he brings'    Ps.126.6
    (|pautunk|    Mass.Ps.)

    imperat. |paudtaush| `bring thou'    Amos.4.1
    (|patauish|    C.)

    \se paudtóonk
    \ps Vbl.
    \ge `a bringing in'
    \so Heb.7.19

    \se |paudtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final |-aw-|
    \ge `to bring sth/sb unto/upon sb'
    \so frequent
    \xv ..., kah nag uppaudtaôunuh Adam ...
    \xe ...; and brought {them} unto Adam ...'    Gen.2.19  { 3->3'+3
    \so -pro objective }
    \xv ..., onk woh Jehovah uppaudtauon Abrahamoh ne anomp.
    \xe ..., that the LORD may bring upon Abraham, that which he hath spoken of him.'    Gen.18.19  { 3->3
    \so +0-def }
    \xv ..., k∞wehquetumauunumw∞ nag kuppaudtaunnaóont kenaau,...
    \xe ... let me, I pray you, bring them out unto you,...
    \so Gen.19.8
    \ng 1->2p+3 t-subordinative
    \xv ... onk woh kuppaudtah kah nutass∞tamóonk ummishe matchesenat? ...
    \xe ..., that thou hast brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin? ...
    \so Gen.20.9
    \ng 2->1+0 absolute
    \xv ...: neit woh nuppaudtau nuhhog matánittuonk, qut matta wunánittuonk.
    \xe ...; and I shall bring a curse upon me, and not a blessing.
    \so Gen.27.12
    \ng 1->3+0 absolute
    \xv Noh woh nehnégikáuut, matta kuppaudtauun∞un,...
    \xe That which was torn of beasts I brought not unto thee;...
    \so Gen.31.39
    \ng 1->2+0 negative objective
    \xv ...: onk paudtauau Simeonoh.
    \xe ... . And he brought Simeon out unto them.'    Gen.43.23 { 3->3'-pro+3
    \so ; absolute secondary object }
    \xv Ann∞s wunnaumonuh Israel, kuppaudtunkqunnaóut, pahke olive pummee, togkuhwhôsu,...
    \xe Command the children of Israel, that they bring unto thee pure oil olive beaten ...
    \so Lev.24.2
    \ng 3p->2+0 t-subordinative
    \xv ...: kah neh uppaudtauonáoh Mosesoh,...
    \xe ... And they brought him unto Moses:...'    Lev.24.11 { 3p->3'+3
    \so -pro; compare Gen.43.23; animate definitive DO--hence |-oh|. See G&B 530. }

    \xv ... n∞naneteaonk ne paudtauun,...
    \xe ..., my blessing that is brought to thee,...
    \so Gen.33.11
    \ng 1->2+_0_
    \xv ..., Hebrew wuttinneum noh paudtiéog,...
    \xe ..., The Hebrew servant, which thou hast brought unto us,...
    \so Gen.39.17
    \ng 2->1p+_3_ participle (or 12?)
    \xv ..., matta paudtauun∞un, káh matta ponóog anaquabean, neit wutchimuneach micheme.
    \xe ...: if I bring him not unto thee, and set him before thee, then let me bear the blame for ever:
    \so Gen.43.9
    \ng 1->2+3-pro negative subjunctive
    \xv ..., kah annoontam∞k adt wohkukquoshik, wutche kitteamonteanittuonk ne paudtanteáog, ∞woshweénat Jesus Christ.
    \xe ..., and hope to the end for the grace that is to be brought unto you at the revelation of Jesus Christ;
    \so 1 Pet.1.13
    \ng X->2p+_0_

    \xv Qut paudtiegk peissisit kematou,...
    \xe But bring your youngest brother unto me;...
    \so Gen.42.20,44.21
    \ng 2p->1+3 imperative
    \xv ..., neg paudtah, kah n∞nanumóog.
    \xe ..., Bring them, I pray thee, unto me, and I will bless them.
    \so Gen.48.9
    \ng 2->1+3(p) imperative
    \xv ..., kah unnán∞team∞ paudtauúnaj uppúhkuk,...
    \xe ..., and [he] commanded his head to be brought:...
    \so Mk.6.27
    \ng X->3+0 imperative
    \xv Newutche paudtau∞k meechummuongash, woh wanohtagish aiuskoianatam∞onk,...
    \xe Bring forth therefore fruits worthy of repentance,...
    \so Lk.3.8

\cf pas∞au
(Cf. also Sansk. pat, ire; pad, ire, adire.)

[Narragansett [xnt] |paútous| `bring hither'    R.W.
Western Abenaki [abe] |apét8n| `il apporte'; |nepét8n| `j'apporte'; with an. obj. |nepés8añ| `je l'apporte'.
Chip. |oo betoon| `he brings it'.
Cree, inan. |péytow|, an. |péyshoohayoo|(?)    Howse 41.

\lx paumuhkauau
\va paumukauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
    \nt +
\ps TA, |-hk-aw-| stem
\nt Remark: The usual phonological distribution of the corporal/pedal final does not hold here.
\twn |paumuhkom|, TI1
\ge `to pass by sb, to pass from sb, to pass over before sb'
\so Gen.32.16,33.3; Ex.12.27; Mt.26.39; Mk.14.35; Lk.10.31,32
    \xv ..., kah peantam, woh n nag, yeu hour woh uppaumukongqun.
    \xe ..., and prayed that, if it were possible, the hour might pass from him.
    \so Mk.14.35
    \ng 0->3 objective
    \xv Kah wonk Levite, ne paont, peyau ummonunneauoh, & uppaumukauouh ogkomáe.
    \xe And likewise a Levite, when he was at the place, came and looked on him, and passed by on the other side.'    Lk.10.32  { 3->3
    \so }
    \xv ..., yeu wutche sephausuonk kupaumukkonkqunnánonut Jehovah, noh paûmukog weekuóash wunnaumonuh Israel ut Egypt,...
    \xe ..., It is the sacrifice of the LORD's passover, who passed over the houses of the children of Israel in Egypt,...
    \so Ex.12.27
    \ng 3->2p t-subordinative

    \xv ..., paumukiek, kah chadchaubshagk nashauwe chipwushaonk, kah chipwushaonk.
    \xe ..., Pass over before me, and put a space betwixt drove and drove.
    \so Gen.32.16
    \ng 2p->1 imperative
    \xv ..., Woi N∞sh, woh nnag, yeu wutattamwaitch paumuhkongquttei:...
    \xe ..., O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me:...
    \so Mt.26.39
    \ng 0->1 imperative


\lx paumukom
\va paumuhkom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
    \nt +
\ps TI1, |-hk-| stem
\twn |paumuhkomauau|, TA
\ge `to come through sth, pass sth, pass by, over, through sth'
\so Num.20.17; Deut.2.4,8,27.4,29.16; Josh.1.11; Lk.11.42,44; Jn.5.24; 1 Jn.3.14
    \xv ..., kupaumukomumw∞ wutohtuóut kematt∞oog,...
    \xe ..., Ye are to pass through the coast of your brethren...
    \so Deut.2.4
    \xv N∞wahteomun nuppaumukommumun nupp∞onk, en pomantam∞enganit,...
    \xe We know that we have passed from death unto life,...
    \so 1 Jn.3.14  { 1p }; similarly Jn.5.24(E), (M) |paumukkom|

    \xv ..., no pajeh paumukomog kussissepoiyeumut.
    \xe ..., until we have passed thy borders.
    \so Num.20.17
    \xv ..., kah uttoh án paukomog ut nashaue wutohtimóneat, nish paumukkomogish.
    \xe ...; and how we came through the nations which ye passed by.
    \so Deut.29.16
    \xv ...: newutche kutogqueneunkqussimw∞ mat naumoe weenohket, kah wosketompaog nish paumukomohettichish matta wunneheoncheéunnáoash.
    \xe ...! for ye are as graves which appear not, and the men that walk over them are not aware of them.
    \so Lk.11.44
    \ng 3p->0, iterative participle; |nish| is either an erroneous demonstrative link, by attraction, or perhaps an (unnecessary) 0p direct object of the participle.

\lx paúpakinasik
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 120
\ps adv.
\ge `in the twilight'
\so Prov.7.9
\dv Dimin. of |pohpohkeni| `it is dark'
    \nt MN: paupohkenik
    \ng Suppositive |paupohkenik| `when dark' (?)
\cf pohkeni
\nt Does not often occur in Eliot's translation; perhaps not elsewhere than in the verse cited.

\lx -pe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 121
\ps the root of names of `water' in nearly all dialects of th Algonquian.
\nt It has usually the demonstrative prefix, and is not found without it in the New England dialects.
\cf nippe
\cf n'pe
\cf -pog
[Cf. the Sansk. pâ, to drink (pa, drinking, for drink; ap, water), a root which runs through almost all Indo-European languages: Zend. péo, water; Afgh. poï; Litu. uppe, flumen; Irish abh, flumen; Greek PO, pépoka; Lat. potum.]

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nebi| (|n'pi|).
Narragansett [xnt] |nip|.
Mahican [mjy] |n'bey|.
Chip. |në'-bi|, |ne-be|, |ne-bee| `water'; |së bë|, |see bee| `river'.
Cree |níp pee|.]

\lx peantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 121
\ps v.i. / TI1a(-O)
\ge `he supplicates; (in Eliot's transl.) `he prays'; lit. `he is small- minded (|pe-antam|), he humbles himself'

    \se peantamauau
    \ps Tr.an. / TA
    \ge `he prays to, supplicates (him)'; `to make supplication to sb'
    \xv ken kuppeantamoush
    \xe I pray to thee
    \so Ps.5.2
    \ng 1->2 indicative }; +Lk.6.12
    \xv ...: kah nuppeantamauop Jehovah.
    \xe ...: and unto the Lord I made supplication.
    \so Ps.30.8
    \ng 1->3 preterite absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk pish nuppeantamungquog yeu ut ohket.
    \xe ..., and [they shall] serve me in this place.
    \so Acts 7.7
    \nt +

    \se !|peantamwontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative
    \nt Remark: The TA gender twin appears in (E0), Gen.18.24, page header: |Abraham peantamwonoog...Sodom & Gomorra| "Abraham prays for Sodom & Gomorrah", but it is replaced by |peantamwanuhshau| in (E1&2), and the sense is indeed different from that attested here. (See note to Gen.18.24.)
    \ge `to pray for sth'
    \so Mt.26.27(!"give thanks"); 1 Jn.5.16
    \xv ..., : na nupp∞ongane matcheseonk, matta nusseuh ne pish uppeantamwontamun.
    \xe ... There is a sin unto death: I do not say that he shall pray for it.
    \so 1 Jn.5.16
    \ng 3->0 objective

    \se peantamwanuhshau
    \ps TA
    \ge `to pray for s.o.'
    `Advocate form' (imperat.) |peantamwansh| `pray thou for (them)'    1 Sam.12.19
    \xv -wanshinnean
    \xe pray thou for us
    \so Jer.37.3

    \se peantamóonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `supplication, prayer'

[Narragansett [xnt] |peeyaüntam| `he is at prayer'    R.W.
Western Abenaki [abe] |pañba`tam| `il prie'.
Delaware [del] |pa ta mau| `to pray'    Zeisb.
Mahican [mjy] |peyuhtom-mauwukon| (vbl.) `religion'    Edw.
Quiripi [qyp] |peaió|, used by Pierson for `holy', etc.,    Catechism 41,42,57; inan. pl. |peaíous|    ibid.55. This seems to be the primary or the simple verb from which |peantam| was formed, and is perhaps identical with |pauwau| (q.v.); |peaiówungan| `holiness'    Pier.51. See |attaboan|.]

\lx peásin
\va peasin

\ge `a small thing'
\so Num.16.13
    \xv Kah wussissipoiyeum∞ wunnaumonuh Dan, peasinup wutch nagoh,...

    \ng 0 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    \xv wussaume peasin
    \xe it is too small
    \so 2 K.6.1

    Suppos. inan. |peasik|, |peesik|, and |peyâsik| `when it is small, a small thing'  { _0_ participle }
    \xv ..., Ephraimme wusseume peasik wutch ken.
    \xe ..., if mount Ephraim be too narrow for thee.
    \so Josh.17.15√
    \xv anue peyasik onk ne mo teag
    \xe less [more little] than nothing
    \so Is.40.17

    \se peamesan[-in

    \ge `a very small thing'
    \so Ex.16.14
    \xv ..., Sun peamesun keneemunúmayeuonk nahsuk,...? ...
    \xe ..., Is it a small matter that thou hast taken my husband,...?

    Intens. |papeásik| (q.v.)

\nt +

\lx peississu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 122
\ps v.i.an. or adj.an. / +predicative; i-stem
\ge `he is very small', +`to be young'

    `very young'
    \xv Neen nuppeisses onk nish papeasikish wame kummonaneteaongash,...

    \ng for Hebr.; cf. AV marginale "{I am lesse then ...}"

    \xe the younger
    \so Gen.19.35

    \xe he that is least

    \xe while he was yet young

    \se |papeississu|, often syncopated
    \nt +
    \ps AI, reduplicated
    \ge `to be small, young'

    Intens. or dimin. of endearment, |papeissit|, pl. |-itcheg| `young children'
    \xv ..., papeississitcheg kah matikenukeg puppinashimwe neetasuog,...
    \xe ... [he] had flocks, and herds,...
    \so Gen.13.5
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \xv ..., papeissitcheg kah matikénukeg,...
    \xe ..., both small and great:...
    \so Gen.19.11
    \ng _3p_ participle, syncopated
    \xv ... wame Jewsog, papeissitcheh kah kehcheiog,...
    \xe ... all Jews, both young and old,...'    Esth.3.13  { _3
    \so _ participle, syncopated, erroneously for _3p_ participle (obviative |-un-| missing in any case) }

    \xe in the narrow path

\lx pemunneaht
\va -unneat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 122
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a cord, a string'; +`chain, rope, thread, wire'
\so Is.50.2; Mk.7.35; +Gen.14.23,41.42; Ex.35.18,(39.3),40; Num.3.26,37,4.26,32; Josh.2.15; Jn.2.15
    |pémunneate| "a thrid"    Gen.14.23(E0)
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wossabpetâhhamwog golde namékag, kah ∞wowunnumpâsumun, uppemunneotonussumun,...
    \xe And they did beat the gold into thin plates, and cut it into wires,...
    \so Ex.39.3
    \ng 3->0 subordinative to TI scissional derivative probably of predicative: "cause to be wire by cutting"
    pl. +|ash| and +|onash|    Judg.15.3; 16.11,12
\dv Suppos. of |pemunohteau| (`it is twisted or plaited'), `when twisted'
    (|peminneaht ome| `a fishing line'; |pea@menyaht| `a cable'    C.)

    \se |peminneohtone|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of small cords'
    \so Jn.2.15(M)
    \xv Kah mahche ayik peminneohtone sohsamehtahheg,...
    \xe And when he had made a scourge of small cords,...
    \so Jn.2.15(M)

\nt The primary meaning seems to be `plaited' or `braided'; that which is made by putting one (strand or thread) across another. Cf. |pummeeche|.
\cf tuttuppun

[Western Abenaki [abe] |pemai8i| `il ya de travers'.
Cree |pim-ich| `crosswise'.
Delaware [del] |pimenatan| `thread'; |pimeü| `slanty'    Zeisb.
Cree |péeme-num| `he awryeth it'; |pímme-num| `he twists it'    Howse 93.
Powh.: "Their women use to spin ... a kind of grasse they call |pemmenau|; of these they make a thread very even and readily." -- J.Smith, Hist. of Va.
    Mun. |pi∙m@áhta∙n| `thread'    G.1981.100.]
    \nt +

\et G.1981, fn.15, 100, from PEA *pïm@nahtän `cordage', to PA *pyi∙m-en- `twist, roll, by hand'; see also S., no. 171, 373-374, H.2887-2895.

\lx penomp
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 122
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a virgin'
\so Gen.24.16; Is.7.4
    pl. |-paog|    Esth.2.19
\dv |penówe| `strange', in its secondary or privative sense, and |-omp|, n.gen. for `man', nescia viri (?).
\cf keeegsquaw
\cf quausses

[Du Ponceau (?) says: "A young man of Delaware is called |pilapé|. This word is formed from |pilsit| `chaste, innocent', and |lenapí| `man', viz., man in his purity and innocence." -- Tocqueville, Démoc. en Amér, app. c.
(|penomp|, |peissit| (?), or |penussu| (?).)
Hkw. gives |pilapeu| `a lad'; |pilawesis| `a boy'; |pilawétit| `a male infant babe'.
Zeisb. gives |pi la pi u| `a big boy'; |pi la we tit| `a little boy'; |pila wetschitsch| `a boy'    Voc.52.]


\lx penôwe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 123
\ps adj. and adv.
\ge `strange, differing, or of another kind, uncommon'
\ge `foreign, of another country or language'
\dv the same base, perhaps, with |panne| (q.v.), `out of the way'

    \se pen∞weyeu∞ [penôwe-u∞]
    \ps Vbl. n. {?} / II
    \ge `it is different, strange'
    \so Prov.21.8.

    \se pen∞wehteau
    \ps Caus. inan. / TI2, causative final
    \ge `he makes (it) different, distinguishes (it)'; `to make sth strange, to confound sth'
    \so Lev.11.47; +Gen.11.7
\cf nanwe

[Western Abenaki [abe] |piri, pir8"i.| `novitatem indicat.'; |pirié| `nouveau.'; +|pir8"iarenañbé.| `homme étranger.', |pir8"iphainem.| `femme étr.', |nepir8añd8"é.| `je parle une langue étrangére.'    R.P33/560b;360/493b;233-234/450b.
Cree X|PITUS| (adv.) `autrement, différent'; |Petoos| `contrary, different, differently, other'; |pîtos-| `changed, different'    Lac.D.572ab; Frs.419b; Alb.E.175a.
Delaware [del] |pili| `another'; +|Pili| `otherwise, another'    Zeisb.; B&A.115.
    Miami-Illinois [mia] |pir8i| `loing hinc'    Grv.476/275b.
    \nt +
Lp.A. |tagachanis p.i.li| `un peu different', |8aziki pali linsk8ans8| `tout a fait different il escrit', |pil8ant8au| `il parle une autre langue'    D.39,74,102.
M.-P. |piluwi| (|piluw-|) `different'; |pili-| (|pil-|) `neu', |pilwiye| II `es ist verschieden'    LeS.69b; Sz.177-179.
    Menominee [mez] |pe∙n-| `clean, new, strange'    M.L.214
    \nt ?
Miami |pilwi| `far away, far off'    B&C.109b.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Pelooä'| `Foreign'; |piley| `new', |piluwe:k| AI,II `changed, different'; |biluey| NI `different, an alien'    R.115b; DeB.68b-69a; MCS.68a-69a.
    Ojibwe [oji] |Bin-| `clean, neat, pure'...    Bar.85a-87a.
    \nt ?
Shawnee [sjw] |pelowi(l)-| `FAR AWAY, LONG, LONG WAY, APART'    D.-V.92
WAbn. |bil-| `new, strange, different, foreign', |bilowi| PT `different, strange', |bilowiki| NI `different land'    D.1.xxxiv, 113-115.]

\et Haas 1958.245 *pelaw- `FAR', without evidence; *pi∙Θ(aw)- looks closer.


\lx pen∞on

\cf pe∞nog


\lx pen∞wanumau
\va penuan-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 123
\ps v.t. an. / TA, psychological final |-ánum-|
\ge `to have a difference with, to contend with (him)'; +`to strive with sb'
    \xv Yeu Meribahe nippe, newutche wunnaumonuh Israel penuánumáog Jehovah:...
    \xe This is the water of Meribah, because the children of Israel strove with the Lord,...
    \so Num.20.13
    \nt +
    \xv uppenuanumouh
    \xe they contended with them
    \so Prov.28.4

    Suppos. part. |penuanumont| `when contending with'    Job 9.3

    \se penuanittuog
    \ps V. mutual an. / AI, reciprocal
    \ge `they contend with each other, "are at strife"'
    \so 2 Sam.19.9

    \se penuánittuonk
    \ps Vbl.n., deverbal to reciprocal
    \ge `mutual strife, contention'
    \so Gen.13.8; 2 K.5.7; Mt.10.35

    \se -itteáe
    \ps Adj.
    \ge `at strife with, contentiously'
    \so Prov.27.15
\dv |penôwe| (emotional an. form).

\lx pen∞woht
\va penuwot
\va penuwoht
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 123
\ps n. / NA
    \dv |pen∞w-| `different, foreign, strange' + |ohk-á-| `earth' + ??|-i|; to a bahuvrihi verb "having a different land"?
    \nt +
\ge `a stranger, one different, a foreigner'
\so Prov.5.20; Deut.27.19
    \xv howane penuwot
    \xe any stranger
    \so Gen.17.12
    \nt +
    pl. |-teáog| `strangers'
    \xv ... k∞skannemunog pish penuwohteaoog ohke matta wuttaihéou,...
    \xe ..., that thy seed shall be a stranger, in a land that is not theirs,...
    \so Gen.15.13
    \nt +
    (|pen∞wohtea| `a stranger'    C.29/175)√
    \xv Sunnummatta nutogquanumuk∞un penuwohteáut? ...
    \xe Are we not counted of him strangers? ...
    \so Gen.31.15
    \nt +
\nt Used by Eliot for `the heathen'    Ezek.36.3,4

    \se -ohteáe
    \ps Adj.
    \ge `foreign'    Ezra 10.11

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nippenowàntawem| `I am of another language'    R.W.9.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |nepir8añd8"é| `je parle une language étrangère'    234,235/450b.√
    W.Abn. |bil((d)ow)-| `different, strange', |bilowiki| NI `different land'    D.1.xxxiv,113-115.]
    \nt +


\lx pen∞wohteau
\va penuwohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 123
\ps v.i. / AI
    \dv predicative verb to |pen∞woht(ei)|; shape of end of stem uncertain.
    \nt +
\ge `he is strange or unlike by nature'; +`to be a stranger; to be alienated'
    \xv Neen nuppenuwohteau, kah nuttinneapeyon weechekenaau,...
    \xe I am a stranger and a sojourner with you:...
    \so Gen.23.4
    \ng 1 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv mô nuppen∞wohteau,...
    \xe I was a stranger,...
    \so Mt.25.35,43
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche yeuyeu matta wonk kuppenuwohteà∞mw∞ kah kuttouohkomukqunnu∞mw∞,...
    \xe Now therefore ye are no more strangers and foreigners,...
    \so Eph.2.19
    \ng 2p negative indicative
    \nt +

    \se !|pen∞wohteayeu|, !|pen∞wohteieu|
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: This appears to be distinct from the preceding, and derived from its stem.
    \ps AI
    \ge `to be a stranger somewhere' (i.e. "live as a stranger somewhere")
    \so Gen.17.8,28.4; Ex.12.19

    \xv ... ohke neadt pen∞wohteayeap,...
    \xe ..., the land wherein thou art a stranger,...
    \so Gen.17.8
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wohonk kutohtouun ohke neadt penuwohteaiyean,...
    \xe ...; that thou mayest inherit the land wherein thou art a stranger,..
    \so Gen.28.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., uttóh en pen∞wohteaet, asuh kohtóhteaeekit.
    \xe ..., whether he be a stranger, or born in the land.
    \so Ex.12.19
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kenaau momansh pen∞wohteayogish, kah ayeuwehteayógish ut kuttenantam∞ongan∞out,...
    \xe And you, that were sometime alienated and enemies in your mind ...
    \so Col.1.21
    \ng 2p iterative
    \nt +
\dv |penôwe| and |ohteau| `he is a stranger or foreigner'

    \se |pen∞wohtea∞onk|
    \nt +
    \ps deverbal noun, II
    \ge `pilgrimage'
    \so Gen.47.9
    \xv ..., ukkesukodtum∞e pen∞wohtea∞óngán∞ash
    \xe ... in the days of their pilgrimage.
    \so Gen.47.9
    \ng 3p possessive 0p

    \xe And Joseph saw his brethren, and he knew them, but made himself strange unto them,...
    \so Gen.42.7

\lx penuhteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 123
\ps v.t. inan. / AI+O
\ge `it casts (it) down, he casts (himself) down upon the ground'

    (|penohkönat| `to throw down'    C.)
\dv Caus. `he makes it fall' (?).


\lx penushau
\va penuhshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 123
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `he falls', +`to fall down'; including euphemism for "to die, be killed"
    \xv ..., nuppinshom waussumónat ut anaquohtag wusseetash angel,...
    \xe ..., I fell down to worship before the feet of the angel...
    \so Rev.22.8
    \nt +
    (|nuppini@sshom| `I fall'    C.)

    \xv Noh ...; panshont, kah wuskesukquash woshwemoash.
    \xe He ..., falling {into a trance}, but having his eyes open:
    \so Num.24.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wame neg pansháncheg ne kesukok, naneeswe wosketompaog kah mittamwossissog, nabo neese muttanonganog kussuog,...
    \xe ... all that fell that day, both of men and women, were twelve thousand,...
    \so Josh.8.25
    \nt +

    \se penusheau
    \ps inan. subj. / II
    \ge `it falls'; as a flower `fadeth'
    \so Is.40.7,8

    \se penushaonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `falling, a fall'

    \se |penushadtam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative(?)
    \ge `to fall on sth' (specifically `on one's face')
    \so Num.16.4, Ruth 2.10, Lk.5.12
    \xv Kah Moses wunn∞tamun, kah penushadtam wuskesuk.
    \xe And when Moses heard it, he fell upon his face:
    \so Num.16.4

    \se !|penushahtau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2 causative
    \ps `to make sth to fall'
    \so Ps.64.8
    \xv Nemehkuh pish nehenwonche wenannu uppenushátaun[e]au ut wuhhogkaout:
    \xe So they shall make their own tongue to fall upon themselves:
    \so Ps.64.8 { 3p->0 objective/subordinative }; (M) |punnishohtoog|

    Cf.
    \xv petshau
    \xe he falls into
    |pogkishin|, an. |pogkussu| `he drops, falls inanimately'
    \xv chauopsheau
    \xe he falls into the water
    \xv kitchisahshau
    \xe he falls into the fire
    \xv kepshau
    \xe he falls by stumbling or by reason of an obstacle
    \so , etc.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |peni`ré| `il tombe d'en haut'. The corresponding primary verb is not found in Eliot. From it |penushau| is formed by adding |sh| (marking mischance) to the root.
Old Alg. |pankisin| `to fall'.]

\et G.1981, 29, p.68, 38, p.75: PA *peni?le∙wa, with final(s) H. p. 247 *-i?l-e∙- `smooth movement, to fly'

\lx pe∞nog
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 123
\ps n.
\ge `a little ship'
\so Mass.Ps., Jn.21.8
\cf keht∞nog
\cf kehte-ônog
\cf peawe-ônog
\cf mu@sh∞n
\ge a ship'. So, |peawe-ônog|
\nt () `a ship'. So,  `the small conveyance'. These names were framed for English and foreign boats, as distinguished from the canoe () or Indian boat. They do not appear to have been widely used

[Western Abenaki [abe] |ket8rak8| `a ship'; |sañr8pé8"rag8| `a barque'.]

\lx pepenam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 124
\ps v.t. inan. / TI1a
\ge `he selects, chooses (it)'
    \nt G&B.692
    \nt +
\so Gen.13.11; Is.40.20
    \xv Neit Lot pepenam wame mukoshqut ut Jordan,...
    \xe Then Lot chose him all the plain of Jordan:...
    \so Gen.13.11
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Nuppepenam.
    \xe I chuse, {or} did'
    \so C.42/184
    \nt +

    \xv Pepenash.
    \xe Choose thou
    \so C.42/184
    \nt +

    \se pepenau
    \ps v.an. / TA
    \ge `he chooses (him)'
    \nt Research needed: It is not clear whether this item exists; most examples are clearly |-aw-| stems (v.i.), and the size and status of any residue are unclear to me at the moment. I list an example that is not clearly an |-aw-| stem. Cf. Delaware infra.

    \xv ... neh wame pepenahetticheh.
    \xe ... which they chose.'    Gen.6.2  { 3p->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \nt +

    \se |pepenauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, |-aw-| stem; perhaps with final |-naw-| `see'?
    \ge `to choose, elect sb'
    \so [common]
    \xv ..., kah nah wutch pepenauau naboneesuoh, uttiyeug wonk âs∞wesitcheg Apostles:
    \xe ...: and of them he chose twelve, whom he also named apostles;
    \so Lk.6.13
    \xv Matta kuppepeniyeúmw∞, qut neen kuppepénauunumw∞,...
    \xe Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you,...
    \so Jn.15.16
    \ng 2p->1, 1->2p
    \xv Wahteauog nemattinnónog womonitteaógish, kuppepenunkqunau GOD.
    \xe Knowing, brethren beloved, your election of God.
    \so 1 Thess.1.4
    \ng 3->2p, subordinative
    \xv ..., newutche GOD wutch waj kutchissik kuppepenunkou en wadchanittuonganit...
    \xe ..., because God hath from the beginning chosen you to salvation ...
    \so 2 Thess.2.13

    \xv N∞n∞wamunnonup n noh pepen∞ogkup,...
    \xe I have made a covenant with my chosen,...
    \so Ps.89.3; (M): |pepenauogup|
    \ng 1->_3_ preterite participle
    \xv Kah neit pish an∞nau wutangelsumoh, kah pish mohmôunau neh pepenauoncheh,...
    \xe And then shall he send his angels, and shall gather together his elect ...'    Mk.13.27  { 3->_3
    \so _ participle }

    \se pepenaue
    \ps Adj.
    \ge `chosen, selected'
    \so Jer.49.19
\dv |penôwe| `he differences it'

[Delaware [del] |pipinamen| `to choose'; +|piipíinam| TI `choose s.t.', |piipíinaweew| TA `choose s.o.'    Zeisb.; O'M.247a.
    Narragansett [xnt] |Pepênash| `Take your choyce.'    R.W.42.]
    \nt +

\lx peskhómmin
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 124

\cf paskuhkom
\ge he bursts (it)
\cf pashksheau
\ge it bursts asunder

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nepéskam| `I fire a gun'; |a8enni peskak| `who shoots?'; |pask8ias8| `(the gun) bursts'.
Cree |páskes-wóosoo| `he shoots himself'; |póoskoopu@thu| `it bursts' (from within), like a gun; |páske-pu@thu| `it bursts' (from without), as a bladder; |pússu@ke-puthu| `it splinters'; |páskesiggun| `a gun'.
Old Alg. |paskisigan|.
Delaware [del] |poak sa can| and |pai achic hi can| `gun'; |pai ach kam men| `to fire a gun'    Zeisb.]


\lx pésuponck
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 124
\ps n.
\ge `an hothouse', "a kind of little cell or cave ... into [which] frequently the men enter after they have exceedingly heated it with store of wood, laid upon an heap of stones in the middle," etc. "Here do they sit round, ... sweating together.'
\so R.W.158
\dv Verbal from *|pésuppaû|.

\lx petan
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 124
\ps n. / NA
    \nt Remark: On gender, c.f. B.1962, 2.28 |pi∙htanwan| `quiver'
    \nt +
\ge `a quiver'
\so Job 39.23; Is.22.6
\dv |petau|.
    \xv OOnaiyeu woskeetomp noh uppetanwonit nomwapenit,...
    \xe Happy is the man that hath his quiver full of them:...
    \so Ps.127.5; (M): |noh uppetanwon namwapinit|
    \nt +

[Western Abenaki [abe] |pítarañn|.]

\et A.1875, H. 2742: *pi∙ntaΘwa∙na NA `quiver' (`inside' + `arrow')

\lx petau

    Suppos. inan. concrete |petunk| (`that which is put into'), `a bag or pouch'

    Imperat. |..., petaush wunn∞taóut wosketompaog mechum,...| `..., Fill the men's sacks {with} food,...'    Gen.44.1√  { 2->0 imperative }

    \xv Petogge
    \xe a bagge
    \so Wood

    \se petshau
    \ps Intens. (involuntary action) / AI
    \ge `he falls into'
\dv |peyau|, caus.an. (?)

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nepi`rañ| `I put it into'; 3d pers. |api`rañr|; |netépt8n| `I put it in' (a dish, vessel, or the like).
Cree |péetche| (prep.) `in, within'; |péethis| `until, unto'. |pit-|, as an `instrumentive characteristic' of verbs, implies action performed `with the arm', `he pulls' [cf. |m'pit| (|muhpit|)]    Howse 87; |péetenum| `he puts it in'; |péeta-hum| `he thrusts it in'; |péechenum| `he puts it in the inside'    Howse 34.
Delaware [del] |pin den| `to put in, to fill'    Zeisb.]

\et H.1743 *pi∙nte∙wi `inside'; Jones 1911, 769; 20, 802-804

    \so indicative }
    \xv ..., newutche teaguash qushkem∞ugkupash ut man∞taut weske nuppethúunnitteamun,...
    \xe ..., Because of the money that was returned in our sacks are we brought in;...

    \ng X->1p indicative
    \xv Onk Joseph pethúunau ∞shoh kah wunneepaiheuh anaquabit Pharaoh,...

    \so absolute }
    \xv Kah kuppeissesum∞óog, ..., neg nuppethuóneau,...
    \xe But your little ones,..., them will I bring in,...
    \so Num.14.31
    \ng 1->3p subordinative (syncopated?)

    \xv ...: kah noh woh neh sohwhe sagkompagunoncheh, kah noh woh pethuunont,...
    \xe ..., and [a man] which may lead them out, and which may lead them in;..'    Num.27.17  { _3_->3
    \so participle }

\lx petshau

    \nt +

    \nt MN: petshónit
    \ng suppositive |petshónit| `when he falls'
    \ng 3'
    part. |petshunt| `when falling' { 3 }
\dv |petau|, with |sh| of mischance or involuntary action.

\lx petuánum
\va peht-
\va pittu-
\va pitchu-
\va pohtu-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
\ps v.i. / TA, mental final
\ge `he is proud' {?}; +`to have sb in reputation'

    \xv ..., Pharise, ussowesu Gamaleel, naumatuongane kuhk∞tomuhteaeneu∞, uttiyeuoh missinninnuog pohtuanumahettiche ...
    \xe ..., A Pharisee, named Gamaliel, a doctor of the law, had in reputation among all the people,...'    Acts 5.34  { 3p->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \nt +

    \se !|pehtuanumwu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, reflexive middle
    \ge `to be proud'
    \so Ps.10.2; Job.40.12
    |pitchuanumoo Diotreph[e]s| ?"Diotrephes is proud"    3 Jn.Hdr  { 3 indicative }

    \xv Matcheetou pitchuanumwudt kodwoskéhheau matchekuoh:...
    \xe The wicked in his pride doth persecute the poor:...
    \so Ps.10.2  { 3 conjunct }; (M) |uppehtuanumooonganit|
    \xv ...: qut pitchuanumwehettit, nóutit wuttin waheuh.
    \xe ..., : but the proud he knoweth afar off.
    \so Ps.138.6
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt MN: noh pohtuânumwit
    \ng suppositive |noh pohtuânumwit| `he who is proud'    Job 40.12
    \ng 3 participle to reflexive middle

    \se petuánumwu
    \va pittuinumóe
    \va pittuanumwe
    \nt +
    \ps Adv. / PreN, PreV, to reflexive middle
    \ge `frowardly', "of pride", +`proud', `presumptuously, to presume to'
    \so Is.57.17
    \xv Qut nag pittuanumwe koshkomme ogquodchuáog en kôdtuhkôag wadchuut,...
    \xe But they presumed to go up unto the hill top:...
    \so Num.14.44
    \xv ..., kah matta pish wonk pittuanumwe panneussu.
    \xe ..., and [they shall] do no more presumptuously.
    \so Deut.17.13
    \nt +
    \xv Qut quoshodtumwaen noh pittuanmwe n∞wadt ut n∞wesuonganit,...
    \xe But the prophet, which shall presume to speak a word in my name,...
    \so Deut.18.20
    \nt +
    \xv pittuinumóe pomantamóonk
    \xe the pride of life
    \so 1 Jn.2.16√
    (|Quinuhqui metah, petuanumöe.| `Haughty, or proud'    C.24/171√
    \xv Pehtuanummoe aiontokkoiog.
    \xe Proud rogues
    \so C.28/174
    \xv Petuanumôê.
    \xe Proudly
    \so C.106/229√.)

    \se petuánum∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `pride'
    \so Job 33.17; Prov.14.3; 16.18
    \xv Nag kutadtashôog wutch uppéhteánum∞ongan∞ wosketompaog,...
    \xe Thou shalt hide them ... from the pride of man:...
    \so Ps.31.20
    \nt +

\lx petukauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
    \nt +
\ps TA, dative final
\dv |petuk-| + |-aw-|
\ge `to come, go in (un)to sb', literally, and euphemistically as OED s.v. go, v., 80e [2nd.: 82e]: "used in all Eng. versions of the Old Testament (after the Heb.) for: To have carnal knowledge of (a woman)."
    \xv Kah petukauóog Noahoh en Arkut,...
    \xe And they went in unto Noah into the ark,...'    Gen.7.15  { 3p->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ... teaguas kittinnumah onk woh kuppetukah?
    \xe ..., What wilt thou give me, that thou mayest come in unto me?
    \so Gen.38.16
    \ng 2->1
    \xv ... kah wunneheau wuhhogkuh, kah ós∞wunum wutogk∞unash, kah petukauau Pharohoh.
    \xe ...: and he shaved himself, and changed his raiment, and came in unto Pharaoh.
    \so Gen.41.14
    \xv Kah wuttinnumáoh Bilhah ummaidumoh ∞mittumwussissinneat, kah Jakob uppetukauau.
    \xe And she gave him Bilhah her handmaid to wife: and Jacob went in unto her.'    Gen.30.4  { 3->3
    \so -obj. (sp.!?) }
    \xv Asuh matta pish petukauôou nupp∞oh,...
    \xe Neither shall he [the high priest] go in to any dead body,...
    \so Lev.21.11
    \ng i.e. "enter a place containing"
    \xv ..., ne nippe matchenehuwóm∞ug, nish noh petukongqun kah pish wesogkon,...
    \xe ..., that the water that causeth the curse shall enter into her, and become bitter,...
    \so Num.5.27
    \ng 0->3 objective, aphesis of |u-|?

    \xv ..., Uttiyeug wosketompaog pétakunkqueaneg yeu nohkog? ...
    \xe ..., Where are the men which came in to thee this night? ...
    \so Gen.19.5
    \ng _3p_->2 participle
    \xv ..., kah weetauadteog, kah nag petukauog, kah nag petukkunkqueog.
    \xe ..., and [if ye] shall make marriages with them, and go in unto them, and they to you:
    \so Josh.23.12
    \ng 2p->3
    \xv ... Nathan quoshodtumwaen paaonont mahche petukauont Bathsheba.
    \xe ..., when Nathan the pophet came unto him after he had gone in to Bathsheba.'    Ps.51 Heading; (M): |petukkouont|  { 3->3
    \so }

    \xv Onk pohchau na én, kah n∞wau, Nah k∞wehquetumoush petukauunitti ...
    \xe And he turned unto her by the way, and said, Go to, I pray thee, let me come in unto thee;...
    \so Gen.38.16
    \ng 1->2 imperative

[Algonquian [alg] |Pindikaw| `entre chez lui'    Cq.342b.]

\et H.2751 *pi∙ntwikawe∙wa


\lx pétukodtum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ge `he brings (it) into'
    \xv kuppetukodtomw∞
    \xe ye bring (it) in

\lx petukonau
\hm 1
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative final
\nt Remark: The relationship to !|petutteaonau|, !petutteauoneau|, T+.125a requires investigation. The present form appears to conform better to Bloomfield's description (B.1962, 16.69, 342-343); the other is then probably a levelled formation. Whether this has a different meaning from the form with the dative final, |petukauau|, awaits study.
\nt cf. G&B.520, 693 s.v. |petuttauonuk| TA `(he, obv.) enters to him'.
\ge `to come in unto sb'; euphemistically "to have sexual intercourse with sb"
\so Gen.19.31
    \xv ... & matta woh toh wosketompaun∞ yeu ohkit kuppetakonukqunnánonut,...
    \xe ..., and there is not a man in the earth to come in unto us...
    \so Gen.19.31
    \ng 3->12 t-subordinative


\lx petukonau
\hm 2
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge ? Possibly technical senses of |petukonau| (1) relating to crime and punishment: `to accuse sb, be of the adverse party to sb, go to law with sb; deliver sb (to sb), haul sb (before sb)'
\so Mk.13.9; Lk.12.58; Acts ?4.3,23.35; 1 Cor.6.1,6,7
    \xv ..., newutche pish nag kuppetukonuk∞∞og moeonganit,...
    \xe ...: for they shall deliver you up to councils;...
    \so Mk.13.9
    \ng 3p->2p objective
    \xv Wechauadt noh petukonukqean en magistrat, ..., ishkont kuppetukonuk en wussittumwaenin,
    \xe When thou goest with thine adversary to the magistrate,...; lest he hale thee to the judge,...
    \so Lk.12.58
    \ng _3_->2 participle; 3->2 indicative
    |^Uppetukonôuh Peter & Iohn^| ?`...put them in hold...'    Acts, header, 119a, preceding 3.20, perhaps to 4.3  { 3p->3' objective }
    \xv HOwane kenaau penuánitteóg, sun woh kuppetukonittimw8 anaquabhettit mat sampwesegig...?
    \xe Dare any of you, having a matter against another, go to law before the unjust,...?
    \so 1 Cor.6.1
    \ng 2p indicative, indefinite object

    \xv ..., paáhettit petukonukqueaneg,...
    \xe ,,,, when thine accusers are also come. ...
    \so Acts 23.35
    \ng _3p_->2 participle
    \xv Qut ∞wemattin petukonont wematoh,...
    \xe But brother goeth to law with brother,...'    1 Cor.6.6  { 3->3
    \so conjunct [!] }

\lx petukqunneg
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a (round) cake, a cake or loaf of bread'
\so Mt.7.9
    (|petukqui@neg|    C.)
    pl. + |ash|    Judg.6.19,20
    |-ganash|    Mt.15.36

    \se petukqunnunk
    \va -ung(an
    \nt +
    \ps n. coll. / NI
    \ge `bread'
    \so Mk.8.4
    \xv ... onatuh puttugquanunkanit:...
    \xe ... like bread,...
    \so Ps.102.9; (M) |puttukqunnonkanit|
    \nt +

    \se |petukqunnegennu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative final, i-stem
    \ge `(for there) to be bread'
    \so Gen.41.54,47.13
    \xv ..., qut wame ohkit Egypt petukqunnegennu∞.
    \xe ...; but in all the land of Egypt there was bread.
    \so Gen.41.54
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv Kah wanne petukqunnegan∞ wame ohkìt ...
    \xe And there was no bread in all the land;...
    \so Gen.47.13
    \ng 0 negative indicative

    \se !|petukqunnunganehteau|, !|petukqunneganehteau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), creative final, built to either nominal stem.
    \ge `to make cakes (of sth)'
    \so Gen.18.6; Num.11.8
    \xv ..., kah wuttappóunneau pannehtu, kah uppetukqunnonganuhkoneau,...
    \xe ..., and [they] baked it [manna] in pans, and made cakes of it:...
    \so Num.11.8
    \ng 3p->0 objective

    \xv ..., tuttuhpunush petukqunneganéhteash ut n∞tau ahohttag.
    \xe ..., knead it, and make cakes upon the hearth.
    \so Gen.18.6; (E0): |petukqunnunganèhtaash|
    \ng 2 imperative

\lx petutteau
\va petuk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
    \nt Remark: palatalized |k| (cf. Josh.14.11); spurious entry |petukau|, T.124b, based on t-subordinative forms, belongs here.
    \nt +
\ps v.t. / AI, long-vowel stem; with (|ut| +) locative
\ge `he enters, goes into', +`to come into'
\so Gen.24.32; Ex.24.18
    \xv ...; kah pish kuppetutteam ut Arkut,...
    \xe ...; and thou shalt come into the ark,...
    \so Gen.6.18; (E0&1): |kuppetutteaum|
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., petutteaog weekit,...
    \xe ... [they] entered into his house:...
    \so Gen.19.3
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne nuttinnuhkesin yeuyeu, wutch ayeuwuttuonk, naneeswe sohhamunat kah petukonat.
    \xe ..., even so is my strength now, for war, both to go out, and to come in.
    \so Josh.14.11
    \ng X t-subordinative
    \nt +

    \xv Kah neg petutteacheg petutteau nompaus, kah squaus,...
    \xe ..., and they that went in, went in male and female ...
    \so Gen.7.16
    \ng _3p_ participle; 3 indicative

    imperat. 2d pers. sing. |pétutteash| `come thou in, enter in'    Gen.24.31,+49.6  { 2 imperative }

\dv |petau|.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Pétitees| `Come in'    R.W.7.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |nepitíghé| v. |nepeta8íghé|, 3. |pit|, 3 |pet.| `J'entre'.    R.220/446√.
    Algonquian [alg] |Pindike| `entrer'    Cq.342b.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |piinjíikeew| AI `come inside'    O'M.246b.
Ojibwe [oji] |Pindigé, (nin)| `I go in, I come in, I enter'    Bar.357a.
WAbn. |bidiga| AI `enter'; |npítiká| `I enter', |wpítikán| `he enters, goes into it'    D.1.109; W.99.]

\et B., 5, 87/442, 74, 110/467, no. 14 *piintwikeewa `he enters a dwelling'; A.1881-1882, H.2758, with the noun stem |-*wik-| `dwelling', H. p.249; G.1981, 39, 76.


\lx petutteaonau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
    \nt +
\nt Remark: cf. |petukonau|
\ps TA, applicative final, apparently to the palatalized AI stem |petutte-|.
\ge `to enter into sb, to come, go in unto sb'; euphemistically "to have sexual intercourse with sb"
\so Gen.16.4; Ruth 4.13; Mk.5.13,7.15,18; Lk.8.30,33; Jn.13.27; Rev.3.20,11.11
    \xv Kah petutteauóneau Hagaroh kah wompequoou,...
    \xe And he went in unto Hagar, and she conceived:...'    Gen.16.3  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., kah nishkeneunkque nashauanitt∞og sohhamwog kah petutteaunàog pigsoh,...
    \xe ... And the unclean spirits went out, and entered into the swine;...'    Mk.5.13  { 3p->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ...: howan n∞tog n∞wadtauatonkqussuonk, kah woshittan∞k, pish nuppetutteaon,...
    \xe ...: if any man hear my voice, and open the door, I will come in to him,...
    \so Rev.3.20
    \ng 1->3 objective

    \xv ..., kah petutteaònont, LORD wuttinnumauoh wompequauonk, kah wunnaumonieu.
    \xe ...: and when he went in unto her, the Lord gave her conception, and she bare a son.
    \so Ruth 4.13

\nt Remark: !|petakonau|, Gen.19.31, may be a variant, with (unexplained) vowel |a| and unpalatalized velar, as if the applicative final |-ôN-| has been combined with a formant lacking the AI final |-á-|.


\lx petuunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge `to put sb into (sth)', with locative
\so Gen.2.15(E0)
    |And         God   took             put him into  the garden Eden
    Onk Jehovah Manit neemunau Adam, & uppètuunuh    tanohketeonganit Eden|    Gen.2.15(E0); (E1&2): |upponuh|

\et Compare H.2745 *pi∙ntene∙wa TA `put in'


\lx peu
\va peeu
\va peweu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it is little, it is small'
    \xv péeu onk
    \xe (it is) less than
    \so Ezra 9.16
\nt This primary verb (represented by Cotton's |peawe|) is rarely found in Eliot by itself, but to it must be referred a great number of modal and derivate forms.

    \se péeheau
    \ps Caus. / TA
    \ge `he makes (him) small, causes him to be small'
    \xv kuppehesh
    \xe I make thee small
    \so Jer.49.15; Obad.2
    pass. `he is made small' (or `low'    James 1.10)

    Imperat. |péuh| `bring (thou) him low'    Job 40.12
\cf peásin

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |nepi8sessi, 3. pi8.| `Je suis petit', |pi8sesen| `Cela est petit'    R.392/505b.
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |PIW-| `menu; de peu de valeur', |Piwipo| `il neige un peu', |Piwandjigan| `miette', |Piwik,i| `être fluet'    Cq.350b-351a.
Cree |PIW| (rac.) `de rien, qui n'a aucune valeur, méprisable, reste, qu'on rejette, en petits morceaux'; |Pewä, pewe, pewi| `Scatter; worthless, useless, lowly, small'      Lac.D.573a; Frs.421b.
EOj. |pepi∙wa∙no∙n| `they (inan.) are small'    B.1957.257b.
Shawnee [sjw] |piiw-| `FEW, SMALL PIECES, INSUFFICIENT', |piiweΘi| `he lacks in quality, is not strong enough, is poor physically'    D.-V.97.
WAbn. |biwi| `small, fine, thin', |biwseso| AI `he is small', |biwsesen| II `it is small'     D.1.119-120.]

\et H.2784-2794 *pi∙w-, with his examples centred on states of aggregation of small fragmented items that often tend to be the remnants of some operation (chips, crumbs, scraps, shavings) and therefore of small size and of little value.

\so Trumbull 125

\lx peyau
\ve in need of considerable enlargement
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `he comes hither', +`to come [to some place]'
\nt G&B.514-515,540,693, stem |pëyô-|, with unstable (umlauting) |-ô-|
\nt Follow up needed: 
    \xv ONk neesuog Angelsog peyauog Sodom,...
    \xe And there came two Angels to Sodom...
    \so Gen.19.1
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., toh woh na kuppeam,...
    \xe ... till thou be come thither:...
    \so Gen.19.22
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Ahque unnantam∞k n∞che peam matcheheonat naumatuonk,...
    \xe Think not that I am come to destroy the law,...
    \so Mt.5.17
    \ng 1 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... n∞che peyom matta matcheheonat qut ussenat.
    \xe ...: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.
    \so Mt.5.17
    \ng 1 negative indicative
    \nt +

    suppos. part. |payont| `when coming'
    \xv ...,, peyauan Gerar...
    \xe ..., as thou comest to Gerar,...
    \so Gen.10.19
    \ng 2 (unchanged) conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ... nish noh ut uttôh paôog,...
    \xe ... at every place whither we shall come,...
    \so Gen.20.13
    \ng 1p->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., toh kô neit peont kemat∞ peissisit.
    \xe ..., except your youngest brother come hither.
    \so Gen.42.15
    \ng 3 unchanged conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Onk n nih payôog ahhut adtaomuk,...
    \xe And it came to pass, when we came to the inn,...
    \so Gen.43.21
    \ng 1p->_adv_ changed conjunct (subjunctive)

    imperat. |..., Peyaush ken,...| `..., Come thou ...'    Gen.7.1  { 2 imperative }
    |peyunk|, |peyonk| `come ye'    +Gen.45.19√

    \se |peyom∞|, |peyaum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, regular derivative
    \ge `to come (hither)'
    \nt G&B.581,693
    \so Gen.6.13,41.35
    \xv ..., kah asquam peyaumun∞ash sahtippomantogkup n∞shik,...
    \xe ..., and have not attained unto the days of the years of the life of my fathers...
    \so Gen.47.9
    \ng 0p negative indicative

    \xv ... yeush nesausuk adtahshinnu∞ukish kodtum∞ash paóm∞ugish:...
    \xe ... of those good years that come.
    \so Gen.41.35
    \ng _0p_ participle

    \se peyauau
    \ps v.t.an. / TA, dative
    \ge `he comes to (him)'
    \xv ..., nishnoh neesuog pish kuppeyauquog,...
    \xe ...; two of every sort shall come unto thee,...
    \so Gen.6.20
    \ng 3p->2 absolute
    \nt +

    \se |peyaoNau|, |peyauoNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative in |-ôN-|
    \twn |peyaontam|
    \ge `to come (un)to sb'
    \xv Qut God peyaonau Abimilechuh ut kouénat kah wuttinuh,...
    \xe But God came to Abimelech in a dream by night, and said to him,...'    Gen.20.3  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., Kusseh, kenaumon Joseph kuppéyaónuk,...
    \xe ..., Behold, thy son Joseph cometh unto thee:...
    \so Gen.48.2
    \ng 3->2 indicative
    \xv ..., Nen Jethro waseenumadt kuppeyaunsh,...
    \xe ..., I thy father in law Jethro am come unto thee,...
    \so Ex.18.6
    \ng 1->2 indicative
    \xv ..., & wame mukkinneonk pish kummoáe peyogquog,...
    \xe ..., all the assembly shall assemble themselves to thee ...
    \so Num.10.3; |peyóquog|    Num.10.4
    \ng 3p->2 indicative
    \xv ..., ahque wuttamteaush, k∞wehquetumoush kuppeyauósinat.
    \xe ..., Let nothing, I pray thee, hinder thee from coming unto me:
    \so Num.22.16
    \ng 2->1  t-subordinative
    \xv Kah matta kuppeyaáus∞mw∞, onk woh kutahtómw∞ {micheme} pomantamóonk.
    \xe And ye will not come to me, that ye might have life.
    \so Jn.5.40; Mayhew: |matta kuppeyaoseumw∞|
    \ng 2p->1 indicative

    \xv ... neyan∞wómuk, ne paôónukqueh,...
    \xe ... according to the cry of it, which is come unto me:...
    \so Gen.18.21
    \ng _0_->1 participle
    \xv ..., tohwutch peyaaúseóg kenaau,...
    \xe ..., Wherefore come ye to me,...?
    \so Gen.26.27
    \ng 2p->1 conjunct
    \xv ..., asq peyaaun∞un ut Egypt,...
    \xe ..., before I came unto thee into Egypt,...
    \so Gen.48.5
    \ng 1->2 negative (changed) subjunctive
    \xv ..., Nen pomantamóe petukqunneg, noh payaôsit matta pish kâkodtupp∞,...
    \xe ..., I am the bread of life: he that cometh to me shall never hunger;...
    \so Jn.6.35; Mayhew: |payaosit|
    \ng 3->1 participle

    \xv ..., monchek, kah pannupwushagk ohke, & koggohkham∞k, kah wonk peyaausek,...
    \xe ..., Go and walk through the land, and describe it, and come again to me,...
    \so Josh.18.8
    \ng 2p->1 imperative
    \xv Ahchue kód peyaauseh paswe.
    \xe Do thy diligence to come shortly unto me:
    \so 2 Tim.4.9; sim. Tit.3.12
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \xv ..., kah n∞wau, Howan kóhkutt∞g peyaausitch, kah wuttattaj,
    \xe ..., saying, If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink.
    \so Jn.7.37
    \ng 3->1 imperative

    \se !|peyaontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative
    \twn |peyaonau|
    \ge `to come (in)to sth, to attain (un)to sth'
    \so Jn.3.20,21; Phil.3.11
    \xv Tohneit ne teag wutcheu woh nuppeyaontamunat wutomohkeongan∞ napukeg.
    \xe If by any means I might attain unto the resurrection of the dead.
    \so Phil.3.11
    \xv Newutche nishnoh pas[u]k matcheseit, sekeneam wequai, kah matta peyaontam∞ wequai,...
    \xe For every one that doeth evil hateth the light, neither cometh to the light,...
    \so Jn.3.20; Mayhew: |matta peyâontom∞|

    \xv ..., kah nag pish kuppaudtunkqunnónog wonk kutt∞wonk, uttiyeu woh ayn kuhquéog, kah uttóh otanash pish páoontamagish,
    \xe ..., and bring us word again by what way we must go up, and into what cities we shall come.
    \so Deut.1.22
    \xv Qut ne wehque peyaontamóg pómushâdtuh nenan quttuhwhéganit, missontamuttuh ne nan teag,
    \xe Nevertheless, whereto we have already attained, let us walk by the same rule, let us mind the same thing.
    \so Phil.3.16

[Narragansett [xnt] |Peyáu| `he is come'; |Peeyâuog| `they are come'    R.W.34√.
Western Abenaki [abe] |neba| `je viens'; |i8 abañn| `il vient ici'.
Cree |pey-|, |péyche| `hitherward'.
Delaware [del] |peü| or |peyeya| `he comes'; part. |payat|; infin. |paan|; imperat. pl. |paak|; |pe ye yu| `it comes'    Zeisb.]

\et See G.1981, 14, 62, 36, 73, G.1982, 3.4, esp. fn.34, 24; and 1979, 4.7-4.8, 61-62 on unstable ä.


\lx piahquttum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\twn |piahtimau| TA
\ge `he has authority over, is master of (it)'
    \xv Ken pish kuppiahquttum wame neek,...
    \xe Thou shalt be over my house,...
    \so Gen.41.40
    \nt +
    infin. |piahquttumunat| `(to have) authority'    Mk.13.34

    \nt MN: noh piahquttuk wetu
    \ng suppositive |noh piahquttuk wetu| `the master of the house'    Mk.13.35
    \xv ..., kah piahqutuk ut neekit yeuoh Eleazar wut Damaskus.
    \xe ...? and the steward of my house is this Eliezer of Damascus.
    \so Gen.15.2
    \ng _3_->0 participle
    \nt +
    \xv piahquttuk sokanumun wuttattamoonk
    \xe the chief butler' (i.e. "he who rules the pouring of the drinks"), |piahquttuk apwon pétukqunungash| `the chief baker
    \so (i.e. "he who rules the baking of the bread")    Gen.40.20  { _3_->0 participle }
    \nt +

    \se piahquttumwe
    \ps As adj. and adv.
    \ge `chief, principal'
    \so Gen.40.2

    \se !|piahquttumwaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, causative
    \ge `to set sb over sth'
    \so Gen.41.33,41
    \xv ..., Naush kuppiahquttumwahush wame ohke Egypt.
    \xe ..., See, I have set thee over all the land of Egypt.
    \so Gen.41.41
    \ng 1->2+0

    \xv ..., kah piahquttumwahheonch ohkit Egypt,
    \xe ..., and set him over the land of Egypt.
    \so Gen.41.33
    \ng 2->3+0 imperative

[Narragansett [xnt] |Ntacquêtunck ewò.| `He is my subject.', |Kuttáckquêtous.| `I will subject to you.' "Beside their generall subjection to the highest {Sachims},... They have also particular Protectors, under {Sachims}". etc.    √R.W.133/r.141
Western Abenaki [abe] |netebérghé| `je gouverne'.]


\lx piahtimau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 125
    \nt +
\ps TA, oral final, palatalizing (lingual) variant (cf. G.1981.89)
\twn |piahquttum|, TI1b
\dv initial |piahqu-|.
\ge `to command sb, to reign over, be lord of sb'
\so Gen.18.19; Mk.10.3; Lk.9.1,19.27; Rom.14.9
    \xv Newutche n∞wáeh, noh woh piahtimau wunneechanoh,...
    \xe For I know him, that he will command his children...'    Gen.18.19  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv ..., Toh Moses kittinuppiahtimukou?
    \xe ..., What did Moses command you?
    \so Mk.10.3
    \ng 3->2p; |-in-| anaphoric to (adverbial) |toh|; not subordinative

    \xv Qut yeug nummatwomog, matta woh piahtimóogig, pas∞k, kah nush∞k ut anaquabeh,
    \xe But those mine enemies, which would not that I should reign over them, bring hither, and slay them before m.
    \so Lk.19.27
    \ng negative participle, 1->_3p_; relationship to AV obscure

    \xv ..., ahque piahtimehhettich:...
    \xe ..., let them not have dominion over me:...
    \so Ps.19.14(E&M)
    \ng 3p->1 imperative

    \se piahtuttum
    \nt Remark: palatalization by levelling, despite PA *-wet-, TI1b (cf. B.1962, 16.13, p.332; G.1981.89).
    \ps TI1b
    \ge `to be lord of sth'
    \so Mk.2.28
    \xv Newutche wosketomp wunnaumonuh, wonk piahtuttumóo Sabboth.
    \xe Therefore the Son of man is Lord also of the sabbath.
    \so Mk.2.28

\lx pittakúnnam
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 126
\ps v.i. / TIa
\ge `he goes back'
    \xv nippitt akúnna/mun.
    \xe I must goe back.
    \so R.W.75√

    \xv Pittúckish.
    \xe Goe back
    \so R.W.67/r.77
    \xv Pittuckétuck.
    \xe Let us goe back.
    \so R.W.67/r.77√
\cf petukau
\cf petukodtum
\nt (Perhaps R.W. mistook the signification of this word, `I go back', for `I go into the house'.)


\lx pittu
\va -eu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 126
\ps n. / ?
\ge `pitch'
\so Is.34.9; +Gen.6.14

    \se |pittukontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative as ornative
    \dv applicative to AI "verb of making" in |-uhk-| (B.1962, 15.13, 276-277; 16.69, 342-343)
    \ge `to pitch sth' (i.e. "coat sth with pitch")
    \so Gen.6.14
    \xv ...: kah pish kuppittukontamun wutch ánomut, kah woskeche pittu.
    \xe ..., and [thou] shalt pitch it within and without with pitch.
    \so Gen.6.14

[Cree |Pícku| `gum or pitch'; +|pícke{kátum}| `he pitches it, (i.e. adds pitch to it,) as a canoe.'    Howse 20.
    Algonquian [alg] |PIKIW| `poix, résine, gomme', |Pikike| `gommer, goudronner un canot'; |Pïkikâtan| `Gommer'    Cq.336b; Lem.D., s.v.]
    \nt +

\et G.1981, 39,43 77-78, 96; H.2582; S., no.102, 346-347: *pekiwa NA `gum, pitch, resin'

\lx piuhsuke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 126
\ps prep.
\ge `over against'
\so Neh.3.23,25,26
\ps adv. / PreV, PreN
\ge `fittingly, fitting'; +`directly' (of space); `plainly" (of speaking); `just' (i.e. "accurate", of weights and measures)
\nt G&B.694 `exactly'
    \xv Piuhsuke quttompagh∞tôsuongash, piuhsuke tuhkequnash, piuhsukequttuhwheg, kah piuhsuke qutchishquiaheg, kah kutahtauunaoash,...
    \xe Just balances, just weights, a just ephah, and a just hin, shall ye have:...
    \so Lev.19.36; (1): |pish| for the second |kah|, correctly.
    \nt +
    \xv ... piuhsuke anaquohtag mukkinneae kommukqut ...
    \xe ... directly before the tabernacle of the congregation ...
    \so Num.19.4
    \nt +
    \xv piuhsuke moehteómuk
    \xe fitly framed together
    \so Eph.2.21

    (|piuhsukke| `exact, right' (?); |piuhsu@kkéye@ue| `plainly'    C.)

    \se piuhsukehteau
    \ps v.caus. / TI2
    \ge `to cause to fit, to join so as to fit'
    \nt +

    suppos. |wunne piuhsukehtunk| `fitly joined together'    Eph.4.16 i.e. `made to fit' (inan. subj. {3->0})
\cf pápiuhsuke

\lx piuk
\va piuk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 126
\ps num.
\ge `ten'
    \xv Piuk. Piukqussuog, Piukqussuash.
    \xe 10
    \so El.Gr.14/260
    \xv ..., paguodche woh kenameh piukqussuog:...
    \xe ...: Peradventure ten shall be found there. ...
    \so Gen.18.32
    \nt +

    \se |piogqussu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, numeral verb (also II?)
    \ge `to be ten'
    \so Gen.8.5,18.32

    \xv ... nó pajeh piogqussuìt nepauz: piogqussuit nepauz, negonne kesukok,...
    \xe ... until the tenth month: in the tenth month, on the first day of the month,...
    \so Gen.8.5
    \ng 3->_adv_ participle
    \xv ..., Matta woh nuppaguanoog piukqusséhettit.
    \xe ..., I will not destroy {it} for ten's sake.
    \so Gen.18.32
    \ng 3p conjunct, quasi "if there are ten"?

    \se piogqué
    \va pioqué
    \va piukque
    \nt +
    \ps Adj. / PreN, PreV
    \ge `tenth', as ordinal, and fractional
    \nt +
    \so Deut.32.30; Ezek.45.14
    \xv piukque chippai
    \xe tenth part
    \so Gen.14.20
    \nt +

    |piogkut nompe| (`to the tenth time') `ten times'    Gen.31.7  { locative, multiplicative }

    (inan. pl. |píukquttash|    Ex.3.28)

[Narragansett [xnt] |piùck|    R.W.
= Peq. |piugg|    Stiles.
Western Abenaki [abe] |mtára|.
Cree |métàtat|; +|Päyuk| `One, a certain one', |Päyukoo| `He is alone, he is one'    ; Frs.412a-413b.

\lx -pog
\va -paug
\va -pogquash
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 126
\ps in comp. words / medial/final, NI
\ge `water'
\nt It represents the suppos. inan. concrete form of |'pi| (|n'pi|, |nippé|) `where water is'. |nippe| was not used in composition.  |-pôg|, the noun generic, was not used separately.
    \cf nunnipog
    \ge fresh water
    \so James 3.12
    \xv sépuash
    \xe rivers
    \so Ps.107.33√
    and |woskeche sepupogwut| `on the surface of (upon) the waters of the river'    Dan.12.6
    \xv Sepúpog wuttitchuwan nuskesukqut:...
    \xe Rivers of waters run down mine eyes...
    \so Ps.119.136; (M): |Sepuppogquash|
    \nt +
    (= |sepué nippeit|    Dan.12.7)
    |tohkekommupóg| (under |tohkekom|) `running (or spring) water'    Num.19.17; Josh.15.19
    |mishippag| (|mishe-pog|) `much water'    Jn.3.23
    \xv sonkipog
    \xe cool water
    \so Prov.25.25; Mt.10.42
    \xv séippog
    \xe salt water
    \so James 3.12
    \xv uppauppog
    \xe abundance of waters (cover thee)
    \so Job 22.11

\lx pogkenau

\ge `he divorces (her)'

    (|pakenau|    C.)

\et A.1793, H.2521, G.1967 (Notes), 9: *pakiΘe∙wa `to divorce'; basic sense of initial presumably `away, to a distance from' (sb/sth), with applicative final. B.1962, 16.64, p.126: pake∙nε∙w, pake∙tam `he sets him, it down, abandons him, it'

\lx pogkussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 127
\ps v.i.act.an. / AI
\ge `he drops, falls' (as an inan. body, or without external cause.
\cf penushau

    \nt MN: howan woh pogkussit
    \ng suppositive |howan woh pogkussit| `whoever shall fall'    Mt.21.4

    \se |pogkussin|
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \twn |pogkishin|
    \ge `to fall; to beat (into)'
    \so Mt.21.44, Mk.4.37, Lk.15.20, Rev. 6.13
    \xv Kah mishetashin, kah tukk∞og pogkussinwog kuht∞nogqut, neit yeuyeu numwohteau.
    \xe And there arose a great storm of wind, and the waves beat into the ship, so that it was now full.
    \so Mk.4.37
    \xv Kah kesukque anogqsog, pogkussinwog ohkeit, neyane figsuhtuk penuhteadt mas∞muneú∞gish figsash nanámanuhhukqut mehshehtahshinneuh.
    \xe And the stars of heaven fell unto the earth, even as a fig tree casteth her untimely figs, when she is shaken of a mighty wind.
    \so Rev.6.13

    \xv Kah howan woh pogkussik yeu qussukquanit pohksun, qut howan penushagqut yeu qussuk, uppeshquttáhhûkqun.
    \xe And whosoever shall fall on this stone shall be broken: but on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder.'    Mt.21.44 { form of |penushagqut| ? 3
    \so /X->3 TA cjt.?? }

    \se pogkishin(ni
    \va pogkushin
    \nt +
    \ps With inan. subj. / II
    \twn |pogkussin|
    \ge `it falls'
    \xv KAH wuttittanohtôadtuonk wunnaumonuh Joseph, pogkushin, wutch Jordan kishke Jericho,...
    \xe And the lot of the children of Joseph fell from Jordan by Jericho,...
    \so Josh.16.1
    \ng calque, AV following Vlg.; despite "Hebr. went foorth."
    \nt +
    pl. |-neash|    Nah.1.12

    \nt MN: ne pogshunk
    \ng suppositive |ne pogshunk| `it (when) falling'    Is.34.4
    \ng to |pogkushau|?
\cf pwohkehchuau

    Western Abenaki [abe] |nebaghesin.| `Je tombe un peu loin'    R.480/535a.

\lx pohkeni
\va -nái
\va pohkenai
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 127
\ps v.i. / II, NI (see below), PreN
\ge `it is dark'; adj. `dark'; n. `darkness'
\so Gen.18.17; Is.5.20; 45.7; Amos 5.18
    \xv Kah nnih waont onk pohkenai....
    \xe And it came to pass that when the Sun went down, and it was {dark},...
    \so Gen.15.17
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv An∞nau pohkenáiyeuoh, onk ayim pohkenai:...
    \xe He sent darkness, and made it dark:...
    \so Ps.105.28; (M) |uppohkunnahtauunap| (v.i.)
    \ng 0 subordinative; MT hiphil
    \nt +

    \xv Onk nnih, papaume kobhamuk squontamash, papohkenagk,...
    \xe And it came to pass about the time of shutting of the gate, when it was dark,...
    \so Josh.2.5
    \ng reduplicated 0->_adv_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv pohkenahtu
    \xe in darkness
    \so Eccl.2.14

    \se pokenáe
    \ps Adv. and adj.
    \ge `darkly, obscurely'
    \so Job 22.13; 1 Cor.13.12
    \xv ..., kah kusseh mishe pohkeni webesuonk wunuhkukkongqun.
    \xe ...: and lo, an horror of great darkeness fell upon him.
    \so Gen.15.12
    \ng PreN
    \nt +


    \se pohpohkeni
    \ps Intens.
    \so Job 24.15

    \se !|pohkinnahteau|, |pohkinteau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, creative final
    \ge `to make darkness'
    \so Ps.18.11, Ps.104.20(M)
    \xv Pohkinteau wutassampamugquodt∞m:...
    \xe He made darkness his secret place:...
    \so Ps.18.11
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \xv Kuppohkinnahteam, kah nuhkanyeuoo:...
    \xe Thou makest darkness, & it is night:...
    \so Ps.104.20(M)
    \ng 2 indicative

    \se !|pohkenahtau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to make it dark'
    \so Ps.105.28(M)
    \xv Annootamup pohkunnai, kah uppohkunnahtauunap:...
    \xe He sent darkness, and made it dark:...
    \so Ps.105.28(M)
    \ng 3->0 preterite objective; MT hiphil

\dv Related to |pohki| `clear, open', as "lucus" to "lucendo", etc.
\cf paúpakinasik
\cf pógkenum
\cf kuppogki

[Narragansett [xnt] |Paukúnnum.|    `Darke.'    R.W.64.
Western Abenaki [abe] |pekenem| v. |pekeneghé| ` Il fait bien obscure (non dans la maison) mais dehors, nuit obscure'    R.364/494b.
Delaware [del] |páckenam|, `very dark'; |páhku@num| II `be dark'    Hkw.; O'M.218a.]

\ge `be dark, darkened' (i.e. be in a dark state?)

    \xe shall the sun be darkened
    \so Mt.24.29

    \xe ..., and the darkness he called Night:...
    \so Gen.1.5

[Delaware [del] |pákenum.| `Dark.'; |Pahkenum|, |Pakenum| `dark'; |páhku@num| II `be dark'    Z.52; B&A.105,106; O'M.218a.

\lx pohkenittipukok
\ve pohkeni-típuk∞k

\lx pohki
\va pahke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 128
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it is clear, transparent, that may be seen through, pervious'
\so Rev.2.11,18
\ps Adj.
\ge `clean, pure'
\so Lev.11.36; Prov.30.5; Ps.51.10
    \xv Kuttinn∞wáonk m∞cheke pohki;...
    \xe Thy word is very pure:...
    \so Ps.119.140; (M): |pohki|
    \nt +

    \se pahke
    \ps Adv.
    \ge `clearly, plainly'
    (|pohkiyeu|    C.)

    Suppos. inan. |póhkok| `when it is clear'; hence, `the (clear) sky'    Mt.16.2,3; Ps.77.17
    \xv yowutche kuskesuk pohkag,...
    \xe if therefore thine eye be single,...' [Vlg. `simplex
    \so ]    Mt.6.22
    \nt +
    \xv pohkohquodt
    \xe when clear, in clear weather, a clear day
    (Cotton has |pahke| and |pohkiyeu| `clearly'; |pohkoiye@ue| `clean'; |pahkeye@uê| `cleanlily'.)
\cf pohquáe

\nt The three roots, |pohk|, (|pâk|), |pohq| (|pôgh|), |pohsh| (|pâsh| or |pâj|), have all the same ultimate base, with the idea of division or separation into parts. |pohq-| and its derivatives denote the act of separating (breaking, opening, beating out, etc.); |pohsh-|, the fact of division or partition (|pohshe|, `half, part of', etc.), and |pohk| (|pohki|, |pakke|) the result of separation, openness, perviousness, a going through.
[Cf. Tamil |pag-u| `to divide, to share'; |pôr| `to cleave'; |pâl| `a
part, a portion'; |pang-u| `a share'    Caldw. 446, 475.
Sansk. |bhag| `dividere'; |bhâg| `dividere, distribuere'; |bhâ'ga| `pars, portio'; |bhan'j|, `frangere'; |pakshá|, `latus, dimidia pars mensis'. These groups of derivatives from a common root correspond nearly with English (and Anglo-Saxon) words beginning with THR: thorough, through, throw (= to through, A.S. thrawan), thrust, thrash (A.S. thersc-an), threshold (A.S. thersc-el, thræcs-wald), thread, throat, throttle, thrill (A.-S. thirlian), and drill, etc.]

[Narragansett [xnt] |pâuqui|, |pâuquaquat| `it holds up' (i. e. the sky clears), R.W. 82.
Western Abenaki [abe] |pañg8^i8i| `purement, sans mélange' (|pañg8^i8i 8ios| `I eat clear meat'); |pa`k8^é| `an arrow'; |pi`kañn| `thread'.
    Alg |PAKAK| `clair, éclatant'    Cq.319b-320a.]
    \nt ?+

    \nt +

\ge `to make darkness sth'

    \nt This is probably a mistranslation, with the meaning "he made his secret place dark". (M) rewords it.

\lx pohquodchabuk-

wheatash k∞chu.| `..., ; lest while ye gather up the tares, ye root up also the wheat with them.'    Mt.13.29  { 2p->0 indicative }


\lx pohquodche
\va poquodche
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \nt Remark: Initial also in |pohquáe| `manifest, open, public', v.s.?
    \nt +
\ps as prep. / PreN
\ge `without, outside of'; primarily `in open air, out of doors', +`abroad, public'
\nt G&B.697, s.v. |pukqua/chimiyeu| P `towards the outside'

    \xv Kah weyáus kah ashkon, wutchikossoh n∞taut poquodche tuppuksinn∞wonganit.
    \xe And the flesh and the hide he burnt with fire without the camp.

    \nt +

    \xe And he brought him forth abroad,...
    \so Gen.15.5
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut nutapimun poquadchik wompanu.
    \xe ...; but we will abide in the street all night.
    \so Gen.19.2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., tohwutch nepaiyean poquadchit?...
    \xe ...; wherefore standest thou without?...
    \so Gen.24.31
    \xv ..., pish wussohh∞wunuh en pohquadchit tuppuksinn∞wonganit ...
    \xe ..., shall he carry forth without the camp...
    \so Lev.4.12
    \ng cf. Lev.9.11, supra
    \nt +
    \xv ut poquadchik

    \xe without

\lx Tawhich neepouweéye an Pucqúatchick?
