\lx pohquohham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 129
\ps v.i. / TI1a(-O), probably with mechanical final; initial |pohqu-| `break' or `outside'?
\ge `he goes clear, escapes'; +`to be quit' (i.e. OED. s.v. 1. "Free, clear")
    \xv ..., neit nequt chepiyeuog neg sequttahwhutcheg, woh pohquohhamwog.
    \xe ..., then the other company which is left shall escape.
    \so Gen.32.8
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah noh wodtaiheit, oxinoh pohquohham.
    \xe ...; but the owner of the ox shall be quit.
    \so Ex.21.29
    \nt +

    \xv Onk pasuk peyau pohquohhogkup, kah unnau Abramwoh wut-Hebrew,...
    \xe And there came one that had escaped, and told Abram the Hebrew;...
    \so Gen.14.13
    \ng _3_ preterite participle
    \nt +

    imperat. |..., pohquohush en wadchuut,...| `...; escape to the mountain,...'    Gen.19.17√ { 2 imperative; vowel |-u-| in all three editions }

    \se |pohquohhamoe|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge "of escape", in "scapegoat"
    \so Lev.16.8,10,26
    \xv Qut nomposhimwe goat, noh wuttittanohtôadtuonk pohquohhamoe goat pagshik, pish keteae nepauweheau anaquabit Jehovah,...: kah ummoncheaheoneat, wutch pohqohhamoe goat, en touohkomuk.
    \xe But the goat, on which the lot fell to be the scapegoat, shall be presented alive before the Lord,..., and to let him go for a scapegoat into the wilderness.
    \so Lev.16.10

    \se pohquohwhunau
    \ps caus. / TA, applicative final
    \twn |pohquohwhuttau|
    \ge `he makes (him) go clear, delivers (him)', +`to redeem sb'
    \nt G&B.688
    \so Lk.11.14
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pohquohwhehteae asq kuppohquohwhunoh kummissinninumog.
    \xe ...; neither hast thou delivered thy people at all.
    \so Ex.5.23
    \ng 2->3, absolute negative; cognate preverb to stem with indefinite object (G&B. no.14, 580)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah na matta howan uppohquohwhunonat.
    \xe ..., and there was none to save her.
    \so Deut.22.27
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nemehkuh kuppohquohwhuninnumwop wutch wunnutcheganit.
    \xe ...: so I delivered you out of his hand.
    \so Josh.24.10
    \ng 1->2p
    \nt +
    \xv ...: Jehovah pish uppohquohwhunoh wuttammepunanit.
    \xe ...: the Lord will deliver him in time of trouble.
    \so Ps.41.1; (M): |uppohquohwunnuh|
    \nt +
    \xv Noh wómônat woh pohquohwhunau:...
    \xe That thy beloved may be delivered;...
    \so Ps.60.5; (M): |pohquahwunnou|
    \ng X->3
    \nt +
    \xv Wekontash, Woi Jehovah, kuppahquahwussinnat:...
    \xe Be pleased, O Lord, to deliver me:...
    \so Ps.40.13(M)
    \ng 2->1
    \nt +

    \xv Noh Angel pohquohwhunugqueh wutch wame matchitut,...
    \xe The angel which redeemed me from all evil,...
    \so Gen.48.16
    \ng _3_->1 participle
    \nt +

    imperat. |pohquohwhus kuhhog| `save thyself'    Lk.23.37,39  { 2->3 imperative }
    \xv Puhquohwusseh...wutche wunnu(t)cheganit nemat,...
    \xe Deliver me,..., from the hand of my brother,...
    \so Gen.32.11
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., pohquohwusseh,...
    \xe ..., to deliver me:...
    \so Ps.40.13
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \nt +

\dv |pohki| or |pohqui|, and |∞m| `he goes'.

    \se !|pohquohwhuttau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2
    \twn |pohquohwhuNau|, TA
    \ge `to deliver sth (from sth)'; `to escape'
    \so Gen.19.17; Ps.81.6
    \xv ...: wunnutchegash pohquohwuttaúunash wutch ayeuónat akuhquog.
    \xe ...: his hands were delivered from the pots.
    \so Ps.81.6; (M): |pohquahwhuttosupash|
    \ng (E) X->0p objective

    \xv ..., Pohquohwhutaush kuppomantamóonk,...
    \xe ..., Escape for thy life;...
    \so Gen.19.17
    \ng lit. "deliver thy life" 2->0 imperative?

    [|Nuppoquohwussu|, etc., `our Savior'    (title-page of N.T.)
    \xv nuppohquohwussuaen
    \xe deliverer
    \so Judg.3.9
    \xv nuppohquohwussuén
    \xe my Savior
    \so 2 Sam.22.2
    \xv kuppohquohwussuaeneum
    \xe thy (own) Savior
    \so Is.43.3
    \xv nohpohquohwhunont
    \xe he who saves (them), who delivers
    \so Judg.3.9; 1 Tim.4.10
    \xv woi ken pohquohwuss∞aen
    \xe O thou that savest!
    \so Ps.17.7
    \xv uppohquohwhunoh
    \xe he saveth them
    \so Ps.107.13,19,20
    `delivered them'    Ps.107.6
    \xv nag pohquoh whunnoncheh Jehovah
    \xe the redeemed of the Lord
    \so Ps.107.2
    \xv pôhquetahham
    \xe he cuts (it) asunder
    \so Ps.107.16
    \xv tomohinnean
    \xe deliver thou us
    \so Judg.10.15
    \ng ?
    \xv pohquahwusseh
    \xe deliver thou me
    \so (intr.)    Ps.119.153
    \xv pohquahwhuneh wutch
    \xe deliver thou me from
    \so Ps.119.134
    \xv pohquahwusseh wutch
    \xe -- evil men'    Ps.140.1 ( `-- my persecutors
    \so Ps.142.6)
    \xv pohquahwussinan wutch
    \xe deliver thou us from
    \so 1 Sam.12.10
    \xv pohquahwussinean
    \xe deliver thou us
    \so (intr.)    Ps.79.9
    \xv pohquahwhunittuonk
    \xe deliverance
    \so Judg.15.18, +Gen.45.7
    \xv pohquohham∞onk
    \xe escaping
    \so Ezra 9.14
    \xv wutch nummatcheseonganunônash
    \xe our iniquities
    \so Ezra 9.6, 7
    \xv nuppohqúnum nummeesunk
    \xe I plucked off my hair
    \so Ezra 9.3]

[NOTE -- The examples inclosed in brackets under this definition appear on a loose slip inserted in the manuscript. They were neither revised nor arranged by the compiler.]

\lx pohshequáe
\va puhsh-
\va pohshequaeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 129
    \nt Remark: No instance in |-ae| yet found.
    \nt +
\ps adv. / AI; perhaps also as an "agent" noun by conversion?
\ge `at noon', +`the sixth hour' (Jn.19.14, Acts 10.9; literal tr. at Mt.27.45, Mk.15.33, Lk.23.44, Jn.4.6, Jn.19.14(M))
\so +Gen.43.16,25; 2 Sam.4.5; 1 K.18.26,27,20.16; 2 K.4.20; Song 1.7; Jer.6.4; Zeph.2.4
    \xv ...: nuttogkussittâssunumun pohshequaeu, onatuh nohkog,...
    \xe ...: we stumble at noonday as in the night;...
    \so Is.59.10
    \nt +

    \xv ... yeug woh n∞weepemukquog puhshaquodt.
    \xe ... these men shall dine with me at noon.
    \so Gen.43.16
    \ng 3 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah wehquetumwog ∞wesuonk Baal, wutch mohtompanaeu nó pajeh pohshequaut,...
    \xe ..., and called on the name of Baal from morning even until noon,...
    \so 1 K.18.26
    \nt +
    \xv Wanûnk∞ukish: kah mohtompogkish kah puhshaquadcheh nuppeantam,...
    \xe Evening and morning, and at noon will I pray,...
    \so Ps.55.17; (M) |puhshaquadcheh|
    \ng 3 conjunct iterative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah kuppohkenaiyeum pish tatuppeyeu∞ pohshaquadt.
    \xe ..., and thy darkness [shall] be as the noonday:
    \so Is.58.10
    \nt +
    \xv ..., n∞wayah nepauz puhshadquadt,...
    \xe ..., that I will cause the sun to go down at noon,...
    \so Amos 8.9
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Peter au woskeche weetuómut peantam puhshaquodt.
    \xe ..., Peter went up upon the housetop to pray about the sixth hour.
    \so Acts 10.9√

\dv |pohshe| `half the day or sun's course'.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Yáhen Páushaquaw.| `Allmost noone', |Páweshaquaw.| `Noone.', |Nawwâuquaw.| `After-noone.' [cf. various entries that follow.]    R.W.62-63√.
Western Abenaki [abe] |pask8^é| `Il est midi, seu, le milieu du jour'    R.302/472b,343/487b,464/529b.
Delaware [del] |Pachhacqueke| `at noon'; +|Pachhakqueu| `noon'    Zeisb.Gr.171; B&A.105.
    Algonquian [alg] |-AKWE| `être (en parlant du soleil)'; |Nawakwe| `il est midi' [fn.2: "Littéralement: `il (le soleil) est au milieu de sa course'. Ce mot appartient au dialecte Sauteux;..."]    Cq.35b; 264a.
    \nt +
Fx. |-A`kwä-| (|-ahkwe∙-|) `course of sun', "with |näwi-| (|na∙wi-|) `noon'"; |na∙wi| `in the middle', |na∙wahkwe∙wi| `it is noon'    Mch.St.624a; Fx.L.120.
K. |naahkwee-, náahkwee-| II `be noon'; |naahkwei, náahkwei|    V.76.
Lp.A. |nahni pansk8au| `il sera bientot midy', |pansk8ata| `a midy'    D.5,95,105.
Mahican [mjy] |naachqua~ta| `mittags'    Schm.102.
Menominee [mez] |na∙wahkow| AI `he (the sun) is at noonday position; he eats the noonday meal', |as na∙wahkik| `at noon, in the south', |as na∙wahkit| `when he eats the noon'    M.L.149.
M.-P. |(koti) pasqe| II `it is (almost) noon', |kisi pasqe| `it is afternoon', |kisi pasqek| `in the afternoon'    LeS.66b.
WAbn. |Paskua.| `Noon; it is noon.', |Paskuak.| `At noon.'; |Môjob kizi paskuat nisômkipodak.| `He started after twelve o'clock (noon)'; |baskwa| NA `noon'    L.19;101; D.1.80.]

\et cf. H.3382 *Θa∙waxkwe∙wi II `it is noon', H., p.244 *-axkw- `sky'

\lx pom-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 130
    \nt +

\ps initial
\ge "move, progress (dynamism either ith respect to an external frame of reference or internally?)"
\so following entries

    [Algonquian [alg] |PIM-| ({i}-bref) `ne set le plus souvent que comme appui à certains verbes qui ne pourraient subsister à l'état isolé ...", "devant un v. complet ... servira à exprimer notre v. français {passer}"    Cq.338b-339a, fn.(1).
    \nt +
Fox "|pem(i)-| expresses the notion of MOVEMENT BY, PAST, ALONGSIDE."..."It comes to have the force of an inchoative.... |pe'm{usä`w^a| `he started off on a walk' (|-usä-| secondary stem TO WALK...)"    J.1911.768-769.]

\et This is evidently connected with PA *pem-, whatever the phonological details may be.

\lx pômantam
\va pomantam
\va pomontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 130
\ps v.i. / TI1a(-O), mental final
\ge `he lives'
\nt G&B.695
\so Gen.5.10,16,19, etc.
    \xv ôâas uppomantamun
    \xe living creature
    \so Gen.2.19
    \ng ?3 subordinative, attributive
    \nt +

    \nt MN: pomantog
    \ng suppositive |pomantog| `when he lives (or lived)'    Gen.5.12,13,15,18, etc.
    \ps adv
    \xv Qut wunnamuhkut neane pomantam,...
    \xe But as truly as I live,...
    \so Num.14.21
    \ng 1->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    part. (indic.) |pamontamunutcheh mukkiesoh| `the living child'    1 K.3.26  { _3'_ participle }
    \xv ..., ash waeeche pomantam∞munogkup yeu kesukok, kutayeuuhmonomw∞ Jehovah,...
    \xe ..., while I am yet alive with you this day, ye have been rebellious against the Lord;...
    \so Deut.31.27
    \ng consociative derivative, 1->2p+_adv_, changed preterite conjunct
    \nt +

    \se |pompomantam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a-O, reduplicated
    \ge `to be alive, to live', in durative senses (see also exs. from Loup A)
    \so Gen.43.28; Ps.49.9(M)
    \xv .... kittinnum n∞shun pompomantam,...
    \xe ..., he is yet alive. ...
    \so Gen.43.28
    \xv Onk woh micheme pompumontam,...
    \xe That he should still live for ever,...
    \so Ps.49.9(M)

    \se pomantamóonk
    \va pomantam∞ong(an
    \nt +
    \ps Vbl.n. / deverbal noun, NI
    \ge `living, life'

    \se !|pomantam∞wonganu|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge "(for there) to be a life"
    \so Gen.18.10

    \xv ..., ne adt∞che pomantam∞wonganú∞k,...
    \xe ... according to the time of life;...
    \so Gen.18.10
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle

    \se |pomantawamheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to keep, preserve sb alive, to save sb's life, quicken sb's mortal body, ...'
    \so Gen.47.25; Ex.1.17,22.18; Num.22.33,31.18; Deut.6.24; Acts 27.34; Rom.8.11; 1 Cor.15.22
    \xv Kah n∞waog kuppomantamwahimun ...
    \xe And they said, Thou hast saved our lives:...
    \so Gen.47.25
    \ng 2->1p indicative
    \xv ..., wunnamuhkut wonk ken woh kenushish, kah noh woh nuppomantamwah.
    \xe ..., surely now also I had slain thee, and saved her alive.
    \so Num.22.33
    \xv ...: kuppompomantamwáheh,...
    \xe ...: thou hast kept me alive ...
    \so Ps.30.3 { to reduplicated stem }; (M) |kuppompomantamwahip|
    \xv Newutche k∞weequetumaunumw∞ meetsek, newutche yeu kuppomantamwahukqunneau,...
    \xe Wherefore I pray you to take some meat; for this is for your health:...
    \so Acts 27.34

    \xv Pomantamwaheúhkon pauwau.
    \xe Thou shalt not suffer a witch to live.
    \so Ex.22.18
    \xv Qut wame mukkiésog kenugke muttamwossisut, ..., neg pomantamwahheuk.
    \xe But all the women children, ..., keep alive for yourselves.
    \so Num.31.18

    \se pomantamwáe
    \va pomantamoe
    \nt +
    \ps Adj. and adv. / PreN, PreV
    \dv The first form is clearly built to the extended stem of the TI verb (G&B.578).
    \nt +
    \ge `living', +`alive, of life'
    \so Gen.1.20,21,2.7,33,50.20
    \nt +
    \xv nishnoh pomantamoe óâas
    \xe every living creature
    \so Gen.1.21
    \nt +
    \xv ... pomantamwae wadchanonat monaog missinninuog.
    \xe ..., to save much people alive.
    \so Gen.50.20

    \se |pomantam∞m∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, regular II final
    \ps "to be alive, live'
    \so Gen.7.3
    \xv ..., onk woh pomantam∞m∞ ∞skannemunnu ut woskeche ohket.
    \xe ...; to keep seed alive upon the face of all the earth.
    \so Gen.7.3
    \ng 0 indicative

\dv |pâme| (or |pam∞|) `it continues', with |-antam|, the formative of verbs of mental and emotional activity. See |pâme|. An earlier derivative, |pômetu| (|pôm-ohteau|), he `continues to be', is not found in Eliot, but he has its verbal, |pometuonk| (q.v.).

[Narragansett [xnt] |Asnpaumpmaûntam| `I am very well.' (`am yet alive'); |Taubot paump/maúntaman| `I am glad you are well.', |Táu bot ne paump/maunthéttit| `I am glad they are well.'    R.W.2-3.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |n8ripemañ8'si| `je suis en bonne santé'.
Cree |pémoot-ayoo| `he walks'; |pemát-issu| `he is alive'; |pémoot-aymagun| `it goes' (as a watch)    Howse 36,80.
Delaware [del] |pommauchsu| `he lives'; part. (suppos.) |pemauchsit|    Zeisb.Gr.
    Algonquian [alg] |Pimatis,i| `vivre, &c.' (with footnote)    Cq.339a.
    \nt +
Lp.A. |mat chipki nikata8i ponpementam8mena| `nous ne vivons pas long temps'; |ki taik8i pemantam8men| `notre vie est courte'; |natang8s, 8ligan panpemantaman| `Mon cousin c'est bien que tu sois en vie'    D.47;48;75.]

\et G.1965, fn.10, 208a "best taken as from" *peme∙lentamwa. (Glossed "heed" at H.2606.)

\lx pompu

    \ge `play, sport'
    \so Judg.16.25
    (|puhu@onk| `playing'; |pompoonk| `recreation'    C.;
    `If any Man profane the Lords-Day, by Work or Play.' Howan nishketeadt Sabbathdayik (ukkesukodteum Nussontimomum Jesus Christ) nashpe Anakausuonk asuh nashpe pohmpooonk.    Ind.Laws, IV√)

[Narragansett [xnt] |pauochaúog| `they are playing'    R.W.
Cree |pâpu| `he laughs'; intens. |pa@pâpu|; freq. |pâpisku|.
Chip. (St Marys) |paú-pë|, (Sag.) |pah-pa| `he laughs'    Sch.II.469.
Delaware [del] |papaby| (for |papahy|?) `to play'; +|Papabin| `to play' (arch., A)    Zeisb.; B&A.108.18
    Algonquian [alg] |PAP,I| `rire', |Papih| `{fais-le rire, ris avec lui, souris-lui}, fais-lui un sourire bienveillant'     Cq.328ab.]
    \nt +
\et ? A.1770, B. 1925, p.152, H.2473-2475 *pa∙hpiwa AI `laughs'


\lx pompuhchái
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 130
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a member, organ, limb, or part of the body'

    \xv Kah bullock, asuh lamb, noh anuwéyeuuk uppohchaiyeum, ásuh quenaúwéhikqut: woh kummagun wutch unnantamwe sephausuonk,...
    \xe Either a bullock or a lamb that hath any thing superfluous or lacking in his parts, that mayest thou offer for a freewill offering;...

    \ng unreduplicated form?
    \nt +

    \xe the virile organ

\lx pomushau
\va pomuhshau
\va paumushau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 130
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he walks'
\ge `he journeys, goes a journey', but in this sense the freq. |popomushau| is more commonly used.
\so 1 K.18.27; 2 K.10.31
\ge `he goes or passes by', `to pass away, on'
    \nt G&B.697
    \nt +
    \xv ..., mahche ne nag woh kuppaumshaumw∞,...
    \xe ..., after that you shall passe on:...
    \so Gen.18.5
    \ng 2p indicative

    \nt MN: pomushadt
    \ng Suppositive |pomushadt| (and |pamwushadt|) `when he walks, if he walk'    Ex.21.19; Gen.3.8
    \xv noh pomushadt
    \xe he who walks
    \so Jn.12.35

    \xv ..., ahque paumshaush k∞wchquetumoush wutch kittinninnúmut.
    \xe ..., pass not away, I pray thee, from thy seruant:
    \so Gen.18.3
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +

    \se pâmsheau
    \va pamushau
    \ps With inan. subj. / II
    \ge `it goes on, passes, is past', +(including borders, paths, ways)
    \xv Kah Pharoh nag, sokanon, kah musségon, & padtahquahan pamusháash, kah wonk matchesu, kah menuhketeop wuttah,...
    \xe And when Pharaoh saw that the rain and the hail and the thunders were ceased, he sinned yet more, and hardened his heart,...
    \so Ex.9.34
    \nt +
    \xv Kah sussippoi weenushau wutch Baalah wutcheksuiyeu wehque wadchuut Seir, kah pamsheau en kishkontu wadchuut Jearim (ne Chesalon) nanummiyeu, kah womsisháu Bethshemesh, kah pamushau en Timnah.
    \xe And the border compassed from Baalah westward unto mount Seir, and passed along unto the side of mount Jearim, which is Chesalon, on the north side, and went down to Bethshemesh, and passed on to Timnah:
    \so Josh.15.10
    \nt +
    pass.inan. (|pâmsheom∞|) |paumushóm∞| `it is passed by or over'    Is.40.27; Jer.6.4
    \xv ..., kah mishant∞waongash kah mussegon paumshaúm∞ash,...
    \xe ...: and the thunders and hail ceased,...
    \so Ex.9.33
    \nt +

    \xv Kah maumuttamwe kesukodtash pamushunk,...
    \xe And when the days of his mourning were past,...
    \so Gen.50.4
    \ng 0 changed conjunct
    \nt +

    \se |pomushaum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, derived
    \ge `to go upon sth'
    \so Gen.7.18
    \xv ...: kah Ark pomushaum∞ woskeche nippekontu.
    \xe ...; and the ark went upon the face of the waters.
    \so Gen.7.18

    \se pomushaen
    \ps N.agent.
    \ge `one who is walking, a traveler'
    pl. |-nuog|    Job 31.32

    \se pomusháonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a journey'
    \so Gen.24.21; 1 K.19.7
    \ge `a walk'

    \se popomushau
    \va -wushau
    \ps Freq. / AI
    \ge `he walks much, goes about, travels, journeys'
    \so Acts 10.38; Mt.9.35 (|papaum-|)

    imperat. |popómshagk| `walk ye'    Jn.12.35

    \se popomsheau
    \ps Freq. with inan. subj. / II
    \ge `it moves about'

    \se |pamwushaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to make sb to pass'
    \so Gen.8.1
    \xv ...kah GOD pamwushaheau wabanoh ohket,...
    \xe ...: and God made a wind to pass over the earth,...'    Gen.8.1  { 3->3
    \so absolute }

    \se !|pomuhshohtou|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, ?applicative
    \ge `to go upon sth'
    \so Gen.3.14
    \xv ...: kenogkis kuppomushohtou,...
    \xe ...; upon thy belly shalt thou go,...
    \so Gen.3.14
    \ng 2->0 absolute

    \se |pomushaumau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, consociative final, in collocation with |weeche|
    \ge `to walk with sb'
    \so Gen.5.24,6.9
    \xv ..., Noah weeche pomushaumau GOD.
    \xe ..., and Noah walked with God.'    Gen.6.9  { 3->3
    \so absolute }

\dv |pâme| (|pummeu|). The primary form of this verb appears to be |pomussu| (see Muh. and Abn. equivalents below), the act. intrans. form (`he continues doing'), as |pom-antam| is the simple intrans. or neuter form (`he continues feeling or thinking, he lives'), and |pomohhom| (or |pám-w∞m|), the inact. intrans. (`he continues going, passively or without action of his own, he sails or goes by boat'). This primary form is energized in |pomushau| by the aspirate, as in the intens. |ussishau| for usussu.
\cf ussë'nát
\cf m'seet
\cf musseet
\so Sansk. pamb, ire, se movere

[Narragansett [xnt] |as pummíssin| `he is not yet departed' (`he lives yet'); |nowécontum púmmishem| `I have a mind to travel'; |as-pumméwi| `he is not gone by'; pl. |aspumméwock|    R.W. This last is an earlier form, which I do not find used by Eliot* [|pom-áu| `he continues going or travels to a place' (see |au|), `goes onward, passes by'], corresponding nearly to the v.i. inan. subj. (and impers.) |pummeu|, |paamu| `it goes on, passes'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nepem8ssé| `je marche'; |pem8ssé| `il marche'.
Mahican [mjy] |n`pumseh| `I walk'; |paumseet| `he who walks, he walking'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |pemiëi| `I walk'.
Cree |Pémoot{ayoo}| `he walks'    Howse 31√.
Chip. (St Marys) |pim-ö-sai'| `he walks', (Sag.) |pemussay|.
Delaware [del] |pomsu|; suppos. |pemsit|    Zeisb.Gr.
    WAbn. |babemosa| AI `he goes farther, he goes by (walking) ...(also |bôbemosa| and |babamosa|)'    D.1.60,58,135.]
    \nt +

[*NOTE. -- The compiler afterward wrote the following in pencil on the margin: "Correct this. Eliot has the verb |ash pam∞adt|, Lk.22.47, `while he was going on', and |pummeu| is v.i.inan.subj."]

\et A.1835, H.2645 *pemwohΘe∙wa `walk' (with reshaping?).

\lx ponanau
\va ponunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 131
\nt Remark: The relationship of these forms to |ponau|, |ponam| is not clear to me--the meanings appear to overlap, and the syncope of medial syllables in |-unun-| seems to be common. (These latter forms have good comparative support, but the structure is unusual, an initial |pon-| with no final, merely a theme sign.) It is possible that they were confused.
\ps v.t. an. / TA, manual final
\ge `he lets loose, sets free' (an an.obj.); +`to let sb go'
    \so Gen.32.26,49.21; Ex.4.26; Lev.14.7,53; Lk.(2.34?),22.68; Acts 4.23
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish ponunau, pomantamóe psuksesoh,...
    \xe ..., and [he] shall let the living bird loose ...
    \so Lev.14.7√
    |qunnegq ponunau| (pass.) `a hind (is) let loose'    Gen.49.21√  { X->3 }
    \xv ..., kah n∞wau, Matta kupponann∞h. kuttumma wunnanumeaen.
    \xe ... And he said, I will not let thee go, except thou bless me.
    \so Gen.32.26
    \ng 1->2 negative, syncopated
    \nt +

    \xv Kah ponunnahettit, wonk moncheog en weetatteamunganuwóut,...
    \xe And being let go, they went to their own company,...'    Acts 4.26  { 3p->3
    \so }
    \nt +

    \xv Kah n∞wau ponuneh newutche mohtompan,...
    \xe And he said, Let me go, for the day breaketh. ...
    \so Gen.32.26
    \ng 2->1
    \nt +

    \se !|ponunum|, ?!|ponanum|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1b
    \ge `to leave sth'
    \so Acts 6.2
    \xv ..., Matta tapeneunkquttinn∞ nupponunnumunan wuttinn∞waonk GOD, kah n∞neech∞hteamun tables.
    \xe ..., It is not reason that we should leave the word of God, and serve tables.
    \so Acts 6.2
    \ng 1p->0

    \se |ponanumauau|, !|ponamauau|, !|ponumauau| (q.v.)
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge "to put sth into, on sb/sth"
    \so Gen.40.21; Num.11.29
    \xv ..., kah ponanumauau wuttattamwaitch Pharoah wunnutcheganit.
    \xe ...; and he gave the cup into Pharaoh's hand.
    \so Gen.40.21; (E0&E1) |ponamauau|, syncopated
    \xv ..., onk wuh Jehovah wunnashauanitt∞moh upponanumauoh.
    \xe ..., and that the LORD would put his Spirit upon them.
    \so Num.11.29; (E1) |upponamauoh|, syncopated

\dv |ann∞nau| `he sends (him) away', with |pa| indefinite or indirective prefixed.

    [Miami-Illinois [mia] |nip8na, nip8nan| `je cesse, mets bas, ne soutiens plus'    M.486/280a.
    \nt +
M.-P. |'ponal| TA `er legt ihn (irgendwohin), |'pon@m@n| TI `er legt es dorthin'    Sz.184.
Shawnee [sjw] |ponamani| `I let go, stop holding'    D.-V.96.]

\et perhaps *po∙n- `cease' (B. 16, 80, 101); + TA manual final *-en-, i.e. "cease to hold" [no exactly parallel case yet found]. (On the spelling, see G.1981, 34, 70?)

\lx ponum
\va ponam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 131
\ps v.t. / TI1a, 1b
\ge `he places, puts (it) by hand' (Lat. pon-it {< *po-sin-, cf. posui, positum}); +`to lay sth, set sth somewhere'
\ps Ex.4.6; 40.22,24
    \xv ..., kah upponamunash Isaakait wunnaumonat,...
    \xe ..., and laid it upon Isaac his son;...
    \so Gen.22.6
    \ng 3->0p objective
    \nt +
    \xv nupponam
    \xe I put (it)
    \so 1 Sam.28.31
    \xv ..., kah wonk upponamunneau qussuk wussissitt∞nonog wutayeuonkganit.
    \xe ..., and [they] put the stone again upon the well's mouth in his place.
    \so Gen.29.3
    \ng 3p->0 objective/subordinative

    \nt MN: ponuk
    \ng Suppositive |ponuk| `he who puts', (and part.) `putting'

    Imperat. |..., Ahque ponsh kenutcheg nunkompaut,...| `..., Lay not thine hand upon the lad,....'    Gen.22.12; also 24.2, 47.49  { 2->0 imperative }
    \xv ponitch
    \xe let him put
    \so Rom.14.13

    \se ponau
    \ps V.t.an. / TA
    \ge `he puts or places (him)', +`to deliver, set sb somewhere'
    \xv upponuh
    \xe he put him
    \so Gen.2.15; Is.14.1
    \xv ...: kah ne upponun wosketompuh neh kahkenaiheaumpoh.
    \xe ...; and there he put the man whom he had formed.'    Gen.2.8  { 3->3
    \so subordinative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah upponuh anaquabenit nahoh,...
    \xe ..., and set {it} before them;...'    Gen.18.8  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nupponopanneg kenutchegan∞óut.
    \xe ...; and I delivered them into your hand.
    \so Josh.24.11
    \ng 1->3p preterite objective
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wutangelumoh Jehovah ponau wuhhogkuh mayut ayeuuhkonittue neh:...
    \xe ...: and the angel of the Lord stood in the way for an adversary against him. ...'    Num.22.22 { 1&2; 3->3
    \so absolute; following verses have |neepau|--aspectual contrast? }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah kuppon wunnânauunumunat kenutcheganae ânakausuongash.
    \xe ..., and didst set him over the works of thy hands:'    Heb.2.7  { 2->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +

    \xv ... GOD noh ponont kummatwomoh ut kenutcheganit:...
    \xe ... God, which hath deliuered thine enemies into thy hand:...'    Gen.14.20  { _3_->3
    \so participle }
    \nt +

    \xv poneh
    \xe put thou me
    \so 1 Sam.2.36
    \ng 2->1 imperative

    \se ponamauau
    \ps V.t.inan. and an. / TA+O
    \ge `he puts (it) on (him)'
    \xv ..., kah wame ne ahtunk upponamauun ut wunnutcheganit.
    \xe ..., and all that he had he put into his hand.
    \so Gen.39.4
    \xv ..., nuhn∞tin nashauanit noh apehtunkquean, kah nag pish nupponamauwonáoh ...
    \xe ...: and I will take of the spirit which is upon thee, and will put it upon them;...
    \so Num.11.17
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m pish ponamauau wame yeush matanittuongash ut kummatwomut,...
    \xe And the Lord thy God will put all these curses upon thine enemies,...
    \so Deut.30.7
    \ng odd syntax: "indirect" object as locative; no n-paradigm, no registering of plural secondary object
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wanne kupponamauon∞mun onkatuk weanun.
    \xe ...; I will put upon you none other burden.
    \so Rev.2.24
    \nt +

    \xv ..., neit pish Wunnaumonain agwapehtauau neh agwe ponamungqutche wame,...
    \xe ..., then shall the Son also himself be subject unto him that put all things under him,...'    1 Cor.15.28 { 3
    \so ->3 conjunct; compare previous verse. }
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |ponamâuta| `(let us) lay it on'; |pónewhush| `lay down your burthens'; |aukùck pónamun| `to lay in the earth'    R.W.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nep8nemen, 3. ap.| `Je le mets'; |nép8nma8añ.| `Je mets dans lui'    R.340/486b.]

\et H.2799,2802 *po∙namwa TI, *po∙ne∙wa TA `lay down'; (phonology? -- cf. |p∞nampau|, |p∞s-|, |p∞t-|, which match it better. G.1981, 34, 70, suggests, plausibly, the influence of L. "ponere" on the spelling; this already then in R.W.)


\lx pooke
\va poke
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 131
\ge `a small kind [of tobacco], with short round leaves', used by the Indians in New England, Josselyn, N.E. Rarities, 54. Wood's vocabulary gives `pooke, coltsfoot.' Prof. Tuckerman, in a note to Josselyn, loc. cit., makes this inferior kind of tobacco, "not colt's foot, but Nicotiana rustica, L., the Yellow Henbane of Gerard's Herbal, p. 356." But he is unquestionably right in his inference that "the name poke or pooke was perhaps always indefinite." It signifies merely `that which is smoked', or `which smokes'. See |p∞keu|, and cf. |pukit|.

[Corvado (Brasil?) boké, tobacco; Puri póke@; see Martius.]


\lx popómompakecheg
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 131
\cf pamompagin

\so Trumbull 131
\ps vbl.n.
\ge `a going to and fro'
\so Is.33.4
\dv |popomshau|, freq. of |pomushau|.


\lx popón
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 132
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it is winter'
\ps n. / NI
\ge `winter'
\so Cant.2.11; Ps.74.17
    \nt G&B.698
    \nt +
    (pret. |pupp∞nup| `it was winter'    Mass.Ps.)

    \se poponáe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `of winter, in the winter'

    \se |poponsin|, |poponshin|, |poponshin|
    \nt +
    \ps AI [expected gender differentiation by |s/sh|? ]
    \ge `to [spend the] winter' (in a place)
    \so Acts 28.11; 1 Cor.16.6
    \xv ...: tohwoh áne koppohhettit Phenice, kah na pop∞nsinneau,...
    \xe ..., if by any means they might attain to Phenice, and there to winter;...
    \so Acts 27.12
\cf tohkoi

[Narragansett [xnt] |Papòne| `Winter.'; |Paponakéeswush| `Winter moneth'; |Papapôcup.| `Winter last.'    R.W.65,66.√
Quiripi [qyp] |pabôuks| `in winter'    Pier.28.
Western Abenaki [abe] |peb8n| `l'hiver'; |peb8né| `le passé'; |peb8'ghé| `le prochain'.
Cree |pépoon| `it is winter'; |pépoon-oop'un| `it was winter'; |kútta@ pépoon| `it will be winter'; suppos. |pepóok| `when it is winter'; |pepóok-oopun| `when it was winter'; |pépooké| `when it shall be winter'    Howse 191,192.
Chip. |peebon| `last winter'; |peebonoong| `next winter'; |peebong|    Sch.
Old Alg. |pipoun|.

\lx poquaûhock
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 132
\ps N
\ge `the round clam, (Venus mercenaria), the "quahaug" of the Eastern markets'; "a little thick shell fish which the Indians wade deep and dive for. ... They break out of the shell about half an inch of a black part of it, of which they make their |suckaúhock| or blackmoney."    R.W.104.
\dv |pohkeni|, in the sense of `closed'.
\cf kuppogki
\cf hogki
\cf sickíssuog
\ge thick', and |hogki|
\nt `thick', and  `shell', distinguishing it from the Mya arenaria () or gaping clam

[Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |p`quaughhaug|, |pouh-quauhhaug|    Stiles.

\lx posekinau
\va -num
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 132
\ps v.t.an. and inan. / TA, TI1b, manual final
\ge `he buries (him), inters (him)'
\so Gen.23.19
    \xv ..., pìsh kuttit posukkinit ut k∞nenukukquiinneat.
    \xe ...; thou shalt be buried in a good old age.
    \so Gen.15.15
    \ng X->2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... onk hó na nupposekinnon nupp∞m.
    \xe ..., and I will bury my dead there.
    \so Gen.23.13√
    \ng 1->3 subordinative
    \xv ..., kah upposekinouh hassunnegit wutohteakonit Machpelah,...
    \xe ..., and [they] buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah,...'    Gen.50.13  { 3p->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah Miriam na wuttit nuppun, kah naut posekinan.
    \xe ...; and Miriam died there, and was buried there.
    \so Num.20.1
    \ng X->3 subordinative
    \nt +
    (|Nupp∞su@kin, -nop.| `I bury, {or} did,'    C.41/183.)

    \nt MN: posekinit
    \ng suppositive |posekinit| `when burying, he who buries', and (pass. part.) `buried'
    \xv Neit neemunnàog wuhhogkuh Jesus, kah ∞weinágkinóuh hashabponakinit, nashpe spices, neáhussehettit Jewsog pósekinuttéhetticheh.
    \xe Then took they the body of Jesus, and wound it in linen clothes with the spices, as the manner of the Jews is to bury.
    \so Jn.19.40; (M) |ne ahhinne p∞suhkinnuwahhittit|
    \ng AI, indefinite object
    \nt +

    imperat. |posekin kenup∞m| `bury thy dead'    Gen.23.11,15  { 2->3 imperative }
    \xv ... ahque posekineh k∞wehquetumoush ut Egypt.
    \xe ...; bury me not, I pray thee, in Egypt:
    \so Gen.47.29
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \nt +


    \se posekináonk
    \ps Vbl.n. act.
    \ge `a burying'

    \se posekinitteaonk
    \ps Vbl.n. pass. / to theme 2a stem
    \ge `a being-buried, burial'
    \so Mt.26.12
    \xv ..., wutussen wutche nupposekinitteaonk.
    \xe ..., she did it for my burial.
    \so Mt.26.12
    \nt +

    \se posekinittuáe
    \dv ?to reciprocal stem, (M) particularly clearly (in passive sense)
    \nt +
    \ps Adj. and adv. / PreN, PreV
    \xv posekinittuae ohke
    \xe a burying place
    \so Gen.23.4,+47.30,50.13
    \xv nupp∞suhkinnittue kesukkodtum.
    \xe the day of my burying
    \so Jn.12.7(M)
    \nt +

    \se |posekinausu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, passive
    \ge `to be buried, lie in the grave'
    \so Jn.11.17; Col.2.12
    \xv Neit paont Jesus, wunnamheuh posekinausu weenohkeit yauquinne mahche
    \xe Then when Jesus came, he found that he had lain in the grave four days already.
    \so Jn.11.17
    \ng 3 indicative

\dv |poskinau| `he strips naked, makes bare' (?), or the derivative |m'pusk| (|muppusk|) `the back', `he places or is laid on his back' (?).

[Narragansett [xnt] |Posakúnnamun.| `To bury.'    R.W.194/r.202.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nep8'skenañ.| `Je l'enterre'.    R.220/446ab.
    Algonquian [alg] |POS-| `profondeur d'un object concave; enfoncement dans une chose quelconque; couleur foncée; foncièrement, profondément'    Cq.353b-354a
    \nt +?

WAbn. |boskena| TA `bury someone'    D.1.132.]

\lx poskissu

    \xv ..., newutche nupposkis,...
    \xe ..., because I {was} naked,...' i.e. by my own act (this is the intransitive active form, or `adj. an.
    \so of Eliot; see |poske|)    Gen.3.10√

\lx psukses
\va pussuhkses-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 133
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a little bird'
\so El.Gr.9
    pl. +|og|
    `a bird'    Eccl.10.20; Amos 3.5
    \xv Na wuttit wadjisheahkoneau psuksesog:...
    \xe Where the birds make their nests:...
    \so Ps.104.17; (M) |pussuhksesog|
    \nt +
    |Psukses, Pissuksemësog| (|Psuksüog.|) `A bird, birds'    C.4/156
    \nt +
    \xv Nanpeh peississu pussuhkis.
    \xe A very little bird
    \so C.26/172
    \nt +

\dv This word is evidently a diminutive from a noun |psuk| or |psukissu|, which I do not find in Eliot. For the class (aves) `fowl' Eliot used |puppinshaasog|, q.v.

[pahshe, half ~ psukses, bird; cf. Sansk. pakshín, avis ~ pakshá, latus, dimidia pars.]

[Narragansett [xnt] |NPesháwog|, |Pussekesesuck.| `Fowle.'    R.W.88√.
Western Abenaki [abe] |sipsis|, pl. |sipsak| `oiseaux'.]


\lx pt∞wu
\va t∞wu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 133
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he moves in air, flies' (as a bird); +`to flee away'
\so 2 Sam.22.11; Ps.18.10; Prov.6.2
    \xv ... woi onunuppohwhunont[i] wuskuhwhunonáut, onk woh nutt∞wem, onk woh nutanwohsin.
    \xe ..., O that I had wings like a dove; for then would I flee away, and be at rest.
    \so Ps.55.6; (M): |nuttooem|
    \nt +
    pl. |pt∞weeog|
    (pret. |t∞weep| `he did fly'    Mass.Ps., Ps.18.10)

    \nt MN: Nish noh oaas momonchin noh t∞weet...
    \ng suppositive |Nish noh oaas momonchin noh t∞weet...| (or |pt∞weet|) `All fowls that creep,...'    Lev.11.20,21√

    \se pt∞eu
    \va t∞eu
    \ps With inan. subj. / II
    \ge `it flies'
    pl. |pt∞eog|    Prov.23.5

    \nt MN: Onatuh pukit pt∞hog, neinne nen∞hkau naghog:...
    \ng suppositive |Onatuh pukit pt∞hog, neinne nen∞hkau naghog:...| `As smoke is driven away, so drive them away:...'    Ps.68.2; (M): |toohohk|
    \ng TI1a causative, perhaps with the TI1 final |-ah-| `by tool, ..., by medium such as wind or water' (B.1962, 16.143, p.357)--though where is the |-a-|? 3s subject?


    \se pt∞wéche
    \ps Adj.
    \so Prov.26.2

    \se pt∞anau
    \va t∞hannau
    \ps Caus. inan. (subj. and obj.) / TI2
    \ge `it drives or causes it to drift in air'; pass. `it is driven or drifted'

    \nt MN: ne t∞unontog
    \ng suppositive |ne t∞unontog| , |pt∞anuntog|  `that which is driven by the wind'    Ps.1.4; 35.5; Hos.18.3
    (|t∞anontog|    Mass.Ps.)

    \se !|t∞we-|?
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O)?
    \ge `to winnow sth'
    \so Ruth 3.2
    \nt Probably a hapax. Form attested cannot be objective, lacking the prefix; is it an AI derivative, of a causative in |-ah|? Perhaps with medial |-min-| `berry, fruit, seed', and AI final |-á-|, accounting for the infection?
    \xv ... kusseh, t∞wehuminneau barly yeu nohkog ut ahhuttannuppoghamuk.
    \xe ... Behold, he winnoweth barley tonight in the threshing floor.
    \so Ruth 3.2

    \se t∞annóhhanne
    \so Adj.-adv.
    \ge `driven, made to drift'
    \so Is.41.2
\dv Nearly allied to, if not formed directly from, |p∞tau| `he blows, moves the air'.
(Cf. Sansk. pat, (1) cadere; (2) volare (cf. |petau|; |petshau|); Greek pipto, petomai; Lat. peto. See Max Müller's Lect. (III) on Darwin's Philos, of Lang., in Living Age No. 1523, p. 424.)

\lx pukkutteau
\va pukuttau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 134
    \nt +
\ps II, ?predicative to |pukit|
\ge `to smoke' ("to emit smoke")
\so Gen.15.17,19.28; Ex.19.18,20.18; Acts 2.19
    \xv Onk wadchu Sinai wame pukutauau ..., kah pukutteau speém∞ onatuh sábasohsue pukut,...
    \xe And mount Sinai was altogether on a smoke, ...: and the smoke thereof ascended as the smoke of a furnace,
    \so Ex.19.18
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv Kah wame missinninnúog náumwog ..., kah wadchu pukuttauau,...
    \xe And all the people saw ..., and the mountain smoking: ...
    \so Ex.20.18
    \xv ..., wutch pukkutteau ut pahsohtheganit.
    \xe ... by reason of the smoke of the pit.
    \so Rev.9.2
    \ng perhaps 0 subordinative form?

    \xv ... neahhuttannunnag paguttoó∞k,...
    \xe ... a smoking furnace,...
    \so Gen.15.17
    \ng _0_ participle
    \xv ..., kah kusseh pukutaou ohket onatuh ahut sabásumuk áhunnupukutáig.
    \xe ...and, lo, the smoke of the country went up as the smoke of a furnace.
    \so Gen.19.28; (E0) "smoak ascended - from earth - as - out of - furnace - its smoak ascendeth."
    \ng 0 indicative; reduplicated |uN-| + _0_ participle

    \se pukkittohkauau
    \ps TA, |-hk-aw-| stem
    \ge `to smoke against sb'
    \so Deut.29.20
    \xv ..., kah umm∞sitteam∞onk pish uppukkittohkauoh neh wosketompuh,...
    \xe ... and his jealousy shall smoke against that man,...
    \so Deut.29.20


\lx pukit
\va pukut
\va pukut
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 134
\ps n. / NI
\ge `smoke'
\dv suppos. form of v.i. |pukkutteau| (Rev.9.2) `there is smoke'
    \nt Remark: As usual, it is difficult to distinguish noun and verb with words of such fugitive denotations and limited syntactic distribution. The status of the final syllable is also unclear.
    \nt +
\dv |pohkeni| `dark' (?), `it blinds' (?).
    \xv Kah locustsog sohhamwog wutch pukuttaut, ut wosketohke,...
    \xe And there came out of the smoke locusts upon the earth:...
    \so Rev.9.3
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wutawakompanáe pukutau ushpemo micheme kah micheme,...
    \xe And the smoke of their torment ascendeth up for ever and ever:...
    \so Rev.14.11
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah uppukuttom ushpemo micheme kah micheme,
    \xe ...And her smoke rose up for ever and ever.
    \so Rev.19.3
    \nt +
\cf p∞keu

    \se pukkuttáe
    \ps Adj.-adv.
    \ge `smoky, of smoke'
    \so Is.14.31; Joel 2.30; +Rev.9.2

    \se pukkuttaemes
    \ps Dimin.
    \ge `vapor'
    \so Ps.148.8
(Cf. Sansk. pañka, lutum, pulvis; Tamil, pug-ei, smoke. {How did he miss Popocatepetl?})

\lx pummee
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 135
\ps n.
\ge `oil'

    (|pummee| or |sammee|    C.)

[Western Abenaki [abe] |pemi| `huile, graisse'; |pemikan| `étant fondue, on la tire (de dessus l'eau)'. This last word, or, rather, the passive participle of the same form, |pemikan| (`fat skimmed' or `dipped' from the surface of the boiling water in which it was melted, to be poured over fine-chopped meat), gave a name to the preparation so much prized by the northern tribes and by Canadian voyageurs.*
Old Alg. |pimite| `fat'    Lah.
Delaware [del] |pæmyy| `fat'    Camp.; |pomi|    Zeisb.]
[*NOTE. -- "Same root with |pummeu|?".]

\lx pummetonkupunnáonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 135
\ps vbl.n.
\ge `crucifixion; the cross of Christ'
\nt (from |pummeut| and |onkapunnau| `he tortures (him) on the cross)' is used by Eliot for the crucifixion; `the cross of Christ'    Heb.12.2; Jn.19.19
    Elsewhere, |pumetshin|, as `(to take up) his cross' |uppumetshineum|    Lk.14.27

    \se !|pummetonkupunnau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \ge `to crucify s.o.'
    \xv Qut nag mishont∞waog, Monchanok, monchanok, pummetonkuppunok, Pilate nah wuttinuh, Woh nuppummetonkuppunau kukketass∞tam∞mw∞?...
    \xe But they cried out, Away with him, away with him, crucify him. Pilate saith unto them, Shall I crucify your King?...
    \so Jn.19.15
    \xv Kah paáhettìt áyeaonganit ussowetamun Calvary, na wuttit pummetonkapunnaóneau,...
    \xe And when they were come to the place, which is called Calvary, there they crucified him,...
    \so Lk.23.33

    \xv Neit matwaog peyaog, kah pohquetahhamwog wuhkontash, noh negonogk∞chik, kah noh onkatog neh weeche pummetonkappunácheh.
    \xe Then came the soldiers, and brake the legs of the first, and of the other which was crucified with him.
    \so Jn.19.32

    \xv Kah nanaánuwaen n∞wau, Tohwutch? toh en matchesu? qut nano m∞cheke mishont∞waog, Pummetónkapunóunaj.
    \xe And the governor said, Why, what evil hath he done? But they cried out the more, saying, Let him be crucified.
    \so Mt.27.23
    \ng 3.sg.pass.imp., G&B 569,571

[Quiripi [qyp] |pummêan| `to walk' (in their own ways)    Pier.37.

\lx pumminnum

\cf pummunnum


\lx pummoh
\va pum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 135
\ps N
\ge a name of the sea, or ocean, which had perhaps become obsolete, or superseded by |kehtoh|, before the coming of the English, but was still retained in compound and derivative words.
\dv It seems to be derived from the diffusive particle |pa@-|, and |∞munát|, the verb of motion -- that which goes all about, is everywhere in motion, without course or direction.
[|kehtoh| (El.), |kítthan| (R.W.), from the inan. adj. |kehte|, means `that which is chief or greatest, relatively great, vast'.]
Among the words preserved by Eliot and R. Williams, into the composition of which this name of the ocean enters, are the following:
    |paumpágussit| (Narr.) `the sea god'    R.W.98
    |pummunat|, |pummunumunat| (?) `to offer, to consecrate'
    |pumupsq|, |pumipsq| `a rock' (in the sea?)
    \xv pummóhhamwaenuog
    \xe mariners
    \so Jonah 1.5
    (|pummoh∞munát| `those who go on the sea'; |pu@mmuhshottoeninuog| |pamushadtaeninuog|?]    C.183)
    |ohquanupam| [|ohquanu pum|] `on the shore or border of the sea'
    = |ohquanu kehtahhannit|    Mk.2.13
    \xv Nuppumos∞@weem, -up.
    \xe I swim, or did
    \so C.79/211;
    \xv Nuppumos∞@we@mun, -nonup.
    \xe We swim, or did
    \so C.79/211;
    \xv Pumosooenat.
    \xe To swim
    \so C.79/212
    \xv pâmôs∞wéneat
    \xe to swim
    cf. |okkuttôs∞wénaóut| [|ukkeihtohs∞wénaóut|] `to cast themselves into the sea, to plunge into the sea'    Acts 27.43
    |wosketupam| [|woskeche pum|] `the surface of the sea'    Is.18.2 (cf. Gen.1.2)
    |kehchippom|, |-pam| [|kehche|= |kutche|, |pum|] `on the shore'    Jn.21.4, etc.
    |keechepam|    Gen.22.17.]

[NOTE. -- The above definition was not transferred from the rough draft of the manuscript to the revision, seemingly through oversight.]


\lx pummóhham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 135
\ps v.i. / TI1(?)
\ge `he goes inactively or without exertion' (?)
\dv |páme| and |∞m|. See under |pomushau|.
\ge `he goes by water, voyages'.
\so Not found in Eliot, except in the derived n. agent. |pummóhhamwaenuog| `mariners'    Jonah 1.5
    (|Pu@mmuhshottoeninuog.| `Mariners'    C.14/163, formed apparently from |pamwushadt|, suppos. of |pomushau|).

    \se |pomohhamóonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, nom.act.
    \ge `voyage'
    \xv Kah wuttinuh, Kusseh nuttenanatam pomohhamóonk woskehhuwon∞ kah m∞cheke wannéhteaonganu∞,...
    \xe And said unto them, Sirs, I perceive that this voyage will be with hurt and much damage,...
    \so Acts.27.10

[Delaware [del] |pom ma chum| `he goes by water'    Zeisb.
Virg. |yapam| `the sea'    Strachey.]

\et ? H., p. 241 *-a∙hw- `convey by water' + |-am-|?


\lx pummompagu
\va -paku
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 135
    \nt +
\ps AI, ?long-vowel stem, type of |monchu| (cf. Gen.7.21)
\dv |pum-| + |-ômpak-| ?`creep' (see speculation under etymology) + ?|-i-|
\nt Remark: The initial vowel is only rarely attested in the weak form |u|. Forms in |u-...-n| have been included as verb forms, though their analysis is unclear. Reduplicated forms in |po(h)pom-| and forms apparently used nominally have also been included in the listing. See also |pamompagin|, T.116ab.
\ge `to creep; (rarely) to move'
\so Gen.1.26,30,6.7,20,7.8,14,21,23,8.17,19,9.3; Lev.5.2,11.23,29,31,41-46,20.25,22.5; Deut.4.18,14.19; Acts 10.12,11.6; Rom.1.23
    \xv ..., kah nishnoh uppumompagen pomantog ohket ...
    \xe ..., and to every thing that creepeth upon the earth, wherein there is life,...
    \so Gen.1.30
    \ng ?3 subordinative
    \xv ..., kah nishnoh pomompakecheg pomompakeog ut woskeche ohket,...
    \xe ..., and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth,...
    \so Gen.7.21  { _3p_ participle; 3p agent nominal? }; parallel passage Gen.8.17: |pohpomompakécheg| (all texts)
    \xv Káh nish noh hawaas uppomompagin noh t∞it,...
    \xe And every creeping thing that flieth...
    \so Deut.14.19
    \ng ?3 subordinative

    \xv Asuh wosketomp, noh masunont howáe papomompakenitcheh,...
    \xe Or whosoever toucheth any creeping thing,...'    Lev.22.5  { _3
    \so _ participle, reduplicated }

    \se pomompagee
    \ps PreN
    \ge `creeping'
    \so Lev.11.43,44,46
    \xv ..., nashpe pomompagée howaas noh pomompagit:...
    \xe ... with any creeping thing that creepeth,...
    \so Lev.11.43

For the final, compare |suhwhompakeneau| `[they] do creep forth', Ps.104.20(M).

[M.-P. |nutiyapeku| AI `he crawls out'; |petapeku| AI `he comes crawling'    LeS.57b;68a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Pe@ma@be@ge| `To creep'; |pemapekit| AI `to crawl along'    R.72a; DeB.18a.]

\et Could this contain the noun stem *-a∙pye∙k- `string', H.242, as a descriptive term referring to the shape of snakes and similar animals?


\lx pummomu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 135
    \nt +
\nt Remark: weakly attested, conjugation class uncertain, no parallel found elsewhere.
\ps AI
\dv ?|pum-| `along' + |-ôm-i-| ?`creep'
\ge `to creep'
\so Gen.1.20; Ps.(M).104.25,148.10

    \xv ..., M∞nahettich nippekontu pomantamwae pomomutcheg,...
    \xe ..., Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life,...
    \so Gen.1.20
    \ng _3p_ participle; 1655 gloss: "creeping thing", reflecting AV marginale to "moving": "{Or, creeping}."

    \xv ... kehtah, uttuh pamomhittit woh mo waogkemomukkeg,...
    \xe ... sea, wherein are things creeping innumerable,...
    \so Ps.104.25(M)
    \ng 3p conjunct
    \xv Puppunashimwog kah wame netassuog, pahpumomutcheg, kah toht∞echeg puppunushaog.
    \xe Beasts and all cattel: creeping things & flying fowl.
    \so Ps.148.10
    \ng _3p_ participle, reduplicated

\lx pummu

    imperat. 2d pers. sing. |pumsh|

    freq. |pepummu|, q.v.

    \se pumwau
    \ps V.t.an. / TA
    \ge `he shoots at (him)'
    \xv Onk woh pumwaog kéme pannuppu wunneet∞oh: teanuk uppumwóuh, kah matta wabesuog.
    \xe That they may shoot in secret at the perfect: suddenly do they shoot at him, and fear not.'    Ps.64.4; (M): |pumwaog|, |uppumwouh|  { ?3p->3' absolute; 3p->3
    \so objective }

    \so objective }
    \nt +

\lx pumóhtaash
\va pumohtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 136
\ps pl. / II
    \dv |pum-| `in a line' + |ahtá-| `be at'; some examples probably show the corresponding nominalization
    \nt +
\ge `(they are in) a row', of inan. objects
\so 1 K.7.3; Lev.24.6
    \xv Kah nish pish keneese pomohtaunash, nequtta tahshinash nequt pomohtaash: ut pohkag table ut anaquabit Jehovah.
    \xe And thou shalt set them in two rows, six on a row, upon the pure table before the Lord.
    \so Lev.24.6√
    \ng with |pomohtaunash| to the causative TI verb |ahtô-|, beside the II |ahtá-|
    \xv Kah tattamwohtaúog noh ut yauut pumóhtaash qussukqunash, pumohtaash, sardius, topaz, kah catbunkle, yeush negonpomohtagish.
    \xe And they set in it four rows of stones: the first row was a sardius, a topaz, and a carbuncle: this was the first row.
    \so Ex.39.10
    \nt +

    \xv Kah pish kupponum naneeswe nish pomohtagish; pohkag frankincense,...
    \xe And thou shalt put pure frankincense upon each row,...
    \so Lev.24.7
    \ng goal not expressed as a locative--the conjunct clause may act as such?
    \nt +
\dv |--| and |ohteau|.

\et There are forms in |pem-/pim-| in Cree and Menominee at least, with the familiar initial used in the sense of `lengthwise, line, row'.

\et G.1965, no.35, 215b (following Mch.1935) *-(e)?le∙wa `bird'; B.1962, 14.272, p. 257: |-qNε∙w-| `bird', c.f. |-qN-ε∙-| `fly', 15.239, pp. 314-315, M.1935, 162b-163a, implying *-?l- `fly', H. p.247: *-il?-e∙- `smooth movement'. Initial perhaps reduplicated *pel- as in *pele∙wa [some bird], A.1814, G.1990, (74), 465, though the reduplication may be light on present evidence, unlike those listed by Cowan (1972) i.e. ?*pepele?le∙-.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |pet8| `scent of an animal', `piste': |pes8is| `chat', which Mr Pickering, in a note to Rasles, thought "probably corrupted from the familiar English word `puss' or `pussy'"; but cf.
Cree |pússoo| `he scents' (as, an animal)    Howse 144.
Chip. (Sag.) |pee shoe| `the lynx'; (St Marys) |pizh iew'|; |mis'si-bizh iew| (great lynx) `panther'.
Menominee [mez] |pah shay ew| `the lynx'; |mainch pay-shay-ew| `the panther'.]

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 137
\cf puttogham


\lx puttahham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 137
\ps v.i. / TI1a (??)
\ge `he goes into a snare or trap, is taken or entrapped'
\so Ezek.17.20
    pl. |-hamwog|    Job 34.30

    \nt MN: ..., matchetou puttuhhuk ut nehenwonche wunnutchegane usseonganit
    \ng Suppositive |..., matchetou puttuhhuk ut nehenwonche wunnutchegane usseonganit| `...: the wicked is snared in the work of his own hands.'    Ps.9.16
    \ng Mayhew: |..., matchetou puttahwhou ...|; form is not conjunct -- theme 2 ?

    \se puttahham∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `entrapping, a trap'

    \se ?!|puttahham∞onganu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(?), predicate nominal to |puttahham∞onk|
    \ge `to be a trap'
    \so Josh.23.13
    \xv ..., qut nag pish appehhannu∞og kah puttahham∞onganu∞og en kuhhogkaout,...
    \xe ...; but they shall be snares and traps unto you,...
    \so Josh.23.13

\dv |pet-au| and |∞m| `he goes into'


\lx puttahhamwehheau

\ge `he makes (him) to be trapped or snared'

    suppos. pl. |-wehettit| `when they are taken', i.e. `made to go into a snare or net'    Eccl.9.12

    \xv ... newutche kuttinn∞waonk nukquaquakqhúk.

\lx quanogkquoan-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 137
    \nt +
\ps ?TA
\nt Remark: These look like TA 3->3' (lacking the obviative suffix in Rev.4.3) forms; see examples from other languages for possible parallels. The |-ogqu-|, could perhaps be the root |agqu-|/ogqu-| `cover', and there are signs of a similar element in other languages. (Tooker, n.d., interprets some of the forms that he collected from published sources, including these, as involving a meaning "long mantle" or "good covering".) The only form with a similar initial is that of Powhatan. Tales about rainbows would clearly be helpful in interpreting this material.
\ge ?; attested forms: "rainbow"
\so Rev.4.3,10.1
    \xv ..., kah ukquanogquonu∞p waéénu appuonk, móneaumunat ogqunneungquodt Emerald.
    \xe ...: and there was a rainbow round about the throne, in sight like unto an emerald.'    Rev.4.3  { ?3->3
    \so preterite objective (obviative inflection absent }
    \xv ..., kah ukquanogquoanuh ut uppuhkukqut ...
    \xe ...: and a rainbow {was} upon his head,...'    Gen.10.1  { 3->3
    \so objective }

[Western Abenaki [abe] |manag8^añn, nar.| `arc-en-ciel'    R.30,386b.
Algonquian [alg] |Otagwanipisan| (|-piisan|, ib., 336a) `arc-en-ciel, litt. {il} (le Manitou) {couvre la pluie d'un manteau.}'; |Otagwänïpîsan| Arc-en-ciel' (i.e. {il couvre la pluie d'un manteau'     Cq.18b; Lem.D.66b.
Delaware [del] |M[o]nukooen| (or |Mu-|?) `rainbow'; |Manochquon| `Rainbow'     J.137a; Z.1788.142a.
"EAbn." |Shomogon| `A Rainbow'    Rosier. (On this, see Barbour's remark in Quinn and Quinn 1983, 485.)
Fx. |anakwe∙wa| `rainbow'    Fx.L.30.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |nanang8e8a, nanag8eïa| `arc en Ciel.'    Grv.316/193a.
Mahican [mjy] |manákkoon| `der Regenbogen'    Schm.114.
M.-P. |monoqan| NA `rainbow'; |m@n@kwan| `Regenbogen'    LeS.47a; Sz.123.
Miami |alangwia| (pl. |aki|) `rainbow'; |alaankwia| NA `rainbow'    D.-V.438; B&C.21a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Wo@lkwo@n'; Mu@nkwo@n'.| `Rainbow'; |m'nqwan| [SH], |walqwan| NA   `rainbow'; |u:npekw| `rainbow (in the bay)'    R.212a; DeB.66a.
Ojibwe [oji] |nagwéiâb|, |obagwanibissan|. ([Cree] |Pisimweyâbïy|); |nahgwáyaub, (pl. -in.); |nagweyaab| NI `rainbow'; |ngwaagan| NI, M., |waagkaagan| NI, W.    Bar.205b; W.325b; N&N.91a; Rh.548b.
    Evans and Jones (1833) use the form |ahgwahnebeson| (Gen.9.14,16) with 1 possessive |nindah gwahnebesom| (9.13).
Powhatan [pim] |Qwannacut| `a Raynebow'        S.(Bod).12

\lx quehchikkompau

\ps AI
\ge `to turn os (back)'

\lx quehchuunau
\va quehchuwunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative final
\dv Applicative to AI !|quehcheu| `to turn', reflecting *kwe∙Θki∙wa `to turn', H.1353?
\ge `to bring sb again, back, rescue sb' (+destination/source)
\so Gen.28.15,48.21; Ex.23.4; Num.35.25; Ps.35.17(M);
    \xv ...: kah GOD k∞wetomuk kah pish kukquehchuwunukou en wutohtuóut k∞sh∞wóut.
    \xe ...; but God shall be with you, and bring you again to the land of your fathers.
    \so Gen.48.21
    \ng 3->2p indicative

    \xv Nogkushkouadt manunneungquean wutoximoh, asuh wutassiumoh quonsénit, quehchúunadt pish kukquehchuuttauonuh,...
    \xe If thou meet thine enemy's ox or his ass going astray, thou shalt surely bring it back to him again.
    \so Ex.23.4
    \ng cognate 2->3 conjunct

    \xv Jehovah, tohsohke pish kunnonamun? quehchuwus nukketeahogkou wutch oowoskhuaonganoo, neanadchanog wutch qunnonoout.
    \xe Lord, how long wilt thou look on? rescue my soul from their destructions, my darling from the lions.
    \so Ps.35.17(M); (E) |kenahamash|
    \ng 2->3

    \se quehchuutteau
    \va quehchuwutteau
    \va quhchuwuttau
    \ps TI2
    \ge `to bring sth back, return sth' (+destination)
    \so Gen.14.16; Ex.19.8; Ps.85.1(E&M)
    \xv ...: Kah Moses quehchuwutteau ukkutt∞wongan∞ash missinninnúog en Jehovahut.
    \xe ...: And Moses returned the words of the people unto the LORD.
    \so Ex.19.8
    \ng 3->0p absolute

    \se quehchuuttauau
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to bring sth back to sb again'
    \so Ex.23.4
    \xv ... pish kukquehchuuttauonuh,...
    \xe ..., thou shalt surely bring it back to him again.'    Ex.23.4  { 2->3'-pro+3
    \so -pro objective }

    \nt +
    `when he had appeased (them)' [i.e. `caused them to desist' (?)]    Acts 19.35

    2d pl. |quihtinn∞k| `forbid ye'

    \nt +
    (|God quehtehchaj| `God forbid'    C.)

    \se nukqueehti@tteam
    \ps TI1a ?
    \ge `I forbid'
    \so C.

\lx quen-
\hm 1
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
    \nt +
\nt Remark: allomorph |ques-| in |quesikkompau|? i.e. |queN-|? Note that the initial |quen-| (2) `want, lack' has final *Θ etymologically, but the (localist) connection if any is not clear.

\ge `on, upon' (a horizontal surface ?)
\so following entries


\lx quen-
\hm 2
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
    \nt +
\ps initial, intransitive
\ge `to be lacking, wanting'
\so following entries


\lx quenappu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
    \dv |quen-| (1) + |-appu| AI
    \nt +
\ps v.t. / AI(+O) (i.e. P+AI)
\ge `he sits or rests upon (it)'

    \nt MN: noh quenapit
    \ng suppositive |noh quenapit| `he who sits upon (it)'    Is.40.22

    (|quenobpuuncke| [= |quenappuonk| vbl.n.] `a stool'    Wood)


\lx quenau
\va -náe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
\ps adv., +conjunction, ?governing conjunct verb
\ge `as soon as'
\so Mk.5.36; Josh.8.19; Deut.8.9
\ge `scarcely'
\so Gen.27.30
    \xv Neit Jehovah monchu quenau mahche ken∞nont Abraham,...
    \xe And the LORD went his way, as soon as he had left communing with Abraham:...
    \so Gen.18.33
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah Jakob quenau monchit wutche anaquabenit Isaakoh ∞shoh, Esau wematoh petutteau,...
    \xe ..., and Jacob was scarce gone out from the presence of Isaac his father, that Esau his brother came in ...
    \so Gen.27.30
    \nt +
\cf quenauet


\lx quenauet
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 138
\ps v.impers. / II, initial |quen-| (2)
\ge `it is wanting'
\so Exp. Mayhew
    |n∞nat| or |quenauat| `to be wanting or defective'
    adv. |quenauadte| `necessarily'    C.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |éska8ana| `j'ai besoin de'.
    Algonquian [alg] |GWINAWI-| `ce mot signifie que ce qu'exprime le verbe devant lequel il est placé, on ne peut réussir à le faire, on ne sait comment le faire, on est dans l'impossibilité de le faire'    Cq.110b-111b.
    \nt +
Cree |Kwe'towe| `adv. of doubt, signifying loss, want, uncertainty'    Frs.307a.
Delaware [del] |kwiila-| `lacking'    O'M.116a.
Fox |kwi∙natawi| (prev) `at a loss, destitute'    Fx.L.86.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |c8ir-| glosses with "ne pouvoir", etc.    Grv.135/106b.
Miami |kwälamaka| `I lose him'    D.-V.309.
Ojibwe [oji] |Gwinawi| `in compositions, signifies doubting, not knowing, loss'; |kwi∙nawi| `doubting, uncertain'    Bar.147ab;P&G.65.
Shawnee [sjw] |kwiilaa-, kwiila-| `FAILURE IN GETTING', |nikwiilawa| `I can't find him'    D.-V.309.]

\et cf. Ho., no. 121, pp. 267b-268a *kwi∙Θ(a)w- `be missing, absent'; A.1123-1131-; H.1400-1406, B.5, 87/442, 104, 122/480


\lx quenauhik∞
\va quenauwahuk∞
\va quenahuk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
\ps v.i. / AI+O, theme 2 reflexive? (to !|quenauwaheau|?, a causative in permissive sense); note also, significantly, the existence of an II(+O?) derivative.
\ge `he wants, is in need'; or impers. `it is wanting to him'
\nt G&B.699 s.v. |(nuk)quenauwehukkumun| AI+O `we need him'; "In origin an inverse TA theme, but the forms with animate objects show that synchronically this is an AI+O,..."
\nt Research needed: Note Deut.2.7 and Mayhew's form.
    \xv ..., wanne teag kukquenauwahuk∞.
    \xe ...; thou hast lacked nothing.
    \so Deut.2.7
    \ng 2->0 negative indicative
    \nt +
    \xv pasuk kukquenauhik
    \xe one thing thou lackest
    \so Mk.10.21
    1st pers. |nukquenauhik| `I am in want of, it is wanting to me'
    \xv ...: newutche nummachek, kah nukquenahik.
    \xe ...: for I am poor and needy.
    \so Ps.86.1; (M): |nukquenawehhuk|
    \ng 1 indicative
    \nt +
    1st pl. |nukquenauhikumun|    Jer.44.18
    3d pl. |quenauhikquog|

    \xv Kah wetomunog, kah quenahukquean, wanne howan nutunkquatunk∞,...
    \xe And when I was present with you, and wanted, I was chargeable to no man:...
    \so 2 Cor.11.9
    \ng 1 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Kah quenahukquehettit wine, Jesus ohkasoh unnuk, Wanne ahtauóog wine,...
    \xe And when they wanted wine, the mother of Jesus saith unto him, They have no wine.
    \so Jn.2.3
    \ng 3p->0 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnumóatinnaoash howan quenauhukqut.
    \xe ...: and distribution was made unto every man according as he had need.
    \so Acts 4.35
    \ng 3(->_adv_) conjunct
    \nt +
    Suppos. 3d pers. sing. |quenahuk| { form?? source? invented? }

    \se !|quenahuk∞m∞|, etc.
    \nt +
    \ps II(+O?)
    \ge `for sth to lack sth, for sth to be lacking'
    \so Lev.2.13; Lk.8.6; Co.1.24; Heb.7.11; Jas.2.16
    \xv ..., newutche quenahuk∞m∞ wuttogki.
    \xe ..., because it lacked moisture.
    \so Lk.8.6

    \xv ...tohwutch nano quenahikk∞m∞∞k onkatog sephausuonk woh waabpemouk,...
    \xe ...,) what further need was there that another priest should rise ...
    \so Heb.7.11
    \xv ... nish quenawahikkumukish wutche muhhog,...
    \xe ... those things which are needful to the body;...
    \so Jas.2.16
    \ng _0p_

    \xv ...; kah ahque quenahikk∞m∞utch wussaltum ∞n∞waonk kum-Manitt∞m, wutch metsue kussephausuonganit,...
    \xe ...; neither shalt thou suffer the salt of the covenant of thy God to be lacking from thy meat offering:...
    \so Lev.2.13
    \ng 0 imperative

    \se quenauhik∞onk
    \va quenauwehik∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `lack, want (of anything)'
    \so Job 4.11; 38.41

    \se quenauwussu
    \va quenassu
    \nt !
    \ps V.an.i. / AI
    \ge `he is wanting, is lacking' (as, to make up a prescribed number of men)
    \so Num.31.49
    \xv ..., sun kuppáguadtoh wame keihtotan ukquenassinneaóut napanna tahsuog? ...
    \xe ...: wilt thou destroy all the city for lack of five? ...
    \so Gen.18.28
    \ng 3p t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wanne quenauwussuh pasuk.
    \xe ..., and there lacketh not one man of us.
    \so Num.31.49
    \ng 3 negative indicative

    \se quenauwéehuau
    \ps Caus. / TI2 (?)
    \ge `he causes (it) to be wanting'
    \so Judg.21.3

    \se quequenauanum
    \ps Augm. / TI1b
    \ge `he is in great want, need, or privation'
    \so 1 Sam.13.6 (`in a strait')

    \se -m∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `difficulty, want, `distress'
    \so Neh.2.17

[Narragansett [xnt] |Matta nickquéhick| `I want it not.', |Machagè nikquehikkômina| `I want nothing'; |Tawhitch quenawáyean?| `Why complaine you?'; |Quenowâuog.| `They complaine.'    R.W.42;61√.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nek8^ir8temen mits8añgan|, nob. |nek8^ir8mañ| `Je ne trouve point mes vivres'.    R.502/543a.
    \nt +
Cree |Kwe'tonowäo| `He cannot find him', |Kwetama'win| `Want, need, necessity'    Frs.307ab.
Ill. {R} |Nic8irama| `je le regrette, ne le trouve plus, je le cherche, je pense s'il y est'    Gr.135/106b.
Menominee [mez] |ki∙nwahεw, ki∙nwaham| `he fails to find him, it with a stick or tool'    M.L.97.
Miami |kwälamaka|, |kwälotamäni| `I lose him, it'    D.-V.309.
Shawnee [sjw] |kwiilaa-, kwiila-| `FAILURE IN GETTING', |nikwiilawa| `I can't find him', |nikwiilaawi?Θeni| `I have nothing to eat'    D.-V.309.]

\lx quenittam
\va quentam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
    \nt +
\ps TI1a, ?directive final
\twn |quentauau| TA
\ge `to come upon, fall upon, seize upon sth' (OED come v., 48b)
\so Gen.34.25; Josh.8.7; 2 Chron.25.13
    \xv ..., neesuoh wunnaumonuh Jakob, Simeen kah Levi Dinah wunohtonukqusoh, neeswe neemunumwog togkodtegash, menuhke quenittamwog otan, kah paguanáog wame wosketompuh.
    \xe ..., that two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah's brethren, took each man his sword, and came upon the city boldly, and slew all the males.
    \so Gen.34.25
    \ng 3p->0 absolute
    \xv ..., nag quentamwog Judae keitotanash,...
    \xe ..., [they] fell upon the cities of Judah,...
    \so 2 Chron.25.13
    \ng 3p->0 absolute

    \xv Neit pish keneepomw∞ wutch adhosineat, kah quentam∞k otan,...
    \xe Then ye shall rise up from the ambush, and seize upon the city:...
    \so Josh.8.7

\nt identity of final? (directive |-ht-aw-|, |-ht-am-|?)


\lx quenohtau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 138
\ps v.t. / TI2
\ge `he lays a foundation for, he founds (it), places (it) upon'
    \xv quenohtauun
    \xe he founded it' (and pass. 'it is founded or rests on
    \so )    Lk.6.48
    pret. |-unap|    Lk.6.48

    \nt MN: quenohtunk
    \ng Suppositive |quenohtunk| `when he places or supports (it)'
    \xv asuh petutteadt wetuomut, kah quenohtunk wunnutch hassunnutonganit,...
    \xe ...; or [as if he] went into the house, and leaned his hand on the wall,...
    \so Amos 5.19
    \ng 3->0 conjunct


    \se quenohteau
    \ps With inan. subj. / TI2
    \ge `it stands or is founded on'
    \so 2 Chr.4.4

    \nt MN: ne quenohtag
    \ng suppositive |ne quenohtag| `that which it stands on'
    As n. `a foundation'    Judg.16.29; 2 Sam.22.8 (=|agwu ohtag| `that which is under'    Ps.18.7)


\lx quen∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 139
\ps v.t.an. / AI(+O)
    \dv |quen-| (2) + |-∞w-á-| `by speech'
    \nt +
\ge `he denies (him), makes denial to (him)'; +`to deny' (abs.)
\so Mk.14.68,70
    \xv Neit Sarah quen∞wau, n∞wau, Matta nutáhanu, newutche wabesu;...
    \xe Then Sarah denied, saying, I laughed not; for she was afraid. ...
    \so Gen.18.15
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    (|Nukquen∞@wam,| |nukquen∞wap.| `I deny, or did deny'
    |Nukquen∞wamun,| |-nonup.| `We deny, or did'
    \xv Queen∞wonat.
    \xe To deny
    \xv Quenôonittinneat.
    \xe To be denyed
    \xv Quenoowash mat quaquêtamöo.
    \xe Deny if you dare
    \so C.47/188.)

\nt Elsewhere |kohkón∞au|, as in Lk.22.57; Titus 1.16
    \xv kohkónnoowau God
    \xe he denies God
    \so Ind. Laws II.
\dv [From |ahque| and |n∞wau| `he refrains from speaking' (?).]

[Chip. |ahgwahnwatum| `he denied (it)'    Jn.18.25
Cree |àgooánwetum| `he denies it' (which Howse analyzes `he strong-back-hears it').]

\lx quentauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 139
    \nt +
\ps TA, ?directive final
\twn |quenittam|, TI
\ge `to come upon, fall upon, press upon sb' i.e. "to attack (suddenly and physically)"
    \xv ..., onk ukquentauóuh wosketompuh Lotuh m∞cheke, onk pas∞tshaog kod pohquanumwog squoant.
    \xe ... And they pressed sore upon the man, even Lot, and came near to break the door.'    Gen.19.9; Josh.11.7  { 3p->3
    \so objective }
    \xv ..., sephausuenuog, kah nananuáenin ut Temple, kah Sadduces ukquentauóuh.
    \xe ..., the priests, and the captain of the temple, and the Sadducees, came upon them,...
    \so Acts 4.1

\lx quequécum
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 139
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a duck'
    pl. +|mâuog|    R.W.
    |quëqueekum|    Stiles.
    Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |quauquaumps| `black ducks'; |quaqueekum| `ducks'    Stiles.
\dv Onomatopoetic, but the form is that of a verb, `he quack-quacks'.
\cf 'hah-ha-way
\cf ungowá-ums
\ge hah-ha-way| `the old-wife or long-tailed duck
\nt Cree  `the old-wife or long-tailed duck' (Anas glacialis), and Peq.  (Stiles), for the same species
\cf sesep

[Western Abenaki [abe] |k8ik8imes8| `canard'.
Delaware [del] |quiquíngus| `the gray duck'    Hkw.; `large ducks'    Zeisb.S.B.28.]

\lx queshau
\va quehshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 139
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he leaps, jumps'
\so Lk.1.41; Jn.21.7; Acts 3.8
    \xv ..., Dan s∞kshas∞wae qunnonou wuskoshimomesoh, noh pish queeshau wutch Bashan.
    \xe ..., Dan is a lion's whelp: he shall leap from Bashan.
    \so Deut.33.22
    \nt +
    (|chânsopsqu∞"shau| `a grasshopper jumps'; |nukqueeshshom| `I leaped'    C.)

    \se quequéshau
    \ps Freq. / AI, II
    \ge `he goes leaping'
    \so Cant.2.8; Acts 14.10
    \xv Onk wutayimunash quequeshaut onatuh cowashinnemesit. ...
    \xe He maketh them also to skip like a calf:...
    \so Ps.29.6
    \ng 0(p) t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Wadchuash quéhqueshôbash onatuh wushkoshimwemésit,...
    \xe The mountains skipped like rams,...
    \so Ps.114.4; (M) |quehquesishopash|
    \nt +

    \xv Kenaau wadchuog quehqueshaóg onatuh wuskoshimwemésit:...
    \xe Ye mountains, that ye skipped like rams:...
    \so Ps.114.6; (M) |quehquesishaogus|
    \nt +

    \se |quequeshahtau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI, causative final
    \ge `to make sth to skip'
    \so Ps.29.6(M)
    \xv Wonk ukquehquesuhshahtauunash onatuh Calfsut:...
    \xe He maketh them also to skip like a calf:...
    \so Ps.29.6(M)
    \ng 3->0p objective

Related to |quogqueu| `he runs', the substituted |esh| denoting sudden or violent motion.
\cf quaquequeshont

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nekesirra|, ou |nekes8ssé| `je cours, je vas vîte.'
Cree |kwôssetow| `he jerks it'; |kwâskwâskoo-púthu| `it moves by leaps or jumps'.]
