\lx quinahsinnunk
\va quinahsinnunk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 139
\dv |qunni|, |quinne|, and |hassun|, |assin|, `long stone'.


\lx -quinne
\va -quinogok
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 139
    \nt Remark: Trumbull's lemma embraces a preverb or adverbial form and a verb derivative. The basic lemma is treated here as if it is |(-)quin-|, with sublemmas for Trumbull's examples, as well as some further cases. The spellings are quite variable with respect to word division, and the forms commonly occur following the verb. This can be seen in other languages, as in the note from Baraga below.
    \nt +
    \ps medial and final
    \nt +
\ge after a numeral or an indefinite quantitative (`few', `many', etc.), is used for |kesukodtash| `days', or (suppos.) |kesukok| `on the day'; or, more exactly, for |nukonash| (`nights'), suppos. |nohkog|.
\dv It is formed from |kouéu| `he sleeps'.
    "The {Indians} count their time by nights, and not by dayes, as followeth. |Sawup| `1 sleepes'/ |Isoqunnocquock| `2 sleepes'/ |Sucqunnocquocke| `3 sleepes'/ |Yoawqunnocquock| `4 sleepes'/ ...    Wood 1634.
    \nt +
    "..., their age they reckon by Moons, and their actions by sleeps, as, if they go a journie, or are to do any other business they will say, three sleeps me walk, or, two or three sleeps me do such a thing, that is in two or three days."    Josselyn's Voy. 136 [Lindholdt 97]√ { presumably reporting the pidgin forms? }
    \nt Remark: Baraga treats the cognate morpheme in Ojibwe as in effect a kind of classifier, in the following remark (1878: 311, Remark 4): "When the substantive following the Cardinal number, from one to nineteen, signifies objects of wood, stone, metal, etc., or when days are mentioned, the Cardinal number is connected with certain syllables alluding to the material, or shape, of the object expressed by the substantive;...". His first set of examples are those "[w]ith the syllable {gwan}, to indicate days; as: {Nijogwan nin gi-bimossê}. I walked two days. ..." The examples are presumably equivalent to the Massachusett preverb forms. (See also Valentine 2001, 17.4, especially pp. 884-885 and 898-899, for some evidence from a current form of speech.)
    \nt +

    \se |(-)quinne|, |(-)quinnu|
    \nt +
    \ps "final", forming composites with quantity expressions that may be free in position (adverbial), preverbs or prenouns, i.e. the result of suffixing |-e| (|-u|) to a complex whose final is |-quin-|.
    \ge `n days', expressing duration ("For" is rare in AV expressing this sense.)
    \xv Kah noh shwosuk audtahshikquinapit, pish quoshqusausu kenugke kenaau,...
    \xe And he that is eight days old, shall be circumcised among you,...
    \so Gen.17.12
    \xv ..., nunksqua n∞wetómukqunán ogguhse quinne yean piukkukquinne,...
    \xe ..., Let the damsel abide with us a few days, at the least ten;...
    \so Gen.24.55
    \xv Kah weetom ogkussequnne,...
    \xe And tarry with him a few days,...
    \so Gen.27.44
    \xv ..., yowutche kittinnumungkou neesequinne meechum, nequtta adtahshequinnukokish,...
    \xe ..., therefore he giveth you on the sixth day the bread of two days;...
    \so Ex.16.29
    \xv Matta pish kummetsimw∞ pasuk kesuk asuh neesukkesukquáe, asuh napanna tahshe kesukquáe, asuh piogkukquinne, asuh neesneechatikquinne. / Nô pajeh mamusse nepauzsaut,...
    \xe Ye shall not eat one day, nor two days, nor five days, neither ten days, nor twenty days; / But even a whole month,...
    \so Num.11.19-20√
    \xv ..., kah mahtokqs wunnúhkukkomun nequtta tahshikquinnu:...
    \xe ..., and the cloud covered it six days:...
    \so Ex.24.16√

    \se |-quinukod|, |-quinnukod|
    \nt +
    \ps II derived "final"
    \ge `to be the nth day; (on) the nth day; n days', the first of these perhaps being basic; with |mahche| `after n days' (the preverb not always being present); participle used to denote a specific day as an entity, as if "what is the nth day" (e.g. Gen.2.3).
    \xv Onk pahto wonk nesausuk tahshikquinukod,...
    \xe And he stayed yet other seven days;...
    \so Gen.8.12
    \xv Kah noh pahkesit pish seauhkon ut neh nishneunkqussinutcheh ut nishikquinukodtut, kah ut nesausuk tahshikquinukukodtut ...
    \xe And the clean person shall sprinkle upon the unclean on the third day, and on the seventh day:...
    \so Num.19.19
    \ng a nominalized form, with the locative suffix?
    \xv ..., Yeu yaunchadtikquinukod matta kummeetseinneau.
    \xe ..., This day is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting,...
    \so Acts 27.33

    \nt MN: Mahche neesequinukok kutomuhquanukqun, kah nishikquinogok pish nuttahshinukqun,...
    \ng suppositive |Mahche neesequinukok kutomuhquanukqun, kah nishikquinogok pish nuttahshinukqun,...| `After two days will he revive us: in the third day he will raise us up,...'    Hos.6.2√
    \ng future
    \xv Kah GOD onantam nesausuk audtashikquinukok kah ∞t∞wontamun:...
    \xe And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it:...
    \so Gen.2.3
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv nashikquinukok
    \xe on the third day
    \so Gen.34.25
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle; past narrative
    \nt +
    \xv Onk mahche tahshikquinógkok ne woh adt neechadt,...
    \xe And when her days to be delivered were fulfilled,...
    \so Gen.25.24
    \nt +
    \xv Kah n nih, mahche m∞chetikquinukok, ketass∞t ut Egypt napuk,...
    \xe And it came to pass in process of time, that the king of Egypt died:...
    \so Ex.2.23
    \ng i.e. "[on a day] after many days"
    \xv Kah n nih, nawhutch missinninnúog sohhamwog nesausuk adtahshequinnukok,...
    \xe And it came to pass, that there went out some of the people on the seventh day for to gather,...
    \so Ex.16.27
    \ng _0_ participle
    \xv KAH nashikquinogok wetauwadtuongan∞ ut Cana ut Galile,...
    \xe ANd the third day there was a marriage in Cana of Galilee,...
    \so Jn.2.1; (M): |nashukqunnogohk|
    \xv ..., Paguatau∞k yeu Temple, kah nishikquinnogkok nutómuhkinumun.
    \xe ..., Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.
    \so Jn.2.19; (M): |nishukqunnogohk|
    \xv Kah mahche nishshwosuk tahshikquinukok, wonk ukkodnetuhtaenumoh moiéoh,...
    \xe And after eight dayes, again his disciples were within,...
    \so Jn.20.26; (M): |mahche nishwosuk âtashukqunnogohk|

    \se -quinnuhshau
    \ps "AI final"
    \dv |-quin-| + |-uhsh-á-| `go, walk'
    \so Gen.30.36; Num.33.8
    \xv Kah nishikquinushon na ponamun nôeu nehenwonche kah Jakob,...
    \xe And he set three days' journey betwixt himself and Jacob:...
    \so Gen.30.36
    \ng perhaps a nominalized form in |-n|, calqued on AV; similarly Deut.1.2
    \xv ..., kah nishikquinushaog ut Ethame touohkomukqut, kah tuppuksinwog ut Marah.
    \xe ..., and went three days' journey in the wilderness of Etham, and pitched in Marah.
    \so Num.33.8
    \xv (Nabo nequttukquinshon wutch Horeb, kishke mayut wadchuut Seir en Kadesh-Barnea.)
    \xe (There are eleven days' journey from Horeb by the way of mount Seir unto Kadesh-barnea.)
    \so Deut.1.2

    \xv nequttaqunohteagk
    \xe tarry all night
    \so Gen.19.2
    \ng 2p imperative, final unclear (|-hk-|+|-á-|??, compare forms from Wood 1634 though); attests sense "night"
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |Neesqúnnagat.| `2 dayes.', |Shuckqunóckat.| `3 dayes.'; |Quttatashuchuckqúnnacaus-keesitínnes wâme.| `In six dayes he made all things.', |Enadatashuckqunnóckat taubatau~mwock.| `On the seventh day they praise God.'    R.W.65;124-126/r.132-134.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |kate`k8ni8i| or |nek8t8gni8i| `une nuit', |nis8gni8i| `deux nuits', etc.    R.360/494a.√
Delaware [del] |guto-kenak| `one day'    Hkw.; |nguttokuni| `one night', |nischogunak| `two nights', etc.    Zeisb.; +|Nuktogunak| `one night'; |-ookwu@n-| `day'    B&A.101; O'M.435ab.
    Algonquian [alg] |KON| `jour naturel, jour civil, composé de 24 heures, à partir de minuit. On ne se sert de ce mot que lorsqu'il s'agit de la durée du temps:...'    Cq.183b.  { for |-KON|? }
    \nt +
Fx. |-guna-|, |-guni-| `day'    Mch.35.635b.
K. |-okone| `days'    V.169.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |-og∙on-/-ukun-| `day'    P.202-203/184-185.
WAbn. e.g. |bazegwenoo| AI `he is one, he is one year old'; |nizogwenagad| II `it is two days'; |nizogweniwi| adv `for two days, during two days'    D.1.83;370.]

\et B., 97, 118-119/476, *-ekon `day' "appears in particles"; H. p.248 *-okon, *-okonak `day', 3189 *tahΘokoni XP `so many [days]', 3187 *tahΘokonakatwi II `[it is] so many [days]'; B.1962, 17.75, p.379 |-εkon(-)| `day'


\lx -quinnohhod
\va -om
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 139
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Only known in conjunct form at present (cf. remark in F&L. on M.-P. form); the example from Josh.4.19 (not unique) appears to show a preverb + verb with |quin-| as initial--this cannot easily be dismissed as a problem of word division.
\ps II; since |nepauz| is animate, it cannot be the subject, and perhaps is to be regarded as the object in an II+O formation.
\ge `on the nth day (of the mth month)'
\so Gen.7.11,8.4; Lev.16.29,23.27; Num.29.12; Josh.4.19; Jer.52.4,12; Ezek.20.1;...

    \xv ..., nahohtôeu nepauz, nabo nesausuk audtahshikquinohhog nepauz ne kesukok, wame tohkekomuash quogquononogkogish pohquodchuwánash,...
    \xe ..., in the second month, the seventeenth day of the month, the same day were all the fountains of the great deep broken up,...
    \so Gen.7.11, sim. Gen.8.4; (E0&E1): |kes∞sh| for "of the month"
    \xv Kah nabo napanna tahshikquinuhhog, nesausuk adtahs∞it nepauz, pish k∞neetupanatamwe mowem∞ ...
    \xe And on the fifteenth day of the seventh month ye shall have a holy convocation;...
    \so Num.29.12
    \xv Kah missinninnuog kuhkuhqueog wutch Jordan piukque quinuhhog, negonne nepauz, kah tuppuksinwog ut Gilgal ...
    \xe And the people came up out of Jordan on the tenth day of the first month, and encamped in Gilgal,...
    \so Josh.4.19 (E1&2)

    |Nesqunnoh, nesu@kquinögod.| `Next day, {or} two days hence, ({or} ago)    C.15/164.
    \nt ?

[M.-P. |amsqahsukonohom| II `it is the first day of the month'    LeS.7a.]


\lx quinnuppe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 139
\ps II
\ge `(it is) round about, all around; it turns'
\ps As adv. and prep.
\nt G&B.700
    \xv quinuuppe kouéog weekit
    \xe they lodged round about the house
    \so 1 Chr.9.27


    \se quinnuppu
    \ps With an. subj. / AI, i-stem
    \ge `he turns, changes his course', +`to go about (somewhere)'
    \xv ..., kah quinnuppoog, petutteaog weekit,...
    \xe ..., and they turned in unto him, and entered into his house:...
    \so Gen.19.3
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... neit pish quinnuppeu, kah k∞woskhukkou,...
    \xe ..., then he will turn and do you hurt,...
    \so Josh.24.20
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jesus au quinnuppu wame Galile ...
    \xe And Jesus went about all Galilee,...
    \so Mt.4.23√
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt It is, in fact, an intransitive verb.

    \nt MN: noh quinnupit
    \ng suppositive |noh quinnupit| `he who turns or is turned'    Lev.20.6

    imperat. 2d pl. |quinnuppegk| `turn ye'    2 K.17.13; +Gen.19.2

    \se -peu
    \ps with inan. subj. / II

    \se quinnuppeonk
    \ps Vbln.
    \ge `a turning'
    \ge `conversion'
    \so Acts 15.3

    \se quinnuppenum
    \ps V.t.inan / TI1b
    \ge `he turns (it) about'
    \so 1 K.8.14

    \nt MN: noh quanuppinuk
    \ng suppositive |noh quanuppinuk| Prov.28.9

    \se quinnuppehtau
    \ps V.i.refl. / AI?
    \ge `he turns himself about'    Mk.5.30

    \se quinnuppunau
    \ps V.t.an. / TA
    \ge `he turns (him) about, "converts" him'

    suppos. part. |quanuppinont| `when turning, "converting"'    Ps.19.7; James 5.19

    \se quinnupsheau
    \va quinnupshau
    \nt +
    \ps V.i. inan.subj. / II(+O?)
    \ge `it (e.g. a path, a trail, a boundary) turns about'; +`to go about, turn; to compass sth'
    \so Josh.19.12
    \xv ..., kah sussippoi quinnupsheau wehque Taánath, Shiloh,...
    \xe ...; and the border went about eastward unto Taanathshiloh,...
    \so Josh.16.6
    \nt +
    \xv Kah quinnupsheau wutch Sarid, en wutchepwoiyeu nogque adt pashpishont, wehque wussippoiyeumut Chisloth-Tabor, kah neit sohwushau en Daberath, kah kuhkukqshau en Japhia.
    \xe And [the border] turned from Sarid eastward toward the sun rising unto the border of Chislothtabor, and then goeth out to Daberath, and goeth up to Japhia.
    \so Josh.19.12
    \nt +

    \xv ..., ne quanupishunk wame ohkeet Havilah,...
    \xe ..., which compasseth the whole land of Havilah,...
    \so Gen.2.11
    \ng _0_ participle (with locative)
    \nt +

    \se quinnuppohteau
    \ps V.t. inan.subj. / II (TI2-O ?)
    \ge `it encompasses, surrounds, turns itself about'

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |k8rbip8'd8| `tourne cela dans ta main', |nek8rbaké`sin. v. nek8rbe'ssin| `je me tourne changeant de place étant couché.', |K8rbaskip8dañs8| `tourner le rotis v.g. pendu a une corde' |nek8rbaskip8d8n|. nob. |nek8rbaskip8'rañ|, |nek8rba`t8n| `Je le tourne sans dessus dessous, Je fais q^ ce qui etoit en bas soit en haut.'; |K8rbaski8i.| `en tournant no' le verrons v.g. quand nou aurons doublé l'anse, q^ no' aurons tourné &c.', |K8rbi8i| `sans dessus desssous.'    R.484/536b;P.22/556b-557a.
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |KWENIB-| [long vowel!] `exprime l'idée de {renverser}, de {tourner}'    Cq.189b.
Cree |Kwä'tipinäo| `He turns him over, (as by hand).', |Kwä'tipinum| `He turns it over, (as a canoe is turned over to drain).'    Frs.306b.
Shawnee [sjw] |kolep-| `TURN OVER, AROUND', |nikolepipe| `we turn around', |kolep⌠inwa| `he turned over lying down', |nikolepΘe| `I turned around while walking'    D.-V.304.]

\et extension to *kweΘ- `turn over' (as "capsize"), reconstructed by Haas as PCA *kweΘep- `TURN AROUND', unfortunately without the Algonquian evidence; H.1393; Siebert 1975, item 45; cf. *kwe:Θk-, with similar glosses, in H.1344-1360, Ho., item 107, p. 266 (short vowel). (Rotation in different planes; vowel length?)

\lx qunnunkque
\va qunnuhque
\va qunnunkqueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 140
\ps II  { is this attested? }
\ge `it is high'
\ps as adv. / PreN, PreV
\ge `on high'
\so Job 39.18
    \xv Ahque qunnunkqueu tahshin∞k kutaskonn∞wôog:...
    \xe Lift not up your horn on high;...
    \so Ps.75.5; (M) |Qunnuhque|
    \nt +

    \se |qunnunkqui|
    \nt +
    \ps II; PreN
    \ge `high'
    \so Num.23.3
    \xv ..., kah au qunnunkqui ayeuonganit.
    \xe .... And he went to a high place.
    \so Num.23.3

    \se |qunúhquodt|, +|qunnunkquodt|, |qunnuhquod|
    \nt +
    \ps II; PreN
    \ge `to be high, of a high stature'
    \so Ex.14.8; Exek.31.3; 2 Cor.10.5; Rev.21.12
    \xv ..., kah kuttinnohkou qunnuhquodt.
    \xe ..., and high is thy right hand.
    \so Ps.89.13; (M) |qunnuhqui|
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu wahteauonk ... qunnuhquodt, matta woh nummissunnum∞un.
    \xe Such knowledge ...; it is high, I cannot attain unto it.
    \so Ps.139.6; (M) |qunnuhquat|
    \nt +
    \xv qunúhquodt
    \xe of an high stature
    \so Ezek.31.3√
    \xv Kah áhtou qussukquaneneutunk missi kah qunnunkquodt,...
    \xe And had a wall great and high,...
    \so Rev.21.12
    \nt +

    \xv ..., ∞netue quanunkquok quttianittuonk,...
    \xe ..., the excellency of dignity,...
    \so Gen.49.3
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt +

    \se qunnunkqussúmau
    \ps TA, ratifying (transitive) final, with |anue|; implying AI !!|qunnunkqussu| (cf. Narr., etc. inf.)
    \ge `he is tall'
    \so 1 Sam.9.2; +Num.24.7
    \xv ..., anue qunnunkqussúmau mìssinninnûh.
    \xe ... he was higher than any of the people.'    1 Sam.9.2  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |Qunnaúqussu.| `A tall man.'    R.W.53.√
Delaware [del] |gunaquot| `it is long, high'; |gunaxu| `he is long, tall of stature'; +|Guanaquot| `long, tall, high; (especially, high. {A.}); |kwu@náhkwat| II `be high, tall', |kwu@náhkwsuw| AI `be long'    Zeisb.; B&A.45; O'M.121a.
Lp.A. |k8n8s8| `long', |k8nai 8isk8ig| `papier long'    D.47.]

\et presumably not to be separated from *kenw- `long, tall', Ho.1957, no.53, 256b-257a, H.1012-1032 (including *kenwa∙xkwatwi II, *kenwa∙xkwesiwa AI), with sporadic distant metathesis of the labialization?

    pl. +|og|

Old Alg. |kinonge|    (Lah.), whence comes |maskinonge| or |muskelunijeh|, the great kinonge of the St Lawrence and northern lakes.

\lx quogkinnum

    \xe And they took Joseph's coat, and killed a kid of the goats, and dipped the coat in the blood;
    \so Gen.37.31

    \xv ... kah quogkinsh kukkodchuhki∞m ut vinegerut. ...
    \xe ...and dip thy morsel in the vinegar.
    \so Ruth.2.14
    \nt +

    (|quogkinnósúe| `dipping, dipped'?    C.)

\et Relationship to A.1030-1032, Ho. no.112, 266b-267a, H.1326-1329 *ko∙k- `dip, dive, jump in water, wash'? i.e. *kwak + -en- `by hand'?


\lx quogquadtinohkonau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 141
\dv ?initial |kwet-| reduplicated, T.142b, + ?
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `he wrestles with (him)'
    \so Gen.30.8,32.4,5
    \nt +
    \xv nukquogquadtinohkon
    \xe I wrestle with (him)
    \so Gen.30.8

    \se quogquadtinnittuog
    \ps AI, reciprocal to stem |quogquadtin-|
    \nt +
    \ge "to wrestle with one another"
    \nt +
    mutual, |quogquadtinnittuog| `they wrestle (one with the other)' { source not given }
    |Angel & Iakob quadtinuttuog| "An angel and Jacob wrestle"    Gen.32.20(Hd)(E0) { unreduplicated }
    \nt +

    \xv ...: kah Jakob wobpe qunukqui quogquadtinuthettit.
    \xe ...; and the hollow of Jacob's thigh was out of joint, as he wrestled with him.
    \so Gen.32.25
    \ng 3p; i.e. "as they wrestled"
    \nt +

    \se !|quogquadtinnitteau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, to stem |quogquadtin-|
    \ge `to wrestle with sth'
    \so Eph.6.12
    \xv Newutche matta nukquogquodtinnitteaumun weyaus kah wsqheonk,...
    \xe For we wrestle not against flesh and blood,...
    \so Eph.6.12

    \se quogquadtinnittuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `wrestling'
    \so Gen.30.8

\et To the root *kwet- `try'; cf. Men. |kociahkatowak| `they wrestle with each other', |kociahkawεw| `he wrestles with him', M.L.100, B.1962, 16.123, 352.


\lx quogqueu

    \xe Run thou to me

\lx quoshauwéheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 141
\ps v.t.caus. / TA
\ge `he makes (him) ready, prepares (him)'
\nt more common in the freq. form, |quaquashwéheau| and |quagquash-|, as in Jonah 4.7
    \xv Kah Moses womussu wutch wadchuut en missinninnútu, kah pahke quashauwehheau missinninnúh,...
    \xe And Moses went down from the mount unto the people, and sanctified the people;...
    \so Ex.19.14
    \nt +

    \se !|quaquoshweheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, reduplicated
    \ge `to make sb ready'
    \so Ex.19.10,11

    \xv ..., Ush missinninnútu pahke quaquashwek yeu kesukok kah saup, kah kutchissittauhettich wuthogk∞unn∞∞ash. Kah nag pakodche quáquashwehettich nishikquinukok:...
    \xe ..., Go unto the people, and sanctify them today and tomorrow, and let them wash their clothes, And be ready against the third day:...
    \so Ex.19.10-11

    \se quoshauwêhtam
    \va quoshaeitam
    \nt +
    \ps With inan. obj. / TI1a
    \ge `he makes (it) ready, prepares (it)'; +`to provide for sth'
    \xv ..., kah yeuyeu ahquompak woh wonk nukquoshaeitam nehenwonche neek?
    \xe ...: and now, when shall I provide for mine own house also?
    \so Gen.30.30
    \nt +

    \xv ... wekummechum, kah petukqunnunk ne quoshauwehtog,...
    \xe ... the savoury meat and the bread, which she had prepared,...
    \so Gen.27.17
    \nt +

    \se quaquoshwéhtam
    \va quagquoshwíhtam
    \ps freq. / TI1a
    \ge `to make (sth) ready, prepare sth'
    \nt +
    \so Jonah 4.6; Prov.30.25
    \xv ...? newutche nummahche quaquashweetam wetu,...
    \xe ..., for I have prepared the house,...
    \so Gen.24.31
    \nt +

    \xv ..., uss∞wus yeug wosketompaog nekit, nush∞k, kah quaquoshwehtam∞k,...
    \xe ..., Bring these men home, and slay, and make ready;...
    \so Gen.43.16
    \ng 3p->0
    \nt +

    \se !|quaquoshwehtamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to prepare sb sth; to get sb sth'
    \so Gen.34.4; Num.23.29; Rev.12.6

    \xv Kah mittamwossis spuhh∞au touohkomuk, uttoh adt wutappuonganit quaquoshwétamauont GOD,...
    \xe And the woman fled into the wilderness, where she hath a placed prepared of God,...'    Rev.12.6  { participle 3->3
    \so +_0_ }

    \xv ..., kah yeuut quaquoshwunnumah nesausuk tahsuog oxenog, kah nesausuk tahsuog ramsog.
    \xe ..., and prepare me here seven bullocks and seven rams.
    \so Rev.12.6
    \ng 2->1+3


\cf quoshwéonk

\lx quoshomau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
\ps v.t.an. / TA(+O)
\ge `he says beforehand to (him), promises (it) to (him)'; +`to betroth sb'
\nt G&B.699
    \xv Pish kukquoshom mittamwossis, kah onkatog pish ∞wehpamoh,...
    \xe Thou shalt betroth a wife, and another man shall lie with her:...
    \so Deut.28.30
    \nt +
    \xv ...(..., kah kukquoshom yeu wanegik kittinneum)
    \xe ..., and thou hast promised this goodness unto thy servant:
    \so 2 Sam.7.28; 1 Chr.17.26
    \ng 2->3+0 absolute[!]

    suppos. part. |quoshomont| `vowing, promising'    Mal.1.14; Heb.6.13
    \xv noh quoshomont
    \xe one who is pledged, "betrothed"
    \so Lev.19.20
    \xv Kah howan quoshomont ummittamwussoh, kah asq nemununk? ...
    \xe And what man is there that hath betrothed a wife, and hath not taken her? ...
    \so Deut.20.7√
    \xv ... neane quoshomadt Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m nannouwe mag∞onk, ne mutt∞n∞e quoshauwáan.
    \xe ...; even a freewill offering, according as thou hast vowed unto the Lord thy God, which thou hast promised with thy mouth.
    \so Deut.23.23
    \ng TA vs. AI(+O?)
    \nt +
    pass. part. inan. |ne quoshómuk| `that which is promised, being promised'

    \xv Quoshaum∞k kah áadtúhkók Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m∞:...
    \xe Vow, and pay unto the LORD your God:...
    \so Ps.76.11; (M) |Quashomoohk|
    \ng 2p->3 imperative

    \se |quoshomuau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), indefinite object
    \ge `to promise, vow (sth)'
    \so Num.6.2; Deut.12.17


\lx ..., Wosketomp asuh mittamwossis, chippeit, quoshomuwadt, Nazarite quoshómuwáonk ...
\ve 3->0 conjunct
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
    \xv ..., asuh matta pasuk kukquoshomuwaongash, nish quoshómuwáanish,...
    \xe ..., nor any of thy vows, which thou vowest,...
    \so Deut.12.17
    \ng 2->_0p_ participle

    \se quoshómáonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \so a promising, saying beforehand'
    \so Acts 1.14; 2 Pet.3.9

\lx quoshqussausu
\va quoshqusausu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
\ps v.adj.an. / AI, II, derivational passive to TI stem
\ge `he is circumcised'
\so Gen.17.10,26
    \xv Ne kesukok quoshqusausu Abraham, kah Ishmael wunnaumonuh.
    \xe In the self same day was Abraham circumcised, and Ishmael his son.
    \so Gen.17.26
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +

    \xv Kah matta quoshqusauseg wosketomp, ∞weyaus ut uhquáeu matta quoshqúsau[si]n∞k, ...
    \xe And the uncircumcised man child, whose flesh of his foreskin is not circumcised, ...
    \so Gen.17.14
    \ng _3_ negative participle; _0_ negative participle
    \nt +

    \se quoshquswau
    \ps V.t.an. / TA, scissive final
    \ge `he circumcises (him)'
    \so Ex.4.25
    \xv Onk Abraham quoshquswau wunnaumonuh Isaakoh...
    \xe And Abraham circumcised his son Isaac...'    Gen.21.4  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +

    \xv ... ayish kenehquogwosh, kah wonk quoshqus wunnaumonuh Israel nohohtôeu.
    \xe ..., Make thee sharp knives, and circumcise again the children of Israel the second time.
    \so Josh.5.2
    \ng 2->3(p) imperative
    \nt +


    \se quoshqussum
    \ps V.t.inan. / TI1b, scissive initial
    \so Gen.17.11,23,24,25
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk quoshqussum weyaus ut uhquae,...
    \xe ...; and [he] circumcised the flesh of their foreskin ...
    \so Gen.17.23√

    \nt MN: ne quoshkussuk
    \ng suppositive |ne quoshkussuk| `that which is circumcised'    Gen.17.24
    \ps 0
    \xv ..., ne quoshqussuk ∞weyaus ut uhquae.
    \xe ..., when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
    \so Gen.17.24
    \ng 3->0+_adv_ participle
    \nt +

    \se quoshqusaúsuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `circumcision'
    \so Ex.4.26; Jn.7.22


\lx quoshwéonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
\ps NI
\ge `an "alarm"'
\so Num.10.5,6
\dv (vbl.n. from |quoshauwéheau| `he makes or causes him to be prepared'); a `note of preparation'; or perhaps directly from |qushehheau| (cus. of |qushau| `he fears') `he makes afraid, alarms'.


\lx quoshwunnau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
    \nt +
\ps TA, manual final
\ge `to make sb ready'
\so Ps.7.12
    \xv ..., ónchippinnau wutohtompe káh ukquoshwunuh.
    \xe ...: he hath bent his bow, & made it ready.'    Ps.7.12; (M) |ukquoshwunnuh|  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    \se quoshwunnum
    \ps TI1b, manual final
    \ge `to prepare sth', +`to make sth ready'
    \so Ps.11.2(E&M)
    \xv ...: quashinumwog úkkónunkquodtou, ut wutahtuman∞óut:...
    \xe ..., they make ready their arrow upon the string;...
    \so Ps.11.2
    \ng 3p->0 absolute

    \se quaquoshwunnum
    \ps TI1b, reduplicated
    \ge `to make sth ready, to prepare sth; to offer sth (for sb)'
    \so Gen.43.25; Num.15.5,28.15,20,23,24,29.2; Deut.33.21; Mt.25.7,26.19
    \xv Kah quaguoshwunumwog mag∞onk peyont Joseph puhshaquódt,...
    \xe And they made ready the present against Joseph came at noon:...
    \so Gen.43.25  { 3p->0 absolute }; (E0) |quaquoshwunumwog|
    \xv ..., nashwé piogque chippag pish kukquaquoshwunumumw∞, wutche pasuk ox,...
    \xe ...; three tenth deals shall ye offer for a bullock,...
    \so Num.28.20
    \ng 2p->0 absolute

    \se quaquoshwunnumauau
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to prepare sb sth'
    \so Num.23.29

    \xv ..., kah yeuut quaquoshwunnumah nesausuk tahsuog oxenog,...
    \xe ..., and prepare me here seven bullocks,...
    \so Num.23.29
    \ng 2->1+3(p) imperative

\lx qushau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
\ps v.t.an. / TA, applicative
\ge `he fears (him), is afraid of (him)'; +"to dread sb"
\so Prov.14.2
    \xv Kah k∞wabesuonukk∞óog, kah kukqushikouoog, nishnoh puppinashim ohket,...
    \xe And the fear of you and the dread of you shall be upon every beast of the earth,...
    \so Gen.9.2
    \ng 3p->2p absolute
    \nt +
    with affixes
    \xv ukqushuh
    \xe he fears him
    \so 2 Sam.3.11

    imperat. 2d sing. |qush|
    \xv Qush Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m, kah waussum,...
    \xe Thou shalt fear the Lord thy God, and serve him,...
    \so Deut.6.13
    \nt +
    2d pl. |qusheuk| or |-∞k|

    \se qusháonk
    \va qushaong(an
    \nt !
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `fearing, fear'
    \so Prov.14.27; 20.2
    \ge `reverence'
    \so C.
    \xv ..., qushaonk GOD matta yeu ayauonganit ohtano,...
    \xe ... the fear of God is not in this place,...
    \so Gen.20.11
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |Kukkushickquock.| `They feare you.', |Nuckqusha.| `I feare him.'    R.W.178/r.186.
Cree |goostáchu| `he is afraid'; |góostayoo| `he fears him'; |goos-tum| `he fears it'.]

\et B., no.44, 90/447; H. 1376 *kwe?Θe∙wa TA `fear/frighten'


\lx qushk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
    \nt +
\ps initial, intransitive
\nt Remark: cf. allomorph |quehch-| with palatalization of final cluster
\ge `back' (in sense of turning back, returning)
\so following lemmas, etymology

[Delaware [del] |kwaxk(w)-| `back, re-, turn back', O'M.113a-114a.]

\et G.1981, 39, 76: |qushk-| < PEA *kw@Θk-; H.1344-1360 *kwe∙Θk- `turn', with shortening of the vowel, but Hockett's reconstruction (1957, no. 107, 266ab) would imply a short vowel and the cognates seem to show some variability.


\lx qushkeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
\ps v.i. / AI, long-vowel stem
\ge `he goes back, returns', + and translating various other AV terms involving turning from a path
\so 2 K.15.12; Josh.10.15
    \xv ..., kah pish kukqushkem en puppissiyeuut.
    \xe ..., and unto dust shalt thou return.
    \so Gen.3.19
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wosketompaog qushkeog nawutch...
    \xe And the men turned their faces from thence,...
    \so Gen.18.22
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... Judah wutch w∞msu wematut, kah qushkeu en Aduliamitoh ussowesu Hirah.
    \xe ... that Judah went down from his brethren, and turned in to a certain Adullamite, whose name was Hirah.
    \so Gen.38.1
    \nt +
    \xv GOD quhteihteaj woh nutchekehtáuunnanónut Jehovah, kah woh nukqushkenanonut wutch ásuhkauónat Jehovah,...
    \xe God forbid that we should rebel against the Lord, and turn this day from following the Lord,...
    \so Josh.22.29
    \nt +
    \xv nukqushkem
    \xe I go back, turn back
    \so Neh.2.15
    (|Nukquishkeem, -up.| `I return, or did'    C.72/206
    \xv Quishkënat.
    \xe To return
    \so C.72/206)
    \nt +

    suppos.
    \xv ..., mahche qushkeit wutch aninnetahwhaonganit Chedorlaomer...
    \xe ... after his return from the slaughter of Chedorlaomer,...
    \so Gen.14.17
    \ng 3->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Kah asquam quashkeik, n∞wop, qushkish wonk en Ged-liahut wunnaumonuh Ahikan,...
    \xe Now while he was not yet gone back, he said, Go back also to Geda-liah the son of Ahikam,...
    \so Jer.40.5
    \ng 3->_adv_ negative participle
    \xv ..., nô paje quashkean ohkekontu:...
    \xe ..., till thou return unto the ground;...
    \so Gen.3.19
    \ng 2->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Mohtompog quashkeit en ∞tanat
    \xe Now in the morning as he returned into the city,...
    \so Mt.21.18
    \ng 3-_adv_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv ... qushkesh en kussonksquomut,...
    \xe ...,  Return to thy mistress,...
    \so Gen.16.9
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., chuh, ken qushkish yeu apsh: kah qushkeu kah nummattappu.
    \xe ..., Ho, such a one! turn aside, sit down here. And he turned aside, and sat down.
    \so Ruth 4.1
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +

    \se qushkeonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `turning back'
    \so James 1.17

    \se qushkée
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `backward, in return'
    \ps Is.1.4

    \se |qushkem∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, default final
    \ge `to return, be returned, turn (to sb) again; to decrease'
    \so Gen.8.3,5,27.44,43.18; Ex.14.26,28; Lev.27,24; Deut.17.17,30.17; Josh.4.18; Ps.35.13(E&M); Lk.10.6
    \xv Kah nìppe qushkem∞ wutch ohkekontu nagwutteaeu:...
    \xe And the waters returned from off the earth continually:...
    \so Gen.8.3
    \xv Kah nippeash nagwutteaeu qushkem∞ash nó pajeh piogqussuìt nepauz:...
    \xe And the waters decreased continually until the tenth month:...
    \so Gen.8.5
    \xv ..., kah nuppeantamowonk qushkem∞ en nupp∞chenauónut.
    \xe ..., and my prayer returned into mine own bosom.
    \so Ps.35.13; (M) |qushkemoop|

    \xv ..., newutche teaguash qushkem∞ugk(u)pash ut man∞taut ...
    \xe ..., Because of the money that was returned in our sacks ...
    \so Gen.43.18
    \ng _0p_ preterite participle

    \se !|qushkeauNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative final
    \ge `to return to sb'
    \so Gen.8.12
    \xv ... kah matta wonk ukqushkeaounuk∞oh.
    \xe ..., which returned not unto him any more.'    Gen.8.12  { 3
    \so ->3 negative objective }

    \se !|qushkehtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, directive final
    \ge `to return unto sb'
    \so Gen.8.9
    \xv ..., kah wonk ukqushketunkquoh ut Arkut:...
    \xe ..., and she returned unto him into the ark;...'    Gen.8.9  { 3
    \so ->3 objective }

    \nt +


\lx qushkinum
\va quoshkinum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
    \nt +
\ps TI1b
\ge `to draw sth back, reverse sth, turn sth away', +`to interpret, translate sth'
\so Num.23.20,25.11; Josh.8.26
    \xv Newutche Joshua matta qushkinum∞ wunnutcheg,...
    \xe For Joshua drew not his hand back,...
    \so Josh.8.26
    \xv ..., nutattumunum wunanitteae kutt∞wonk, kah wunnanitteau, kah matta woh nukqushkenum∞un.
    \xe ..., I have received commandment to bless: and he hath blessed; and I cannot reverse it.
    \so Num.23.20
    \xv Phineas ..., qushkinum nummusquantam∞onk wutch wunnaumonuh Israel,...
    \xe Phineas ..., hath turned my wrath away from the children of Israel,...
    \so Num.25.11
    \xv ..., onkatog ukquaquoshkinnumunat unnont∞waongash.
    \xe ...; to another the interpretation of tongues.
    \so 1 Cor.12.10
    \ng 3->0(p) t-subordinative to reduplicated stem
    \xv Newutche noh kéket∞kóhtunk pen∞wont∞waonk, peantaj onk woh ukqushkinnumun,
    \xe Wherefore let him that speaketh in an unknown tongue pray that he may interpret.
    \so 1 Cor.14.13
    \ng 3->0 objective
    \xv Matta wóh nukquishkinnu@mun.
    \xe I can't translate
    \so C.81/213
    \nt +

    |Ne quoshkinnumuk nashpe Wuttineumoh CHRIST noh as∞wesit JOHN ELIOT.| "Translated by the servant of Christ who is called John Eliot"    (E2), title page  { X->0 participle, with calqued agent phrase }
    \xv ..., kuttumma quohquoshkinuk,...
    \xe ..., except he interpret,...
    \so 1 Cor.14.5
    \ng 3 conjunct, reduplicated

    \se quogquoshkinnumwénin
    \ps NA, to reduplicated stem
    \ge `interpreter'
    \so Job 33.23
    \xv Ann∞naénuh weetomukqut, quogquoshkinnumwénin,...
    \xe If there be a messenger with him, an interpreter,...
    \so Job 33.23

    \se qushkinumauau
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to restore sb sth' i.e. "to return sth to sb"
    \so Gen.20.7,42.28
    \xv Kah unnaog wematóuh nutteaug nukqushkinumóntean,...
    \xe And he said unto his brethren, My money is restored;...
    \so Gen.42.28
    \ng objective X->1+0

    \xv ...: kah matta qushkenumauóadt, wahteaush pish wunnamuhkut kenup,...
    \xe ...: and if thou restore her not, know thou that thou shalt surely die,...'    Gen.20.7  { 2->3+3
    \so negative conjunct }

    \xv Kah yeuyeu qushkinumau wosketomp ummittamwussoh, newutche noh Manittowompaenin onk pish kuppeantamwanshuk, kah pish kuppomantam:...
    \xe Now therefore restore the man his wife; for he is a prophet, and he shall pray for thee, and thou shalt live:'    Gen.20.7  { 2->3+3
    \so imperative; (E1) |qushkenumau| }

    [Algonquian [alg] |Kwekowe| `tourner la parole, traduire, interpréter'    Cq.189b.]
    \nt +


\lx qushkodteau
\va qushkogk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 142
\ps v.i. / AI+(O)?
\ge `he passes over [fords?], goes across (a river) [on foot?]'
\so Gen.31.21; Josh.3.17; 4.10; +Gen.32.21,22,32.21; Mt.10.23; Mk.5.1, Lk.8.22,16.26; Jn.6.1,17,18.1
    \xv Kah tohwutch pohquenumóg wuttahh∞oash wunnaumonuh Israel, wutch qushkogkonat en ohkit ne Jehovah anumauont?
    \xe And wherefore discourage ye the heart of the children of Israel from going over into the land which the Lord hath given them?
    \so Num.32.7
    \ng X t-subordinative; cf. G.1981, 39, 77
    \nt +
    \xv Qut mos nunnup yeu ut ohkeit, matta mos nukqushkodteoh Jordan qut pish kenaau kukqushkodteaumw∞, kah kutohtauunneau ne wunohkomuk.
    \xe But I must die in this land, I must not go over Jordan: but ye shall go over, and possess that good land.
    \so Deut.4.22
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Matta pish kukqushkodteoh yeu Jordan.
    \xe ..., Thou shalt not go over this Jordan.
    \so Deut.31.2
    \xv ..., kah qushkodteaog Jordan,...
    \xe ..., and [they] passed over Jordan,...
    \so 2 Sam.2.29√

    \xv Qut qushkodteáog Jordan, kah wutohkeóg ohkeit ne Jehovah kum-Manitt∞mw∞ anumungqueog ohtauunat,...
    \xe But when ye go over Jordan, and dwell in the land which the Lord your God giveth you to inherit,...
    \so Deut.12.10
    \nt +
    \xv seip ne woh mo qushkodtéomuk
    \xe a river that could not be passed over
    \so Ezek.47.5

    \xv K∞wehquetumoush qushkodteadti onk woh naumun wunohke, ne ongkoue Jordan,...
    \xe I pray thee, let me go over, and see the good land that is beyond Jordan,...
    \so Deut.4.25
    \xv ...: newutche yeuyeu neepaush, qushkodteash yeu Jordan,...
    \xe ...; now therefore arise, go over this Jordan,...
    \so Josh.1.2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Qushkodteadtuh ne ogkomut nippissepaguot,...
    \xe ..., Let us go over unto the other side of the lake. ...
    \so Lk.8.22
    \nt +

    \se !|qushkodteaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to bring sb over sth, cause to pass over sth'
    \so Gen.32.23; Josh.7.7
    \xv Onk noh wunnemunoh, kah ukqushkodteaheuh sepuut,...
    \xe And he took them, and sent them over the brook,...
    \so Gen.32.23
    \ng AV: Heb. "caused to passe"

    \xv ...: tohwhutch qushkodteaheadt Jordan yeug missinninnuóg,...
    \xe ..., wherefore hast thou at all brought this people over Jordan ...? ...
    \so Josh.7.7
    \ng 2->3

    \se |qushkodteato|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to send sth over'
    \so Gen.32.23
    \xv ..., kah qushkodthato wame ne ahtunk.
    \xe ..., and [he] sent over that he had.'    Gen.32.23 { (E2) with printer
    \so s error for (E0&E1) |qushkodteato| }

    \se !|quoshkodteanshau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-nuhsh-| representative/benefactive final
    \ge `to go over sth for sb'
    \so Deut.30.13

    \xv ..., howen pish quoshkodteanshikqueog,...
    \xe ..., Who shall go over the sea for us,...
    \so Deut.30.13
    \ng 3->1p/12+0; E1: |howan|

    \se ?!|qushkodteaNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, applicative in |-N-| (prbably to an AI stem, but, if this should happen to be a TI verb, c.f. B.1962, 16.89, 346, on |-εN-| "freely added to TI stems, forming TA verbs of causative meaning")
    \ge `to bring sb over sth [a river]'
    \so Num.32.5

    \xv ..., kah ahque qushkodteasinan Jordan.
    \xe ..., and bring us not over Jordan.
    \so Num.32.5
    \ng 2->1p

    \se |qushkodteaum∞|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, inanimate subject
    \ge `to go, pass over sth'
    \so Gen.32.21; Josh.4.11
    \xv Neit mag∞onk negonne qushkodteáum∞:...
    \xe So went the present over before him;...
    \so Gen.32.21

\et G.1981, 39, 67: PEA kw@Θkakëw


\lx qushk∞hkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \nt +

\ge `to make sb to turn back, turn sb (into somewhere), to flight'

\lx qusseáshk∞

[Western Abenaki [abe] |nek8ssihada|, ou |-d8| `j'avale'.]

\et c.f. H.1366 *kwenle∙wa TA `swallow'? Not connected by G.1973, item 3, p.4a (c.f. G.1981, 27, p.66, on expected outcome, viz. |-h⌠-|). What is the final anyway? *-e⌠k- `by foot or body' (but the wrong allomorph following coronals)?? Note also H.1368 *kwentamwa TI `swallow'--perhaps an *-s- allomorph *kwen-s- existed in PA? [*kwes- `sink'?]

\lx qussinausu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 143
\ps v.adj. an.
\ge `she is menstruous'; +`to have an issue of (one's) blood, have one's sickness'

    \nt MN: Kah mittamwossis qussinausit m∞chetikquinne,...
    \ng suppositive |Kah mittamwossis qussinausit m∞chetikquinne,...| `If a woman have an issue of her blood many days ...'    Lev.15.25,20.18
    \ng 3 conjunct
    \xv Kah howae mittamwossis quashinausit nabo neese kodtumwaeu.
    \xe And a certain woman, which had an issue of blood twelve years,
    \so Mk.5.25
    \nt +

    \se -sue
    \ps as adj. and adv.
    \so Lev.15.19,25,26

    \se -ausuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `menstruation'
    \so Lev. 12.2

\lx qutchehheu
\va qutchehheau
\va qutcheheau
\ve r.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 143
\ps v.t. an. caus. / TA
\ge `he makes trial of (him), proves (him), tempts (him)', +`to try to'
    \xv ..., GOD qutcheheau Abrahamoh,...
    \xe ..., that God did tempt Abraham,...'    Gen.22.1  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu k∞ch pish qutchehetteanéau,...
    \xe Hereby shall ye be proved:...
    \so Gen.42.15
    \ng X->2p subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut nìsh noh ut qutcheheau, neyane nenawun, qut matta matcheseonganu.
    \xe ...; but [he] was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin.
    \so Heb.4.15
    \ng X->3 absolute
    \nt +

    \xv Newutche nagum chequnehtog, quajhit, noh tapenum wuttanumauónat neh quajhetcheh.
    \xe For in that he himself hath suffered being tempted, he is able to succour them that are tempted.
    \so Heb.2.18
    \nt +
    \xv K∞sh∞wóog quajhehettit quasukaihettit, kah naumwog nutanakausuongash yauunchage kodtumwae.
    \xe When your fathers tempted me, proved me, and saw my works forty years.
    \so Heb.3.9
    \nt +

    imperat. |qutcheh| `prove thou (them)'
    \xv qutcheheh
    \xe prove thou me
    \so Ps.26.2
    \xv Nat∞tomah, woi Jehovah, kah qutcheheh, qutcheh nutt∞unnussog, kah nuttah.
    \xe Examine me, O Lord: and prove me; try my reins and my heart.
    \so Ps.26.2
    \ng 2->1 imperative, 2->3 imperative; (M) also
    prohib. |Qutcheheuhkon Jehovah kum Manitt∞m neane qutcheheòg ut Massah.| `Ye shall not tempt the Lord your God, as ye tempted him in Massah.'    Deut.6.16√
    Qutche weekontamwäke.| `Try to make me glad'    C.53/193  { for 2->1 imperative !|qutchheh|? }
    |Nukqutchhüwam,| |-wap.| `I prove, or did'    C.70/205  { 1 indicative to indefinite form }

    \se qutchehwáe
    \va -uháe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `of temptation, tempting'
    \so Ps.95.8

    \se qutchuaénin
    \ps N.agent.
    \ge `one who tries, a tempter'
    \so 1 Thess.3.5

    \se qutchhuwaonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a trying, trial, temptation'
    \so Lk.4.13

\et Ho., no 102; H.1362 *kwecihe∙wa TA `to try sb'.

\lx quttaueu

    \xv ...: kah GOD pamwushaheau wabanoh ohket, kah qutóm∞ nippe.

\lx quttukquau

\lx sâchim

[Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |súnjum| `king'    Stiles.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |shahman|.
Western Abenaki [abe] |sañgmañ| `capitaine'; |nesañgmañi| `je suis capitaine'.
Delaware [del] |sagkimau| `he is a chief'    Hkw.
Mass. |sachim, sagamore| `a king'    Wood.
The comparison of these forms shows the identity of the names `sachem' and `sagamore', the latter representing the 3d sing. indic. of the verb |sonkqhuau|, or |sohkauau| (as Eliot wrote it), `he prevails over', `has the mastery'. Cf. |sontim|.]

\lx sagkinuttum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 144
    \nt +
\ps TI?
\ge "to attach sth to sth, to join things by holding"?
\so Ex26.6,11,28.14; Acts 28.20 (reduplicated [some "doubly" so]); all conjunct forms translating nouns (`chain', `tache'). Compare entries under |sogk-|.

    \xv Kah pish kutayim napanna tahshinchagadtash golde sohsagkinnittúm∞ugish, kah pish k∞wáadjishadtoh onkwhonganash, nashpe sahsohsagkinnittum∞ugish,...
    \xe And thou shalt make fifty taches of gold, and couple the curtains together with the taches:...
    \so Ex.26.6
    \xv Kah pish kutáyim napanna tahshinchagadtash brasse sahsagkinuttum∞ugish, kah pish kupponam sahsagkinuttum∞ugish ut wutt∞nuhtu,...
    \xe And thou shalt make fifty taches of brass, and put the taches into the loops,...
    \so Ex.26.11
    \xv ..., newutche, wutch wutannoausuonk Israel, yeu nutahtagkupsin sasasagkinnittum∞ug,
    \xe ...: because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
    \so Acts 28.20
    \ng 1 & 2

\et H.2920-2945 *sak- `grab, seize; hold; fasten'


\lx sagkompanau
\va -pagunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 144
\ps v.t.an. / TA
\ge `he leads (them), directs (them)'
\so Is.40.11
    (|nus-sogkompaginnu@wam| `I lead, I rule'    C.)
    pl. |-anaog|    Mt.15.14
    \xv sagkompagunuh
    \xe he led (i.e. continued to lead) them
    \so Ex.13.17,18

    suppos. pat. |-pagunont| `when he leads, leading'    Mt.15.14

    |ahque sagkompaginnean|    Lk.11.4
    = |ahque sagkompagunaiinnean| `"lead us not", do-not lead-thou-us'    Mt.6.13

    \se sagkompaginnuen
    \ps N. agent.
    \ge `one who leads, a leader'

    \xv salte kehtoh
    \xe the salt sea

\lx saltanahham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 145
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\ge `to salt, season sth'
\so Lev.2.13
\dv Ornative denominal to L.W. |salt(an)|; on the type, see B.1962, 16.143, 357: "As a secondary suffix, |-ahw|, |-ah| is added to nouns:...", with ornative examples, including `he salts him, it'. The passage in the beatitudes (Mt.5.13) uses a different formation, apparently just the predicative type; Mk.9.50 also differs. The extension in |-an-| is well attested.
    \xv kah nish noh mag∞onk, metsue kussephausuónk pish kussaltanahhamun nashpe salt:...
    \xe And every oblation of thy meat offering shalt thou season with salt;...
    \so Lev.2.13

\so Trumbull 145
    \nt +
\ps PreN
\ge `salt'
\so Gen.14.3
    \xv ..., ne salte kehtoh.
    \xe ..., which is the salt Sea
    \so Gen.14.3

\lx samp∞

    \se samp∞au

    \xe I am a guide to (them)
    \so Rom.2.19


\lx samp∞au
\va somp∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 145
\ps v.t. an. / AI(+O) (object denoting what is confessed), long-vowel stem
    \dv presumably with linguistic final |-ow-á-|
    \nt +
\ge `he confesses to (him)'; +`to acknowledge (sth)'
    \xv Kah Judah somp∞wau,...
    \xe And Judah acknowledged {them},...
    \so Gen.38.26
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nussamp∞am nummatcheseongash Jehovahut,...
    \xe ..., I will confess my transgressions unto the Lord,...
    \so Ps.32.5; (M): |nussampooam|
    \xv Neit pish nnih kesohkôontog yeush pasuk∞kish: pish samp∞wau noh matcheseu, ne papaume.
    \xe And it shall be, when he shall be guilty in one of these things, that he shall confess that he hath sinned in that thing:
    \so Lev.5.5
    \nt +

    \se !|sampumau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O)
    \dv |sampw-| + |-m-| TA `by mouth, speech'; content as secondary object
    \ge `to confess, profess sth unto sb'
    \so Deut.26.3; Acts 24.14
    \xv ..., nussampum Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m yeu kesukok, nuppetutteam ohkit,...
    \xe ..., I profess this day unto the Lord thy God, that I am come unto the country ...
    \so Deut.26.3
    \xv Qut yeu kussampumunnun nenógque en n∞waog ne heresie, ne nuttinne waussumon ummanitt∞m∞oh n∞shog:...
    \xe But this I confess unto thee, that after the way which they call heresy, so worship I the God of my fathers,...
    \so Acts 24.14
    \ng objective secondary object

    \se samp∞antam
    \ps inan. / TI1a
    \ge `he confesses (it)'
    pl. |-tamwog|    Neh.9.2

    \se sampweantam
    \ps v.i. / TI1a-O
    \ge `he is frank-minded'
    (cf. Abn. |sanbi8i| `franchement, sans feinte', under |sampwi|)
    (Primarily, `he is honest or frank toward'.)

\ps TI1b
\ge `to justify sth'
\so Lk.16.15

    \xv ..., Kenaau nagoh sampwanumogig kuhhogkaoog ánaquahettit missinninnuog,...
    \xe ..., Ye are they which justify yourselves before men;...

    \ng _2p_->3(p) participle; gender discrepancy--perhaps with mental final |-ánum-| TA
    \nt ?

    \se sampwunnumauau

    \nt !
    \ps TA+O

    \so Gen.46.28; Ps.5.3

    \so +0 t-subordinative }

\lx sampwi
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 145
    \nt Remark: Slightly reorganized to distiguish verb and prenoun/preverb
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it is straight'
\ge `[it is] right, just, upright'
    suppos. (rarely used) |..., kah uttoh en sampoi.| `..., and whether {it be} right.'    Prov.20.11 [?]*  { 0 indicative; T. has taken AV subjunctive as implying conjunct? }

    Suppos. inan. |ne sampwag| `that which is right'    2 K.22.2  { _0_ participle }; Gen.18.19 "justice"


    \se sampwe
    \ps Adj. inan. / PreN
    |sampwe yeu|    Ezek.45.11
    \xv en sampwe mayut
    \xe in a straight way
    \so Jer.31.9
    \xv en sampwe mayut
    \xe by the right way
    \so Ps.107.7; (M) |ut sompwe mayut|

    \se sampwesu
    \ps V adj. an. / AI
    \ge `he is straight, upright', +`to be righteous'
    `an upright man'    Job 1.1

    \nt MN: noh sampwesit
    \ng suppositive |noh sampwesit| `he who is upright'    Micah 7.4
    \ps 3
    \xv sampwesecheg
    \xe the righteous
    \so Gen.18.23
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +

    \se sampohteau
    \ps V.adj.inan. / II
    \ge `it is straight, upright'

    \se sampwehteau
    \ps caus. / TI2 causative
    \ge `he makes (it) straight'

    \xv ...: sampweteaush kummay ut anaquabeh.
    \xe ...; make thy way straight before my face.
    \so Ps.5.8(E&M)
    \ng 2->0 imperative

    \se sampwehteauun
    \ps part.
    \ge `straightened'

    \se sampweusseu
    \dv |sampwe-| initial + |usse-| AI
    \nt +
    \ps V.adj.an.act. / AI
    \ge `he does straight, uprightly' { i.e. "to act righteously }

    \xv ..., nushon sampweussecheg weeche matchet∞woh:...
    \xe ..., to slay the righteous with the wicked,...
    \so Gen.18.25
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +

    \se sampweusseáe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `doing justly, uprightly'
    \so 2 Pet.27.7
    `righteous'    Ps.11.7

    \se sampweusseonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `uprightness (in doing), justice, righteousness'
    \so Deut.24.13; Ps.11.7

    \se sampweusseaen
    \ps N.agent. / NA, agent noun final |-ënunü-|
    \ge `he who does right or justly, a just man', +`true man'
    \so Gen.6.9,18.26,42.11
    \nt +

    \se !|sampweusseaneu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, predicative
    \ge "to be a righteous man"
    \so Gen.15.6
    \xv ..., kah wutogquanumoh sampwe~usseaeneuunneat.
    \xe ...; and he counted it to him for righteousness.
    \so Gen.15.6
    \ng X t-subordinative

(Cf. Sansk. samá, (1) similis, æqualis; (2) æquus; (3) integer; sampád, perfectio, felicitas. Lat. similis; Engl. same.)

[*NOTE. -- Marked " No!" by the compiler in the manuscript.]

[Narragansett [xnt] |saûmpi| `straight'
Quiripi [qyp] |sompâio| `(it is) right'    Pier.
Western Abenaki [abe] |sanbi8i| `franchem't, sans feinte', but the examples given show that the word was used in the sense of "fairly, justly".    R.P.34/561ab√
Cree |símmutz| `perpendicular'; |símmutinum| `he erects it'.
    Algonquian [alg] |CABO-| `à travers, d'outre en outre'    Cq.78ab-79a.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |shaapwíhleew| AI `have diarrhea', |shaapwshéeshum| TI `cut through s.t.'    O'M.286.]
M.-P. |sapessu| AI `he has diarrhea', |sapi| (|sap-|) PreV `through'; |sapotiyaamo| AI `er fällt hindurch'     LeS.83b-84a; Sz.193-194.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |S@b| or |S@p| {prefix} `Through'    R.265a.
Shawnee [sjw] |⌠aapw-, ⌠aapot-| `IN AND OUT, THROUGH'    D.-V.310.

\et G.1965, no. 46, 217ab, G.1981, 6, 58: *⌠a∙pw- `through'.


\lx sampwushanau

\ge `he guides(them)'

    \xv ... kah wussompshanuh en touohkomuk onatuh floksut.
    \xe ..., and guided them in the wilderness like a flock.

    \nt +

    \xv ken sampwushshanop Joseph
    \xe thou that leadest Ioseph

    \ng √; why preterite?
    Part.suppos. |sampshanont|
    pl. |-oncheg| `they who guide, guides'    Is.9.16
    \xv Qut ken wosketomp kuttatuppeyeu∞mun, sampwoshássean, kah neetomp.
    \xe But it was thou, a man, mine equal, my guide, and mine acquaintance.
    \so Ps.55.13 { 2->1 }; (M): |nussompohshassoowaeninyeum|
    \nt +

    \xv ...: newajeh, newutche k∞wesuonk sagkômpáneh, kah sampwusháseh.
    \xe ...: therefore for thy names sake lead me, and guide me.
    \so Ps.31.3; (M): |sampshaseh|
    \nt +

    \se sampwushaen
    \ps N.agent.
    \ge `a guide'
    (= |sampwoshássean|    Ps.55.13)

\lx saupáe

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 146

\so Dan.2.43
    |saupáe man∞nsk| (`softened clay') `mortar'    Gen.11.3
    \xv Kah nauman missehchuog kenugshau sabáe man∞nskut,...
    \xe And whereas as thou sawest iron mixed with miry clay,...
    \so Dan.2.43 (also 2.41)
    \nt +

    Suppos. concrete, |sábahég| `that which is made soft, "pottage", boiled food' (perhaps from a causative form, |saupahhéau| `he makes it soft')
    hence |sappaen| (modern {suppawn, sepawn, sepon}, Webst.) for |saupáun| `softened'.
    "The crushed corn is daily boiled to a pap called by them suppaen." -- Descr. of N.Neth., 1671
\cf sábasum
\ge he melts, softens by heat

[Narragansett [xnt] |nasàump| "a kind of meal pottage, unparched; from this the English call their samp", etc.,    R.W.33.
Western Abenaki [abe] |ntsañbañn| `sagamité'; |ntsañbé| `fais-en'; |kesañb8|, |8iossañb8| `bouillon de chair'; |naméssañb8| `bouillon de poisson', etc.
Chip. |Nissabawe, (nin)| `I get wet, I am wet also, I am drowned'    Bar.302b√]

\et On |nasàump| etc., see Geary Lg. 21 (1945), 40-45, suggesting "(à) la soupe". Whatever one thinks of this suggestion, it is hard to reconcile with its use in the present translation.

\lx sauunum

\lx séahham
\va seóh-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 147
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\ge `he scatters (it), sprinkles (it)'; `to shed sth (of blood), spill sth'
\so Prov.20.8; Ps.53.5; Lev.3.2
    \xv Howan seohhog ∞sqheunk wosketomp ∞sqheunk pish seohhamun nashpe wosketomp:...
    \xe Whoso sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed:...
    \so Gen.9.6
    \ng 3->0 conjunct (?participle _3_->0); X->0 objective

    \xv ..., Ahque seahham∞k ∞squeheonk ...
    \xe ..., Shed no blood,...
    \so Gen.37.22
    \nt +

    \se seseahham
    \ps Freq. (with inan. suffix) / TI1a
    \so Prov.11.24

    \se seahwhau
    \va seaéhheau
    \ps With an.obj. / TA
    \ge `he scatters, disperses (them)'
    \so Prov.20.26; Is.24.1
    \xv nag seahwhóog
    \xe they are scattered
    \so Ezek.34.5
    \xv ...: kah kussewhahumunnonup kunnukke penoowohteaut.
    \xe ...: and hast scattered us among the heathen.
    \so Ps.44.11(M); (E): |kussiswahimun|
    \nt +
    \xv ...: seahhwhau t∞puoh onatuh pukquéit.
    \xe ...: he scattereth the hoar frost like ashes.
    \so Ps.147.16
    \nt +

    suppos. (pass.) |seahwhutteaóg| `when you are scattered'    Ezek.6.8

    \se seahshau
    \ps With augm. of mischance / AI?
    \ge `he scatters disastrously'    1 Sam.11.11(E1); 2 K.25.5

    \se seauhkonau
    \va sea∞kau
    \ps With augm. of continued action / AI?
    \ge `he habitually scatters, goes on scattering (them)'
    \nt (These forms are all causative. The primary verb is not used by Eliot, except perhaps in Lk.11.23 |seáeiyeu| [= |se-á-ei-u|] `he scattereth'.)
\cf nanwiyeu
\cf naswaeu

[Narragansett [xnt] |Sawhóog {&} Sawhósachick| `Loose Beads'    R.W.149/r.157.

\lx sealham
\va sealhum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 147
    \nt +
\ps TI1a,b, ?mechanical final
\so 1 K.21.8; Neh.9.38,10.1; Esth.3.12,8.8,8.10; Job 33.16,37.7; Ezek.28.12; Dan.6.17,9.24,12.4,9
    \xv ..., mamusse kussealh[a]m,...
    \xe ...; Thou sealest up the sum,...
    \so Ezek.28.12
    \ng 2 absolute
    \xv ..., wus-sealhumuneau.
    \xe ..., [they] seal unto it.
    \so Neh.9.38
    \ng (E1) |-ham-|; 3p->0 objective

    \xv KAh yeug nag sealhamutcheg, Nehemiah ...
    \xe Now those that sealed were, Nehemiah,...
    \so Neh.10.1  [ _3p_ participle }

    \se sealhausu
    \ps II, derivational passive
    \ge `to be sealed'
    \so Deut.32.34; Job 14.17; Song 4.12; Jer.32.14
    \xv Sun yeu mo n∞wadchanumonteanas, sealhausu ut kenugke nunnompak∞unit.
    \xe Is not this laid up in store with me, and sealed up among my treasures?
    \so Deut.32.34
    \ng 0 indicative
    \xv Chippinnúsueu tanohketeaonk noh neetompas, weetauômog, tohkekom kuppuhhausu, ashim seal[hau]su.
    \xe A garden enclosed is my sister, my spouse; a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.
    \so Song 4.12
    \ng ?0 indicative (attributive subordinative?)

    \xv ..., naneeswe ne sealhausik, kah ne woshwohtag wussukwhosuonk,...
    \xe ..., both which is sealed, and this evidence which is open;...
    \so Jer.32.14
    \ng _0_ participle

    \xe [Those that were sealed]

\lx sekeneam
\va sekenam
\va -á-
\ve long
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 147
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\ge `he refuses, rejects'; +with t-subordinative as clausal object
\ge `he manifests aversion to'
\ge `he hates (it)'
\so Gen.37.35; Jer.31.15; Prov.13.5
    \xv Kah Edom sekeneám wuttenanumonat Israeloh pannupwushonat wutohke,...
    \xe Thus Edom refused to give Israel passage through his border:...
    \so Num.20.21
    \nt +

    \xv Newutche sekeneáman kummoncheáhheonáont, kah nano kogkánunadt,
    \xe For if thou refuse to let them go, and wilt hold them still,
    \so Ex.9.2
    \nt +
    \nt MN: noh sekenog
    \ng Suppositive |noh sekenog| `he who refuses, hates'    Prov.15.27

    \se sekeneauau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, stem in |-aw-|
    \ge `he refuses, rejects, hates (him)'
    \so Gen.27.41
    \xv nussekeneau
    \xe I hate him
    \so 1 K.22.8; 2 Chr.18.7
    \xv Kah Esau sekeneauau Jakoboh newutche wunnanittuonk unnadt woh wunnanumukupuh ∞shoh,...
    \xe And Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing wherewith his father blessed him:...'    Gen.27.41  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish kussekeneunkumw∞ wame wosketompaog newutche n∞wesuonk:...
    \xe And ye shall be hated of all men for my name's sake:...
    \so Mk.13.13
    \ng 3(p)->2p absolute
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh sekeneait
    \ng suppositive |noh sekeneait| pl. |-itcheg| `they that hate me'    Prov.8.36√
    \xv ..., kah sekeneauweyôg,...
    \xe ..., seeing ye hate me,...
    \so Gen.26.27
    \ng 2p->1
    \nt +
    \xv Wame sekeneaitcheg nukkehkemwáónukquog,...
    \xe All that hate me, whisper together against me:...
    \so Ps.41.7; (M): |sekinniitcheg |
    \ng 3p->1 participle
    \nt +

    \xv Ahque sekene∞k noh kodt∞hkont, newutche matta pohquohhamópanneg, sekeneauáhettit noh kodt∞hkomp ut ohkeit, ánue m∞cheke pish mat kuppohquohum∞mun,...
    \xe See that ye refuse not him that speaketh. For if they escaped not who refused him that spake on earth, much more shall not we escape,...
    \so Heb.12.25
    \nt +

    \se sekeneauáonk
    \ps Vbl.n. act.
    \ge `hating, hatred felt'
    \so 2 Sam.13.15
    \xv Neit Amnon umm∞cheke sekeneauoh, newaj wussekeneauáonk ne an sekeneauont anue missi onk ne womonáonk ne an womonomp,...
    \xe Then Amnon hated her exceedingly; so that the hatred wherewith he hated her was greater than the love wherewith he had loved her. ...'    2 Sam.13.15  { 3->3
    \so nominal, parallel to verb of which it is the cognate object; cf. G&B.585 }

    \se sekeneausuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `hatred in exercise, active hatred'


    \se sekeneadtuonk
    \va -eoadtuonk
    \ps Vbl.n. pass.
    \ge `being hated; hatred received'
    \so Gen.3.15; Eccl.9.1

    \se sekeneaittuonk
    \ps Vbl.n., reciprocal or mutual
    \ge `enmity, mutual hatred'
    \so Prov.10.12

[Narragansett [xnt] |Sékineam| `I have no mind to it'; |Nissékineug| `He likes not me'; |Sekinneauhettu~ock| `They hate each other'.    R.W.179/r.187.√
Western Abenaki [abe] |nesigañdam| `Je ne le veux pas'.    R.496/541a.
Delaware [del] |schinginamen| `to hate something' |-galau| `he is hated'; +|Schingalan| `to hate somebody', |Schingi| `unwilling, disliking, unwillingly' (also as initial), |Schinginamen| `to hate'; |shiingáalu@weew| AI `hate people'    Zeisb.; +B&A.128-129; O'M.294a-295a.
    Algonquian [alg] |CING-| `...; en haine, en déplaisir, en horreur', |Ni cingenima| `je l'ai en aversion, en horreur...'; |Ni cingiTawa| `je n'aime pas à l'entendre', etc.    Cq.90b-91a; Cq.1891, 249, 91-92.
    \nt +
Chip. |Jingenima, (nin)| `I hate him, I detest him', |Jingendan, (nin)| `I hate it, I detest it'    Bar.172b.
eOj |⌠i∙nke∙nema∙t| `he hates him'    B.1957,261b.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |nichinkira8eha| `je le choque; il me haït'    Grv.121/100a.
Mah.(Schmick) |schegen-| `hate'    Masthay 77-78, 183.
Menominee [mez] |se∙hkanεw|, |se∙hkatam| `he hates him, it'    B.1962, 16.65, 342; M.L.239.
Miami |⌠ängilanähita| `I abhor him;, |⌠ängilanälindamani| `I abhor it'; |⌠iinkilaweeh-| TA `dislike, be hated by, be hateful to', |⌠iinkilaweelintam-| TI `dislike it, hate it'    D.-V.317; B&C.119a.]

\et Massachusett final here is perhaps *-naw, *n- `to see', as B.1962, 16.127, p.354, including e.g. |nεhko∙senawε∙w| `he is angry at him', and other verbs denoting psychological orientation towards sb/sth; Illinois and Miami cognates however indicate that there must be another possible source of |-naw-|. G.1981, 41, 85: PA *⌠i∙nkinamwa, without comment.

\lx sekousq
\va sekousquâ
\ve for

    \xe I am a widow
    \so 2 Sam.14.5

    \se |sekousquau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, i-stem
    \ge `to be a widow'
    \xv ..., kusseh, na mo nupp∞ wutch sohh∞wunon, wunnukquttegheonoh okásoh, kah noh sekousquau,...
    \xe ..., behold, there was a dead man carried out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow:...
    \so Lk.7.12

    As a verb, imperat. 2d sing. |...: Sekousquaish ut wekit k∞sh,...| `..., Remain a widow at thy father's house,...'     Gen.38.11√

\dv |asuhkau| (`she comes after') or |sequnau| (`she is left') and |squâ|, `a left woman, a relict'.

\lx senunum
\va senum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 148
    \nt +
\ps TI1b, manual final
\dv |sen-| `pressed, squeezed' + |-un-|
\ge `to press, wring out sth'
\so Gen.40.11; Lev.1.15
    \xv ..., kah nussénuminash ∞tattamwaitchuwut Pharoh,...
    \xe ..., and [I] pressed them into Pharaoh's cup,...
    \so Gen.40.11
    \ng 1->0p-pro objective
    \xv ..., kah wusqueheonk pish senumun ut yôáe Altatut.
    \xe ...; and the blood thereof shall be wrung out at the side of the altar:
    \so Lev.1.15
    \ng X->0

    \se senunumauau
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to wring sth out to sb'
    \so Ps.79.10
    \xv ...: kah nippe numwohteau sénumauoneau naghok.
    \xe ...: and waters of a full cup are wrung out to them.
    \so Ps.79.10; (M) |numwohtae nippeash senumauoneau|

[Algonquian [alg] |SIN-| `exprimé, qu'on fait sortir en pressant ce dans quoi il est contenu', |Sinatikwe| `traire'    Cq.369ab.

\lx sepe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 148
\ps Adv, PreN, PreV
\ge `it spreads out, extends'; hence `it is long, a long time'
\so Josh. 6.5; Mt.23.14
    \xv ..., kah sepepomantamwog,...
    \xe ..., and [were] well stricken in age:...
    \so Gen.18.11
    \ng initial or preverb
    \nt +
    `a good while'    Gen.46.29
    \xv Nussontimom sepe mat peyauou
    \xe My lord delayeth his coming;
    \so Mt.24.48
    \nt +
    \xv sepe mahche
    \xe long after
    \so Josh.23.1
\cf qunni
\cf sesekeu
(Cf. Greek spá-ein `to draw forth'; spízein, spend-ein (speid-ein) `to pour out a liquid'; Goth. and Ang.-Sax, spinnan, spannan.)

\lx sephausu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 148
\ps v.i. / AI(+O)
\ge `he sacrifices, offers sacrifice', +`to offer sb/sth (up)'
    pl. |-uog|    Hos.4.13
    (|Seephausu.| `It is offered, {or} sacrificed'    C.67/202)
    |Seephausinneat|, |sephausuaen.| `To sacrifice, a priest'
    \nt +
    \xv Sephausittinneat.
    \xe To be sacrificed
    \so C.72/207
    \xv ..., & wussephausinuh, wutche chikohtae sephausuonk...
    \xe ..., and offered him up for a burnt offering...'    Gen.22.13  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah naut sephaush chikóhsue sephausuonk...
    \xe ...; and offer him there for a burnt offering...
    \so Gen.22.2
    \ng 2->3 imperative

    \se sephausuonk
    \ps Vbl.n. / NA or NI
    \ge `a sacrificing, an offering'
    \so Ezra 9.4; Ps.118.27
    pl. |sephausuongash|
    \xv Kah pish nushau nomposhimwe lamboh, ut ayeuonganit ne adt nushont matcheseongane sephausuongoh, kah chikkohtae sephausuongoh,...
    \xe And he shall slay the lamb in the place where he shall kill the sin offering and the burnt offering,...'    Lev.14.13  { NA, 3
    \so }
    \nt +

    \se sephausuaen
    \ps N.agent. / NA
    \ge `one who offers, a priest'
    \so Lev.1.9
    \xv ..., kah noh mo wussephausuaénumoh quanunkquappit GOD.
    \xe ..., and he was the Priest of the most high God.
    \so Gen.14.18
    \ng 3 possessor obviative
    \nt +

    \se |sephausuwae|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge "burnt offering", "holy [things]", for expected "sacrificial"
    \so Gen.22.6
    \xv sephausuwae wuttuhqunash
    \xe the wood of the burnt offering
    \so Gen.22.6
    \xv sephausuwae teanteaquassinish
    \xe holy things
    \so 1 Cor.9.13

    \se |sephausueinnu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, predicative
    \ge `to be a priest'
    \so Heb.7.3
    \xv ...: qut, tatúppehheau wunnamônat GOD, nagwutteae sephausueinnu∞
    \xe ...; but made like unto the Son of God,; abideth a priest continually.
    \so Heb.7.3

    \se sephaueueneú∞onk
    \ps N.collect.
    \ge `priests collectively, the priesthood'
    \so 1 Pet.2.5

\lx sepohtaeu
\va sepohteau
\ve for  ?
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 148
\ps v.i. / AI
    drv |sep-| `extended' + ?|ohk(e)-| `earth' + ?|-á-| AI; this final would yield the palatalization, but it is not clear to me how the velar variant would arise. (|Ohteau| `to be somewhere' itself is ruled out as an II verb.)
    \nt +
\ge `he is, or continues, long (in a place?)'
    \xv Onk Paule nâ ut sepáhteau,...
    \xe And Paul after this tarried there yet a good while,...
    \so Acts 18.18
    \nt +
    \xv Kodtantunnáhettit noh wuttin sepóhkon, matta ∞namptaúoh.
    \xe When they desired him to tarry longer time with them, he consented not;
    \so Acts 18.20
    \ng stem in (palatalized) |-(h)k|? or distinct stem?
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh sepohtadt
    \ng suppositive |noh sepohtadt| `when he had been there a long time'    Gen.26.8√; (E0&E1) |sepohteadt|
    \xv Wessentamwaenin sepohteadt,...
    \xe While the bridegroom tarried,...
    \so Mt.25.5
    \nt +

    \se sepohtóe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `(long) continuing'
    \so Jer.3. 23

    Participial |sepahtauun| `long continuing, "durable"'    Prov.8.18

\lx sepsumau
\va seepsumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 148
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative
\twn |sepshitteo| TI2
\ge `to lay sb'
\dv |sep-| `extend' + |-sum-| TA `to lay sb' (B.1962, 16.46, pp.338-339)
\so Ps.88.6, Mt.15.30, Mk.15.47,16.6, Lk.16.20,23.55, Jn.11.34,19.42(M)
    \xv Kussepsumeh quanónogok pasohtheonk:...
    \xe Thou hast laid me in the lowest pit,...
    \so Ps.88.6; (M) |Kussepsumip|
    \xv ..., Uttuh kussepsumonaous?...
    \xe ..., Where have ye laid him?...
    \so Jn.11.34(M)

    \xv ...: naum∞k ayeúonk toh seepsumómukup.
    \xe ...: behold the place where they laid him.
    \so Mk.16.6

    \se sepsum∞
    \ps AI, middle reflexive
    \ge `to lie' (as corpse), `to lie down'
    \so following derivatives

    \se sepsumwahhau
    \ps TA, causative final
    \ge `to make sb to lie down'
    \so Ps.23.2(E&M)
    \xv Nusseeps[u]mwahik ashkoskuhkontu...
    \xe He maketh me to lie down in green pastures;...
    \so Ps.23.2; (M) |Nusseepsumwahik|

    \se !|sepsum∞mau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, consociative final
    \ge `to lie with sb'
    \so Gen.47.30
    \xv Qut n∞weeche sepsum∞m n∞shog,...
    \xe But I will lie with my fathers,...
    \so Gen.47.30
    \ng 1->3(p) absolute

\et Final: B.57, 104/461; A.413; H. p.246 *-h⌠im `place' (better: `lay'?). Presumably a connective vowel has been syncopated; on the middle reflexive, B.1962, 15.120, 297 and 16.46, 338-339.


\lx sépu
\va séip
\va seep
\va seip
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 148
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a river'
\so Dan.8.3,7; Gen.2.10,14
    pl. |-uash|    Ezek.47.9
\dv Literally, `it extends, stretches out, is long', a continuing stream. See |sepe|. The inseparable generic name for river used in all compound words was |-tuk| (q.v.), from |tukk∞|, fluctuat, undat.
    \xv ut sepuut
    \xe by the river
    \xv nashaue sepuwehtu
    \xe in the midst of rivers
    \so Ezek.29.3

    \xv sepupoq
    \xe a river of water
    \so Ps.119.136; Rev.22.1

    \se sepuese
    \va sepuwus
    \ps Dimin. / NI
    pl. |-ésash| `brooks'    Job 20.18
    \xv sepuwus
    \xe creek
    \so Acts 27.39
    \ng NB. English English sense, an inlet (of river estuary or sea).
    \nt +

    \se |sepu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to be a river'
    \so Is.30.25; Ps.46.4(M)
    \xv Seipoooo,...
    \xe There is a river,...
    \so Ps.46.4(M) { 0 indicative }; (E) |Na seip,...|
    \xv Kah nishnoh ut kussohkôi, kah qunuhkqui wadchuut na pish sepu∞,...
    \xe And there shall be upon every high mountain, and upon every high hill,  rivers ...
    \so Is.30.25
    \ng 0 indicative

[Narragansett [xnt] |séip|    R.W.; |sepe|, |sebe|    Stiles; dimin. |sepoêse| `a little river'; |sepoêmese| `a little rivulet'    R.W.88.
Old Alg. |sipim| `a river' (|sibikinan| `to pour out')    Lah.
Western Abenaki [abe] |síp8, ar| `rivière'    R.523a.
Cree |séepee|, pl. +|a@|.
Chip. |sëbë|, |séepee|, pl. +|wun|.
Delaware [del] |si po|    Zeisb.
    Algonquian [alg] |SIPI| `rivière, fleuve'    Cq.370b-371a.]
    \nt +

\et H.3001 *si∙piwi NI `river'


\lx sequan
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 149
\ps II
\ge `(it is) summer'
\so Ps.74.17; Mt.24.32
\nt rather, `early summer'
    (|séquan| `spring'    C. and R.W.)
\cf népun

    \se sequáne
    \ps Adv. and adj.
    \ge `of summer, in summer'
    \so Dan.2.35; Prov.26.1
\nt The radical perhaps signifies `dry'; cf. Abn. |síg8ân|, with |sikkaañs8| `le ruisseau est tari'. In the Catechismo Algonchino, p.22 (qu.28), |sâkwaninik| (`in the spring') is translated `diffluente arborum humore', Fr. `quand la sève coule'. But there is no `arbor' in the synthesis. It means probably `when water runs' (i.e. `when it thaws'?).

[Quiripi [qyp] |sequoks| `in summer'    Pier.28.
Western Abenaki [abe] |síg8ân| `le printemps'.
Cree |sékwun| `it is spring'.
Chip. |sëgwun| `spring'.
Delaware [del] |si quon| `spring'    Zeisb.]


\lx sequanamáuquock
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 149
\ps n.pl. / NA
\ge `bream'
\so R.W.
\dv [|sequane-âmaug|, pl. +|quog| `early-summer fish']
\nt The same species as |mishcùp-paûog|. "Of this fish there is abundance which the natives dry in the sun and smoke." Probably the species now known as `scuppaug' and `porgy' (Pagrus argyrops, Cuy.).


\lx sequnau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 149
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he remains behind, is left'
    (|nen webe nussequinit| `I remain alone, am left'    1 K.18.22)

    \nt MN: noh sequnut
    \ng suppositive |noh sequnut| , |-it| `he who is left'
    pl. |nag sequnutcheg| `the remnant that are left'    1K.14.10; 2 K.19.4
    (= |ashqunutcheg|    Neh.1.3)

    \se sequnneau
    \ps Inan. / II
    \ge `it remains, is left'

    \nt MN: ne sequnuk
    \ng suppositive |ne sequnuk| , |asqunuk|, |ashqunuk| `that which remains, the remainder, the remnant'    Lev.2.3; 14.17; 19.6

    \se ashqshunk
    \ps N.coll.(?) / 0 conjunct to (unrelated) II verb
    \ge `what (things) remain'
    pl. +|ish|    Lev.27.18
\cf asuhkaue
\ge (it comes) after
\cf nussequnneat
\ge to remain alone

[Western Abenaki [abe] |sk8âñik pem8ssé| `he last comes', `il vient des derniers'; |nen8ss8ka8añ| `je le suis, sequor'.
Narragansett [xnt] |segaûo| `he is a widower [a relict], is left'    R.W.138.
    Algonquian [alg] |CIK-| `racine qui renferme l'idée de vide, vide, viduité,...'    Cq.88a.]
    \nt +

\et H.2989-2995 *si∙kw- `empty, pour out, spill', H.3088-3090a *⌠i∙kw- `empty', with a merger of roots.


\lx sequnittuonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 149
\ps pass. vbl.n.
\ge `that which has been left by another, a remnant'
\so Ezra 9.8


\lx sequnau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 149
    \nt +
\ps TA, manual final
\twn |sequnnum|, TI1b
\ge `to empty sb'
\so 2 Chr.24.11
    \xv ..., peyaog, kah sequnâog chestoh, kah wunnunnumunaoash,...
    \xe ... [they] came and emptied the chest, and took it [the money],...'    2 Chr.24.11  { 3p->3
    \so absolute }


\lx sequnnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 149
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Forms from the merger of etymologically distinct sources are combined here, as if polysemous. The amount of data currently available is small. Note that H.2994-5 and H.3088-9 cannot in fact be differentiated on the basis of the data provided, but the former provide the only evidence that Hewson provides for a sense "empty" of PA *si∙k(w)-.
\ps TI1b, manual final
\twn |sequnau|, TA
\ge `to empty sth; to leave sth [as a remainder]'
\so Gen.42.35; Lev.19.10; Deut.28.62; Ruth 2.16; Is.24.3; Lk.21.6
    \xv ..., kesukodtash pish peyaum∞ash, ne matta pish sequnnum∞un pasuk qussuk petwohtáut,...
    \xe ..., the days will come, in the which there shall not be left one stone upon another,...
    \so Lk.21.6
    \ng X->0 negative indicative[!]
    \xv ..., nish pish kussequnnumunash wutche matcheku, kah wutche pen∞wot,...
    \xe ...; thou shalt leave them for the poor and stranger:...
    \so Lev.19.10
    \ng 2->0p objective
    \xv Ohke pish papuhquanne sequnnumun, kah papuhquanne matchehteauun:...
    \xe The land shall be utterly emptied, and utterly spoiled:...
    \so Is.24.3
    \ng X->0 indicative

    \xv Onk n nih sequnnumohettit wunn∞taóash,...
    \xe And it came to pass as they emptied their sacks,...
    \so Gen.42.35
    \ng 3p->0(p) conjunct

    \xv Kah unnantamwe penuhteógk nô nequttenutchanash wutche noh, kah nish sequnnumok ...
    \xe And let fall some of the handfuls of purpose for her, and leave them,...
    \so Ruth 2.16
    \ng 2p->0 imperative

[Cree |Së'koonäo| `He empties him (as a kettle)', |Se'konum| {sic} `He empties it'    Frs.451b.
Delaware [del] |shíikwu@num| `take all of s.t. out (of something)', O'M.294a.]

\ve for

\ps v.t.an. / TA (TI+O), dative final, to |sequnnum|
\ge `he leaves a remainder to (him)'
    negat. |matta sequnnumauwo∞og| `they leave not a remainder to (him)'    2 Sam.14.7

    (|asquttahwuteheg|    1 K.9.21)

\lx sesékq
\va seségk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 149
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a venomous serpent, "adder"'
\so Gen.49.17; Prov.23.32
    \xv Maumachish ogque m∞h∞wom∞ ask∞kut, kah unutchohk∞h∞wau sissequaut.
    \xe At the last it biteth like a serpent, and stingeth like an adder.
    \so Prov.23.32
    \nt +
    `viper'    Acts 28.3
    pl. |-quáog|
\nt Perhaps this name was applied by the Indians only to the rattlesnake, and is onomatopoetic. Cf.
    \xv sesék∞
    \xe he peeps
    \so (as a bird)    Is.10.14
    |sausauag| (suppos.) `when it "tinkles"'    1 Cor.13.1
and cf. |ask∞k| `snake'; |quequssu| `he "hisses"'.
(Cf. Greek sízei; Tonga, sisi; Polish, hszyk, to hiss.)

\lx sheep
\va sheps-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 150
    \nt +
\nt Remark: inflected forms normally built to the extended stem; uninflected |sheeps| rare (Acts, Ex. in current corpus). Inflected and derived forms are commonly to a stem in final |-s|--it is worth noting that OED (16th-19th C.) and EDD attest plurals in "-s", and also forms with the short vowel, as  <ship>.
\ps NA
\ge `sheep'
\nt G&B.706; note the remark on loan words from English in |sh-|.
    \xv shepsoh nomposhimwoh
    \xe the ram
    \so Gen.22.13
    \ng obviative

    \se shepwussemes
    \va shepsemes
    \nt +
    \ps NA, (double) diminutive
    \ge `lamb'
    \so Gen.21.28
    \xv shepwussémesog
    \xe lambs
    \xv ..., qut uttiyeuoh shepsemes,...
    \xe ...: but where is the lamb...?
    \so Gen.22.7
    \nt +

    \se shepsehtu
    \ps ?collective NI or second locative in |-ëht^eü| (G&B.497-498)
    \ge `flock' (of sheep)
    \so Gen.21.28
    \xv ... nesáusuk tahsuoh squoshimwoh shepwussémesog wutch shepsehtu
    \xe ..., seven ewe lambs of the flock...
    \so Gen.21.28

    \se shepse
    \ps PreN
    \ge "of a sheep"
    \so Gen.22.13
    \xv shepse nomposhim
    \xe a ram
    \so Gen.22.13

\se shehteâen
\ps n.agent. / NA
\ge `a murderer'

\lx shwosuk tahshe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 150
\ps num.
\ge `eight'
\so El.Gr.14

    pl. inan. |shwosuk tahshinash|
    an. |shwosuk tahsuog|    Gen.8.23  { proximate plural }

    \xe ...: these eight Milcah did bear to Nahor, Abraham's brother.
    \so Gen.22.22
    \ng obviative
    \nt +

    \xv shwosuk tahshishquanogkod
    \xe eight cubits
    \so (measures of length)    Ezek.40.9
    \xv noh shwosuk audtahshikquinapit
    \xe he that is eight days old
    \so Gen.17.12

    \ge `eighteen'

    \se shwosuk tahshinchag

    \ge `eighty'
    pl.an. |shwosuk tahshinkodtog|
    inan. |shwosuk tahshinkodtash|
    \xv Kah Abram shwósuk tahshinchag kodtumwohkomup kah nequtta,...
    \xe And Abram was fourscore and six years old,...
    \so Gen.16.16
    \nt +

\nt Otherwise written |nishwosuk|, from |n'shwe| (|nishwe|) `three', the third finger of the second hand, or 5+3.

[Narragansett [xnt] |shwósuck| `eight'; |piuck-nabna shwôsuck| `eighteen'; |swoasuck ta shincheck| `eighty'    R.W.41,42.

\lx -si
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 150
    \nt +
\nt Remark: The entry requires further work. The examples from the entry |ussinát|, T.175b, have been removed to here, and a few further relevant examples have been added, together with references to the status of the form.
\ps AI(+O), suppletive to |(un)n∞wau|
\nt Remark: The distribution of forms is characterized at G&B.514 as follows: "The variant |-si| of the stem `say (thus)' is used in the prefixed forms, and |unuwá-| in non-prefixed forms (with one possible exception; v. AI preterite)." See also G.1981, 42, 94. The form |(un)n∞wau| has the same initial as |unnau|/|wuttinuh| TA+O `to say sth to sb', but with the indefinite object final (cf. G.1990, 6, (128) on the Fox cognate, the parallel form appearing here with the levelling of palatalization typical of an Eastern language), and is hence of AI(+O) type. The initial |un-| `thus' is cataphoric to the object, which denotes the content of what is said.
\ge `to say (sth)'. Note that forms in |usse-| (and changed variants) are distinct in origin and belong with |unnau|.
\nt G&B.514,706,722, s.v. (nus)sim, unnoowau.
    \xv ..., ishkont woh kussim n∞weenaìkeh Abram,
    \xe ..., lest thou shouldest say, I have made Abram rich:
    \so Gen.14.24
    \ng 2->0 indicative
    \xv Nean∞waop negonne, ne wonk yeuyeu nussin,...
    \xe As we said before, so say I now again,...
    \so Gal.1.9
    \ng 1->adv subordinative; nice contrast with 1p->adv changed conjunct to |unn∞wau|
    \xv ...: na nupp∞ongane matcheseonk, matta nusseuh ne pish uppeantamwontamun.
    \xe ... . There is a sin unto death: I do not say that he shall pray for it.
    \so 1 Jn.5.16
    \ng 1->0 negative indicative

\nt Remark: The following are the relevant examples removed from the entry |ussinát|, T.175b. They have not yet been checked.
    \xv wussinat nashpe wussisset∞nut
    \xe to pronounce with his lips
    \so Lev.5.4
    \xv nussin
    \xe I say
    \so Gal.1.9
    \xv kussin
    \xe thou sayest
    \so Mt.27.11; Mk.15.2
    \xv wussin
    \xe he saith
    \so Zech.1.3

    \xv nussim
    \xe if I say, when I say
    \so Prov.30.9; Ps.78.2
    \xv kussim
    \xe when thou sayest
    \so Job 22.13; Is.47.8
    \xv woh nussim
    \xe shall I say?
    \so Heb.11.32
    \xv toh kussimw∞
    \xe what say ye?
    \so Mt.16.15
    \xv nussip
    \xe I said
    \so Eccl.3.17,18; 7.23
    (|nissim| `I say'
    \xv teagua kissim
    \xe what you say?
    \xv nissimun
    \xe we say
    \xv nissimunnönup
    \xe we said
    \so C.207
    |toh kuttinn∞wam| or |kussin| `what do you say?'    C.217)
