\lx siogkod
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 150
\ps II
\ge `it is hard, difficult'; +`grievous, hardly; a mystery'
\so Prov.13.15; Mk.10.24
\dv [for |siogkoht| (|siúckat| R.W.), from |siogkohteau|, v.i. inan. subj.]
    \xv ...Wunnamuhkut kuttinnonnumw∞, siogkod weenaieetu uppetukon kesukque ass∞tam∞onganit.
    \xe ..., Verily I say unto you, That a rich man shall hardly enter into the kingdom of heaven.
    \so Mt.19.23
    \nt +
    \xv ..., k∞sukkuhhumauwunnaóut nish nán, matta siogkodtinno wutche nen, qut wutche kenaau wanne nukquodtinno.
    \xe .... To write the same things to you, to me indeed is not grievous, but for you it is safe.
    \so Phil.3.1
    \nt +
    \xv Noh papaume monatash an∞wáog, kah siogkodtash ket∞hkontamunat,...
    \xe Of whom we have many things to say, and hard to be uttered,...
    \so Heb.5.11
    \nt +

    \xv Matta pish kutogquontamôuh saógok chippunnúe moncheaheadt,...
    \xe It shall not seem hard unto thee, when thou sendest him away free from thee;...
    \so Deut.15.18
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu missi siogok, qut nuppapam∞wam Christ kah moeuwehkomonk.
    \xe This is a great mystery: but I speak concerning Christ and the church.
    \so Eph.5.32
    \nt +

    \se |siogkod|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, deverbal noun to II
    \ge `mystery'
    \so Col.2.2,4.3; 1 Tim.3.9,16; Rev.10.7,17.5,7
    \xv Kah matta chann∞wáe, missi wussiogkodt∞m manittóoonk:...
    \xe And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness:...
    \so 1 Tim.3.16
    \xv Kah ut wuskodtukqut, wesuonk wussukwhosu. SIOGKOK, BABYLON MOHSAG, OKASOOOH NANWUNOODSQUAAUSUENUOG, KAH OHQUANUMU(G)QUOKISH OHKEIT. ...? kuttinun wussiogkodt∞m mittamwossis, kah puppinashim noh naiyeumont,...
    \xe And upon her forehead was a name written, MYSTERY, BABYLON THE GREAT, THE MOTHER OF HARLOTS AND ABOMINATIONS OF THE EARTH. ... ? I will tell thee the mystery of the woman, and of the beast that carrieth her,...
    \so Rev.17.5-7

\lx -sip

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 150
\ps final
\ge in compound words signifies `to drink'
\nt It represents a primary verb which is not found separately in Eliot. Possibly related to |saupáe| (q.v.).     Cf.
    |nontsippam|
    |missippan|
    |kogkeissippam|
    |ohksippam|    C.
    |tâpsippam|, etc.
To this corresponds the inseparable |-upp∞|, |-ipp∞| `to eat', which is found in a similar group of compounds.

\lx siswá-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 150
    \nt +
\ps AI(?), middle reflexive? [root basically transitive?]
\ge `to be scattered'
\so Gen.11.4
    \xv ...: kah ayimontuh wesuonk ishkont kussiswaómun yeu ut wame ohket.
    \xe ...; and let us make us a name, lest we be scattered abroad upon the face of the whole earth.
    \so Gen.11.4
    \ng 12 indicative

    \se |siss∞num|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1b
    \ge `to plaster sth'
    \nt Remark: The sense is probably `to spread sth (on sth)', with the possibility of the locative as an alternative direct object; see etymology.
    \so Lev.14.42,43; Deut.27.2,4
    \xv ...: kah pish nemunum onkatuk puppissi, kah pish wussiss∞numun wetuómut.
    \xe ...; and he shall take other mortar, and shall plaster the house.
    \so Lev.14.42
    \ng apparently: "plaster it on the house"
    \xv ..., pish kukquenohtoh mogke qussukquanash, kah pish kussiss∞numun suss∞neg.
    \xe ..., that thou shalt set thee up great stones, and plaster them with plaster:
    \so Deut.27.2
    \ng |-neg| E1&2

    \xv ..., mahche amaunuk qussukquanash, kah mahche chekhog weetu, kah mahche suss∞unuk.
    \xe ..., after that he hath taken away the stones, and after he hath scraped the house, and after it is plastered;
    \so Lev.14.43
    \ng E1&2

    \se siss∞nósu
    \ps II
    \dv "derivational passive", G&B.581, no. 17
    \ge `to be plastered'
    \so Lev.14.48

    \xv ..., mahche wetu suss∞nósik,...
    \xe ..., after the house was plastered:...
    \so Lev.14.48

[Western Abenaki [abe] |sisse`rré| `Éparpillé'    R.224/448a.
Algonquian [alg] |SASWE-, voy. SISWE- [no such entry exists]|, senses: `arroser, disperser/dispergere, éparpiller'    Cq.364ab.
Cree |SISO-, SISWE-|, senses: `disperser, frotter, peindre, répandre, semer'; |siso-, siswa-|, senses: `scatter, spread about; embrocation, to paint'    Lac.D.597a-598a; Frs.458b-459a.
Menominee [mez] |seqsi/o-|, senses: `scatter, splash about'    M.L.236.
M.-P. |sisse (sissiy-)| PV `in all directions, scattering', |sissessu| II `it spreads out; it disperses; it scatters'    LeS.164a.
WAbn. |sisa-|, senses: `scatter, spread, strew'    D.1.451-452.]

\et H.2972-2975 *se?sw- `to scatter, sprinkle'

\lx sogkodtunk

\so Trumbull 151
\ps n. / NI
\ge `milk' (of animals, though wrongly used by Eliot in his earlier translations for milk from the female breast. See *|meninnunk|); +pl. `breasts, paps, teats'
\so Gen.18.8; Prov.30.33; Joel 3.18
    (|Sogködunk, weyaus.| `Milk, flesh', |Senunumu@nat sogködonk.| `To milk'    C.12/162,66/201.)
    pl. |-ngash| `teats, dugs {not AV}]'    Ezek.23.8,21; Lk.23.29
    \xv ..., kah nag puppukîttahhamwog uppenompae sogkodtongash,...
    \xe ..., and they bruised the breasts of her virginity,...
    \so Ezek.23.8
    \xv ...: Egyptiansog papuhkehtahammohettit kussogkodtungash, wutche k∞skenue sogkodtungash.
    \xe ..., in bruising thy teats by the Egyptians for the paps of thy youth.
    \so Ezek.23.21

\dv A verbal (suppos.) from |sohkodtinnum| `he draws forth, that which is drawn out'.

\lx soh-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 151
\ps as a prefix / initial
\ge signifies `forth from, out from, movement from the place where or in which the action of the verb begins'. It is opposed to |pe|, |pâ|, signifying `approach to, or toward':
    \xv peyau
    \xe he comes to
    \xv sohham
    \xe he goes forth, out from
(Cf. Sansk. su, se movere, effundêre, and its derivatives; or sî, saî. Lat. se-, sine, separative particle.)


\lx sohham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 151
\ps v.i. / AI (?TI1a-O)
\ge `he goes forth', +`to come, go out (of)'
\so Mt.13.3; Is.42.13
\dv [|soh-∞m|]
    \xv Onk Kain sohham wutch anaquabit Jehovah,...
    \xe And Cain went out from the presence of the Lord,...
    \so Gen.4.16
    \nt +
    (|suhham|    Mass.Ps.)
    inan. part. |sohhamun| `gone forth'

    \nt MN: sohhog
    \ng suppositive |sohhog| `if or when he goes forth'
    \xv Wame keteahogkóunog ..., neh waj sohhamunutcheh wohpéit,..
    \xe All the souls ..., which came out of his loins,...'    Gen.46.26  { _3
    \so _ participle }
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |sohhash| `go forth' { 2 imperative }    Gen.8.16
    \xv ..., nishnoh pasuk sohhaj,...
    \xe ..., Cause every man to go out from me. ...
    \so Gen.45.1
    \ng 3 imperative
    \nt +

    \se sohham∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a going forth, departure'
    \so Heb.11.22

    \se sohhamun
    \ps NI, deverbal ("agent") noun
    \ge `out-going'
    \so Ps.65.8
    \xv mohmohtompanaeu, sohhamunah, kah wunnonkwaeu
    \xe the out-goings of the morning and evening'    Ps.65.8  { printer
    \so s error in (E1) for |-ash| }

\lx sohh∞hkauau

    \xv ..., yeush wutohtimoneash anueyeu∞ash onk nen, uttoh woh nuttinne sohh∞kauónat?
    \xe ..., yeush wutohtimoneash anueyeu∞ash onk nen, uttoh woh nuttinne sohh∞kauónat?

\lx sohh∞wunau
\va -N-
\ve , see conjunct, imperative forms.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 151
\ps v.t. an / TA, applicative final
\ge `he puts, brings, or thrusts (him) out'; +`to bring sb forth, out of, carry sb out of (somewhere), make sb go forth'
    \so Ps.78.50
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish kussohh∞wuneh wutch Egypt. ...
    \xe ..., and thou shalt carry me out of Egypt,...
    \so Gen.47.30
    \ng 2->1 indicative, without mutation
    \nt +
    \xv Qut nehenwonche ummissimmimmúmoh ogque wussohh∞wunuh shepsoh...
    \xe But made his own people to go forth like sheep,...'    Ps.78.50; (M) |wuttogque sohhoowunnopah|  { 3->3
    \so (preterite) objective }
    \nt +
    \xv Newaj Pilate yeu n∞tog, sohh∞wunau Jesusoh,...
    \xe When Pilate therefore heard that saying, he brought Jesus forth,...
    \so [i.e. "removed him from the room"]    Jn.19.13
    \nt +
    infin. |-wunónat| `to bring (them) out'    Is.42.7; Ex.3.8

    \xv Nen Jehovah kum Manitt∞m mahche sohh∞wunnun wutch ohkit Egypt,...
    \xe I am the Lord thy God, which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt,...
    \so Ex.20.2
    \ng _1_->2 participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., toh wutch sohh∞wusseog wutch Egypt, nuppunnanónut ut touohkomuk? ...
    \xe ..., Wherefore have ye brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? ...
    \so Num.21.5
    \ng 2p->1p
    \nt +
    \xv Neit ahque ishkont k∞wanânum Jehovah noh sohh∞wunukqueókup wutch ohkeit Egypt,...
    \xe Then beware lest thou forget the Lord, which brought thee forth out of the land of Egypt,...
    \so Deut.6.12
    \ng 3->2p[!]
    \nt +

    \xv Sohh∞wus nish noh oaas uppomantamun weetappemukquéaneg,...
    \xe Bring forth with thee every living thing that {is} with thee,...
    \so Gen.8.17
    \ng 2->3(p) imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah sohh∞wusseh yeu wutch wetuómut.
    \xe ..., and bring me out of this house:
    \so Gen.40.14
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., sohh∞wus wosketompaog neg peyoónukqueaneg ...
    \xe ..., Bring forth the men that are come to thee,...
    \so Josh.2.3
    \ng 2->3 imperative
    \nt +

    \se sohh∞wuttau
    \va sohwuttau
    \nt +
    \ps inan. subj. { sic! } / TI2 causative
    \ge `he brings or puts (it) out', +`to bring sth forth'
    \xv Kah Melchisadek ketass∞t Salem, sohwuttau petukqunnunk kah wine,...
    \xe And Melchizedek King of Salem brought forth bread and wine:...
    \so Gen.14.18
    \ng 3->0 absolute

    \cf sohwunum

    \se !|sohh∞wuttauau|, |sohwhuttauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem, perhaps a directive final
    \ge `to bring sb sth forth, bring sb out to sb'
    \so Gen.19.5; Deut.8.15

    \xv ..., noh sohh∞wuttunkquean nippe wutch soggohtunkanompskut,
    \xe ...; who brought thee forth water out of the rock of flint;
    \so Deut.8.15
    \ng _3_->2+0

    \xv ...? sohwhutaiinnean, onk woh n∞wahéonnônog.
    \xe ..., bring them out to us, that we may know them.
    \so Gen.19.5
    \ng 2->1p+3

\lx sohk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 151
    \nt +
\nt Remark: also occurs in palatalized form |soht-|, and in a complex with preceding aphetic |un-|
\ps initial, ?relative root
\ge "so far, long"
\so entries |sohkunkquodt|, |sohteau|, |sohtipomantam|

[Delaware [del] |sahk-| `so long'; |sahk-| in (spatial and temporal) derivatives such as |sahkáalakat| II `be a certain depth, be a certain length (of holes)', |sahkáhkeew| AI `be gone a certain length of time', |sahkéew| II `be a certain length', |sahkii-| PV `a certain length (of time, measurement)'    G.1979.194; O'M.273b-274b,512ab.]


\lx sohkau
\va sonqhuau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 151
    \nt Remark: two distinct initials/stems
    \nt +
\twn |sohkom| TI1
\ps v.i. / 1. AI?; 2. TA causative?
\ge `he overcomes, prevails, has the mastery'
    \xv ... kah nussongqueh ...
    \xe ..., and I have prevailed:...
    \so Gen.30.8√
    \ng 1->3, ?to !|sonkqueheau|
    \xv Kah nish noh wosketomp ummenuhkenat wutch sonkqhuónat, iohgunnuppo ut wame teanteaquassinut:...
    \xe And every man that striveth for the mastery is temperate in all things. ...
    \so 1 Cor.9.25
    \ng indefinite object
    \nt +
    \xv kummicheme sohkau
    \xe thou prevailest forever
    \so Job 14.20
    \ng to |sohkauau|


    \nt MN: noh sohkog
    \ng suppositive |noh sohkog| `he who overcomes, has the mastery'    Rev.3.21
    \ng to |sohkom| TI1, v.i.

    \se sohkauau
    \va sonqhuauau
    \nt Remark: two distinct initials/stems; currently (5.2004) no evidence for the latter (which cannot exist if the |-u-| represents an indefinite object).
    \nt +
    \ps With an.obj. / TA, |-aw-| stem
    \ge `he prevails over, has the mastery of (him)', +`to subdue sb'
    \xv Kah nag matta wussohkauoh,...
    \xe And when he saw that he prevailed not against him,...'    Gen.32.25  { 3->3
    \so negative }
    \nt +
    \xv Gad chippan∞onk pish sohkunk, kah nagum pish sohkauau maumachish.
    \xe Gad, a troop shall overcome him: but he shall overcome at the last.
    \so Gen.49.19
    \ng 0->3-pro absolute, 3->? absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Pish sohkauau missinninnuh kenaan ut agwu;...
    \xe He shall subdue the people under us,...
    \so Ps.47.3; (M): |sohkauau|
    \nt +
    \xv Neit Agrippa unnau Pauloh, Nahén kussohkah Christian[n]owunneat.
    \xe Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.
    \so Acts 26.28
    \ng 2->1 to |-aw-| stem
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh sohkauont
    \ng suppositive |noh sohkauont| `he who overcomes, subdues'    Ps.144.2; 1 John 5.5; Lk.11.22; (M): |sohkouont|
    pl. |nag sohkauoncheg|    Rev.15.2

[Cree |sàkoo-hayoo| `he overcomes, subdues him'; |sàkoo-tow| `he overcomes it'    Howse 91,165.
Chip. |nin gé sháhgooje-óg| `I have overcome them'    Jones in ibid.]

\et H.3023-3029 *⌠a∙kw- `beat, defeat, overcome', etc., (to |sonqhu-|!).


\lx sohke
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
    \nt +
\ps PreV, to initial |sohk-|
\ge "so far, long"
\nt G&B.702 |sahke| `as long as'
\so Gen.3.14,17,8.21; Josh.1.5,4.14; Deut.6.2,12.19,22.29,30.20; Mt.9.15; Rom.7.2; 1 Pet.3.6; 2 Pet.1.13
    \xv ..., kenaau wuttaunoh nesohke wunneseóg, kah matta wabeseóg asuh chepshau∞óg.
    \xe ...: whose daughters ye are, as long as ye do well, and are not afraid with any amazement.
    \so 1 Pet.3.6


\lx sohkenum
\va sok-
\va s∞k-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he pours forth, pours out'
    \xv -- nippe
    \xe he pours out water
    \so Num.24.7
    (|s∞kunum|    Mass.Ps.)

    \nt MN: noh sohkenuk
    \ng suppositive |noh sohkenuk| `he who pours'    2 K.3.11
    \xv Onk Pharaoh muskquanumoh neswe utannohsueneumoh; piahquttume sokenumunutche wuttattamôonk, kah ...
    \xe And Pharaoh was wroth against two of his officers, against the chief of the butlers, and ...
    \so Gen.40.2
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. and pl. |sohkinush|, |-∞k| `pour out'
\dv |sohkeu| `it pours', with the formative |'num|, denoting action of the hand.

    \se !|sokenumwohtau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, causative to |sohkenum|
    \ge `to cause sth to be poured'
    \so Num.28.7 (Ex.30.9?)
    \xv ..., ut wunnetupanatamwe ayeuonganit, pish kussokenumwohtoh wuttattamoe sephausuonk manuhkag wine en Jehovah ut.
    \xe ...: in the holy place shalt thou cause the strong wine to be poured unto the Lord for a drink offering.
    \so Num.28.7

\lx sohkenumau
\va sohkenumauau
\ve r.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.t. an. and inan. / TA+O
\ge `he pours (it) out to (him)'
\so Job 16.20


\lx sohkeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it pours forth, emits'
\nt Ths primary verb is not perhaps used by Eliot; but he has its pass. (inan. sub].)]

    \se sokem∞
    \ps II
    \ge `it is poured out'
    \so 1 K.13.5; +Gen.8.2
    \xv Kah wonk Altar sokshau, kah pukquee sokem∞ wutch Altarut,...
    \xe The altar also was rent, and the ashes poured out from the altar,...
    \so 1 K.13.5
    \ng 0 indicative
    \nt +

\nt From its base, |sohk|, |sook|, are formed:
    |sohkinnum|, t.inan. `he pours (by hand)'
    \xv sokanon
    \xe water pours, it rains
    |suhkou|, |suhquontam| `he spits, urinates (expels water)', etc.
\cf sonkin
\ge it springs up (as a plant), it grows
(Cf. Sansk, su, effundere; sic, emittere, inspergere, humectare, irrigare, perfundere; shîkára, pluvia tenuis; Old Germ. seihjan, mingere; seich, urina.)
\cf sokanon

[Western Abenaki [abe] |s8gherañn| `il pleut'.]

\et *so∙k- `pour, soak' Siebert 1975, item 159; H.3002; cf. |sokananon|, infr.


\lx sohkom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.t. inan. / TI1a
\twn |sohkau| TA
\ge `he overcomes, prevails over (it)'; +`to take sth' (i.e. "capture"); `to cause, make sth to cease'
    \xv -- otan
    \xe he took the city
    \so Judg.9.45
    \xv Sohkom ayeuhteaongash...
    \xe He maketh wars to cease...
    \so Ps.45.9
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche howan wadchegit Godut, sohkom muttaok, kah yeu sohkausuonk, ne sohkomuk muttaok, k∞namptam∞onganun.
    \xe For whatsoever is born of God overcometh the world: and this is the victory that overcometh the world, even our faith.
    \so 1 Jn.5.4√

    \xv Kah pish n nih, sohkomog otan, pish kutchikosumw∞, otán,...
    \xe And it shall be, when ye have taken the city, that ye shall set the city on fire:...
    \so Josh.8.8
    \nt +
    \xv ...: noh sohkog, nuttinnunnumau meechinat wutch pomantamóe mehtugq ...
    \xe ...; To him that overcometh will I give to eat of the tree of life,...
    \so Rev.2.7
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah ohke sohkomuk ut anaquabeôg,...
    \xe ..., and the land shall be subdued before you;...
    \so Num.32.29
    \ng X->0
    \nt +

    imperat. |Ahque sohkongqush mâchuk, qut sohkash machuk nashpe wanégik.| `Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good.'    Rom.12.21

\cf sohkau

\lx sohkomunau
\va sohkom∞unau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
    \nt +
\ps TA, stem in |-N-|; TA+O? (food as direct object)
\ge `to feed sb, to cherish sb (OED s.v., 2)'; `to feed sb with sth'
\so Gen.48.15, Ps.78.72, 1 Cor.3.2, Rev.7.17, Jn.21.15-17, 1 Thess.2.7, Rev.12.14
    \xv ..., kah kussohkom∞nuk Manna,...
    \xe ..., and [he] fed thee with manna,...
    \so Deut.8.3
    \xv Onk wussohkomonuh nean sampwag wuttah:...
    \xe So he fed them according to the ingegrity of his heart:...
    \so Ps.78.72; (M): |wussohkommoonopah|
    \xv Nag kussohkomm∞noog missuppegunne petukqunnunk:...
    \xe Thou feedest them with the bread of tears:...
    \so Ps.80.5; (M): |kussohkommoonoog|
    \xv Kussohkom∞nunnumw∞ sogkodtunk, kah matta meechum,...
    \xe I have fed you with milk, and not with meat:...
    \so 1 Cor.3.2
    \ng 1->2p

    \xv ..., noh Manit sohkomónukqueomp, nó utt∞che nen, yeu pajeh kesukok.
    \xe ..., the God which fed me all my life long unto this day,
    \so Gen.48.15
    \ng _3_->1 preterite participle
    \xv Noh sohkom∞nukquean Manna ut touohkomuk,...
    \xe Who fed thee in the wilderness with manna,...
    \so Deut.8.16
    \ng _3_->2 participle
    \xv ..., neyane n∞chachuus sohkomm∞unont wunnechansoh
    \xe ..., even as a nurse cherisheth her children.'    1 Thess.2.7  { 3->3
    \so +_adv_ participle }

    \xv ..., wuttinuh, Sohkomm∞s nutshepsemesog.
    \xe ... He saith unto him, Feed my lambs.
    \so Jn.21.15(+16,17); (M): |sohkomm∞s|
    \ng 2->3(p) imperative


\lx sohkôsu
\va sohkausu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.i. (an.act.) / AI
\ge `he gains the mastery, prevails, conquers'; +`to prosper'
\so Rev.6.2
    `is victorious, is prevailing'
    \xv ..., newutche onatuh Sontim kummenuhkes ut Godut kah missinnunnútu, kah kussóhkus.
    \xe ...: for as a prince hast thou power with God and with men, and hast prevailed.
    \so Gen.32.28
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh menadcheanit, onk wóh k∞ne sohkaus uttoh aoan.
    \xe ..., that thou mayest prosper whithersoever thou goest.
    \so Josh.1.7
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh sohkausit
    \ng suppositive |noh sohkausit| `he who is victorious'    Rev.3.5
    \xv Noh sohkog, n∞wet∞wom n∞wetappemukqunat ut nutappuonganit, neyane wonk nen sohkosséomp, kah n∞weetappem n∞sh ut wutappuonganit.
    \xe To him that overcometh will I grant to sit with me in my throne, even as I also overcame, and am set down with my Father in his throne.
    \so Rev.3.21
    \nt +

    \se sohkôsuonk
    \va -kausuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `mastery, victory'

    \se *!|sohkosuwonishau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, in |-(wo)nish-|
    \ge `to get sb the victory'
    \so Ps.98.1(M)
    \xv ...: wuttunnuhkou kah wunnetupantamwe wuhpit mahche sohkosuwonishuk.
    \xe ...: his right hand and his holy arm hath gotten him the victory.
    \so Ps.98.1(M)


\lx sohkunkquodt
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
    \nt Remark: derivative of (relative root?) initial |sohk-|
    \nt +
\ps as n. / II
\ge `height'
\ps adv.
\ge `in height' (measure of altitude or elevation)
    |ne sohkunk|, |ne sohkunkquok| `its height'    Rev.21.16; Ex.25.23
\dv [i.e. suppos. `that to which it has grown, gone up to'?]. From |sonkin| (?).
\nt A great number of forms, of several roots, are employed by Eliot to express `height', `in height', and `high'. Besides those noted are:
    \xv ne sohkonkog
    \xe the height of it
    \so 1 K.6.2
    |ne ashpohtag|    Ex.37.1
    |ne ashpúhtag|    Ex.37.10
    |ne ohshpohtag|    Ex.37.25
    |ne kôdtunkquog| (of a small object)    Ex.30.2
    |ne an∞hque spohtag|, |ne an∞hque sp∞nogkog|, |ne an∞hque spongok| `its height from bottom to top'    Gen.6.15; Ex.25.10; 27.1

[Western Abenaki [abe] |spigañn8| `la cabane est haute'; |ni éspigañnik| `voilà de combien (elle est haute)'.]

\lx soh∞hkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
    \nt +
\ps TA, corporal final

\ge `to drive sb out'
\so Gen.3.24; Ex.10.11
    \xv ...; kah wussoh∞hkauoh wutch Pharaoh anaquabit

    \so objective }


\lx sohq
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\cf s∞kq


\lx sohqu-
\va s∞hqu-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge "broken, destroyed, in bits, in pieces, rent, smashed, torn" (no implication of the form or nature of the material of the entity affected, just a loss of former integrity?); more often for E. "smash" than for "break"?
\so following entries
\nt Remark: No perfect matches have been found as yet, but the following sample seems hard to dismiss out of hand. Some effects on the vowels may be related to the likely prevalence of reduplication, and perhaps of unrecognized uses of vowel change, quite apart from other expressive processes such as phonaesthesia. (Cf. E. "smash") Whether the two forms of the initial in Western Abenaki can/must be accounted for in this way I do not know--"strengthening" of consonants is commonplace as an expressive feature, and pre-aspiration occurs in some forms of reduplication in Algonquian languages.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |Seg8skip8dé| `cela ë brisé dans le sac v. sur le traîne', |tâikaba`tâi séseg8stéhañ i8 péskameghé.| `Il se briseroit en mille pièce si on tiroit contre'    R.72/399b,394/506b.
Algonquian [alg] |CACAK-| `cette racine onomatopéique exprime [l'i]dée de mâcher, broyer, écraser, craquer', |Cacakwam| `écrase-le avec les dents, mâche-le'...    Cq.79ab.
Cree |sikuskawew| (v.a.) `il l'écrase avec ses pieds', |sikwatahwew| `il l'écrase, il le broie'; |sikonew| TA `S/he crushes them with her/his hands', |sikwahwew| TA `S/he crushes them'    Lac.D.592b-593b; Alb.E.189b.
Delaware [del] |shkwáham| TI1a `pound s.t., crush s.t., grind s.t. (using a tool or instrument)'...    O'M.298b-300a,290ab.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |nichag8iscan| `je casse, brise, ecrase avec le pied.'...    M.109/94a.
    Miami |⌠akki⌠⌠imaka| `I dash his brains out'    D.-V.314.
    \nt ?
Mi'kmaq [mic] |sekwiskina:l'k| TA `rip or tear up', |sekwiste:k| TA `pound or hack to bits'    DeB.78a.
Nask. |sikunaaw| TA, |sikunim| `she/he crushes it by hand'    McK&J.1.333a.
Ojibwe [oji] |Jajagoshkan, (nin)| `I crush it with my foot or body'    Bar.165a
Shawnee |ni⌠ekwama| `I mashed him with my teeth' (as when lice are caught), |ni⌠⌠ekwaa| `I chewed him to pieces'    D.-V.313.
WAbn. |zegweskada| AI `crack or break up with the teeth', |zegweskiwita| AI `explain, i.e. analyze-tell, taking-apart tell'; |zokwa| TI `break up, spoil', |zokwigo| AI `he is weak, fainting, coming apart'     D.1.521;529-530]

\et Basic form *⌠ekw-; S., no.62, 331, gives cognates, all but one glossed as `crush', the glosses of the Virginian forms probably being compatible with this, and assigns this meaning to the proto-form; perhaps it covers all types of loss of an original form or state of aggregation.


\lx sohqshanau
\va s∞kshanau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.t. an. / TA, ?applicative
\ge `he tears (him) in pieces (as a wild beast his prey), rends (him)'; +`devour'
    \xv Onk ∞wahteauun, kah n∞wau, Nunnaumon wuthogk∞onk, matche puppinashim umm∞whóuh, Joseph wunnamuhkut s∞kshanau.
    \xe And he knew it, and said, It is my son's coat; an evil beast hath devoured him; Joseph is without doubt rent in pieces.
    \so Gen.37.33
    \ng X->3
    \nt +
    \xv Ishkont sohkwushónau nukketeahogkonah, onatuh qunnônou sohqshadtunk,...
    \xe Lest he tear my soul like a lion, renting {it} in pieces, ...
    \so Ps.7.2√;  (M) |sohkwushonau|, |sohkshadtnnk| [sic]
    \xv ..., kehchemugquomp wabesit, ishkont Paul woh sohqshanâu, unnau wutayeuteomuh,...
    \xe ..., the chief captain, fearing lest Paul should have been pulled in pieces of them, commanded the soldiers to...
    \so Acts 23.10
    \nt +

    \xv ne wutche kummatwom∞ mattannit, onatuh mishont∞wae qunnonou, papomwushau natinneahwhau neh woh s∞kshanoncheh.
    \xe ...; because your adversary the devil, as a roaring lion, walketh about, seeking whom he may devour:
    \so 1 Pet.5.8
    \nt +

    \se sohqshadtau
    \ps with inan. obj. / TI2
    \ge `he teareth (it'
    |sokshadtoh|    Deut.33.20
    pass. inan. |-adtauun| `it is (violently) broken or torn in pieces'    Is.30.14

    \nt MN: sohqshadtunk
    \ng suppositive |sohqshadtunk| `when he tears, "rends it in pieces"'    Ps.7.2
    \ng v.s.

    \xv ..., ahque m∞sontupunk, asuh ahque s∞kqshadtau∞k kuthogk∞unóash,...
    \xe ..., Uncover not your heads, neither rend your clothes,...
    \so Lev.10.6
    \ng 2p->0(p)
    \nt +

\lx sohquhkauau
\va s∞quhk-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.t. / TA, corporal final
    \nt Remark: Perhaps the corporal final is used as indicating the loss of the structural integrity of a complete entity.
    \nt +
\twn |sohquhkom|, TI
\ge `he continues tearing or rending (him)'
\dv with the characteristic |-uhk| of continuing action.

    \xv S∞hquhkaúut, paudtauutch wutch wauwaonk, noh s∞hquhkauoi, pish matta wuttauadtuhkauoh.
    \xe If it be torn in pieces, then let him bring it for witness, and he shall not make good that which was torn.
    \so Ex.22.13
    \ng X->3; ?X->3+absentative participle (E1&2)
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nupp∞e muhhog, kah s∞hquhkausik, matta pish ummeech∞un,...
    \xe That which dieth of itself, or is torn {with beasts}, he shall not eat ...
    \so Lev.22.8
    \ng conjunct to II s-passive
    \nt +


\lx sohquhkom
\va s∞quhkom
\va s∞hq-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
    \nt +
\ps TI, |-hk-| stem
\twn |sohquhkauau|, TA
\ge `to burst, rend sth'
\so Gen.37.29; Mk.2.22; Lk.5.37
    \xv ..., kah s∞quhkom wuthogk∞onash
    \xe ..., and he rent his clothes.
    \so Gen.37.29
    \xv Kah matta howan ponam∞ wusku wine nukonishquadt, ishkont wusku wine s∞hquhkom wishquosh,...
    \xe And no man putteth new wine in old bottles; else the new wine doth burst the bottles,...
    \so Mk.2.22; sim. Lk.5.37

\nt Remark: The following example is currently puzzling, since it appears to contain what must be an AI+O stem to the present complex stem:
    \xv ..., kah nuss∞quohkonash ut anaquabeog.
    \xe ..., and [I] brake them before your eyes.
    \so Deut.9.17(E1&2)
    \ng 1->0p objective
    \nt +


\lx sohqui
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152

\ge `(it is) in small pieces, fine, in dust or powder'

    \nt MN: ne sohquag

    \se sohque
    \ps adv., adj.
    \xv sohque puppissi
    \xe small dust

\lx sohqunnum
\va sohquen-
\va sukqunnum
\va s∞quanum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 152
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge`he breaks (it) in pieces, he pulls (it) to pieces'; +`to rend sth'
\so Mk.6.41; Is.5.5; Jer.1.10; +Mt.26.26,27.40
    \xv Pish kussohquánumun, kah kussokanumun pummee,...
    \xe Thou shalt part it in pieces, and pour oil thereon:...
    \so Lev.2.6
    \nt +
    \xv Onk metsehettit Jesus nemunnum petukqunneg, kah peantamóe wunnanittamun, kah wuss∞quanumun, kah wuttinnumaun kodnetuhtaénuh,...
    \xe And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and brake it, and gave it to the disciples,...
    \so Mt.26.26
    \nt +

    \xv ... petukqunnunk, ..., kah sohqunuk wunn∞che meechin.
    \xe ... bread,..., and when he had broken it, he began to eat.
    \so Acts 27.35
    \nt +

    \xv ..., Ahque sohqunnummuttuh, qut tannahtaadtitteuh,...
    \xe ..., Let us not rend it, but cast lots for it,...
    \so Jn.19.24  { 1p->0 } (M) |sukqunumuttuh|
    \nt +

\dv |sohqui|, with transformative |-nnum|, denoting action performed by the hand.

\lx sohqussum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he cuts (it) small, makes it small by cutting'
    \xv sohqsumun
    \xe he cuts it in pieces
    \so 2 K.24.13

    \se sohqusswau
    \va sukqusswau
    \nt !
    \ps TA
    \ge `to cut sb in pieces'
    \xv Kah pish kussukqus nomposhim en wutchippiyeumut, kah pish kukkútshitoh wuttinnomhog, kah wuhkontash, onk nish pish móe kupponamunash s∞kqusausikis kah uppuhkuk.
    \xe And thou shalt cut the ram in pieces, and wash the inwards of him, and his legs, and put them unto his pieces, and unto his head.
    \so Ex.29.17
    \nt +
    \xv nussohqus
    \xe I cut (her) in pieces
    \so Judg.20.6
\dv |sohqui|, with formative |-sum|, denoting cutting, etc. (see Howse, Cree Gr.87).


\lx sohquttahham
\va sohquet-
\va sukquihtham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
\ps v.t. / TI1a, mechanical final
\ge `he breaks (it) in small pieces, pounds (it) or beats (it) small'
\dv The formative |tahhum|, according to Howse (Cree Gr. 86), "implies he beats or batters the object, after the manner of the root."
\nt Inan. pl. |sohquttahhamunash| `they (grains of corn, Is.28.28) are broken'; otherwise |s∞hq-|, |sukq-|
    \xv ...: nagum pish sukquihtham kuppuhkuk,...
    \xe ...; it shall bruise thy head,...
    \so Gen.3.15
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kittinumunkqunàout pahke olive pummee, sukquéhthamunat wutche wequanananteg,...
    \xe ..., that they bring thee pure oil olive beaten for the light,...
    \so Ex.27.20
    \nt +

    \se sohquttahháe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `pounded'
    pl. |sohquttahhash|, whence the adopted name "succotash".

    \se !|sukquttahhamauau|
    \nt ?+
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to bruise sb's sth'
    \so Gen.3.15
    \xv ..., kah pish kussukquttahhamau wogquan
    \xe ..., and thou shalt bruise his heel.
    \so Gen.3.15
    \ng 2->3+0 absolute (despite pronominal indirect object

\cf pohqunnum

[Cree |séekwa-tahúm| `he beats it into smaller pieces'.]


\lx sohquttahwhau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
    \nt +
\ps TA, mechanical final
\twn |sohquttahham|, TI1a
\ge `break, grind sth (with sth)'
\so Deut.9.21; Ps.2.9
    \xv Pish kussukquttahwhôog nashpe móohshogque anwohhou,...
    \xe Thou shalt break them with a rod of iron,...
    \so Ps.2.9; (M) |kussukquttahwhoog|
    \ng 2->3p objective


\lx sohqutteahháu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
\ps v.i. / AI, bahuvrhi
\ge `he is faint-hearted, cowardly'; +`for sb's heart to faint'
    \xv ..., monchitch kah qushkeitch en wekit, ishkont wematoh sokhqutteaoh, neane wuttah.
    \xe ...? let him go and return unto his house, lest his brethren's heart faint as well as his heart.
    \so Deut.20.8; (E1): |sohkqutteaoh|
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah newutche nag n∞tamwog matchissetonkquot, nag sohqutteaháog,...
    \xe ...; for they have heard evil tidings: they are faint-hearted;...
    \so Jer.49.23√

    \nt MN: ..., howan wabesit kah sohquteahont, monchitch kah qushkeitch en wekit,...
    \ng suppositive |..., howan wabesit kah sohquteahont, monchitch kah qushkeitch en wekit,...| `..., What man is there that is fearful and faint-hearted? let him go and return unto his house,...'    Deut.20.8√

    \se sohkutteahhaue
    \ps adj.
    \ge `fainthearted'
    \so C.

\cf sequttahwhau
\ge he remains

[Western Abenaki [abe] |sk8itéhé| `il a peur' (v.g. des tourments), `il craint le châtiment', etc.; v.i. |séghesi| `il a peur'; an. |séghes8| `il craint'.
Cree |sègissu| `he shrinks, he is afraid'; |sègehayoo| `he frighteneth him'; |sàkoo-tay-áyoo| `he is faint-hearted, cowardly'. (By this division of the word Howse marks a derivation from |`tay| (|m'tah|, El.) `heart' (?).)]


\lx sohsum∞u
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
    \nt +
\ps AI
\twn |sohsum∞m∞|, II
\ge `to be glorious, to shine'
\so Ex.15.11; Phil.2.15
    \xv ...? howan aununkquean? kussohsum ut wunneetupanatama∞ongit,...
    \xe ...? who is like thee, glorious in holiness,...
    \so Ex.15.11
    \ng 2 indicative

    \xv ... wutohtimoin, kenugke nag sohsum∞k neyane wequanantegash muttaohket.
    \xe ... nation, among whom ye shine as lights in the world;
    \so Phil.2.15
    \ng 2p->_adv_ participle


\lx sohsúm∞m∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
\ps v.pass. inan. / II
\twn !|sohsum∞u|, AI
\ge `it shines (forth), emits light, is bright'
    \xv wequai sohsum∞m∞ pohkenahtu
    \xe the light shineth in darkness
    \so Jn.1.5
    (cf. |wohsum∞munneat| `to shine')

    \se sohsumwáe
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `shining (forth)'
    \xv sohsumwae wequai
    \xe a shining light
    \so Jn.5.35√  (M) |wossum∞e|
    \xv sohsumóe ketass∞t
    \xe the king of glory
    \so Ps.24.7,9√  (M) |sohsumoe|

    \se sohsúmmóonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a shining-forth' (used by Eliot for `glory')
    \xv wuttouohkomukque sohsúmóonk
    \xe his-forest glory, "the glory of his forest"
    \so Is.10.18

\nt (In preparing a list of words selected from Eliot's Bible Mr Duponceau, misled perhaps by the order of words in this verse (Is.10.18), inserted |sohsúmóonk| for `forest', and on his authority it appears with that meaning among the `Select Words from Eliot's Translation', incorporated into the index of Mr Pickering's edition of Eliot's Grammar.)

\lx sohteau
\va soh-ohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
    \dv |sohk-| "so far, long", + |-á-| II, with palatalization
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it extends, is extended, is long' (relatively or by measure), +"to be so far, so long".
\nt G&B. 702 |sahchauk|
\nt Found only perhaps in the suppos. |ne sahteag| `the extending of it, its length':
    \xv Kah netatuppe wonk nanumáyeu wutch nesahteag Tapistry ohhogk∞tik nequt pasuk∞e sahteau ...
    \xe And likewise for the north side in length there shall be hangings of an hundred cubits long,...
    \so Ex.27.11
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle; 0 indicative
    \nt +

    \xv ne sahteag kah ne koskag kah ne sohkunk
    \xe the length and breadth and height of it
    \so Rev.21.16
    \xv aétaeu nesahteag
    \xe on the two ends' (i.e. `on both sides of the length of it
    \so )    Ex.25.19
    \xv ...; mat ne sahgteag kukkitteaonk qut wanegkuk,...
    \xe ...; not the length of thy life but the goodness of it...
    \so C.113/236
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle
    \nt +

    \se sohteaonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `length, measure of length'
    \so Eph.3.18


\lx sohtikquohham
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\ge `to point out sth' i.e. "to mark out sth (with points)" [c.f OED s.v. "point", v.1, 2(?), BWB 261; Geneva: "marke out".]
\so Num.34.7,8,10
    \xv Wutch wadchuut Hor, pish kussohtikquohhamumw∞ paudshaat Hamath, kah sohwushait sussippói pish wehque Zedad.
    \xe From mount Hor, ye shall point out {your border} vnto the entrance of Hamath: and the goings foorth of the border shall be to Zedad.
    \so Num.34.8


\lx sohtipomantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
    \nt +
\nt Remark: cf. unpalatalized variant |nisohkuppomantam|, Job 27.6
\ps TI1a(-O)
\dv |sohk-| `extent' + |-i-| + |pomantam| `to live'
\ge `to attain to (an age), (to do sth) all the days of sb'
\so Gen.47.9; Josh.24.31

    \xv ..., kah asquam peyaumun∞ash sahtippomantogkup n∞shik,...
    \xe ..., and [they] have not attained unto the days of the years of my fathers...
    \so Gen.47.9
    \ng 3(p)->_0(p)_ preterite participle
    \xv Kah Israel woussumau Jehovah nisahtepomantog Joshua, kah nisahtepomantamwéhetiit Eldersog neg anue pomantam∞moncheg Joshuahoh,...
    \xe And Israel served the LORD all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders that overlived Joshua,...
    \so Josh.24.31
    \ng 3->_0(p)_ participle; 3p->_0(p)_ participle

\lx sohwehtauau

\lx sohwhohkoNau
\va sohwohkoNau
\va sohwhokoNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
    \nt +
\ps TA, corporal + applicative finals (cf. B.1962, 16.122, 352, 16.125, 353)
\ge `to cast sb out, draw sb out, put sb out, send sb forth, thrust sb out'
\so Gen.3.23; Ex.11.1; Ps.18.42; Mt.8.12,10.1,21.39; Mk.3.23,9.18,12.8; Lk.20.12; Jn.12.42; Acts 7.39,58,21.30; 3 Jn.10; Rev.12.9
    \xv Newutche Jehovah Manit, wussohwohkonuh wutch tanohketeaonganit Eden,...
    \xe Therefore the LORD God sent him forth from the garden of Eden,...'    Gen.3.23; (E0): |wussohwohkònuh| "put him out"  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv ..., sohwhokonittue kussohwhohkónukou na wutch moáe.
    \xe ..., he shall surely thrust you out hence altogether.
    \so Ex.11.1
    \ng 3->2p; cognate preverb to theme 2a?
    \xv ..., ishkont sohwôhkonog wutch synagogsut.
    \xe ..., lest they should be put out of the synagogue:
    \so Jn.12.42
    \xv ..., onk tohqunaog Pauloh, kah wussohwhókonaoh wutch Temple,...
    \xe ...: and they took Paul, and drew him out of the temple,...
    \so Acts 21.30

    \xv ..., sohwohkauseog, ontunkonnan herde pigsehtu.
    \xe ..., If thou cast us out, suffer us to go away into the herd of swine.
    \so Mt.8.31
    \ng 2->1p conjunct

\lx sokanon
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 153
\ps II
\ge `[it pours], it rains'
\so Mt.7.25
    \xv Onk woh kittinnumauúnnumw∞ sokanon kutohkeyeuwóut, uttoh adt tapeneunkquok, negonne sokanon, kah maumachish sokanunk,...
    \xe That I will give you the rain of your land in his due season, the first rain and the latter rain,...
    \so Deut.11.14
    \nt +
    (|sookunnon|    Mass.Ps., Ps.105.32
    \xv [s]∞kenonni
    \xe it rains
    \xv Sun s∞ke@non.
    \xe Does it rain,
    \so C.71/206√

    \nt MN: sokanonk
    \ng suppositive |sokanonk| , |sokenunk| `when it rains'    Deut.32.2
    \xv nashpe pahkontaut mahche sokanonk
    \xe by clear-shining after rain
    \so 2 Sam.23.4
    \cf sokanon n∞tau
    \cf sokanum n∞tau
    \ge it rained fire'    Lk.17.29, with |sokanum n∞tau|
    \nt `it rained fire'    Lk.17.29, with  `he rained (poured out) fire'    Gen.19.24

    \se |sokanon|
    \nt +
    \ps  as n. / NI
    \ge `rain'
    \xv ..., kah sokanon wutch kesukquiug mat sokémun∞.
    \xe ..., and the rain from heaven was restrained.
    \so Gen.8.2
    \nt +

    \se |sokanum|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1b, ?manual final
    \ge "to pour sth out" (container, or contained)
    \so Rev.16.1
    \xv Neit Jehovah sokanum ut Sodom & ut Gomorrah brimstone kah n∞tau...
    \xe Then the LORD rained upon Sodom & upon Gomorrah, brimstone and fire,...
    \so Gen.19.24
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    |Angelsog sokanumwog wisquash| "The angels pour out the vials"    Rev.16.1(Hd) (Ii 3r/p.253a)
    \xv S∞kenumu@nat, s∞konitt\üonk.
    \xe To pour, to be poured out
    \so C.69/204

    \xv ..., monchek, kah sókanum∞k musquanittamwe ∞wishkquash GOD ohkeit.
    \xe ..., Go your ways, and pour out the vials of the wrath of God upon the earth.
    \so Rev.16.1

    \se !|sokanumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to pour sb sth, sth on sb; to rain sth upon sb'
    \so Gen.40.5,13; Ps.11.6; Mt.26.7; Mk.14.3; Rom.13.4(?)
    \xv Matcheetowoh pish wussokanummaoh ahpehhanoh, n∞htau kah brimstone nashquttin:...
    \xe Upon the wicked he shall rain snares, fire and brimstone, and +an horrible tempest:...', `+{Or, a burning tempest.}
    \so Ps.11.6; (M): |wussokanummauoh|
    \xv ..., kah pohquanau boxuh, kah wussokanumauon uppuhkukqut.
    \xe ...; and she brake the box and poured it [the ointment] on his head.'    Mk.14.3  { 3->3
    \so +0-pro }

    \xv ..., kah pish kupponam ∞tattamwaìtch Pharoh wunnutcheganit neyanayéop, wonk sokanumauádt ∞tattamóouk.
    \xe ...; and thou shalt deliver Pharaoh's cup into his hand, after the former manner when thou wast his butler.
    \so Gen.40.13
    \ng 2->3+0

    \se sokanónteau
    \va sokanonteau
    \nt +
    \ps Caus. / AI, denominal, creative final, i.e. |sokanon-uhk-á-|
    \ge `he causes it to rain'
    \so Ex.9.23; +Gen.7.4
    \xv ..., nussokanonteam ut ohkeit yauonchagkodtash kesukodtash kah yauonchagodtash nukonash:...
    \xe ..., and I will cause it to rain upon the earth forty days and forty nights;...
    \so Gen.7.4
    \nt +

    \se !|sokanonteam∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, regular derivative to |sokantonteau|
    \ge `to give rain'
    \so Jas.5.18
    \xv ..., kah kesukquash sokanonteam∞ash,...
    \xe ..., and the heaven gave rain,...
    \so Jas.5.18
    \ng 0p indicative

    \se |sokanonukauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, dative final to |sokanonteau|
    \ge `to give rain to sb, send rain on sb'
    \dv (Compare |wesuonganuhkauau|, T+.191a, for various difficulties.) Analysis of this verb as containing the "by foot or body movement" final (B.1962, 16.122, p.352, rather than 16.181, 364) may initially appear to meet the requirements of the meaning better, but the form is to be regarded as an ornative, denominal, with the basic stem seen in |sokanonteau| (above) under the (denominal) analysis suggested. (The roles of the arguments of the verb are more obscure in Deut.28.12.)
    \so Deut.28.12; Mt.5.45
    \xv Jehovah pish k∞wóshwunumunk ∞ne nompakou, kesukquash kussokanonukkongqunat ut kutohkit, ut utt∞cheyeu∞ut;...
    \xe The LORD shall open unto thee his good treasure, the heaven to give the rain unto thy land in his season,...
    \so Deut.28.12
    \ng 3->2 or 0(p)->2?
    \xv ...: kah wussokanonukauau sampwe usseaeneuh, & matta sampwe usseaeneuh.
    \xe ..., and [he] sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust.
    \so Mt.5.45
    \ng Why |wu-|?

    \se |sokanonukontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a, applicative to |sokanonteau| (cf. B.1962, 16.69, 342-3 for a similar example)
    \ge `to cause [it to] rain upon sth'
    \so Gen.2.5; Deut.28.12,24
    \xv Jehovah pish kutohkeim sokanonukontam sohquag kah puppissi,...
    \xe The LORD shall make the rain of thy land powder and dust:...
    \so Deut.28.24

    \xv ...: newutche Jehovah Manit asq sokenonukontam∞g ohke,...
    \xe ...: for the LORD God had not caused it to rain upon the earth,...'    Gen.2.5; (E0): "not yet-had caused rain upon-
    \so { 3->0 negative conjunct }

    \xv Onnöh quat.
    \xe Raining
    \so C.95/222.)

\dv |sohk|, |sohkeu| `it pours', with a formative denoting rain or water falling, as distinguished from |-pog|, `water at rest'. This formative or generic is |-'non|, |-nnon|, or |-nn∞n| (Abn. |-'rañn|; Del. |-'lan|). It is found, besides in |sokanon|, in
    |mogkinnon| (|mogke-non|), `it rains excessively'
    \xv mishinnon
    \xe it rains much
    \xv nishkenon
    \xe it mists or drizzles
    |ahqunnon| (|ahque-non|) `the rain ceases, it holds up'
    and in its suppos. form in |onnohquat| `raining' (`when it rains')    C.
    \xv =ánaquat
    \xe rain
    \so R.W.
\cf sohkenum

(Cf. Sansk. unná, madidus (und, madidum esse); ra\n, ire. Goth. rann, currere, fluere.)


[Narragansett [xnt] |sókenun|, |ánaquat| `rain'; |sókenitch| `when it rains'; |mishúnnan| `a great rain'    R.W.81,82.
Western Abenaki [abe] |s8gherañn| `Il pleut, pluit' (probably from |soh-kenum| `to pour forth'; but cf. Sansk. s'îkára, pluvia tennis, from sic' and s'îk, irrigare, humectare; s'c'ut, effundere; s'c'yut, stillare, fluere); |kisrañn| `il a pleû'; |è`k8rañn| (|ahqunnon|, El.) `il cesse, &c.'.    R.400/508b√.
Chip. |kimiwan|, |gimiwan| `it rains' (|siginan| `he pours it out, spills it'    Bar.).
Cree |kímmewun| `it rains' (cf. Old Alg. |kimiouan|, Lah.); |séke-stum| `he spills it'; |sêeke-puthu| `it spills'; |séekoo-num| `he empties it'; |séekee-num| `he pours it'.
Delaware [del] |sókelan| `it rains'; |k'schilan| `it rains hard'; +|sóokùlaan| `rain, be raining'; |sookalúndam| `sprinkle s.t. with water'; |sookalúndaweew| `sprinkle s.o. with water, spray s.o. with water'    Zeisb.; O'M.284a.
    K. |-enaan| VI `rain'    V.150.
    \nt +
EAbn. |Soogoran| `Raine'    Rosier 1625.
WAbn. |zogelôn| `it rains'; |awalôn| `fine rain, drizzle; |b(e)melôn| `it rains somewhere in the distance'; |gizelôn| `it is after the rain, it has finished raining', etc.    D.1.528;48;94;211.]

\et H.3002 *so∙k- `pour, soak'; S. item 159, p.369; G.1981, 28, 67: PEA *sök@rän `rain'; S. item 244, 405: complex final *-ela∙nwi II `rain' (corresponding final already posited by Trumbull s.v. |ahqunnon|, and for Kickapoo by Voorhis; also G.1990.461: Munsee final |-@la∙n| II `rain'). This clarifies the spelling of the Massachusett form and the otherwise unexpected nasal vowel in the conjunct forms.

\lx sonk∞hquaeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 154
    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv |sonk-| `out(wards)' + |-uhqu-| `eye' + |-á-| AI, bahuvrihi

\so Gen.26.8
    \xv ..: Abimelek ketass∞t Philistims sonk∞hquaeu wutch kenogkenéganit kah naau, ...
    \xe ... Abimelech king of the Philistines looked out at a window, and saw, ...
    \so Gen.26.8
    \ng perhaps means "stuck his head out"?


\lx sonksq
\va sonkusq
\va sunkisq
\va sonksq
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 154
\ps n. / NA
\ge `queen, mistress, a woman who rules'
\so 2 Chr.9.1; Esth.1.9,11,15; Nah.3.4
    \xv ..., kah wahteunk ∞wompequauonk ummishananumau wussonksquaumoh, nehenwonche wuskesukqut.
    \xe ...: and when she saw that she had conceived, her mistress was despised in her eyes.
    \so Gen.16.4
    \nt +
    |kehchissunkisq| = |kehchi-sunkisq| `chief mistress, great queen'    Esth.1.12
    \xv ..., kah sonksqaog matta ohguhs∞og.
    \xe ..., and of the chief women not a few.
    \so Acts 17.4
    \nt +
\dv [|sonqhuau| or |sohkau|, and |squa|; cf. *|sâchim|.]
\nt Often written |sunksquaw| and |sunck squa|. { This may well be the derived AI verb? }

    \se !|sonksquau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, predicative
    \ge `to be a queen'
    \so Rev.18.7
    \xv ...Nutap sonksquainneat, kah matta nu[s]sekousquaouh, kah matta pish nunnaum∞ neuanatam∞onk.
    \xe ..., I sit a queen, and am no widow, and shall see no sorrow.
    \so Rev.18.7

\lx sontim

    \xv ..., pish nabonees∞∞woh sontimoh wunnaumonaeu,...

    \xv nussontimom
    \xe My Lord
    \so Gen.18.3,12
    \nt +

    `a prince'    Cant.7.1
    \xv nussontimom ketas∞t
    \xe my lord the king
    \so 2 Sam.13.33
    pl. |-móog|

    \se !|sontimos|
    \nt +
    \ps NA, diminutive
    \ge `prince
    \so Gen.12.15; 1 Cor.2.8

    \so Gen.12.15
    \ng 3p possessor obviative, possessive theme
    \xv Uttiyeu matta sontimósog yeu muttaohket wahteauhetteg,...
    \xe Which none of the princes of this world knew:...
    \so 1 Cor.2.8
    \ng plural

    \se sontim∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `sovereignty'
    \so C.

    \se !|sontimáeu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, denominal predicate
    \ge `to be a lord, master'; AI+O(?), refl. `to make os a prince'
    \so Gen.27.29,42.30; Num.16.13; Jn.3.10
    \nt G&B 514, 708: |sôt^yimôwi-|
    \xv ...: qut wonk kussontimáeu kuhhog ânue onk nenawun;
    \xe ..., except thou make thyself altogether a prince over us?
    \so Num.16.13
    \xv ..., Ken kussontimau ut Israel, & sun yeush mat k∞wahteau∞unash?
    \xe ..., Art thou a master of Israel, and knowest not these things?
    \so Jn.3.10; (M): |kussontimau|

    \xv Wosketomp noh Sontimáit ná ut ohkìt
    \xe The man, who is the lord of the land,...
    \so Gen.42.30
    \ng 3 participle

    \xv ..., ken Sôntimaish ut kematut,...
    \xe ...: be lord over thy brethren,...
    \so Gen.27.29
    \ng 2 imperative

    \se sontimohteau
    \va sontimohk-
    \nt !
    \ps AI+O, creative final
    \ge `to make (sb) a prince'
    \so Ps.45.16(M)

    \xv ..., nag woh Sontimmohteaan ut mamusse ohkeut.
    \xe ..., whom thou mayest make princes in all the earth.
    \so Ps.45.16(M)
    \ng 2->_3_ participle

    \se !|sontimohkoNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative final
    \ge `to make sb a prince'
    \so Ps.45.16
    \xv ..., yeug woh kussontimóhkonog wame ohkeit.
    \xe ..., whom thou mayest make princes in all the earth.
    \so Ps.45.16
    \ng 2->3p objective
    \xv Wussontimmohkonuppah ut wekut,...
    \xe He made him lord of his house,...'    Ps.105.21(M)  { 3->3
    \so preterite objective }

\lx sowanshin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 154
\ps II
\ge `the wind blows from the south'

    |sowansh| (suppos. `when it blows'), as n. `the south wind'    Job 37.17; Cant.4.16

[Narragansett [xnt] |touwúttin| `the south wind'; |sowwánishen| `the southwest wind blows'. "This is the pleasingest, warmest wind in the climate, most desired by the Indians, making fair weather ordinarily; and therefore they have a tradition that to the southwest, which they call |sowwainiù|, the gods chiefly dwell; and hither the souls of all their great and good men and women go."    R.W.83.
Quiripi [qyp] |perôu kon saúunáiôuk| `in another country to the southward'    Pier.28.]

\lx Squántam
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 155
    "They acknowledge a God who they call |Squantam|, but worship him they do not." -- Josselyn's Voy.
    "The good god they call |Tantum|, and their evil god, whom they fear will do them hurt, they call |Squantum|." Higginson's N.E. Plantation.
\dv The name is clearly the contracted form of |musquantam| `he is angry'.
    "If it be but an ordinary accident, a fall, etc., they will say "|... musquántum manit| `God is angry'." -- R.W.109.

[Narragansett [xnt] |squáshim|    R.W.
Delaware [del] |ochquéchum|    Zeisb.
In the Abnaki, Rasles says "the small animals (including the otter, the marten, etc.) were distinguished by |nañbékik8| `male', and |sk8ékik8| `female'; the moose and both species of deer by |aiañbe| `male'; |hé`rar| `female', and the lynx, `lion' [panther], hare, and some others by |nañbéssem| `male', and |sk8éssem| [= |squáshim|, El.] `female'." { selected and translated from R.22-23/382b-383b } ]

\et A.399, H.805 *eΘkwe∙?Θemwa `bitch' (*eΘkwe∙- `woman' + -a?Θem- `dog'), with the de-stem form of the final, as B., no. 181, 60, 105/462, *wa∙pa?Θemwa (retranscribed) `white dog'

\lx squehteam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 155
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\twn ?|(u)squehtahwhau| TA
\ge `to leave sth; to be left, remain' (i.e. as remainder of a previous larger quantity)
\so Ex.23.18, Ruth 2.14
    \xv ..., kah noh meetseup kah wamep∞p, kah squehteam.
    \xe ..., and she did eat, and was sufficed, and left.
    \so Ruth 2.14

    \xv ..., asuh wees, ut nussephamónteaonganit, squehteam∞hkon en mohtompog.
    \xe ...; neither shall the fat of my sacrifice remain until the morning.
    \so Ex.23.18

\nt Remark: The evidence is slight at present. The initial is also seen in TI conjunct form in |mussegon asquehtahhukupash| `which the hail had left' Ex.10.15, and II |ne asqueiyeu∞g musquanittuonk| (|asqueyeuuk| (M)) `the remainder of wrath' Ps.76.10, confirming the initial vowel.

\et Compare H.684-687 with *e⌠kwi(∙)- `left, set apart', Cq.115b-116a ICKO- `de reste'. T.'s conflation of two verbs (in the previous entry) is surely incorrect.

\lx sugketam
\va ságket
\ve in part moved from T.144a  etc.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 156
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
    \ge `to piss (on sth)'
    \nt +
    \nt Probably only conjunct forms attested in the bible, in a formula.
    \nt +

    \xv ... matta wussequttahhamauuh pasuk∞, noh sagkeet ut kishkeneutunkanit,...
    \xe ...: he left him not one that pisseth against a wall,...
    \so 1 K.16.11
    \ng AI, to H.3067 *⌠ekiwa
    (|..., noh sáketog pummeneutunk.| `... that pisseth against the wall.')    1 Sam.25.34; 2 K.9.8

[Western Abenaki [abe] |neseghi| `mingo', ... substantivum |seg8di|, 3. |8seg8di|.    R.134/419b.]

\et H.3064-3068 *⌠ekitamwa TI `urinate'


\lx suhkou
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 156
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he spits'
\so Mk.7.33
    \xv ..., kah uppetauoh uppohchánutchegash wuhtaúogkut, kah suhkou, kah ummussunumauoh weenan.
    \xe ..., and [he] put his fingers into his ears, and he spit, and touched his tongue;
    \so Mk.7.33
    \nt +
    (|suhquinneat| `spitting'    C.; but it is in the form of the so-called infinitive, `to spit':
    \xv nuteesköuous
    \xe I spit
    \xv nissuke
    \xe I am mischievous, spiteful
    \so (?)    C.)
\nt The primary meaning appears to be `to eject, discharge liquid'; hence |noh ságket|, |noh ságketog| `qui mingit' { `who urinates'; but cf. Alg. |CIK,I| `pisser, uriner', Cq.88ab }.
\cf s∞hq

    \se suhkesu
    \ps V.adj. an.
    \ge `he is a spitter, he ejects water'
    (|súkkissu|, |-og|    C.
    |sickissu|, |-og| `long clams, "spitters"'    R.W.)

    \se !|suhquonau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative in |-ôN-|
    \ge `to spit upon sb'
    \so Lev.15.8

    \xv Kah noh sohwutchuanit suhquonont neh pahkesinitcheh, neit pish kutchessittau wuthogk∞unash,...
    \xe And if he that hath the issue spit upon him that is clean; then he shall wash his clothes,...
    \so Lev.15.8

    \se !|sissukquonau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA (to the preceding with some form of reduplication; c.f. Abn., inf.)
    \ge `to spit upon sb'
    \xv Kah nag pish ummomontauouh, kah wuttattogkomouh, kah pish wussisukquonouh kah pish wunnushouh,...
    \xe And they shall mock him, and shall scourge him, and shall spit upon him, and shall kill him:...
    \so Mk.10.34
    \xv Newutche pish ponau Gentilsut, kah pish aontukanau, kah onkapunanau, kah sissuhquoanau.
    \xe For he shall be delivered unto the Gentiles, and shall be mocked, and spitefully entreated, and spitted on:
    \so Lk.18.32

    \se |suhquontam|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a
    \ge `to spit on sth'
    \so Jn.9.6
    \xv Yeu an∞wadt, suhquoantam ohke,...
    \xe When he had thus spoken, he spat on the ground,...
    \so Jn.9.6

    \se !|suhkquontamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem, as "possessive dative"
    \ge `to spit in/on sb's sth'
    \so Deut.25.9
    \xv Neit wussuhquontamauouh wuskesuk,...
    \xe Then did they spit in his face,...
    \so Mt.26.67

    \xv ..., kah sahquoantamaúont wuskesukquash,...
    \xe ...; and when he had spit on his eyes,...
    \so Mk.8.23

[Western Abenaki [abe] |sëssek8| `crachat'; |sësseg8| `il crache'; |nesesek8| `salive'; |neseghi| `mingo'
Delaware [del] |n'sis suk| `spit'    Zeisb.
    Algonquian [alg] |SIK,o| `cracher', |O ki sikwanawan Jezosan| `ils ont craché sur Jésus'    Cq.368a.]
    \nt +

\et H.2968-2971 *sehkwiwa AI `spit', *sehkwa∙Θe∙wa TA *sehkwa∙tamwa TI `spit on'; S., item 200, p.388

\lx sukoshkodtassin
\va -sun
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 156
    \nt +
\ps AI, initial |suk-|, final |-sin-| AI `to fall, lie'
\ge `to fall on one's face; to couch'
\so Gen.17.3,17,49.9
    \xv Kah Abram sukoshkodtassin, kah GOD ukken∞nuh n∞wau,
    \xe And Abram fell on his face, and God talked with him, saying,
    \so Gen.17.3
    \ng 3 indicative
    \xv Judah qunnonou wunneechanoh, wutch wunnehtoonganit nunnaumon kukkuhkukquem, sukoshkodtaeu sukoshkodtassun onatuh qunnonou, kah onatuh keneungqussu qunnonou,...
    \xe Judah is a lion's whelp: from the prey, my son, thou art gone up: he stooped down, he couched as a lion, and as an old lion;...
    \so Gen.49.9
    \ng "couch", see OED s.v. 17: "To take or fall into a posture more or less approaching that of lying at rest. a. To lie down, crouch, cower, as a beast, in obedience, fear, etc."; 18: "To lie in ambush, to lurk."

\lx summágunum
\va sohm-
\va samogkin-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 156
\ps v.t. / TI1b, manual final
\ge `he stretches forth, holds out (his hand or something in or with his hand)'
\so Is.5.25; Gen.22.10; Ex.15.12
    \xv Kah Israel summagunum wuttinohkou kah upponamun Ephraim uppuhkukqut,...
    \xe And Israel stretched out his right hand, and laid it upon Ephraim's head,...
    \so Gen.48.14
    \nt +
    (|Nussummogkinnitchäem.| `I stretch out my hands'    C.78/211.)  { AI, bahuvrihi }

    \nt MN: ..., kah quogqueog, quenau summagunuk wunnutcheg,...
    \ng Suppositive |..., kah quogqueog, quenau summagunuk wunnutcheg,...| `..., and they ran as soon as he had stretched out his hand:...'    Josh.8.19√
    \ng 3->0 conjunct
    Pass. |..., kah yeu menutcheg ne samogkinumuk en wame wutohtimóneat.| `...; and this is the hand that is stretched out upon all the nations.'    Is.14.26√  { X->_0_ participle }

    \xv ..., summagunash qunnontug ne ohtag kenutcheganit,...
    \xe ..., Stretch out the spear that is in thy hand ...
    \so Josh.8.18
    \ng 2->0 imperative
    \nt +

    \se summagohteau
    \ps With inan. subj. (v.i.) / II
    \ge `(his hand) is held out'
    \so Is.14.27
    \xv ...? kah wunnutcheg summagohteau,...
    \xe ...? and his hand is stretched out,...
    \so Is.14.27
    \nt +

    \se summagunumauau
    \ps With inan. obj. and an. ending / TA+O, dative final
    \ge `he holds out (his hand) to or against (him)'
    \so Is.5.25; +Ps.143.6
    \xv Kussumogkunumoush nunnutcheganash:...
    \xe I stretch forth my hands unto thee:...
    \so Ps.143.6; (M) |Kussumogkunumauush|
    \nt +

\dv |soh-| and |mag∞| (`he gives, presents'), with formative (|-'num|) denoting action of the hand.

    [Algonquian [alg] |CIMAT-| `droit, en posture droite, verticale'    Cq.90a.
    \nt +?
Cree |SIMATCH| `droit'; |simacî-| AI `stand upright; rear up (e.g., horse)'    Lac.D.594a; W&A.170.]


\lx sun
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 156
\ps is called by Eliot (Gr. 21) an `adverb of asking', signifying `is it?' / particle, clause-initial
\ge polar interrogative
    "{Of Asking.} |Sun|, |Sunnummatta|; {Is it?} or {Is it not?}"    El.Gr.21/268.
    \xv ..., Sun yeu wuttapinneau onkatoganeg? ...
    \xe ..., Hast thou here any besides? ...
    \so Gen.19.12; (E0) gloss: "doe...[abide]"
    \xv sunnamatta
    \xe is it not?
    \xv sun wunnegen wunnesen
    \xe is it well to do good?
    \so etc.,    Mk.3.4
    |sun nen god| etc., `am I a god?'    2 K.5.7
    \xv sunnamatta yeu ...
    \xe is not this ...?
    \so Job 4.6

Chip. |nu|.]

\lx tahn∞che

    \ge `to be(come) (in) vain'
    \so Rom.1.21; Gal.3.4; Jas.1.26
    \xv ..., qut tahn∞cheyeu∞og ut wuttenanatam∞ongan∞out,...
    \xe ...; but became vain in their imaginations,...
    \so Rom.1.21
    \ng 3p indicative
    \xv ... yeuoh uppeantam∞onk tahn∞cheyeu∞.
    \xe ..., this man's religion is vain.
    \so Jas.1.26
    \ng 0 indicative

    \xv Sun ne keteasheu chequnnehtamunneau tahn∞che? tohneit ash tahn∞cheyeu∞k.
    \xe Have ye suffered so many things in vain? if it be yet in vain.
    \so Gal.3.4
    \ng 0 conjunct

    \se !|tahn∞cheyeheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to make sb in vain, to use sb despitefully'
    \so Mt.5.44

    \xv ...: tohwaj tahn∞cheáheadt wame wosketompaog?
    \xe ...: wherefore hast thou made all men in vain?
    \so Ps.89.47; (M) |tahnoochehhohp|
    \ng 2->3 (preterite) conjunct
    \xv ...: peantamwanshuk nagoh tahn∞chehukqueògig, kah woskhukqueôgig.
    \xe ..., and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you;
    \so Mt.5.44
    \ng _3p_->2p participle

    \se !|tahn∞cheyehteau|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to make sth of none effect, void'
    \so Ps.33.10(M),Ps.89.39
    \xv ...: tohnoocheyeuweto wunnatwontammooonkannoowoash missinninuog.
    \xe ...: he maketh the devices of the people of none effect.
    \so Ps.33.10(M)
    \ng 3->0(p) absolute
    \xv Kuttahn∞cheêhteoh ∞n∞waonk kittìnneûm:...
    \xe Thou hast made void the covenant of thy servant:...
    \so Ps.89.39
    \ng 2->0 absolute
    \xv ...: newutche tahn∞cheteaog kittinnaumatuonk.
    \xe ...: for they have made void thy law.
    \so Ps.119.126
    \ng possibly directly to |tahn∞che|? 3p->0 absolute
    \nt ?

[Chip. |anisha| `vainly, without effect, for nothing'    Bar.]


\lx tahs-
\va tahsh-
\va adtahs-
\va adtahsh-
\va hettahs-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
    \nt +
\nt Remark: The variants are grounded in a Proto-Algonquian contrast of palatalized and unpalatalized forms of the final consonant of *tahΘ- `so many', at least to some extent as animate and inanimate gender forms, respectively. The second form, deriving from the unpalatalized proto-allomorph, has in various contexts been levelled into the domain of the first. The two forms are listed by Trumbull under the lemma |tohsú|, |tohshéu|, T.164a. (See G.1981, 26, 65-66 for a summary; the entries at H.3183ff. versus some of those that follow here give a further indication of the possible complexities of the distribution.) Changed forms behave as if the form begins in a weak vowel, and are spelt |adt-| or |audt-| in general. See also entries under |teáhsh-|.
\ps initial, relative root, quantitative
\ge `so many, so much'
\so Several lemmas that follow.


\lx tahshadchasuau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
    \nt +
\ps ?AI+O
\ge `to have sth [in such and such a quantity]' (characteristically participial and associated with quantifier |wame|?)
\so Gen.24.2; Mt.13.44,46,18.25,19.21; Mk.5.26; Acts 5.1; Rev.3.1

    \xv ... masugkenutche wuttinnumoh ut weekit nanawunnumunit wame ne adtashadchásuadt,...
    \xe ... his eldest servant of his house, that ruled over all that he had,...
    \so Gen.24.2
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \xv ..., monchish, kah magish ne adtahshadchassuwaan,...
    \xe ..., go and sell that thou hast,...
    \so Mt.19.21
    \ng 2->_0_ participle


\lx tahshegen
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
    \nt +
\ps II(+O?)
\twn !|tahshetu| AI
\ge "to be so much of sth"
\dv |tahsh-| relative root `so much' + |-(e)kin-| II "to grow"
\so Mt.13.8,23
    \xv ..., kah meechummu∞ash, nawhutche nequt pasuk∞e tahshit tahshegen, nawhutche nequtta tahshinchag tahshit tahshegen, nawhutche shwincheg tahshit tahshegen.
    \xe ..., and [they] brought forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold.
    \so Mt.13.8


\lx tahshem∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157

\ps II, perhaps to stem of currently unattested !|tahsheu| AI

\so Gen.7.17; Ezek.28.2,5; Micah 5.9
    \xv Kenutcheg pish tahsheem∞ ut ayeuuhkônukqueaeneg,...
    \xe Thine hand shall be lifted up upon thine adversaries,...

    Pass. |kuttah tahshém∞| `thy heart is lifted up'    Eze.28.2 { 0 indicative; transferred from |tahshin|. }


\lx tahshetu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Currently only attested in conjunct forms.
\ps AI+O
\twn |tahshegen| II
\dv |tahsh-| relative root `so much' + |-(e)k-| AI "to grow"
\ge "to be so much (of sth), to (come to) have so much of sth (as)", translating various AV locutions, e.g. `increase', `living', `substance', `what one has'
\so Gen.12.5,13.1,39.5,6,45.10,11,46.1.,32,47.1; Deut.14.28,26.12; Josh.2.13,6.23,7.15,24; Lk.8.43; Mk.10.21

    \xv ..., kah wame neadtáhshekhettit nish magkunnumohettiche,...
    \xe ..., and all their substance that they had gathered,...
    \so Gen.12.5
    \ng 3p->_0_ participle
    \xv ... kah moncheáheuk nagum, kah ummittamwussoh kah neadtahshekhettit.
    \xe ...: and they sent him away, and his wife, and all that he had.
    \so Gen.12.19 (AV: 12.20)
    \ng 3p->_0_ participle (erroneous translation)
    \xv ..., kah wame ne adtahshekit,...
    \xe ..., and all that he had,...
    \so Gen.13.1
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \xv ..., pish kuppaudto wame kuppiukque chippiyeum, tahsheganit ne kodtumuk,...
    \xe ... thou shalt bring forth all the tithe of thine increase the same year,...'    Deut.14.28 { analysis of |-an-|? 3
    \so ->_0_? why? }
    \nt ?
    \xv ..., monchish, magish wame ne adtahshekean, kah unnunnumau matchekuog,...
    \xe ...: go thy way, sell whatsoever thou hast, and give to the poor,...
    \so Mk.10.21
    \ng 2->_0_ participle
    \xv Kah mittamwossis qussinausit nobonéese kodtumwae, noh mahtshunk wame neadtahshegit ut ponaskehtuóadtinneat,...
    \xe And a woman having an issue of blood twelve years, which had spent all her living upon physicians,...
    \so Lk.8.43

\lx tahshikquinnukod

\lx tahshin
\va tashin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
    \nt +
\ps II, relative root initial; ?also PreN
\twn |tahsu|, |tohsu|, AI
\ge "to be so many, so much, that many, that much"
\nt G&B.711
\so Common in numeral expressions that require its presence (see e.g. El.Gr. 14/20-261; B.1962, 22.49, 445-446); presumably required as modifier (prenoun-like, with plural |-ash| where appropriate--cf. B.1962, 17.31, 375, with the reference to "the noun |tahnε∙n| `object bearing such-and-such a number' and the derived homonymous particle (17.10)") of forms that do not act as finals to the initial |tahsh-|.
    \xv ..., kah pish nesit tahshin neadt tahshe mukkinnemohettit asekesukokish.
    \xe ...; and it shall be twice as much as they gather daily.
    \so Ex.16.5
    \xv Kah nish noh pasuk neg yau∞utcheg puppinashimwog, nequtta tahshin nuppóhwhunóog,...
    \xe And the four beasts had each of them six wings about him;...
    \so Rev.4.8
    \ng animate noun!

    \xv ..., nutteagunnonash nenan aidtahshìkup,...
    \xe ..., our money in full weight:...
    \so Gen.43.21
    \ng 0(->_adv._) preterite participle: "as much as it was"
    \xv ...: kah pish wuttôadtuhkon neadtahshik, kah pish k∞tnum napanna adtahshe chippag. ...
    \xe ...; he shall even restore it in the principal, and shall add the fifth part more thereto,...
    \so Lev.6.5
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle } "what it is as much as, amounts to"
    \xv Nequtta tahshik kesukquae anakaus,...
    \xe Six days thou shalt labour,...'    Deut.5.13  { cf. |nesausuk adtahshikquinogkok| `the seventh day
    \so , Deut.5.14 }
    \xv ..., kah nag sohkauoncheg puppinashimwoh, kah wuttinneukontunkoh, kah ukkehkinneásuonk, kah ∞wesuonk ne adtahshik ...
    \xe ...: and them that had gotten the victory over the beast, and over his image, and over his mark, and over the number of his name,...
    \so Rev.15.2
    \ng "what his name is as much as, amounts to"

    \se tahshinnu∞
    \nt Remark: precise formal and distributional relationship to the headword still unclear, though apparently similar to that of a numeral verb (i.e. a verb predicating a quantity) to the numeral noun or prenoun, and perhaps identical to the II (denominal) predicative formation.
    \ps II
    \ge `to be so much, many'
    \so Gen.41.35,43.34; Ex.12.3; Josh.19.40; Rev.1.11,21.20
    \xv ..., qut Benjamin assamâonk napanna tahshit tahshinnú∞ neadtahshinnu∞∞g nagog,...
    \xe ...: but Benjamin's mess was five times so much as any of theirs. ...
    \so Gen.43.34
    \ng 0 indicative; 0 participle

    \xv ..., kah negonchhuash en nesausuk audtahshinnu∞gish moeuwehkomongash nish ut Asia,...
    \xe ..., and send it unto the seven churches which are in Asia;...
    \so Rev.1.11
    \ng _0p_ participle
    \xv Napanna adtahshinnu∞k sardonix, nequtta adtahshinnú∞g sardios, nesausuk adtahshinnú∞g chrysolite,, shwosuk adtahshinnú∞k beryl, pask∞gen adtahshinnu∞k topas, piukqunnu∞k chysophasus, nabo noquttu∞uk jacinth, nabo neesinnú∞k ammethist.
    \xe The fift Sardonix, the sixt Sardius, the seuenth Chrysolite, the eight Beryl, the ninth a Topas, the tenth a Chrysoprasus, the eleuenth a Iacint, the twelfth an Amethyst.
    \so Rev.21.20
    \ng _0_ participle

    \se tahshinnu∞ut
    \ps ?PreV, locative, multiplicative
    \ge "so, thus manifold, multiplied by so, thus much"
    \so Mk.10.30
    \xv Qut pish attumunum nequt pasuk∞e tahshinnu∞ut, yeuyeu yeu aquompak,...
    \xe But he shall receive an hundredfold now in this time,...
    \so Mk.10.30

[Algonquian [alg] |∙∙TASIN-| `toutes les..., toutes les fois que...;'    Cq.383b-384a.
Menominee [mez] |tahse∙w, tahnε∙n| `he, it is so many'    B.1962, 15.193,307.]

\et H.3186 *tahΘenwi II `so many', G.1981, 26, 66.

\lx tahshinum
\va tohshinum
\va tashinum
\va toshinum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
\ps v.t. inan. obj. / TI1b, manual final
\twn |tahshinau| TA
\ge `he raises (it), lifts (it) up'; +`to hold sth up; carry sth up'
\so Gen.40.20
\nt (Primarily, `he lifts with the hand' |tahshenum|.)
    \xv ...kah toshinum ∞shoh wunnutcheg,...
    \xe ...: and he held up his father's hand,...
    \so Gen.48.17
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., & pish k∞ce tahshinnumunneau nuskonash yeuwutche.
    \xe ..., and ye shall carry up my bones from hence.
    \so Gen.50.25
    \ng 2p->0(p) subordinative
    \nt +
    (|tashun-|    Mass.Ps.)

    \nt MN: noh tahshinuk
    \ng suppositive |noh tahshinuk| `he who lifts it up, when he lifts it'    Is.18.3

    imperat. |tohshinush kenutcheg| `lift up thy hand'    Ps.10.12  { 2->0 imperative }

    \se !|tahshinumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to lift sth up unto sb'
    \so Ps.143.8
    \xv ..., Nuttashinnumaomp nunnutcheg Jehovah ...
    \xe ..., I have lift up my hand unto the LORD,...
    \so Gen.14.22
    \ng 1->3+0 preterite absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche kutahshinnumaush nukketeahogkou.
    \xe ...: for I lift up my soul unto thee.
    \so Ps.143.8; (M): |kuttashunumauush|

    \se tahshinau
    \va tohshinau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, manual final
    \ge `he lifts (him) up'; +`to bring sb; to extol sb; to uphold sb'
    \xv Qut neen, kutahshineh nussampwutteahaonganit ...
    \xe And as for me, thou upholdest me in mine integrity:...
    \so Ps.41.12; (M): |kuttahshinneh|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., yeuyeu nuttahshin nuhhog.
    \xe ...: now will I lift up myself.
    \so Is.33.10√
    \ng 1->3 indicative
    \xv Hohpagk anaquabit LORD, kah noh pish kutashinuko∞.
    \xe Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he shall lift you up.
    \so Jas.4.10
    \ng 3->2p objective
    \nt +

    \xv KUtashinush, woi Jehovah, newutche kutashinip:...
    \xe I Will extol thee, O Lord, for thou hast lifted me up,...
    \so Ps.30.1; (M) |kutashinush|, |kutashinnip|
    \ng 1->2 indicative; 2->1 preterite indicative
    pret. |Kah Moses neáne tôhshinohp ask∞koh ut touohkomuh, netatupe wosketomp wunnaumonuh nein tahshinon.| `And as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness: even so must the Son of man be lifted up:"    Jn.3.14√  { 3->3' preterite changed conjunct }; (M) |tashunuhp|, |tashunôu|
    suppos. part. |tahshinont| `when lifting (him)'
    pass. |-inimuk| `when he is lifted'    Jn.12.32

    \xv ..., kah tahshin∞k k∞sh∞, kah peyonk.
    \xe ..., and bring your father, and come.
    \so Gen.45.19
    \ng 2p->3 imperative
    \nt +
    imperat. 2d sing. |Tahshin kuhhog ...| `Lift up thy self,...'    Ps.94.2; (M) identical  { 2->3 imperative }

    [Algonquian [alg] |TES-| `racine qui exprime la position, la situation sur un plan horizontal, au dessus du sol; ...' |Tesinindjin,i| `{étendre la main}, tenir la main {étendue} horizontalement'    Cq.397b-398a.
    \nt +
Ill. {r} |tess-|, e.g. |tessa8e| `en droiture, tout droit', |tessahagane| `chose qu on met sous une autre pour qu elle ne touche pas a terre, a leau,...'    M.571/320b-321a.
M.-P. |tehsahqi (tehsahq-, tehsaq-)| PV `on top of', |'tehsaqopin| AI(+O) `he sits on top of it', |'tehsahqehlal| TA `he lifts him up and puts him on top'    LeS.93a.]

\et A.2027-2028, H.3271-3273, Mch.1935,150b,169a *te∙hΘ- `upon'.


\lx tahshinunneu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Relationship to the relative root |tahsh-| `so many' seems certain--note the changed conjunct forms with the signature |adt-|--, though the semantic relationship must remain obscure without the identification of the final. (One obvious possibiity is as the medial |-inin-| `human being, person', exemplified in B.1962, 14.374, 18.182, perhaps as a dependent compound (i-stem): "to be so many people".) See also |teáhsh-|. Reduplication is used to indicate plurality of groups (cf. Gen.7.1 and Ex.12.21).
\ps AI+"O", with a quantity argument
\ge `to be a family, house, household' (?"to be so/that many people")
\so Gen.7.1,10.18,36.40; Ex.6.17,6.25,12.21; Josh.7.18 ...

    \xv ... wame neadtahshineog,...
    \xe ... all thy house...
    \so Gen.7.1
    \ng 2p->_adv_ participle; see note in commentary
    \xv Kah yeush ∞wesuongan∞ash mugquompaog wutontseongash Esau ne ahhuttahshinunnéhettit, ne ahhuttahshohkeahettit ne ussoweshettit,...
    \xe And these are the names of the dukes that came of Esau, according to their families, after their places, by their names;...
    \so Gen.36.40
    \ng 3p->adv_ participle, reduplicated preverb
    \xv Wunnaumonuh Gershom: Libni, kah Shimi, neáhuttashinnunnéhettit,
    \xe The sons of Gershon; Libni, and Shimi, according to their families.
    \so Ex.6.17
    \ng reduplicated preverb
    \xv ..., kah neemunnumunk sheepsemesog, neahut tahshinninnéog,...
    \xe ... and take you a lamb according to your families,...
    \so Ex.12.21
    \ng reduplicated preverb
    \xv Kah wosketompae pas∞au neadtahshinuned,...
    \xe And he brought his household man by man;...
    \so Josh.7.18
    \ng changed initial
    \xv Wonkum Prisca kah Aquila, kah ne adtahshinunit Onsephorus,
    \xe Salute Priscilla and Aquila, and the household of Onesiphorus.
    \so 2 Tim.4.19
    \ng changed initial


\lx tahshit
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 157
    \nt +
\ps particle; (?) PreV (often modifying a preverb)
\dv locative to the initial |tahsh-| `so many' in multiplicative (and number adverb) sense.
\ge "so many times" (literally), with uses in forming complex numerals that do not allow straightforward glossing.
\so common
    \xv ..., pish an∞tauau nesausuk tahshit nompeu:...
    \xe ..., vengeance shall be taken on him sevenfold. ...
    \so Gen.4.15
    \xv ...: Joseph nabo nesausuk audtashit kodtumwohkog ...
    \xe .... Joseph, being seventeen years old,...
    \so Gen.37.2
    \ng changed preverb
    \xv ..., pish pasukquinne k∞ch ayeuuhkonittue sohwehtau, kah pish k∞sem ut anaquabit nesausuk tahshit chippe,...
    \xe ...: thou shalt go out one way against them, and flee seven ways before them;...
    \so Deut.28.25
    \xv ..., seepsin wutapinneat shwosuk tahshit kodtumwae, kah nanunkqussu.
    \xe ..., which had kept his bed eight years, and was sick of the palsy.
    \so Acts 9.33

\va tahs∞t

\lx tahtippadtau

\lx tan-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge lit. "there", but perhaps used as for an imperfective mode of action, in durative/habitual sense. This appears to be restricted to the one or the other of the (PA) forms--palatalized or unpalatalized--in central languages, but I assume that the typical Eastern levelling to the unpalatalized (unmutated) reflex |n| has occurred. Note in particular the use in derived forms denoting instruments or places that have a characteristic use. See, for instance, |tannegen| II+O `to bring sth forth (there characteristically)', tanninneau| II `to burn (there characteristically)', |!(ad)tannuppogham| TI1a `to thresh sth (there characteristically)'.
\so Relevant examples that follow; explicit grammarians' statements and direct evidence from related languages.

[Algonquian [alg] |∙∙TAN| `... Il est difficile de donner le sens précis de cette Racine, je le crois plus étendu que celui de ∙∙TAJE qui n'exprime guère que l'idée de localité. ∙∙TAN indique de plus la présence actuelle, la demeure, et même la possession, la propriété;...'    Cq.380b-382a.
Cree x|TASIKKAWEW|, |KAM|,... `il est occupé à le travailler', |TASIHEW|, |TTAW| `il est occupé à le faire, ou mieux, |tasikkammew|, |kkam|, |TASIMEW|, |TTAM| `il est occupé á parler de lui'; |Tuss'e| and |Tus'sinä| advs. `Meaning continuous, incessant, perpetual, action or motion;...'    Lac.D.609b; Frs.480b.
Ill. Entries s.v. |entachi| and |tachi|, with glosses such as `constenmant', `long temps', `semper', `toujours'; also |entara-|, |tara-|    Grv.150/113b, 534/304a; 150/114a, 543/307b.
Ojibwe [oji] |Daji-| `This word, prefixed to a substantive or verb, denotes the {place} where some action is performing, or where a certain object comes from.'    Bar.100b.]


\lx tannadtupp∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he feeds (as sheep or cattle), grazes'
\so Gen.41.18; Ezek.34.14
    \xv ..., kah tannadtupp∞og wompasquehtu.
    \xe ...; and they fed in a meadow:
    \so Gen.41.18
    \nt +

    \xv ..., missohhamah k∞wehquetumoush uttoh adtannadtupwehettit floksog.
    \xe ..., tell me, I pray thee, where they feed their {flocks}.
    \so Gen.37.16
    \ng assuming intransitive verb
    \nt +

    \se -p∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `pasturage, pasture'
    \so Ezek.34.14; 45.15


\lx tannag
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
\ps n.
\ge `a crane'
\so Jer.8.7
\cf sassadt
\dv |tanni| `harsh, hoarse, a tearing sound'.

\lx tanne ontowâonk
