\lx tannegen
\va tannekin
\va adtannegen
\va dtannegen
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
    \nt Remark: The forms in |adtan-| are changed forms, and hence only proper to the conjunct order. However, there appear to be some non-conjunct order forms with a levelled initial syllable or the aphetic form in |dt-| (as, e.g. Lev.25.19,21, Mt.7.17,13.26, and, in an imperative, Mt.21.19).
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / II(+O)
\dv |taN-| `there' + |-ekin-| II `to grow'
\ge `it brings forth, produces, yields' (as the earth plants, a tree fruit), +`to grow; bear sth'
\so Jn.12.24; Mt.7.17; 13.26
    \xv Neematog sun woh figsuhtug tannegen olivesash, asuh weenomussippogqut figsash? ...
    \xe Can the fig tree, my brethren, bear olive berries? either a vine, figs? ...
    \so Jas.3.12
    \nt +
    \xv Netatup, nishnoh wunnegen matug adtannegen wunnegenash meechummuongash, qut matchit matug adtannegen matchetoash mechummuongash.
    \xe Even so every good tree bringeth forth good fruit; but a corrupt tree bringeth forth evil fruit.
    \so Mt.7.17
    \nt +

    \nt MN: tannegik
    \ng suppositive |tannegik| , |-kik|, |dtannegkuk|     Gen.1.29; Lk.13.9
    "  every    tree   bringing   fruit   kernelling     kernells     that you may eat of them."
    \nt +
    |& nish noh mahtug dtannegkuk meechum úbbuhkumin∞∞k ubbuhkuminash, woh kummeechumw∞.|        Gen.1.29(E0)
    \xv ..., yowutche nishnoh pasuk matug matta adtannegenun∞g meechummúonk wunnegen, tummethamun, kah unnohkon n∞taut.
    \xe ...: therefore every tree which bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire.
    \so Mt.3.10
    \nt +

    \xv ... dtannékej ohke moskeht,...
    \xe ..., Let the earth bring forth grass,...
    \so Gen.1.11  { 0 imperative ]
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttitamun, matta meechum dtannegenunnu∞utch, yeu wutch, kah micheme. ...
    \xe ..., and [he] said unto it, Let no fruit grow on thee henceforward for ever. ...
    \so Mt.21.19
    \ng theme 4 form, 3->2, to a nonce TA stem? Or extension of negative |-un-| to an imperative??
    \nt +

    \se tannétu
    \va tannetu
    \nt +
    \va -ek-
    \ps With an.obj. / AI(+O?)
    \ge `he grows'
    pl. |dtannetuog|    Ps.92.13


\lx tannikehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
    \nt +
\ps AI+O
\dv |(ad)tan-| `there (?characteristically)' + |-(w)ik-| `house' + |-uhk-| creative final + |-á-| AI (de-stem form to |wekehteau|, |weekitteau|, T.187b)
\ge `to build sth'
\so Gen.10.11
    \xv ..., kah tannikketeau Niniveh, kah keitotan Rehoboth, kah Kalah.
    \xe ..., and builded Nineveh, and the city Rehoboth, and Calah.
    \so Gen.10.11
    \ng 3->0 indicative


\lx taninneau
\va tanunneau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
    \nt +
\ps II, |(ad)tan-| "there (characteristically, regularly)", v.s., + |-in-| `burn' + |-á-| II
\ge `to burn (there)'
\so Gen.15.17; Lev.6.9,12,13
    \xv ..., kah n∞tau ne altarut ne pish taninnaau.
    \xe ..., and the fire of the altar shall be burning in it.
    \so Lev.6.9; (E1): |taninneau|; Lev.6.13: |tannunneau|

    \xv .... kah kusseh neahhuttannunnag paguttoó∞k,...
    \xe ..., behold a smoking furnace,...
    \so Gen.15.17
    \ng |ne| + reduplicated 0->_adv_ participle
    \nt +

\et G.1980 [11th.Alg.Conf.], 144: *-eΘe∙- II `blaze, burn', citing Menomini, Munsee, Arapaho; G.1982, (109), 28; B.1962, 15.184, p.306, 15.245,248, p.314: |-εnε∙-| `blaze'


\lx tannogki
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it is torn'
\ps adj.
\ge `torn'
    \xv tannogki petasquishäonk
    \xe a torn coat
    \so C.
\dv |tanni| `it tears, makes a tearing sound'
With |tanni|, |tannogki| (Abn. |taraghi|) `it "tears"', |tannag| `a crane', cf. Sansk. dar (ar), `lacerare, dilacerare, findere'; Gr. déro:; Russ. dra-tj, scindere; Goth. ga-tar; Ang.-Sax. tær-an, tir-an; Sw. tära; Dan. täre, to tear; and Greek grù (a sound, a grunt), grúzein, grúlle, géranos, a crane; Lat. grus, gruere (Engl. `the crane crunketh'); grunnire, to grunt; Ang.-Sax. craen; Dutch and Germ. kraan; Sw. trana; Dan. trane, a crane.

[Narragansett [xnt] |tanócki|, |tanócksha| `it is torn or rent'    R.W.134.
Western Abenaki [abe] |taraghi`rré| `cela est déchiré (ou crevé)'; imperat. |taraghi|, `déchire'; |tarok8^és8| `(le loup) hurle'.
Delaware [del] |ta lackat| `cracked, split'    Zeisb.]


\lx tannogkinnum

\ge `he tears (it), as cloth or a garment'
\so 1 Sam.15.28
\dv |tannogki|, with the formative |-num|, denoting action performed by the hand.

[Narragansett [xnt] |kum-mache-tannakúnnam-ous| `I have torn it off for you'.
Western Abenaki [abe] |nedararaghinahad8n| `I tear (my dress)'; |netaraghenemen| `je le crève de la main'.]

    \nt +

\ge "to plant (sth) (there characteristically)"

    Suppos. inan. |adtanohketeamuk| `when planted, cultivated'; used for `garden'    Gen.2.9  { X changed conjunct, as participle X->_loc_ "where one plants" }

\lx tanohtóadtu

\lx Tantum
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 158
    "The Penobscots call their god |Tantum|." -- Capt. J. Smith.
    "The good god they call |Tantum|, and their evil god, whom they fear will do them hurt, they call |Squantum|." -- Higginson's N.E. Plantation.
\dv Probably contracted from |keihtánnitt∞m| `my great god'.
\cf Keihtannit
\cf manit
\cf Squantum

\lx tapeneam
\va tapeneaum
\va -á-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 158
\ps v.t. / TI1a, visual final (v.i. etymology)
\ge `he accepts (it), receives (it) with satisfaction'; +`for sth to please sb, to think sth good'
\so Eccl.9.7
    \xv Kah ∞shoh matta wuttápeneaum∞un,...
    \xe But his father refused,...
    \so Gen.48.19
    \ng 3->0 negative objective
    \nt +
    \xv Ne wuttapeneaumun wut∞shin, wame ne adtahshimmeechimuk woh ayeumoash wuhhogkat.
    \xe For it pleased the Father that in him should all fulness dwell;
    \so Col.1.19
    \ng 3->0 objective
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah unnehhuk nag uttoh en tapeneamóg ut kuskesukouóut,...
    \xe ..., and do ye to them, as is good in your eyes:...
    \so Gen.19.8
    \ng 2p->_0_ participle
    \nt +

    imperat. 2d sing. |tapeneash|    Deut.33.11
    3d sing. |tapeneaj| `let him accept it'    1 Sam.26.19

    \se tapeneauau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, visual final
    \ge `he accepts (him), is satisfied with (him)'; +`to approve, respect sb, to consent unto sb; to have delight in sb'
    \so Gen.4.7,34.15; Deut.25.7; Esth.6.6; Rom.14.18
    \nt +
    \xv Wunnesean, woh mo kuttapeneonteoh? ...
    \xe If thou doest well, shalt thou not be accepted? ...
    \so Gen.4.7; (E0): "shalt - not - thou be respected"
    \ng X->2, negative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche tepeneauau wuttaunoh Jakob:...
    \xe ..., because he had delight in Jacob's daughter:...
    \so Gen.34.19
    \ng (E0&E1) |tapeneauau|
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche noh yeush ut waussumont Christoh, neh wuttapeneauoh GOD, kah tapeneaúau wosktompaehtu.
    \xe For he that in these things serveth Christ is acceptable to God, and approved of men.
    \so Rom.14.18
    \nt +

    suppos. part. |tapeneauoncheh|, |tapeneaúont| `delighteth (to honour)'    Esth.6.6√
    \xv Kah wosketomp matta tapeneauonk nemunon wematuh ummittamwussoh,...
    \xe And if the man like not to take his brother's wife,...
    \so Deut.25.7
    \nt +

    \se !|tapeneamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to allow sb sth', etc.
    \so Gen.4.4,19.21; Num.30.5,8,11; Lev.1.4; 1 Thess.2.4
    \xv .... Kusseh kutapenaumaunun yeu wutche, kah matta woh nukkepuhteam yeu otan,...
    \xe ..., See, I have accepted thee concerning this thing also, that I will not overthrow this city,...
    \so Gen.19.21
    \ng 1->2+0-obj. objective; sentential direct object, ?with redundant |yeu wutche|
    \xv ..., kah pish kitteámonteanittamwe tapenaumauon wutche nagum, wutche wunnohteaheonat.
    \xe ...; and it shall be accepted for him to make atonement for him.'    Lev.1.4   { X->3-pro+3
    \so objective }
    \xv ...: kah Jehovah pish ummonaneteae ahquontamauau, newutche ∞shoh matta wuttapeneamunk∞un.
    \xe ...; and the LORD shall forgive her, because her father disallowed her.'    Num.30.5  { 3
    \so ->3-pro+0-pro objective }

    \xv Qut neyane tapeneamunkqueog GOD nuppaubuhtanumukqunnanônut wunaunchem∞kaonk, ne nuttiné yinnean,...
    \xe But as we were allowed of God to be put in trust with the gospel, even so we speak;...
    \so 1 Thess.2.4
    \ng 3->1p+0; sentential direct object?
    \xv Qut wessukeh ne kesukok n∞tunkqut, mattá tapeneamauunk,...
    \xe But if her husband disallowed her on the day that he heard it,...'    Num.30.8  { negative 3->3
    \so -pro+0; status of direct object uncertain }


    \se tapeneaum∞onk
    \ps Vbl.n. (pass.)
    \ge `acceptance, being accepted'

    \se wuttapeneam∞onganeu
    \ps AI(+O), i-stem
    \dv verb of possession to previous sublemma

    \xv Matta wuttapinneamooonkaneos kuttunomatuonk,...
    \xe Unless thy law had been my delights:...
    \so Ps.119.92(M)

    \se |tapeneamoe|, |-we|, |-aum∞e|
    \nt +
    \ps A, Adv
    \ge `acceptably; in, of pleasure'
    \so Phil.1.15; 2 Thess.1.11; 1 Tim.5.6; Jas.5.5; Heb.12.28
    \xv Qut noh tapeneamoe pomontog, nupp∞, ash pomantog.
    \xe But she that liveth in pleasure is dead while she liveth.
    \so 1 Tim.5.6
    \xv ..., num-Manitt∞mun woh kutogquanumukkou tapenumuk yeu ∞wehkómmuwaonk, kah pakodcheussen wame ∞ne tapeneaum∞e wunnet∞onk,...
    \xe ..., that our God would count you worthy of this calling, and fulfil all the good pleasure of his goodness,...
    \so 2 Thess.1.11
    \xv ..., ne nashpe woh tapeneamwe waussumogkut GOD nashpe quttianumáonk kah manitôe wabesuonk.
    \xe ..., whereby we may serve God acceptably with reverence and godly fear:
    \so Heb.12.28

[Delaware [del] |tepihilleu| `it is enough'    Zeisb.
    Menominee [mez] |tε∙penawε∙w| AI `he is pleased', TA "unrecorded"    B.1962,16.127,354.]
    \nt +

\et *te∙p- + *-naw-, *-n- TA, TI "used of seeing and of intellect and emotion", B.1962, 16.127,354, cf. ib. "an unrecorded formation is implied by related AI tε∙penawε∙w `he is pleased'"; H.2233-2234


\lx tapeneunkquodt
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 159
    \nt +
\ps II
\twn |tapeneunkqussu|
\ge `to be acceptable, convenient, expedient, meet; to be reason; to become (sb/sth); comeliness'
\so Mt.3.15, Rom.12.1, Phil.1.7, Col.3.18, 2 Thess.1.3, Tit.2.1
    \xv ..., kah namohettit ohke Jazar, kah ohke Gilead, kah kusseh, ne ayeuonk tapeneunkquot wutche neetahsuog.
    \xe ...: and when they saw the land of Jazer, and the land of Gilead, that, behold, the place was a place for cattle;
    \so Num.32.1
    \ng c.f. Vlg. "cumque vidissent Iazer et Galaad aptas alendis animalibus"
    \xv ..., noh pish mishánumukqussue wishquiyeu∞, wunnetupanatamwe kah tapeneunkquot wutche sontim wutawohteaonk,...
    \xe ..., he shall be a vessel unto honour, sanctified, and meet for the master's use,...
    \so 2 Tim.2.21
    \xv ..., Matta tapeneunkquttinn∞ nupponunnumunan wuttinn∞waonk GOD, kah n∞neech∞hteamun tables.
    \xe ..., It is not reason that we should leave the word of God, and serve tables.
    \so Acts 6.2
    \xv Wame teanteaguassinish wunnegenash ut nuhhogkat, qut wame teanteaguassinish matta tapeneunkquodtinn∞ash:...
    \xe All things are lawful unto me, but all things are not expedient:...
    \so 1 Cor.6.12 (1 Cor.10.23 sim.)
    \xv ..., kah kukkâusuo(n)gane pompuhchaiyeúmunnônash, m∞cheke anue tapeneunkqutash.
    \xe ...; and our uncomely parts have more abundant comeliness.
    \so 1 Cor.12.23

    \xv Kah tapeneunkquok kesukod payaum∞uk ...
    \xe And when a convenient day was come,...
    \so Mk.6.21
    \xv QUt ken n∞wash nish tapeneunkquokish wunnekuhk∞tomwehteaonganit.
    \xe But speak thou the things which become sound doctrine:
    \so Tit.2.1


\lx tapeneunkqussu
\va tapenunkqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 159
    \nt +
\ps AI
\twn |tapeneunkquodt|
\ge `to be approved, apt to, fit, sufficient; to become (sb); to be goodly' [OED goodly a. 1. "Of good appearance; good-looking, well-favoured or proportioned; comely, fair, handsome."]
\so
    \xv ..., kah Joseph tapenunkqussu, kah wunnetu.
    \xe And Joseph was a goodly person, and well favoured.

\lx tapenum

\lx taphéau
\va tapheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 159
\ps v.caus. an. / TA, causative final
\ge `he makes (him) satisfied, satisfies, contents (him)'; pass. `he is satisfied, made content'; +`to comfort sb'
\so Prov.14.14
    \xv ... kusseh, kemat Esau taphéau wuhhogkuh papaume ken, noh kittinnushikqunat,
    \xe ..., Behold, thy brother Esau, as touching thee, doth comfort himself, {purposing} to kill thee.'    Gen.27.42  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk nah wuttapheuh, kah ∞che ken∞nuh wuttahhut.
    \xe ... And he comforted them, and spake kindly unto them.'    Gen.50.21  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut yeuyeu noh tapheau, kah ken kutawakompenam.
    \xe ...: but now he is comforted, and thou art tormented.
    \so Lk.16.25
    \ng X->3
    \nt +

    suppos. part. |tapheunt| `when satisfying'    Prov.6.30

    \se |Taphuaenin|
    \nt +
    \ps NA, nom.ag., to TA lemma with indefinite object final
    \ge `the Comforter, which is the Holy Ghost'
    \so Jn.14.26

    \se tapehteau
    \ps With inan. + an. obj. (traditive) / TA+O ?
    \ge `he satisfies (him) with (it), makes (it) satisfy (him)'
    \xv nuttapehteau
    \xe I satisfy (them) with
    \so Ps.132.15; Jer.31.14


\lx taphum
\va tabhum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 159
\ps v.t. / TI1b, mechanical final (without initial |-a-|?)
\ge `he buys, i.e. makes satisfaction for (it)'
\so Gen.47.20; K.16.24
    \xv Kah Joseph taphum wame ohke ut Egypt wutche Pharoh,...
    \xe And Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh;...
    \so Gen.47.20
    \ng 3->0 indicative
    \nt +

    \se taphou
    \va tapwhau
    \nt !
    \ps With an. obj. / TA, mechanical final
    \ge `to buy, purchase sb'
    \nt +
    \xv Wonk Ruth um-Moabit, ummittamwussoh Mahlon, nuttap∞ n∞mittamwussissinneat,...
    \xe Moreover Ruth the Moabitess, the wife of Mahlon, have I purchased to be my wife,...
    \so Ruth 4.10
    \ng 1->3 indicative (objective)
    \nt +
    \xv nuttap∞h
    \xe I bought (them)
    \so Lk.14.19
    \xv Kutapwhutteomwop wutch neanóadtik...
    \xe Ye are bought with a price;...
    \so 1 Cor.7.23
    \ng X->2p preterite indicative
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah noh tapwhut howane penuwot wutche teauguash,...
    \xe ..., or [he that is] bought with money of any stranger,...
    \so Gen.17.12
    \ng X->_3_ participle
    \xv ... missinninnuog paumushahettit neg ta(b)whodcheg.
    \xe ..., till the people pass over, which thou hast purchased.
    \so Ex.15.16
    \ng 2->_3p_ participle
    \nt +


\lx tâpi
\va taupi
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps v.impers. / II, PreV?
\ge `there is enough, it suffices'
\so Prov.30.15,15

    imperat. 3d sing. |tabach| `let it suffice'    Ezek.40.6

    \se !|tapet|
    \nt ??
    \so Gen.33.9
    \nt Remark: On this currently isolated form, see Notes and Queries to Gen.33.9; ??perhaps theme 2a form to otherwise unattested TA verb.
    \xv Kah Esau n∞wau, Nuttapet nemat, wuttaiheesh ne ahtóan.
    \xe And Esau said, I have enough, my brother; keep that thou hast unto thyself.
    \so Gen.33.9; (E0) |nuttápet|
    \ng 1s indicative

(Cf. Sansk. tarp, satiare; Greek térpo.)
\cf wame

\lx tashkuhkom

    \xe A plentiful table

\lx tatuppe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 160
\ps v.impers. / (transitive) PreV, PreN, ?II(+O)
\ge `it is equal'
\ps as adv.
\ps `alike, equally'
\nt G&B.713
\so Job 21.26
    {Of Likeness.} |Netatup,| `Like so.'    El.Gr.22/268.
    (|tatu@ppéyeu| `just so'; |-yéue| `equally'    C.)

    \se tattuppeyeu
    \ps Adj. / II
    pl. |-yeuash| `equal' (things)    Is.40.15; Rev.21.16

    \se tatuppeyeu∞
    \ps V.subst. / AI(+O), II(+O)
    \ge `he is (or it is) the same as, equal to'
    \xv ..., newutche kuttatuppeyeu Pharaoh.
    \xe ...: for thou art even as Pharaoh.
    \so Gen.44.18
    \ng 2->3
    \nt +
    \xv Kah newutche ohké ..., matta, netatuppeinn∞ ohkit Egypt,...
    \xe For the land, ..., is not as the land of Egypt,
    \so Deut.11.10
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wame weyaus moskehtu∞, kah wame na ut wanegik tatuppeyeu∞ ohteuhkone uppeshaonut.
    \xe ...? All flesh is grass, and all the goodliness thereof is as the flower of the field:
    \so Is.40.6√
    pl. |..., kah neg na wadohkitcheg tatuppeyeu∞og chansompsit,...| `..., and the inhabitants thereof are as grasshoppers;...'    Is.40.22√; Lk.20.36
    \xv ..., nésahteag kah ne koskag, kah ne sohkunkquok tatuppeyeuash.
    \xe .... The length and the breadth and the height of it are equal.
    \so Rev.21.16
    \ng 0p
    \nt +

    suppos. |...: kuskesukquash naj tatuppeyeu∞kish.| `...: let thine eyes behold the things that are equal.'    Ps.17.2  { _0p_ participle }; (M) |sampoiyeuukish|

    \xv Tatuppeyeuitch en wohhogkat ogkooonkanit {ne} onkhukquit,...
    \xe Let it be unto him as the garment which covereth him,...
    \so Ps.109.19(M)  { 0 imperative }; (E) |Tatupontaj|
    \nt +

\dv |tâpi| `it suffices', by intens. reduplication.


[Narragansett [xnt] |Netâtup.| `It is all one'    R.W.157/165.
Western Abenaki [abe] |Tétebi8i| `à l'égalité, égalem't'    R.40P,563b.
Cree |Tàbiskooch| `alike'; |E-áp-itch| `the same'; +|TâP| (rac.) `être à la place, comme si, etc., pareillement'; +|TEP| (rac.) `assez, qui est suffisant'     H.240b;241a; Lac.D.606b;614b.
Chip. |tibishko, tetibishko, tâbishkotch| `Equally'; |Tibishkô| `Likewise, just so, equally; equivalent; opposite, (F. vis-à-vis)'    Bar.89a;386b.
Delaware [del] |tpisqui| `exactly so'    Zeisb.
    Menominee [mez] |tepa∙h| `evenly, equally; exactly opposite; at the same time; alike', |ta∙tepah| `equal to one another, exactly alike'    M.L.255.
    \nt +
M.-P. |tetpi| |(tetp-)| PV `to the same extent as (something else); evenly'    LeS.93b,164b.]

\et There appears to be a considerable degree of variation in the vowels here, but the connection with *te∙p- `enough, suffice' (as H.3276-c.3306) seems initially plausible. (Williams evidently considered them related.) The two roots posited by Lacombe for Cree suggest that a more careful sifting is required.


\lx tatuppanumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 160
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv |tatup-| `alike, equal' + mental final |-ánum-|
\ge `to count sb worthy'
\so Acts 5.41,10.34
    \xv ..., muskauanatamwog, newutche wuttatupanumouh chequnehtamunat akodchuonk ...
    \xe ..., rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer shame ...
    \so Acts 5.41
    \ng 3->3p objective
    \xv .., Wunnamuhkut nen n∞wahteoun wame wosketompaog wuttatupanumuh GOD.
    \xe ..., Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons:'    Acts 10.34   { sense, following the Greek text, "shows no partiality": "God counts all people worthy", 3->3
    \so , objective due to preceding object(?) }

    \se tatuppantam
    \ps TI1a
    \ge "to consider sth equal to sth"?
    \so following sublemma

    \se tatuppantamauau
    \ps TA+"O", where O may be predicative; |-aw-| stem
    \ge "to think sth equal to, the same as sth; to think in the same way about sth as sb", `to count sth (as) sth; to be of the same mind (as sb with respect to sth)'
    \so Gen.31.33; Rom.12.16,15.5; Phil.2.20
    \xv ..., ne pìsh tatupantamauonuh kôm∞tukus.
    \xe ..., that shall be counted stolen with me.
    \so Gen.31.33
    \ng analysis uncertain--ill-formed X->3+"0"?
    \xv Yeuyeu manunnishuwae, kah weekontamwahuwae God aninnumauunungqutch onk woh kuttatupantam∞timw∞,...
    \xe Now the God of patience and consolation grant you to be likeminded one toward another ...
    \so Rom.15.5
    \ng 2p->0 (or 3?) (anaphoric), reciprocal: "to think of one another in the same way as him/this"

    \xv Tatupanatam∞uttegk,...
    \xe Be of the same mind one toward another,...
    \so Rom.12.16
    \ng 2p->0 (anaphoric), reciprocal

\nt Puzzle: A consistent analysis of the following example still eludes me: |Newutche wanne howan nuttatupanitam∞muk∞h ...| `I have no man likeminded,...'    Phil.2.20 { with implicit "to him" }

\lx tatuppequanum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 160
    \nt Remark: perhaps for |tutupp-| (see etymology, with unusual reduplication), with changed vowel in the participle.
    \nt +
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `he rolls (it) along'
\so Mt.27.60,28.2

    \nt Remark: The variety of forms in the meaning "chariot" requires study.
    \nt +
    Suppos. pass. |tatuppequanumuk| `when rolled, that which is rolled'  { X->_0_ participle }
    hence, as n. `a wagon', +`chariot'
    \xv ...: nequtta tahshinash onkwhôsue tatuppequanumukquash kah nabo nees∞og oxenog pasuk tatuppequanumuk wutch nees∞og Sontimóog,...
    \xe ..., six covered wagons, and twelve oxen; a wagon for two of the princes,...
    \so Num.7.3
    pl. |tatuppequanumugish| `wagons'    Gen.45.19
    and |tatuppequanumugquaash| `wagons', `chariots'    Gen.45.21, Ex.14.7

    Suppos. inan. |tatuppequashunk| (from |tatuppequasheau| v.i. `it rolls') `when it rolls';
    as n. `that which rolls, "a rolling thing"'    Is.17.13

    |tatuppin|, n. `a thread'    Cant.4.3
\cf tuttuppun

\et H.3353-3359 *tetep- `roll'.

\lx tauw-
\va touw-
\va taúw-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 160
    \nt +
\ps initial, intransitive
\ge `to be a breach, gap, hole, opening'
\so individual entries; some oddments with various extensions follow:
\nt Remark: OED, s.v. "breach", sb. +4. "An irruption {into}; an infringement {upon}; an inroad, injurious assault."
    \xv ..., newutche Jehovah touwehtham wutchippau∞ongash Israel.
    \xe ..., because that the LORD had made a breach in the tribes of Israel.
    \so Judg.21.15
    \xv Kah David neuantam, newutche Jehovah tauwetahwhau Uzzah,...
    \xe And David was displeased, because the LORD had made a breach upon Uzzah:...
    \so 2 Sam.6.8
    \xv Kah David matta tapenam∞un, newutche Jehovah touwutchahtahwhau Uzzahoh,...
    \xe And David was displeased, because the LORD had made a breach upon Uzza:...
    \so 1 Chron.13.11
    \xv Newutche, newutche matta negonne kutusseumwop, Lord kum-Manitt∞mun, kutâuwutchahtôhukqunnónup,...
    \xe For because ye did it not at the first, the LORD our God made a breach upon us,...
    \so 1 Chron.15.13
    \ng 3->12 preterite

[Western Abenaki [abe] |ta8aï'gan, nar| `Trou dans la glace p'r pêscher'    R.488/538b.
WAbn. |dawabi| AI `sit in something', |dawaka| AI `throw in, put down inside', |dawapska| II `hole in rock, cave, literally down inside rock', |dawigen| II `it is open, there is an opening in it',...    D.1.158-159.
Algonquian [alg] |TAWA| `c'est ouvert, il y a ouverture, brèche, espace, intervalle', |Tawate| `il y a de la place', |Tawatina| `gorge de montagne, espace entre deux montagnes', |Tatawipo| `il neige par intervalles' ...    Cq.386ab.
Cree |tawâw| II `It has an opening', |tawatinâw| `A gap between hills', |tawikahwew| TA `S/he cuts it to make a clearing' ...    Alb.E.204ab.
Delaware [del] |Tauwiechen| `open', |Tauwinachgechi| `open arms', |Tauwiquoakan| `key', |Tauwunummen| `to open'; |tawáxun| II `be blown open by the wind', |tawíikwam| TI `unlock s.t.', |tawúneew| TA `to open s.t. animate' ...    B&A.139; O'M.310b-311b.
Fox |tawa∙wi| `it is an opening', |tawa∙hiwi| `it has an opening (dim.)' |tawenike∙wa| `he clears things away'    Fx.L.163.
Ill. {r} |ta8a, ta8i| `breche, ouverture, separa[ti]on, ou autre chose semblable' ...    G.540-541/306a-307a.
Menominee [mez] |tawa∙hε∙w|, TA, |tawa∙ham| TI `he makes a hole in him, it by tool' ...    M.L.251.
Ojibwe [oji] |tawi:pin| TA `move s.o. over; make room for s.o.'; |dwaabded| AI `have teeth missing', |dwaahged| TI `make a hole in the ice'    P&G.164; Rh.121ab.
Shawnee [sjw] |taw-| `OPEN', |tawaawi| `it is open, it is a space', |ke?tawena| `you must open it'    D.-V.142.

Note also:
[?Abn. |netañ8"dé`t8n ... krañgan, 3. ap.| `Je l'ouvre, la porte, v.g.', |tétañ8aragat, pls. -gakir| `Trou dans le bois, à la cabane, &c.'; |tañ8détté| `Il ou celà est ouvert', |tañ8denañs8, -n8añn, -nemassin| `Ouvrir'    R.488/538b; A.386.
Cree |tâwaskâw| `A path or gap in the tall grass', |tâwatiw| AI `S/he opened her/his mouth wide, s/he yawned'    Alb.E. 206b-207a.
[Menominee [mez] |ta∙wanεw| AI `he holds his mouth open, he gapes'    M.L.252.]
Ojibwe [oji] |ta:wani| `open one's mouth'; |daawnid| AI `open one's mouth, have one's mouth open'    P&G.159; Rh.101b.]

\et H.3259-3267 *taw- `open', with a broad range of finals; S. no. 250, 408-409, H.3141: *ta∙waΘ- `yawn, gape'. The difference in vowel length demands an account. In addition there is the form |adtauwunusik| `breach', Ps.106.23(E) (not (M)), with the changed form found otherwise with PA *te∙wa `exist'--presumably erroneous, not attested elsewhere.

    \nt +

\lx teâg
\va teag
\va teaug
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
\ps as n. / NI
\ge `thing, object (chose)'

    |ne teag ... matta teag|, or |matteag| `something ... nothing'    Lk.22.35; Prov.9.13
    \xv ne teag peyasik
    \xe a very little thing
    \so (suppos.)    Is.40.15

\et G.1981, 39, 76; H.972 *ke∙kw- NI `something'


\lx teaguas
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
\ps n. / NI, indefinite pronoun
\ge `things, matters, which are not tangible or material'; +`what' (interrogative)
\nt G&B.509, 714, with collection of variant spellings
\so Is.42.9
    \xv ..., teaguas kittinninnúmah...
    \xe ..., what wilt thou give me,...?...
    \so Gen.15.2
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne ne teaguas ut nashauwe nen kah ken?...
    \xe ..., what is that betwixt me and thee?...
    \so Gen.23.15
    \nt +
    pl. |-assinish|
    \xv ne teaguas
    \xe something
    `something spoken'    Lk.11.54

    \se tanteaguassinash
    \va teahteaquassinash
    \nt +
    \va teanteaquashinish
    \va -gqu-
    \ps Augm. / NI ?plurale tantum, with strong reduplication
    \ge `things'
    \so Gen.24.1; Prov.26.10; Is.44.24

\nt The primary signification of |teâg| seems to be `property, possession, something had':
    \xv ne ohtunk
    \xe what he hath
    \xv ne ohtog
    \xe what is
    \so (se habet)
\cf ohtauunát
\cf ohtuk

[Narragansett [xnt] |teáqua| `what is this?'; |teaqua naúntick ewò| `what comes he for?'; |téaqua cun-nàtinne| `what look you for?'; |teàg yo augwháttick| `what hangs there?'; |nit-teauguash| `my money'    R.W.]

\lx teagunninn∞

    \xe There is nothing from without a man, that entering into him can defile him:...
    \so Mk.7.15
    \ng 0 negative indicative
    \xv ... newutche yeush negonne mos nniyeuash, qut wohkukquohshik matta teagunnán∞.
    \xe ...: for these things must first come to pass; but the end is not by and by.
    \so Lk.21.9
    \ng 0 negative indicative

\lx teahsh-
\va teash-
\va teáhsh-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
    \nt +
\nt Remark: On etymological grounds the vowel is to be taken to be |-á-|. It is not clear whether this is merely homophonous with the initial in words for family and related social groupings or a member of the same family of words. This initial also appears to be used in the same way as |tahsh-| in number expressions, as in the examples given below.
\ps initial, relative root(?)
\ge `how many, how much', indefinite-interrogative of quantity; syntactic/semantic relationship to |tahsh-| not determined.
\so Entries that follow.
    \xv Paguodche matta wutappeineau napannatahsuog sampwesecheg, neh woh napanna wutteashinehchagsinneau,...
    \xe Peradventure there shall lack five of the fifty righteous:...
    \so Gen.18.28
    \xv ..., kah wutchekitteauau Jakoboh napanna wutteáshompaneaont:
    \xe ..., and [she] bare Jacob the fifth son.
    \so Gen.30.17
    \xv ..., newutche nequtta nutteashompaégitteau,...
    \xe ..., because I have borne him six sons,...'    Gen.30.20 (c.f. |nequtta tahshu wunnaumonuh| `the sixth son
    \so , Gen.30.19)
    \xv Kah Pharaoh unnau Jakoboh kitteashequinne kodtumwae kuppomantam∞onk?
    \xe And Pharaoh said unto Jacob, How old art thou?
    \so Gen.47.8
    \xv ..., nó pajeh nequtta wutteashinehchage kodtumwohkomunat, ne pish nnih k∞n∞whaonk, napanna tahshinchagkodtash silvere shekelsash,...
    \xe ... even unto sixty years old, even thy estimation shall be fifty shekels of silver,...
    \so Lev.27.3
    \xv ..., ut nabo napanna wutteashikqunhomunat negonne nepauz:...
    \xe ..., on the fifteenth day of the first month;...
    \so Num.33.3

    \xv ..., Kutteáhshohtómw∞ petukqunnégash? ...
    \xe ..., How many loaves have ye? ...
    \so Mk.6.38

    \se teahshe
    \va teahsheu
    \ps PreV
    \ge `as much, so much'
    \so Lk.6.34,19.15
    \xv ...? newutche matcheseáenuog namohkeiheaog matcheseaeneuh, woh wutteasheu wonk attumunumunneau.
    \xe ...? for sinners also lend to sinners, to receive as much again.
    \so Lk.6.34
    \ng 3->0 subordinative
    \xv ..., onk woh wahteóu toh wutteashe nishnoh wosketomp aneukomauon nashpe anaqushaonk.
    \xe ..., that he might know how much every man had gained by trading.
    \so Lk.19.15
    \ng 3->0 subordinative

[Western Abenaki [abe] |kekéssigadémena8a| `Quel âge as tu?', |késsen8rna8a?| v. |késsen8ar késsen8gar.| `C'bien y a-t-il de ces choses?', |Késseta| `c'bien de fois'    R.15/380b,118/415a,P.20/555a.
F. |ke∙swi| `how many'    Fx.L.67.
K. |keeΘi-| AI, |keeΘen-| II `be how much?, be how many?'    V.39.
Delaware [del] |kéexu| PC `amount', |keexéeli| PC `several'    O'M.82a; also B&A.52.
M.-P. |kehsi| (|kehs-|, |kes-|) PV `X much, X many'    LeS.24a,151b.
Virg. |Keis.| `how manie'    S.(Bod.).8a.
Narragansett [xnt] |Cutchashematítin?|, `How many brothers have you?', |Chashecautúmmo cuttáppemus?| `How many yeeres since you were borne?', |Cutchashekeâmis?| `How many children have you had?', |Cutchashineánna?| `How many have you kild'    R.W.29,66,140/r.148,164/r.172.
WAbn. |gassi| PT `so many', |gagasi| PT `as many as, as much as'    D.1.182-183,174; also |gass-| `together with', ib.XXXVIII, 182-183.]

\et G.1981, 40, 82: *ke∙hΘ- `how many, so many' (no evidence cited).


\lx teahshinunneu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv |teahsh-| ?`how many' + ?|-ininü-| `man' + |-i-| predicative final
\nt Remark: Syncope is confirmed by the |-inunn-| and |-inninn-| (C.) of the nominal derivative.
\ge "to be so many people", as participle, `family'
\so Gen.10.18,20

    \xv ...: kah ompetak neadtahshinnehettit Kananitog naswaeog.
    \xe ...: and afterward were the families of the Canaanites spread abroad.
    \so Gen.10.18
    \ng 3p->_adv_ participle, syncopated


\lx teahshinunneong
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
    \nt +
\ps NI, deverbal noun to ?!|teahshinunneu|.
\ge `family'
\so Gen.10.5; Ex.6.24
    \xv ... nishnoh neaunag wutteashshinnunneongan∞ wutohtuout.
    \xe ... [every one] after their families, in their nations.
    \so Gen.10.5
    \ng 3p possessor
    \nt +
    \xv ...: yeush wutteateashinnúnneongash Ukkorite.
    \xe ...: these are the families of the Korhites.
    \so Ex.6.24
    \ng 3 possessor 0p, reduplicated
    \nt +


\lx teahshaiyeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv |teáhsh-| + ?|ayi-| AI `to be (somewhere)'
\ge `to be a family, fellowship' (?)
\so Gen.10.31; Acts 2.42
    \xv Yeuh wunnaumonuh Shem, nishnoh wutteahshaiyeuunneau, ne unnont∞wahettit, wutohtuout, wutohtìmoeuwout.
    \xe These are the sons of Shem, after their families, after their tongues, in their lands, after their nations.
    \so Gen.10.31
    \xv Kah ummenuhkénumunneau ukkuhk∞tomuhteaongan∞ Apostlesog, kah wutteahshaiyeuunneau; sohqunnumwog petukqunneg {moeu}, kah {moeu} peantamwog.
    \xe And they continued stedfastly in the apostles' doctrine and fellowship, and in breaking of bread, and in prayers.
    \so Acts 2.42

[See above, s.v. |teahsh-|; the following may also be relevant:
Western Abenaki [abe] |késsi| `ensemble', |késs8ssañn| `Compagnie, pour le marcher'     A.222,125.
WAbn. |gassi| PT,AI `(be) together with', |gassinoak| `they live together', |gassigao| `he sleeps with someone', |gassowiak| `they are together'    D.1.182-183.]


\lx teashiyeuonk
\va teateash-
\va teahteahshaiyeuong
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
    \nt Remark: The initial syllable in the second form is perhaps a rare form of reduplication in |-á-|. It is unlikely to be the fugitive vowel of the relative root |tahsh-| because that root appears as <-dtahsh-> in the changed form, and the persistent spelling |-eash-| would remain unaccounted for. (Cf. !|tahshinunneu|; and on the reduplication: Men. |neta∙htahsemenaw| `we are so many', M.L.247, to that other initial.)
    \nt +
\ps vbl.n. / NI
    \dv verbal noun to !|teahshaiyeu|
    \nt +
\ge `a family'
\so Deut.29.18; Jer.33.24, +Gen.10.32; Num.3.20; Ruth 2.1; ...
    \xv Yeush wutteahteashaiyeuongan∞ wunnaumonuh Noah,...
    \xe These {are} the families of the sonnes of Noah,...
    \so Gen.10.32
    \ng 3p possessor, reduplicated
    (|Chashiyeüonk| `A family', |Kutteashinnu@nnëonk.| `Your family'    C.12/161.)

\lx tióhqui
\va tiuhque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 161
\ps II
\ge `it is short'
\ps adv. and adj.
\ge `short'; +including intervals of time
\so Num.11.23; Ps.89.47; Rom.9.28; +Rev.12.12
    (|nuttiohquem| `in short', i.e. `I am brief, I will speak briefly'    C.)

    \se tiohqussu
    \ps V.adj. an. / AI
    \ge `he is short, of low stature'

    \se tiohquehtéau
    \ps V.caus. inan. / TI2
    \ge `he shortens (it), makes (it) short'

    \xv kuttiohquehteôh
    \xe thou makest (it) short to him
    \so Ps.89.45
    \ng TA+O ?

    \se !|tiukqussum|
    \nt +
    \ps TI1b
    \ge `to cut s.t. short'
    \xv Newutch noh pish pakodchteau usseonk & wuttiukqussumun en sampweusseonganit, newutche tiuhque usseonk pish ussu GOD muttaohkit.
    \xe For he will finish the work, and cut it short in righteousness: because a short work will the Lord make upon the earth.
    \so Rom.9.28

[Narragansett [xnt] |tiaquónqussu| `he is short'    R.W.60.
Quiripi [qyp] |taíoquíah| `is short (of life)'    Pier.39.
Western Abenaki [abe] |taák8éss8| `il est court'; |ta8a`k8ât| `cela est court'.
Delaware [del] |taquetto| (adv.) `short'    Zeisb.
Lp.A |taik8as8| `Court'; |taik8 kizigat.| `Jour court.'; |kitaik8i pemantam8men. `Notre vie est courte.'    M.47,48.]

\lx togkodtam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 162
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\ge `he strikes (it) with a stick or some implement'
\so Ex.7.20; Num.20.11

    \nt MN: noh togkodtog
    \ng suppositive |noh togkodtog| `he who strikes' (`he when striking')    Is.41.7; Ezek.7.9

    \se tohtogkodtam
    \va tattagk-
    \ps Freq. / TI1a
    \ge `he strikes repeatedly, beats (it)'

    \nt MN: noh tohtogkodtog
    \ng suppositive |noh tohtogkodtog| `he who beats (it)'    1 Cor.9.26

    \se togkodtuonk
    \ps Vbl.n.
    \ge `a blow, a striking'
    \so Ex.21.25

    \se todtogkodtuonk
    \va tatogk-
    \ps Vbl.n. freq.
    \ge `a beating'
    \so Deut.17.8; 21.5
    (pl. |tattagkodtuongash| `stripes'    Ind.Laws)

    \se togkomau
    \ps With an.obj. / TA
    \ge `he strikes (him)', +`to slay, smite sb'
    \xv Kah wuttogkomouh wosketompuh pogkenumoonk ...
    \xe And they smote the men ... with blindness,...'    Gen.19.11  { 3p->3
    \so }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., paguodche woh nuttapenum nag nuttogkomononaóont,...
    \xe ...: peradventure I shall prevail, that we may smite them,...
    \so Num.22.6
    \ng 1p->3p t-subordinative; apparently both plurals marked, with abbreviated |-uná-| (c.f. G&B 543)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah Balaam togkomau assoh ukquinnuppunnonat en mayut.
    \xe ...: and Balaam smote the ass, to turn her into the way.
    \so Num.22.23
    \nt +

    \nt MN: noh togkomont
    \ng suppositive |noh togkomont| `he who strikes or may strike'    Ex.21.12,15
    \xv ..., Toh kittinhesh waj nishwudt nompe togkomean?
    \xe ..., What have I done unto thee, that thou hast smitten me these three times?
    \so Num.22.28
    \ng 2->1
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ∞wesuonk Israelle wosketomp, noh togkomut, noh weeche togkomomukkup Mideanite mittamwossis Zimrì,...
    \xe Now the name of the Israelite that was slain, even that was slain with the Midianitish woman, was Zimri,...
    \so Num.25.14
    \ng |-ut|: X->3; the analysis of <-omukk-> is not quite clear, as it may contain a syncopated vowel concealing the structure |-om-Vm-ômuk-|, where the second |-m-| belongs to the final normally induced by consociative |weeche| and the third to the alternative TA X subject inflection |-ômuk|. The forms in 25.15,18 look identical, but lack |weeche|.
    \nt +

    \se |togkomwaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O?), causative to |togkomau|
    \ge `to cause sb to be beaten, smitten'
    \so Deut.25.2,28.7
    \xv Jehovah pish togkomwaheau anaquabean kummatwomoh,...
    \xe The Lord shall cause thine enemies ... to be smitten before thy face:...
    \so Deut.28.7

    \se tattagkomau
    \ps freq. / TA
    \ge `he beats him'

    \se togkom∞waonk
    \ps act. vbl.n.
    \ge `a blow given'
    \so Ps.39.10

    \se togkomitteaonk
    \ps pass. vbl.n.
    \ge `a blow received, a being-struck'
    \so Job 23.2
\cf togku

    [Lp.A |nitak8ans 3e s8| `je pile'    D.90, (different reading: 93).]
    \nt +

\et S., no. 228, 397-399; H.3201: *takw- `pound fine, bray, beat to a powder'


\lx togkodteg
\va togkodteg
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 162
\ps n. / NI
    \dv |-ëkan-|, to stem |togodt-| (G&B., no.4, 578; cf. B.1962, 14.65-66, 236-238)
    \nt +
\ge `a sword' (`a striking instrument')
\so Lev.26.6; 1 Sam.17.45
    pl. |-egash|, |-eganash|    Ps.59.7
\dv |togkodtam|.
(Cf. Sansk. tug', ferire, vulnerare, tremere; tad., pulsare, ferire; tat., percutere, ferire. Hib. tathaim, I kill; tathog, `a slap'. Cf. Lat. tignum, with Ind. n. gen. -uhtug, wood, a beam, a stick.)

[Narragansett [xnt] |n'tatakcóm-muckqun ewò| `he struck (beat) me'    R.W.148.
Western Abenaki [abe] |neda`kh8âmen| `je pile' (quelque chose); |nedagamañ| `je l bats' (v.g. lapide); |netaghé`t8n| `je frappe avec cela'.

\lx togkogku
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 162

\so of the progress of pestilence    2 Sam.24.5
    \xv nuttogkögkem
    \xe I stop
    \so C.
    \ng AI

    \se togkogqshau
    \ps II
    \ge `it was stopped, stayed'
    \so Num.16.48,50
    \xv Kah noh neepau nashaue napunutche kah pamontamunutcheh, kah enninneaonk togkogqshau.
    \xe And he stood between the dead and the living; and the plague was stayed.
    \so Num.16.48
    \nt +
    \dv With |ksh|, characteristic of sudden or violent action
    \xv Kah petutteahettit kuht∞nogqut, waban togkogshau.
    \xe And when they were come into the ship, the wind ceased.
    \so Mt.14.32
    \nt +
    = |togkogqushom∞| (pass. form)    Num.25.8
    = |ontappu|    Ps.106.30
\cf togkushin

\lx togkuppinau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 162
\ps v.t.an. / TA, manual final
\ge `he holds (him) fast by bonds'; +`to bind sb'
\so Judg.15.10 (infin.)
    \xv ..., togkuppinnonat Sampson n∞che peyoumun,...
    \xe ..., To bind Sampson are we come up,...
    \so Judg.15.10
    \nt +

    \se tohtogk-
    \va tattagk-
    \va tahtogkuppunau
    \nt +
    \ps Augm. and intens. / TA, reduplicated
    \ge `to bind sb'
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah tahtogkuppunau Isaakoh wunnaumonuh,...
    \xe ..., and [he] bound Isaac his son,...'    Gen.22.9  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv wutohtogkuppinouh
    \xe they bound him
    \so Judg.15.13
    \xv ..., newutche wutahtagkuppinuh.
    \xe ..., and because he had bound him.'    Acts 22.29  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +

    suppos. part. |Asuh toh woh wuttin petukon menuhkoshketomp wekit? kah matchehtinneat ummaumachiash, kuttuma negonne tohtogkuppinont menuhkoshketompuh,...| `Or else, how can one enter into a strong man's house, and spoil his goods, except he first bind the strong man? ...'    Mt.12.29
    \xv Kah n∞woskhé∞g yeu nogqueuyeuitcheg en nupp∞wonganit, tahtagkuppinnúgquean, kah kopshagquinnukquean wosketompaog kah mittamwossissog.
    \xe And I persecuted this way unto the death, binding and delivering into prisons both men and women.
    \so Acts 22.4
    \ng 3->1 [sic!]
    \nt +

    \xv ..., Tohtagkuppinók wunnutcheganit kah wusseetit, kah amaunòk ...
    \xe ..., Bind him hand and foot, and take him away,...
    \so Mt.22.13
    \nt +

    \se togkuppinauau
    \ps Double trans. / TA+O (O being animate)
    \ge `he binds (him) fast to (him)'

    \se |togkuppissu|, and reduplicated
    \nt +
    \ps AI
    \ge `to be bound' (stative)
    \so Mk.5.4; Acts 28.20
    \xv ..., newutche, wutch wutannoausuonk Israel, yeu nutahtagkupsin sasasagkinnittum∞ug,
    \xe ...: because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
    \so Acts 28.20

    \xv Newutche m∞chekit nompe tohtogkuppissit, nashpe tahtogkuppiss∞unash,...
    \xe Because that he had been often bound with fetters ...
    \so Mk.5.4

    \se !|togkuppissuonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `bond'
    \xv ..., qut pannuppu ogqunneungqusséog nuhhogkad, qut matta yeush tahtágkuppissuonganash.
    \xe ..., and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.
    \so Acts 26.29

    \se !|tohtogkuppissuenu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, verb of being to agent noun
    \ge `to be bond', i.e. "to be (one that is) bound, a bondsman or bondswoman, a slave" (OED, s.v., sb., 2,3 or adj. 1; the association with "bind" is by folk etymology)
    \xv Na matta Jewunn∞ asuh Greekunn∞, na matta tohtogkuppissuénuunn∞, asuh chippinnúunn∞, na matta wosketomp kah mittamwossis,...
    \xe There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither bond nor free, there is neither male nor female: ...
    \so Gal.3.28
    \ng verb of being acts as II in existential, hence |-un-| inthe negative

\dv |tohqunau| `he holds fast'; with the characteristic of binding or tying (|-pi|).

[Cree |táhkoop-íssoo| `he is tied up'; |-ittáyoo| `it is tied up' (|iáppee| `a line or cord').
Chip. (suppos.) |tahkoobezood| `bound fast'    Jn.11.44.]

\lx togkussittassun
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 162
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `he stumbles'
\so Jn.11.10
    pl. |-unwog| `they stumble'    Rom.11.11
    (|nut-togkissitassin| `I stumble'    C.)
\dv |togkushin| and |m'seet| (|musseet|) `the foot'.

    \ge `be offended' (Vlg. scandalizari)
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wuttogkussittassom∞unòuh,...
    \xe And they were offended in him.
    \so (et scandalizabantur in eo.)    Mt.13.57
    \xv YEush kuttinnonnaopash onk matta woh kuttokussittassun∞mw∞.
    \xe These things have I spoken unto you, that ye should not be offended.
    \so (haec locutus sum vobis ut non scandalizemini)    Jn.16.1

    \xv Wame wosketompaog togkussittassunéhettit newutche ken, nen matta nuttogkussittassun∞h.
    \xe Though all men shall be offended because of thee, yet will I never be offended.
    \so (Et si omnes scandalizati fuerint in te, ego numquam scandalizabor.)    Mt.26.33

\lx toh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 163
    \nt Remark: It is difficult to separate this material from that placed in the following lemma by Trumbull, so I have augmented this one, as an interim measure. It is also unclear whether any clear distinction from |uttoh| can be drawn at present.
    \nt +
    \ps particle; pronoun, nominal and adverbial, interrogative and indefinite/generalizing; commonly collocated with |woh|.
    \nt +
\ge `adv. of doubting'; +pronominal/adverbial indefinite/generalizing particle: `how, what, why,...; anything' (perhaps as a negative polarity item)
    \nt G&B.716: toh 'maybe, perhaps, may, (who)ever, (what)ever, (how)ever' P; C.33/177
    \nt +
\so El.Gr.22
    `it may be'
\ge `of wishing'; used as an annex `to every person and variation in the optative mood', signifying `O that it were!' (utinam) ; `would that'
\so El.Gr.34,65
    "Of Wishing. |Woi|, |Napehnont|, {Oh that it were}, |Toh|."    El.Gr.21/268
    \nt +
    "Of Doubting. |Pagwodche|, {It may be}. |Toh|, {It may be}."    El.Gr.22/268
    \nt +
    "This Adverb (|toh|) or (|napehnont|) properly signifieth (|utinam|) {I wish it were}."    El.Gr.34/281
    \nt +
    \xv n∞waadchanun toh
    \xe I wish I keep him
\ge with the suppos. mood, `in what manner, how'
    \xv ahqueteau∞k toh n∞tamóg
    \xe take heed how you hear
    \so Mk.4.24
    \xv ..., toh weekeneaman n∞weenohkeinonit posekin kenup∞m:...
    \xe ..., in the choice of our sepulchres bury thy dead;...
    \so Gen.23.6
    \ng perhaps "whatever pleases you"?
    \xv ..., Jehovah toh ânukque ne nussin.
    \xe ..., what the LORD saith unto me, that will I speak.
    \so 1 K.22.14√

    \xv ..., kah nunnaum toh wuttin usseneau neyan∞wómuk,...
    \xe ..., and [I shall] see whether they haue done altogether according to the cry of it,...
    \so Gen.18.21
    \ng interrogative
    \nt +
    \xv ... newutche matta woh toh nutussúh, toh woh na kuppeam,...
    \xe ...: for I cannot do any thing till thou be come thither:...
    \so Gen.19.22
    \ng the second token, glossed "till" (E0), apparently a temporal use?
    \nt +
    \xv ..., asuh matta woh toh ut ne Jehovah num-Manitt∞mun ne quohtinukqueog.
    \xe ..., nor unto whatsoever the Lord our God forbad us.
    \so Deut.2.37
    \ng with locative particle
    \nt +
    \xv Yeuoh wosketomp matta wutaumáseik Godut, matta woh toh ussu.
    \xe If this man were not of God, he could do nothing.
    \so Jn.9.33
    \nt +

\cf uttoh

[Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |taugh|, |taukh|    Edw. and Prayers, I,6,7.]


\lx toh
\va tohhen
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 163
\ps interrog. particle
\ge `how? where? what?'
\nt It supplies the place of the interrog. pronoun, inanimate, as |howan| [|éwo-un|], `who?', does that of the animate. In some dialects, for example the Cree, |tohhen| or its representative has sing. and pl. an. and inan. forms; but as used by Eliot, it is indeclinable.
\cf tohneit
\cf tohnoh
\cf tohwutch
    \xv Kah toh woh hen kuhk∞tomúhkon, matta an∞nittumuk?...
    \xe And how shall they preach, except they be sent?...
    \so Rom.10.15
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |tou wuttîin| `where lives he?'; |tuckowêkin| [|toh kowêkin|] `where dwell you?'; |tahéna| [|toh hennou|] `"what is his name", how is he called?'; |tahéttamen| [|toh hettamun|] `"what call you this", how is it called?'
Western Abenaki [abe] |tañni aiañian| quo vadis?; |tañni 8e`man| unde venis?; |arenañbes tañni| `combien d'hommes!'; |tañna| `quiconque'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |dò| "note interrogative, comme num, ou ne, en latin"; interrog. pron. (an.) |tän|, pl. |tanik|; (pret.) |tanak|, pl. |tannkik| `celui que'; (inan.) |tän|, pl. |tänel|; (pret.) |tänel|, pl. |tännkel| `ce que'; "|tän| est aussi adverbe de temps, et signifie quand"; "est encore adverbe de lieu, et signifie où, en quel lieu, en ce lieu"    Maill.
Cree |tàna@|, interrog. pro. an. `which'; pl. |tàn-ánekee|; inan. |tàn-emah|, pl. |tàn-ánehee|    Howse 189 (but in the examples, p. 280, the inflections are transferred to the verb or verbal to which |tàn| is prefixed, its use corresponding with that of |toh| (indecl.), by Eliot).
Delaware [del] |ta|, |tani| `where?'    Zeisb.]


\lx tohkaeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 163
\ps adv.
\ge `in cold weather'
\so Prov.25.20
\cf tohkoi


\lx tohkekom
\va tohkoi-'k-∞m∞
\va tohkekom
\ve =  `it comes cool'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 163
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a spring (of water), a fountain'
\so Lev.11.36; +Gen.7.11,8.2
    |... ut kishke tohkekomuut touohkomukqut,...| `... by a fountain of
    \nt +
water, in the wilderness,...' Gen.16.7  { locative }
    \xv ..., kah ut tohkekommútu,...
    \xe ..., and in the springs,...
    \so Josh.12.8
    \ng 2nd locative
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah wonk aninnumah tohkekommupóg, kah wuttinnumauoh kuhkuhque tohkekommuash, kah agwee tohkekomuash.
    \xe ...; give me also springs of water. And he gave her the upper springs, and the nether springs.
    \so Josh.15.19
    \xv ... netatuppe wanné tohkekom m∞skemun∞ naneeswe séippog kah nunnippog.
    \xe ...? so can no fountain both yield salt water and fresh.
    \so Jas.4.12
    \nt +

    \se -kommue
    \ps Adj. and adv.
    \ge `of fountains'
    \so Cant.4.15; Neh.3.15

    \xv tohkekomeupog
    \xe running water', |tohkekommupóg| `springs of water
    \so (|-pog|)    Num.19.17√; Josh.15.19

[Western Abenaki [abe] |tekebi| `eau froide'; |tekepíghe| `fontaine'.
Cree |tàke-gúmu| `cold-liquid-is-it'; `it is cold' (?).

\lx tohkequn
\va tuhkekun
\va tuhkéquan
\va tuhkequan
\va tuhkequn
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 163
\ps v.i. / II
\ge `it is heavy'; +in measure predications: `the weight (thereof) be (such) ...'; transferred: `sore', of eyes `dim' (Gen.48.10, calqued on Hebrew)
\so Prov.27.3; Job 6.3,23.2
    \xv ..., newutché mahshagquot tuhkequn ohkeit Kanaan,...
    \xe ...; for the famine is sore in the land of Canaan:...
    \so Gen.47.4
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ummag∞onk, pasuk silvere wunnonk, nequt pasuk∞e kah nishwinchag shekelse unne tuhkéquan,...
    \xe And his offering was one silver charger, the weight thereof was an hundred and thirty shekels,...
    \so Num.7.13,...
    \nt +
    \xv Qussuk tohkequn, kah nagunt tohkequn qut mattamog m∞squanum anue tuhkequan onk nish naneeswe.
    \xe A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool's wrath is heavier than them both.
    \so Prov.27.3√
    \nt +
    pl. |Newutche wuss∞anehteâog tuhkequnash weánunash wussauunukqunaoash,...| `For they bind heavy burdens and grievous to be borne,...'    Mt.23.4√
    \xv tukkekhukqunash
    \xe they are heavy (for me)
    \so Ps.38.4
    \xv ..., wame silvere wishquash, neese muttannungane, kah yauut pasuk∞e shekelse unnuttuhkequnash,...
    \xe ...: all the silver vessels weighed two thousand and four hundred shekels,...
    \so Num.7.85√
    \ng numerical value in a preverb, with cross-reference through relative root (initial or preverb) i.e. number ... thus^heavy; numerical expression as preverb often found without relative root

    \nt MN: ...: onatuh tuhkequog weanin, naish wussaume tuhkekhukqunash.
    \ng suppositive |...: onatuh tuhkequog weanin, naish wussaume tuhkekhukqunash.| `...: as an heavy burden they are too heavy for me.'    Ps.38.4√; (M): |...: onatuh tahkequog weanun wussaume tuhkequanuash wutche neen.|
    \xv ne tuhkequok
    \xe the weight of it
    \so 1 K.10.14

    \se unuttuhkequane
    \ps adj., adv.
    \ge `by weight, of the weight of'

[Narragansett [xnt] |Qussúcqun-náukon| `Heavie, light.'; |Kuckqússuckqun| `You are heavy.'    R.W.44;73.√

\lx tohkoi

    \xe the cold of snow

    (|Mooche@ke tohkoi yeu kesukod.| `It is very cold to day.    C.118/239.    { 0 indicative })

    suppos. (concrete) |tohkag| `when it is cold'    Job 24.7  { 0->_adv_ participle }
    pl. |-gish|    Nah.3.17

\dv The primary signification is, perhaps, `congealed, stiffened, or made hard, solid (by cold)'.

\ge it congeals, it freezes
\so (Narr. )

\cf togkogku
\ge it is stopped, obstructed
\so *, and with these

    \xv Woi God, tohsohkee pish matwau ushpunnamuau?...

\cf nisohke


\lx tohshinum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 164
\cf tahshinum


\lx tohsú
\va tohshéu
\va tahsu
\va tohsu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 164
\ps adj. or, as Eliot classes it, a `distributive pronoun signifying how much' / AI, relative root. (Trumbull includes prenoun and preverb forms in |-e| here.)
\twn |tahshin|, II
    \ge `as many as'; participle used to translate "company, host" (e.g. Gen.2.1, Num.16.5; examples at e.g. Num.16.11, Deut.1.11, Gal.3.27 make unambiguously clear what is the subject of the verb.)
    \nt +
    pl. |tohsuog|, |tohsunash| `how many'    El.Gr.8
    Elsewhere (p. 14) he gives "|tohsú|, or |tahshe|, which is varied [in the pl.] |tohsúog|, |tohsúash|, or |tohshinash|", as an `additional' or `word suppletive, which signifieth nothing' added to the numerals from 5 to 9 (inclusive), and `which receiveth the grammatical variation of the things numbered, animate or inanimate':
    \xv napanna tahshe
    \xe five
    an.pl. |napanna tohsuog|
    inan.pl. |napanna tohsuash| [or |tahshinash|]
    \xv yeu tohsheu
    \xe for so much?
    \xv nux, ne tohsheu
    \xe yes, for so much
    \so Acts 5.8
    \xv wunneese tahshe
    \xe twice as much
    \so Job 42.10
    \xv nequt pasukwe tahshee
    \xe a hundredfold (times so much)
    \so Lk.8.8
    (|tohshe| `so much'; |ne tohshit| `so often, so many times'    C.)
    pl. an. |tohsuog| `how many (persons')
    inan. |tohshinash|, |tahshinash|, |tohsúash| `how many (things)'

    suppos. inan. |..., noh wohwohtog, ógketaj ne adtahsik puppinashim: newutche wutteas∞∞onk wosketomp, kah wutteas∞∞onk ne, nequtta tahshe pasuk, nequtta tahshinchag kah nequtta.| `.... Let him that hath understanding count the number of the beast: for it is the number of a man; and his number is Six hundred threescore and six.'    Rev.13.18 { AI verb to be expected with NA subject |puppinashim|? Perhaps the syntax, with demonstrative link |ne|, could be comparable to "what numbers the beast", with II+O (or substantive attribution?) construction, as _0_->3 participle? }
    \xv ..., kah wame ne adtahsehettit.
    \xe ..., and all the host of them.
    \so Gen.2.1
    \ng 3p->_adv_ participle, cf. (E0) "all that there was in them"
    \nt +
    \xv ... nesausuk audtahsuit nepauz, na(b)o n(e)sausuk audtahshikquinahog nepauz,...
    \xe ... in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month,...
    \so Gen.8.4
    \ng 3->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ken∞nau Korahoh kah wame ne adtahs∞it,...
    \xe And he spake unto Korah and unto all his company,...
    \so Num.16.5
    \ng 3->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Ne waj ken wame ne adttahs∞wean, áyeuuhkonittue mukkinehtauadt Jehovah:...
    \xe For which cause both thou and all thy company are gathered together against the LORD:...
    \so Num.16.11
    \ng 2->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Jehovah um Manitt∞moh k∞sh∞woog muttannonganahuk∞k m∞cheke onk mahche neadtahsuóg,...
    \xe The LORD God of your fathers make you a thousand times so many more as ye are,...
    \so Deut.1.11
    \ng 2p->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    (|Kah Joab aninnumauau David ne âudtahsinit missinninnuh,...| `And Joab gave the sum of the number of the people unto David. ...'    1 Chr.21.5√)    { 3'->_adv_ participle }

    suppos. an.pl. |ne adtahshehettit| `they being (when they were) so many, as many of them as'    Judg.3.1; 1 Tim.6.1

    |ne adtahshe|, |ne ahhut tahshe|, `[that which is to or at so many] so many as, the sum of'    2 Sam.2.23; Mk.6.56; 2 K.4.8

    \se |teas∞∞onk(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, action noun to |tahsu-| AI?
    \ge `number'
    \so Deut.32.8; Rev.13.18 (v.s.)
    \xv ..., wunohtau∞p missinninnuog ukkuhkhonkan∞∞ash, neaunag wutteas∞∞ongan∞ wunnaumonuh Israel,
    \xe ..., he set the bounds of the people according to the number of the children of Israel.
    \so Deut.32.8

\nt As a `suppletive' to the numerals from 5 to 10, the signification of |tahshe| (|tohsú|) is obscure, though Eliot was certainly wrong in supposing it without significance. It may not improbably be related to |tahshin| `he lifts himself, raises up', and |tahshinum| `he holds up or raises (his hand or something in his hand)'.  With an inan. subj. |tahshin| becomes |tahsheu| `it lifts, or is lifted up'.
    The Algonquian system of numbers was quinary, and borrowed doubtless from the fingers of the hand. At five (|napanna|, |nabo napanna|, or sometimes |napanna tahshe|), one hand was put up (|neep∞|, |neepauun| `stood upright'); at six, 5+1, one finger of the second hand was raised, |nequtta tahshe|, and so on.

[Narragansett [xnt] |Tashin Commêsim?| `How much shall I give you?'    R.W.154/r.162√.
Western Abenaki [abe] |késs8akna8a|, ou |tañni késs8"ihidit| `combien sont ils?'; |késsen8rna8a|, ou |késsen8ar| `combien ... de ces choses?'; |ni aké`sinañ| `voilà tout, voilà toutes (des poires)'; |neg8^dañs| `six'; pl. an. |neg8dañskéss8ak|; inan. |-késsen8r|.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |tach| `combien?'; |tachigek| `combien sommes-nous?'; |tachigigik| `combien sont-ils?' etc. (comme un verbe) ; an.pl. |aj8gom dèchigik| `six'; |dèch| `s'emploie ordinairement après les nombres 6,7,8,9,10,100,1000, etc'.
Cree "from |táhto| `number' [fn. om.] are formed |Ittússuuk| (intran.anim.), `they are, or they number, so many.'; |Ittáhtinwah| (id. inan.), idem.", etc.; |Nickoot-wâss'ik| `Six.'.    Hws.29,308.√
Delaware [del] |tschitsch| `more, again'; |ta tchen| `how much?'    Zeisb.]

\et Compare H.3183 tah⌠iwa AI `so many', 3186 *tahΘenwi II `so many', acting as quantificational predicates, though the gender correspondences are not yet clear to me; also G.1981, 26, 66.

\lx tomogkon
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 165
\ps v.i. / II(+O), instrumental object
\ge `it is flooded, there is a flood'; +`to flow with sth'
\ps As n. / NI, deverbal noun
\ge `a flood'
\so Gen.6.17; Job 22.16; Mt.7.25
    `the rising of water, flood tide'
    (|Nippe tâmogkon nuttamogkonehteamun.| `We flow, or did' [sic]
    \xv Tâmogkanehkönat.
    \xe To flow
    \so C.51/191.
    \xv Tomokkonnuooo.
    \xe Flowing
    \so C.91/220.
    |tommogkon|, |tommog| `flood'    Mass.Ps.)
    Pl. |wadchuash sogkodtunk tomogkonash| `the mountains flow with milk'    Joel 3.18

    \nt MN: tomogkog
    \ng Suppositive |tomogkog| `when it flows with, when there is a flood'    Ex.3.8
    \xv ... mahche tomogkog ...
    \xe ... after the flood, ...
    \so Gen.9.28
    \ng 0->_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ut ohkeit ne tamogok sogkdtunk kah hony,
    \xe ..., in the land that floweth with milk and honey.
    \so Deut.6.3
    \nt +

    \se |tomogkonne|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `flood'

\lx -tuk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 166
\ps n. / final, NI
\ge generic for `river'; found only in compound words
    \xv kishketuk
    \xe near to or by the river
    \so Ex.2.5; Ezek.47.6,7
    |nóahtuk| (|nóeu-tuk|) `the middle of the river'    Josh.12.2; 13.9,6
    \xv kehteihtukqut
    \xe at the great river
    \so Gen.15.18
    |keteihtequt Fuphrates| (sic) `the great river Euphrates'    Rev.16.12
    \nt +
    So
    |qunnitukut| (hodie, `Connecticut') `at the long river'
    |missituk| (`Mystic') `the great river', etc.
\dv It is a contraction, or perhaps the suppos. form, of a verb |tukk∞|, signifying `it waves, flows in waves, fluctuatus est'. The pl. |tukk∞og| is used by Eliot for `waves', Ps.65.7; 89.9; Mk.4.37, etc.
    (|keitoh wuttuk∞moh| `the sea whose waves', etc.    Is.51.15)
    Heckewelder confounds this word, which, for the Delaware, he writes |hittuck| and translates `a rapid stream', with |m'htuk| (|m'htug|, El.) `a tree', Hist. and Lit. Trans. Am. Philos. Soc. I, 61. |tukk∞| itself is either a derivative form or nearly related to the primary verb |togku| `he strikes'. It has apparently dropped an initial syllable, |ont|, the characteristic of involuntary motion or change of place (see |ontapinneát|), which syllable is restored to its derivatives:
    \xv kehtontukquog
    \xe the mighty waves
    \so Ps.93.4
    |mishontuk∞e kehtohhanit| to "the troubled [great-waved] sea"'    Is.57.20
    \xv kehtahhanontuk
    \xe a wave of the sea
    \so James 1.6
    \xv ketahhannuppog tuk∞∞∞gk
    \xe the waters of the sea (when they) are troubled
    \so Ps.46.3
\cf sepu

[Western Abenaki [abe] |teg8, teg8"'ak| `flot'; |kesañteg8, ak| `g'd flot'    R.252/456b.
Chip. |tigou-u@g| `waves'    Lk.21.25.]

\et H.1575,1822,2506 *-e?tekw(e∙) `river'

\va tugk∞

    \nt +
\ps NA
\ge `wave'
\so Ps.65.7,88.7,89.9,93.3, Mt.8.24
    \xv ∞wadtauatonkqussuongan∞ tukk∞og
    \xe the noise of their waves

    \xv ...: kah k∞tamehpunaseh nashpe wame kuttugk∞mog.
    \xe ..., and thou hast afflicted me with all thy waves.
    \so Ps.88.7; (M): |kuttukkoomog|
    \xv wuttugk∞moh
    \xe their waves
    \so Ps.93.3; (M): |wuttukoomoouh|

    \se tukk∞e
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `(of) waves'
    \so Ps.65.7(M)
    \xv tukkooe wadtauohtunkquodt

\et H.3317 *tekowa NA `wave'

\lx tummûnk
\va tummunk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 167
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a beaver'
    |Tummunk|, |Tummunkquaog| `The beaver.'    El.Gr.9/256√
    (|Tu@múnk, -quaog.| `A beaver, beavers'    C.4/156
    \xv Easu tommoc quocke
    \xe halfe a skin of Beaver
    \so Wood 1634.
    \nt +
    |Tommunque|    Stiles 1762 [Cowan 1973, no.84])
\dv This name is evidently a verbal from the base |tummu| (`he severs, cuts off'), from which are formed |tummussum|, |tummehtam|, |tummigquohwhau|, etc., and signifies `the cutter'.
    "His teeth ... be sharpe and broad, with which he cuts downe trees as thicke as a man's thigh, afterwards dividing them into lengths," etc.,    Wood.
\cf amisque

[Narragansett [xnt] |tummòck|, pl. +|quaûog|; (also) |nóosup-paûog|; |súmhup-paûog|    R.W.
Western Abenaki [abe] |tema`k8é| `Castor'; `mâle', |atsimesk8|, f. |n8sémeskk8|.    R.22/383a, 90/405a.√
Delaware [del] |tamáque|    Hkw.]

\et G.1971, 143b-144a: *tema∙xkwe∙wa `cutter-off-of-trees'


\lx tummussum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 167
\ps v.t. / TI1b, scissive final
\ge `he cuts off', +`to shave sth off'
\nt as used by Eliot it has the same signification as |tummehtam|, q.v.*
    \xv ..., pish m∞sum wame ummeesunk, uppuhkukqut, kah ∞weeshitt∞nôunut, kah ummomóunoh, wame ummeesunk pish wuttummussumunash,...
    \xe ..., that he shall shave all his hair off his head and his beard and his eyebrows, even all his hair he shall shave off:...
    \so Lev.14.9
    \nt +

    \se |tummuswau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA
    \ge `to cut sb off'
    \so Gen.17.14
    \xv ..., n noh keteahogkou pish tummuswau wutch ummissinninnutu,...
    \xe ..., , that soul shall be cut off from his people;...
    \so Gen.17.14
    \ng X->3 absolute

    \se tummussahwhau
    \ps With an.obj. / TA
    \ge with nearly the same signification as |tummehtahwhau|

    \se tadtamswau
    \ps Freq. / TA, reduplicated
    \xv ..., kah pish chequodweham uppuhkuk, kah tadtamswau wuhkasoh.
    \xe ...; and she shall shave her head, and pare her nails;
    \so Deut.21.12√

[*MARGINAL NOTE.-- "The difference is that one is severed by repeated blows (|-ehtahum|), the other by simple cutting (|-ussum|). See Howse 87 et seq."

[Western Abenaki [abe] |netemesemen|, |netemes8ñ| `je le coupe'.]

\lx túppaco
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 167
\ps ?
\ge `toward night'
    |otematíppocat| (suppos.) `toward night'
    \xv nanashowatíppocat
    \xe midnight
    \so R.W.67
\nt Eliot does not employ this word in the present or indicative, but has its suppositive (|tipuk∞k|, |-ok|) in the compounds
    \xv pohkenittipuk∞k
    \xe in the darkness of the night' (`when it is dark night
    \so )    Prov.7.9
    \xv pajeh nôetipukkok
    \xe till midnight
    (|nouttippo@hkod| `late at night'    C.)
    \xv nôetipukodáeu
    \xe at midnight
    \xv neasittupukok
    \xe yesternight
    \so Gen.31.29
    \nt +
\dv |túppaco| signifies `it is dark', or `the time of darkness', and has the same base with |pohkeni| (q.v.), if not formed from it directly by the prefix |adt| or |ut| (|adt'-pohk-eni|).

[Western Abenaki [abe] |tañni éd8tsi tebi`kat| `quel temps de nuit?'; |titeb8k8^ikeban| `la nuit (passée)', de totâ nocte dicitur; |i8 tébk8^i8ik| `cette nuit'.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |tepk.8n8get| `lune, mois'; +|De@pkek| `Night', |u@tpoo'nok| `To-night', |u@tpook| `Last night', etc.    R.180a.
Delaware [del] |tpóku|    Zeisb.130 and Hkw.; B&A 143.√
Cree |tibbiskow| `it is night.
Chip. (St Marys) |téb ik ud| (Gr.Trav.) |tebik| (|tibikad| `night'    Bar.).
    Algonquian [alg] |TIBIK| `nuit', |Tibikat| `il est nuit'    Cq.400ab.]
    \nt +

\et A.2042, H.3346-3349, S., item 255, pp.411-412: *tepexk- `night'; G.1982, 5.10.1 with fn. 109, pp.36-37.


\lx tuppantam

    \nt +
\ps TI1a, mental final |-ánatam-|

\ge `to care about, for sth'? (Cf. Cuoq's gloss on the initial, s.v. |tuppanumau|.)
\nt G&B.718 |(kut)tupantammunnaont| TI-1a
\so Mt.15.6,22.5; 1 Cor.1.27,7.21
    \xv Qut matta toh wuttin tuppantam∞unneau,...

    \xv ..., kah GOD pepenam nan∞chumwagish yeu muttaohkit, mat tohhen tuppantam∞un nish mogagish.
    \xe ...; and God hath chosen the weak things of the world to confound the things which are mighty;
    \so 1 Cor.1.27
    \ng sense?

    \xv Wehkomit wuttinneumuk? ahque tohhentupontash, qut woh chippinnuwéan, an nemunush.
    \xe Art thou called being a servant? care not for it: but if thou mayest be made free, use it rather.
    \so [servus vocatus es non sit tibi curae...]    1 Cor.7.21

\lx -uhk-au-
\va -uhk-om-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 168
    \nt +
\nt complex final, expected allomorph |-usk-| not yet noted.
\ps corporal final, TA, TI1; assibilates.
\ge traditionally "by foot or body action", but also expresses a relationship of the whole body or person to sb, sth, "to stand in relation X to sb"?
\nt B.1962, 16.122-16.126, 352-254, with derivatives 15.227, 313, & ?16.104, 349, 15.68-69, 288-289; H. pp.244-245
\so See scattered entries e.g. |anuhkauau|, |(ke)ket∞hkauau|, |mussuhkauau|, |no∞suhkauau|, |pas∞suhkauau|, |wuttinneumuhkauau|.


\lx -uhk-au
\va -uhk-ontam-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 168
    \nt +
\ps complex final, denominal: creative final + dative final
\ge crudely "to perform the act of creation with respect to sb"
\nt Remark: A further common derivational type transitivizes the creative verb stem with the applicative final. The object then denotes what is turned into what is created or what comes to have what the underlying noun denotes, in an ornative verb, as B.1962, 16.69, 342-343; Howse 1844, no. 7, 20.

\so See scattered entries e.g. !|nemounuhkauau|, |nippehkontam|, |pittukontam|, |wesuonganuhkauau|.

[Alg.: Cq.151, fn.(1), Cq.1891, 257, 94 (e.g. |Ni mikiwamikawa| `je lui fais une maison'); Lem.D., s.v. Faire "|-ke| ({abs.}), |-ken| {g. in. et a.} {en comp. avec le Subst.). ... -- { pour qq..,} |-kaw| {g. a.} ..."
Cree: Lac.G., No.21, 113-114 |Kkawew|, appears to belong here, "c'est le verbe {faire} comme les phrases suivantes vont le faire comprendre, v.g. ... "{otoni}kkawew, il lui donne une bouche, c'est-à-dire, il lui met dans la bouche ce qu'il doit dire,..." (cf. ib., No. 1, 88: "En ajoutant {kkew} (3me pers. du sing.) à un nom quelconque on forme un verbe qui veut dire: {faire} la chose exprimée, par la racine." I have not yet found this formation confirmed explicitly in other sources on Cree. Howse, for instance, seems only to cite a different transitivizing final in this connection, apparently the applicative (PA *-Θ-) in |-t-|; similarly, Frs.116ab, s.v. "make". One recent example is apparently of the same form: |maskisinihkew| AI `s/he makes footwear, i.e.: shoes or mocassins', |maskisinihkawew| `s/he makes footwear for her/him, i.e.: shoes or mocassins', Alb.E.357ab, s.v. "make". This may be a matter of dialect differences. See also V.160b.
Men.: B.1962, 15.13-14, 276-277 + 16.181, 364 (2 examples; as in Cree, the applicative seems to be preferred, cf. 16.69, 342-343).
Ojib.: V.466-467, cf., in particular, (668) |nwapwaankaw| `prepare provisions for a trip for AN', and Rh.326b-327a, 543b.]

\lx uhquáe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 168
\ps adj. / PreN, PreV
\ge `at the point or extremity of'
\ge `at the end, border, or extreme part', +`in the side'
    \xv ... kah wusquoant ut Arkut pish uhquáe kupponamun,...
    \xe ...; and the door of the ark shalt thou set in the side thereof;...
    \so Gen.6.16
    \nt +
    \xv Ut onkoüwe, ohquäe.
    \xe On the further side, other end
    \so C.111/235
    \xv ukquáe wutanwohhou
    \xe the end or tip of his staff
    \so Judg.6.21
    \xv ut ahquae
    \xe at the ends
    \so Ex.39.15
    = |wohkukquóag|    Ex.39.16
    \cf wóhkôeu
    \xv uhquáe Moab
    \xe upon the border of Moab
    \so Num.21.15
    \xv uhquáe wutogk∞unit
    \xe (to) the skirts of his garment
    \so Ps.133.2
    \xv --
    \xe the borders of his garment
    \so Mk.6.56
    \xv ut ohquáe
    \xe on the edge of
    \so Ex.26.4
    \xv qut asquam ∞hquaeu
    \xe but the end (shall) not (be) yet
    \so Mk.13.7
\cf ahque
\nt The radical |uhq| or |uhk| (`a point or sharp extremity') enters into a great number of compound words, as
|úhkos| (|múhkos|) `the nail of a man or hoof of an animal'
    \xv uhquan
    \xe a fishhook' (|mukqs|, |uhks|, |uhkas| `an awl
    \so ), etc.
    \xv wuttuhquab
    \xe his skin
    \xv onkqunnésog
    \xe claws
    \so , etc.
\cf wehqshik
\cf wôhkuhquôshik
\cf uppuhkuk
\cf wussúkqun
\cf kuhkuhqueu
\cf unkque

\lx uhqunneunkqussu

    \nt +
\ps AI, verb of undergoing
\dv |ôhkw(i)-| "intense" + |-nunkqus-| "to appear, seem" (T+.96b)
\ge `to be terrible'
\so Deut.7.21,10.17
    \xv ..., newutche Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m, kenugke kenaau, masugkenuk God, kah uhqunneunkqussu.
    \xe ...: for the LORD thy God is among you, a mighty God and terrible.
    \so Deut.7.21

    \se uhqunneunkqussuonk
    \ps NI
    \ge `terribleness, terror (in "active" sense?)'
    \so Deut.26.8; 2 Cor.5.11
    \xv Kah Jehovah nussohh∞wunukqun wutch Egypt, nashpe menukke menutcheg, kah nashpe Summagunnum∞e muhpit, kah nashpe missi unkqunneunkqussuonk,...
    \xe And the LORD brought us forth out of Egypt with a mighty hand, and with an outstretched arm, and with great terribleness,...
    \so Deut.26.8
    \xv Newutche wahteauog wutuhqunneunkqussuonk GOD, nupweshanómun missinninnuog;...
    \xe Knowing therefore the terror of the Lord, we persuade men;...
    \so 2 Cor.5.11

    \se uhqunneunkquodt
    \va uhqueneunkquodt
    \ps II, verb of undergoing
    \ge `to be a fearful thing, grievous, terrible; to be an abomination, a worse thing'
    \so Gen.18.20,41.31; Ex.9.24; Deut.1.19,10.21,12.31,17.4; Jn.5.14; Heb.10.31; 1 Jn.5.3
    \xv Kah na musségon kah n∞tau kenukshau musségonit: ahche uhqueneunkquod,...
    \xe So there was hail, and fire mingled with the hail, very grievous,...
    \so Ex.9.24
    \xv ..., kah wutann∞team∞ongash matta uhqunneunkquodtinn∞wash.
    \xe ...: and his commandments are not grievous.
    \so 1 Jn.5.3

    \xv ..., noh kum-Manitt∞m, noh aseaunshikquean yeush magagish kah uhqueneunkquokish,...
    \xe ..., and he is thy God, that hath done for thee these great and terrible things,...
    \so Deut.10.21
    \xv ..., newutche nish noh uhqueneunkquok en Jehovah ut ne sekeneauoncheh, ne wuttinheoneau um Manitt∞m∞oh:...
    \xe ...: for every abomination to the LORD which he hateth have they done unto their gods;...
    \so Deut.12.31
    \xv ..., ahque wonk matchesish, ishkont ohqunneunkquok kuppeyaónuk.
    \xe ...: sin no more, lest a worse thing come unto thee.
    \so Jn.5.14; (M) |uhquinneuukquohk|

    \se uhqunneunkque
    \va uhqueneunkque
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `fierce, grievous, terrible'
    \so Ex.9.18; Num.32.14; Deut.8.15
    \xv Kusseh, nussokun yeu utt∞che saup, ahche uhqueneunkque mussékon ...
    \xe Behold, to-morrow about this time I will cause it to rain a very grievous hail,...
    \so Ex.9.18
    \xv ..., nano misheteauunat uhqueneunkque ummusquanittam∞onk Jehovah ayeuuhkone Israel.
    \xe ..., to augment yet the fierce anger of the LORD toward Israel.
    \so Num.32.13

\lx úhquontamauónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 169
\ps v.t. inan. subj. / TA
\ge `to be abhorrent to, to be an abomination to'
    \xv pish kutúhquontamunáoash
    \xe they (inan.) shall be an abomination to you
    \so Lev.11.11


\lx ûhquontamunát
\va ôhquánit-
\va óhquont-
\va ohquoantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 169
\ps v.t. inan. / TI1a, mental final
\twn |áhquanumónat|, |uhquanumau|, TA
\ge `to abhor, to hold in abhorrence, to have extreme aversion to' (see |ahquanamau| `he forsakes'); +`for sth to be an abomination unto sb; to curse sth'
    \xv ... ohquoantamun ohke wutche ken,...
    \xe ...: cursed {is} the ground for thy sake;...
    \so Gen.3.17
    \ng X->0 ?absolute
    \xv ..., newutche ne wutóhquontamunneau Egyptianeog.
    \xe ...; for that is an abomination unto the Egyptians.
    \so Gen.43.32
    \ng 3p->0 objective
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jehovah naum, kah wutunkquanume uhquontamun,...
    \xe And when the LORD saw {it}, he ||abhorred {them},... [marginal: ||{ Or, despised.}]
    \so Deut.32.19√
    \ng on spellings, see G.1965, no.10, 213a; cognate preverb construction with mixed stems: TI objective verb for the AV verb with animate plural object, probably taken as intransitive, or as referring to the situation.
    \xv ..., qut pish pannuppe kussekeneamun, kah pish pannuppe kutuhquontamun, newutche ne, mattantamwae teaguas.
    \xe ...: but thou shalt utterly detest it, and thou shalt utterly abhor it; for it is a cursed thing.
    \so Deut.7.26√
    (|pish kutúhquontamunáoash| `ye shall have (them, inan.) in abomination.'    Lev.11.11)√
    \xv ôhquonittamwoh
    \xe they abhor (it)
    \so Ps.107.18

    \xv ..., newutche ne ohke Jehovah ohquanìttogkup.
    \xe ..., because of the ground which the Lord hath cursed.
    \so Gen.5.29
    \ng 3->_0_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv Kah jishontamóg nukkuhk∞waongash kah kukketeahogkôun∞ ûhquontamóg n∞sittum∞angash,...
    \xe And if ye shall despise my statutes, or if your soul abhor my judgments,...
    \so Lev.26.15√
    \ng curious agreement: LXX and Hebrew have 2p possessor, singular possessed, and 3s verb, followed by AV; Vlg has 2p subject.

\nt Remark: Two PA finals will have merged with this outcome, viz. *-i?l- and *-wehΘ-; it is not yet clear to me whether they are to be treated as homophonous finals in Massachusett, though two distinct names are assigned in a preliminary fashion. The status of a gender distinction is also not certain.
\ps AI, II finals, tentatively "fugitive/volative" and "ambulatory". There do appear to be conjunct forms in |-ôt| (G&B.551) and |-ôk| (G&B.554, weakly attested).
\ge `to go'

\lx -uhtuq-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 169
    \nt +
\ps final, NI
\ge `river, stream'; see the initial part of Trumbull's characterization below. (Note that the application to inland stretches of rivers often seems to be in connection with some property relating to activity of the water or the spatial configuration.)
\so |kehteihqu-|, |kishketuk|, |nóahtuk|; see also under |-TUK|, T.166a.
    "|-TUK| (Abn. |-teg∞é|; Del. |-ittuk|;) denotes a river whose waters are driven {in waves}, by tides or wind. It is found in names of tidal rivers and estuaries; less frequently, in names of {broad and deep} streams, not affected by tides."    Trumbull 1870.8-12. { Note that tides and estuaries are much less likely to have been relevant in the non-maritime regions where the centre of gravity of the language family is to be found, so that this property is probably the result of a transfer. F.R.H. }

[Abn. s.v. "rivière": |tsitsik8tg8^éss8| `petite'; |kesski`teg8^é| `grande', |érmi`teg8^ek| `Rivière qui entre dans une autre', |sa`saghí`te8^é| `Rivière q. va droit', |pañbébetketeg8^é| `q. [qui] tourne'; |niketa8"'teg8^é|, v. |niket8teg8^é| `qui fourche'    R.444/523ab.
Algonquian [alg] |TIKOW-| `flot, vague', |-Tikwi| `flots d'un rapide', |Wawackitikweia| `la rivière coule en serpentant', |Pagotikweia| `la rivière n'est pas profonde'    Cq.401b.
Cree "|{makkistikweyaw}|, ou, |{misistikweyaw}| `grande [rivière], |{apisistikweyaw}| `petite [rivière]. La terminaison |{tikweyaw}|, donne l'idée d'une [rivière], v.g. [rivière] croche |{wâwâkis}tikweyaw|"    Lac.D.244b.
Miami-Illinois [mia] |rarag8ite8e| `un confluent de deux rivieres. la pointe ou elles se joignent' (with other scattered examples)    Grv.497/285b.
Menominee [mez] |-aqtεkw-| `river', |pa∙kwaqtεk| `rapids'    B.1962, 14.281, 258.
M.-P. |Panuwapskewtoq| NI `Penobscot River' (etc.)    F&L.
Narr. "{|Qunníhticut|} River", |Quintikóock| name of a Nation    R.W.A6v, A3v. (The |h|, heard as velar, could be the source of the "ct" in "Connecticut"?)
Nask. |paaikustikaaw| `there is one river', |niisustikaawa| `there are two rivers', |nistustikaawa| `there are three rivers', |naaustikaawa| `there are four rivers'    McK&J.238b,219b,212b,196a.
Ojibwe [oji] |-(i)tigwewaa| II `specifying features of rivers'    V.368.
Shawnee [sjw] |-?tekwi|, |-e?tekowali| `STREAM(s)'    D.-V.150.
WAbn. |Pôntegw.| `A rapid.', |Tego{ak}| `The waves.'; |jigôwtegwihla| II `the river keeps on going'     L.16; D.1.246; see D.2.319-322, s.v. "river" for many more examples.]

\et H., p.246 *-e?tekw(e∙) `river'

    \xe ..., and putteth forth her hand, and taketh him by the secrets:...

\dv Perhaps from |kezheaónat| (`to give life to'): |kezheau| `he created (Gen.1.21), gave life to'.
    \nt Remark: Also compare M.L.2: |neka∙san| AN `my vulva', |meka∙san| `a vulva'; though B.1962, 14.240, 18.59 lists the stem as |-kasan-|? The second spelling given by Trumbull might also rule this connection out. The word is used of a male at Lev.18.7: |Ukkôsuonk k∞sh|, as at Deut.25.11 (testicles).
    \nt +

\lx unkquamónat
\va -anat
\va oncquomonat
\va unkquomom∞
\va onkquommom∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 170
\dv initial |onkqu-| intense negative emotion or sensation, T+.108b + final |-omomw-i-| middle reflexive `suffer pain'.
\ps v.i. / AI, middle reflexive
\ge `to suffer pain, to feel pain'

    \xe I am in pain, I feel pain
    \so Jer.4.19
    \xv nutonquomomumun
    \xe we are in pain
    \so Is.26.18
    \xv Qut ∞weyausu wuhhog pish onkquamom∞,...
    \xe But his flesh upon him shall have pain,...
    \so Job 14.22
    \ng 3 indicative

    \nt Remark: See also |onkquom-|
    \nt +
\cf kehkechísu

\lx unkquánumwinneat
\va onkquanumw-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 170
\ps v.p. / AI
\ge `to be grieved or afflicted, to be in affliction'; +`to suffer'
\so Is.14.3
\nt Research needed: Middle reflexive to the |-ánum-| verb? See B. 73, 109/467: "-eelemo ... beside -eelem", and G&B 580, item 11: "|-wi-| (and variants) AI forms middle reflexives from TA stems."
    \xv ..., newutche GOD nummishummeechummehuk, ut nutúhquónamuneat.
    \xe ...: For God hath caused me to be fruitful in the land of my affliction.
    \so Gen.41.52
    \ng t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv nag mishe unkqúanumôog
    \xe they are in great affliction
    \so Neh.1.3

    \xv onkquanumwit
    \xe when he was in affliction
    \so 2 Chr.33.12
    \xv Qut howan onkquanumwit neyane Christianut, ahque akodchitch;...
    \xe Yet if any man suffer as a Christian, let him not be ashamed;...
    \so 1 Pet.4.16
    \nt +

    \se uhquanumweheónat
    \ps caus. an. / TA
    \ge `to cause to be afflicted, to afflict'
    \xv wutúhque onkquanumweheuh
    \xe he did grievously afflict her
    \so Is.9.1

    \xv onkquanumwehit
    \xe he afflicts, makes me afflicted
    \so Is.58.5
    \xv uhquanumweheunt
    \xe afflicting, making afflicted
    \so Is.58.5

    \se !|ohquanittamheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative to TI1a stem !|ohquan(it)tam-|
    \ge `to afflict sb'
    \nt Relationship to causative of the TA stem (above) not clear.
    \so Ruth 1.21
    \xv ..., kah wame Masugkenuk nutohquanittamhik?
    \xe ..., and the Almighty hath afflicted me?
    \so Ruth 1.21

\cf úhquanumónat
