\lx unkque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 170
\ps adj. / PreN
\ge `sore, severe, grievous'
\ps adv. /PreV
\ge `sorely, grievously' (`extremely' = |úhquáe|); +`utterly'
    \xv unkque kechísuongash
    \xe sore boils
    \so Job 2.7
    \xv wutúhque onkquanumweheuh
    \xe he did grievously afflict her
    \so Is.9.1
    (|wutunkque|    Jer.4.8)
    \xv uhqueu
    \xe "cruel", rigorous
    \so Ex.6.9
    \xv Kah neemunnumumun wame ukkeit∞tanash na ut ahquompag, kah nuttunkque paguanomun wosketompaog, kah mittamwussissog, kah mukkiesog nish noh ut otan wanne howan ushqueu.
    \xe And we took all his cities at that time, and utterly destroyed the men, and the women, and the little ones, of every city, we left none to remain:
    \so Deut.2.34
    \ng aphaeresis of |nu-|
    \nt +

\nt (Apparently the same with |uhquáe|, `at extremity'. Its derivatives are numerous, and exhibit a wide range of meaning, everywhere traceable, however, to this radical signification. See corresponding words under |uhquáe|.)

[Cree |áwkoosu| `he is sick'    Howse 79 (see also pp. 152-153).
Mod. Abn. |a-kwan| `bitter, acrid'.
Delaware [del] |achewon| `strong, spirituous'; |achowat| `hard, painful, troublesome'    Zeisb.Gr.167.]

\et G.1965, no.10, 212b-213a: *a∙hkw- `intense', A.6-12, H.8-14

\lx unnai
\va unni
\va nnih
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 171
    \nt +
\ps II, to relative root |un-|
\twn ?|unnayeu| AI
\ge "to be so, come to be so, come to pass that...", covering a wide range of AV locutions
\nt G&B.720; G.1981, 10, p.59, 14, pp.62-63; T.86ab |nnih|, T.18b |áunag|, T.75b |nan|, T.170b |unnag|, T.171b-172a |unne|.
    \xv ..., kah mónkô n nih.
    \xe ...: and it was so.
    \so Gen.1.7

    \xv ..., mahche ne nag woh kuppaumshaumw∞,...
    \xe ..., after that you shall pass on:...
    \so Gen.18.5
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle
    \xv ..., qut matta n nán∞g, onk nukkod wahteoun.
    \xe ...: and if not, I will know.
    \so Gen.18.21
    \ng 0 negative conjunct (subjunctive)
    \xv ..., kah wutchadchekeimoh papaume nish aunakish.
    \xe ..., and [he] sware to him concerning that matter.
    \so Gen.24.9
    \ng _0p_ participle
    \xv ..., nussontimom matta wahteau uttoh onag ut wetuomut, kah ponam wame ne ohtunk nunnutcheganit.
    \xe ..., my master wotteth not what {is} with me in the house, and hath committed all that he hath to my hand;
    \so Gen.39.8
    \ng _0_ participle
    \xv ONk n nih mahche yeu nag ...
    \xe And it came to pass after these things,...
    \so Gen.40.1
    \ng 0->_adv_
    \xv ..., nó∞sukkoiitch ne kìttinneumog woh asehettit ne yeu aunag.
    \xe ...? God forbid that thy servants should do according to this thing:
    \so Gen.44.7
    \ng 0->_adv_ participle

    \xv ..., ahque ne naj n∞sh,...
    \xe ..., Not so, my father:...
    \so Gen.48.18
    \ng 0 imperative

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nni, eíu.| `It is true.', |Mat enâno|, {or}, |mat eâno.| `It is not true.'    R.W.57.
Western Abenaki [abe] |arâi, arâighesa, arâigheban| `cela arrive, hoc accidit'    R.34/387b.
Pen. |àle| `it happens so'    S.1975.302.]

\et G.1981, 59: reshaped, as if to (pseudo-)PA *eΘye∙wi


\lx unnaiinneat
\va unnauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 171
    \ps TA, dative final
    \nt +
    \ge `to be like (unto) sb'
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Kusseh, wosketomp kuttinnngqun,...
    \xe ..., Behold, the man is become as one of us,...
    \so Gen.3.22; (E0&1): |kuttinnungqun| { 3->12 indicative }; (E0): "is like us"
    \nt +
    \xv Kenugke manitt∞wog, matta pasuk kuttinnongk∞, woi Jehovah:...
    \xe Among the gods there is none like unto thee O Lord:...
    \so Ps.86.8
    \ng 3->2
    \nt +
    \xv ne wunnegen unnaiinneat
    \xe it is good so to be
    \so , i.e. in such a state or condition    1 Cor.7.26
    \ng AI, to !|unnaieu|
    (|unniinat| `to become'    C.181)

    \xv Jehovah kum Manitt∞m, keneepauunumunk Manitt∞womp wutch nashaue kuhhogkat, wutch kematog aunnkqueaneh,...
    \xe The Lord thy God will raise up unto thee a Prophet from the midst of thee, of thy brethren, like unto me;...
    \so Deut.18.1
    \ng 3->1; (E1): |anunkqueaneh|
    \nt +

    \xv Nematog, k∞wehquetumonumw∞, unniyegk neyanie, newutche nen neyane kenaau,...
    \xe Brethren, I beseech you, be as I am; for I am as ye are:...'    Gal.4.12 { i.e. 2p->1 `resemble me (TA), (such) as I am
    \so (1 conjunct AI)? }
    \nt +

\lx unnantam∞onk

    |wuttenantamóonk| (q.v.) `his will'
    \xv Kuttenantam∞ongan∞ash ponum∞k nish ongkoue ohtagish,...
    \xe Set your affection on things above,...
    \so Col.3.2

    \se unnanumaonk
    \nt Remark: removed, see s.v. |unnanumau|

[Narragansett [xnt] |nteatammowonck| `that is my thought or opinion'    R.W.65.]


\lx unnantamúnát
\va anantamunát
\va unnantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 171
    \nt Remark: See also T.8a, under the spurious entry |anántam-|
    \nt +
\ps v.t. / TI1a, |un-| relative root + TI mental final
\twn |unnanumónat|
\ge `to think', +`to think so, thus, that ...'; `to make sb sth' (factitive, ?conceptual)
\nt Remark: Instances like Ps.52.7 perhaps also have to be viewed as having a simple verbless (copular) clause as object.
\so 2 Cor.3.5
    \xv ..., matta nuttenantam∞ woh nunnaum keskesuk,..
    \xe ..., I had not thought to see thy face:...
    \so Gen.48.11
    \ng 1->0 negative absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., yeuoh wosketomp matta unnantam∞ GOD nummenuhkesuonk;...
    \xe ..., this is the man that made not God his strength:...'    Ps.52.7  { 3->3(
    \so )+0 negative absolute; |nu-| erroneous }
    \nt +
    `to suppose'    2 Sam.13.33
    `to purpose, to will, to have in mind'
    (`to suppose or imagine'    C.211)
    \xv nuttenantam
    \xe I think
    \so Acts 7.40
    `I suppose'    Lk.7.43
    \xv sun kuttenantam
    \xe thinkest thou?
    \so Job 35.2
    \xv unnantam
    \xe he thought
    \so Lk.12.17
    `he purposed'    Acts 19.21
    \xv nuttenantamun
    \xe I will (it)
    \so Mt.8.3
    \xv unnantamohp
    \xe I thought
    \so Num.33.56

    \xv unnántómog
    \xe if it be your mind
    \so Gen.22.8
    \ng 2p conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ne anantamup
    \xe that which I have thought
    \so Is.14.24
    (|ne pakodtantamup| `that which I have purposed, intended    Is.14.24)
    \xv matta ne anantam nen, qut ken ne anantaman
    \xe not as I will, but as thou wilt
    \so Mt.26.39
    \xv yeu ananatamon
    \xe "having this confidence", when I thought thus
    \so 2 Cor.1.17
    \xv ne anontog
    \xe according to his will' (`what he may will
    \so )    Dan.4.35
    \xv howaneh anantogeh
    \xe whom he (may) will
    \so Jn.5.21; Dan.4.17

    \xv ahque unnantam∞k
    \xe do not (ye) think
    \so Mt.5.17
\cf anántam
\nt In form this verb is a frequentative or intensive from |antamunát|, or |anatamunát| (Narr. |ntunnántum| or |neántum| `I think'; |tocketeántam| and |-tannántum| `what do you think?'    R.W.64). The latter is not found in Eliot's translation and perhaps was not in use, but it serves in forming a great number of verbs expressing states of the mind, mental operations, passions and emotions, etc.
    Among the more important of these are the following:
    |ahquoantamunát| (|ahque| `not to think of') `to forgive'
    |kodtantamunát| (see |kod|) `to desire'
    |matchenantamunát| (|matchet| `bad') `to think evil of'
    |mehquantamunát| (|mehqunum| `he finds') `to remember'
    |missantamunát| (|missi| `much, greatly') `to think much, to meditate'
    \xv monchanatamunát
    \xe to be astonished
    |musquantamunát| (|musqui| `red or bloody') `to be angry'
    |muskouantamunát| (|muskôau| `he boasts') `to be boastful, to be very glad'
    \xv natwontamunát
    \xe to devise, to meditate upon
    \xv neuantamunát
    \xe to grieve, to be sorry
    \xv onquotantamunát
    \xe to recompense, to avenge
    |pabahtantamunát| (|pabahtanum| `he trusts') `to trust'
    |pakodtantamunát| (|paguodche| `perhaps') `to intend or have a mind to'
    |peantamunát| (|pâ| `let me') `to pray'
    \xv poanatamunát
    \xe to be mirthful, to make sport
    |tabuttantamunát| (|taupi|, |tâpi| `sufficient, enough') `to be thankful, to give thanks' (`to be satisfied or to have enough)'
    \xv waantamunát
    \xe to be wise
    |wannantamunát| (|wanne|, negat.) `to forget'
    |weekontamunát| (|weekone| `sweet, pleasant') `to be pleased, to be glad'
    \xv wuttamantamunát
    \xe to be troubled
    |wunnantamunát| (|wunne| `good') `to bless'.
    From the same root appear to be derived the names given by the Indians to their gods. "They do worship two gods, a good god and an evil god. The good god they call |Tantum| and their evil god, whom they fear will do them hurt, they call |Squantum|." -- Higginson's N. E. Plantation. The latter name, applied to the same evil deity who was called |Habbumouk| or |Hobbamoco| (Lechford's Pl. Dealing 52), appears to be the contracted 3d pers. sing. indicat. present of |musquantamunát|: |m'squantam| `he is angry', or literally, `bloody-minded'. The composition of |Tantum| is less obvious.

[NOTE. -- The last paragraph of this definition is marked "No" in the margin. It was probably the compiler's intention either to rewrite or to omit it.]

\lx unnanumónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 172
    \nt Remark: See also T.8a, under |anántam-|; also |annumau|, under |ann∞|, T.10a, and |annúmau|, T.10b?
    \nt +
\ps v.t. an. / TA(+"O"), with the relative root cataphoric to the clause denoting the act.
\dv |un-| relative root + |-ánum-| TA mental final
\twn |unnantamúnát|, T.170b
\ge `to permit'; +`to let, suffer sb (to do sth)'; `to be minded'
    \xv Qut matta nuttenanumoh mittamwossis kuhk∞tomuhkonat, asuh wunnemunumunat wunnánauwunónat wosketompuh, qut chequnapitch.
    \xe But I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence.
    \so 1 Tim.2.12
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah matta pish unnanumau∞og wunnupp∞e wuhhogkauh ponónat wenohkeit.
    \xe ..., and [they] shall not suffer their dead bodies to be put in graves.
    \so Rev.11.9
    \nt +
    \xv Nag ummenuhke unnanumukquoh k∞weecháush, neit wutahque ken∞nuh.
    \xe When she saw that she was stedfastly minded to go with her, then she left speaking unto her.
    \so Ruth 1.18
    \nt +

    \xv ..., LORD unnanumit
    \xe if the Lord permit' {sc. `me
    \so , 3->1 }    1 Cor.16.7
    \xv unnantog
    \xe if (he) permit (it)'    Heb.6.3 i.e. `if he will
    \so { 3->0, ==> the TI twin }

    \xv ... Unnanumeh quompatásh ne moshquag sôbàheg k∞wehquetumoush,...
    \xe ..., Feed me, I pray thee, with that same red pottage;...
    \so Gen.2530
    \ng 2->1; c.f. Geneva "Let me eat of...", Tyndale "Let me syppe of...", for Hebrew 1 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv unanumeh
    \xe permit me
    \so C.203)

\cf unnantamúnát

    \se |unnanumaonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, deverbal to |unnanumau|
    \ge `thought'
    \so Job 12.5
    \xv Noh kenuppee t∞nequssuk, ogqueneunkqussu lamp noh jishanumit ut unnanumaonganit noh manunussit.
    \xe He that is ready to slip with his feet is as a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease.
    \so Job.12.5
    \ng locative; on the interpretation and the syntax, see G&B.585

    (|unnanúkkönat| `to permit'    C.203) { distinct stem }

    \so ? }

[Narragansett [xnt] |Aaunchemókaw.| `Tell me your newes.'; |AUnchemokauhettíttea.| `Let us discourse, or tell uewes.'; |Tocketeáunchim?| `What newes?' (`what tell you?'); |Cuttaunchemókous.| `I will tell you newes.'; |Cummautaunchemókous.| `I have done my newes.'    R.W.54.√]


\lx unnauwuttam
\va nauwuttam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 172
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\dv |un-| relative root + |auwuttam| TI ?`intend, mean, think', q.v., T+.19b.
\ge `to mean, signify sth'; `is' in explanatory formulas of the types "that/which is (, being interpreted,):__", "that is to say, __"
\nt Remark: The inanimate subject form given in the sublemma is not always used where it might be expected; the usage may be largely restricted to the explanatory tags (but note e.g. Mk.9.10).
\so Gen.33.8,50.20; Mt.27.46; Mk.3.17,3.41,7.2,9.10; Lk.8.9; Heb.9.8
    \xv ..., Toh kittinnauwuttam neg wame netasuog nogskóuagig? ...
    \xe ..., What meanest thou by all this drove which I met? ...
    \so Gen.33.8
    \xv Kah kenaau kutauwuttamûmwop wutche ne machuk, GOD wuttinnauwuttamun wanegik,...
    \xe But as for you, ye thought evil against me; but God meant it unto good,...
    \so Gen.50.20
    \ng note occurrence of the unadorned final
    \xv ... (kah wunneese∞wesuonganuhkauoh Boanerges, ne nauwuttamun wunnaumonauh padtuhquohhan.)
    \xe ...; and he surnamed them Boanerges, which is, The sons of thunder:
    \so Mk.3.17
    \ng parenthesis from AV
    \xv .... Talitha-keumi, ne nauwuttamun, nunksquau kuttinsh omohkish
    \xe ..., Ta-litha cumi; which is, being interpreted, Damsel, (I say unto thee,) arise.
    \so Mk.5.41
    \xv ... meechwog petukqunneg, nishkenutchaog, (ne nauwuttamun mat kussénutchau∞og) ...
    \xe ... eat bread with defiled, that is to say, with unwashen hands,...
    \so Mk.7.2
    \xv Kah ne wunnanauwéhteauunneau ne n∞waonk ut wuhhogkaóut: nat∞tommôadtéhettit, toh nauwuttamun omohkéonk wutch nuppunat.
    \xe And they kept that saying with themselves, questioning one with another what the rising from the dead should mean.
    \so Mk.9.10
    \xv ... Wuttinóuh, Rabbi, (ne nauwuttamun, Nussontimom) toh kuttaiin?
    \xe ... They said unto him, Rabbi, (which is to say, being interpreted, Master) where dwellest thou?
    \so Jn.1.38; (M): |unnauwuttamun|
    \xv ..., Monchish kutchissumwush Siloame nuppissepagwut, (ne nauwuttamun, An∞tamunat.)
    \xe ..., Go, wash in the pool of Siloam (which is by interpretation, Sent)
    \so Jn.9.7; (M): |ânauwuttamuk| i.e. "by which one means"?

    \xv Newajeh nashpe ussenat toh anauwuttog naumatuonk wanne weyaus sampweogquanum∞un ut anaquabit,...
    \xe Therefore by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight:...
    \so Rom.3.20, also 3.28
    \ng obscure AV passage; translated as "by doing what the law intends, means", with no marking of inanimate subject? (Compare e.g. Mt.9.13, below.)

    \se unnauwuttam∞m∞
    \va nauwuttam∞m∞
    \nt Remark: Instances with |-tam∞∞| have been included here, though their status is unclear, in particular it is hard to attribute them to syncope but equally hard to see what else they might be.
    \ps TI1a, inanimate subject final
    \ge `for sth to mean sth, for sth to be the interpretation of sth'
    \so Gen.21.29,40.5,12,18; Deut.6.20; Josh.4.6; Mt.9.13,12.7; Lk.15.26,18.36; Jn.21.19; Acts 2.12,10.17; Heb.7.2,12
    \xv ..., Toh nauwuttam∞∞ yeug nesausuk tahsuog squoshimwog shepwussemesog chaupunàcheg.
    \xe ..., What {mean} these seven ewe lambs which thou hast set by themselves.
    \so Gen.21.29
    \ng ??0->0 absolute
    \xv ..., yeu nauwuttam∞∞, nishwinash man∞tash, ne nishikquinogkod.
    \xe ..., This is the interpretation thereof: The three baskets are three days:
    \so Gen.40.18
    \ng 0->0 absolute
    \xv ..., toh nauwuttam∞m∞ash yeush qussukqunash?
    \xe ..., What mean ye by these stones?
    \so Josh.4.6
    \ng 0p->0 absolute
    \xv Kah ukkodnetuhtaénumoh wunnat∞tomungquoh n∞waog, Toh nauwuttam∞∞ yeu kuhkinneasuonk.
    \xe And his disciples asked him, saying, What might this parable be?
    \so Lk.8.9
    \ng ?0->0 absolute
    \xv Yeu ∞che yin, nauwuttam∞∞ uttôh pish áne nuppuk,...
    \xe This spake he, signifying by what death he should glorify God. ...
    \so Jn.21.19
    \ng 0->0 absolute; (M) differs.

    \xv ..., nuttinukquomumun neeswe, nean nauwuttam∞∞ug unnukquom∞onk.
    \xe ...; we dreamed each man according to the interpretation of his dream.
    \so Gen.41.11
    \ng syncope + degemination? 0->_0_
    \xv Qut monchek kodnetuhtau∞k uttoh anauwuttam∞m∞uk,...
    \xe But go ye and learn what that meaneth,...
    \so Mt.9.13
    \xv Kah n∞tauont mattaánutcheh paumushánit wunnat∞tomauoh toh anauwuttam∞m∞uk.
    \xe And hearing the multitude pass by, he asked what it meant.
    \so Lk.18.36


\lx unne
\va aune
\va âne
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 172
    \ps PreV, relative root "so, thus", together with changed and reduplicated forms
    \nt +
\ge may have been, originally, an indeclinable adjective and adverb, expressing likeness or resemblance, the relation of the individual to its kind, or of species to genus, etc.
    \nt G&B.721
    \nt +
    (|ne u@nni@| `that is proper or right'    C.174
    |nenih| or |sampwi| `right'    C.174
    \xv uttoh unni
    \xe what manner
    \so C.176;
    |nahnaunne| adv. `especially'    C.228
    \xv yeuunni
    \xe thus
    \so C.234
    |en unni|    Mass.Ps., Jn.3.9
    = |en nnih|    El.);
it is not found, however, in this form in Eliot or the vocabularies, but is used largely in composition and as a verb substantive:
    \xv ne-ane
    \xe so, such, of this or that kind
    \so ,
    whence |nan| and |ne-nan| (q.v.) `the same';
    \xv âunag
    \xe if it be so, when it is so'; hence, as a noun, `an event, an occurrence (possible or actual), that which is or may be so
    \so (see |áunag|);
    and with |ne|, |ne áunak| `the color, appearance, or other specific quality of an object';
    \xv unne
    \xe "that is", id est
    \so Rom.9.8;
    |unnaiinneat| (q.v.), for |unne-ayinneat| `to be so', i.e. of such kind or condition.
    |-in| or |-en|, as a suffix of animate nouns, has the same meaning, referring an individual to the species or kind, and constituting nouns general [?] or appellative [?], as
    \xv wuttaun-oh
    \xe his or her daughter, the daughter of
    \xv wut-taun-in
    \xe a daughter, any daughter
    |wut-taun-éunk| (collective) `the daughterhood, or the whole of the daughters'
    \xv adchaen
    \xe a hunter
    \so , i.e. some particular hunter
    \xv adchaen-in
    \xe a hunter
    \so , i.e. any hunter, one of the hunter kind.


\lx unneapeyau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 172
\cf enneahpeyau


\lx unnehenát
\va unhenát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 172
    \nt Remark: Not distinct from following lemma?
    \nt +
\ps v.i.
\ge `to act, to conduct one's self'


\lx unneheónat
\va unheónat
\va unneheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 172
\ps v.t. an. / TA+O, causative final, to relative root |un-|.
\ge *`to conduct one's self toward or with respect to another, to act toward, to do to or deal with'; +`to do sth to sb'; `to make sb so/such'
    \nt Remark: The material requires considerable (re)organization, and supplementation. Classification as TA+O depends on treating the structures that the relative root can be cataphoric to as (secondary) objects, when an adverbial interpretation ("so, thus") is in fact no doubt primary. The same will apply to the TI twin below. The structure apparently permits a simple causative interpretation "to cause sb/sth to be such", and a less straightforward one as "to do such to sb/sth", the latter probably more frequent.
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne kesukok GOD kezheunt mìssinninnúh wuttinheuh wutogqunneunkqussinneat Godut.
    \xe .... In the day that God created man, in the likeness of God made he him;'    Gen.5.1  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Toh kittinheh? ...
    \xe ... What is this that thou hast done unto me? ...
    \so Gen.12.18
    \ng 2->1+0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wunnaumonuh wuttinhukqun nean ann∞nomp.
    \xe And his sons did unto him as he commanded them:'    Gen.50.12  { 3
    \so ->3 objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Toh kittinne kodtantamumw∞ noh nuttinheónat? ...
    \xe ..., What will ye then that I shall do unto him ...?
    \so Mk.15.12√
    \xv ...: wunass∞muwaénin wunass∞muwae unnéhhuau, kah matchehuwaénin matchehuau,...
    \xe ...; The treacherous dealer dealeth treacherously, and the spoiler spoileth. ...
    \so Is.21.2√
    \ng indefinite object
    \xv toh kittinhesh
    \xe what have I done (do I) unto thee?
    \so 1 K.19.20
    \xv ne an∞wadt wuttinheónat ummissinninnúmoh
    \xe that "which he thought to do unto his people"
    \so Ex.32.14
    \xv matta ne pish kuttinheon
    \xe thou shalt not do so unto (God), treat him so, so deal with him
    \so Deut.12.31
    \xv Yeu nuttinheonan, nuppomantamwaheóunonog,...
    \xe This we will do to them; we will even let them live,...
    \so Josh.9.20
    \ng 1p->3-obj+0-obj
    \nt +

    \xv ... kah wahteau peississinutche wunnaumonuh neanhikqut.
    \xe ..., and knew what his younger son had done unto him.'    Gen.9.24  { 3
    \so ->3+_0_ participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Yeu k∞womoausuonk pish ánhean ...
    \xe ..., This is thy kindness which thou shalt show unto me;...
    \so Gen.20.13
    \ng 2->1+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., netatupe womoausuonk ne ánhen, ne pish kuttinhen,...
    \xe ...: but according to the kindness that I have done unto thee, thou shalt do unto me,...
    \so Gen.21.23√
    \ng 1->2+_0_; 2->1+0-obj  participles
    \xv ..., womonetuaéu unnehheóg, kah sampwenéheog, nussontimom, ussegq,...
    \xe ..., if ye will deal kindly and truly with my master, tell me,...
    \so Gen.24.49
    \ng 2p->3 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wame ne machuk ne neanheogkutup.
    \xe ..., all the evil which we did unto him.
    \so Gen.50.15
    \ng 12->3+_0_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wame ne anheunt nees∞oh Amoritse ketass∞tamwoh,...
    \xe And all that he did to the two kings of the Amorites,...'    Josh.9.10  { 3->3
    \so +_0_ participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ne nuttínheun ne ánhit
    \xe I will do so to him as he hath done to me' (`I will do it that he may have done or may do
    \so )    Prov.24.29
    \ng 1->3+_0_ objective; 3->1+_0_ participle
    (|ne anheop| `as I dealt with (him)'    2 Chr.2.3)
    \xv ..., togkuppinnonat Sampson n∞che peyoumun, nuttinheonanonut neanhikqueog
    \xe ..., To bind Sampson are we come up, to do to him as he hath done to us.
    \so Judg.15.10√
    \ng 1p->3+"0"; 3->1p+_0_

    \xv ..., GOD unnéhikqush onatuh Ephraim ...
    \xe ..., God make thee as Ephraim ...
    \so Gen.48.20
    \ng 3->2 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ne unnehe
    \xe so deal thou with me
    \so 2 Chr.2.3
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    |unnéhúk|, |unnehhuk|, |unneheuk, nag| `deal ye with them, do to them'    Gen.19.8; Judg.19.24  { 2p->3 imperative }
    \xv ...nag ènneh onatuh wheelut,...
    \xe ..., make them like a wheel:...
    \so Ps.83.13
    \ng 2->3(p) imperative; (E1) |énneh|
    \nt +
    \xv unnéhúk nanuk nag
    \xe so do ye to them
    \so Mt.7.12
    \ng 2p->3 imperative
    \xv wussittumóonk unnehenach
    \xe let judgment be executed on him
    \so Ezra 7.26
    \ng X->3 imperative


    \se ?!|unnehetteaong(an)|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, deverbal noun to theme 2a
    \ge `wrong' ("something done to sb")
    \so Gen.16.5
    \xv ..., Nuttinhetteaonk kuttinhin,
    \xe ..., My wrong be upon thee:...
    \so Gen.16.5
    \ng 1 possessor, "a wronging of me"
    \nt +

Various initials:
    \xv matcheneheónat
    \xe to act evilly toward, to treat badly
    \xv kum ... matchenehennumun
    \xe we will deal badly with thee
    \so Gen.19.9
    \xv k∞nenehikqun
    \xe (he may) do thee good
    \so Deut.8.16

    \se !|unnehteau|
    \nt +
    \ps Inan. / TI2, |un-| +causative final
    \ge +`to do sth/so for/to/with sth'; `to make sth such, of such fashion'
    \xv Onk yeu pish kuttinteauun:...
    \xe And this is the fashion that thou shalt make it of:...
    \so Gen.6.15
    \ng 2->0 objective
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah pish wuttinteauun noh wusqueheonk neantonkup ∞sheonk oxen, kah pish wusseauhkon ut pehtwohtáe ummoneteae appuonganit kah anaquohtag monaneteae appuonganit.
    \xe ..., and do with that blood as he did with the blood of the bullock, and sprinkle it upon the mercy seat, and before the mercy seat:
    \so Lev.16.15; (E1): |nean-/teunkup|
    \nt +
    ?|..., kesukque tahs∞tamóonk chekée, unneteauun,...| `... the kingdom of heaven has suffered violence ...'    Mt.11.12  { X->0 ?subordinative }
    \nt +

    \xv uttoh anteunkup
    \xe what he did to (it)
    \so Deut.11.4
    \ng 3->0+_adv_ preterite participle
    \xv ..., matta woh webe nont kutusseinneau yeu anteaumuk figsuhtugq,..
    \xe ..., ye shall not only do this which is done to the fig tree,...
    \so Mt.21.21
    \ng X->0+_adv_ participle
    \nt +

\nt Research needed: I have collected a few forms that look like relic |s|-forms.

[NOTE. -- "Is this a verb causative from |neane| (|nan|), with verb subst.? See |áunag|."]

[Delaware [del] |liho| `do it to him'; |lihineen| `do unto us'    Zeisb.Voc.9,20.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nederihañ| `Je lui fais qq ch.'; |ni arihiáné, netse nañbi kederih8ren.| `Je te ferai co'e tu me feras'    R.242/452ab.]
    \nt +

\et cf. B. 80, p. 112/469, H.629, 633 *e⌠ihe∙wa *e⌠ihta∙wa `he makes him, it so', with levelling of initial as |un-|.


\lx unnehtam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\dv |un-| `so' + |-eht-| `ear, hear' + TI1a; cf. B.1962, 16.137, 356
\ge `to hear sth'
\so Gen.37.2; Jn.4.47(M.)

    \xv Anuhtog Jesus mahche wuttussuhham Judea en Galile, wuttâônopah,...
    \xe When he heard that Jesus was come out of Judea into Galilee, he went unto him,...
    \so Jn.4.47(M.)

    \se unnehtamauau
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to hear sth of sb'
    \so Lk.16.2
    \xv ..., Tohwutch yeu unnehtamauun? ogketamah kummaumachiyeue kenananumóonk,...
    \xe ..., How is it that I hear this of thee? give an account of thy stewardship;...
    \so Lk.16.2

    \se unnnehtamóonk
    \ps NI
    \ge `fame', "hearing"
    \so Gen.41.15,45.16
    \xv ..., kah nunn∞tam unnehtamóonk papaume ken,...
    \xe ...: and I have heard say of thee,...
    \so Gen.41.15
    \xv Kah unnehtam∞onk n∞tunkquodt Pharaoh wekit,...
    \xe And the fame thereof was heard in Pharaoh's house,...
    \so Gen.45.16

\et H.782 *eΘehtamwa TI `hear', with the aural final |-eht-|.


\lx unnehtongquat
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]

\ge `a story'
\so C.163
    pl. +|ash|


\lx unnequanumunát

\lx unnehtahwau

    \so objective }

    \xv ..., qut howan anehtohukquean kuttinnohkoeu konn∞naut,...
    \xe ...: but whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek,...
    \so Mt.5.39
    \ng _3_->2 participle


\lx unnetu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\ps AI(+O)
\dv |uN-| + |-ek-|
\ge `to grow (like sth)'
\so Ps.92.12(E&M)
    \xv ..., pish unneetu onatuh musquohtugkusseit ut Lebanon.
    \xe ...: he shall grow like a cedar in Lebanon.
    \so Ps.92.12

    \se unnetuonk
    \va unnetuong(an
    \ps NI
    \ge `goods, state, substance; lineage'
    \so Gen.13.6,34.23,36.6,43.7,46.6; Josh.14.4; Lk.2.4
    \xv ... newutche wuttinneetuongan∞ missi, kah woh mat weechayeuwuttéog.
    \xe ...: for their substance was great, so that they could not dwell together.
    \so Gen.13.6
    \ng 3p possessor
    \xv ..., wosketomp nat∞tomoe nunnat∞tomunkqun nuttinnetuwonganun, kah nuttinonkumónónuh,...
    \xe ..., The man asked us straitly of our state, and of our kindred,...
    \so Gen.43.7
    \ng 1p possessor
    \xv Kah neemunaog neetasu, kah wuttinnetuonganu ...
    \xe And they took their cattle and their goods,...
    \so Gen.46.6
    \ng 3p possessor
    \xv ... (newutche noh wutch wekit, kah wuttinneetuonganit David.)
    \xe ..., (because he was of the house and lineage of David,
    \so Lk.2.4
    \ng 3 possessor locative


\lx unneu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
\ps adj. an.
\ge `anyone' = |howan| (?)
    \xv ..., nashpe mohsag kuhpit, unneu pish chequnappuog onatuh qussuk,...
    \xe ...; by the greatness of thine arm they shall be as still as a stone;...
    \so Ex.15.16
    \nt +
    \xv toh pish unneu namp∞hamauau
    \xe what shall one (i.e. anyone) answer?

    (|nen unnuh| `I am he'    Mass. Ps., Jn.9.9
    = |noh neen|    El.
    \xv tonoh unnuh
    \xe where is he
    \so (this man)    Mass.Ps., Jn.9.12)

\lx unninnohteashau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\ps AI, long-vowel stem
\dv |unnunnohko(un)-| `right hand' + |-uhshá-| `to go', source of palatalization uncertain; for further details, see |wuttinnohko(un)| `right hand', T.212a.
\ge `to depart, go to the right hand', (E0) `to right hand it'
\so Gen.13.9
    \xv ..., menadtuhteashaan nen nuttinohteasheam, asuh eninnuhteashean nen nummenadteasheam.
    \xe ...: if thou wilt take the left hand, then I will go to the right; or if thou depart to the right hand, then I will go to the left.
    \so Gen.13.9
    \ng 1 indicative; 2 conjunct

    \xv Kah nag Cyprus, nuttinnohteahkomunnan, ...
    \xe Now when we had discovered Cyprus, we left it on the left hand...
    \so Acts 21.3.
    \nt ??

    \xe they (rivers) flow to the sea

\cf wuttitchuwan


\lx unniyeuonk
\va unnai-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
\ps n. / NI, to |unnai|
\ge `a matter, affair, case, business'; +`form (e.g. of a syllogism), manner'
\so Deut.17.8
    \xv Pasuk unnaumatuonk, kah pasuk unniyeuonk ne pish wutche kenaau, kah wutch pen∞wot, noh neaneapeont.
    \xe One law and one manner shall be for you, and for the stranger that sojourneth with you.
    \so Num.15.16
    \nt +
    \xv kuttinniyeuonk
    \xe "thy matters", business
    \so 2 Sam.15.3
    |-ongash|    2 Sam.19.29
    \xv wuttinniyeuongash
    \xe his business or matters concerning him, his affairs
    \so 2 Chr.19.11
    \xv wunnohteae unnaiyeuongash
    \xe "conditions of peace", terms
    \so Lk.14.32
    {Three      Syllogisticall  forms.}
    \nt +
    |Nishwinash oggusanuk∞wae wuttinniyeuongash.|    Log.Pr.50/62 { Not the sole rendering of "form" in this text. }
    \xv matcheniyeuonk
    \xe "evil case", bad state of affairs
    \so Ex.5.19
    (|ponniyeue u@nniye@uonk| `rude behavior, manner, way, state, condition'    C.174
    \xv wunnegen unniyeuonk
    \xe a good cause
    \so C.216)

\dv |unnehenát| (?).


\lx unnoadtu
\va unnôadtu
\va unn∞adtu
\va nóadtu
\va nôadtu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\ps II, AI (cf. Ps.44.12; WAbn.; B.1962, 15.192, p.307), i-stem
\ge `to be of (such) a price, of (such) value, of (such) worth'
\nt G&B. 516, 721 |unnoatt∞|
\so Gen.23.9,15; Lev.25.16,50; 2 Sam.24.24; Job.28.13,15,18; Mk.6.37; Lk.14.28; Acts 5.3; 1 Cor.6.20,7.23,9.24
    \xv ..., ohke nóadtu yauudt pasuk∞∞ash shekelsash Silver,...
    \xe ..., the land is worth four hundred shekels of silver;...
    \so Gen.23.15
    \ng 0 indicative

    \xv Neyane mónak meechumue kodtum∞ash, pish kummishteóh ne anóadtik, kah neyane ogguhse kodtumm∞ash, pish kutoggusteoh ne anoadtik, newutche ne adtahshik meechummue kodtum∞ash, pish kittinnumunkqun.
    \xe According to the multitude of years thou shalt increase the price thereof, and according to the fewness of years thou shalt diminish the price of it: for according to the number of the years of the fruit doth he sell unto thee.
    \so Lev.25.16
    \xv Newutche howan kenaau, kodayimóg qunnúhqukkomuk, matta nummatappu kah negonne ogketam∞ toh anôadtik,...
    \xe For which of you, intending to build a tower, sitteth not down first, and counteth the cost,...
    \so Lk.14.28
    \xv ..., onk k∞wadchanum nawhutch ne anóadtik ohke.
    \xe ..., and to keep back part of the price of the land?
    \so Acts 5.3

    \se unn∞adtuonk
    \va innôadtuonk
    \ps NI
    \ge `price'
    \so Deut.23.18; Ps.44.12; Prov.27.26
    \xv Kummag kummissinninnumog wutch monteag, onk matta k∞chenaetu wuttinnoadtuongan∞.
    \xe Thou sellest thy people for nought, and doest not increase thy wealth by their price.
    \so Ps.44.12; (M): |nashpe neanoatehtit.|
    \ng |-htit| = |-hettit|

    Other examples of the final:
    1 K.10.28 locative of derived noun?
    |ánue-| Prov.31.10 (AI?)
    |unn-| Is.45.13,55.1
    |tahn-| Jer.15.13
    |yan-| Mt.27.6
    |mish-| Mt.13.46; Mk.14.3; Jn.12.3; 1 Pet.3.4

[Narragansett [xnt] |Tahenaúatu?| `What price?'; |Yo chippaúatu.| `This is of another price.', |Augausaúatu.| `It is Cheap.', |Muchickaúatu.| `It is deare.', |Wuttunnaúatu.| `It is worth it.'     R.W.153/r.161;154-155/r.162-163.
WAbn. |ôwad-| `be valuable, have worth', |lôwad| `have value, be worth', |lôwado| AI II `he/it has value    D.I.lxi,xlviii,279.]

\et Could this be an extended form of H.145, 147-149 *a∙w- `to be so, such' subjected to semantic specialization? The verb shows the gender neutralization seen in Menomini, and its use would be consonant with that of |teag| for money in its lack of specificity. Western Abenaki shows it lacking the relative root initial. (Compare the use of "be" in English in asking for and giving prices, particularly following an initial (slightly) more specific inquiry "how much is that?".) But what about H.384-387 *ata∙w- `trade'?


\lx unnogque
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\nt Remark: See s.v. |nogque|, T.88a, its common aphetized form.
\ps PreN, PreV; also |(un)nogqu-| as initial?
\ge `toward'


\lx unnoh
\va nnoh
\va n noh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\ps animate demonstrative
\ge `the same, that (same), he, she'
\nt G&B.508, s.v. |noh|(1), 672, cf. cross-reference at |unnoh| 722
\so common
    \xv ..., n noh keteahogkou pish tummuswau wutch ummissinninnutu, n noh pohqunnum n∞n∞waonk.
    \xe ..., that soul shall be cut off from his people: he hath broken my covenant.
    \so Gen.17.14
    \xv ..., n noh ∞wutch ânadcheh kittinnúm Isaak:...
    \xe ..., {let the same be} she {that} thou hast appointed for thy servant Isaac;...
    \so Gen.24.14
    \xv ... , unnoh Jesus unnoh nohshóg,...
    \xe ..., that same Jesus, whom ye have crucified,...
    \so Acts 2.36

    \se |noh|
    \nt ?
    \nt Remark: possibly should be under |noh|; evidence lacking
    \ps demonstrative adverb
    \ge `there'
    \nt G&B.653, s.v. |na| (1), |noh| (2), 672
    \so Gen.19.25
    \xv ... kah wame neg noh apitcheg otanash...
    \xe ..., and all the inhabitants of the cities,...
    \so Gen.19.25
    \ng (E0) gl. "there"

\lx unnohkónat
\va unnohteauónat
\ve spurious lemma; for the intended form, v.i.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
\ps v.t. an. / AI+O

    \se |unnohkoNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, applicative (cf. Ps.102.12(M), with distinct initial)
    \ge `to cast sb down (into sth)'
    \so Gen.37.24; Dan.8.7;
    \xv wuttinnohkonuh ohkeit
    \xe he cast him down to the ground
    \so Dan.8.7
    \xv Onk wutohqunouh, kah wuttinohkonáoh pahsahtheganit,...
    \xe And they took him, and cast him into a pit:...
    \so Gen.37.24
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche noh unnohkon hashabput nashpe nehenwonche wusseetash,...
    \xe For he is cast into a net by his own feet,...
    \so Job.18.8
    \ng analysis? for |unnohkonau| X->3?

    (|kuppenuhkoneh| `thou [hast] cast me down'    Ps.102.10 { 2->1 indicative, distinct initial |pen-|; (M) |kuppunuhkosip| })


\so |n∞konónat
\cf penohkónau
\cf kepuhkonau

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |nedera`ké8añn.| `Je lui jette q^q^ ch.', |nekiba`kañn|, pls. |nekiba`kañnak.| `Je le jette par terre (de ignob. et nob.); |netebakkañ| `je le laisse t'ber dans sac, ouragan, vase, &c. nob.    R.294/468b; 480/535a.
    \nt +
Del.(M) |nt@lá∙he∙n| AI+O `I threw it'; |láaheew| `throw sth,...'    G.1982, (97), 27; O'M.625a.

\ps |unnohquaeu|

    \ng 2p->3

    \so Ex.7.9√

\lx unnomâi
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
\ps II?
\ge `a reason, the reason'
\so 1 K.9.15
    \xv Kah yeu unnomâi móunnum∞onk ne Solomon ayik ayimunat wek LORD,...
    \xe And this is the reason of the leuie which king Solomon raised, for to build the house of the LORD,...
    \so 1 K.9.15
    (|ennomai|    Samp.Quinnup.
    |Unnömmai|, |ennomaiyeuon[k].| `Reason' (Section "Of the Human Faculties.")    C.7/158.)√

    |Logick   the Rule    where by     every   thing,    every   Speech      is composed, analysed,         or   opened      to be known.        |
    \nt +
    |ANomayag ne kukkuhwheg, ne nashpe nishnoh teag, kah nishnoh keket∞kaonk mo∞wam∞, kah kogáhkenaanum∞m∞, asuh woshwunum∞∞ wahtamunak.|    Log.Pr.[1] { 3.s. changed conjunct }

    \se |unnomaiyeue|
    \nt +
    \ps PreV (?)
    \ge `reasonable, with(out) reason'
    \so Ps.35.7(M), C.
    |Newutche matta unnomaiyeue ut pasahtheganit nupponahshaponkuppanneg, ne matta unnomaiyeue wonnahteahhitteup wutche nukketeahogkou.| `For without cause have they hid for me their net, in a pit, which without cause they have digged for my soul.|    Ps.35.7(M)
    \xv Enomaiyeue,
    \xe Reasonable,
    \so C.28/174

\et As a localistic figure, this matches quite well H. 759 *eΘamowi II `lead', as "what leads thither". The final, listed for this item only at H. p.243, is explicit in Cq.37b-38a: |-AMO|, `chemin, route' as |Andi enamok mikan?| `Où conduit ce chemin?'. See also e.g. Bar.153a, Frs.109a. (Is it tempting to see |may| `way, path', Lp.A. |mai| `chemin' as connected?)


\lx unnompamau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\nt Remark: At present, a hapax, supported only by related forms and comparative evidence.
\ps TA
\ge `to profit sb', "to be useful to sb"
\so Lk.8.28; v.i., Job 15.3, for participial form (to an indefinite object stem?)
    \xv ..., Toh kittinnompomsh, Jesus ken Wunnaumonuh GOD quanunkquapit? k∞wehquetumaush áhque onkapunaneh.
    \xe ..., What have I to do with thee, Jesus, thou Son of God most high? I beseech thee, torment me not.
    \so Lk.8.28

    \se unnompaseu
    \ps AI, middle reflexive
    \ge `to profit'
    \so Gen.37.26
    \xv , Toh kittinnompasimun nushogkut kematun, kah adtahtauog ∞sqheonk?
    \xe What profit is it if we slay our brother and conceal his blood?
    \so Gen.37.26
    \ng as "how do we benefit...?"

    \se unnompamukqussu
    \ps AI, dispositional
    \ge `profitable'
    \so Lk.17.10
    \xv ...nenawun matta toh nuttinnompamukqusseumun, webe nutussenan ne woh aseogup.
    \xe ..., We are unprofitable servants: we have done that which was our duty to do.
    \so Lk.17.10

    \se unnompamukqussue
    \ps PreN, PreV, dispositional
    \ge `profitable'
    \so C.106/229
    \xv Wunnompamukquissüë.
    \xe Profitably
    \so { possibly with initial |wun-|? }

    \se unnompamukquodt
    \ps II, dispositional
    \ge `profitable'
    \so Jer.13.7
    \xv ..., kah kusseh, puttukquobpus anit, matta toh unnompamukquodtinn∞.
    \xe ...: and behold, the girdle was marred, it was profitable for nothing.
    \so Jer.13.7

    \se ánompatam∞e
    \nt Remark: extended form of root, |-ompat|; changed vowel, and possibly negative stem form
    \ps PreN
    \se `profitable'
    \so Job 15.3
    \xv Sun woh keket∞kontam matta toh ánompatam∞e keket∞kaonk? asuh kutt∞wongash nish noh matta toh ánompadtam∞gish?
    \xe Should he reason with unprofitable talk? or with speeches wherewith he can do no good?
    \so Job 15.3
    \ng negative participial form 3->_0p_; indefinite object stem?

[Western Abenaki [abe] |n8dañbédamen| `J'ai affaire de cela, j'en profite', |n8rañbémañ| `Je le récompense, seu, je profite de lui'    R.10/380a,432/519a; see also A.418, s.v. "Profiter" for further examples.
WAbn. |lôbadam| `he uses for some purpose'    D.1.276,2.430.
Algonquian [alg] |ABADJ-| `se servir de, faire usage de', |ABAT-| `utile, qui sert'    Cq.3b,4b.
Cree |âbat-| (rac.) `utile, propre à rendre service, faire usage'; |âpaci-, âpat-| `cure, faith, useful ...'    Lac.D.279a-280b; Alb.E.14ab.
Delaware [del] |Apendamen| `to enjoy, to make use of', |Apensuwi| `useful, enjoyable'; |laapéemeew| TA `find s.o. useful,...'    B&A.22; O'M.127a-128a.
Menominee [mez] |ena∙patεsew| AI, |ena∙patεt| II `he, it is useful thus, good for that'; |-a∙pat| `use, utility'    M.L..51; B.1962, 18.99.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |e@la@be@du@m| `To use'    R.274a.]

\et ?H.714 *eΘa∙p- `potential', H.715-716 *eΘa∙pacihe∙wa TA `use'


\lx unnónat
\va unnau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt Remark: Viewed more helpfully as |uNau|, with mutation in typical contexts. See also, for entries currently scattered through Trumbull's dictionary, the entries |ussinát|, T.175b and |wuttinuh|, T.212b.
    \nt +
\ps v.t. an. / TA(+O); propositional object often in direct speech for indirect speech of original? (examples given hardly illustrate this point!)
\twn !|itam| (|ittam|), TI(+O), s.v. |wuttitam-|
\ge `to tell, to say to'; +`to say sth (un)to sb, to tell sb sth; to speak sth of sb'
\nt G&B.624, s.v. |(wutt)inuh|
\so 2 Sam.17.16; Mt.28.9 {t-sub.}
    \xv ..., kah wuttinuh,...
    \xe ..., and [he] said unto him,...'    Gen.17.1  { 3->3
    \so -pro+0 indicative }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wuttinóuh,...
    \xe And they said vnto him...'    Gen.18.9  { 3p->3
    \so -pro+0 indicative; sim. Gen.19.5 }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., unnonah Abraham, n∞wau,...
    \xe it was told Abraham, saying,...
    \so Gen.22.19
    \ng X->3absent.? (+0) absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah unnon Jerichoe ketass∞t n∞waog ...
    \xe And it was told the king of Jericho, saying, ...
    \so Josh.2.2
    \ng X->3+0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche nen wosketomp agwu nanaânuwaog, kah ayeuteaog nutagwappehtunk, kah yeuoh nuttin monchish, kah monchu,...
    \xe For I am a man under authority, having soldiers under me: and I say tothis man, Go, and he goeth;...
    \so Mt.8.9; sim. Lk.7.8
    \nt +
    \xv ..., pish nuttin kepenumwog, negonne mukkinum∞k taresash,...
    \xe ... I will say to the reapers, Gather ye together first the tares,...
    \so Mt.13.30
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nuttin nukketeahogkou, Keteahogkou, monatash kutáhto maumachìash wadchanausu m∞cheke kodtumwae, anwhôhsish metsish, wuttattash, kah wekontash.
    \xe And I will say to my soul, Soul, thou hast much goods laid up for many years; take thine ease, eat, drink, and be merry.
    \so Lk.12.19
    \nt +
    { Further exs. of 1->3: Jn.7.17; Acts 23.30; 1 Cor.7.8 }
    \xv Kah nuttinnomunnonup nussontimomun N∞wut∞shimun kutchisse,...
    \xe And we said unto my lord, We have a father, an old man,...
    \so Gen.44.20,22
    \ng 1p.->3; c.f. Gen.42.31
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kittinomp kittinneumog, Paudtiegk noh, onk woh nunnau.
    \xe And thou saidst unto thy servants, Bring him down unto me, that I may set mine eyes upon him.
    \so Gen.44.21, sim. 23
    \nt +
    \xv Kah unnau wosketompuh ut nóeu neh senoshkag wunnutcheg, Neepaush.  Kah nah wuttinuh, Sun wunnegen wunnesen Sabboth dayeu, asuh matchesen?
    \xe And he saith unto the man which had the withered hand, Stand forth. And he saith unto them, Is it lawful to do good on the sabbath days, or to do evil?
    \so Mk.3.3-4
    \nt +
    \xv Kah quenahukquehettit wine, Jesus ohkasoh unnuk, Wanne ahtauóog wine,  Jesus wuttinuh, Mittamwossis, toh kittinhesh? nuthourum asq peyaumun∞h.  Ohkasoh unnauo wuttinneumoh, Uttoh anukqueog, ussek,
    \xe And when they wanted wine, the mother of Jesus saith unto him, They have no wine.  Jesus saith unto her, Woman, what have I to do with thee? mine hour is not yet come.  His mother saith unto the servants, Whatsoever he saith unto you, do it.
    \so Jn.2.3-5
    \nt +
    \xv Peter nauont, unnau Jesusoh, LORD, kah toh yeuoh (pish ussen) wosketomp?  Jesus wuttinuh, Unnantog noh appit na en nuppeyónat wonk, ne toh kittinhukqun asuhkah ken.
    \xe Peter seeing him saith to Jesus, Lord, and what shall this man do?  Jesus saith unto him, If I will that he tarry till I come, what is that to thee? follow thou me.
    \so Jn.21.21-22
    \nt +
    \xv Onk negonne nohtompeantog Ananias, unnau weechekompaumoncheg tagkom∞k ut wutt∞nit.  Neit Paul wuttinuh, God pish kuttágkomuk, ken wompetetusueekommuk,...
    \xe And the high priest Ananias commanded them that stood by him to smite him on the mouth.  Then said Paul unto him, God shall smite thee, thou whited wall:...
    \so Acts 23.2-3
    \nt +
    \xv Neit Agrippa unnau Pauloh, Nahén kussohkah Christan[n]owunneat.  Kah Paul wuttinuh, Nutahchue kodtantam matta webe ken, qut neg wame n∞taitcheg yeu kesukok, matta webe nahen, qut pannuppu ogqunneungqusséog nuhhogkad,...
    \xe Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.  And Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also all thathear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am,...
    \so Acts 26.28-29
    \nt +

    \xv ...? tohwutch mat usseas yeuoh nummittamwus, tohwutch n∞waan neetompas yeuoh? ...
    \xe ...? Why didst thou not tell me, that she was thy wife? [v.19] Why saidst thou, She is my sister? ...
    \so Gen.12.18[-19]
    \ng 2->1+0 preterite subjunctive; note the contrast in usage between |unnau| and |unn∞wau|.
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh Jehovah uppaudtauon Abrahamoh ne anomp.
    \xe ..., that the LORD may bring upon Abraham, that which he hath spoken of him.'    Gen.18.19    { 3->3
    \so +_0_ preterite participle}
    \xv Onk n∞wau howan woh ánont Abrahamoh, Sarah woh n∞sóou mukiesoh?...
    \xe 21.7: And she said, Who would have said unto Abraham, that Sarah should have given children suck? ...'    Gen.21.7  { 3->3
    \so +0 changed conjunct }
    \nt +

    \nt Remark: See s.v. |ussinat| for themes 3 and 4, objective forms, and conjunct and imperative orders.
    \nt +

\cf hennau
\cf unnaunchem∞kauónat

\cf wuttinuh
\nt +

\et A.392, H.778 *eΘe∙wa TA+O


\lx unnont∞wáonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
\ps n. / NI, deverbal noun to !|unnont∞wau| "to speak a language", spec. one's native language; see |-ont∞wá-| T+.110a.
\ge `language' (in its restricted sense, peculiar to a people or nation); `vocal' (i.e. "vowel"), +`speech, tongue [in the sense of language]'
\so Gen.11.1
    \xv kutt∞e unnont∞waonk
    \xe the voice of speech
    \so Ezek.1.24
    \xv kuttinnont∞waonk
    \xe thy speech
    \so (manner of speech)    Mt.26.73


\lx unnont∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\ps AI (also II? -- see ex.)
\dv |unn-|+|-ont∞wá-|
\ge "to sound thus, have such a voice, speech", `to speak [a language]'
\so Rev.1.15

    \xv ..., ne unnont∞wahettit ...
    \xe ..., after their tongues,...
    \so Gen.10.20
    \ng 3p (unchanged) conjunct
    \xv ...: kah ∞wadtauatongqussuonk onatuh ne anont∞wag m∞cheke nippeash.
    \xe ...; and his voice as the sound of many waters.
    \so Rev.1.15

    \se unnont∞wau
    \ps NI, agent noun
    \ge `Vocal'. i.e. "(simple) vowel"
    |Unnontoowaash. / a e i o u. / Neesontoowaash / ai au ei eu eau oi oo ∞ ou.|    Ind.Prim.(1669/1877) A3  { Lists essentially identical to these are labelled as "{Vocals}" and "{Dipthongs}, or {double sounds}" in El.Gr.2 }

    [Narragansett [xnt] |Eenàntowash| `Speake Indian'    R.W.8.]
    \nt +

\et G.1965, no.19, 214a: *-a∙towe∙ `speak a language'; see also entry |-ont∞wá-|, T+.100a.


\lx unnontukquohwhónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
\ps v.t. an. / TA(+O ?) { What is the order of arguments? -- cf. Lk.16.5; number of stems not clear. }
\ge `to owe to another, to owe'
    (|unnohtukquahwhittinneat| `to owe' (`to be in debt')
    \xv kuttinnohtukquahe
    \xe I am in your debt
    \so C.203)
    \xv toh kittinnontukquohhuk
    \xe how much dost thou owe to
    \so Lk.16.5

    \xv anuntukquohwonche
    \xe one who owes
    \so Mt.18.24

    \xv ahque toh unnontukquâwhutteg
    \xe "owe no man anything", do not owe
    \so Rom.13.8

    \se n∞namontukquohh∞waen
    \va -in
    \ps NA
    \ge `a creditor'
    \so Lk.7.41.
\cf n∞namontukquohwhônat

\lx unn∞hamunát

\lx unn∞hkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 173
    \nt +
\ps TA, ?|-hk-aw-| stem
\ge `to drive sb (somewhere)'
\so Deut.4.19,30.1; Mk.1.12; Lk.8.29
    \xv Kah Ishkont kuttahshinnum kuskesukquash en kesukqut, kah nauadt nepauz, kah nanepaushadt kah anogqsog, wame kesukque kenauwameonk, woh kittinn∞kont nag waussumonaout,...
    \xe And lest thou lift up thine eyes unto heaven, and when thou seest the sun, and the moon, and the stars, even all the host of heaven, shouldest be driven to worship them,...
    \so Deut.4.19
    \ng X->2
    \xv Kah teanuk nashauanit, wuttinn∞hkauoh touohkomuk.
    \xe And immediately the spirit driveth him into the wilderness.
    \so Mk.1.12; Lk.8.29

    \xv ..., nish qushkeahtéauan en kutahhut, ut wame wutohtimoneat uttoh Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m an∞hkunkquean.
    \xe ..., and thou shalt call them to mind among all the nations, whither the Lord thy God hath driven thee,
    \so Deut.30.1

\lx unn∞hqueu

\so Trumbull 173
\ps relative root, quantity, spatial distance, temporal; often in changed form |an∞hque|
\ge `so far distant, at such a distance'

    (|uttoh unnuhku@hquat| `how far?'    C.228
    = Narr. |tounúckquaque|    R.W.74)
\cf n∞hqueu

\nt +


\lx unn∞wónat
\va unn∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \ps AI(+O); commonly aphetic, |n∞wau| -- see T.92b-93a.
    \nt +
\twn |unn∞wom∞|
\ge `to speak to, to tell, to command; +`to say sth, speak of sb/sth, to sb'
\nt G&B 514, 722, s.v. |unnoowau| `he says', stem |unuwá-|; see also T.10ab, s.v. |ann∞|, T.92b-93a, s.v. |n∞ónat|.

    \xv ...: Kah Abram wun∞swetauoh ne an∞wadt Sarai.
    \xe .... And Abram hearkened to the voice of Sarai.
    \so Gen.16.2
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne kesukok ne an∞wop GOD.
    \xe ..., in the selfsame day, as God had said unto him.'    Gen.17.24  { 3->3
    \so +_adv_ preterite participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ...: wame ne an∞wadt Sarah n∞tamwe ussish wuttinn∞waonk:...
    \xe ...; in all that Sarah hath said unto thee, hearken unto her voice;...
    \so Gen.21.12
    \ng 3->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne an∞womuk ne pajeh yeu kesukok,...
    \xe ...: as it is said to this day,...
    \so Gen.21.14
    \ng X->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah kusseh wuttinonkumôin ne Boaz an∞wopoh, pomushau,...
    \xe ...: and, behold, the kinsman of whom Boaz spake came by;...'    Ruth 4.1  { 3->_3
    \so _ preterite participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ...; woh n∞wahteauunnan uttiyeu, wuske kuhk∞tomuhteaonk ônag, yeu an∞waanh.
    \xe ..., May we know what this new doctrine, whereof thou speakest, is?
    \so Acts 17.19
    \xv Newutche noh pen∞wontuwaé an∞wodt, matta ken∞nauou wosketompuh, qut Goduh,...
    \xe For he that speaketh in an unknown tongue speaketh not unto men, but unto God:...
    \so 1 Cor.14.2
    \nt +

    \se unn∞waonk
    \ps NI, deverbal noun
    \ge `commandment, voice, word, words'
    \xv ..., N∞tam∞k nuttinn∞waonk,...
    \xe ..., hear my voice,...
    \so Gen.4.23
    \ng 1 possessive

    \se ôunn∞wau
    \ps AI(+O?), reduplicated form of |unn∞wau|
    \ge `to say sth', with some notion of iteration?
    \xv ..., Yeuoh kogkehtumowen, toh ôunn∞wau?...
    \xe ..., What will this babbler say?
    \so Acts 17.18

\cf ann∞
\cf n∞ónat

\et Following G.1990, (128), p.475: PA *e⌠-iw-e∙ AI, to *eΘ- TA(+O) + indefinite animate object final *-iw-, presumably with the general Eastern restoration of the nasal by levelling.


\lx unn∞wom∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \nt +
\ps II(+O)
\twn |unn∞wau|
\ge `to say (sth)'
\so Lk.4.12, Rom.4.3,7.7,10.11, Jas.2.23, Rules C.L. Headings 1,2
    \xv Kah Jesus wunnamp∞hamau wuttinuh n∞wom∞, qutchheuhkon Jehovah kummanitt∞m.
    \xe And Jesus answering said unto him, It is said, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.
    \so Lk.4.12
    |N∞wom∞ Wuttin∞waonk Gad, {Gen.5.22}. {Enohh} weeche pomushau God ...| "The word of God says {Gen.5.22} `Enoch walked with God ...'"    Rules C.L. Heading 2

    \xv .... newutche matta n∞wahteó∞p nanwekodtantamóonk, matta n∞wogus naumatuonk ahque nanwekodtantash.
    \xe ...: for I had not known lust, except the law had said, Thou shalt not covet.
    \so Rom.7.7
    \xv Kah wussukwhonk mo pakodche nnihyeup, ne an∞wom∞ukup, Abraham wunnamptauop Goduh,...
    \xe And the scripture was fulfilled which saith, Abraham believed God,...
    \so Jas.2.23

\lx unnukkuhque
\va nukkukque
\va nukukqueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \nt +
\ps PreV, II, relative stem, of degree, extent
\nt Remark: As usual with such forms, it can be hard to determine which instances are in fact verbs. As an interim measure, no attempt is made to separate them here.
\ge `(so, thus) big, long, much' (space and time)
\so Gen.15.15; Deut.31.27; Ps.39.5; Mt.6.23; Mk.9.21; Jn.14.9; Heb.10.29
    \xv ..., ash waeeche pomantam∞munogkup yeu kesukok, kutayeuuhkonomw∞ Jehovah, kah uttoh wonk nukkukqueu mahche nuppon?
    \xe ..., while I am yet alive with you this day, ye have been rebellious against the Lord; and how much more after my death?
    \so Deut.31.27
    \xv Pish kuppeyam koweenohkeit k∞nenukkukquiinneat,...
    \xe Thou shalt come to the grave in a full age,...
    \so Job.5.26
    \xv ... kuttogquehteoh nukkesukkodumash munnitcheg ne anukkuhque kushkag, kah nuttunukkuhquiyeuonk wanne teag ut anaquabean:...
    \xe ..., thou hast made my days as an hand-breadth, and mine age is as nothing before thee:...
    \so Ps.39.5(M); (E): |menutcheg neanuhkuhque kiskag|
    \xv ..., yowutche k∞wequa∞m ne apehtunkquean, pohkenag toh unnukkukqueu missi ne pohkenai.
    \xe ... . If therefore the light that is in thee be darkness, how great is that darkness!
    \so Mt.6.23
    |..., Tohnukkukqueu yeuh uppeyaonukqushoh? kah n∞wau, Magkiesuut.| `..., How long is it ago since this came unto him? And he said, Of a child.    Mk.9.21
    \xv ..., Anuhkuhque weetômun kah asquam k∞waheuh, Phillip? ...
    \xe ..., Have I been so long time with you, and yet hast thou not known me, Philip? ...
    \so Jn.14.9; (M): |Sun ne kuttunukkuhque wetomununneau|

\nt Remark: There are also instances that appear to lack the first |-uk-|, as Jn.11.36(E) (compare (M)), 2 Cor.8.3. It is not yet clear whether this is a phonological or a morphological difference.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |Éreghikk8^i| `tant il est, &c.'    R.P.12/552b-553a.
Algonquian [alg] |INIKIK| `ce qui, ce que; telle quantité, tant que; pendant l'espace de, durant'    Cq.128a.
Menominee [mez] |εNεkohkw-| `so big', |i∙Nεkohkw-| `of that size' (plural)    B.1962, 15.311, 326, 22.37, 443, 22.42, 444.]


\lx unnukquominneat
\va nukquom
\va unnukquom
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), C-final stem; often with cognate object calqued on AV, and hence on the Hebrew.
\ge `to dream'
    \dv |uN-| `so' + |-ukwôm-| AI `sleep'
    \nt +
\so Gen.41.17, +Gen.31.24,40.5
    \xv unnukquom
    \xe he dreamed
    \so Gen.41.1,5
    \xv ..., nuttinnukquómun unnukquom∞onk,...
    \xe ..., We have dreamed a dream,...
    \so Gen.40.8
    \nt +

    \se !|unnukquomwehtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O), directive final |-htaw-|
    \ge `to dream (sth) of sb'
    \so Gen.42.9

    \xv Onk Joseph mehquontam wuttinnukquom∞ongash nah ánukquomwehtauwomp,...
    \xe And Joseph remembered the dreams which he dreamed of them,...'    Gen.42.9  { 3->3
    \so +_0_ preterite participle }

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |nedereg8^assi `Je rêve, en dormant; je songe'    R.443/522b,464/530a. (with final *-enkwa?⌠i- `sleep', H. p.245, B.1962, 15.258, p.319)
    \nt +
WAbn. |Leguaso{wôgan}.| `A dream.'    L.23. (same final)
Lp.A |neteleg8am| `je pense en dormant a tuer quelqu un'    D.52.
Mahican [mjy] |Nò o@no@quààm.| `Ich habe schön geträumt.'    Schm.59.
Delaware [del] |n'delungwam.| `I dream'; |lóngwaam| AI `have a dream'    Voc.61/B&A.171; O'M.142a.]

\et H. p.245 *-enkwa∙m(-wa) `sleep', B.1962, 15.128-129, p.298.

\lx unnunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \nt +
\nt Remark: |ununô-|; for final, see s.v. |pummunau|, T.135b.
\dv |un-| + |-un-ô-| `to fly'
\ps AI
\ge `to fly'
\so Is.6.6; Rev.12.14
    \xv Neit pasuk Seraphim unnunau nuhhogkat,...
    \xe Then flew one of the seraphim unto me,...
    \so Is.6.6
    \ng 3 indicative


\lx unnunkumau
\va innunkumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge `to have sb as a kinsman, to be of the kindred of sb'
\so Ruth 2.3
    \xv ... Boaz, neh wuttinnunkumópoh Elimelech.
    \xe ... Boaz, who was of the kindred of Elimelech.
    \so Ruth 2.3
    \ng Despite the AV text, this is most simply treated as an independent form. The failure to translate a relative clause by means of a participle is not unprecedented.
    \xv Kah yeuyeu sunnummatta Boaz kittinnunkumoun, nô mo weetomadt ummaidumoh?
    \xe And now is not Boaz of our kindred, with whose maidens thou wast?
    \so Ruth 3.2
    \ng 12->3 negative objective

    \xv Kah unnau anunkumoncheh,...
    \xe And he said unto the kinsman,...'    Ruth 4.3 { 3->3', i.e. "him (3') that he (3) was related to (3
    \so )" }

    \se unnunkumauau
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem
    \ge ?"to have sb as a kinsman through sb"
    \so Ruth 2.1
    \xv KAh Naomi wessukeh wuttìnnunkumauoh mishénaétuen,...
    \xe And Naomi had a kinsman of her husband's, a mighty man of wealth,...
    \so Ruth 2.1
    \ng Analyzed as: "Naomi had a mighty man of wealth as a kinsman through her husband", the "dative" expressing the affinal "route" that links them.

    \se |unnunkumau|
    \nt +
    \ps NA, undergoer, by conversion from the TA stem
    \ge `kinsman'
    \so Gen.12.1; Ruth 2.20,3.2
    \nt Remark: See also under |wuttinnunkumôin|, T.212b.
    \xv ..., wosketomp kuppaswauwômukqun, pasuk noh nahohtoe kuttinnunkumoun.
    \xe ..., The man is near of kin unto us, one of our next kinsmen.
    \so Ruth 2.20
    \xv Wonkom∞k Herodian nuttinnonkum,...
    \xe Salute Herodion my kinsman. ...
    \so Rom.16.11
    \ng This is not of the required form--perhaps simply the verb, "I have him as kinsman"
    \nt ?

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |nederañg8'mañ| `Je l'ai p'r parens', |8d.| 3.; |érañg8m8'ghik, érañg8mátsik, érañg8mañtsi.| `Mes parens, tes p., &c.'    R.378/499.
    \nt +
WAbn. |Alôgomômek.| `The relation.'; `the relative; one is related to him'; |álôkómokík| `my relatives', |álôkómocí| `his relatives'     L.20; D.1.34; W.135.]

\et G.1965, no.11, 213a: *eΘa∙nko∙me∙wa; A.374, H.712: *eΘa∙nkwime∙wa `he has him as (that kind of) relative'. Compare the formation at B.1962, 16.13, 332-333: |ena∙wε∙mε∙w| `he is related to him'. The |-um-| looks like the possessive theme sign, but on this analysis is merely an instance of the TA final |-m-|. Western Abenaki |alôgomômek| is presumably an X->_3_ participle. (Day categorizes it as "AI isc".)


\lx unnunum
\va unninnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \nt +
\ps TI1b, manual final
\ge `to guide sth, set sth (in some way)'
\so Gen.48.14; Num.24.1
    \xv ...: waantamwe unninum wúhpittenash...
    \xe ..., guiding his hands wittingly;...
    \so Gen.48.14
    \ng 3->0(p) absolute
    \xv ..., qut unnunum wuskesuk nogque touohkomuk.
    \xe ..., but he set his face toward the wilderness.
    \so Num.24.1
    \ng 3->0 absolute

\et H.788 *eΘenamwa TI `to handle'


\lx unnunnumauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Content of original entry |aninnumau| { r. |aninnumauau| }, T.9b, transferred here. Forms with the expected |unn-| and |inn-| are common, and there is an occasional |enn-|. Forms in |a-| seem to be surprisingly common in the imperatives. Note the likelihood of syncopated forms, per G&B.482-483, clearly attested in their entry for this verb, ib., 723-724. (Phonological conditions unclear.)
\ps TA+O, relative root |un-| + manual final+dative final
\ge `to give sb sth, to deliver sb (to) sb, minister sth to sb; to sell sth to sb, to show sth unto sb'; `to make sb of sb'; as TA: `to help sb'
\so common
\nt G&B 723, s.v. |(nutt)unnunnummau|
    \xv ...: kah wonk wuttinnumaun wasukeh weeche,...
    \xe ..., and gave also unto her husband with her,...'    Gen.3.6  { 3->3
    \so +0-pro, syncopated }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., , K∞skannemunneog nuttinnumauóneau yeu ohke:...
    \xe ..., Unto thy seed will I give this land:
    \so Gen.12.7
    \ng 1->3p-pro+0 objective, syncopated
    \nt +
    \xv ..., teaguas kittinninnúmah...
    \xe ...., what wilt thou giue me,...?...
    \so Gen.15.2
    \ng 2->1+0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnumauunoh wessukeh Abram...
    \xe ... and gave her to her husband Abram,...'    Gen.16.3  { 3->3'+3
    \so -pro objective, syncopated }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah n∞wau, Chauguash kittinnumauush, kah Jakob n∞wau, Matta teag kittinnumaiyeuh:...
    \xe And he said, What shall I give thee? And Jacob said, Thou shalt not give me any thing:...
    \so Gen.30.31
    \ng 1->2+0 absolute; 2->1+0 negative, syncopated
    \nt +
    \xv ..., neit pish kittinnumánumw∞ kematou,...
    \xe ...: so will I deliver you your brother,...
    \so Gen.42.34
    \ng 1->2p+3 indicative, syncopated
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah kuttinnummoush madtauánukeg missinninnuog,...
    \xe ..., and I will make of thee a multitude of people,...
    \so Gen.48.4
    \ng 1->2+3(p) absolute, syncopated
    \nt +
    \xv Tohneit Jehovah tapeneunkqueog, neit woh kuppas∞qun yeu ohkeit, kah woh kittinnumunkqunan,...
    \xe If the Lord delight in us, then he will bring us into this land, and give it us;...
    \so Num.14.8
    \ng 3->12+0 objective, syncopated
    \nt +
    \xv Nen Jehovah kum-Manitt∞mw∞, sohh∞wunukqueóg wutch ohkeit Egypt: kittinnumauunnaóut ohke Kanaan, k∞-Manitt∞munneaóut nen.
    \xe I am the Lord your God, which brought you forth out of the land of Egypt, to give you the land of Canaan, and to be your God.
    \so Lev.25.38
    \ng 1->2p+0 t-subordinative; double syncopation
    \nt +
    \xv Wonk matta kuppas∞∞mun ohkeit ne tomogkok sogkodtunk kah hony, kittinnummiinneanónut ohteakone kah weenominneohtekone ahtôonk:...
    \xe Moreover thou hast not brought us into a land that floweth with milk and honey, or given us inheritance of fields and vineyards:...
    \so Num.16.14
    \ng 2->1p+0 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Wamé teanteaquasinish nuttinnumont wutch N∞shut,...
    \xe All things are delivered to me of my Father:...
    \so Lk.10.22
    \ng X->1+0(p) absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ...: nag kittinnumonteánunk mag∞onk wutche Jehovah,...
    \xe ...: to you they are given as a gift for the Lord,...
    \so Num.18.6
    \ng X->2p+3p(NA)
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche ussenat yeu pumminum∞onk matta webe wuttinnumauôun ne quenauhúkquehettit wunetupanatogig, qut ...
    \xe For the administration of this service not only supplieth the want of the saints, but ...
    \so 2 Cor.9.12
    \nt +

    \xv ..., Mittamwossis ne anumaiyean n∞weetomuneat ...
    \xe ..., The woman whom thou gavest {to be} with me,...
    \so Gen.3.12
    \ng 2->1+_3_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wame ne pish ánumaiyean wunnamuhkut pish kittinumaush nishnoh pìukque chippai.
    \xe ...: and of all that thou shalt give me I will surely give the tenth unto thee.
    \so Gen.28.22
    \ng 2->1+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wame wunnomwausséonk, ne anumauadt kittinneúm,...
    \xe ..., and of all the truth, which thou hast showed unto thy servant;...
    \so Gen.32.10
    \ng 2->3+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., neg nunnaumonunk GOD anumaiitcheh yeu ut,...
    \xe ..., These are my sons, whom God hath given me in this place. ...'    Gen.48.9  { 3->1+_3
    \so _ participle }
    \nt +
    \xv Yeuh wunnaumonuh Zilpah, Laban anummaompuh Leahoh wuttaunoh,...
    \xe These are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to Leah his daughter;...'    Gen.46.18  { 3->3'+_3
    \so _ preterite participle }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah kemat nano matchekit kenugke kenaau, kah aninnumáuunumuk ...
    \xe And if thy brother that dwelleth by thee be waxen poor, and be sold unto thee;...
    \so Lev.25.39
    \ng X->2 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Ann∞s wosketompaog onk woh natinneohkontamwog ohke Kanaan ne anumauog wunnaumonuh Israel. ...
    \xe Send thou men, that they may search the land of Canaan, which I give unto the children of Israel:...
    \so Num.13.2
    \ng 1->3+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Qut uppiukque ch(i)ppiyeum∞ wunnaumonuh Israel, nish pish anumauahetticheh Jehovah, wutche tatashinnumwe mag∞onk, nuttinnumauoneau Levitsog wutche ahtôonk:...
    \xe But the tithes of the children of Israel, which they offer as an heave offering unto the Lord, I have given to the Levites to inherit:...
    \so Num.18.24
    \ng 3p->3+_0(p)_ participle; on the inanimate plural ending, see G&B 549.
    \nt +
    \xv ...kah upposekinôuh wadchuut, ne wadtaumaiog Phineasut wunnaumonuh, ne anumauut ut Ephraime wadchuut.
    \xe ...; and they buried him in a hill that pertained to Phinehas his son, which was given him in mount Ephraim.
    \so Josh.24.33
    \ng X->3+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nux kutaninnumoush,...
    \xe ...; yea, I will help thee;...
    \so { 1->2 indicative }    Is.41.10
    \xv ...: wuttattamwaitch ne N∞sh anumaiyeup, matta woh n∞tattam∞un?
    \xe ...: the cup which my Father hath given me, shall I not drink it?
    \so Jn.18.11
    \ng 3->1+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Peyôog kutohtue ohkeyeuout, ne anumauunog.
    \xe ..., When ye be come into the land of your habitations, which I give unto you,
    \so Num.15.2
    \ng 1->2p+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Yeuyeu noh anummaont wuskannemuneash ohkehteaénoh, aninnumunk∞k petukqunnunk wutch kummetsuongan∞; kah...
    \xe Now he that ministereth seed to the sower both minister bread for your food, and ...'    2 Cor.9.10 { _3_->3
    \so +0 participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ... wunneetupanatamwe an∞teamowonganit, neanummaut
    \xe ..., the holy commandment delivered unto them.
    \so 2 Pet.2.21
    \ng X->3+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Kah ohke aninnumauau mittamwossissoh,...
    \xe And the earth helped the woman;...'    Rev.12.16  { 0->3
    \so absolute }

    imperat. 2d+1st sing. |..., Yeu aninnumah uppuhkuk John kutchessummúaénin ...| `..., Give me here John Baptist's head ....'    Mt.14.8√  { 2->1+0 imperative }
    Imperat. 2d pl. |..., aninnumok metsuonk| `...; give ye them to eat.'    Mt.14.16√  { 2p->3(p)+0 imperative }
    \xv ... aninnumaiegk ohtauunat posekinittuae ohke,...
    \xe ...: give me a possession of a buryingplace with you,...
    \so Gen.23.4
    \ng 2p->1+0 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Yeuyeu kesukok enninnumah kummohtomegitteaowonk.
    \xe ..., Sell me this day thy birthright.
    \so Gen.25.31
    \ng 2->1+0 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv Hah eninnumauontuh Ishmaelitsog,...
    \xe Come, and let us sell him to the Ishmaelites,...
    \so Gen.37.27
    \ng 1p->3(p)+3 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., aninnumaiinean petukqunneg,...
    \xe ..., Give us bread,...
    \so Gen.47.15
    \ng 2->1p+0 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche yeuyeu uninnumah yeu wadchu ...
    \xe Now therefore give me this mountain,...
    \so Josh.14.12
    \ng 2->1+0 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., neg wáapehéttich, kah aninnumungk∞k,...
    \xe ...? let them rise up and help you,...
    \so Deut.32.38
    \ng 3p->2p imperative, despite context
    \nt +
    (|aninnumeh| `help thou me'    Ps.22.19; 38.22
    \xv ..., teanuk aninnumah woi Jehovah.
    \xe ...; make haste to help me, O LORD.
    \so Ps.70.1
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv Ken ununu@mah.
    \xe Give thou me
    \so C.53/192)
    \ng with fairly full independent absolute paradigm

\cf annúmau

[Narragansett [xnt] |Kuttánnummi?| `Will you helpe me?'; |Anúnema| `Helpe me'.    R.W.39.√]

\et *eΘenamawe∙wa, etc.: H.787-788


\lx un]nussu
\va unnussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
    \nt Remark: See also s.v. !|neanussu|, T.80ab
    \nt +
\ps AI
\twn |unni|, |unnai|, |nnih|, II
\dv |un-| `thither, thus' + |-us-i-| AI
\ge `(he is) shaped or formed, made like, made such as' [unnussu]; +`to be so, such, to be after sbs kind, after the manner of sb'
    \xv toh unnussu
    \xe what form is he of?
    \so 1 Sam.28.14
    \xv mukhogkat nussu
    \xe in bodily shape
    \so Lk.3.22
    \xv ..., pish kenemun nequt chippissuog wutch napanna tahchinchagkodtut, wutch missinninnuog, wutch k∞washinog, wutch assesog, kah wutch floksut, wame nish noh wuttinussinneau puppinashimwog,...
    \xe .., thou shalt take one portion of fifty, of the persons, of the beeves, of the asses, and of the flocks, of all manner of beasts,...
    \so Num.31.20
    \nt +

    \xv ..., Ayeuontuh wosketomp neanséog ...
    \xe ..., Let us make man in our image,...
    \so Gen.1.26
    \ng 1p->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Puppinshasog neanussehettit neetasuog neanussehettit,...
    \xe Of fowls after their kind, and of cattle after their kind,...
    \so Gen.6.20
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wunnaumonáeu nehenwonche wutogqunneunkqussuongano, kah neánusit;...
    \xe ..., and begat a son in his own likeness, after his image;...
    \so Gen.5.4
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut nano ian∞wussuog, neane neansehetteup,...
    \xe ...; but they were still ill-favoured, as at the beginning. ...
    \so Gen.41.21
    \ng 3p preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv .... nen yeu ánusse,...
    \xe ..., such a man as I ...
    \so Gen.44.16
    \ng 1->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv matta n∞wahteaou neanussit
    \xe I could not discern the form thereof
    \so (an.)    Job 4.16
    \xv neanussit God
    \xe in the form (likeness) of God
    \so Phil.2.6
    \xv Newutche nagum naum, kah monchu, kah teanuk wanántam toh ánussis wosketomp.
    \xe For he beholdeth himself, and goeth his way, and straightway forgetteth what manner of man he was.
    \so Jas.1.24
    \ng s-preterite, as G&B 566-568 (c.f. |-hettis| forms from El.Gr.), like the indirect question, Mayhew Jn.20.15?; |ánussit| attested e.g. Mt.17.21
    \nt +

\xv Qut yeug, ahennusséhetteup nishkeneungque puppinashimwog, neg ayeuutcheg tohqunonat kah paguanónat,...
\xe But these, as natural brute beasts, made to be taken and destroyed,...
\so 2 Pet.2.12
\ng 3p preterite participle to changed reduplicated stem; sense?

\cf neane
\cf neaunak
\cf nussu
\cf neanussu
\nt +

    [Delaware [del] |Lissin| `to be so; to do so;...', |Wtellsin| `to be so, to do so'     B&A.65,169.]
    \nt +

\et H. lists no stem *eΘ-es-i- AI.


\lx un]nussuonk
\va innussuong
\va unnussuonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 174
\ps n. / NI?, deverbal; perhaps dependent?
\ge `form or shape' (of an. obj.?), + and translating many other AV terms: `countenance, frame, image, pattern, similitude,...'
    \xv ...: kuttinsuonk ummuskouánatamheuh m∞cheke.
    \xe ...: thou hast made him exceeding glad with thy countenance.
    \so Ps.21.6(E&M)
    \ng 2 possessor
    \nt +
    \xv wuttinnussuonk
    \xe his form
    \so Is.52.14
    \xv ut nehewonche wuttinnussuonganit
    \xe in his own image
    \so Gen.1.27
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnussuonk Jehovahnoh pish naum,...
    \xe ...; and the similitude of the Lord shall he behold:...
    \so Num.12.8
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Naum∞k wuttinnussuonk wut-Altarumut Jehovah,...
    \xe ..., Behold the pattern of the altar of the Lord,...
    \so Josh.22.28
    \ng Anchor Bible: "replica"
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche wahteo nuttinsuonkanun: unnummehquantam nuppuppissiyeuoomun.
    \xe For he knoweth our frame: he remembreth that we are dust.
    \so Ps.102.14(M)
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wuttinnussuongan∞ locustsog ogqunneunkqussuog horsesut quogquoshwéhtamwéhettit ayeuwuttuonk,...
    \xe And the shapes of the locusts were lke unto horses prepared unto battle;...
    \so Rev.9.7
    \nt +

\lx uppuhkuk

    `scalp'    Ps.68.21
    \xv ..., kah uppuhkuk∞∞ásh horsesog, onatuh uppuhkuk∞ash qunnon∞og,...

    \so Rev.9.17
    \ng 3p possessor 0p
    \nt +
    \xv Matta pish kuttummutchanóhhamómw∞ ut kuppuhkuhk∞out,...
    \xe Ye shall not round the corners of your heads,...
    \so Lev.19.27

    \nt +
    \xv Qut mittamwossis qunuhquoant, ne wussohsumóonk, newutche uppúhkuk aninnumauonan wutch woh upputtag∞humunat.

    \so 1 Cor.11.15

    \so Deut.28.44

    \xe ...: he shall be the head, and thou shalt be the tail.
    \so Deut.28.44

    \se !|uppuhkehk∞waheau|

    \so Deut.1.15,28.13

    \ng "over you" untranslated
    \xv Kah Jehovah k∞puhkehk∞wahik, kah matta wussukqunaiyeh,...
    \xe And the Lord shall make thee the head, and not the tail;...
    \so Deut.28.13

\lx ushpuhquáinat

\ps v.i. / AI
    \dv |ushp-| `up(wards)' + |-uhqu(á)-| `eye, face' + |-i-|?, AI bahuvrihi The verb shows signs of having a long-vowel stem, but, unusually for a bahuvrihi, with a final in |-i-| of some kind, the |-á-| perhaps being associated with the noun stem.
    \nt +
\ge `to look upward', +`to lift up one's eyes'

    \so Mk.6.41

    \xv nuttushpoquáim
    \xe [I] will look up.
    \so Ps.5.3√; (M) without accent
    \xv ishpuhquain
    \xe to look up
    \so Ps.40.12; (M) |uspuhquaenat|

    \xv Kah ashpuhquait natauwompu...

    \xv aspuhquait
    \xe when he looked (up)

\lx ushqu-
\va usqu-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 175
    \nt +
\ps initial
\ge "left (over), remaining (as residue)"
\so lemmas below

[Western Abenaki [abe] |ésk8^akena8a i8 mitseb8.| `Il y reste encore q^q^ ch.'    R.507/544b.
Algonquian [alg] |ICKO-| `de reste'; |Ickose| `il y en a de reste, il en reste', with derivatives in |-h-| and |-n-|    Cq.115b-116a.
Cree |Isko'näo| TA `He leaves him or them, he lets them remain (after working at, or killing the others', |Isko'num| `He leaves it (i.e., after taking or using the rest)'; x|ISKW| (rac.) `le dernier, à la fin, en dernier lieu, au dernier rang'    Frs.258b-261a; LacD.354a-355a.
Fox |a⌠kwi| PreV `saving, leaving'; |a⌠kwi∙wa| `he stays behind', |a⌠kwe∙yawi| `at the very end'    Fx.L.21.
Ill. {R} |Isc8∙ isc8i, saepe ic8| `marque du deffaut'    Grv.176/126b.
M.-P. |esqiyak| `leftovers', |esqopu| AI `s/he is last one left, is left over', |sqiye| AI, II ``s/he, it is left over' (food, building materials, etc.)    F&L.
Menominee [mez] |eski∙ciakan| `last-born child', |eski∙hsen| AI, |eski∙hnen| II `he, it is left to the last, left over'    M.L.60.
Miami |ehkwihtam-| TI `set aside, left over from eating'    B&C.36a.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |e@skwaadoo; e@skoodu@m| `To leave'; |eskwiyaq| II, |eskwiyet| AI `leftover; remainder'; |eskwàlêt| TA `you leave someon or something animate behind or towards the back of a group', |eskwàdùn| TI `you leave something behind'    R.156a; LeB.15b; MCS.139a.
Shawnee [sjw] |⌠kw-| `RESERVED FRACTION OF GOODS', |ni⌠kona| `I left it there after giving part of it away'    D.-V.315.]

\et H.684-687: *e⌠kwi∙wa AI `left'

    \ps AI, predicative final
    \ge `to be a woman'
    \so currently unattested as such; cf. |kogkeusquau| `to be a harlot', T.39a; |sekousquau|, T+.147b; |sonksquau| `to be a queen', T+.154a, etc.

    \se ushquain
    \va usquain
    \nt !
    \ps NA, ?deverbal noun
    \ge literally "the being a woman, womanhood", metonymically as `womb'; see Notes and Queries on Gen.49.25.
    \so only currently known from (E0). Gen.20.18,25.23,24,29.31,30.2,22,49.25
    \xv wame usquàinneuh ut weekit Abimelech
    \xe all the wombs of the house Abimelech
    \so Gen.20.18
    \xv neesinash wutohtimòineash ohtàash kutishquàuneate
    \xe Two nations are in thy womb
    \so Gen.25.23
    \xv & woshwunúmauoh wutusquaen
    \xe and opened her wombe
    \so Gen.30.22

    \se usquoshim(w
    \nt Remark: Rare(?) form of |squa-| lacking aphesis of |u-|.
    \ps NA; see also T.155a, s.v. |squáshim|.
    \ge "she beast"
    \so Gen.12.16

[Narragansett [xnt] |Squàws-suck| `Woman-women.', |paúsuck squàw.| `One woman,'    R.W.27,126/r.134.]

\lx ushqueu

\ps AI
\twn ?|ushqueyeu|, II
\ge `to remain' (in the sense, "to be left over, be a remainder")

    \xv ... wanne howan ushqueu.
    \xe ..., we left none to remain.
    \so Deut.2.34
    \ng no obvious reason for loose translation

    \so _ participle }

    \xe ...for the families of the children of Kohath that remained.

\lx usph∞wáonk

\ps n. / deverbal noun to |uspuhh∞| (inf.)
\ge [`a high place' (?)] `a refuge'

    |... nequtta tashinash otanash pish kutusph∞aongan∞oash.| (E1&2) `..., six cities shall ye have for refuge.'    Num.35.13
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nish pish k∞tushp∞h∞aonganinneaoash wutch noh ann∞tont musqueheonk.
    \xe ...: and they shall be your refuge from the avenger of blood.

    \se spúhh∞wáongánu∞

    \ng 1p->0(p) absolute


\lx uspuhh∞
\va ushp-
\va sp-
\va sp∞h-
\va sph∞-
\va spuhh∞au
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 175
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `to flee for refuge'
    \xv ..., pish wutusphoan pasuk yeush otanash, & pish pomantam
    \xe ...; he shall flee unto one of those cities, and live:
    \so Deut.19.5
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah spuhh∞waog touohkomukque mayut.
    \xe ..., and [they] fled by the way of the wilderness.
    \so Josh.8.15√
    \xv ..., kah wanne menuhkesuonganeog yeu wutusp∞hoanaout asuh yeu nogque:...
    \xe ..., and they had no power to flee this way or that way:...
    \so Josh.8.20
    \nt +
    \xv Noh nashteadt pehcheu, kah asq ananatam∞g howane nashont, onk woh na wutushpuhh∞un,...
    \xe That the slayer that killeth any person unawares and unwittingly may flee thither:...

    \nt +
    \xv Kah mittamwossis spuhh∞au touohkomuk,...
    \xe And the woman fled into the wilderness,...
    \so Rev.12.6
    \nt +

    \xv Kah yeu wuttinniyeuonk nushehteaen na pish ashph∞adt, onk woh pomantam,...
    \xe And this is the case of the slayer, which shall flee thither, that he may live:...
    \so Deut.19.4
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah missinninnuog neg asph∞acheg touohkomuk, adtumehtauaog n∞swehtohukquehetticheh.
    \xe ...: and the people that fled to the wilderness turned back upon the pursuers.
    \so Josh.8.20
    \nt +
    \xv Kah noh asp∞adt pasuk yeush otanash,...
    \xe And when he that doth flee unto one of those cities ...

    \xe ..., Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and flee into Egypt,...
    \so Mt.2.13
