\lx uspunauónat
\va ushpun-
\va aspun-
\va ashpun-
\va spun-
\va ushpunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 175
\nt Remark: The forms in |a-| are presumably changed conjunct forms.
\ps AI+"O", long-vowel stem; the relative root initial ("so") may be cataphoric to nominal expressions, giving the verb the appearance of taking an object.
\ge `to happen unexpectedly, to chance'; +`to befall sb, unto sb'
\ge `to ail or to be ailing'
    an.subj. |toh kutushpunam| `what aileth thee?'    Judg.18.23 { 2->0 }
    \xv Toh kuttushpunnamus, woi kehtoh, waj wussemweoph?...
    \xe What ailed thee, O thou sea, that thou fleddest?..
    \so Ps.114.5(M); (E1&2): |kuttinnai|
    \nt +
    \xv toh kutushpinam
    \xe What aileth thee?
    \so 2 Sam.14.5√
    \xv toh ushpunaog missinnuog
    \xe what aileth the people?
    \so 1 Sam.11.4
    \xv ... Tohspinau Hagar, ahque wabesish,...
    \xe ..., What aileth thee, Hagar? fear not;...
    \so Gen.21.17√
    \ng verb form (all editions) appears to be 3 indicative (recognized by Trumbull in his gloss: "what aileth thee (her?)"; for the correct 2 form, compare Judg.18.23, 2 Sam.14.5, Ps.114.5(M) above and the Narragansett form in Williams, below.
    \xv ..., kah nish wutushpunónash:...
    \xe ...; and such things have befallen me:...
    \so Lev.10.19; for the error, compare Lev.10.19(1): |... kah nish nutushpunonash:...|
    \ng AI+O, or subordinative form, with |nish| as the correlate of the relative root
    \nt +

\nt The forms of this verb are irregular. It is generally used intransitively after an animate subject, which in the English translation becomes the object.  { A dark saying. Perhaps the verb is more helpfully to be thought of as like "for sb to fall under sth, suffer sth" ("undergo") than as "for sth to befall sb", i.e. with the experiencer expression as subject. }
    Occasionally the animate form (|ushpunónat|) is introduced, as in Eccl.3.19:  { This must be a misunderstanding on Trumbull's part; there is no difference between the two sets of examples. I have reorganized the examples that follow into three blocks. }
    \xv ne ashpunahettit ... wosketompaog, ne wutushpunóneau puppinashimwog, pasuk ushpunáog wame
    \xe that which befalleth ... men [which men may encounter by chance], befalleth beasts, even one thing befalleth them [all]
    \so Eccl.3.19
    \xv tatuppe uspunâog wame
    \xe one event happeneth to them all
    \so Eccl.2.14
    \xv nag wame ... ushpunaog
    \xe chance happeneth to them all
    \so Eccl.9.11
    \xv ne ashpunadt mattamog, ne nutushpinon
    \xe as it happeneth to the fool so it happeneth to me
    \so Eccl.2.15

    \xv Wunnamuhkut nnag, tohwutch yeu spinai?
    \xe ..., If it be so, why am I thus?...
    \so Gen.25.22
    \ng 1->_0_ conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ummishamáuneau wame ne aspunánit,...
    \xe ..., and told him all that befell unto them,...'    Gen.42.29  { ?3
    \so ->_0_ changed conjunct }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnóneau wame ashpunáhettit.
    \xe ..., and told him all things that befell them:
    \so Josh.2.23
    \ng 3p->_0(p)_
    \nt +
    \xv tohwutch wame yeu spunnaog
    \xe why is all this befallen us?
    \so Judg.6.13
    \ng 1p->_0_
    \xv matta wahte∞un uttôh ashpinai
    \xe not knowing what things shall befall me' (`may happen to me
    \so )    Acts 20.22
    \ng 1->_0_

    \xv shpunnadti toh kod shpunnai
    \xe let come on me what will
    \so Job 13.13
    \ng 1->0 imperative; 1->_0_ conjunct
\cf miskauau

    \se !|ushpunnamau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, with locutionary final |-m-|?
    \ge `to reproach sb'; also occ. `to accuse sb; to mock sb'
    \nt Remark: The verb (and the derived noun) is used more often in Mayhew's texts.
    \so Gen.39.17; Ps.74.22(M),79.12; Jn.5.45
    \xv ..., nuppetukunk onk woh nutaiuspunámuk.
    \xe ..., [he] came in unto me to mock me:'    Gen.39.17 { Potiphar
    \so s wife speaking; presumably a reduplicated form. }
    \xv Nummatwomog nuttushpunnamukquog quinne kesukod:...
    \xe Mine enemies reproach me all the day:...
    \so Ps.102.8(M); (E): |nukkehkómukquog|
    \xv Ahque unnanatam∞k, kutushpunaumunumw∞ ut ánaquabit Wut∞shiman: noh pasuk aspunómukqueog, noh Moses, noh pabuhtanumog.
    \xe Do not think that I will accuse you to the Father: there is one that accuseth you, even Moses, in whom ye trust.
    \so Jn.5.45; (M): |kuppetukkonunnumw∞|, |pátukkonukqueogq|

    \xv ..., ukkekom∞aongan∞ ne ashpunnamukqueán, woi Jehovah.
    \xe ..., their reproach wherewith they have reproached thee, O Lord.
    \so Ps.79.12; (M): |..., wuttushpunnamuwaonkanoo nag ne nashpuhpunamukquean, woi Lord.|.
    \ng Eliot does not maintain the cognate object, unlike Mayhew. The initial |n-| may represent the relative root |un-|, though that should take the change here.

    \se |iaspinumitteaonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, theme 2a, ?reduplicated
    \ps `reproach' (objective genitive)
    \so Gen.30.23
    \xv ..., , GOD amaunum nuttiaspinamitteaonk.
    \xe ..., God hath taken away my reproach.
    \so Gen.30.23

    \se |ushpunnamuau| [(M)?]
    \nt +
    \ps AI, with indefinite object final |-uw-| (G&B, item 12, 580)
    \ge `to reproach'
    \so Ps.74.10,18(M)
    \xv Woi God, tohsohkee pish matwau ushpunnamuau?...
    \xe O God, how long shall the adversary reproach?...
    \so Ps.74.10(M); (E): |kekôm∞wau|

    \se !|ushpunnamoheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to put sb to (a) reproach, shame'
    \so Ps.78.66(M), Heb.6.6
    \xv ...: um-micheme ushpunnamuwaheopah.
    \xe ...: he put them to a perpetual reproach.
    \so Ps.78.66(M); (E): |ukkekontuwáheuh|
    \xv ..., kah ∞wohshwe ushpunnámohéouh.
    \xe ..., and put him to an open shame.
    \so Heb.6.6

\nt Follow up needed: nominal forms

[Narragansett [xnt] |Tahaspunâyi| (= |toh asp-|) `What ayles he?'; |Tocketúspanem| `What aile you?' |Tocketuspunnaúmaqun| `What hurt hath he done to you?'    R.W.187/r.195.]√

\et H.818-820 *eΘpen- `sick, disease; deal with thus'. On *-pen-: B. 1962, 15.236, 314, with |ehpε∙nε∙w| `he sickens, fares ill, perishes thus'; Mch. BAE AR40, 623b. On the use of the oral/locutionary final in |-m-|, compare Cuoq 125b: |Gotc anotc nind inapinemik|, `il me dit toute sorte d'injures'. (with a renewed initial) and Lacombe 344b: |ISPINEMEW| `il lui dit toutes sortes d'injures'.

\lx ussenát
\va asénát
\va usseu
\ve 2nd form spurious
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 175
\ps v.t. / AI+O, long-vowel stem
\ge `to do, to perform, to accomplish, to execute'
\so Ps.149.7; Mt.6.1; 5.17
    \xv ..., Toh kutussem?...
    \xe ..., What hast thou done?...
    \so Gen.4.10
    \ng 2->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah yeu n∞che ussenaous,...
    \xe ...; and this they begin to do:...
    \so Gen.11.6
    \ng ?3p->0 subordinative interrogative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish nanaihteaog ummay Jehovah, ussen sampwagk,...
    \xe ..., and they shall keep the way of the LORD, to do justice...
    \so Gen.18.19
    \ng X->0 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Matta woh nutussen newutche yauonchagodtog.
    \xe ..., I will not do it for fourty's sake.
    \so Gen.18.29
    \ng 1->0 negative objective
    \nt +
    \xv ..., toh kuttéhessemw∞.
    \xe ..., What is your occupation?
    \so Gen.46.33
    \ng 2p->0 indicative to reduplicated stem
    \nt +
    |usseu|, |ussu| `he does, or did'    Esth.4.17; Prov.14.17
    \xv ne nutussen
    \xe that do I
    \so Rom.7.15
    \xv ..., newutche uttôh kodusse, matta nutussein, qut toh sekeneam, ne nutussen.
    \xe ...: for what I would, that do I not; but what I hate, that do I.
    \so Rom.7.15√
    \ng 1->_0_ participle; 1->0 negative objective; 1->0 objective
    (|Nuttissem machuk.| `I commit evil'    C.44/186)

    \xv ... teaguas yeu ásean?...
    \xe ..., What {is} this {that} thou hast done?...
    \so Gen.3.13
    \ng 2->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne asehettit wame muttaohkeog.
    \xe ..., after the manner of all the earth.
    \so Gen.19.31
    \ng 3p->_adv_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv Qut kuskesuk∞∞ash naum∞m∞ash wame ummishanakausuongash Jehovah, nish aseehpash.
    \xe But your eyes have seen all the great acts of the Lord which he did.
    \so Deut.11.7
    \ng 3->_0p_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    |usseit|, |usit|, |aseit| `when he does, if he does'    Mt.7.24,26
    \xv toh usée
    \xe what I did' (`might be doing
    \so )    Neh.2.16
    \xv noh asit
    \xe he who performeth, or executeth
    \so (suppos.)    Is.44.26; Ps.146.7
    (pass.) |uttoh aséinit| `whatever was done'    Gen.39.22
    \xv ne asemuk
    \xe what is done
    \so Eccl.8.17
    pl. |asemukish| `(things) done'    Eccl.8.16

    \xv ussish
    \xe do thou
    \so Ex.20.9
    \xv ne ussek
    \xe that do ye
    \so James 2.12
    \xv ..., usseitch unnonkumau wuttusséonk, qut matta unnehikk∞an unnonkumau ne áhusset, neit nen pish kuttinhennon ne áhusset unnonkumau,...
    \xe ...; let him do the kinsman's part: but if he will not do the part of a kinsman to thee, then will I do the part of a kinsman to thee,...
    \so Ruth 3.13
    \ng with reduplicated forms of conjunct
    \nt +
    (negat.) |ussekon| `thou shalt not do'    Ex.20.10

    \se !|usseanshau|, !|usseaunshau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-nuhsh-| stem, benefactive/representative
    \ge `to do sth for sb'
    \so Gen.19.19; Deut.10.21; Josh.24.31

    \xv ... & kummishteauun kummonaneteaonk neaséanshean wadchanumun nuppomantamóonk ...
    \xe ..., and thou hast magnified thy mercy, which thou hast showed unto me in saving my life;...
    \so Gen.19.19
    \ng 2->1+_0_ participle; misglossed in (E0) as "in doing this"
    \xv ..., noh aseaunshikquean yeush magagish kah uhqueneunkquokish,...
    \xe ..., and he is thy God, that hath done for thee these great and terrible things,...
    \so Deut.10.21
    \ng 3->2+0(p)
    \xv ... wame wutanakausuongash Jehovah, ne áseanshunk Israeloh.
    \xe ... all the works of the Lord, that he had done for Israel.'    Josh.24.31  { 3->3(
    \so )+_0(p)_; puzzling form--as if TI, and without nominal ending? different stem? }


[Delaware [del] |lüssu| `he doth'; |lüssi| `do it'    Zeisb.Voc.59.
Cree |a'cheeoo| `he moves, has the faculty of moving'    Howse 32; |is-puthu| `it so moveth'    ibid.80.]

\et ?(pseudo-)PA *eΘ- + *-i(∙)-wa AI "to be so", hence "act so", the transitivity arising from (reinterpretation of) the cataphora.

\lx ussinát
\va wussinát
\va -ussim-
\va -ussin-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 176
    \nt Remark: The examples of the suppletive morpheme |-si| have been removed to a separate entry, T+.149a. The remainder still have to be sorted. Note that the conjunct and imperative forms listed in general do not belong here, but to |unnau|/|wuttinuh| TA+O, T.173a, 212b, G&B.624, and (therefore) normally take two objects. Historically they are from *eΘ-, |us| then being a TA(+O) imperative to be reconstructed as *e⌠i, following B. 43, 100/456, and similarly for the other forms in |s|, usually with theme 3, showing the usual mutation of |N|.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI(+O)
\ge `to say, to tell'
\nt G&B 514, 706 s.v. |(nus)sim|, on suppletion (cf. ex. from C. below and T.'s comment on asterisked forms); also v.i. |yin|.

    (an.) |kutûsseh|* `thou sayest to me'    Ex.33.12 (?); +Acts 23.3
    \xv nuttinn∞wap
    \xe I said
    |toh kuttinn∞wam| or |kussin| `what do you say?'    C.217)

    |uttoh asean| (?) `whatsoever thou sayest unto me'    Num.22.17 { 2->1+_0_, participle to |unnau| }

    \xv us
    \xe say thou
    \so 2 Sam.13.5
    |nag us|* `say thou to them, tell them'    Lev.18.2; Zech.1.3
    \xv ussegq
    \xe tell me
    \so Gen.24.49 (2x)
    \ng 2p->1+0
    \nt +
    \nt Research needed: The form |áei| in the following looks like a 1.sg. changed conjunct form to the suppletive root reconstructed as *e-, comparable to the (unchanged) conjunct form B.1962, 7.16, 140: |eya∙n| `when I say so', and a further fragment of this system to put beside |apan| (G&B 706, from text 80:1). (See B. 34, 98/454, item 121.)
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche matta nehenwonche nussein: qut Wut∞shin noh an∞sit, nuttinan∞nukqun ne woh an∞wai, kah ne woh áei,
    \xe For I have not spoken of myself; but the Father which sent me, he gave me a commandment, what I should say, and what I should speak.
    \so Jn.12.49
    \nt +

[*The examples marked with an asterisk are rarely, perhaps not at all, used except in the indicative, suppos. present, and imperative; |n∞wonát| and |ann∞wonat| (|unnónat|) supply the other tenses and persons.]
\cf n∞ónat
\cf uttinónat


\lx ussinónat
\va us-
\va ás-
\ve To be incorporated into preceding entry, or reorganized to cover just the / forms.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 176
    = |uttinónat| `to say to, to tell'
    \xv ussegq
    \xe tell (you) me
    \so Gen.24.49
    \xv usseh
    \xe tell thou me
    \so 1 Sam.14.43; +Mt.14.28, Acts 22.27
(See examples (*) under |ussinát|.)


\lx ussish[au]ónat
\va ussishau
\ve more than one stem represented here?
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 176
    \dv |uss-| relative root + |-uhsh-á-| `fly'
    \nt +
\ps v.t. / AI(+O)
\ge `to run to, toward, into', +`to flee to'
    \xv ..., kah nag ashqueneanutcheg ussishauog wadchuut.
    \xe ...: and they that remained, fled to the mountain.
    \so Gen.14.10
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Abraham ussishau wunneetasumut,...
    \xe And Abraham ran unto the herd,...
    \so Gen.18.7
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ussishónat
    \xe to flee to
    \so Jonah 1.3
    \xv ..., nequtta tahshinash keitotanash pish uspuhh∞onganu∞ash, nish pish kahtimogish wutch nushehteaen, onk woh na wutusishon:...
    \xe ... there shall be six cities for refuge, which ye shall appoint for the manslayer, that he may flee thither:...
    \so Num.35.6
    \ng 3 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv woh nutussishon
    \xe that I may run (hasten, go quickly) to (him)
    \so 2 K.4.22
    \xv ussishau
    \xe he ran to (them)
    \so Gen.18.7
    `(him)'    1 Sam.3.5
    \xv na ussishau
    \xe (he) runneth into it
    \so Prov.18.10
    \xv ussishau wunnogskauoh
    \xe he ran to meet him
    \so Gen.29.13
    \xv ahaósukque (ahauhsukqueu) ussishaog
    \xe they run to and fro
    \so Joel 2.9
    \xv kutushishaumw∞
    \xe ye run to (it)
    \so Hag.1.9

    \xv ... wutche nagum noh asishont wutuspuhh∞wae otanat,...
    \xe ... for him that is fled to the city of his refuge,...
    \so Num.35.32;
    \nt +
    \xv ... otanat, uttoh áshomp,...
    \xe the city ..., whither he was fled:...
    \so Num.35.25
    \nt +

    \xv ná usishash
    \xe escape thither
    \so Gen.19.22
    \ng 2 imperative
    \xv Kah yeuyeu ushshash kutayeuonganit,...
    \xe Therefore now flee thou to thy place:...
    \so Num.24.11 { (E1): |ussishash|; hence perhaps a misreading; or syncope? }√
    \xv ahauhsukque ussishunk
    \xe run ye to and fro
    \so Jer.5.1; 49.3
    \xv na ussishash
    \xe run thou to, "escape thither"
    \so Gen.19.22
    \ng repeated

    |nussishau| (|nusseuussishau|) `he runs alone'    2 Sam.18.24,26
    \xv moushauog
    \xe they run together to
    \so Acts 3.11
    |negonshont| (|negonne-ussishont|) `running before (another)'    2 Sam.18.27
\cf pomushau

[Cree |it-iss'emoo|, v.i. `he flees, speeds thither'; |it-i@ss'awayoo|, v.t. `he dispatches him thither'    Howse 172.]

\et H.655 *e⌠i?le∙wa `to fly thither', relative root *eΘ- `thither' + *-i?l- `fly' + -e∙- AI. Hewson gives no Cree cognate, and PA *-?l- should yield /hy/.


\lx ussowenónat
\va uss∞-
\va ussowenau
\va uss∞wenau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 176
\ps v.t. an. / TA+"O", the relative root being cataphoric to the name.
\ge `to name, or give a name to (an. obj.)', +`to call sb's name sth, call the name of sb, call sb sth'
    pass. |ussowenittinneat| `to be named'
    \xv wuttissowenuh Israel
    \xe he called his name Israel'    Gen.35.10,18  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv pish kuttissowen Jesus
    \xe thou shalt call his name Jesus
    \so Lk.1.31, +Gen.16.11,17.19
    \ng 2->3 indicative
    = |woh kuttuss∞wen Jesus|    Mt.1.21
    \xv ... newutche nag kuttuss∞wenukquog pagkenit:...
    \xe ...; because they called thee an Outcast,...
    \so Jer.30.17√
    \ng 3p->2 indicative
    pass. |nutuss∞wenitteamun k∞wesuonk| `we are called by thy name'    Jer.14.9

[Cree |Wée{th}ayoo| `he names him'    Howse 46√.]


\lx ussowenónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 176
    \nt Remark: This appears to be identical to the verb of the preceding entry.
    \nt +
\ps v.t. / TA+"O"
\ge `to call by the name of, to give the name of to' (an. and inan.)
    \xv Onk Adam ussowenau ummittamwussoh Eve, newutche wame okasuoh pomantogig.
    \xe And Adam called his wife's name Eve; because she was the mother of all living.'    Gen.3.20  { 3->3
    \so indicative }

    \xv ..., ahque ussoweneg Naomi, ussoweneg Marah,...
    \xe ..., Call me not Naomi, call me Mara:...
    \so Ruth 1.20√
    \ng 2p->1 imperative

\cf hettam

[Narragansett [xnt] |Tahéna| (|toh hennau|) `What is his name?'; |Tahossowêtam| (|toh ussowetamun|) `What is the name of it?'; |Tahéttamen| `What call you this?'    R.W.6.√]

\et B. no.46, 90/446, S., no 137, 361; G.1982, (87), 27; H.3997 *wi∙nle∙wa TA `to name sb', cf. G.1981, 27, 66, (this verb stem is however not referred to); with relative root initial *e⌠-i-.


\lx ussowessu
\va ussowesu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 176
\ps adj. / AI(+"O")
\ge `(is) named', +`for sb's name to be sth'
    \nt G&B.725
    \nt +
\so Gen.27.36
    \xv ... Adam uttoh anont nishnoh ôâas uppomantamun ne wuttissowesin.
    \xe ... whatsoever Adam called every living creature, that {was} the name thereof.
    \so Gen.2.19
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut pish kuttissowes Abraham,...
    \xe ..., but thy name shall be Abraham:...
    \so Gen.17.5
    \ng 2 indicative
    \xv toh ussowessu
    \xe what is his name?
    \so Prov.30.4
\nt The 3d pers. sing. of an irregular verb (|ussowesittéinát|?) `to be named or called'
    |kuttisowis|, |kuttisowes| `thou art named'    Gen.17.5; 35.10
    \xv toh kuttisowis
    \xe what is thy name?
    \so Judg.13.17

    \xv as∞wesit
    \xe when he is named, being named
    \so 2 Sam.13.1,3

    \xv ussowes
    \xe call his name, name him
    \so (?)    Hos.1.6,9
    \xv ...: kah n∞wesuonk ussowéshettich,...
    \xe ...; and let my name be named on them,...
    \so Gen.48.16
    \ng 3p->0 imperative
    \nt +

\dv (from |ussoweseónat| v.t.an. (?): |ussoweseóóg| `if you shouldcall me'    Ruth 1.21)

[Narragansett [xnt] |Tocketussawêitch| `What is your name?', |Taantússawese?| `Doe you aske my name?', |Ntússawese| `I am called, &c.', |Matnowesuónckane| `I have no name.', |Nowánnehick nowésuonck| `I have forgot my Name.' "Which is common amongst some of them,..."    R.W.5√.]

\et S.1975, no. 137, p.361, H.3999 *wi∙nsowa AI `name', with relative root initial; presumably a middle reflexive to the transitive stem.

\lx uss∞wessenat
\hm 2
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
    \nt Remark: identical to |ussowessu| and |uss∞wessenat|?
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `to be called, or to have the name of'
\nt G&B. 725
    \xv ...; kah wuttinnúmu mittumwussissoh wut-Egiptianuh ussowesu Hagar.
    \xe ...: and she had a handmaid, an Egyptian, whose name was Hagar.
    \so Gen.16.1
    \ng translating relative clause structure
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Sun nummattá wunnamuhkut ussowesu Jakob?...
    \xe ..., Is not he rightly named Jacob?...
    \so Gen.27.36
    \xv ussowesu Jakob
    \xe he is named Jacob
    \so Gen.27.36
    \xv Kah matta pish wonk kuttchinitteoh Abram, qut pish kuttissowes Abraham,...
    \xe Neither shall thy name any more be called Abram, but thy name shall be Abraham;...
    \so Gen.17.5
    \xv ..., Kuttissowis Jakob matta pish wonk kuttissowesu Jakob, qut Israel ne k∞wesuonk, kah wuttissowenuh Israel.
    \xe ..., Thy name is Jacob: thy name shall not be called any more Jacob, but Israel shall be thy name: and he called his name Israel.
    \so Gen.35.10
    \xv pish ussowesu
    \xe his name shall be called
    \so Is.9.6
    \xv kuttuss∞wésimw∞
    \xe ye are called, or named
    \so 2 K.17.34

    (|ass∞wesit| `called'    C.184)
\cf hettam


\lx uss∞wetamunát
\va ussowetam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
\ps v.t. / TI1a(+O)
\ge `to name, or give a name to' (inan. obj.), nominare
    \nt G&B.725
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche wuttahhamunk ussowetamun Beerlahairoi,...
    \xe Wherefore the well was called...Beer-lahai-roi:...
    \so Gen.16.14
    \ng X->0 objective/subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jakob wuttissowetamun ne ohke Peniel,...
    \xe And Jacob called the name of the place Peniel:...
    \so Gen.32.30; 33.20
    \ng 3->0+0 objective
    (|Toh katuss∞wetam Table.| `What you call table?'    C.41/184)√

    \xv Newaje ussowetamuk Babel, newutche Jehovah na wuttit ayimun papén∞want∞waonk wame ohket:
    \xe Therefore is the name of it called Babel; because the Lord did there confound the language of all the earth:...
    \so Gen.11.9
    \ng X->0+"0"+_adv_ participle; punctuation suggests editors of modern AV do not understand the structure, unlike 1611 edition, with its comma
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttissowetamunash, ∞shoh ne as∞wetogkup.
    \xe ...: and he called their names after the names by which his father had called them.
    \so Gen.26.18
    \ng 3->0+_0_ preterite participle
    \nt +

\lx uss∞wuNau
\va uss∞unnau
\va iss∞wunnau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Note the PA l-transitivizer in the etymology.
\ps TA
\twn |uss∞wuttau|, TI2
\ge `to bring, carry, draw, lead, send sb (to sb/somewhere)'
\so Gen.24.22,27,37.25,28,43.16,50.13; Mk.15.16; Lk.22.66,23.1; Acts 2.23,7.16,21.34,37,25.21; Jas.1.14,2.6(?); Rev.7.17
    \xv ... pomashàon mayut, Jehováh nutuss∞wunuk weekit nussontimom waweematutog.
    \xe ...: I being in the way, the Lord led me to the house of my master's brethren.
    \so Gen.24.27; Rev.17.3
    \xv Kah wunnaumonuh uss∞unuk en ohkit Kanaan,...
    \xe For his sons carried him into the land of Canaan,...'    Gen.50.13; (E0) ?|u[n]∞unuk|  { 3
    \so ->3 objective }
    \xv ..., sunnummatta weenaueetuenuog kummukk∞kinuk∞óog, kah kuss∞wun∞wóog anaquohtag wussittumoe appuongash?
    \xe ... Do not rich men oppress you, and draw you before the judgment seats?
    \so Jas.2.6
    \ng analysis opaque; erroneous form (no |-t-|, no theme 2 suffix)?
    \xv Newutche Lambe ... pish nah wossohkom∞unuh, kah pish wuttiss∞wunuh en pomantamwae tohkekomue nippeit ...
    \xe For the Lamb ... shall feed them, and shall lead them unto living fountains of waters:...
    \so Rev.7.17

    \xv ... wunnaumonuh Jesusoh, uttiyeuoh kenaau as∞wunogkup,...
    \xe ... his Son Jesus; whom ye delivered up,...
    \so Acts 2.23
    \xv Onk Paul as∞wúnut wonkon∞sinut, unnau negone mugquompuh woh kekun∞nush;...
    \xe And as Paul was to be led into the castle, he said unto the chief captain, May I speak unto thee?...
    \so Acts 21.37
    \xv Qut Paul kodtantog ∞sumukqunat Augustus, nussim nanaihhinaj, onk woh uss∞wunau Cesarut.
    \xe But when Paul had appealed to be reserved unto the hearing of Augustus, I commanded him to be kept till I might send him to Caesar.
    \so Acts 25.21
    \ng 1->3 conjunct
    \xv Qut nishnoh wosketomp qutcheheau, uss∞unukqut nehenwonche ummatchekodtantam∞onk, kah nupweshanukquit.
    \xe But every man is tempted, when he is drawn away of his own lust, and enticed.
    \so Jas.1.14
    \xv ...? howan ás∞wussit Edom?
    \xe ...? who will lead me into Edom?
    \so Ps.60.9; (M): |assoowussit|
    \ng 3->1 participle, with mutation

    \xv ..., uss∞wus yeug wosketompaog nekit, nush∞k, kah quaquoshwehtam∞k,...
    \xe ..., Bring these men home, and slay, and make ready;...
    \so Gen.43.16
    \ng 2->3(p) imperative, with mutation
    \xv ..., kah matta wahteauog uttôônag, newutche wogkouéonk, n∞wau, uss∞wununaj wonkon∞sunit.
    \xe ...: and when he could not know the certainty for the tumult, he commanded him to be carried into the castle.
    \so Acts 21.34
    \xv ...: uss∞wusseh qussukquanit, ne anuwohquss∞mukqueh.
    \xe ...: lead me to the rock that is higher then I.
    \so Ps.61.2; (M): |ussoowusseh|
    \ng 2->1 imperative

\et H.662 *e⌠iwele∙wa TA `to take sb thither', TA l-causative [on the basis of Cree |isiwiye∙w| (source?)] to (extended) relative root ("to cause sb to go thither").


\lx uss∞wuttau
\nt Follow up needed: : to complete }
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
    \nt +
\ps TI2
\twn |uss∞wunnau|
\ge `to bear, bring, carry, send sth'
\so Gen.32.18,37.25; Acts 9.15
    \xv ...kah kusseh chipwusháog Ishmaelitsog ∞mwoh Gilead, weeche kamelsoh, kenunnumwog spicery kah balme, kah myrre, wutuss∞wuttanaóash Egypt.
    \xe ..., and, behold, a company of Ishmaelites came from Gilead with their camels bearing spicery and balm and myrrh, going to carry it down to Egypt.
    \so Gen.37.25
    \xv ..., Monchish newutch yeu pepenamowe ouwohteaonk uss∞wetaúun n∞wesuonk anaquabhéttit Gentilsog,...
    \xe ..., Go thy way: for he is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles,...
    \so Acts 9.15

\lx ut
\va et
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
    \nt Remark: Note the changed reduplicated form |ahhut|, found commonly in certain words for items of habitual use.
    \nt +
\ps (|-ut|) a suffix or inseparable particle, marking the locative case
\ge `at, by, in'
\ps prep. / P(reN), often co-occurring with a locative form except with place names and other "intrinsic" locativals.
\ge `in, at, by', +`on'
    rfr G&B.726
    \nt +
    \xv ummayut
    \xe in his way
    \so Is.42.24
    \xv kishke mayut
    \xe by the wayside
    \so Gen.38.14, 21
    \xv neane mukkiesut
    \xe as (like to) a little child
    \so Lk.18.17

    \xv ut Damaskus
    \xe at Damascus
    \xv ut synagogs
    \xe in the synagogues
    \so Acts 9.19,20
    \xv ...et pasukqunnu,...
    \xe ... unto one place,...
    \so Gen.1.9(E0)
    \nt +
    |kusseh monaog Publikanog kah matcheseaenuog peyauog ut ∞wetapemouh, kah ukkodnetuhtaeneumoh. `behold, many publicans and sinners came and sat down with him and his disciples.'    Mt.9.10
    \nt +
\nt The vowel of the locative suffix is variable, as:
    |ut otanit|    Acts 8.8
    |ut kehtahhennit|    Is.43.16

    |en wekit|
    |en ohkeit| (or |ohket|)
    |ut man∞tat|    Acts 9.25
    |ut wuhhogkat|    Mk.5.29
\cf adt

[Cree |itta@|, adv. `there, thither'    Howse 33.]


\lx -ut
\va -it
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
    \nt +
\ps suffix
\ge `times', forming numeral adverbs to numerical expressions
\nt Remark: This is perhaps the locative suffix, as in the previous entry. (Compare |-ing| in Baraga's description, 320-321, 332-334.) However, the use of a dental suffix in Loup A and Western Abenaki suggests caution. There is considerably more to be said about the uses of these forms.
    \xv ..., yeu kesukok, yeu nohkog, negonae monsh kutt∞adt neesit, woh kukkohkonn∞aausen nishwudt.
    \xe ..., That this day, even in this night, before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice.
    \so Mk.14.30
    |..., kah pish nesausuk wutteahshit seâuhkon ut anaquabit
Jehovah,...| `..., and [he shall] sprinkle it seven times before the Lord,...'    Lev.4.17
    \xv ..., kah nukqutchhikquog yeush piogqut nompe,...
    \xe ..., and have tempted me now these ten times,...
    \so Num.14.22

\lx uttinónat
\va unnónat
\va unnau
\ve =
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\ge `to tell, to say to'
    \xv nuttin
    \xe I say to (this man)
    \so Mt.8.9
    \xv kuttinsh
    \xe I say to thee
    \so Jn.13.38
    (|nissim| `I say'; |nuttinn∞wap| `I said'    C.207)
    \xv wuttinuh
    \xe he said to him
    \so Jn.8.25; 9.35
    (|wuttunuh|    Mass.Ps., Jn.3.4)
    `he said to them'    Jn.8.39
    \xv wuttinóuh
    \xe they said to him
    \so Jn.8.25,39
    (|wuttonapah| `he said unto him'    Mass.Ps., Jn.3.2,3
    \xv kuttunush
    \xe I say to thee
    \so Mass.Ps., Jn.3.5)
    \xv nuttinonash muttaok
    \xe I say to the world (these things)
    \so Jn.8.28
    \xv kuttinnonnumw∞
    \xe I say unto you
    \so Jn.13.20,21
    \xv yeu kuttinnunnunan
    \xe this we say unto you
    \so Acts 4.15
    \nt Most of these are absolute or n-paradigm forms of the TA+O type, to |unnau| (|unnónat|) `to say sth to sb'. See in addition the separate entry |wuttinuh|.
    \nt +

[Narragansett [xnt] |téaqua ntúnnawen|, or |ntéawem| `what shall I speak?'    R.W.64.
Cree |itwayoo| `he so says'    Howse 42.]


\lx uttiyeu
\hm 1
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
\ps adv.
\ge `where'
\so El.Gr.21
    "Of place. |Uttiyeu|, {Where}."    El.Gr.21/268.
    \xv uttiyeu áne
    \xe wherever
    \so Deut.28.37
    \so Gen.4.9,27.33,38.21; 1 Cor.1.20,12.17

[Narragansett [xnt] |túckiu|, |tíyu| `where'    R.W.49; |túckiu sáchim| `where is the sachim?'    ibid.48.]


\lx uttiyeu
\hm 2
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
\ps "The {Interrogative} of {things}."; +also commonly as relative pronoun.
\ge `which'
    \nt G&B.508,726.
    \nt +
    "The Interrogative of things; { sing. |Uttiyeu|, or |tanyeu|.
                                    { pl.  |Uttiyeush|, {Which}."    El.Gr.7/253.

    pl. |Uttiyeush| `Which'    El.Gr.7/253
    \xv uttiyeu
    \xe which (who) of these
    \so Lk.22.24,27

    \se |uttiyeuoh|; |uttiyeug|
    \nt +
    \ps relative pronoun, proximate (cf. |yeuoh|); plural
    \ge `where', `who, which'
    \xv ..., uttiyeuoh mat wanaumoniyean.
    \xe ..., , which is not of thy seed.
    \so Gen.17.12
    \ng (E0) "who is"
    an.pl. |uttiyeug| `whom'    Lk.6.13



\lx uttoh
\va ut-toh
\va uttôh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
    \nt Remark: probably also in aphetic form |toh|
    \nt +
\ps adv., +animate pronoun, as link in participial clauses
\ge `to what, whereunto', +`as; who(m), which'
    \nt G&B.726 `whatever', P
    \nt +
\so Mt.11.16
    \xv ... Isaak, uttoh woh Sarah neechadche wutche ken...
    \xe ... Isaac, which Sarah shall beare vnto thee,...
    \so Gen.17.21
    \ng (E0) "wh.m"
    \nt +

    `whither'    Cant.6.1
    `to what, how':
    \xv ..., nishnoh ut uttôh paôog,...
    \xe ...; at euery place whither...
    \so Gen.20.13
    \nt +

    \xv uttoh en wunnegen
    \xe how beautiful!
    \so Cant.7.1
    `wherein'    Gen.21.23
    `how?'    Job 22.13
    (|uttoh missi| `how great'    C.171
    \xv uttoh unni
    \xe what manner
    \xv uttökau asuh matta
    \xe whether or no
    \so C.171
    \xv (Nt.) uttoh unukku@hquat ne ayôan.
    \xe Q. How far are you going?
    \so C.100/225
    \nt +
    \xv Uttoh unnuhk\ühquat
    \xe How far
    \so C.104/228)

\nt [A curious analogy might be traced between |ut-toh| and Engl. whi-ther (Old Germ. hue-dar, Goth. hva-t har; Slav. kotorü; Sansk. katará (Bopp. 69,1-2), from ka, interrog., and tara; Greek -tepos, Lat. terminus, trans, transgredi. Cf. tat, Bopp.161.]

[Delaware [del] |enda|    Zeisb.]


\lx utt∞che
\va utt∞chu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
\ps adv. / PreV
\ge `in due season, seasonably'; +`at the time of, that'; "at such a time, at that time"
\so Ps.104.27
    \xv .... Qushkeon nukqushkem en kuhhogkaáeu ne adt∞che pomantam∞wonganú∞k,...
    \xe ..., I will certainly return unto thee according to the time of life;...
    \so Gen.18.10
    \ng changed
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wanonk∞∞k mittamwussissog ât∞chu sohamohettit wutáhapahettit.
    \xe ... at the time of the evening, even the time that women go out to draw water.
    \so Gen.24.11
    \ng changed
    \nt +
    \xv Onk n nih, ne áhutt∞che wompoquahettit netasuog, nuttishpadtauomp kah nunnaum ut kouenat,...
    \xe And it came to pass at the time that the cattle conceived, that I lifted up mine eyes, and saw in a dream,...
    \so Gen.31.10
    \ng changed, reduplicated, durative
    \nt +
    \xv wutch utt∞chéeu kah ahquompi
    \xe for a season and a time
    \so Dan.7.12
    \xv papaume ahhutt∞che wayont
    \xe at the time of the going down of the sun
    \so Josh.10.27√
    \ng changed, reduplicated, durative
    \xv noh hô utt∞che
    \xe as often as
    \so 1 Cor.11.25,26
    \xv tohutt∞che
    \xe how long
    \so Num.14.11

    \se utt∞cheyeu∞
    \ps V.subst. / II
    \ge `there is a season, fit time, opportunity'
    \so Eccl.3.2,3,4
    \xv Kah nah wunnashpe chadchekeyeuónuh ..., matta pish wonk utt∞cheinn∞.
    \xe And sware by him ..., that there should be time no longer:
    \so (Quia tempus non erit amplius/hóti khrónos oukéti éstai)    Rev.10.6
    \nt +
\cf ahquompi
\cf ∞ch

    \se |utt∞cheyeu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps NI (syntax and relationship to verb not yet clear)
    \ge `season, time'
    \so Ps. 16.7(M), Lk.13.35
    \xv ...: onk nuttoounissog nukkuhkootomunkquog ut nukkonnaeu uttoocheyeuash.
    \xe ...: my reins also instruct me in the night seasons.
    \so Ps.16.7(M)
    \xv ..., Matta pish kenayeumw∞ noh pajeh utt∞cheyeu∞ peyaum∞uk, n∞waóg,...
    \xe ..., Ye shall not see me, until the time come when ye shall say,...
    \so Lk.13.35
    \xv Newutche Angel w∞mussu utt∞cheyeu∞ut en nipsut, kah momóntunnum nippe:...
    \xe For an angel went down at a certain season into the pool, and troubled the water:...
    \so Jn.5.4
    \xv ..., en wutayeuonganit, uttoh adt sohkom∞nut, utt∞cheyeu, kah utt∞chéyeu∞ash, kah pohshe utt∞cheyeu∞,...
    \xe , into her place, where she is nourished for a time, and times, and half a time,...
    \so Rev.12.14


\lx utt∞tauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge "to relate to sb in such a way, treat sb so, thus" (This is a makeshift gloss, in lieu of direct evidence; see the larger context of the examples, the comparative evidence tentatively suggested here, and N&Q on Genesis 38.9. The principal formal question is the status of the initial vowel.)
\so Gen.38.9; Jn.2.4(M)
    \xv Kah Onan wáhteunk wuskannem matta woh toh wuttit∞tauoh,...
    \xe And Onan knew that the seed should not be his,...
    \so Gen.38.9
    \xv Muttumwussus, toh kuttutt∞tauush?
    \xe Woman, what have I to do with thee?
    \so Jn.2.4(M); (E) |kittinhesh|

[Algonquian [alg] |TOTAM| `faire ainsi, agir de la sorte', |TOTAW| `fais-le lui, fais-lui, traite-le'; |ni totawa endotawitc| `je le traite comme il me traite' Cq.406b-407b; 1892,98.
Cree |totam| `il agit, it fair quelque chose', |totawew| `il lui fait ...'; |itôtawew| `S/he does it to her/him', |tôtawew| `S/he does it to her/him'; |tiyötahkwäwi| `whenever they did this'.    Lac.D.623b; Alb.E.26a,213b; Wolfart, 83a.
Fox ?|itwa| `he fares so', |to∙tawe∙wa| `he acts so upon him'; |ät(ö)tawätc| (i.e. |e∙to∙tawa∙c| `how he had done to [his friend]'    Fx.L.60,167; Jones 1907.138.7 [macron damaged].
Menominee [mez] |to∙tawεw|, |to∙tam| `he deals so, does so with or to him, it'; |tayo∙tawacen|    M.L.258; B.1962.446,488.
Ojibwe [oji] |doodwaad| TA `do something to s.o', |endoodwaad, e-doodwaad|    Rh.119b.]

\et A.2048, H.3363-69 *to∙tawe∙wa, ?with possible influence of *et-, as in H.703 *etamwa `to say sth so, thus'.


\lx -w'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 177
The inseparable pronoun of the 3d pers. sing. and pl. Before |w| it coalesces with that letter, and the sound of |∞| is substituted. Before a vowel |'t| or |ut| is inserted for euphony, as |ohtomp| `a bow', |wutohtomp| `his bow'.

\lx waantamunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 178
\ps v.i. / TI1a-O
\twn |waanumau|
\ge `to be wise'
\so (conjugated in El.Gr., pp. 25-27, as example of verb subst.)
    \xv n∞waantam
    \xe I am wise
    \xv k∞waantam
    \xe thou art wise
    \xv waantam noh
    \xe he is wise
    \xv waantam
    \xe "in his right mind", compos mentis
    \so Lk.8.35
    \xv waantamwog
    \xe they are wise
    negat. |waantam∞unát| `not to be wise'

    \xe when I am wise (or if I am wise)
    \xv waantaman
    \xe if thou art wise
    \xv waantog
    \xe if he be wise

    \xv waantash
    \xe be thou wise
    \xv waantaj
    \xe let him be wise

    \xv ... wunnetupanatamwe wussukwhongash, nish tapenum∞m∞ugish k∞waantamwáhikqunat en wadchanittuonganìt nashpe wunnamptam∞onk ne ut Christ Jesus ut.
    \xe ... the holy Scriptures, which are able to make thee wise unto salvation through faith which is in Christ Jesus.
    \so 2 Tim.3.15

    \xv ..., kah wunnegen nohen moneaumunneat, kah mahtug ukkodtantamunat ne waantamwahukquitt ...
    \xe ..., and that it was pleasant to the eyes, and a tree to be desired to make one wise,...
    \so Gen.3.6
    \ng _0_->3 participle

    \se !|waantamwes(e)u|

    \dv to |usseu|?

    \so Deut.29.9

    \so Deut.29.9

\lx waantamwutteahhau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 178
    \nt +
\ps AI, bahuvrihi
\ge `to be wise-hearted'
\so Ex.35.10,25,35,36.1
    \xv wunnumwohtauoh waantamwutteahhon ayimunat wame anakausuonk...
    \xe Them hath he filled with wisdom of heart, to work all manner of work,...
    \so Ex.35.35
    \ng X-subj. subordinative?

    \xv Kah wame waantamwutteahhóncheg kenugke kenaau, pish peyauog,...
    \xe And every wise-hearted among you shall come,...
    \so Ex.35.10

\nt Remark: The following suggests a different analysis:
    \xv Kah Moses weehkomau Bezaleeloh kah Aholiaboh, kah nish noh howan waantamwutteâhon,...
    \xe And Moses called Bezaleel and Aholiab, and every wise-hearted man,...
    \so Ex.36.2
    i.e. perhaps a noun? -- agentive in /*-w/, to stem in unstable *a∙, representing final nasal vowel?? B.'s AI suffix -∙ε, (1962, 15.175, p. 305-306), appears to be unstable; but the agentive /-w/ conditions the raising, (14.96, p.242). Stalemate. Perhaps just another bad spelling on a page of bad spellings--though 1 has the form as well.

\lx wabewuNau
\va wabuwuNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 179
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative (to root)
\ge `to make sb afraid'
\dv |wabe-| `afraid' (extended? G&B.578) + |-ôN-|
\so Lev.26.6; Ps.18.4,83.15
\nt Remark: There is another causative derivative, in |-ht-|, to this initial at Rom.13.3.
    \xv ..., kah matta pish howan k∞wabewunuk∞mw∞:...
    \xe ..., and none shall make you afraid:...
    \so Lev.26.6
    \xv ...: wuttomogkan∞m∞ matta peantam∞gig n∞wabuwunukquog.
    \xe ..., & the floods of ungodly men made me afraid.
    \so Ps.18.4; (M) |noowapoowunnukquog|
    \ng 3p->1 indicative

    \xv ...: kah wabuwus nashpe kummehshittashshinneum.
    \xe ..., and make them afraid with thy storm.
    \so Ps.83.15  { 2->3(p) imperative }; (M) |wapissuwah|.

\et The Loup A form |ke8ap8li| `j'ai peur de toy' (D.41) confirms the existence of an s-less initial, and, if a 2->1 form, may also indicate the existence of an applicative derivative of the initial.


\lx wabesenát
\va wabesinneát
\va wabesu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 179
\ps v.i. / AI
\ge `to fear, to be afraid'
    \xv neit n∞wabesip
    \xe and I was afraid
    \so Gen.3.10
    \ng 1 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche wabesu;...
    \xe ...: for she was afraid. ...
    \so Gen.18.15
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ...: newutche wabesu ayin Zoar,...
    \xe ...: for he feared to dwell in Zoar,...
    \so Gen.19.30
    \ng 3 indicative, governing X subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv wabesu
    \xe (he) feareth, is afraid
    \so Prov.14.16
    (|N∞wäbes.| `I am afraid, {or} I fear'
    |N∞wapantamu@mu@n| {or} |n∞wabe@sumun.| `We are afraid, {or} do fear'    C.35/179,51/191 [variant sp.])
    \xv wabesuog
    \xe (they) were afraid
    \so Is.41.5

    \xv ..., Ahque wabesish...
    \xe ..., Fear not,...
    \so Gen.15.1
    \ng 2 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ahque wabesek
    \xe fear ye not
    \so Gen.50.21
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    \xv wabsek
    \xe fear ye
    \so Ex.20.20
    \xv ahque wabsek
    \xe fear not
    \so Mt.14.27
    = |wabesehteok|    Is.44.8
\cf quehtam
\cf qushau

    [Lp.A |né8apis, 3 -s8.| `j'ai peur', |ak8i apis8kan| [sic] `n'aye pas peur', |ten 8agi 8apisian| `pourquoy as tu peur'    D.41.]
    \nt +


\lx wabesuoNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 179
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative |-ôN-|
\twn |wabesuontam|
\ge `to be afraid of, fear sb, for the fear of sb to be upon (sb)'
    \xv Kah Moab muttae wabesuóneau missinninnuh,...
    \xe And Moab was sore afraid of the people,...
    \so Num.22.3
    \xv Onk woh k∞wabesuon Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m,...
    \xe That thou mightest fear the Lord thy God,...
    \so Deut.6.2
    \xv Matta nag pish k∞webesuónoóg,...
    \xe Ye shall not fear them:...
    \so Deut.3.22
    \ng 2p->3p
    \xv ... newutche wabesuonaog missinninnuh.
    \xe ...; for they feared the people.
    \so Lk.22.2

    \xv ..., noh wabesuónuhkon
    \xe ...: thou shalt not be afraid of him.
    \so Deut.18.22
    \ng 2->3 prohibitive
    \xv ..., ahque wabesuos,...
    \xe ..., be not afraid of them:...
    \so Deut.20.1
    \ng 2->3 imperative
    \xv ..., áhque wabesuon∞k neg noshoncheg muhhogkuh,...
    \xe ..., Be not afraid of them that kill the body,...
    \so Lk.12.4
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative

    \se wabesuonaonk
    \ps NI, nom. act.
    \ge `fear' (of sb)
    \so Ex.20.20
    \xv ..., ahque wabesek, newutche GOD peyau, kukqutchhikou, onk woh wabesuonàonk ohteau anaquabeog, onk woh mat kummatchesúmw∞.
    \xe ..., Fear not: for God is come to prove you, and that his fear may be before your faces, that ye sin not.
    \so Ex.20.20
    \ng i.e. "the fear of him"

    \se wabesuonitteaonk
    \ps NI, nom. act., theme 2
    \ge `fear' (of sb)
    \so Deut.11.25
    \xv ..., pish ponum kukqushitteaongan∞, kah k∞wabesuónitteaongan∞ wame ohke ne tashkukkomôg,...
    \xe ... [he] shall lay the fear of you and the dread of you upon all the land that ye shall tread upon,
    \so Deut.11.25

\lx wabesuwaheau

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \nt +

    \xe ...: so shall your children make our children cease from fearing the LORD.'    Josh.22.25  { 3p->3
    \so absolute; "our children" not translated (E1&2); meaning "cease to cause"? }
    \xv ..., kah ahque wabesuontam∞k ne woh wabesuwahikqueog, asuh ahque wuttamanatam∞k.

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ps v.t. an. / TA
\twn |wadchanum| TI1b
\ge `to keep (a person or an. obj.), to keep securely, to protect'
\so (conjugated in El.Gr.28-58)
    \xv K∞wadchansh
    \xe I keep thee
    \xv N∞wadchanóog
    \xe I keep them
    \xv N∞wadchanukquog
    \xe they keep me' (`I am kept by them
    \so )
    negat. |Wadchanounat| `not to keep'    El.Gr.58
    pass. |wadchanittéinát| `to be kept'
    \xv wadchanóunát
    \xe not to be kept
    \so El.Gr.62,63
    \xv n∞wadchanit
    \xe I am kept
    \xv wadchanau
    \xe he is kept
    \xv wadchanoog
    \xe they are kept

    \nt MN: wadchanitteaon
    \ng suppositive |wadchanitteaon| `when I am kept'
    \ng X->1 subjunctive
    \xv wadchanit noh
    \xe when he is kept
    \xv ..., sunumm[at]ta nen kutassum, nayeumukquean, na wutch adt wadcháneap yeu pajeh yeu kesukok,...
    \xe ..., Am not I thine ass, upon which thou hast ridden ever since I was thine unto this day? ...
    \so Num.22.30
    \ng 2->1
    \nt +

    [LpA. |8achan-| "avoir", e.g. |mat n'8achann8m8 chab8g8i| `je n'ai pas de poudre a tirer', |k8achann8m8 ka makian sinibat| `as tu de l'argent'    D.6 (and passim).

\lx wadchanumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 179
\ps v.t. inan. / TI1b
\twn |wadchanau|, TA
\ge `to keep (it), to own or possess', +`to save sth'
\so (conjugated in El.Gr.25-27)
    `to save'    Mt.18.11
    \xv N∞wadchanumun
    \xe I keep it
    \xv K∞wadchanumun
    \xe thou keepest it
    \xv ∞wadchanumun
    \xe he keeps it
    \xv K∞wadchanumumw∞
    \xe ye keep (it)
    \xv Wadchanumwog
    \xe they keep (it)
    Negat. |Wadchanum∞unát| `not to keep'

    \nt MN: Wadchanumon
    \ng Suppositive |Wadchanumon| `if I keep'
    \xv Wadchanuman
    \xe if thou keepest
    \xv Wadchanuk
    \xe if he keep
    (|noh wadchanuk| `he who keeps or possesses'
    \xv God wadchanuk kesuk kah ohke
    \xe God the possessor of heaven and earth
    \so Gen.14.19,22)
    \xv Wadchanumog
    \xe if we keep
    \xv Wadchanumóg
    \xe if ye keep
    \xv Wadchanumahettit
    \xe if they keep

    imperat. |Wadchanish| `keep thou (it)'
    \xv Wadchanitch
    \xe let him keep (it)
    \xv Wadchanumuttuh
    \xe let us keep
    \xv Wadchanum∞k
    \xe keep ye

    \se !|wadchanumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, dative final
    \ge `to keep, lay up, preserve, reserve sth for sb'
    \so Gen.19.32,34,27.36,45.7; Ps.89.28; Lk.12.21; Rom.11.4; 2 Cor.12.14; Jude 13
    \xv ...Matta k∞wadchanumiyeuh wunnanittuonk?
    \xe ..., Hast thou not reserved a blessing for me?
    \so Gen.27.36
    \ng 2->1+0 negative
    \xv N∞wadchanumau nummonaneteaonk micheme:...
    \xe My mercy will I keep for him for evermore,...
    \so Ps.89.28; (M): |noowadchonumau|
    \xv ..., newutche wunnechaneunk matta wadchanumauo∞og ∞chetuongan∞uh, qut wutchetuonganog wutche wunnechan∞oh.
    \xe ...: for the children ought not to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children.
    \so 2 Cor.12.14

    \xv Noh neyane wadchanumauont wuhhogkuh nompakou, kah matta wenauéku nogqueu en Godut.
    \xe So is he that layeth up treasure for himself, and is not rich toward God.
    \so Lk.12.21

[Narragansett [xnt] |Waucháunama| `Keep this for me.'    R.W.40.√]

\lx wadchinat
\va wutchayeu
\va wutchiyeu
\ve spurious form, based on changed conjunct? basic form is , , q.v.?; the entry contains a range of distinct stems
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 179
\ps v.i. / II & AI
\ge `to come or proceed out or from'
    \xv mush∞nash wutjishaash
    \xe boats came from (Tiberias)
    \so Jn.6.23
    \xv Waban ∞tshon tôh kod wutjishont,...
    \xe The wind bloweth where it listeth,...'    Jn.3.8; (M) |wuttishonk| { different stem: |wutch-|+|-ihsh-| `fly, smooth movement
    \so +|-á-| II?? [c.f. H.2851-2852] }√

    \xv toh wadchiit
    \xe whence he was' (`might come from
    \so )    Judg.13.6
    (|NA mo wosketomp wachiit Pharisesut,...| `THere was a man of the Pharisees ...'    Mass.Ps., Jn.3.1)
    \xv ne wadchieh
    \xe whence I am
    \so Jn.7.28
    \xv noh wajehayeuut Godut
    \xe he which is of God
    \so Jn.6.46
    \xv neg wadchiitcheg Christ
    \xe they that are Christ's
    \so Gal.5.24
    \xv nish wutchiyeuash Jehovah
    \xe these things "are the Lord's"
    \so Deut.10.14
    \xv ne ... ∞tcheun mittamwomsissoh
    \xe (of) "that made he a woman"
    \so i.e. "that he from-ed a woman"    Gen.2.22
    \xv wajhet mittamwossissit
    \xe born of a woman
    \so Gal.4.4
    \xv howan wadchegit Godut
    \xe whosoever is born of God
    \so 1 John 3.9; 5.4
    \xv noh wutchu ... nish wame
    \xe of him [as cause or source] are all things
    \so Rom.11.36
    \xv wutchaiyeum∞
    \xe it belongs to (him)', in the sense of `it proceeds from or is caused by
    \so Ps.3.8
    \xv menuhkesuonk wutchaiyeum∞ Godut
    \xe power belongeth to God
    \so Ps.62.11
    \xv nuhhogkat wutchaiyeum∞ash (nish)
    \xe to me belong (these things)
    \so Deut.32.32
    \xv yeush wajehayeúugish
    \xe "these things which concern" him
    \so Acts 28.31
    \xv kenaau k∞chaiimw∞ wutchagwu, neen n∞chai wohkumaieu
    \xe ye are from beneath, I am from above
    \so Jn.8.23
\dv |wutche|, |∞ch|.
\cf ∞munát

\lx wadtauatonkqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 180
    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv final |-htonkqu-se-| AI, |-htonkqu-odt-| II `to be heard, sound (so)', T+.29b; the initial, which also appears as |wut-|, uncertain, quite possibly the ablative initial (with change).
\ge `to make a noise'
\so Is.17.12; Ezek.26.10
    \xv Kukkeitah, kah n∞tah, nummau nunnannompauwaonganit kah n∞wadtauatongqus.
    \xe ...: I mourn in my complaint, and make a noise:
    \so Ps.55.2
    \ng 1 indicative
    \xv ... monacheg missinninnuog, ogque wadtauatongqussuog kehtoh, ∞wadtauatonkqussuonk,..
    \xe ... many people, which make a noise like the noise of the seas;...
    \so Is.17.12√

    \xv ..., kuthassunninnutunk pish nunnuksheau wadtauatonkqussehettit horsmanog kah wheelash, kah chariotsash,...
    \xe ...: thy walls shall shake at the noise of the horsemen, and of the wheels, and of the chariots,...
    \so Ezek.26.10
    \ng 3p conjunct


\lx wadtauatonkqussuonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 180
\ps n. / ?NI
\ge (`the making a sound') `the voice'
\so Is.40.6
    \xv OOwadtauatonkqussuonk noh mashont∞adt ut touohkomum; quagquashwehtam∞k ummay Jehovah,...
    \xe The voice of him that crieth in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the LORD...
    \so Is.40.3
    \ng 3 possessor
    \nt +
    \xv Wadtauatonkqussuonk n∞wop, Mishont∞wash,...
    \xe The voice said, Cry. ...
    \so Is.40.6
    \nt +
    \xv ∞wadtauatonkqussuonk
    \xe his voice
    \so Is.42.2√
    \xv Kah wonk {nann∞tau} pomantamwae oaas wunnuppuhwhunne mummussuhkoadtue wadtauatonkqussuonk, kah wheele wadtáuatonkqussuonk piuhsuhke nagoh, kah mishe tequnum∞e wuttauatonkquodt.
    \xe I heard also the noise of the wings of the living creatures that touched one another, and the noise of the wheels over against them, and a noise of a great rushing.
    \so Ezek.3.13√
    \ng (E1) 1st token: |wuttauat-|
    \xv wutauatonkqussue wusseetash
    \xe the sound of her feet
    \so 1 K.14.6
    \ng PreN, head-like
    \xv wusseetoe wutauatonkqussuonk wussontimomoh
    \xe the sound of his master's feet
    \so 2 K.6.32
    \nt +

    \xv Unkqueneunkquodte wodtauatonkqussuonk, ut wehtauugkut:...
    \xe A dreadful sound is in his ears:...
    \so Job 15.21√

\lx wae-
\va wawe-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 180
    \nt +
\nt Remark: |wáw-| is probably the basic (original) shape; relationship to forms meaning "witness" unclear; probably not reduplicated--forms that appear to have a single |w| generally have alternants with two, and no forms have been found with a single |w| in other languages other than the possible exception of WAbn. (which could be a back-formation?)
\ps initial
\ge `know'
\so entries that follow; no promising cognates identified yet in the "central" languages.

[Western Abenaki [abe] |m8"é8érdamen| [sic], 3. |8e8-| `Je sçai cela', cf. |n8e8érdam88n|;  |8e8i|, etc.    R.458/527a,P.15/553a; A.467.
Delaware [del] |wawoâto~n| `to know', |wowoa^ha| `to know him'; |weewáatam| `come to, be aware', |wéewsuw| `know the news, hear the news, know what's going on'    Z.109; O'M.338b-339a.
M.-P. |wewi, (wew-)| `correctly; knowledgeably; perceivably', |wewisu| AI `he inquires'; |wewiiso| `er weiss davon, er erhält Kenntnis davon'    LeS.104b; Sz.239.
WAbn. |waldam| `know, be aware of something (see |wawaldam|)'; |wawala| `discover someone', |wawalda| `know (in general), be knowing'     D.1.471;481-482.]

    \xe ..., that his name may be famous in Israel.

\lx waeenodtumunát
\va waeenot-
\va woween-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 180
v.t. inan. obj. / TI1b(-O)
\ge `to praise or commend'
    \xv waeenodtumwog
    \xe they praise (it)
    \so Ps.89.5
    \xv waeenotum magugish
    \xe it boasteth great things
    \so James 3.5
    \xv Newutche monaog meyausue wáeenotumwog, nen wonk n∞woweenotumun.
    \xe Seeing that many glory after the flesh, I will glory also.
    \so 2 Cor.11.18
    \nt +

    \xv waeenodtumwehettich
    \xe let them praise (it)
    \so Ps.148.5; 149.3

    \se waeenotumauau
    \ps With an. obj. / TA+O
    \xv waeenotumaunnog nag
    \xe I boast of you to them
    \so 2 Cor.9.2
    \ng secondary object animate
    \xv k∞woweenótumaúonúmwo
    \xe we commend (her) to you
    \so Rom.16.1

\lx waéenómonat

    \so objective, syntax awry }

    \xe For he flattereth himself ...'    Ps.36.2  { 3->3
    \so absolute }; (M) |waechumau|

    \xv Howan waeenomont wuhhogkuh wutch pann∞wae mag∞onk,...
    \xe Whoso boasteth himself of a false gift ...'    Prov.25.14  { 3->3
    \so conjunct (?participle) }
    \xv ... ussowesupanneg waeenomutcheg.
    \xe ..., men of renown.

    \nt +

    \xv waeenom∞k
    \xe praise ye (him)
    \so Ps.150.1,2,3

    \xe let him praise (him)

    freq. |woweenomonat| { probably same stem without loss of |-w-| }

\lx waenekompau

    \xe ..., and, behold, your sheaves stood round about, and made obeisance to my sheaf.

    \ng 0p indicative

    \xv ..., , kah ∞weénekompauwéheuh wetuómut.
    \xe ..., and [he] set them round about the tabernacle.

\lx waeenomukqussu

    \nt +
\ps AI

\lx waeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 180
    \nt +
\nt Remark: form of stem still uncertain, perhaps e.g. |wá(w)eu| (with fugitive intervocalic |w|); cf. forms in Del., Lp.A, M.-P. WAbn.
\ps AI(+O)
\ge `to discern, know sth; cannot tell sth'
\so Gen.43.7,22; Lk.12.56; Jn.4.22,16.18(E&M)
    \xv ...; sun woh nuppahke waémun, woh nuttugk∞onganun w∞msúun∞k kematou?
    \xe ...: Could we certainly know that he would say, Bring your brother down?
    \so Gen.43.7; (E1) |waámun|
    \ng 1p indicative
    \xv ..., matta n∞waónan howan ponug nutteagwunonash nunn∞tanonut.
    \xe ...: we cannot tell who put our money in our sacks.
    \so Gen.43.22
    \ng 1p negative objective + indirect question
    \xv Kenaau eiantukkeiog, woh k∞waómw∞ woskeche pohkok, kah ohke, qut toh n nih, matta k∞wauwóneáu yeu aquompak?
    \xe Ye hypocrites, ye can discern the face of the sky and of the earth; but how is it that ye do not discern this time?
    \so Lk.12.56
    \ng 2p->0 indicative; 2p negative indicative objective; NTGr. |oídate dokimázein|, |ou dokimázete|; Vlg. |probare|, |non probatis|
    |..., Teaguas yeu an∞wadt Paswese? matta n∞waómun toh an∞wadt.| `...,
What is this that he saith, A little while? we cannot tell what he saith.'    Jn.16.18; (M) |n∞wâómun|  { 1p negative indicative, with indirect question; NTGr. "ouk oídamen", Vlg. "nescimus" }

[Delaware [del] |weewáatam| AI(-O?) `to come to, be aware', |wéewsuw| AI `to know the news, hear the news, know what's going on'    O'M.338b-339a.
Lp.A. |Na8a| `je le connois', |Kena8en ka| `le connois tu'; |ne8a8ian| `je le connois'; |8a8ianiana 8atankepimit ...| `Si tu connois le maitre de l'eau de vie ...'; [??|ninamen sip8| `je connois la riviere', |mat kenen8l8| `je ne te connois pas', |kenen8l| `je te connois']      D.11;72;83;[111].
M.-P. |wewi| PreV `correctly, knowledgeably, perceivably', |wewisu| AI `he inquires'; |wewiiso| `er weiss davon, er erhält Kenntnis davon`     LeS.104b; Sz.329.
Micm. ?|wewin| AI `you take notice of something.'    MCS.366b.
WAbn. |wawa-/i-| `know'    D.1.481-485.]


\lx wáeyohsheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 180
    \nt +
\ps II (& AI?)
\ge `to fetch a compass' i.e. "to take a circular or circuitous course, make a circuit or detour, ..." [OED s.v. "compass" sb. 11d; BWB 134]
    \xv Kah sussippôe pish wáeyóhsheau wutch Azmon nó pajeh Egpte sepuut, kah na weehqshik pish keihtoh.
    \xe And the border shall fetch a compass from Azmon unto the river of Egypt, and the goings out of it shall be at the sea.
    \so Num.34.5
\nt Remark: For possible spellings, compare |wayeôagish| `rings', and the forms of |waéenu| `round about'

\lx waheónat
\va waeheau
\va waheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 180
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\twn |wahteau|, TI2
\nt G&B.728
\ge `to know (a person, or an. obj.), to recognize'; +`to be made manifest; make account of sb'
    \xv Newutche n∞wáeh, noh woh piahtimau wunneechanoh,...
    \xe For I know him, that he will command his children,...
    \so Gen.18.19
    \ng 1->3 objective, proleptic
    \nt +
    \xv Onk Joseph waheau wematoh, qut nag matta ∞waheóuh.
    \xe And Joseph knew his brethren, but they knew not him.'    Gen.42.8√  { 3->3' absolute; 3p->3
    \so negative objective }
    \xv Onk Joseph nâau wematoh kah ∞waheuh,...
    \xe And Joseph saw his brethren, and he knew them,...'    Ps.138.6; Gen.42.7√  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv neen n∞wáeh
    \xe I know him
    \so Jn.7.29; Gen.18.19
    \xv matta pasuk n∞waheoh
    \xe I do not know one
    \so Is.44.8
    \xv k∞wahush
    \xe I know thee
    \so Gen.12.11; Ex.33.12
    \ng 1->2 indicative
    \xv ..., onk woh n∞wahéonnônog.
    \xe ..., that we may know them.
    \so Gen.19.5
    \ng 1p->3p objective
    \nt +
    \xv Kah matta n∞waheop: qut noh woh wahheau ut Israel, newaj peyoi kutchessummuónat nippe.
    \xe And I knew him not: but that he should be made manifest to Israel, therefore am I come baptizing with water.
    \so Jn.1.31
    \ng 1->3 negative preterite; X->3 objective, (M) |washanôu|
    \xv k∞wahéúmw∞
    \xe ye know me
    \so Jn.7.28
    \ng 2p->1
    \xv matta k∞wahunnumw∞
    \xe I know you not
    \so Mt.25.12
    \ng 1->2p
    \nt +
    (|k∞wahhish| `I know thee'; { 1->2 }
    \xv n∞waeh noh
    \xe I know him
    \so ;
    \xv n∞waheâog
    \xe I know them
    \so C.196,197)

    \xv ..., noh matta wahheáog.
    \xe ..., whom ye know not.
    \so Jn.7.28√
    \ng negative 2p->_3_
    \xv Kutayeuuhkonittue cheketauomw∞ Jehovah wutch na kesukok wahenog.
    \xe Ye have been rebellious against the Lord from the day that I knew you.
    \so Deut.9.34
    \ng 1->2p
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nnoh ken waheadt?
    \xe ..., that thou makest account of him?
    \so Ps.144.3
    \ng 2->3 conjunct
    \nt +


\nt Cotton gives two pages to the conjugation of the several forms of |waheónat|, |wahteouu@nal|, |wahteauwaheonat|, etc.).

[Narragansett [xnt] |mátta nowáuwone|, |matta nowáhea| `I knew nothing'    R.W. (cf. |matta n∞wahheoh| `I know not'    Gen.4.9)

\lx wahikquodt
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 181
    \nt +
\ps II
\twn |wahikqussu|
\ge `to be evident, manifest; to be (made) known'
\so Gal.3.11; Heb.7.15; 1 Tim.5.25; Ex.33.16; Log.Pr.38/51
    \xv Newutche uttoh pish en wahukquodt, neen nummiskom∞onk kitteamonteanittuonk, ut kuskesukqut, neen kah kummissinninnúmog?...
    \xe For wherein shall it be known here that I and thy people have found grace in thy sight?...
    \so Ex.33.16
    \xv Qut wahikquodt wánne howan sampweogquanumóun nashpe naumatuonk anaquabit GOD, newutche sampweogquanumutcheg pish nashpe pomantamwog wunnamptam∞onk.
    \xe But that no man is justified by the law in the sight of God, it is evident: for, The just shall live by faith.
    \so Gal.3.11
    \xv Neyane wonk nawhutche ∞[n]anakausuongan∞∞ash, nish negonáeu wahikquodtash, kah nag penuwayeuwutch[e]g matta onkwhôsin∞,
    \xe Likewise also the good works of some are manifest beforehand; and they that are otherwise cannot be hid.
    \so 1 Tim.5.25
    {Again, But that   the works of        may be made known in him.}
        |Wonk, Qut  wutche anakausuongash God  woh wahukqutash yeu ut.|    Log.Pr.38/51

\lx wahteauunát
\va waeht-
\va wahteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 181
\ps v.t. inan. / TI2
\twn |waheau|, TA
\ge `to know or have knowledge of, to understand', `to perceive, see sth'; +`to know that S'
\nt G&B.728
\so Eccl.1.17; 7.25
    (|-ouunat|    C.)
    \xv ..., kah matta wahteau ne seepsik kah omohkeit.
    \xe ...: and he perceived not, when she lay down, nor when she arose.
    \so Gen.19.34
    \ng 3(->0) negative absolute
    \nt +
    `to perceive'    Deut.29.4
    \xv ..., wahteouun wanegik kah machuk.
    \xe ... knowing good and evil.
    \so Gen.3.5
    \ng X->0 subordinative
    \xv wahteou
    \xe he knoweth, understandeth (it)
    \so 1 Chr.28.9
    (|-au|    Ps.104.19)
    \xv matta wahteauou
    \xe he does not know (it)
    \so Jn.15.15
    \xv k∞wahteóuunneau
    \xe ye know it
    \so Jn.7.28
    \xv k∞wahteoh wuttahh∞woash
    \xe thou knowest their hearts
    \so 1 K.8.39
    \xv n∞wahteauun
    \xe I know {it}
    \so Gen.48.19√
    \ng 1->0 objective (2x)
    \xv k∞wahteoun
    \xe thou knowest it
    \so Rev.7.14
    \xv ne wahteouun
    \xe this thing is known
    \so Ex.2.14

    \nt MN: noh wautog
    \ng suppositive |noh wautog| `to him that understandeth' (v.i.)    Prov.8.9√
    \xv wahteunk
    \xe knowing
    \so Mk.5.30,33√; +Gen.3.22
    \ng 3->0 conjunct
    \xv ..., wahteauan wahteaush k∞skannemunog pish penuwohteaóog,...
    \xe ..., Know of a surety, that thy seed shall be a stranger,...
    \so Gen.15.13(E0)
    \ng 2->0 conjunct; 2->0 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wahteunk ∞wompequauonk...
    \xe ...: And when she saw that she had conceived,...
    \so Gen.16.4
    \ng 3->0+_adv_ conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche wunnamuhkut wahteauon, machuk pakodtantamun ut n∞shut kukquentunkqunat, ...
    \xe ...: for if I knew certainly that evil were determined by my father to come upon thee,...
    \so 1 Sam.20.9
    \ng 1->0 subjunctive
    \nt +
    \xv Woi napehnont wahteau uttoh woh adtnámeheog,...
    \xe Oh that I knew where I might find him! ...
    \so Job 23.3
    \ng 1->0 conjunct
    \nt +

    \xv wahteaush
    \xe know thou
    \so Dan.3.18
    \ng 2->0 imperative

    (|N∞wateo, up.| `I know (understand), or did'
    \xv N∞wâteomun, -nônup.
    \xe We know, or did
    \xv Nag wahteoog.
    \xe They know, or did
    \xv Wahteonu@nat.
    \xe To know
    \xv Wahtouish, or wawagk.
    \xe Know thou
    \xv Wahtou noh, noh wahteöitch.
    \xe Know her, or let him know
    \so C.58-59/196)

    \se |wahteaue|
    \nt +
    \ps PreV
    \ge "by, of knowing"
    \so Gen.15.13
    \xv ..., Wahteaue wahteaush ...
    \xe ..., Know of a surety, that ...
    \so Gen.15.14

[Narragansett [xnt] |Nowaûtam| `I understand.', |Cowâutam?| `Vnderstand you?', |Cowâwtam tawhitche nippeeyaûmen| `Doe you know why I come.'; +|Mat nowawtauhettémina| `We understand not each other.'    R.W.8;9√.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |ne8"é8érdamen, 3. 8e8| `Je sçai cela' (with plausible correction of editor's reading from copy of MS.)    R.458/527a.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |weewíhtoow| TI2 `to know s.t.    O'M.339a.]


\lx wahteauwaheonat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 181
\ps v.t. an. (caus.) / TA+O, causative final, to |wahteau| TI2
\ge `to make one's self known to (another)'; +`to make sb (to) know sth, make sth known, manifest to sb, declare sth unto sb'
    \nt Remark: The reflexive use does not appear to be common, and it is not clear that it reproduces the AV sense precisely. The direct object in some examples  denotes a proposition, or "it".
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nen Jehovah pish n∞wáhteauwah ut monamansuonganit,...
    \xe ..., I the LORD will make myself known unto him in a vision,...
    \so Num.12.6
    \ng 1->3+0 indicative
    \xv Kah k∞wahteauwahik∞wop ∞n∞waonk,...
    \xe And he declared unto you his covenant,...
    \so Deut.4.13
    \ng 3->2p+0 preterite absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah woh k∞wahteauwahukqun wosketomp matta wutch pomantam webe pétukqunnunk,...
    \xe ...; that he might make thee know that man doth not live by bread only,...
    \so Deut.8.3
    \ng 3->2+0 objective
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah k∞wahteauwahe waantam∞onk ne patogkuhwhôsik.
    \xe ...: and in the hidden part thou shalt make me to know wisdom.
    \so Ps.51.6; (M) |koowahtauwahhe|
    \ng 2->1+0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut yeuyeu wahteauwaheoneau wanetupanatogig.
    \xe ..., but now is made manifest to his saints:
    \so Col.1.26
    \ng X->3p+0 objective
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nag pish k∞wahteauwahikk∞wôog wame nish aunagish yeu ut.
    \xe .... They shall make known unto you all things which are done here.
    \so Col.4.9
    \ng 3p->2p+0p absolute[!]
    \nt +

    \xv wahteauwaheont ∞wematin
    \xe while [he] made himself known unto his brethren'    Gen.45.1√  { 3->3
    \so +0 conjunct }
    \xv Asuh ummatchesonk wahteauwahit, nean matchesit,...
    \xe Or if his sin, which he hath sinned, come to his knowledge;...
    \so Lev.4.28
    \ng X->3+0 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv Mahche wahteauwahikqueog siohkok wuttenanatam∞onk,...
    \xe Having made known to us the mystery of his will,...
    \so Eph.1.9
    \ng 3->12+0 conjunct
    \nt +

    \xv ... Monchek wahteauwahuk yeushog James,...
    \xe ..., Go show these things unto James,...
    \so Act.12.17
    \ng 2p->3+0p imperative
    \nt +
    (|wahteauwah| `make him to know'    C.196)


\lx wahteauwahuónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 181
\ps v.t. inan. (caus.) / AI+O, indefinite object final, long-vowel stem
\ge `to make a thing known to'; +`to proclaim sth (to be sth), to declare, publish sth'
\so Is.64.2; Rom.9.22; +Ps.98.2
    \xv Kah pish k∞wahteauwahuam nenan kesukok,...
    \xe And ye shall proclaim on the selfsame day, that ...
    \so Lev.23.21
    \ng 2->0, erroneous singular
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Moses n∞che wahteauwahuau yeu naumatuonk, n∞wau,
    \xe ..., began Moses to declare this law, saying,
    \so Deut.1.5
    \ng 3->0 absolute[!]
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche nummishont∞wae wahteauwahuwam ∞wesuonk Jehovah;...
    \xe Because I will publish the name of the LORD:...
    \so Deut.32.3
    \ng 1->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Jehovah wahteauwahuwop ∞wadchànuwaonk:...
    \xe The Lord hath made known his salvation:...
    \so Ps.98.2; (M) |wahtauwahhuwop|
    \ng 3->0 preterite absolute
    \nt +
    (|pish wahteauwahuau| `he shall make it known'    Is.38.19)
    \xv n∞wahteauwahikqun
    \xe he made (it) known to me
    \so Eph.3.3
    \xv wame nish k∞wahteauwahununáoash
    \xe I make all these things known to you
    \so Jn.15.15

\lx wahwapimau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 181
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv reduplicated (CVC?), probably with TA oral final |-m-| (cf. entries from Bloomfield and Cuoq.)
\ge `to hasten sb'
\so Gen.19.15
    \xv Kah nompoáeu Angelsog wahwápimáog Lotuh,...
    \xe And when the morning arose, then the angels hastened Lot,...'    Gen.19.15  { 3p->3
    \so absolute }

\cf wapantam

[Algonquian [alg] |WIBATC| `tout de suite, vite, bientôt'; |WEWIB| `vite', |Wewibitwa| `{agir vite}, se hâter à l'ouvrage, se dépêcher', |Wewibim kitci madjâtc| `presse-le de partir'    Cq.434ab;433a.
EOj. |we∙wi∙p| `quickly , right away', |we∙wi∙pe⌠ka∙| `he goes hurrying',
\xv we∙wi∙petta∙
\xe he hastens his work or action', we∙wi∙pe∙nta∙kwat `it is urgent
\so B.1957.267b.
Menominee [mez] |wε∙we∙pa∙nεhkεw| `he digs in a hurry'; |we∙pac| `quickly, soon', "also, with specialized meanings, in reduplicated forms": |wε∙we∙pac| `one is glad of it', |wa∙wε∙we∙pac| `at frequent intervals'; |wε∙we∙pemεw| `he hurries him on by speech'    B.1962, 15.276;17.11;16.20; other exs. B.1975.273.]

\et While the vowels are clearly problematic, it is hard to ignore these parallels, and the corresponding entries at H.3635-3641 with an initial *we∙wi∙p- `quick', and 4008 *wi∙paci `quickly'. Perhaps there has been a conflation with the reflexes of *we∙p- `begin, start; fly', H.3597-3619, richly attested in the central languages but invisible in Massachusett. Note also H.3614 *we∙pime∙wa TA `talk to' (cf. LacD.646ab), with the Cree form glossed as `he urges him'. Perhaps, then, the differentiation is old--could it be by back-formation from reduplicated forms?

\lx waj
\va wajeh
\va wutch
\va wutche
\ve = ,
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 181
\ps P, Conj. / changed form of |wutch(e)|, used with participle; also independently.
\ge `for, because of', +`therefore' ("for that reason")
\so Prov.17.14
    \xv ..., newutche yeu waj peyaog ut agwe onkouohtáut neekit.
    \xe ...; for therefore came they under the shadow of my roof.
    \so Gen.19.8
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Teaguas kenaum yeu waj ussean?
    \xe ..., that thou hast done this thing?
    \so Gen.20.10
    \nt +
    \xv yeu wajeh
    \xe for this cause
    \so Jn.12.18
    \xv newajeh
    \xe therefore' (`for that cause
    \so )    Jn.12.17,19,21
    = |newaj|    Jn.13.31 { syntax }
    \xv newutche yeu waj
    \xe for, for this cause
    \so , etc.    Rom.13.6
    (|ne waj| `for which cause'    C.234
    |waj|, conj. `for'    C.234)
\cf wutche

    [Men. Cf. B.1962, 17.7, 369, initial change in particles: |oht-| => |wε∙h| `the reason why'.
    \nt +
WAbn. |oji| pt. `from, since, because'; |waji| pt. `for purpose of, in order to, so that, so as to, as for (also |weji|)    D.1.397; 469.]


\lx wame
\va wamu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 181
    \nt Remark: At present, no distinction of use or meaning is known.
    \nt +
\ps adv. / PreN, PreV
\ge `all, wholly'
\so El.Gr.21
\ge `full'

    \se wameyeue
    \ge `universal'
    \so C.30/176
    \ge `usually'
    \so C.107/230

    \se wamut
    \ps with v. subst. / II
    \ge `there is enough, sufficient'
    \so Gen.45.28; Ex.9.28; Mt.6.34
    \xv n∞wameit
    \xe I have enough, there is enough for me
    \so Gen.33.11
    \ng different stem
    \xv ..., N∞wadchanumumun sekupog(h)ungash kah weatchiminneash wamut, kah toh woh kaemuk.
    \xe ..., We have both straw and provender enough, and room to lodge in.
    \so Gen.24.25
    \ng no agreement
    \nt +
    inan. pl. |wamutash| `sufficient'    Ex.36.7
    \xv ohke wamut
    \xe there is land enough
    \so Gen.34.21
    |..., wadchu matta wamattinno wutche nenawun:...| (E1&2) `..., The hill is not enough for us:...'    Josh.17.16  { II negative }
    \nt +

    |wamók|, |womohk| `when or if it is enough, if it suffice'    1 K.20.10
    \xv ánue ne woh adt womohk
    \xe more than (when it was) enough
    \so Ex.36.5

    \xv wamach
    \xe let it suffice
    \so Deut.3.26
    \xv wamatitch
    \xe let them suffice, be sufficient
    \so Deut.33.7

    \se wamenau
    \va wamunau
    \nt !
    \ps TA, manual final
    \nt +
    \twn |wamunum| TI1b
    \ge `he has enough', +`to bear sb' (i.e. "to suffice sb")
    \so Gen.13.6
    \nt +
    \xv Onk ohke mat tapenum∞p wamunon náhoh,...
    \xe And the land was not able to bear them,...'    Gen.13.6  { 0->3
    \so subordinative }
    \nt +

    \xv ...: muskesuk matta wamenaum∞mun∞,...
    \xe ...: the eye is not satisfied with seeing,...
    \so Eccl.1.8
    \ng distinct stem
    \xv n∞wamanittamumun
    \xe it sufficeth us, we have enough
    \so Jn.14.8
    \ng distinct stem?

\cf tâpi
\cf tabach
\ge let it suffice
\so (     Ezek.44.6)
\cf pohshe

\lx wanne
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 182
\ps (strictly, it is an indeclinable adjective meaning `none, not any'; as an adverb it expresses exclusion, loss, or destitution, and is occasionally used by Eliot for direct negation) / PreV (?PreN)
\ge `without, destitute of'
    \xv Wanne wut∞she, wanne wutokase, wanne ontseu, matta kutchissinno kesukodtash asuh wohkukóe pomantamóonk:...
    \xe Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days, nor end of life:...
    \so Heb.7.3√
    \xv wanne wahteóe
    \xe without knowledge
    \so Job 35.35
    \xv wanne ohtan∞
    \xe there shall be none
    \so Ex.16.26
    \xv wanne kutahtoou
    \xe thou hast not
    \so Jer.30.13
    \xv wanne nippeno
    \xe there was no water in it' (`it was without water
    \so )    Gen.37.24
    \xv ..., kah k∞wahteomw∞ wanne nushehteaenin, ahtoon micheme pomantamóonk wutappetunkqunat.
    \xe ...: and ye know that no murderer hath eternal life abiding in him.
    \so 1 Jn.3.15√
    \xv wanne kutchohkesu
    \xe there is no spot in thee
    \so Cant.4.7
    \xv wanne howane
    \xe there was no one (left alive)
    \so Num.21.35
\cf howan
\cf unne
\cf -∞-

\et B. 101, 120/478 *wan- `disappear'; H.3533-3554, 3577-3579 `deceive, lack, lose, mistake' etc., *wani- PV `lose'; S. no.120, 354 *wani?le∙wa AI `lost'

\lx wannehteauunát
\va wanteauunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 182
\ps v.t.; v.i. / TI2
\ge `to lose', inan.obj., or intrans, `to be deprived of, to be without'
    \xv Noh woh nehnégikáuut, ..., ne n∞wanteauun,...
    \xe That which was torn {by beasts},...; I bare the loss of it;...
    \so Gen.31.39
    \ng 1->3-pro objective
    \nt +
    \xv matta pish wanneteauou
    \xe he shall not lose (it)
    \so Acts 27.22
    |pish ∞wanteoun|, |∞wanteauun| `he shall lose it'    Mt.10.39; 16.25; Mk.8.35

    \xv ne wanteauomp
    \xe that which I lost
    \so Lk.15.9
    |wannehteunk|, |wanteunk| `if he lose, losing'    Mt.10.39; Lk.13.8
    pass. |ne wanteamuk| `that which is lost'    Mt.18.11
    |-ómuk|    Lev.6.3.

[Cree |wúnnetou|    Howse 41.]

\lx waogkemau
\va woogkemau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 183
    \nt +
\nt Remark: The relationship to |ogke-| `to count' suggests that there might be an initial or preverb present, perhaps associated with the modal (dispositional) sense of the examples (and the negative polarity), or else with the perfective Aktionsart ("to count up", reflected in LXX "eks-"; cf. |wamogkemau|). A connection with |wame| itself is not inconceivable. (Bloomfield lists a number of particle finals in |-m|, B.1962, 17.16, 372.)
\ps TA
\ge `to number sb'
\so Gen.13.16,16.10; Ps.104.25(M); Lk.12.1; Rev.7.9
    \xv ..., nemehkuh wosketomp woogkeetog puppissiyeuash, ohkeit, neit woh woogkemau wonk k∞skannemunneoh.
    \xe ...: so that if a man can number the dust of the earth, then shall thy seed also be numbered.'    Gen.13.16  { 3->0(p) conjunct (TI); X->3(
    \so ) absolute }
        |..., matta pish waogkemóog newutche monaog.| `..., that it shall not
be numbered for multitude.'   Gen.16.10  { X->3p objective }

    \xv ..., kah kusseh matáanugeg, matta woh howan wáogkemunke,...
    \xe ..., and, lo, a great multitude, which no man could number,...'    Rev.7.9 { negative 3->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \xv AShpámu moiéhettit matta woh wôogkemóoncheg missinninnuog,...
    \xe In the mean time, when there were gathered together an innumerable multitude of people,...'    Lk.12.1 { Compare Ps.104.25(M): |woh mo waogkemomukkeg| `innumerable
    \so }

    \se woogketam
    \ps TI1a(-O)
    \ge `to number sth'
    \so Gen.13.16,32.12,41.49; Num.23.10
    \xv ..., onk na pajeh ahque waogketamug, newutche matta woh woogkeetamm∞un
    \xe ..., until he left numbering; for it was without number.
    \so Gen.41.49
    \ng 3(->0) negative changed conjunct; X->0 negative objective

    \xv ... kehtahanne naguntu, na matta woh wóogketam∞mug newutche muttaanwog.
    \xe ... the sand of the sea, which cannot be numbered for multitude.
    \so Gen.32.12
    \ng X->0 negative participle
    \xv Howan woh woogketog uppuppissiyeum Jakob, & ne adtahshik weyauut chippissuonk Israel,...
    \xe Who can count the dust of Jacob, and the number of the fourth part of Israel? ...
    \so Num.23.10
    \ng 3->0 changed conjunct

    \se wôogketausu
    \ps II, s-passive, to TI stem
    \ge `to be numbered'
    \so Lk.12.7
    \xv Qut ne adtahshik kumméesunk kuppuhkukqut wôogketausu,...
    \xe But even the very hairs of your head are numbered,...
    \so Lk.12.7

    \xe ..., Sampson, the son-in-law of the Timnite, because he [the Timnite] had taken his [Sampson's] wife, and given her to his [Sampson's] companion. ...'    Judg.15.6√ { _3
    \so _->3, "one (obv.) that has the Timnite as parent-in-law"; apposition of proximate and obviative? }

\lx wasukeh
\va wahsukeh
\va wessukeh
\va -esuk- ?
\va ?
\ve ?-ásuk--ásuk-|
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 183
\ps n. (construct.) / NA, dependent
\ge `the husband of, (her) husband'
\so Num.30.7; Deut.25.3; Rom.7.3
    \nt Remark: The vowel variation in the initial syllable is puzzling, but the distribution looks very much like free variation. Perhaps there is an influence from changed (participial) forms of the verb of possession. I have not yet seen any example of |nessuk-| or |kessuk-|.
    \nt +
    \xv wessukeh Abram
    \xe her husband Abram
    \so Gen.16.3
    \ng 3 possessor obviative
    \nt +
    \xv pish ken wessuke
    \xe thou shalt be her husband
    \so Deut.21.13√
    \xv nasuk
    \xe my husband
    \so Gen.29.32
    \xv kasuk
    \xe thy husband
    \so Gen.3.16
    \xv kahsuk
    \xe thy husband
    \so Judg.14.15
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh nag kasukó∞óog?
    \xe ..., that they may be your husbands?
    \so Ruth 1.11; Col.3.18: |kasuk∞wóog|
    \ng 2p possessor plural
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kah nasuki nupp∞i.
    \xe ..., and mine husband is dead.
    \so 2 Sam.14.5
    \ng 1 possessor absentative
    \nt +
    \xv kahsukowoog
    \xe your husbands
    \so Eph.5.24
    |wasukkoouh| (obj.) `to their husbands'    Eph.5.24

    \se ∞)wessukiin
    \ps NA, indefinite possessor (G&B.491 (including plurals), 500)
    \ge `(a) husband; the husband [no relatum specified]'
    \so Deut.24.3,25.7, 1 Cor.7.4,11,11.2, Eph.5.2,25, Col.3.19
    \nt Remark: On the apparent hypercharacterization with |∞-|, see G&B. 500, and below. It would appear that in certain contexts the third person (obligatorily) possessive form in |w-| is reanalyzed as a stem to which the third person prefix may be attached. (This is also found with at least |wemat| `brother' and |wetomp| `friend'.)
    \xv ... uttoh woh asit ∞wesukiin wematoh.
    \xe ... the duty of my husband's brother.'    Deut.25.7 { Against |nasuk wematuh| `my husband's brother
    \so earlier in the verse }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wessukiin pogkenuhkitch ummittamwussoh.
    \xe ...: and let not the husband put away his wife.
    \so 1 Cor.7.11
    \nt +
    \xv ∞wessukiinneunk womon∞k kummittamwuss∞óog,...
    \xe Husbands, love your wives,...
    \so Col.3.19
    \xv ∞wessukkiinneunk
    \xe all husbands
    \so , collectively    Eph.5.25√
    (|Womâsüe ouwase@kkïen.| `A good condition'd husband'    C.12/161√
    \xv Wunnene@hhuäe wasu@kkien.
    \xe Kind husband
    \so C.25/171√)

    \se ?|(∞)wasukieu|, |∞wessuk-|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), possessive verb
    \ge `to have (sb as) an husband'
    \so Ex.21.3, Num.30.6, Deut 22.22, Ruth 1.12, Jn.4.17,18, Rom.7.2
    \nt Remark: The hypercharacterizing |∞-| appears here also, and is especially striking in the conjunct and imperative forms. The expected changed forms in |wá-| show some less common spellings.
    \xv ..., newutche nuppápaquanu kechisquaesu, woh n∞wásukiinneat,...
    \xe ...; for I am too old to have an husband. ...
    \so Ruth 1.12
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Matta n∞wasukoiyeu. Jesus wuttinuh, K∞nomwam matta n∞wasukoiyeu.
    \xe ..., I have no husband. Jesus said unto her, Thou hast well said, I have no husband:
    \so Jn.4.17; (M): |n∞wasukkoiyeu|, |n∞wasukkiyeu|
    \xv Newutche napanna tahsuog k∞wasukeiip, kah noh yeuyeu wadchanadt, matta k∞wahsukeien, ...
    \xe For thou hast had five husbands; and he whom thou now hast is not thy husband:...
    \so Jn.4.18 { objective }; (M): |k∞wasukkiup|, |k∞wasukkóieun|

    \xv Kah ∞wessukiis, kah quoshoadt ...
    \xe And if she had at all an husband, when she vowed,...
    \so Num.30.6
    \xv Wosketomp wachenit wehpamont mittamwussissoh waussukkiinitcheh,...
    \xe If a man be found lying with a woman married to a husband,...
    \so Deut.22.22
    \xv ..., ∞wasukiean wonk yeu nohkog,...
    \xe ..., if I should have an husband also tonight,...
    \so Ruth 1.12
    \xv Newutche mittamwossis woahsukkiit, noh kenéhpsu wasukut nashpe naumatuonk, nesohkepomantog: qut wasukkeh nupuk, noh ompeneau wutch wuttinnaumatuonganit wessukeh.
    \xe For the woman which hath an husband is bound by the law to her husband so long as he liveth; but if the husband be dead, she is loosed from the law of her husband.
    \so Rom.7.2√

    \xv ..., kah nish noh mittamwossis nehenwonche ∞wessukiitch.
    \xe ..., and let every woman have her own husband.
    \so 1 Cor.7.2

    \xv ..., wunnukqutt∞wasukionat.
    \xe ..., having been the wife of one man.
    \so 1 Tim.5.9
    \ng dvigu
    \nt +

    [|noh asúkkauau| `he whom she follows after'?]

\cf wusukeh

[Narragansett [xnt] |Wâsick| `An Husband.'    R.W.28.√
Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |nehyushamug| `my husband'    Stiles.
    Mahican [mjy] |Waughecheh `Her husband'    Edwards 1788, 7.
    \nt +
    Mahican [mjy] |wächi@a@, wáchi@a@| `mein Mann'    Schm.85.
    \nt +
    Shawnee [sjw] |Wasecheh| `Her husband'    Edwards 1788, 7 (Parsons).]
    \nt +

\et cf. G.1973, 47-48: *ne?Θa dependent NA, `my husband', *we?Θali `her husband', presumably reshaped from some mutated form, such as the possessive verb: *we?⌠i- AI+(O) `to have (sb as) a husband' (> Mass. |wusso| `she is a man's wife', Gen.20.3, T. 207a.) The examples from Edwards are 3 participles and the example from Schmick a 1 participle to reflexes of this verb. See Goddard for Munsee cognates.
