\lx Waútacone
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 184
\ps NA
\ge `Englishman'
    pl. |Waútaconûaog| "that is, coat-men, or clothed (|Watâhk∞@nog|, Englishmen, `such as wear coats'    C.169)
    \xv Wautacónisk
    \xe an English woman
    \xv Wautaconémese
    \xe an English youth
    \so R.W.65
\dv |wuttunkum| `he covers with (it)'
\nt Other names given to the English were:
    |Awaunagress| (for |-gus|?), pl. |-suck| "as much as to say, these strangers"
    \xv Cháuquaquock
    \xe knife-men, sword-men
    \so R.W.51,65.
\cf awâùn
    Morton (N.E. Canaan, 3,5) says: "The Salvages of the Massachusets ... did call the English planters |Wotawquenange| [|-auge|], which in their language signifieth stabbers or cut-throates" .... "A southerly Indian that understood English well ... calling us by the name of |Wotoquansawge|, what that doth signifie, hee said hee was not able by any demonstration to expresse."

[Delaware [del] |wtak ho hen sin| `to cover'    Zeisb.]

\lx wauwônat
\va wauwaonat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 184
\ps v.i. / AI, AI+O {?}
\ge `to bear witness, to testify (of)
\so Jn.1.7,9
\ps v.t.an. / TA {?}
    \xv wauwau
    \xe he testifies
    \so Heb.7.17
    \xv n∞wauwon
    \xe I testify
    \so Gal.5.3; Eph.4.7
    \xv n∞wauwonan
    \xe we do testify
    \so 1 John 4.14
    \xv Kah ne nag káh n∞tog, ne ∞wâuwon, kah matta howan attumunum∞ ∞wawauonk
    \xe And what he hath seen and heard, that he testifieth; and no man receiveth his testimony.
    \so Jn.3.32

    \xv nag wauwacheg
    \xe they who bear witness
    \so 1 John 5.7,8
    \xv wauwón
    \xe if I testify
    \so Acts 20.24
    \xv nish wauwaonógish
    \xe the things which I testify to you
    \so Deut.32.46
    \ng 1->2p, but what stem?

    \xv wauwónaj
    \xe let it be a witness, let it testify
    \so Gen.31.44

    \se |wauwom∞|, |wauom∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, gender twin to |wauwônat|
    \ge `to be a witness'
    \so Gen.30.33,31.52; Josh.22.28,34
    \xv Neit pish nussampweusseonk wauwom∞ wutch nen saup,...
    \xe So shall my righteousness answer for me in time to come,...
    \so Gen.30.33
    \xv ..., qut ne wauwóm∞ nashaue ut kenaau kah nenawun.
    \xe ...; but it is a witness between us and you.
    \so Josh.22.28

    \xv Yeu nomungquâg wauwóm∞udj:...
    \xe This heap be a witness,...
    \so Gen.31.52√

    \se !|wauwaoNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O), applicative |-ôN-|
    \ge `to be a witness against sb, unto sb, to testify of sb' (with respect to sth) i.e. "to give, provide testimony about"
    \so Gen.21.30; Jn.15.27
    \xv ..., neg woh n∞wauwaónukquog, yeu nukkuthamunah yeu wuttahhamonk.
    \xe ... that they may be a witness unto me, that I have digged this well.
    \so Gen.21.30
    \ng 3p->1+0 objective
    \xv Nunnemunum kesukquash kah ohke kutayeuuhkonittue wauwaonukqunnaóont yeu kesukok, pomantam∞onk kah nupp∞onk nupponum anaquabean,...
    \xe I call heaven and earth to record this day against you, that I have set before you life and death,...
    \so Deut.30.19
    \ng 0(p)->2p? role of preverb uncertain
    \xv ..., onk woh na ohteau wutche k∞wauwaónukqunat,
    \xe ..., that it may be there for a witness against thee.
    \so Deut.31.26
    \xv ..., k∞wauwaonomw∞ kuhhogkaóog, kuppépenunkou Jehovah wowussumónat, kah nug n∞waog, n∞wauwómun.
    \xe ..., Ye are witnesses against yourselves that ye have chosen you the Lord, to serve him. And they said, We are witnesses.
    \so Josh.24.22
    \xv Qut peont Taphuaénín, ..., noh n∞wauwaonuk.
    \xe But when the Comforter is come, ..., he shall testifie of me.
    \so Jn.15.26; Mayhew |n∞wauwaonuk|

    \xv ..., newutche neane wauwaósean ut Jerusalem, nemos kittinne wauwon ut Rome.
    \xe ...: for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witness also at Rome.
    \so Acts 23.12

\lx wayont
\va waont
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 184
\ps part. of |wauónat|
\ge `sun-setting'
\so Gen.15.12; Mk.1.32; Lev.22.7

    \se wayau
    \ps AI {c.f. gender of |nepauz|, at least in the sense `month'}
    \ge `it was sunset'
    \so Gen.28.11
    \xv Onk ne peyon ayeuonganit, kah ∞wompanóhkon newutche wayau,...
    \xe And he lighted upon a certain place, and tarried there all night, because the sun was set;...
    \so Gen.28.11
    \nt +
    `the sun went down'    2 Sam.2.24
    \xv Ut ukkesukodtumut, pish kutoadtuhkau wutonkquatunk, kah matta pish nepauz wunnashpe waôun,...
    \xe At his day thou shalt give him his hire, neither shall the sun go down upon it;...
    \so Deut.24.15
    \nt +

    \xv ...: kah quenau waônt, Joshua ann∞team∞ n∞kinônat wuhhogkuh wutch mehtugqut,...
    \xe ...: and as soon as the sun was down, Joshua commanded that they should take his carcase down from the tree,...
    \so Josh.8.29; (E1): |wáont|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., papaume ahhutt∞che wayont,...
    \xe ... at the time of the going down of the sun, ...
    \so Josh.10.27√
    \xv ash waoongkup
    \xe before (it was) sunset, "before the sun went down"'    Judg.14.18 { |ash| takes negative conjunct form of verb, at least in the sense `before
    \so ; hence |-k|. }

    \xv Musquanatam∞k kah ahque matchesek ahque waonch ut kummusquanittam∞onganit.
    \xe Be ye angry, and sin not: let not the sun go down upon your wrath:
    \so Eph.4.26
    \nt +

    (|oowayaonk nepaz| `sun setting'    C.164)

[Narragansett [xnt] |wayaàwi| `the sun is set'    R.W.67.

\lx weadtimau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 184
    \nt +
\ps TA, oral final
\twn |weogquttum|, TI; on the slighly opaque relationship, see G.1981, 42, 89.
\ge `to make mention of sb, mention sb, speak concerning, of sb; to take counsel against sb'
\so Gen.40.14; Ps.87.4; Jer.49.30; Jn.8.27; Jn.(M).6.71,7.13,8.27,12.41,13.18; Acts 2.25; Eph.1.16; 1 Thes.1.2
    \xv ...: newutche Nebuchadnezzar Babylone ketass∞t ayeuuhkonittue k∞weadtimuk∞,...
    \xe ...; for Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon hath taken counsel against you,...
    \so Jer.49.30
    \ng 3->2p
    \xv Newutche David ∞weadtimuh, negonae nunnau LORD nagwutteae ut anaquabeh,...
    \xe For David speaketh concerning him, I foresaw the Lord always before my face;...'    Acts 2.25  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    \xv Matta ∞wohtauóuh, noh weadtimont Wut∞shineuh.
    \xe They understood not that he spake to them of the Father.'    Jn.8.27  { 3->3
    \so (?) [use of conjunct?]; (M) |weatimau| }
    \xv Yeush wussinneapash Esaias, ne nág wussohsumm∞onk kah wayatimont.
    \xe These things said Esaias, when he saw his glory, and spake of him.|    Jn.12.41(M)  { 3->3
    \so changed conjunct }

    \xv ..., kah weadtimeh ut Pharohut,...
    \xe ..., and make mention of me unto Pharaoh,...
    \so Gen.40.14
    \ng 2->1 imperative


\lx weamukshau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 184
    \nt +
\ps AI+O?
\ge `to be among sb', where the subject/object relationships remain unclear. Compare Num.11.20 and 11.21 (and |anaquabit|?).
\so Num.11.20,21,16.3,17.6; Deut.15.4; Josh.10.1
    \xv ...: kah ummehtugk∞mes Aaron weamukshau nag ummehtugk∞mes∞óut.
    \xe ...: and the rod of Aaron was among their rods.
    \so Num.17.6
    \ng gender? role of locative?
    \xv Onk woh mo matchéku k∞wéamukshom∞,...
    \xe Save when there shall be no poor among you;...
    \so Deut.15.4
    \xv ..., kah ∞wéamukshonuh.
    \xe ..., and [they] were among them;
    \so Josh.10.1

    \xv ...Jehovah, noh weamukshôóg ...
    \xe ... the LORD which is among you,...
    \so Num.11.20
    \ng 2p->_3_
    \xv ..., Missinninnúok neg weamukshóuneg, neg nequtta tahshe pasuk∞e muttannonganogkussuog mahtsitâushacheg,...
    \xe ..., The people among whom I am, are six hundred thousand footmen;...
    \so Num.11.21
    \ng 1->_3p_

\et Deverbal noun to H.4058-4059 *wi∙wa⌠iwa AI `carry' (cf. next lemma) and p.247 *-i∙waΘ `pack, bundle', verb of possession to (reanalyzed) dependent noun *-i∙waΘ-. See B. 103, 121/479 for observations on reanalysis of the formation, and G.1981, 104 on the retention of PEA *nïwa⌠.


\lx weassunónat
\va weasseu
\ve r. !
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

    \xv ..., kah noh weásehheont wuhhogkuh pissogque man∞nskoh.
    \xe ..., and to him that ladeth himself with thick clay.'    Hab.2.6  { 3->3
    \so participle }

\xe those that laded
\so Neh.4.17
\ng 3p participle to creative verb to deverbal noun: "those that gather burdenings"

    \xe parched corn

    \xe green ears of corn

    \xv munnequomin
    \xe growing corn

[Cf. Tupi ubatim, viba-tim, uba-tim, avaty, avatyi (ui, uy^, vi, flour, `farinha' ), which Von Martius (Wörtersamml. Brasil. Sprachen, 427) derives from viba, `gramen' and tim, `nasutum' (tim = fructus, Callinago; timiû, `comida', `sustento', `alieonto', Seixas), or from viba-tuûma, `gramen medullosum'; Omaguas dialect and Oyambi (of Cayenne), auaty, abaty; Cocomas, awate (Castelnau) ; Caraib avachit, aoachy, goaxi (Callinago); Cayapós, muschiú; Araicû, metschy (cf. meechu?); Chicriabás, notsche; Taino (Yucatan), mahiz, mayz; Maya, yxim; Tecuna, schiauü, Von Martins, l.c.; Corapô dialect, tschumnam.] See |meechu| `he eats'; |min| `a fruit'.

\lx web
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 185
    \nt +
\ps NA
\ge `wife'
\so Josselyn Voy. 67/94, 91/127, 96/135; N.E. Rar.98; see also OED, s.v.
    \xv Web
    \xe a wife
    \so Wood 1634, O 3v, c.1 (also 1635, 1639)
    |The {Indian Webbes} make use of the broad Teeth of the {Fawns} to hang about their Childrens Neck when they are breeding of their Teeth.|    Josselyn, N.E.Rar. 20
    |... an {Indian Webb}, or Wife, (for so they call those Women that have Husbands;) ...|    Josselyn, N.E.Rar.62
\nt The word is so far attested only in English sources; could it be, despite OED's shot in the dark ("perh. obs. Algonkin."), that this is in fact a pidgin form? Given the apparently short vowel, it may not be quite close enough to connect with "wife" with perfect certainty, though otherwise this fits very well? There may still have been relevant dialects of English with a fronted variant of the ME long /i:/ as the vowel shift proceeded, and no quantity contrast was available in the borrowing language(s).


\lx webe

    \so ; (E0) gl. "but more once"    Gen.18.32

    \xe not only so

    \xe you yourselves apart' (`you only
    \so )    Mk.6.31
    \xv ken webe nussu
    \xe thou only
    \so 2 K.19.19
    \xv matta howan ... webe nen
    \xe there is no one besides me
    \so Is.43.11

    \so Rev.2.17

    \xe Alone

    \nt +

    \xe Mere dunce
    \so C.26/172
    \nt +
    \xv Matta webe, {or} webeyeue.
    \xe Not only
    \so C.109/234
    \nt +
    \xv ..., woh matteag kuttïssu qut webe woh kunnup.
    \xe ..., thou mayest have nothing to do but to dy.

\lx weechauónat
\va wecháónat
\va weechauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 185
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\twn |weechahtom|?
\ge `to accompany, to go with'; +`to take sb (with one), to follow sb'
\nt G&B.736
    \xv ..., kah Lot ∞weechauoh...
    \xe ..., and Lot went with him...'    Gen.12.4  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk weecháau neesuoh ∞skenumoh,...
    \xe ..., and took two of his young men with him,...'    Gen.22.3  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah peyaog Egypt Jakob kah wame ∞skannémuneuh weechôg.
    \xe ..., and [they] came into Egypt, Jacob and all his seed with him.'    Gen.46.6  { ?3
    \so ->3p-def absolute[!] }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah weechog wame wuttinneumoh Pharoh,...
    \xe ...: and with him went up all the servants of Pharaoh,...'    Gen.50.7  { 3
    \so ->3-def absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Nuttinn∞hquabuonk pish k∞weechog,...
    \xe ..., My presence shall go with thee,...
    \so Ex.33.14
    \ng 0->2 indicative
    \xv Neit n∞che monaoh ukkodnetuhtáénumoh qushkeoh, kah matta wonk ma ∞weechóg∞oh.
    \xe From that time many of his disciples went back, and walked no more with him.'    Jn.6.66  { 3
    \so ->3-pro negative objective indicative }
    \xv ..., kah mohtompog ∞weechauoh nahog Peter, kah nawhutch ∞weemattinneunk ∞weechaóuh wutch Joppa.
    \xe .... And on the morrow Peter went away with them, and certain brethren from Joppa accompanied them.'    Acts 10.23 { 3->3'-def indicative [|nahog| usually proximate?]; 3p->3'-pro indicative }; sim. 20.38,23.32: |-auóuh| { 3p->3
    \so -pro }√
    (= |..., neh ∞weechógquoh Asia.| `there accompanied him into Asia ...'     Acts 20.4 { 3'-pro->3-pro objective, list of names resumed by pronoun |neh|)√
    \xv ..., wunnamuhkut k∞wechaush, ..., kah Debora neepoh kah weechauau Barak en Kadesh,
    \xe ..., I will surely go with thee:.... And Deborah arose, and went with Barak to Kedesh.'    Judg.4.9  { 1->2 indicative; 3-pro->3
    \so absolute, with switch of obviation? }

    \xv Lot wonk weechauont Abramoh,...
    \xe And Lot also which went with Abram,...'    Gen.13.5  { _3_->3
    \so participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ... en Godut, noh n∞tiup ne kesukok wodtamehpunáon, kah noh weecháop en mayut ne aóyomp
    \xe ... unto God, who answered me in the day of my distress, and was with me in the way which I went.
    \so Gen.35.3
    \ng _3_->1 preterite participle (cf. G&B.565)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., qut matta pajeh weechauóg peissisit kematou,...
    \xe ..., Except your youngest brother come down with you,...
    \so Gen.44.23
    \ng 2p->3 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wusken matta weechógk∞un. ...
    \xe ..., and the lad be not with mee,...
    \so Gen.44.34
    \ng 3->1 negative subjunctive
    \nt +
    \xv ..., noh weechogquean,...
    \xe ..., he it is that doth go with thee;...
    \so Deut.31.6
    \ng 3->2 participle
    \xv ..., kah unnau umumugquompom∞uh ayeuteaog, neh weechogqutcheh,...
    \xe ..., and said unto the captains of the men of war which went with him,...'    Josh.10.24 { _3
    \so _->3 }
    \nt +
    \xv Qut nematog neg weechogqueuhpanneg ...
    \xe Nevertheless my brethren that went up with me ...
    \so Josh.14.8
    \ng _3p_->1 preterite, theme 2
    \nt +
    |Kah Naomi n∞wau, qushkek wonk nuttaunog, tohwutch weechaéóg?|
    \nt +
`And Naomi said, Turn again, my daughters: why will ye go with me?'    Ruth 1.11 { 2p->1 }
    \xv weechaiean
    \xe if thou go with me
    \so Judg.4.8
    \ng 2->1 conjunct

    \xv ..., kah wusken weechauonch wematuh.
    \xe ..., and let the lad go up with his brethren.'    Gen.44.33  { 3->3
    \so imperative }
    \nt +
    \xv ...: kummukkiésum∞óog wonk weechóg∞k.
    \xe ...: let your little ones also go with you.
    \so Ex.10.24
    \ng 3->2p imperative
    \xv ..., weechogqush wame ayeuteae missinninnuog, kah neepaush, kuhkuhquegk én Ai:...
    \xe ...: take all the people of war with thee, and arise, go up to Ai:...
    \so Josh.8.1
    \ng 3->2 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv Howan chequshanukquean wechaónat pasuk mile, wechau nees.
    \xe And whosoever shall compel thee to go a mile, go with him twain.
    \so Mt.5.41√
    \ng 2->3 imperative


[Narragansett [xnt] |Cowéchaush.| `I will goe with you.'; |Cowéchaw ewò.| `He will goe with you'; |Cowechauatímmin.| `I will goe with you.'; |Wechauatíttea.| `Let us accompany.'    R.W.70.√
    Western Abenaki [abe] |ne8"itsé8añ|, 3. |a8it| `[je vais avec lui]'    R.4/379a.
    \nt +
Delaware [del] |wiichéeweew| TA `accompany s.o., go with s.o.'    O'M.340a.
Lp.A. |ki8ichiaux| `je t accompagne'    D.21.

\et B. 62, 106/463, A.2220, H.3924: *wi∙cye∙we∙wa TA `he accompanies him', with B.1962, 16.179, p.363 |wi∙ci∙wε∙w| `he goes along with him'


\lx weechayeumau
\va weechiyeumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 185
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv |weech-| `with' + |aye-| `to be at' + |-m-| TA consociative final, to |weech-|
\ge `to be among, with sb, to dwell with sb,', etc.
    \xv ..., noh wuttin weechayeuwutinneaoont ..., kah woh mat weechayeuwuttéog.
    \xe ..., that they might dwell together,..., so that they could not dwell together.
    \so Gen.13.6
    \ng 3p t-subordinative, reciprocal; 3p negative indicative, reciprocal
    \xv Newutche ∞wenaiétuongan∞ wussaumanit matta woh wunnu wechaiyeuteog,...
    \xe For their riches were more than they might dwell together:...
    \so Gen.36.7
    \ng 3p indicative, reciprocal
    \xv ..., nohsiit paantog, ukkodnetuhtaeneumoh weechiyeumuk,...
    \xe ..., as he was alone praying, his disciples were with him:...'    Lk.9.18  { 3p->3
    \so objective }
    \xv ..., wuttabarnakleum GOD weechayeumau wosketompuh, kah nah pish ∞weechinninneumoh, ..., kah GOD nagum pish ∞weetomuh,...
    \xe ..., the tabernacle of God is with men, and he will dwell with them, ..., and God himself shall be with them,...
    \so Rev.21.3

    \xv Kah kenaumw∞ wutuhquanittam∞m∞oash, kah wunnishkeneunkque wuttinneukontunkan∞oh, mehtugq kah qussuk, silver kah gold, neh weechiyeumukquehetticheh)
    \xe And ye have seen their abominations, and their idols, wood and stone, silver and gold, which were among them:)'    Deut.29.17  { _3
    \so _->3p participle }
    \xv ...uttoh woh adt wunnass∞tamauont, matta weechayeumunk muttaanutcheh.
    \xe ... to betray him unto them in the absence of the multitude.
    \so Lk.22.6

    \xv ..., wunnohteae weechayeum∞k wame missinninnuog.
    \xe ..., live peaceably with all men.
    \so Rom.12.18


\lx weeche
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 185
\ps prep. / P, PreV/initial
    \nt Remark: Commonly takes ratifying consociative final in combination with an AI verb; may occur with "silent" 3(') object, as Gen.7.13, 9.8.
    \nt +
\ge `with, in company with' (a person, or an. obj.)
\nt G&B.736 P `together (with)'
\so Ex.23.1; Job 1.4
    \xv ... uppomantamunnaoont weeche ken:...
    \xe ..., to keep them alive with thee:...
    \so Gen.6.19
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nishnoh ummittumwussoh wunnaumonuh weeche ...
    \xe ..., and the three wives of his sons with them,...
    \so Gen.7.13
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wunnaumonuh ummittumwussuoh weeche nagum.
    \xe ..., and his sons' wives with him:
    \so Gen.8.18
    \nt +
    \xv Kah GOD ken∞nau Noahoh, & wunnaumonuh weeche, n∞wau,
    \xe And God spake unto Noah, and to his sonnes with him, saying;
    \so Gen.9.8
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Sun kuppagwun sampwesecheg weeche matchet∞wog?
    \xe ..., Wilt thou also destroy the righteous with the wicked?
    \so Gen.18.23
    \nt +

    \xv K∞weche w∞mseumsh en Egypt:...
    \xe I will go down with thee into Egypt;...
    \so Gen.46.4√
    \xv ..., kah noh papequo[h]tunk monopuhpeg, no[h] weechiyeumuk.
    \xe he was with me.
    \so Neh.4.18√
    \ng no sign of 1 prefix |n∞-|
    |weechepeyamooncheg Jakoboh ... ut Egipt^| "Those who came with Jacob to Egypt"    Gen.46.11(Hd,E0),46.26  { _3p_->3' participle }
    \nt +

\cf nashpe
\ge with
\so (inan. obj.)

[Delaware [del] |witschi|    Zeisb.]


\lx weechekompaumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 185
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv |weech-| + |-kompau-| `stand' (T+.40a) + consociative final
\ge `to stand by, with sb' (often with deictic, `here', `there')
\so Gen.18.2,45.1; Ex.34.5; Num.1.5,11.16; Deut.29.15; Mt.26.73; Lk.9.32; Jn.18.5; Acts 1.10,4.14,23.2,11; 2 Tim.4.16
    \xv ..., nishuoh wosketompuh weechekompaumuk,...
    \xe ..., three men stood by him:...'    Gen.18.2  { 3
    \so ->3 absolute }
    \xv ..., onk matta howan wéechekompaumuk∞,...
    \xe .... And there stood no man with him,...'    Gen.45.1  { 3
    \so ->3 negative absolute }
    \xv Kah Jehovah n∞keu nashpe mahtokqs, kah na wuttit weechekompaumon:...
    \xe And the LORD descended in the cloud, and stood with him there,...'    Ex.34.5  { 3->3
    \so subordinative }
    \xv ..., kusseh, nesuog wosktetompaog ∞weechekompaumóoh womphogkouunáog.
    \xe ..., behold, two men stood by them in white apparel;'    Acts 1.10  { 3p->3
    \so objective }

    \xv Qut nashpe noh weechekompaumukqueog yeu kesukok ut anaquabit Jehovah kum-Manitt∞mw∞,...
    \xe But with him that standeth here with us this day before the LORD our God,...
    \so Deut.29.15
    \ng _3_->1p participle


\lx weechinnineumau
\va wechinninnumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 185
    \nt +
\ps TA, consociative final
\nt Remark: This is an extension of Trumbull's entry, which follows. Probably built to a predicative verb derived from a compound noun (unattested as yet?) |weechinnin(u)| `fellow man', with |weech-| conditioning the occurrence of the TA final. See N&Q on Gen.42.13.
\ge "to have sb as a fellow", or, more specifically, "as a cohabitant" (cf. Rev.21.3)? Used to translate `family, household' in participial form.
\so Gen.18.19,40.7,42.13; Lev.25.10,41; Ps.68.6; Eph.2.19; Phil.4.22; Rev.21.3
    \xv ..., muttásons weecheninneumau n∞shunónuh yeu kesukok,...
    \xe ..., the youngest is this day with our father,...'    Gen.42.13  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv GOD ponamauau nonsiyeu∞oh weechinninnumonát ...
    \xe God setteth the solitary in families:...
    \so Ps.68.6; (M) |wechinninnumuwaheau| (causative)
    \xv ..., Kusseh, wuttabarnakleum GOD weechayeumau wosketompuh, kah nah pish ∞weechinninneumoh, kah nag pish neh ummissinninneumoh,...
    \xe ..., Behold, the tabernacle of God is with men, and he will dwell with them, and they shall be his people,...'    Rev.21.3  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    \xv ..., noh woh piahtimau wunneechanoh, kah weechininnúmonche nahohtôeu,...
    \xe ..., that he will command his children and his household after him,...'    Gen.18.19  { 3->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \xv ..., kah nish noh wosketomp en weechinninneumoncheg, pish qushkeu.
    \xe ..., and ye shall return every man unto his family.
    \so Lev.25.10
    \ng 3->_3p_??; tr.: main verb erroneously 3 for 2p, hence clash of proximates?

\lx weekontamunát
\va wekon antamunat
\va wekontam
\ve =
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 185
\ps v.i. / TI1a(-O), mental final
\ge `to be glad, to rejoice, to be pleased'; +(negated) `to refuse to, not to like to, not to be willing to'
\so Eccl.3.12; 8.15; +Deut.25.7,8
    \xv ..., Paguodche mittamwossis matta weekontam∞h yeu pajeh weechógqunat yeu ohket:...

    \so Gen.24.5
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta n∞wekontam∞ nemunonat.
    \xe ..., I like not to take her;
    \so Deut.25.8
    \nt +
    \xv n∞wekontam
    \xe I am glad
    \so Ps.9.2
    \xv wekontam
    \xe he is glad
    \so Ps.16.9
    (C.192 `to be willing'    C.215)


    \xv wekontash
    \xe rejoice thou, be glad
    \so Joel 2.21
    \xv wekontam∞k, kah ahche muskouantam∞k
    \xe rejoice (ye) and be exceeding glad
    \so Mt.5.12

    \se wekontam∞m∞
    \ps pass. form with inan. subj. / II
    \ge `(it) rejoices, is made glad'
    \so Ps.16.9

    \se |wekontamwahtau|, |-hteau|
    \nt +
    \ps 0->0 causative
    \ge `to make sth glad'
    \so Ps.46.4,104.15

    \xv Na seip n ne kussitchuan weekontamwahtunk wut∞tan GOD:...
    \xe There is a river, the streams whereof shall make glad the city of God:...
    \so Ps.46.4; (M) |wekontamwohtunk|
    \ng _0_->0 participle

\cf wussekitteahhuönat

\lx wekontam∞woNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 186
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative
\ge `to rejoice over sb'
\so Deut.28.63,30.9; 2 Cor.1.14; Gal.6.4
    \xv ..., nenawun k∞wekontam∞wósinan neyane kenaau wonk k∞wekontamóunnumun, ut ukkesukkodumut LORD Jesus.
    \xe ..., that we are your rejoicing, even as ye also are ours in the day of the Lord Jesus.
    \so 2 Cor.1.14
    \ng 2p->1p, 1p->2p i.e. "ye rejoice over us ... we rejoice over you"
    \xv ..., neit pish wekontam∞wonau wuhhogkuh nussu,...
    \xe ..., and then shall he have rejoicing in himself alone,...
    \so Gal.6.4

    \xv ..., neane Jehovah wekontam∞ónukqueog k∞nenehukqunnaóut, kah kummuttaanhukqunnaóut, netatuppe Jehovah pish kittin wekontam∞ónukqunneau, kummatchuwahukqunnaóut, kah kuppagwanukqunnaóut,...
    \xe ..., that as the Lord rejoiced over you to do you good, and to multiply you; so the Lord will rejoice over you to destroy you, and to bring you to nought;...
    \so Deut.28.63
    \xv ..., newutche Jehovah pish qushken, k∞wekontam∞onukqunnat wutch wanegik, neane wekontam∞onomp k∞shikoh.
    \xe ...: for the Lord will again rejoice over thee for good, as he rejoiced over thy fathers:
    \so Deut.30.9


\lx wekontamwaheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 186
    \nt +
\ps TA, causative to |wekontam|
\ge `to comfort sb, to make sb glad, to make sb to rejoice'
\so Gen.24.67; Ruth 2.13; Ps.86.4,89.42; Lk.15.29; 2 Cor.1.4,6,2.2,7; Col.4.11
    \xv ..., ne wutche k∞wekontamwahe,...
    \xe ... for that thou hast comforted me,...
    \so Ruth 2.13
    \xv ...: k∞weekontamwah wame ummatwomoh.
    \xe ...: thou hast made all his enemies to rejoyce.'    Ps.89.42  { 2->3(
    \so ) absolute }
    \xv Noh wekontamwahikqueog ut wame k∞tamehpunaonganónut, onk woh kuttapenumumun nag wekontamwaheonat, toh áne wuttamehpunacheg, nashpe ne wekontamwàhettuonk ne adt wekontamwahikqueog GOD.
    \xe Who comforteth us in all our tribulation, that we may be able to comfort them which are in any trouble, by the comfort wherewith we ourselves are comforted of God.
    \so 2 Cor.1.4

    \xv Newutche n∞hennog, howan neit noh wekontamwahit, kah noh neuanatamheóg.
    \xe For if I make you sorry, who is he then that maketh me glad, but the same which is made sorry by me?
    \so 2 Cor.2.2

    \xv Weekontamwah ukketeahogkôunnoh kittinnum,...
    \xe Rejoyce the soul of thy servant:...'    Ps.86.4; (M): |Wekontamwah|  { 2->3(
    \so ) imperative }
    \xv Weekontamwâhinnean neâne kesukodtash onkkuppunnaneuog,...
    \xe Make us glad according to the dayes wherein thou hast afflicted us:...
    \so Ps.90.15; (M): |Wekontamwahhinnean|

    \se !|wekontamwehtunkquissu|
    \nt +
\ps AI, final |-htonkqu-se-| `to make an X noise, to sound X', T+.29b
\ge `to make a joyful noise'
\so Ps.81.1(M)

    \xv .... wekontamwehtunkquisseg en um-Mannittoomoh Jakob.
    \xe ...: make a joyfull noise unto the God of Jacob.
    \so Ps.81.1(M)
    \ng 2p imperative


\lx weematoh
\va -emat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 186
\ps n. / dependent NA
\ge `(his) brother'
    constr. `the brother of'    Gen.25.26; Acts 12.2; Mk.3.17
    \xv nemat
    \xe my brother
    \so Acts 9.17
    \xv kemat
    \xe thy brother
    \so Gen.27.35
    |kematti| AV "his brother"  { 2 possessor absentative }
    \xv neematog
    \xe my brethren
    \so Mt.12.48
    \xv kematog
    \xe thy brethren
    \so Lk.8.20√
    \xv wematoh
    \xe his brethren
    \so Lk.8.19√
    \xv kematt∞wóog
    \xe your brethren
    \so Num.32.6
    \xv ... Nen Joseph kematou noh mag∞ógkup en Egypt.
    \xe ..., I am Joseph your brother, whom ye sold into Egypt.
    \so Gen.45.4
    \ng 2p possessive singular

    \se !|weematu|, !|wematu|
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: The form of the participle indicates that the 3 possessor form |weemat-| is taken as the basis for the possessive verb.
    \ps AI(+O), predicative verb, possessive verb
    \ge `to be sb's brother, to have (sb as) a brother'
    \so Gen.42.13,44.19,49.5; Deut.17.15
    \xv ..., K∞t∞shimwou? asuh k∞wemattimw∞?
    \xe ..., Have ye a father, or a brother?
    \so Gen.44.19
    \ng 2p absolute

    \xv ..., matta woh kupponum pén∞wot kenanauunukqunat, noh matta waemattean.
    \xe ...: thou mayest not set a stranger over thee, which is not thy brother.
    \so Deut.17.15
    \ng 2->_3_, negative participle

    \se |wemattittuog|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, plurale tantum, reciprocal to !|weematu|
    \ge `to be brethren'
    \so Gen.13.8,42.19
    \xv ... kittinneumog nabo neesu wemattittuog,...
    \xe ..., Thy servants are twelve brethren,...
    \so Gen.42.13
    \ng 3p reciprocal, predicative

\cf weetompas
\cf weetuksquoh

    [Delaware [del] |Nimat| `my brother; (used also as friendly salutation between distant relatives. A.)'; (Unami) |ní:maht@s| `my brother (man speaking)', (Munsee) |ní:mat| ~ |ní:màt@s| `my brother (man speaking)'    B&A.97; G.1973.40.
    \nt +
Lp.A. |nimat. (pl.) tak.| `mon frere', |k8imatetemenen 8ami| `nous sommes tous freres'    D.86.
Menominee [mez] |ne∙mat| `my (man's) brother'; |owe∙matemε∙w| TA `he (man) has or treats him as a brother, cousin, friend; he makes friends with him', |owe∙matew| AI `he (man) has (some boy or man as) a brother, cousin, friend', |owe∙mate∙htowak| AI `they (boys or men) are brothers, cousins, friends; they make friends with each other'    B.1962,15.11,18.16; B.1975.186.

\lx weenuhkauónat
\va weinuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 186
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\dv |waen-| (etc.) `around' + |-hk-aw-| TA
    \ge `to be, encamp round about sb, environ sb round'
    \nt +
\twn |weenuhkomumunát|
    \xv Newutche Cananitsog, kah wame neg wadohkitcheg ohkeit pish wunn∞tamunneau, kah pish n∞weinuhkonkqunonog,...
    \xe For the Canaanites and all the inhabitants of the land shall hear of it, and shall environ us round,...
    \so Josh.7.9
    \ng 3p->1p
    \nt +
    \xv Wut-angelsumuh GOD weenuhkauwaog nag nah quoshoncheg:...
    \xe The angel of the Lord encampeth round about them that fear him,...
    \so Ps.34.7√; (M): |oowenuhkauuh|

    \xv Ahque asuhkau onkatogig manitt∞og, ummanitt∞m∞oh missinninnuog, neg weenuhkongqueanag.
    \xe Ye shall not go after other gods, of the gods of the people which are round about you;
    \so Deut.6.14
    \ng 3(p)->2[!]; E1: |-eg|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., netagwapetau ketass∞t, onatuh wame wutohtimoneash weenuhkiitchish.
    \xe ..., I will set a king over me, like as all the nationss that are about me;
    \so Deut.17.14
    \nt +

    \xv ayeuuhkone weenuhkók
    \xe camp [ye] against it round about
    \so Jer.50.29
\cf waéenu


\lx weenuhkomumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 186
\ps v.t. inan. / TI1a, corporal final. (On |hk|, see B.1962, 1925, 419.)
\twn |weenuhkauónat|
\ge `to camp round about (it), to besiege, to compass', +`to compass sth round'
    \xv ..., weenuhkomwog wetu,...
    \xe ..., [they] compassed the house round,
    \so Gen.19.4
    \ng 3p->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah pish k∞weinohkomumw∞ keitotan, wame ayeuhteaenuog,...
    \xe And ye shall compass the city, all ye men of war,...
    \so Josh.6.3
    \ng 2p->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nishwe kodtumwae ∞wéenuhkomun
    \xe ..., and [he] besieged it three years.
    \so 2 K.17.5
    \ng 3->0 objective

    \xv ..., kutchittóushagk, kah weénuhkom∞k otan,...
    \xe ..., Pass on, and compass the city,...
    \so Josh.6.7

\lx weenusheau
\va -shau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 186
\ps v.i. / II(+O)
\ge `it goeth around, "compasseth"' (of a boundary line); + presumably OED s.v. 7: `To encircle, environ, lie round and enclose, as the sea, a girdle, etc. Also with {round}, {about}, {in}."
\so Josh.18.14; 19.14
    \xv Kah sussippoi weenushau wutch Baalah wutcheksuiyeu wehque wadchuut Seir,...
    \xe And the border compassed from Baalah westward unto mount Seir,...
    \so Josh.15.10
    \ng Anchor Bible: "The boundary turned around west of Baalah to Mount Seir", whatever that means--at least a change of direction?
    \nt +
    \xv Kah sussippoi weenushau en nannummiyeu en Hannathon,...
    \xe And the border compasseth it on the north side to Hannathon:...
    \so Josh.19.14
    \xv pemunneat weenisheau
    \xe a line compasses it about
    \so 2 Chr.4.2

\lx weeswe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 187
\ps n.
\ge `the gall'
\so Deut.29.18; Ps.69.21
    \xv n∞weeswe
    \xe my gall
    \so Job 16.13
\cf wesogkon
\ge bitter
\cf weesóe
\ge yellow
(Cf. also Sax. ge-alewe, yellow; gealla, gall; Greek xolè, bile; xlóe, xlóa, greenish yellow; Arab. murr and sô'uda, bile; murr, bitter; âçfer (fem. çàfra), yellow.)

\et A.2248-2250, H.4000,4012-4024,4030, with some discrepancies. (G.1965, no. 66, 220b, glossed `yellow', also no doubt belongs here, just as gall (and gold) and yellow are cognates in English.


\lx weetahtu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 187
\ps n. / NA, dependent
\ge `a sister or half-sister'
    \nt Remark: Mayhew (Jn.(M), ch.11) appears to use these for cross-sex siblings; Eliot's usage occasionally conforms to this, but perhaps accidentally.
    \nt +
\so Lev.20.17; 21.3; Jn.11.5 (strictly, one of the same household or family, a near relative) The category of the word is unclear, but it does not behave like a possessed noun, as witness the lack of the obviative suffix and the endingless forms |netaht| (Jn.11.21,32(M)) and |ketaht| (Jn.11.23(M)); nevertheless, |wetahtu∞uh| `their brother', Jn.11.19(M). Additional instances in Eliot: Gen.28.9; Num.6.7; Josh.2.13,17.4
    \nt Remark: |-t-| a palatalized |-k-|?; c.f. |weetukssquoh|.
    \nt +

    (|netukkusq| `my sister'    Lk.10.40)
\cf ummissies
\cf weetompas
\cf weetuksquoh

[Narragansett [xnt] |Wéticks, {&} Weésummis| `A sister.'    R.W.29√.]

    \xv Weetanum∞mog, matta ∞namptam∞uneau:...

\lx weetauomónat

    \xe AND there went a man of the house of Levi, and took to wife a daughter of Levi.
    \so Ex.2.1√
    \xv ..., ummittumwussoh noh napuk matta pish wutauomoou penuwohteuh,...

    \so negative absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche nesausuk tahsuog ∞weetauomouh,

    \so }

    \xv ...: onk ompetak wunnaumonuh GOD weetoamâhettit wosketompaog wuttón∞oh ...
    \xe ...; and also after that, when the sons of God came in unto the daughters of men,...'    Gen.6.4  { 3p->3
    \so conjunct }
    \nt +
    \xv Noh wadchanont weetauómutcheh, noh wesseentamwaen,...
    \xe He that hath the bride, is the bridegroom:...'    Jn.3.29  { ?X->_3'_ participle }; (M) |wetauwateanitcheh|  { _3
    \so _ participle to |wetauadteau|, v.i. }
    \nt +
    \xv Newaj wásukeh pomantamunit weetauomont onkatogke wosketompuh, pish hennau manúsquaaúsuénin:...
    \xe So then if, while her husband liveth, she be married to another man, she shall be called an adulteress:...'    Rom.7.3√  { 3->3
    \so conjunct }
    pass. |sekousq noh wetauomomp sephausuaenin| `a widow who had a priest (for husband)'    Ezek.44.22

    \xv ..., petukau kemat ummittumwussoh, kah wetauam,...
    \xe ..., Go in unto thy brother's wife, and marry her,...
    \so Gen.38.8
    \ng 2->3 imperative
    \nt +

    \se !|wetauadteau|, |wetauak-|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, indefinite object final (G&B. no.14, 580)
    \ge `to be married, to marry'
    \so Josh.23.12; Lk.20.34,35; 1 Cor.7.9,11,28,33; C.
    \xv ..., matta nag wetauadteog, asuh matta wetauadheoog.
    \xe ..., [they] neither marry nor are given in marriage:
    \so Lk.20.35
    \ng causative with palatalization? Lk.20.34 should be parallel but shows unexpected forms, E1&2: typographical error?
    \nt +
    (|Noowetauattam| `I am married, (the woman,)'    C.65/201√
    \xv Wetouadtinnate wetouakönate
    \xe To be married,
    \so C.65/201√)
    \xv Wetouadteau, kekompau.
    \xe Marrying, married.
    \so C.93/221
    \nt +

    \xv Qut toh n ne qushkeog, kah mosogquehtamog ashqueyeu∞gish yeush wutohtimoneash, yeush ashqueyeu∞gish ut kenugke kenaau, kah weetauadteog,...
    \xe Else if ye do in any wise go back, and cleave unto the remnant of these nations, even these that remain among you, and shall make marriages with them,...
    \so Josh.23.12
    \nt +
    \xv ...: noh matta wetauwáteog,...
    \xe .... He that is unmarried ...
    \so 1 Cor.7.32
    \nt +
    \xv Qut noh wetauadteadt, ...
    \xe But he he that is married ...
    \so 1 Cor.7.33√
    \xv Qut wetauadteaan matta kummatcheseu,...
    \xe But and if thou marry, thou hast not sinned;...
    \so 1 Cor.7.28√

    \xv Qut matta kehchithahettegk, wetauadteahettich, newutche an wunnegik wetauákon onk ne chikohsimuk.
    \xe But if they cannot contain, let them marry: for it is better to marry than to burn.
    \so 1 Cor.7.9
    \ng perhaps reciprocal; subordinative form (velar) indefinite
    \nt +
    \xv Qut amait, wetauadteakitch,...
    \xe But and if she depart, let her remain unmarried,...
    \so 1 Cor.7.11
    \nt +

    \se !|wetauadteu|

    \ps AI, i-stem, reciprocal to lemma
    \ge `to make a marriage'
    \so Gen.34.9

    \xv Kah wetauatitteuh,...
    \xe And make ye marriages with us,...
    \so Gen.34.9
    \ng 12 imperative

    \xv nummittumwussissu
    \xe I (a man) am married
    \so C.201)

    \so objective }

    \xe he shall not dwell in my house
    \so Ps.101.7  { 3->1 negative indicative }; (M): |aiyeu|
    \xv ..., Sun ne kuttunukkuhque wetomununneau, kah asquam k∞waheuh, Philip? ...
    \xe ..., Have I been so longtime with you, and yet hast thou not known me, Philip? ...'    Jn.14.9(M.) { 1->2p subordinative; Eliot
    \so s version looks defective. }

\lx wetomp-
\va weetomp-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 188
    \nt +
\ps n. / NA, dependent
\ge `a friend, kinsman'
\so Ex.33.11; Prov.17.17; 27.6
\nt Remark: Replaces Trumbull's lemma |weetompain| [|weetu-omp| (?)], an indefinite possessor form (G&B. 491, 500) to this stem.
    \xv neetomp
    \xe my friend
    \so Is.41.8; Lk.11.6
    \xv ketomp
    \xe thy friend
    \so 2 Chr.20.7
    \xv neetompaog
    \xe my friends
    \so Cant.5.1
    `my kinsmen'    Ps.38.11; Lk.14.12

    \se !|(∞)wetompaeu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), verb of possession
    \ge `to be (sb's) friend, to have a friend'
    \nt Remark: On the initial |∞-|, compare entry |wasukeh|, T+.182b.
    \xv ..., Yeuoh wosketomp pohquohwhunat, matta k∞wetompoou Cesar:...
    \xe ..., If thou let this man go, thou art not Cæsar's friend:...
    \so Jn.19.12; (M): |matta k∞wetompomoh|
    \ng with possessive theme sign

    \xv ..., howan kenaau ∞wetompait, peyaonont nóetipukkodtáe, kah unont,...
    \xe ..., Which of you shall have a friend, and shall go unto him at midnight, and say unto him,...
    \so Lk.11.5
    |..., sun mat k∞wahteauomw∞, ∞weetompoáyeog muttaohke, yeu wutjishontamóonk | GOD? newutche ∞weetompait muttaohke, wutayeuhkonukquoh GOD.| `..., know ye not that the friendship of the world is enmity with God? whosoever therefore will be a friend of the world is the enemy of God.'    Jas.4.4

    \xv ..., ∞wetompohteagk nashpe pann∞wausseaen mammon n∞sinnitteaog,...
    \xe ..., Make to yourselves friends of the mammon of unrighteousness;...
    \so Lk.16.9
    \ng TI causative to the sublemma
\cf wuttinnunkumôin
\ge a kinsman


\lx weetompas
\va weetompassu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 188
\ps n. / NA, dependent, ?diminutive to |weetomp(á)-|
    \nt Remark: expected usage (see Algonquian parallels below): cross-sex sibling, as in 2 Sam.13; not checked
    \nt +
\ge `(his or her) brother or sister, the brother or sister of'
    \xv netompas
    \xe my sister
    \so Gen.20.12; 2 Sam.13.6; Mk.3.35
    \xv Tamar neetompas
    \xe Tamar my sister
    \so { "my" denotes Amnon }
    \xv neetompas
    \xe my brother
    \so 2 Sam.13.12  { "my" denotes Tamar }√
    |ketompas| (|két-|) `thy sister' (father's or mother's daughter)    Lev.18.9; (E1): |kummissis|√
    \xv ketompas
    \xe thy brother
    \so 2 Sam.13.20 { "thy" denotes Tamar; also examples with 1 and 3 possessor in this verse) }√
    \xv weetompasu
    \xe his or her sister
    \so 2 Sam.13.2; Ezek.16.45
    `his or her brother'    2 Sam.13.8, 10.20
    (|Wetompasin, asuh netat.| `A sister'    C.13/162)

    \xv netukkusq
    \xe my sister
    \so Lk.10.40
\cf ummissies
\cf weematoh
\cf weetahtu

[Narragansett [xnt] |wéticks|, |weésummis|    R.W.45.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |nidañbé| `Mon frère, seu, un étranger que j'aime comme mon frère'    R.378/499a.
    \nt +
Del. "For siblings of opposite sex, Delaware uses regularly formed possessives of the ordinary words for `man' (Unami |l@'nu|, Munsee |l@'n@w|) and `woman' (Unami |xkwé:|, Munsee |óxkwe:w|)."    G.1973.42.
Lp.A |nitambas| `Mon frere dit la soeur, ma soeur dit le frere'    D.86.
WAbn. |Nidôbso| `My brother; (when the speaker is a {female}.)', `My sister; (when the speaker is a {male}.)'    L.21; also Speck 1918,157, D.1.236.]

\et See B.1941 for parallel formations in *-i∙t `fellow'; G., no.35, 215b-216a, as if from *-i∙t + *-(n)a∙pe∙- `male'; here, a diminutive derivative.

\lx weet∞womau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 188
    \nt +
\ps TA, with |-m-| of speech
\ge `to assent, confer, grant; be confederate with'
\nt Lemma remark: relationship to |weetauomau| `to marry sb' uncertain
\so Is.7.2; Acts 24.9; Gal.1.16; Eph.3.16; Philm.14; Rev.3.21
    \xv ..., Syria weet∞womau Ephraimoh,...
    \xe ..., Syria is confederate with Ephraim. ...
    \so Is.7.2
    \xv ..., teanuk mat n∞weet∞wom∞ weyaus & wsqueheonk
    \xe ...; immediately I conferred not with flesh and blood:
    \so Gal.1.16
    \xv Woh k∞wetuwomukqunnaóut, neyane wenauwetúm∞uk wussohsumóonk, menehkhettinnat ...
    \xe That he would grant you, according to the riches of his glory, to be strengthened ...
    \so Eph.3.16

    \xv Kah Jewsog weet∞womahettit n∞wáog nennih.
    \xe And the Jews also assented, saying that these things were so.
    \so Acts 24.9
    \ng 3p conjunct -- why?


\lx weetsum∞mau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 188
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv probably |weet-| (or |weech-, with syncope & assimilation) + |-(h)sum-| (speculative) `lay (lie?)' + |-m-| TA, to |weet-|
\ge `to lie, sleep with sb'
\so Deut.31.16
    \xv ..., kusseh k∞weetsum∞m k∞shik, ...
    \xe ..., thou shalt sleep with thy fathers;...
    \so Deut.31.16

\nt Remark: Compare |n∞weeche sepsum∞m n∞shog| `I will lie with my fathers', Gen.47.30, and the final seen in *e⌠i-h⌠im-e∙-wa TA `he lays him so', B. no.166, 57, 104/461--perhaps in a detransitivized form?


\lx weetukquom∞mau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 188
    \nt +
\ps TA
\dv |weet-| `with' + |-ukquôm-| `to sleep' + |-m-| TA (speculative)
\ge `to lie with sb', i.e. "to sleep with sb"
\so Gen.30.16
    \xv ..., kah weetukquom∞tuog ne nohkog
    \xe .... And he lay with her that night.
    \so Gen.30.16
    \ng 3p reciprocal


\lx weetuksquoh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 188
\ps n. (constr.) / NA, dependent
\ge `the sister of, his or her sister'
\so Jn.11.1
    \xv kokas weetakusquoh
    \xe thy mother's sister
    \so Lev.20.19
    \nt +
    (|wetukkushquoh|    Lk.10.39)
    \xv netukkusq
    \xe my sister
    \so Lk.10.40
\nt Like |weetahtu|, it is not restricted in its application to a sister of the whole blood, or uterine, but signifies any near kinswoman or female inmate of the house. From |wetaht-squa|. See |weetahtu|. { The |-t-| must represent a palatalized |-k-|. }
    It is not certain that Eliot correctly employed or himself understood the various terms employed to express the relationship between male and female offspring of the same parents or parent. In the Gospel of St John, published with the Psalter (1709), the terms brother and sister are rendered as follows:
    \xv wematoh
    \xe his brother
    \so Jn.11.41
    (so Eliot)
    \xv wetahtuoh
    \xe her brother
    \so Jn.11.2
    (|wunnohtónukqussoh|    Eliot)
    \xv wetahtuoh
    \xe his sisters
    \so Jn.11.3
    (|weesumisoh|    Eliot)
    \xv wetahtu
    \xe the sister of (him)
    \so Jn.11.39
    (so Eliot)
    \xv wetukishquoh
    \xe her sister
    \so Jn.11.1; 28.5
    (|weetuksquoh|, |weetáhtu|    Eliot)
    So, when the speaker is a female, |netaht| `my brother'
    (|nohtónukqus|; |netukkusq| `my sister'    Eliot)    Jn.11.21; Lk.10.40

\lx wehkomâonk
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 188
\ps vbl.n.
\ge `(a) calling'
\so C.182,184


\lx wehkomónat
\va weék-
\va wék-
\va weekomau
\va wehkomau
\va wekomau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 188
\ps v.t. an. / TA, oral final
\ge `to call to, to call', +`to call unto sb'
\so Mt.9.13
    \xv Neit Pharaoh weekomau Abramoh,...
    \xe And Pharaoh called Abram,..'    Gen.12.18  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wutangelumoh Jehovah ∞wehkomuh wutch kesukqut...
    \xe And the angel of the LORD called unto him out of heaven,...'    Gen.22.11  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah an∞team∞ kah wekomon Jakob ...
    \xe ...: and she sent and called Jacob ...
    \so Gen.27.42
    \ng X->3 subordinative
    \nt +
    |wehkomau| |weékomau| `he called (him or them)'    Ex.24.16; 1 Sam.13.17
    \xv k∞wehkomunup
    \xe I called thee
    \so Num.24.10
    \xv k∞wehkomunumwop
    \xe I have called you
    \so Prov.1.24
    \xv k∞wehkomeh
    \xe thou didst call me
    \so 1 Sam.3.5,8
    \xv ∞wekkomuh
    \xe he called her
    \so 2 K.4.36
    \xv ∞wékomuh nahhog
    \xe he called them to him
    \so Acts 20.1

    |wehkomont| (part.) `calling'    Is.41.2
    \xv Onk pish n nih Pharoh wekoukqueôg,...
    \xe And it shall come to pass when Pharaoh shall call you,...
    \so Gen.46.33
    \ng 3->2p subjunctive
    \nt +

    \xv monchish wehkom kahsuk
    \xe go call thy husband
    \so Jn.4.16

    \se !|wehquetu|, !|wehquttu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, reciprocal
    \nt Remark: On the formation, compare B.1962, 160, 303: "TA stems ending in |-m| form the reciprocal by adding AI |-ti| without connective". The variation in stem shape appears to bear on a point raised by Goddard (1981, 34: 71). One of the currently known attestations is clearly reciprocal (Lk.7.32), a second is closer to Bloomfield's "several acting in concert", though it is more like a causative to an intransitive of such a sense (Acts 5.21), and the third is used in a passive sense (Josh.8.16). The use of a reciprocal in a passive sense, while not unexpected, is not clearly documented as yet--G&B. state (no. 15, 580), unfortunately with only slight exemplification, that the reciprocal final "makes reciprocals from TA stems; especially with indefinite subjects and in further derivation reciprocal stems are used with a passive meaning", but that does not apply to Josh.8.16, which would presumably show |-tuun| with an indefinite subject.
\ge `to be called; call one another'
\so Josh.8.16; Lk.7.32; Acts 5.21
    \xv Kah wame missinninnuog neg apitcheg Ai moae wehquttuog wunn∞suttahwhonaóont:...
    \xe And all the people that were in Ai were called together to pursue after them:...
    \so Josh.8.16
    \xv Ogqunneunkqussuog mukkiesit, aphettit adt kodtauwompasimuk, wehquetehettit, kah an∞wahettit,...
    \xe They are like unto children sitting in the market place, and calling one to another, and saying,...
    \so Lk.7.32
    \xv ... kah wehquttuog wame ken∞nutteúog, kah wame negonne nananuacheg Israel,...
    \xe ..., and [they] called the council together, and all the senate of the children of Israel,...
    \so Acts 5.21
\cf wehquetumónat

[Narragansett [xnt] |Wécum, naus| `Call fetch.'    R.W.35.√
    Algonquian [alg] |Wikomasimwe| `appeler un chien, en sifflant, siffler un chien', to |WIKO-| `racine qui exprime l'idée de tirer, d'attirer, d'amener, (au propre et au figuré)', |Wikom| `invite-le au repas'    Cq.438ab
    \nt +
Cree |WIKKOMEW| `il l'invite à manger au festin.'    Lac.D.650a.
Fx. |wí`ku-| `give invitations, especially to religious ceremonies (with |-wä-| when intransitive'; |wi∙hkome∙wa| `he invites him to eat'    Mch.St.657a; Fx.L.182.
M.P. |wihqimal| TA `he calls him to him'; |wiihkwiimal| `er ruft ihn'    LeS.105b; Sz.249.
Miami |wiihkam-| TA `summon him, call him'    B&C.131.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |Wegoomk'| `To call'    R.48b.
Shawnee [sjw] |wi?ko-| `CALLING', |niwi?koma, niwi?kota| `I called him, it'    D.-V.417.
WAbn. |wikwimô| TA `call him hither'    D.1.496.]

\et H.3930-3934 *wi∙hkwi- `invite', G.1981, 34, 71 *wi∙hkwem-, *wi∙hkom- TA

\lx wehqsheau

    \nt +
\ge `it reaches to, ends at'; + conjunct form as `goings out'

    \so Josh.19.11√

\lx wehquetumónat
\va wehquetumauau
\va weequetumauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 189
\ps v.t. / TA(+O), dative final
\ge `to call upon, to ask for (an. and inan.)', +`ask sth of sb, to pray sb', with content in direct speech
    \xv k∞weequetumoush
    \xe I pray thee
    \so Gen.12.13,13.8,38.25
    \ng 1->2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... Kusseh yeuyeu nussantimomog quinnuppegk k∞wehquetumauunumw∞ weekit kuttinninnumw∞,...
    \xe ..., Behold now, my lords, turn in, I pray you, into your servant's house,...
    \so Gen.19.2
    \ng 1->2p(+0) indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah yeuyeu k∞wehquetúmauúnumun,....
    \xe ...: now therefore, we pray thee,...
    \so Gen.47.4
    \ng 1p->2+0 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv k∞wéquetummauunup
    \xe I have called on thee
    \so Ps.17.6
    \xv k∞wehquetumunk (-uk) keteaonk
    \xe he asked life of thee
    \so Ps.21.4
    \ng 3->2+0 absolute
    \xv n∞wehquetumunk
    \xe he shall call upon me
    \so (i.e. for help)    Ps.91.15
    \ng 3->1 absolute
    (|k∞wequetummâush| `I beseech you'    C.182)

    \xv ..., kah matta woh nukkepuhteam yeu otan, ne wehquetumaean.
    \xe ..., that I will not overthrow this city, for the which thou hast spoken.
    \so Gen.19.21; (E0) "which thou hast requested for."
    \ng 2->1+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ... kuppéantamoonk ne wehquetumauadt.
    \xe ... thy petition that thou hast asked of him.
    \so 1 Sam.1.17√
    \ng 2->1+_0_ participle
    \xv ut wame ne waj wehquetumunkquean
    \xe in all that they call for unto thee.
    \so 1 K.8.52√
    \ng 3(p)->2+_0_ participle

    \xv wehquetumau
    \xe call thou upon (him)
    \so Jonah 1.6
    \xv wehquetumah
    \xe call thou upon me, ask (it) of me
    \so 2 Chr.1.7; Ps.2.8; 50.15
\cf nat∞tomau
\ge he questions (him)
\cf wehkomónat
\cf wequtteamunát

\lx wehquetumunát
\va wehquetum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 189
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\ge `to ask for, to call for or upon', inan.obj.; +`to call sth; to call to sth'
    \xv ... kah wehquetum ∞wesuonk Jehovah.
    \xe ..., and [he] called upon the name of the Lord.
    \so Gen.12.8
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Masugkenuk Manit Jehovah wussinneah, kah weequetum muttaok waj pashpishont, onk yeu pajeh wayont.
    \xe The mighty God, even the Lord hath spoken, and called the earth from the rising of the sun, unto the going down thereof.
    \so Ps.50.1; (M): |wehquttumup|
    \nt +
    \xv Wutch wohqut weehquetum kesukquash, kah ohke, onk woh wussumau ummissinninnumoh.

    \xe He asked water,...

    \xe I call upon, ask for
    \so Deut.4.26
    \xv n∞wehquetumun
    \xe I called on (his name)
    \so Ps.116.4
    \xv ..., k∞wehquetum ne siohkok,...
    \xe Thou hast asked a hard thing
    \so 2 K.2.10√

\lx wekinasq
\va weekinashq
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 189
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a reed'
\so Is.42.3
\ge `(sugar) cane'
\so Is.43.24
    pl. |+uash| `reeds'    Is.19.6
\cf mishashq
\dv Perhaps from |wék| and |ashq| (|méoskeht|) `house grass', with which the roofs of the wigwams were filled in or covered.
    "Their houses are very little and homely, being made with small poles pricked into the ground and so bended and fastened at the tops, and on the sides they are matted with boughs and covered on the roof with sedge and old mats." -- Higginson's N.E. Plantation, ch. 12.
    "The meaner sort of wigwams are covered with mats they make of a kind of bulrush." -- Gookin, 1 Mass. Hist. Coll. 1.149.

[Narragansett [xnt] |wékinash| `reed'; pl. |+quash|    R.W.98/r.96]√

\lx wekuhkauónat
\va wekuhkônat
\va weekikauau
\va wekuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 190
\ps v.t. an. / TA+O, dative final, to |weekitteau|, |weekuhteau|, AI, T.185a.
\ge `to build a house for (another person, etc.)', +`to build sb a house'
\so 2 Chr.2.3,6.7; +Gen.33.17; Ex.1.21
    |Kah Jakob au Sukkoth, kah wekitteau, kah wekikauau wunnetasumoh,...|
`And Jacob journeyed to Succoth, and built him a house, and made booths for
his cattle:...' Gen.33.17  { 3 indicative to |wekitteau|; 3->3' absolute }
    |Onk nnih newutche midwifesog qusháog Goduh, ∞wekikaúuh.| `And it came
to pass, because the midwives feared God, that he made them houses.'
Ex.1.21  { 3->3' objective }
    \xv k∞wekekauununnanonut
    \xe [we] to build thee a house
    \so 1 Chr.29.16
    \ng 1p->2 t-subordinative
    \xv ..., kah wekikauau wunnetasumoh,...
    \xe ..., and [he] made booths for his cattle:...'    Gen.33.17  { 3->3(
    \so ) absolute }
    \xv Noh pish n∞wekekunk ut n∞wesuonganit,...
    \xe He shall build a house for my name;...
    \so 1.Chr.22.10√
    \ng 3->1 indicative

    \xv ..., kah wekuhkau Jehovah kum-Manitt∞m,...
    \xe ..., and build the house of the Lord thy God,...
    \so 1.Chr.22.11√
    \ng 2->3 imperative

    \xv wekuhkon
    \xe he went on building
    \so Neh.4.18
    \ng distinct stem

\lx wenauwetu
\va wunne-wétu
\va weenauwet-
\va weenaeék-
\va wenauék-
\ve ?
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 190
\ps adj. an. / AI, palatalized velar, i-stem
\ge `(is or was) rich', +`to have wealth'
\so 2 Sam.12.1
    \xv Onk Abram ahche weenauweeteup puppinashimwoh, Silver kah Gold.
    \xe And Abram was very rich in cattle, in silver, and in gold.
    \so Gen.13.2
    \ng 3 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    pl. +|og|    Ruth 3.10
    \xv Noh neyane wadchanumauont wuhhogkuh nompakou, kah matta wenauéku nogqueu en Godut.
    \xe So is he that layeth up treasure for himself, and is not rich toward God.
    \so Lk.12.21
    \nt +
    \xv ..., k∞wahteaóunnan yeu nashpe kutanakausuwonganun k∞che weenaeékinnean.
    \xe ..., ye know that by this craft we have our wealth.
    \so Acts 19.25
    \ng 12 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche kussim n∞weenauweet,...
    \xe Because thou sayest, I am rich,...
    \so Rev.3.17
    \ng palatal by levelling
    \nt +
    (|wunne wétu| `a good house'    C.170)

    \xv Ahque wabesish, howan weenauweekit:...
    \xe Be not thou afraid when one is made rich,...
    \so Ps.49.16
    \ng 3 conjunct
    \nt +

    \xv Mechumuhkonuk nag wenauwékitcheg yeuut muttaohket,...
    \xe Charge them that are rich in this world,...
    \so 1 Tim.6.17
    \nt +

    \se wenauwetuen
    \va -in
    \ps (indef. and general) / NA
    \ge `any rich man'
    \so Prov.28.11
    "A |winnaytue|, that is a rich man, or a man of estimation, next in degree to a sachem or sagamore." -- Morton's N.E. Canaan, ch. 19.

    \se !|weenaikeheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to make sb rich'
    \so Gen.14.23
    \xv ..., ishkont woh kussim n∞weenaìkeh Abram,
    \xe ..., I have made Abram rich:
    \so Gen.14.23
    \ng 1->3 absolute

    \xv Ahque wapissish howan wenaekehhit,...
    \xe Be not thou afraid when one is made rich,...
    \so Ps.49.16(M)
    \ng X->3 conjunct

\cf wunneetu+

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |n8ira8ighi, ... 3. 8ir| `Je suis riche'    443/523a.
    \nt +
    Algonquian [alg] |WIN| `moelle'    Cq.439b.
    \nt ?
Cree |weyotisiw,ok| `il est riche, il abonde, fécond'; |Wäyo'tisew| `He is rich, he is affluent, he abounds in it', |Wäyo'tun| `It is abundant, it abounds'    Lac.D.648b; Frs.509b.
Delaware [del] |Wilawi| `rich, valuable, precious'; |wiilawii-| `fancy'    B&A.158; O'M.340b-341a.

Nask. |waayuutisiiw| AI `rich'    McK&J.1.416b.

\lx weogkeheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 190
    \nt +
\ps TA, ?causative final
\twn !|weogkehteau|, TI2
\ge `to have to do with, meddle with sb', negated `to refrain from sb' [cf. OED s.v. "meddle": "+4. {intr}. for {refl}. To mix or join in company; to mingle, associate with. {Obs}."]
\so Deut.2.19; Acts 5.38; Heb.4.13

    \xv ..., ut wuskesuqkut, nok weogkeheogut.
    \xe ... unto the eyes of him with whom we have to do.
    \so Heb.4.13
    \ng 12->_3_ participle

    \xv ... wunnaumonuh Ammon, ahque unkquanumwehuk, asuh weogkeheonteog,...
    \xe ... the children of Ammon, distress them not, nor meddle with them:...
    \so Deut.2.19
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative
    \xv ..., Weogkehheaunteog kah ahqhuk yeug wosketompaog,...
    \xe ..., Refrain from these men, and let them alone:...
    \so Acts 5.38
    \ng 2p->3(p)


\lx weogkehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 190
    \nt +
\ps TI2
\twn !|weogkeheau|, TA
\ge `to attend upon sth, be a busybody (in sth), to handle (sth)'
\so Rom.13.16; 1 Pet.4.15; C.18,92
    \xv ...; newutche noh wuttinnúmoh GOD, nagwutteae weogkehteauun yeu nân.
    \xe ...: for they are God's ministers, attending continually upon this very thing.
    \so Rom.13.16
    \ng X->0 t-subordinative
    \xv Weogkehtauu@nat.
    \xe Handled
    \so C.92/220
    \ng X(->00 t-subordinative

    \xv ..., asuh neyane weogkehteunkig onkatogig wuttinniyeuongan∞oash.
    \xe ..., or as a busybody in other men's matters.
    \so 1 Pet.4.15
    \ng ?_3p_->0 participle
    \xv Weogkehteünkik onkatoh unniyeüonk.
    \xe A busybody
    \so C.18/166


\lx weogkunutchontam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 190
    \nt +
\ps TI1a-O, |-nutch-| `hand' + |-ontam| directive final ?
\ge `to handle'
\so Ps.115.7(M)
    \xv Wunnitchegannuog, qut matta weogkunutchontamooog;...
    \xe They have hands, but they handle not:...
    \so Ps.115.7(M)
    \ng 3p negative indicative


\lx weogquttum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 190
    \nt +
\ps TI1b
\twn |weadtimau| TA
\ge `to speak of, make mention of, tell of; to murmur, rumour; to dispute (w. others), hold a council or consultation, reason (together), take counsel'
\nt The stem is broad in its meaning, speech about a topic being the central element. Prominent secondary notions are that the talk is reciprocal or collective, and that it is of an extended or intense kind. It cannot be exemplified adequately at present. Cotton's examples (including stems in |-ht-| and |-in-|) show more of the range, with glosses like `busybody', `to handle', `to treat' (i.e. "negotiate"). (M) often substitutes this verb for a variety of other verbs used by Eliot, typically in translation of "to speak of sth'.
\so Ps.(E&M).77.12,105.2,119.27,145.5; Mt.12.14; Mk.2.6,8.16,13.7,15.1; Lk.21.5; Jn.2.21(M),7.32(E),11.13(M); Phil.2.14; Heb.11.22,11.32
\nt G&B 738 "to consider, discuss"
    |Kah teanuk Jesus wahteunk ut wunnashaonganit, ne wuttine weogquttumuneau wuttinnómiyeum∞wout, nah wutinuh, tohwutch yeush weogquttumwog ut kuttahh∞wóut?|`And immediately when Jesus perceived in his spirit that they so reasoned within themselves, he said unto them, Why reason ye these things in your hearts?'    Mk.2.8

    \xv Newutche noh nagum papaume yeush weogquttumuk, wutchayeu onkatuk chippann∞wonk,...
    \xe For he of whom these things are spoken pertaineth to another tribe,...
    \so Heb.7.13
    \ng presumably X-subj. conjunct; syntax unclear to me

    \se weogquttam∞m∞
    \va weogquttum∞m∞
    \ps TI1a,b, inanimate subject
    \ge `to speak of sth'
    \so Ps.37.30(E&M),119.72(M)
    \xv Nenan pish weogquttumoomoo kuttinnoowaonk;...
    \xe My tongue shall speak of thy word:...
    \so Ps.119.72(M)  { 0->0 indicative }; (E) |yeum∞|

    \se weogqutausu
    \ps AI
    \ge `to be spoken of'
    \so Mk.14.9
    \xv ..., yeu wonk noh áseit pish weogqutausu, wutche mehquánumáonk nagum.
    \xe ..., this also that she hath done shall be spoken of for a memorial of her.
    \so Mk.14.9

    \xe you killed him
    \xv wèpe kukkemineantín
    \xe you are the murderer
    \xv wèpe cukkúmmoot
    \xe you have stole

    |cuppittakûnnamun wèpe wáme| (he commands that) `all men now repent'    118
    (`only'    Mass.Ps., Ps.2.12)

\lx wesháganash
\va wishagkinish
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 191
\ps n.pl. / NI
\ge `hairs on the body or limbs of man or animals'
\so Ex.35.23; Is.7.20; Mk.1.6; Mt.3.4
    (cf. |meesunk|)

    \se ∞weshaginnúe
    \ps Adj.
    \ge `hairy'
    \so 2 K.1.8
    pl. |weshakinnú∞ash|    Gen.27.23

    \se ∞weshaganu
    \ps V.subst. / AI, verb of possession
    \ge `he was hairy'
    \so Gen.27.11

    (|ukkeeshäe moskq| `a hairy bear'    C.171;
    \dv |kushki| `rough'?)
\nt [Mr Pickering in index to El.Gr. gives "|weshagan| `hair of animals'," The meaning can not be thus restricted, as will be seen from the above examples. It is compounded from |--| and |hog| `body', or |hogk∞| `it clothes, covers the body', as |weeshitt∞n| from |t∞n| `mouth'.]
\cf wishshuwussuonk
\et S., no. 22, 315-316, H.1956-1957 *mi∙?l- `hair', presumably with the indefinite possessor prefix; *-kan- as final? PA alternation with *mi∙?Θ- noted at G.1982.22, fn.24, whose palatalized forms, H.1958-1960, yield Mass. |meesunk|.

\lx wessukeh

\so Trumbull 191
\cf wasukeh


\lx wesuonganuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 191
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Most currently known examples, including the one conjunct form (Rom.15.20), show a prefixed |∞-|. Some of these are objective forms, but this may nevertheless reflect the behavior of dependent nouns in denominal verbs.
\ps TA
\dv denominal "verb of making" in |-uhk-| (G&B. no. 10, p.579, unpalatalized before the following vowel) + |-aw-| TA, "dative", giving an ornative sense. This use of the final seems unusual, but see B.1962, 16.181, 364 and Cq.1891, 223, 86 and 257, 94. (The alternative, to treat this as an instance of the complex final |-uhk-aw-|, with the "by foot or body movement" suffix, may go beyond the limits of this quite elastic category, and does not account for the TI counterpart any better.)
\ge `to give sb a name, name sb'
\so Gen.?Hd.2.14(E(0)); Gen.2.20; Ruth 4.17; (Mk.3.17); Rom.15.20; Phil.2.9; C.66/202,94/221
    \xv Onk Adam ∞wesuonganuhkauau wame netasu,...
    \xe And Adam gave names to all cattle,...
    \so Gen.2.20
    \ng 3->3(p)+0 absolute
    \xv Wesuonkanehkönat.
    \xe To name,
    \so C.66/202

    \xv ...: matta uttoh Christ adt ∞wesuonganuhkauut ...
    \xe ..., not where Christ was named,...
    \so Rom.15.20
    \ng presumably in the sense: "not where he had had his name mentioned, had been talked of"}  { X->3+_loc_ participle

\nt Remark: |Wesuonkanuhkonittinneat| `To be named' C.66/202, { X->3 }, is perhaps an alternative formation with the TA applicative final? Or possibly a misspelling of |-on(t)tinn-|?

    \se wesuonganuhkontam
    \ps TI1a
    \dv If this verb is parallel in structure to the TA verb, denominal via a verb of making, the ultimate final ought to be a TI twin to TA |-aw-| "dative". Bloomfield appears to deny the existence of any such form for Menominee (1962, 16.1, pp.329-330; 16.120, pp.351-352). In fact, it looks like the familiar TI applicative in |-ont-|, which is the transitivizing final that Bloomfield links with the verbs of making (1962, 16.69, pp.342-343). The TI verb is not therefore not exactly parallel to the TA, but fits a known type.
    \ge `to call, name sth'
    \so Rom.4.17; C.66/202
    \xv ..., GOD neh pâmontamwâheunt nupp∞óh: kah wesuonganukóntam nish matta ohtán∞gish, onatuh ne óhtag.
    \xe ..., even God, who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were:
    \so Rom.4.17
    \xv N∞wesuonkanehköntam, up.
    \xe I name, or did,
    \so C.66/202


\lx wésuonk
\va ∞we-
\va wesuong-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 191
\ps n. / NI
    \nt Remark: Most instances have the possessive prefix, and one might expect this to be a dependent noun. The instances without the possessive tend to occur in phrases such as "in this name", and may perhaps not have been natural.
    \nt +
\ge `a name'
\so Gen.11.4
    \xv n∞wésuonk
    \xe my name
    \so Is.42.8
    \xv k∞wesuonk
    \xe thy name
    \so Gen.12.2
    \xv Kah yeush ∞wesuongash wunnaumonuh Ishmael nashpeu ∞wesuongan∞∞ash,...
    \xe And these are the names of the sons of Ishmael, by their names,...
    \so Gen.25.13
    \ng 3p possessive plural, "short" and "long" stems
    \nt +
    (= Narr. |wésuonck|    R.W.29)
\dv |wussin| (?).
\cf ussowessu

    { See under |wesuonganuhkauau|. }

\lx weetappemau
\va wetapemau
\va weechappemau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 191
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Entry subsumes Trumbull's entry *|wetapímmin| (Narr.). The form in |weech-| is currently only attested in Gen.8.17(E0&1).
\ps TA, consociative final
\twn |weechahtom| TI1a
\ge `to be, sit down among, to sit with sb'
\so Gen.8.17; Mt.8.11,9.10; Mk.2.15; Lk.7.49,22.21,22.55; Acts 8.31,26.30; Gal.1.18; Rev.3.21
    \xv ..., Peter ∞weetappemo
    \xe ..., Peter sat down among them.'    Lk.22.55  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    \xv ... nish noh oaas uppomantamun weetappemukquéaneg,...
    \xe ... every living thing that {is} with thee,...
    \so Gen.8.17(E2)
    \ng _3p_->2 participle; (E0&1) have |weech-|.

    \xv Wetapwâuwwas.
    \xe Sit and talke with us
    \so R.W.57
    \ng distinct stem
    (|Taúpowaw.| `A wise speaker.'    R.W.57√)

\lx wétu
\va weetu
\va weku
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 191
    \nt Remark: The relationship between the various forms remains to be sorted out.
    \nt +
\ps n. / NI, ?dependent (i.e. |-etu(om)|)
\ge `a house', +`habitation, tent'
\nt G&B.617, s.v. |(n)ek|, 736, s.v. |Wechu|
\so El.Gr.11
    \xv witeo
    \xe an ordinarie house
    \so Winslow 1624.27.27
    \nt +
    \xv weetu
    \xe the tent
    \so Ps.78.60; (M) |wuttohkeakamuk|
    \xv weekuwóash
    \xe tents
    \so Gen.13.5
    \nt +
    |Wechu| NI `house'    Ntv.Wr.46:9,13,27
    \nt +

    |neek| (|nék|) `my house'
    \xv keek
    \xe thy house
    \xv week
    \xe his house
    \xv neekun
    \xe our house
    \xv keekou
    \xe your house
    \xv weekou
    \xe their house
    pl. |wetuomash| `houses'    Lev.25.31
    \xv wekuomash
    \xe habitations
    \so Gen.49.5
    \nt +
    \xv kek∞oash
    \xe your houses
    \so Neh.4.14√
    \xv nekinonash
    \xe our ... houses
    \so Neh.5.3√
    \xv nekit
    \xe in my house
    \so { 1 possessor locative }
    "|Weekuwout| {or} |wekuwomut| `in his house. {Hence we corrupt this word} Wigwam."    El.Gr.11/258

    \se |wetu|, |weetu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, denominal, of predicative form (with possessive-like sense, cf. B.1962, 15.5, 275?)
    \ge `to dwell, to pitch one's tent, to tent'
    \so Gen.13.12,29.30; Is.40.22
    \xv ..., kah weeteup kishke Sodom.
    \xe ..., and pitched his tent toward Sodome.
    \so Gen.13.12
    \ng 3 preterite indicative; (E0) "tented"

    \xv ..., kah wutogque sepagunumunash weetu ne weetimuk.
    \xe ..., and spreadeth them out as a tent to dwell in
    \so Is.40.22
    \ng X->_0_ participle

[Narragansett [xnt] |Wêtu| `An House', |Wetuômuck nóteshem| `I came from the house.'; |Nékick| `To my house.'; |Kékick| `To your house.'; |Wetuômuck| `At home.'    R.W.3;4;31.
Quiripi [qyp] |wejo|    Pier.21.
Cree |Wéegee| ({g} hard) `{a tent or dwelling}.', |Wéegu| (neut.) `he {dwells or tents}.'    Howse 22√.]

\et G.1981, 8, 58; 28, 66 *wi∙kiwa∙Hmi, -ali NI; also ib. 37, 74 |keekou| `your house' < *ki∙kewa∙wi NI, relationship not specified; H.3944 and A.2225, H.3939 *wi∙ki NI `tent, home, place'; H.3943 *wi∙kiwa AI `to dwell'.

\lx wehwepapiNau
\va wewe-
\va weehwee-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\so Gen.39.20
    \xv ...kah ∞weehweepapunoh ut anaquabhettit.
    \xe ..., and [he] bound him before their eyes.'    Gen.42.24  { 3->3
    \so objective }

    \xe ..., a place where the king's prisoners were bound:...

    \xe ..., the place where Joseph was bound.

    \xe If ye be true men, let one of your brethren be bound in the house of your prison:...
    \so Gen.42.19


\lx weyaus
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
\ps n. / NI, NA, ?dependent, |w-| taken variably as 3 possessor
    \nt Remark: There is variation in treatment: the stem |-eyaus| is found (with |n-|, |k-|, |m-|, and presumably |w-|), acting as a dependent noun (in reference to an inalienable possession), without the possessive theme suffix; |weyaus| is often used as a stem that does not take the possessive theme suffix; but it is also used as a stem that does take the suffix |-um-|, perhaps only in reference to meat (e.g. Gen.25.28, 27.25 `his venison'). No pattern has yet been noted. The presence of the locative suffix does not appear to have an effect. Mayhew uses the stem |weyaus| in all but a couple of cases. There are a couple of animate (obviative) examples involving metonymic extension. (For an example of variability here, see Log.Pr.77-78/92-93 on Rom.8.1.)
    \nt +
\ge `(his) flesh', +`carcass' (perhaps unique?)
\so Is.22.13
    \xv ..., kah wonk yeânunumun weyaus wonk nompe.
    \xe ..., and closed up the flesh instead thereof.
    \so Gen.2.21
    \nt +
    \xv Kah puppinshasog paahettit weyausut,...
    \xe And when the fowls came down vpon the carcasses,...
    \so Gen.15.11
    \nt +
    \xv k∞weyaus∞
    \xe your flesh
    \so Gen.17.11
    \ng 2 plural possessor
    \nt +
    \xv keyausut
    \xe in your[!] flesh
    \so Gen.17.13
    \ng 2 possessor locative
    \nt +
    \xv keyaus∞
    \xe your flesh
    \so Lev.19.28, Rom.6.19
    \ng 2 plural possessor
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish meech keyaus onatuh n∞tau,...
    \xe ..., and [it] shall eat your[!] flesh as it were fire. ...
    \so Jas.5.3
    \nt +
    \xv k∞weyaus
    \xe thy flesh
    \so Prov.5.11
    \xv neyausut
    \xe in my flesh
    \so Rom.7.18
    \nt +
    \xv ut nupp∞e neyausinnonut
    \xe in our mortal flesh
    \so 2 Cor.4.11; similarly Eph.2.3
    \nt +
    \xv ∞weyausum
    \xe his venison
    \so Gen.25.28
    \nt +
    `venison'    Gen.27.3,7

    \xv kesittáe weyaus
    \xe sodden flesh
    \so 1 Sam.2.15
    \xv askeyaus
    \xe raw flesh

    \xv N noh assamau wame weyausoh:...
    \xe Who giveth food to all flesh:...
    \so Ps.136.25; (M): |meauussoh|  { 3 possessor obviative; X possessor obviative }nashauanit kodnushau weyausoh,.v
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche weyaus kodnushau Nashauanitto, kah nashauanit kodnushau weyausoh,...
    \xe For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh:...
    \so Gal.5.17
    \nt +

    (|meyauussue| `of the flesh'    Mass.Ps., Jn.1.15.)

    \se |weyaus∞|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, II, predicative, i-stem
    \ge `to be carnal, flesh, natural'
    \so Gen.2.24,6.3; Ps.78.39; Rom.7.5,14,?8.5; 1 Cor.3.1,3,4,6.16,?10.18,15.46
    pl. |Newutche mehquantamup nag webe weyausog:...| `For he remembred that they were but flesh;..'    Ps.78.39√  { 3p predicative; clearer in (M): |weyausuooog| }
    \xv ..., qut n∞weyausu, newutche magun nuhhog agwu matcheseonganit.
    \xe ...: but I am carnal, sold under sin.
    \so Rom.7.14
    \ng 1 indicative

    \xv ..., n∞nanum kukken∞nunnaôont neyane wunnashauanitt∞mitcheg, qut neyane weyausuutcheg,...
    \xe ... I,..., could not speak unto you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal,...
    \so 1 Cor.3.1
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \xv ..., qut ne weyauseyeu∞k,...
    \xe ..., but that which is natural,..
    \so 1 Cor.15.46
    \ng _0_ participle, possibly distinct stem

\cf ôâas
\ge an animal

[Delaware [del] |o i@oos| `meat, flesh'    Zeisb.
    Lp.A |8iaux| `viande'    D.15+.]
    \nt +

\et A.2264, H.4062 *wi∙yawehsi NI `meat', diminutive, to A.2265, H.4063 *wi∙yawi NI `his body'

\lx wodtum
\va wodtam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
    \nt +
\ps TI1b?
\dv unclear, apparently lacking TI final, unless that is |-dt-| with initial |wo-|; same applies to the TA+O derivative.
\ge `to interpret (sth?) (so)'
\so Gen.41.12
    \xv ..., kah n∞wodtumungqunan nuttinnukquom∞onganun, naneswe neaunag wutinnukquom∞onk wuttin wódtumun.
    \xe ..., and he interpreted to us our dreams; to each man according to his dream he did interpret.
    \so Gen.41.12
    \ng subordinative, 3->0-pro+adv
    \xv ..., , kah matta howan ∞wodtum∞un, kah nunn∞tam unnehtamóonk papaume ken, unnukquom∞onk n∞tog, woh ∞wodtamun.
    \xe ..., and there is none that can interpret it: and I have heard say of thee, that thou canst understand a dream to interpret it.
    \so Gen.41.15
    \ng 3->0-pro

    \se wodtumauau
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to interpret sth (un)to sb, declare sth to sb'
    \so Gen.41.8,12,13,15,24
    \xv ...: kah Pharoh wuttinuh nahog wuttinnukquom∞onk, qut matta howan ∞wodtumauoun Pharohoh.
    \xe ...: and Pharaoh told them his dream; but there was none that could interpret them unto Pharaoh.'    Gen.41.8  { 3->3
    \so +0 objective }
    \xv .... qut matta howan n∞wodtumunk∞unash.
    \xe ...; but there was none that could declare it to me.
    \so Gen.41.24
    \ng negative 3->1+0p objective

    \xv Onk nnih nean wodtumungqueog,...
    \xe And it came to pass, as he interpreted to us,...
    \so Gen.41.13
    \ng 3->1p+_0_

\lx wogkoueu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
    \nt +
\ps AI
\ge `to make a tumult, for there to be an uproar'
\so Ps.83.2; Mt.27.24; Mk.14.2
    \xv ..., qut teaoggu wogkoueog,...
    \xe .... but that rather a tumult was made,...
    \so Mt.27.24
    \ng 3p indicative
    \xv ... ishkont wogkoueog missinninnuog.
    \xe ..., lest there be an uproar of the people.
    \so Mk.14.2
    \ng 3p indicative

    \se wogkoueonk
    \va -eongan
    \ps n. / NI, deverbal noun
    \ge `a stir, a tumult, commotion'
    \so Hos.10.14; Rom.7.5

    \se !|wogkoueonganu|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge "for there to be an uproar"
    \so Acts 20.1

    \xv KAH mahche wogkoueongan∞gk,...
    \xe And after the uproar was ceased,...
    \so Acts 20.1
    \ng 0->_adv_ conjunct


\lx wogkouuhtonkquissu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
    \nt +
\ps AI, final |-uhtonkqu-si-|
\ge `to make a tumult'
\so Ps.83.2(M)
    \xv ..., kummatwomog wogkouuhtunkquissuog:...
    \xe ..., thine enemies make a tumult:...
    \so Ps.83.2(M)
    \ng 3p indicative


\lx wogkouunumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
\ps v.t. / TI1b
\twn |wogkauunonat|
\ge `to stir up, to set in motion, to excite' (inan. obj.)
    \xv n∞wogkouunum
    \xe I stir up (your hearts)
    \so 2 Pet.3.1

    \xv wogkouunish
    \xe stir up (thy strength)

    pass. |otan wogkouwém∞| `the city was moved'    Acts 21.28 { distinct stem }

    \xv nippe wogkouém∞uk
    \xe when the water is troubled, stirred
    \so Jn.5.7


\lx woh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
\ps conj. "{Of possibility}" / PreV (or perhaps pre-PreV?)
\ge `{May} or {Can}.'
    \nt Remark: The uses of this modal particle require study; it includes permissive and (with negation least) strong deontic senses expressed by "shall not". (E0) contains a body of examples of |pish| uniformly emended to |woh| in (E1). There appears to be some association with rhetorical questions.
    \nt +
\so El.Gr.22/269
    "There is another {Mode of the Verb} in reason of speech and in some other Languages, {viz.} The {Potential}, which doth render the action in {a possibility to be.} But this Language hath not such a {Mode}, but that {notion} is expressed by a word signifying ({may}) to the {Indicative Mode}. The usual word with us is ({woh}) {may} or {can}."    (El.Gr.20/266)
    \xv woh kenusheh
    \xe intendest thou to kill me?
    \so Ex.2.14
    \xv uttoh woh yeush en nnih
    \xe how can these things be?
    \so Jn.3.9
    \xv matta woh wunnamp∞hamauoh
    \xe he can not answer him
    \so Job 9.3

    \xv Woh wussioggehukqun Jehovah?...
    \xe Is any thing too hard for the LORD?...
    \so Gen.18.14
    \nt +

\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 192
\cf hogki


\lx wôhkôeu
\va wohkóe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
\ps adv. and adj.
\ge `at the side or sides, on the sides of, on the ends of'
    \xv ... wutch waénu wohkóeu Egypt onk yeaen ongkoue.
    \xe ..., from one end of the borders of Egypt even to the other end thereof.
    \so Gen.47.21
    \nt +
    \xv woskeche kah wôhkôeu waéénu
    \xe on "the top thereof and the sides thereof, round about"
    \so Ex.30.3
    \xv neese wohkóe
    \xe on the two sides thereof
    \so Ex.37.27
    \xv ut wohkôeu
    \xe in thy borders
    \so Ps.147.14
    \xv ut auohquaeu
    \xe on the two ends of (the breastplate)
    \so Ex.28.24
    \xv ut uhquaeu
    \xe at the ends
    \so Ex.28.22
    \xv ne an∞hqueu kishkag
    \xe its breadth (from side to side)
    \so Ex.28.16
    \xv ∞quohtogquosh
    \xe the ends (of the chains)
    \so Ex28.25

    \nt Remark: The forms listed under |wahquh/tukquaak|, G&B.729, which "appears to mean `at the end of the river or estuary'", probably have the same initial.
    \nt +

\cf uhquáe

\lx wohkukquoshinát
\va wohkukquoshin
\va wohkuhquohshin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 192
    \nt Remark: There may be a simple i-stem verb (cf. causative?) in addition to the one in |-shin|. The examples in this entry are presumably of the form in |-shin|, the t-subordinative used by T. as headword is not attested in the current corpus.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / II, final |-shin| II.
\ge `to come to end, to be ended', +`to end, be accomplished'
    \xv Uppeantam∞ongash David ..., neit wohkukquohshin.
    \xe The prayers of David ... are ended.
    \so Ps.72.20, (M) |wohkuhquohshinash|    { 0 indicative (erroneous, corrected in (M))
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ∞wadtauatonkqussuongan∞ ne wekontogig wohkukquoshin,...
    \xe ..., the noise of them that rejoice endeth,...
    \so Is.24.8√
    \ng 0 indicative
    |..., ummattompagum wohkukquashin,...`..., that her warfare is accomplished,...'    Is.40.2√  { 0 indicative }
    \xv pish wohkukquoshinash
    \xe (they) shall be ended
    \so Is.60.20
    \xv ..., nepun wohkukquoshin,...
    \xe ..., the summer is ended,...
    \so Jer.8.20(E1)
    \ng 0 indicative ((E2 with erroneous |-k|)
    \xv ..., kah ukketass∞tamoonk matta wohkukquoshinin∞.
    \xe ...; and of his kingdom there shall be no end.
    \so Lk.1.33
    \ng 0 negative indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ...: newutche yeush papaume nen, wohkukquoshinash.
    \xe ...: for the things concerning me have an end.
    \so Lk.22.37
    \ng 0p indicative
    \nt +

    \xv .... onk pish nanawehteauonash na ut wohkukqushik.
    \xe ...; and I shall keep it unto the end.
    \so (of a matter, or in time)    Ps.119.33  { 0->_adv_ conjunct (participle?) }; (M) |en wohkuhkuhquoshik.|
    \xv ..., muttaok matta wohkukquoshinn∞g. Amen.
    \xe ..., world without end. Amen.
    \so Eph.3.21
    \ng _0_ negative participle
    \nt +
    \xv Nen Alpha kah Omega, waj kutchissik kah wohkukquoshik,...
    \xe I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end,...
    \so Rev.22.13
    \ng ?0->_adv_ conjunct, ?"(the time) when/(the place) where it (all) begins"
    \nt +

    \se !|wohkuhquoshin|
    \nt +
    \nt Remark: examples transferred from prior entry
    \ps NI, derived
    \xv en wohkukquoshinit
    \xe to the end, to the utmost, thoroughly
    \so Job 35.36
    \ng locative to NI abstract?
    \xv ... Job woh qutcheheau en wohkukquoshinit,...
    \xe ... that Job may be tried unto the end,...
    \so Job 34.36√
    \ng locative
    \xv no pajeh wohkukquashinit
    \xe unto the end
    \so Rev.2.26
    \ng locative
