\lx wohquoantam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 193
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\ge various and diverse, centred on a degree of anxiety or concern about something; see examples. (
\nt Follow up needed: )
\so Phil.2.30,4.6,10; 2 Pet.2.5
    \xv Qut nummishe wekontam ut Lordut, yeuyeu wonk maumachish k∞wohquanummuongan∞ wonk wunne nekin: yeu wonk k∞wohquoantamunnaóh, qut kukquenahikkumw∞ wunuhkom∞onk.
    \xe But I rejoiced in the Lord greatly, that now at the last your care of me hath flourished again; wherein ye were also careful, but ye lacked opportunity.
    \so Phil.4.10
    \ng 2p->0, objective, "absentative";
    \xv Kah matta wohquoantam∞ nukkônemuttaok, qut wadchanau Noahhoh shwosik adtuhshuit,...
    \xe And [God] spared not the old world, but saved Noah the eighth person,...
    \so 2 Pet.2.5

    \xv Newutche waj wutanakausuonk Christ nahen nupp∞p, matta wohquoantam∞g uppomantamóonk pakodjteauunat, aninnohsuonk en nuhhogkat, ne matta aseóg.
    \xe Because for the work of Christ he was nigh unto death, not regarding his life, to supply your lack of service toward me.
    \so Phil.2.30

    \xv Ahque teag wussaume wohquoantam∞k ...
    \xe Be careful for nothing;...'    Phil.4.6 { i.e. "full of care", `anxious, worried
    \so }

    \se !|wohquoantamauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O
    \ge various and diverse, centred on a failure to provide something to someone e.g. `keep back, withhold sth from sb', the relationship to the headword not yet clear--"to be `careful' with sth with respect to sb"?; see examples.
    \so Gen.23.6,39.9; Ex.22.29
    \xv ...: matta howan neenaw[u]n woh k∞wohquoantamáuun∞mun n∞wenohkéinonash wutche ken,...
    \xe ...; none of us shall withhold from thee his sepulchre,...
    \so Gen.23.6
    \ng 1p->2+0 negative
    \xv ...: kah matta teag n∞ohquontamunk∞h, qut ken, newutch ken ummittamwussoh:...
    \xe ...; neither hath he kept back any thing from me but thee, because thou {art} his wife:...
    \so Gen.39.9
    \ng 3->1+0 negative

    \xv Kukkâkenúmunnumash, kah k∞togkoiyeumash wohquoantamauuhkon mohtommegitcheg kenaumoneunk pish kittinnumah.
    \xe Thou shalt not delay {to offer} the first of thy ripe fruits, and of thy liquors: the firstborn of thy sons shalt thou give unto me.
    \so Ex.22.29
    \ng probably 2->1+0, given the 2->1+0 of the second verb

\lx wohsumunát
\va ∞wohsumunát
\va wôsum-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 193
\ps v.t. / TI1b (often intransitively or without object expressed)
\ge `to shine upon, to give forth bright light'
\so 2 Cor.4.6; Rev.21.23
    \xv ∞wohsumun
    \xe (it) did lighten it
    \so Rev.21.23
    \xv pish k∞wôsum
    \xe thou shalt shine forth
    \so Job 11.17
    \xv pish wôsumwog
    \xe they shall shine
    \so Dan.12.3
    (|n∞wossum| `I shine'    C.208
    \xv nepâz wohsum
    \xe the sun shineth
    \so C.208)

    \xv wôhsish
    \xe shine thou' (`give light')    Is.60.1; +Ps.94.1 `shew thyself
    \xv wequai wôhsum∞kitch
    \xe let not the light shine on it
    \so Job 3.4
\cf sqútta

    \se !|wohsumwehteau|, |-waht-|, |-woht-|
    \nt +
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to make sth to shine'
    \so Ps.104.15(M),119.135(E&M)
    \xv ..., kah pumme wosumwehtauunnat wuskesuk;...
    \xe ..., and oil to make his face to shine:...
    \so Ps.104.15(M)
    \ng 0 t-subordinative

    \xv Kuskesuk wohsumwahtoush ut kittinneumut:...
    \xe Make thy face to shine upon thy servant:...
    \so Ps.119.135; (M) |Wohsumwohtauush|

    \se |wohsumwahteauau|
    \nt +?
    \nt Remark: Uncertain, owing to spelling
    \ps TA+O, dative
    \ge `to make sth shine upon sb'
    \so Ps.31.16

    \xv Kuskesuk wóssumwahteauush kittinnumoh...
    \xe Make thy face to shine upon thy servant:...
    \so Ps.31.16  { ?

[Western Abenaki [abe] |8asák8ré| `lumière'; |8assénemañgan|, |-nar| `chandelle'.
    cf. Men. |wa∙qnenεw, wa∙qnenam| `he throws light on him, it; he lights him, it up', with the manual final    M.L.267.]
    \nt +


\lx wohtamunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 193
\ps v.t. / TI1a
\ge `to understand, to comprehend'
\so Eph.3.18
    \xv numm∞cheke wohtam onk ...
    \xe I have more understanding than ...
    \so Ps.119.100
    (|wohwohtam|    Ps.119.99)
    \xv matta wahteau∞og asuh wohtamwog
    \xe they have not known nor understood
    \so Is.44.18
    \xv ..., K∞wehquetumoush, Assyriae unnont∞wanumau kittinneumog (newutche n∞wohtamunan (-un?)) kah ahque Jewsont∞wánumaiinan,...
    \xe ..., Speak, I pray thee, to thy servants in the Syrian language; for we understand it: and talk not with us in the Jews' language ...'    2 K.18.26√ { (probably) (E1) also; Trumbull
    \so s query reproduced }

    \xv wohtash
    \xe Understand
    \so Deut.9.6
    \nt +
    \xv wohtam∞k
    \xe understand ye
    \so Prov.8.5; +Deut.9.3
    \xv wautaj
    \xe let him understand
    \so Mt.24.15
    = |wahteauutch|    Mk.13.14

    \se wohwohtamunát
    \ps V.i. freq. / TI1a(-O)
    \ge `to possess or exercise the understanding, to understand'
    \so Dan.10.12
    \xv woh k∞wahteomw∞ ... k∞namptiimw∞ ... k∞wohtamumw∞
    \xe ye may know, ... believe me ... (and) understand
    \so Is.43.10


\lx wohtauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 194
    \nt +
\ps TA, aural final
\ge `to understand sb'
\nt G&B.733, s.v. |(noo)watawoun| `we (cannot) understand him'
\so Gen.11.7,42.23; Mk.14.68; Lk.2.50; Jn.8.27,10.6; 1 Cor.14.2
    \xv Hah, n∞kétuh pen∞wehteúttuh unnont∞waonk, onk woh mo wohtauuttéog.
    \xe Go to, let us go down, and there confound their language, that they may not understand one another's speech.
    \so Gen.11.7
    \ng 3p indicative to reciprocal derivative, i.e. "understand one another"
    \xv Kah nag matta wahteauog Joseph ∞wohtauoh, newutche wuttinnont∞wanumauoh keket∞hkanshaenuut.
    \xe And they knew not that Joseph understood them; for he spake unto them by an interpreter.
    \so Gen.42.23
    \xv ..., Matta n∞waheoh, asuh matta k∞wahtauun∞h toh an∞waan;...
    \xe ..., I know not, neither understand I what thou sayest. ...
    \so Mk.14.68
    \ng negative 1->2(+0), proleptic object

[WAbn. |wawtawô| TA `he understands him'    D.1.486.
K. |-ehta(w)-| TA `hear him, understand him; think he sounds so'    V.149.]

\et H., p.245: *-ehtaw `hear'

\lx womoausu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 194
\ps adj. an. / AI
\ge `(he is) kind, loving'
\so 1 Cor.13.4
\nt G&B 740
    \nt Remark: The relationship of this entry and the next to the TA verb |womonau| remains unclear to me. It is probable that the verb |womonau| has the TA applicative |-ôN-| (TI |-ont-am|) attached to an initial of roughly the shape |womo-|. |Womoausu| is then a middle reflexive to this stem, with the mutation typical of the formation (G&B. no. 11: 580), perhaps with a loss of |-w-| accounting for the hiatus. See B.1962, 15.49, 284-285 for a promising set of relationships. Here, |au| is simply one way of spelling the nasal vowel before |s|, noted by Goddard (G.1981, 33: 70).
    \nt +


\lx womoausúe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 194
\ps adj. / PreN, PreV
\ge `of love, loving'; +`kindly'
    \xv ..., kah womoausue kah wunnamuhkutée unnehhe,...
    \xe ..., deal kindly and truly with me;...
    \so Gen.47.29
    \nt +
    \xv k∞womoausúe kitteamonteanítteáonk
    \xe thy loving kindness
    \so Ps.92.2

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 194
    \nt +
\ps NI, deverbal to |womoausu|
\ge `kindness'
\so Gen.20.13,21.23,...
    \xv ..., yeu k∞womoausuonk pish ànhean,...
    \xe ..., this {is} thy kindness which thou shalt show unto me;...

    \ng 2 possessor

    \xe if thou be kind to this people

    \xe whom he loveth'    Prov.3.12  { 3->_3
    \so _ participle }
    \xv ..., Wosketomp womoausit, woh nánauwèhteou nuttinn∞waogash:...
    \xe ..., If any man love me, he will keep my words:...
    \so Jn.14.23; Mayhew |wamosit|
    \nt +
    \xv Noh mat womauseg, matta nanauwehteauou nukkutt∞wongash,...
    \xe He that loveth me not, keepeth not my sayings:...
    \so Jn.14.24; Mayhew |wamosék|
    \nt +

    \xv womoaus
    \xe love thou (him)
    \so Mt.22.39
    \xv womon∞k kummatwóm∞ôog
    \xe love your enemies
    \so Lk.6.35
\nt [Du Ponceau, in Notes to El.Gr. x, derives this verb, as well as |wunnánum[ónat]| `to bless', from |wunnegen| good, "Del. wu-lie-chen"; but cf. |monánumau| `he is merciful to (him)'; |uttoh woh monánumog| `to whom I will show mercy'    Ex.33.19.  Cotton (Voc.200,201) gives the verbs |womoaussinneat| (v.i.) `to love'; |womonat| (v.t. an.), and |womontamunat| (v.t. inan.) in the several tenses and persons of the indicative.]

    \nt +

\lx wompag

\lx wompam
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 195
    pl. |wauômpeg|, |wauompésichick| `the white money',
    "Their owne is of two sorts; one white, which they make of the stem or stocke of the {Periwincle}, which they call |Meteaûhock|, when all the shell is broken off: and of this sort six of their small Beads (which they make with holes to string the bracelets) are currant with the {English} for a peny."    R.W.144/r.152
    The |wompam| was half the value of the |suckaúhock| (or black money), q.v.
    "A kind of beads ... which they call |wampampeak|, and it is of two sorts; the one is white, the other is of a violet coloure." -- Morton's N.E. Canaan, 1,12.

\so Trumbull 195
\ps v.i. / AI(+O)
\ge `to conceive, to become pregnant; to be with child', +`to conceive sb, sth'
    |wompequôou|, |wompoquoóu|, |wompequoou|    Gen.4.1,17; 16.4√
    \xv ... Kusseh k∞wompequau,...
    \xe ..., Behold, thou art with child,...
    \so Gen.16.11
    \ng 2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Bilhah wompequau, kah neechanushau Jakoboh.
    \xe And Bilhah conceived, and bare Jacob a son.
    \so Gen.30.5
    \nt +
    \xv wompequauog
    \xe they conceived
    \so Gen.30.39
    \xv onk woh wompequau∞og
    \xe that they might conceive
    \so Gen.30.38,41√
    \xv ..., howan yeush wadtihéit noh wutche n∞wompequain,...
    \xe ..., By the man, whose these are, am I with child:...
    \so Gen.38.25√
    \ng 1 subordinative
    \xv ... pish k∞wompequau, kah keneecham kenaumon,...
    \xe ..., thou shalt conceive, and bear a son;...
    \so Judg.13.5
    \ng 2 indicative; also Judg.13.7; cf. Judg.13.3: |kummehche|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., mukkutchouks wompequain.
    \xe ..., There is a man child conceived.
    \so Job 3.3
    \ng X->3 subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Pish k∞wompequomw∞ wussadteamunash,...
    \xe Ye shall conceive chaff,...
    \so Is.33.11
    \ng 2p->0(p) indicative
    \nt +
    (|Kah wonk wompequaeu,...| `And she conceived again,...')    Hos.1.6√; also ib.1.8
    pass. |wompequâinneat| `to be conceived'    Hos.9.11

    \xv wompequait
    \xe if she conceives
    \so Lev.12.2
    \xv ... kah wut chamberumut noh wompequa∞p nuhhog.
    \xe ..., and into the chamber of her that conceived me.'    Song 3.4  { _3_->3
    \so preterite participle }
    \nt +
    \xv asquam wompequau∞muk
    \xe before he was conceived
    \so Lk.2.21
\cf neechan
\cf neechau
\cf wunneechanat

    \se !|wompequaonau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, ?applicative final
    \ge `to conceive sb'
    \so Ps.51.5(M)
    \xv ...: kah ut matcheseonganut noowompukquaonukup nookas.
    \xe ..., and in sin did my mother conceive me.
    \so Ps.51.5
    \ng 3->1 preterite indicative; (E) a puzzle.

\et ??cf. H.3468 *wa∙pikwani NI `flower', if this is itself deverbal in some form. There appears to be a great deal of variation across the languages, suggesting that euphemism is at work.

    dimin. |wompsikukquamesuog| `young eagles'    Prov.30.17
\dv [= |wompi-wussuqun| `white-tail'. The name is perhaps more descriptive of the fishhawk or osprey (Pandion haliaëtus) than of the bald eagle (Haliaëtus leucocephalus), but was very likely applied to both by the Indians of the coast of New England.]

\lx wompu
\va ompu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 196
\ps AI, final
\ge `he sees, he looks'
\nt This primaryverb is not found separately in Eliot, but is employed to form numerous compounds, in the sense of `to look' (`to see purposely'), as
    |wómompu| (|w∞miyeu|) `he looks down'
    \xv p∞sampu
    \xe he looks into
    \so , etc.
It is found in other dialects of the Algonkin, as
    Cree |wâppu| `he sees'    (Howse 43)
    Chip. |oowáhbunden| `he sees it'    (Jones, Jn.11.9)
\cf naumunat
\cf nuhquaeu
\nt and . The three verbs signify:
    \xv naum
    \xe he sees
    \so (voluntarily or involuntarily, without reference to purpose)
    \xv nuhquaeu
    \xe he directs his eyes, looks
    \so (by accident or designedly)
    \xv ompu
    \xe he looks and sees
\cf wompi
\ge bright, white
\cf wompag
\ge bright light, "when he sees"
\cf mohtompan
\cf motauban
\ge break of day
\so (R.W. ) , etc
\cf nadtauwómpu

[Cree |wâpun| `it is daylight'    Howse 77.
Western Abenaki [abe] |ioppa| `voilà'    (Rasles, subst.part. |añ|).
Old Alg. |ni-ouapaman| `I see (him)'; |ni-ouabaten| `I see (it)'    Le Jeune (Arch.Am.II.25); |ouabemo| `to see'    Lah.]

\lx wonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 196
\ps adv. / also as PreV
\ge `also'; +`again, and, moreover, too' (On "again", cf. OED s.v. A.1b.: "{esp.} with {go}, {come}, {wend}, {turn}, {throw}: back, {esp.} all the way back, back to the point of starting.")
    \nt G&B.741
    \nt +
\so Eccl.3.11
    \xv ... ne wonk aquompak kodtum∞k.
    \xe ... at this set time, in the next year.
    \so Gen.17.21
    \ng probably for AV "next"; (E0) "[.] - t[..]s [s.]t - time n[.x.] - [...]r"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wonk pas∞wau weematuh Lotuh,...
    \xe ..., and also brought againe his brother Lot,...
    \so Gen.14.16
    \ng cf. OED gloss
    \nt +
    `again'    Ps.78.39
    `moreover'    Ps.19.11
    \xv Kooche wonk.
    \xe Much longer
    \so C.26/173
    \nt +
    \xv Ahque wonk wutta@ttash.
    \xe Drink no more
    \so C.?49/189
    \nt +
    \xv Ahquomppak wonk kuppéyam.
    \xe When will you come again
    \so C.86/217
    \nt +
    \xv ôu, mat kootâmehhïnnook kooche wonk.
    \xe R. Well I wont detain you much longer.
    \so C.102/227
    \nt +
    (|wonkanet|, |wonk|, |onk| `again'    C.233)
    \xv Matta neen wonckanet namen Winsnow
    \xe that is to say, "O Winslow I shall neuer see thee againe."
    \so Winslow 1624, 28.22-24
    \ng pidgin
    \nt +
\cf onk

WAbn. |wôlagw| `a hole'    D.1.507.]

\et Sb.1967b, 52-53; A.2128, H.3493: *wa∙Θakwi NI `hole, pit, burrow'; G.1990b, (65, p.463; significance, if any, of final *-akw- unclear. Reference is to a hollow(ed out) structure, not to an opening?


\lx -wontam-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 197
    \nt +
\ps TI1a, final; probably not a distinct type--see comment
\ge Non-direct inanimate objects, of indirect type,--applicative, benefactive, etc.
\nt Relationship to TA |-aw-|, |-oN-|, (|-nuhsh-|?) not clear to me at present, other than the points (a) that the |-t-| is that of the TI types and (b) that the |-on-| is probably the product of the contraction of |-aw-|. The initial |-w-| is that of the derived stem (as G&B 578). The formal and functional properties appear most clearly in derivatives from TI verbs, which will therefore constitute most of the examples given here.
    \xv ..., negonne missohhamup, Jesus woh nupp∞wontam ne wutohtimóin.
    \xe ..., he prophesied that Jesus should die for that nation;
    \so Jn.11.51; Mayhew |nupp∞ontam|
    \xv Matta howan yeu wutánue womoausuwontamóun, wosketomp wunnupp∞onaonk wetompuh.
    \xe Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends.
    \so Jn.15.13; Mayhew |wamoahsuontam∞un|
    \ng Literally, presumably something like: "No one loves more than this, ...", where the final expresses the "than this" part.
    \xv ..., qut GOD kukenauwéhteop muhhogkuh, umm∞cheke aninnumontamun quttiantamunat, ne quenauhikk∞m∞uk.
    \xe ...: but God hath tempered the body together, having given more abundant honour to that part which lacked:
    \so 1 Cor.12.24
    \xv ...; Christ nupp∞wontamup kummatcheseonganunonash neâunag wussukwhonganash.
    \xe ..., how that Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures;
    \so 1 Cor.15.3
    \xv ... Yeu wutche kussamp∞wonsh ut kenugke Gentilsut, kah ket∞hamwontam k∞wesuonk.
    \xe ..., For this cause I will confess to thee among the Gentiles, and sing unto thy name.
    \so Rom.15.9
    \xv ...: qut kukkodtóhtinunnumw∞ k∞waantam∞wontamunneau ne wanégik, kah as∞kekodtum∞un ne machuk.
    \xe ...: but yet I would have you wise unto that which is good, and simple concerning evil.
    \so Rom.16.19
    \xv Kah matta howan wunnemunnumwontamauóon wuhhogkuh yeu quttianittuonk, qut noh wehkomut nashpe GOD, neyáne Aaron.
    \xe And no man taketh this honour unto himself, but he that is called of God, as was Aaron.
    \so Heb.5.4
    \xv ...: na nupp∞ongane matcheseonk, matta nusseuh ne pish uppeantamwontamun.
    \xe .... There is a sin unto death: I do not say that he shall pray for it.
    \so 1 Jn.5.16
    \xv ..., kah na wutch penushon mishanogqus wutch kesukqut, nashqunau onatuh lamput, kah pogkussumwontam nashwe chippagish sepuash,...
    \xe ..., and there fell a great star from heaven, burning as it were a lamp, and it fell upon the third prt of the rivers,...
    \so Rev.8.10

\et Compare B.1962, 16.180, p.364, on |-ama∙t| ("|-amow| plus TI |-εt|, with contraction of |owε| to |a∙|").


\lx wonteauunát
\va wonehteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 197
    \nt Remark: The spelling and etymology suggest |wôn(eh)t^á-|, the glottal fricative being attested in certain infected and derived forms.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI+O, creative final
\ge `to dig a hole', +`to till (the ground)'
    \xv ..., onk woh wonteau ohke, ne waj neemunómukup.
    \xe ..., to till the ground from whence he was taken.
    \so Gen.3.23
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche wame wutahamongash ∞shoh wuttinnumoh ∞wónuhkonapash pomantog Abraham ∞shoh, Philistiansog ukkuphamunáash,...
    \xe For all the wells which his father's servants had digged in the days of Abraham his father, the Philistines had stopped them,...
    \so Gen.26.15
    \ng despite AV source, apparently independent preterite objective, no palatalization
    \nt ?+
    \xv Kah wuttinúmoh Isaak wónéteaog ∞nauhkói,...
    \xe And Isaac's servants digged in the valley,...
    \so Gen.26.19
    \nt +
    \xv n∞wonteam
    \xe I have digged
    \so 2 K.19.24
    \xv wonteau ohkeit
    \xe he digged in the earth
    \so Mt.25.18√
    \xv Wônteauh, kah ukkuthámun,...
    \xe He made a pit & digged it,...
    \so Ps.7.15√; (M) |Wonteauh|
    \ng 3 (absentative?)
    \xv Pittuanum∞og wônteaog wutche neen:...
    \xe The proud have digged pits for me,...
    \so Ps.119.85 { 3p indicative } ; (M) |noowonuhkunkuppaneg| (3p->1+0p preterite to |wonuhkauau|, v.i.)

    \xv ..., kah wônteaon ut hassunnutonkanit,...
    \xe ...: and when I had digged in the wall,...
    \so Ezek.8.8√
    \ng 1 changed conjunct
    \xv ..., kah matta mo wosketompainoh woh wanteunk ohke.
    \xe ..., and there {was} not a man to till the ground.
    \so Gen.2.5
    \ng _3_->0 negative participle
    \nt +

    \xv ..., wônteash eyeu ut hassunnutonganit,...
    \xe ..., dig now in the wall:...
    \so Ezek.8.8
    \ng 2 imperative

    \se !|wonuhkauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA+O, |-aw-| stem, to AI stem (without |-á-| final)
    \ge `to dig sth for sb'
    \so Ps.119.85(M)
    \xv Pahtuanumwitcheg noowonuhkunkuppaneg wonogquash,...
    \xe The proud have digged pits for me,...
    \so Ps.119.85(M)
    \ng 3p->1+0p

    \xv .... n∞wenohkit wónohkoaogkup nuhhog, ut ohkit Kanaan....
    \xe ..., in my grave which I have digged for me in the land of Canaan, ...
    \so Gen.50.5
    \ng 1->3+_0_ preterite participle

\cf kuttahham

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |n8"añrkéhemen, 3 a8.| `Je creuse avec instrum't'    R.147/424b.
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |WANIKE| (|ä| long) `creuser, faire une fosse, un fossé'    Cq.424ab.
Cree |Wa'tékäo| `He makes or digs a cave, or a pit, or cave'; |wâtihkew| AI `S/he digs a hole'    Frs.505a; Alb.E.224a.

\lx woskeheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 198
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Trumbull treated these under the syncopated form |woskheónat|; the two entries have not yet been consolidated. The derived nouns are under separate headwords.
\ps TA
\ge `to defile, hurt, oppress, persecute, wound sb'
\so Gen.4.23; Mk.7.18; Lk.10.19,11.49; Jn.5.16; Acts 7.24,13.50,22.7,26.14; Gal.1.23,4.29; C.
    \xv ..., ne teaguas wutch woskeche petutteaónukqut wosketomp woh mo woskehuk∞un?
    \xe ..., that whatsoever thing from without entreth into the man, it cannot defile him;
    \so Mk.7.18
    \ng negative 0->3 objective
    \xv Qut neyane naut, noh weyausue neekit, woskeheau neh nashauanittoe nekinitche, neyane yeuyeu.
    \xe But as then he that was born after the flesh persecuted him that was born after the Spirit, even so it is now.
    \so Gal.4.29
    \xv Woskehhittinneat.
    \xe To be hurt
    \so C.57/195

    \xv ..., newutche nunnush wosketomp kod woskehit, kah wuskenin toh kodnehit.
    \xe ...: for I have slain a man to my wounding, and a young man to my hurt.
    \so Gen.4.23; (E0) "when he desires to hurt me ... when he would kill me"
    \ng _3_->1 participle
    \xv K∞nanumitteamw∞ wosketompaog mamatchenukqueog, kah woskehukqueog,...
    \xe Blessed are ye, when men shall revile you, and persecute you,...
    \so Mt.5.11
    \ng 3->2p
    \xv Qut kuttinnonnumw∞, howan woskehukquean, ahque adtumehtau,...
    \xe But I say unto you, That ye resist not evil:...
    \so Mt.5.39
    \ng Very loose version: "if someone harms you, do not resist him"
    \xv ..., Saul, Saul towhutch woskehhean;
    \xe ..., Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
    \so Acts 22.7
    \ng conjunct 2->1
    \xv ..., neen Jesus ut NaZareth uttiyeuwoh waskheat.
    \xe ..., I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom thou persecutest.
    \so Acts 22.8
    \ng 2->_3_ participle

    \se woskehuau
    \ps AI, TA + indefinite object
    \ge `to be noisome, venomous, wont to push' i.e. "harmful or dangerous in some respect" (with intensive reduplication in two of the examples)
    \so Ex.8.21,21.29; Acts 28.4
    *|Woske@heuönat.| `To hurt'    C.57/195
    \xv N∞woskheuam, -huap.
    \xe I hurt, {or} did
    \so C.57/195

    \xv ..., kuppaudtinnummaush, kah ut kummssinninnúmehtu, kah ut kuttinneúmut, kah ut keekuwóut ianussuog (wowoskehuwacheg) ...
    \xe ..., I will send ||swarmes of flies vpon thee, and vpon thy servants, and vpon thy people, and into thy houses:...' + marginale `||{Or, a mixture of noysome beasts, &c.}
    \so Ex.8.21
    \ng reduplicated
    \xv Qut oxun woskehuadt negonnáeu,...
    \xe But if the ox were wont to push with his horn in time past,...
    \so Ex.21.29
    \ng i.e. "had a tendency to gore"?
    \xv Kah barbarianéog nauahettit wohwoskehuadt ogquom∞ wunnutcheganit,...
    \xe And when the barbarians saw the venomous beast hang on his hand,...
    \so Acts 28.4
    \ng reduplicated

    \se !|woskehuwom∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, derived
    \ge ?"to hurt,..."
    \so Gen.20.5
    \xv ..., kah matta woskehuwomun∞ut nunnutchegash yeu nutussen.
    \xe ...: in the integrity of my heart and innocency of my hands have I done this.
    \so Gen.20.5
    \ng negative t-subordinative


\lx woskehittuonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 198
\ps n.
    \dv derived to theme 2a of |woskeheau| why |-u-onk| then? either derived to the reciprocal stem used i_? (G&B.584)--but why |-u-onk| then? either derived to the reciprocal stem used in passive sense (G&B. no.15., 580) or identical to |woskehtuonk|, |wosketuonk| (v.i.).
    \nt +
\ge `violence (suffered), a wound'; +`persecution'
\so Ex.21.25
    `spoiling'    Hab.1.3
    (= |woskehuwaonk| (?)    Gen.6.13
    cf. Gen.6.11)
    \xv ... Kah na àquompak missi woskehittúonk ayeuuhkonitue moyeuwehkomonganit ...
    \xe .... And at that time there was a great persecution against the church ...
    \so Acts 8.1
    \nt +


\lx woskehtinneat
\nt Follow up needed: }
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 198
\ps v.t. inan. and v.i. / TI2
\ge `to do harm to' (inan. obj.)
\so Rev.7.2
    = |woskehteauunát|
    \xv n∞wosketeóh
    \xe I persecuted
    \so (it, the church)    Phil.3.6
    \xv matta ∞wosketeaunnaóut moskehtuash
    \xe (they) not to hurt the grass
    \so Rev.9.4

    \xv ahque woskehteau∞k ohke
    \xe do not harm (ye) the earth
    \so Rev.7.3

    \se |wosketuonk|, |woskehtowonk|, |wosketóonk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, deverbal noun to |woskehteau|
    \ge `evil, mischief'
    \so Gen.19.19,42.4,38
    \xv ... ishkont wosketuonk nunnahtwunuk kah woh nunnup.
    \xe ... lest some evil take me, and I die:
    \so Gen.19.19; (E0) "mischife"
    \xv ..., ishkont pagquodcheh woh woskehtowonk mussuhkunk
    \xe ..., Lest peradventure mischief befall him.
    \so Gen.42.4

    \xe male and female created he them

    \xe among men
    \so Ps.78.60

    \se wosketompo∞
    \ps v. subst. / AI, predicate nominal; II, existential
    \ge `he is a man, he became a man'
    \so El.Gr.12,16
    "By turning the Noun into the Verb-substantive form: as |Wosketompo∞| {He became a man}."    El.Gr.12/259, also 16/262
    \xv ... & matta wohtoh wosketompaun∞ yeu ohkit...
    \xe ..., and there is not a man in the earth,...
    \so Gen.19.31
    \ng 0 negative indicative

    (|nukkone wosk| `an old man'    C.157
    \xv nawhutche wosk
    \xe some men
    \so C.175
    \xv onkatog woske
    \xe another man
    \so C.232
    \xv nanwi woske
    \xe any man
    \so C.232)

\ps v.t. an. / TA

\so Prov.6.18
    \xv n∞woskhukqunat
    \xe to hurt me
    \so Gen.31.7
    \xv Menuhkesuonk ohteau nunnutcheganit k∞woskhenunat,...
    \xe It is in the power of my hand to do you hurt:...'    Gen.31.29√ { 1->2 (!); AV, Hebrew: 2p -- "you" presumably including the whole of Jacob
    \so s family (not implausibly); LXX, Vlg.: 2s }
    \xv ... neit pish quinnuppeu, kah k∞woskhukkou,...
    \xe ..., then he will turn and do you hurt,...
    \so Josh.25.20

    \xv ∞woskheonaóut wosketompuh
    \xe (they) to hurt men
    \so Rev.9.10

    \xe we harm them not
    \so 1 Sam.25.7
    \xv woskéheau
    \xe he wrongeth, injureth
    \so Prov.8.36
    \xv woh woskeheau
    \xe (it) may harm (him)
    \so Job 35.8
    \xv mat pish ∞woskhukk∞
    \xe he shall not hurt thee
    \so Acts 18.10√
    pass. |n∞woskhit| `I am hurt'    Jer.8.21
    \xv k∞woskitteop
    \xe thou wast spoiled
    \so Is.33.1
    (|woskehheaog wuhhogkäuh| `they hurt themselves' (`injure themselves')    C.239)

    \xv ..., newutche nunnush wosketomp kod woskehit,...
    \xe ...,  for I have slain a man to my wounding,...
    \so Gen.4.23; (E0): "when he desires to hurt me"
    \nt +
    |woskeheunt| particip. `harming, one who hurts'    Rev.11.5
    \xv uttoh woskheadt
    \xe "whom thou persecutest", injurest
    \so Acts 9.5√
    \xv woskhuwaan
    \xe thou that spoilest
    \so Is.33.1

    \xv matta ∞woskheuh
    \xe hurt thou him not
    \so Lk.4.35
    \xv woskeheúhkon
    \xe do him no harm
    \so Jer.39.12
    \xv ahque woskéheuk
    \xe do (them) no harm
    \so Ps.105.15

\ge `to beget a son or sons'; +`to bear a son'
\nt Remark: c.f. |wuttauneu|, |wuttóneu| `to bear, beget a daughter', 211b.
    \xv ... Kusseh k∞wompequau, pish k∞namoni:...
    \xe ..., Behold, thou art with child, and shalt bear a son,...

    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah petutteaònont, LORD wuttinnumauoh wompequauonk, kah wunnaumonieu.
    \xe ...: and when he went in unto her, the Lord gave her conception, and she bare a son.
    \so Ruth 4.13
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Ken nunnaumon, yeu kesukok n∞naumon kuhhog?...
    \xe ..., Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee?...

    \nt +
    \xv wunnanionieu
    \xe he begets a son
    \so Eccl.5.14

    \xe he shall beget sons
    \so Gen.17.20
    \xv ... wunnamoniyeu kuhhogkanonash,...
    \xe ... begat he us,...
    \so Jas.1.18√
    (|n∞naumoniyeum| `I beget (a son or sons)'    C.181)

    |noh wunaumoniit|, |-nait| `if he beget a son'    Prov.17.21; Ezek.18.10,14

    \xe he who begat thee
    \so Prov.23.22

    \xe beget (ye) sons
    \so Jer.29.6

\lx wunnamptamunat
\va wunnomuhtam
\ve reorganized slightly
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 200
\ps v.t. / TI1a(-O), directive final
\ge `to believe', +often (mainly?) absolute
\nt G&B.483; 731; |-p-| intrusive, cf. (M)
\so Lk.24.25
\nt [with an. obj. expressed, `to believe or believe in (a person)']
    \xv n∞namptam
    \xe I believe
    \so Mk.9.24; Acts 27.25; C.182
    \xv wunnamptamwog
    \xe they believed
    \so Ex.4.31
    |wunnamptam|, |∞namptam| `he believes'    Prov.14.15

    \se wunnamptauónat
    \va wunnamptauau
    \nt +
    \va wunnomuhtauau
    \nt !
    \ps (an. and inan.) / TA, directive final
    \ge `to obey'; +`to believe (on) sb, to hearken unto sb'
    \xv Kah Abraham ∞namptauau Ephronoh,...
    \xe And Abraham hearkened unto Ephron;...
    \so Gen.23.16√
    \ng erroneous prefix
    \xv ..., matta ∞namptauoh nesinát,...
    \xe ..., that he hearkened not unto her, to lie by her,...
    \so Gen.39.10
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah missinninnuog qushaog Jehovah, kah wunnamptauáog Jehovah, kah Mosesoh wuttinnúmoh.
    \xe ...: and the people feared the Lord, and believed the Lord, and his servant Moses.
    \so Ex.14.31
    \xv ..., newutche nah mat ∞namptauoh.
    \xe ..., for he believed them not.'    Gen.45.26  { 3->3
    \so negative objective indicative }
    \xv k∞namptau
    \xe dost thou believe on (him)?
    \so Jn.9.35√; (M): |k∞nomuhtam ut|
    \xv k∞namptamw∞ God
    \xe ye believe in God
    \so Jn.14.1; (M): |k∞nômuhtauômw∞|
    \ng 2p->3 objective
    \xv Ketass∞t Agrippa k∞namptau quoshodtumwaenuog? n∞wahteauun k∞namptam.
    \xe King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest.
    \so Acts.26.27
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Howan noh Nussontimom, onk woh n∞namptau?
    \xe ..., Who is he, Lord, that I might believe on him?
    \so Jn.9.36√; (M): |n∞nomuhtau|
    \xv ..., matta k∞namptáuau.
    \xe ..., him ye believe not.
    \so Jn.5.38; (M): |k∞nomuhtauou|
    \ng 2p->3
    \nt +
    (|wunnamptoadtinneat| `to be believed'    C.182)

    \xv ..., nag yeuh wanamptauoncheg pish wutattumunóuh,...
    \xe ..., which they that believe on him should receive:...
    \so Jn.7.39; (M): |wanonuhtauoncheg|
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wutahtushonáoh Goduh, n nah wanamptauáhettiche.
    \xe ..., they commended them to the Lord, on whom they believed.
    \so Acts 14.23
    \nt +
    \xv howan wunnamptauont
    \xe whoso believeth in (him)
    \so Rom.9.33
    = |howan wanamptog|    1 John 5.1,5

    \xv ..., nen wonk wunnamptiék.
    \xe ..., believe also in me.
    \so Jn.14.1; (M): |wunnômuhtiek.|
    \ng 2p->1
    \nt +
    |... wunnamptau Lord Jesus Christ, kah woh k∞wadchanitteamw∞,...|  { 2->3 } `..., Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved,...'    Acts 16.31
    \nt +


[Narragansett [xnt] |Coanáumatous| `I believe you.' {Obs.} This word they use just as the {Greeke} tongue doth that verb, {pisëyein}: for believing or obeying, as it is often used in the new {Testament}, and they say |Coannáumatous|, I will obey you.    R.W.59.√]

\et Compare Mayhew's form: |wunnomuhtam| (etc.); the two are related by syncope of the third syllable, the stem being that meaning `true' (`good'+`by mouth'). For an indication of existence of the syncope required within Massachusett proper, see |namehteau| `to find'.

\va wunnamuhkutée

    \va -uhkut-
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `(it) is true'; +`to be verified' [cf. OED s.v.3 "In passive: To be proved true or correct by the result or event, or by some confirming fact or circumstance;...."]

    \xe Stand therefore, having your loins girt about with truth, and having on the breastplate of righteousness;
    \so Eph.6.14

\lx wunnántamunat
\va wunnanittamunát
\va wunne-unnantamunát
\va wunnantam
\va -ánatam
\va -anetam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 201
\ps v.t. inan. / TI1a, mental final (syncopated)
\twn |wunnánumónat|
\ge `to bless (it)'
\so Deut.28.12; 2 Sam.7.29
    \xv pish wunnantam
    \xe he will bless (it)
    \so Deut.7.13
    \xv ...wame wutohtimoneash ut ohkit pish wunnanetamunash,...
    \xe ... shall all the nations of the earth be blessed;...
    \so Gen.22.18
    \ng X->0p absolute
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wosketomp monchantog chequnikompau, uttoh wuttin Jehovah wunnantamun uppomushaonk asuh matta.
    \xe And the man wondering at her held his peace, to wit whether the Lord had made his journey prosperous or not.
    \so Gen.24.21
    \nt +
    \xv Pish wunnanittamun ummeechumuonk kutóontómuk,...
    \xe Blessed shall be the fruit of thy body,...
    \so Deut.28.4,5√
    \ng transferred from TA lemma
    \xv ..., kah nemunum napanna tahshinash petukqunnunganash kah nesuoh namohsoh, kah aspuhquait kesukqut ∞nanatamun, kah wussohqunnumun,...
    \xe ..., and [he] took the five loaves, and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he blessed, and brake,...
    \so Mt.14.19
    \nt +

    \xv wunantash
    \xe bless thou (it
    \so )    Deut.33.11
    \xv micheme wunnantamunach
    \xe let (it) be blessed forever
    \so 2 Sam.7.29
\nt Primarily, to be pleased with a thing.

[Narragansett [xnt] |nowecóntam|, |noweeteántam| `I am glad'    R.W.65.
Delaware [del] |nolelendam| `I rejoice, am glad'; |nolatenami| `I am happy'    Zeisb.Voc.50.

\lx wunnánumónat
\va wunnanumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 201
\ps v.t. an. / TA, mental final
\twn |wunnántamunat|
    \nt G&B.743
    \nt +
\ge `to bless, to invoke blessings on'
\so Num.24.1
\ge `to confer blessings'
    \xv ... kah k∞nânumush...
    \xe ..., and I will bless thee,...
    \so Gen.12.2
    \ng 1->2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... kah ∞[n]anumuh nah nishnoh pasuk∞ ne[a]unag ∞naneteaonk ∞nanumoh.
    \xe ... and [he] blessed them; every one according to his blessing he blessed them.'    Gen.49.28  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv wunnánumomp
    \xe he blessed (them)
    \so Deut.33.1
    \xv ∞nanumonaoont
    \xe they to bless (them)
    \so Deut.27.12
    \xv k∞nanumoush
    \xe I will bless thee
    \so Gen.22.17
    \xv n∞nanum
    \xe I bless (her)
    \so Gen.17.16
    pass. |Pish k∞nanumit ut otanat, kah k∞nanumit pish ut ohteakonit.| `Blessed shalt thou be in the city, and blessed shalt thou be in the field.'    Deut.28.3 { noteworthy positioning of 2nd |pish|, E1&2--printer? }√
    (|wunnaunumonat|    C.182; |nen n∞nânum| `I bless'    C.182.)
    (|wunnani@ttinneat| `to be blessed'    C.182)

    \xv Kah nnih, ash pame wunnanumont, noh wutamaehtauuh, kah speuunau en kesukqut.
    \xe And it came to pass, while he blessed them, he was parted from them, and carried up into heaven.
    \so Lk.24.51
    \nt +

    \xv wunnanumeh
    \xe bless me
    \so Gen.27.34
    \ng 2->1 imperative
    \xv ..., wunnanumonch wuskenésoh:...
    \xe ..., bless the lads;...'    Gen.48.16  { 3->3
    \so imperative }
    \nt +

    \se |wunnanitteau|
    \nt +
    \ps AI, |wunnanum-| TA + |-t^eá-| indefinite object final (G&B. item 14, 580, but not the long form)
    \ge `to bless'
    \so Gen.22.17; Num.23.20
    \xv Kusseh nutattumunum wunanitteae kutt∞wonk, kah wunnanitteau, kah matta woh nukqushkenum∞un.
    \xe Behold, I have received commandment to bless: and he hath blessed; and I cannot reverse it.
    \so Num.23.21
    \ng 3 indicative

    \xv Wunanitteáon k∞nanumoush,...
    \xe That in blessing, I will bless thee,...
    \so Gen.22.17
    \ng 1 subjunctive

    \se !|wunnanumwaheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative final; structure unclear
    \ge `to make sb blessed' (AV, cf. other texts, roughly: "give blessings")
    \so Ps.21.6(M)
    \xv Newutche kummoocheke wunnanumwaheop micheme:...
    \xe For thou hast made him most blessed for ever:...
    \so Ps.21.6
    \ng 2->3 preterite absolute

\lx wunnash
\va wunnashau
\ve r.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 201
\ps v. / TA { |apheh|, |ahkuhk| are animate }
\twn |wunnohteauunát|
\ge `to erect, to set upright' (lit. `to set on end')
    \xv wunnashau
    \xe he set up
    \so (a pillar)    1 K.7.21

    \xv noh wánashont ahpehanoh
    \xe he that setteth snares
    \so Jer.5.26

    \xv monchish askuhweteaenin wunnash
    \xe Go, set a watchman
    \so Is.21.6
    \ng 2->3 imperative
    \xv wunash ahkuhk, wunash
    \xe Set on a pot, set it on
    \so Ezek.24.3√
    \ng 2->3 imperative
\cf wanashque
\ge on the top of', or rather
\so on end'

[Delaware [del] |wo nach qui wi| `top of a house or tree'    Zeisb.]

\et H.3688 *wela?le∙wa TA `place' i.e. *wel- `in order, in place' + *-ap-l- `to place', with TA final *-l-; c.f. TI twin. See also G.1982, no. 269, p.45 with fn.170. (In principle this might perhaps reflect the initial *wen- `upwards, lift' [G.2002.56].)

\lx wunnaumatuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 201
    \nt +
\ps TA, corporal final |-hk-aw-|
\ge `to follow after sb, pursue (after) sb'
\so Gen.14.14,15,31.36,44.4; Lev.26.19; Josh.2.5; Ps.18.37
    \xv ..., kah ∞nomatuhkaouh Dan wehque.
    \xe ..., and pursued {them} unto Dan.'    Gen.14.14  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \xv N∞nômahtúhkôomp nummatwóog,...
    \xe I have pursued mine enemies,...
    \so Ps.18.37; (M) |Noonomatuhkouomp|
    \ng 1->3(p) preterite absolute

    \xv ..., , waj musquanittamwe wunnaumatúhkáean?
    \xe ..., that thou hast so hotly pursued after me?
    \so Gen.31.36
    \ng 2->1 conjunct
    \xv ..., kah pish k∞semw∞, wanne howan wunnaumatuhkongk∞óog.
    \xe ...; and ye shall flee when none pursueth you.
    \so Lev.26.17
    \ng 3->2p negative

    \xv ..., Neepaush wunnaumatuhkau wosketompaog, kah mattanadt us,...
    \xe ..., Up, follow after the men; and when thou dost overtake them say unto them,...
    \so Gen.44.4
    \ng 2-3(p) imperative
    \xv ...: wunnaumatehtuhh∞k teaneuk, newutche woh kummattannoôog.
    \xe ...: pursue after them quickly; for ye shall overtake them.
    \so Josh.2.5
    \ng 2p->3(p) imperative; (E1) also |-hh-|, presumably in error

    \se wunnaumatuhkauonk
    \ps NI
    \ge AV finite verb (c.f. G&B.585-586)
    \so Lev.26.36,37
    \xv ..., kah nag pish penushaog, wanne howan wunnaumatuhkauonk.
    \xe ...; and they shall fall when none pursueth.
    \so Lev.26.36

    \se wunnaumatehtahwau
    \ps TA, |-ahw-|
    \ge `to pursue after sb'
    \so Ex.14.8
    \xv ..., kah wunnaumatéhtahwhau wunnaumonuh Israel:...
    \xe ..., and he pursued after the children of Israel:...
    \so Ex.14.8


\lx wunnaumoniin

\lx wunnaumonuh
\va -naumon-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 201
\ps n. constr. / NA, dependent
\ge `(his or her) son'
\so Gen.22.3; 21.2,3,5,7
\nt G&B. 488 (|-ï| final stem), 491, 661
    (`the son of')    2 K.4.37
    \xv nunnaumon
    \xe my son
    \so Gen.21.23; 22.7,8
    \xv nunnaumon wunnaumonuh
    \xe my son's son
    \so Gen.21.23
    \xv kenaumon
    \xe thy son
    \so Gen.22.2,12; Lev.18.10
    (|kenômon| `thy son', pl. |kenaumö^nog|    C.162.)
    \xv en wunnaumonat
    \xe toward or to his son
    \so Deut.28.56,57
    `on his son'    Gen.22.6
    pl. |nunnaumonog| `my sons'    Gen.31.28  { 1 possessor plural }
    \xv wunnaumonuh
    \xe his sons, the sons of
    \so 1 Chr.21.20; 2 Sam.23.6; Gen.50.12
    \ng 3 possessor obviative
    \xv wunnaumonuh nummisinninnumog
    \xe the sons of my people
    \so Gen.23.11
    \ng 3p possessor obviative; (E0) |wunnaumonáuh|, (E1) |wunnaumon∞h|
    \nt +
    \xv ...(... Boanerges, ne nauwuttamun wunnaumonauh padtuhquohhan.)
    \xe ... Boanerges, which is, The sons of thunder:
    \so Mk.3.17
    \ng 3p possessor obviative
    \nt +
    \xv wunnaumonáoh wosketompaog
    \xe the children of men
    \so Ps.11.4(E); (M) also, except accent
    \nt +

    (collectively, `all my sons' |nunnaumonunk|    Gen.48.9; 1 Sam.2.24, +Gen.48.5)

    \se |wunnaumonaeu|, |wunnaumonaieu|, |wunnaumonieu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI(+O), verb of possession
    \ge `to bear, beget, have a son, for a son X to be born unto sb', `to sonn' ((E0) gloss) (used of male and female parent)
    \so Gen.4.18,26,5.4,...,17.12,...,19.37,38,...; Ex.2.2
    \xv ..., kah kusseh Sarah kummittamwussis pish wunnaumonáieu,...
    \xe ...; and lo, Sarah thy wife shall have a son.
    \so Gen.18.10
    \ng 3 indicative
    \xv wunnaumonieu
    \xe bare a son
    \so Gen.19.37,38
    \ng (E0) "sonned"

    \xv ..., uttiyeuoh mat wanaumoniyean.
    \xe ..., which is not of thy seed.
    \so Gen.17.12
    \ng 2->_3_ negative participle

    [LpA. |neman| `mon fils' (Day suggests that this is Abenaki, n. 537.)    D.64.
    \nt +
Western Abenaki [abe] |Nnemañn, 3. 8némañnar| `mon fils'    R.376/498a.
Pen. |ne∙'mon| `son', |une'manal| `her son'; |-néman-| nad `son'    Sp.1918a.160,Sp.1918b.237b; V.1979.61.
WAbn. |-namôn, -namônak| `son', |Wanamônid| `The Father, he who has a Son'    D.1.348,474.]

\lx wunnauwadtuwaheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 202
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge `to make (an) atonement for sb'
\so Lev.4.21,29,31,19.22
\nt Remark: The verb is presumably derived from a stem |wunnauwadt-|, attested at Gen.31.44 in the sense `make a covenant' and at 1 Jn.5.8 as `to agree (in one)'. This perhaps reflects the still live awareness on Eliot's part of the (noteworthy) etymology of "atone(ment)". (OED, s.v.: "{Atone} was not admitted into the Bible in 1611, though {atonement} had been in since Tindale.")
    \xv Kah sephausuen pish sephausu, matcheseongane sephausuonk, kah pish wunnauwadtuwaheau, noh pahkhet wutch wunnishkeneunkqussinneat,...
    \xe And the priest shall offer the sin offering, and make an atonement for him that is to be cleansed from his uncleanness;...
    \so Lev.14.19
    \xv Kah na pish matta howan, ut mukkienáekomukqut, petutteadt, ∞nauwàdtuwahuônat ut wunneetupanatamwe ayeuonganit,...
    \xe And there shall be no man in the tabernacle of the congregation when he goeth in to make an atonement in the holy place,...
    \so Lev.16.17
    \xv Newutche yeu kesukok {sephausuen} pish k∞nauwadtuwahukou, kuppahkhikqunnáout,...
    \xe For on that day shall the priest make an atonement for you, to cleanse you,...
    \so Lev.16.30

    \xv ...: newutche ne wusqueheonk wunauwadtuwaheont keteahogkôunoh.
    \xe ...: for it is the blood that maketh an atonement for the soul.
    \so Lev.17.11

    \se wunnauwadtuwahtau
    \ps TI2
    \ge `to make (an) atonement for sth'
    \so Lev.14.53,16.18,20,33
    \xv ...: kah pish wunnauwadtuwáhtau wetu, kah pish pohki:
    \xe ..., and [he shall] make an atonement for the house: and it shall be clean.
    \so Lev.14.53
    \xv Kah pish wunnauwadtuwahtau wunnetupanatamwe sanctuary, kah mukkinneae kommuk, kah Altar pish wunnauwadtuwohtau. kah sephausuenuog, kàh wame moeuwehkomongane missinninnuog pish wunnauwadtuwaheuh.
    \xe And he shall make an atonement for the holy sanctuary, and he shall make an atonement for the tabernacle of the congregation, and for the altar, and he shall make an atonement for the priests, and for all the people of the congregation.
    \so Lev.16.33

    \se wunnauwadtuonk
    \ps NI
    \ge `atonement'
    \so Ex.29.33,36,37,30.10,16
    \xv ..., kah sephausuaén pish ayim nag ∞nauwadtuongan∞, kah pish kutteamonteanitteae ahquontamauóog.
    \xe ...: and the priest shall make an atonement for them, and it shall be forgiven them.
    \so Lev.4.20
    \ng The calque of Exodus is largely displaced by the verb in Leviticus.

    \se wunnauwadtuwahuwae
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of atonement'
    \so Lev.23.27,28,25.9
    \xv Wonk piogkukquinhog nesausuk adtahsuit nepauz, ne pish wunnauwadtuwahuwae kesukod,...
    \xe Also on the tenth day of this seventh month there shall be a day of atonement:...
    \so Lev.23.27


\lx wunne
\va ∞ne
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 202
\ps adv. and adj.
\ge `well, beautifully, pleasantly (Lat. bene); good, beautiful, pleasant'
    \xv wunne wutt∞antash
    \xe be of good courage
    \so 1 Chr.19.13
    \xv wunne ohke
    \xe a good land
    \so Deut.8.7
    \xv ∞ne méechum∞mash
    \xe his pleasant fruits
    \so Cant.4.16
    \xv woh k∞ne mukk∞nóminneau
    \xe ye might well bear with him
    \so 2 Cor.11.4

    \se wunniyeu
    \va wunnieu
    \ps adj. an. with prefix / AI, |wun-| + |aye-|
    \ge `to be happy, for it to be well with sb' [on "happy", note OED, s.v., 3: "Characterized by or involving good fortune; fortunate, lucky; prosperous; favourable, propitious.", i.e. commonly at this period not referring to an emotional state.]
    \nt +
    \xv k∞ni
    \xe thou art happy'    Deut.33.29; +Ruth 3.1: `that it may be well with thee
    \xv pish k∞ni
    \xe thou shalt be secure
    \so Job 11.18
    \xv onk woh n∞ni wutche ken
    \xe that it may be well with me for thy sake
    \so Gen.12.13√
    \xv k∞naiimw∞ nish usseóg
    \xe happy are ye if ye do them
    \so Jn.13.17

    \xv Qut naumánumeh wunnayean, kah kittumonteanumeh k∞wehquetumoush,...
    \xe But think on me when it shall be well with thee, and shew kindness, I pray thee, unto me,...
    \so Gen.40.14
    \nt +
    \xv wunniítcheg
    \xe they who are happy, the happy
    \so Mal.3.15
\cf wunnegen
\cf wunniyeu

\lx wunnegen
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 202
\ps `adv. of quality' (El. Gr. 22) and adj. / II, C-final
\twn |wunneetu|, AI.
\ge `(it is) good, pleasant'
\nt (used by Eliot sometimes as the equivalent of |wunne|, but, strictly regarded, |wunne| or |wunni| is applicable to the abstract, the possible or suppositive, or the subject, |wunnegen| to the concrete, the actual, or the object; yet Eliot was compelled to employ the latter form to express abstract good.
\cf wunnegik
    \xv wunnaumun ... na en wunnegen
    \xe he saw ... that it was good
    \so Gen.1.4,10,18
    \xv ne wunnegen ut wuskesukqut
    \xe the thing was good in his eyes
    \so Gen.41.37
    `"he was content" with it'    Lev.10.20
    \xv anue wunnegen
    \xe (it is) better, a better thing
    \so Mt.18.8,9
    \xv ut wunnegen ohkeit, ... wunnegen nutahtauonk
    \xe in pleasant places, ... I (have) a goodly heritage
    \so Ps.16.6
    (rare in) pl. |wunnegenash| `good things'    Mt.12.35
    v. subst. negat. |matta wunnegeninn∞|, |-no| `it is not good'    Gen.2.18; 2 Sam.17.7; Mt.19.10

    \xv .., wahteunk wanegik kah machuk,...
    \xe ..., to know good and evil:...
    \so Gen.3.22
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., yauut pasuk∞∞ash shekelsash silver wanegigkish ut kenugke kodtauwompasuenuog.
    \xe ... four hundred shekels of silver, current money with the merchant.
    \so Gen.23.16
    \ng _0p_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah kittinnumáunumw∞ ne wanegik ut ohkit Egypt,...
    \xe ..., and I will give you the good of the land of Egypt,...
    \so Gen.45.18
    \ng _0_ participle
    \nt +

    \xv quenau wanne wunnegennin∞gk
    \xe thenceforth it is (will be) good for nothing
    \so Mt.5.13
    \xv wanne wunnegenninn∞gk
    \xe no good thing will (he withhold)
    \so Ps.84.11

[*FOOTNOTE. -- "On reflection I am convinced that |wunnegen| is, primarily, the contracted infinitive, or 3d pers. sing. indic. pres. of a verb |wunnegenát| `to be good', as |wunnesenát| `to do good or well'. From this verb |wunnegik| and (negat.) |wunnegenninn∞g|, etc., are regularly formed. No, it is the inanimate noun, or 3d pers. pres. indic., meaning `good thing' (bonum or kalòn) or it is good'."]


[Western Abenaki [abe] |8righen| `cela est bon, beau'    Rasles.
Narragansett [xnt] |wunnégin|, cówish| [|kóuesh|] `welcome, sleep here'    R.W.38.
Delaware [del] |wu lie chen| `it is good or well done'    Zeisb.Voc.34.]

\lx wunnehteauunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 203
\ps v.t. inan. / TI2, causative
    \dv |wunn(e)-| `complete, good, in order, ready' + |-ht-aw-| TI2 causative
    \nt +
\ge `to beautify (it), to render beautiful or pleasing'; +`to build, rear up sth, to make sth ready (i.e. "to complete, finish sth"?), to order sth (i.e. "put sth in order"), to make sth prosper, to prosper sth; to dress, till (earth, ground)' { relationship to |wunnohteau|, 203b? cf. Ex.40.18 infr.; also |wonteau|, 197a }
\so Is.60.13
    \xv ... kah upponuh tanohketeaonganit Eden, ∞nteauunat, kah wunnanauwchteauunat.
    \xe ..., and put him in the garden of Eden to dress it and to keep it.
    \so Gen.2.15
    \ng 3->0 t-subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah Abel assamau sheepsoh, kah Kain ∞nehteaun ohke.
    \xe .... And Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.
    \so Gen.4.2
    \ng 3->0 subordinative?
    \nt +
    \xv noh wunnehteou nishnoh teag
    \xe he has made everything beautiful
    \so Eccl.3.11
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \xv ..., newutche Jehovah ∞wetomuh, kah ne asit, Jehovah ∞nteauun.
    \xe ...; because the Lord was with him, and that which he did, the Lord made it to prosper.
    \so Gen.39.23
    \ng syncopated
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wunnéhteau wuttátuppequanumuk, kah weechauau ummissinninnúmoh.
    \xe And he made ready his chariot, and took his people with him:
    \so Ex.14.6
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Moses wunnehteau pummuwuttauwáekommuk, kah ponum mortisash, kah wunnohtou pahso∞nogquash, kah wunnohtóu qunnunktogquash, kah wussukómpadtau neepattunkquongash.
    \xe And Moses reared up the tabernacle, and fastened his sockets, and set up the boards thereof, and put in the bars thereof, and reared up his pillars.
    \so Ex.40.18
    \nt +

    \xv Wunnehteauan ohke yeu wutche onk yean, matta pish kittinnumunkou ummissetuonk,...
    \xe When thou tillest the ground, it shall not henceforth yield unto thee her strength;...
    \so Gen.4.12; (E0): |Wunnèhteauan|
    \ng 2->0 conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., wunnehteauan nummay uttôh ayoi.
    \xe ..., if thou do prosper my way which I go:
    \so Gen.24.42
    \ng 2->0 conjunct; possibly AV "do" as causative, but transitive use of "prosper" also attested, OED, s.v. 2
    \nt +

    \se |wunnehteauáe|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN
    \ge `prosperous'
    \so Gen.39.2
    \xv Onk Jehovah wetomau Josephoh, kah wunnehteauáe wosketomp,...
    \xe And the LORD was with Joseph, and he was a prosperous man;...
    \so Gen.39.2

\lx wunneneheónat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 203
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\ge `to do well toward (or do good to) another'; +`to deal well with sb'
    \so Gen.27.46,32.9; Deut.5.29; Lk.6.33; 1 Cor.15.32
    \nt +
    \xv ...: Jakob ummittumwussit wuttaunoh Heth, ..., toh woh nuttine wunnenehukqun nuppomantamóonk?
    \xe ...: if Jacob take a wife of the daughters of Heth, ..., what good shall my life do me?
    \so Gen.27.46
    \ng 0->1
    \nt +
    \xv ... Qushkish en kutohket, kah en kutawâmóohtu, kah pish k∞nenehush.
    \xe ..., Return unto thy country, and to thy kindred, and I will deal well with thee:
    \so Gen.32.9
    \ng 1->2
    \nt +
    \xv Onk pish nnih, neane Jehovah wekontam∞ónukqueog k∞nenehukqunnaóut, kah kummuttaanhukqunnaóut,...
    \xe And it shall come to pass, that as the Lord rejoiced over you to do you good, and to multiply you;...
    \so Deut.5.29
    \ng 3->2p, t-sub.
    \nt +
    \xv wunnenehikk∞
    \xe (do not my words) do good to (him)
    \so Mic.2.7
    \xv woh k∞neneheoóog
    \xe (when) ye may do them good
    \so Mk.14.7

    \xv Kah wuneneheog nág wánenehukqueogig, ne toh unne wunnegen? ...
    \xe And if ye do good to them which do good to you, what thank have ye? ...
    \so Lk.6.33√
    \ng 2p->3p; 3p->2p

    \xv Newutche wunuhkomog wunnenéheontuh wame, nahnáunneu peh nnag, wunnamptamóe neadtahshinnéhettit.
    \xe As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all men, especially unto them who are of the household of faith.
    \so Gal.6.10√

    \se |wunnenehu(w)om∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \dv II in |-m∞u-| to AI from TA with indefinite object in |-uwá-|
    \ge `to profit, to avail'
    \so Rom.2.25; Gal.6.15
    \xv Newutche quôshqusausuonk, wunnamuhkut wunnenehuómm∞, nanauwehheadt naumatuonk ...
    \xe For circumcision verily profiteth, if thou keep the law:...
    \so Rom.2.25
    \xv Newutche ut Christ Jesusut quoshqusausuonk wanne tohhen wunnenehuwomun∞, asuh matta quoshqusauséonk, qut wuske oâas.
    \xe For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision, but a new creature.
    \so Gal.6.15

\dv |wunne-unneheonat|.

\lx wunnepog
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 203
\dv ? + |-epag(u)| NI `leaf'
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a leaf'
\nt G&B.685
\so Lev.26.36; Is.64.6
    (|wonnepog|)    Job 13.25
    (|Wunnëpog, wosh.| `A leaf, leaves'    C.16/164)√
    \xv ∞nepog
    \xe his leaf
    \so Jer.17.8
    (|ooneepog|    Mass.Ps., Ps.1.3)
    pl. +|quash|    Dan.4.12,14
    \xv meechu wunnepogquash
    \xe he eats herbs
    \so Rom.14.2
    = |wunnepaquash|    Ps.105.35
    = |wunnepukquash|    Mk.4.32
    \xv ut n∞chumwe wunnepogqut
    \xe on the tender herb
    \so Deut.32.2

    \xe an olive leaf
    \so Gen.8.11
    \ng "head first" attribution
    \nt +

    \xe Better is a dinner of herbs where love is,...
    \so Prov.15.17√
\cf weesadtippogquosh
\ge bitter herbs
\so Ex.12.8
\so Num.9.11

[Narragansett [xnt] |Wunnèpog-guash| `Leafe, leaves'    R.W.92/r.94.√
Delaware [del] |wu ni pak|; |waníipakw| NI `leaf'    Zeisb.Voc.35; O'M.332b.
    Western Abenaki [abe] |pen8bagat| `Feuilles t'bent'; |8émibagat.| `Leurs feuilles s't de la g'deur qu'elles doivent être'    248/455b;30/386b.
    \nt +
Algonquian [alg] |-BAK| `feuille'    Cq.75a.
Cree |Pakwew| `désigne les feuilles.'    Lac.G.87, no.63.
K. |-ipak-| `leaf'    V.154.
Lp.A |8nibac8sa[u]| `Les feuilles poussen[t]', |skipagat| `Les feuilles sont vertes', |kizi bac sa[u] `Les feuilles son[t] grandes', |pinipagat| `Les feüilles tombent'    D.19.
Mahican [mjy] |wanépak|, plur. |wa@nëpá@chquàn| `Blatt'    Schm.90.
Menominee [mez] |-εpakw| `leaf'    B.1962, 14.323, 262
Miami |-epakw| NI `leaf'    B&C.38a.
WAbn. |wanibagw| `leaf'    D.1.475.]

\et The Delaware form, if nothing else, presumably disposes of the connection with |wunne| suggested at T.286b. While the initial is unclear, the final reflects H. p.248 *-pakw `leaf'; on |weesadtippogquosh| `bitter herbs', cf. H.4017 *wi∙?sakepak- NI `smartweed' (with palatalized *k, from proto *-i- therefore).


\lx wunnesenat

\lx wunnetoöahta@ui@nat
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]

    3d pers. |∞"netoöahta@ui@nat| `to make (it) good'    C.226


\lx wunneetu
\va wunnetu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 203
    \nt +
\ps AI, i-stem
\twn |wunnegen|, II
\dv wun- `good' + |-ek-i-| `grow'; there are reasons to doubt this as a general synchronic analysis, as witness: the apparent long-vowel 2 indicative form (Ps.119.68), and the 3 conjunct form in |-k| (perhaps influenced by the II twin??). The |-t-| itself appears to have been levelled into forms of the conjunct, for instance.
\ge `to be beautiful, (very) fair, good, goodly, well-favoured' (usually of bodily appearance, but also axiological), and a range of other less common uses; collocated with |pannupp-|: `perfect'
\so Gen.6.2,9,17.1,24.16,26.7,29.17,39.6; Ex.2.2; 1 Cor.2.6; 1 Tim.4.4; Tit.2.5
    \xv ...: Noah sampweusseaen, kah pannuppu wunneetou ut uppometuonganit,...
    \xe ...: Noah was a just man and perfect in his generations,...
    \so Gen.6.9
    \ng 3 indicative
    \xv Onk nunksquau wunneetu m∞cheke móneaúonat,...
    \xe And the damsel was very fair to look upon,...
    \so Gen.24.16
    \xv ..., kah Joseph tapenunkqussu, kah wunnetu.
    \xe ... And Joseph was a goodly person, and well-favoured.
    \so Gen.39.6
    \xv ... kah wunnaumonaieu, onk wunnauouh wunnetu kah wuttattashuh nishuoh nepauzóh.
    \xe ..., and bare a son: and when she saw him, that he was a goodly child, she hid him three months.
    \so Ex.2.2
    \xv Ken k∞netum, kah k∞[n]ésem:...
    \xe Thou art good, and doest good:...
    \so Ps.119.68; (M) |koonetum|
    \xv OOwaantamunnaóut, kohkonantamunnaóut, apitcheg wekuóut, wunnetuog, n∞swehtawaog nehenwonche wessukóuh,...
    \xe To be discreet, chaste, keepers at home, good, obedient to their husbands,...
    \so Tit.2.5

    \xv Wunne énne woi Jehovah, neg waneetukeg:...
    \xe Do good, O Lord, unto those that be good,...
    \so Ps.125.4; (M) |wanetugik|
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \xv Neen wunneetou nanánont she(p)soh, wanetuk nanawunont shepsoh mag∞wanshau shepsoh ukketeaonk.
    \xe I am the good shepherd: the good shepherd giveth his life for the sheep.
    \so Jn.10.11  { _3_ participle }; (M) |wunnet∞e| (both tokens)
    \xv ..., jishánumoncheg neh wanetinutcheh.
    \xe ..., despisers of those that are good,'    Tit.3.3  { _3
    \so _ participle }

    \xv ..., pompomusháush anaquabeh kah pannuppe wunneetush.
    \xe ..., walk before me, and be thou perfect.
    \so Gen.17.1
    \ng 2 imperative

\et G.1981, 38, p.74, 39, p.77, 42, pp.88-89: PEA *w@rïk@w, PA **welikiwa.


\lx wunnetue

    \xe ... he which sat ... at the Beautiful gate of the temple:...
    \so Acts 3.10
    \nt +
    \xv wunnetou
    \xe a good man
    \so Ps.112.5; Mt.12.35

\ge rich

\lx wunnetuonk

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\lx wunnetupanatam
\va wunneetupanatam
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 203
    \nt +
\ps TI1a(-O)
\twn |wunnetupanumau|, TA
\ge `to be holy, to be edified, sanctified'
\so Lk.2.23, Acts 9.31,41,20.32, Rom.8.27, 1 Cor.7.34, Tit.1.8, Rev.4.8,13.7
    \xv (Neansukwhôsik ut wuttinnaumatuonkanit God, Nishnoh wosketomp wôshwunont ôontomukqut, pish hennau wunneetupanatam en Godut.)
    \xe (As it is written in the law of the Lord, Every male that openeth the womb shall be called holy to the Lord;)
    \so Lk.2.23
    \xv ..., kah matta anwôhsinóog kesukodtáe kah nukkonae, n∞waog, Wunneetupanatam, wunneetupanatam, wunneetupanatam, LORD GOD wame manuhkésit. ...
    \xe ...: and they rest not day and night, saying, Holy, holy, holy, Lord God Almighty,...
    \so Rev.4.8

    \xv Kah wussogkenutchanoh, wutashinuh, kah wehkomont waneetupanatamunutcheh, kah sekousquoh, wunnahtuhkonuh keteáu.
    \xe And he gave her his hand, and lifted her up, and when he had called the saints and widows, presented her alive.
    \so Acts 9.41
    \xv ..., kah anumungqueog, {wunngen} ahtoonk k∞wutche wame wunneetupanatogig.
    \xe ..., and to give you an inheritance among all them which are sanctified.
    \so Acts.20.32
    \xv Newutche wosketompaog pish womononcheg nehenwonche wuhhogkauh, iahchewontogig, waeenowacheg, pahtuanumutcheg, blasphemacheg, mat n∞swehtauonkig ∞chetuongan∞uh, mat tabuttantam∞gig, mat waneetupanatam∞gig.
    \xe For men shall be lovers of their own selves, covetous, boasters, proud, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy,
    \so 2 Tim.3.2

    \se wunnetupanatamweyeu∞
    \ps AI
    \twn |wunnetupanatamweyeu∞|, II
    \ge `to be holy'
    \xv ... neg pish wunneetupanatamweyeu∞og en Jehovahut, wutche sephausuen.
    \xe ...: they [sacrificial lambs and goats] shall be holy to the Lord for the priest.
    \so Lev.23.20
    \xv Newutche wussukwhosu, wunneetupanatamweyeu∞k, newutche n∞neetupanatamweyeu.
    \xe Because it is written, Be ye holy; for I am holy.
    \so 1 Pet.1.16
    \xv Wunnanumau kah wunneetupanatamweyeu∞ noh nohwodtohtunk negonne omohkeonk:...
    \xe Blessed and holy is he that hath part in the first resurrection:...
    \so Rev.20.6

    \xv ..., yeush wussinneash noh waneetupanatamwayeuit, noh wunnamuhkutéyeuit,...
    \xe ...; These things saith he that is holy, he that is true,...
    \so Rev.3.7

    \xv ..., kah noh wanetupanatamwéyeuit, wowunneetupanatamweyeuitch.
    \xe ...: and he that is holy, let him be holy still.
    \so Rev.22.11

    \se wunnetupanatamweyeu∞
    \ps II
    \twn |wunnetupanatamweyeu∞|, AI
    \ge `to be holy'
    \so Ex.29.33,34,37,30.10,29.32, Lev.6.17,25, Rom.11.16, 1 Cor.3.17
    \xv ..., kah matta pish penuwot ummeechuun, newutche nish wunneetupanatamweyeu∞ash.
    \xe ...: but a stranger shall not eat thereof, because they are holy.
    \so Ex.29.33

    \xv Newutche kakenúmunneash wunneetupanatamweyeú∞uk, kah musseu wonk, kah wadchábuk wunneetupanatamweyeu∞k, neit wonk wutuhqunash.
    \xe For if the first fruit be holy, the lump is also holy: and if the root be holy, so are the branches.
    \so Rom.11.16

    \se wunnetupanatamwaheau
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to hallow, sanctify sb'
    \so Ex.29.1,33, Lev.20.8, Jn.10.36,17.17,19, 1 Cor.7.14, Heb.2.11, Jude 1
    \xv Newutch matta wanamptam∞g wessukiin wunneetupanatamwáheau nashpe ummittamwussoh, & matta wanamptam∞k ummitamwussin wunneetupanatamwaheau nashpe wessukeh,...
    \xe For the unbelieving husband is sanctified by the wife, and the unbelieving wife i sanctified by the husband:...
    \so 1 Cor.7.14

    \xv KAh yeu pish anheadt noghok, wunneetupánatamwáheat,...
    \xe And this is the thing that thou shalt do unto them to hallow them,...
    \so Ex.29.1
    \xv ...: nen Jéhovah, noh waneetupanatamwahikqueóg.
    \xe ...: I am the Lord which sanctify you.
    \so Lev.20.8
    \ng not 1->2p
    \xv Newutche noh waneetupanatamwahuwadt, kah neg wanetupanatamwahetcheg, nag wame pasuk∞∞og,...
    \xe For both he that sanctifieth and they who are sanctified are all of one:...
    \so Heb.2.11

    \xv Nag wunneetupanatamwah nashpe k∞namuhkuteyeu∞onk, kuttinn∞waonk wunnamuhkuteyeu∞.
    \xe Sanctifie them through thy truth: thy word is truth.
    \so Jn.17.17; (M): |wunnetupantamwah|

    \se wunnetupanatamwahteau
    \ps TI2, causative
    \ge `to hallow, sanctify sth'
    \so Ex.29.43,40.9, Lev.8.30,21.23,25.10,27.17
    \xv ..., kah tabernacle pish wunneetupanatamwahteauun nashpe nussohsumóonk.
    \xe ..., and the tabernacle shall be sanctified by my glory.
    \so Ex.29.43
    \xv ..., kah pish k∞neetupanatúmwàtin, kah wame auwohteaóngash noh ut, kah pish wunneetupanatamweyeu∞.
    \xe ..., and shalt hallow it, and all the vessels thereof: and it shall be holy.
    \so Ex.40.9

    |..., | newutche nen Jehovah nish waneetupanatamwahteauonish.| `...: for I the Lord do sanctify them.'    Lev.21.23 { taking |-ish| as hbitual/iterative }
    |Wunnetupanatamwahtunk wutohteuk wutch Jubile kodtum∞ut, neyaunag k∞n∞hamóonk ne pish n nih.| `If he sanctify his field from the year of jubile, according to thy estimation it shall stand.    Lev.27.17

    \se wunnetupanatamwahteauau
    \ps TA+O
    \ge `to hallow sth unto sb'
    \so Lev.22.2

    \xv ..., nag matta woh nishketeou∞og n∞neetupanatamwe wesuonk, ut yeush waneetupanatamwahtiéhetticheh,...
    \xe ..., and that they profane not my holy name in those things which they hallow unto me:...
    \so Lev.22.2

\lx wunnishitteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 203
    \nt +
\ps TI2
\dv |wun-| `in order' + |-shi-| II `fall' + |-t-| TI2 (B.1962, 16.46)
\ge `to lay sth (in order)'
\so Gen.22.9; Heb.6.1
    \xv ..., kah Abraham na wuttit ayimun Altar, kah wunishitteau wuttuhqunash,...
    \xe ...; and Abraham built an altar there, and laid the wood in order,...
    \so Gen.22.9
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \xv ... ontuh en panuphettuonganit, matta wonk wunnishitteauunat ne quenohtag aiuskoianatamôonk ...
    \xe ..., let us go on unto perfection; not laying again the foundation of repentance ...
    \so Heb.6.1
    \ng X->0 t-negative subordinative


\lx wunniyeu
\va wunnaiyeu
\va ∞na yeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 203
\ps adj. an. (?) / AI
\ge `(he is) happy'
\so Job 5.17; Ps.127.5; 137.8,9
    \nt Remark: See under |wunne| for 1, 2 forms, in |-unni| and conjunct forms. This verb is presumably to be analyzed as |wun-| `good' etc. + |aye-| `to be'. The latter shows 1, 2 forms such as |nuttai|, v.s. 20a.
    \nt +
    \xv noh wunniyeu
    \xe happy is he who
    \so Prov.16.20
    \xv anue wunniyeu
    \xe more happy
    \so 1 Cor.7.40
    (|sun ... wunniyeuog| `are (they) well?'    C.225)
\cf wunne
\cf wunnegen

\lx wunnogque
\va wunogk∞e
\va wunne-hogk
\ve =  `good-bodied or well-covered'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
\ps adj.
\ge `fat'
\so 1 Sam.28.24; Ezek.34.20

    \se wunogk∞
    \va wunnogk∞
    \nt !
    \ps AI
    \ge `to be, become fat'
    \xv ..., kah pish wunogk∞og,...
    \xe ... they shall have ... waxen fat;...
    \so Deut.31.20√; Ps.92.14
    \xv ..., kah Eglon mo ahche wunogk∞.
    \xe ...: and Eglon was a very fat man.
    \so Judg.3.17√

    \xv ..., nemskomah na wutch neesog goatsemesog wónogqutcheg,...
    \xe ..., and fetch me from thence two good kids of the goats;...
    \so Gen.27.9; Ps.22.29
    \nt +

    \se !|wunnogk∞onk|
    \nt +
    \ps NI
    \ge `fatness'
    \so Gen.27.28,39
    \xv ... GOD anninnumungqush néchipog wutch kesukquiug, kah ∞nogk∞onk ohke,...
    \xe ... God give thee of the dew of heaven, and the fatness of the earth,...
    \so Gen.27.28
    \ng derivative of II verb expected?

    \se !|wunnogk∞m∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II
    \ge `to be fat'
    \so Gen.49.20; Ps.119.70
    \xv Wuttahh∞woash wunnogk∞m∞ash onatuh pummeit;...
    \xe Their heart is as fat as grease:...
    \so Ps.119.70; (M) |wunnogkoomoo| (with singular subject)

[Narragansett [xnt] |Wauwunockôo.| `It is fat'    R.W.167/r.175.
    Fx. |anakwiwa| `he is fat'    Fx.L.30.
    \nt +
Miami-Illinois [mia] |8irin8a| `le gras, lard d'ours. it. il est gas.'    Grv.398/237a.
Menominee [mez] |ona∙kow| AI `he is fat'    B.1975.106.
Shawnee [sjw] |holakw-| `FAT', |noolakwipe| `we are fat', |weelakwita| `one who is fat', |noolakweewe| `I am fat bodied'    D.-V.453.]

\et G.1981, 39, 78 *welakowa AI `he is fat', without evidence; G.2002.57, (201) *weLakwiwa, presumably implying skepticism about the apparent initial, and therefore about Trumbull's suggestion.

\lx wunohkoNau
\va wunnohkoNau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
    \nt +
\ps TA, applicative
\ge `to be at, make peace with sb, be reconciled to sb'
\so Deut.20.12; Josh.11.19; Ps.7.4(E&M),55.20(E1&M); 1 Cor.7.11; 1 Thess.5.13
    \xv ..., onk woh n∞nohkonuk,...
    \xe ..., that he may make peace with me;...
    \so Is.27.5
    \ng 3->1
    \xv ..., ayeuau ummatwomoh ∞nuhkonukqunnat.
    \xe ..., he maketh even his enemies to be at peace with him.'    Prov.16.7  { 3->3
    \so t-subordinative }

    \xv Kah matta wunohkonukk∞an, qut ayeuuhkonukquean, neit pish kukquinupuhkauóog.
    \xe And if it will make no peace with thee, but will make war against thee, then thou shalt besiege it:
    \so Deut.20.12
    \xv Na matta keitotan ne wanohkonont wunnaumonuh Israel:...
    \xe There was not a city that made peace with the children of Israel,...
    \so Josh.11.19
    \xv Onkquodtaúogis matcheseonk wonohkasit ...
    \xe If I have rewarded evil unto him that was at peace with me ...
    \so Ps.7.4; (M) |wanuhkosuhp|
    \ng 3->1 (preterite) participle

    \xv Qut amait, wetauadteakitch, asuh wonk wunohkononch wessukeh,...
    \xe But and if she depart, let her remain unmarried, or be reconciled to her husband:...
    \so 1 Cor.7.11
    \xv Kah womausue mishanum∞k, wutche wutanakausuongan∞, kah wunohkonittegk.
    \xe And to esteem them very highly in love for their work's sake. And be at peace among yourselves.
    \so 1 Thess.5.13

\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
    \xv pish wunohquodt
    \xe it will be fair weather
    \so Mt.16.2
    (|weeko@hquat| `fair weather'
    \xv wunnohquat
    \xe pleasant weather
    \xv wekeneankquat
    \xe warm weather
    \so C.158)
\cf onnöhquat

[Narragansett [xnt] |wekineaûquat| `fair weather' R.W.81.]


\lx wunnóhteahuau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
    See following lemma.
    \nt +


\lx wunohteau
\va wunnohteau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
    \nt +
\nt Remark: The semantic connection with |wunohkonau| (v.s.) suggests that the |-t(e)-| derives from palatalization. This would rule out a connection with |wunnohteauunát|, the following lemma. It is not yet clear whether the apparently transitive examples (e.g. Josh.10.4) are to a distinct TA stem.
\ps AI+O? (TA?)
\ge very varied, equivalent to "to (come to) be at peace, reconciled"; `to make peace with sb'
\nt G&B.742-743
\so Gen.43.23,27; Josh.10.1,4; Mk.5.34; Lk.24.36; Jn.20.19,21; Acts 24.2; Rom.5.10; 2 Cor.5.19,13.11; Gal.6.16; 3 Jn.14
    \xv ...  kah wadohkitcheg Gibeon, wunohteaog Israelloh, kah ∞wéamukshonuh.
    \xe ...; and how the inhabitants of Gibeon had made peace with Israel, and were among them.
    \so Josh.10.1

    \xv ..., Wajeh mishe wunnohteaog nashpe ken,...
    \xe ..., Seeing that by thee we enjoy great quietness,...
    \so Acts 24.2
    \xv Newutche áyeuwéhteaénueog n∞nohteaunnómun GOD, nashpe wunnupp∞onk Wunnaumonuh, ánue m∞cheke, mahche wunnohteaog, n∞wadchanitteamun nashpe uppomantamóonk.
    \xe For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son, much more, being reconciled, we shall be saved by his life.
    \so Rom.5.10
    \ng |n∞nohteaunnómun| an |-un-| derivative, 1p->3? Sense hard to gauge since AV passive rendered in peculiar, though not unusual fashion.

    \xv Onk wuttinuh wunohteagk, ahque wabesek,...
    \xe And he said, Peace {be} to you, fear not:...
    \so Gen.43.23
    \xv ..., monchish wunnohteash, kah neetskésish wutch kummahchinâonk.
    \xe ...; go in peace, and be whole of thy plague.
    \so Mk.5.34
    \xv ..., pannuppe wunnet∞k, wutt∞anatam∞k, weechetahhodtegk, wunnohteagk,...
    \xe .... Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace;...
    \so 2 Cor.13.11
    \xv Kah ne adttahshe pomushahettit neyane yeu quttuhwheganit, wunnohteahettich,...
    \xe And as many as walk according to this rule, peace be on them,...
    \so Gal.6.16

    \se wunnohteaheau
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge varied, e.g. `to be the author of peace, to make atonement for sb, to reconcile sb ((un)to sb)'
    \so Lev.1.4; 1 Cor.14.33; 2 Cor.5.19; Gal.3.20; Eph.2.15,16; Heb.2.17
    \xv ..., kah pish kitteámonteanittamwe tapenaumauon wutche nagum, wutche wunnohteaheonat.
    \xe ...; and it shall be accepted for him to make atonement for him.
    \so Lev.1.4
    \xv Ne yeu, GOD ut Christut wunnohteaheau ut wuhhogkat muttaok,...
    \xe To wit, that God was in Christ, reconciling the world unto himself,...
    \so 2 Cor.5.19

    \xv Kah wame teanteaguashinish wutchayeum∞ash Godut, noh wonohteahikqueog ut wuhhogkat, nashpe Jesus Christ,...
    \xe And all things are of God, who hath reconciled us to himself by Jesus Christ,...
    \so 2 Cor.5.18
    \ng _3_->1p participle

    \se wunohteahuau
    \ps AI, indefinite final
    \ge `to make peace'
    \so Ps.147.14
    \xv Wunnóhteahuau ut wohkôeu:...
    \xe He maketh peace in thy borders:...
    \so Ps.147.14; (M) |wunnohteahhuwau|
    \ng 3 indicative
    \xv Newutche GOD matta nanwonyeumwohh∞wóou, qut wunnohteahuwón,...
    \xe For God is not the author of confusion, but of peace,...
    \so 1 Cor.14.33
    \ng X subordinative
    \xv ..., onk woh ayimun ut wuhhogkat, neesuog, pasuk woskosketomp, nemehkuh wunohteahuwon. / Onk woh naneswe wunohteahuau ut Godut ut pasuk∞inneat muhhog,...
    \xe ...; for to make in himself of twain one new man, so making peace; / And that he might reconcile both unto God in one body ...
    \so Eph.2.15-16

    \se wunnohteaonk(an
    \ps NI, deverbal noun
    \ge `peace; welfare'
    \so frequent
    \xv ..., naish ∞nohteaongan∞ kematog onk wunnihettit floksog,...
    \xe ..., see whether it be well with thy brethren, and well with the flocks;...
    \so Gen.37.14
    \ng Marginale: "+{Hebr. see the peace of thy brethren &c.}"

    \se wunohteaongane
    \ps PreN
    \ge `of peace'
    \so Rom.3.17; Phil.4.9
    \xv Kah wunohteaongane may wanne wahteau∞og.
    \xe And the way of peace have they not known:
    \so Rom.3.17
    \xv ...: kah wunnohteaongane GOD pish k∞wetómukou.
    \xe ...: and the God of peace shall be with you.
    \so Phil.4.9

    \se wunohteaonganu
    \ps II, verb of being
    \ge `for peace to be (un)to sth, to be peaceable'
    \so Lk.10.4; Jas.3.17
    \xv Qut ne waantamóonk wutche waabe, negonne pohkoi, neit wunohteaonganeu∞, nanauwussuonganú∞, kah nukkume nanompassumau,...
    \xe But the wisdome that is from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, and easy to be entreated,...
    \so Jas.3.17

    \xv Kah nishnoh wetu kuppetukoneau, negonne n∞waog, Wunohteaonganuutch yeu wetu.
    \xe And into whatsoever house ye enter, first say, Peace be to this house.
    \so Lk.10.5

    \se wunohteae
    \va wunnohteae
    \va wunohteaeu
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `of peace; in peace, peaceably'
    \so frequent
    \xv ..., qut kenaau wunohteae monchek en k∞sh∞wóut.
    \xe ...; and as for you, get you up in peace unto your father.
    \so Gen.44.17
    \xv ..., an∞nau an∞naénuh, kah kodtantam wunnohteae unnaiyeuongash,
    \xe ..., he sendeth an embassage and desireth conditions of peace.
    \so Lk.14.32
    \xv ..., Uttoh n∞wunnegen wusseet∞oash neg kohk∞tumuhteacheg wunohteae wunnussetongquot,...
    \xe ..., How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the gospel of peace,...
    \so Rom.10.15
    \xv ..., wunnohteae weechayeum∞k wame missinninnuog.
    \xe ..., live peaceably with all men.
    \so Rom.12.18


\lx wunnohteauunát
\va wunnehteau
\ve = , 202b?
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
\ps v.t. / TI2
\twn |wunnashau|
\ge `to set up, to erect, +to rear sth up'; +`to order sth' i.e. "to put, keep sth in order"
    \xv ..., Aaron pish ∞nahtauun, wutch wunnonk∞ut yean mohtompanit,...
    \xe ..., shall Aaron order it [the light] from the evening unto the morning ...
    \so Lev.24.3
    \nt +
    \xv Ut pahke wequananteganuhtugqut, pish ∞nteauun wequanantegash, anaquabit Jehovah. yeayatcheh.
    \xe He shall order the lamps upon the pure candlestick before the Lord continually.
    \so Lev.24.4
    \nt +
    \xv wunnohtóog
    \xe they set up
    \so (towers)    Is.23.13

    \xv Kah ne kesukok Tabernakle mahche wunohtomuk, matohkqs nuhkuhkom Tabernakle kah wauwáe weetu;...
    \xe And on the day that the tabernacle was reared up the cloud covered the tabernacle, namely, the tent of the testimony:...
    \so Num.9.15
    \nt +

    \xv Wunnohtauush nuttontannehtuonkash kuttinoowaonkanut:...
    \xe Order my steps in thy word:...
    \so Ps.119.133(M); (E): |OOnahtaash|
    \nt +
\cf wunnash(au)

\et As |wunnashau|, with final *-?t- TI2 (i.e. *-ap-t-)


\lx wunnomatehtahwhau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
    \nt +
\nt Remark: Relationship to following lemma still uncertain, though some examples may reflect the "by tool" sense of the final. What the collocation |-eht-ahw-| implies is not obvious to me, nor is identity of the first element.
\ps TA
\ge `to chase, follow after, persecute sb'
\so Ex.14.4; Deut.11.4; Ps.35.5,6,71.11(M),83.15(M); Mt.23.34
    \xv Newutche matta mehquantamoop monanukkonat, qut wunnomattehtwhop matchekoo kah quenawehkooenin,...
    \xe Because that he remembred not to shew mercy, but p[er]secuted the poor and needy man,...
    \so Ps.109.16(M); (E): |woskeheau|
    \xv Sontimoog noonomattehthukuppaneg tohnoooche:...
    \xe Princes have persecuted me without a cause:...
    \so Ps.119.161(M); (E): |n∞woskehukquog|
    \ng 3p->1
    \xv ..., kah nawhutche woh kussasamatahh∞óog ut kussynagogsumm∞òut, kah woh k∞nomatteihtahh∞oog wutch otanat en otanat.
    \xe ...; and some of them shall ye scourge in your synagogues, and persecute them from city to city:
    \so Mt.23.34; (E1): |k∞nomateihtahh∞óoog|

    \xv ..., uttoh anteunkup misque ketahhane nippe wunnetippannonat, nag wanomatehtohukqueog,...
    \xe ...; how he made the water of the Red sea to overflow them as they pursued after you,...
    \so Deut.11.4
    \ng 3->2p

    \xv ...: kah wut angelsumoh GOD wunnaumatehtahwhonch.
    \xe ...: and let the angel of the Lord chase them.
    \so Ps.35.5
    \xv ...: wunnomattehthook kah tohqunoohk ...
    \xe ...: persecute and take him;...
    \so Ps.71.11(M)
    \xv Nag ne inne wunnomattehtah nashpe kummisshehtahshinneum,...
    \xe So persecute them with thy tempest,...
    \so Ps.83.15(M); (E): |woskeh|


\lx wunnomatuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
    \nt +
\ps TA, |-hk-aw-| stem
\ge `to chase, follow after, hunt, persecute, pursue, run after sb' (Note OED s.v. "persecute." +1.: "To pursue, chase, hunt, drive (with missiles, or with attempts to catch, kill or injure). {Obs.}", and B&W. 257, on usage in OT of AV.)
\so Gen.14.14,15; Ps.7.5(E&M),18.37(E&M),35.5(M),71.11,140.11(M); Mt.23.34??; Jude 11
    \xv ..., kah ∞nomatuhkaouh Dan wehque.
    \xe ..., and [he] pursued them unto Dan.
    \so Gen.14.14; Gen.14.15: |∞namatuhkaóuh|
    \xv N∞nômahtúhkôomp nummatwóog, kah nummátanôog,...
    \xe I have pursued mine enemies, & overtaken them:...
    \so Ps.18.37; (M): |Noonomatuhkouomp|
    \xv ...: chekeunnehhuwaenin, machuhk pish oonomattoohkunkqun, ukkepuhkonukqunnat.
    \xe ...: evil shall hunt the violent man to overthrow him.
    \so Ps.140.11(M)

    \xv Matwau wunnômattuhkauonch nukketeahogkounuh, kah tohqunonch,...
    \xe Let the enemy persecute my soul, and take it,...
    \so Ps.7.5; (M): |wunnamatuhkauonch|
    \xv ...: wunômohtuhkau kah tohqun, newutche matta howan uppohquohwhunoh,
    \xe ...: persecute and take him, for there is none to deliver him.
    \so Ps.71.11

    \se wunnomatuhkom
    \ps TI1
    \ge `to run after sth'
    \so Jude 11
    \xv ..., newutche nag auog ut ummayut Kain, kah nehnehteáe wunnamatuhkomwog uppanneusseonk Balaam wutche onkquatunk,...
    \xe ...! for they have gone in the way of Cain, and ran greedily after the error of Balaam for reward,...
    \so Jude 11

\lx wunnompewessu

    \xe ..., Behold an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile!

    \nt +

    \nt +

\lx wunnomwau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
    \nt +
\ps AI
\dv final |-(a)m(w)-| `by mouth, by speech', as B.1962, 16.13, 332? (See 16.155, 359 for an allomorph with |-w-|.) Snag: TA final, and verb appears to be intransitive; middle reflexive would be in |-wi-| (B.1962, 16.11, 332, G&B item 11, 580). Hewson (p.249) lists a final |-we∙-| `sound'.
\ge `say the truth, say truly, say well, speak right'
    \xv Wuttaunoh Zelophehad wunnomwaog,...
    \xe The daughters of Zelophehad speak right:...
    \so Num.27.7
    \xv ... K∞nomwam matta n∞wasukoiyeu.
    \xe ..., Thou hast well said, I have no husband:
    \so Jn.4.17; (M): |K∞ne unn∞wàm|
    \xv ..., ne kuttin wunnomwón.
    \xe ...: in that saidst thou truly.
    \so Jn.4.18; (M): |ne kuttut wunnomwón|
    \xv ..., Suñummatta n∞nomwómun ken Wussamaritane, kah kutappéhtunk mattanit?

    \so Jn.8.48

    \xv ...? Kah wunnomwáeeyán, tohwutch mo wunnamptiéog.
    \xe ...? And if I say the truth, why do ye not believe me?' { more likely to be |wunnomwáe eyán| i.e. PreV + |yi-| `to say
    \so ? See under this lemma, 214b. }    Jn.8.46; (M): |unn∞waon wunnomwaonk|

    \se wunnomwom∞
    \ps II
    \dv AI stem, with the normal default II final
    \ge `to be true'
    |..., kah n∞wahteómun ∞wauwaonk | wunnomwóm∞.| `...: and we know that his testimony is true.'    Jn.21.24; (M): |wunnomwaonkanu∞| i.e. denominal II

    \xe ...: but all things that John spake of this man were true.
    \so Jn.10.41; (M): |wunnomwaonkanupash| i.e. denominal II

\lx wunn∞wáonk
\va wunne-n∞wáonk
\va wunn∞waong
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
\ps n. / NI
\nt G&B.744
\ge `a covenant, an agreement'
    \xv n∞n∞wáonk
    \xe my covenant
