    \xe make a covenant with me by a present
    \so Is.36.16


\lx wunn∞wónat
\va wunn∞wau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 204
\ps v.t. an. / AI(+O)
\dv |wun-| `good, in order' + |-ow-á-| `by talk'
\ge `to make a league with', +`to make a covenant with sb'
\so Dan.11.6
\nt G&B.745 AI `they agree'
    \nt Remark: Often with plural subject, in effect as reciprocal. This appears to translate a large number of different AV verbs (e.g. "agree, avouch, band together, concord, consent, conspire, determine, make a covenant"), with considerable polysemy, if this is indeed a single lexeme. Most cases seem to involve collective acts involving speech. Only a few of the cases are currently exemplified here. There can be no doubt that there is a basic AI verb here, but the transitive uses are occasionally puzzling.
    \nt +
    `to covenant with'
    \xv Ne kesuksukok [sic] Jehovah wunn∞wau Abramoh, n∞wau, En k∞skannemunut nummagun yeu ohke wutch Egypt sepuut, onk yean, kehteihtukqut Euphrates.
    \xe In the same day the Lord made a covenant with Abram, saying, Unto thy seed have I given this land, from the river of Egypt unto the great river, the river Euphrates:
    \so Gen.15.18
    \nt +
    \xv ...: onk neeswe wunn∞waog
    \xe ...; and both of them made a covenant.
    \so Gen.21.27
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu kesukok k∞n∞wam Jehovah kum-Manitt∞munneat,...
    \xe Thou hast avouched the LORD this day to be thy God,...
    \so Deut.26.17
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jehovah yeu kesukok wunn∞wau kenaau ummissinninneumunneat,...
    \xe And the Lord hath avouched thee this day to be his peculiar people,...
    \so Deut.26.18
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah uttoh woh kittin wunn∞wonan.
    \xe ...; and how shall we make a league with you?
    \so Josh.9.7
    \ng 12, subordinative, understood reciprocally?
    \nt +
    \xv Kah toh unne wunn∞waog Christ kah Belial,...
    \xe And what concord hath Christ with Belial? ...
    \so 2 Cor.6.15
    \nt +

    \xv Kah nag wame wunn∞wahetti[t] n∞che wunnummoáog,...
    \xe And they all with one consent began to make excuse. ...
    \so Lk.14.18
    \nt +

    \xv Yeuyeu newutche peyaush, wunn∞wadtuh nen kah ken: kah wauwónaj ut nashauwe nen kah ken.
    \xe Now therefore come thou, let us make a covenant, I and thou; and let it be for a witness between me and thee.
    \so Gen.31.44; Josh.9.6
    \nt +

    \se !|wunn∞wonau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, ?applicative
    \ge `to consent to sb (to do sth)'
    \so Gen.34.22
    \xv Webe yeuut wosketompaog k∞n∞wónanónog, k∞weetomukqunnanonut, kuppasuk∞inneanónut, nish noh wosketomp quoshqusausit,...
    \xe Only herein will the men consent unto us for to dwell with us, to be one people, if every male among us be circumcised,...
    \so Gen.34.22
    \ng analysis?--apparently 12->3p--"get sb to agree"?
    \xv ..., matta pish k∞n∞wáunáóog, asuh kittumonteanumóog.
    \xe ...; thou shalt make no covenant with them, nor show mercy unto them:
    \so Deut.7.2
    \ng causative derivative? applicative?

    \se ?!|wunn∞wohkoNau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, creative+applicative finals (to putative |wunn∞wau| NI)
    \ge `to make a covenant with sb'
    \so Ps.50.5(M)

    \xv ..., nag wanoowohkonukqueomp nashpe sephausooonk.
    \xe ...,: those that have made a covenant with me by sacrifice.
    \so Ps.50.5(M)
    \ng _3(p)_->1 preterite participle

\et *wel- `good, in order' + *-ow- `make vocal noise' (G.1981, 39, 78; B.1962, 18.112 |-w-| `sound'; Cq.430a |-WE| `bruire, faire du bruit, pousser un son, parler, dire, proférer') + *-e∙- AI.

\lx wushim-in
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 205
\ps n. / NA, dependent
\ge `a daughter-in-law, a son's wife'
\so Mt.10.35
    \xv kushim
    \xe thy daughter-in-law
    \so Gen.38.24
    (`son's wife')    Lev.18.15
    |wushimoh| (constr.) `his daughter-in-law'    Lev.20.12

    \se !|wuhshim(e)u|(?)
    \nt +
    \ps AI+O, verb of possession, i-stem
    \ge `to have sb as daughter-in-law' (?), translating "father-in-law"
    \so Gen.38.13,25
    \nt Remark: The pronouns |kuhhog| and |wuhhog| are "secondary objects", with syntactic behavior as indicated at G.1979, 3.14, pp. 37-38, 3.29, p. 47; G&B. 507, 511, 579.

    \xv Onk unnaú Tamar, n∞wau, Kusseh wohshìmit kuhhog ogquodchuau Timnath m∞swau wutshepsumoh,
    \xe And it was told Tamar, saying, Behold, thy father-in-law goeth up to Timnath to shear his sheep.'    Gen.38.13; E0: |wohshu[m]it|; E1: |wohshimit| { _3_->3
    \so , "he that has thee as daughter-in-law" }
    \xv Pas∞wudt, an∞team∞ wohshimunutche wuhhog n∞wau, howan yeush wadtihéit noh wutche n∞wompequain,...
    \xe When she was brought forth she sent to her father-in-law, saying, By the man whose these are, am I with child:...'    Gen.38.25 { _3
    \so _->3, i.e. "he (obviative) that had her (proximate) as daughter-in-law" }

[Delaware [del] |chumm|    Zeis.
Western Abenaki [abe] |Nesem| `dit le père à la femme de son fils, ma bru.'    R.378/499a.√
    Lp.A |nisim| `ma bru'    D.86.]
    \nt +

\et Mch.1935, 136b: *ne?Θemya `daughter-in-law'; Ho.1964, 253, A.1501-1502: *ne?Θem- `my cross-niece; daughter-in-law'

\lx wuskannem
\va wuskannem
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 205
    \nt Remark: The |e| seen in |-uneash|, |-uneog| is due to infection (G.1981, 41, 84-96.
    \nt +
\ps n. / NI, NA (depending on sense)
\ge `seed' (semen), lit. `his or its seed' (?) {in all biblical senses}
    (cf. |skannémunash| `seeds'    Gen.1.11,12)
    \xv ..., K∞skannemunneog nuttinnumauóneau yeu ohke:...
    \xe ..., Unto thy seed will I give this land:...
    \so Gen.12.7
    \ng NA, 2 possessor plural
    \nt +
    \xv ..., & ∞skannemunneoh pish muttaánit wutohtimoneash.
    \xe ..., and his seed shall become a multitude of nations.
    \so Gen.48.19
    \ng NA, 3 possessor obviative
    \nt +
    of plants or grain    Lev.27.16; Mt.8.20,22,23
    \xv wuskannem mustard
    \xe a mustard seed
    \so Mt.13.31
    of man    Gen.38.9
    \xv Kah howae wosketomp, weepam∞e wuskannem sohwetunkqut,...
    \xe And if any man's seed of copulation go out from him,...
    \so , semen virile    Lev.15.16√,18
    \xv Kah wosketomp neesuk mittamwussissoh, ut wepamuwae wuskannemunit,...
    \xe And whoever lieth carnally with a woman,...
    \so Lev.19.20√
    pl. |wuskannemuneash|, |-nash| `seeds'    Mt.13.31
    `seed corn'    Gen.47.19,23,24
    \xv ∞skannemuneash
    \xe the seed thereof
    \so Lev.27.16√
    \xv k∞skannemuneash
    \xe thy seed
    \so Deut.11.10√

    \se !|wuskannemunu|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to yield seed'
    \so Gen.1.11

    \xv ..., moskeht skannémunú∞k skannémunash,...
    \xe ..., herb yielding seed ...
    \so Gen.1.11
    \ng 0 conjunct (participle?)

    \se !|wuskannemunnu|
    \nt +
    \ps NI, to II predicative
    \ge `seed'
    \so Gen.7.3
    \xv ... onk woh pomantam∞m∞ ∞skannemunnu...
    \xe ...; to keep seed alive ...
    \so Gen.7.3
    \ng 3 possessive

[|wuskeminneash| (?), but cf. |wuskenuunneat| `to be young'.*]
\cf sohqui

    = |wuskon-óntup| `bone-head'
    so, |mishkonóntup| [= |mishewuskon-ontup|]    Jn.19.17
    (|muskonontip|    C.157)

\lx wussenát
\va wussemo
\va wussem∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
\ps v.i. / AI, i-stem (middle reflexive)
\ge `to flee', +`to fly'
    \xv ..., kah ketass∞tamwog Sodom kah Gomorra wussemowog, kah na petshaog,...
    \xe ...: and the Kings of Sodom & Gomorrah fled, and fell there:...
    \so Gen.14.10
    \ng 3p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv n∞sem
    \xe I flee', (or) `I fled
    \so 1 Sam.4.16
    \xv pish n∞semun
    \xe we will flee
    \so Is.30.16
    \xv k∞semw∞
    \xe you flee
    \xv wussem∞og
    \xe they flee
    \so Is.30.17; Prov.28.1
    |wussem∞| (=|-au|) `he fled from'    Ex.2.15

    \xv Tohwutch wussemoan kemeu,...
    \xe Wherefore didst thou flee away secretly,...?
    \so Gen.31.27√; AV "flie"
    \xv ..., newutche na GOD wuttit naéihtaonah wasemwut wutch wuskesukqut wematoh.
    \xe ...: because there God appeared unto him, when he fled from the face of his brother.
    \so Gen.35.7
    \nt +

    \xv Wussem∞k, qushkek, ayek monaiyeuut,...
    \xe Flee ye, turn back, dwell deep,...
    \so Jer.49.8√

    \se !|wussemoehtauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, directive final
    \ge `to flee from sb'
    \so Gen.16.6
    \xv ...: kah Sarai onkapunânont, ∞semoteunkquoh wutch anaquabit,
    \xe ... And when Sarai dealt hardly with her, she fled from her face.'    Gen.16.6 { 3
    \so ->3 objective; (E0&1) have |-oetunk-| }

\cf ussishónat

    \nt Remark: I can currently (texts of NT, Pentateuch) find no evidence for a stem that lacks the |-m-|. See also the etymology. The TA (directive) form of Gen.16.6 appears to be built to this middle reflexive form, when the simple TA form, expected form !|wussemau|, should have been adequate for this meaning--either it had been lost, or this form was an artefact of elicitation. (Examples in Genesis are calqued on the Hebraicism "from the face of" using the middle reflexive.)
    \nt +

    [Algonquian [alg] |OJIM,o| `fuir, s'échapper par la fuite', |Ojimoh| `fais-le fuir, fais qu'il s'échappe'    Cq.295b.
    \nt +
Cree |Osi'mäo| TA `he flees from him', |Osi'moo| `he escapes, he flees'; |osimow|    Frs.393a; G.1982.23.
Delaware [del] |{uschimo}| `he flees'; |wshíimeew| TA `run away from s.o., flee from s.o.' |wshíimuw| AI `run away, flee'    B&A.128; O'M.354ab.
Menominee [mez] |ose∙mow| AI `he runs away'    M.L.182.
Ojibwe [oji] |o⌠imo| AI `run away'    P&G.113.
Shawnee [sjw] |ho⌠imo| `running away', |noo⌠ita, noo⌠ima| `I ran away from it, from him'    D.-V.450.]

\et G.1982, 3.3, 23 *we⌠imowa `to run away', as middle reflexive to (presumably) *we⌠ime∙wa; the form cited by Bloomfield is perhaps a de-stem (deverbal, in his sense) form: B.1962 15.119, 16.45: prefinal |-es-| `run, chase', |-esem-| TA

\lx wussénumónat
\va wussenumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
\ps v.i. / TA, verb of possession, to a stem |-sen-| with final |-(u)m-|
\ge `to be a son-in-law of (to be married to the daughter of?)' { i.e. "to have sb as parent-in-law" }
    \nt Remark: There seems to be no reason to distinguish this form from those listed at T.182b under the glosses "mother-in-law", |wasenumonche| and "son-in-law", |wasénumukqutche|, i.e. `parent-in-law' may suffice. There is a PA reconstruction glossed by Hewson as "in-law" (see below), but it is not clear whether that is intended to be generationally reciprocal, given the sparse evidence cited. (The English form "in-law" invariably denotes the parental generation in my usage.) I have not yet assembled all the evidence from the bible, but "parent-in-law" seems to work well for the instances examined, apart from some awkwardness with Judg.15.6 (q.v.).
    \nt +
\so 1 Sam.18.18, 23, 27
    \xv ..., howan nen? kah teaguas nuppomantamóonk, asuh n∞sh wutteashiyeu∞onk ut Israel, onk woh nen ∞senumonat ketass∞t?
    \xe ..., Who am I? and what is my life, or my father's family in Israel, that I should be son-in-law to the king?'    1 Sam.18.18√ { t-subordinative, 3->3
    \so , subject apparently interpreted with respect to |nen|, i.e. "I...have the king as parent-in-law". [Why not |n∞senumonat|?] }
    \nt +

    \xv ...waseenumukqueaneg,...
    \xe son-in-law
    \so Gen.19.12
    \ng _3p_->2 participle
    \nt +
    \xv Matánumunaj noh wehpamont wessenumoncheh,...
    \xe Cursed be he that lieth with his mother in law. ...'    Deut.27.23 { 3->_3
    \so _, unchanged }
    \nt +
    \xv waseenumadt
    \xe thy mother-in-law
    \so Ruth 2.11
    \ng 2->_3_ participle: "the one that thou hast as parent-in-law"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., yeu kesukok pish ken waseenumukqueh ...
    \xe ..., Thou shalt this day be my son-in-law ...
    \so 1 Sam.18.21√
    \ng _3_->1 participle: "thou shalt [be] the one that has me as parent-in-law"
    \xv ..., Sampson wasénumukqutche wut-Timnite ...
    \xe ..., Samson, the son-in-law of the Timnite,...'    Judg.15.6 { _3
    \so _->3 conjunct: "the one that has the Timnite as parent-in-law"? The obviation seems wrong for this gloss, in that "Sampson" is not marked as obviative, and the whole participle is, despite the apposition. }

    \xv ...: newutche yeuyeu wussénum ketass∞t
    \xe ...: now therefore be the king's son-in-law'    1 Sam.18.22√ { 2->3, TA imperative: "have the king as parent-in-law"; E2 has characteristic printer
    \so s error: |wussénnm|. }

[+Ojib. |zhinmaad| vta Ot `have s.o. as an in-law'    Rh.397b,501b.]

\et H.3828 *we⌠iΘeme∙wa TA `in-law'

\lx wussikkitteaanumau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
    \nt +
\ps TA, mental final |-ánum-|
\ge `to take pleasure in sb; to have a favour unto sb'
\so Ps.44.3(M),147.11(M)
    \xv ..., newutche koosikkittaanumopaneg.
    \xe ..., because thou hadst a favour unto them.
    \so Ps.44.3
    \xv Jehovah wussikkitteaanumau neh quahshukquitcheh, nag annoontogig ukkuttummonteanitteaonk.
    \xe The Lord taketh pleasure in them that fear him, in those that hope in his mercy.
    \so Ps.147.11(M)

    \se wussikkitteaantam
    \ps TI, mental final |-á(a)tam-|
    \ge `to take pleasure in sth'
    \so Ps.102.14(M)
    \xv Newutche kuttinninnumog wussikitteaantamwog ukqussukquonumash,...
    \xe For thy servants take pleasure in her stones:...
    \so 102.14(M); (E) |tapeneñmwog|
    \ng !
    c.f. also the TI applicative |matta wussikkitteaantam∞ontam∞| `he taketh not pleasure in sth' (Ps.147.10(M)).


\lx wussikkitteaheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
    \nt +
\ps TA
\ge `to appease, please sb; find grace in the sight of sb', also as common translation of "be (well) pleased"
\so Gen.32.20,34.18,47.25; Ex.21.8; Ps.51.19,69.31; Mt.3.17; Mk.15.15; Jn.8.29; Acts 12.3,25.9; Rom.15.1,2,27; 1 Cor.1.21,7.32,33,34,(8.8),10.5; 1 Jn.3.22
    \xv ..., , N∞sikitteoh nashpe mag∞onk negonshaûm∞úk,...
    \xe ..., I will appease him with the present that goeth before me,...
    \so Gen.32.20
    \ng 1->3
    \xv Yeu nashpe n∞wahteoun k∞sekitteahe,...
    \xe By this I know that thou favourest me,...'    Ps.41.11  { 2->1 }; (M) |koosikkittahaose|, { 2->1 applicative, presumably correcting (E)
    \so s "thou pleasest me" }
    \xv Neit pish k∞seketahhuk sampweusseae sephausuongash,...
    \xe Then shalt thou be pleased with the sacrifices of righteousness,...
    \so Ps.51.19; (M): |koosikitteahhit|
    \ng 0(p)->2; X->2

    \xv Matta wussikkitteahunk wussantimomuh, matta ∞wisqueteog;...
    \xe If she please not her master, who hath betrothed her to himself,...'    Ex.21.8 { 3->3
    \so negative conjunct; translation of second clause unexplained at present }
    \xv ..., Yeuoh n∞womunnegoneu nuttai∞m, noh wohsikkitteahikque.
    \xe ..., This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.
    \so Mt.3.17
    \ng 3->1 participle
    \xv ..., tapeneungque sephausuonk, wásikkitteahikqut GOD.
    \xe ..., a sacrifice acceptable, well-pleasing to God.
    \so Phil.4.18
    \ng 0->3 participle

    \xv ... kuppomantamwahimun wussikkitteahitteadtuh anaquabit nussontimom, kah nenawun wuttinneumoh Pharoh ...
    \xe ..., Thou hast saved our lives: let us find grace in the sight of my lord, and we will be Pharaoh's servants.
    \so Gen.47.25
    \ng X->1p imperative; "let us be pleased" for expected 1p->3 (or 1p->2)?

    \se wussikitteahittuonk
    \ps NI, deverbal to theme 2a
    \ge `grace'
    \so Gen.33.8
    \xv ..., Newutche namehteauun wussikitteahittuonk ut nussontimom anaquabit.
    \xe ..., These are to find grace in the sight of my lord.
    \so Gen.33.8

    Compare *|wussekitteahhuönat|, with indefinite object.

\et Initial is perhaps PA *we⌠-, palatalized form of *weΘ-, an allomorph of *wel- `in order'.

\lx wussittum∞onk
\va wussittumôonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
\ps n. / NI, deverbal noun
\ge `judgment, sentence'
\so Rom.5.16; Is.9.7; +Gen.18.19
    \xv ∞sittum∞onk
    \xe his judgment
    \so Rom.2.2


\lx wussittumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
\ps v.t. inan. (and intrans.) / TI1b, oral final
\twn |wussumónat|
\ge `to judge, to pass judgment on'
\so 1 Chr.16.33; Ps.96.13
    \xv wussittumunát awakompanáe
    \xe to condemn
    \so Jn.3.17
    \xv n∞sittum
    \xe I judge
    \so Ezek.34.17
    \xv ken k∞sittum
    \xe thou who judgest
    \so Rom.2.1
    \xv wussittum
    \xe he judges
    \so 1 Cor.2.15

    \xv ken wassittuman
    \xe thou who mayest judge, thou when thou judgest
    \so Rom.2.1
    \xv wussittuk
    \xe when he judges
    \so Rom.2.16
    \xv noh wussittuk
    \xe he who judges (when he judges), the judge of
    \so Gen.18.25
    \ng _3_->0 participle
    \xv wasittumwóg
    \xe if ye judge
    \so Mt.7.2

    \xv ..., Jehovah wussittich nashauwe ken, kah nashauwe neen.
    \xe ...: the LORD judge between me and thee.
    \so Gen.16.5; +Gen.31.53
    \ng 3 imperative

\et To be associated with *we⌠(i)- H.3815-3826, with senses (suspiciously) similar to *wel- (`aranged, into shape, made, ready')? (Cf. G.1982, fn.24, 22.) For the form, cf. H.3824 *we⌠ihtamwe∙wa TA(+O) `arrange'. (Eliot is unlikely to have known the etymology of E. `law', and probably did not know German (hence not `Gesetz'); Skinner (1671) is in the dark about `law' and about `deem'/`doom'. Therefore this is unlikely to be a calque,--but it might have meant `to decide, settle sth'?)


\lx wussittumwaen
\va -in
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
\ps n. / NA
\ge `a judge, one who judges'
    pl. |-waenuog| `judges' (as in title of the book of Judges)


\lx wusso
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 207
\ps AI, verb of possession, to the initial seen in |wasukeh|, `sb's husband', T.182b; presumably an i-stem.
\ge `is a wife, is married (of a woman)', +i.e. `to have (sb as) a husband'
    \xv noh wusso
    \xe she is a man's wife
    \so Gen.20.3√
    \xv Howan Wosketomp namhit ut kouwee wutapineat weeche ummittamwussissit noh wusso, naneeswe yeug pish menuhki sasamatawhoog
    \xe If any Man be found a Bed with another Mans Wife, they shall both of them, be severely Scourged:
    \so Ind. Laws XI, p.8√
    \ng The independent form is unexpected here. There are signs of unidiomatic translation in the previous clause.
\cf mittamwus
\cf ummittamwussoh

[Abn. `Je suis marié, ait vir', |nekit8dé|; `mulier verò', |n8ssi.|    R.334/484a.√
    Algonquian [alg] |'C| `mari, époux; (1)', |Oc,i| `avoir un mari'; fn.(1) "On disait autrefois n'ic, `mon mari', k'ic `ton mari', wican, `son mari'."    Cq.78a; ib., fn.(1).
    \nt +
Menominee [mez] |oqsew| `she (animal) is in heat'    B.1975.179.
Shawn. ho?⌠iwa `she is married'    G.1973,48.]

\et G.1973, 47-48: *we?⌠i- `to have (sb as) a husband', verb of possession to *ne?Θa NA, dependent `husband'. Additional examples from G.1973,48.

    \xe he judges (them)

    \xe he sentenced him' (`gave sentence

    \xe they judge him

    \xe Are ye not then partial in yourselves, and are become judges of evil thoughts?

    \xv k∞sumomwop

\lx wut-
\va wutch-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 208
    \nt +
\ps initial, transitive
\ge `from, of', common in verbs denoting a source of some thing or some effect, also e.g. verbs of appurtenance.
\so entries that follow, comparative evidence, etymology.

\et A. 2183, 2189, 2190-2193; H.3725-3740 *wenci- `thence' (H.3758-3780 *went- `thence', perhaps itself *wem+t-? (S., item 56, `come from there', 327-328), and *wens- 3749-3755); B., items 4, 33, 36, 301, 328, 329


\lx wut-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 208
\ps prefixed to the name of a place or people
\ge forms a gentile or ancestral noun, as
    \xv wut-Hebrew
    \xe the Hebrew
    \so Gen.14.13
    |wut-Amorite|    Gen.14.13
    so |ukkananit| `the Canaanites'    Gen.14.21
    \xv wut-Egyptianseog
    \xe the Egyptians
    \so Ex.7.18
    \xv wutohkit
    \xe an inhabitant of' {?--c.f. Ruth 1.2 |wutohkit Moab| `the country of Moab
    \so }
    \xv wutóhtu
    \xe an inhabitant of
    \xv Onk Sopater wutóhtu Berea, Aristarchus kah Secundus wutohtu Thessalonia, Gaius wutohtu Derbe kah Timothius, Tichicus kah Trophimus wutohtuog Asia, neh ∞weechógquoh Asia.
    \xe And there accompanied him into Asia Sopater of Berea; and of the Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus; and Gaius of Derbe, and Timotheus; and of Asia, Tychicus and Trophimus.
    \so Acts 20.4


\lx wutadtippadto
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt +
\ps TI2
\dv |wut-| ?ablative + |-adt-| [?common extension] + |-ip(a?)-| `water'
\ge `to water sth'
\so Gen.2.6,10; Ex.11.10; 1 Cor.3.7
    \xv Qut ouwan waápu wutch ohkekontu, kah wutadtippodto wame woskeche ohkeit.
    \xe But there went up a mist from the earth, and watered the whole face of the ground.
    \so Gen.2.6

    \xv Kah seip wutchishau Eden wadtattippadtunk tanohketeaonk,...
    \xe and a river went out of Eden to water the garden;...
    \so Gen.2.10
    \ng _0_ participle
    \xv Nemehkuh neit, noh áhketeadt matta tohhen tuppéeu, asuh noh wadtattippadtunk, qut GOD noh nano mishemaguk.
    \xe So then neither is he that planteth any thing, neither he that watereth; but God that giveth the increase.
    \so 1 Cor.3.7
    \ng _3_ participle

\lx wutamiyeu
\va wuttamiyeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
\ps adv. as n. / deverbal NI to II verb?
\ge `the hind parts of man or other animal, behind'
    \xv Wutteateashiyeuongan∞ Gershonitsog, nag pish tuppuksinwog, wuttamiyeu Tabernakleut, kehtahhanniyeu.
    \xe The families of the Gershonites shall pitch behind the tabernacle westward.
    \so Num.3.23
    \nt +
    \xv ut wutamiyeu
    \xe into the draught
    \so Mt.15.17
    \ng error (of tr.)?; sense here is "latrine, privy": Vlg. "in secessum"; OED s.v. draught 46.
    \xv ∞támiyeu
    \xe his hinder part
    \so (opposed to |wuskesuk|)    Joel 2.20
    \xv ∞támiyeumoash
    \xe their hinder parts
    \so (of animals)    2 Chr.4.4
    (|wuttommiyeu| as prep. `behind'    C.235)

\lx wutchaiyeum∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt Remark: The stem of the following item, |wutchayeu|, with the II derivational final.
    \nt +
\cf wadchinat


\lx wutchayeu
\va wutchaiyeu
\va wutchiyeu
\va wadchinat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt +
\ps AI+locative, transitive initial; also II occurrences (e.g. Deut.32.5, 1 Jn.2.16)
\ge `to be of sb, to be sb's'
    \xv Nag annushéaog wuhhôgkauh. wutchohkésuongan∞ matta wutcháinoh wunnaumonat,...
    \xe They have corrupted themselves, their spot is not the spot of his children:...
    \so Deut.32.5
    \ng II
    \xv ...nen n∞chi Paulut, kah onkatuk nen n∞chí Apollo,...
    \xe ..., I am of Paul; and another, I am of Apollos;...
    \so 1 Cor.3.4, also ib. 1.12, sp. |n∞chai|
    \xv K[a]h kenaau k∞chiyimw∞ Christut, kah Christ wutchiyeu Godut.
    \xe And ye are Christ's; and Christ is God's.
    \so 1 Cor.3.23
    \xv Newutche wame ne ohtag muttaohket, weyause matchekodtantamóonk, muskesukque matchekodtantamóonk, kah pittuinumóe pomantamóonk, matta wutchaiinn∞h Wut∞shinneat, qut wutchayeu muttaohket.
    \xe For all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, is not of the Father, but is of the world.
    \so 1 Jn.2.16
    \ng unequivocally II

    \se wutchayeum∞
    \va wutchaiyeum∞
    \va wutch ayeum∞
    \ps II+O, transitive initial
    \ge `to be of sb, to be sb's due, to belong to sb'
    \so Gen.35.11,40.8; Josh.17.8; Deut.18.3,29.29,32.35,33.12; Mk.11.30; Lk.12.15; 2 Cor.5.18; Heb.5.14; Jas.1.17; 1 Jn.2.21,4.7
    \xv Kah yeu pish wutchayeum∞ sephausuenutu wutch missinninnuut,...
    \xe And this shall be the priest's due from the people,...
    \so Deut.18.3
    \xv ...; kah Tappuah wussissippoiyeumut Manasseh, wutchayeum∞ wunnaumonat Ephraim.
    \xe ...: but Tappuah on the border of Manasseh belonged to the children of Ephraim;
    \so Josh.17.8
    \xv Kah wame teanteaguashinish wutchayeum∞ash Godut
    \xe And all things are of God,...
    \so 2 Cor.5.18

    \se wutchiyeuonk
    \ps NI?, deverbal
    \ge `usury'
    \so Lev.25.36,37
    \xv Ahque neemunumau wutchyeuonk, asuh nano missegenit,...
    \xe Take thou no usury of him, or increase:...
    \so Lev.25.36

    \se wutchayeue
    \va wutchiyeue
    \va wutchaiyeueu
    \ps PreN
    \ge `servile' (of work) (as if "belonging to another"?)
    \so Num.29.1,12,35
    \xv ... matta pish wutchayeue anakausuonk kutusseumw∞,...
    \xe ...; ye shall do no servile work,...
    \so Num.29.12

    \se wutchéheau
    \ps TA, causative (w. second object from P as locative)
    \ge "to cause sb to be from sth/sb" ?
    \xv Newutche wosketomp matta wutchéheau mittamwussissit, qut mittamwussis wutchéheau wosketompaut.
    \xe For the man is not of the woman; but the woman of the man.
    \so 1 Cor.11.8
    \nt Analysis takes these to be X->3 forms.

\nt This no doubt should include the instances assigned by Trumbull to |wadchinat|, as under |wutchaiyeum∞| and probably those under |∞chiinneat| `to be advantaged or profited'; these entries are in any case spurious, being based on the shape of different inflected forms. They probably belong here. The relationship to |wutchii-| forms (as T.112a |∞chiinneat|) with senses `advantage, increase (Num.18.30), profit' is not yet totally clear and this is given a second entry.


\lx wutchayeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt +
\ps v.p. / ?AI/?II(+O), where the beneficiary is denoted by the subject
\ge `to be advantaged or profited'
    |..., tapenuman wutchiinneat kah sohkomanat.| `...; if so be thou shalt be able to profit, if so be thou mayest prevail.    Is.47.12√ { X t-subordinative }
    \xv ..., wanne teag wutchieu wosketomp,...
    \xe ..., It profiteth a man nothing ...
    \so Job 34.9
    \ng 3->0 negative absolute
    \xv ..., teag n∞chiin,...
    \xe ..., What advantage will it be unto thee? ...
    \so Job 35.3√
    \ng 1->0 objective, with switch to oratio recta
    \xv ..., kah matta n∞chiéin.
    \xe ..., and it profited me not;
    \so Job 33.27√
    \ng 1->0 negative objective
    \xv ..., neemun Mark, kah weeche peyaush: newutche noh n∞chiin wutche nohtompeantogóowonk.
    \xe ... . Take Mark, and bring him with thee: for he is profitable to me for the ministry.
    \so 2 Tim.4.11
    \ng 1->3 objective
    \nt +
    \xv Teaguas k∞chiyimw∞ nunnúkontungane manit, waj noh kezheunt kogkoxwont,...
    \xe What profiteth the graven image that the maker thereof hath graven it;...
    \so Hab.2.18√
    \ng apparently 2p->0 indicative
    \xv ∞chiin
    \xe (it) is profitable
    \so Eccl.10.10
    \xv woh ∞chiin
    \xe it may profit
    \so Job 35.8
    \xv ..., newutche nish matta pish k∞chiéinash.
    \xe ...; for they [thy works] shall not profit thee.
    \so Is.57.12√
    \ng 2->0p objective

    \xv nish matta wadchiyeumukish
    \xe things which can not profit' (`be profitable
    \so )    1 Sam.12.21

\cf ∞tcheun
\ge he made from (it)


\lx wutchaubuk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
\cf wadchábuk


\lx wutche
\va wutch
\va ∞tch
\va wu+wutch
\ve i.e.
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
\ps prep. / (transitive) PreN, PreV; occasionally governs locative
\ge `from'
\so Eccl.3.11; Ps.78.4
\ge `for'
\so Eccl.3.1
\ge `instead of, in the place of'
\so 1 Pet.3.18
\ge `because of'
    \nt Remark: Note the usual form of the changed allomorph: |wajeh|. (The two are related explicitly in the Illinois dictionary quoted below, with the implication that the unchanged form is less common in clauses of reason, presumably because these would normally have changed forms.)
    \nt +
    \xv Wutche ∞shoh. asuh wutche ohkasoh, wutche weematoh asuh wutch weetahtu, matta nah ∞tch nishkeaun wuhhogkuh nuppinit,...
    \xe He shall not make himself unclean for his father, or for his mother, for his brother, or for his sister, when they die:...
    \so Num.6.7
    \ng |nah| (obv.) obj. of |wutch|; subordinative verb, contraction of |wu-| prefix
    \nt +
    \xv nenan wutche
    \xe for the same cause
    \so Phil.2.18
    \xv ne wutche
    \xe for the cause that, for that cause, therefore
    \cf newutche
    \xv noh wutchu
    \xe of him
    \so (as a cause or source)    Rom.11.36.
\cf ∞ch
\cf wadchinat
\cf waj
\cf ∞tshoh
\cf wutchisheau
\so (), the active form

[Narragansett [xnt] |yò wuchê| `from hence'    R.W.74.
Delaware [del] |untschi| `of, by, therefore'; |wuntschi| `of, on account of'; |wentschi| `therefore, for this reason'    Zeisb.Gr.178; |untschi|, |wuntschi|, |wentschi| `of, from, on account of, for the sake of'    Zeisb.Gr.182.
    Miami-Illinois [mia] |8ntchi| `de la, d'ou. pourquoy rarius. aliqdo dr 8intchi qd vide supra.' |Tane 8ntchi piaïani?| `d'ou viens tu?'; {R} |8intchi| marque la raison pourquoy et les questions qua et unde. |kec8ne 8intchi piaïani?| `pourquoy viens tu?'    Gr. 406/241b; 393/234b.]
    \nt +


\lx wutcheheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt +
\ps TA+"O", causative with source, i.e. "to cause sb to come to exist from, out of somewhere"
\ge `to be by, of sb, to make sth sb, to raise up sb of sth'
\so Gen.2.22; Mt.3.9; 1 Cor.11.12
    \xv Onk ne muhpeteog Jehovah Manit neemunuk wutch wosketompaut, ∞tcheun mittamwossissoh,...
    \xe And the rib, which the Lord God had taken from man, made he a woman,...'    Gen.2.22  { 3->3
    \so +0 subordinative/objective }
    \xv ..., God tapenum wutcheheun yeu qussukquanéhtu wunnaumonuh Abraham.
    \xe ..., that God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham.'    Mt.3.9  { X->3
    \so +0-def objective }
    \xv Newutche neyane mittamwossis wutchéheau wosketompaut, netatup wosketomp wutchéheau mittamwossissut, qut wame wutcheheáog Godut.
    \xe For as the woman is of the man, even so is the man also by the woman; but all things of God.'    1 Cor.11.12  { syntax unclear -- perhaps 3->3
    \so , with subject denoting God, locative hypercharacterized; but third conjunct then baffling. }

[Delaware [del] |wunjíiheew| TA `make s.t. animate from something, make s.t. animate for a certain reason'    O'M.369a.]

\et One expects a proto-form; H.3729 *wencihe∙wa TA corresponds to this, but the reflexes listed have considerably different and varied senses, due no doubt to the protean ablative sense of the initial (for instance, yielding distancing as well as derivation).


\lx wutchenauwetu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt +
\dv |wutch-| + |(w)enauwek-| `to be rich', T.189b
\ps AI(+O)?
\ge `to be made rich (by sb)', i.e. "to become rich from some source"
\so Rev.18.15,19

    \xv Neg yeush magugek neh nag wejenauéekhetticheh, pish nôogkompóog,...
    \xe The merchants of these things, which were made rich by her, shall stand afar off ...'    Rev.18.15  { printer
    \so s error, for (E1) |wajén-|; syntax obscure. }
    \xv ... Kuttummunk, kuttumunk, ne mishe keitotan, noh wajeénoweehettit, wame yeug ahtauéhetticheh kuht∞nógquog kehtahhannit, newutche ummishâatdik∞m,...
    \xe ..., Alas, alas, that great city, wherein were made rich all that had ships in the sea, by reason of her costliness! ...'    Rev.18.19  { printer
    \so s error, for (E1) |wajeénoweekhettit|; role of |noh|, normally proximate singular: probably locative; role of |waj-| perhaps as cataphoric to the |wutche| phrase? }

\lx wutcheken
\va wutchegen
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
\ps II(+O), via transitive P
\twn |wutchetu|, AI+O
\ge `it bears, yields, brings forth, produces'
    \xv ..., nesausuk tahshinash missunkquaminash wutchekinash pasukquinnu ummehtugquoquamut,...
    \xe ..., seven ears came up in one stalk,...
    \so Gen.41.22
    \nt +
    \xv wutchegen meechum
    \xe it bore fruit
    \so Lk.8.8
    \xv wutcheken ... almondsash
    \xe it yielded almonds
    \so Num.17.8
    \xv ..., kah noh pish wûtcheken ketass∞timwe waégogish.
    \xe ..., and he shall yield royal dainties.
    \so Gen.49.20
    \ng ?0(p)->3-pro absolute
    \xv ..., onk woh mo sokanonau, kah ohke matta wutchekennunn∞ ummeechummuonk,...
    \xe ..., that there be no rain, and that the land yield not her fruit;...
    \so Deut.11.17
    \nt +
    \xv ..., pish wutchegen pasuk bath,...
    \xe [ten acres] ... shall yield one bath,...
    \so Is.5.10√


\lx wutchequeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt +
\ps AI
\ge `to be a leper'
\so Lev.13.45,14.2,3,22.4

    \xv Yeu pish naumatuonk wutche watchequt,...
    \xe This shall be the law of the leper...
    \so Lev.14.2

    \se wutchek∞e
    \ps PreN
    \ge `leprous, of leprosy'
    \so Lev.13.44,47,
    \xv Noh wutchek∞e wosketomp, noh nishkeneunkqussu,...
    \xe He is a leprous man, he is unclean:...
    \so Lev.13.44
    \xv Ne unnaumatuonk nishnoh wutchek∞e enninneâonk, kah mukkeontuppáonk.
    \xe This is the law for all manner of plague of leprosy, and scall,
    \so Lev.14.54

    \se !|wutchek(q)(∞)|
    \nt ?
    \ps NA
    \ge `leper; leprosy'
    \so ?Lev.13.45?, Lk.4.27
    {? |noh wutchekq| `the leper' Lev.13.45 (1&2) }
    \xv Ne nukkone wutchekq ut wadtuhquabée weyausut,...
    \xe It is an old leprosy in the skin of his flesh,...
    \so Lev.13.11; (1): |wutchekq|
    \xv Kah peyaónuk wutchek∞uh,...
    \xe And there came a leper to him,...
    \so Mk.1.40
    \xv Kah monaog wutchek∞og ut Israel pamontog Elizeus quoshodtumwaen,...
    \xe And many lepers were in Israel in the time of Eliseus the prophet;...
    \so Lk.4.27

    \xe his hand was leprous

\lx wutchetu

\nt Remark: palatalized velar
\ps AI(+O)

\dv |wutche| `from' + |-(e)tu|, |-ek-i-| "to grow" (q.v., T+.26b)
\ge `to be born to sb, to come from sb (by descent)' (governing the locative?)
\so Num.26.5,...,26.60, 1 Jn.2.29,3.9; [Num.26.59 erroneous]
\nt G&B.733, s.v. Watke|nitcheh
    \xv ..., nishnoh pasuk noh sampweasit neh wutchetuoh wuhhogkat.
    \xe ... every one that doeth righteousness is born of him.
    \so 1 Jn.2.29
    \xv Kah Aaronut wutchetu Nadab kah Abihu Eleazar kah Ithamar.
    \xe And unto Aaron was born Nadab, and Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
    \so Num.26.60

    \xv ..., wunnaumonuh Ruben, Enoch neh wadchekhetticheh Enochitsog, Phallu neh wadchekhetticheh Phalluitsog.
    \xe ...: the children of Reuben, Hanoch, {of whom commeth} the family of the Hanochites: of Pallu, the family of the Palluites:'    Num.26.5,...  { 3p->_3
    \so _ participle }

\lx wutchimau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
\ps v. / TA(+O?)
    \nt Remark: If the initial is indeed |wut(ch)-|, which is transitive, then an additional object is imported, and may denote the source of the blame; this may account for the n-paradigm forms, not as subordinatives but as objectives (as if for "for/of it").
    \nt +
    \dv |wut(ch)-| `from' + oral final
    \nt +
\ge (`he blames'?); pass. `he is blamed'; +`to blame sb, to have sth against sb'
\so 1 Tim.3.2
    \xv ... kenaau woh matta k∞chumitteaneau.
    \xe ...; and ye shall be blameless.
    \so Gen.44.10
    \ng X->2p negative subordinative(?)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah nenawun mat pish n∞chumitteaunan ...
    \xe ..., and we will be guiltless:...
    \so Josh.2.19
    \ng X->1p subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv Qut Peter paont Antioch, nutayeuuhkóne nepauwehtau ut anaquabit, newutche woh wutchimau.
    \xe But when Peter was come to Antioch, I withstood him to the face, because he was to be blamed.
    \so Gal.2.11
    \xv Qut neteag k∞chumush, newutche kenukkodtam negonne k∞womantamóonk.
    \xe Nevertheless I have somewhat against thee, because thou hast left thy first love.
    \so Rev.2.4
    \ng 1->2
    \nt +

    \xv ..., neit auwohteahettich wutannohsuonk Deakon, mon teag wutchimomuk.
    \xe ...; then let them use the office of a deacon, being found blameless.
    \so 1 Tim.3.10

    \xv ..., matta paudtauun∞un, káh matta ponóog anaquabean, neit wutchimuneach micheme.
    \xe ...: if I bring him not unto thee, and set him before thee, then let me bear the blame for ever:
    \so Gen.43.9
    \ng X->1 imperative; see G&B.569, with note c & 572.

\lg Wampanoag [wam]

Gen.21.30; |..., kah na pish k∞tnon ummittamwussoh nunnaumon.| `..., and thou shalt take a wife unto my son from thence.'    Gen.24.7; [!!BUT: |Onk nag as∞kutcheg neemunnumwog ∞wequanantegan∞ash, qut matta k∞tnum∞og pumme.| `They that were foolish took their lamps, and took no oil with them:' Mt.25.3]: cf. B., item 301 *wenteneewa `he takes him from there by hand' i.e. !|wutnau| TA ? }
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209


\lx wutohkinneat
\va wadohkinneát
\va wutohtu
\ve latter form spurious
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 209
    \nt Remark: 3 independent form is |wutohtu|.
    \nt +
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), verb of possession, to |ohke|.
    \nt Remark: It is noticeable that the place is often specified in the locative form rather than as a direct object (E&M). If this is not simply a calque, it may indicate some idiomatization of the original verb of possession.
    \nt +
\ge `to be an inhabitant of or to dwell in (a land or country)' { as opposed to a building }; +`to get possessions'
\nt G&B.733
\so Neh.11.2; +Gen.4.16,13.7,12,14.12,16.3,26.17,27.39,34.10,47.20,50.11; Lev.20.22,25.19; Num.32.40; Josh.17.12,19.27,50; Acts 18.11
    \xv Onk Kain sohham wutch anaquabit Jehovah, kah wutohtu ohkeit Nod wutchepwáou wutch Eden.
    \xe And Cain went out from the presence of the Lord, and dwelt in the land of Nod, on the east of Eden.
    \so Gen.4.16
    \ng 3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Abram wutohteup wutohket Kanaan,...
    \xe Abram dwelled in the land of Canaan,...
    \so Gen.13.12
    \ng 3 preterite indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh k∞tohtimw∞ ohkit Goshn,...
    \xe ...: that ye may dwell in the land of Goshen;...
    \so Gen.46.34
    \ng 2p indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ... ohke ne Jehovah kum Manitt∞mw∞ ânumungqueóg, kah pish kutohtauuneau, kah na pish k∞tohkinneau.
    \xe ...the land which the Lord your God giveth you, and ye shall possess it, and dwell therein.
    \so Deut.11.31
    \ng 2p->0 objective/subordinative; 2p subordinative
    \nt +
    \xv ...? yeu wadchu GOD kodtantog ∞tohkinneat, nux, Jehovah ummicheme wutohkin.
    \xe ...? this is the hill which God desireth to dwell in, yea, the LORD will dwell in it for ever.
    \so Ps.68.16; (M): |ootohkenat|, |ootahken|
    \ng |micheme| follows verb.
    \nt +
    \xv ...: yeu n∞tohkin,...
    \xe ...: here will I dwell,...
    \so Ps.132.14; (M): |nootohken|
    \ng 1 subordinative

    \xv Kah neh wadohkehettit wutch Meshua,...
    \xe And their dwelling was from Mesha,...
    \so Gen.10.30
    \ng 3p->_adv_ participle
    \xv ... Amoritog wodôhkitcheg Hazezon-tamar.
    \xe ... the Amorites, that dwelt in Hazezon-tamar.
    \so Gen.14.7
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ... wodohteup Sodom,...
    \xe ...(who dwelt in Sodom)...
    \so Gen.14.12
    \ng _3_ preterite participle
    \nt +
    \xv ... mahche piukque kodtumwae wutohket Abram ohket Kanaan,...
    \xe ..., after Abram had dwelt ten years in the land of Canaan,...
    \so Gen.16.3
    \ng 3 (unchanged) conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta keneemunoh ummittumwussoh nunnaúmon wutaun∞oh Kananiteog uttiyeu ohke, wadohkéomp.
    \xe ..., Thou shalt not take a wife to my son of the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I dwell:
    \so Gen.24.37
    \ng 1->_3p_ preterite participle
    \xv Kah na wadohkitcheg ne ohkit uk-Kananitsog, naumwog ...
    \xe And when the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, saw ...
    \so Gen.50.11
    \ng _3p_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv uttoh wodohkeyog, ut toh wôdohke
    \xe (the land) which ye shall inhabit, wherein I (shall) dwell
    \so Num.35.34
    (cf. |uttiyeu kutohk| `what is thy country?'    Jonah 1.8)
    \xv IEhovah, howan woh apit kekit? howan woh wadohket k∞netupanatamwe wadchumut?
    \xe LOrd, who shall abide in thy tabernacle? who shall dwell in thy holy hill?
    \so Ps.15.1√; (M): |wadohket|
    \xv neg wodohkitcheg
    \xe they who dwell in (a place or country), the inhabitants of
    \so Gen.26.7; Is.9.2; +Mk.1.5

    \xv wutohkish en ohkit
    \xe dwell thou in the land
    \so Gen.26.2
    \xv ..., kah na wutohkek.
    \xe ..., and get you possessions therein.
    \so Gen.34.10
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche wutóhkhettich ne ohkeit,...
    \xe ...; therefore let them dwell in the land,...
    \so Gen.34.21
    \ng 3p imperative
    \nt +

    \se wutokeinat
    \ps pass.
    \ge `to be inhabited'
    \so Is.13.20

    \se !|wutohkem∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II(+O), inanimate form of headword
    \ge `to dwell (somewhere)'
    \so Ps.26.8(M),85.9(M)
    \xv ...; onk woh sohsumooonk wuttohkemoo nutohkenonut.
    \xe ...; that glory may dwell in our land.
    \so Ps.85.9(M)

    \xv ..., kah ayeuonk uttoh wadtohkemoouk kussohsummooonk.
    \xe ..., and the place where thine honour dwelleth.
    \so Ps.26.8(M)

    \se !|wutohkeheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O), causative to headword
    \ge `to make sb dwell (somewhere), to place sb'
    \so Gen.47.6,11; Ps.4.8(M),78.55(M),107.36(M),143.3
    \xv ..., newutche webe ken Jehovah kootohkeahhe nanauiyeuonkganit.
    \xe ...; for thou Lord only makest me dwell in safety.
    \so Ps.4.8(M)
    \ng 2->1 indicative
    \xv ..., kah wuttahkeahhop Israele chuppanooonkash ut wekoowout.
    \xe ..., and made the tribes of Israel to dwell in their tents.'    Ps.78.55(M)  { 3->3
    \so preterite absolute; despite NI object }
    \xv ...: n∞tohkehhik pokenahtu onatuh yeug sepe nuppukeg.
    \xe ...: he hath made me to dwell in darkness, as those that have been long dead.
    \so Ps.143.3; (M) |nootahkeahhukup|
    \ng 3->1 (preterite) absolute

    \xv ..., ne wanegik ohke wutokkéh k∞sh kah kematog wutohkhettich ohkit Goshen:...
    \xe ...; in the best of the land make thy father and brethren to dwell; in the land of Goshen let them dwell:...
    \so Gen.47.6
    \ng 2->3(p) imperative


\nt This is one of a considerable number of words which Eliot made use of to express, approximately, an idea which the Indian was slow to receive -- that of fixed and permanent habitation. Thus
    \xv ohtauunát
    \xe to possess (a place)
    \xv apinneat
    \xe to be or remain in a place, to stay
    \xv wutayinneat
    \xe to be in a place named, in this place' (|yeu|, |ayeuonk|), and, so, `to dwell in
    \so (a house, a tent, etc.)
    |weetomónat| (from |wétu|) `to dwell with, to live in the house of or with'
    \xv wutohkinneat
    \xe to be of the land of (|wutohke|), to inhabit
    \so , etc.
\cf wadohkinneát


\lx wutohtimoin
\va wutohtimoin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 210
    \nt Remark: indefinite possessor form to |ohke|. (On the palatalized |k|, see G.1981, 39, 77.)
    \nt +
\ps n. / NA, NI
\ge `a nation', +`country'
\nt G&B.491,493,747
\so Is.60.12; Jer.7.28
    (|Wuttohtimoin| `A nation'    C.5/157)
    pl. |wutohtimôneash|    Gen.10.32; Is.40.15, 17
    \xv wutohtimoinneunk
    \xe the nations
    \so Jer.31.10 (collectively or corporately) collective plural
    \ng NA plural
    \xv ..., kah Tidal ketass∞t wutohtimoneat,...
    \xe ..., and with Tidal king of nations,...
    \so Gen.14.9(E1)
    \ng locative
    \nt +
    \xv ... onk au wutohtimoneat, wutch wuskesukqut wechaioh Jakoboh.
    \xe ..., and went into the country from the face of his brother Jacob.
    \so Gen.36.6
    \ng locative
    \nt +

    \se ?!|wutohtimoinnu|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative final
    \ge `(for there) to be a nation'
    \so Jer.49.36
    \xv ..., kah na pish mat wutohtimoinneaén∞,...
    \xe ...; and there shall be no nation...
    \so Jer.49.36
    \ng 0 negative indicative


\lx wutóhtu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 210
\ps n. / agent noun to |wutohtu| AI
    \nt Remark: The 3 indicative of the verb under the entry |wutohkinneat|, |wadohkinneát| (c.f. G.1981, 39, p.78); examples provided there. Subject (inhabitant: "one that has somewhere as his land") or object nominal (place: "what someone has as his land") nominal to the verb of possession.
    \nt +
\ge `an inhabitant of or one belonging to a place'
    \xv Sopater wutóhtu Berea
    \xe Sopater of Berea
    \so Acts 20.4
    |wutch wutohtuóut Israel| (a captive) `from the land of Israel'    2 K.5.2
    \xv wutohtu
    \xe "he dwelt" (was a dweller) in
    \so , etc.    Gen.20.1,26.6
    \xv en wutohtuóut k∞sh∞wóut
    \xe unto the land of your fathers
    \so Gen.48.21
    \nt +

\lx wutôu

    \nt +
    \ge `to bring, carry sth from swh'

    \so Gen.43.2; Ex.12.39,13.19; 1 Sam.4.4; ?Mk.8.4

    \xv ..., kah pish yeu k∞tauunneau nushkonash.

    \nt +
Del. Mun. |wé∙nt@k| `where he got it'; |wúnd| TI3 `get s.t. from a certain place, get s.t. from somewhere', |Chétum nóondum| `I got it in Chatham.'    G.1979.74; O'M.366b.]

\et G.1981, 37, 73: "(presumably /w@tôw/, as if from PEA **w@ntäw; Mun |nó∙nt@n `I got it from there' points to a Class 3 TI PA *went- rather than a Class 2 TI *wentaw-)"; reshaped as TI2 here? The final *t probably acts as a (TI) transitivizer (causative) on *wem-.

\lx wuttaihe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 210
    \nt Remark: Requires further study and reorganization
    \nt +
\ps NA, NI? - category and form (with elusive |h|'s) uncertain, though there are AI verb forms in this entry, belonging to a verb of possession. The form |wuttaihe| appears to be used attributively as well as predicatively. It is presumably a dependent noun, perhaps to a stem of shape |-aih-e-|.
\ge `his, (is) his, belongs to him'
    \nt Compare G&B.687, s.v. othiheun AI+O `he has it as his property' and G&B.499, 715, s.v. |(wut)thihe| NId `his property'
    \nt +
\so Lev.27.15,10,26
    \xv ... k∞skannemunog pish penuwohteaoog ohke matta wuttaihéou,...
    \xe ... that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs,...
    \so Gen.15.13
    \ng 3p possessor
    \nt +
    \xv N∞womonog nuttaiheh kah nen wuttaiheuh:...
    \xe My beloved is mine, and I am his:...
    \so Cant.2.16√
    \ng morphology? syntax?
    \xv nish wuttaiheash Cesar
    \xe the things which are Cæsar's
    \so Mk.12.17
    \ng nominal
    \xv Kah wame nuttaiheog, kuttaiheog, kah kuttaiheog nuttaiheog,...
    \xe And all mine are thine, and thine are mine;...'    Jn.17.10√ { Compare Mayhew
    \so s version, below. }

    \se ?!|wuttaiheu|
    \nt +
    \ps AI+O, ?possessive verb
    \ge `to be sb's'
    \so frequent
    \xv nuttaihe
    \xe (is) mine, belongs to me
    \so Ps.60.7
    \xv nippe nutaihen
    \xe the water is ours
    \so Gen.26.20√
    \xv wame ne nauman nuttaihe
    \xe all that thou seest is mine
    \so Gen.31.43
    \xv wame ... nutaihéin
    \xe all ... is ours
    \so Gen.31.16√
    \xv ahtóonk kuttahein
    \xe the inheritance shall be ours
    \so Mk.12.7
    \xv ..., newutche wame ne wanegik ut Egypt kuttaiheeu.
    \xe ...; for the good of all the land of Egypt is yours.
    \so Gen.45.20
    \ng 2p
    \nt +

    \xv ..., anaquabhettit nemattinnónog naish uttiyeu wadtaihéean, ut nuhhogkát,...
    \xe ...: before our brethren, discern thou what is thine with me,...
    \so Gen.32.32
    \ng 2->_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv noh wadtiheit
    \xe "he whose right it is", to whom it belongs
    \so Ezek.21.27; +Gen.38.25
    \xv Kah wame watiheoneg k∞tiheneunk, kah watiheaneg n∞tiheneunk;...
    \xe And all mine are thine, and thine are mine;..
    \so Jn.17.10(M)
    \ng 1->_3p_ participle; 2->3p-pro; 2->_3p_ participle; 1->3p-pro
    \nt +

    \xv ..., wuttaiheesh ne ahtóan.
    \xe ...; keep that thou hast unto thyself.
    \so Gen.33.9
    \ng 2->0
    \nt +


\lx wuttamantamunat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 210
\ps v.t. / TI1a(-O), mental final
\ge `to be troubled, to have care or trouble about anything'; +`to be distressed, grieved; to be troubled at sth'
    \xv k∞tamantam
    \xe thou art careful, full of care
    \so Lk.10.42
    \xv wuttamantam
    \xe he is or was troubled
    \so Dan.5.9
    `grieved'    Jn.21.17
    \nt +
    \xv n∞tamanatam
    \xe I am troubled
    \so Ps.38.6

    \xv wuttamanatam∞k
    \xe be ye troubled
    \so Is.32.11

    \se !|wuttamanatamheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, causative
    \ge `to be grievous (to sb), to be troubled by sb' i.e. "to cause sb to be grieved"
    \so Gen.21.11,12; Ntv.Wr.154.28
    \xv Onk yeu ∞saume wutamanatamhukqun ut anaquabit Abraham newutche wunnaumonuh.
    \xe And the thing was very grievous in Abraham's sight because of his son.
    \so Gen.21.11
    \ng 0->3, objective inanimate subject
    |... nenauun wunnummohkit moochukke nootammantahikkummin yeug neteahteamongganunnonog inglishmonsog yeu ut nuttahkenannit wonoh noomarshinnannit numuhtukqunnonit ...| "..., we truly are much troubled by these English neighbors of ours being on this land of ours, and in our marsh and trees."    Ntv.Wr. 158.27-29  { 0->1p, absolute inanimate subject (G&B.520-521)

    \xv ..., Ahque wutamanatamhukqush ut anaquabean newutche wusken,...
    \xe ..., Let it not be grievous in thy sight because of the lad,...
    \so Gen.21.12
    \ng 0->2 imperative, inanimate subject
\cf wutt∞antamunát

    (|Wuttanantamunat.| `To care'    C.41/184; {distinct stem})

[Narragansett [xnt] |nétop notammâuntam| `friend, I am busy'    R.W.49.
Cree |áthem-issu| `he is difficult' (?); |-- ehayoo| `he perplexeth, embarrasseth him'    Howse.]

\et H.3864-3872; 3864 *wetame∙lentamwa TI `preoccupied'; 3867 *wetami- PV `busy'

\lx wuttameheónat
\va wuttameheau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 211
\ps v.t. an. / TA
\twn |wuttamehteau|
\ge `to trouble, to disturb, to discomfort, to hinder'; +`to let sb; to offend sb; to restrain sth from sb'
    \xv ..., kah yeuyeu matta woh wuttamheóog ne ahchewesehettit.
    \xe ...: and now nothing will be restrained from them, which they have imagined to do.
    \so Gen.11.6
    \ng ?X->3p+0 negative objective
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Toh kittinheimún? kah toh kittinne wuttamhish ...
    \xe ..., What hast thou done unto us? and what have I offended thee,...
    \so Gen.20.9
    \ng 1->2 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ∞tameheonaoont
    \xe to trouble them
    \so 2 Chr.32.18
    \xv ..., Martha, Martha, ken k∞tamantam, kah kumm∞cheke wuttamhik teaguasinish.
    \xe ..., Martha, Martha, thou art careful and troubled about many thngs:'    Lk.10.41  { `careful
    \so in its original, literal sense! }
    \nt +
    \xv Jesus wahteunk ut wuhhogkat, ukkodnetuhtaénúmoh m∞hm∞squeuttamunneau, nah wuttinuh, Yeu k∞taméhukqunneau?
    \xe When Jesus knew in himself that his disciples murmured at it, he said unto them, Doth this offend you?
    \so Jn.6.61
    \nt +
    \xv Newajeh kodpeyaônunog n[e]n Paule, pasukqut kah wonk, qut mattannit n∞tamehikqun.
    \xe Wherefore we would have come unto you, even I Paul, once and again; but Satan hindered us.
    \so 1 Thess.2.18
    \nt +
    \xv ..., webe noh yeuyeu wadtaméhit, pish wuttamhuau nô pajeh amaunonat.
    \xe ...: only he who now letteth will let, until he be taken out of the way.
    \so 2 Thess.2.7
    \ng indefinite object
    \nt +

    \xv Ne wunnegen matta meech∞un weyaus, asuh matta wuttattum∞un wine, asuh matta onkatog, uttoh adt woh keemat togkussittassuk, asuh adt wuttamhìt, asuh adt nochumwéhit.
    \xe It is good neither to eat flesh, nor to drink wine, nor any thing whereby thy brother stumbleth, or is offended, or is made weak.
    \so Rom.14.21
    \nt +

    \xv Kah wuttinuh nahog, ahque wuttamhegq,...
    \xe And he said unto them, Hinder me not,...
    \so Gen.24.56
    \ng 2p->1 imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ahque wuttamheh
    \xe do not trouble me
    \so Lk.11.7
    \xv ahque wuttameh kuhhog
    \xe do not trouble thyself
    \so Lk.7.6
    \xv howan wuttamhehkitch
    \xe let no man trouble me
    \so Gal.6.17√
    \ng 3->1 prohibitive
    (|wuttamhuönat| `to hinder'; |n∞tamehhu@wam| `I hinder'    C.194)

[Narragansett [xnt] |cotámmish| (|k∞tamehish| C.194) `I hinder you'; |cotammúme|, |cotamme| `you trouble me'    R.W.49.
Cree |ootumme-thoo| `he is busy'; |otúmmehayoo| `he interrupts him'    Howse 82.
    Algonquian [alg] |Koni kit ondamihin, ninge.--Kawin kit ondamihisi, nind anis| `peut-être que je vous dérange, ma mère.--Vous ne me dérangez, ma fille'    Cq.302a.]
    \nt +?

\et H.3864-3872 *wetami- `busy, delay, occupy, play, preoccupied', 3868 *wetamihe∙wa TA `delay'; cf. G.2002, (13c) *wetam- `busy, occupied', presumably taking the Ojibwa forms to be anomalous.


\lx wuttamehpunau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 211
    \nt +
\ps AI
\ge `to be afflicted, in tribulation, in trouble, troubled, vexed'
\so Deut.4.30; Ps.6.3(M),25.16,66.14,69.17,...; Mt.17.15,24.21; Jn.12.27; 2 Cor.1.4; Eph.3.13; Rev.1.9,2.9,10
    \xv Appean wuttámehpunônat, kah wame yeush kenuhkukkonkqunash,...
    \xe When thou art in tribulation, and all these things are come upon thee,...
    \so Deut.4.30
    \xv Nukketeahogkou wonk mishe wuttamehpunnau:
    \xe My soul is also sore vexed:...
    \so Ps.6.3(M); (E): |onkupunnau|
    \xv ...: newutche nonsiyeu kah n∞tamehpunâm.
    \xe ...: for I am desolate and afflicted.
    \so Ps.25.16; (M): |nootamehpunam|; Ps.31.9,69,17,119.117(M)
    \xv Matta nag wuttammepunoog onatuh onkatogane:...
    \xe They are not in trouble as other men:...
    \so Ps.73.5; (M): |wuttamehpunoooog|

    \xv Nish nussissit∞nash an∞wohpash, kah nutt∞n an∞wohpash wadtamehpunaon.
    \xe Which my lips have uttered, and my mouth hath spoken, when I was in trouble.
    \so Ps.66.14; (M): |watamehpunaon|
    \xv K∞wehquetumaiip wadtammehpunaan kah kuppohquohwununup,...
    \xe Thou calledst in trouble, and I delivered thee;...
    \so Ps.81.7; (M): |watamehpunnaan|

    \se wuttamehpunaNau
    \ps TA, applicative
    \ge `to afflict sb'
    \so Ps.88.7
    \xv ...: kah k∞tamehpunaseh nashpe wame kuttugk∞mog.
    \xe ...; and thou hast afflicted me with all thy waves.
    \so Ps.88.7; (M): |kootamehpunnassip|
    \ng 2->1
\nt Follow up needed: Action noun and preverb forms, well attested.

\et See |onkapunanonat|, T.108a, here with AI *-e∙- final, as H.819.

\lx wuttattamunat
\va wadt-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 211
\ps v.i. / TI1a (TI-O)
\ge `to drink'
\so 2 Sam.11.11; Neh.8.12; Esth.3.15
    \xv wuttattam
    \xe he drank
    \so 1 K.19.6
    \xv wuttattamwog
    \xe they drank
    \so Ex.24.11
    (|n∞tâttam| `I drink'; |nâgum wuttâttam| `he drinks'    C.189)

    \xv qut kuttumma wuttattamon,...
    \xe except I drink it,...
    \so Mt.26.42
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah tuppuksinwog Rephidim, kah wanne nippeno missinninnuh woh wodtatog.
    \xe ..., and [they] pitched in Rephidim: and there was no water for the people to drink.
    \so Ex.17.1
    \nt +
    \xv ... uttoh meech, kah toh wadtattam?...
    \xe ... what I eat or what I drink?...
    \so 2 Sam.19.35√
    \xv Newutche asuh metséog asuh wuttattamóg, asuh uttoh aseóg, ussek wame en wussohsum∞onganit God.
    \xe Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God.
    \so 1 Cor.10.31√

    \xv wuttattash
    \xe drink thou
    \so Gen.24.14, 18; Lev.10.9
    \xv wuttattam∞k
    \xe drink ye
    \so Cant.5.1
    \xv wuttattaj
    \xe let him drink
    \so Jn.7.37

    \se !|wuttattamweheau|, !|wutattamweheau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA(+O), causative final
    \ge `to make sb (to) drink sth; to water sb'
    \so Gen.19.32,33,34,35,21.19,29.2; Ps.36.8,60.3
    \xv Onk wutattamweheaog ∞shuoh wine ne nohkog,...
    \xe And they made their father drink wine that night:...'    Gen.19.33  { 3p->3
    \so +0 absolute }
    \xv ..., newutche ne wutch wutahamonganit ∞tattamheonneau floksoh:...
    \xe ...; for out of that well they watered the flocks:...'    Gen.29.2  { 3p->3
    \so subordinative }
    \xv ..., kah k∞tattamheoog kussepue weekontamwongash.
    \xe ...; and thou shalt make them drink of the river of thy pleasures.
    \so Ps.36.8; (M) |kootattamheoog|
    \ng 2->3p+0(p) (primary) objective
    \nt +
    \xv ...: k∞tattamhimun quoshkussippâm∞e wine.
    \xe ...: thou hast made us to drink the wine of astonishment.
    \so Ps.60.3; (M) |kootattamhimunonup|
    \ng 2->1p+0 (preterite) absolute

    \xv ...: wonk wuttattamweheuntuh wine yeu nohkog,...
    \xe ...: let us make him drink wine this night also;...
    \so Gen.19.34
    \ng 12->3+0 imperative

\nt (|wuttattamunat| has the form of a verb transitive and frequentative.
    The earlier form of the intransitive is not found in Eliot. As |meechinat| means primarily `to eat vegetal food', the radical verb from which |wuttattamunat| is derived signified `to drink water'. This earlier form, without reduplication, may be traced in some of the phrases given by Roger Wiliiams and Cotton :
    |Aquie waúmatous.| (|ahque wameattoush|) `Do not drinke all.'    R.W.12√
    \xv Sun woh k∞tam eyeu.
    \xe Will you smoke it now?' [i.e. `drink
    \so (?)]    C.120/241.√

    There was another word, meaning to drink (intransitive), whose original form it is not easy to trace in its compounds. The radical appears to be |sip|, related perhaps to |saupáe|, |sabáe| (q.v.), |suppequash| (`tears'); possibly to |sepe|, |sep|.
    \xv kogkeissippamwáen
    \xe a drunkard
    \so (|koghesip-|    C.; |kakesup-|    Mass.Ps.)
    \xv ..., tohneit wonk ohksippamwëan,
    \xe ..., if you would leave off drinking too.
    \so C.119/240√ [|ahque-sip-(?)|]
    \xv nuttann∞tam matokqs woh matta missippano sokanunk
    \xe I will command the cloud that it rain no rain upon it
    \so Is.5.6
    |tápsippámhettit| (|tâpsuppamwehhittit|    Mass.Ps.) `when they have well drunk' [|tápi-sippam-|]    Jn.2.10
    \xv nuppomgranatsum ∞weeksippáonk
    \xe the (sweet? |wekon|?) juice of my pomegranates
    \so Cant.8.2
\cf mussuppeg
\ge a tear

[Narragansett [xnt] |Niccàwkatone| `I am thirstie.'    R.W.10 (= |nuk-kohkutt∞n|); |Pàutous notatàm.| `Give me drinke.'; |Wuttàttash| `Drinke.'    R.W.12; |Wuttattumutta.| `Let us drinke.'    R.W.14.]√

\et ?*wentantamwa TI `to drink from sth' (with a partitive sense?), with the ablative initial and the oral final.

\lx wuttauatongqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
    \nt +
\nt Remark: There are noticeable numbers of examples with the changed vowel in the indicative stem, paralleling the variation in the derived verbal noun.
\ps AI
\ge `to cry, cry with a loud voice, lift up one's voice, make a noise'
\so Gen.16.21,41.43; Num.14.1; Ps.98.4; Mt.21.15,27.50; Mk.5.39; Jn.5.28; Acts 16.28,21.36; Rev.6.10,10.3,19.17
    \xv ... kah n∞wadtauatongqus.
    \xe ..., and make a noise:
    \so Ps.55.2
    \ng 1 indicative
    \xv ..., kah mukkiog wadtauatonkqussuog temple ut,...
    \xe ..., and the children crying in the temple,...
    \so Mt.21.15
    \ng 3p indicative
    \xv Kah mishont∞wáe wuttauatunkqussu, ..., kah wadtauatonkqussit,...
    \xe And [he] cried with a loud voice, ...: and when he had cried,...
    \so Rev.10.3
    \ng 3 indicative; 3 changed conjunct

    \xv Jesus wonk wadtauatunkqussit, nupp∞.
    \xe Jesus, when he had cried again with a loud voice, yielded up the ghost.
    \so Mt.27.50
    \ng 3 changed conjunct
    \xv Wadtauatonkqussetettit, Israeléog aninnumaiinean,...
    \xe Crying out, Men of Israel, help:...
    \so Acts 21.28
    \ng for |-hettit|; 3p changed conjunct

    \xv Weekontamwaeu wuttauatongqussek en Jehovah...
    \xe Make a joyful noise unto the Lord,...
    \so Ps.98.4
    \ng 2p imperative

    \se wutauatongqussue
    \ps PreN
    \ge `voice of' (?head-first)
    \so Ps.66.8
    \xv ..., ayimau wuttauatongqussue tabuttantam∞onk n∞tamoúnat.
    \xe ..., and make the voice of his praise to be heard.
    \so Ps.66.8(E); (M) |waenomamaonkane oowadtauatunkqussuonk|

    \se wuttauatongquodt
    \ps II
    \ge `a voice'
    \so Acts 9.4
    \xv Kah penushau en ohkeit, kah n∞tam wadtauatongquot, n∞wau, Saul, Saul, tohwutch woskenehhean
    \xe And he fell to the earth, and heard a voice saying unto him, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
    \so Acts 9.4
    \ng i.e. impersonal "it voiced, there was voicing"

\nt Remark: Most items with this pair of finals, |-qussu| and |-quodt|, have meanings in the domain of perception, usually of the "verb of undergoing" type. This pair of verbs is then exceptional in denoting an act, or, at least, an event.


\lx wuttaun

\va -taun
\va -tân
\ve spurious form

    constr. |wuttaunoh| `the daughter of'    1 Chr.2.40

    \xe my daughter

    \xe your daughters

    \xe thy daughters

    \xv Newutche nuppeam ponumunat penuánittuonk wosketomp, ayeuuhkonittue ∞shoh, wuttaunìn ayeu[u]hkonittue okasoh, wushímin ayeuuhkonittue wasenumonche.
    \xe For I am come to set a man at variance against his father, and the daughter against her mother, and the daughter in law against her mother in law.

    \nt Remark: Some of the earlier grammarians/lexicographers take the -t- to be the sandhi "t", and list the morpheme as having an initial vowel--for instance Cuoq (Cq.38ab) and Lacombe (Lac.G.20).

[Narragansett [xnt] |Tou pìtch wuttìn?| `Where wil the wind be?'; |Nqénouhìck wuttìn| `I stay for a wind.'; |Wunnêgitch wuttìn|    `When the wind is faire.'    R.W.86-87.

\lx wuttinau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
    \nt +
\ps TA+O, manual final, transitive initial |wut-| `from'
\twn |wuttinum|, TI1b

\so Gen.2.23,3.19,21.30; Ex.21.14; Num. 11.25; Deut.19.12,30.4
    \xv ..., pish hennou Ishah, newutche wuttinau wosketompaut.
    \xe ...: she shall be called Woman, because she was taken out of Man.
    \so Gen.2.23; (E0): |wuttinâu|
    \ng X->3 objective
    \xv ..., Newutche yeug nesausuk tahsuog squoshimwog shepsemesog k∞tnôóg nunnutcheganit,...
    \xe ..., For these seven ewe lambs shalt thou take of my hand,...
    \so Gen.21.30
    \ng 2->3p objective
    \xv ...: pish k∞tin nut-altarumut onk woh nushau.
    \xe ...; thou shalt take him from mine altar, that he may die.
    \so Ex.21.14
    \ng 2->3 objective
    \xv ..., kah ne pish k∞tinukqun.
    \xe ..., and from thence will he fetch thee:
    \so Deut.30.4
    \ng 3->2 objective

    \xv ..., kah neh keteáhogkounoh, wódtinonche Haran,...
    \xe ..., and the souls that they had gotten in Haran;...'    Gen.12.5 { 3(p)->_3
    \so _ participle }


\lx wuttininüme@kossinat
\lg *Wampanoag [*wam]
\so Trumbull 212
    \xv wuttinnumuhkoattinneat
    \xe to be served
    \so C.208


\lx wuttinneumuhkauáonk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
\ps n.
\ge `his service, a serving (him), service rendered to'
\so Ezra 6.18


\lx wuttinneumuhkauónat
\va wuttinneumuhkauau
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
\ps v.t. an. / TA(+O?), corporal final
\ge `to serve (him)'
    \dv This contains the corporal final |-uhkaw-| TA, as B.1962, 16.122,125, pp.352-353. It differs from the verb of possession derived from the underlying noun in its dynamic/non-stative sense, and, as often, seems to imply a use or application of the whole body or being. The base appears to be that of the verb of possession, viz. |wu-|+|-inninn(e)-|+|-um-|, which would, in crude terms, require, say, "they served him" to have an interpretation such as "they caused him (permitted him, acted in such a way as to allow him) to have them as servants" or, better perhaps, "they acted as servants to him". Note the presence of the reflexive objects and the doubled-up prefix in a number of the examples.
    \nt +
\so 2 Chr.29.11; 34.33
    \xv Nabo neese kodtumwae wuttinneúmohkauaog Chedorlaomer;...
    \xe Twelve years they served Chedorlaomer,...'    Gen.14.4  { 3p->3
    \so absolute }
    \xv Aninnumah nummittumwussog, kah neechanog newutche nag k∞tenûmuhkaúunup nuhhog, kah moncheti:...
    \xe Give me my wives and my children, for whom I have served thee, and let me go:...
    \so Gen.30.26√
    \ng independent, 1->2+3(?), theme 4; |nuhhog| suggests some kind of reflexive syntax, as if "caused thee to have me as servant"?? also e.g. Gen.47.19, Mt.6.24
    \xv ...: noh pamuhshadt pahke mayut pish nootinninnumuhkonkq.
    \xe ...: he that walketh in a perfect way, he shall serve me.
    \so Ps.101.6(M)
    \nt +
    \xv ...: woh mo k∞tinninneumuhkauoh kuhhog God kah Mammon.
    \xe .... Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
    \so Mt.6.24
    \ng commonplace error of number; reflexive |kuhhog|?; |-oh| due to negative (G&B. 533)
    \nt +
    \xv Wanne howae wuttinnéumun woh wuttinneumuhkauwo nesuoh sontimoh ...
    \xe No servant can serve two masters:...
    \so Lk.16.13
    \ng absolute negative
    \nt +

    \xv ...; webe ahque auwohteagk chippinnu∞onk wunuhkomunat weyaus, qut nashpe womonittuonk wuttinneumuhkôadtegk nishnoh pasuk.
    \xe ...; only use not liberty for an occasion to the flesh, but by love serve one another.
    \so Gal.5.13
    \ng 2p imperative, reciprocal
    \nt +

    \se !|wuttineumuhkonau|
    \nt ?+
    \ps TA, applicative in |-ôN-|
    \ge "to make sb a servant", factitive to the possessive or predicative denominal verb?
    caus. |..., kah wutch siogke missinnainneat uttoh adt wuttinneumuhkonuninumukup.| `..., and from the hard bondage wherein thou wast made to serve,'    Is.14.3√ { changed conjunct, X->2, theme 4; perhaps applicative final |-ôN-| following |-hk-| (B.1962, 16.104); |-un-| not identified }
    \xv Weekontamwe wuttinneumuhkonittinneat, neyane ut Lordut, kah matta wosketompaut.
    \xe With good will doing service, as to the Lord, and not to men:
    \so Eph.6.7
    \ng X subject, reciprocal [c.f. forms at G&B. 543]
    \nt +
    \xv ...: matta k∞tinninneumuhkônuwahinn∞ nashpe mag∞onk,...
    \xe ... I have not caused thee to serve with an offering,...
    \so Is.43.23√
    \ng causative to applicative?, 1->2, theme 4


\lx wuttinniin
\va wuttinnaiinneat
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
    = |wut-unne-aiin-neat| `to be like (or such as) himself, to be of his (own) kind' (?)
    \xv neâne unnantog ut wuttahhut, ne wuttinniin
    \xe as he thinketh in his heart, so is he
    \so Prov.23.7
    \xv ne pish wuttinniin
    \xe so will be his manner
    \so 1 Sam.27.11
    \xv neaniit wuttinneumin, ne wuttinniin wussontimomun
    \xe as with the servant, so with his master
    \so Is.24.2
    \xv wuttinniin howan
    \xe whosoever
    \so Mt.16.24,25
    (|wuttinnaiin howan|    Prov.6.29)
\cf unnaiinneat
    \dv An n-paradigm (subordinative) form to |unnayeu|, q.v., T+.170b.
    \nt +
\nt Follow up needed: Move this entry to |unnayeu|.

\lx wuttinum
\va wuttinnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
    \nt +
\ps TI1a
\twn |wuttinau|, TA
\ge `to take sth, take sth off; to find sth (somewhere)'
\dv |wut-| `from' + |-un-| `by hand'
\so Ex.5.11; Lev.3.9,14.15
    \xv ...: wees ne na ohtag, kah mamusse wadtan ne pish ∞tinnumun kishke wussukqunnátikkonne wuskonit ...
    \xe ...; the fat thereof, and the whole rump, it shall he take off hard by the backbone;...
    \so Lev.3.9
    \xv Kah sephausuen pish nohwuttinum né wunnonteamese pummee,...
    \xe And the priest shall take some of the log of oil,...
    \so Lev.14.15; (E1): |noh wuttinum|
    \ng Does the initial render the partitive?

    \xv Monchek, neemunnum∞k moskehtuash uttoh woh wadtinnumóg,...
    \xe Go ye, get you straw where ye can find it:...
    \so Ex.5.11

\et B. no.301, 83, 113/471 *wenteneewa `he takes him from there by hand', H.3775 *wentenamwa TI `to take thence'


\lx wuttinnúm
\va wuttinnum-
\va wuttinninneum-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
    \nt Remark: The root is |-inninn-|, often syncopated. See s.v. |inin|, T+.29a.
    \nt +
\ps n. / (dependent) NA, possessed form; occurrence as indefinite possessive is common, with the (infecting) suffix |-un-| (G&B.491).
    \nt Remark: The root is barely attested in Massachusett in isolation; see T.86b, under |nnìn|. The present form is (quasi-)dependent in the sense `servant', and at times appears to be treated as a unit, though it is hard to sort out what is to be attributed to the idiosyncracies of verbs of possession.
    \nt +
\ge `(his or her) servant'; +`maid, man'
\so Gen.16.3
    \xv wuttinnúmun
    \xe the servant
    \so Gen.24.5,9√
    \ng indefinite possessive
    \xv Neyane ann∞ne wuttinneumun,...
    \xe But as an hired servant,...
    \so Lev.25.40√
    \ng indefinite possessive
    \xv Na neeswe wosketompae missinnoe kittinninneum, kah mittumwossisse missinnoe kittinninneum, ..., nag pish kutadounnaôog, wosketompae kah mittamwossisse wuttinninneumun.
    \xe Both thy bondmen, and thy bondmaids, ...; of them shall ye buy bondmen and bondmaids.
    \so Lev.25.44√
    \xv ...nush∞k nish noh kittinneum∞óog neg mósogquehtauoncheg Baal Peoroh,
    \xe ..., Slay ye every one his men that were joined unto Baalpeor.
    \so Num.25.5
    \nt +
    \xv nuttinnum
    \xe my maid
    \so (servant)    Gen.16.2
    \xv nuttineneum
    \xe my man
    \so El.Gr.12
    \xv wuttinneumoh
    \xe his servant
    \so (constr.)    2 Sam.13.18
    |wuttinnumoh|    Gen.30.7
    \xv kittinnum
    \xe thy servant
    \so Gen.16.6
    \xv kuttinninnumw∞
    \xe your servant('s)
    \so Gen.19.2
    \nt +
    |kittinneum|    Neh.1.7,8, +Gen.32.4
    \xv ... nush∞k nish noh kittinneum∞óog...
    \xe ..., Slay ye every one his men ...
    \so Num.25.5
    \ng 2p possessive, plural: "your men"
    \nt +
    \xv Kah n∞wadchan oxinog, kah assesog, floksog, wosketompae wuttinneumuneunk, kah mittumwussisse wuttinneumuneunk,...
    \xe And I have oxen, and asses, flocks, and men servants, and women servants:...
    \so Gen.32.5
    \ng plural to possessive indefinite
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wehkomau pasuk∞ wuttinneumunneuh,...
    \xe And he called one of the servants,...
    \so Lk.15.26
    \ng obviative to possessive indefinite
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche ken matta wonk wuttinneumein, qut wunnaumoniin;...
    \xe Wherefore thou art no more a servant, but a son;...
    \so Gal.4.7
    \ng apparently, predicative use of indefinite possessives
    \nt +
    (|Wuttinninümin| `A servant'
    \xv Nuttinninnuum, -og
    \xe My servant, my servants
    \xv Wuttinninnu@moh
    \xe His servant
    \so C.19/167
    \xv Wuttinnumin
    \xe A servant
    \so C.74/208)


\lx wuttinnúmuhkausu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
\ps adj. an. / AI
\ge `(is or was) serving'
\so Gen.29.20 (`he served')
