\so Trumbull 212
\ps n.
\ge `service done, the doing of service'
\so Ezek.29.18


\lx wuttinnúmunneat
\va wuttinnumu
\va wuttinninneumuneu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
\ps v.i. / AI(+O), possessive verb; this commonly (overtly) contains the (infecting) indefinite possessive suffix |-in^eï| (G&B.491), and this formation should probably have a distinct lemma, once the material has been sifted.
\ge `to be a servant, to serve'; commonly "to be, become sb's servant, serve sb"
    \nt Remark: This common verb needs more extended study. It certainly is used as a verb of possession, "to have sb as servant". What is not clear is whether it can also be a verb of being in Bloomfield's sense i.e. equivalent to a simple nominal predication, "to be a servant", the doubts being partly a result of the stem-like treatment of the nominal possessive that it incorporates. Inconsistencies in its use and uncertainties about the syntax of AI+O verbs add to the difficulties. (The objects of AI verbs are formally third person, but may refer to speaker or addressee, since the independent pronouns are possessive forms [G&B.507]; hence the notation with quotation marks used in this entry as a warning.) The status of the indefinite possessive suffix remains uncertain, because it is liable to be syncopated and can perhaps be apocopated.
    \nt +
\so Ex.21.7
    \xv ..., Kanaan ohquanumunach ∞tinninneumuneuh wuttinneumoh weematoh.
    \xe ..., Cursed be Canaan; a servant of servants shall he be unto his brethren.'    Gen.9.25 { ?3'->3' objective, with subject |wuttinneumoh weematoh|, and pronominal object; lit. "his brother
    \so s servants shall have him as servant" }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttinnumu wosketompuh kah mittamwossissoh...
    \xe ..., and [he had] menservants and maidservants,...'    Gen.12.16  { 3->3
    \so indicative }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah pish ∞tinninnúmunneáuh,...
    \xe ..., and [they] shall serve them,...'    Gen.15.13  { 3p->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche ken neemat, sun woh n∞tinninneum kuhhog wutch monteag ? ...
    \xe ..., Because thou art my brother, shouldest thou therefore serve me for nought? ...
    \so Gen.29.15
    \ng 1->3 indicative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., nen kittinninneum nuhhog nesausuk tahshit kodtumwae wutch Rachel ...
    \xe ..., I will serve thee seven years for Rachel ...
    \so Gen.29.18
    \ng 2->"1"(3); E0,1&2; note the absence of the |-∞-| seen in Gen.29.25, giving this the appearance of a possessed noun rather than a verb of possession; but then |nuhhog| is left hanging.
    \nt +
    \xv ...? sunnummatta k∞tinninnumeúmus nuhhog wutch Rachel?
    \xe ..., did not I serve with thee for Rachel? ...
    \so Gen.29.25
    \ng 2->"1"(3); on inflection, see G&B 545
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wosketomp maguk wuttónoh, wutche mittamwussisse wuttinnúmunneat, matta pish amaeu neane wuttinnúmunneunk.
    \xe And if a man sell his daughter to be a maidservant, she shall not go out as the menservants do.
    \so Ex.21.7√
    \ng X->3 ?
    \xv Neyane ann∞ne wuttinneumun, onatuh anyeapeyont, pish k∞weetomuk: nó pajeh Jubile kodtum∞ut, pish k∞tinninneumun,
    \xe But as a hired servant, and as a sojourner, he shall be with hee, and shall serve thee unto the year of jubilee:
    \so Lev.25.40
    \ng 2->3, objective
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche tohkonogque nutchippinnúin wutch wame wosketompaut, ohch nutayeu nuhhog ∞tinninneumunneaóont wame,...
    \xe For though I be free from all men, yet have I made myself servant unto all, ...
    \so 1 Cor.9.19
    \ng 3p->3; |nuhhog| being the object of TA |ayeuau| in a presumably non-idiomatic factitive construction
    \nt +

    \xv Neit Sontim neh wadtinninneumit kodtummonteanumukqut,...
    \xe Then the lord of that servant was moved with compassion,...'    Mt.18.27 { participle, _3_->3
    \so }
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche uttiyeuoh ane missugkenuk? noh apit metsinneát, asuh noh wadtinninneumimuk,...
    \xe For whether is greater, he that sitteth at meat, or he that serveth? ...
    \so Lk.22.27
    \ng participle, X->_3_
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche kenaau wadtinneumit matcheseonk kutchippémw∞ wutch sampweusseonganit.
    \xe for when ye were the servants of sin, ye were free from righteousness.
    \so Rom.6.20
    \ng presumably: _3_->"2p"(3) participle, with 2p pronoun object and personified/animated subject
    \nt +
    \xv Qut yeuyeu chàpinnitteaog wutch matcheseonganit, kah wadtinninnúmut GOD kutahtomw∞ kummeechummuongan∞ en sampweusseonganit,...
    \xe But now being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness,...
    \so Rom.6.22; E1: |wadtinninnúmit|
    \ng presumably 3->(2p), with ellipsis
    \nt +

    \xv Misinninnuog wuttinnúmish, kah wutohtimoneash nauaeihtunkwush,...
    \xe Let people serve thee, and nations bow down to thee:...
    \so Gen.27.29
    \ng 2->3p
    \nt +
    \xv Kah howan kodmisssugkenuk, wuttinneumegk.
    \xe And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant:
    \so Mt.20.27
    \ng 2p->3
    \nt +
    \xv Kutapwhutteomwop wutch neanóadtik ahque kenaau wuttinneumhettich wosketompaog.
    \xe Ye are bought with a price; be not ye the servants of men.
    \so 1 Cor.7.23
    \ng 3p->"2p"(3), with 2p pronoun object
    \nt +


\lx wuttinnúmunneunk
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 212
\ps n. coll. / NA, animate plural to indefinite possessive in |-in^eï|
\ge `the servants collectively'
\so Ex.21.7
    |wuttinneumunneunk|    Eph.6.5
\cf wuttinnúm
    \nt +



\lx wuttinnunkumôin
\va wuttinonk-
\va wuttinnonkumóin
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 213
\ps n. / NA?
\ge `a kinsman'
    \nt Remark: The lemma is probably an indefinite possessor form |wu-...-in(eï)| (G&B 491, 500, T.172a, s.v. |unne|) to a stem |unnunkum-|. The precise morphological relationship of this apparent noun stem to |adtonkqs| (T. 4a), with a different initial, and to the TA verb stem |unnunkum-| (T+. 173b) eludes me at present. Both forms exemplified here from Romans could on the face of it be TA (absolute) verb forms, but the existence of a nominal form seems certain and these can be taken to exemplify it. The best hypothesis that I can make at present is that these are instances of Bloomfield's "undergoer" nouns (1962, 14.99, 242-243; and perhaps 16.37, 337), identical in form to the indefinite subject form of the TA verb. This suggests that the lemma should have the form |unnunkum(au)|, and examples are given below.
    \nt +
\so Ruth 3.12; 4.1, +Lk.1.61, Rom.9.3
    \xv ..., wosketomp kuppaswauwômukqun, pasuk noh nahohtoe kuttinnunkumoun.
    \xe ..., The man is near of kin unto us, one of our next kinsmen.
    \so Ruth 2.20
    \nt +
    \xv Kah yeuyeu, wunnomwayeuonk, nen kuppas∞tauwamsh, qut nná wutinnonkumóin paswe onk nen.
    \xe And now it is true that I am thy near kinsman: howbeit there is a kinsman nearer than I.
    \so Ruth 3.12
    \nt +
    \xv ..., noh unnehikquean ne unnonkum∞ ahusseet, ne naj, usseitch unnonkumau wuttusséonk,
    \xe ..., that if he will perform unto thee the part of a kinsman, well; let him do the kinsman's part:...
    \so Ruth 3.13
    \xv Wonkom∞k Herodian nuttinnonkum,...
    \xe Salute Herodion my kinsman. ...
    \so Rom.16.11
    \nt +
    \xv Wonkom∞k Andronicus, kah Junia nuttinnunkumóog,...
    \xe Salute Andronicus and Junia, my kinsmen,...
    \so Rom.16.7
    \nt +
\cf weetompain

    \se !|innonkumóhtu|
    \nt +
    \ps N? locative? collective?
    \so Gen.24.4
    \xv Qut woh kuttôm nehenwonche nutohket, kah nuttinonkumóhtu ...
    \xe But thou shalt go unto my country, and to my kindred,...
    \so Gen.24.4
\cf unnunkumau
\nt +
    \nt +

\et TA verb: A.374, H.712-713, G.1965, item 11, p. 213a: *eΘa∙nkwo∙me∙wa, referring to Geary 1945, 40.


\lx wuttinuh
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 213
\nt Remark: Entry requires further work including consolidation with other scattered entries.
\ps TA(+O), objective form
\twn |ittam| (|uttam|), TI
\ge `he said to him'; +`to ask, command, declare, speak unto, tell sb sth'
\nt G&B 624. (This helpfully lists the page numbers of the scattered occurrences of the forms of this verb in T.)
    \xv ..., asuh matta kutuss∞unah,...
    \xe ..., neither didst thou tell me,...
    \so Gen.21.26
    \ng 2->1+0-obj negative, with mutation and aspectual "absentative"(?)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., matta woh kittinninn∞mun máchuk asuh wunnegik.
    \xe ...: we cannot speak unto thee bad or good.
    \so Gen.24.50
    \ng 1p->2(p) negative absolute
    \xv Kah n∞wau, wunnamuhkut kuttinnonnumw∞, wanne howan quoshodtumwaen tapeneauau nehenwonche wutohket.
    \xe And he said, Verily I say unto you, No prophet is accepted in his own country.
    \so Lk.4.24
    \ng 1->2p+0; formula
    \nt +
    \xv ..., newutche howan woh wuttugqun uttoh pish utt∞che n nag.
    \xe ...: for who can tell him when it shall be?
    \so Eccl.8.7√
    \xv ..., kah okasoh wuttugquoh, Nunnaumon, tohwutch yeu nehheog,...
    \xe ...: and his mother said unto him, Son, why hast thou thus dealt with us? ...'    Lk.2.48  { 3
    \so ->3+0 }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah woh kenamp∞hamunkou, kah kuttugkou, Matta k∞wahenn∞mw∞, uttoh wom∞k.
    \xe ...; and he shall answer and say unto you, I know you not whence ye are:
    \so Lk.13.25
    \ng 3->2p+0
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nuttìnóun nussampweusséaneumun, matta nunnátauaheámun.
    \xe And we said unto him, We are true men; we are no spies:
    \so Gen.42.31
    \ng 1p->3obj.+0; c.f. Gen.44.20,22
    \nt +
    \xv Kah nuttenantam kuttinnunnun nussim, adtóush ut anaquabhettit yeu wadohkitcheg,...
    \xe And I thought to advertise thee, saying, Buy it before the inhabitants,...
    \so Ruth 4.4
    \ng 1->2+0obj.
    \nt +
    \xv Newutche yeu kuttinnunnunan nashpe wuttinn∞waonk LORD,...
    \xe For this we say unto you by the word of the Lord,...
    \so 1 Thess.4.15
    \ng 1p->2p+0obj.
    \nt +
    \xv Kah wuttinuh, wunnamuhkut kutussumw∞ yeu nuppówaonk, ponaskehtuaenin neetskeh kuhhog,...
    \xe And he said unto them, Ye will surely say unto me this proverb, Physician, heal thyself:...
    \so Lk.4.23
    \ng 2p->1+0
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu ∞che unneau ukqutchheaonganou, woh wuttitaspunnanónaout,...
    \xe This they said, tempting him, that they might have to accuse him. ...
    \so Jn.8.6
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Kummahche unnunnunnau, kah matta ken∞tam∞uneau,...
    \xe ..., I have told you already, and ye did not hear:...
    \so Jn.9.27
    \ng 1->2p+0
    \nt +
    \xv Jesus wuttinuh, Sunummatta kuttinn∞mus, wunnamptaman, woh kenaum wussohsumóonk GOD?
    \xe Jesus saith unto her, Said I not unto thee, that, if thou wouldest believe, thou shouldest see the glory of God?
    \so Jn.11.40 { neg. interrog. 1->2, with syncope in |-in-un-|; on |-m-|, see G&B. 545, only reported there for AI stems--perhaps following the vowel of the negative sign here? }; (M): |kuttunnunn∞mus|; also Num.23.26
    \nt +
    \xv ..., sunnummatta ne wonk nuttinnonaóus kutann∞naénûog,...
    \xe ..., Spake I not also to thy messengers ...?
    \so Num.24.12
    \nt +
    \xv Neit woh kuttisseh, neit tohwhutch wutchemukquéog? ...
    \xe Thou wilt say then unto me, Why doth he yet find fault? ...
    \so Rom.9.19
    \ng 2->1+0; mutation in theme 3
    \nt +

    \xv ..., kah Adam uttoh anont nishnoh ôâas uppomantamun ne wuttissowesin.
    \xe ...: and whatsoever Adam called every living creature, that {was} the name thereof.'    Gen.2.19  { 3->3
    \so +_adv_ participle }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah yeu ∞sh∞oh anukquehettit, kah ∞nanumuh nah...
    \xe ...: and this is it that their father spake unto them, and blessed them;...'    Gen.49.28  { 3
    \so ->3p+_0_ participle }
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu ussean, kah ne GOD nukquean, neit woh kuttapenum neepauun,...
    \xe If thou shalt do this thing, and God command thee so, then thou shalt be able to endure,..
    \so Ex.18.23
    \ng 3->2+0
    \nt +
    \xv ..., onk woh n∞wahteoh uttoh woh wonk asit Jehovah.
    \xe ..., that I may know what the Lord will say unto me more.
    \so Num.22.19
    \ng 3->1+_0_ participle
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ne ásóp Wut∞shìmau ne nussin.
    \xe ..., even as the Father said unto me, so I speak.
    \so Jn.12.50
    \ng preterite changed conjunct, 3->1+_adv_
    \nt +
    \xv Newajeh unnog wunnaumonuh Israel, Wanne keteahogkou kenugke kenaau, pish meechu wusquehéonk:...
    \xe Therefore I said unto the children of Israel, No soul of you shall eat blood,...
    \so Lev.17.12
    \ng 1->3+_adv_ changed conjunct }; Num.18.24: |unog| { 1->3p
    \nt +
    \xv ..., na ut unnutup, Mátta kenaau nummissinninnúmog, na ut pish hennóneau, wunneechanoh pomantamóe GOD.
    \xe ..., that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people; there shall they be called the children of the living God.
    \so Rom.9.26
    \ng X->3, pret. conjunct
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Newajeh enunnóg, matta howan woh nuppeyog∞h, qut aninumaúut wutch N∞shit.
    \xe ..., Therefore said I unto you, that no man can come unto me, except it were given unto him of my Father.
    \so Jn.6.65
    \ng 1->2p
    \nt +
    \xv Neit wut∞shin wahteaoun ne nan hower, Jesus adt unnohmp. Kenaumon pomantam:...
    \xe So the father knew that it was at the same hour, in the which Jesus said unto him, Thy son liveth:...
    \so Jn.4.53
    \nt +

    \xv ... ken Christùaen, piuhsuke ussinnan.
    \xe ... If thou be the Christ, tell us plainly.
    \so Jn.10.24
    \ng 2->1p.
    \nt +
    \xv Neit kehchemugquomp peyau kah wuttinuh, Usseh, ken kit-Romannu? n∞wau, Nux.
    \xe Then the chief captain came, and said unto him, Tell me, art thou a Roman? He said, Yea.
    \so Acts.22.27 { 2->1 >
    \nt +

    \se !|wuttitamun| (i.e. !|ittam| (|uttam|, !|itam|)
    \nt +
    \ps TI1a (TI+O), in objective form
    \twn |wuttinuh| (|unnau|)
    \ge `to say sth to, against sth; to pronounce sth sth', etc.
    \nt B. 81, 112/469, item 282 *etamwa
    \xv Kah Moses uttam mukkinnéonk,...
    \xe And Moses said unto the congregation,...
    \so Lev.8.5
    \ng similarly Josh.9.19; |mukkinneonk| appears to be treated as inanimate here? I have not noticed an example of it as an inanimate subject.
    \xv Yeu unnaumatuonk papaume wutchek∞e enninneâonk, ut w∞lle asuh hashbpe hogk∞onganit, ..., wuttittamunat pohki, asuh wuttittamunat nisheneunkquodt.
    \xe This is the law of the plague of leprosy in a garment of woollen or linen, ..., to pronounce it clean, or to pronounce it unclean.
    \so Lev.13.59
    \xv Kah naik figsuhtug kishke mayut, uppeyaontamun, kah wanne teag ∞tinnum∞un, qut webe wunnepaguash, kah wuttitamun, matta meechum dtannegenunnu∞utch, yeu wutch, kah micheme. ...
    \xe And when he saw a fig tree in the way, he came to it, and found nothing thereon, but leaves only, and said unto it, Let no fruit grow on thee henceforward for ever. ...
    \so Mt.21.19
    \xv Kah nauáhettìt wosketompuh uttiyeu neetskeheut ∞weechekompaumuk∞uh, matta toh wuttittamm∞unneau.
    \xe And beholding the man which was healed standing with them, they could say nothing against it.
    \so Acts 4.14
    \xv Kah matta howan yeu uppanne uttam∞un, peississit wunnánumau nashpe masugkenutcheh.
    \xe And without all contradiction the less is blessed of the better.
    \so Heb.7.7

    \xv ..., qut wonk, uttamóg yeu wadchu, ontapush, kah chauopshash ketahhannit, onk pish nnih.
    \xe ..., but also if ye shall say unto this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea; it shall be done.
    \so Mt.21.21
    \xv Noh wohtauogkut n∞tamunat n∞taj uttoh aûdtog Nashauanit moeuwehkomongash,...
    \xe He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches;...
    \so Rev.2.11
    |ádtog|, |áudtag|, |âdtog|    Rev.3.6,13,22

    \xv Kah mattannit wuttinuh, ken wunnaumonait God, uttash yeu qussuk puttukqunnunkanuutch.
    \xe And the devil said unto him, If thou be the Son of God, command this stone that it be made bread.
    \so Lk.4.3; Is.40.9
    \xv ...: utash Judáe keitotanash, moninneuk kum-Manitt∞mw∞.
    \xe ...: say unto the cities of Judah, Behold your God!
    \so Is.40.9

\nt Follow up needed: :
(1) more examples?;
(2) transitivity cf. N.Am. young(ish) vernacular "I was like: `...'"; as in that construction, |-unn-| anticipates the oratio (usually [or always?] recta), and the IO of English is a supernumerary object (B.s "implied goal" pseudo-object);
(3) contrast |wuttugquoh|/|wuttugqun|, Eccl.8.7/Lk.2.48 (i.e. TA abs. vs. TA+O obj.?)
(4) variation due to levelling w.r.t. B.'s distributional statement e.g. Acts 11.7 |nuttuk| `saying unto me', Acts. 11.12 |nuttinuk| `bade me' (c.f. G&B 624)
(5) Redistribute forms listed under |ussinát|, T.175b.
(6) See s.v. |unnau|/|unnónat| for forms with absolute secondary object.
(7) See also |hennau|.

[NOTE. -- The definition was not completed. Above the words "said to" the compiler wrote "commanded" in pencil.]
\et B.34, 98/454, 38,40, 99/455, 81, 112/469

\lx wuttitchuwan
\va wuttitch∞wan
\va wadtutchuan
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 213
\ps defect. v. / II
\ge `(it) flows or flowed from' (after |nippe|, |sepu|, etc., in sing. and pl., with or without the pl. affix |-ash|)
\so Ps.105.41; Jn.7.38
    \xv sepupog wuttitchuwan
    \xe rivers of water run down
    \so (from)    Ps.119.136
    \xv sepuash wadtutchúog
    \xe rivers run from
    \so Eccl.1.7
    \xv nuppe wuttitchuánup kah kussitchuan anuwutchuwan
    \xe the waters gushed out (from the rock) and the streams overflowed
    \so Ps.78.20
\nt The several words which describe running water are used by Eliot, with little apparent regard to grammatical construction, as verb, noun, or adjective, as the construction requires. The radical is uncertain, perhaps |wutche| or |∞ch| (q.v.). In Gen.2.10-14, are other forms of these compounds:
    \xv seip ne aushunk
    \xe the river which goeth toward (flowing)
    \so Gen2.14
    \xv seip ne quanupishunk
    \xe which compasseth' (`flowing about
    \so )    Gen 11.13
    \xv seip wutchishau
    \xe a river went out of' (`flowed from
    \so )    Gen.11.10
    \cf ánuwutchuwan
    \cf anitchewan
    \ge it overflowed, overflowing
    \xv kussitchuan
    \xe it flowed in a stream' (n. `a stream
    \so )
    |pamítchuan|, |pumitchuwan| `it ran or flowed' (generally or indefinitely)
    \xv sohwútchuan
    \xe it flowed out of, forth from
    \xv sohkhetchuan
    \xe it gushed out, burst out
    \so Is.35.6
    \xv unnitchuan
    \xe it flowed to, ran to
    \xv woweeyonchuan
    \xe it flowed round about
    \so 1 K.18.35

[Western Abenaki [abe] |arits8"añn| `il coule', v.g. le sang.    R.136/421a.]
\et H., p.247 *-iciwan `flow', as 2617 *pemiciwanwi II `flow', 3728 *wenciciwanwi II `flow thence'

\lx wuttuhppa[enat

    (|wuttuhhupponat|    Mass.Ps., Jn.4.7,15)

    (= |quomphippaog|    1 Chr.11.18)

\lx yane
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
    \nt +
\ps Adv., anaphoric ("relative" root?), as correlative (to |ne(y)ane|)
\ge `so, likewise'
    \xv Kah Jesus neemunum petukqunnegash, onk mahche tabuttantuk, wutchadchapenúmmaon ukkodnetuhtaenumoh, kah kodnetuhtaénuog nah nummatapinitcheh, ne wonk yane namóhsemésog, ne an∞hque kodtantamwéhettit.
    \xe And Jesus took the loaves; and when he had given thanks, he distributed to the disciples, and the disciples to them that were set down; and likewise of the fishes as much as they would.
    \so Jn.6.11
    \xv Newutche neyane ukkutshamun yóáyeu wohsum∞m∞ wutch agwekesukqut, wohsum∞m∞ ogkomae agwe kesukqut: ne pish yane wosketomp wunnaumonuh ut ukkesukodtumut.
    \xe For as the lightning, that lighteneth out of the one part under heaven, shineth unto the other part under heaven; so shall also the Son of man be in his day.
    \so Lk.17.24
    \xv Qut matta neane matcheseonk, ne wonk yane nanowe mág∞onk;...
    \xe But not as the offence, so also is the free gift. ...
    \so Rom.5.15


\lx yaneìnn
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
    \xv wanne yaneìnno wutch mattamog
    \xe is not seemly for a fool
    \so Prov.26.1
    { c.f. Mt.3.8 }


\lx yanem∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
    \nt +
\ps II
\ge `to be dim' (i.e. partially closed?)
\so Gen.27.1

    \xv ... Isaak kohchisu∞ut, kah yanèm∞uk wuskesukquash, woh mat naum∞,...
    \xe ... when Isaac was old, and his eyes were dim, so that he could not see,...
    \so Gen.27.1


\lx yânequohh∞
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a veil'
    \dv |yân-| `to close, shut' + |-equ-| `face' + |-ahw-| TA(?) mechanical causative + NI?
    \nt +
\so Gen.24.65
    \xv ..., newutche neemunnum yânequohh∞, weyanequawhun.
    \xe ...: therefore she took a veil, and covered herself.
    \so Gen.24.65;
    \ng (E0&E1) |neemunoh|, presumably erroneous
    \nt +
    = |puttogquequohhou|    Gen.38.14
    = |ongquequohhou|    Ex.34.33; 2 Cor.3.14

    \so Is.17.5 (circumstance to circumstance or fact to fact)

\lx yaneungqussu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
\ps AI(+O) (via object of |yane|)
\twn |yáneyéu|?
\ge `to be as, like'

    \xv Nish noh howan paauónuk∞h, kah n∞tog nuttinn∞waongash, kah nish usseit, kukkuhk∞tamauonumw∞ howane yaneunkqussitche.
    \xe Whosoever cometh to me, and heareth my sayings, and doeth them, I will shew you to whom he is like:

    \xv Kah matta metseógish, ahque yaneungqussegk eiantukkeiit maenonkqussinneat,...
    \xe Moreover when ye fast, be not, as the hypocrites, of a sad countenance:...
    \so Mt.6.16


\lx yânitchan
\va yanitanum-nutcheg
\ve `he shuts the hand'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
\ps n. / NI
\ge `a handful'
\so Lev.2.2
    \xv Kah nesausuk tahshit kodtumwae masegik ohkeit, wutchegen yeanitchanash.
    \xe And in the seven plenteous years the earth brought forth by handfuls.
    \so Gen.41.47
    \nt +
    pl. |..., wutch yânitchanash barlyhash, kah wutche petukqunnege kodchuhkiash? ...| `... for handfuls of barley and for pieces of bread,...'    Ezek.13.19√

    \xv nequtnutchan n∞khik
    \xe a handful of meal
    \so 1 K.17.12√

    [Western Abenaki [abe] |neg8dab8rtsañnar nek8tsiretsañnar nemireghé| `Il m'a donné une poignée, &c.'    R.402/509b.]
    \nt +


\lx yânittanumunát
\va yeanittanum
\va yanittanum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
\ps v.t. / TI1b, ?manual final
    \dv Perhaps with incorporated noun as object/classifier |-itt(an)-| `door', cf. |wohshitanumunát|; otherwise, with indefinite object final?
    \nt +
\ge `to shut' (a door, gate, etc.)
\so +Gen.19.10; 2 K.4.33; Neh.7.3
    \xv ...; kah yanitanum parloure squont ...
    \xe ..., and [he] shut the doors of the parlour upon him,...
    \so Judg.3.23√
    \ng 3->0 absolute
    \xv ..., yánittanumwog.
    \xe ..., they shut the gate.
    \so Josh.2.7√
    \ng 3p indicative
    \xv Kah petutteaan, pish keánittanum, kah ut kenaumonat ...
    \xe And when thou art come in, thou shalt shut the door upon thee and upon thy sons,...
    \so 2 K.4.4√
    \ng 2 indicative

    \xv Qut ken peantamanish, aush p∞tsauut, kah yeantanumaish, peantamau kemeu,...
    \xe But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret;...
    \so Mt.6.6
    \ng (E1) also; syncopated; form probably in error for 2 iterative conjunct |yeantanumanish| (though it should not be iterative semantically, since it is under the scope of the earlier iterative as "and then when thou hast..."; perhaps by attraction then).
    \nt +

    \xv ...? nók peyont ann∞naénin, yáuntánum∞k,...
    \xe ..., look, when the messenger cometh, shut the door,...
    \so 2 K.6.33
    \ng 2p imperative
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah ash nag na neepauweéhettit, yanittannumwéhettich, kah kuppáhhamwéhettich,...
    \xe ...; and while they stand by, let them shut the doors, and bar them:...
    \so Neh.7.3
    \ng 3p imperative
    \nt +

    \se !|yeanittumau|
    \nt ?
    \ps ?AI
    \ge `to close a door with respect to o.s.'
    \so Gen.19.6(E2)
    \xv ..., kah yeánittanumau.
    \xe ..., and shut the doore after him,
    \so Gen.19.6
    \ng 3 indicative

    \se !|yeanittumauau|
    \nt +
    \ps TA, dative final
    \ge `to shut the door upon sb'
    \so 2 K.4.5,21,?6.32
    \xv Neit wunnuskonuh, kah yanittánumauau wuhhogkuh, kah wunnaumonuh;...
    \xe So she went from him, and shut the door upon her and upon her sons,...'    2 K.4.5  { 3->3
    \so absolute }
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah weyanittanumauoh, kah sohham.
    \xe ..., and shut the door upon him, and went out.'    2 K.4.21  { 3->3
    \so objective }
    \nt +


\lx yanunnum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
    \nt +
\ps TI1b
\ge `to compare sth (with sth)'
\so 1 Cor.2.13
    \xv ..., yanunnumunat nashauanittowe teagwassinish kah nashauanittowe teagwassinish.
    \xe ...; comparing spiritual things with spiritual.
    \so 1 Cor.2.13


\lx yânunumunát
\va yeânunum
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
\ps v.t. / TI1b, manual final
\ge `to shut', +`to close sth up'
    \xv ..., kah wunneemunumauoh pasuk wuhpeteog, kah wonk yeânunumun weyaus wonk nompe.
    \xe ..., and he took one of his ribs, and closed up the flesh instead thereof.
    \so Gen.2.21; (E0&1): |yeânunnum|
    \nt +
    \xv yânunum wuskesukquash
    \xe he shuts their eyes
    \so Is.44.18

    \xv nok yanunuk
    \xe he who shuts
    \so (his eyes)    Is.33.15

    \xv yanunush
    \xe shut thou
    \so (their eyes)    Is.6.10

\lx yau
\va yauwe
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 214
\ps num.
\ge `four'
\so (El.Gr.14), Ezek.1.10
\nt G&B.510,749
    |yauog|, |yau∞og| an. pl. `four' (living beings)    Gen.14.9; Ezek.1.5,8
    |yauunash| pl. inan. `four' (things)    Prov.30.18,21
    \xv yauut nai
    \xe four square
    \so Ex.38.1
    \ng locative
    \xv yauquinogkok
    \xe on the fourth day
    \so 2 Chr.20.26

    \se !|yauunnu∞|
    \nt +
    \ps II, predicative
    \ge `to be four'; participle used for "fourth"
    \so Gen.2.14; Rev.6.7,21.19

    \se |yauwe|
    \nt +
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `fourth'
    \so Ex.27.2,29.40; Num. title,25.9; Josh.19.17
    \xv Yauwe upbookum MOSES, ussowetamun NUMBERS.
    \xe THE FOVRTH BOOKE of Moses, called Numbers.
    \so Num. title
    \xv Kah yauwe tanohtoadtuonk kuhkuhquem∞ en wunneechanoh Issachar,...
    \xe And the fourth lot came out to Issachar, for the children of Issachar ...
    \so Josh.19.17

    \se nabo yau
    \ps PreN, PreV
    \ge `fourteen'
    \so El.Gr.14/261
    \xv Onk nabo yauut kodtum∞k,...
    \xe And in the fourteenth year ...
    \so Gen.14.5
    \ng locative
    \nt +

    \se yauonchag
    \va yaunehchag-
    \ps numeral
    \ge `forty'
    \so El.Gr.14/261; passim
    \nt G&B.749
    \xv Yauunchag kodtog, kodtash.
    \xe 40
    \so El.Gr.14
    \ng erroneously as |Nauunchag| in reprint, 261
    \xv yauwinnechak.
    \xe forty
    \so C.32/177
    \nt +
    \xv Neyaunehchage kodtumwohkomup ...
    \xe Forty years old was I ...
    \so Josh.14.7
    \nt +
    \xv ... Yauwinehcheg kah nukquttuh tashikkodtam∞ yeu temple oiayimunah,...
    \xe ..., Fourty and six years was this temple in building,...
    \so Jn.2.20(M)
    \nt +
    \xv Yaunnehchage kodtumwae
    \xe Fourty years long
    \so Ps.95.10(M)
    \nt +
    \xv yauinchag Shillingsash
    \xe Forty Shillings
    \so Ind. Laws 4.
    \nt +

    \xv ..., nussokanonteam ut ohkeit yauonchagkodtash kesukodtash kah yauonchakodtash nukonash:...
    \xe ... I will cause it to rain upon the earth forty days and forty nights;...
    \so Gen.7.4
    \ng 0p
    \nt +

    Compounds:
    \nt +
    \xv yâogkontoncheg
    \xe four-footed
    \so Acts 10.12
    \ng dvigu
    \nt +
    \xv Onk tomogkun yauonchatikqunnu ut woskeche ohket,...
    \xe And the flood was forty days upon the earth;...
    \so Gen.7.17
    \ng palatalized |k|?
    \nt +
    \xv mahche yaunnehcheadtequinokok
    \xe at the end of forty days
    \so Gen.8.6
    \nt +

\lx yean
\va yâ-en
\ve `to yonder, thither'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
\ps prep. / preposition/conjunction, may govern locative
\ge `to, as far as'; +`unto', often |onk yean|; `until', with t-subordinative or conjunct verb
    \xv ..., onk yean, kehteihtukqut Euphrates.
    \xe ... unto the great river, the river Euphrates:
    \so Gen.15.18
    \ng locative
    \nt +
    \xv wutch ... yean
    \xe from ... to
    \so Mic.7.12
    = |yaén|    Zech.9.10
    \xv yeu wutche onk yean
    \xe henceforth
    \so Gen.4.12
    \nt +
    \xv ..., peyauan Gerar onk yean Gaza;...
    \xe ..., as thou comest to Gerar,  unto Gaza;...
    \so Gen.10.19
    \nt +
    \xv Kah weetom ogkussequnne, yeán kemat ummusquantam∞onk qushkem∞uk.
    \xe And tarry with him a few days, until thy brother's fury turn away;
    \so Gen.27.44
    \ng (E0&1) have t-subordinative.
    \nt +
    \xv ..., N∞nanumumun, yean wame pas∞wônaont floksog moeu, kah yean wutomp∞chanumunaónt qussuk wutch wussissitt∞nónog,...
    \xe ..., we cannot, until all the flocks be gathered together, and till they roll the stone from the well's mouth;...
    \so Gen.29.8
\cf yeu
\cf


\lx yeanittanumunát
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
\cf yânittanumunát


\lx yeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
\ps demonstr. pron. inan.; +proximal; demonstrative PreN
    \nt Remark: Entry partly reorganized; includes animate forms; some classifying tags added.
    \nt +
\ge `this'
\nt G&B.508, 749-751
    inanimate singular:
    \nt +
    \xv yeu ut wame ohket
    \xe upon the face of the whole earth
    \so Gen.11.4
    \ng (E0), gl. "in this all earth", for "this in all earth"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Naush yeu nomungquag, kah naush yeu neepatuhquonk ne yeu nomunkquodtau ut nashauwe neen kah ken,
    \xe ..., Behold this heap, and behold this pillar, which I have cast betwixt me and thee;
    \so Gen.31.51
    \nt +
    \xv ...: tohkonogque ayeuwuttuonk waabehtunkqueon, yeu nuttut papahtantamun.
    \xe ...: though war should rise against me, in this will I be confident.
    \so Ps.27.3(M)
    \ng (E) |neit|
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu nashpe n∞wahteoun k∞sekitteahe,...
    \xe By this I know that thou favourest me:...
    \so Ps.41.11
    \nt +
    \xv Maunnitteaunnon, neit nummatwomog qushkeog: yeu n∞wahteoun, newutche GOD n∞weech∞humuk.
    \xe When I cry unto thee, then shall mine enemies turn back: this I know, for God is for me.
    \so Ps.56.9
    \nt +
    \xv Newajeh ummissinninnumoh yeu en qushkenit:...
    \xe Therefore his people return hither:...
    \so Ps.73.10
    \nt +

    \xv yeu nepauz
    \xe this month
    \so Ex.12.2
    \xv yeu kodtumuk
    \xe this year
    \so Lk.13.7
    \xv Yeu waj
    \xe For this cause
    \so (El.Gr.22/269)
    \xv yeu wutch
    \xe from hence
    \so C.109/233
    \nt +
    \xv yeu in kah yeu in
    \xe thus and thus
    \so 2 Sam.17.15

    animate singular:
    \nt +
    \xv ..., howan noh masunont yeu wosketomp asuh ummittumwussog [sic!], pish nushau.
    \xe ..., He that toucheth this man or his wife shall surely be put to death.
    \so Gen.26.11
    \nt +
    \xv Kah Jakob nauont nah, n∞wau, Yeu wutáyeuwohteomoh GOD,...
    \xe And when Jacob saw them, he said, This is God's host:...
    \so Gen.32.2
    \ng also (E0&1)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., ahque wabesish, yeu wonk mos k∞wadchan kenaumon.
    \xe ..., Fear not; thou shalt have this son also.
    \so Gen.35.17
    \ng also (E0&1), split structure
    \nt +

    proximate animate:
    \nt +
    an. |yeuoh| / apparently a proximate animate form
    \xv Onk Adam n∞wau, Yeuoh yeuyeu wuskon wutch n∞skon, kah weyaus wutch n∞weyaus, pish hennou Ishah, newutche wuttinau wosketompaut.
    \xe And Adam said, This is now bone of my bone, and flesh of my flesh: she shall be called Woman, because she was taken out of man.
    \so Gen.2.23
    \nt +
    \xv Sunnummatta nuttugk∞us yeuoh nummissis kah nagum nux nagum nehenwonche n∞wop yeuoh nohtonugqus:...
    \xe Said he not unto me, She is my sister? and she, even she herself said, He is my brother:...
    \so Gen.20.5
    \nt +
    \xv ..., howan yeuoh wosketomp pamshadt ohteakonit kenogkunkqun? ...
    \xe ..., What man is this that walketh in the field to meet us? ...
    \so Gen.24.65
    \nt +
    \xv ..., Yeuoh quaguashwehtamah nunksquau n∞mittumwussissin.
    \xe ..., Get me this damsel to wife.
    \so Gen.34.4
    \ng On the hyperbaton, see G&B.590.
    \nt +

    proximate plural:
    pl. an. |yeug| `these'
    \xv Yeuh wunnaumonuh Esau (noh Edom) kah yeug umummugquompomuh.
    \xe These are the sons of Esau, who is Edom, and these are their dukes.
    \so Gen.36.19
    \ng final word sic, in E2; |yeug| in E0, E1 also.
    \nt +
    \xv Kah yeug neg kéhchimayog,...
    \xe And these are they by the wayside, ...
    \so Mk.4.15
    \ng similarly: 4.16,18,20
    \nt +

    obviative plural[?!]:
    \nt +
    pl. an. |yéuh| `these' (accus.) { i.e. obviative }    Gen.15.10
    \xv Yeuh wunnaumonuh Bilhah, ..., kah yeuh wunnekitteauonuh Jakoboh, ...
    \xe These are the sons of Bilhah, and she bare these unto Jacob:...
    \so Gen.46.25
    \nt +
    \xv ..., howan yeuh wuttinneúhkontunkoh kah ∞sukuhwhonk,...
    \xe ..., whose is this image and superscription? ...
    \so Mk.12.16
    \nt ?+

    inanimate plural
    \nt +
    pl. inan. |yeush|
    |yeushoh| 0p, `these things, these' (rare), Mt.11.4,13.56,23.23; Lk.14.21; Jn.21.24; Acts 10.8; 2 Pet.1.12
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah wuttinonash yeushoh neg noh ápitcheg weekit okasoh.
    \xe ..., and [she] told them of her mother's house these things.
    \so Gen.24.28
    \ng i.e. ?apparently 3->3p+0p
    \nt +

    \se uttiyeu
    \ps interrog.
    \ge `which?'
    pl. |uttiyeush| (El.Gr.7)

\ps adv.
\ge `here, in this place', +proximate; local, manner; `after, in this manner, on this wise, so, thus', manner -- note the use of anaphoric |-unn-| with the subordinative.
    \xv YEU ne kesteounah kesukquash kah ohke,...
    \xe Thus the heauens and the earth were finished,...
    \so Gen.2.1
    \ng (E0) gl. "Then"
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah n∞wau, Neen yeu.
    \xe ... And he said, Behold, here I am.
    \so Gen.22.1
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu in GOD amaunau wunnetasumoh k∞sheu, kah nuttinumunkqunuh.
    \xe Thus God hath taken away the cattle of your father, and given them to me.
    \so Gen.31.9
    \nt +
    \xv Kah en ∞shut yeu wuttinne negonshhuon,...
    \xe And to his father he sent after this manner:...
    \so Gen.45.23
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu nuttinne kepshonah ut anaquabit Jehovah, yauunchadet-kesukquaeu kah yauunchage nukkonaeu, kah neane negonne kepshoomp...
    \xe Thus I fell down before the LORD forty days, and forty nights, as I fell down {at the first},...
    \so Deut.9.25
    \nt +
    \xv Yeu kittinne waussumunun ash pomantam:...
    \xe Thus will I bless thee, while I live:...
    \so Ps.63.4
    \ng (M) |Yeu pish kuttinne wunnanumunun,...|
    \nt +
    \xv Pharise nepau, kah yeu wuttinne peantamun ut wuttinnomomiyeumut,...
    \xe The Pharisee stood and prayed thus with himself,...
    \so Lk.18.11
    \nt +
    \xv ..., sun yeu kuttinne nomp∞humauon negone sephausuenin?
    \xe ..., Answerest thou the high priest so?
    \so Jn.18.22(M)
    \nt +
    \xv ..., kah yeu wuttinne nahtuhkon wuhhogkuh.
    \xe ..., and on this wise shewed he himselfe.
    \so Jn.21.1
    \nt +
    = |yeuut|    Gen.21.23
    \xv yeu nogque
    \xe toward this way
    \so (El.Gr.21)
    `hither'    2 K.2.8
\cf ayeu

[Delaware [del] |yun| `here'    Zeisb.Gr.171.
Quiripi [qyp] |yeuoh|    Pier.5.
Narragansett [xnt] |yo| (q.v.).
Cree (an.) |ow'a@|, (inan.) |oom'a@| `this'    Howse 188.
Chip. (an.) |wowh|, (inan.) |oowh|    Howse 188.
Mi'kmaq [mic] |8t| `ici'    Maillard 30.]

\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 215

[Mohegan-Pequot [mqm] |nehyeugh| `my wife'; |nehyushamug| `my husband'    Stiles.]

    \nt +

\ps demonstrative, animate

    \xv Howan wunnaumonut yeuhoh.
    \xe Whose son is that
    \so C.33/178

    \ps (proximal) demonstrative adjective/ proximate 3 pronoun

\lx yeu unne
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
\ps adv.
\ge `in this manner, thus'
\so Jn.11.48
    = |yeu in|    2 Sam.17.15
    (|yeu unni| `thus'    C.234)


\lx yeuyeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
\ps adv.
\ge `now'
\so (El.Gr.21), Gen.21.23; 22.2; 2 Cor.6.2
    \xv Yeuyeu
    \xe {Now}
    \so EGr.21/267


\lx yi-
\va ey-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
    \nt +
\ps AI+O, TA+O (as e.g. 1 Sam.10.16)
\ge `to say, speak' [followed by direct quotation?]
    \xv ... kah Jakob matta toh éyeu ne toh wuttit peyónau.
    \xe ...: and Jacob held his peace until they were come.
    \so Gen.34.5
    \xv Kah missinninnúog umm∞m∞skomôuh Mosesoh, yeuwog, chaugua woh wodtattamog,
    \xe And the people murmured against Moses, saying, What shall we drink?
    \so Ex.15.24
    \xv ..., nuppahke yikqun assesog namehheaog:...
    \xe ..., He told us plainly that the asses were found. ...
    \so 1 Sam.10.16
    \ng 3->1p+0
    \xv Qut nano ummenuhke yin, ...
    \xe But he spake the more vehemently, ...
    \so Mk.14.31
    \xv Qut yeu wunnashpe yin nashauanitto,...
    \xe (But this spake he of the Spirit, ...
    \so Lk.7.39
    \xv Neit ken∞che yimw∞, ...
    \xe Then shall ye begin to say, ...
    \so Lk.13.26
    \xv Qut kusseh, uppiûhsukeh yin, ...
    \xe But, lo, he speaketh boldly, ...
    \so Jn.7.26
    \xv ...: newutche matta pish wutchippeéyin,...
    \xe ...: for he shall not speak of himself;...
    \so Jn.16.13
    \xv Kusseh, yeuyeu kuppiuhsukeu yin, kah matta kusséen ut kuhkinneasuonganit,
    \xe Lo, now speakest thou plainly, and speakest no proverb.
    \so Jn.16.29
    \xv Yeu ∞che yin, nauwuttam∞∞ uttôh pish áne nuppuk, sohsum∞ónonat Goduh,...
    \xe This spake he, signifying by what death he should glorify God.
    \so Jn.21.10
    \xv ..., kah aninnumau kittinnumog, woh ummenuhke yinneau kuttinn∞waonk.
    \xe ...: and grant unto thy servants, that with all boldness they may speak thy word,
    \so Acts 4.29, sim. ib.4.31
    \xv Matta yeu n∞che eyin kuttitashpunnanúnnanónut, newutche nummamahcheyip,...
    \xe I speak not this to condemn you: for I have said before, that...
    \so 2 Cor.7.3
    \ng twice
    \xv Ne an∞wai, matta nutogque eyin wutch Lordut, qut onatuh mattammagwut,...
    \xe That which I speak, I speak it not after the Lord, but as it were foolishly,...
    \so 2 Cor.11.17
    \xv ...(nummattammagweyim)...
    \xe ..., (I speak foolishly,)...
    \so 2 Cor.11.21; ib., 11.23
    \xv ..., woh GOD n∞wohsunuumunkqunnanónut wunnont∞wáe squoant, yunneat wussiogkod∞m Christ,...
    \xe ..., that God would open unto us a door of utterance, to speak the mystery of Christ,...
    \so Col.4.3
    \ng t-subord., no (overt) prefix, no preceding |-e|
    \xv ..., ne nuttiné yinnean,...
    \xe ..., even so we speak;...
    \so 1 Thess.2.4
    \xv Newutche woh nummenuhkeyimun,...
    \xe So that we may boldly say,...
    \so Heb.13.6

    \xv Kah upponamauóoh mechum anaquabenit, qut n∞wau, matta nummetsuh, onk mahche eyon nuttinsháonk, kah n∞wau, keket∞kash.
    \xe And there was set meat before him to eat: but he said, I will not eat, until I have told mine errand. And he said, Speak on.
    \so Gen.24.33
    \ng conjunct? subordinative? no prefix
    \xv ...? Kah wunnomwáeeyán,...
    \xe ...? And if I say the truth,...
    \so Jn.8.46
    \xv ..., newaj matta woh toh éyog.
    \xe ...; so that we need not to speak any thing.
    \so 1 Thess.1.8
    \ng conjunct, no prefix, neg.

\nt In view of the interest of this case, all examples noted to date have been cited.
In (partial) suppletion with |si-|? These examples are generally in a context in which the morph is not immediately preceded by a personal prefix--there is at least a separation.)
The |-n| of Mk.14.31 is presumably a form of the |n|-paradigm (as in a number of forms of |si-| cited by G&B under a rubric AI+O).
The form of the morpheme is not completely clear--note that most of the examples in |yi-| follow a suffixal |-e|; however, on the basis of the evidence found to date, it certainly cannot be claimed that this is a regular loss of initial |e-| in this environment in this context.

\et This is clearly related to the archaism noted by Bloomfield (1946, 34, 38: 98-99/454-455, e.g. no.121 *ewa `he says so'), and to the forms found by Goddard in M(unsee)-Delaware (1979, 5.0.3: 77; 1982, 5.5.3: 33, w. fn.94): AI stem /i:-/ `say', in suppletion with /si:-/, as in /nkata-i:n/ `I want to say it'--to which Lk.13.26 is directly comparable--beside /nsi:n/ `I said it'.


\lx yo
\lg Narragansett [xnt]
\so Trumbull 215
    = |yeu|
    \xv yo wégue
    \xe thus far
    \xv yòwa
    \xe thus
    \so R.W.55
    \xv yò wutché
    \xe from hence
    \so R.W.74
    (= Mass. |yeu wutche|    Ex.33.15)

[Delaware [del] |yu-wuntschi| `from hence, therefore'    Zeisb.Gr.171.]


\lx yô
\va yâ
\va ya
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
\ps adv.
\ge `yonder, that way'
\nt G&B.749, s.v. |ya| `yonder, yon'
    \xv yeu nogque in kah yâ in
    \xe hither and thither, to this side and to that
    \xv ... kah togkodtam nippeash kah nish chippem∞ash yeu nogque in kah yâ in,...
    \xe ..., and smote the waters, and they were divided hither and thither,...
    \so 2 K.2.8; sim., ib.2.14
    \nt +
    \xv yô nuttónan
    \xe we will go yonder
    \so Gen.22.5
    (|wonk hô kuppeyaunumun| `we will come again [hither (?)] to you'    Gen.22.5)
    \xv ..., kah ya nuttit nogkushkauon.
    \xe ..., while I meet the Lord yonder.
    \so Num.23.15
    \nt +
    \xv monchish yeu wutch, yaaush
    \xe go hence to yonder place' i.e. `go hence, go to yonder
    \so (from |yâauonat|)    Mt.17.20

[Narragansett [xnt] |yo nowêkin| `I dwell here'    R.W.29.]


\lx yôái
\va yôaeu
\va yoáe
\va yô ayeu
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\so Trumbull 215
\ps adv.
\ge `on that side'
\so 2 Sam.2.13; Dan.7.5
    \xv wutch yôáe kesukqut kah yeu onk in aongkoue
    \xe from the one side of heaven unto the other
    \so Deut.4.32
    \xv wutch yoáe ... nogque
    \xe on the one side ... on the other
    \so 1 Sam.14.4
    \xv yôaeu ... nahohtóe yóayeu∞k
    \xe on the one side (of the ark) ... on the other side
    \so Ex.37.3
    |ut yóáe| `at the sides of (the ark)    Ex.37.5
    \xv wutch yeóáeu ... ogkómae
    \xe out of one side ... out of the other (of the candlestick)
    \so Ex.37.18
    \xv pasuk yoáyeu ... onkatuk ogkomáeu
    \xe one on one side (of him) ... another on the other
    \so Ex.17.12
    \xv yóáeu nannummiyeu
    \xe on the northward side
    \so Lev.1.11
\cf ongkome

[Delaware [del] |yawi| `on one side'    Zeisb.Gr.171.]

\lg Narragansett [xnt]
    \xv Yotáanit
    \xe the fire god
    \so R.W.47,110.
\cf n∞tau

\lx yowutche
\va yeu-wutche
\ve `because of this'
\lg Wampanoag [wam]

\ge `wherefore'
\so Mt.18.8

[Delaware [del] |yu wuntschi| `from hence'    Zeisb.]


\lx yoyatche
\va yeoyatche
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
\ps adv. / PreV
\ge `always'
    \dv PreV derivative in |-e| to the following lemma.
    \nt +
\so Mt.28.20; 26.11
    (`usually'    C.230)
    |yeoyatche|    Is.45.17
    \xv Wunnanumoog nag oaiitcheg kekut: nag pish keyoyatche wowaenomukquog.
    \xe Blessed are they that dwell in thy house: they will be still praising thee.
    \so Ps.84.4(M); (E): |nano|; on sense of "still", see OED s.v., adv. 3.
    \nt +
\cf wameyeue
\cf nagwutteáe

[Mi'kmaq [mic] |yapchi8| `toujours'    Maillard 28.
Delaware [del] |yanewi|    Zeisb.]


\lx yoyat-
\lg Wampanoag [wam]
    \nt +
\ps initial (adverbial)
\ge `alway(s)', and in equivalent locutions indicating duration.
\so Ps.82.5(M), 102.24(M)
    \xv Matta wahteoooog, kah matta wohtamooog, yoyatushaog pohkinnaiyeuut:...
    \xe They know not, neither will they understand, they walk on in darkness:...
    \so Ps.82.5(M)
    \xv ...: kukkodtumoomash yoyatohtaash en wame pometuonkanit.
    \xe ...: thy years are throughout all generations.
    \so Ps.102.24(M)
